column2: Freeman Leroy Fairbank, former Judge of the Municipal Court and former assistant State's attorney, was fatally injured tonight in an accidental fall in his home. He would have been 56 years old tomorrow.

The value of imports from the United States into Argentina in October amounted to 23,527,000 pesos, which is 249,000 pesos above the value of imports from Great Britain and 9,500,000 pesos more than imports from this country in October, last year, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

Movements of the principal foreign exchanges were mixed in yesterday's dealings and the volume of transactions was small. The pound sterling rose 1-16 cent to $4.99 9-16, but showed a-net loss of 15-16 cent in the week. The franc at 3.39 9-16

BASSON--GBAFF--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Basson announce the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy B., to Mr. Fred Graff of Brooklyn, N. Y. BOROWITZ--SPATT--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Spatt, 451 Avenue 8, Brooklyn, announce the engagement of their daughter, Gladys, to Mr. Selig S. Borowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Borowitz.
A smaller volume of bonds was called last week for redemption prior to maturity than in the preceding week, owing in part to the Thanksgiving holiday.

The adaptation of the Diesel principle to privately owned passenger automobiles may be one of the future developments in the motor car industry, but, in the opinion of most automotive engineers, it still is lacking in many refinements needed in the power plant of such a vehicle.

Spanish Insurgent advices said tonight that General Francisco Franco had sent the Loyalist government an ultimatum demanding unconditional surrender before Dec. 5. The advices said that he threatened to launch a general drive, ready since Nov. 10, if the government refused to accept his terms.

Dr. and Mrs. Warner Bishop entertained with a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their daughter, Miss Dorothy W. Bishop, before the Knickerbocker Assembly at the Ritz-Carlton. The other guests were

ASHORTER, more direct link in the existing highway system connecting Stockton and Sacramento and contiguous areas with the San Francisco Bay region is supplied by the 3,100-foot high-speed double tunnel through the Contra Costa hill, leading into upper Broadway in Oakland.

Charles A. Harnett. Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, announced today that in the two weeks ending Nov. 13 he had revoked or suspended 1,021 certificates of registration and licenses to drive automobiles.

Disappointment among business men last week over the unlikelihood of tax relief being enacted during the special session of Congress was balanced somewhat by their growing belief that few of the restrictive bills now pending and affecting various aspects of industry, advertising and trade will be passed on before Jan. 1, according to comment by association lawyers here yesterday.
THIS is a historic document, written by Hitler's former director of propaganda in the United States. It is an inside view of Nazism, given by a man of great analytical ability and writing talent.

Samuel King, Delegate from Hawaii, asserted today that a Veterans Administration employee who criticized Hawaii's petition for statehood "disclosed bias, ignorance and an absolute lack of understanding of local conditions."

The New York Americans had little trouble with the Chicago Black Hawks last night. Red Dutton's band of stick-wielders, taking advantage of every opportunity that was presented, stepped heavily into the Windy City aggregation and registered a well-deserved 4 to 0 triumph.

A new venture in astronomy, a telescope built to study the dark places in the sky, instead of the usual light objects, was described today at Indiana University. The dark places are regions where no star can be seen.

The foreign exchange market here was quiet and featureless today and changes in rates were confined within narrow limits. The dollar eased fractionally at the opening and closed slightly lower at $4.99 1/2 to the pound. The French franc was unchanged at 147 1/3.

Neither wars nor rumors of wars have served to interrupt or to discourage, but rather would appear to have accelerated, the social tempo of a season that bids fair to be one of the liveliest in several years at the Capital on the Potomac.
University of California athletic heads ducked into seclusion today as the zero hour neared for their announcement regarding the Rose Bowl football bid.
" There is a possibility now that war in Europe may be averted entirely"-- "In the Orient? Oh, I don't know about that. I don't believe any one knows, really, what might .happen there."
Mr. and Mrs. George Hallam Sicard of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Sicard, to Louis Ward Locke Jr., also of Utica.
Ginger Foran, 130, Ireland, won the decision from John Mirabella, 126 1/2, Bensonhurst, in the eightround feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove last night before a crowd of 3,000 persons.

Sale of Wendover, property of the estate of Mrs. Jenny B. Benedict at Woodbury, Conn., to Mrs. Stephen Barker of Short Hills, N. J., was reported yesterday by Previews, Inc. Root Boyd acted as brokers in the deal.

Shot through the head and chest, the body of Raymond Hoffman, 25 years old, a taxicab driver, of 237 West Tenth Street, was found lying in the gutter in front of 840 Greenwich Street about 10 o'clock last night. The police said they believed that Hoffman had been thrown from a speeding automobile.

Alarmed by reports that England will seek drastic tariff reductions on whisky, domestic distillers last week were planning to make an organized fight against any concessions on Scotches or other imported whiskies in the proposed Anglo-American trade agreement.

A Christmas sale of articles made at Greenwich House Pottery and Ceramic School, under the direction of Miss Maude Robinson, will be opened Tuesday at 650 Madison Avenue at Sixtieth Street, and will continue until Jan 1.

The first of the Coffee Dances for this season will take place on the night of Dec. 13 at the Cosmopolitan Club. These dances, which have been held for many years, received their name from the custom of subscribers in taking their guests to the club for coffee and dancing after dinner parties. Many such dinners are being planned for this occasion.

If they had wanted to mystify public opinion, these French Ku Kluxers, or Cagoulards (hooded ones), could not have succeeded better. It was only after ten days' search that their name and symbol were discovered, or at least revealed.
Dr. Richard Newman Brackett, last survivor of the original faculty that opened Clemson College in 1891, died here today of a heart attack. his age was 74.

COURTESY on the road is being advocated with growing earnestness in many States as an important step in the safety drive. The Pittsburgh Motor Club has implemented its "Try Courtesy" campaign with signs on many highway markers which give warning of dangerous curves, hills and intersections in Pennsylvania. Thousands

THE mutiny of the Bounty and its outcome, the settlement on Pitcairn Island, has been a fruitful theme for writers, and many of the famous libraries and museums in the world contain a collection of Bounty literature and relics.
A LTHOUGH frequently spiked with insipid solutions of the Shag, Suzy-Q and the Coney Islandish hula - hula, the rhumba is nonetheless being done by simply everybody.

Decorative and useful articles suitable for gifts during the holiday season will be offered for sale in conjunction with the card party to be held Thursday afternoon in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Silver Cross Day Nursery.

A party will take place at Mon Paris this afternoon as a benefit for the National Bureau for Blind Artists. A new project of. this bureau is to organize an orchestra of blind musicians who wish to be independent and to succeed on their own artistic merit.

IN most discussions of so-called "humanism" the commentator devotes himself mainly to the place of the more "cultural" or literary subjects in the history of civilization, and tends to minimize or overlook the influence of science. George Sarton, however. in his illuminating series of four essays, has taken a wider point of view; instead of neglecting science, he has built his entire thesis about science. and has

Bonds of a union free school district wholly or partly within a city are not considered as indebtedness of a municipality under provisions of the State Constitution, in the opinion of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

The AllUnion Central Council of Trade Unions entered a united front agreement today with the International Federation of Trades Unions, the liberal, but by no means radical organization, with headquarters in Paris, to which the American Federation of Labor and the trade unions of many other countries belong.

It is a political, economic and social problem, all in one, to avoid the freezing of class lines as they already are formed in Europe, while an effort is made by the government to bring greater opportunity and security to the mass of the people, Robert Jackson, assistant United States attorney general, declared here today.
Appointment of Charles E. (Gabby) Street as manager of the St. Louis Browns today left Babe Ruth again "on the outside looking in" as far as a major league baseball post for 1938 was concerned.

Women who have long taken an active interest in the many philanthropic projects furthered by the Barat Settlement will assist at the annual bazaar for the benefit of the organization on Wednesday in the small ballroom of the Plaza. A feature of the fair will be the luncheon and tea served by officers and directors of the Barat Auxiliary, Mrs. John L. Gormley, president.

Mr. and Mrs. William Hamm Combs of South Orange have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Ethel Von Dersmith Combs, to John Ferguson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferguson of Montclair.

Miss Virginia Blackall Woodruff, daughter of Mrs. Heman Judson Pettengill Jr. of Waban, was married here tonight in the First Church in Newton to James Henry Hood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Hood of Watertown.

The profound problems now centering in Palestine should not be reduced to personal issues. But Judge Crabites is, if I may say so, right in assuming that special significance attaches to Haj Amin Eff. El Husseini, the deposed Mufti of Jerusalem, in any appraisal of the events that have culminated in the present Palestinian situation.

A man and his two sisters, all residents of the Bronx. were killed and five other persons injured, three seriously, in a three-car collision late tonight on Brunswick Pike near Clarksville, five miles north of here.

IT is always a delight to be able to report to the readers of the Book Review on the rise of a new talent full of promise for the future. With her first novel, "Der zweite Sommer" (S. Fischer. Berlin), Imma von

President Maurice Podoloff announced tonight that in the near future two referees, instead of a referee and a linesman as at present, will officiate at games in the International-American Hockey League.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:

Dr. James H. Andrew of 163 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, ophthalmologist, died Friday night in the Brooklyn Hospital following an operation for a cerebral tumor. He was born in Cambridge, N. Y., sixty-three years ago.

The find of a fragment of a cuneiform tablet, dating from about 1700 B. C., by the Yale expedition which has been excavating the site of the ancient city of Dura in French Syria for the past ten years, has helped to pierce the veil of darkness which has covered the 1,500-year period between the Sumerian and early Babylonian civilization that flourished along the Euphrates River, and HellenisticRoman times.

Allan J. Schnebbe was re-elected president of the Treasurers Club of America at its annual meeting Saturday night at the Park Central Hotel. The club members are ticket sellers in the legitimate theatres and opera houses of Greater New York.
The money market here witnessed a normal increase in demand this week because of month-end payments. Day loans were quoted at 2% to 2 7/8 per cent.

Howard Burden Thompson gave a reception at his home here today at which he announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Helen R. Thompson, to Fielding Simmons Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Simmons of Ruxton, Md.
The Essex Club scored a 5-0 sweep against the Englewood Field Club as the Class C circuit of the New Jersey Division, Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, opened the season today.

Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist organization of America, in concluding a four-day convention here today commended Great Britain for showing "a determined stand to quell the terroristic acts of the lawless element of Arbas in Palestine," and urged it "to continue with a firm hand to stamp out violence and establish peace and security in the land."

A new "Oats King of the World" was crowned today at the nineteenth international grain and hay show. Alex Stewart, who farms some 200 acres and also raises beef at Ailsa Craig, Ont., won the oats grand championship with his Alaska O. A. C. No. 157 variety, developed by the Ontario Agricultural College.

Van Lingle Mungo, speedball right-hander and stormy petrel of the Brooklyn pitching staff, may be seen in the livery of some other National League club next season, but only in the event that such a shift can be brought about in a deal that would prove wholly satisfactory and advantageous to the Dodgers.

The engagement of Miss Anne Geraldine Shepard, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Bishop Shepard of 212 East Forty-eighth Street, and the late Mr. Shepard, to William Sutcliffe Sagar of Greenwich, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Sagar of Methuen, Mass., has been announced by her mother.

The army should be strengthened through increased enlisted and officer personnel, augmented reserves and improved equipment and should be better paid so that it can more effectively guard the "peace and security" of American citizens, Secretary Woodring reported to President Roosevelt today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As long as our financial structure is routed on a one-way street with a dead end, the government must continue its heavy spending and tax collecting. On Dec. 4, 1936, THE TIMES contained a letter directed at the leaders of finance and industry, in which appeared the following question:

A group of Republican members of the House Agriculture Committee today vigorously assailed the "evernormal granary" farm bill reported to the House last week, argued that it would be declared unconstitutional and intimated that some supporters of this type of legislation were interested in its passage as an indirect method of reviving strife over the Supreme Court.

A young brunette in a silvertrimmed white evening gown got out of a taxi in front of 237 East 104th Street at about 8:30 last night and found herself in front of a locked door with rain pouring down on her tiara of metallic braid, her light wrap and her trailing skirt.

The International Paper Company announced last night through The Associated Press that it did not plan to increase its price for newsprint for the last six months of 1938. Its base price of $50 a ton for delivery at Chicago and New York and other Atlantic and Gulf ports previously set for the first six months of next year would be extended through December, the company said.

Lord Strabolgi, as director of the publishing firm of Rich Cowan, announced tonight that his firm expected to publish an authorized life story of the Duke of Windsor by Compton Mackenzie, noted Scottish novelist and historian.

Lard futures moved downward early last week on the Board of Trade, but recovered later in sympathy with cottonseed oil and on buying attributed to investment interests. A falling off in the movement of hogs to leading markets had some effect on sentiment.
Federal supply contracts let in the week ended on Nov. 25, under provisions of the Public Contracts Act, amounted to $6,698,553, the Department of Labor has announced.
Registration and placement activities in the local offices of the State Employment Service will be suspended until Thursday in preparation for the opening on that date of new offices in all boroughs.

Negotiations for settlement of the sixteen-State strike of Greyhound bus drivers moved so smoothly yesterday that a Federal labor conciliator in Cleveland expressed himself as "extremely optimistic" of an early agreement, the Associated Press reported.

A prediction that public welfare work will not replace private charity, and that the "quiet dignity" of the latter cannot be supplanted by the "red tape," "cold-hearted" and delayed methods of State aid was made last night by Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the First Department, Appellate Division, at a dinner given for City Court Justice Vincent S. Lippe by the Milk and Egg League at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The New York City advisory committee of the National Youth Administration urged continuance of the Federal youth program in a statement made public yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Edward Roberts Moore, chairman of the advisory group.

The art calendar holds some twoscore new exhibitions as November merges into December. The advancing season is further earmarked by the opening of three Christmas group shows of pictures at moderate prices. One-man exhibitions again predominate, with several unusual group events breaking the long list of solos.

Even after its passing, the old Fall River Line, immortalized in song and story, has not lost its sentimental appeal. Among 2,000 persons who have gone aboard the steamer Commonwealth to view the furnishings offered for sale was one man who said he would pay any amount for a grease-stained chair in the engine room.

The heroic and dynamic-some would say warlike-ideology that National Socialism is implanting in the German people was explained anew for the benefit of a puzzled Western world by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering in a speech in Hamburg Friday night, the official text of which was not published until today.

That department stores in the last eight years have become more, and more convinced of the effectiveness of newspaper advertising is indicated in an analysis of the October linage figures of Media Records, in comparison with the like month of 1929.

The recent improved tendency of the franc has not had any marked influence on the Bourse. Nevertheless it has paved the way for the stock market to retain a relative firmness despite the unfavorable factors with which it recently has had to contend.

German industry on the whole is quiet pending the termination of the November seasonal boom in consumption goods. The textile and rayon industries are well occupied, stocks of cotton at Bremen have increased and West German spinners say they are somewhat better supplied.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Gayet of this city, formerly of Pau, France, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Henriette Madeline Gayet, to Joseph John Pemoulie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Pemoulie of Astoria, also formerly of Pau, France.

The November air is as sallow and smoky as the political atmosphere in the Department of the Nord. Dark towns in the northeast corner-Lille, Roubaix, Tourcoing-string together to make one great town, the most densely populated, the most highly industrialized and the richest in France.

Although business improved last week in a number of divisions in the New York wholesale market, action continued to run behind last year. Calls for dresses improved in all price groups. Evening gowns and wraps moved well and some of the "formal" resources reported slow deliveries.

There were several thousand buffalo too many in Buffalo National Park in Alberta. To keep them from overflowing the park they are now being shot off. At first thought this fact may not seem important. But it is important.

Letter men of Army's football team, in their traditional meeting today aboard the train which carried them to West Point from yesterday's game with Navy, unanimously elected Cadet James T. L. Schwenk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton G. Schwenk of Schuykill Haven, Pa., captain of the 1938 eleven.

Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of the American Social Hygiene Association, declared last night that the use of liquor by young persons tended to increase the rate of social disease in this country. He spoke at the closing session in the Hotel Victoria of a three-day conference of forty social hygiene executives from sixteen States.
Something more of ground was lost by the stock market early last week, but with frequent recoveries and with decided advance on Friday and Saturday.

Corn prices held within relatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade last week, with a fair export business and a falling-off in the receipts of the cash staple at terminals. This resulted in the appearance of sufficient support to prevent much change in the price level.

The Jewish Theatrical Guild of America held its 100th meeting and at the same time celebrated Chanukkah yesterday afternoon at the Morosco Theatre. Several hundred persons attended. Jack Pearl was guest of honor.

Mrs. Lee Lawrie, wife of a sculptor, who made many reliefs and statues for Harkness Memorial quadrangle at Yale University, died yesterday in Grace Hospital at the age of 69, after a long illness. She was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Frolich of Brooklyn.

Emphasis was placed on honesty by members of the Episcopal clergy in Advent sermons yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, rector of the Church of the Transfiguration, popularly known as the Little Church Around the Corner, at 1 East Twenty-ninth Street, said:

The Montreal Maroons gained a tie with the Canadiens for third place in the international division of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, before 8,819 spectators.

August Strindberg's play, "Queen Christina," as translated into English by Graham Rawson, received good critical comment when it opened at the Westminster Theatre tonight, although there is apparently a doubt as to its popular appeal.

Manhattan's football squad, idle since last Wednesday, will resume practice at Innisfail Park today for its closing game with the University of Tulsa in Tulsa, Okla., Saturday. The Jasper eleven will have time for only three practices on its home field before entraining on its 1,500-mile journey Wednesday afternoon.

Slingin' Sammy Baugh pitched the Washington Redskins to a 14-to-6 victory over the Green Bay Packers today in a National League football game. Baugh whipped a 55-yard pass to Charley Malone, an end, in the third period to set the stage for the first touchdown.

A nineteen-gun salute boomed a greeting today to Governor George H. Earle and a group of- twenty-five Pennsylvanians of Swedish descent as they arrived on a good-will visit. The official welcome party boarded the liner Drottningholm at sea and escorted the Americans into the flag-draped city.

The Metropolitan Opera tonight opens its fifty-third season with the biggest drawing card of its repertoire, played by some of the brightest lights of its company. "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the title roles, will be played before a capacity house that had been sold out a week ago.
Senator Claude Pepper of Florida said in a statement today that the treaty with Panama now awaiting ratification in the Senate should be "pigeonholed until peace is restored in the Far East."
Undefeated Villanova wound up its football campaign today with a 25-to-0 victory over Loyola University and sat back to await possible invitations for post-season games.

The appointment of British consular agents to Insurgent territory and the arrival here during the last fortnight of Basque childrefugees returning from Britain, have provided evidence of a growing friendliness toward Britain.

Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, first president of Czechoslovakia, and his wife, Charlotte Garrigue, were honored at a memorial service in Brooklyn yesterday morning by the church in which she was baptized a member on Feb. 22, 1851.
The French France the weekly wholesale price index on recently Nov. 20 stood at 595, compared with 604 both a week and two weeks before.
An attempt was made on the life of Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha tonight when four shots were fired at his car. He escaped uninjured.

The New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects announced yesterday the appointment of a committee to encourage a building revival in this city through joint action of architects, engineers, builders and mechanics.

Oxford will publish on Dec. 2 "Arthur Rimbaud in Abyssinia," by Enid Starkie, an account of the French poet's little-known activities in Ethiopia, where he was involved in gun-running and the slave-trade during the final years of his short life.

Representatives of five embassies joined today with members of the Fidac in paying honor to the unknown dead of the World War. They gathered at the tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery, where Nathaniel Spear of Pittsburgh and New York, American vice president of the Fidac, placed a wreath on the tomb.

Reversing the trend of the preceding week, cotton prices gradually strengthened last week. At the close, active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 23 to 31 points.

Attacks being made against organized labor and the dangerous situation of the trade unions as a result of the business recession require the speedy conclusion of peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, the general executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, declared in a resolution made public yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the organization.

Winfield Sheehan, in Hotel Ambassador, Park Ave and 51st St. Joseph L. Steinfeld, in 1,225 Park Ave; George W. Korn, in 151 E. 80th St; Joseph L. Shapiro, in 75 Central Park W; Robert H. Cox, in 1,111 Park Ave; Arthur G. Meyer, in 205 W 54th St; Mary L. and Katherine Davis, in 15 W 8th St; Byrne Bowman. Inc, brokers.

A smashing attack carried Stanley Galowin, N. Y. U. senior and his professional partner, Joseph Wiener of the 42 Broadway Gym, into the third -ound of the Heights Casino squash racquets pro-amateur doubles tournament yesterday.

ERNEST DIMNET'S new book continues the amiable personal narrative begun some years ago in "My Old World." This time the French Abbe carries his story through the World War and over to the United States, in which he became widely "known about 1928 for a treatise called "The Art of Thinking," and to which he now returns year after year, one of the willing and no doubt well-rewarded legates to these infidel parts.

Two 15-year-old girls who ran away from their homes in Massachusetts Saturday morning in the hope of seeing Broadway were stranded penniless in the Bronx yesterday and were picked up early last night by the police before they had had a chance to view even the pastoral northern section of the theatrical thoroughfare.
Homer Martin, in a move reported as "disciplinary," placed the Pontiac local of the United Automobile Workers of America under direct control of the union's international board today.

The condition of General Gerardo Machado, deposed President of Cuba, was reported good yesterday at the Murray Hill Hospital, where he is under a twenty-four-hour United States Marshal's guard. The former Cuban President was arrested Friday after coming from Canada and entering the hospital to undergo an operation.

A benefit performance of "Father Malachy's Miracle" will be held the evening of Dec. 9 at St. James Theatre under the auspices of the New York Junior Committee of the National Cathedral Association. Mrs. Frederic W. Rhinelander of this city and Newport, daughter of the late Right Rev. Henry Yates Satterlee, first Bishop of Washington, heads the New York Committee, and Mrs. Ernest R. Adee of Tuxedo Park is vice chairman.
The Insurgent regime proclaimed a blockade of all Spanish Government ports today, including those on the island of Minorca.

Mrs. A. R. Demory of Santa Barbara, Calif., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Florence Virginia Demory, to Robert Moulton Coles Raetze of this city. Miss Demory, daughter of the late A. R. Demory of Santa Barbara, is a granddaughter of Mrs. Stephen L. Selden of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Selden.

The National Labor Committee for Palestine closed its thirteenth annual convention yesterday afternoon after a three-day conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania, during which it was voted to raise $E90,000 for the work of the General Federation of Jewish Labor in Palestine.

Trade restrictions and other economic discriminations are the cause of "the troubles of the modern world," Senator Pope said over the Columbia Broadcasting System today in an address on a program sponsored by the National Peace Conference.

Francis Joseph Reynolds, head of the readers' research bureau of the Crowell Publishing Company and former reference librarian of the Congressional Library in Washington, died Saturday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Frank A. Quackenbush, Buttonwood, Shrewsbury, N. J., after a long illness. His age was 70.

The exhibition game between the New York Giants and the Paterson Panthers in Paterson, N. J., and most of the other contests listed for gridirons in the metropolitan area, weer washed out by yesterday's heavy rainstorms.
Dr. and Mrs. Armistead Crump of 213 East Forty-eighth Street will give a series of dinners during the holiday season to introduce their daughter, Miss Jean Brevard Crump.

Miss Betty Slocombe and Nicholas Anthony Welch, both of Hartford, Conn., were married Saturday evening in the Unitarian Church of Lynchburg, Va. The bride's father, the Rev. Edwin Mitchell Slocombe, officiated.

Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Edwin Freston of Pelham Manor, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Elizabeth Freston, to Richard K. Hungerford of New York, son of Edward P. Hungerford of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Hungerford.

" The way people are disposed toward pledge cards and church offerings will determine the destiny of the church in America," declared the Rev. Dr. Herman C. Weber in a sermon yesterday morning at the Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church, 152 West Sixty-sixth Street.

A system of deflation and inflation suggestive of the bulls and bears of Wall Street is being experienced in the church today, according to the Rev. Charles C. Cole, pastor of Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th Street, who drew the comparison in his sermon yesterday morning.

A Netherlands engineer named van Wielen, the inventor of.a new type of diving apparatus, obtained a license today to salvage a cargo of 30,000,000 ducats from the Spanish galleon Duke of Florenca, which carried the Armada treasure.

William C. Bolton, secretary and treasurer of the L. J. Charrott Company, importers of artificial flowers, 36 West Thirty-seventh Street, Manhattan, died Saturday at his home, 759 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, after a short illness of pneumonia at the age of 45.

Forest Ave (10-2662), s e cor of 168th St, 123x61; Mendel Herman to Sermor Realties, Inc. 10 E 43d St. 174th St (11-2848), n e cor of Jerome Ave. 100x165; Bedford Park Garage, Inc, to 1,650 Realty Co, Inc. 1,650 Jerome Ave; mtg, S120,000.

A taxicab crashed through the barrier at the foot of Second Street, in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning and plunged into the East River. A sailor from the gunboat Erie was rescued from the water, but died soon after being taken to the Navy Hospital.

Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., reports for the three months ended on Sept. 30 a loss of $63,689, after depreciation allowance of $233,072. This compares with a profit of $132,058 for the third quarter of.1936.

Japan is ready to play the part of a "generous victor" and ?? not wish to exact "punitive peace terms" from China if the Chinese Government will end hostilities with an agreement to abandon anti-Japanism and suppress Communist tendencies, according to Shigeru Kawagoe, Japanese Ambassador to China.

Art treasures of the Russian imperial family valued at $25,000, ineluding a Bible once owned by Nicholas II, last Czar of Russia, and a pair of gold and silver champagne coolers used by Czar Alexander II, were stolen early yesterday morning from the Schaffer Art Galleries in Rockefeller Center by thieves who, in haste or ignorance, overlooked even more valuable objects.

A combination of kerosene and cat caused commotion and calamity here today suggestive of Mrs. O'Leary's fabled Chicago cow. When Mrs. Bessie Warner, housewife, tried to encourage a slow stove fire with kerosene, the flames leaped out and set fire to the Warners' cat.

A broadening of the campaign to raise funds for infantile paralysis aid and relief of sufferers was announced yesterday by Keith Morgan, chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday to Fight Infantile Paralysis.

Donald Lash, Olympic runner from Bloomington, Ind., captured the fortyfirst annual national A. A. U. senior cross-country championship over the Branch Brook Park course today as the Millrose A. A. of New York, ran off with the team title.

Pickets who patrol the entrances of the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here tomorrow, seeking to make effective a strike called by the United Automobile Workers of America, will need mittens and long underwear.

An orphan tabby found in the Yonkers station of the New York Central Railroad several years ago rose to fame here today at the closing day's exhibit of the fifth annual championship show of the Westchester County Cat Club in the County Center.

Leonard Proscer, 19 years old, of 523 West Fifty-second Street, was shot in the chest last night at a dance at the recreation hall of the Strykers Lane Community Center, 541 West Fifty-second Street. Friends took him to Roosevelt Hospital, where physicians said that his right lung had collapsed and that his condition was serious.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, declared yesterday morning that the sermon in Protestant Churches had not lost its value. He said it was "tragic when sometimes Christian ministers belittle the power of the spoken word."

Mr NEW WORLD, byErnest Dimnet (Simon Schuster, $2.50). Concluding volume of the Abbe's autobiography. UPPER MISSISSIPPI: A WILDERNESS SAGA, by Walter Havighurst (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50). Second volume in the Rivers of America series.
A simplification of the method of reporting and paying taxes under Title VIII of the Social Security Act, effective Jan. 1, was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.

The emergence of a new conception of Thanksgiving which amounts to a revolution in religious feeling was hailed yesterday morning by J. Hutton Hynd, leader of the St. Louis Ethical Culture Society, and Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott, senior leader of the New York group, at the New York society's meeting house, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

New and substantial charges against County Clerk Albert Marinelli have been uncovered, it was learned yesterday as District Attorney-elect Thomas E. Dewey worked with full speed preparing an answer to Governor Lehman on the County Clerk's fitness for office.
A model charter for Newark, or any other municipality that might wish to change its form of government, was approved unanimously last night at a meeting of the Fusion committee of Newark.

Twenty-five thousand rounds of rifle and machine-gun shells exploded today during a fire which destroyed the R. S. Diehl Garage and the second-floor armory of Troop G, 103d Cavalry, Pennsylvania National Guard, with a loss estimated at more than $100,000.

Miss Katherine E. Sullivan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Sullivan of 375 Park Avenue, entertained with a buffet supper at her home last night. Miss Sullivan will be introduced to society on Jan. 1 at a supper dance at Sherry's.

NOW that it's all over but some scattered shouting, four teams stood out where the big-game hunting was on. In alphabetical order they were Alabama, California, Fordham and Pitt. Down in the deep South they probably would let it go just that way and refuse to stand for any tinkering with the alphabet.
The state Conservation Department has sent out more than 600,000 hunting, fishing and trapping licenses to county clerks for distribution starting Dec. 1.. The licenses are for use during 1938.

A wild riding Mexican polo team scored its second straight triumph in the international series with the California All-Stars, 13 to 9, today, in the Golden Gate Park Bowl. On Thanksgiving Day, Mexico won, 10 to 6. The third game will be played Wednesday.

Arthur Mahoney and Thalia Mara made their first Broadway recital appearance last night at the Guild Theatre in a program of dances that proved to be not only diverting entertainment but something of a novelty in the matter of programmaking.

Net written premiums of the General Reinsurance Corporation were $4,262,808 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 the largest total for any corresponding period since 1929 and $214,406, or 5 per cent, greater than that for the first nine months of 1936, Edgar H. Boles, president, announced yesterday.

A discussion of the anti-trust laws and the possibility of their revision to tighten Federal control of monopolies occupied, along with other discussions, President Roosevelt's time today as he headed southward for a short fishing vacation off the Florida coast. The other discussion dealt with housing, unemployment and liquidation of the PWA.

More than 600 persons last night attended the testimonial dinner at the Hotel Astor for Mgr. Edward F. Leonard, pastor of St. Malachy's Church, ) West Forty-ninth Street, "a few footsteps from Times Square." The dinner was held to celebrate the fact that the "actors' priest" had been made a papal chamberlain.

The Northeast first team, undefeated in the first three rounds of the national women's field hockey tournament, was upset by a strong Southeast first eleven, 5 to 0, on snowcovered Skokie Field today.

Dr. Demitrios Sicilianos, Greece's Minister to the United States, will present a modern Greek library to Columbia University at a dinner on Thursday evening in the Men's Faculty Club of the university.

Borrowing by State governments after the depression started in 1929 has increased the gross bonded debt of the States 34.25 per cent, or from $2,372,041,765 in 1930 to $3,184,467,709 in 1937, according to an analysis titled the "Resources and Debts of the Forty-eight States," just published by the Municipal Service Department of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Of the more than 50,000 visitors who registered at the Hayden Planetarium during the period from Oct. 3 to Nov. 26, about 26,000 were from other States, Alaska, the United States possessions and foreign countries, it was announced yesterday. Total attendance was 80,000.

The dignity and simplicity of Josef Hofmann's acknowledgment of the homage accorded him when he appeared last night on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House was a flash of revelation of the nature of the man and the artist, and it was of a piece with the nature of the whole occasion.

A total of $1,529,026 was spent by the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30,. 1937, to aid 39,823 persons in 18,610 families, it was reported yesterday by Barklie Henry, president of the organization.

Miss Emily Chadbourne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank - Merriam Chadbourne of 40 East Sixty-second Street, has chosen the afternoon of Dec. 22 as the date for her marriage to Allen Hurlbert Minor, son of Colonel and Mrs. John Crannell Minor, also of New York, and of New Canaan, Conn. The ceremony will take place in St. James Episcopal Church.

The new French game of 71.2 balkline billiards will be introduced to this country this afternoon where two of the leading American cue artists, Willie Hoppe and Jake Schaefer, open a twelve-block match, 250 points to a block, at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

The Jewish Theological Seminary yesterday opened a special exhibition in its museum at Broadway and 122d Street. The exhibition which celebrates the season of Chanukkah, the eight-day Feast of Lights, includes books and many lamps from the seminary's collection.

President Alfonso Lopez issued yesterday a decree, under temporary legislative powers authorizing the Superintendent of Banking to license commercial banks to issue short-term "maximum one-year" first-mortgage bonds up to 50 per cent of the appraised value of perfectly titled and unencumbered private real estate.

Reconstitution of the American Jewish Congress through direct election of delegates to the meeting to be convened next June was voted today at the closing of the emergency session called to consider the creation of a united democratic front against antiSemitism in this country and abroad.

Not since the overwhelming surge of popular resentment against the HoareLaval "deal," nearly two years ago, forced the Cabinet to abandon the proposed partition of Ethiopia, has British public opinion been so stirred or so sharply divided as today on the issues involved in the current diplomatic exchanges between London and Berlin and London and Paris.

Accepting "secondary" truths, modern man "has chosen for denial the most important and fundamental truths of revelation," the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, declared yesterday morning in the first of a series of Advent sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The first fifty years of Josef Hofmann's career as an artist in America were celebrated last night at the Metropolitan Opera House where, as a boy of 11, he made his debut on Nov. 29, 1887.
The indefatigable Lehman Engel, who, has ideas of his own, brought a choral group to the little Mercury Theatre yesterday afternoon to present "Music by Princes and Music by the People."

Recovery in the dollar seems to suggest a more hopeful view of business prospects in the United States, because much of its recent weakness has been due to the repatriation of foreign funds frightened away by the trade recession and the slump in Wall Street.

Jokers" inserted in two New England flood-control compacts by utility interests would wreck the Federal Government's power program, Judson King, director of the National Popular Government League, asserted in a bulletin made public today. The compacts are now before Congress for ratification.

A solution of the business depression is a test of democracy and failure to achieve a satisfactory solution will "strengthen the hands of dictatorship the world over," John Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee declared today in a radio address over the Columbia network.
A step which is expected to have a farreaching effect in the development of skiing in North America was taken 'today' at Bryant Camp, Bolton Mountain.

A last-period rally gave the New Haven Jewels a 19-to-18 victory over the New York Celtics in an American Professional Basketball League game before a crowd of 3,500 at the Hippodrome last night. The teams were deadlocked 15--all at the end of the second period.

Robert McNaught of 4,502 Avenue K, Brooklyn, who retired in 1920 as a police lieutenant after twentyfive years in the department, died yesterday in the Kingsway Hospital, Brooklyn, after a brief illness, at the age of 65.
The Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie preached his last sermon yesterday morning as rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-inthe-Bouwerie, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue.

There is no reason to modify in any really important respect the view that the business outlook in Great Britain remains encouraging. Order books are full enough to maintain activity for some months ahead in the principal industries.

Mrs. Ella Ritch, 50 years old, a teacher, was found dead in the bathtub of her apartment at the Hotel Irving, 26 Gramercy Park, at about 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Police said the death was due to natural causes, probably a heart attack.

The five five-story apartment houses at 3,281 to 3,289 Broadway, northwest corner of 132d Street, have been purchased by David Pasinsky from the New York Trust Company, trustees for the Gruener estate.

" Creative Artists, 1938," a new volume showing lithographic reproductions of subjects by leading commercial artists, will be distributed shortly to national advertisers, agency art directors, production managers and others by the Sackett Wilhelms Lithographing Corporation, 562 Fifth Avenue.

The annual Christmas sale of the work of members of the Studio Club of the Young Women's Christian Association, which opens on Friday at 210 East Seventy-seventh Street and continues there until Dec. 19, will be augmented each day with afternoon tea and special entertainment programs.

Oats showed the most resistance to pressure of any grain on the Board of Trade last week, closing yesterday with prices 1/4 cent a bushel lower to 1/2 cent higher, with the December at 303/8 cents, the May at 29 7/8 and the July at 29 1/4.
A young local violinist, John Dembeck, a graduate of the Institute of Musical Art, made his debut last night at Town Hall, assisted at the piano by his teacher, Ronald Murat.

Frank J. Marshall, former national titleholder, scored his second victory in defense of his championship of the Marshall Chess Club in the second round of the annual tournament yesterday. His opponent was John W. Brunnemer, who had the black side of an English opening and lost in fifty moves.

ANDREW--Dr. James H. The Doctors Club of Brooklyn announces with deep regret the death of its beloved member. Dr. James H. Andrew, 163 Hancock St.. Brooklyn, N. Y. Dr. PHILIP GOLDFADER, President. Dr. LOUIS BERGER, Secretary. ANTHONY--Gardner Chace, at his home, 5 Circuit Road, New Rochelle, N. Y., Nov. 28. Funeral notice later.

The nation's Class I railroads will start to present to the Interstate Commerce Commission tomorrow evidence which their executives hope will result in the granting of rate express estimated at $508,000,000 a year.

Hiram Koch, 98-year-old former chief of police of Bethlehem, Pa., died today. Born in a suburb of Easton, Pa., in 1839, he operated a farm near his birthplace for four years before moving to Bethlehem where he served as chief of police from 1898 to 1906. He then retired and returned to Easton.

Alfred De Pierre Beeken, a resident of Fanwood for half a century, died last night at the home of a son, William S. Beeken, in Springfield, Mass. He was born in Brooklyn, N. Y., eighty-one years ago. In 1925 he retired as a printer and manufacturing stationer after many years in business on Park Place, New York.

According to the Paris correspondent of the Tokyo Nichi Nichi, British and American delegations to the Brussels conference agreed to render substantial assistance to China in the form of loans and war materials.

Pushing their rapid advance northward along the west shore of Lake Tai, Japanese forces last night succeeded in completely surrounding the important town of Ihing, whence the highway leads westward to Nanking. Another highway leads northeast along which a further advance would cut off and outflank the Wutsin area.

Transactions in cotton futures on the New York, New Orleans and Chicago Cotton Exchanges will be made public daily, beginning on Thursday, Dr. J. W. T. Duvel, chief of the Commodity Exchange Administration, announced today.

The gift by John D. Rockefeller Jr. of a plot on the north side of West 150th Street just west of Seventh Avenue for permanent use as a neighborhood playground was announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

36th St. 25-27 W: Eugene L. Garey, referee, to Union Dime Savings Bank; foreclosure ($100). 95th St. 210 E; Retsalf Realty Corp (Siegbert Pflaster, president) to Sincha Pflaster, 1,685 Morris Ave, and Evelyn Pflaster, 1,109 Boynton Ave; mtg $9,500. 119th St, 307 E; Elliot J. Sachs, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp, 350 5th Ave; foreclosure (50c).

The process of Rose Bowl matchmaking went on behind a thick veil of secrecy today but University of California athletic officials indicated they were making as much speed as possible toward selection of an opponent for their Golden Bears in the New Year's Day football classic at Pasadena.

The German wholesale price index on Nov. 17 stood at 105.6, against 105.5 on Nov. 10. In the first ten months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index, based on the average of 1913 as 100, ranged between 106.9 on Aug. 11 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

All was quiet today on Elysian Park's "moving mountain," a 350Eoot bluff that pitched an avalanche of 1,000,000 tons of earth across Riverside Drive and into the Los Angeles River bed last Friday night.

Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, challenger for the chess championship of the world, tonight defeated Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam in the twenty-second game of their series. The Franco-Russian master, who lost the title two years ago to his rival, now has a fourpoint lead. He has won eight games, lost four and drawn ten.

The average American man has social aspirations, faith in democracy and believes "what he reads in the papers," Dr. John Dollard, young professor of the Yale University Institute of Human Relations, revealed last night in enumerating twenty-one distinguishing characteristics of the "normal adult American male."

Following news from Moscow of a working agreement between the Second and Third Labor Internationals, Maurice Thorez, secretary of the Communist party, made another appeal here tonight for a political fusion of the Communists and Socialists.
The Men's Clothing Manufacturers Trade Bureau, Inc., will hold a dinner meeting tonight at the Commodore Hotel, with Benjamin Goldman, president, heading the list of speakers.

Sir Lenthal Cheatle, British surgeon, Sir Frederick Williams-Taylor, Elie L. Ponvert, Dowager Lady Beauchamp, Wing Commander Sir Louis Greig, Pierre Wertheimer, Mrs. J. Laurens Van Alen, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Schuyler, Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. McLean and Professor Rudolf Kommer are passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Fourteen gunners braved the rain for the final shoot of the month over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. A high wind whirled the blue rocks into difficult shooting angles and under the circumstances the scores were excellent.

Plans for a roll-call of the 30,000 members of the Knights of Columbus on Long Island to raise funds for relief and scholarship purposes were adopted last night at the monthly meeting of the Long Island Chapter in the Knights of Columbus Institute, 80 Hanson Place, Brooklyn.

Miss Marjorie Elaine Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence B. Stein of Larchmont, N. Y., was married here last evening at the Pierre to Lawrence Maslow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Maslow of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Miller of Temple Shaare Torah performed the ceremony.

The current trade recession in the United State. is being followed here with the keenest interest, more especially so as it is generally conceded that it will have a dominating role in the molding of European economic developments.
A skull of one of the dumbest creatures which ever lived was added today to the collections of the Smithsonian Institution.

Colonel Francois de la Rocque's Rightist French Social party today repudiated the secret committee for revolutionary action accused by the French Government of plotting a dictatorship under a restored monarchy.
Representatives of furniture workers from A. F. of L., C. I. O. and independent unions voted here today to set up under the C. I. O. a new international union for furniture workers.
Higher wages mean better automobiles to the average family in villages of six East Central States, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

A direct avenue for the invocation by employers of the aid of the State Labor Relations Board in determining the sole collective bargaining representative for their workers was provided yesterday in rules and regulations promulgated by the State board.

Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, the English duo-pianists, were again soloists at yesterday afternoon's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, under the direction of John Barbirolli.
A Philippine Army detachment fought a losing battle today against Moro outlaws entrenched in a cotta or earthen fortress near Dansalan, Lanao Province.

Miss Helen Wolcott Bedford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Bedford of 950 Fifth Avenue, will be married at noon today to Arthur McCashin, son of Mrs. James McCashin of Morristown, N. J., and the late Mr. McCashin.

A plea for new modes of Catholic action was made yesterday morning by the Rev. James M. Gillis, editor of The Catholic World, who spoke at the first annual communion breakfast of alumni of St. John's University, Lewis Avenue and Willoughby Street, Brooklyn.

Viewing parking as the key obstacle to a solution of the city's traffic problems, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday a broad program to provide additional parking space in buildings and on vacant lots in congested areas.

Since the greater city was consolidated in 1898 more than $6,500,000,000 has been invested through public and semi-public agencies to promote the beauty of the city and to aid the comfort, convenience and general welfare of its inhabitants, it was disclosed in a survey, made public yesterday, by the Merchants Association of New York.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reports today that a downward trend in residential building costs is under way. Rising building costs have been an important factor in retarding construction, particularly in residential building.
Walter Duranty discussed "The Current Situation in Europe"-in a talk broadcast from Vienna over WABC-Columbia network yesterday, at 1:30 P. M. Regarding the situation in Russia he said:
With only two days of the Eastern racing season rehiaining, it is a safe prediction that Maryland betting for 1937 will approach $33,000,000, a new high for any year since the depression.
Bequests of $50,000 each were left to Pittsburgh and Yale Universities in the will of Erwin W. Smith, Pittsburgh attorney, filed for probate yesterday.
As a result of slashes ordered in operating costs by New York banks, RKO has dropped a number of employes and notified several producers that their options will not be exercised.

The British security markets still are passing through bewildering phases of gloom and transient cheerfulness. This week opened with the markets slumping in all directions and sentiment as depressed as at any time in this long decline.
Stocks recovered and closed higher on the week after declining to the lowest levels since April, 1935; turnover, 6,474,340 shares.

The Virginia Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of a series of folk dance recitals by Dance International, the first of which takes place tomorrow afternoon in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, "New York's Criminal Record," W. P. Beazell, 11 A. M.; "Does the Professional Woman Have an Equal Opportunity Under Dictatorship?" Mrs. Isabel Rhees Kappeyne, 6 P. M.

The last college goal post has toppled for the year in the East. Jupiter F vius, mali--nantly lacking In a sense of proportion the last three Saturdays, will ruin no more fine feathers and millinery of football crowds, not to speak of dispositions and coaches' beautifully laid plans, and the boom in cellophane is over.

The American Academy in Rome announced yesterday its annual competition for the Prix de Rome. Provided candidates reach the required standard, fellowships will be offered in architecture, landscape architecture, painting, sculpture, music and classical studies. Each fellowship is for two years and is worth approximately $2,000 a year.
The Count of Covadonga arrived by plane today from Havana to await a Cuban court decree dissolving his marriage to the former Marta Rocafort.

This week again witnessed a fairly weak stock market, with a partial recovery toward the close. In the absence of any domestic or international developments of a distinctly satisfactory or unsatisfactory kind,

Student farmers of Kansas State Agricultural College at Manhattan repeated their victory of last year by winning the collegiate livestock judging contest today at the International Livestock Exposition.

Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fahnestock of 15 East Sixty-sixth Street have announced the marriage in Reno yesterday of Mr. Fahnestock's daughter, Mrs. Ruth Fahnestock Schermerhorn, to Marie Alfred Fouquereaux De Marigny of Mauritius, a British island possession east of Madagascar.
Manager Al Youst and twenty-five employes of La Paloma night club, including thirteen hostesses, arrested last night in a raid by Sheriff's deputies, were released today on order of Circuit Judge H.

Braving a downpour of rain and strong off-harbor winds that whipped the low bordering arbor vitae branches into their faces, almost 100 Spanish-American War veterans and members of their auxiliaries climbed the steep hill to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery here this afternoon to pay their annual tribute.

Champion Hagerty's Fascinating Model, a handsome dark seal brindie dog owned by August Droll and Benjamin Rosenbloom of Brooklyn, was named best of breed at the seventh annual specialty show of the Brooklyn Boston Terrier Club at Trommer's Gardens yesterday.

The New York Rovers came from behind in the closing minutes tonight to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 2, in an Eastern American Hockey League game. The Orioles went into the final five minutes with a 2-1 lead, but could not stop Desmarais and Rimstad. Twice Rimstad slipped the puck to Desmarais, who scored.

With the season completed, except for a few and widely separated contests, Sid White of Brooklyn College is the Eastern individual football scoring champion for 1937 with 113 points in nine games, The Associated Press reports.
The concert given by the New Friends of Music at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon was a red-letter event in the organization's current series.

The church need not be apologetic when criticized by "the modern mind," the Rev. Cyril Hudson, canon of St. Albans Cathedral in England, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's ProtestantEpiscopal Church, Park Avenue at Fifty-first Street.

A return to Winter weather, is expected here today after two days of unusually high temperatures and heavy rain. The advance front of a widespread cold wave already was freezing up the Middle West yesterday, turning rain into snow and sending temperatures down toward an expected 5 above in some places.

An investigation by the Federal Trade Commission of alleged efforts by drug retailers to force wholesale newsdealers to recall from circulation magazine articles "attempting to give the facts about the Miller-Tydings resale pricemaintenance amendment, which the organized druggists fear to have come to the attention of consumers" is asked by Congressman Emanuel Celler in a letter to W. A. Ayres, chairman of the commission.

John Howard Cromwell, retired member of the New York law firm of Sweeney Cromwell, and a resident of this borough for the last fifteen years, died early today at his home, 223 Elberon Avenue, following a long illness. His age was 80.

Health Guard, Inc., Buffalo, N. Y., has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to stop making misleading representations for a device it makes for use on gas heaters and stoves for the purpose of removing or reducing the amount of carbon monoxide gas expelled.

The New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union 2, by a vote of 543 to 287, ratified last night the wage scale and working conditions contract entered into last July by its scale conference committee with the Publishers Association of New York City.

Although the antlerless deer season had to be eliminated from the sporting schedule of the Pennsylvania hunter, the regular season on male horned deer opens at 9 A. M. today, and thousands of hunters will take to the field throughout the State.
A nation-wide check among housewives of average-income homes indicated an 8-to-2 "vote" for a boycott against Japanese goods, according to announcement made by the editors of National Consumer News.

Premier Camille Chautemps and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France, together with their advisers, arrived here in a choking November fog late tonight for a series of conversations that both the British and French- Governments regard as potentially of great importance for the future peace of Europe.

PINS AND NEEDLES, a revue in two acts and nineteen scenes. Music and lyrics mostly by Harold J. Rome. Sketches by Arthur Arent, Marc Blitzstein, Emanuel Eisenberg, Charles Friedman and Mr Rome. Directed by Mr. Friedman. Produced by Labor Stage, Inc., under the sponsorship of the International Ladies. Garment Workers Union. At the Labor Stage Theatre.

Nels Stewart personally conducted the New York Americans to a 3-3 overtime deadlock ~with the undefeated Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game' tonight before 12,000 spectators at the Boston Garden.
Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell turned today from the fields of the government homestead at Arthurdale to see the squalid, - dusty Scott's Run mining section in which the homesteaders formerly lived.

Opening the second nation-wide campaign for cancer control, Dr. C. C. Little, managing director of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, and Marjorie B. Illig, national commander of the Women's Field Army sponsored by the society, announced yesterday that they had sent letters of appointment to commanders of divisions of the "army" in forty-two States.
The President's letter to Senator Barkley concerning the amount that will be needed to pay for the Farm Bill is as sound in principle as it is politically courageous.

The temple of Shaaray Tefila, which is better known as the West End Synagogue, 160 West Eightysecond Street, will be rededicated at services on Friday night and Saturday morning, Dec. 17 and 18, it was announced yesterday by Harry N. Wessel, president of the congregation.

King Football saved some of the season's chief schoolboy surprises for the final days of his 1937 reign. Thanksgiving Day competition produced several unanticipated upheavals, but, with one or two exceptions, none overshadowed Erasmus Hall's unexpected victory over Peabody (Mass.) High on Saturday.
Members of the Art Students League will show their work at an invitation exhibition to open tomorrow in the league's gallery at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Fifty artists will be represented.

Chicago's powerful Bears clinched the Western section title of the National Football League today by defeating the Cleveland Rams, 15 to 7, at Wrigley Field. The victory was the Bears'. eighth, against one defeat and one tie.

The report of Edward S. Greenbaum, trustee in bankruptcy of the United States estate of Kreuger Toll, to be filed today with. Harold P. Coffin, referee in bankruptcy of the United States District Court,

William Goldstein, counsel for the Wolf Drug Company here, announced today that- he expected settlement and discontinuance tomorrow of a Chancery Court action brought against his client by Pinaud, Inc., under the New Jersey Fair Trade Practices Act. The controversy involved price-cutting.

Although the appointment of Walther Funk, Secretary of State, to succeed Dr. Hjalmar Schacht as Reich Minister of Economies was the sole impor- = tant event in an exceptionally dull business week here, it created only a moderate stir and in no way affected the Boerse.

The Committee for Industrial Organization stepped into Indiana's political picture today in an effort to replace Senator Frederick Van Nuys with Alex Gordon, Indianapolis labor leader, for the Democratic Senatorial nomination next year.

Not scheduled to close until last night, the variety show at the Apollo Theatre, 221 West Forty-second Street, suspended yesterday afternoon when eight principals who are members of the American Federation of Actors refused to report at the theatre.

Preliminary reports from collectors of customs show that 97.01 per cent of the refined sugar and 97.55 per cent of the unrefined sugar admissible duty free from the Philippine Islands in 1937 under the Philippine Independence Act had been received in this country up to Nov. 20, according to the Commissioner of Customs.

Facilities of the Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy will be offered to all American organizations aiding the Chinese, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Walter B. Cannon of Harvard University, national chairman of the bureau.

Nicolas Titulescu is expected to arrive in Rumania tomorrow and will come here shortly after his long, self imposed exile-because of his fear of assassination by Rumanian Fascists. His wife already has opened their beautiful Bucharest house.

Mrs. Thalia W. Malcom of Paris, now at the St. Regis here, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Elisabeth Millett, to Henry de Vilmorin of Paris. The ceremony will take place in the French capital on Dec. 11. Mrs. Malcom will sail for home on Wednesday.

William A. Kuntz Jr., 12-year-old son of a police detective, accidentally shot and killed his 9-year-old sister, Marion, with his father's service revolver yesterday morning as she was lying on the floor of the enclosed sun porch of their home, 3,513 Snyder Avenue, Brooklyn, reading newspaper comic sections.

Human wisdom has not kept pace with the progress of knowledge, according to the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street. In his sermon yesterday morning, Dr. Ayer asserted that "the moral brakes of the world are not strong enough for the mental horsepower of the day," and added:

With the Brooklyn Council count completed Saturday, all but one of the members of the new Council have been determined. The count in the Bronx, delayed by fraud charges and impounding of ballots by the courts, will not be completed until today or tomorrow, but has progressed far enough to show the election of four candidates in that borough.

St. Thomas College completed its most successful football campaign in five years today with a 19-0 victory over La Salle of Philadelphia on a muddy gridiron before 4,500 spectators. The victory was the Tommies' sixth of the season.

Miss Alice Willing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Willing of New York, and James Halley Ruby of Miami Beach, Fla., son of Mrs. Freda Ruby of New York, were married yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker by Rabbi Abraham Burnstein.

PauI S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.,- will preside at the twenty-ninth annual convention of his organization opening today for two days at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

The Soviet Union is ready now, as in the past, to cooperate with other nations to secure peace, but it will rely on its own constantly increasing forces, not on international conferences, for protection against any enemy,

Dr. Gardner Chace Anthony, dean emeritus of the Engineering School of Tufts College and author of several mathematics textbooks, died here today at his home, 5 Circuit Road, at the age of 81. His second wife, who was Ella M. Taylor of Brooklyn, N. Y., at their marriage in 1921, and a son of his first marriage, Charles Pearson Anthony, survive.

Weston Fletcher, 28-year-old Grand Blanc (Mich.) resident suffering from the rare streptococcus viridans infection, remained in serious condition here today after receiving a second blood transfusion. Lawrey Barnes of Simcoe, Ont., was the blood donor, the second of more than 2,000 persons who have volunteered to aid Fletcher after an appeal by his mother.

An aftermath of the Army-Navy game occurred near here today when Lieutenant A. L. Schroeder of Bolling Field overturned his attack plane while attempting to return to his station after attending the game.
The Swiss sharply rejected today a Fascist amendment to the Constitution to exclude Masons and Odd Fellows from its guarantee of the right to free association.

Mrs. Frederick Tracy Millham of this city has announced the marriage on Thanksgiving Day of her daughter, Miss Margot Millham, to Douglas Turnbull Hopkins, son of Mrs. Allison Turnbull Hopkins of New York and. of John Appleton Havens Hopkins of Washington.

Santa Clara's Broncos, only major Far Western football team to complete its season without defeat or tie, made its last and .greatest bid for a second invitation -to the Sugar Bowl today with a 27-to-0 victory over Gonzaga University.

Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein issued a statement today attacking Warren Dixon Jr., Special Assistant Attorney General, for not calling him before the Essex County grand jury in the investigation of Newark's municipal affairs.

Many students of the human comedy, among whom Mr. Stuart Chase is the latest, have drawn attention to some of the dangers inherent in the use of language. It was Robert Louis Stevenson, if one's memory is not at fault, who said that we live not by bread alone but principally by catchwords.
Howard Dunney, veteran Violet end and ace kicker, was the player who got away the eighty-yard punt that surprised spectators and the Fordham team alike in Saturday's game at the Yankee Stadium.

The President's program of Princeton University, designed to assist the institution's future development, gained financial support from an undergraduate organization today for the first time since its inception in 1935. The University Glee Club will give half the net proceeds of its Winter concert series to the program.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,931,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

More than 200 leaders of the academic world, members of the faculties of sixty-four outstanding American universities, joined yesterday in a protest against the institution of "ghetto" benches in Poland and in an open letter to their colleagues in the universities of Poland, appealing to them "to oppose this plan of segregation,"

The seismograph at Fordham University registered its most severe earthquake in years yesterday morning, the delicate needle of the instrument being agitated violently for several hours, the Rev. Joseph Lynch of the Department of Physics reported.

After a comparative calm for several days Palestine's wave of terrorism was renewed today. One British policeman was killed and a Jew was wounded. Late in the afternoon a truck loaded with laborers from the Jewish settlement of Kfar Hakhoresh in Northern Palestine met a rain of bullets from the hills.

Senator Pat McCarran, sponsor of legisolation now before the Senate which would place the airlines of the country directly under the Interstate Commerce Commission and would strip both the Commerce and Postoffice Departments of much of their present control, said today that he would make this bill a major issue in the coming regular session of Congress.

By comparing the total deaths due to automobile accidents in the first ten months of 1937 and 1936 with the increase in motor traffic for the same period in the same years, the National Safety Council contends that drivers have improved.

Sinclair Lewis's latest novel, "The Prodigal Parents" (publication date Jan. 21), is now being dramatized by Helen Jerome, Mr. Lewis disclosed yesterday. As already noted, its story is of the conflict between the younger and older generations, told from the latter's viewpoint.

Women who want members of their sex to get political preference failed to take the opportunity offered in the recent -election, Mrs. William P. Earle Jr. said last night a few hours after learning that she had been elected the only woman on-the new City Council.
The Stock Exchange is having trouble again with the SEC. This time the Securities Board wants it to reorganize with paid

Continued drastic limitation of production by manufacturers of rayon woven broad goods is shown in the survey of loom activity for the week ended Nov. 20, announced today by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

The Banca Commerciale Italiana Trust Company of Boston, announced tonight that it would begin voluntary dissolution tomorrow, paying 2,200 depositors in full with interest up to Dec. 31.. Payments will amount to $1,334,000.

Seven burials that were scheduled for yesterday at Greenwood Cemetery in South Brooklyn, one of the largest cemeteries in the world, had to be postponed and the bodies placed in receiving vaults because of the strike of grave-diggers and other employes there that began on Saturday.

A certificate emblematic of the championship in the "tall potato story contest" was awarded tonight by Maine's Governor, Lewis O. Barrows to Governor Barzilla W. Clark of Idaho for asserting that Idaho potatoes are best.

George H. Johnson Jr., '39, of Drexel Hill, Pa., star fullback for the past two seasons, today, was elected captain of Princeton's 1938 soccer team, Coach William F. Logan announced. Johnson succeeds another fullback, Lawrence Singmaster, '38, of Philadelphia.
The trustees of the American Football Coaches Association met at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to outline plans for their annual convention, which will be held at New Orleans from Dec. 29 to 31.

With a police detail posted outside to prevent further violence, sixty insurgent members of the Building Laborers' Local No. 310, key labor unit in the building trades, voided the local's constitution today, overthrew its "dictator" organizer and elected new officers. The election was called illegal by the organizer, John McGee.

A strong move toward the establishment of a corporate State for Mexico rose in Congress late last night as the official National Revolutionary party bloc backed a proposal for the establishment of nationwide corporations under Presidential direction. The move was opposed immediately by the nation's labor forces.

Fluctuations in the wheat market in the last month have been largely a reflection of factors which normally have little influence on the grain markets, but the latter have shown much more resistance to pressure than securities.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 31 per cent of capacity, down 5 points from the Nov. 21 report. The rate was only three-eighths of that twelve weeks previously, in the 'week before Labor Day.

Repeal or amendment of uneconomic tax laws and the balancing of the budget by reduction of government expenditures are urged by the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issue of its publication, The Guaranty Survey, as remedies to relieve the problems created by the increased cost of doing business.

The first step in a sweeping "revitalization" of the Police Department, which will permit younger men to move into positions now held by aging members of the force, is expected to be taken this morning by Commissioner Valentine.
Minister of Justice Francisco Campos today declared that Brazil's newly promulgated corporative regime is "the foe of communism and hence also the foe of liberalism."

William Allen White of Kansas, in an article in the Survey-Graphic (which is this week celebrating a quarter of a century of the life of the nourishing Survey Associates), uses a sentence of St. Paul's to suggest to us a strange and to him inexplicable thing: "I show you a mystery."

Premier Camille Chautemps and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos, accompanied by Alexis Leger, permanent secretary of the Foreign Office, and Rene Massigli, its political expert, went to London this afternoon for the forthcoming conferences with the British. When these four travel together anywhere, it is important. In the present instance it is more than usually important.
Frightened capital that had been exported still is returning to France, and if the money market were left to its own devices there is little doubt that the franc rate would rise quite steeply.

Buying of steel in November has been approximately 15 per cent under that of October, with virtually all producers meeting about the same conditions, according to the magazine Steel. Much of the current lack of buying is attributed to sufficient inventories in the hands of consumers to meet present reduced demands for their products.

In a ceremony resplendent with the pomp of Czarist Russia, the Russian Cathedral of St. Nicholas, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street, marked its thirty-fifth anniversary in a two and one-half hour service yesterday morning attended by 200 persons.

Dance International 1900-1937, an exposition which will continue until Jan. 2, was opened officially yesterday afternoon. The ceremonies occurred at a preview of the exposition's art exhibition in the International Building of Rockefeller Center.

The six-day bicycle race was started last night by Mayor La Guardia. Armed -with a blank pistol, the city's Chief Executive stood on the Fiftieth Street side of the Madison Square Garden track at 9 o'clock, and, with fifteen teams of riders awaiting his signal, fired the shot that sent the pedal-pushers on a grind that will last, without scheduled interruption, until 11 o'clock Saturday night.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 85.1, which compares with 86.1 a week ago, 87.1 two weeks ago, 87.9 three weeks ago and 88.1 four weeks ago.
As a stimulus to new ship construction, the Maritime Commission will make no further sales of surplus vessels in its laid-up fleet of World War origin, Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman, announced today.

The steamship Pennland of the Red Star Line, which sailed from Hoboken Saturday for Southampton and Antwerp, was in collision that night with the four-masted American schooner Anna R. Heidritter about thirty-eight miles southeast of the Ambrose Channel lightship, according to a report made yesterday by the United States Coast Guard.

John W. Davis, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, announced last night that J. P. Morgan Co. had contributed $25,000 to the drive. Mr. Davis said campaign workers were intensifying their efforts to bring in $500,000 by Friday.
Back to Broadway - specifically, to the Martin Beck Theatre-comes Ina Claire tonight to star in "Barchester Towers," the comedy "freely adapted" by Thomas Job from the Anthony Trollope novel.
Wilson Fitch Smith, civil engineer, who had directed many important works in his field, died yesterday, after a long illness, at his residence, 116 East Fifty-third Street. He was 66 years old.

Cold weather in some sections of the country last week stimulated reorders on seasonal goods but, on the whole, the volume on mail business coming into the local merchandise markets yesterday was confined to fill-in requests for holiday goods, according to manufacturers and resident buyers.
