The State Industrial Board tonight granted a month's grace to Pennsylvania employers before they must conform to the provisions of the State's forty-four-hour work week law, which had been scheduled to go into effect at midnight tomorrow.

The executive committee of the New Orleans Mid-Winter Sports Association-spent six hours behind locked doors tonight considering football teams to play in the fourth annual Sugar Bowl game New Year's Day and adjourned without making any selections.

Undefeated, untied Colorado University is represented by three players on the 1937 Associated Press All-Rocky Mountain conference football team. Two of them-Byron (Whizzer) White, Phi Beta Kappa student, quarterback and the nation's top scorer with 122 points, and Gene Moore,

Mrs. Annie D. Holmes, widow of James S. Holmes and daughter of Rush Burgess, former New Jersey Assemblyman and Collector of Internal Revenue under President Grant, died yesterday at the age of 74. She had resided here with a son, Everett H. Holmes.

Ferdinand Augustus (Gus) Buescher, founder of the Buescher Band Instrument Company, and identified with the industry since he came to Elkhart as a lad of 14 in 1875, died early this morning at his home here following a heart attack. Mr.

The Society of Restaurateurs at its monthly dinner last night at the a Lafayette, 33 University Place, had a as its honor guest Ralph Hitz of the Hotel New Yorker. He is president of the National Hotel Management Corporation.
Mrs. Elizabeth Tatham Dick, widow of Evans R. Dick, former senior member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Dick Brothers Co., died on Sunday at her home at Garrison-on-Hudson.

The Federal Theatre Project is negotiating for the lease of five theatres, one in each borough, for the presentation of its more important productions this Winter, George Kondolf, project director, announced yesterday.

From 11 o'clock in the morning, when they met in Downing Street, until late tonight after an informal dinner at the house of Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden leaders of the French and British Governments were in close and intimate conversation over world problems.

Officials of the Philadelphia School District, Philadelphia, Pa., have called for tenders to be submitted Dec. 14 for the purchase of an issue of $6,650,000 of bonds. The new issue is to be dated Dec. 16, 1937,

The marriage of Miss Helen Wolcott Bedford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Bedford of New York, to Arthur John McCashin, son of Mrs. James McCashin of Morristown, N. J., and the late Mr. McCashin, took place here at noon today at the Bedford country place on Frost Point.

The four-story apartment house at 238 Railroad Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Excelsior Mutual Building and Loan Association to Frederick Pescio, who intends to modernize it. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Big business is moving blindly but with gathering momentum down the road to ultimate government supervision, Homer S. Cummings, United States Attorney General, told leaders of business and finance who packed the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday to hear him discuss "The Unsolved Problem of Monopoly."

The appointment of Robert L. Freeman as coach of the Penn junior varsity basketball team was announced today by H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics. Freeman succeeds Paul Davenport, who will coach the Penn freshmen this Winter in place of William Leopold, resigned.

Taxes are a necessary function of government. Without taxes government cannot exist. From the Federal Government's standpoint, taxes may be placed in three principal categories: First, those based on ability to pay, such as income, estate and gift taxes; second,
Ten games have been booked for the Colgate sextet this Winter, it was announced tonight by William A. Reid, director of athletics. Home and home contests with Cornell's hockey forces are listed.
The undefeated University of Colorado football team will meet a Southwest Conference representative in the Cotton Bowl game here New Year's Day.

New York University students consider the Ten Commandments as cogent rules for "the mad scheme of modern living," but many of them question the validity of five of the commandments-the three on the attitude of man to God, and the two on sex conduct.

Assurances that substantial modifications will be made in the undistributed corporate income and capital gains taxes in the interest of business revival were given to the country tonight by Senator Harrison of Mississippi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, in a radio address broadcast from Washington.

Johnny Pastor, 163 pounds, of Hightstown, got up off the canvas to take an eight-round decision over Stanley Pyontek, 168, of Trenton, tonight, but a pair of Trenton lightweights in the semi-final supplied the loudest fistic thunder.

The new capital city which Chancellor Adolf Hitler in his Saturday speech promised to erect here will be strikingly different and far more grandiose than the present rather planless and featureless Berlin.

With the opening game scheduled Friday night against the alumni, Coach Joe Lapchick of the St. John's University basketball team made three changes in the line-up in the drill at the DeGray gymnasium yesterday.

The Regis High School basketball team scored its second straight victory yesterday, crushing St. Agnes Academy of College Point, 57 to 21, on the winner's floor. James McKay, captain and left forward, led the attack for Regis with eighteen points.

Andrew Ponzi captured the two opening blocks of his twelve-block pocket billiard engagement with Irving Crane at the Strand Academy yesterday. In the afternoon Ponzi won, 125 to 119, in twentytwo innings, with a high run of 33 to 54 for his opponent. He won the evening test, 125 to 30, in nine frames, scoring a high of 43 to 14 for Crane.

A resolution declaring that strikes, rioting and similar disorders in the industrial centers of the North and East have caused more loss of life than all the lynchings in the South," was adopted unanimously today by the Georgia House of Representatives and sent to the Senate.

Mrs. Henry Darlington, wife of the rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, is a patroness for the benefit bridge party to be given at the parish house this afternoon under the auspices of the Junior Guild of the church.

The St. Ann's Academy quintet opened its season with a 33 to 14 victory over the Immaculata High School team on the former's court yesterday. Ryan of the victors captured high scoring honors with twelve points.

" Long Live Nicholas Horthy, King of Hungary;" With these words were concluded posters affixeddoubtless without the Regent's approval-on the walls of Debreczen and Budapest last night by Major Ferenc Szalasi's Hungarian National Socialist party. Leaflets bearing the same legend were also distributed in the streets.

Improved conditions brought about by Federal rehabilitation activities have started the Virgin Islands on the road to economic self-recovery and preparations for establishing universal suffrage after Jan. 1 have stirred wide interest among the people, Governor Lawrence W. Cramer said in his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior today.

Valentine Holdosi, 15-year-old Russian-born schoolboy, who won the William 0. Stillman Humane Medal for heroism in rescuing his pet dogs and birds when his home was destroyed on Oct. 30 in the International Settlement in Shanghai, has been found in Shanghai,
Miss Anna Vanuxem Wurts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Wurts, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her parents at their Germantown home, Hedgefield.

John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, announced yesterday that Supreme Court Justice Isidore Wasservogel had signed an order restraining Vincent Forgione, doing business as Vincent Forgione Company, 50 Broad Street, from the sale of oil royalties and securities in this State.

James J. Lipsett of Greenwich, former hotel proprietor, died suddenly in Gulfport, Fla., last night at the age of 72. Mr. Lipsett left on Nov. 18 by train for his Winter home at Gulfport, where he was stricken with an attack of gastritis and heart ailment.

Use of stamps on orders from manufacturers by retailers requiring identification of fiber content to meet the requirements of the Federal Trade Commission's rayon rules has not brought protests from manufacturers, it was indicated by executives of three metropolitan department stores yesterday.

Canadian residents who derive income from United States sources will pay a flat 5 per cent income tax, to be deducted at the source; but residents of other countries who draw income from American sources, through Canadian Agencies, will be taxed 10 per cent.

Several leases for large quarters were among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. Among them was one for 12,000 square feet of space in the six-story building at 436-40 Lafayette Street, which was taken by the United Scientific Laboratories, Inc., radio manufacturers.

A program of construction and expansion calling for an expenditure of $30,000,000 to $35,000,000 in 1938 and 1939 is under consideration by the Boston Edison Company and the New England Power Association, Frank D. Comerford, president of the Edison company, told Representative John W. McCormack today in a telegram to Washington.

The 1937 Class A and B scholastic football champions of Nassau County will be named tonight when the Robert Low Bacon Trophy Committee convenes at the Freeport Lodge of Elks to make its second annual selections. Two trophies will be awarded in the separate classes.

At a tea given at their home on Hycliff Terrace Dr. and Mrs. Donald Robert MacLean announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise MacLean, to the Rev. Richard Irwin Porter, son of Mrs. William Coulter of New London.

Although there is an increased demand for coconut charcoal from Malaya for. gas mask manufacturers, production of the charcoal at present price levels is not profitable owing to the high freight rates from Malaya on this product, according to a report from Singapore made public by the Department of Commerce.
H. J. Blue of Aberdeen won the par-bogey competition for Class A Tin Whistle Club members today I with a gross card of 33, 35-68, which netted him 80 points.
WHAT Harold nicolson did with bravado and cynicism in his book called "Peacemaking" James T. Shotwell of Columbia University now does more soberly in "At the Paris Peace Conference."*

Former Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu received an ovation from his admirers on his return tonight after sixteen months of self-imposed exile, due largely to fascist threats against his life. It is believed that, despite the undiminished political hostility, the anti-Semitic Iron Guard has promised Dr. Julius Maniu, in connection with his electoral pact, these threats will not be carried out.

By completing 95 of 216 forward passes for an efficiency of 43 per cent over their full schedule, the Green Bay Packers established a new National League Football mark, official statistics revealed yesterday. Green Bay and Brooklyn were joint possessors of the old mark of 41 per cent.

As baseball men here prepared yesterday to leave for Milwaukee to attend the minor league meetings the Brooklyn club announced that John Gorman, its business manager for the last two years, had severed relations with the Dodgers.
The two-story business building at 35-10 Broadway, Astoria, L. I., has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to an investing client of John J. Reynolds, broker in the deal.

Sales of copper were made yesterday in the export market at prices ranging from 9.83 to 10.30 cents a pound c.i.f the European base ports. Most of the business was done between 9.83 and 10.15 cents. On Friday sales were made at 9.83 cents.
Milton N. Johnson, manager of the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here, announced tonight that fiftytwo cars were turned out despite a strike by the United Automobile Workers of America.
Nash Motors today started a four-day week of eight hours instead of the five-day normal week, and curtailed production and employment to the lowest level of the current year.

The executive committee of the Republican National Committee will meet in St. Louis Dec. 13 to "consider chairmanship and membership of the Program Committee," John M. Hamilton, chairman of the National Committee. announced today.
The bright side of the administration picture was extended in area today by the President's message on housing plans and Senator Harrison's radio speech on taxation.
The indications are for fair and continued cold weather today and tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

A drop of 15.8 per cent in the number of job placements in private industry by the State employment office last month, as compared with September, is shown in the report today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner. October placements in private industry were 6.6 per cent less than in October, 1936.
Senator McAdoo of California said today he would seek Congressional action in January on his proposed "death sentence" for holding companies engaged in the chain banking business.

President Roosevelt's message to Congress urging legislation to stimulate a housing program brought praise from the Democratic ranks on Capitol Hill, a tolerant attitude on the part of Republicans, but a coolness from labor leaders as to that part suggesting lower labor costs.

Although "The New Gossoon" has been played here twice within the last five years and is only a middling comedy at best, all the faithful were on hand at the Ambassador last evening to see the Abbey Theatre Players act it once more.

Contempt proceedings against six Hudson County Newspaper Guild members and a C. I. 0. organizer in the picketing of a store and the use of a sound truck to advertise the strike of the editorial employes of The Bayonne Times was put off until Dec. 16 by Vice Chancellor James F. Fielder today.

Differences between the estimated historical worth of imperial Russian art treasures and the actual "melt-down" value given police led yesterday to divergent estimates on the amount of loot taken from the Schaffer Art Galleries in a burglary early Sunday morning.

The National Association of Insurance Commissioners opened a three-day convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, attended by insurance officials of thirty-nine States and two Canadian provinces.

More than twenty-four hours after the freighter Cauto went aground about a mile off Puerto Mexico, attempts were still being made tonight in a pounding sea and a heavy gale to get ashore the thirty-two members of the crew still aboard..

H. Victor Schwimmer, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a report to the commission, recommended yesterday that a stop-order suspending the effectiveness of the registration statement covering 74,000 shares of common stock of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., be issued.
The Rev. Arthur C. Carty, a Protestant Episcopal clergyman and formerly a chaplain at the Philadelphia Navy Yard, died in Episcopal Hospital here today after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

Real estate and construction interests in New York generally viewed the recommendations of President Roosevelt for easier financing of building work and home buying as a "step in the right direction."

Commenting on the skirmishes between the police of Jersey City and the band of C. I. 0. organizers and sympathizers who defied his ban on the distribution of propaganda pamphlets yesterday, Mayor Frank Hague recalled a visit he had made to New York recently and the sights he had seen.

Stocks of crude oil and its products in the Pacific Coast territory at the end of October amounted to 123,371,404 barrels, an increase of 1,597,539 in the month, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Merryall District School had a teacher as usual today, but none of the eighteen pupils was present, as parents protested that the children had been severely disciplined.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Sunday at Tryon, N. C., of Mrs. Kate Strong Sewall, wife of the Rev. Charles G. Sewall, formerly of Rye, N. Y., and daughter of the late Rev. Dr. Augustus H. Strong, former president of the Rochester Theological Seminary.

Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff gave a tea yesterday afternoon at their home, 860 Park Avenue, for Prince and Princess Simon C. Sidamon Eristoff and others interested in the success of the Allaverdy Ball, which will be held Friday at the Plaza.

The Senate resumed debate on the Farm Bill, received President Roosevelt's message urging a sixpoint housing program and the Wagner bill for carrying out the President's recommendations, and recessed at 5 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

A hearing on a petition filed on Nov. 19 by the Asbury Park Hotel and Realty Company, owner of the Monterey Hotel in Asbury Park, to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act was set here today by Federal Judge William Clark for Dec. 6.

Frank V. Whiting, general claims attorney of the New York Central Railroad, will retire today after fifty-three years of service and will be succeeded by 0. G. Browne, who for nine years has been assistant general claims attorney. Herbert L. Hanson has been appointed an additional chief claims agent here.

A complete restoration of confidence in the banking system of the nation has been achieved in the United States since 1933 and the masses of the people have been turning to these institutions more than ever before for advice and guidance, Gilbert T. Stephenson, director of the trust research department of the Graduate School of Banking of the American Bankers Association, said here today.

Postmaster General James A. Farley, acting as chairman of the Democratic State Committee, sent letters yesterday to the party leaders of the sixty-twocounties in the State inviting them to attend a luncheon conference at the Biltmore Hotel Jan. 8.

Four Russian scientists who are spending the long polar night on a slowly drifting ice floe in the Arctic Ocean reported today that cracks in their floe had refrozen so quickly that there was no danger of its breaking up.

The five-story stone residence of Charles S. Guggenheimer at 923 Fifth Avenue, between Seventythird and Seventy-fourth Streets, has been leased for a long term by Dr. Paul Laval, operating as the Laval Realty Corporation, and will be converted into small apartments.

Following the examples set by the favorites in the first five races, Mrs. A. M. Creech's Catomar, odds-onchoice in the sixth at the Fair Grounds, lost by a head to Mrs. W. D. Barnhardt's Janeen today.
The fifth City Council candidate to be elected in the Bronx was undetermined last night as the canvassers at the 105th Field Artillery armory completed the twenty-fourth count in that borough.

Dan W. Tracy, president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. of L. affiliate with a membership of 215,000, commended yesterday as "intelligent and constructive" the rules and regulations promulgated by the State Labor Relations Board for the determination of collective bargaining agencies of employes.

William Henry Naugle of the Ansonia Hotel, an official of the Suchar Process Corporation, 120 Wall Street, died yesterday after a Short illness in the Wickersham Hospital, 133 East Fifty-eighth Street, at the age of 73.
The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors received a communication today from the Building Trades Council urging establishment of a junior college or vocational school in the county.

A. P. Herbert, father of the new British Divorce Act, upset the dignity and equanimity of the House of Commons tonight by injecting into the debate on a bill aimed at improving population statistics pithy comment to the effect that the government really asked authority to "ask peonle why they have ceased to breed."

ANTHONY-Gardner Chace, at his home, 5 Circuit Road, New Rochelle. N. Y., Nov. 28. Services Geo. T. Davis Memorial, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, 2:30 P. M. Wednesday. APPEL-Harry, beloved husband of Anna, devoted father of Samuel, Benjamin and Hannah Cohen. Funeral today, Nov. 30, 10 A. M., from 2,773 West 37th St., Coney Island. Services Congregation Kneses Israel of Seagate. 10:30 A. M.

Mineral production in Alaska since 1880, the first year that records are available, has amounted to $722,222,000, or more than 100 times the $7,200,000 which the United States paid Russia for the territory, Governor John W. Troy said in his annual report to Secretary Ickes today.
The Italian Government has completed payment of its 1937 League of Nations dues, a total of 1,383,628 gold francs, it became known today.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation in its statement for the six months ended on Oct. 31, released today, reports a net profit of $4,440, 801 after all charges, including depreciation, depletion, interest and taxes, other than surtax on undistributed earnings, and after deducting minority stockholders' proportion of the net profit of Pacific Mills. Ltd.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of Joseph H. Choate Jr. in THE TIMES on the effects of taxation should be limited to your readers, numerous though they be. I wish it were possible to circulate it by the millions in all sections of the country.

The six-story apartment house at 344-46 West Fourteenth Street will be sold at auction today by B. Hollander Son in a foreclosure auction brought by St. Luke's Hospital against Mary Fromer and others.

The fuel-tax division of the State Tax Department asked today that Budget Commissioner Stephan approve a requested appropriation of $15,000 for purchase of a boat to replace the one now on patrol in New York Harbor.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 24:

Professor Royal B. Way, head of the Political Science Department of Beloit College for thirty years, died tonight at the of 64 after a brief illness. He had been active in international law associations and wrote "Diplomacy of the SpanishAmerican War."
Miles M. Sherover of the Hanover Sales Corporation of New York arrived here today to try to arrange the release of $25,000,000 in frozen credits which American business men invested in Spain.

The United States District Court here approved today the sale by trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad of the steamboat Mohawk to the Central Vermont Transportation Company for $20,000.
President Roosevelt's recommendations to Congress for changes in the National Housing Act were the chief topic of conversation in New York realty circles yesterday.

Stanley Martin Jr., 29 years old, of 305 West Ninety-eighth Street, Manhattan, pleaded guilty before Judge Thomas Downs in the Queens County Court yesterday to manslaughter in the first degree and was remanded to the Queens city prison for sentence Friday.

Fashion's star performance of the season was put on last night according to tradition at the opening of the Metropolitan. No crashing climaxes marked its progress and the curtain calls will be taken much later,

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Noble will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their wedding tomorrow with a mass in the morning at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church here and with a reception, dinner and dance later in the day at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, in which borough they were married. Mr.

The Metropolitan Trust Company of Chicago has been admitted to membership in the Federal Reserve System, and becomes the first member in the Seventh Federal Reserve District which does not do a banking business.

The National Labor Relations Board, by its own ruling, denies an employer the right to ask for an election to determine what representatives the majority of his employes want to bargain blood brotherhood for them. The New York State Labor Relations Board has ruled that it will grant the employer this right.

The message which Mr. Roosevelt sent to Congress yesterday marks a new phase in the evolution of the New Deal. For here, in the President's eagerly awaited program for a revival of the building industry, is a philosophy of action strikingly at variance with the policy which has animated AAA, NRA and various other New Deal measures.

Following is the text of the message on housing sent to Congress today by President Rooseevelt: To the Congress of the United States: In my message to the Congress upon the convening of the extraordinary session on Nov. 15,

Cuban raw sugar exports this year to Oct. 31, amounted to 2,341,960 long tons, compared with 2,289,235 correspondingly in 1936, according to a report from Havana and made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The dispute over responsibility for the recent decline in security prices which has already brought a charge from Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, that excessive regulations were threatening the market, and a long delayed reply from W. 'O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in which he threatened further restrictions, continued unabated. Mr.
Mr. and Mrs. Albert D. S. Palmer of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Palmer, to Ward Lawrence Luther Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther, also of White Plains.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today an export program with benefit payments to exporters of shelled pecans, in order to reduce the current domestic crop and to aid the industry to establish permanent foreign markets.
Stocks closed steady at slightly lower levels; turnover 1,145,910 shares. South American issues higher, other bonds firm and mixed in quiet trading; transactions, $6,626,500.

Clubs belonging to the Metropolitan Badminton Association will swing into team competition in the various divisions on Sunday. The campaign will run well into January. Thirty-nine clubs will have seventy teams competing.

Because most of the milk produced in New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut is going into fluid milk, leaving little for butter or cream, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday that dealers here had been permitted to bring cream for manufacturing purposes from Indiana and Wisconsin.

Count Emanuele Castelbarco is having his first one-man show in America. It opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Marie Sterner Gallery, 9 East Fiftyseventh Street, and will continue until Dec. 11.

Strong pressure by large buyers in both the jobbing and chain store fields for lower prices on volume women's shoes developed yesterday at the opening of the annual showing sponsored by the National Volume Shoe Manufacturers Association.
Quebec and Ontario, which rank first and second as producers of pulpwood and newsprint in Canada, have reached an agreement on wages and prices in the industry.

Any tendency to minimize the seriousness of the current recession has been dispelled by the continued curtailment reflected by nearly all indices of production and trade during October and the first half of November, according to the monthly review of business conditions issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The volume of freight moved by truck in October was 2.78 per cent above the total for October, 1936, but 4.28 per cent below September of this year, the American Trucking Associations, Inc., announced today.
An experiment in art education of the young will be begun today by the Museum of Modern Art and twelve cooperating schools of the city, including the Spence, Chapin and Horace Mann Schools.

With acceptance by the House of Representatives this morning of modifications introduced in the Emergency Electoral Code by the Senate, the date of elections for partial renewal of the lower chamber has been fixed as March 5.

What may prove to be the final attempt of Democratic House leaders to force a discharge from the Rules Committee of the wages and hours measure was started today. When the House adjourned, eight more names had been added to the discharge petition, which for more than a week has been on the Speaker's desk.

The Manhattan division of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom is planning an air parade of about twenty airplanes over the city Dec. 17, according to Mrs. Portia Willis Berg, chairman.

Dexter Fellows, famous circus press agent, will be buried here Wednesday afternoon. The Rev. Elmer L. Olsen will officiate at funeral services at 2 P. M. at the Fellows home, Mrs. Martin W. Sandstrom, his mother-in-law, said.

Completing the most successful season since its start in college football, the Brooklyn College team, victorious in seven of its nine contests this Fall, will be honored and presented awards by the Flatbush Avenue Boosters Club in a giant rally to be held on the stage of the Farragut Theatre at Flatbush Avenue and Rogers Avenue at 8:30 tomorrow night.

A sharp increase in the number of auto accidents, deaths and injuries over the week-end compared with the corresponding period last year was reported yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department.

This is the last chance. If you don't get into a duck blind today you will have a wait eleven months, unless you plan to have some shooting in the Southern zone, which comprises Maryland, Virginia and on southward and westward to Arizona, Texas and California. This zone opened last Saturday.

The American Newspaper Guild opened its "unfair labor practices" case against The Seattle Star today with testimony that efforts of the strikers to return to work as a body July 31 were rebuffed. The strike was called July 3.

October sales of reporting wholesale concerns in this district averaged 6.5 per cent lower than last year, following two months in which sales had increased, according to the monthly report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent here.

Ralph Zannelli, Providence's undeheated welterweight, gained his twenty-seventh triumph in twentynine professional ring starts tonight when he outpointed Phil Furr, Washington veteran boxer, in a ten-round bout attended by 2,335 fans. Zannelli won handily against a foe who claimed he had broken his right hand in the second round.

Although allowance was made for the holiday, the daily average of automobile production last week declined sharply against an upward seasonal trend and the adjusted index has slumped to 77.3 from 96.0 in the preceding week. It was 112.0 for the week ended Nov. 28, 1936.
Mr. and Mrs. John Bromley of Chestnut Hill have announced the engagement of Mr. Bromley's daughter, Miss Janet Bromley, to William Pepper Watts,

Trade rumors were almost as numerous as pints of beer in Milwaukee today as baseball's David Harums, big and small, gathered at hotels. Though the minor league meetings do not open until Wednesday, most of the traders came two days in advance to bait their hooks.

The number of business failures in the United States for the fiveday period ended Nov. 24 was 184, compared with 206 for the previous full week and 129 in the corresponding five-day period last year; according to the weekly report yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Appointment of Harold T. Hulett as manager of the commercial refrigeration section, specialty appliance division of the appliance and merchandise department, General Electric Company, Cleveland, was announced here yesterday by Rex Cole, Inc., local distributor. Mr.

Georges Robinet, governing director of G. H. Mumm Co. (Societe Vinicole de Champagne Successeur) Reims, France, will give a luncheon today at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for the Mumm champagne distributors in the Eastern section of the country.

The National City Bank of New York, as fiduciary trustee, and Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, the former Gertrude Vanderbilt, as transferee, owe the government of the United States $804,689, with interest, for unpaid income taxes on profits made from the sale of the old Vanderbilt mansion at Fifty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson ruled yesterday.
The stock market was generally cheerful today with sentiment lifted by the week-end strength in Wall Street. Gilt-edge issues were quiet and firm but foreign bonds behaved undecidedly.
Forty golfers who have attained the age of 50 or more put finishing touches on their game today for the inaugural of the Professional Golfers Association seniors' tournament.

Explosion of a tear gas bomb, dropped by an unidentified person, interrupted a recital by Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, at the University of Michigan tonight. Fumes from the bomb caused many in the audience of 5,000 to leave hastily.
Friends of Lois Clarke de Ruyter Spreckels Clinton, formerly of New York City and California, said today she was on her way to Reno from Boise, Idaho, for a third Nevada divorce.

Delaney, 181 pounds. of Oshawa, Ont., tonight lost a tenround decision to Maurice Strickland, 187, of New Zealand, at Harringay Arena, in a British Empire heavyweight elimination bout to select an opponent for Champion Tommy Farr.

Beginning last night, more than 700 members of Theatrical Protective Union 1, the stagehands' organization, are each turning over two performances a week to aid the 571 members who are not employed on full time.

Determined not to let the Eastern Division championship of the National Football League slip out of their hands for the second successive season, the New York Giants will start work today for their decisive battle with the powerful Washington Redskins at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

The police recorded as a suicide the death this morning of Mrs. Sophie Sarver, 50 years old, wife of Isaac Sarver, silk manufacturer, of 186 Lawrence Place. She was found fatally injured in the driveway of her home and died in Barnert Memorial Hospital without regaining consciousness.
The Brooklyn College basketball team will open its 1937-38 court campaign Saturday night against Coach Nat Holman's City College quintet.

Further governmental regulation of the security exchanges of the nation would endanger the market, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, warned last night in a statement replying to the recent threat by the Securities and Exchange Commission that stock exchanges must reorganize and reform or face Federal intervention.

Dance International, an exposition devoted to dancing and the related arts since 1900, began a fiveweek season yesterday morning in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, after an Invitation preview on Sunday afternoon.

Offering will be made to the public tomorrow of $15,000,000 in Province of Quebec bonds, part of a $25,000,000 issue. The balance already has been sold. The proceeds of the loan will be used to retire outstanding short-term borrowings and for general purposes.

Plans for the twenty-first annual conyention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards have been completed. Advance reservations for the three-day meeting, which opens on Thursday at the Hotel Traymore, Atlantic.City, indicate a large attendance, according to a statement from headquarters of the association here.

The engagement of Miss Rebecca Gans, daughter of Mrs. Marks L. Gans of 784 Park Avenue and Dallas, Texas, and the late Mr. Gans, to Stanley R. Levy, son of Mrs. Isaiah D. Levy of this city and Baltimore and the late Mr. Levy, has been announced by her mother.
The United States has lost its leadership in world affairs and to that fact largely can be attributed the impotence of the Nine-Power Treaty Conference in Brussels.

Two Canadian paper companies, the Abitibi Power and Paper Company and Price Bros. Co., Ltd., announced today a price of $50 a ton for newsprint for the last half of 1938, the same as previously announced for the first half of next year.
The Football Writers Association held its annual business meetingat the Hotel Co nmodore yesterday and elected officers. Arthur J. Daley of THE NEW YORK 'TIMES was elected president;

A request by spokesmen for the Committee for Industrial Organization that the American Federation of Labor Committee reduce to writing its verbal assurances of willingness to agree upon the industrial form of union organization for certain industries was refused by the Federation group today and the deadlocked conference adjourned until 11 A. M. tomorrow.
At a special meeting in Boston, stockholders of the Walworth Company approved the plan for dividend payment and issue of additional stock. More than 68 per cent
Dealings in the foreign exchange market were again dull yesterday, but such changes as occurred were mostly in favor of the dollar.

Manager Jack Adams of the once proud Detroit Red Wings, admitting he has been disappointed by the Stanley Cup hockey champions' current downslide, asked for waivers tonight on two players in a drastic shake-up of his team.

Checking a note sent to the Bronx Medical Examiner's office, which said that the writer, Etelka Baker, intended to commit suicide, the police yesterday hurried to her apartment at 361 East 163d Street, the Bronx, where they found her dead of gas poisoning.
Dividend Shares, Inc.-Total assets, with securities priced at market quotations on Oct. 31, were $35,359,359, according to the report for the year ended with October.

Violation of the anti-trust laws was charged against certain railroads serving the South in an amended complaint which the Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted nine Southern States to file in connection with their proceeding for a revision of rates between the North and South, charging existing rates are prejudicial to the South.
Engineering contracts totaling $766,806.76 were awarded by the War Department today, as follows:

At a hearing marked by bitter oral exchanges, Mary K. O'Connor, 19year-old college student, was held, without bail by Mayor Wilson today to await the action of the coroner on a charge of homicide in connection with the death on Labor Day of Nancy Glenn, 5 years old.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh today criticized "governmental benevolence" and "extravagance" on the part of Secretary Ickes in connection with the construction of a $125,000 consolidated school in East Lampeter township, Lancaster county, in the face of protests by Amish and Mennonite taxpayers.

With their ardor still at high pitch despite last year's snow famine in the East, skiers in this part of the country are beginning to make extensive preparations for the coming season, which should even surpass that of the highly successful one two Winters ago.

The trend in furniture production in October continued on the downswing, with new orders for the month amounting to about 30 per cent less than in October, 1936, according to the November bulletin issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.

The University of Pittsburgh's rating as No. 1 college football team of the year fell only a trifle short of being unanimous in the. final round-up of votes for The Associated Press national writers' poll.
In the presence of Crown Prince Gustaf Adolf of Sweden, a monument in the park overlooking Goetenborg Harbor was dedicated today by Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania.

A glistening silvery train. streamlined from the blue-trimmed nose of its giant locomotive to the observation end of its fifth car, made its debut in a demonstration run today preparatory to going into regular service for the Reading Company between this city and New York on Dec. 13.

Professor Russell Potter's indictment of women speakers as in general less popular with their audiences than man has a corollary, Mrs. Poletti declared yesterday, in the faults of many men speakers, particularly when addressing women. Mrs. Poletti is State chairman of the League of Women Voters.
A loan exhibition of portraits of children in painting and sculpture by distinguished artists will be held at the Arden Gallery, 460 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the Greenwhich House Music School.

Albert Morris Bagby'gave his second Musical Morning of the season yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Lotte Lehmann, soprano, and Mario Chamlee, tenor, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Moriz Rosenthal, pianist.
Edward A. Malloy of Scranton, Pa., wants to bring suit against P. Lorillard Company, Inc., because a prize was not awarded to him in the recent nation-wide Old Gold contest.

Princeton's basketball team forged into the lead in the first period and never was headed as it downed La Salle College of Philadelphia, 31-29, in a pre-season practice game at the university gymnasium tonight. The Nassau quintet will open officially against Dickinson College here Dec. 8.

John David, founder of a chain of men's wear stores in New York City, who died in Atlantic City, N. J., on Nov. 15, left his estate in trust to his widow, Mrs. Vera Beatrice David of 375 Park Avenue. His will was filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court.

Grocery manufacturers, gathered at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria for the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., sat back yesterday afternoon while the customers they serve outlined the steps they feel producers must take to solve merchandising problems confronting the industry.

Adoption of President Roosevelt's theory of valuing public utilities on a "prudent investment" basis for rate-making purposes must be authorized by Congress instead of a court decision if there is to be a change in present practice, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company told the Supreme Court today.

J. A. Voice, president of the Consolidated Lithographing Corporation, announced yesterday after a meeting of the directors that he had bought an additional 40,000 shares of the company's common stock, increasing his holdings to approximately 90 per cent of the stock outstanding.
In a little less than forty years, so the Merchants Association reports, public and semipublic agencies in

The bond market was a dull and mixed affair yesterday, although gains somewhat outnumbered losses at the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The volume of business totaled $6,626,500, third smallest day of the month, compared with $6,829,700 Friday.

Minimum resale price contracts for standard groceries, similar to those adopted for books, tobacco products, drugs and other articles, were urged upon grocery manufacturers last night by the Five Borough Retail Merchants Association, Inc., in a resolution adopted at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Miss Nancy Gilmour, only child of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Gilmour of 116 East Sixty-eighth Street, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital, in her nineteenth year, after a fortnight's illness. She was to have been introduced to society last Friday at a tea dance at Sherry's. The invitations were recalled on Nov. 18.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Dorothy Parker McCarter of this city and New Brunswick, N. J., to Louis C. Madeira 3d of New York and Philadelphia, which took place on Sunday in the apartment of the bride at 111 East Fifty-sixth Street.

A semi-monthly newspaper called The Projector will be published by a group of tenants of Williamsburg Houses, Brooklyn, starting Dec. 15. according to an announcement yesterday by Hyman Rothman. chairman of a committee in charge of the publication. The committee has thirty-five members working from 7 to 10 o'clock each night.

The will of Howard E. Coffin, who died at Sea Island Nov. 21 from a rifle bullet wound in the head, was filed here today. Alfred W. Jones, a cousin, was named executor of the estate and to the widow, Mrs. Gladys Baker Coffin,

Mickey Farber, 134% pounds, East Side, gained the decision over Johnny Cabello, 130, Puerto Rico, in the feature eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 3,000 witnessed the card.

Two youths, who admitted, according to the police, having stolen more than fifty automobiles, were arrested yesterday on charges of automobile homicide and grand larceny after a stolen car they were driving had fatally injured a policeman at Brook Avenue and 146th Street, the Bronx.

Diplomatic sources said today that several high Soviet officials had disappeared from public life recently. Among those reported missing were Jean Joseph Arens, former chief of the Foreign Press Depart. ment and until recently consul general at New York;

Mr. and Mrs. Ellwood Jackson Turner of Edgewold, Media, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Addis Turner, to Robert George Gilfillan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilfillan of Swarthmore.

Although Administration leaders in the executive and legislative branches have been citing this year's bumper crops of cotton and wheat as demonstrating the need for immediate crop control legislation, the measure pending before the House with Administration support would not restrict marketing of those commodities next year.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, with 983 passengers on board from Europe, struck the south side of Pier 90, the North River and West Fiftieth Street, at 9:05 o'clock yesterday morning.
President Roosevelt left here today aboard the yacht Potomac for a fishing cruise of six or seven days off the Florida coast. While Mr. Roose

Three types of prejudice affecting banking have been dis-losed in a study of public opinion about banks and banking which has been made by the American Bankers Association, Gurden Edwards, director of the association's research council, told yesterday a meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers, held at the Lawyers Club.

Nicholas (Nick) Montana's sentence on his recent guilty plea to the misdemeanor charge of accepting the proceeds of prostitution was postponed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Nott until next Monday.

Manufacturers' sales during October showed a gain of slightly more than 3 per cent over October, 1936, while the dollar volume of wholesale trade declined 4 per cent in October, compared with the corresponding month a year ago, according to a joint report made public today by the National Association of Credit Men and the Department of Commerce.

Great Britain today denied the right of the Spanish Insurgents to blockade Spain or to "attack" any merchant ship in or out of Spanish territorial waters. The British position was defined in representations which British naval authorities at Palma, Majorca, were instructed to make to the chief Insurgent naval commander.

The monopolistic nature and methods of a few of the biggest companies in the country were in large measure responsible for the current recession, Leon Henderson, economic adviser to the WPA, charged last night in an address at a dinner of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers at the McAlpin Hotel.

Although "hand-made" models were shown in New York at the company's showrooms and in other cities during the annual automobile show period, the regular production Ford V-8 cars for 1938 go on display today for the first time in dealers' showrooms throughout the country.

With Mark Shoesmith, reputedly the first sightless sculptor, hewing out a head of his mother in stone, unmindful of the crowds that watched him, the fifteenth annual sale of the New York State Commission for the Blind opened yesterday.

The text of Charles R. Gay's reply to William 0. Douglas follows. I have been asked to comment upon the recent public statement of William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in regard to the regulation of stock exchanges, particularly of the New York Stock Exchange, of which I have long been a member and governor, and, since May, 1935, president.

A contribution of $30,000 to the United Hospital Campaign from the Consolidated Edison Company of New York was announced last night by Clarence Francis, chairman of the commerce and industry committee of the drive.

In a bulletin to members the Lithographers National Association has urged them to put on special efforts to obtain volume, despite the present recession in business. The bulletin pointed out that advertisers cannot stop advertising, even though they may be holding back for the time being on large campaigns and that the practicality of "spot" advertising such as window displays, dealer helps, novelties, circulars, broadsides, posters, etc., be emphasized.

E.B. Orme chairman of Martin's Bank, Ltd., and director of several large companies, died today in Liverpool at the age of 68. Mr. Orme was the former president of the Liverpool Cotton Association and vice president of the World Cotton Conference in Liverpool in 1921.
The Sheffield Farms Company sold to Samuel Zimmet the garage building at the southeast corner of Alabama and Pitkin Avenues, Brooklyn, through Andrew McTigue Sons, brokers.

Mayor Ed Bass and City Attorney Joe W. Anderson testified before a three-judge Federal Court hearing litigation brought by eighteen private utility corporations to invalidate the TVA Act, today, that David E. Lilienthal, director of the TVA, cited a Supreme Court decision holding that a municipality could tax a public service corporation although in competition with it.

The Rev. Moses Neilson, pastor of the Northfield Baptist Church here, known locally as "the marrying parson," died of a heart attack in the parsonage last night while his congregation was waiting for him to conduct services. His age was 68.

Miss Polly Thomson, who has been the "eyes and ears" of Miss Helen Keller, internationally known deaf and blind writer and lecturer, since the death of Mrs. Anne Sullivan Macy, will apply for citizenship papers next Monday morning before Justice James T. Hallinan in Supreme Court, Long Island City.

A district court in this Silesian town today deprived a father and mother of their children because they opposed the National Socialist ideology, taught their children not to give the Hitler salute and were pacifists. Both parents are members of a Christian sect known as International Bible Researchers. They had adopted a number of pacifist ideas of the Quakers and similar sects.
Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, as president of the board of trustees of Notre Dame College on Staten Island, broke ground yesterday for a new building to be erected on the campus.

Operations in the steel industry for the week beginning yesterday are scheduled at 29.6 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This is the lowest rate since the week of Dec. 3, 1934, when operations were at 28.8 per cent of capacity.

The printed version of John Steinbeck's play, "Of Mice and Men," which has opened at the Music Box Theatre, will be published on Dec. 3 by Covici, Friede. It is Mr. Steinbeck's first attempt at playwriting.

A blue-ribbon jury was chosen yesterday at the trial of Max Silverman; his son, Harold, and his sonin-law, Edward Braff, on charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice by aiding the elder Silverman to remain a fugitive while under indictment for conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Samuel Drukman murder case.

The Duke of Windsor announced formally through his solicitors today that he would have nothing to do with any biography of himself. The statement was prompted by published reports that an authorized biography would be written by Compton Mackenzie, one of the stormy petrels of British literature.

Senator Guffey will introduce Vice President Garner and some other Washington officials to Pennsylvania deer hunting on Wednesday. The party will leave Washington by train tomorrow for a one-day expedition into the central part of the State, the exact site still to be determined.

Edouard Elias Kaufer, a portrait painter of Palm Beach, Fla., died yesterday morning of a heart attack in the Park West Hospital, 170 West Seventy-sixth Street. Shortly before he and his family had been en route to Florida by automobile from his apartment at 20 West Eighty-fifth Street and he was stricken at Seventy-eighth Street and Central Park West.

The financial condition of the railroads of the, United States probably is worse today than at any time in their history, J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, testified today before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Benjamin F. Myers, one of the founders of Texas City, shipping man and developer of iron ore properties on the Mesaba range in Minnesota, died yesterday at his home in suburban Chestnut Hill in his seventyfifth year. He was a cousin of President Harding.

The Metropolitan Opera opened its fifty-third season last night with a performance of its best-seller, "Tristan und Isolde." For the second successive year a towering music-drama of Richard Wagner, greatest of all composers for the lyric theatre, was the inaugural opera, and for the second time Wagner virtually stole the show from the audience of audiences that congregated for the most famous of American first nights.
General Erich Ludendorff, German World War commander, is believed to be dying here in a Catholic nursing home. He is being cared for by Catholic Sisters.

The four-story industrial building at 438 East Fifty-ninth Street, facing the Queensboro Bridge, has been leased by William L. Byrnes, Inc., trucking and storage firm, which will use the structure for storage purposes. The lessor is Mary Heyman.

After a pre-parliamentary meeting the United Australia party, which enthusiastically adopted a resolution expressing appreciation of Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons's leadership. Mr. Lyons tendered his resignation today to the Governor General. Lord Gowrie.
New York prepared administrative facilities today for the first slicing of a $100,000,000 unemployment insurance melon planted by the 1935 Legislature.

On motion of John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor, Federal Judge John C. Knox yesterday dismissed an indictment charging violation of the Sherman anti-trust law, against Louis Fishman, a member of Local 2 of the Fur workers Union, one of fifteen individual and corporate defendants.

A bill to amend the Merchant Marine Act as recommended by the Maritime Commission was introduced in the House today by Representative Bland, chairman of the Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee. It would liberalize subsidies, broaden the powers of the commission and more clearly define certain sections of the present law.

Lawrence Million, 18 years old, of 6,809 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty of second-degree manslaughter yesterday when called to trial before Kings County Judge Peter Brancato on an indictment charging first-degree manslaughter. He was remanded to Brooklyn City Prison to await sentence.
Swedish members of the European ferrosilicon cartel have decided to leave the syndicate for an indefinite period, according to a report from Stockholm made public today by the Department of Commerce.

A court test of the plan by which a group of Coney Island residents hope to establish their own bus service, in competition with the Norton Point trolley line, a B. M. T. subsidiary, began yesterday when the driver of one of the two buses was brought into court on a summons charging violation of the Transportation Law.

A five-day celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Metlakatla, on Annette Island, by William Duncan, who emigrated there from Metlakatla, B. C., ended yesterday with the unveiling of a monument to the memory of the pioneers.

An nouncement has been made by Mr and Mrs. Edgar Sergeant of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Tacie Nairn Sergeant, to Briscoe Baldwin Ranson 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Briscoe Baldwin Ranson Jr. of Maplewood.
A presentment is expected to be handed up today by one of the two special rackets grand juries that have examined more than 400 witnesses in the Albert Marinelli case.

Henry Lanz, Professor of Philosophy at Leland Stanford University, Palo Alto, Calif., has been awarded the first prize of 2,000 kronor offered by a group of Scandinavian publishers for the best discussion on whether there can be any objective basis to ethics or morals.

Mayor La Guardia's official plurality over Jeremiah T. Mahoney on Nov. 2 was 453,374 votes, according to the official canvass of the election made public yesterday by S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections.
Henry (The Hawk) Hawk, just out of Alcatraz Federal Prison and facing a life term in the Nebraska State Prison at Lincoln, said today that "The Rock" was a "swell place."

Opposition to putting the Federal Government into the broadcasting business and a plea that the American radio system, "founded on freedom and fairness of the air," be kept wholly impersonal and nonpartisan were voiced today at the second annual conference on educational broadcasting.

Buying of December wheat against sales of the May and liquidation of December corn featured the trading in grain futures on the Board of Trade here today. A large part of the day's business consisted of spreading operations.

Johns Hopkins University's completely deemphasized football team found that playing for fun paid dividends. This season, completing four years of slow reorganization of its athletic policies, the university did not send its football team out for either gate receipts or guarantees, won four of six games, drew the largest crowds in five years and came out heads up financially.

Defense counsel's charges that Colonel Francois de la Rocque and his French Social party had "delivered" the Cagoulard ["hooded ones"] suspects, Duke Joseph Pozzo di Borgo and General Edouard-Arthur Duseigneur,

Efforts to mediate the strike of 350 gravediggers and other employes at the Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn failed yesterday as Mayor La Guardia threatened to declare. an emergency under the Sanitary Code and provide city employes to bury the growing number of bodies placed in temporary reserve vaults at the cemetery.
At about 3:30 this afternoon a Jewish bus on the Haifa-Safed service was attacked by a band of Arabs near the Arab village of Faradieh. Three Jews were wounded by the rain of bullets.

Mille. Suzanne Deutsch de la Meurthe died here this morning of a heart ailment. Her age was 45. Continuing the tradition of her late father, the wealthy iron master, Henry Deutsch de la Meurthe, who founded a number of dirigible and aviation prizes in the infancy of flying, she became the leading benefactress of French civil aviation.

The Italo-German-Japanese anti-Communist pact bore its first visible fruit today when the Italian Government formally recognized Manchukuo as an independent State and proclaimed its intention of establishing a legation at Hsinking.

The Securities and Exchange Commission .has issued orders as a result of which the West Texas Gas Company, a subsidiary of the Southwestern Development Company, will be permitted to distribute as dividends to the parent company, owner of all of its common stock and. bonds, profits for the present year estimated at approximately $315,000.

The six-day bicycle race moved into its second twenty-four-hour session at Madison Square Garden last night. The sturdy riders, still comparatively fresh, continued their circular grind, to the satisfaction of an enthusiastic gathering of 8,000 fans.

Samuel E. Vail, widely known book manufacturer, died today at his home here after an illness of several months. His age was 74. Mr. Vail was the senior member of the Vail-Ballou Press, which has turned out-work for scores of publishine companies.

Two decisions by Supreme Court Justice John H. McCooey of Brooklyn in the controversy between the waiters and the management of Joe's Restaurant, 8 Nevine Street, Brooklyn, were reversed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn.

Jacques A. L. Raffray, former husband of Mary H. Kirk, school friend of the Duchess of Windsor and now herself Mrs. Ernest Aldrich Simpson, yesterday obtained a license to marry Mrs. Constance E. De Bower.

Calumet Dick, winner of the Thanksgiving Handicap here in handsome fashion and before that the conqueror of Seabiscuit in the Narragansett Special, is ?kely to rule a strong choice in the $7,500 added Bryan and O'Hara Memorial Handicap that will mark the close of the Eastern racing season tomorrow.

The Research Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission has compiled extensive data concerning the registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933 and underwriting activities which will be available soon.

Racing Secretary Charles J. McLennan of Hialeah Park today released a list of seventy-eight nominations, including the Kentucky Derby winner, War Admiral, for the $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup Handicap on March 5.

The National Hockey League scoring race has developed into a family affair among members of the Toronto Maple Leafs. Conny Smythe's Snipers have all the individual honors and most of the second and third places, too.

Authority was granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission to the Oregon Electric Railway Company to extend the maturity date of $1,951,000 of first-mortgage twenty-five-year gold bonds from May 1, 1933, to May 1, 1958, bearing interest from May 1, 1937, to the new maturity date of 3 per cent.
John Fairchild McKelvey, who was associated with the Pearl Assurance Company, Chicago, died there last Wednesday, according to word received here. Mr. McKelvey was 26 years old.

Thomas R. Mountain, '39, of East Orange, N. J., brilliant 165-pound halfback, today was elected captain of the Princeton University 1938 football forces at the "picture" meeting of the past season's letter men.

Silks and rayons valued at $15,000 and the truck and trailer in which they had been left outside of the New York office of the Brook Transportation Company of Richmond, Va., at 12 White Street, near Sixth Avenue, was stolen yesterday morning in the absence of the diriver and his helper.
The AngloFrench diplomatic conversations in London appear on the surface to provoke neither curiosity nor suspicion in German official quarters.

While ill in bed Miss Dorothea (Dolly) Madison, 36-year-old Republican leader of this section, was arraigned this afternoon before Mayor Arthur K. Hillpot, acting as recorder, on a warrant charging her with having obtained money under false pretenses. She was held in $3,000 bail for action of the Middlesex County grand jury.
The City A. C. took undisputed possession of first place in the Class B competition of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League yesterday by downing the Columbia Club, 3 to 2, on the losers' courts.

Leaders in social, diplomatic, artistic and civic circles assembled last night in the vast auditorium of the Metropolitan Opera House for the premiere performance of the fifty-third season of Metropolitan Opera.

The National Maritime Union, ally of the C. I. O. was declared the winner of the National Labor Relations Board election on two more ship lines yesterday, bringing its victories to eleven since the Federal board started its industrywide action to determine the agency preferred by the unlicensed personnel of Atlantic lines as spokesman on labor matters.
Commodity futures were mostly lower on the local exchanges yesterday. A feature was a further decline in coffee futures, which sent all positions except the spot month to new low levels.

Mr. and Mrs. Hendrick Vanderbilt Duryea entertained with a dinner last night at the Madison for Mr. and Mrs. Stoddard Hoffman, Mr. and Mrs. Arnall P. Hodges, Mrs. Skinker Matthews, Mrs. Davidson Johnstone, Miss Ruth M. Belsterling, Miss Margaret Widdemer, Charles S. Inman, John L'Escuyer and David Orr.
It has been many years since the Metropolitan Opera had such a brilliant opening as that of last night, with Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," and Flagstad and Melchior in the title roles.
Steel-helmeted police, reinforced by troops, tonight brought a measure of peace to Cairo, which had been torn by riots since last night's attempt on the life of Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha.

William S. Murray of Utica, chairman of the Republican State Committee, came here yesterday for a week of conferences on party affairs. Mr. Murray said he was not prepared to say when the Republican State Committee would meet to elect a secretary to fill the vacancy
The world zinc production in October amounted to 162,322 tons, compared with 151,357 in September and 145,123 in October, last year, according to the American Bureau of Metals statistics.

The New York Telephone Company won the first round yesterday in its test case to have city-assessed valuations on some of its operating properties in Queens declared excessive by $11,657,718 w? Supreme Court Justice Peter M. Daly upheld the company's right to appeal the valuation on a writ of certiorari.

Two waitresses who stirred up "a little fun" by turning in a false alarm of fire at Avenue B and Sixteenth Street at 4 o'clock yesterday morning were found guilty of disorderly conduct by Magistrate Leonard McGee in Yorkville Court.

President Roosevelt stepped forward today with his first major stroke for ending the business recession and putting the country on a new road to prosperity-a private housing drive through which he contemplates that $12,000,000,000 to $16000,000,000 will be expended In the next five years.

In one of the most sweeping reorganizations in the history of the Police Department, Commissioner Valentine served notice yesterday morning on sixty-six members of the force who will be more than 64 years old by the end of the year that they must retire from duty not later than noon Dec. 13.

An invading five-man team of :rie, Pa., amateur fighters, dropped three bouts to Rochester boys tonight. Tilly Bellucci won a verdict from Johnny Junda, Ossie Sussman scored a fourth-round technical knockout against Joe Wojecki and Carl Erne stopped Pete Wornecki in the second round for the home team.
A demand has been made on Japan that the United States be consulted when any questions pertaining to the customs organization and arrangements in China are taken up by the Tokyo authorities.

Edward B. Margolies, Deputy Assistant District Attorney, decided yesterday not to wait for the general exodus of District Attorney William C. Dodge and his staff when Thomas E. Dewey takes office. He handed in his resignation to Mr. Dodge, to become effective today.

Mayor La Guardia's plan to abate traffic congestion by providing additional parking facilities off the streets met with strong approval yesterday by organizations concerned with the use and sale of automobiles.

And down the other side of dream and up this side of heaven, I smelled a hoarse and hilly stream and grass that grew uneven. And up the farther side of hill and down into the hollow, I heard the small gray whippoorwill flick feather toward his fellow.

Those who found in the opening performance of the opera last night an irresistible attraction, but who were unable or unwilling to pay more than $2 to get in, evidenced their interest in a variety of ways.

Greyhound Bus line officials ordered their striking drivers tonight to report for work at noon Wednesday or consider themselves "as having resigned." The "deadline" was set in letters sent to striking drivers of nine Greyhound lines a short time after T. J. McGrath, counsel for the drivers, had reported that "prospects for settlement are getting brighter."
Under the auspices of William and Harry Brandt, motion picture theatre operators, a comeback for vaudeville is tentatively in the offing.

John J. Lussier, proprietor of the Hotel Bridgway since last February and previously in the hotel and restaurant business in New York and Brooklyn for many years, died in his apartment in the Bridgway today. His age was 69. He was born in Brooklyn, the son of Francis Xavier and Sarah Reynolds Lussier.

A hospital attendant reported tonight that Eddie Jankowski, Green Bay Packer football player, was "getting along pretty well." X-ray exminations will be taken tomorrow to determine whether his skull was fractured when he was tackled in yesterday's game with the Washington Redskins.

The International Rubber Regulation Committee, representing producers of 99 per cent of the world supply, prepared tonight to fix the basic production quota for the first quarter of 1938. Its decision will be made tomorrow.

Without mentioning specific dates or without making definite promises, House leaders today indicated that revision of the undistributed profits tax and certain other features of the Revenue Act of 1936 would be accomplished early enough in the regular session of Congress to affect the first payments on March 15 of taxes for the calendar year 1937.

The current issues of Treasury bills, maturing around March 15 will be continued to Dec. 15, which means the last issue will be sold on Dec. 13, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference this afternoon.

Identical bills to carry out President Roosevelt's recommendations for the machinery to enable public and private interests to push forward a nation-wide housing program were introduced in both houses of Congress today.

Prince Bernhard, consort of Crown Princess Juliana, was injured here today in an automobile crash. The fact that both Queen Wilhelmina and Princess Juliana asked that apartments be prepared for them at the Burges Hospital, in Amsterdam, where he is being treated, was first considered an indication that his condition was very serious.

Many public utilities, electric light plants and waterworks throughout Nicaragua are being purchased by municipalities because of the failure of private enterprises to enlarge their plants to meet the demands of the public.

Willie Hoppe and Jake Schaefer, two of the country's outstanding cue artists, introduced the French game of 71.2 balkline billiards to the United States yesterday at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. Schaefer captured the first two blocks, the matinee session by 250 to 245 in nine innings and the night test by 250 to 173 in nineteen.

James F. McLean, City Cashier of Yonkers for five years until last June, died here today at his home, 156 Ashburton Avenue, in his fortyfirst year. Formerly for fifteen years he operated the St. Joseph's Motion Picture Theatre here. He belonged to the Elks and Knights of Columbus.

A net balance of merchandise exports of $108,745,000 in October was sufficient to change the foreign trade position of the United States from a $50,000,000 net balance of merchandise imports for the first nine months of the year to a net export balance of $60,443,000 for the first ten months,- according to preliminary figures made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Stock Exchange firm of H. T. Carey, Joost Patrick has been formed with offices at 50 Broadway and branches at Troy and Middietown, New York. The firm, which will conduct a strictly commission business, is a consolidation of H. T. Carey Co. and Joost, Patrick Co.

The Food Administration issued today two instructions rationing the consumtion of butter and other fats "to avoid every unnecessary consumption and generally reduce the present excessive consumption to about pre-war levels."

Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday sentenced Victor A. Chiofalo, 28 years old, of 65 Third Place, Brooklyn, to two and onehalf to five years in Sing Sing for the theft of $10,347 in the last two years from the legal department of the city relief headquarters at 20 East Twenty-first Street, where he was employed as a clerk.

Mrs. Kathleen Barbeau Williams, daughter of Mrs. Alexis Cartier Barbeau of Silver Creek, N. Y., was married here this afternoon in the village chapel to Alfred Peyton Jenkins, son of the late Luther H. Jenkins and Mrs. Jenkins of Richmond, Va., and Southern Pines.

The rise above 8 cents at the end of last week brought out more selling on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices were set back 11 to 14 points. Following recent active covering operations, the market disclosed a change in technical conditions which caused an easier tone from the start.

Mrs. Marta Stockton Dayton, widow of William Lewis Dayton, former United States Minister to The Hague and former judge of the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals, died on Sunday in her apartment at the Hotel Barclay, 111 East Forty-eighth Street, after an illness of two weeks. She was 83 years old.

W. E. (Billy) Coyle, New York State champion, and- Walter Kinsella, the veteran professional, gained the semi-final round of the Heights Casino pro-amateur squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday.

NEWS of the Rose Bowl bid was being awaited with bated breath around town yesterday afternoon. Would Fordham get it? Or Pitt? Or Dartmouth? Or Alabama? Somebody said Villanova was as strong as any of them.

The Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland,with other coinsurers, has executed a bond of $1,200,000 for Siems-Helmers, Inc.; Johnson, Drake Piper, Inc., and the Leo Butler Bros. Company covering a contract for the construction of part of the Delaware Aqueduct Tunnel for the Board of Water Supply.

With practically all the returns in, Byron (Whizzer) White, Colorado University's great all-round back, is kingpin of the point getters for the 1937 football season, according to The Associated Press.
Columbia will move into Winter sports along five fronts, with basketball, track, swimming, fencing and wrestling sharing the spotlight for the next four months.

Nine children of all ages, from 2 years old upward, were taken by their parents, relief recipients, to a sit-down strike of thirty-seven men and thirty women yesterday in the offices of the city Department of Public Welfare on the fifth floor of 376 Lafayette Street, a business building. They remained there through last night.

The Men's Clothing Manufacturers Trade Bureau, Inc., comprising most of the New York clothing manufacturers who sell to the New York trade, launched a drive last night to extend its membership and its program for uniform fair trade practices nationally.

Angry practitioners of the art of pulling rabbits from silk hats took determined legal action on two fronts yesterday against the ancient menace that has plagued their art from time immemorial-the telling of "how it is done."

Charles Levine, whose star of destiny began to fade after his flight as the first transatlantic airplane passenger, was a defendant again yesterday, this time charged in West Side Court before Magistrate Edgar Bomberger with violation of Section 925 of the penal laws, dealing with avoiding a hotel bill.

Counsel for a group of bondholders of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company told the Federal court today that the company's re organization was impossible under the "remote control" of large banking firms, and asked- for the appointment of an "independent" trustee.

The retirement of George A. Lobb, who drove New York City elevated trains a distance equivalent to four round trips from the earth to the moon, was announced yesterday by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

The touch-football game between New York debutantes and Princeton undergraduates, which had been scheduled to be held in Central Park next Sunday, was called off yesterday because Princeton would not permit students to take part.

Henry Stanley Ward, assistant clerk of the Supreme Court, New York County, and president of the Clerks Association of the Supreme Court, New York County, died yesterday at his home, 2,956 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx. He was 57 years old.
Whatever its drawbacks, Manhattan's impending late-season battle against Tulsa down in Oklahoma on Saturday has certain advantages.

Mayor La Guardia's demand for a reduction of at least 15 per cent in the rates of the Staten Island Edison Company, which was made last September, has been consolidated by the Public Service Commission with its inquiry into theaccounting methods of the company, it was disclosed at a commission hearing yesterday.
The Executive of the Republic may exercise the functions of his office in any part of the country, according to a decree signed by General Alberto Enriquez, Provisional President.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag declared yesterday that there was no impropriety or inconsistency involved in the retention by William Fellowes; Morgan Jr. of his position as president of the Brooklyn Bridge Freezing and Cold Storage Company while serving as Commissioner of Public Markets, Weights and Measures.

Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, refused yesterday to dismiss extradition proceedings brought by the Cuban Government in 1934 against General Gerardo Machado, its deposed President, on charges of murder and embezzlement. No representative of Cuba attended the hearing.

The threatened C. I. O. mass invasion of Jersey City in defiance of Mayor Frank Hague started yesterday with a series of encounters between details of policemen and a handful of union sympathizers who, before the day was done, had either been arrested or driven out by the police.

Discontinuance of the Medical Research be Bureau, established last Summer by the United Automobile Workers of America, seemed imminent today as part of a retrenchment program necessitated by curtailed employment in the automotive industry.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell lunched on corn pudding and chicken today with homesteaders from the coal mines.

Having noted an increased interest in topical subjects, Paramount today added a fifth to the series the studio is making on headline subjects. "Queen's Local," by Albert Duffy and Marlan Grant, a story of cafe racketeering, is the latest.
Japanese munition and supply trains having again overtaken the rapidly advancing infantry, the Japanese army scored more smashing successes yesterday.

At a special meeting of the member clubs of the American Professional Football Association at the Hotel New Yorker last night the organization upheld the action of its board of directors in disallowing a protest in connection ith the game between the Paterson Panthers and the Newark Tornadoes on Nov. 21.

Mrs. Sarah E. Gill of East Orange, president of the Orange and Domestic Laundry Company here, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital after in operation. Her age was 69. Mrs. Gill took over the laundry twentyfive years ago upon the death of her husband, Edward F. Gill, who rounded the business.

The Beechcraft airplane that was flown in the Bendix Trophy race from Los Angeles to Cleveland last September, overturned early this evening while landing here at the end of a test flight. The pilot, James H. Drummond, escaped with slight bruises.

Pitt's football Panthers turned thumbs down today on participation in postseason games, including those in the Rose, Sugar and Cotton Bowls. The decision was made at a secret and reportedly stormy meeting called by Athletic Director James Hagan to sound on the opinion of the players.

The trial which began at Ponce on Sept. 13 of eleven Nationalists charged with the murder of Policeman Loyola last Palm Sunday, when twenty-one were killed and 100 injured in a clash between Nationalists and police, today gave signs of breaking up because of the illness of the jurors.

Nathaniel D. Chapin, president and founder of the Billings-Chapin Company, manufacturers of paints and varnishes here since 1897, died today of a heart attack as he was returning to his home from his office. His age was 76.

Sales of copper abroad were made late yesterday at 10 to 10.05 cents a pound, c. i. f. European base ports. Earlier, however, a few sales were made at 10.35 cents, approximately the high level of Monday.
