Directors of corporations were more conservative in declaring dividends in November than a year ago. A total of $713,805,827 was voted by 1,113 companies, compared to $304,634,647 for 888 companies in October and $883,202,332 for 1,127 corporations in November, 1936.

Charging violations of the Sherman and Clayton anti-trust acts, the Quemos Theatre Company, former operator of the Mosque Theatre in Newark, filed suit today for $3,525,000 in Federal court here against fortytwo motion picture companies and individuals, representing the major part of the motion picture industry.

Eddie Brink, 141, Scranton, showed his usual courage throughout the eight rounds he fought with Johnny Bellus, 135, of New Haven, in the main contest at the Coliseum last night before 12,500 spectators, but courage was not enough. The better boxing ability of Bellus kept him well ahead of his opponent throughout the contest and won him-the decision.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in November was the smallest since August and the slowest for November since 1934. The largest day's business was 1,923,650 shares on Nov. 10 and the smallest, 758,570 on Nov. 17.

James O. McKinsey, chairman and senior executive officer of Marshall Field Co., died tonight at the Woodlawn Hospital after a brief illness. He was 48 years old. Mr. McKinsey entered the hospital on Nov. 20 after suffering several days from a deep-seated cold.

In an attempt to remove "existing irritations" from the municipal college system, the Board of Higher Education has selected from its members a committee of five who are to undertake an investigation of all the city colleges, it was disclosed yesterday.

William J. Dwyer, president of Franklin Society, announced yesterday that 8,000 checks totaling $465,000, including dividends, were being mailed to members of the institution's Christmas club. The number of accounts was 10 per cent larger than last year.
Appointment of Dr. John H. Travis, 48, as superintendent of Willard State Hospital, effective Jan. 1, was announced today by Dr. William J. Tiffany, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.

Definite improvement was reported today in the condition of Prince Bernhard, Crown Princess Juliana's consort, who is being treated for concussion of the brain after an automobile accident yesterday. Queen Wilhelmina and Princess Juliana stayed at the hospital here last night, and they will remain in residence at the hospital until further notice.

Diplomatic sources said today that they understood Japanese officials had decided to return an American - owned steam launch seized by Japanese yesterday. United States Consulate officials confirmed Japanese assertions that Japanese sailors had not thrown the United States flag into the Whangpoo River when they took over the vessel.

Due to the holiday last week, visiting buyers registered in the market were considerably less than in the preceding week. The total was also well below the corresponding week last year, according to the listings in The Times.

Office employes of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation will be placed on a "share the work" program, beginning today. The schedule provides for the elimination of all Saturday work and the reduction of the weekly payroll by a corresponding amount, approximately 9 per cent.

Aaron Bezedesky and Jacob Firstenberg, American citizens engaged in business in Antwerp, pleaded guilty here yesterday in Federal Court to an indictment charging them and others with conspiracy to smuggle diamonds into the United States.

Yielding to pressure for price concessions, manufacturers at the shoe showing sponsored by the Volume Shoe Manufacturers Association of America at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday booked appreciably more business than on the previous day.

A banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers won yesterday the award of $10,200,000 of electric plant revenue bonds of the Department of Water and Power of the city of Los Angeles on a bid of 100.048, which represented an interest cost basis of 3.6335 per cent.
Appointment of Dr. Walter H. Durfee, head of the Department of Mathematics at Hobart College, as dean of the college was announced today by President William A. Eddy.

A memorandum by Health Commissioner Rice, describing the progress made in sanitation and the prevention of disease in the city in the last four decades, was made public yesterday by the Merchants Association as part of its program in celebration of its fortieth anniversary.
St. Peter's of Jersey City remained undefeated by topping Cathedral College of the Bronx, 34-31, in a basketball game on the losers' court last night.

More orderly grain markets could be maintained in years of small crops if a ten-day period were established between the delivery date and the end of trading in expiring futures contracts, government experts asserted today before a Department of Agriculture hearing at the Chicago Board of Trade.

League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Will Victory in China Wreck Japan?" Charles C. Batchelder. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Nineteenth Century American Landscape Painting," Alfred Busselle Jr., 11 A. M.; "Rugs for the Modern Home," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M. and 3 P. M.; American Wing (general tour), 2 P. M.; "Medieval Minstrels and Romance," Margaret B. Freeman, 4 P. M.

Ruth Etting, a singer, won an uncontested Circuit Court divorce today from Martin Snyder of New York. She said she would take a world tour on a tramp steamer with her stepdaughter, Edith Snyder, 19, and retire after the trip to her family farm near David City, Neb. Miss Etting testified Mr. Snyder had a "violent temper" and that last August, in the presence of guests, he struck a cane against her legs.

A committee of friends and admirers of the late Elinor Wylie is planning to establish an Elinor Wylie Poetry Fellowship to assist "American men and women whose published work indicates poetic ability of a high order." The committee, .of which Carl van Doren is chairman, is seeking an endowment of $100,000 to make possible an annual award of $5,000.

Lawrence Beck, 53-year-old retired policeman, of 115-26 Myrtle Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, was convicted last night by a jury in the Queens County Court, Long Island City, of murder in the second degree for the slaying of his brother-in-law, Patrolman William Bosshart, 41, in the cellar of the Bosshart home at 88-56 207th Street, Bellaire, Queens, on the morning of Oct. 9, 1936.
Busy K, who could have been claimed for $2,500 last September at Aqueduct, today conquered the cream of Maryland's handicap horses as the Eastern racing season on major courses closed at Bowie.

Sugar cane farmers presented a proposal today for fair compensation for sugar from central mills at a hearing held by Dr. Jossua Bernhardt, chief of the sugar section, called to seek information on which the Secretary of Agriculture may fix such compensation.
C. Albert Wheeler, vice president of the Western Savings Fund Society of Philadelphia, died today at his home in Jenkintown after several months' illness. He was 54 years old.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Certain-teed Products Corporation has been called for Dec. 17 to vote on a proposal to give the preference stockholders the right to elect one-third of the directors after dividends on that issue are in default for six quarterly payments.

The New York Stock Exchange will admit to listing today American share certificates for $10-par capital stock of the Patino Mines and Enterprises, Consolidated, Inc., and will suspend from dealings American share certificates without par value.

Charles R. Stevenson of Stevenson, Jordan Harrison was elected president of the Association of Consulting Management Engineers at its annual meeting yesterday at the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street.

Members of the Securities and Exchange Commission would make no comment today upon the statement issued yesterday by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange. It is understood that they will await developments in the next few weeks before taking any further steps in the direction of imposing stricter governmental control over the Exchange.

It took a long time, but now we know. The new City Council will have its fourteen regularly nominated Democrats, five Labor members, three Republicans, three Fusionists and one Independent Democrat. In case of a tie the deciding vote will be cast, under the provisions of the new charter, by the President of the Council--Newbold Morris, an anti-Tammany official. P. R.

The exhibition of portraits of children at the Arden Gallery, 460 Park Avenue, held for the benefit of the Greenwich House Music School, has been arranged with great care. There is nothing perfunctory about it. The roster of painters and sculptors contains some very distinguished names and in many instances the artists are represented at the top of their form.
R. H. Reilly Jr. is with Burton, Cluett Dana in Philadelphia. Edward G. Wyckoff Co. of Philadelphia have established an institutional investment department under the supervision of Howard J. Laurent.
The police have decided to do something for supperless husbands. They will ban bunco, a game played with dice for silk comforters,

Three Londoners were accused in Bow Street Police Court today of a conspiracy with other persons, unknown, to "defraud such persons as might part with money to Heilbut-Symons Co., Ltd., of London in connection with financing businesses in foreign countries."

The large tract of land on the south side of Leggett Avenue, near the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad tracks, which formerly was owned and occupied by Church E. Gates Co., lumber dealers, was sold at auction yesterday in the Bronx salesrooms, 3,208 Third Avenue.

The Labor minority in the House of Commons won a point today when Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, in response to their objection, changed three of the four members of the committee originally named to investigate labor conditions in the Imperial Airways, Ltd.
The ninth annual dinner dance of the Marine Manor Property Owners Association of Brooklyn will be held at the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island, on Saturday evening.

Mrs. Isabel Walthall, actress and former wife of the late Henry B Walthall, famed for his role in the motion picture "Birth of a Nation," died yesterday at Hackensack Hospital after a long illness. She was 64 years old.
Nanking, preparing to meet the advancing Japanese Army, saw a grim display of fireworks today when an ammunition dump blew up about twenty miles to the east of the city.
Turkish, Armenian and Arabian dignitaries of Alexandretta asked the League of Nations today to remove the French flag until the new autonomous State could choose a flag of her own.

Leaders in the medical profession in this country and Cuba favor the extension of "the good-neighbor policy" in the field of medicine in Central and South American countries, it was declared yesterday at a conference of officers and directors of the Pan-American Medical Association held in the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The vestry of the Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie has several men under consideration as successor to the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, who retired yesterday as rector, according to Boyd Langdon Bailey, junior warden.

Laxity in the enforcement of existing criminal laws, rather than inadequate legislation, was blamed today for increasing crime in New York State, District Attorney John T. Delaney of Albany County declared at a legislative hearing.

American jazz was what we -heard in the trenches at University City tonight--a snappy foxtrot, a tango and "Kitten on Keys." All were played much too fast, but anyway nobody could dance standing ankle-deep in mud with bullets whining overhead and crashes of trench mortars on both sides.

A decidedly better undertone was shown yesterday in almost all sections of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. The improvement took place in a somewhat more active trading pace, with the best gains shown among the secondary and more speculative issues. Underlying loans, meanwhile, maintained a steady to firm undertone.

The adoption by the Laborite Social Mass party leaders of a Nazi platform has not increased the party's popularity with the electors. In the Tokyo municipal elections, just concluded, the Social Mass party elected only ten of its forty-two candidates.

For the second day in a row an odds-on favorite, lost in the Fair Grounds feature when Chance Ray was beaten in the Bay St. Louis Claiming Handicap today. The five-year-old son of Chance Play and Ex Ray closed at 9 to 10, but could do no better than third after having the lead in the stretch.
Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that there had been no recent negotiations with the United States for a debt settlement.

Executives of the Transamerican Freight Lines, Inc., a motor trucking company with headquarters in Detroit, announced yesterday that the company had closed its New York terminal at 447 West Seventeenth Street, throwing sixty-six employes out of work, and had abandoned plans for a large, new terminal because of labor trouble.

Mr. and Mrs. James Wilmot of Port Chester, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Louise Wilmot, to Curtis Ronald Andrews; son of Henry F. Andrews of Norwich, Conn., and the late Mrs. Andrews.

Mayor La Guardia and Governor Lehman moved yesterday for a special session of the Legislature this month to adopt the city's new administrative code prior to Jan. 1, when the new City Charter becomes effective.

State Senator Lester H. Clee, Republican candidate for Governor, who was defeated by United States Senator A. Harry Moore by a plurality of 45,226, challenged the election today and requested a Supreme Court investigation of the balloting in Hudson County.

The Merchant Tailors Society of the City of New York will hold its annual dinner tomorrow night at the Commodore Hotel. Officers for the coming year will be nominated. James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for Eckstein Richman, New York, distributors of silks and rayons.

Sir Stanley Johnson, former Member of Parliament and a noted figure in the civic life of London, died today two hours after having been found in his bedroom with a bullet wound in his head. He was 68. Pending an inquest, his death was publicly attributed to the accidental discharge of the revolver that was found near his body.

The strike of gravediggers and other employes at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn was settled yesterday. The strikers will return to work this morning, pending probable appointment of a fact-finding committee by Mayor La Guardia to study conditions at the cemetery and recommend possible changes.
Eight Manhattan properties, ineluding seven apartment houses, were sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The list follows:

The Intercoastal Freight Shipping Association defended yesterday a proposed revision of charges for segregation of freight arriving at the Atlantic terminals of its member lines. The defense was made at a hearing before John Russell, examiner of the Maritime Commission, at the Federal Building, 45 Broadway.

Japan wants to buy Nicaragua's entire cacao crop. The price has increased 3 cents a pound. Germany is willing to take all the cotton, hemp and coffee raised in Nicaragua, giving German products in barter. However, there will be allotted to her only a portion of Nicaragua's coffee crop, as she cannot furnish oils, gasoline, flour and steel products.
War Admiral, champion 3-year-old of 1937, will not race in the forthcoming $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap Trainer George Conway announced today.
Hoffman Philip, United States Ambassador to Chile, and Mrs. Philip, who arrived here recently, are at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Oliver G. Jennings is at 720 Park Avenue for the Winter.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, fugitive described as Public Enemy No. 1, was accused in a Federal indictment yesterday of having recently helped to finance round-the-world "tours" for several young women who were among twenty persons rounded up as international traffickers in narcotics.

President Roosevelt was off the Dry Tortugas today and sent some of his party to see Fort Jefferson, where Dr. Samuel Mudd spent four years in army prison for giving aid to John Wilkes Booth, who had broken his leg jumping from Lincoln's box in the Ford Theatre in Washington after fatally shooting the Civil War President.

New York State's Conservation Department announced today that twentyseven hunters had been killed and ninety-four others wounded or injured thus far in the 1937 hunting season, mainly because of "carelessness and inexperience in handling guns."
Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, said in a formal statement today: "The international union is determined to end, once and for all, unauthorized strikes."

The York Railways Company, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Company system, filed yesterday a voluntary petition for reorganization under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act in the Federal court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

Hearings began today before the House Banking and Currency Committee on the Steagall Housing Bill. The Senate Committee on Banking and Currency will start hearings tomorrow on an identical bill offered by Senator Wagner.
A gift of $25,000 to the United Hospital Fund, from an anonymous donor, was announced yesterday by Miss Louise Iselin, chairman of the women's committee for the campaign.

Japan's war expenditure is believed here to be surprisingly light despite the extent and intensity of the operations. The current issue of the Oriental Economist, Tokyo publication, points out that only 500,000,000 yen worth of bonds has been issued out of the 2,400,000,000 yen authorized at a special session of the Diet last August. The last bond issue was made on Nov. 16.

After a minute scientific examination that lasted nine years and proved the value of scientific study in protecting collectors and museums against fraud, the Boston Museum of Fine Arts has returned to exhibition an Italian Renaissance tomb which gained international notice in 1928 when it was thought unquestionably to be a fraud.

Frank Vivian Whiting, 70 years old, who passed a bar examination and in 1912 was admitted to practice before the United States Supreme Court though he had attended only a half term at high school, retired yesterday from the New York Central System after fifty-three years of railroad service.

Today's events: "Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.; Jascha Heifetz, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Walter Gieseking, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Rosalyn Tureck, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.

Emil Ludwig, noted German biographer, last night revealed a recent conversation with President Roosevelt in which the President remarked that he would "hate to be a dictator," because he would be "bored without opposition."

W. P. Lipscomb's "Thank You, Mr. Pepys," originally titled "Ninety Sail," which was presented at the Shaftesbury Theatre tonight, makes no attempt to whitewash the characters of Charles II or Pepys, although it tries to avoid the conventional picture of a Charles who does little else than dally with women, or a Pepys who spends his time gossiping and seeking odd amours.
Ten 1937 national champions in health among 4-H club members-six of them boys--were announced today by the National Committee on Boys' and Girls' Club work among the farm youth.

Twice yesterday Willie Hoppe of New York came from behind to take the measure of Jake Schaefer of Chicago in their twelve-block encounter for the 71.2 balkline championship of the United States at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. In the afternoon Hoppe, aided by a scintillating run of 144, triumphed in thirteen innings, 250249, and at night he scored in nine turns at the table, 250--232.

In celebration of his recent elevation to the rank of Monsignor by Pope Pius XI, the Right Rev. William A. Courtney, pastor of St. Stephen's Church and president of the Board of Child Welfare of New York City, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner and dance at the Hotel Commodore.

Governor General Lord Gowries said in his speech opening Parliament today that Australia welcomed the prospect of cordial understanding between the British Empire and the United States and that Australia would play a part in the conclusion of such an understanding provided the best interests of the Commonwealth were safeguarded.

The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on 5,053,700 yards of WPA cotton textiles. The bids are dated Dec. 3, to be opened on Dec. 13, with detailed information not available until Dec. 6, when the proposals will be in the mails.

The army is, looking for 1,800 volunteers for service in Hawaii, Colonel William H. Patterson, in charge of recruiting headquarters in the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street, announced yesterday. In the enlistment drive, starting today, unmarried American citizens between the ages of 18 and 35,

The month-old strike of 250 employes of stores of Davega City Radio, Inc., was settled yesterday by the signing of an agreement between the company and Local 830 of the Retail Employes Union. According to Bernard Phillips, counsel for the company, the agreement provides for an open shop but recognizes the union as the sole collective bargaining agency.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Derby Stanley of Bar Harbor, Me., of the marriage of their daughter, Miss Wilma Stanley, to Dr. Harold W. Hill of this city. The wedding took place in Durham, N. H., on Nov. 6.

Italy's friendly services at the NinePower Brussels Conference and Mussolini's formal action on Monday in recognizing Manchukuo have been promptly rewarded. On Tuesday a Japanese official spokesman announced that his Government would forthwith recognize Nationalist Spain.
Mr. and Mrs. Dwight L. Burnham of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Burnham, to Alexander M. Fraser of Reading, Pa.

Local police and the microscope men of New York State's "Scotland Yard" are seeking saboteurs who wrecked ten knitting machines Sunday night in the plant of the Hirsam Knit Sportswear Company, one of the concerns that "ran away" from New York City to the openshop Haverstraw Industrial Terminal in Garnerville, near here.

The possibility of a radical change in the rules of indoor polo appeared last night as officials and delegates gathered at the annual meeting of the Indoor Polo Association of America at the Metropolitan Club.

Howard Elliott, vice president of the Materials Delivery Corporation and the Nassau Sand and Gravel Company, died yesterday at his residence, London Terrace, 425 West Twenty-third Street, after a sixmonth illness at the age of 59.

The marriage of Mrs. Miriam Tyler Doty, widow of Alvah Hunt Doty Jr. and daughter of Mrs. Frederick A. Tyler of Albany and the late Mr. Tyler, to Bayard Boyd Webb, son of Mrs. George C. Webb of Fulton, N. Y., and the late Mr. Webb, took place here yesterday noon in the Church of the Ascension.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Morris of 71 Park Avenue and The Trees, Ossining, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Theodora Lyons Morris, to Edwin Colby Walton, son of Herman M. Walton of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Mrs. Walton.

The ancient and picturesque array of fruit and vegetable stands known as "Paddy's Market" is going to stay right where It has been for the last forty-eight years, the Cohens and the Goldbergs and the Tarrones and the Nebbias asserted grimly, but somewhat fearfully yesterday, in the face of an order to move this morning and make way for the new Lincoln Tunnel approach.

THERE was more of that waiting around the phone yesterday, with Graduate Manager Jack Coffey of Fordham playing the part of head waiter. This, of course, was before Alabama was chosen to oppose California in the Rose Bowl game. The more or less innocent bystanders were putting in time giving the football situation a general kicking around about as follows:

Ephraim Johnson, a retired architect, of 183d Street and Third Avenue, the Bronx, died of a heart attack yesterday while walking in front of 447 Tremont Avenue. He was born in Brooklyn seventy-five years ago. Mr. Johnson, who formerly lived at 208 East Thirty-ninth Street, was a widower.
Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Weed of Garden City, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Scott Weed, to Dr. Ralph Frederick Schneider of New York.

Assemblyman Thomas Glynn Walker of Arlington, N. J., Speaker of the 1937 House, was sworn in today as a judge of the Court of Errors and Appeals, a position which automatically makes him a member of the Court of Pardons.

The wind blew, the rain fell, snow turned to slush and the muskeg became a soggy sponge, but Sidney Sparks trailed along behind Alex Price in search of New Brunswick deer. They saw deer, plenty of them, but Sparks didn't want "any old deer." He wanted a big one.
About 300 employes of the Hodson Berg hat plant, a unit of the Hat Corporation of America, went on strike today, charging that a new machine just installed would make

The Countess of Granard, Earl and Countess Beatty, Lord and Lady Digby, Sir William Erskine, The Marquess of Milford Haven and the Count and Countess de Limur are among the passengers booked to sail today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Testing their aerial attack and running game in a short scrimmage at Innisfail Park, Manhattan's football players yesterday concluded preparations for their intersectional game with the University of Tulsa in Tulsa Saturday.

An apartment house on upper Riverside Drive and a large site for a multi-family building in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, where considerable activity has been noted recently, figured in the real estate transactions reported yesterday.

Steel ingot production declined further last week in face of a steady seasonal trend, and the adjusted index slumped to 47.7 from the previous week's 55.4. For the week ended Nov. 28, 1936, the index stood at 117.2.

Attorneys for the Associated Investing Corporation filed today a petition seeking to restrain the Atlas Corporation, an investment company, from dealing in securities of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation without the specific consent of the Federal court.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Nov. 19 at his home in Rome of the Rev. Canon Harry Walstane Guerard de Nancrede, former Canon of Gibraltar. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania in 1872,
District Attorney-elect Thomas E. Dewey's answer to Governor Lehman on the Albert Marinelli case, containing three new charges as well as a reiteration of the earlier attack, was finished last night.
The petition for a 15 per cent advance in freight rates presented by the railways to the Interstate Commerce Commission was on Monday argued simply and forcibly before that body.

Mayor William Sauerbier died tonight of a heart attack at his home. He was 65 years old. Besides being Mayor for the last six years, Mr. Sauerbier was serving as justice of the peace, having been elected for a fourth term last month.
Physicians pronounced Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller "on -the up grade" tonight at a local hospital, where he is under treatment after an acute bronchitis attack.

Edwin Howland Blashfield, who was known as the dean of American mural painters, left a net estate of $1,023,421, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Of the total an interest, valued at $186,037, goes to various charitable institutions.

Mary K. O'Connor tonight was admitted to $5,000 bail on a charge of homicide in the death of Nancy Glenn. Judge L. Stauffer Oliver fixed the amount at a hearing on a habeas corpus petition filed by William A. Gray, counsel for Miss O'Connor.

Mrs. Mary Barber celebrated her 100th birthday here today with a reception for about thirty relatives and friends at the home of her daughter-in-law, Mrs. William Barber of 224 Anderson Street. Mrs. Barber was born in New York City and spent most of her life there.

General farm legislation was threatened on two fronts today as advocates of wages-and-hours legislation promised retaliation unless its discharge petition succeeded, - and two national farm organizations denounced compulsory crop. control features of House and Senate bills.
Mayor La Guardia threatened yesterday to get "damn rough" if the Federal Government delayed much longer in releasing funds for more low-cost housing construction.
State and defense accepted within two hours today eight of the twelve jurors who will decide the fate of 18-year-old Paul Dwyer, charged with murdering Dr. James G. Littlefield.
Three veterans tied at 75 today for the leadership of the first annual seniors' professional golf tournament, an event for club swingers from 50 years up.
Miles Franklin Portlock, vice president of the Old Dominion Tobacco Company, died last night at his home here. He was 61 years old. He also was chairman of the board of directors.

The vibrant rhythms of the jungle mingled with. the more soothing folk dance measures of the Ukraine in an elaborate exhibition of the dances of. many nations in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center yesterday afternoon. About 250 persons, including Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, witnessed the performance.

The Westchester team sprang a surprise by defeating both New York, the defending champion, and New Jersey in Group A team matches of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association on the Ardsley Country Club courts today.

Judge John Rufus Booth ordered Edward C. Plaut, president of the Lehn Fink Drug Company, today to pay temporary alimony of $1,000 a month to his estranged wife, Alexandra Stewart Plankinton Plaut of New York.

SERENADE, by James. M. Cain. (Knopf, $2.50.) A novel by the author of "The Postman Always Rings Twice." THE ABC OF MUNICIPAL BONDS, by Louis S. Lebenthal. (Harper, $1.50.) A statement for investors on the functions and benefits of municipal bonds.

Young Chappie, 132 3/4, Albany, scored a technical knockout victory over Bernie (Schoolboy) Friedkin, 131 1/4, Brownsville, last night in the feature engagement at the Broadway Arena, scheduled for eight rounds. The end came in one minute of the seventh session.

A further amendment to the Multiple Dwelling Law which is destined to have a marked influence on future construction and design of apartment buildings inNew York has been drafted for presentation in the next session of the State Legislature.

Lucien C. Powell Jr. of Forester, Ark., star right end of the Naval Academy eleven, has been named captain for next year, it was announced today by Commander Andrew C. McFall, graduate manager of athletics. The Navy ace played his position through the major part of every game.

Minimum prices at the mine for coal produced in all areas east of the Mississippi River and in Iowa were announced tonight by the Bituminous Coal Commisssion. The territory produces more than 80 per cent of the country's bituminous tonnage.

As a result of the weakness of the dollar in the foreign exchange market and the consequent rise in the price of the metal abroad, gold was shipped to Europe in November for the first time since March, 1936.

Surgeons at Croydon General Hospital ten days ago revived a woman who had "died" on the operating table by massaging her heart through the diaphragm and then gave her a transfusion of three pints of her own blood. to make good what she had lost through internal hemorrhage-and she is on the road to recovery.
A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Ruth Dill Johnson from John Seward Johnson of Brunswick, N. J. She charged cruelty. Custody of their four children was decided by an agreement.

Robert B. Upham, City Controller, is planning the refunding of $10,000,000 and the retirement of $12,000,000 of city bonds which will mature on Jan. 1. The refunding bonds will expire on dates after 1940.

JAMES M. CAIN'S new novel* is an amazing performance, a piece of great story telling. It carried me away as few other books have ever done, from the first page to the. last, and I was willing to break the rush of it only once, and that out of sheer surfeit.
S. Merritt, former president of Merritt Co., metal locker manufactuurers, died yesterday at his home, 212 West Highland Avenue, Chestnut Hill. He was 73.
Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. O'Keefe of South Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Angela Jean O'Keefe, to John W. Piper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Piper, also of South Orange.

The Harlem Uproar House, 209 West Fifty-first Street, one of Broadway's night clubs, failed to open last night. L. T. Farrar, associated with Jay Faggen, the proprietor, said that it was the club's plan to reorganize and that there was a possibility of its reopening on Friday night.
Washington ordered today an investigation of reports that Japan had violated the Chinese Open Door and tariff treaties by reducing duties on many of her products at Tientsin.

Herbert J. De Varco announced last night that he had resigned as counsel to the United Licensed Officers Association because of difficulties within the membership which he attributed to contending ambitions of officials to control the union.

Incensed over a hopeless traffic tie-up in which he was caught while returning to Police Headquarters from a City Hall conference on traffic problems yesterday noon, Police Commissioner Valentine seized the opportunity to do a little traffic directing himself.

Emil W. Hunzinger, retired investment broker, died in the home of his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. William Rowe, Byram Shore, Greenwich, today, after an illness of several months. He was 77 years old.

Negotiations are under way between the Farm Security Administration, the General Homes, Inc., of Chicago, builders of pre-fabricated houses, the Federal Housing Administration and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the erection at Greenbelt, the near-by Maryland Federal low-cost housing project, of about 200 "ready-made" homes.

The program that the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, Antonia Brico conductor, presented last night in Carnegie Hall, advanced as one of its major items a short but very distinctive tone poem of Sibelius, "Okeanides," which is unknown to New York audiences of the present day.

Although many of President Roosevelt's recommendations in his housing message to Congress undoubtedly are sound, some doubt arises as to the soundness of raising the insurable limit of FHA mortgages from 80 per cent of the appraised value to 90 per cent on small dwellings, according to L. Seth Schnitman, consulting construction economist to the International Statistical Bureau, Inc.

Harvard's 1939 football schedule was released by Athletic Directer Bill Bingham today. The Crimson will resume gridiron relations with Penn here on Oct. 21 and the previous Saturday Harvard will go to the Middle West to meet Chicago, which will play at Cambridge next Nov. 5.

On Monday last one-half of the amount sought for the United Hospital Fund was in hand. On Friday of this week the last formal Manhattan report meeting will be held. This leaves but a short time in which to complete the other half.

There will be fourteen members of the new City Council who were elected on the regular Democratic ticket, a majority of two, it was determined yesterday when the final count in the Bronx, twentyeight days after the vote was cast, resulted in the election of Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley as the fifth Councilman for that borough.

Defense Minister Emilio Bello explained today before committees of the Chamber of Deputies the urgency of purchasing material for Chile's armed forces in accordance with plans drawn up after a close study by technical experts.

The Citizens Committee for the Continuation of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad announced tonight that more than 30,000 signatures had been placed on a petition asking the Legislature to create a transit authority to acquire and operate the railroad as a State enterprise.

Mrs. Vincent Astor will give a tea on Dec. 10 at her home, 130 East Eightieth Street, for members of a committee now arranging a dinner and musical to be given on Jan. 2 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Astor is acting president.

Architects filed plans yesterday for three six-story apartment buildings, for erection on the south side of Queens Boulevard between Sixtysixth and Sixty-seventh Avenues, in Forest Hills, at an estimated total cost of $650,000, and for a six-story apartment house on 193d Street, Jamaica, costing $250,000.
Some Hamburg chemical corn panies hope to free for household consumption more than 400,000 eggs annually by the industrial production of albumen from fish for industrial and baking purposes.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in moderate activity on the local Exchanges yesterday. Rubber and hides were higher, but cocoa, tin and coffee futures declined, with the latter recording new low levels in the Santos option.

Stimulated by the recent report of the Maritime Commission indicating its interest in developing transoceanic aircraft service, the American Export Lines announced yesterday that the captains of its eighteen steamships are to be instructed by Dr. James H. Kimball in making special weather observations which will augment a new Atlantic weather survey for aerial travel and shipping. Reports will be sent in by wireless twice a day.

Apartment leases reported by brokers yesterday centered chiefly in buildings on the east side of the midtown section. Among them was one taken by Andrew Anderson on a large unfurnished duplex penthouse at 1,088 Park Avenue.

Taking of direct testimony in the suit of five railroad companies and their subsidiaries to enjoin New Jersey from collecting the full amount of taxes levied for 1934, 1935 and 1936 ended today in the United States District Court here.
In New York for a shopping trip, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, not only finished all her Christmas buying yesterday morning but also purchased all her Winter clothes.

In a basketball battle that required two overtime periods before the issue was settled, the Bishop Loughlin team yesterday defeated the Brooklyn Poly freshmen, 2221, in the winners' gymnasium before a student crowd of 1,000. Bill Graham, substitute Loughlin guard, netted a field goal for the victory.

Announcement has been made to friends in New York by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Withrow MacPherran of Duluth, Minn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth MacPherran, to Frederick Leas Worcester of Zamboanga, P. I., son of Mrs. Dean Conant Worcester of Manila and the late Mr. Worcester.

The six-day bicycle race resolved into a spirited spectacle of mad riding last night as the thirteen teams remaining in the grind fought bitterly for eminence. While a crowd of 13,000 fans looked on in Madison Square Garden the rival riders maintained an almost continuous jam session, whirring around the pine-saucer at breakneck speed and thrilling the spectators time and again with their reckless cycling.

The Pittsburgh University football team was awarded the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, emblematic of leadership among Eastern gridiron teams, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon for the judges at the National Democratic Club. This marked the second straight year that the Panthers were honored with the prize.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday at his Winter home in Overhills, N. C., of Percival Leonard Rosseau, painter of animals, who was well known for his portraits of field dogs. He was born in New Orleans seventyeight years ago.

A flist mortgage loan of $75,000 for ten years at 4 1/2 and 5% has been placed on the six-story apartment house recently completed at 3,310-3,312 Perry Ave. Bronx. Henry Waltemade, Inc, broker, arranged the loan for the N. V. S. Corporation, Nicholas Scarano, president.
The Senate continued debate on the Farm Bill, received President Roosevelt's message on decreased expenditures for highways, and recessed at 4:58'P. M. until 11 A. M. tomorrow.

Only forty-six infant deaths were reported in New York City for the week ended last Saturday, a drop of twenty-four from the previous week, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Mrs. Grace Paine Dakin of Millerton, N. Y., a great-great-grandniece of Thomas Paine, died Monday, aged 70, at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Dorothy Paine Dakin Pine of Upper King Street, Port Chester, N. Y. She was a descendant of Elder William Brewster of the Plymouth colony.
12th St. 703 E, 23.10 1/2x103.3; 703 E 12th St Corp to Samuel Schleimer and Samuel Koplik, 5 Columbus Circle, c/o S. Schleimer.

The stock market here was quiet today. The overnight reaction to yesterday's performance in Wall Street prompted some profit-taking. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, but among the foreign loan Far Eastern bonds were weak. Transatlantic shares held firm and United States Steel and International Nickel improved.

The Japanese Government will recognize the Franco regime in Spain today, and General Francisco Franco will recognize. Manchukuo probably tomorrow, receiving in return Manchukuo's recognition, according to the newspaper Asahi.

Five men armed with clubs were arrested by the Boston police tonight, one person was injured in a crash in South Boston and a bus carrying ten. passengers was stalled by strikers in Wrentham in the second outburst of violence since the strike of drivers of the Greyhound Lines, Inc., began six days ago.

Dr Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris resumed play today in their match for the title, with the latter leading by four points and favored to regain the honors he lost two years ago.

Two men formerly employed as chauffeurs by Max Silverman, alleged labor racketeer who is on trial in Brooklyn Supreme Court for conspiracy to obstruct justice, testified yesterday that at Silverman's direction they had assumed fictitious names under which they received mail intended for Silverman and which often contained large sums of money in $100 notes.

Preliminary plans for a nationwide contest to stimulate interest in home building and renovation, and to be advertised in April issues of magazines, were announced by H. M. Shackelford, vice president,

" Hooray for What!" the musical comedy which is to return Ed Wynn to the living stage, is scheduled to open this evening at the Winter Garden.. It may go on without one of the important members of the cast, though, for Jack Whiting was out of last evening's preview with a cold and his physician thought he would not be present tonight.

Combined total sales of all departments of 572 reporting automobile dealers in the nine months ended Sept. 30 were $201,834,994, compared with $191,348,463 in 1936, an increase of 5.48 per cent, the National Automobile Dealers Association reported today.

Cash dividend payments by the companies of the Standard Oil group for this year are estimated at $273,735,561, the largest for any year with the exception of 1930, when $286,526,728, a high record, was distributed, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co. made public yesterday. This year's distributions are $34,734,934, or about 15 per cent, more than the $239,000,627 disbursed in 1936.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am wondering whether in discussing the question of reduced wages and pricesas a means- of restoring the balance of: our economic machine, "H. S." in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES is not presenting us with a problem in psychology as well as economics.
Thomas J. O'Keefe, a salesman for the American Radiator Company, was driving his automobile along the Henry Hudson Parkway yesterday morning on his way to Bronxville, when men in uniform stopped him.
Arthur Bruggeman, who retired as captain of the Fire Island Lightship in January, died last night at Tucson, Ariz., where he had gone to recuperate from a bronchial ailment.

Three teams of Washington women and a Pittsburgh team held the first positions in a field of thirteen teams as the national women's team-offour championship in contract bridge opened here this afternoon. The best New Yorkers could do was to make fifth position.

With the Giants in their best physical shape in a month Coach Steve Owen began drilling the squad yesterday in preparation for the important encounter with the Redskins at the Polo Ground on Sunday when the Eastern championship and a place in the play-off against the Bears are decided.

Arthur Lawrence, Captain of the 50-foot power yacht Scouter II and his crew of two, all believed to be Americans, were detained today by customs authorities at Arroyo Mantua on the north coast of Pinar Del Rio Province.

Max Sweig of 115 Central Park West, one of the first men to make a successful business of cleaning large hotels, office buildings, theatres, terminals and piers, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 54 years old.

The C. I. O. mass meeting originally scheduled to be held in Jersey City Friday night was postponed yesterday until next Tuesday night as union sympathizers who ran afoul of Mayor Frank Hague's police in a demonstration to advertise it tried to extricate themselves from their legal difficulties.

Net earnings of the Vick Chemical Company and subsidiaries for the three months ended on Sept. 30 were reported yesterday to have been $1,000,784, after providing for taxes, depreciation and other charges but before surtax on undistributed income. They were equivalent to approximately $1.44 a share on the outstanding stock.

Witnesses for the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey completed today their testimony before an examiner for the Federal Power Commission on the company's application for approval of the merger of nine affiliated companies.

District Attorney- Dodge, who started a grand jury inquiry Monday to determine whether justice had been obstructed when The New York Post brought to New.York a witness sought in the vice trial case of Nicholas Montana, said yesterday there would be no indictments.
The tenement house at 1,968 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Anna O'Neil to a client of the Cross Brown Company which negotiated the sale in conjunction with the Standard Realty Company.

Outstanding gains in sales of household electrical refrigerators were registered by manufacturers in October, according to figures released here yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
The Tapay Realty Holding Corp assigned to the Penny Realty Corp a mortgage for $4.500 on 236 W 137th St.

The John Prentiss Poe Cup, the highest honor conferred upon a Princeton University football player, was awarded to Jack H. White, 1938, of Lebanon, Pa., regular varsity halfback for the past three seasons, at the tenth annual football dinner at the Princeton Inn tonight.

Manhattan's varsity basketball team will play a sixteen-game schedule this season, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. Five of the contests are meetings with New York University, Temple, St. Thomas, City College and St. John's in Madison Square Garden. The schedule:

President Albert Lebrun and United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt attended a ceremony today placing an inscription on a house occupied by the American mission of the Rockefeller Foundation, which assisted in organizing the French fight against tuberculosis.

John J. Thompson, an attorney specializing in patent laws, died in his home here Sunday night at the age of 63. He was active in the Sons of the American Revolution and was a graduate of Yale University.

Yesterday's London Times editorial on German-Czech relations has aroused a storm of indignation in two countries that consider themselves virtually abandoned by this newspaper to Adolf Hitler's tender mercies.

Driving ahead with plans to inaugurate a new administration Jan. 2, Mayor La Guardia today sees nonpartisan municipal government here to stay in this city and a realignment of national political parties in the making.

Two properties in New Jersey have been sold by the First National Bank of Union City. One is the six-family dwelling at 967 Park Avenue, Union City, which was purchased by Samuel Meltzer, Inc., as an investment.

With inventories now in better shape than for six months past, retailers here are showing a moderate degree of optimism on the prospects for Christmas trade as the heaviest shopping month of the year opens today.

Secretary Wallace, testifying before the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today on the Regional Conservation Bill, said that he favored the Administration proposal to establish seven planning zones based on the country's principal watersheds for conservation, flood control and hydroelectric power development.

Carlton Glidden, artist, playwright and author, died in his home here this morning at the age of 61. Born in Charleston, S. C., July 17, 1876, he was the son of Charles H. and Mary Turner Glidden He went to Europe to study painting as a young man and for some time was a student at the Beaux Arts, Paris. He attained success as a portrait painter.

Managed Estates, Inc., Philadelphia, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $500,000 of 5 per cent twenty-year secured bonds due in 1957 and to be offered at 102. The proceeds will be used for investment. Griffin Vose, Inc.. was named underwriter.

David Saperstein, director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, left that post today to resume the private practice of law in New York. He was succeeded by Ganson Purcell, who recently was named acting director.

Attorney General Fernandez Garcia will urge the next Legislature to amend the court procedure so as to provide for two alternate, or substitute, jurors, as in Federal courts, when a criminal trial indicates unusual length

The number of commercial failures in the United States in the week ended Nov. 24 showed increases in all groups, as compared with a year ago, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet. It was the second week in which this had occurred.

Despite the implication contained in the latest exchange of words between Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, over the responsibility for the recent decline in stock prices, there is little likelihood that the latter will accept the new challenge of Wall Street, as exemplified by Mr. Gay's statement published yesterday.

Dr. Daniel Frederick Rambaut, early practitioner in modern methods of treating mental diseases and medical superintendent of St. Andrew's Hospital, in Northampton, the largest mental hospital in England, died today at the age of 72.

Mercy for a man whom Victor F. Ridder, publisher of the New Yorker Staats Zeitung, had charged with dangerous driving was granted in Traffic Court yesterday at Mr. Ridder's request. Mr. Ridder said that if any effort were made to suspend or revoke the man's driving license because of the incident he would plead for him.
Yesterday this column spoke about the six and a half billion dollars which has been invested for health,
In the only women's Class B match played in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday, the Staten Island team defeated the Cosmopolitans, 4--1, on the losers' court.

John G. Treuer, retired building contractor, died today at his home here after an extended illness. He was 75 years old. A native of Mount Vernon, N. Y., Mr. Treuer had lived here for the last twenty years.

Liquidation by holders of December corn contracts sent all deliveries on the Board of Trade here to new low levels for the season today closing trades being at the inside figures with net losses of 5/8 to 3/4 cents a bushel.

Somewhat irregular fluctuations over a 10-point range took place yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here and the market closed with losses of 5 to 8 points. Following a lower opening, the list recovered in sympathy with the stock market and, as selling pressure was light, the near months advanced to around 8 cents a Pound.

The Montreal Maroons jumped from a tie for third place in the National Hockey League's International division into a tie for second tonight by beating the Chicago Black Hawks, 1 to 0. The victory advanced the Maroons two points above their local rivals, the Canadiens, and put them on a level with the New York Americans.

A new Mark Twain Memorial Museum, next door to the home in which he lived as a boy, was dedicated today on the 102d anniversary of his birth. Of the same construction as Twain's early home. the four-room house once was owned by his father, John M. Clemens. Originally it was the property of Moses D. Bates, founder of Hannibal.

Assemblyman Phelps Phelps, New York Democrat, announced yesterday that he would introduce in the forthcoming Legislature a resolution calling upon Congress to approve the Vandenberg child labor amendment to the Constitution.

Reflecting the dearth of new financing, the total of bonds called for redemption before maturity during November aggregated only $76,172,000. This was the smallest volume for any month since April, 1935, when $38,328,000 were retired, and compares with $134,043,000 redeemed in October and with $126,941,000 in November, 1936.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,425,800 barrels, compared with 3,573,850 in the previous week, a drop of 148,050, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 73,200 barrels less than the calculation of 3,509,000 daily for November by the Bureau of Mines.

The public offering of new securities here during November showed a decided slump in volume from preceding periods. Bond offerings were the smallest since September last, but excluding the $25,000,000 of Home Loan Banks bonds, the November total would have been the smallest since November, 1933.

An appeal for support of religious and social agencies engaged in charitable work on the West Side was made yesterday by the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, pastor of Holy Cross Church in West Fortysecond Street, at a luncheon of the Lions Club in the Hotel Astor.

Miss Anne Russell, daughter of Supreme Court Justice ,and Mrs. Pierce H. Russell of Troy, N. Y., was married here at noon today to William Wolfe Morrell of Pittsburgh at the home of the bridegroom's father, the Rev. Dr. Wheeler H. Morrell, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, who performed the ceremony.
The Federal Housing Administration explained today that President Roosevelt's housing program called for reductions of 1/2 or 3/4 of 1 per cent in the total charges on insured mortgages.

An expedition to Mount Auyantepuy, which rises from the jungles of "no man's land" in Southern Venezuela and has never been scaled by any man, so far as is known, is now on its way, under the sponsorship of the American Museum of Natural History, it was announced yesterday.

If there are people who complain that affairs in Washington are marking time, and that "things aren't happening rapidly enough" to restore the confidence of business men, let them note that on two successive days the President has reversed two major recovery Policies of his Administration.

King George left London tonight for a two-day tour of the Duchy of Cornwall, a 300,000-acre estate largely in Southwestern England. During his stay the Duchy's royal landlord will receive his feudal dues in a picturesque ceremony.
166th St (9-2388), n e cor of Park Ave, 48x96; Harlem Savings Bank to Louis Landau, 86 Ft Washington Ave.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 (AP).--The. St. Louis assembly plant of the Ford Motor Company operated again today, with police escorting employes through a picket line of the striking United Automobile Workers of America.

LONDON, Nov. 30.--In the gray November twilight of Victoria Station late this afternoon a group of silk-hatted diplomats congregated beside the brown and cream pullmans of the Continental Express were busily engaged in the calisthenics of courtesy.
Health Commissioner John L. Rice predicted yesterday that complete 1937 statistics would show an all-time low in the city's tuberculosis, maternity and infant mortality rates.
J. Edgar Hoover said today that Federal agents had arrested William Hurwitz at Boston on charges of concealing $40,000 worth of merchandise belonging to a bankrupt Newark (N. J.) concern.

Due to an injury to his eye, Ernest Schelling will be unable to conduct this, the fifteenth anniversary season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's Young People's Concerts. Rudolph Ganz, conductor, pianist, composer and president of the Chicago Musical College, will take over the series.

Major concessions to the New Deal power policy embodied in a series of compromise proposals aiming at an Administration-utilities "peace pact" were advanced by Wendell L. Willkie, president of Commonwealth Southern Corporation, in his recent conference with President Roosevelt.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Oakley Brown of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Frances Brown, to John Avery Curtis, son of Mrs. Osborn Curtis of Point Pleasant, N. J.

The Squash Club, defending champion for the past two years, started with a victory as twelve clubs in Groups I and II opened the Class B season in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association last night.

Norman C. Armitage of the Fencers Club, former national saber titleholder, defeated Miguel A. de Capriles, Salle Santelli star, in a fence-off, 5 to 3, last night to take first-place honors in the senior individual saber competition held by Amateur Fencers League of 'America on the strips of the Salle d'Armes Vince.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ewing Hope of 43 East Seventieth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Talcott Hope, to David Edward Austen, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Austen of Charlottesville, Va.

A special primary in the thickly populated Eleventh Massachusetts Congressional District tonight gave State Representative Thomas A. Flaherty the Democratic nomination to the seat vacated by appointment of John P. Higgins as Chief Justice of the State's Superior Court. The election will be held Dec. 14.

Imports of cement into the United States during October this year totaled 51,467,083 pounds, valued at $117,391, compared with a September total of 54,762,241 pounds with a value of $124,822 and October (1936) total of 71,515,509 pounds valued at $166,966, the Commerce Department reported today.

A drastic cut in crude rubber exports for the first quarter of 1938 was announced today by the international regulation committee, composed of representatives of virtually all rubber exporting countries.

The net operating income of the Class I railroads in October was 32.4 per cent below that in October, 1936, owing to higher operating costs and lower revenue, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Unemployment in the United States in October advanced 293,000 over the September level to an estimated total of 6,355,000, according to the latest report of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public last night.

To the long list of Soviet diplomatic officers who have been recalled to Moscow recently and of whom the only subsequent news has been, in some cases, reports of their execution, the name of General Nikolai Semenoff, Soviet military attache here, must be added.
Police today arrested fifteen Nazis in the village of Neustift in connection with the slaying of Johann Weichselberger, 28-year-old farmer, whose bullet-scarred body was found in a near-by forest.

A [pounds sterling]2,000,000 credit for the purchase of German goods has been extended to Manchukuo by the firm of Otto Wolff at Cologne. Manchukuo's central bank guarantees the credit, which will be amortized in semi-annual pavments ending in 1944.

The mother of Captain Lawrence Oates, who gained a niche in British history as "a very gallant gentleman," died yesterday-twenty-five years after her son voluntarily walked out of a tent to die in a South Polar blizzard.
Chairman W. A. Ayres of the Federal Trade Commission was named by that organization today to direct the inquiry into the causes for the high cost of living asked recently by President Roosevelt.
Following a disagreement over production methods, William Keighley today withdrew from the direction of "The Adventures of Robin Hood" at Warners. Michael Curtiz was named to succeed him.

A celebration by two business partners over their success in selling a large electric refrigerator ended here at 1 A. M. today when Aloysius C. Kersting of 1,600 Chester Street, the Bronx, was accidentally shot and killed by his partner, Edwin R. Perley of 10 Parker Street, Port Chester, according to police.

Louisiana State University and the University of Santa Clara, opponents in the 1937 Sugar Bowl football classic, were picked today to meet here again this New Year's Day. Joseph Cousins, president of the Mid-Winter Sports Association,

The American Federation of Actors, which covers the principal performers in night clubs, motion picture presentation houses and vaudeville, announced yesterday that it was "going after" jurisdiction now held in part by the Burlesque Artists Association and the Chorus Equity Association, the last-named a subsidiary of the Actors Equity Association. The three unions are affiliates of the American Federation of Labor.

City Court Justice James C. Madigan ruled yesterday that the usual form of public liability insurance policy protects a landlord or building operator from claims arising out of an unprovoked assault by an employee. His ruling is the first judicial interpretation covering this question in New York.

The master and fourteen members of the crew of the fishing schooner Reliance were picked up from lifeboats by the fishing schooner White Star last night off Cape Blanco on the Pacific coast of Costa Rica. The master of the White Star reported that he was standing by until the Reliance sank but abandoned the watch this noon.

The Metropolitan Opera Company opened its Philadelphia season here tonight with a performance of Bellini's "Norma," given to a packed house in the Academy of Music. Several hundred, seeking tickets, were turned away.

The City Athletic Club, last year's champion, lost to Jackson Heights, 3--2, in Group 1 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association at Jackson Heights last night. Midston House defeated the New York A. C., 3--2, while the Bayside Tennis Club won all five matches by default from the Crescent A. C.

West Virginia will have 3,000 square feet of exhibit space, with an option for an additional 1,500 square feet, to display the State's natural resources and industries at the New York World's Fair in 1939, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair.

Kenneth Johnston, 26 years old, of 1,036 East Tenth Street, Brooklyn, who said he was a striking employe of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, was arrested last night on a charge of disorderly conduct after he was taken off a picket line formed in front of Martin's Department Store, Bridge and Fulton Streets, Brooklyn.

Efforts of Ferenc Szaiasi's Hungarian National Socialist party to secure Regent Nicholas Horthy's proclamation as King of Hungary were sharply reproved by Premier Koloman Daranyi on his return from Berlin in a declaration to the press today.

Seventy-six men, women and children, most of them Negroes, who had been on a sit-down strike since early Monday morning on the fifth floor of the Department of Public Welfare's building, 376 Lafayette Street, ended the sit-down last evening and returned to their homes.

In the interest of clarity I have prepared this brief memorandum with the hope that it will be helpful in working out a satisfactory relationship between the private utilities and the Federal Government.
Stocks recovered Monday's losses and closed with gains ranging from fractions to 2 points; turnover, 1,152,300 shares.

Clint Frank, one of the greatest backs ever to play for Yale, will receive the John W. Heisman Memorial Trophy at a dinner in the Downtown Athletic Club on Tuesday night. The annual award, first made two years -ago, goes to the player who, in the- opinion of 600sports editors, writers and radio announcers, proves himself most valuable to his team.

General Water, Gas and Electric CompanyandSubsidiaries-Twelve months to Oct. 31: Net income after expenses and charges, $446,656, equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $1 a share on the outstanding common stock. This compares with a net of $439,067, or 96 cents a common share, in the twelve months to Oct. 31, 1936.

Abandonment after eight years of the attempt to establish through government subsidy a successful national system of cooperative marketing for grain producers became a virtual certainty today when the Farmers National Grain Corporation announced that the directors had voted to dissolve the organization.

Henry Lancaster Scott, manager of American Factors, Ltd., of New York, sugar brokers, died of a heart attack today in his home here. His age was 68. He was a member of the Metropolitan Club of New York, Lotos Club of New York, Baltusrol Golf Club and the United States Senior Golf Club.

Development of an "objective rating scale" for supervisors, listing 118 characteristics possessed by the ideal teacher and intended to eliminate the personal element from teacher-supervision, was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners.

CHATANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 30.--Executives of two utility corporations testified here today before the three-judge Federal court that their companies would be driven to bankruptcy if they were forced to compete with Tennessee Valley Authority rates for electric service, and with municipalities seeking to distribute TVA power.

A million dollars worth of baseball "ivory" was "bought and sold" verbally in hotel lobbies today as delegates to the minor league meeting awaited the opening tomorrow of their thirty-sixth conventionbut through the cigar and rumor smoke only one actual transaction emerged.

Justice Peter M. Daly, in the special term of the Queens Supreme Court, Jamaica, handed down yesterday a decision in a foreclosure action in which the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York was plaintiff and in which the court upheld the constitutionality of the legislation creating the commission and entitling it to remedial action.

Complete reorganization of the police detective division is being conducted by Commissioner Valentine, it was learned yesterday. The reorganization is part of the shake-up which, while not identifiable with politics, has resulted in the enforced retirement of nearly all of the police commanders in power when the department was controlled by Tammany Hall.

The share market managed to maintain a steady undertone most of yesterday and the closing was firm. On the average, the market retrieved the ground lost on Monday, with a bit to spare, although there was little increase in volume.

Turpentine firm, 27c: sales, 119 barrels; receipts, 371 barrels; shipments, 76 barrels; stock, 38,173 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 409; receipts, 1,533; shipments, 281: stock, 82,965. Quote: B, D, E, $5; F, $5.55; G, $5.60; H, $5.65: $5.75; K. $5.85; M. $5.90; N, $5.95; WG, $6.50; WW, X, $6.85.

The Rockaway Hunting Club team of Johnny Smith, former assistant pro at the Penn A. C., and D. Lee Norris, furnished a surprise yesterday by eliminating last year's winners, Walter Kinsella and W. E. (Billy) Coyle,

Charles Ryder, engineer of the Water and Power Resources Board, said today that the State would proceed "immediately" to buy options on land for the flood control project at Johnstown, scene of two notable inundations.

C. Raymond Hulsart died in the New Rochelle Hospital today of a heart ailment, exactly twenty years after a fierce morning of fighting at Cambrai, which won him the American Distinguished Service Cross and the British Military Cross.

An offer of wage increases by the International Mercantile Marine Company to ship repair employes, which would exceed 100 per cent on overtime work, was rejected yesterday by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, an affiliate of the C. I. O.

After having burned the bottom of his right foot with a glowing cigarette to lend versimilitude to a fantastic tale of having been kidnapped, which turned out to be a pretext for running away from school, 14-year-old Louis Atwood of St. Georges, Del., was taken home today by his mother, Mrs. Helen Atwood.

James J. Braddock, former heavy-weight champion, and his manager, Joe Gould, were notified by the State Athletic Commission yesterday that they had until today to pay the penalty of $1,000 assessed against them for the failure of Braddock to go through with his scheduled bout with Max Schmeling last June.

Interrupted in the midst of a busy practice session at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy yesterday afternoon, Clair Bee, coach of the Long Island University basketball team, adopted a somewhat pessimistic attitude when queried concerning the prospects of the Blackbirds for the coming season.

Contrasting with the general representation in the German press that Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's resignation from the Economics Ministry was a purely organizational change, the Rheinfront, National Socialist newspaper, which occasionally voices. independent views, writes today:

The Conservative party's 31-year tenure in the Victoria Federal constituency was broken today, with R. W. Mayhew as the first Liberal elected to the House of Commons from the Riding since 1906. The by-election was necessitated by the recent death of S. F. Tolmie, Conservative.

Trading was fair to slow in the-local market yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs sold very unevenly; top retail sales were weak to slower, but others were strong to $1 higher. Lamb carcasses were steady, but cuts were steady to sharply higher. Fresh pork cuts were steady to slightly higher. Other classes were mostly unchanged.

The three-story and basement building at 2,472 Third Avenue, the Bronx, running through to 171 Lincoln Avenue, has been leased by the Saranac Realty Company to the Mauser Plumbing Supply Company for use as general offices and warehouse.

Complaints are being heard in Washington from members of Congress toiling to pass the farm relief and the wages-and-hours legislation that the human objects of their efforts don't seem much interested in what happens to these bills.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York was the beneficiary of a luncheon, exhibition of ship models and a Christmas cruise style revue yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. A feature of the benefit was the display of the latest costumes for holiday cruise wear in which debutantes acted as manikins.

Dr. William Hosea Ballou, scientist and writer, who specialized in the study of fungi, reptiles and fish, died this morning in his home here at the age of 80. He had been in failing health for several years.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith diagnosed the ills underlying the business recession throughout the nation yesterday and declared there was no present reason to expect any great flow of capital into industry "while human nature is as it is."
More than 700 men attended last night the 181st annual dinner of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

Comparing the number of deaths by automobile in the first ten months of this year with those of the same period last, the National Safety Council is cheered. The deaths from automobiles in 1936 were 29,560, those of 1937 31,950, an increase of 2,390.

The Haitian public is incensed over the allegedly passive attitude of President Stenio Vincent in the controversy with the Dominican Republic arising from border fighting in which many Haitians were killed.

Henry L. Maxwell, Henry S. Morgan and Robert N. Bavier form a committee appointed by Philip J. Roosevelt, president of the North American Yacht Racing Union, to study possible modifications in the Universal Rule of measurement or the International Rule with an eye toward less expensive open class yachts of light displacement. Announcement of the selection of the committee was made yesterday.

Reaching up to the library shelf, Thomas Job has selected "Barchester Towers" for dramatization, and Ina Claire took charge of it at the Martin Beck last evening. To satisfy the scruples of the Trollope scholars, Mr. Job calls it "freely adapted" in acknowledgment of the license he has taken with a standard book of the nineteenth century.

Suspension of dividends on the preferred stock "pending the return of profitable operations" was announced by the directors of the American Woolen Company at the close of its board meeting yesterday. The last dividend payment of $1 a share on Sept. 15 was made on account of arrears which amount to $62.25 a share.
Mrs. Caroline Everett Jules, grandniece of Edward Everett, Governor of Massachusetts 100 years ago, died today at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Genevieve Creeley, at the age of 84.

Federal agents have arrested Fern Moore and Arch J. Holbrook at Rogers, Ark., on charges of participating yesterday in a $14,415 hold-up of the Citizens Bank of Springfield, Mo., it was revealed today at the Department of Justice.

The La Guardia administration was criticized last night by Douglas L. Elliman, former president of the Real Estate Board of New York, for continuing the practice of past administrations in disregarding the plight of real estate owners and spending money as if the sources of revenue were unlimited.

Fourteen seamen of the governmentowned freighter Algic, who "sat down" in sympathy with longshoremen on strike in Montevideo, Uruguay, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today for conspiracy to revolt and "unlawfully and feloniously endeavoring to make a revolt."

Voted out of the presidency of Universal Pictures Company,. Inc., at a special meeting of its board of directors yesterday, Robert H. Cochrane protested last night, through his attorney, that the action was "without authority, illegal and bad from a business point of view."

The two-family dwelling at 50-70 Forty-fifth Street, Woodside, L.I., was sold by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to Patrick Kenny. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $5,300. Lawrence Brown was the attorney for the purchaser and William Adam Schulz was the broker in the deal.

A Bal de Tate was held last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis in aid of the Lighthouse Eye Clinic of the New York Association for the Blind. Several dinners and supper parties were given.

Requests for immediate repeal of undistributed profits and capital gains taxes, amendment of the National Labor Relations Act to define and prohibit unfair labor practices and a suggestion that any revision of the Federal anti-trust laws be preceded by competent and impartial investigation were included in resolutions adopted last night at the closing business session of the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

TO THE CONGRESS: By the act of June 16, 1936, the Congress authorized appropriations totaling $216,500,000, for each of the fiscal vears 1938 and 1939, for Federal-aid highways, secondary or feeder roads, elimination of grade crossings, forest highways, roads and trails, and highways across public finds, to be administered by the Department of Agriculture.

The independent spirit in Congress, which has smoldered ever since the special session began, flared out today with the presentation of President Roosevelt's message demanding curtailment of the highway building program as a step toward balancing the budget.
Premier Mussolini's newspaper, the Popolo d'Italia, today expressed ironic "satisfaction" with the result of the Brussels conference.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 28,000, including 6,000 directs. The market opened steady to 15 cents lower and closed 25 cents lower than Monday's average.

Kirsten Flagstad left New York for St. Louis yesterday to sing with the St. Louis Opera Company tonight in "Tristan und Isolde," the work in which she opened the Metropolitan Opera season here on Monday.
Glen Lee of Nebraska, who became a middleweight title threat as the result of a successful campaign in California, will make his New York debut tonight at the Hippodrome.

Pittsburgh was held to a scoreless tie this year by Fordham in the only game either powerhouse failed to win, but the Panthers outnumber the Rams, 5 to 3, on two Eastern all-star football teams, compiled 'yesterday by The Associated Press.
Gerardo Machado, former President of Cuba, lay on a sickbed yesterday in Murray Hill Hospital and pleaded not guilty to charges of mass murder and the misapplication of funds of his government.

The University of Alabama accepted tonight an invitation to play the Golden Bears of California in the New Year's Day Rose Bowl football classic at Pasadena. Kenneth Priestley, graduate manager of the University of California, announced negotiations had been completed by telephone with Alabama officials.

William B. Herlands, chief aide to Special Rackets Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, was named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to take the post of Commissioner of Investigation on Jan. 1 under the new City Charter, which becomes effective at that time.
Kingsbridge Rd, E (12-3316); 59 E Kingsbridge Rd, Inc, to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtg to Nov. 24, 1942, at 5 percent; $40,000.
Yehudi Menuhin will play the recently unearthed Schumann violin concerto for the first time in this country at his Carnegie Hall recital next Monday night, it was announced yesterday.

The directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway have authorized the sale of $4,000,000 of equipment trust certificates to finance the purchase of stainless steel cars and oil-electric locomotives, S. T. Bledsoe, president, announced yesterday.

The Right Rev. Basil M. Kerbawy, since 1907 dean of the St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Cathedral at 355 State Street, Brooklyn, died Sunday in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness, at the age of 64. A native of Antioch, Syria, he had been headmaster of the Presbyterian Seminary for Boys there before coming to this country in 1899.

To maintain leadership or to attain it, "advertise continuously," Ralph W. Knox, manager of the advertising department of Quality Bakers of America, yesterday advised members of the association, which is a cooperative group of independent bakers, at its conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

Seven games have been scheduled for the City College eleven for next season, it was announced yesterday. The campaign will open on Oct. 1, with Buffalo providing the opposition, and will come to a close on Nov. 12, when Moravian comes to New York for the first time to meet the Beavers.
