Women themselves are responsible for barriers that exist against them in the business and professional world, Catherine Filene Shouse, chairman of the board of the Institute of Women's Professional Relations and author of "Careers for Women," declared tonight at a dinner tendered in her honor by the Women's City Club of Boston.

Resumption of exports of coffee from Brazil, which virtually have been suspended since Nov. 3 when the coffee exchanges were closed, will be resumed immediately under the terms of a new decree, the Department of Commerce announced today.
The engagement of Miss Kathryn Elizabeth Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lindley Gilmore Coleman of Kew Gardens, to William Warnock Gibbs of Jacksonville, Fla.. has been announced by her parents.

The railroads of the United States might well spend $900,000,000 annually in the next several years for improved plant and equipment if increases are granted in freight rates for the country and passenger rates for the East, Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

Textile firms and manufacturers of wearing apparel were prominent among the organizations reported yesterday as having leased new space for commercial purposes. A number of full-floor units were rented.

Chairman Kennedy of the Maritime Commission sent invitations today. to authorities of twenty-seven port cities to attend a conference here on a realignment of steamship services in foreign trade. In a recent survey of the merchant marine, Mr. Kennedy pointed out that there were twenty-three basic routes from the United States to foreign ports.

The most remarkable result of yesterday's conversations in Downing Street is their effect in reassuring French public opinion. The French are agreeably surprised that accord with the British proved so easy.
Sister Margaret Mary Hughes died of a heart ailment this afternoon in the Mother House of the Sisters of the Presentation at Mount St. Joseph's near here this afternoon. She was 81.

The marriage of Miss Roberta Alexander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Alexander of Los Angeles, to Bernard Looms, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Looms of Market Harbour, Leicestershire, England, took place here last night in the Church of the Transfiguration.

The House subcommittee on taxation continued today its studies with Treasury experts of proposed tax legislation which might stimulate business and industry. Chairman Vinson said the committee worked on gift and estate taxes, but "had nothing to report." The problem is complicated, he said, by State acts dealing with the same type of levies.

Lawsence A. Atwell of Wskefield, Mass., tonight was elected captain of the Brown varsity football team for 1938. Atwell, a back, is the son of Willard B. Atwell, Brown, '03, superintendent of the Wakefield Public Schools.

The end of a bridge romance was revealed yesterday with the announcement that Mrs. Ely Culbertson was on her way to Reno to obtain a divorce from her husband. The couple, however, will continue to maintain their business relationship and play professional bridge in partnership.
Several sales of properties in Westchester County were reported yesterday by the Suburban Realty Company, broker.
Captain Benjamin Dutton Jr., commander of the heavy cruiser Portland, died today at Southgate, Calif., the Navy Department was informed. He was 54 years old.

According to a message received here yesterday by the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company, the moderating of the weather off Puerto Mexico, Mexico, enabled twelve of the crew of thirtyone of the stranded freighter Cauto to be taken off in a breeches buoy.

Judge Wallace in General Sessions yesterday dismissed the indictment charging Harry Sherman, former president of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union, with misappropriating $150,961 of the union's funds in December, 1933.

Ruth Draper, the American disease, is now almost a legend in London, but one that does not grow stale, and at the Vaudeville Theatre, where she began a three weeks' season tonight, her creations seem as fresh and full of vitality as ever.

The editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES today on "America's Aloofness" attracted widespread attention in the capital and was praised highly in official circles. A "splendid editorial" was the burden of the comment.

Tonight's bulletin says General Eric Ludendorff's condition has improved slightly, but adds that the dangerous complications continue. According to the bulletin, this condition cannot be expected to disappear for some time.
A goldenrod stalk tossed by a playmate cost 11-year-old Edward Choose of Stuyvesant his right eye, but brought him a $30,000 award for damages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--Drastic regulation of large corporations is proposed in a bill introduced today by Senators O'Mahoney and Borah. The bill, which pools ideas its sponsors had incorporated in separate measures, was referred to the Judiciary Committee, of which both are members.

A quiet, frail man of 80, who had spent almost every afternoon for sixteen years in the reading rooms of the public ibraries of West Harlem, died on Monday morning in the furnished room at 509 Manhattan Avenue where he had lived since 1921.

Sixteen salesmen for the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company, under the direction of their sales manager, Harry Kuesel, sat on a platform in the Colonial Room of the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday, and for the edification of several hundred members and guests of the Sales Executives Club of New York went through the routine of an actual sales meeting.

The right of the government to advance money for municipal power plants in competition with private enterprise was defended today in a brief filed by the Department of Justice with the Supreme Court preparatory to arguments on this issue next week.

Two explosions, fifteen seconds apart, wrecked one house in Merion thisafternoon, badly damaged two others and injured six persons, one of them seriously. The blasts were apparently caused by illuminating gas, ignited by a spark. Hundreds of windows were shattered- in the near-by area.

The Ministry of Finance said today a new issue of Treasury bonds would be floated tomorrow which it was hoped would bring in about 3,500,000,000 francs (about $116,600,000). Maturing in nine years, the bonds will bear 5 per cent interest.

Plans to place the high school cafeterias of this city under a central management, controlled by representatives of civic and welfare organizations in cooperation with the Board of Education,were announced yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the board's building and site committee.

Power generated by the electric light and power industry in the United States during September was 6.4 per cent ahead of the same month in 1936, according to statistics released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute.

Commissioner Carl K. Withers of the State Department of Banking and Insurance reported today that all but nine of twenty-nine State banks and trust companies taken over since 1930 have been liquidated.

Herbert S. Brower, president of the South Shore State Bank and former president of the Great Kills (S. I.) Building Loan and Savings Association, died yesterday at his home, 24 Brown Avenue, Great Kills, after a lingering illness. He was 74 years old.
Wheat prices soared today on buying stimulated by unfavorable crop comment from Argentina and Australia and reports of an active foreign demand for domestic hard and soft red Winter grain.
Frank C. Scott, president of the Cleveland Law Library and a practicing attorney here for fifty years, died at his home early today after a brief illness. His age was 75.

A good demand for residential properties in New Jersey was indicated in sales announced yesterday. Charles E. Sweeney, Rumson broker; reported sales of four estates, three of them on the North Shrewsbury River.
Miss Gertrude Epstein, honor graduate of Barnard College in 1934 and a former editor-in-chief of The Barnard Bulletin, renewed yesterday her legal battle to obtain a teacher-in-training license.

A steady withdrawal of troops, artillery and supplies from the Nanking area to points up the Yangtze River and across the river indicate the Chinese are taking steps to avoid the trapping of large forces in and around the capital by Japanese encircling tactics.

A women's committee for the appointment of Marshall B. Dierssen as one of the six members of the new City Planning Commission, which begins to function on Jan. 1, has recently been formed, it was learned yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta reported today that farm income in six Southeastern States increased 25.1 per cent for the first nine months of 1937, compared with the corresponding period of 1936.

Pneumonia, rated high among public health enemies, is being fought in two Toronto hospitals with a serum made from the blood of rabbits. Results of treatment so far are said to indicate the serum's value in some cases.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that deliveries of sugar to domestic markets in the first ten months of 1937 amounted to 5,754,497 short tons, raw value, or an increase of 258,519 short tons over the same period last year. Deliveries in November amounted to 380,724 short tons.

The Administration's plan to wage war against trusts to break up concentrations of industry gained impetus yesterday when Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney, acting on instructions from Attorney General Cummings, filed anti-trust suits here against the Western Union Telegraph Company, the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation and the latter's thirty-six subsidiaries.

FIRST MILITARY AREA The following Reserve Officers recently released to the 1st Military Area, N. Y., are assigned as follows: HDQRS. 98TH DIVISION (Ordnance Section) Major Stanley H. Ellison, Ord. Res., 1,821 James St., Syracuse, N. Y.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and adjacent suburban areas showed a decrease of 3 per cent under a year ago for the week ended Nov. 27, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. This compares with a drop of 10 per cent for the preceding week.

Those Senator and Representatives who are described in Washington dispatches as believing the President is manoeuvring to put all responsibility on Congress have evidently been oversleeping at the switch. Their conclusion is based, in the dispatches, on Mr. Roosevelt's demand for curtailment of the Federal-State road-building program. But the background is larger and contains more incidents.
Kenneth Johnston, a striking employe of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Folwell in Bay Ridge Court on a charge of disorderly conduct.
Hard-pressed British statesmanship, began to turn its attention today to possible colonial concessions which might be offered to Germany as part of a "general settlement in Europe."

A number of penthouse apartments were among the quarters included in yesterday's renting report. Ettore Panizza, conductor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, leased a furnished triplex penthouse of ten rooms and four baths at 50 Central Park West through Madison Realty Company, broker.

Johanna Samuels bought from the Haber estate the two six-story apartment houses containing thirtytwo apartments and two stores at 520-22 East 118th Street. Assessed at $70,000, the property was sold for cash over a new first mortgage of $46,000 on both buildings, which was taken back by the seller.

The importance of the proposed Anglo-American trade pact as a means not only of stimulating international trade but also of promoting peace in the world was emphasized by Herschel V. Johnson, charge d'affaires of the American Embassy in London in an address tonight before the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce.

Members of the New York alumni association of Duke University will give a dinner dance tomorrow in the Grill Room of the Ambassador to celebrate the 100th anniversity of the founding of the university. Dr. William Preston Few, president of the institution, will be the guest of honor.
Squadron C, which will open its indoor season next Saturday night in a feature polo contest against Fort Hamilton at the squadron armory in Brooklyn, staged its annual dinner there last night.
With that little matter of "Angel Island" well behind them, George Abbott and his season's leading author, Mrs. Bernie Angus, will have another stage offering, "Brown Sugar," this evening.

The report of business rentals submitted yesterday included several contracts for large units of space. The Chatham Cloth Sponging Works, Inc., have leased the store and basement, comprising about 20,000 square feet of space, in 40-46 West Twentieth. Street, through Mills Co. and Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc., co-brokers.
Public school officials were declared by a Federal court judge today to be without authority to expel pupils who refuse to salute the American flag because of their religious convictions.
Benjamin Kulp, president of the Wilson-Jones Company of Chicago, topped a list of corporation salaries made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Kulp received $65,090.

A campaign to raise $300,000 for the support of twelve institutions represented in this country by the Associated Boards for Christian Colleges in China was announced yesterday by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of a national emergency committee which is directing the appeal. Pledges of' $50,000 have been obtained.
The possibility that a means may ultimately be found to vaccinate human beings against cancer is suggested in a report of the British Empire Cancer Campaign, just published tonight.

Mayor La Guardia delivered a vigorous defense of the Children's Court as an informal tribunal. for adolescent cases yesterday when he attacked the proposal to extend the jurisdiction of the Children's Court to offenders up to the age of 18.

Appointment of Jerome N. Frank, former general counsel of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, and John Wesley Hanes, a member of the brokerage firm of Charles D Barney Co. in New York, as members of the Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to be announced officially by President Roosevelt in the near future.
Today's events: PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; "Aida," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 P. M.; Ralph Lawton, pianist, Town Hall, evening.

A tea was given yesterday by Miss Dorothy Gerster at her home, 18 East Seventy-eighth Street, for members of the junior committee, of which she is chairman, for the Allaverdy Ball, to be held tomorrow night at the Plaza.

Seven members of the American women's ski team sailed yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to compete in Europe's leading tournaments leading up to the world championships this Winter.

The release of Arthur Lawrence, American captain of the small yacht Scouter, and her crew of two, detained by the Cuban authorities at Arroyo Mantua on the northern coast of Pinar del Rio Province yesterday has been ordered by navy headquarters, it was learned tonight.

Unofficial unscrambling of the Nov. 2 election returns which gave Republicans control of the 1938 State constitutional convention by 92 to 85 showed today that former Senator George R. Fearon, veteran Republican leader, had won one of six disputed Republican seats, and that another had gone to Frederick E. Crane, chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals.

Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, former Vice Chancellor of Austria, will marry Nora Gregor, an actress in the Vienna Burgtheater, tomorrow in the Vienna Archbishop's private chapel. Only a few friends have been invited to the ceremony.

Marcos Leos, who stunned officials by showing up twenty years after he fled prison and offering to serve out his manslaughter sentence, was sent back to his wife and nine children today by Governor Clyde Tingley as "a free man."

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Beverly Macfadden, youngest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernarr Macfadden of Englewood, N. J., to Roland Hebert of Holyoke, Mass., which took place on Nov. 15 in Elkton. Md.
Empress Nagako wrote today her second poem since the outbreak of hostilities in China, dedicating it to the spirits of Japanese slain in battle.

The Chamber of Deputies was asked tonight to approve a 10 per cent increase in Italy's 1937-38 naval budget to finance new construction. Approval was a foregone conclusion. Public Works Minister Giuseppe Cobolli-Gigli proposed the increases on behalf of Premier Benito Mussolini, who also is Minister of Marine.

Amendment of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 to attract private capital to the shipping industry and clear the way for the training of American seamen was urged yesterday by the Propeller Club of New York at a meeting at the Downtown Athletic Club.

Stanley T. Soofield, assistant to the vice president of the United States Steel Corportion, died Tuesday in the Presbyterian Hospital of polyneuritis after an illness of five months. He was 51 years old.

Organization of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association, tentatively planned at a meeting in the Larchmont Yacht Club last month, is to be put through tonight at a dinner meeting in the Hotel Lexington, Forty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue. The gathering is scheduled for 7 P. M. in the Florentine Room there.
Mary K. O'Connor, held on a homicide charge in connection with the death of Nancy Glenn, 5 years old, was released in $5,000 bail from Moyamensing Prison late today.

Fielding. practically' the same team that defeated Wales, 2-1, two weeks ago, England scored a 5-4 victory over Czechoslovakia in an international soccer game today. The Englishmen .led, 3-2, at half time.

Mickey Mouse has fallen under the censor's ban here. The daily comic strip appearing in Politika is now forbidden. It told the story of how the uncle of a reigning prince became alarmed at the popularity of Mickey--the reigning prince's double--who was substituting for the absent prince.

California's powerful Bears, Pacific Coast Conference champions and Western representatives for the New Year's Day Rose Bowl game, placed five men on The Associated Press's thirteenth annual all-Pacific Coast football team, released today. Washington claimed two positions, with one each to Stanford, Santa Clara, Oregon State and Gonzaga.
Dr. Helen D. Bragdon's resignation as dean of women at the University of Rochester was announced today by Dr. Alan Valentine, president of the university.

Walter Gieseking's final piano recital here this season was played to an enraptured audience at Town Hall last night which filled every available space in the auditorium, with an overflow seated upon the stage.

The unlicensed personnel of the nineteen tankers operated by the Atlantic Refining Company have indicated their desire to have no union representation in dealings with their employer, the National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday.

Thirty-first annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents will open at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria this morning at 10 o'clock. It will continue tomorrow. Luncheon and afternoon sessions.

The list of the Italian liner Rex, arriving today from Mediterranean ports, includes James Mooney, vice president of General Motors Export Company, with Mrs. Mooney; Tito Schipa, operatic tenor; O. H. Ammann, engineer and designer, with Mrs. Ammann; Colonel and Mrs. Luis Beltram, Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Scott, Dr. and Mrs. James Campbell, Francesco Pisa and Dante Alessio.
The New York University- women's basketball team will play a ten-game schedule, it was announced yesterday by Miss Frances V. Froatz, director - of women's athletics. .
Cliff Battles of the Washington Redskins has a big margin as the leading ground gainer in the National Football League and looks a cinch to repeat his 1938 performance in this respect.
The Maryland Racing Commission, absolving two trainers of any connection with sponging incidents at Bowie, decided today to turn responsibility for protecting- horses aver to the race tracks.

Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, speaking at Hagen today, revealed that 8,000 Catholic monks and lay brothers have been charged with committing various crimes since the National Socialist regime came into power.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools.

An original manuscript journal of a tour through the Eastern United States in 1801 brought $850 last night at the American Art Associatiori-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of Americana from the library of the late Joseph B. Shea of Pittsburgh.

The office of Commissioner of Accounts, later changed to Investigation and Accounts and abbreviated under the new charter to Investigation, goes back to 1873. It was then set up, as the retiring Commissioner, Paul Blanshard, has stated, "as a special instrument for exposing graft."

Extension of the term of the State's Governors from two to four years and three other of six constitutional amendments submitted to voters at the Nov. 2 election were approved by decisive majorities, an unofficial canvass of complete returns showed today. The vote on the Governor's term amendment was: Yes, 838,762; no. 505.943.
The course of operations in the steel districts suggests the possibility that the decline in steel

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System may be expected to fall from their present level of around $1,140,000,000 to $900,000,000 in the next three weeks and will thereafter rise to about $1,250,000,000 by the end of January, according to the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.

The work of the Musicians Emergency Fund in aiding needy musicians was praised by John Barbirolli, conductor of the PhilharmonicSymphony; Arthur Rubinstein, pianist, and Dr. Walter Damrosch, conductor, yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis at the organization's first Fall luncheon.

The butter industry is "unadaptable" to the proposed Federal wages and hour regulation bill now before Congress, the American Butter Institute declared today in a resolution passed at its annual meeting.

The Merchants Association threw its support yesterday behind Mayor La Guaardia's plan for additional parking space, both in buildings and on vacant land, and also expressed its backing of the Mayor's drive for an increase in off-thestreet loading facilities in warehouses and other commercial buildings.

The sleep of Yonkers residents must not be disturbed by the construction work on-New York City's $272,000,000 Delaware Aqueduct, Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief ruled today in two decisions filed here. He granted injunctions restricting work at the Palmer Avenue shaft to the hours between 7 A. M. and 7 P. M.

Federal income-tax agents here have begun the distribution of new tax forms to taxpayers with annual net incomes of $100,000 or more, requiring them to tell the government their "net worth" by giving information as to all their assets, including property that is not taxable and from which no income is derived.

Three detectives returned from Philadelphia yesterday with a blond, well-built youth who, they said, has admitted stabbing to death a 65-year-old woman last Friday when she caught him attempting to rob the cash drawer of her small shop. They also brought back the youth's pretty, dark-haired wife, who expects to become a mother early in the new year.

Frederick J. Waugh, American artist, has won the Popular Prize for his painting "Meridian"--the fourth successive time in the Carnegie. International, at Pittsburgh that his work has been thus acclaimed.

After a- jury had returned a verdict of guilty against two men, accaused with others of swindling the public of $500,000 in the sale of oil stock, in 1934, 1935 and 1936, Federal Judge Harold P. Burke sentented them to terms in the penitentiary.

At the close of a hearing in the Felony Court yesterday, Marcel de Passy, a self-styled count who has had many contacts with the police in Germany and this country in the last fifty-one years, was discharged by Magistrate Renaud on the charge that he had misappropriated $1,835 he had obtained from Sarandi Ralli, an importer and dealer in oriental rugs, of 209 East Fiftyeighth Street.

A plea for a Washington-London-Paris axis to save liberty and peace was made here tonight by Finance Minister Georges Bonnet in a speech to former liaison officers serving with the American Army during the World War.

Making her first start since last Summer, Brown Jade, 3-year-old filly, scored an impressive victory today in the six-furlong feature race at Tanforan track. The time, 1:11, was the fastest clocking for the distance during the current meeting.
Turpentine, firm, 26 3/4c; sales, 69 barrels; receipts, 178 barrels; shipments, 195 barrels: stock, 38,176 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 916; receipts, 1,189;

With dramatic swiftness Governor Lehman moved yesterday toward putting County Clerk Albert Marinelli on trial for his job. Six hours after receiving from Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey renewed and additional charges that Mr. Marinelli, who is also the Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District West,

The Aulick-Johnson Memorial Cup, awarded annually by Columbia College to the fraternity foremost in scholarship, athletics and campus activities, has been presented for the second consecutive time to Alpha Delta Phi, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes.
The case of the Ely Culbertsons is another example of how unsafe it is to generalize about an epoch or a world, any more than about a man.

Seco retary Woodring pictured the Philippine Commonwealth today as one of the world's most prosperous governments. The Far Eastern ward of the United States. not only balanced its budget last year but had a surplus of $3,970,214, representing nearly 10 per cent of annual expenditures, he said in his report for the War Department's Bureau of Insular Affairs.

Pensioned On their own applications: CAPTAINS-John A. Hamill, 2d Precinct, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Nov. 18, 1897. Thomas Leahy, 8th Precinct, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Aug. 1. 1899. PATROLMEN--William S. Burden, 15th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 2, 1907. Michael Carlin, 19th Division, office of the Chief Inspector, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 26, 1901.

Three new officers of the Women's New Jersey State Golf Association were elected at the annual meeting and election of officers today a? the Montclair Golf Club. About sixty-five members, representing twenty-five clubs attended the meeting and luncheon.

Those Democratic Senators whose terms expire in December, 1939, have decided to abandon the traditional policy of leaving the naming of a chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee to the leader of the Senate.

The general character of the Treasury's financing program for December will be announced tomorrow morning by Secretary Morgenthau. Full details will be made public on Monday. It is the general belief that the Treasury will borrow a substantial amount of money-at least enough to meet the maturity of $450,000,000 in discount bills immediately after Dec. 15. On this, however, official comment has been withheld.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiary companies reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 a net income of $3,677,044, against $2,973,373 for the same period last year. Gross operating revenues of the system for the twelve months were $51,986,518, against $47,468,937, an increase of $4,517,581.

Alarm was felt here today for the safety of thirteen Americans, mostly women and children, marooned in an isolated region in the center of Chinese-Japanese fighting. Mission headquarters and the United States Consulate General expressed anxiety after more than a week had passed without word from the Americans.

Approval for the construction of a high-level bridge across the Passaic River as a new connecting link between Newark and Kearny on the Lincoln Highway was given today by the United States War Department, according to an announcement made here by E. W. Wollmuth, executive vice president of the Newark Chamber of Commerce.

The Duchess of Windsor, the former Wallis Warfield of Baltimore, is listed with the royal family, with the wives of the brothers of King George VI, in- the 1938 edition of the British "Who's Who." The volume was issued yesterday in London, and will be published in this country by the Macmillan Company on Dec. 6.

Some of the peace terms suggested to President Roosevelt by Wendell L. Willkie are "impossible" from the Administration's view, informed persons said tonight. A tentative agreement on two major issues had been reached, it was said, but these points remained at issue:

Although led by Thomas Johnston, vigorous Prohibitionist Laborite of Stirling, Scottish drys lost their fight in the House of Commons tonight against the the wets who determined that visitors to the much-advertised Empire Exhibition at Glasgow next year shall be able to have a "wee deoch and doris."
Extension of its fair trade contracts to all of the forty-two States having fair trade laws by the Lehn Fink Products Corporation was announced yesterday by Edward Plaut, president of the company.

A Simplification of the present complex structure of Federal estate and gift taxes and a lowering of exemptions in some respects to increase the Treasury's return by $15,000,000 or more annually was tentatively agreed on today by the House Subcommittee on Taxation.
William James McAlister, chairman and managing director of the General Steam Navigation Company, died today after a long illness at his country home in Millfield, Arran, at the age of 60.

Stocks erased Tuesday's gains and closed slightly lower in dull and quiet trading; turnover, 695,570 shares. United States Government issues slightly higher in smallest turnover since August, 1931; other bonds firm and mixed; transactions, $5,849,300.

The first of the three operas by Richard Strauss to figure in the repertory of this season at the Metropolitan was performed last night: "Der Rosenkavalier." The performance was delightful, not only for such achievements as Lotte Lehmann's justly famous Princess and the fatuous and admirably drawn Baron Ochs of Mr. List but for each figure, great and small, in a virtuoso ensemble.

Nearly 250 motorists got the first batch of 1938 automobile license plates, which bear the legend "New York World's Fair 1939," in this city yesterday, it was announced last evening at the office of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau, 80 Center Street.

A distinguished citizen returning to his own country after a long public service abroad when asked what change was to him most noticeable replied that it was the great number of women, chiefly young women, moving in the streets at certain hours to and from offices and shops.

It was officially announced today that Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia will arrive in Rome Sunday for a three-day visit. He will confer with Premier Mussolini and Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano.

Using a rubber diving suit of his own devising, Max E. Nohl, 27, of Milwaukee, descended today to a greater depth in water than any human being had ever before reached in a dive. Operating off Port Washington, Wis., from the deck of the Coast Guard cutter Antietam, he touched the bottom of a valley in Lake Michigan 420 feet below the surface.

(With apologies to A. E. Housman) With rue their dreams are blighted, The Rose Bowl dreams they had; The Crimson Tide's invited; The Old Maroon is sad. In Alabama's keeping The Rose Bowl bid was laid; And Fordham hopes are sleeping In fields where roses fade.

Statisticians of the Bituminous Coal Commission estimated today that the minimum prices which the commission has ordered effective Dec. 16 should increase the annual return to producers by $40,000,000 to $300.000,000.

Cephas Tidd, clerk in a gents furnishing store in Syracuse, is a bluecollar man. He doesn't belong to a union, but he is strong for the rights of labor. He came down to New York by bus the other day to go to the funeral Of an aunt.
An armed bandit escaped with $135 shortly after 4 A. M. yesterday after holding up the night manager of the Brevoort Hotel, Fifth Avenue and Eighth Street.

Former President Herbert Hoover made a tour of the site of the 1939 World's Fair yesterday, as the guest of Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation After inspecting the grounds at Flushing Meadow Park,

The Coal Commission has at length fixed bituminous prices in all areas east of the Mississippi River and in Iowa. Thus on Dec. 16, when these prices go into effect, our experiment in this field will begin to have its real test.
The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar of 500,000 shares of no-par common stock of the Elk Horn Coal Corporation. Thomas J. Mullins is in the trading department of White, Weld Co.

The Grover Cleveland and Manual Training High soccer teams battled to a 2-all tie in a semi-final play-off of the city P. S. A. L. championship at Commercial Field in Brooklyn yesterday. The teams will replay the game Saturday morning on the same field.

A new doctrine governing Brazilian jury duty makes a jury liable to prosecution for perjury if a trial court considers the jury has rendered a verdict contrary to the evidence. The committee appointed under the new regime to codify Brazilian court procedure agreed that this provision should put juries on the alert to study the evidence closely and render intelligent verdicts.

The Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute basketball team defeated the Hudson College quintet of Jersey City last night, 41 to 40, on the 101st Signal Battalion Armory court in Brooklyn. The game was won in the final five seconds when Don Pitman tossed in two free shots for the Engineers, the first one tying the score at 40--40 and the second one deciding the contest.
Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Grant of East Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Alexander Grant, to Robert Witherbee Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph E. Rogers of Albany.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of directors of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Ino., at a hearing before the Public Service Commission yesterday stated that his company will sell $30,000,000 of new twenty-year debentures in the early part of next year for new capital.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 30: COLONEL Hamilton, C. S., Int., Philippines, to duty in connection with National Guard Affairs, Headquarters, Baltimore, Md.; previous orders revoked.

The house of Jay Thorpe staged last night a skillful showing of midseason styles. The review was limited as to quantity but the fashion quality moved an audience of style authorities to applause. A group of skating and ski cbstumes originating in Sweden drew special notice.

A new service station for the Lincoln and Lincoln Zephr division of the Ford Motor Sales Company will be established at Broadway and Sixty-second Street, where the Ford Company has just leased a six-story building. The structure, known as 1,884-6 Broadway, occupies a plot 116 by 164 feet at the northeast corner of Sixty-second Street.

Formation of a consumers' cooperative organization for the purchase and distribution of milk directly between the producer and consumer in New York City seemed assured yesterday when Holton V. Noyes, State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, announced his willingness to license such an organization "in the public interest."

Mrs. Leopold Stokowski filed suit for divorce today from the conductor of the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, charging extreme cruelty. Although a waiver and a stipulation denying the charge were filed by Mr. Stokowski's attorney, C. D. Breeze, he said the action would be uncontested.

The New York-Pennsylvania Baseball League tonight voted to change the circuit's name to the Eastern League. Officials said the change was made because the circuit now includes a club in New Jersey and may go into Connecticut:

Mayor La Guardia will transfer his office from City Hall today to the twenty-second floor of the Empire State Building, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, where he plans to remain for about three weeks while alterations are made in the City Hall offices.

Miss Isabelle Kirkpatrick Marckwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hunt Marckwald of this place, has chosen Jan. 14 as the day of her marriage to Daniel Bushnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Davis Bushnell of Montclair, N. J.

The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor approved a budget of $1,548,715 for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1938, at. a meeting. of the board of managers yesterday at the association's headquarters, 106 East Twenty-second Street.

Great Britain's "mosquito fleet" of high-speed-naval vessels was augmented today by Motor Torpedo Boat 102, -which experts contend is the fastest and most powerful vessel of her type. While traveling at fifty knots she can fire from both of her 21-inch torpedo tubes.
Secretary Roper declared in an address to business leaders here tonight that there was "need of a general revision of our entire tax structure."
The Japanese Navy returned to its owners with apologies today an American-owned launch, seizure of which by Japanese sailors yesterday drew a protest from the United States Consul General.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "America's Aloofness" is a masterpiece in logic and a most enlightening summary of the international situation and the dangers America is running in continuing its present ostrich-like policy.

The annual rummage sale under the auspices of the Women's Auxiliary of Grand Street Settlement, of which Mrs. Walter N. Rosenau is president, will open today at 1,285 Second Avenue, corner of Sixtyseventh Street,. and continue there for ten days.

Louis C. Gosdorfer was appointed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as a member of the Board of Child Welfare to succeed the late Conrad Engel. Mr. Gosdorfer is president of the United National Bank of Long Island in Forest Hills, and has been active in the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce and the Long Island Chamber of Commerce.

Proposed changes in State insurance laws affecting life companies and hospital service corporations will be discussed next Tuesday and Wednesday at public hearings of the Joint Legislative Committee on the Revision of the Insurance Law in Room 500 of the State Office Building. 80 Centre Street.

Mrs. Philip Rhinelander 2d gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Thomas P. Jones, sculptor. Other guests included Mrs. Hooker Talcott, Mrs. J. G. Phelps Stokes, Mrs. John Walton Livermore, Mrs. Philip A. S. Franklin Jr., Mrs. Lloyd Schultz, Mrs. Rosalie Fellows Briley, Mrs. Charles F. Kiely, Mrs. Sydney D. Ripley, Mrs. Frank Reavis, Mrs. Philip W. Lennen, Mrs. James A. Wiley and Mrs. Charles Bennett Marr.
Mrs. Jessie Marvel MacDade, wife of Judge Albert Dutton MacDade of Delaware County common pleas court. died in her home here today.

At its annual meeting tonight in the Garden City Hotel, the Long Island Golf Association re-elected all incumbent officers save one. The exception was T. Suffern Tailer Jr. of the Piping Rock Club, who succeeds Dr. T. K. Healy, Lido Golf Club, as vice president.

Dance International presented the first of a series of five weekly lectures last night in exposition headquarters in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, when Rolf de Mare spoke on the "Evolution of the Ballet."

The Metropolitan Opera Guild's final campaign luncheon will take place on Dec. 15 in the ballroom of the Hotel Pierre, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. August Belmont, chairman, after the opera lecture given by Olga Samaroff Stokowski.

BRONX ALGIE. MARY (Feb. 21, 1937). Gross assets, $4,300; net, $1,274. To John Algie, James Algie, Harold Algie, Violet Regan and Charlotte Gieseler, children. one-fifth residue each. Chief assets, real estate, $4,200. Robert, C. Van Derveer, attorney, 1,177 East Tremont Ave.

A tea will be given this afternoon by Mrs. Frank J. Foley at her home, 320 Central Park West, to celebrate the first anniversary of the Family Thrift Shop, 631 Eighth Avenue, which maintains a permanent rummage sale.
Chilcan mining organizations, principally the Mining Credit Bureau, urged the authorities today to adopt immediate measures to protect the exportation of low-grade copper ores to Japan.

Leigh Bence Liggett, son of Louis K. Liggett, founder and head of the United Drug Company and former Republican National Committeeman, died tonight at the Newton Hospital. He was in his forty-first year and lived in Chestnut Hill.
The Public Utility Commission granted today to railroads in Pennsylvania a $1,250,000 increase in freight rates on basic commodities, except anthracite, shipped within the State, effective on Friday.

Midshipmen paraded in full dress today in celebrating the 100 anniversary this month of the birth of Admiral George Dewey, hero of the Spanish-American Battle of Manila. The admiral, a native of Vermont, was graduated from the Naval Academy in 1858.

The report of the Diamond Match Company and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $1,595,078 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

The Allis Chalmers Manufacturing Company union, affiliated with the U. A. W. A., has demanded that its members receive a share of the company's profits this year in addition to the $2,500,000 wage increase granted by the company on April 1.

A sensational story of the landing of a large force of Japanese troops at Chikkai Island, forty miles from Macao, on the Canton River opposite Hong Kong, was brought here today by the Rev. Dr. Harry Blaber of the Maryknoll Mission, who is leaving for Seattle, Wash.
Witmel Hardy Reed, former official of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, died yesterday in his home here. He was 58 years old.

Faced with a revolution and the formation of "a military dictatorship at the end of hostilities when the war's costs are counted," Japan's only salvation lies in an immediate cessation of war and a peace amenable to both countries, Charles C. Batchelder, former assistant chief of the Far Eastern Division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, told members of the League for Political Education yesterday.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Harry J. Mehre, a Notre Dame star of the early Twenties, tendered. his resignation today as head football coach of the University of Georgia. Critical alumni had urged a change' in 'coaches. Only a year ago the "wolves" howled when the Georgia team was unimpressive in. its early-games.

The National Association of Insurance Commissioners closed a three-day session at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday by setting committees to work on several inquiries that the supervisory officials of more than thirty States considered vital to the insurance business.

Thomas E. Dewey's report to Governor Lehman on County Clerk Marinelli, dated Tuesday, was in the form of a sworn statement. The text follows: November 30, 1937. His Excellency Herbert H. Lehman, Governor of the State of New York,

Fordham's unbeaten football team will be honored at a victory dinner tonight in the campus dining hall. The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university; the Rev. John Tynan, athletic moderator; Jack Coffey, graduate manager, and Head Coach Jimmy Crowley will speak.

A private playing last night by Yehudi Menuhin of Schumann's recently discovered "Lost Concerto" so impressed the Boston Symphony conductor, Serge Koussevitzky, that he urged the young violinist today to drop the Brahms concerto from

The Federal District Court was transformed into a "little red schoolhouse" today to give a blushing Amish girl opportunity to prove that, at 14, she had learned enough of the three R's" that she might remain at home to help with the baking and farm work despite Pennsylvania's law requiring children to go to school until they are 16.

The Penn A. C. defeated Seton Hall, 24 to 21, as the Pirates opened their basketball season at the Orange Armory tonight. In a preliminary contest, the Manhattan freshmen downed the Seton Hall yearlings, 40 to 25.

The new Westchester store of Arnold, Constable Co., at Main Street and North Avenue, New Rochelle, will open on Saturday with ceremonies at which Mayor Harry Scott will cut a ribbon at the North Avenue entrance.

The Port of New York Authority urged speedy completion of the deepening of the Harlem River to fifteen feet, as an aid to freight transportation, at a hearing yesterday morning before Major H. C. Fairbanks of the army engineers at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall South Street.

complete settlement of the six-day-old strike of 1,300 drivers of the Greyhound Bus Lines was reached tonight. The drivers will get onefourth of a cent a mile increase in pay but not a closed shop, a primary demand of their union.

A campaign to raise a fund of $7,000,000 for the development of Stevens Institute of Technology, to enable it "to do its share in equipping the young men of today to manage the industries of tomorrow," was announced last night at the thirty-fifth annual dinner of the Stevens Alumni Association at the Hotel Astor.

M. W, Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, testified today before the Interstate Commerce Commission that the increase in freight and passenger rates asked by the railroads would result in an immediate increase in employment, within and without the industry; would add momentum to business and would create a spirit of confidence that "would get everybody moving forward."

Government should participate in the making of standards affecting commerce and industry, but should not be the sole determinant of them outside of the sectors of public health, safety or national defense, Frank B. Jewett, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and vice president of the Bell System Laboratories, said yesterday at a luncheon held in conjunction with the annual meeting of the American Standards Association in the Hotel Astor.

Striking editorial employes of The Bayonne Evening Times were prohibited yesterday from picketing the newspaper's advertisers. The prohibition, imposed by Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan in Jersey City, extended the scope of the temporary injunction he issued on Nov. 13 against the Hudson County Newspaper Guild, eight strikers and one sympathizer.

A blistering farewell statement by Walter E. O'Hara as publisher of The Providence Star - Tribune was "killed" today by a Superior Court judge while presses rolled and newsboys waited to carry it out to the city.

An extensive national advertising campaign will be launched late this month for a new type of foods for older children, called "chopped foods," by the H. C. Clapp Company, which has - just introduced these products on a national scale.

The two-story stucco dwelling at 214 Beach Thirty-second Street, Edgemere, L. I., recently sold by the Lewis H. May Company, broker, to C. Greenstein, has been resold to William Brown, an investor. The house accommodates two families.

With the aid of a magnificent run of 147 in the opening inning, Willie Hoppe of New York defeated Jake Schaefer of Chicago, 250 to 136, last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy and gained an even break for the day, as well as squaring the match for the 71.2balkline championship of the United States. Each now has won three times and six blocks remain.

A new printing annex of The Times of London, forming part of an extensive modernization program that calls for the ultimate replacement of the entire group of historic buildings clustered around tiny Printing House Square, was opened tonight by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain.
A plan for State control of the anthracite industry in Pennsylvania has been drafted by the Anthracite Coal Industry Commission, Morris L. Ernst, a member of the commission, announced yesterday.

Nanking Government leaders continue shouting phrases about resisting to the last man and last breath," but meanwhile Japan's diplomats and militarists in Shanghai and elsewhere are more realistically talking about peace, while inspired suggestions come from places as widely separated as Tokyo and Rome.

John H. MacMillan Jr., president of Cargill, Inc., of Minneapolis, a leading grain company, today urged the Commodity Exchange Administration to take from the business conduct committee of the Chicago Board of Trade all power to order a member of the Exchange to dispose of any part of his grain holdings.
Announcement has been made by Hyman Braunstein of this city of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Miriam Braunstein, to Dr. Philip P. Popick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Popick of Newark.

An institute to advise physicians in the serum treatment of pneumonia will be set up soon by the city Department of Health as its latest move in a campaign to combat this "cold weather" disease which takes 7,000 lives each year in New York.

James Felt, chairman of the old law tenements committee of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., and of the old housing committe of the Citizens Housing Council, will discuss the question "Why Do We Have Slums?", over radio station WNEW on Tuesday from 8:30 to 9 P. M.

Just 360 years to the month after Sir Francis Drake started his three-year voyage around the world, five Royal Air Force flying boats will leave Cattewater at dawn tomorrow on the longest formation flight ever attempted.

A plea for more liberal regulations for German Stock Exchanges to permit them to fulfill their functions as instruments of State finance and economic policy was made before the Berlin Chamber of Industry and Commerce today by State Counselor Friedrich Reinhart, president of the Berlin Boerse.

City College yesterday announced complete schedules for five Winter varsity sports. The swimming schedule comprises six dual meets, with a new rival in Brooklyn College. Princeton is the newcomer on the fencing list of six dual meets and th intercollegiate championships:

Now that the text of Mr. Willkie's memorandum to the President has been made public, it is not difficult to understand why a more hopeful view has been expressed in Washington of the prospect of an early peace between the Government and the public utility industry.

The marriage of Miss Ethel Grimmer, daughter of Otto Grimmer of 120 East Thirty-first Street, and Ocean Grove, N. J., and the late Mrs. Grimmer, to Robert Freeman Spindell of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Foster Spindell of Chester, Mass., took place here yesterday afternoon in the First Baptist Church, Seventy-ninth Street and Broadway.

Vice President Garner donned hunting clothes today, and "bagged" a deer. Hunting for the first time in Northern woods, on the heavily timbered, well-stocked 10,000-acre preserve of Colonel William Kaul near this town, the Vice President shot the first buck brought down by a party, including nine Senators nd five other government officials.

Premier Camille Chautemps and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos returned from London yesterday in much better spirits than when they left for it, and tomorrow M. Delbos will set out to visit Warsaw, Bucharest, Belgrade and Prague much encouraged by his London visit.

Numerous transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations in October were shown today in a summary made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Jackson Ave, (10-2647), n e cor of 160th St, 48x79; Kasoff Realty Corp to Marian S. Honeyman, Huntington, N Y; extends mtgs to Dec 1, 1941, at 4 per cent; $35,000. Barker Ave, (16-4623), e s, 200 ft s of Juliana St, 25x70; Leonardo Malorni to Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association, 441 Lexington Ave, installments, 5 per cent; $10,500.

Directors of the American Agricultural Chemical Company declared a dividend of $1.25 a share, bringing total payments for this calendar year to $7.75. The company's fiscal year began on July 1 and since then a dividend of $4 was paid, on Sept. 30.

With the field reduced to twelve teams, the six-day bicycle race continued to hold forth at Madison Square Garden last night. The riders showed little signs of weariness as they went through their brisk paces before a gathering of 10,000 spectators.

A banking group composed of the Anglo-California National Bank, the American Trust Company, Bankamerica Company and the Capital National Bank, purchased yesterday an issue of S3,000,000 of State of California unemployment relief registered warrants on a 0.75 per cent interest basis.

Patrolman James F. McKenna, 34 years old, of 426 Eighty-third Street, Brooklyn, attached to the Bath Beach station, shot himself fatally yesterday afternoon while alone in the second-floor dormitory of the station house at Bay Twenty-second Street and Bath Avenue.
The soil conservation problem has become an outright emergency in New Jersey, Dr. W. H. Martin, director of research for the State
The Art Workers Club for Women, an organization of women artists and models, will be the beneficiary of a bazaar, fashion show and tea to be held this afternoon at the Pierre.

Astronomical studies have made two important contributions to medical diagnosis and treatment, Dr. Edgar Jones of Vanderbilt University at Nashville, Tenn., and Dr. Narcisse F. Thiberge of the Louisiana State University School of Medicine stated today at the annual meeting of the Southern Medical Association. More than 2,000 physicians were present.

With sixteen teams participating, Class C competition in the three groups of the New York Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association got under way yesterday. Jumping into the lead in Group I were the Princeton Club, Squash Club and Yale Club.

On the opening day of a Federal Trade Commission hearing today, charges were made that cement prices had been raised through an illegal combination to stifle competition to a point which reduced the public benefit, sought from emergency acts of Congress, and endangered the success of the government's new housing program.
Conviction of seven C. I. O. members here last Monday for unlawful distribution of literature was affirmed today by Common Pleas Judge Thomas F. Meaney.

More than half the Winter homes here, including seventy completed during the Summer, are occupied, and the season was opened today by the Bath and Tennis, Seaspray, Gulf Stream, Seminole and Palm Beach Golf Clubs.
Army today announced a ninegame football schedule for 1938, opening with Virginia Poly on Oct. 1 and- closing with the traditional Navy game on Nov. 26.

Colonel-General Hermann Goering's hunting visit to Austria has been postponed indefinitely. Originally invited by Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt to Vienna, he expressed a desire to see Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and subsequently to visit either Innsbruck or Salzburg.

The Millinery Center Building Corporation sold to a large financial institution an issue of leasehold bonds amounting to $780,000. The bonds bear interest at 4 1/2 per cent and are secured by the leasehold of the property at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, improved with a twenty-two-story building.

This season's Saturday matinee performances by the Metropolitan Opera Company, beginning this week with Massenet's "Manon," will be broadcast to the world under the sponsorship of the Radio Corporation of America, as last season, it was announced yesterday.

Declaring there is no crisis in the construction industry, Thomas S. Holden, president of the New York Building Congress and vice president of the F. W. Dodge Corporation, endorsed last night the recommendations for further liberalization of housing finance made by President Roosevelt in his housing message to Congress.

With the end of this month bringing the expiration of the Presidential proclamation fixing the price at which the government buys newly mined domestic silver at 77.57 cents an ounces or about 33 cents more than the market price, future policy is being studied by Administration officials.

A constitutional amendment to authorize private courts to take sex cases out of the public view and thus shield innocent persons involved from embarrassing publicity was proposed today by Martin W. Littleton, District Attorney of Nassau County.
The story of "The Conquest of Cholera" from its outbreak in the United States in 1832 to its final conquest in 1892 has been written by Dr. J. S. Chambers of the University of Kentucky.

THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial, "America's Aloofness" is furiously denounced in the German press as "lying agitation fed by Jewish-Bolshevist sources for the purpose of inducing America to interfere in European politics."

Need for a better understanding by both government and business of the point of view of the other was stressed today by Bernard M. Baruch, honorary chancellor of Union College, in a talk to the student body and faculty. The two must work together for all concerned, he added.

California's Golden Bears--who once named Pittsburgh their No. 1 choice of opponents--will be glad to see Alabama in the Rose Bowl New Year's- Day. While the California players previously, and informally, had expressed a preference to meet Pitt in the football classic at Pasadena, their reaction to Alabama was reflected best today through the views of Perry Schwartz, firststring end.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 29: LIEUTENANTS Chapman, J. E., the Winslow, to Destroyer Squadron 12 as engineer officer. Ragan, T. C., Battle Force, to the staff of the Commander of Battle Force as communication officer.

The Church of the Epiphany announced yesterday that $201,098, or 61 per cent of the quota, had been received in its campaign for $330,000 to build a new church at York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street.

The Senate debated the Farm Bill and adjourned at 5:42 P. M. until noon tomorrow. The House was not in session. Senate and House Banking and Currency Committees held hearings on the Housing Bill, the Senators hearing Stewart McDonald, Federal Housing .Administrator, and the House group Jesse Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The problem of comprehensive modern zoning regulations is receiving an increasing amount of attention from municipal officials and plannin, experts interested in promoting the orderly growth of both urban and rural communities.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, who is also State Democratic leader, issued a statement tonight charging that the various moves in the contest of the election of United States Senator A. Harry Moore as Governor had the "sinister object" of bringing about the installation of voting machines in all counties of the State.

Columbia varsity schedules in swimming, wrestling and fencing were announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, athletics manager. The swimming team will participate in nine dual meets, the wrestling team in eight and the fencers in eleven, with all three teams entered in intercollegiate championships at the conclusion of their seasons.
" Encouraging support" is being received by the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis at its national headquarters, 50 East Forty-second Street, Keith Morgan announced yesterday.
A low bid of $534,400 for construction of the Canal Street postoffice station in New York City has been submitted by Thomas J. Waters Sons of New York, the Treasury announced today.

Ridge St, 150, 25x100; Sylvia Meyers to Relgro Realty Corp, 17 John St, care of Sidney Ostro. Madison St, 216, 26.1x100; Joseph M. Paley, referee, to Herman Goldner, 153 Bay 26th St, Brooklyn, consideration $500, foreclosing tax lien. Clinton St, 23, 25x100; Harold Treanor to Emigrant Bank, consideration $1,000, foreclosure.

The possibility that Police Commissioner Valentine may further lower the compulsory retirement age for members of his department to 60 years was indicated yesterday when he disclosed that the Corporation Counsel had advised him, in response to his request for a legal opinion, that retirement at that age could be legally enforced.

Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system, said yesterday in an interview that litigation between private utilities and the Federal Government should not be permitted to go to the bitter end. Now that the issues were defined clearly, he agreed, an excellent opportunity was presented to effect a settlement of the problem.
The United Hospital Fund received a contribution of $10,000 yesterday from the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, according to an announcement from John W. Davis, campaign chairman.

The bustle of New York almost seemed mild and restive to the Washington Redskins when they arrived in town yesterday, ready to put the finishing touches on their preparations for their battle with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds on Sunday with the Eastern championship at stake.

The interdenominational committee in charge of the fifteenth annual sale of articles made by the blind was praised for its work yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in an address at the Farmers Loan and Trust Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street, where the sale is being cenducted.
Harry Hampton Hunt, electrical engineer and vice president of Stone Webster, died yesterday in Boston while on the way to his home in Melrose. He was 69 years old.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told the House Banking and Currency Committee today that he had no fear the proposed housing program would be an expensive operation for the government.
A brilliant cast of international stars started the five-day third annual national Winter sports show and ski meet tonight at the Boston Garden, which was transformed into a real snow setting.
More than $25,000 was contributed last night at a dinner in the Biltmore Hotel to the $6,250,000 New York-Brooklyn campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies.
Diplomatic sources disclosed today that forty-four German prisoners had been deported from Soviet Russia in virtual exchange for two Soviet ship crews recently released in Spain.

160th St (10-2647), n e cor of Jackson Ave, 79x48; Robert B. Honeyman Jr. to Kasoff Realty Corp, 2,382 Jerome Ave; mtg., $35,000. 3d Ave (9-2306), e s, 28 ft s of 144th St, 28x85; Charles A. Furthman to Charles D. Sprung, 353 N High St, Mt. Vernon. Beaumont Ave '(11-3103), e s, 204 ft n of 183d St, 111x100; Dollar Savings Bank to Anthony Colangelo. 2,330 Crotona Ave.

An apparent defect in the Federal statute for the retirement of Federal judges by which the President might appoint their successors without confirmation by the Senate is receiving the attention of members of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Publication of the long-awaited price list of the Bituminous Coal Commission has brought little immediate change in the general market situation here, industrial purchasing executives specializing in coal purchases said yesterday.

After engaging a taxicab for a ride of about five miles from Manhattan to Brooklyn, a fashionably dressed young man last night held up the driver at the point of a long blue-steel revolver for a sum of $3.75 and made a leisurely escape in a R. M. T. subway.

Ralph K. Guinzburg, president of the I. B. Kleinert Rubber Company, was tendered a testimonial dinner last night at the Biltmore Hotel by about 350 leaders in the notion and novelty and allied industries in recognition of his business, civic and charitable activities.

" Excellent fishing" off Garden Key in the Dry Tortugas kept the yacht Potomac with President Roosevelt aboard at that spot today. Herbert G. Theurer, White House postal inspector, flew on a naval plane to the Potomac, carrying a pouch of official mail and documents for the President's attention and returned here in the afternoon with another pouch of letters and data which Mr. Roosevelt was dispatching to Washington.

Mayor La Guardia and Mrs. La Guardia enrolled under the American Labor party emblem when they voted at Fifth Avenue and 109th Street in the last election, it was disclosed yesterday at the Board of Elections.
Jock Hutchinson of Golf, f11., former British open champion, took the lead at the thirty-six-hole flag today in the seniors' professional golf tournament.

Twenty-eight Manhattan football players, bearing the good wishes of their fellow-students and friends, left yesterday afternoon for a 1,500-mile trip to Tulsa, Okla., where they will meet a powerful University of Tulsa eleven Saturday. With four consecutive victories to their credit, the Jaspers will wind up a hard ten-game schedule against the Golden Hurricane.

THE only thing Germany can't do for itself is to recover its colonial empire. It could (conceivably)-take over Austria, pinch off from Czechoslovakia certain desirable areas, march across a friendly Poland into the granary of the Ukraine, force an unfriendly Poland to give back the Corridor.

Telling a policeman he can "go to hell" is "a simple declaration of fact," Magistrate Rudich ruled in Pennsylvania Avenue court, Brooklyn, yesterday in dismissing a charge of disorderly conduct against Miss Margaret Greenberg, 26 years, old, a bookkeeper, of 796 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn.

Dexter W. Fellows, press agent of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey circus, was buried here this afternoon in the presence of hundreds of friends from Connecticut cities and New York, who later organized informally to plan the erection of a permanent Dexter W. Fellows memorial in this city.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 30, unless specified. At San Pedro: Cuyama, Kanawha. Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Washington Yard, via potomac River points.

Trading in beef cuts was slow and prices were weak to lower on better grades in the local market yesterday. Lamb carcasses were steady and cuts steady to higher; fresh pork cuts were steady to higher and calf cuts steady to slightly lower; other classes mostly unchanged. Trading only fair to slow on lamb veal and pork.

The House of Commons today reflected anxiety over the fate of British interests in Japanese - conquered Shanghai in questions put to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden. Mr. Eden said negotiations with Japan were proceeding and that "we have not agreed to anything yet."
J. W. Sparks Co. announce the admission to general partnership of Charles K. Wynn and the retirement of E. Schuyler Jackson Jr. as a general partner.

With the closing of the Maine deer season in all but two counties, Washington and Hancock, officials .of the Fish and Game Commission were confident that a final checkup would reveal, that more deer were shot in the State this year than ever before.

As a result of the nation-wide scare produced by investigations into Cagoulards [Hooded Onesl activities, great quantities of arms and munitions are now being abandoned in empty lots, parks and other similar places.

Planning a musical of unusual proportions which will embrace names outside of motion pictures, Samuel Goldwyn today signed Fannie Hurst, the novelist, to write the story for next year's program. Jascha Heifetz will be one of those featured.

Mrs. Jeanne Marie Decroix Schley of this city and Grasse, France, widow of Grant Barney Schley, was married to John Frederic Byers of Sewickley, Pa., and Aiken, S. C., yesterday afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. J. Denniston Lyon of 825 Fifth Avenue. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. William I. McKean of Bernardsville, N. J.
Mrs. Nettie Streit, whose late husband was a well-knbwn baker of matzoths, died yesterday at her home at 2 Brighton Ten Court, Brooklyn.

Van Lingle Mungo, recalcitrant speedball pitcher of the Dodgers who, at the moment, tranquilly was cooling his heels in distant Pageland, S. C., today became the most talked of man in baseball as major and minor league bigwigs assembled here for the opening of their annual Winter conclaves.

The New York Curb Exchange has received notice that the interest due yesterday on the York Railways Company's first mortgage and collateral trust 5 per cent gold bonds is being paid, but that no provision has been made to meet the principal, which also was due yesterday.

Included in the Bronx properties reported yesterday by brokers as having been sold were two apartment houses in' Davidson Avenue. The estate of Max Dick sold the five-story, multi-family dwelling containing eight stores at 2,460 Davidson Avenue, corner of Fordham Road.
Spanish Government reports tonight said the Insurgents lost heavily in five futile attacks on Government positions southwest of Toledo on the west bank of the Tagus River.

A promotional plan whereby residential electric customers of the Consolidated Edison Company may obtain from approved appliance dealers a "merchandise credit" on the purchase of appliances in proportion to the amount of electricity used by them during a month was announced last night by E. F. Jeffe, vice president in charge of sales of the utility, at a meeting in the company's auditorium, 4 Irving Place, attended by 1,000 dealers.

Mr. and Mrs. Artemus L. Gates gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the museum's ten year development program. The dinner was followed by a tour of the Hall of Man, where exhibits were described by Dr. William K. Gregory and Dr. Harry L. Shapiro and plans for the new Hall of Man were discussed.

Livestock movements in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows: HOGS Receipts 22,000 including 8,500 directs. The market was generally 10-15c lower than Tuesday's average; top $8.45;

Amanda Siebert, Coney Island sideshow "fat lady," fell out of bed last night in her furnished room at 2,854 Stillwell Avenue, Coney Island. It required the combined efforts of five heaving policemen to put her back again. She weighs 650 pounds.

As had been generally expected last night, when adjournment was taken, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion pf the world, succeeded tonight in drawing the twenty-third game of his title match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris after a total of fifty moves had been recorded.

EveryBody's AUTOBIOGRAPHY, by Gertrude Stein (Random House, $3). A sequel to "The Atoiography of Alice B. Toklas." ALL MEN ARE BROTHERS, by Shui Hu Chuan (Joahn Day, $3.50). A one-volume edition of the classic Chinese novel, ranslated by Pearl Buck.
The National Labor Relations Board intervened today in the week-old strike of the United Automobile Workers of America against the Ford Motor Company.

An appeal has been made to Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace that no 1938 sugar quotas be allotted to owners of more than 500 acres so that small growers may be benefited. E. Martinez Rivera, a lawyer and sugar grower, pointed out to the Secretary that the law prohibited corporate ownership of more than 500 acres.
Sumner M. Cross, president of the Columbia Life Insurance Company for eighteen years, died in his home today after a brief illness. He was 58 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bonner Wilson of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Earle Wilson, to Charles Clement Richardson, son of Mrs. Paul A. Richardson of Cedar Acres, Lynnhaven, Va., and the late Mr. Richardson.

Princess Mechtilde Lichnowsky, whose late husband was German Ambassador to Great Britain at the outbreak of the World War, today was married to Major Ralph H. Peto. She broke their engagement thirty-seven years ago. The couple met again recently at Monte Carlo.
The following securities have been suspended from dealings in the New York Stock Exchange: W. T. Grant Company capital stock without par value, Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc.;

The Association of Life Insurance Presidents will open a two-day convention at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel today. It will be attended by executives of companies with 60,000,000 policyholders and invested assets representing $25,000,000,000.

Charging Mayor La Guardia with an attempt to exercise political control of the New York City Housing Authority in a manner wholly unauthorized by law, Langdon W. Post, chairman of the Authority, said last night that the Mayor's attitude is a grave deterrent to public support of the entire housing movement.

The Merritt Parkway may not be formally opened for traffic from Norwalk to the New York line before July 1, in the opinion of John A. MacDonald, Highway Commissioner, who came here today for a conference with the Parkway Commission.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reduced yesterday the price of copper in the domestic market from 10.75 cents to 10.50 cents a pound. Producers, however, continued to quote 11 cents for the metal, with the result that there are still two prices for domestic copper.

" Hooray for What!" Hooray principally for Ed Wynn. After six desperate years on the radio, the perfect fire-chief fool has returned in a Broadway carnival that opened at the Winter Garden last evening.
The East New York Savings Bank sold to Sophie Zimmerman the thirty-five-family apartment house at 1,073 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, and the banquet hall at 434 Hopkinson Avenue to Isaac Lifschitz.

The Tennessee Valley Authority's "unified plan" for the development of the navigation facilities of the Tennessee River and its tributaries will cost the Federal Government $425,650,000 more, six times more, than the anticipated commerce on the stream for the next thirty years will justify, according to Major Rufus W. Putnam, Chicago consulting engineer, who testified before a three-judge Federal Court here today.

Senator Vandenberg of Michigan is "not a candidate" for the Republican Presidential nomination and "should not be put in a false position," he wired to friends here who today proposed a Vandenberg-forPresident club.

The Chinese Minister this morning called on Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, and made a strong oral protest against Italian recognition of Manchukuo. Count Ciano limited himself to taking note of the protest.

Clarence V. Lodge, who for fifteen years was Monroe County Superintendent of the Poor, died last night at his home in Sterling. Mr. Lodge, who was 84 years old, received injuries in a fall six weeks ago which eventually caused his death.

An unusual run of victories by last year's champions fell just short of the mark in the women's contract bridge tournament this afternoon; and' the national team-of-four title for women. was won by the team of Mrs. James Lemon, Mrs. Martin R. West and Mrs. A. P. Stockvis of Washington and Mrs. Ralph Young of Philadelphia.

The stock market was predominantly cheerful today and most sections advanced. Gilt-edge issues improved, while among the foreign loans Chinese bonds strengthened on word of a better customs position. Transatlantic stocks acted undecidedly, with United States Steel and International Nickel closing slightly lower.

A liquor price war in the midtown section in which the price of at least one brand of Scotch was cut more than $1 a bottle and bottled-in-bond liquors were sold at retail at 50 cents under the price levels established under the Feld-Crawford Act, had the industry upset here yesterday.

Foreign buying of hides on an advancing price trend in the Buenos Aires market in the last few days has brought a stronger tone to the American- market, - where some prices have been advanced in quoted lists although buying at the rise here has been limited.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Waitstill Orvis and Mrs. Hardin Orvis will wive a tea dance in the ballroom of the Colony Club on Dec. 20 to introduce to society Miss Barbara Nazro Orvis, daughter of Mrs. Hardin Orvis.

Maintaining an unbeatable pace, Joseph Wiener, professional at the 42 Broadway Gym, and his college partner, Stanley Galowin of N. Y. U., carried off the final of the proamateur invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Heights Casino yesterday, after one of the finest exhibitions of team play seen during the three years that the competition has been staged.

Charles P. Randolph Jr. of suburban Oak Park, vice president in charge of engineering for the Edison General Electric Appliance Company, died yesterday at Rochester, Minn., after a short illness. He was 49 years old.
Exports of zine in October of this year amounted to $166,453, compared to $190,238 in September, but were $35,990 more than in October of 1936, the Commerce Department reported today.

When P. T. Moore pulled out the final game of his match with the veteran Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club to win 15-6. 12-15, 18-17 last night, the Montclair Athletic Club kept its season's record clean in Class A of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association and remained at the top of the standing with six straight victories.

Samuel Gordon, alleged to be a confidence man, specializing in marriage swindles, was under arrest here today as a fugitive from justwice pending action of the Jersey City police, who want him on a charge of grand larceny filed by Lena G. Fisher of 29 Bentley Avenue, Jersey City, according to local authorities.

Observing that the slump in business had become more pronounced in November, the National City Bank in its monthly bulletin, issued yesterday, points out that whatever business men may think concerning the duration of the recession, it is plain' that they are taking no more chances. than they have to, but are following policies of the utmost prudence.

Sale and removal of buildings on the large hill at North Beach Airport in Queens were authorized yesterday by the Sinking Fund Commission at a meeting in City Hall. The bluff is to be leveled in connection with the expansion of the airport, since it is a hazard to pilots landing from certain directions.

Nearly $5,200,000 of the State's levy of $19,361,025 for 1937 was withheld today as railroads operating in New Jersey paid $14,191,594 in taxes. The carriers now are suing in the Federal Court to restrain the State from collecting the full amount levied for the preceding three years, contending that the sum is exorbitant and the method of valuation improper.
The New York State unemployment insurance law differs from the laws of forty-five other States in that strikers may draw unemployment insurance benefits under it, an analysis disclosed yesterday.

Following announcement of the first two private final crop estimates of the season, each showing an increase of several hundred thousand bales over last month, several commission house interests liquidated holdings in advance of next week's annual government report and prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday lost 4 to 6 points, or 20 to 30 cents a bale.
The deadline for dealers in securities to renew their licenses to operate next year in Pennsylvania expired at 5 P. M. today.
