Buying improved substantially at the Spring shoe showing, which closed yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, but many manufacturers were disappointed at the total volume booked since the opening on Monday.

A Soldier's Medal was awarded by the War Department today to Edward J. Brennan of Hoboken, N. J., private in the Coast Artillery Corps, for heroism in rescuing a soldier from drowning at Neptune Lock, Fort Slocum, on the night of July 26.

Leading Article, 6-year-old gelding owned by B. P. Woodson, kept intsat one of the season's most consistent records when he won the six furlongs of the West End Handicap at the Fair Grounds today for his fifth straight triumph.
The National Labor Relations Board was asked today to decide whether Hollywood screen writers were artists or employes entitled to the protection of collective bargaining under the Wagner Act.
Mr. and Mrs. Lee P. Fiero have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jane Haliday Fiero, to Alvin W. Rowe of West Orange, son of Mrs. Jeremiah Rowe of Harrisburg, Pa.

J. C. Denton of Tulsa, Okla., attorney for the Mid-Continent Petroleum Company, in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case, declared today in his argument for the defense that if a conspiracy existed, it started in the office of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, who was Petroleum Administrator under the NRA.

Prospects that naval construction work will continue in the Camden yards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, thereby removing the danger of closing the plant and discharging 5,000 workmen, brightened today when the corporation was found to be the low bidder for the building of a seaplane tender and- a destroyer tender.

To avoid the possibility of injury to bathers, as well as motorists on Ocean Parkway at Jones Beach, the Babylon Town Board voted today to prohibit rabbit hunting on all town land south of the parkway.

With allowance made for the holiday, the daily average of electric power production declined last week against normally rising seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index receded to 97.4 from 100.2.

The Bowery Savings Bank extended these five mortgages: $19,950 on 93 Baxter St, 91-93 Baxter St Realty Corp. owner, to Aug. 1, 1942 3 1/2-4 1/2 per cent; $15,450 on 317 Madison St, Kelbank Realty Corp., owner, to Aug. 1, 1942, 3 1/2 per cent; $882,200 on 325-339 W 45th St, Abram Adolph, owner,

Glen Lee, Nebraska middleweight, who. has done most of his fighting in California, made his first appearance in New York at the Hippodrome last night and gained a decision over. Walter Woods of the East Side. A crowd of 3,400, which paid $6,948 to witness the battle, saw the two middleweights fight ten slashing rounds in which there was action evry minute.

The 1,850-ton destroyer leader Somers, first of the new class of flotilla leaders, was commissioned yesterday morning at the navy yard in Brooklyn. The new man-of-war, ninth of the 1,850-ton type, is modified in design from her predecessors of the Porter class.

Miss Barbara Jeanne Day, daughter of Mrs. E. McCormack Day of this city, and of Irving Meade Day of Greenwich, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest to Edward John Noble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Noble, also of Greenwich.

West St, 388-90; 88x28.1 for 1-story stores; Silver Dollar Properties, Inc, 715 11th Ave. owner; William 'Shary, architect; cost, $7,500. Adterattons Worth St, 71-3, to 5-story offices and showrooms; Estate of Charles Fred Hoffman, Inc, 258 Broadway, owner; Jardine, Murdock Wright, W. H. Wright, successor, architect: cost, $5,000.

Among the passengers who sailed yesterday for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary was Ernest A. Simpson, former husband of the Duchess of Windsor, accompanied by his bride, the former Mrs. Mary Kirk Raffray. Their names were not on the printed passenger list.

Commander Ben Moreell of the Navy Civil Engineer Corps, who had been public works officer of the Naval Operating Base at Pearl Harbor, became chief of the Navy Bureau of Yards and Docks today, with the rank of Rear Admiral, succeeding Rear Admiral Norman M. Smith, who is retiring at his own request.

Mrs. Helen Dorothy Case Conahan, wife of John J. Conahan, 32year-old correspondent for a commercial institution, appeared yesterday to be the niece and only heir of Frank DeForrest Case, recluse who died on Monday in a furnished room at 509 Manhattan Avenue, leaving bank deposits of more than $90,000.

The annual December Ball in aid of the Grosvenor Neighbqrhood House of 321 East Forty-ninth Street will take place tonight at the Ritz-Carlton. Committees of younger members of society have been active for several weeks in planning the ball, net proceeds from which will assist Grosvenor House in. maintaining an extensive welfare program for its locality.

A lastminute warning today from Secretary Wallace that the Senate farm bill might cost the Treasury more than $1,000,000,000 a year, coupled with numerous requests for modifications 'of the measure, caused some Senate leaders to despair of its passage this week and others to question whether it could be disposed of during the special session.
Assertions that the standards of radio programs must be improved (by law, if necessary) were made today by George Henry Payne, Federal Communications Commissioner.

MANHATTAN BROWN, MARY (Aug. 26). Estate, $1,510. To Ambrose Brown, executor, 34-57 82d St., and Anna Posser, West Norwood, N. J., $400 each five specific bequests. BROWN, RENICK S. (Oct. 31). Estate, $1,800. To Cora L. Gascoigne, cousin, 832 Webster St., Needham, Mass. Henry L. Gascoigne. same address, executor.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck denied yesterday a motion made by Edward A. Malloy of Scranton, Pa., for permission to examine officials of P. Lorillard Company, Inc., so that he might obtain facts concerning the $200,000 Old Gold cigarette picture puzzle contest.

President Lazaro Cardenas today completed half of his six-year tern, declaring he wanted Congress to pass all pending legislation rather than giving him extraordinary powers to legislate ad interim as has long been the Mexican custom.

Donald Jones, vice president and director of William A. White Sons, one of New York City's' oldest real estate firms, was appointed today by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, as adviser on project managewent, operation and development.

The Duke of Windsor as recently as October planned to cooperate in the publication of an authorized biography, it became known today in a statement growing out of the issuance last Monday of the denial that he had planned such a course.

Turf fans found $33,577,171 to bet on the horses in Maryland this year. Figures compiled by the State Racing Commission showed today the handle for the, States four, major tracks represented an increase of- more than $4,000,000 over -last year. Bowie, :last of the four to close, wound up its Fall program yesterday.
The coaches have been squawking that the defense has become top dog in college football and, this time at least, the figures say they don't lie.

Immediately upon being paroled from Elmira Prison yesterday morning, after serving two and a half years of a ten-year-sentence for grand larceny, Marty Portnoy, 23 years old, who said he was a salesman and gave his last address as 1,737 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, was arrested on a New York City warrant charging him with a first-degree robbery in connection with a jewelry-store hold-up July 29, 1935.

Plans for a housing project an one of the largest unimproved realty holdings in the Sutton Place. section of Manhattan were announced yesterday when builders purchased from the Henry Phipps Estates the vacant property at the southwest corner of Sutton Place and East Fifty-seventh Street.

Opening its production season, the Yale University Drama Department presented tonight in the University Theatre "Coronation," which had as its theme the tragedy of Maximilian and Carlotta in Mexico, 1867.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses submitted to Mayor La Guardia yesterday plans for beach improvements at Coney Island, Far Rockaway and South Beach, Staten Island, comparable with his development of Jones Beach, which has been hailed as a model. Mr. Moses estimates that the shorefront improvements would cost about $16,150,000.

A drive by Democratic leaders in the House today revived Administration hopes that the Wages and Hours Bill, one of the four objectives listed by President Roosevelt in his call for the special session of Congress, might be enacted before adjournment.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday designated Arthur Meyer, member of the New York State Board of Mediation, to sit as a one-man committee to study conditions at Greenwood Cemetery in Brooklyn, where a strike of employes started Saturday and ended yesterday.

The first of the monthly index numbers, compiled by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., as of Dec. 1, shows a decline in average commodity prices in November of 3 5/8 per cent. The Dec. 1 average is the lowest computed by the concern in eighteen months, or since June 1, 1936. The decline from the year's highest, reached on Jan. 1, is 14 3/8 per cent.

J. J. Slater, shoe stylists and merchants, is opening two Florida stores, one at Miami Beach and the other at Palm Beach. Roger Kent, men's clothing retailers, has opened a store in the Lampoon Building, Harvard Square, Cambridge, Mass. Mal Malone, formerly of the. Roger Kent store in New Haven, is in charge.

Charging that practices in which they engage tend to maintain prices for their products at an artificial level and destroy competition, the Federal Trade Commission today issued an order directing nineteen corporations manufacturing metal window products and their trade association, Metal Window Institute, Washington, to abandon such activities.

The Committee on Civil Legislation of the Chamber of Deputies approved today a draft of a new press law empowering the government, on advice of the Foreign Minister, to ban the export of specified issues of French newspapers and periodicals.

For the first time a foreigner has had the distinction of winning the Prix de Goncourt for novelists when the Goncourt Academy prize was awarded to Charles prize was awarded to Charles Plisnier, a Belgian lawyer, surrealist and poet internationalist, who has been expelled form the Communist party.

Six hundred employes of the General Motors Corporation in the company's assembly plant here were laid off today for an indeterminate period, according to an official announcement from the plant offices. Those who were discharged were almost

Webb Institute's basketball team, opening its season at home last night against Wagner College, went down to defeat, 41-33. Harry Gott, Wagner center, was high scorer with five field goals and two fouls for 12 points, while Walter Michel turned in 10 points for the losers.
Stormy scenes in Parliament today marked the feud between the liberal democratic elements and the adherents of the Hungarian Nazi movement.

Alarmed by an increase in degenerative diseases as a result of business pressure, a group of underwriters announced yesterday a plan to encourage conservative living among the larger buyers of life insurance as a means of prolonging the life span and making them more acceptable risks.

For a week utility circles have been alive with discussions of the proposed terms of peace between the Federal Government and the power-and-light industry. Intimate details of the conference between President Roosevelt and utility executives have now been revealed, but up to the present there is little evidence that anything like a definite basis for agreement has been reached.

The engagement of Miss Frances Stewart Whitall, eldest daughter of Mrs. Thomas wistar Whitall of Acorn Farm, this place, and the late Mr. Whitall, to John Leonidas Calvocoressi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonidas J. Calvocoressi of New York and New Canaan, Conn., has been announced by her mother.

Led by Captain Sam Cohen, who scored 16 points, the DeWitt Clinton High School quintet, defending city P. S. A. L. champion, opened its season by downing St. Simon Stock High, 33-19, in a non-league battle on Clinton's floor yesterday.

Max J. Kramer, president of the Hotel Edison, announced early this morning that he had signed contracts for a syndicate which he heads to take over the French Casino, theatre restaurant, which closed last week.

A caucus of the six American Labor party members of the new City Council paved the way yesterday for the election of B. Charney Vladeck for minority leader as Morris L. Ernst submitted a preliminary report to Attorney General Bennett nailing proportional representation as a success despite "propaganda to the contrary."

The undertone of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was irregular yesterday and the trading pace was much slower than on Tuesday. Trading, in fact, was the smallest since Nov. 1, last, dwindling to $5,849;300, compared with $8,485,175 on Tuesday.

Mr and Mrs. David Kane of Far Rockaway have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Schilling Kane, to Phillip Millburn Nelson, son of Mr. and Mrs Frederick A. Nelson of Jamestown, N. Y.
Motorists who have made inquiry concerning 1938 automobile license plates were told yesterday by Charles A. Harnett,

The appointment of John J. Seery, chief inspector of the Police Department, as first deputy police commissioner is expected to be made by Commissioner Valentine at the beginning of the new year., it was learned yesterday from an authoritative source.

Following further intensive and, for the most part, futile bartering, the major leaguers, who have been hovering on the outskirts of the minor league baseball convention, finally moved into the spotlight today with completion of the first player transaction of outstanding importance.

The University of Pittsburgh was one of the buyers yesterday afternoon at the auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., of Americana from the collection of the late Joseph B. Shea of Pittsburgh;

Pat Hanley, Boston University's football coach, is having schedule trouble. Having elevated the Terriers from the depths-they won only four games in the four years preceding the Hanley regime-to a ranking of national respectability with twenty victories, eight defeats and four ties from 1934 through 1937, Hanley finds some opponents balk at renewing contracts.

Rene Doumic, permanent secretary to the French Academy and director of The Revue des Deux Mondes, died today of a heart attack. Though in poor health, recently he had worked yesterday in his offices of The Revue.
Paul Dwyer, 18, pleaded guilty today to strangling Dr. and Mrs. James G. Littlefield, reversing an earlier plea of not guilty, and was immediately sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor.
The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday reduced the price of copper from 10.5 to 10 cents a pound in the domestic market. On Wednesday it had reduced its price from 10.75 to 10.5 cents.

In behalf of 64,000,000 holders of life insurance policies, for whom the insurance companies of this country now hold $26,350,000,000 of invested premiums, the annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel with an inquiry: "What does America need in the field of economics?"

The National Retail Druggists Association is "already under investigation" by the Federal Trade Commission for its alleged price maintenance activities, according to a letter sent to Representative Emanuel Celler by W. A. Ayres, chairman of the commission, the text of which was learned here yesterday.
Wheat prices were on the upgrade in North American markets today, moving up nearly 3 cents a bushel at the extreme, following receipt of bullish estimates on the new crop in Argentina.

Exports of iron and steel products and scrap from the United States in the first ten months of this year exceeded shipments for the corresponding period of 1929 and established other export records for this type of goods, the Metals and Minerals Division of the Department of Commerce reported today.

Even after allowance had been made for the holiday, a sharper recession than anticipated seasonally took place in lumber output last week, and the adjusted index slumped to 58.7, its lowest point since July 6, 1935.

Most listed bonds on the New York Stock Exchange followed an uncertain course yesterday in somewhat heavier trading volume. United States Government obligations showed little response to the official announcement that there will be no new-money financing by the Government this month.

Resumption of athletic relations of Notre Dame and Michigan, broken in football twenty-eight years ago, appeared certain tonight as coaches and athletic directors of the Western Conference gathered for the opening of the Big Ten meeting tomorrow.

Funds under the United States Housing Authority's $526,000,000 slum clearance program will be earmarked tentatively at a conference here Tuesday, Nathan Straus, administrator, told representatives of various cities today.

The Bank of Canada reported today for the week ended yesterday a decline of more than $17,000,000 in deposits of chartered banks and a drop of about $13,000,000 in holdings of Dominion and Provincial short-term securities. Notes in circulation were down more than $1,500,000.

Norfolk St. 2R, 25x100; Sol Fisher to Gertrude Stempler, 1,456 E 14th St, Brooklyn (1). 8th St. 3T6-37S E. 39.7x97.6; executor will of Abraham Landau to Bertha Balmuth, 248 Hewes St. Brooklyn, subject to all liens, consideration $1.000..

Lester C. Leonard, special Assistant Attorney General for New Jersey, contended in a brief filed today that a Federal statutory court is without jurisdiction "to restrain or curtail operation of a State law essential to the maintenance of complete government prior to a pronouncement of unconstitutionality."

A new plan for the reorganization of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, the largest of the mortgage guarantee companies to go into liquidation, was submitted yesterday to Referee James A. Martin in behalf of a committee representing about one-third of the $460,000,000 in claims that have been filed by creditors.

Jacob Riis, whom Theodore Roosevelt called "New York's most useful citizen," is still at work in this city and throughout America, and especially at the Christmas season, for it was an article of his in one of the periodicals of his day that led to the first experiment in the use of Christmas seals in the United States.

Twenty-seven persons, including Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein, two city Commissioners, two former city Commissioners, four other present or former city officials and eighteen citizens, were indicted today on charges growing out of land purchases by the city at Port Newark, near the Newark Airport, between May 1, 1933, and May 1, 1937.

One of the season's infrequent double-headers gives first-nighters their choice of two new items this evening, the same being as follows: "Merely Murder," a mysterycomedy adapted by A. E. Thomas from Georgette Heyer's novel, at the Playhouse.
Leading industrial shares rose 1 to 6 points; turnover, 937,180 shares. All groups of bonds steady and mixed ;,transactions, $7,033,025.
John Ingle, New York lawyer, died this morning of a heart attack at the Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. He was 62 years old and A lived at 99 Beach Street here.

In the first of a series of squash racquets matches bringing together men and women stars, played yesterday on the Junior League courts under the auspices of the Women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, the men's team won by 4 to 1.

Giles H. Turnure, deputy commissioner of public works of White Plains, died of a heart attack today at the Taghkanic Manor Hunting Club near Copake, N. Y. His age was 46. He had gone to the club on Tuesday. Ill for several years, Mr. Turnure hunted from a horse-drawn wagon.
A reopening of a Federal investigation of County Clerk Albert Marinelli's actions in the Charles Falci case to determine if he harbored a fugitive was indicated yesterday.

The reopening of the United States Consulate at Bilbao is still held up because Consul W. E. Chapman, who recently became second secretary of the embassy to Spain, refuses to have any direct contact with Antonio San Groniz, chief of General Francisco Franco's diplomatic Cabinet.
One of the largest philanthropic entertainments of the season thus far-the annual December Ball-took place last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton.

Several hundred women attended a commemorative service and tea yesterday marking the twenty-fiftn anniversary of the dedication of the headquarters building of the National Board of Young Women's Christian Associations at 600 Lexington Avenue.

Angered by a remark of his opponent in a debate last night, former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer walked off the platform in the auditorium of the Men's Club, Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, where he and Maurice Samuel, author and publicist, discussed "Anti-Semitism and Zionism."

President Lazaro Cardenas decided tonight to leave the management of 7,000 miles of railroads, recently nationalized, in the hands of the former directors of the National Railroad Compay and the Railroad Lines of Mexico Company.

Harold Fowler McCormick, chairman of the board of the International Harvester Company, disclosed tonight that his daughter, Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard, granddaughter of the late John D. Rockefeller, had adopted a 4-year-old girl from an institution in the East.
Ethel Levey, leading American comedienne on the British vaudeville stage during the World War years, filed a petition for divorce against Claude Grahame-White, pioneer airman.

Seven juniors took their places today on The Associated Press 1937 All-Southwest Conference team selected by coaches and nine sports writers. Three of the seven came from a rugged Texas Christian team, Halfback David O'Brien, Center Ki Aldrich and Tackle I. B. Hale.

Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Dec. 1 unless specified. Acushnet, at Washington Yard. Dec. 2. Argonne, Mare Island Yard to San Pedro. Blue, Guantanamo Bay to Havana, Dec. 2. Brazos, at Pearl Harbor. Case, at Boston Yard.

The dollar value of stock sales on all registered securities exchanges in October increased 14.1 per cent over September, while the volume of sales increased 38 per cent, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Joseph C. Kadane, who practiced law here for thirty-seven years, specializing in corporate real estate and surrogate work, died on Wednesday night in his home at 20 West Seventy-seventh Street after a brief illness.

The marriage of Miss Clara Louise Donaldson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Donaldson of this place, to Robert Hogg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Hogg of Scarsdale, took place this evening in the Pleasantville Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Arthur Campbell, the pastor, performed the ceremony.
These are the 218 House members, listed by States, who signed a petition to force a House vote on wage-hour legislation, all being Democrats, unless otherwise designated:

Nelson Doubleday of New York has posted a check for $450, made out to Chief Game Warden A. A. Richardson, following charges made by Federal and State game wardens of shooting duck over baited fields on the Combahee River.

MANHATTAN BANGHART, OSCAR H. (Oct. 23). Estate, more than 520,000. To May L. Livermore, sister, Cascade. Iowa, two-twentyfirsts of residue; John W. Banghart, nephew, 315 W. Adams St., Chicago, Ill., two-twenty-firsts residue and one-half of decedent's stock in Valentine Son, Inc.;

Voters of 196 municipalities located in thirty-one States approved during November bond issues aggregating $139,345,647 as compared with $5,937,060 approved in October, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

Two Rome newspapers today comment on THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial suggesting economic measures against Italy, Germany and Japan. First is the Giornale d'Italia, which limits itself to printing on its last page about a quarter of a column dispatch giving the views of the Berliner Tageblatt and the Nachtausgabe.
The War Departmerit issued the following orders dated Dec. 1: COLONELS Kelley, R. H.. Infantry, 2 months 9 days leave, April 18, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Harry J. Fishbein and Mrs. Sam Rush of New York won the national mixed pair championship in the American Contract Bridge League's Winter tournament today. They made up an 1124 point margin by which they had trailed the leaders at the start of the final session, and won with points to spare, 311 to 306 over the runners-up.

Lucius Beers has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of Barnard College to succeed James R. Sheffield, who is retiring as chairman on account of poor health, the trustees announced yesterday. Mr. Beers, a senior member of the law firm of Lord, Day Lord, has been a trustee since 1920 and clerk since 1927.

Directors of the United Fruit Company voted to declare a special dividend of $1 a share, payable on Dec. 23 to next Monday's stockholders of record. The regular quarterly distribution of 75 cents, payable on Jan. 15 to stock of record of Dec. 20, also was declared.

Dr. Peter M. Campbell; Unity candidate, defeated A. J. Burnap, Social Credit nominee, in today's by-election to fill a vacancy in the Alberta Legislature. The vote was: Campbell, 3,980; Burnap, 3,210.

Lee Pressman, general counsel for the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced today the organization would throw its full weight into a campaign to break the "vicious anti-union drive of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City."

Active short-covering and scattered new buying in the final hour of trading yesterday, which caused the ticker to run behind the market in the final fifteen minutes, enabled many leading stocks to close the day with net gains of 1 to 4 points.

In the present state of medical knowledge, money now spent to support the sick would prevent their sickness, according to Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

Another ray of light penetrated through the sightlessness and deafness of Helen keller yesterday and gave her a new feeling of "safety." In Supreme Curt in Long Island City, Miss Mary Agnes (Polly) Thomson, the "eyes and ears" of the internationally known deaf and blind writer, was admitted to citizenship by Justice James T. Hallinan.
Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Shumway of Cooperstown, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Julia Sands Shumway, to George Blank, son of Mrs. Elizabeth J. Blank of New York.

A call for an end to governmental "harassing" of business as the best guarantee of business revival and stimulation of employment was made last night by Orval W. Adams, president of the American Bankers Association, in an address at the twenty-fourth annual forum dinner of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Contributions to the United Hospital Fund announced yesterday ranged from a $15,000 anonymous gift to an eleven-cent donation from a Bronx girl. The anonymous gift was announced by Clarence Francis, chairman of the commerce and industry committee,
The native hunters spat tobacco juice into a fireplace today and agreed that yesterday's Senatorial deer hunt "was the longest period the Senators ever went without talking."

Mrs. Ruth Haller Ottaway of New York was re-elected president of the National Council of Women yesterday at the biennial meeting of the federation at the clubhouse of the Beethoven Association, 30 West Fifty-sixth Street. Representatives of large organizations of women affiliated with the council attended from many parts of the country.

Eli B. Felsenthai, retired attorney, the last of the charter members of the board of trustees of the University of Chicago, died yesterday in his home in Winnetka at the age of 79. He had been an honorary member of the board for the last nine years.

A bill which would make the provisions of the Railway Labor Act apply to disputes in the maritime industry, not only among seamen, but among longshoremen and other shore and harbor employes of the industry, was introduced in the Senate today by Chairman Copeland of the Commerce Committee.

On their face, the government's suits against the two large telegraph companies add yet another inconsistency to New Deal policies. A declared purpose is to reduce "excessive competition" between the companies. Yet competition is the object of the Sherman anti-trust laws, newly pressed by the administration, and has long been represented in legislature and in court as the preventive of monopoly and the source of lower prices.
Bob Zuppke said tonight he didn't see why more than 1,200 persons attended a dinner in his honor, because "I'm not the greatest coach in the country."

Mayor La Guardia summarily supplanted Langdon W. Post as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority yesterday by swearing in Lester B. Stone, his secretary, immediately upon being informed that Mr. Post had said he would continue at work until his successor had been named.

The possibility of another flare-up over President Roosevelt's intentions toward the Federal judiciary were seen today in the determination of a Senate subcommittee to search the record of Professor Henry W. Edgerton of Cornell before passing on his qualifications for membership on the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

Gaetano Vecchiotti, Italian Consul General in New York, gave a farewell luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Count and Countess Vittorio Ciano, who will sail tomorrow on the Rex for their home in Rome.

Aparently working on the theory that the best way to counteract the Giant twoteam system is to hold practice on the double-header principle, Coach Ray Flaherty sent his Washington Redskins through two workouts today on the polo field at the Westchester Country Club.
PEPITA, by V. Sackville-West. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.) Family memoirs by the author of "The Edwardians."

Martha Westman bought 1,623 York Ave from the Sandor Realty Corp, Martin Hersh. vice president, for a consideration indicated as $8,000 over a first mortgage for $17,000 and gave back a purchase money second mortgage for $5,500, due in five years at 5 per cent, with half yearly amortization during the last four years of $150 to $250.

Hope for two navy fliers, missing since their plane nosed into breakers off Virginia Beach last night, waned today after a twenty-fourhour search by combined naval, Coast Guard and CCC forces proved futile.
Visibly pleased by the warm welcome he received on his rain-soaked tour of the prosperous farming counties of Cornwall, Devon and Somerset, King George returned to London tonight on a local train.

Total sales of more than 11,700 independent retail firms in twenty-five States reporting to the Market Data Section of the Department of Commerce showed an increase of 2 per cent in October over the same month last year, it was announced today.
Sir Albert William Wyon, senior partner in Price, Waterhouse Co., famous firm of chartered accountants, died yesterday at the age of 68.

Ashbourne Orange, grand champion steer of the International Livestock Exposition, sold at auction today for $2.35 a pound, 65 cents less than the price paid for the last three kings of cattle. Wilson Co. bought it for the Palmer House, Chicago.
The Board of Tax Appeals agreed today to payment of $666,984 in settlement of a $2,534,338 estate tax claim against the estate of F. G. Bonfils, former Denver publisher.

Class I railroads, exclusive of switching and terminal companies, had 1,133,003 employes at the middle of September, compared to 1,101,643 at the same time last year, a gain of 31,360, or 2.85 per cent, the Interstate Commerce Commission announced today.
Plans were filed yesterday for a motion-picture theatre, store and office building at the northwest corner of Broadway and Seventysecond Street, the site of the Hotel St. Andrew.

Charles A. Klein, 60 years old, head of a Fifth Avenue company of certified public accountants, was found brutally beaten in Central Park last night at about 8 o'clock. With four stab wounds in his chest, inflicted by an awl, and severe injuries to his skull, he was taken unconscious to Metropolitan Hospital on Welfare Island.

The Nash-Kelvinator Corporation yesterday reported a net profit of 63,640,747 for the fiscal period ended on Sept. 30, which amount is after depreciation and taxes, including provision for surtax on undistribute income.

With a mixture of merriment and praise, Mayor La Guardia pinned special Congressionall medals yesterday on nine members of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition at City Hall in the presence of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, commander of the expedition to the South Pole.
Members of the Peoples Mandate 'Flying Peace' Caravan visited President Juan Demostenes Arosemena and Foreign Minister Jose E. Lefevre today after arriving unexpectedly from Colombia last night.

The trade agreement promulgated under the Feld-Crawford act fixing the retail prices of Philco radios and the trade-in allowances which dealers can make is invalid because it is widely and flagrantly violated, R. H. Macy Co., Inc., charged yesterday. The charge is contained in the department store's answer to injunction proceedings instituted to compel it to observe the prices fixed in the agreement.

The the broker-dealer registration of Albert A. Hall, doing business as the A. A. Hall Company, 60 Broad Street, New York, has been revoked by the Securities and Exchange Commission following a consent by Mr. Hall to the entry of a decree enjoining him from further violations of the Securities Act of 1933, the com mission announced today.

Three bomb-laden planes hopped off for Lanao Province today to aid troops battling Moro outlaws. A fourth plane carried General Paulino Santos, Chief of Staff of the Philippine Army, and other staff officers.

Engineering construction awards last month amounted to $165,581,000, or 12 per cent lower than October and 2 per cent above November, 1936, according to The Engineering News-Record, which reports that private construction last month was 47 per cent below the preceding month and 10 per cent below November, 1936.

Stanley G. Murray, vice president and chief engineer of the Richardson Scale Company, died yesterday of a heart attack while on a business trip in the northwestern section of the State. Herbert Godfrey, a business associate, was with him when he was stricken.

Mr. and Mrs. Walworth Pierce of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Walworth Pierce, to Donald McKellar Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald McCallum McKellar of Garden City, L. I.

Colonel and Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan entertained with a luncheon today at their home on Hypoluxo Island. Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogle of New York have opened Trailside, where their guest for the season is her cousin, Mrs. Annie F. Breniser.

The New York Rangers yielded second place in the American group of the National Hockey League tonight by dropping a furiously fought battle to the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 1, before about 7.500 spectators.

An audit by the State Department of Agriculture of the books of New York City's major milk distributors indicated the companies had been operating at a loss since last March, representatives of the distributors said yesterday.

Jock Hutchison, 54-year-old former British champion, captured the professional golfers' inaugural $2,000 seniors' tournament today, carding the only par round of the event to finish with a fifty-four-hole total of 223.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, met today for the first time in seven months to talk about the terms of peace that may settle organized labor's two-year civil war.

Eighty Columbia athletes and managers were named to receive awards for participation in varsity and freshman football and crosscountry, it was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, graduate manager of athletics.

The question whether, under the Motor Carrier Act, a trucking operator who leases rather than owns the trucks that carry his freight is a common carrier by motor vehicle is raised by the application of Freight Forwarders, Inc., for a certificate authorizing operation as a common carrier by motor vehicle, according to a brief in behalf of Trunk Line Rail Carriers.
An amended five-day week bill for city employees designed to overcome Mayor La Guardia's objections to the original measure was adopted yesterday by the Board of Aldermen in City Hall.

The marriage of Miss Liljan Johanna Larsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anton Larsen of Brooklyn, to Robert Romain Edge, son of Mrs. Edith R. Butler of Asbury Park, N. J., and of the late George W. Edge, took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fettretch, 137 East Thirty-eighth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ernest W. Mandeville.

The Mackay Radio Corporation and the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company were accused of violation of the Wagner act in a complaint issued yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, after an investigation of charges filed against the companies by the American Radio Telegraphists Association, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

New York City will be asked to pay part of the other-than-labor costs of maintaining the four WPA Federal Arts Projects here, Paul Edwards, administrative officer of the projects, announced yesterday.
The Illinois Central Railroad Companywas found "not to be in need of financial reorganization in the public interest at this time" in a decision announced today by the Interstate

The Chicago Board of Trade today asked the Commodity Exchange Administration to "bring within the scope of the law" the so-called gentlemen's agreement limiting the open speculative grain holdings of an individual to 5,000,000 bushels.

Riding to hounds, society's traditional sport, has come under the dog quarantine imposed on Nassau County by the State Department of Health and the bark of hounds catching the scent of the quarry will not be heard again until health authorities are satisfied that no dog in the county has the dreaded rabies.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Assignment to desk duty continued: James J. Cooke, from 18th Division, M. O D., Brooklyn, to 10th Division. Thomas J. Gillen, 7th Precinct to 18th Division. Michael Carey. 74th Precinct to 76th Precinct.

After public hearings by boards in producing Districts Fourteen and Sixteen, the National Bituminous Coal Commission today issued orders determining and establishing initial classifications of coal for code members in the two districts.

Raoul Ponchon, poet and member of the Goncourt Academy, died here today at the age of 89. Stricken with a pulmonary congestion Sunday, he yesterday, for the first time since his election in 1924, missed the meeting of the academy, which awarded the Goncourt Prize.

Mrs. Dora Katlowitz of 531 Crown Street, Brooklyn, for many years a prominent figure in Jewish charities in Brooklyn, died yesterday at the age of 71. Mrs. Katlowitz was a founder of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and the Jewish Maternity Relief Society, of which latter she was president for many years. She was the widow of Morris Katlowitz.
Miss Martha Willamina Huffman, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. F. Harl Huffman of this place, was married here tonight at the West Side Presbyterian Church, of which her father is pastor, to the Rev.

The National Safety Council today attacked President Roosevelt's proposal to slash Federal appropriations for highways. W. H. Cameron, managing director of the council, described the President's message to Congress on Wednesday as "a distinct menace" to progress in reducing America's automobile toll which for 1937 will approximate 40,000 killed and 1,000,000 injured.

Dr. Demitrios Sicilianos, Greek Minister to the United States, formally presented 175 volumes of modern Greek literature to Columbia University at a dinner last night in the Columbia Men's Faculty Club.

Princeton University's varsity hockey forces launched their 19371938 campaign in an impressive fashion tonight on the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink by registering a decisive 7-1 triumph at the expense of the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York.

Continued weakness in the price levels of farm products, foods and hides and leather products precipitated a further sharp decline in the Department of Labor's wholesale price index in the week ended Nov. 27, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Braniff Airways, Inc., today filed a complaint with the Interstate Commerce Commission against Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., charging "unfair competition," to the detriment of the aviation transport industry.

Miss Jane Preston, daughter of Mrs. Charles Leonard Preston of this place and the late Mr. Preston, was married here this afternoon in the Hitchcock Memorial Church to S. Gordon Apgar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Keller Apgar of Orlando, Fla., by the Rev. Dr. George H. Smyth.

Three days after their famous match at Fresh Meadow, which was stopped by an overflow crowd on the ninth green, Babe Ruth met John Montague, "mystery golfer" now on the Coast, and beat him, the former home-run king of baseball admitted yesterday.
The present business slump cannot be classed as a "depression," Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told the Senate Banking Committee today.

Spokesmen for the School Board at Minersville indicated today that the board would appeal the decision of Federal Judge Albert B. Maris in which he held here yesterday that pupils refusing to salute the American flag because of religious convictions could not be expelled from school.

Leopold Stokowski's second marriage was dissolved here today when Judge William E. Orr granted, an uncontested divorce, on grounds of cruelty, to Mrs. Evangeline Brewster Johnson Stokowski. The suit, filed yesterday, was held in a closed session at her request.

Sabueso, the Argentine thoroughbred owned by Bing Crosby and Lynn Howard, captured the Paicines Rancho Handicap at Tanforan today, defeating Top Radio by a length. Primulus was third, a nose back. Sabueso traveled the mile in 1:38 to equal the track record established by Top Flight last year.

Search was started today for John Henry Adams, 23, Dartmouth College junior, who has been missing since Sunday. Robert K. Thomas of Garden City, L. I, a fraternity brother, told Police Chief Hallisey that Adams went to bed in the Delta Upsilon house Sunday night and disappeared before Monday morning.

At the end of her journey from Seattle to accept the emblem of the national crochet championship conferred on her last week, Mrs. Frank Hayward was too fatigued to be flustered at being the center of attention yesterday at the American Woman's Association, where her masterpiece is on display this week with many others.

After five months of negotiation, Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, entered into an agreement yesterday covering 200 building service and maintenance workers in the Thirty-third Street store and warehouses of the company.

The parish bazaar arranged by members of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, headed by Mrs. Charles S. McVeigh and Mrs. Reginald L. Auchincloss, which opened yesterday at the Memorial House, 207 East Sixteenth Street, will continue there this afternoon and evening. Proceeds will be used for the redecoration of the Memorial House.
Fred Warren Weller, a retired vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and a close friend of the late John D. Rockefeller, died at his Winter home here early today.

The antiSemitic campaign in the Mexican press is increasing rather than diminishing. The newspaper Novedades carries a statement by the middle class Nationalist League asserting that the Government immigration quotas for 1938 for such countries as Poland and Czechoslovakia "will permit another wave of Jewish immigration."

The first of the Junior Assemblies for this season will take place tonight at the Ritz-Carlton. Among those who will give dinners beforehand for their daughters are Mrs. Elton S. Wayland for Miss Lucy Wayland, Mrs. Kalt Treadway for Miss Margaret Treadway, Mrs. Henry A. Clark for Miss Elizabeth Clark and Mrs. Charles W. Bowring for Miss Millicent Bowring.

AFTER the usual preliminary skirmishes, the A baseball magnates milling around in the ivory mart finally began making a few trades and purchases. The trades rarely are of the earth-shaking variety that rock the seismographs in university cellars from coast to coast. But the preliminaries are generally hilarious.

Emphasizing the need for identification at point of sale, to maintain volume, representatives of twenty-four cotton, rayon and linen converters authorized appointment of a committee of seven to develop plans for formation of a Fashion Merchandising Guild, at a meeting at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday.
Conference of the American Association of Museums, Hotel WaldorfAstoria, 10 A. M. "Children's Museum's," Mrs. Dean C. Osborne, chairman.

Marcel Dupre, eminent organist, will appear in recital toni t in the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church, Tompkins Avenue and McDonough Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Dupre is the organist of St. Sulpice in Paris and of the Paris Conservatoire.

Building authorities who contend that the increased costs of materials and labor have caused the recent decline in construction activity and in home buying generally are convinced that the chief hope of Reducing the price of dwellings lies in large-scale operations and the resultant economies.
The closing of a lease for an entire floor in the Bartholomew Building, at 205-17 East Forty-second Street, by the New York State Deapartment of Social Welfare was announced yesterday.
Dr. John Lewis Lane, who was serving his sixth term as Mayor of this place, died today at his home following an illness resulting from a stroke suffered last August. He was 71 years old.

More railway executives, including D. J. Kerr, president of the Lehigh Valley; J. B. Hill, president of the Louisville Nashville, and E. E. Norris, president of the Southern Railway, told the Interstate Commrece Commission today that increased freight rates for the whole country and increased passenger rates for the Eastern roads are the remedy for the financial plight of practically all of the railroads of the country.

The record of the Survey Associates, which was fittingly celebrated last night in New York, has been literally "twenty-five years of social discovery." Inheriting their task from such sturdy progenitors as Edward Everett Hale, who fifty years ago was editing LendA-Hand;

Frederic Ewig, a director of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and vice president in charge of Eastern operations, announced yesterday his withdrawal from active service in the company due to his health. He will continue, however, as a director during the next eighteen months before resigning from the board.

Henry A. Harris of 201 Palisade Avenue, supervisor of operations for the WPA in Hudson County and a construction engineer, died this morning in Christ Hospital here after a brief illness. He was 55 years old.
Stars from Manhattan's basketball teams of the past will oppose the varsity in Manhattan gymnasium tonight as Neil Cohalan inaugurates his ninth consecutive season as Jasper mentor.

Tenant Fiorello La Guardia and Landlord Al Smith started the day with a pleasant chat yesterday as the Mayor settled down to his first day's work in his temporary executive chambers in the Empire State Building, which he will occupy while alterations are made at City Hall.

Harry Lawrence of the credit department of James Talcott, Inc., factors, has been placed in charge of the credit department of the Scottish American Company, Chicago, correspondent company of Talcott.

With five out of six classifications showing a loss, newspaper linage in November dropped sharply, according to a compilation based on Media Records Figures yesterday. The total for last month was 9,916,786 lines, a decline of 15.3 per cent from the corresponding month of 1936.

Consideration by the House of the Wages and Hours Bill on Dec. 13 was assured today when 218 signatures were obtained to the petition to discharge the Rules Committee from further consideration of the measure.
The Senate received a request today to amend the Merchant Marine Act so that officers will not have to dress for dinner.
The t Canadiens handed the Bruins their first National hockeyy League defeat of the season tonight, scoring a 2-to-0 victory on goals in the first and third periods.

Two transactions in Bronx realty disclosed yesterday the purchase of plottage in Riverdale for apartment house sites. Michael and Armino Campagna bought a tract of about 43,000 square feet of vacant land on Tibbett Avenue, between 230th and 231st Streets in the Riverdale area.

Wool goods markets here continued to mark time last week, with clothing manufacturers and retailers concentrating on clearances of Fall and Winter apparel, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday.

In Keeping with the annual custom of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the Postoffice Department cooperating, mail carriers in the rural sections this week are scattering about 750,000 "pig cards" in producers' mail boxes.

The Megliss Milli, the community council of the Coptic Church, will meet immediately to discuss the appointment of Abuna Abraham as head of the Coptic Church in Ethiopia and the attempt to make the Coptic Church there independent of the Coptic Church in Egypt, under whose jurisdiction it has been since the fourth century. This has caused resentment here.
Louis Marks, formerly associated with the Goodwin Goodywin Management Corporation for about twenty years, has joined the sales and appraisal department of Proops Management, Inc.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, noting "with growing anxiety the continued recession of business and the steady increase in unemployment," called yesterday for "drastic economies" in Federal appropriations and immediate legislation "to reverse the downward movement."

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities throughout the nation for the five-day week ended on Wednesday declined 25.2 per cent to $4,604,181,000 from the $6,154,592,000 in the corresponding week of five days last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Still alert and active, Edward Mandel, Associate Superintendent of Schools, probably the "dean" of the city's educational force, begins his fiftieth year of service in the New York City school system today.

With the end of their confinement gradually approaching, the six-day bicycle race riders went through their paces last night with the same vim and daring they have shown since the grind got under way last Sunday.
Stillwell Ave (16-4417), n e cor of Demeyer St, 150x100: Stillwell Homes, Inc, to Knickerbocker Federal Savings Loan Association, 640 Madison Ave, due as per bond: S20.900.

Nearly five hundred airplanes were assembled at the Municipal Airport and surrounding fields here today in preparation for the beginning tomorrow of the annual all-American air manoeuvres which will open Miami's Winter travel and sports season with an extensive program of airplane racing, acrobatics and militarv tactics.
A "fore runner of Christmas party" will be staged tomorrow by Uncle Robert, safety crusader, at 9 A. M. at the Chaloner Theatre, Ninth Avenue between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets.

Miss Margaret Whittemore, a founder of the National Woman's party and internationally known as a suffragist leader, died here today of a heart ailment in her fifty-third year. Born in Evanston, Ill., she came to Santa Barbara many years ago with her father, James Whittemore, a patent attorney of Detroit.

Representatives from the forty-eight States have been called to meet in Chicago on Dec. 20 and 21 to discuss the welfare of consumers of gasoline and oil by Assemblyman Harold B. Ehrlich of Buffalo, N. Y., chairman of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee to investigate the petroleum industry, it was announced yesterday.

Four parading Japanese soldiers were wounded, two seriously, when an Oriental, believed to have been a Korean, threw a hand grenade at a marching column on Nanking Road near the corner occupied by Sincere's department store a few minutes after 1 P. M.

Frederick B. Ryan Jr., recent winner of the Princeton Club tournament, was the top seeded player to advance in the opening round of the National Squash Tennis Association's annual Fall scratch tournament at the Harvard Club yesterday.

Miss Betty Lou Harris, a waitress, died in the New Rochelle Hospital late last night of a fractured skull suffered when she was beaten Nov. 20 in an inn on the Boston Post Road here, police said today.
The Chase National Bank headed the successful banking syndicate yesterday in the sale of a new issue of $2,500,000 of land purchase, bridge and improvement bonds of Nassau County, L.. I.

Sweeping changes in the Army Council, the supreme British military directorate, were made tonight by Leslie Hore-Belisha, Secretary of State for War, in a dynamic fashion that recalled the actions of David Lloyd George when he was dealing with the army chiefs during the critical days of the World War.

The business of the General Motors Corporation in foreign markets has increased 25 per cent over last year, according to James D. Mooney, president of the company's export division, who arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Rex after six weeks in England, France, Belgium, Germany and Italy.
The retail liquor price structure, supported since last Spring by the State's Feld-Crawford act, continued crumbling yesterday in the second day of a spreading price war among retailers.

THIRD RAIL MAINTAINER--Salary, 70 to 75 cents an hour, pension, vacation (70 cents an hour for first year). Vacancies. five; others from time to time. Ages, through 45 on Dec. 21. Applications received 9 A. M., Tuesday, Dec. 7, to 4 P. M., Tuesday, Dec. 21, Room 1400, Municipal Building, Manhattan. Subjects and weights:

The Metal Window Institute declared in a statement today that a Federal Trade Commission order against it and nineteen manufacturers of metal windows "was not a contested order but was the result of protracted negotiations."

The private motor car has only a limited use in cities if the owner cannot leave it unattended for a reasonable time after he has arrived at or near his destination. It has an even more limited use if he is allowed to leave it in such a position and for such a length of time that it becomes a serious obstruction to traffic.

Further curtailment last week in all lines of economic activity brought the index of business in the Pittsburgh district to a new low level in the current recession, according to the bureau of business research of the University of Pittsburgh. Pronounced decreases were reported in all the major lines of production in both rail and river shipments, and in most branches of retail and wholesale trade.
Manager Jack Adams of the floundering Detroit Red Wings announced today that he has obtained Alfie Moore, goalie, from the New York Americans of the National Hockey League.

Edouard Daladier, Minister of National Defense, tonight told the Chamber of Deputies that France was seeking to scrap that section of the Versailles Treaty which forbids her to fortify her frontier with Switzerland.

One heartening bit of news appeared in Wall Street yesterday when it was announced that all employes of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange would receive increases in salaries at the beginning of next year.
The University Club's Class A squash racquets team scored its fifth straight victory of the season last night, vanquishing the Princeton Club, 4 to 1, in a Metropolitan League match.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Charlotte Glover Roberts of this place to William Van Kirk of Southport and the University Club in New York. Their marriage will take place in January and they plan to spend the Winter in New York.

The British Color Card Council has been a potent factor in introducing a number of successful colors in the market there in the last six years, George C. Innalls, secretary of the organization, said yesterday in a talk before the style trend council of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc.

The Salle Santelli trio, composed of the Misses Dorothy Grimmelmann, Barbara Cochrane and Mildred Stewart, defeated the Waverly F. C., 5 to 3, last night on the strips of the East Building of New York University, to win the national junior foils championship.
James W. Carmalt, chairman of the National Mediation Board, died at his home today after an illness of several weeks. He had served on the board since 1934.

The thousands of properties acquired by banks through foreclosures during the depression are gradually being sold back to the public and housing managers will be fewer and more important in the future, James C. Downs Jr. of Chicago, presidentelect of the Institute of Real Estate Management of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, said today.
Contracts for the purchase of 238 airplane engines at a cost of $2,491,819.69, and for 229 light chassis trucks with cargo bodies, to cost $512,547.80, were announced today by the War Department.

The Norman Stewart Hall Football, a new award "for outstanding service to Yale football by a member of the Jayvees," was presented to Richard Ward Day of Boston at a dinner at the Yale Club last night.
Mrs. Olga Riddle, 45 years old, of 1,090 University Avenue, the Bronx, was injured fatally early last night when struck by an automobile while crossing Sedgwick Avenue at University Avenue.
The 200 marines in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn have new headgear, and for once, a "leatherneck" is sheepish.

Five hundred and seventy shop stewards and delegates of the Coal Trimmers Association, an affiliate since Wednesday of the Inland Boatsmen's Union, a C. I. 0. group, at a meeting last night at Lexington Hall, 109 East 116th Street, voted to call a strike of the several thousand members of their organization this morning in an effort to obtain a written agreement on working conditions from the Coal Merchants Association of 1,270 Sixth Avenue.

The marriage of Miss Audrey Shampan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Shampan of 2 East Eightysixth Street, to Bernard Aronson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Aronson of 1,016 Fifth Avenue, took place yesterday in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein performed the ceremony.
SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against ARROW FROCKS, INC., 134 W. 37th St.--By Empire Carriers Corp., for $5: Olian Bros., upward of $300; Olian Cantor, upward of $300.

The city of Boston and the Boston Port Authority filed today a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission contending that there is no evidence before the commission in the Philadelphia case that Boston's port rates are preferential.

Samuel D. Riddle, owner of War Admiral, said tonight he was undecided whether his 3-year-old champion would start in the $50,000 Widener Challenge Cup race at Miami, Fla., or the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap at Los Angeles.

IT was Dorothy Parker, if memory has not gone woollcotting, who once spoke of V. SackvilleWest's enthusiasm for showing tourists through Knole, her famous ancestral home--at $3 per volume. There's quite a lot about Knole in the entertaining pages of her latest book, "Pepita,"* the story of the romantic Spanish dancer who was her grandmother.
Mr. and Mrs. Loyall Farragut Sewall of Bath, Me., have joined Mrs. Walter Evans Edge at the Ambassador. Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas has come from Newport to the Drake.

Adverse criticism of Brazil's suspension of its foreign debt payments by creditors was discussed here today simultaneously by several daily newspapers. These carry editorials defining Brazil's position which may be accepted as a semi-official expression.
The government collected 42,176,670 marks in the "Reich escape tax" during the first seven months of the current fiscal year from persons emigrating or escaping from the Reich.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The total of loans and investments of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City continued to shrink in the last week, according to the condition statement of the banks as of Wednesday, which was published yesterday.
The Presidential fishing party on the yacht Potomac off the southern end of Florida is still enjoying "excellent" fishing, James Roosevelt reported to the temporary White House offices here today.

Buddy Clark, in 175 W 76th St: Sylvia Gerson, in-467 Central Park West; Samuel Zipser, in 375 Riverside Drive: Ralph Riemenschneider, in 76 W 86th St; H. Hornstein, In 697 West End Ave; Apartment Renting Company, Inc, agents. Benay Venuta, in 107 Riverside Drive: Mark Rafalsky Co. agent.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes in francs:

German efforts to mediate in the Chino-Japanese dispute were seen in the sudden arrival here from Hankow yesterday of the German Ambassador, Oskar P. Trautmann. Herr Trautmann avoided newspaper men and the German Embassy spokesman would say only that Herr Trautmann's trip was for the purpose of "inspecting" the situation here.

The program given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was distinguished by one of the best performances, if not the best, that John Barbirolli has given since he came to this city. The work involved was Brahms's D major symphony, which he also conducted last season, but in which, yesterday evening, he showed a significant and very interesting growth since the previous occasion.
Turpentine firm, 26 1/2c; sales, 80; receipts, 409 barrels; shipments, 642 barrels; stock, 37,943 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 360; receipts, 745: shipments, 1,705; stock, 83,194.

Winston Churchill's solicitors, Nicholl, Manisty Co., have issued a writ for alleged libel against Messrs. Heinemann, publishers, and Geoffrey Dennis, author, in connection with a passage in Mr. Dennis's book, "Coronation Commentary."

Three properties in Jersey City formed the basis for an exchange transaction announced yesterday. The four-story brick apartment at 208-05 Harrison Avenue, on the corner of Hudson Boulevard, was sold by N. Fisher, Inc., to Barnet Holding Company, which gave in part payment the three-story store and dwelling at 537 Newark Avenue and the two-story brick apartment and store building at 207-07A Mallory Avenue.

The Rev. Alfred B. Oates, until recently pastor of St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church, 30 West Sixteenth Street, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after an illness of more than five months.
Mrs. Dunshee D. Battin of Montecito has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Patricia Battin, to Walter Trusdale Rodman, son of Mrs. Walter T. Rodman. also of Montecito.

In a speech which could be interpreted as throwing his hat into the ring for the Presidential or Vice Presidential nomination in 1940 on a Farmer-Labor basis, or at least sending up a trial balloon, Mayor La Guardia, fresh from his reelection triumph with labor support, last night emphasized the national importance of the farm problem at a public dinner in the Hotel Biltmore.

The annual stag party in observance of the opening of the "721" Men's Club at Bonwit Teller yesterday afternoon was attended by more than 500 members of the club and their guests. The club, founded by the company three years ago with 100 members, now has a membership of 1,500.

Public offering will be made today by Distributors Syndicate, Inc., of a new issue of $1,150.000 of cumulative convertible preferred stock of $10 par value of the Manufacturers Trading Corporation. The stock will be priced at $11.50 a share.

The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange announced yesterday that, beginning on Jan. 1, increases in salaries of an undisclosed percentage would be granted to its employes. The rises were voted by the board of managers at a special meeting.

Ray A. Brunner of Schenectady, a junior, was selected as Syracuse University's varsity football manager for 1938 at the Fall elections today. Shephen Cheney of Manlius was chosen freshman pilot, with assistant positions going to Arthur Gabriel of Syracuse and Roger Mabie of Port Ewen.

Mrs. Constance E. de Bower, former stage actress, was married yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock to Jacques Achille Louis Raffray, an insurance broker. He was divorced recently from the former Mary H. Kirk, a school friend of the Duchess of Windsor, who is now herself married to Ernest Aldrich Simpson.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 20,000, including 6,500 directs. The market was strong to 10c higher than Wednesday's average.
After adopting a program of urgent procedure, the Chamber of Deputies began discussion of the budget today with the prospect of making rapid progress.

Intersectional ice boat racing, stilled since before the World War, was discussed last night at the organization of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association, first body of its kind in this section of the country. The proposal even has a Rose Bowl aspect of East against West.

Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos headed for Warsaw tonight for the first of a series of visits to France's Eastern and Central European allies designed to bring them in line with AngloFrench efforts for a general diplomatic settlement with Germany.

Sixteen new factories and major expansions by thirteen other manufacturing plants highlighted the industrial picture in Southern California during November, according to the Southwest Business Review, released today by the Chamber of Commerce.

Max J. Kramer, president of the Hotel Edison, acknowledged yesterday that he had not signed any contract to reopen the French Casino and that an announcement saying he would, made public by the hotel early in the morning, was false.

The spectacle of the Congressman who throws his hat in the air for a balanced budget, and then fights like a tiger to obtain larger appropriations for his own constituents, has become so familiar that it is cheering to read such a statement as Senator Bailey made yesterday.

Police Commissioner Valentine vigorously condemned the present system of "arresting, convicting and incarcerating" young offenders yesterday and declared that society' whole approach to the problem of juvenile crime required a change from punitive to educational methods.

Trading was fair to slow yesterday. Steer cuts sold unevenly; calf weak to slightly lower; other classes traefa meats unchanged. Kosher business was slow with considerable quantities of all classes carried over from Wednesday's market as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Testimony that George (Bugs) Moran, Chicago gangster, threatened to take Patrick Corcoran "for a ride," about a year before the Minneapolis labor leader was ambushed and slain here, was given today at the Corcoran inquest by Frank Dorrance, a milk driver.

George A. Sigman, division sales manager for the John C. Winston Publishing Company and former graduate manager of athletics at Lafayette College, died in Jefferson Hospital today after an illness of five weeks. His age was 59.

Real estate transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday included sales of properties by savings banks. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to the 1,432 Bryant Avenue Corporation, Nathan Ribler, president,
The Spanish astronomer, Professor Jose Comas y Sola, died today after a long illness, at the age of 69. For twenty-six years he was president of the. Spanish-American Astronomical Association.
The Senate debated the Farm Bill, received the Copeland bill making the Railway Labor Act applicable to the marine industry and recessed at 5:21 P. M. until 11 A. M. tomorrow.
Stipulations by two New York distributors of medicinal preparations to cease making certain representations concerning their products were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.
David Lloyd George today warned the British Government against making any "thieves bargain" with Germany which would give the Nazi Reich a free hand in Europe or elsewhere.

The season's first Italian opera, none other than "Aida," was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, bringing back surging Latin melody, the gaudy panoply of "grand opera" and frequent, often intrusive, applause and bravos.
Life insurance presidents yesterday began a two-day convention in town. In addition to representing, by our news account yesterday, 60,000,000
Bacterialaden bombs dropped on London and other British cities by enemy aircraft will be dealt with as part of the government's precautions against air raids, it was revealed today.

Count Harry Kessler, the first German Minister to Warsaw and a close friend of Marshal Pilsudski, died here today. Count Kessler chose to exile himself to France with Hitler's advent, having allegedly fallen into disgrace over his friendship with Walter Rathenau, on whom he wrote a book.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Woolsey Freeman and their daughter, Miss Dorothy Freeman, of Riverdale-on-Hudson, will give a dinner tonight in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Dorothy Miller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Miller of Greenwich, Conn., and her fiance, Rector Thomson Davol of Stamford. Some of the guests will go later to the Junior Assembly at the Ritz-Carlton and others will remain in the Persian Room for dancing.

Dr. Carl Koller, the eye surgeon, who in 1884 at the age of twentyseven, introduced cocain as a local anaesthetic in eye operations and thus opened up the era of local anaesthesia for operations in the various branches of medicine and surgery, will celebrate his eightieth birthday anniversary today.

Probably not since the big memorial exhibition at the Newark Museum, two or three years ago, have so many examples of Pop Hart's work been available as are now to be seen at the Keppel Galleries, 71 East Fifty-seventh Street. A large collection was formed by Miss Jeane Hart, the painter's niece.

The protective committee for refunding mortgage bonds of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway Company has asked Oliver E. Sweet, director of finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission, for an extension of time from the hearing scheduled for Dec. 14, it was learned today.

Lucien P. Locke, vice president of Outdoor Advertising, Inc., 60 East Forty-second Street, New York, died in a hospital here today after a long illness. He was 37 years old. He maintained his residence at Greenwich, Conn., but was passing the Winter with Mrs. Locke at Ponte Vedra, near here.

The Texas Company has announced sale to the Universal Oil Products Company of a non-exclusive right to grant licenses under the former's oil-cracking patent rights. Patent infringement suits which the Texas Company had been prosecuting against certain licensees of Universal Oil will be discontinued, it was said.

A formal protest against the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to strikers was registered yesterday by employer representatives in the advisory council of the State Labor Department's division of placement and unemployment insurance.

For the first time in almost three months, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices advanced in the week ended on Tuesday, reaching 86.8, compared with 86.7 in the preceding week and 87.6 a year ago.

Five Royal Air Force bombers rose through the rain and mists of Plymouth Harbor today to begin a tour from which they will return six months hence. This reconnaissance squadron, under Wing Commander K. B. Lloyd, will go to Australia to assist in the celebration of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the founding of New South Wales.
The members of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association lost no time getting everything ready for the coming season when they held their annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

" The Citadel," by Dr. A. J. Cronin, will be Metro's next venture in London, the studio announced today when assignment of the leading role was made to Elizabeth Allen. Miss Allen, who has been featured in a number of Hollywood films, "The Tale of Two Cities," "Looking Forward" and others, is now in London, while Dr. Cronin is here cooperating on the preparation of the script.

Recoganizing to conserve United States Navy contracts for the benefit of 1 both creditors and stockholders, the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd.. today filed a petition in the Federal court under the terms of the amended Bankruptcy Act.

Business picked up a bit at the major-minor league baseball mart today. In one of many deals, the Cincinnati Reds sold Outfielder Hub Walker to Nashville. Chattanooga purchased Outfielder Johnny Gill from San Francisco.
Lady Elizabeth Percy, one of Queen Elizabeth's trainbearers at the coronation, was married to the Marquess of Douglas and Clydesdale today before 1,700 guests in St. Giles Cathedral..

Lansing Parmelee Reed, corporation lawyer, died yesterday at his home, 158 East Seventy-first Street, of pneumonia. Mr. Reed, who had been ill nine days, was a partner of John W. Davis, once Democratic nominee for President, in the law firm of Davis, Polk, Wardwell, Gardiner Reed, 15 Broad Street. His age was 55.

The leasehold property known as 48 Main Street, Hempstead, L. I., has been sold through the Brown Company, broker, to the Crown Drug Company, Inc. There is a two-story business building on the 25-by-100-foot plot. The lease runs for seventeen years from Feb. 1, 1938, with a total aggregate rental of $175,000.
The Navy Department issued the following orders today under date of Nov. 30: REAR ADMIRAL Webb, U. R., (MC) detached, San Diego, Calif., Jan. 15; to home relieved from all active duty.

A mortgage of $500,000 has been arranged With the Franklin Savings Bank on the 14story building at 485 Park Avenue by Hoffman, Snyder Co.. Inc.. and Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. The loan runs for three years with interest at 4 per cent and provides for semi-annual amortization payments.

Demonstrating that a new style of billiards makes no difference when played with the same type of balls on the familiar table, Willie Hoppe jumped into a commanding lead by taking both of yesterday's blocks of his 71.2 balkline match with Jake Schaefer at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

During the week ended December 1 member bank reserve balances decreased $43,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $64,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $14,000,000 in money in circulation, offset in part by increases of $7,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency and a decrease of $26,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Twelve members of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party's youth organization appeared in court today to answer charges of homosexuality which were chiefly directed against the absent thirteenth codefendant--the "Foreign Minister" of the Sudeten German party, Heinz Rutha, who killed himself soon after his arrest early in November.

By a victory of 5 to 0 over Jackson Heights, the Midston House team retained its position at the head of the standing in the Eastern Squash Racquets Group 2 tournament yesterday. Midston House has four victories and no defeats.
Art tree Jarrett, orchestra leader, filed suit today to divorce Eleanor Holm, the former Olympic swimming star who is planning to become the bride of Billy Rose the showman, according to the latter.

Joe Jossel, who is retiring as president of the Garment Salesmen's Guild after three years in that office, was tendered a testimonial dinner last night at the New Yorker Hotel by the guild and leading manufacturers and contractors of the dress industry.

On Dec. 9 W. W. Norton will publish a "World History of the Dance," written by Dr. Curt Sachs and translated from the German by Bessie Schonberg, vice president of the American Dance Association. The book traces the history of the dance from its beginnings in the Stone Age to the present.

The American Bar Association announced today the results of a referendum of its members on a child labor amendment. With fewer than half of the association's 31,000 members voting, 7,513 favored and 6,126 opposed the constitutional - amendment process in general.

Nebraska's gridiron opportuniststhey whipped Indiana on the first scrimmage play, came from behind twice to beat Minnesota and almost downed mighty Pitt-placed five men on The Associated Press Big Six all-star football team, announced today.

The Virginia Coal and Iron Company has notified holders of the Keokee Consolidated Coke Company's purchase money mortgage, and deed of trust 5 per cent fiftyyear bonds, due on July 1, 1959, that there has been drawn by lot for redemption on Jan. 1, 1938, at par, $13,000 of these obligations. Payment will be made at the office of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company.

The tale of a mysterious witness who came all the way from Niagara Falls to New York City at his own expense to answer a magistrate's court subpoena was unfolded yesterday by Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in a letter to all city magistrates warning them to confine their subpoenas to New York City.
Being a prudent fellow, George Abbott has not thrown the office safe into his production of Bernie Angus's "Brown Sugar," which was acted at the Biltmore last evening.

One of the healthy symptoms of a free press is that there is no news quite so hot as an attempt to suppress news. This fact is illustrated by the experience of Mr. Walter E. O'Hara, who until this week was the publisher of The Providence Star-Tribune. Mr.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. gave a formal opinion today that all State officials, whether judicial, legislative or executive, are subject to the State personal income tax. He thus upheld the law passed by the 1937 Legislature providing for the tax on such officials.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers. now on active duty with the CCC is. with his consent, continued on active duty until the date set opposite his name: Capt. Paul W. Barclay, Q.M.-Res., June 1T.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mrs. Grace E. Taylor of Auburn, R. I., and St. Petersburg, Fla., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Avis Taylor, to C. Dudley Ingerson, son of Mrs. Henrietta Dudley Ingerson of Cranston, R. I.

Manhattan's Tulsa-bound football team stopped off for a workout here today before proceeding on the last lap of its 1,500-mile journey from New York to the Oklahoma oil center for an intersectional battle with the University of Tulsa's powerful eleven Saturday.
