Following a setback of $1.50 a bale from recent high marks, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange developed resistance yesterday and ended with an improvement of 5 to 10 points. Early liquidation attracted more support than earlier in the week and,

Emi Klamt and her daughter, Ada Verowa Klamt, both of Berlin, lost the suit they filed last year to establish their right to ownership of a process for making photographs in natural colors. Judge John C. Knox yesterday dismissed the action against American Natural Color Films.

Dr. W. T. Duvel, chief of the Commodity Exchange Administration, announced today that cotton futures transactions on Dec. 1, on the New York Cotton Exchange, the New Orleans Cotton Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade aggregated 128,800 bales.

One test of musical comedy, we have always felt, is whether it breaks out into song or breaks down into it. "Blossoms on Broadway," which was planted at the Criterion yesterday, falls squishily into the unfortunate second cater gory.

The resignation of Cary D. Terrell, vice president of the American Car and Foundry Company, was announced yesterday. Mr. Terrell, who had served the company thirty years, resigned because of ill health.

Two hundred and fifty resident students paid tribute to Fordham's greatest football team last night at a victory dinner in the university dining hall on Rose Hill. The Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J., president of Fordham; the Rev. John W. Tynan, S. J., faculty moderator of athletics; John F. Coffey, graduate manager, and Coach Jim Crowley and his staff attended the enthusiastic gathering.

The stock markets here, occupied with settlements, were extremely quiet today. Several sections suffered from profit-taking. Gilt-edge issues lost ground and foreign bonds were irregular. International shares turned dull, reflecting the lower levels in Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel declined.
Engagement of $1,894,000 gold in Canada for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was the first shipment of gold from Canada to be reported since Oct. 27.

Three John Brown memorial murals, painted for the Torrington postoffice by Arthur S. Covey, were unveiled today at exercises at which Oswald Garrison Villard, biographer of the leader in the movement for the abolition of slavery, drew the lesson from his life that "it is the weapons of the spirti that advance humanity and not violence and destruction."

Passengers booked to sail for Plymouth and London on board the American Trader of the United States Line include Mr. and Mrs. Roy W. Baker, Miss Elizabeth Craig, Mrs. Florence Curry, Charles Townsend, Miss Veronica K. Hewett, Dr. D. E. Sturgis and Mrs. Mabel W. Liveing.
Julius Bernstein, proprietor of a tobacco store at 1,395 Second Avenue for the last forty years, died late Wednesday night in his apartment over the store of pneumonia. He was 74 years old.

Fed eral Judge Patrick T. Stone re versed his ruling against testimony proposed by the defense today ir the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case regarding con. editions in the oil industry before the alleged conspiracy of the six teen oil companies that are on trial before him and a jury.

A move to have the Senate Farm Bill sent back to committee for further consideration was under way in the chamber today in the wake of warnings from Secretary Wallace that it might cost the Treasury more than $1,000,000,000 a year and recommendations that the bill be made less restrictive of agricultural production and marketing.

The East New York Savings Bank has sold dwellings in Brooklyn as follows: 841 Belmont Avenue to Liberato Blagioti; 785 Sheperd Avenue to Sara Sher; 521 Jerome Street to Lillian Krinsky; 1,040 East Ninety-fourth Street to Charles Balducci and 262 Glenore Avenue.to Salvatore La Rosa.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In Topics of The Times recently you said: "It does seem that Professor Alonzo F. Myers of New York University lets honest indignation carry him too far in saying that if you forbid a woman teacher to marry, you thus thwart her life."

Several dinners and supper parties will be given tonight in connection with the New York debut recital to be given by William Fleming, pianist, at Carnegie Hall as a benefit for Huntington House, a girls' residence club maintained by Grace Church.
An attempt by the National Labor Relations Board to subpoena the records of a magazine which criticized the board met with outright defiance today.

Sidney Wingfield Holland, passenger traffic manager in charge of domestic travel of the American Express Company, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 525 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn. His office was at 65 Broadway. Mr. Holland was 56 years old.

Despite his unsuccessful efforts to have the bow and arrow placed on a legal par with the shotgun in New Jersey, George W. Jacobs of Mountain Lakes, N. J., is going to hunt deer with these weapons during the season which opens on the 17th.

Completing his recent manifesto, the Count of Paris today published in his official newspaper, the Courrlier Royal, another declaration repudiating the Royalist newspaper and the organization known as Action Frangaise.

Affiliation of the American Association of University Women with the Consumer-Retailer Relations Council was announced here yesterday following the meeting of several committees of the council in the Hotel Astor. The council was stated to be working closely with other women consumers' groups, with headway made toward completion of the detailed set-up of the council.

Arthur W. Stanley is in the trading department of Dyer, Hudson Co. as a specialist in bank insurance stocks. The National City Bank has been appointed New York registrar for 1.590,077 shares of common stock of Rayonier, Inc.

Gori Bruno, a senior, has been elected captain of the varsity swimming team at City College, it was announced yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. Gerard Tracy, '38, is the new manager.

Miss Dorothy D. Butler, chairman of the debutante committee for the performance of "Aida" on Dec. 28 for the benefit of the Children's Aid Society's Foster Home Department and Jones Children's Center, entertained with a tea yesterday at her home, 55 East Eightysecond Street, for the other members of the group.

Yachtsmen of the New York Power Squadron held their annual meeting and election last night at the Hotel McAlpin and installed Ambrose Day of the Larchmont Y. C. as squadron commander, to succeed Bertrand H. Perry, a clubmate.

A move to promote a new charter for Newark to replace the commission form of government, long hailed throughout the country as one of the most modern forms of city government, opened today when the Newark Better Government League issued a call to citizens to attend a meeting Dec. 15 at the Essex House.
A house to be built on a plot on Fairway Drive, White Plains, Westchester County, has been purchased by Harold L. Peckham from the Fairway Construction Company.

Captain William A. Maher, secretary of the Associated Marine Workers, announced yesterday that his organization, consisting of about 2,500 employes on harbor craft, would accept a charter from the Committee for Industrial Organization.

At a hearing before the Public Service Commission yesterday the Western Union Telegraph Company revealed that it intends to meet the maturity of $8,745,000 of collateral trust 5 per cent bonds, due Jan. 1, 1938, through the aid of local banks.

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania strolled arm in arm with Sweden's King Gustaf V tonight during a brilliant court reception at the royal palace. Guest of honor at a palace banquet, Mr. Earle presented to the King a letter from President Roosevelt.

Today's events: "Siegfried," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; William Fleming, pianist, Carnegie Hall, evening; Eleanor Steele and Hall Clovis, vocal duet program, Town Hall, evening; Federal Symphony Orchestra, WPA Theatre of Music, evening.

Establishment of a new city authority which could sell bonds to finance the construction of large parking garages to relieve congestion in Manhattan will be recommended to Mayor La Guardia's Committee on Traffic by city officials who have studied the problem, it was learned yesterday.

The four-story industrial building at 426-8 West Fifty-fifth Street was leased by the Chase National Bank and John W. Hannon, co-trustees, to the Abbott Glass Company, which will occupy the property for its main plant and executive offices about Jan 1. John J. Meenan, Inc., was the broker.

Max Silverman, alleged labor racketeer, and his son, Harold, were found guilty early this morning by a blue-ribbon jury in the Brooklyn Supreme Court of charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice. Silverman's son-in-law, Edward Braff, was found not guilty.

The first American industrial arts and crafts expositions ever held in Sweden, Norway and Denmark will open March 21 at Stockholm, April 25 at Oslo and May 25 at Copenhagen and will continue for two weeks each. The exhibitions, which are the result of increasing requests from Scandinavian business leaders for more American goods, will be sponsored by the Philadelphia Commercial Museum.

Former Premier Andre Tardieu's name, which has been mentioned several times in connection with the "plot" of les Cagoulards, became the subject of all kinds of rumors throughout Paris today when it was variously reported he had been called by the examining magistrate and had refused to go and that he had been arrested.

The New York County grand jury declined yesterday to vote an indictment in an investigation of alleged bigamy in the marriage of Lolita Cordoba, dancer and singer, i to Prescott Van Wyck, grandnephew of Robert A, Van Wyck, first Mayor of Greater New York.

The number of foreign skiers in this country was increased yesterday when two crack Norwegian "riders" arrived on the steamship Stavangerfjord of the NorwegianAmerica Line. Miss Ella Gulbrandsen, 17-year-old woman jumper from Aamot Modum, and Olaf Ulland, whose spectacular performances on the towering slides of European Winter resorts have gained him world fame, arrived in this country with hopes of enjoying

Still another setback in the match for the chess champion ship of the world loomed tonight for Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdan when, after a full session, the twenty-fourth game was adjourned with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in complete control of the situation. At that stage the challenger sealed his forty-first move.

The Mexican police believe they have discovered a far-flung plot to run arms via Mexico to Cuba for use in an uprising against Colonel Fulgencio Batista, chief of staff of the Cuban Army, inconnection with the murder in a Mexico City suburb today of Dr. Pedro Pablo Torrado, former Cuban Under-Secretary of Justice in the Grau San Martin government.

Northwest Territory, Canada, Dec. 2.-Preparations for a Winter search for Sigismund Levanevsky and five other missing Soviet fliers are about ready. Aklavik is working furiously in the daylight hours from 10 A. M. to 3 P. M. Radio Operator W. R.

Chile soon will adopt one of the recommendations made at the Buenos Aires Peace Conference, it was admitted today when Congress approved statements made by Senator Maximiano Errezuriz for rewriting textbooks in order to remove all references to other countries which might be considered derogatory.

Southern Boulevard, (10-2729), n e oor oe Leggett Ave, 116x101; Ernest R. Noha to Webco Associates, Inc. 700 Southern Boulevard, mtg $35,000. Elliot P1, (11-2841), a s, 114 ft e of Walton, Ave. 117x100; The Daniel Houlihan Corp to Essex Estates, Inc. 292 Madison Aves, mtg $198,600.

None of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."

Leading all the way, the St. Michael's High School quintet downed St. Augustine's High, 28 to 24, as competition in the Brooklyn Division of the C. H. S. A. A. started yesterday. The game was played on the Thomas McGee Club court.

The Treasury's financing plans announced in part today by Secretary Morgenthau include no "new money" borrowing. The Treasury will offer on Dec. 15 an issue of $450,000,000 of securities. the nature of which was not disclosed by Mr. Morgenthau at his press conference today. Details of the new issue, the only part of the financing plans not discussed by the Secretary, will be announced formally on Monday.

The statement that a "desperate need" exists for "tighter" laws to deal with sex offenses was made before the Joint Legislative Committee on Law Enforcement today by Thomas D. Scoble, chairman of the Westchester County Citizens Committee, which investigated vice.

Surrounded by a police cordon to exclude reporters and the public, Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg, former Vice Chancellor, was married today to Nora Gregor, leading actress of the Burgtheater, with whom his name has long been associated, in the small chapel on top of the Kahlenberg, with its superb view of Vienna and the Danube.
About 13,000 of 15,000 articles of the priceless Peiping Palace treasures, including many pieces exhibited in London two years ago, have been moved from this former capital.

A changed attitude toward business on the part of the government itself will perhaps do more than anything else to enable business to play its part in aiding recovery and to bring forth private capital to provide the needed funds, according to Francis E. Frothingham, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

The engagement of Miss Isabel Mary La Monte, daughter of Mrs. M. Brewster La Monte of this place and George Vaill La Monte of Bound Brook, to Stephen Stuart Chamberlain, son of Dr. and Mrs. Aims R. Chamberlain of Maplewood, has been announced by--her mother.

Mayor Hague, benevolent sovereign of Jersey City, is always jealous to maintain his royal rights. To him Hudson County is The Hague. It must be protected from invasion. So a delegation of C. I. O. intruders has found to its cost.

Patrons of the aviation ball on Saturday night at the Miami Biltmore Country Club, which will climax social events in connection with the tenth annual Miami all-American air manoeuvres, include Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt. Robert W.
William J. Tracy, for forty years an official of the Connecticut Company, the trolley system of the State, died at his home last night after a long illness. His age was 68.

Charles Belous, member of the new City Council from Queens, issued a statement yesterday to clarify his position. He has joined in the caucus of the American Labor party, -but said that he was still a member of the Fusion party and that he had been a member of the American Labor party since its inception.

Testimony in the continued hearing today of the Federal Trade Commission's complaint of price fixing and discrimination made against the Cement Institute and its seventy-five member corporations centered on the government's interest in any price variation, however slight, because of the large amounts of cement required for Federal projects.

Janeen, owned by Mrs. W. D. Bernhardt of New Orleans and ridden by Cornelio Mojena, Cuban rider, won the New Iberia Purse, mile and seventy-yard feature today at the Fair Grounds. Forced to race wide as she came around the leaders entering the stretch, Janeen finished with a fine rush.

It is not in the power of the Secretary of Commerce to fix taxes, or even to make recommendations concerning them in his official capacity. But the statement of Secretary Roper in an address at Chicago is none the less significant as a reflection of the changed attitude of the Administration toward the undistributed profits tax and of its increased concern for the effect of the tax burden as a whole on private business.

Mary Morris, American actress, appealed yesterday to the Actors Equity Association for cooperation in distinguishing herself from Mary Morris, English actress, who recently was signed by a motion picture firm in Hollywood.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. S.-Something new in the sporting annals of South America was recorded today when eighteen association football players arrived here by plane from Iquitos, capital of the Department of Loreto, situated 2,000 miles up the Amazon River.

The Florsheim Shoe Company has leased 1,500 square feet of space at 475 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-first Street, for the sale of women's shoes. The store, which will front 22 feet on the avenue and 70 feet on the street, will open about Feb. 1.

Exports and imports of the United. States by classified groups of merchandise in October, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared in the following tables with data for the preceding month and with October, 1936.

Today's events: Fritz Kreisler, Carnegie Hall, afternoon; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, evening; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Tessa Bloom, pianist, Town Hall, evening; Sergei Radamsky, tenor, Town Hall. afternoon.

While petitions were pending for an increase of one-half cent in railroad passenger-coach fares in the East and for one of 10 per cent in the Pullman Company's rate, the Interstate Commerce Commission granted today to railroads west of the Mississippi River and Lake Michigan increases in passenger fares estimated to yield about $2,500,000 annually.

-Professor and Mrs. Walter B. Kennedy of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carmen Rita Ken nedy, to Robert Thor Lund, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel E. Lund, also of Pelham Manor.

A procession of several hundred school children costumed as medieval pages, courtiers and members of religious orders in the Roman Catholic Church lent a touch of pageantry yesterday to the observance of the tenth anniversary of

Miss Elise Irving van Siclen, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. van Siclen, is leaving Monday for Baltimore, where she will attend the Bachelors Cotillion. She will be accompanied by her grandmother, Mrs. Huntington Tappin, and they will be the guests of her cousin, Mrs. Graham Boyce.
The Senate debated the Farm Bill, as its Banking and Currency Committee heard Secretary Wallace and others on revision of the Housing Act, and recessed at 5:03 P. M. until 11 A. M. tomorrow.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Klenke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Klenke Jr. of Hempstead, to Frank Henry Rath, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Rath of Brooklyn, took place here tonight in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Senator Burke's discovery of grounds for opposing the nomination of Professor Henry W Edgerton of Cornell University to be a justice of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia strongly emphasizes the necessity of amending the act for the retirement of judges of the inferior Federal courts.

Outside France it is difficult to realize the extent of the retreat in the last six months from the advanced positions of the Blum experiment. The broad roof of the Popular Front covers many separate foyers,...

At their regular quarterly meeting yesterday, directors of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company declared a dividend of $3 a share on the common stock and another of $1 a common share. On the preferred stock, an 87 1/2-cent distribution was voted, payable on Jan. 15, 1938, to stock of record of Dec. 28, 1937.

There is no reason, from the point of view of the human organism, why an automobile should not be driven 400 or even 500 miles an hour, Captain George E. T. Eyston, holder of the world's speed records for a kilometer, a mile and many longer distances,

Harlem River Terrace (11-3235). s e cor of Landing Rd, 95x113; Berson Holding Corp to Bural Garage, Inc., 605 W 130th St; mtg $60,000. Heath Ave. 3,060 (12-3257). Ahneman Younkheere, Inc.. to Alex Weinberg, 2.782 .Johnson Ave.

Following the procedure of the national lottery, the Cuban Senate held a drawing this afternoon to decide which Senators should hold office for four years and which for eight years in accordance with the present Provisional Constitution.

The Midwest Coal Traffic Bureau, representing producers of bituminous coal in Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma and Arkansas, joined today in the motion of the National Coal Association asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss the application of the Class 1 railroads for increased freight and passenger rates, in so far as that application applies to bituminous coal.

Universal Bible Week will begin tomorrow culminating with annual Universal Bible Sunday on Dec. 12. Pastors will urge daily reading and a more systematic study of the Bible in church and synagogue schools. Tomorrow is the second Sunday in Advent. In Methodist churches throughout the country there will be an appeal for contributions toward a fund, the goal of which is $250,000 for a China Emergency Relief Fund.
C. W. Dempsey, formerly controller and secretary of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation, was promoted yesterday to vice president and secretary.

Fortythree States in the country showed gains in population during the year ended last July 1, the Bureau of Census announced today. Four States recorded no change, and one--Kansas-fell backward with a loss of 22,000.

PLUTARCH a his elbow, Egypt's story pretty thoroughly in his mind after that long voyage on the Nile through time and space, Emil Ludwig has contrived a smooth and plausible protrait* of Cleopatra. To read about her beauty and her accomplished ways is always a pleasure.
Southern Methodist tackles the football team of Rice Institute tomorrow, and upon its performance against the Owls rests the Southwest Conference title.
St. John's University opened its basketball season by downing the alumni quintet, 50 to 37, before a large crowd in the De Gray Gymnasium last night.

Major Alexander P. de Seversky brought his pursuit plane down at the Havana Army Airfield at 4:28 this afternoon, establishing a record of 5 hours 2 minutes 51 seconds for the flight from New York. This breaks the record of 6 hours 41 minutes set by Lou Reichers on Dec. 2, 1931.

Virgil H. (Bert) Effinger, 57 years old, reported head of the Black Legion, surrendered at his home here today to fight charges of criminal syndicalism filed against him in Michigan. He thus ended a fifteenmonth period of elusiveness since he walked out of an extradition hearing in Columbus Aug. 25, 1936, and disappeared.

Jules Hauvette Michelin, general manager of the Michelin Tire Company, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 56. He was a nephew of Edouard Michelin and the late Andre Michelin, who were credited by France with having invented pneumatic automobile tires.

Paul F. Miller of the General Ice Cream Corporation, Schenectady, was elected president of the New York State Ice Cream Manufacturers Association today at a luncheon of the newly elected board of directors. Mr. Miller, former vice president, succeeds W. J. Monaghan. Buffalo was selected as the convention city for 1938.
Estate, about $2,000. To John and Sarantos Kollianitis, son, Katsouleika, Lacedaemon; Greece, one-half residue each. Gust Camitsis, executor, 1,086 2d Ave.

Edward J. Flynn, supervisor of the minimum wage division of the State Department of Labor, made public today the results of a survey of wages of women and minors in small New Jersey factories, disclosing that an estimated 34,000 work for less than $5 a week and that about 292,000 others receive less than $17.

Lawrence Beck, 53 years old, a retired patrolman, of 115-26 Myrtle Avenue, Richmond Hill, Queens, was sentenced yesterday to twenty years to life in Sing Sing by County Judge Downs in Queens County Court, following his conviction for a second-degree murder in the killing of Patrolman William F. Bosshart, his brother-in-law, on Oct. 9, 1936, in Bosshart's home, at 88-56 207th Street, Queens Village.

After traveling nearly 4,000 miles alone from Norway with her name and destination stitched on her coat and sweater, Elinor Richard, 8-year-old orpnan, whose knowledge of her native language is limited to two words-"Mickey Mouse" -blinked at New York yesterday and said:

Ted Screech, Harlan County, Ky., mine superintendent. was acquitted tonight of a charge that he committed perjury before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee. A Federal jury deliberated an hour and forty-five minutes.
Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos's tour of the capitals of France's friends and allies in Eastern and Central Europe has opened most auspiciously.

John E. Shotford of Eldorado, Ark., who was National Coordinator of Refining under the NRA Petroleum Code, testified today before the Federal court jury that is trying sixteen oil companies on anti-trust law charges that limitation of the amount of gasoline that could be

To SportsEditor of The New York Times: I know that your readers were not a little bewildered upon reading of the record attendance at Chicago's charity prep school game last Saturday and of the amazing feats of Bill DeCorrevont, star of the battle. Hence, here's some information intended to shed some light on the matter.

A well-bred little melodrama mannerly and subdued, the Roxy's "Dinner at the Ritz," deserves at least your polite attention-by which we mean that you should not yawn too openly if you must yawn at all. Produced by Twentieth CenturyFox's British subsidiary,
New York City has agricultural interests of its own. It is wrong to suggest, as our own news story did yesterday,

Langdon W. Post, dismissed Thursday by Mayor La Guardia as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, exercised his prerogative as Tenement House Commissioner yesterday to charge that the Board of Aldermen had made an alteration in the new building code they adopted last July which formed a serious setback to the building of modern low-rent housing.

Max Schmeling and Harry Thomas yesterday signed a contract to cover any contingencies arising from their fifteen-round fight in Madison Square Garden Dec. 13. The new terms were insisted upon as a protection to Schmeling in the event Thomas should win.

Three City Councilmen and a former field employee of the Works Progress Administration were arrested today on charges growing out of the investigation of city affairs. One of the Councilmen is a member of the city committee which is investigating alleged frauds in municipal payrolls.

William F. Costello has been elected assistant vice president of Fish Marvin. The real estate clubs of the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities and the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City will hold a "beefsteak" on Tuesday.

Philadelphia and New York teams led a field of twelve that qualified for the American Contract Bridge League's team-of-four championship tournament here today. The New Yorkers are Harry Fishbein, Philip Abramsohn and Morie Elis,...

Pensioned On their own applications: CAPTAIN-William Kelliher. Traffic Preinct 1, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Aug. 1, 1899. PATROLMAN-James E. Feeley. 19th Division, Office of the Chief Inspector, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 26, 1907.
The Middle Atlantic States Motor Carrier Conference, Inc., filed today a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission holding that Freight Forwarders, Inc.,

Officials of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, largest operating subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced last night in Pittsburgh that present prices on tin-mill products would hold for the first nine months of next year, or from Jan. 1 to Sept. 30.

Restoration of profits to private business by the Federal Government would go a long way toward ending the current slump, Dr. William Trufand Foster, economist and writer, said today at the twentyfirst annual convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards in the Hotel Traymore.

Although shoe advertising budgets are being somewhat curtailed, shoe manufacturers will seek more for their advertising money in 1938 than ever before, according to the Samuel G. Krivit Company, advertising agency specializing in shoe and leather accounts.

Frank Barra, 42 years old, of 831 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, was fatally injured shortly after 6 P. M. yesterday while crossing Twenty-first Street near Forty-first Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, when a passing truck knocked him under the rear right wheel of a bus. Barra was taken to St. John's Hospital in Long Island City, where he died shortly before 1 o'clock this morning.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag dismissed yesterday a $1,000,000 suit brought by Elizabeth Sweinhart. who was known as Betty Randolph when she was a Follies girl, against Louis Bamberger, broker. The action was based on an agreement allegedly resulting from a breach of promise to marry.

Alfred Crane, hydraulic engineer of New York, testified in Federal Court today that in his opinion the Tennessee Valley Authority had failed to carry out the purpose of the law creating it because its enterprise- was development of power resources rather than flood control and improvement of navigation.

Additional evidence was presented at the hearing of the National Labor Relations Board here today in an effort to show that the Berkshire Employes Association of the Berkshire Knitting Mills of this city was a company union maintained in violation of the Wagner act.

With public sentiment aroused over the case and civic organizations joining with Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, in deploring inadequate police protection in the parks, the Police Department started an intensive hunt yesterday for two Negroes who robbed Charles A. Klein, 60-year-old head of a Fifth Avenue company of certified public accountants, after fatally beating and stabbing him in Central Park Thursday night.

While reports yesterday showed United States exports of iron and steel products reached high levels during the first ten months of this year, the Department of Commerce reported today that imports of these products had declined markedly during the same period.

Senate farm legislation for carrying out Secretary Wallace's ever-normal granary plan was denounced by Senator Borah today as an unconstitutional attempt to place the American farmer under complete bureaucratic control and to curtail the nation's food supply at a time when millions were hungry and in need throughout the country.

The Cunard White Star liner Carinthia arrived last night with 455 passengers from a cruise to Nassau and Havana and was twelve hours late due to strong headwinds and high seas for the last thirtysix hours.
Not the least interesting aspect of the stronger stock market of the last two days has been the circumstance that prices rose without anything much in the news to give point to the rise.
The Fascist Integralist party and all other Brazilian political parties were dissolved today by a decree issued by President Getulio Vargas.
Jacob Pfeiffer, an executive of the American Surety- Company of New York and the New York Casualty Company, died on Thursday at his home, 1,809 Albemarle Road, Brooklyn, at the age of 73.
Election of three new vice presidents and increase in the responsibilities of another were announced yesterday by George K. Throckmorton, president of RCA Manufacturing Company.

The Utility Operators Company, New York, has withdrawn its application for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act and has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the act.

It is an honor to be invited to address you, and I feel a particular inspiration when I contemplate the distinguished men of the South who are now, and who have been members of this society, as well as those who have been privileged to address it in these fiftytwo years.

In his first decree after temporarily taking over the Economics Ministry, Col. Gen. Hermann Goering proclaimed that "wage improvements cannot be granted," even though the Four-Year Plan calls on the workers for increased efforts.

After calling Stanley Martin Jr., 29 years old, an automobile salesman, of 305 West Ninety-eighth Street, Manhattan, a "loafer, coward and welcher," Judge Downs in Queens County Court yesterday sentenced him to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing prison, the maximum under a conviction of firstdegree manslaughter.

A dinner to United States Senators who helped defeat President Roosevelt's measure to increase the Supreme Court judiciary will be given by the American Defense Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania tonight, it was announced yesterday.
A new move to have the ban lifted on training tables for football players in the Western Conference was made today when coaches and directors of athletics met with faculty representatives.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union made public yesterday its budget for the calendar year of 1936 of $5,320,586, showing a balance of $942,499 in receipts over expenditures.

Underlying companies of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company began action today in Federal district court to obtain about half of the transit company's $10,000,000 reserve and all net income from the transit system.

Peace parleys between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization were in a virtual state of collapse tonight as the second meeting in twenty-four hours between William Green, president of the federation, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the C. I. O., ended after two hours of futile discussion.

Tuxedo Park will be the scene today of one of the rarest and most exclusive events in American sport. For the first time since 1931 a match for the world championship in court tennis, that royal and ancient game with seven centuries of history behind it, will be held at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.
Dr. Leo F. Adt, Albany eye specialist who was best known as the inventor of the pince-nez style of eye glasses, died in St. Peter's Hospital today after a ten-day illness of pneumonia. He was 71.

Prices of wheat in North American markets advanced today in the early trading, the December delivery on the Board of Trade here rising 2 1/4 cents a bushel from yesterday's last quotation to the highest level since Nov. 1.

Germany's chemical industry, particularly that portion of it devoted to manufacture of synthetic products to replace former imports, has been running full speed ahead in recent months, according to a report from Frankfort-on-Main made public today by the Department of Commerce.
Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that he had accepted the application for retirement, effective Dec. 8, of Captain William Kelliher, in command of Traffic I, Brooklyn.

Villanova had little trouble defeating Rider College tonight, winning 6839. Led by a sophomore flash, Duke Duzminski, who netted 21 points, the Wildcats overcame a 9-15 deficit early in the game, and went on to score as they pleased.

There are just two closings this evening-two, that is, unless some of the other shows that are hanging, as they say, .by a thread, decide to sever their connections with Broadway. But definitely leaving,

The British Government tonight dipped into its rich store of seasoned colonial administrators and pulled out 55-yearold Sir Harold MacMichael, Governor of Tanganyika Territory, to fill the supremely difficult post of High Commissioner of Palestine.

Agents of the special service branch of the Department of the Interior charged with deporting undesirable foreigners asserted today that 22 per cent of the persons deported from Mexico this year had been Jews. It was said that "their form of business often conflicts with that of our nationals" and that many of them therefore are being sent out of Mexico quietly.

The number of new applicants who registered at its free employment bureau in November was about the same as during October and 16 per cent more than in November, 1936, the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations announced yesterday.
The Tashi Lama, exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, died last Tuesday midnight, according to information received from the town of Jyekundo in Western China. His age was 54.

Mrs Grace Healy, 17 years old, whose husband, Joseph, of the same age, is facing a possible first-degree murder indictment in the stabbing of elderly Mrs. Martha Hore nine days ago in the robbery of her grocery at 564 Greenwich Street, was released yesterday as a material witness in the case.

The Rev. L. Humphrey Walz, 27 years old, will officiate for the first time as pastor-elect tomorrow morning at worship in the Second Presbyterian Church, Ninety-sixth Street near Central Park West. He recently accepted a call to succeed the Rev. Dr. George J. Russell, now chaplain of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. Mr. Walz comes from the Presbyterian Church. Oceanside. L. I.

Dr. Oskar Trautmann, German Ambassador to China, today ended a brief visit to Nanking, during which it was understood he talked with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, possibly to suggest terms for peace between China and Japan.
The Corn Exchange Safe Deposit Company has been authorized to open a branch office at 453-455 East Eighty-sixth Street, New York City, the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department said today.

Former Police Captain John J. McNally, who was appointed to the police force in 1881, died yesterday in his home, 395 Fort Washington Ave. He was 80 years old and had been in ill health for some time.

St. Francis College's basketball team of Brooklyn defeated St. Peter's College of Jersey City tonight, 30 to 27. The victors led, 21-15, at half time. Lynch, O'Neill and Lenowics, set the pace for St. Francis.

Leopold Stokowski, conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, expressed resentment today over the charges of "extreme mental cruelty" made by his second wife, Mrs. Evangeline Brewster Johnson Stokowski, who obtained a divorce yesterday at Las Vegas, Nev.

Word was received here last night of the death in San Antonio, Texas, on Thursday of Luigi Solari, shipping executive and former president of the. Italian Chamber of Commerce in New York. He was 81 years old and died of a heart attack.

A mortgage for $727,500 on 11-13 E 26th St, held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, from Madeleine I. Dinsmore, was extended to Oct. 1. 1942. at 41/2 per cent. The Union Dime Savings Bank extended to Nov. 1, 1942, at 5 per cent a mortgage for $15,000 on 511 W 159th St held from Greenab Realty Corp, Abraham Greenberg, president.

The Pittsburgh Baseball Club announced today that Joe Schultz has been obtained from the Cardinals as field director for the minor league interests of the Pirates. Schultz, a native of Pittsburgh, is 43 years old.

Hoping for action during the special session of Congress on President Roosevelt's recommended housing legislation, the House and Senate Banking and Currency Committees speeded hearings on enabling legislation today.
Carl K. Withers, State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, announced today that Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan had approved payment ot a 5 per cent dividend,
Directors of the reorganized Pressed Steel Car Company, Inc., today elected John F. MacEnulty president. George H. Fleming, director and vice president, was elected executive vice president.

Approximately $5,000,000 in gold has been engaged for export to France on the Lafayette, sailing tonight, it was reported yesterday in Wall Street. This would make a total of approximately $30,250,000 in gold shipped to France since the first week of November.
Alabama today placed three players on the 1937 All-Star Southeastern Conference football team selected for The Associated Press by coaches and sports writers.
Dr. Charles V. Paterno of Stanwich Road, Greenwich, has purchased for $135,000 Round Hill, a noted elevation which has given a name to an important section of Greenwich.
The Atlantic City Sea Gulls regained first place in the Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League tonight, defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 5-1.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 964,000 bales, against 866,000 a week ago, 802,000 two weeks ago, 781,000 three weeks ago and 832,000 a year ago; of which American 538,000 bales, against 434,000 a week ago, 362,000 two weeks ago, 335,000 three weeks ago and 294,000 a year ago.

A California planist in his late twenties, William Fleming, played his first New York recital last night at Carnegie Hall. The occasion was a benefit for Grace Church's Huntington House, and was attended by a sizable audience that included many socially prominent art patrons and workers in philanthropies.
Mr. and Mrs. James Harrington Stark gave a tea dance yesterday in the ballroom of the Colony Club to introduce to society their daughter. Miss Nancy Stark.

With Christmas shopping becoming more of a factor, retail trade here improved sharply during the last few days. Gains on Thursday were particularly pronounced, with the increases of some stores ranging up to 15 per cent over the same day last year.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced cancellation of the registrations as brokers or dealers in the over-the-counter market of James P. Jamieson, Charles F.

Backing his demands with the statement that there are only 387,000 soldiers on French soil facing more than 1,000,000 on the eastern and 300,000 on the southeastern frontiers, Defense Minister Edouard Daladier today obtained passage of next year's military credits by the- Chamber of Deputies without a single dissenting vote.

The plan to raise the FHA mortgage insurance limit on homes costing $6,000 or less to 90 per cent of the value of the property has inspired renewed efforts to bring about reform in mortgage and foreclosure laws throughout the country.
Deportation of all foreigners engaged in activities "for the moral or material support of armed conflicts in foreign countries" has been ordered by President Federico Laredo Bru.

Because of the slow healing of President Roosevelt's gum where an abscessed tooth was extracted on Nov. 18, he has decided to cut short his fishing cruise and cancel his plans to stay in Georgia, in order to get back to Washington two days earlier than he had planned. In announcing this change the President said that his general health was excellent.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a net gain of 4,019 instruments in operation in November, compared with one of 10,040 in November, 1936, and one of 5.588 in November. 1935.

The National Maritime Union threatened yesterday to call a strike on the vessels of the Eastern Steamship Company if members of the crew of the steamship St. John who have been displaced in recent weeks are not reinstated. The union gave until Tuesday for the company to act.

Mrs. Richard Percy Limburg, chairman of the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, announced yesterday that $801,400 had been contributed to the campaign by more than six thousand women in the metropolitan area since the opening of the drive, Oct. 7.

Making his first speech in the House, Representative Bruce Barton of New York asserted today that the "longsuffering, slow-to-anger" middle class was beginning to "stir" as it continued to experience an increase in living costs.

Temporary injunctions to halt the liquor price war which has cost retailers an estimated $500,000 to $750,000 in a week of price slashing will be sought this morning, officials of the Distillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd., and the Calvert Distillers Corporation, a subsidiary, announced yesterday.
The Rev. Dr. George Heathcote Hills, active as a minister for fifty-two years and for a quarter century rector of Grace Episcopal Church, died today at the age of 75.
Funeral services for Major C. Raymond Hulsart, who fought in the Battle of Cambrai during the World War, were held this morning at the Church of the Holy Family here. Public officials,

A net profit of $1,663,133 for the first ten months of this year was reported yesterday by the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but excluding surtax on undistributed income. This is equal to $2.20 a share on the 753,799 shares of common stock.

With demand for Winter apparel the strongest for the season thus far and Christmas buying heavier, retail sales this week exceeded the previous week by 1 to 4 per cent and the corresponding week last year by 3 to 12 per cent, according to the weekly trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Viscount Poullet, former Prime Minister of Belgium, died this morning at the age of 69. A member of the Catholic party, he formed in 1925 after a seventy-two-day Ministerial crisis the Poullet-Vandervelde Cabinet, which was fated to struggle with the most serious financial difficulties.
The first formal social event of the season at Rutgers University, the "Sophomore Hop," was held tonight. About 500 couples attended.

Accounting systems for Class I motor carriers, both omnibus and truck, differing somewhat from the methods prescribed for railroads, have been adopted by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the commission announced today.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 2, unless specified: At San Pedro, Argonne. Dec. 3; Arctic. At Norfolk yard: Herbert, Dec. 3; Leary. Tucker. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Dec. 3.

New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, 10:30 A. M. "Creative Learning," John L. Tildsley. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Palma Vecchio, Sebastiano del Piombo, and the Youthful Titian," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.;

Evidence that the Federal Government once seriously considered building a cement plant to get supplies for the Grand Coulee Dam on better terms than those offered by manufacturers, and that the latter, Within six months submitted bids representing a reduction of 75 cents a barrel, was presented at today's hearing on the Federal Trade Commission's charges against the Cement Institute and its seventy-five member corporations.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company to pledge and repledge until June 30, 1939, all, or any part, of $3,600,000 of general consolidated mortgage 5 per cent bonds, due in 2003,

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "A slight improvement in the demand for men's-wear tropical and women's-wear lines, supplementing further government contracts, has given the domestic market for wool more activity, especially in scoured and pulled wools, which are fully firm.

The income tax returns of former President Hoover have been under investigation of the Treasury Department for the last three weeks with the object of getting "something on him," William Starr Myers, Professor of Politics at Princeton University charged yesterday at Town Hall, in a lecture on current history before the League for Political Education.

Eleanor Steele and Hall Clovis returned to Town Hall last night to give a recital of vocal duets. A good-sized audience, obviously familiar with the work of these artists, attended the unusual program with manifest enjoyment.
Elaborate preparations by the British Government to move its "portable embassy" in China from Hankow to Shanghai by the circuitous Hong Kong route were disclosed in informed quarters today.

Miss Alice K. Carnick, 22 years old, of 185 South Mountain Avenue, whoreturned recently from a trip abroad after her graduation in June from Wellesley College, was found dead at 6 P. M. today in the garage at the rear of her home.

The University of Pennsylvania football team named five Cornell players on an all-opponent team today The selections: Ends, Holland and Spang, both of Cornell; tackles, Berner, Navy, and Van Ranst, Cornell; mguards, Economos,

Frank L. Nowosatka, 33 years old, formerly a leader of the coal bootlegging racket in this city, was released on a suspended sentence yesterday by General Sessions Judge Allen on his previous guilty plea to a ?? indictment.
Colgate University honored its athletes at the annual Varsity C dinner, held in the James C. Colgate Student Union Building tonight. Letters awarded to various units totaled 184.
The All-America swing back to the section that cradled this foundation for annual football argument, well under way last season, reached a peak during the spectacular campaign of 1937.

At first it was quite funny to Mrs. John King Roosa Jr. that she had President Roosevelt's old telephone number and that it was rung frequently by persons asking for some member of the President's menage. But yesterday, after it got into the papers and practical jokers phoned her, Mrs. Roosa, glad she-was going out of town for the week-end, had her telephone disconnected.

Charles E. Swope, former assistand trust officer of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, pleaded guilty yesterday to an indictment charging that he embezzled $37,342 of the bank's funds between April 10, 1934, and July 28, last, when his thefts were discovered and he was discharged. Federal Judge John G.

The Botany Worsted Mills of Passaic, N. J., was directed by the National Labor Relations Board today "to refrain from interfering with its employes in the exercise of their rights to self-organization and collective bargaining."
Pearl St, n s, block from John to Platt Sts, 123.31/2 on former and 83 on latter; Walter A. Lynch to Creek Holding Corp, 45 Beaver St; consideration $6,700 foreclosure.

It is a striking fact that of the 196 Democrats who have now signed a petition to bring the Administration's Wages-and-Hours Bill before the House only 45 are members representing districts south of the Mason and Dixon line. The party is split wide open on this issue,

Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and High Commissioner in Nicaragua, announced today that, despite bad exchange conditions and curtailment of imports. customs revenues had increased 20 per cent in 1937.

A suit for damages for the death of Ray M. Sands, a city fireman, was settled in favor of the widow, Mrs. Hannah Sands, 43 years old, of 46-40 189th Street, Flushing. for $11,500 in Queens Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The third of a series of fifteen folk-dance recitals presented by Dance International in the Rainbow Room will take place this afternoon, Saturday, and will be in honor of Yugoslavia whose national holiday it is.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Armstrong, daughter of Mrs. N. S. Wyckoff Vanderhoef of 1,192 Park Avenue, and of Daniel W. Armstrong, also of this city, to Robert Amory Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Amory of Boston.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 1: CAPTAIN Lewis, J. W.. Navy Yard, Mare Island, Calif., to command the Portland.

It was a wise little bird that whispered in Mr. Albert Marinelli's ear yesterday that the time had come to surrender the burdens of his office. It was an educated little bird that had been reading the newspapers.

Two of Europe's most talented skiers, Otto Furrer and Arthur Schlatter, yesterday became the latest entrants for the Madison Square Garden's Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet that starts a five-day run on Tuesday night.
Overtures for peace in the litigation over the plans for reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation were made today before Judge William H. Holly.
Steady progress in regional planning in the New York district is reported by George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association, in his annual report made public yesterday.

The Crescent A. C. Class C squash tennis team won its fifth straight match of the season and held first place in the Metropolitan Interclub League series last night, sweeping to a 5-0 triumph over the Princeton Club representatives on the New Moon courts.

Captain William H. (Bill) Wood, former Army backfield ace and a twelve-letter athlete during his cadet career, today was named head coach of West Point football to succeed Captain Garrison H. (Gar) Davidson.

One of the most popular acts passed by the Legislature of 1937 was the measure subjecting State officers to the State income tax. The herd of unofficial income-tax payers resents what seems an unnecessary discrimination, inequality, injustice, a favoritism resting on an essentially technical ground.

The Hershey Bears trounced the Bronx Tigers, 5 to 0, last night at the New York Coliseum and thus broke the previously existing tie for fourth place between the clubs in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League race.

The New York Giants have stopped smiling. The rollicking, care-free attitude that has been the hall-mark of all Giant practices this year has given way to a grim earnestness that bodes ill for the Washington Redskins when the two teams meet tomorrow

Governor Lehman has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the committee for New York in the tenth anniversary celebration in 1938 of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Everett Ross Clinchy director of conference.

Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel, asked his friends yesterday to desist from further efforts to recanvass the vote by which he was defeated as a candidate for delegate-at-large to the Constitutional Convention.

For the fifth consecutive week new bond financing was restricted exclusively to tax-exempt flotations. Increased activity, however, was shown in the market for those issues and with the appearance of several sizable loans,

The decree by which Marx Dormoy, Minister of the Interior, revoked the powers of Jacques Doriot, leader of the Anti-Soviet French Social party, as Mayor of St. Denis, a Paris working suburb, was annulled today by the Conseil d'Etat, a body of the French Government which has jurisdiction over administrative legality. When M. Doriot was summarily dismissed a new election was ordered and a new Mayor of St. Denis was elected.

Recovery has been reversed and may even become another "real depression," according to Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of General'Motors Corporation. He says it can be avoided only by changing the course of national economic policies and the reactions of industrial management.

Expressing the conviction that another depression at this time is neither inevitable nor probable on the basis of present conditions, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told the fifty-second annual dinner of the New York Southern Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night that the need of the moment was cooperation of business with government.

The Marquess of Hartington, Under-Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs, today told Parliament thatthere was clear evidence of recent increases in emigration from the Irish Free State into Britain but that the emigrants were being absorbed into employment.

The seventeenth annual Yale Barn Party will be held tonight in Nick Roberts's Old Yale Barn in Montclair, N. J. Members of this year's Eli football squad, led by Captain Clinton E. Frank, and other guests of honor who will attend the party will meet at a dinner in Montclair earlier in the evening.
A Congressional Committee heard today that the Maritime Commission hoped to complete a permanent subsidy program for the American merchant marine within thirty days.
Tom Lonchar's 28-yard field goal in the third period gave South Carolina's Gamecocks a 3-0 football victory tonight over the University of Miami before 7,543 persons.

Numerous dinners were given in advance of the annual Allaverdy Ball held under the auspices of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The organization maintains a vacation home at Cold Spring, N. Y., where free vacation periods are provided to children and to members who cannot afford to pay for Summer outings.
The forty-ninth annual exhibition of the New York Water Color Club was opened with a preview last evening at the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

James McBey's well-known etching, "Dawn: Camel Patrol Setting Out," brought $1,500 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of prints collected by Mrs. Leonard Elmhirst, the late Theodore A. Peyser, the late Seth Sprague Terry, D. Lyle Russell and Milton Towne.
Seward Park High's quintet, runner-up to De Witt Clinton for the city championship last season, downed Stuyvesant, 28--14, at Seward, in a lower Manhattan Division P. S. A. L. contest yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Jack W. Salisbury entertained at their home here today for Senator and Mrs. Heaton Treadwell, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger, Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton, Dr. and Mrs. Hobart Endicott Warren, Mr. and Mrs. A. Kinnaird Tod, Mr. and Mrs. George Stevenson Fenton.

Hardly a day passes without a German or Japanese intimation that this or that possible basis for negotiation would be favorably considered by Tokyo if only the Chinese Government would be "reasonable," recognize that it is beaten, and ask the conqueror for his terms.

Making its seasonal bow, Port Richmond High School of Staten Island lost to its local rival, St. Peter's, 22 to 17, last night at the victors' gymnasium. St. Peter's took an early lead and was never headed.

Bronx Grand Concourse, n e cor of 162d St, 142x 108; 8-story tenement; Dillerwood Realty Co. Inc, 161 E Gun Hill Rd, owner; I. L. Crausman. architect; cost, $400,000. Blair Ave. 3 s. 160 ft s of Shore Drive, 16x42: Edgewater Camp, bungalow No. 175. 1-story dwelling; Richard Shaw, owner and architect; cost, $1,500. Blair Ave, e s, 160 ft s of Shore Drive, 16x42; 1-story dwelling; same owner and architect: cost. $1,500.

The marriage of Miss Frances M. Eaton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Wales Eaton, to Frank Woodburn Dinsmore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dinsmore of Madison, was performed at the bride's home here tonight. The Rev. Thomas W. Attridge of the Church of the Redeemer officiated.
Mrs. E. H. Bartlett's Zevson, one of the best handicap horses of last Winter, won the Audubon Handicap at the Fair Grounds today, coming from behind under a rousing ride by Cornelio Mojena.

An amendment to the registration statement covering the proposed new issue of $10,000,000 of West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company first mortgage bonds, due 1952, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, naming the interest rate at 4 1/2 per and disclosing the several underwriters and their respective participations.

As the vanguard of the major league club owners and managers came trooping into this metropolis tonight after their three days of intensive bartering during the minor circuit convention in Milwaukee the Giants were the first to break away from the barrier with a deal.

Senator Bridges, on the Senate floor today, described the National Labor Relations Board's subpoena on the editor of Mill and Factory as "one of the most open attacks on a free press in the history of this country."

Chester William McNally of Kew Gardens, L. I., former counsel for the Yorkshire Indemnity Company, who was convicted of corruptly requesting a gratuity to settle a claim against the company, was disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division. Abraham Sonne, an attorney of 51 Chambers Street, who paid the gratuity and subsequently was the star witness for the State at McNally's trial, was also disbarred.

Several large mortgage loans on Brooklyn Apartment houses have been placed by M. C. O'Brien. Inc. brokers. They are: $350,000 on the partly completed structure on Newkirk Ave. between E 16th and 17th Sts, for Newkirk Apartments, Inc; $220.000 on 45 Linden Blvd,

The American Federation of Labor decided today to recommend that Congress enact a minimum wage and maximum hour statute which wolud fix a flat forty cents an hour as the statutory wage and a fortyhour week as the work week.

Directors of the Alleghany Corporation and of the Chesapeake Corporation announced jointly today abandonment of a plan to consolidate the corporations. Railroad analysts said this probably would result in the eventual dissolution of the Chesapeake Corporation.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Lynn Robb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Robb of this place, to Lloyd Ross Freeman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd R. Freeman of Glen Ridge, N. J., formerly of Norfolk, Va.
New officers of the Queens county Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars were elected last night at O'Connell Post, 123-09 Liberty Avenue. Richmond Hill.

Dr. Charles E. Kaufman, town health officer of West Haven, died suddenly of a heart attack at his home today. Earlier this week he suffered a similar attack in Hartford at the meeting of the Community Public Health Association. He was 51 years old.
A 30 per cent shortage in the supply of fresh cream for New York City has resulted in the sale of cold storage cream here by the larger distributors, it became known yesterday.

Robert E. Perry, former Councilman of Westfield and for many years sales manager of T. Shriver Co. of Harrison, N. J., manufacturers of filter presses, died in the Rahway Memorial Hospital today of pneumonia at the age of 69.

The formal public celebration of his induction into the office of Preaiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church by the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Bishop of Virginia, will take place in St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, on Jan. 2, at 11 A. M.

Miss Adeline Thellusson, who for more than twenty-one years was commandant matron at St. Dunstan's Home for the War-Blinded, died today. She was a cousin of Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council in the British Cabinet.
Ward Boss, on the comeback trail after an illness, recorded an upset victory in the featured handicap at Tanforan today, defeating Clarcarole by three and one-half lengths. Mam Lindy, the favorite,

Miss Phyllis Day, daughter of Colonel Clarence Richmond Day, U.S.A., retired, former Chief of Staff of the Seventy-ninth Division, and Mrs. Day, formerly of Washington, was introduced this afternoon at a tea given by her parents at their Radnor home, Happy Hollow Farm.
Five men armed with machine guns and sawed-off shotguns held ?p a mail truck in front of the postoffice today, shot a postal clerk, stole nearly $25,000 in currency and kidnapped the chief of police.

The Lathrobe Realty Company, Inc., has purchased the apartment house on a plot 37.6 by 100 feet at 1,460 Wilkins Avenue, Bronx. The seller was the Cufasa Realty Corporation. Sale was for cash above a first mortgage of $27,000.
F. Harrison Higgins, son of former Governor Frank W. Higgins of New York State, died last night after a long illness at the age of 52.

In the contest between the Chicago Board of Trade and Cargill, Inc., before the Commodity Exchange Administration, attorneys for Cargill attempted today to prove that the board's business conduct committee acted without precedent in ordering the Cargill Grain Company of Illinois,
The high cost of living, through the range of meat, milk and rents, was attacked last night at a community meeting held under the chairmanship of Mary K. Simkhovitch in Greenwich House.
Collateral borrowings by members of the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business on Nov. 30 amounted to $687,786,579, a decline of $37,836,293 from the total on Oct. 30 of $725,622,872.

Word was received here yesterday of the death in Fort Sam Houston, Texas, on Tuesday of Mrs. John C. Covington, wife of First Lieutenant John C. Covington, Air Corps, and daughter of Colonel and Mrs. E. R. W. McCabe. Mrs. Covington,

Unwilling to have his name added to the long recent list of Soviet diplomats who have never been heard from since they were recalled to Moscow, Alexandre Barmine, former Soviet Charge d'Affaires at Athens, Greece, disobeyed his recall order and took a train to Paris, whence he sent his letter of resignation to the Soviet authorities.
President George H. Bond of the New York State Bar Association appointed a seven-member committee today to attend funeral services tomorrow for Lansing Parmelee Reed, New York City attorney.
Fillmore Van S. Hyde of the Harvard Club, who won the first of four national squash tennis championships in 1918, was one of the winners yesterday in the Fall scratch tournament at the Harvard Club.

Howard G. Turner 3d, '39, of Ridgewood, N. J., prominent in campus extra-curricular activities, has been named manager of the Princeton University 1938 varsity football team, it was announced today by William T. Galey 3d, -'38, of Overbrook, Pa., retiring manager.

Sixty-five cafeteria strikers were arrested last night outside restaurants in the theatre district. Thirty-nine men and one woman, part of a crowd of ninety-two pickets who marched in front of the Horn Hardart Automat cafeteria at 1,557 Broadway, between Forty - sixth and Forty- seventh Street, at 7 o'clock last night, were arrested by police for disrupting pedestrian traffic.

HOLD that line! There was to have been something in this corner today about the impending battle tomorrow for the Eastern championship of the professional football field, but a twenty-four-hour delay was found necessary.

Sylvia Sidney, the actress, has purchased a residence dating back to 1805 on a farm located two miles south of Flemington in Hunterdon County, N. J. Records show that the property was owned at one time by Samuel Carmon, who settled in the section about 200 years ago.
Foreclosures of non-farm real estate in the United States declined 25.7 per cent from 14,970 in October, 1936, to 11,123 in October, last, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

Mrs. Helen Olcott Coffin Paine died on Thursday at her home, 444 East Fifty-seventh Street, after a long illness, at the age of 79. Born in Annapolis, Md., Mrs. Paine was a descendant of Tristram Coffin of Nantucket,

Total volume in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Nov. 6, in which there were five trading days, dropped to 6,798,040 shares sold, compared with 12,246,060 in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

A large apartment and store building in New Rochelle figured in the Westchester realty transactions announced yesterday. The four-story brick, Spanishtype apartment building at 760 North Avenue on the southwest corner of Eastchester Road,

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 10,000, including 4,500 directs. Market very uneven; hogs, 220 pounds down, 15-25 cents higher than Thursday's average. Butchers 250 pounds up slow.

Willie Hoppe, 49-year-old cue wizard who has held every title and set up many records in all balkline and cushion billiards, last night reached another pinnacle by making a world record high run of 248 in the tenth block of his match with Jake Schaefer in the new French game of 71.2 at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

The following discussions of a recent NEW YORK TIMES editorial entitled "America's Aloofness" was printed today in The Washington Star under the heading "Washington Observations," by Frederic William Wile:

A warning that organized labor is alienating its friends by "abuse of the picketing system" and that unless corrective measures are taken picketing "must die and be abolished by public indignation," was contained in a presentment handed up yesterday by the Kings County November grand jury.

Alex Rosenswaike, Chief of Police, and Harry Yale, police lieutenant, both of the Island Park (L. I.) Police Department, and four civilian co-defendants were sentenced yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions on charges of conspiracy to defraud in the operation of a charity scheme in which several thousand persons were said to have been victimized.

With the Second Five-Year Plan within a month of its end, intense efforts are being made in virtually all branches of Soviet industry to increase production so as, if possible, to meet the ambitious schedules that many of the most important departments have been unable to attain.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 27 amounted to 558,627 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 88,624 cars, or 13.7 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 121,673 cars, or 17.9 per cent,

The Ways and Means subcommittee on taxation today considered the possibility of either a constitutional amendment or legislation by which the Federal Government and States could tax each other's securities.
