Several of the Pittsburgh football players who voted against a Rose Bowl trip are anxious to play in the Shrine's annual East-West game here New Year's Day.

A memorial service for Canon H. R. L. Sheppard of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, England, who was commonly known as "Dick" Sheppard, will be held tomorrow at 4 P. M. in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, near Third Avenue. Canon Theppard died Oct.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, in Brooklyn yesterday, granted a modified injunction restraining members of the New York Newspaper Guild from causing any kind of demonstration outside the hairdressing establishment of Mlle.

The first of the Junior Assemblies for this season took place last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. With this dancealways one of the most important for girls making their debuts during the Winter-the long history of the famous assemblies was continued.
The St. Michael's High School quintet of Union City scored a 28-to-20 victory tonight over St. Benedict's Prep. St. Michael's overcame a sevenPoint lead to win.

Two American race pilots of high rank were killed at the opening of the AllAmerican Air Manoeuvres at the municipal airport here this afternoon. Rudy King of Lemont, Ill., and Frank Haines of Detroit,

In the absence of general reports in Peiping from Japanese detachments operating in various parts of North China, official Japanese reports are the only ones available, and they are causing the utmost speculation in foreign circles. Aside from saying that Japanese planes bombed several Chinese military concentrations, the Japanese spokesman in the last ten days has limited himself to saying: "All fronts are quiet."

Just how much time will elapse before the sportsmen of New York State rise up and demand less talk and more action on the matter of the formation of some kind of farm-game program is a matter for conjecture.
The Spanish Insurgents opened a heavy artillery bombardment of Madrid today, advices reaching the frontier said.

Brooklyn College's inexperienced basketball team will open its 1937-38 court campaign against Nat Holman's veteran City College quintet in the feature attraction at the dedication ceremonies of the new Brooklyn College gymnasium at Bedford Avenue and Avenue H tonight.

The theft of seven bags of registered mail from a United States mail truck en route from the Genetal Postoffice at Thirty-third Street and Eighth Avenue to Lackawanna Terminal in Hoboken Thursday night became known last night as the New York police recovered from the East River five burlap bags filled with registered mail apparently discarded by the thieves.

The Beechwood Players, a little theatre group, opened their nineteenth season here tonight by presenting "Good Morning," a new play by John Gibbs, before an audience of 200 in the Beechwood Theatre of the Scarborough School.

Without resuming play, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, world chess champion, today resigned the twenty-fourth game of his title match, adjourned last night, to Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, his challenger and probable successor.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association. Inc.:

The scholastic football campaign in the metropolitan area will finally come to a close today, when eight games will be played. Many of these contests were postponed from earlier in the season. One is scheduled on a New York City gridiron and seven on New Jersey fields.
A covered wagon drawn by oxen rumbled out of Hamilton today on the way to Marietta, Ohio, re-enacting the departure of pioneers leaving for the Northwest Territory 150 years ago.

Former Patrolman William F. Glendenning, 33 years old, who was at one time attached to the Charles Street station, was sentenced to serve thirty days in the workhouse and fined $100 yesterday in Special Sessions Court for driving an automobile while intoxicated.

A nobly impressive and excellently sung performance of Wagner's "Siegfried" was given last night at the Metropolitan. The presentation was one not equaled in certain respects for many seasons, and there were three debuts to lend extra interest to the proceedings.
Two "first pints" of Florida's. Winter strawberry crop have been sold for a total of $5.50.
Seven matches were played yesterday in the opening round of the Long Island open squash racquets championship at the Jackson Heights Squash Club and resulted in two closely contested battles.

Albert Marinelli resigned as County Clerk yesterday under the fire of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey. He did so, he told Governor Lehman in submitting his resignation twenty-eight days before his term
The Lieutenant Norman Prince Memorial in St. John's Chapel of Washington Cathedral will be dedicated at a special service Monday at 11 A. M.

Federal Judge John P. Nields of the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., presiding over reorganization proceedings of the $900,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company, handed down yesterday a ruling permitting the utility to solicit acceptance of the plan of reorganization presented to the court on Nov. 24.

The Chilean State Railways has bought $1,000,000 of rails from the Bethlehem Steel Company, E. Guzman-Donoso, United States repretentative of the line, announced yesterday. The management also is considering the purchase of six locomotives.

The American Smelting and Re-fining Company yesterday advanced the price of copper in the domestic market from 10 to 10.50 cents a pound. On Thursday that companycut the price from 10.50 to 10 cents. Producers are continuing to quote 11 cents.

Refusal of a 13-year-old Long Island schoolgirl to salute the flag because of religious belief brought from the State Education Department today a ruling that all public school pupils must pledge allegiance.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Renshaw of 120 East End Avenue and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their debutante daughter, Miss Lisa Lawrence Renshaw, to Charles Henry Mills Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mills of Dongan Hills, S. I.
A new reduced rate-on the Lackawanna ferries of 25 cents for automobile pleasure cars, including passengers, will become effective on Dec. 10, it was announced yesterday.
A petition by George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks, Freight Handlers, Express and Station Employes, to intervene in the proceeding in which the Louisiana

Alfred Toepfer, anonymous donor this Autumn of a system of scholarships on the Cecil Rhodes model to bring British students to German universities, has been imprisoned here for some time, it is learned.

Despite agitation for three specific rule changes designed to help the offense in football, a nation-wide poll of college coaches by The Associated Press reveals strong sentiment to "leave well enough alone."

A further recovery yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange here carried all but two near months above 8 cents. As January approached the 8-cent level, however, the market ran into more contracts and closed with a loss of 3 to a gain of 2 points.

Miss Ruth Eleanor Roeser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward N. Roeser of this city, was marrie? last night in the chapel of the Riverside Church to Dr. Jed Hotchkiss Irvine, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Estil Irvine of Charlottesville, Va. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Eugene Carder and the Rev. Dr. Ernest Youtz.

Two new titles have been added to the Phaidon Art Series which the Oxford University Press is publishing. "The Impressionists," in which are represented such artists as Manet, Pisaro, Sisley, Monet, Renoir, Gauguin, Degas and ToulouseLautrec, was published last Thursday. On Thursday "Cezanne,"

Indoor polo opens its new season tonight with games in Manhattan and Brooklyn which will be used to prepare the way for important changes in the rules. The rules committee of the Indoor Polo Association yesterday announced that for tonight, at least, the old halfpoint deduction for fouls had been eliminated and that in its place would be substituted the outdoor ?? free-bit penalty.

Colourgravure, Inc., H. E. Benedict, president, of New York, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 150,000 shares of $5 par value 40-cent cumulative preferred and 150,000,000 of 10-cent par value common stock to be offered in units of one preferred and one common share.

The six-day bicycle race swept into its final phase at Madison Square Garden last night with six of the ten teams remaining closely grouped at the head of the procession. The riding was spirited and brisk all through the evening program and the lead was constantly fought for by the apparently fresh athletes.

It can be taken for granted that no one in New York City is more anxious than Mayor La Guardia is to get lowrental housing started. Yet within the past two weeks he has done more to hinder this program than to help it. For reasons which did not appear on the face of the record he flew out at

Andrew Ponzi and Irving Crane broke even in their exhibition pocket billiard match at the Strand Academy last night. In the first block Ponzi ran 100 to defeat Crane, 125 to 17, in five innings, while Crane turned the tables in the second, triumphing, 125 to 3, in twenty-nine frames.
Senator King of Utah said today after a conference with Treasury officials that he was convinced that the Administration would continue its present silver policy indefinitely.
Hundreds of tax officials from all parts of the country are gathering in Atlantic City, N. J., for the three-day conference of the National Association of Tax Administrators, which opens tomorrow.

Fifteenhundred miles from home, but only a short step from the best season in its football history, Manhattan's football team will conclude its 1937 campaign tomorrow against the powerful eleven of the University of Tulsa.
The new store here of Arnold Constable Co. was opened for a preview today to more than 3,000 public officials, clubwomen and civic leaders of New Rochelle and vicinity.

A mysterious epidemic which strikes the new born and kills 50 per cent of its victims was being investigated tonight by pathologists and bacteriologists of the city following an outbreak at St. Elizabeth's Hospital that has taken ten lives since Nov. 23.

Gino Garibaldi, 218, Italy, pinned Mike Mazurki, 228, New York, in 40:02 of the star attraction at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night. A crowd of 2,500 saw Garibaldi triumph with an Indian death grip.

Legends of heroism and pathos began to cluster long ago around the career of Jacob Svoboda, the little "Major" who really was a corporal. Filtered through the fine mesh of fingerprint lines, however, his history yesterday showed up nothing more clearly factual than the roster of his crimes.

Investigations of the fake radio and bogus watch rackets by James J. Wilson, assistant district attorney, came to a close yesterday in Special Sessions with the disposal of the last-of numerous cases.
An appeal for the endowment of "an institute dedicated to the study of the process of aging" was made here yesterday by Dr. Alexis Carrel of the Rockefeller Institute.

The political parties headed by former Presidents Mario G. Menocal and Miguel Mariano Gomez and the Popular Revolutionary bloc will not participate in the elections of March 5 to renew half the seats in the House of Representatives. They have approved a resolution recommending that the public refrain from participating in the elections.
The forceful personality of Colonel Charles F. B. Price has helped that officer get many a difficult situation in hand for the marines in the far corners of the world.
The Manhattan College basketball team opened its season by overwhelming a strong Alumni squad; 49 to 29, last night in the Manhattan gymnasium before a crowd of 500.

To date, this year, the National Academy of Design has purchased three paintings through the Henry W. Ranger Fund, the acquisitions being "Mediaeval Art," by the late Edwin H. Blashfield; "Fifteenth Century French Madonna and Child," by Harry W. Watrous, and "Boxholder 27," by Francis Speight, A. N. A. Both Blashfield and Watrous served as presidents of the academy.

People who can read say that "Merely Murder" was a gay little homicide in Georgette Heyer's crime novel. People who go to the theatre are likely to find it politely debilitating in the comedy written by A. E. Thomas that was presented at the Playhouse last evening.

Prince and Princess Wilhelm von Lichnowsky, Baroness Maud Ledyard von Ketteler, Bishop Basil Takach, Francis R. Stewart, United States Consul at Venice, and Mrs. Stewart; Baron Giuseppe Zezza and Italo E. Verrano, general manager of the Italian Line in the United States. are booked to sail today for Mediterranean ports in the Italian liner Rex.

A revision of the American Standard Version of the Bible, embodying the best results of modern scholarship and expressing this meaning in the simple, classic style of the King James Version, will begin at once and will require five years to complete, it was stated today by Dean Luther A. Weigle of the Yale University Divinity School.

Dwight School's speedy five downed Trinity School, 39--28, on the losers' floor yesterday. Dwight held a 15-8 leeway at half time in the non-league encounter. Karpowitch, with 18 points, led the attack for the winners.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Lily Stungo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Stungo of Edinburgh, Scotland, to Dr. Donald K. Binder of this city, which took place on Nov. 23 in Edinburgh. Dr. and Mrs. Binder will make their home in New York.

The difficulties encountered by Mr. and Mrs. James R. Herbert Boone of 765 Park Avenue with customs officials upon their arrival from Europe on Thanksgiving Day were settled yesterday, according to Gregory O'Keefe, Assistant Collector of the Port.

The 112th Field Artillery opened its season with a victory over the Westfield Polo Club tonight, 23 1/2 to 13 1/2. Scoring seven goals in the first period, the artillerymen went out in front and stayed there. Warren Wentzel tallied nine goals.

A Japanese attempt to seize a large part of the International Settlement at Shanghai was abandoned yesterday after United States Marines' officers insisted on withdrawal from the sector guarded by their forces.
Joseph R. Swan has been elected president of the New York Botanical Garden and Dr. William J. Robbins has been selected as the new director of the institution, it was announced yesterday.

This is a story of a man who did not like what he got to eat at the White House, complained, and was served broiled chicken. Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, went to the Executive Mansion on Nov. 1 with a headful of figures and a stout appetite.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 2: Holbrook, Maj. Gen. L. R., four months leave, March 17. Beacham, Col. J. W., Jr., Inf., three months and twenty-eight days' leave, Jan. 2, with permission to visit foreign countries. Endicott, Col. F. C., Inf., designated as executive officer of the National Matches for 1938.
Colonel Frederick H. Allen died today at the Newport Hospital at the age -of 79. He was a former member of the Democratic National Finance Committee, a former Mayor of Pelham Manor, N. Y.,

The Rev. Dr. Albert Horton Ball, retired clergyman, father of Professor Margaret Ball of Mount Holyoke College and Professor Albert Ball of the College of the City of New York, died here today. His age was 94. He retired in 1906.

Trading was fair in meet classes of locally dressed meats yesterday. Prices showed little change except on an occasional cut. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be steady to higher, calf and lamb steady. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Miss Harriet Mead Howard, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Howard of this place and the late Mr. Howard, was married to Everett Ostrander, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ostrander of Staatsburg, N. Y., in the Congregational Church, Bedford, N. Y., this morning.

Daniel Dickey Hains, for the last ten years an assistant manager of the Equitable Life Assurance Company and a former Professor of Greek at Wabash College, died on Thursday at Memorial Hospital at the age. of 64. Mr. Hains.

An appropriation of $16,505,000 to construct seven new high school buildings in 1938 and purchase seven additional sites at an undetermined cost was recommended yesterday by the building and sites committee of the Board of Education. The money is being sought from the 1938 capital outlay budget.

Figures supplied by nineteen New York Stock Exchange firms to the Securities and Exchange Commission show that as of Nov. 20 only 15.1 per cent of their accounts were in the restricted class. Reflecting the lower margin requirements, this is compared to 39 per cent on Oct. 26 and 47.1 per cent on Sept. 20.
Navy's 1938 football schedule, announced today, gives two major games each to Philadelphia and Baltimore.

Despite the business recession of the last few months, the marked improvement in the 1937 United Hospital Fund campaign over last year has continued. Complete figures will be well over the 1936 total, it was indicated, as contributions to date were announced yesterday at the formal final report luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore.

Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein, indicted with twenty-six others on charges of conspiracy to defraud the city in land purchases at Port Newark, issued a statement promising to fight the case "to my last breath," predicting his eventual vindication, and attacking his accusers as engaged in a conspiracy to drive him out of public office. He asked the public to withhold judgment until the trial.
Gross assets, $1,144; net, $538. To husband. Hagbart Engh. Chief assets, personal property, $1.144. Barondess Mushin, attorneys, 570 7th Ave., Manhattan.
Royal prerogatives do not embrace special parking privileges, King George has decided, weeks after taxi drivers, police and the Duchess of Kent brought the problem into the limelight.

Three Central Badminton Club teams triumphed in their opening Metropolitan Association matches The club's two combinations in Class B of the men's division scored shut-out victories, while the women's Class A team prevailed over the Gramatan Hills Badminton Club, 3 to 2.

Wilkins Ave (11-2966) e s, 187 ft n of 170th St, 37x100 Latrobe Realty Co to Cufasa Realty Corp, at Cooper Sq, N. Y. City, five years, 4 per cent: $23,000. Morris Ave (11-3191), n w cor of 193d St, 1OOx150; Keo Realty Corp to Franklin Savings Bank, extends mtgs to Nov. 16, 1940, at 41/3 per cent: $155.000.

Helen Keller has never seen Mary Agnes Thomson-or "Polly" Thomson, as she is better known-nor has she ever heard the cheerful voice with a Scottish accent of her constant companion. Yet she was able to be a "character witness" at the ceremony of admitting Miss Thomson to citizenship in the United States.

A recession took place in cottonmill activity last week, but the decline in daily average operations was smaller than anticipated on the basis of seasonal trend, and the adjusted index has advanced to 110.8 from 104.4, the revised figure for the previous week. For the week ended Nov. 28, 1936, the index stood at 134.0.

The Coventry Club has leased from Mrs. Frank C. Munson, widow of the president of the Munson Steamship Lines, the five-story American basement house at 12 East Sixty-seventh Street. It will have for its club facilities a large library, game rooms,

More than half a million dollars unclaimed by creditors of defunct banks in this State for more than four years after liquidation of the closed institutions has just been turned over to the State Controller by the New York State Banking Department.

Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, commandant of the Seventh Regiment; Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Phillips Kohl, Miss Fay Devereux Keith and Dr. and Mrs. George E. Heye are among those who will give dinners tonight before the annual Autumn Military Ball of the Seventh Regiment, which will be held in the regiment's armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

United States RRECISION LENS, PRISM AND TEST PLATE MAKER, $7.872, $8.352, $8.832 a day. United States Navy Yard, Washington, D. C. Applications must be on file with the recorder Labor Board, United States Navy Yard, Washington. D. C., not later than Dec. 30.

Death Announced Retired Fireman James P. Reilly, formerely a member of H. and L. 21, residing at 203 W. 91st St., Manhattan, died Dec. S. Funeral will take place from the Bowertown Funeral Chapel, 43 W. 60th St., Manhattan, at 10:30 A. M. Monday, Dec. 6. Interment Calvary Cemetery. The deputy chief of the 4th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

Some people may have trouble finding jobs, but not Governor Hoffman. His trouble is to decide which job to accept. Recently the position as executive director of the State Unemployment Compensation Commission at $12,000 a year was offered to him when his term as Governor at $20,000 annually expires next month.

Results of an official traffic study recently completed by the police covering the congested area bounded by Fourteenth and Fifty-sixth Streets, Second to Eighth Avenues, showed 15,762 vehicles of all types parked along the curbs between 10 o'clock in the morning and 4 in the afternoon, it was learned yesterday.

T. O. M. Sopwith, owner of the America's C??p yacht Endeavour II, will arrive early in January to try out Panama's famous sailfishing, according to a letter received here by Captain F. G. Whaler, who has been engaged as guide for the expedition.

Seabiscuit, Charles S. Howard's champion American money winner, and Amor Brujo, South American mystery horse, may meet for the first time in the $10,000 added San Francisco Handicap at Tanforan Dec. 18.

Before Jack Benny appears as a football coach in "Give 'Em the Axe," he will desert musicals for one film and portray a hypochondriac in "Never Say Die," by Preston Sturgess, Paramount disclosed today. The picture also will introduce Franceska Gaal as a comedienne,
Alabama's Rose Bowl-bound Crimson Tide unpacked uniforms and returned to the practice field today to begin preparations for the New Year's Day game with California at Pasadena.

More shakeups in the British Army were foreshadowed today following last night's sensational "purge" of the Army Council and the appointment of Viscount Gort as Chief of the General Staff over the heads of fifty senior officers.
Karl C. Delong, head of ecclesiastical and architectural designing for the Delong Furniture Company, died at his home last night in his thirtieth year.

Plans for fifteen new buildings costing $725,800 were filed last month in Manhattan, according to Samuel Fassler, Commissioner of Buildings, who said this compares with twenty-five new structures costing $488,000 during the corresponding month last year.
The Almoners will resume their weekly sewing classes tomorrow at the home of Mrs. Girard S. Wittson. 262 Central Park West. and will continue on subsequent Mondays throughout the Winter.
TOURISTS visiting the Dominican Republic this Winter will find landing a comparatively easy matter, for new piers and a recently dredged harbor permit even large ships to tie up at docks.

ONE of the January publications of the new firm of Carrick Evans will be "The Lady and the Panda," by Ruth Harkness. This is an informal account of the author's adventures on the expedition which resulted in the capture of the baby giant panda, the first animal of that species ever captured alive.

After the lapse of months, it was a pleasure to hear Bizet's lustrous and spirited score last night at the Metropolitan. The production of "Carmen" was far from flawless, but, being the season's first, the principals and even the chorus seemed newly alive to the abundant beauty and emotional force of the work.

California shipping and agricultural interests were elated when head offices of the Panama Pacific Line announced that fortnightly service between New York and San Francisco will be continued through the Winter season, despite reports earlier that service would be curtailed Jan. 1.
Joseph Ward, head of the Sheffield scrap metal firm of Thomas W. Ward, Ltd., stated tonight that he expected that the purchase by his company of the liner Leviathan would be announced on Monday.
Miss Anna Katherine Briggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Stacy Briggs of Brookline, Pa., was martried this afternoon to Glenn Joseph Frey of Tunkhannock, son of Mrs. Gertrude Frey.

Wells College students who have chosen the recently created special field of esthetics and the arts are convinced already of the advantages offered by the subject major in contrast with the usual major with its valuable specialization in one department.

With Dr. C. T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador, attending as the guest of honor, the Chinese Women's Relief Association will hold an auction of valuable Chinese and modern art pieces at a benefit cocktail party this afternoon at 4:30 o'clock at the Park Lane Hotel.

The recommendation of the Kings County grand jury that picketing be limited was condemned yesterday afternoon as "inimical to the fundamental and inalienable rights of labor" in a resolution adopted by more than 100 lawyers at a joint meeting of the Harlem Lawyers Association and the legal staff of the International Labor Defense in the Y. M. C. A. Building at 180 West 135th Street.

The Children of Mary Society, oldest student organization at Marymount College, will celebrate its twentyfifth anniversary on Wednesday, Founder's Day. Five students who organized the society and a former president of the group will be the guests at a dinner Wednesday evening.

Several events recently have indicated the Administration's determination to press through to an early conclusion its drive for anti-trust legislation, although there is reason to believe that action may not come as soon as was first expected.

Cabinet members, Nazi party chiefs and stage and screen stars braved the rain today to solicit street-corner contributions for the Winter Relief Fund. The event officially was named the "Day of National Solidarity."

Considerable discussion in realty circles has been aroused, points out Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, over the relief proposal presented before the recent Pittsburgh convention of that organization by Wendell P. Barker, former chairman of the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York. Mr.

Henry W. Edgerton, Professor of Law at Cornell University, will be recommended for confirmation as associate judge of the Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia by the Senate Judiciary subcommittee, which has the matter in charge.

More than 10,000 dentists are expected to attend the thirteenth annual Greater New York Dental Meeting, opening tomorrow at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Sessions will continue through the week and more than 150 papers will be read. Clinics will be held and discussion groups will consider recent theories and discoveries in dentistry.

While Congress worked in special session last week in Washington, the President of the United States went fishing in the warm Gulf water off Florida. (Today he is on his way back to Washington, two days earlier than he had originally planned, for dental treatment.)

LANSING, Mich. A NEW-TYPE airplane designed especially for aerial photogra phy and mapping was recently test flown successfully at Marshall, Mich. It places the pilot in the nose of the cabin and the photographer and engine behind him.

In a spectacular upturn or downturn of American finance and industry-especially when the movement has brought bewilderment to the home marketparticular interest is always taken in sober foreign judgment.

Inventory reduction has been proceeding at a pace which now justifies confidence that the stock-showing at the end of the fiscal year will be favorable, retail executives here said yesterday. They added that their problem now has become one of spurring turnover in a period of business uncertainty, not only through the markdowns taken to move inventories but to obtain goods at wholesale levels which will permit retail prices highly attractive to the consumer.

Twenty-five seamen, described by the police as having staged a sitdown strike aboard the Norwegian tanker Racine at the Morse Plant United Shipyards, Inc., drydock, on the Erie basin at Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, were arrested shortly after 8 o'clock last night on charges of disorderly conduct.
Sergei Radamsky, tenor, was heard in recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall before an audience that gave frequent signs of its pleasure in a varied program.

Through Dr. Elizabeth Gardiner, chairman of the division of maternity, infancy and child hygiene of the State Federation of Women's Clubs, New York clubwomen will have an opportunity to express themselves on the practicability of keeping in touch with all expectant mothers in order that the location of clinics and other information may be disseminated in the concerted action to reduce the maternity mortality rate.

The monopoly which pie held on the Shelton High School menu appeared today to be weakening under the attacks of students and parents. Mrs. Mary C. Mahoney, member of a Board of Education committee studying means to improve the menu in the school's cafeteria, said she was working on a plan to add milk and sandwiches by Jan. 1.

Annual meeting of the National Industrial Council begins at WaldorfAstoria, 10 A. M. and continues tomorrow. Morning and afternoon sessions. Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, 10:45 A. M. "The Dangers of Having a Mind," Professor Walter B. Pitkin.
The Cuban Government will press for the extradition of Gerardo Machado y Morales, former President and dictator, on seven counts, an official communique from -the Department of State said today.

Industry and finance in this country perhaps have had too many discouraging experiences with this Administration to make them enthusiastically receptive to a suggestion that they at once begin to organize a demonstrative implemented cooperation with Washington. But, whether this can be done with enthusiasm or not, it should at once begin if the present drive against the business recession is to be successful.

A plea for some form of Federal assistance for the construction of multi-family houses in well-to-do urban residential sections is voiced by I. Jerome Riker, head of the realty company bearing his name.

Seeking to establish by law a maximum of thirty pupils a class for New York schools and to obtain approval of a $200,000,000 bond issue for school building construction, the Teachers Union yesterday announced that it was setting aside the week of Dec. 13 as "Small Class Week."

Three subsidiary holding companies of Massachusetts Utilities Associates, a holding company in the system of the New England Power Association, a registered holding company, have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission plans for their voluntary liquidation and termination under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

The work in 1938 to educate Americans in nonpartisan politics, in accordance with traditions of the nation's founding, was outlined yesterday afternoon at the annual business meeting of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York by William T. Van Alstyne, president. The meeting was held in Fraunces's Tavern, 54 Pearl Street.
An unexpectedly large attendance at the first forum meeting of the Advertising Women of New York has made it necessary to provide larger quarters for the December discussion.

A special commission, to be known as the Committee on Scientific Aids to Learning, with President James B. Conant of Harvard as chairman, has been established under the auspices of the National Research Council, President Frederick D. Keppel of

ON THEIR. OWN APPLICATIONS. To take effect 12 midnight, Dec. 4: PATROLMEN Charles J. Planagan, 17th Precinct. at $1.500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 3. 1912. To take effect 12 noon, Dec. 16: William J. Butler Jr., 71st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 5, 1902.
Russell F. Prudden of 19 East Eighty-eighth Street entertained with a dinner last night at his home for Mr. and Mrs. Knox B. Phagan of Bronxville, later taking his guests to a theatrical performance.

Rice Institute's greatest "substitute," burly Ernie Lain, today scored the two touchdowns that defeated Southern Methodist, 15 to 7, won the Southwest Conference title and obtained for the Owls an invitation to play in the Cotton Bowl classic here on Jan. 1.
Mrs. Sarah Swift Wendell, widow of B. Rush Wendell and member of a prominent New York city and Cazenovia family, died tonight at her home here of the age of

WASHINGTON.--Costs of automobiles have forged ahead to second place in the expenditure of farm families in the United States, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reveals in a study of the changing pattern of spending among rural families.
Mrs. Alfred J. Brosseau gave a party today at El Toto for her house guests, Mrs. George H. Townsend and Mrs. Townsend Chapman of Greenwich. Conn.

The performance of "Barchester Towers" tomorrow night at the Martin Beck Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Women's League for Palestine. Proceeds will be used for the construction in Jerusalem of a communal center for refuge girls from East European countries.
" HE is a handsome man, and of a noble carriage," observed one of Lanigdon's contemporaries. "He has been a member of Congress, and is now one of the first people."

IN this year's sheaf of Shakespeareana two volumes may be taken as companion pieces--companions because their authors so archly illustrate each other. Professor Schelling as the orthodox Shakespearean and Alden Brooks as the latest in the long parade of "Baconians."
The Senate Farm Bill was denounced by Senator King today as evidence of a trend away from democratic ideals and toward a dictatorial, centralized form of government.
Builders and housing experts are watching with interest the possible effects of liberalization of the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage insurance policy.

Former Governor Alf M. Landon told a banquet of young Republicans tonight that every one is "dizzy not only with the political confusion, but with the economic confusion," in the Roosevelt administration.
An "antidote" for incendiary bombs, the real menace to large cities in wartime because of the devastating fires they can start, is revealed in a German patent just come to light here.

THERE are few remaining ancient customs among natives of the South Sea Islands, but one that still persists in spite of many attempts to wipe it out is the widely practiced habit of drinking kava-a strange tasting beverage, which the natives drink on all ceremonial occasions.

Two goals late in the third period brought the New York Americans a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Maroons in a closely fought National Hockey League game tonight and broke the triple deadlock for second place in the International Group as the Canadiens played a tie at Toronto.

That national and State agencies are taking cognizance of the phenomenal growth of skiing and are giving the sport a definite place on their outdoor recreational program was the outstanding development today at the State conference on skiing.

Radcliffe College students have found a course that will give them a better figure and greater poise and at the same time help then to win an academic degree. It is the new course in dancing given by Miss Katherine Schroeder, and 225 undergraduates are taking advantage of it.

The first in a series of events to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of the founding of Madison House is the tea dance to be held this afternoon in the Mirror Room of Le Coq*Rouge under the auspices of the Junior Board of Madison: House.

Avoidable corporate taxes have introduced a rather new philosophy in our system of taxation. Arbitrary declarations under the present capital-stock tax law may be made so as to avoid the imposition of the excess-profits tax, and the cost of avoidance is included in the capital-stock tax.

The United States Department of State is taking steps to obtain pardons for Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Fernandez Villa, United States naturalized citizens, whom a local Insurgent military court last month sentenced to twenty and twelve years, respectively, in prison for "sympathizing " with the enemy.
Delegates to the Fall conference of the State Business Education Association were advised today to develop night schools for post-graduate study.

Loans aggregating $27,830,000 for the construction of new homes were mado by savings, building and loan associations to approximately 8,800 persons during October, reports the United States Building and Loan League.

An entertainment that will be of unusual interest both to children and their elders is now being arranged for the Christmas season as a benefit for the New York Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital at 420 East Fifth-ninth Street.

The eel fisherman down on his luck, who cast his line in the East River Friday night, fished out "one of the most mystifying cases that has occurred in the Postoffice Department." Thus bafflement was the professed official status last night of a mail theft that has reached a known loss of $60,000.

The screams of half a dozen Negroes fleeing to the roof of a blazing rooming house in Harlem, in which the body of one person later was found burned beyond recognition, were responsible yesterday for saving the life of a baby apparently born dead during the height of the excitement.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Chace of this city and Mystic, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Ray Chace, to Gustav George Freygang 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav G. Freygang of Weehawken, N. J. The announcement was made at a luncheon given by Mr. and Mrs. Chace yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton.

Education of the New York City electorate in proportional -representation is one of the municipality's greatest needs, according to a survey conducted by the Social Research Laboratory at City College, the results of which were announced last week by J. Elliott Fisher, director of the project.
The young National Guardsmen of the Seventh Regiment (107th Infantry) presented a glittering Mexican Fiesta last night in their armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Members of the housing committee of the American Federation of Labor declared today that they were not worried about the confirmation of Nathan Straus as Housing Administrator and they criticized his opponents as being "more interested in long-term politics than in a longterm housing program."

First Lieutenant William F. Tierney, VetRes., now on active duty at Headquarters Trenton District, CCC, Trenton, N. J., is continued on active duty until June 19. 1938. Leave of absence for fifteen days, effective on or about Dec. 5, 1937, to terminate not later than Dec. 20,. 1937,

President Roosevelt's promise of a balanced budget for the fiscal year 1938-1939 will be advanced through slashes amounting to $800,000,000 below the amounts appropriated last year by Congress for Federal expenses, it is understood on Capitol Hill, following reports that the Bureau of the Budget has already agreed on the cuts to be made.

A gift of $10,000 to the United Hospital Fund was announced yesterday on behalf of John W. Davis, chairman of the drive. The donor was William Nelson Cromwell. Gifts of $4,000 by John Hay Whitney, $2,500 by Miss Edith Scoville and $2,000 by Robert Beaver Smith also were listed, as well as twoscore from $100 to $1,000.
Mmes. Anna Burke, Eliza Musser and Rebecca Reybar, representing the Peoples Mandate "flying caravan," arrived here yesterday and were entertained by Boaz W. Long, the American Minister.

Duquesne University scored a 9-0 victory over Mississippi State today with a field goal and a last-minute touchdown from an intercepted pass. With two minutes to play, the Dukes reached the State 6 with a first down, but three plays left the oval 3 yards short of the goal.

A statement significantly bearing on cooperation in the Danube Valley, particularly between Austria and Czechslovakia, appeared in yesterday's Reichspost, which cites approvingly passages in an article in the Essener National Zeitung.

Soviet organs are stressing that the vote whereby the Supreme Council will be elected will be secret, but the authorities today significantly informed the voters that it would be perfectly lega for them to sign their own names on the ballots.

William L. Hayward. one of the most prominent woolen manufacturers in New England, died suddenly at noon today at his home here. He was 52 years of age. Born in East Douglas, he attended the old Worcester Military Academy and was graduated from Lowell Textile School.

A display of anti-religious propaganda from Soviet Russia will be one of the features of an anti-God exhibit of blasphemous cartoons, newspapers, magazines and other material which will be privately shown at the Center Club, 120 Central Park South, for five days, starting tomorrow.

The recent ruling by Federal Administrator Stewart McDonald which enables field offices of the FHA to make tentative acceptance of both large and small scale rental housing projects was hailed yesterday by Thomas G. Grace,...

A Golden Rule Dinner for the benefit of the civilian war victims in the Orient will be held Thursday evening at the Biltmore Hotel, closing a stewardship conference of leaders called by the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery.

The mysterious elements which alone are responsible for the disturbed situation in Palestine are again working with renewed energy. The writer learns from the most reliable source that several agitators arrived in Palestine from Syria within the last week.
WASHINGTON.--The value of the annual sales of industries covered by trade-practice agreements is well over a billion dollars, the Federal Trade Commission recently disclosed.

Application for re-hearing by the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals of a suit involving tariff rates on imported felt hat bodies will be made by John Lerch, attorney for domestic producers, early this week.

THERE is a classic story about a Governor of one of the States of the deep South who replied to an invitation to attend a conference on interracial relations with the statement that the race problem in his State had been solved. The story is genuinely illustrative of the method through which some political dignitaries solve the problem by rationalization.

Chinese forces on the Yangtze front are rallying desperately in an effort to stem the Japanese advance into the outer defenses of Nanking. Following the loss of the Kiangyin forts and Tanyang on the Nanking-Shanghai Railway, the Chinese troops are reforming on a line from Chinkiang on the Yangtze south through a point west of Liyang and down to Szean.

Mrs. Charles Baker Hester will give a tea on Wednesday at her home, 1,261 Madison Avenue, for members of the parents' committee of the Children's Playshop who are arranging a square dance in behalf of the organization to be held Friday night at the Heckscher Foundation for Children.

The government last night prohibited the sale of several anti-Nazi books, among them the famous Hitler biography by Konrad. Heiden and another by Rudolf Olden, and a history of the thirtieth of June, 1934, by Otto Strasser.

A symbol of the tremendous growth in the city's public higher education system, Wadleigh High School this week celebrates its fortieth anniversary as the first high school for girls established in Manhattan.

ACHILD of Polish intellectuals in Russian Poland in the last century learned early that the only things which may never be taken from you are those which you carry in your head, and also that life is for many a continual struggle.
THIS is a worthy companion piece to the author's "A Star for Hansi." for like that lovely little book this one, too. epitomizes the spirit of giving.

A "decided gain in favorable sentiment" toward the present State liquor laws and administration-especially in the dry counties-as compared with the situation two years ago was found in a survey by the State Liquor Authority, according to the December issue of the A B C News, the authority's monthly organ, published today.

Reorganization managers for the United Telephone and Electric Company have filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a declaration covering the issuance of securities by a new company, not yet named, to be set up as the result of reorganization of United Telephone.

Hitting its stride in the third period after a dull first half, the Rutgers basketball team opened its season with a 43-26 victory over the University of Delaware five before a crowd of 1,500 in the Rutgers gymnasium today.

Dive bombing as it is practiced by the air forces of the leading powers was demonstrated at the All-American air manoeuvres here today by fortyone Marine Corps planes in command of Colonel Roy S. Geiger of Quantico, Va.

Severe Rightist attacks upon Minister of Interior Marx Dormoy were beaten off by the government when his Ministry's budget was voted in the Chamber of Deputies today. The session was a noisy one in which tension over the numerous arrests in the Cagoulard [Hooded Ones] plot came to the surface and every means was used to force the government to drop its prosecution of the plot.

John E. Sawyer, '38, of Worcester, will next week become the first Williams undergraduate to be taught by the new president, James P. Baxter 3d. Having said in his address at the opening of college that he hoped to do some lecturing and to take a section in American

The Lambs, a theatrical organization numbering many prominent performers in its membership, held its annual Winter gambol last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Thirteen hundred persons attended the gambol, which was for the benefit of the memorial and relief fund of The Lambs.

Although the issuance of so-called distinctive automobile license plates for 1938 by the Motor Vehicle Bureau in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, will not cease until Dec. 20, a large majority of the 13,000 favored motor-car owners have taken up their claims.

TODAY Denver String Quartet plays Schumann's Quartet No. 1, Opus 41. Members of the group are Henry Trustman Ginsberg and Richard Sears, violinists; Robert R. Becker, violist, and Frank John, 'cellist: WEAF, 12 M.

To hear the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in the great studio in Radio City, one month after its public debut as a new symphonic organization, was to realize what has been accomplished in an amazingly short space of time by this magnificent body of players, and also what has been achieved, in the same interval, in improving acoustical conditions in the concert room and radio transmission of the performances.

KEYNOTES of broadcasting that must be strengthened and preserved in the American democracy are freedom and fairness of the air, William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, told the members of the second national conference on educational broadcasting, assembled in Chicago last week.

IN that wild and sparsely populated strip between the north rim of the Grand Canyon and the southern boundary of Utah a herd of some 600 wild mustangs has long been a source of annoyance to cattlemen. These hardy horses, though smaller than the average ranch horse, are nevertheless voracious eaters, and in a land where forage is none too plentiful for the cattle the amount consumed by them is important.

Miss Janet St. Clair Mullan, daughter of the late Justice and Mrs. George V. Mullan, and her fiance, Frederick Giller Duncan, were the guests of honor at a large tea given yesterday by Miss Diana Tate Smith at the home of her pital. mother, Mrs. Baedes D. Smith,

The Transport Workers Union of America, C. I. O. affiliate, suggested to the State Labor Relations Board yesterday that it make the city, as distinguished from the Board of Transportation, a party to conferences on the union's demand for recognition as sole bargaining agent for the 5,400 employes of the Independent Subway System.

A typhoon of high intensity advanced tonight on the Central Philippines, a region in which two similar storms wrought death and havoc three weeks ago. The new storm immediately isolated the island of Samar, on the east central fringe of the archipelago, where typhoon signal No. 6 was hoisted.

Three student representatives, selected by the Student Council from their own ranks, will help for the first time to control student activities at Brooklyn College. The reorganization this semester of the Faculty Committee on Student Activities into a joint student-faculty

Two of Chicago's leading grain statisticians, both former experts for the Department of Agriculture, testified here today at a hearing held for that department that the government had been inconclusive in charts and figures presented in support of a change which it is seeking in the rules for trading in grain.

After the devastating temperatures of a couple of years ago many gardeners went to the extreme in providing plant "protection" last Winter. Doubtless this season, the 193637 Winter having been mild, many will swing back to a careless attitude toward this important chore.
CORSICAN FAMILY: French police, investigating the alleged revolutionary plots of the "Hooded Ones," last week clapped into the old Sante prison, on charges of
Ten motion pictures filmed in or depicting subjects pertinent to the life and history of six countries are announced for presentation as a feature of the second season of the Wesleyan Cinema Club.

TOMORROW night, at his violin recital in Carnegie Hall, Yehudi Menuhin will give the first public performance in America of the much discussed posthumous, or, as many publications erroneously put it, "lost" violin concerto in D minor of Robert Schumann.

Through special remedial treatment, 3,000 New York City school children, failing in their class work because of reading difficulties, vere elevated to a higher school level at the end of a three-year experiment conducted by the Child Guidance Bureau of the Board of Education.

Mr. and Mrs. George A. Dorr of Newport, N. H., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Helen Dorr, to Charles Young Wadsworth, son of Lewis L. Wadsworth of Winchester, Mass., and the late Mrs. Wadsworth.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schey gave a large supper dance last night at the Pierre for their debutante daughter, Miss Theresa Todd Schey, for whom they gave a tea at their home, 895 Park Avenue, last Sunday.

The Japanese occupation of part of Shanghai's International Settlement on Friday has raised serious questions here, but there is no indication that the British Goverment will take an aggressive position.

THE task of most economists has ever been to tell us that things that are deserve to be because they fulfill the purpose for which they exist. From Plato to Pareto and Pigou, authoritative exponents of economic doctrines could be depended upon to present a logical justification of the status quo.
BETWEEN now and Spring American motorists will spend about $67,000,000 for automobile radiator anti-freezes, according to a recent report made before the American Chemical Society by Dr. H. C. Duus.

Sheriff George H. Bradford of New London County, Republican leader in Eastern Connecticut for many years, died today at the age of 69. His death followed by seven months that of his close political ally, J. Henry Roraback, for many years a member of a powerful Republican bloc in the East.

A painting entitled "Our Lady of the Cardinals," depicting the Madonna and Christ Child and a group of Cardinals, was ??veiled last night in the vestibule of the Holy Name Roman Catholic Church, Ninety-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York and pastor of the church.

The annual tea of the New York Alumnae of Pi Beta Phi, which takes place this afternoon in the clubrooms of the New York City Panhellenic at Beekman Tower, will be augmented by a benefit sale in the interest of the Pi Beta Phi Settlement. School in Gatlinburg, Tenn.

Scoring its second successive victory by defeating the Essex Club today, 4--1, the Montclair Athletic Club took the lead in the New Jersey Class C division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association in defense of the title it won a year ago.

The revamping of the tax system, land registration and foreclosure reform and a possible tapering off of the mortgage moratorium are among the matters which demand the immediate attention of real estate men, states Benjamin J. Rabin, chairman of the State Mortgage Commission.

State statutes prohibiting retailers from selling goods at less than cost plus a minimum mark-up force consumers to pay excessive prices on staple products which can be handled profitably at little more than cost, according to an attack launched by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company against the minimum price statute of Minnesota.

As snowflakes lent an appropriate Dickens setting, the novelist's old house at 48 Doughty Street, London, where he wrote "Oliver Twist" and "Nicholas Nickleby," was opened today, restored as nearly as possible to the condition it was in in 1837. The ceremony was performed by Lady Dickens, 86-year-old widow of the novelist's son, who became a judge.

Plinio Salgado, leader of the Fascist Integralist party dissolved yesterday by Presidential decree, said today that the party will follow the demands of the official order. However, he explained, the party now will become a cultural and benevolent organization and will change its name in accordance with President Vargas's decree.

The influence of science and engineering on the modern arts will be the subject of an international symposium at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology next June. The symposium will consider not only the obvious applications of industrial design but the intangible and subtle effects of science on music and other art forms.
THE High Coat of Living Blinks across the front page again: the same old familiar H. C. L. that afflicts the American people with pain in the pocketbook nerve every so often, or oftener.

PARIS. PARIS is changing, and changing fast. The fact is undeniable, but whether Paris is changing for better or for worse is a matter for endless argument. One may set aside at the outset the jeremiads of the oldest visitor who can proudly remember the days when there were no shops in that sacred mile between the Concorde and the Arc de Triomphe. when one drove leisurely along the boulevards in a horse-drawn fiacre.

For Wellesley students, enrolled in a seminar on the Education of Young Children, a fourth has been added to the customary "Three R's." "Ruggedness," if that term may be applied to healthful wellbeing and normal growth development, is considered as much the aim of modern education as a mastery of reading,' 'ritin' and 'rithmetic."

The activities of Tufts College during the past quarter century have been perpetuated photographically by Professor Melville S. Munro of the engineering school faculty, and he has just started on the recording of the next twenty-five years.
A dispatch from Chicago recording the death there of Tell Taylor, 61, music publisher, stated that he was the author of a popular song of

Midnight Star, a black gelding, won the $2,500 world's championship five-gaited saddle stake tonight at the closing horse show of the thirty-eighth International Live Stock Exposition. The victory gave the Leisure Hour Stables at San Antonio, Texas, a trophy in addition to the cash award. Frank Heathman was riding.
ACCORDING to the latest available figures, necessarily incomplete, there are more than 150,000,000 people who are members of cooperatives doing a total business of $67,000,000,000 a year.

The discovery of a new and safe tuberculosis vaccine, which its discoverers believe will confer a limited immunity to the disease, is reported in the current issue of The Journal of Experimental Medicine, a publication of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

A jury before Federal Judge John W. Clancy filed yesterday a verdict awarding $10,000 to Mrs. Margaret E. Moffett of 2 Keer Avenue, Newark, N. J., for the death of her husband, Montgomery Moffett, an attorney, in a hotel elevator mishap here.

Mayor La Guardia will name Almerindo Portfolio, retired cloak manufacturer, now president of the Bank of Sicily of New York, as City Treasurer, effective Jan. 1, it was disclosed yesterday. Formal announcement of the appointment is expected soon.

That "extra something" which, added to the bare subsistence afforded by home relief, fortifies family morale, is provided in the case of indigent Syrian people in the City of New York by an organization of women which for thirty years has worked to keep unimpaired the Syrians' record of a minimum of crime and juvenile delinquency among the immigrant peoples of the metropolis.

Preparations are under way for am elaborate program of Christmas music by the Campus Glee Club at Georgian Court College here. The organization of fifty-seven members is under the direction of Nicola a. Montani, member of the Music Department faculty.
New York a la "Tobacco Road" To the Drama Editor: According to the drama columns, Dec. 4 marks the fourth misleading year of "Tobacco Road." The adjective "misleading" is my own.
MAYFAIR is looking forward to a return of the old days at the British Court. As though to set the stage. King Leopold of the Belgians recently paid a state visit to Buckingham Palace;

THE Presidential train is a "Radio City" on wheels. When Mr. Roosevelt decides to go on a trip in quest of "first-hand knowledge of the nation as a whole," word is flashed to the broadcasters to prepare the Presidential car and a radio crew for the journey across the rails.
Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Felt of 1,035 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruby M. Felt, to Dr. Sidney D. Leader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Leader. also of this city.

The first intercollegiate debate on this year's program of the Preston Debating Society of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel will take place on Thursday, when Good Counsel will meet Hofstra College of New York University here.

Announcement was made yesterday by C. H. Pearsall, president of the Colombian Steamship Company, that one of the three fast mail steamships that have been operated between Panama and San Francisco has been purchased from the United Fruit Company.

Miss Bessie Beatty of the National Garment Label Council will discuss the consumers' protection label and Edward J. Slynn Jr., chief investigator for the Division of Minimum Wage, the minimum wage enforcement, at a meeting of the Consumers League of New Jersey at the Newark Y. W. C. A. Thursday.

Charles Abrams, counsel for the American Federation of Housing Authorities, said yesterday that the success of the President's new housing policy will depend largely on the possibility of devising effective controls on land and material costs.

Elevator care and maintenance will be the topic of the operating forum and luncheon of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York on Thursday in the Town Hall Club. Charles A. Flynn will be the chief speaker.

Frank S. O'Hara, Jackson Heights broker, will be formally installed as president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at its inaugural luncheon for the coming season on Wednesday, Dec. 15, at the Hotel Commodore.

Memories of old New York will be stirred to life on Thursday night with a revival of The Fireman's Ball at the American Music Hall, 141 East Fifty-fifth Street. Men and women of prominence in society and theatrical circles are cornbining efforts toward the success of the evening's entertainment, which has been arranged as a benefit for the Stage Relief Fund.

Frederick P. Bryan, Assistant Corporation Counsel in charge of tort litigation, will become First Assistant Corporation Counsel on Jan. 1, succeeding William C. Chandler, who becomes Corporation Counsel on that date. Announcement of Mr. Bryan's coming promotion was made yesterday by Mr. Chandler.

IN this beautiful book Audubon's paint ings of the birds of America are brought together for the first time in a single volume and placed within reach of the general public. The original Elephant Folios, engraved in Edinburgh and London, appeared in parts over eleven years. beginning in 1826.

Yale seniors will throng the offices of the Department of Personnel and Bureau of Appointments during the next two weeks seeking the answer to a question which transcends anything that may be asked in their final examinations.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that Judge John C. Bowen had signed a permanent decree in the Federal District Court for the Western District of Washington enjoining the Nicholson Creek Mining Corporation from selling more of its securities without registering them under the Securities Act of 1933.

Councilmen-elect of the American Labor party met yesterday at the Hotel Brevoort and decided to organize a research bureau of their own, the better to perform their functions as members of the lower house of the city's legislature.
efficient living." he adds succinctly, "would r u i n any nation." No, the Chinese, disarmingly candid. are not efficient:

THE old saw about it being an ill wind which blows nobody good finds pertinent application in the French film indus try today, according to Jean Lenauer, manager of the local Filmarte Theatre, who has just returned from a picture shopping trip to Paris and a consequent observation of the production facilities over there.

Inventories of dry goods jobbers for the country as whole as of Dec. 1 stood about 2 per cent below those of a year ago, despite an increase of about 15 per cent in stocks of both heavy underwear and work clothing, according to estimates by resident offices here yesterday.

Several younger members of society are aiding in the plans for card party in behalf of the Maternity Center Association which will be held Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Lafayette Guild of the association.

It was exactly forty years ago tomorrow that Bernhard von Buelow, the Kaiser's Foreign Secretary, declared: "We do not want to put any one in the shade, but we demand for ourselves a place in the sun."

Operations at Floyd Bennett Field, the municipal airport in Brooklyn, were suspended for thirty minutes yesterday afternoon while airport officials and pilots tried to "corral" a runaway plane. Some 2,000 persons who had been lured to the field by the fine weather witnessed the chase.

George Thomas 3d, treasurer of the Lukens Steel Company of Coatesville, breakfasted with members of his family today, then went to his study on the third floor of his home at Whitford. Later he was found shot to death with a .32-caliber revolver.

PARAMOUNT shuffled its production schedule around the other day, with the result that the long deferred "The Light That Failed" now is on the immediate shooting calendar and may face the cameras before the new year.
Wigs and Cues. the student dramatic society at Barnard College. is preparing to present "The Admirable Crichton" by J. M. Barrie in Brinkerhoff Theatre on the campus on Dec. 17 and 18.

The Winter concert of the Greenwhich Choral Society will be held Christ Episcopal Church Monday evening. The group of seventy-five voices will present Handel's "Messiah," as well as a group of Christmas carols.
Patrick Henry Murray, retired contractor, succumbed today to the illness which brought his daughter by ship and train from Batavia, Dutch East Indies, to his bedside. He was 74 years old.

A report on the success of the settlers in the autonomous Jewish territory of Birobidjan, Soviet Russia, was made last night by Aaron Lipper, chairman of the budget and policy committee of the American Committee for the Settlement of Jews in Birobidjan.

Miss Mabel A. Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Matthews of Hempstead, was married to Webster J. Nesselhauf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert G. Nesselhauf of this place, here this afternoon in the Garden City Community Church by the Rev. John Gardner.

Actual application of the rules requiring rayon marking, as promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission, continues to more-or less hang fire as the various divisions of the manufacturing trades and the retailers seek to get together on a mutual observance program.
WHATEVER advance expectations may have been concerning the exposition in Rockefeller Center which calls itself Dance International, the public response thus far has almost certainly exceeded them.

General Francisco Franco is now harvesting a bumper crop of olives for olive oil pressing. The trees are laden with fruit in quantities unseen in many years past. Nationalist [Insurgent] authorities are meeting the situation efficiently,
NELLY WEETON, named for the British privateer which her father commanded during the American War, belonged to that class of individuals of whom we are wont to speak as being before their time;

Thirty-two campus organizations at Manhattan College have placed on file with the Student Council their rosters of officers, it was revealed by Edward J. Shaughnessy of Waltham, Mass., president of the governing body.

THE new Hungarian Quartet gave a concert in the Salle Gaveau recently. This new group is composed of unusually gifted musicians and their ensemble is close to perfection. A Mozart quartet in G major, Bartok's Quartet No. 5 and Beethoven's quartet, Opus 95, in F minor, made up the program. The extremely rapid passage work in the last movement of the Mozart quartet was enunciated with impeccable clarity by the players.

The entire "Leader Corps" of the National Socialist regime, including members of the Cabinet, party chiefs and high government officials, turned out today to swing collection boxes in public streets for the benefit of the National Socialist Winter relief campaign.

SYDNEY, Australia.-Javanese ox-drivers' thoughtfulness for their beasts has opened an export market in old automobile and truck tires for Australia. The Javanese use the tires to make shoes to protect the feet of their oxen from the stony roads and tracks. Truck tires are preferred because they are thicker.

In a little 13x13 room over a garage on Cape Cod Dr. Frederick S. Hammett of the Marine Experimental Station of the Lankenau Hospital, Philadelphia, has been setting an example of what can be done in cancer research by the methods adopted in great industrial laboratories.

The Ridgewood Polo Club, national junior indoor champion, signalized its return to action tonight by trouncing the New York A. C. trio, 12 to 5 1/2, in a fast game before a crowd of 2,000 at the Essex Troop Armory.

FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City THE NEW YORK TIMES today makes its twenty-sixth yearly appeal. Here, on these pages, are printed 100 stories of tragic want; of want that cuts deeper than hunger and cold; of the deepest want known to exist in the city today.

A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. at the board headquarters, 500 ParkAvenue. Election of an associate superintendent is scheduled for this meeting. Plans for the 1938 building program will also be considered.

With the fall of Nanking imminent and China's submission still "obstinately" withheld, the government here is perplexed regarding the next move and its perplexity is reflected in the press. Officials admit the difficulty.

The third meeting of the central committee for the Vassar Club's opera benefit next month will take place on Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Winchester Noyes, 45 East Sixty-second Street. Several out-of-town representatives of the committee will be among the guests.

The Hudson River Junior Service League gave a tea and preview of an exhibit of photographs at its clubhouse here today. The show, which includes one hundred photographs exhibited by residents of Western Westchester, will be open to the public tomorrow and will be continued through Wednesday.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Dec. 1, which included only five business days, aggregated $7,801,000,000, or 3 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 20 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year, which also included only five business days.

Manhattan College's new $300.000 library, erected in honor of Cardinal Hayes, a member of the class of 1888. will be dedicated on April 25, 1938, it was announced yesterday by Brother Patrick, F. S. C., president.

The Federal Trade Commission expects to start hearings in January in two cases against the Ford Motor Company and General Motors Corporation. At the same time the Department of Justice is said to be negotiating with the same concerns and the Chrysler Corporation as well, for a stipulation in the department's case charging the companies with dictating to their dealers as to which finance company their installment retail sales should be made through.

The West End Synagogue, 158 West Eighty-second Street, has been completely reconstructed and remodeled after the original building was destroyed in an incendiary fire set last March by its caretaker, it was announced yesterday by Harry N. Wessel, president of the congregation.
With a view to helping needy students, the University of Maine has constructed six cabins that will reduce by about half the living expenses of the twenty-two students occupying them.

Production and sales of gypsum and gypsum products in the JulySeptember quarter of 1937 show increases over the corresponding period of 1936 in all but a few of the items reported to the Bureau of Mines by the operators.

FOR the first time in philately's history, stamps have been released in tribute to a coun try's "smoke eaters." Panama's long-heralded "Jubileo Cuerpo de Bomberos" (Fire Department Jubilee) series has been received.

The Regional Plan Association made public yesterday its quadrennial list of "urgent major public works for New York and environs, embracing forty-two projects which the association believes should be advanced or completed by the end of 1940.

A glitter ball was held here tonight at the Wee Burn Club under the auspices of the Darien Community Association, of which Mrs. George P. MacNichol is president. Mrs. Victor J. M. Hugo-Vidal was chairman of the committee arranging the event.

Dickinson Straith Talley of 106 Glenwood Avenue, an attorney for the American Mutual Insurance Liability Company, New York died of pneumonia yesterday at United Hospital in Portchester after a brief illness. He was 36 years old.

New home-mortgage loans made by all active savings and loan associations in the United States aggregated $660,229,000 in the first ten months of this year, an average of slightly more than $66,000,000 a month, according to a summary issued today by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
WHEN a pretty actress gifted with a winsome personality comes to Hollywood from the Continent she is inevitably slated to be a "glamour girl" of one' sort or another.

Scenes are being shifted behind the curtain in the present controversy between the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission which should result in a more amicable working spirit between Washington and Wall Street.
MORE than two score new exhibitions again clamored for attention on the art calendar last week, all of them continuing through the present week, or longer in cases where a closing date is mentioned.

Although the trend was not uniform, a sharp increase in holiday buying, together with colder weather in some districts, brought a sufficient stimulus to retail trade to reverse the downward trend of the last several weeks.

George Clemens Lenorth, 23 years old, a steamfitter, of 110 West Eleventh Street, Linden, N. J., was killed today when his ten-year-old unlicensed Stinson cabin plane crashed. Although he had been flying five years, according to his mother, he had only a student's permit. The license card said the machine was "not licensed or registered" as airworthy. The commercial license numerals had not been painted off since the license expired, however.

Mr. and Mrs. John Alden Knight of Orange, formerly of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally M. Knight, to Paul Edward Godknecht, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Godknecht of Brooklyn.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls increased their lead in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight by defeating the New York Rovers, 5-1. Bunny McKillop led the attack for the Gulls with two unassisted goals.

As the site for a six-story apartment house, a vacant plot 100 by 105 feet on the west side of Morris Avenue, north of 183d Street, the Bronx, was sold by the Sternschauss estate to Bio Associates, Inc., Abe Spirer, president. The sale was negotiated by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., brokers, and was the first involving the propertv in more than forty years.
LONDON OF the eight British Prime Ministers during the present century. James Ramsay MacDonald was probably the best-read man.
Ernest Recco, vaudeville comedian for thirty years, died in the stage's best tradition here last night. Known as "Ridiculous Recco." he collapsed in a tiny theatre. His age was 57.

" A Deeper Root" (Little Brown. $2.50}. by William Chace Greene, is a story of the owner of a New England textile mill who identifies himself with his mill and with the town of which it is the mainstay.

FULL directions are given here for preserving and shrinking (to the size of an orange) the head of any enemy you may intend to decapitate; and while you may not have any immediate use for such information, it is well to be prepared for eventualities.

Canada's primary iron and steel industry has now been operating on an upward trend for nearly five years. The low point of the recent trade recession was reached in 1932 and output since has increased steadily.

Police protection was invoked yesterday by the Coal Merchants Association to guard against violence in the delivery of coal to homes, apartment buildings and business establishments. Coal trimmers employed by members of the merchants group were called out on strike on Friday by the Coal Trimmers Association, an affiliate of the C. I. O. Inland Boatmen's Union.

Families gathered in their homes on Christmas Eve will have an opportunity to bring relief and cheer to many destitute and friendless girls by subscribing to "the Phantom Ballet," "a non-performance hearthside benefit" for the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help.

TWO of the Metropolitan Opera's benison of revivals should reach the stage next week: "Otello" and "Romeo et Juliette." The new sets by Don ald Oenslager for Verdi's penultimate opera were seen resting against the fuliginous Seventh Avenue wall last week, evidently pausing en route before being set up, on the stage for a scene rehearsal,
