A collection of relics from the Tut-ankh-Amen tomb, consigned to an undisclosed destination in New York, was ??en today in the London dock district.

The Freeport Sulphur Company has produced 1,100,000 tons of elemental sulphur at Grand Ecaille. La.. in the swampy delta, since production got under way four years ago, L. M. Williams Jr., president, announced yesterday.

BONOM--GOLDBERG--Mrs. Fanny Schancupp Goldberg announces marriage of her daughter. Clarice Juliet Goldberg, to Mr. Samuel Bonom. FREEMAN--WOLFF--Mr. and Mrs. Louis Wolff of Brooklyn announce the marriage of their daughter, Ethel' Lynn, to Mr. Arthur R. Freeman of New York City on Nov. 28, 1937.
Josef W. Najman, Minister of Trade and Economics, died today of a stroke at the age of 55. He belonged to the Czech Industrial party.

IN the year 1898 Joseph Joachim, the moat famous violinist of his generation, celebrated in Berlin his sixtieth jubilee, which I attended, and that same year Andreas Moser, Joachim's friend and pupil, published his biography, entitled simply 'Joseph Josohim.'

I am frequently asked how I can bring myself to violate the original experience that must have informed some poem, by revising it at a later time when my experience must be different. My only answer is that.
Membership in the Metropolitan Opera Guild has been made available to Girl Scouts through special gifts, Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., chairman of the Greater New York Federation, announced yesterday.

Mme. Rosika Schwimmer, whose peace activities in the last twentyfive years have left her a woman without a country, accepted yesterday a fund of $8,300 raised by admirers in twenty-four countries. She detailed a plan for an all-inclusive, non-military democratic federation of nations she believes would bring peace.

Miss Helen Rodgers of this place, daughter of Mrs. Jennie Rodgers of Clinton, Mass., and the late Charles Rodgers, was married this 'afternoon to Walter Erskine Bradley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erskine H. Bradley of Greenwich, at the home of the bridegroom's parents, by the Rev. Andrew F. Chamberlain, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church.

At the cancer symposium held last nweek in Philadelphia by the Lankenau Hospital Dr. Stanley P. Reimann made the important announcement that Dr. Frederick S. Hammett has discovered one reason why cells develop into arms, legs, eyes and brains.

Hershey continued its upward march in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight, defeating the Bronx Tigers, 4 to 0. Hershey scored its first goal early in the game when Tony Graboski sent the puck into the net on a perfect pass from Jo Graboski.

FOR a while it seemed that people were no longer interested in what and how much their neighbors ate at the morning meal. But a letter. published recently in THE NEW YORK TIMES, describing the hearty Vermont breakfast, let loose the forces of an eternal dispute.

LABOR DAY is popularly supposed to mark the opening of each new season of drama, but since the theatre is ruled by tradition rather than time many managers are indifferent to that date and its portents.

The Eastern championship of the National Football League will be at stake today when the Washington Redskins, the defending titleholders, and the New York Giants collide at the Polo Grounds in the grand finale to the professional season here that it expected to be witnessed by a banner crowd of 50,000. The kick-off is scheduled for 2 P. M., the earliest of the year.

Bennington College students are busy coping with their annual unemployment problems as the Winter field and reading period is only three weeks off and during January and February Bennington girls must go out into the world. on projects of their own.

Bruce Barton, newly elected Representative from the Seventeenth Congressional District, declared yesterday that labor would "rue the day if it ever permitted hours and wages to be fixed by bureaucrats at Washington."

The sixteenth biennial Exposition of Chemical Industries will open tomorrow afternoon at the Grand Central Palace with the most comprehensive collection of industrial exhibits in its history. The show, which will continue through Saturday, will include hundreds of new products and processes of manufacture.

Traffic through the Panama Canal in November declined, according to a report by the War Department. Last month 435 commercial vessels passed through the canal and paid tolls of $1,893,462, as compared with 461 vessels and tolls of $1,981,087.87 in October.

THE broadcasters hope to avert a musicians' strike that threatens to paralyze radio programs on Dec. 15. Labor, through the International Board of the Federation of Musicians, warned the broadcasters in August that they were not employing enough musicians.

Charles Irving Taylor of 277 South Harrison Street, New York lawyer, a member of the firm of Beardsley Taylor, 64 Wall Street, died early this morning after a brief illness of internal hemorrhages at his home here. He was 63 years old.

Dr. Harvey Jathaniel Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken, has been ti elected head of the American Socity of Mechanical Engineers and will be inducted into office at the fifty-eighth annual meeting tomorrow at the Engineering Societies

REALIZING that from an architectural and archaeological point of view Mitla and Monte Alban, in the high valley of Oaxaca, are the most important of the country's ruins, the Government of Mexico is building motor highways to these places.

The body of Michael Mazzardi, years old, who had been murdered by blows on the head, according to the police, was found yesterday at 9 A. M. floating in the East River at the foot of Washington Street, Brooklyn.

The budget balancers in the Federal Government appear at last to have attained the upper hand, with President Roosevelt himself assuming the leadership, yet nothing could disarrange all his calculations so quickly and effectively as a sharp rise in unemployment, with a corresponding increase in relief needs.

IN line with the prevailing trend In the automotive industry to provide localized facilities for servicing precision parts of motor vehicles and to better serve car owners, the AC Spark Plug Division of General Motors announces that it has established fuel-pump rebuilding stations in twenty-one cities, where pumps needing repairs will be rebuilt by authorized rebuilders and distributed to dealers.

Clearings of the Westchester County Clearing House Association for the week through Wednesday amounted to $4,258,997, against $3,444,458 for the preceding week and $2,596,947 for the corresponding week in 1936.
Lovers of old San Francisco feared that the great new San FranciscoOakland and Golden Gate bridges would put the picturesque- sidewheel ferries of the bay out of business.
A "great national bridge party" to aid the fight against infantile paralysis will be held next year, it was announced tonight by officials of the American Contract Bridge League.

Miss Marjorie E. Agor, daughter of Mrs. Edward S. Agor of this place, and the late Mr. Agor, was married to Paul F. Cole, son of Mrs. Daniel H. Cole of Carmel, and the late Mr. Cole, this afternoon in the Presbyterian church here.

Despite some curtailment in the last week of November, rayon yarn producers entered December with stocks amounting to about 1.6 months' supply, which was an increase of a half a month's supply over that of the first of November, it was estimated unofficially yesterday.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding week, principally because of the calling of many small amounts of municipal, real estate and religious institutional bonds. The calls, however, were mostly for retirements in future months, only a few small amounts of municipal bonds and one industrial loan being added to the December list.

John W. Van Allen of Buffalo, N. Y., said today in an address before manufacturers and wholesalers of automobile parts that the taxing and regulatory policies of the Roosevelt Administration had "undermined business."

Governor Lehman will speak on religious education at the Chanukkah dinner of the Jewish Education Association tonight at the Hotel Astor, it was announced yesterday by Harry H. Liebovitz, president of the association.

The Women's University Club, which two months ago announced it would move because of maintenance costs, will establish new headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore on Jan. 1. The organization has taken a nine-month lease on an entire floor of one wing, Miss Martha E. Dodson, president, said yesterday.
IT is remarkable with what sobriety and solemnity Mr. Fletcher embarks on this ac count of his life, this "onward earthtrack, never transcended," to quote from a poet he would approve of.

The apartment house for fiftynine families at 200 Pinehurst Avenue, near West 187th Street, has been sold by the Hallcrest Building Corporation to an investing client of Nathan Strunsky, broker. It was erected by the seller in 1935 and contains 186 rooms. Delson, Levin Gordon represented the buyer and Fred S. Weitzner the seller.

A week hence 100,000,000 Soviet citizens, virtually the entire population, male and female, over the age of 18, will go to the polls for the first election under the new Constitution. Elaborate efforts will be made to bring out the total vote;

IF the Industry's plans materialize, 1938 will be noted for the documentary flavor of its fare. Of all the cycles-and that includes the gangster series-none has been as pretentious as that which looms.

MONTREAL.--Modern inventions are dismounting the picturesque Mounties who police all but three Provinces of Canada. Motor cycles, motor cars, motor trucks and airplanes are being substituted swiftly for saddle horses.

A young man in a stolen automobile snatched a purse from a woman in Selwyn Avenue, the Bronx, last night. She jumped to the running board of the car and held on until the thief beat her off with a wrench. In doing so he lost control of the car and had to abandon it, but escaped with her $25.

Hazel M. Adams, clerk at the Bloomfield Bank and Trust Company, died today at her home here after a brief illness following an operation for appendicitis. Her age was 29. She was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh M. Adams and was born here.

From Europe, South America and even from China twelve foreign students have traveled to Washington this Fall to study at first hand our government and people. They form the first group of fellows at the Hall of Nations, a new division of the American University Graduate School.

Canadian Government, Provincial and municipal financing in Nomember amounted to $210,016,217 and was the largest for that month in the last five years, according to data compiled by Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.

Charles Reviol, for more than thirty years active in Democratic politics and in the American Federation of Labor, died last night at this home here at the age of 79. During the adminiserved as a justice of the peace and as a police court magistrate.

After the admirable beginnings with Wagner and Strauss and the sop of "Aida" for the Italian repertory on Thursday evening, the Metropolitan Opera Association offered for its first matinee of the season yesterday Massenet's "Manon," with a cast nearly identical with the one which graced the opera when it was revived last Winter.

GEORGE SAINTSBURY once remarked: "As in no case is generalization easier than in the case of the literary [for our purpose, artistic] aspects and tendencies of periods and nations, so in no case is it apt to be more delusive unless corrected and supported by ample information of fact and detail."

Ten weeks of intense activity will be culminated for some 150 Princeton University undergraduates next Friday evening when the Triangle Club, one of the country's leading campus dramatic organizations, opens its forty-ninth annual musical comedy production, "Fol-de-Rol."

The New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities will spend more than half of their joint $6,250,000 budget for services to children, according to a report made yesterday by Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, vice president of the New York Federation and chairman of the board of the women's division.

The seriousness of the Rome-Berlin axis as a threat to peace was minimized, for varying reasons, by unofficial representatives of Germany, Great Britain, France and Italy yesterday at a luncheon discussion arranged by the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor.
Further "loophole plugging" of the income tax laws was tentatively agreed upon today by the Ways and Means Subcommittee, of which Repretentative Vinson of Kentucky is chairman.

WASHINGTON.-Transmitted by United States Navy radio, the proceedings of Congress, summarized by the State Department, are each day placed on the desks of American diplomats in foreign countries, under a news service developed by the department to keep its overseas personnel posted.

Centenary of Shreveport and Louisiana Tech resumed football relations today after a lapse of seven years by playing to a 7-7 deadlock before 6,000 fans. The game was thought on a muddy field and both touchdowns were made in the first period.

Detective Chief L. O. Scarboro said today that a youth giving his name as Phillip C. Rogers, 21, admitted firing a shot that critically wounded Phil Harris, 34, editor in the city's publicity bureau, in an altercation after the South Carolina-Miami football game last night.

Two arrangements constituting important elements of the silver program of the United States are scheduled to expire on Dec. 31. One is the London Silver Agreement, reached by the United States and delegates of seven other nations at the World Economic Conference of 1933.

Eleven student committees were appointed yesterday to serve for the sixth annual "Dean's Drag" of Columbia College, to be held next Saturday in John Jay Hall, Amsterdam Avenue at 114th Street. Proceeds from the dance, which will be attended by students in all four college classes, will be contributed to Dean Herbert E. Hawkes's fund for needy students.
Under the leadership of Sir Archibald Sinclair, Opposition Liberals are organizing a monster petition to Parliament protesting against the high cost of living.

The "rejuvenation" of the British Army Council and the replacement of the Chief of the Imperial General Staff Thursday by a younger man mark the high point of what will probably prove to be the most important and far-reaching reorganization of the British Army in decades.
The Free State will celebrate its fifteenth and last anniversary on Monday. On Dec. 29 the Free State will cease to exist and the new State of Ireland will come into being.

The Junior League will inaugurate tomorrow in its clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, the annual Christmas sale of articles from the occupational therapy workshops of eight hospitals-Bellevue, City, Neurological Institute, New York Infirmary for Women and Children, Presbyterian, Reconstruc-, tion, Hospital for the Ruptured and Crippled, and Roosevelt.
Southampton dockers have refused to unload Japanese goods from the Canadian Pacific liner Duchess of Richmond. The liner will return to Canada next week with the goods still in her hold.

It is easy to forget, with a season just closed, how soon it will again be time for garden planning and seed starting. The planning can of course be done no matter how far the snow drifts spread, nor how deep the ground is frozen. The early starting of seeds is quite another matter.

Richard Rothchild of the Downtown A. C., second on the seeded list, entered the semi-final round in the Long Island open squash racquets championship tournament yesterday at the Jackson Heights Squash Club by defeating Albert Caesar of the home club, 15--9, 15-11, 17--15.

ON Jan. 1 the government of New York City will change over to a new charter. One of the provisions of this document is that the Mayor shall have an assistant, who will assume some of the duties which now rest upon the chief executive.

Thirteen locomotives were ordered in November, according to Railway Age. No orders were placed in October. The total to date this year now is 291. November freightcar orders amounted to 1,625, against 21 in October, and raised the eleven months' total to 49,451.
Largely through the increased demand for its products in essential fields, including the greater use of fuel oil for heating homes, the petroleum industry has solved most of its complex problems.

As though ten-best lists were not bad enough to compile, some one wrote in last week to ask what we considered was the most memorable scene or sequence among all the films, domestic and foreign, shown this year.

Is final victory within the grasp of General Franco's Rebels in Spain? There have been many conjectures to that effect-but there remain many factors of doubt. Except perhaps for the southern area northeastward of Malaga the fighting weather is over, the cold has set in, and the prospects, barring a surprise, are for a stalemate until the Spring or early Summer.

Rearrangement of courses for the second semester at Russell Sage College finds the liberal arts receiving renewed emphasis. Numerous new courses have been added and others chanced to more clearly point up the importance of the arts in a wellrounded, richly filled life.
No more mystery ever surrounded a Houdini masterpiece than cloaked the meeting of the parent assembly of the Society of American Magicians at the McAlpin last night.

Serving human beings with the object always in mind of maintaining their good-will is one of the most important factors in good building management, perhaps, in some respects, the most important, according to H. I. Feldman, architect, in discussing certain problems of successful building management.

" The Background of the Far Eastern War" will be discussed by Nathaniel Peffer at a meeting of the Greater New York branches of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom tomorrow afternoon at 99 Park Avenue.

Lady Grenfell, wife of Sir Wilfred Grenfell, will be guest of honor at a committee meeting and tea to be held on Wednesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Lincoln Cromwell, 711 Park Avenue, for the various groups actively associated

William Turner Pullman of 4 Fairview Place, who retired six years ago as head of John Pullman Co.. New York linen and lace goods firm founded by his late grandfather, died of pneumonia at New Rochelle Hospital yesterday after a short illness. His age was 63.

Harry F. Wolf, the national champion, hurdled into the quarter-final round of the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament at the Harvard Club yesterday by winning from E. P. Field Jr. The two met in a third-round match after C. S. Smith of the Harvard Club had defaulted to the No. 1 player.
With some of Yale's oldest graduates in attendance, 250 Eli alumni gathered tonight for the seventeenth annual barn party in Nick Roberts's Old Yale Barn to honor members of the football team.

THE fourth concert of the New York season of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Dec. 14 will be conducted by Leopold Stokowski, who will present a program consisting of two new American works and his own transcriptions of seven short compositions.

Directors of three companies will meet on Dec. 14 to consider dividend payments on the stook of their concerns. A dividend by the American Metal Company, Ltd., if declared, will be payable on Dec. 24 to holders of record of Dec. 17.

PINEHURST, N. C.--Field trials will continue to divert the resort colony from golf, usually the leading sport, during this week, but golf, along with tennis, horseback riding and skeet shooting, will have a place on the sports schedule.

Miss Muriel Arthur of Ardsley-onHudson, one of the most promising of the young riders, today became the second to qualify this year for the Good Hands Trophy competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden in 1938. She won the Good Hands event, one of the outstanding numbers on the program of the Boulder Brook indoor show.
Secretary Morgenthau denied today that the Bureau of Internal Revenue had singled out the income tax returns of former President Hoover for investigation.

ASWEEPING realignment of the duties of the members of the Federal Communications Commission has been announced by Frank R. McNinch, chairman. Under the new arrangement, effective immediately, each commissioner, to relieve the commission of detail, will, for the period of a month, be assigned to a specific phase of the commission's work.

MISS Mackenzie's study of the sundown of the Anglo-Scottish House of Stuart is an important contribution to the history of a country, a period and an alleged lost cause by far too much ignored, or else wilfully misinterpreted by popular historians of the Macaulay-Trevelyan breed.

Municipally owned and operated public garages will not solve the parking problem which is snarling traffic notably in the midtown area of Manhattan, according to Ralph T. Walker, architect, who is a member of the Mayor's Traffic Committee.
At the request of Germany, negotiations for a commercial agreement will be resumed next Tuesday in Berlin. This appears in direct consequence of a public statement by The Netherlands
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 2: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Bannerman, G., Naval Academy, to Asiatic Station.

Reviewing the sales results during the past six months of properties held by the various savings, building and loan associations in the country, E. C. Baltz, president of the United States Building and Loan League, states that not only are houses being sold at better prices than have been experienced since 1930 but there is also seen a definite speeding up in the transfer of these houses to private ownership.
MANCHURIA, once Japan's lifeline and later its promised land, is now, one finds on the scene, only the abode of uncertainty.

Charges of violation of the National Labor Relations Act were filed against the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday by the Industrial Insurance Agents Union, Local 30, which is affiliated with the C. I. O. through the United Office and Professional Workers of America.
Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer will leave today for Palm Beach to pass the Winter at Capricho, their home.

A $3,000,000 arms deal is in the process of being negotiated here between the American "second-hand arms trust" and China. The sellers constitute a New York group which professes to have cornered 90 per cent of "all secondhand war material now available in the United States."

Proportional representation, which has just had its first trial in New York City, in the election of the City Council, has been urged for many years on the theory that it would provide in New York's-governing body an active intelligent minority which would oppose the representatives of the Tammany majority.
A set of criteria for determining the respective merits of one community over another was made public yesterday by the Institute of Educational Research, Teachers College, Columbia University.

Mrs. Caroline O'Day, vice chairman of the People's Mandate to End War, will preside on Saturday at a luncheon at the Carlton Hotel in Washington at a formal welcome back to this country for the "Flying Caravan," now touring the Latin Americas on behalf of the ratificastion of the peace treaties adopted at the Buenos Aires conference of last December.

Ambassador Oskar P. Trautmann of Germany left Nanking for Hankow early this morning after a hurried visit to confer with Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek on possible peace terms. His unexpected departure, after only one conference with the generalissimo, was believed to indicate an emphatic Chinese rejection of mediation offers.

Miss Eloise Eubank, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Eubank of Dallas, Dexas, was married to David E. Lesan, son of Mrs. Henry Lesan of Hartsdale and the late Mr. Lesan, this afternoon in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here. The Rev. George Smyth performed the ceremony.

Miss Louise Helen Scofield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Noel P. Scofield, was married last evening in the Community Church, Douglaston, Queens, to Lawrence I. Fries, son of Frank Fries of Las Vegas, N. M., and the late Mrs. Fries. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. M. Eugene Flipse.

PARK COMMISSIONER ROBERT MOSES, apparently determined to recast every bit of New York's waterfront upon which he can lay his hands, last week proposed a $16,150,000 plan for rejuvenating Coney Island, Rockaway Beach and South Beach, Staten Island.

The onrush of Japan's military forces toward what seems to be inescapable domination of North China has aroused a large amount of speculative concern here on the part of those who occupy themselves with long-range trends in the world.

The Cabot Gas Corporation, owner of a gas plant and mains which carry natural gas from Pennsylvania to this city, was upheld today in the Supreme Court in its fight to carry its gas mains under highway property of the New York Central Railroad without the consent of the railroad.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

SILOAM SPRINGS, Ark. TOURISTS have begun to visit the memorial in Sequoyah County, Okla., built by WPA under the sponsorship of the Oklahoma Historical Society to a remarkable half-white Indian, Sequoyah.

Closing the first year under which it has operated with a "labor dividend plan," directors of the National Brewing Company of Baltimore announced yesterday that the policy has been a complete success and will be continued with the distribution of a second annual dividend to workers below executive rank on Dec. 15. Arthur H. Deute.

The United States Department of Agriculture reported today that prices on greasy shorn domestic wools here were irregular, while purchases were small and confined, filling old orders for making up samples for new lines of goods.

Bonds continued their upward course in a quiet trading session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Although lacking the buoyancy that was general on Friday, the market for secondary corporate loans extended the upswing with numerous good-sized gains being registered at the close. Total transactions amounted to $4,884,500, the smallest turnover since Nov. 13, and compared with $5,240,400 on the preceding Saturday.

An aggressive Princeton University hockey team, displaying a well coordinated attack, lived up to expectations this afternoon by defeating Boston College, 6--2, before 800 spectators in the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink.
While a more confident tone was to be noted in the securities markets last week, it was in commodities that sentiment showed the best improvement.
The University of Arizona Wildcats overpowered the Oregon Webfeet, 20 to 6, today, striking with brilliant scoring thrusts in the second and third periods.

Miss Virginia Center Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Van Bokkelen Nichols and a descendant of several noted Colonial families, was introduced to society yesterday afternoon at a reception given by her parents in their home at 30 East Fifty-fifth Street.

A twoday session of the executive committee of the Interstate Commission on Crime of the Council of State Governments ended today with a decision by the committee to concentrate its efforts during the next year on obtaining nation-wide adoption of its four-point program.

The old estate known as Colonial Acres at Southbury, Conn., has been purchased by Frederick D. Hollister, a retired New York engineer. Arthur Baese was the seller.

At Kew Observatory, England, Professor F. Paneth of the Royal College of Science is sending up little balloons and collecting samples of air at small and great heights. His object? To find out of what the atmosphere is composed down below and up above.

A series of smoldering blazes in parked automobiles, beginning at 4:10 o'clock yesterday afternoon and continuing until after nightfall, kept firemen busy in an extended mid-Manhattan area and opened search by the police and Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy for a new kind of incendiary.
President Anastasio Somoza is studying a project to aid Nicaraguan coffee growers because of Brazil's decision to discontinue her valorization plan.

I hereby resign from the office of County Clerk of the County of New York, to take effect immediately. These nineteen words, signed by Albert I. Marinelli, Tammany co-boss of Manhattan's Second Assembly District, were sent last Friday to Governor Lehman.

Hockey will make a brief return to Madison Square Garden tonight, when the New York Rangers skate against the redoubtable Bruins of Boston. Local fans are expected to pack the Eighth Avenue arena, inasmuch as the game will be the last one here for an entire week.

Lady Sysonby, Irs. Arthur James, Lady. Bingham, ord and Lady Charles Montagu nd Mary, Countess of Howe, were among the guests at a dinner party given this week by the Belgian Amassador, at the Belgian Embassy.

Alfred F. Cohen, Assistant Attorney General, announced today that a Supreme Court order had been issued here permanently restraining Millard H. Bard of Lockport, N. Y., a broker, from "further engaging in the security business in or from the State of New York."

HERE are two of the season's reprints worth singling out for attention because they offer within convenient compass the best work of a great American writer. Thoreau, unlike most of his contemporaries, has grown in stature, and today his place in the front rank goes undisputed. Far removed as any man could be from being a mere stylist, his prose stands with the best in English.

THE assertion of Secretary Woodring in his annual report of the War Department's activities for the fiscal year that, when the 2,320 "Baker Board" airplane procurement program is completed the Air Corps will require only 500 replacements annually, has caused serious thought and some equally serious arguments among the army's most capable fliers and executives.

The more you mingle with guides, and with sportsmen who only manage to "exist" between open seasons, the stranger are the stories you hear. You wonder why it is, despite your many treks over wide fields and deep woods, that none of these things ever happen to you.

Mr. and Mrs. David Landreth of Mostyn, Bristol, gave a dinner dance tonight at the Torresdale Country Club, at which they introduced their daughter, Miss Emily Landreth. The debutante, who attended St. Mary's Hall at Burlington, N. J., Is studying voice.

Facts which Congressional sources say will tend to halt a budding movement for World War veteran pensions are being put into a report by the World War Veterans Committee of the House, which at the direction of Congress has completed a survey of veterans' facilities.
