Colonel General Hermann Goering today inaugurated at Tempelhof Airfield the first section of what will be the world's largest air terminal when it is completed in 1939.

Spotting the Montreal Canadiens two goals while two men short, the Toronto Maple Leafs came back to earn a 3-3 tie with the Montrealers in a wild National Hockey League game before 12,000 fans tonight.

SPREAD out a map of the world, shut your eyes and stick it with a pin--and the chances are just about even that James A. FitzPatrick has been to the particular spot which you touch or somewhere in the close vicinity.

UNQUESTIONABLY Professor Jones's "Sound" provides the best introduction to general acoustics to be found in the English language. If the acoustical section of a library were to be confined to a single volume the well-advised librarian would unhesitatingly select this work to fill that niche.

George Welwood Murray, 81-year-old New York lawyer, identified with many great legal battles of the last half century, has received the Columbia Lion of the Columbia University Alumni Club of Essex County, N. J., it was announced yesterday by Willard I. Kimm, president of the club.

Tonight, as on every St. Nicholas Hive since 1908, the story tellers of the New York Publio Library will brush up on their stock of holiday tales in preparation for the Christmas story season opening tomorrow and continuing through Twelfth Night.

Five components of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity were lower for the week ended Nov. 27 and the combined index has dropped three points to 85.7. The revised figure for the previous week was 88.8. A year ago the index stood at 106.3.

The Adisco Discount Corporation of 120 Wall Street has been restrained permanently from dealing in securities by order of Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary, it was announced yesterday by Attorney General Bennett.

One of the advantages of plantings for Autumn display is that many of the most useful trees and shrubs obtain their effect not from leaves alone but from fruits of from a combination of the two, Thus furnished, they attract the birds and these in turn lighten thi aspect of the short, dark days..
THE pleasant purling of Miss Stein's prose brings us by degrees to her American tour three years ago and what she thought about everybody and everything.
THE works of the popular Spanish writers Pio Baroja and Ricardo Leon serve Dr. Reid as a basis for his study of social problems in present-day Spain and the antecedents of the civil war.
Mrs. Sarah Thayer, 81, today packed away her mountain climbing togs for the Winter after completing the long ascent to the top of Bald Mountain.

Stocks closed steady and mixed in quiet trading; turnover, 566,970 shares. United States Government and second-grade railroad bonds generally higher; other issues firm and dull; transactions, $4,884,500.

Canadian unity is being severely tested. Coinciding with the opening session in Winnipeg this week of a Royal Commission to determine how responsibilities and taxing powers can be shuffled to relieve the strains that are warping the fabric of confederation, came indications that these strains may be increased.

The Cabinet today approved an exchange control decree raising the value of the Uruguayan peso to 7.60 to the pound sterling, or approximately 1.54 to the dollar. (The New York quotation yesterday was 53 cents for the peso, or about 1.89 pesos to the dollar.)

Pierre Etchebaster of St. Jean-deLuz, world open court tennis champion, gained a lead of 3 sets to 1 over Ogden Phipps of New York, national amateur titleholder, today in their challenge match at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club.

AN annual award, available to gifted young musicians who appear at Town Hall in the course of the music season, will be made by the Town Hall music committee, it was announced by Walter W. Naumburg, chairman of the committee. The proposal, suggested by Kenneth Klein, manager of Town Hall, will go into effect at once.

Yale dropped its opening fame of the 1937-38 hockey season to the St. Nicks of New York tonight. The score was 4--2. Boasting a line-up freely sprinkled with sophomores, the Elis wilted before the New Yorkers' steady attack.

A large tract of land, comprising more than 700 lots, in the Colonial Heights section of Crestwood, Westchester County, has been purchased by the recently organized building firm of Mooney, Taylor Willis, Inc., which plans to improve the site with 200 new homes.

POINTING out that 100 years ago, when Joseph Aloysius Han som patented his two-wheel cab, vehicles and pedestrians had, roughly, the same rate of acceleration, W. D. H. McCullough paints an amusing if disheartening picture of present-day London traffic in The Times.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, gave a concert at Carnegie Hall last night with Mishel Piastro, violinist, and Charles Wakefield Cadman, composer-pianist, as soloists.
Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch left tonight for Rome to return the visit made here in March by Italian Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano. Not since 1924 has a Yugoslav Premier visited Italy.

To the Art Editor: EVERAL Sundays ago Philip Peirce exploded into print in your paper. Writing from Pittsburgh Mr. Peirce carried the torch for "The Yellow Cloth," first prize-winning canvas in the Carnegie International. With the same torch he scorched the local press, aiming his attack directly upon The Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph. As the art critic of that paper I wish to refute a few of Mr. Peirce's flamboyant assertions.

Dr. and Mrs. Chester Arthur Peake of Brooklyn, and Avon-bythe-Sca. N. J., gave a reception yesterday at their home, 114 Maple Street, Brooklyn, to introduce to their older friends their daughter, Miss Virginia Jessie Peake, who made her debut at the Debutante Ball on Thanksgiving Eve.

This World War and C. M. T. C. camp would be made a permanent army training center for the First Division, Second Corps Area, at a reconstruction cost of $1,315,166, under the terms of a bill introduced in Congress.

The Federal Government won a decision worth $10,000,000 to $22,000,000 today when Judge Leon R. Yankwich at Fresno upheld its title to land in the Elk Hills petroleum field, as against the claim of the Standard Oil Company of California, and awarded the government $6,164,102 as damages due to drilling operations over a long period.

Texas A. and M. crushed the University of San Francisco eleven today, 42 to 0. It was one of the worst defeats ever inflicted on the Dons. The Aggies opened the scoring with a touchdown midway in the first period, Left Halfback Dick Todd, who returned a punt 17 yards to the home team's 45, dashed 11 and 22 yards, then crashed over from the 1-yard line.
In the rental by Franklin E. Tyrrell, Forest Hills, L. I., broker, of two stores on Austin Street last week, Mr. Tyrrell states that all of the retail store space in Forest Hills is now occupied.

Six bequests to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund have been added within the last year to the ever-lengthening list of such gifts from friends of the fund who wished their assistance to those in the greatest distress of all in the city to continue after they themselves had passed on.
The first of Mrs. Samuel Woodward's musicales for this season is to be given tomorrow night at the clubhouse of the Plays and Players. Miss Ruth Barber and Morton Howard will assist Mrs. Woodward.

Seventy thousand fans saw the Trojans of Southern California defeat the Bruins of the University of California at Los Angeles in a spectacular gridiron battle at the Memorial Coliseum today, 19 to 13.

To the Art Editor: DUE to my prolonged absence in Europe, correspondence that appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Aug. 8 under the heading "Opinions Under Postage" has only just been brought to my notice.

William S. Dunloy, assistant treasurer of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, will celebrate today the fiftieth anniversary of his joining the forces of the company. He began as an office; boy in the treasury department when the Lackavanna's general offices were at 26 Exchange Place.

In order to form and strengthen relations between students, staff, alumnae and community, and to create a social life for the students by providing for informal lowpriced fun, Hunter College has adopted the House Plan.

BLOCK--GRAVER--Mr. and Mrs. Herman Grayer of Brooklyn announce the engagement of daughter, Ruth, to Stanley Block, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob W. Block of Manhattan. BROWN--HOLLANDER--Mr. and Mrs. Herman Hollander announce the engagement of their daughter, Gertrude. to Mr. William Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Brown. Far Rockaway, L. 1.

A moving picture, "The Story of the United States Coast Guard," depicting rescues at sea and other activities of that branch of the government service, will be shown to members of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island Thursday night, it was announced yesterday by Commodore Leuman M. Waugh of the yachting department of the club.

A collection of furniture, Oriental rugs, antique fabrics, Chinese porcelains and statuettes, English and French silver, and other decorations, comprising property of William B. Leeds of New York, Mrs. George Cromwell, Godfrey Preece of Westbury, and others will be sold at auction at the American Art Association - Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Special instruction in the preparation of cosmetics for the Christmas holidays is being offered men and women of this city by the WPAAdult Education program of the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday.
WHEN "Father Malachy's Miracle" was produced a fortnight ago some of the Broadway publicans apprehensively wondered what the attitude of the Catholic Church would be.

Miss Marion Sims Rosengarten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Rosengarten of Chestnut Hill, has cornpleted plans for her marriage on Dec. 18 to Morris W. Stroud 3d, son of Mrs. R. Sanford Saltus of Hollow Trees, Villanova, and of the late Morris W. Stroud Jr. The ceremony is to take place in St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill.

The fund for the Hundred Neediest Cases, established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, late publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, today presents for the twenty-sixth time its hundred stories from real life. No one can read these stories carefully and still believe that public charity is, or can be, enough.

Expressing the belief that the President's recent housing message will result in an energetic building campaign for medium-priced homes next year, Martin Schonberger. treasurer of Kent Homes, Inc., developers in Forest Hills, announces that a plot of 260 lots has been purchased from the Wellmade Construction Company at Springfield and Linden Boulevards in the St. Albans section of Queens.

Fritz Kreisler's second and last recital of the season given in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon once again found the master violinist playing in his unrivalled manner. Proficient artists on the four strings of the instrument come and go, but Mr. Kreisler still maintains his undisputed supremacy after all the years.

Willie Hoppe, veteran New Yorker, who at one time or another has held practically every major billiard title, yesterday added the 71.2 balkline championship of the United States to his collection by defeating Jake Schaefer of Chicago in the final two blocks of their week-long meeting at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

FOR years the American reading public has wondered why we had no cheap. paper-covered editions of good books like the 'Tauchnitz" of Germany. the 'yellow backs" of France. or the "Penguins" of England.

Interest on a $1,000,000 endowment from the Horace H. Rackham and Mary A. Rackham Fund will finance the study at the University of Michigan of the prevention, cure and mitigation of arthritis, during the next five to ten years.

The Cuba Company and subsidiary and affiliated companies reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 a loss, after taxes. interest. depreciation and other charges. amounting to $436,642. compared with a loss of $528,249 for the same period in 1936.

Eleven Federal agencies awarded 111 supply contracts valued at about $6,137,612 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Dec. 2, the Labor Department announced today. Of this total, $127,202 was for indefinite amounts based on last year's purchases and for delivery on an "if, when and where needed" basis.

Relative renting conditions and earnings in residential and commercial properties from November, 1936, to November, 1937, in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens are reviewed in the December Market Letter of the New York Title Insurance Company.

Brooklyn's fashionably dressed young man with the tortoise-shell glasses and the long-barreled blue-steel revolver, who specializes in robbing taxicab drivers of petty sums, staged three more such holdups last night in the Fourth Avenue section of Brooklyn, the second while police were searching the area for him.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Carinthia, sailing today for Liverpool via Ireland and Scotland, includes Lady Ramsden, Percy H. Crockett. T. H. Clapham, Mrs. George Brain, J. R. Kerr, the Rev. Barclay Buxton, E. A. Owen and J. D. Scaife.

T. Sherwood Boyd died at his home here on Friday at the age of 62. He was for twenty years a sales representative of the Northam Warren Company, toilet preparations, in New York. Earlier he had owned a chain of drug stores in Chicago. Mr. Boyd belonged to Pacific Lodge of Masons. Scottish Rites bodies, and Mecca Temple in New York City.

The Long Island University basketball team scored over the alumni quintet, 84--40, last night. A crowd of 1,000 watched the Blackbirds tally their first victory in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy Gymnasium.

Colonel Vivian L. Outerbridge of Thompson Hill Road died Thursday night in his home, after an illness of almost a month. He was 54 years old. He had served in the old Twentythird Regiment, New York National Guard, of Brooklyn, which later became the 106th Infantry.

FRANK, JOSEPHINE MILLER (Nov. 16). Estate, more than $10,000. To Ruth Fraser, niece, Oakland. Calif., and Ida Knowles, niece. Piedmont, Calif., equal shares in residue; six minor bequests. William S. Grey, 130 W. 57th St., executor.

The rate of construction of dwellings in ten Northern New Jersey counties compares very closely with the rate for the United States as a whole during the period from 1920 to the present time, according to a report by the division of economics and statistics of the Federal Housing Administration.
Florida beat Kentucky, 6 to 0, today in the final game of their 1937 football schedules. Kentucky almost scored in the closing moments when Robinson dropped Davis's pass on the Gators' 1-yard line.

The procession of elections for 1938 in the United States Power Squadrons is on. Taking the cue from the New York unit, which had its annual meeting last week, the Staten Island Power Squadron will hold its assembly Dec. 13 at Stork's Nest, Tompkinsville.

WALTER DAMROSCH, Efrem Zimbalist, the Musical Art Quartet and the Stradivarius Quartet will appear in the benefit concert to be given by the Stradivarius Memorial Association at Carnegie Hall Monday evening, Dec. 20.

WASHINGTON. THE legislative struggle for control of the airlines is once more under way. Ever since former Senator Black conducted his "famous" investigation and fathered legislation which was to be an all-time cure for aviation troubles members of Congress and others have been trying to improve upon it in one way or another. An aviation board was appointed to look into things and make recommendations.

George Long Hutchings, a retired banker, formerly cashier of the Third National Bank of New York, died Thursday at his Winter home in Charleston, S. C., at the age of 93. A son of the Rev. Samuel Hutchings and Eliza Colt Hutchings, he was born in London, England, while his parents, both missionaries,

Lawyers will again predominate in the Assembly in 1938. The official clerk's manual issued today shows that 68 of the 150 members are classified in that profession. In addition, two others are law clerks.

The annual Christmas Festival of the People's Chorus of New York will take place the night,of Dec. 22 at Carnegie Hall. Four hundred Breed members of the chorus, assisted by sixty members of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, will participate in the program, under the direaction of Lorenzo Camillieri. Mrs.
Twenty-six homes in Brooklyn and Queens and Nassau Counties have been sold recently through the real estate division of the Home Title Guaranty Company, as agent for the various investors.
The story of how a murder suspect was "persuaded" to return to British Guiana to face arrest was told today when Charles Alleynes was brought down the Demarara River from the Rupununi hinterland.

Hamilton College's two candidates for Rhodes Scholarships are both from foreign countries. They are Peter C. Hoch of Zurich and Robert L. Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. cady H. Allen, Missionaries in Hamadan, Iran.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, challenger, who bids fair to regain the honors he lost two years ago, started the twenty-fifth game of this series for the title tonight.

Remarking that it was "about time that city officials and assessors began to face the problem of overtaxation-in the real estate field," Frank A. MBatrunola, president of the Colonial Realty Company of Brooklyn, charged yesterday that assessments on properties in Brooklyn, in some instances, are more than 27 per cent above prevailing prices.
A supper dance will be given under the auspices of the alumnae of the Trinity. College, Washington, on Dec. 28 at the Pierre for the benefit of the college building endowment fund.
Northeast High today won the Philadelphia Public High Conference football championship, beating West Philadelphia High, 12 to 7, in a play-off game before 25,000 at Franklin Field.

The liner Mauretania, the largest ship ever built in England and successor in name to one of the most popular ships ever to serve the British merchant fleet, will be launched next July 28 and enter service in 1939, it was announced yesterday.

The very slick basketball operatives from City College, functioning with a smoothness rarely seen so early in the season, administered a sound and workmanlike 48-32 beating to Brooklyn College as part of the exercises that dedicated the new $1,000,000 gymnasium in Flatbush last night.

A marked increase over the earlier estimate of the tobacco crop of Canada has just been announced. The revised figure of the yield for the Dominion is 71,352,000 pounds. The new estimate is made by the Tobacco Division of the Dominion Experimental Farms. The previous figure was "in the neighborhood of 56,000,000 pounds."

IT is a common practice (in fiction) for Scotland Yard detectives to call for amateur assistance in solving their cases, and however improbable such procedure may be, it has resulted in the creation of several sleuths who have delighted leaders of crime stories. Such a sleuth is Desmond Merrion, who helps his friend, Inspector Arnold, in what looks in the beginning like a simple case of murder by a jealous husband.
The experience of a tiny electric impulse darting from mountain peak to mountain peak is being studied by meteorologists and radio experts in an attempt to forecast weather conditions.

Curtis High School's football team gave its outgoing coach, Al Fabbri, a fine farewell gift yesterday as the Red and White overpowered Samuel J. Tilden High, 26 to 0, at Thompson Stadium, Stapleton, S. I, before 1,500 spectators. The contest had been- postponed earlier in the season and marked the close of the school campaign in New York City.

Infants Welfare League-Benefit dinner dance, 6 P. M., Hotel Astor. Pi Beta Phi (New York Alumnae)--Sale of mountain Handicraft, Beekman Tower Hotel. Woman's Club of Little Falls (N. J.)--Mass meeting for peace, Herman Dinsmore, speaker. Methodist Church, 8 P. M.

HARRY WOODBURN CHASE Chancellor of New York University, in discussing the problems of dovetailing education with radio, told the National Conference of Educational Broadcasting held during the past week in Chicago, that classroom techniques do not hold radio audiences.

Audubon High School's eleven held a strong claim on the Group 3 State High School Football championship following its 23-to-0 triumph over Carteret High today on a neutral field in a post-season game.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in French in day secondary schools, other than Junior high schools. be issued, as of Dec. 3. 1937, to the following applicants who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Beatrice Elaine Altschuler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs;. Robert A. Altschuler of this place, to Paul Harry Metcalf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Edward Metcdlf of Plainfield.

INTERNATIONAL echoes from the new land plane speed record recently set by a Messerschmitt plane in Germany came last week from England. C. G. Grey, editor of the British magazine Aeroplane, ventured that the British Spitfire model can "make quite a mess of the Messerschmitt's record.

A large exhibition of art by pupils of Mexican public schools, sponsored by the Mexican Ministry of Education, was opened yesterday in Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History. The show, which will continue until the end of the month, includes toys, watercolor and oil paintings; posters, block prints, theatrical designs and pages from illustrated notebooks.
A spokesman declared today that Buffalo dealers had refused to bargain with farm leaders who have threatened a milk strike here tomorrow in a move to get higher prices for milk.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that William E. Chapman, United States consul at Bilbao, Spain, had received a leave of absence to return to the United States because the Insurgent authorities were obstructing his return to duty at his post.

Reports that the Japanese had reduced customs rates at Tientsin on a wide range of their commodities were found to be without foundation when the United States consulate at Tientsin reported to the State Department today that there had been no change in duties there.

Continued reduction in cottonmill operations has failed to prevent a steady rise in stocks of goods in the last few months, and selling agents yesterday predicted that mills will make drastic cuts in schedules in the short period now remaining before year-end inventory taking.

The claim of Miss Marjorie Browning, 22 years old, of New Rochelle, to an award of $1,000,000 from the estate of Edward W. Browning, former New York real estate dealer, who, she alleged, was her foster father, was denied yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty. The suit was begun last May.

Projects of the Works Progress Administration have enhanced public property of communities of the nation by more than $1,500,000,000 worth of new construction completed or well under way, according to Aubrey Williams, deputy administrator.

Miss Rebeokah Du Bois was introduced to society yesterday at a tea dance given by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Floyd Du Bois, in the ballroom of the Colony Club. The debutante received before a background of smilax and ferns.
Missing since 4:30 P. M., Thursday, Mrs. Isabella James, 78 years old, of Blachley Road, was found dead in a woods three miles from her home this morning.

Among the old tenemtn structures on the lower East Side for which alteration plans have recently been filed are the three five and six-story houses at 206 Broome Street, 90 Henry Street and 175 Norfolk Street, owned by Leopold Saberski of Tarrytown.
This year for the first time the Metropolitan Museum of Art will take official notice of Christmas by arranging a special exhibition to illustrate "The Christmas Story in Art."

Mrs. F. Graham Cootes, chairman of the annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Greene County, Va., will give a tea for her cornmittee Wednesday t her home, 50 West Sixty-seventh Street.

Mrs. John M. Curran, who wrote verse and prose at what she said was dictation, through the ouija board, of the spirit of a seventeenth century Englishwoman, died here yesterday of pneumonia. Her age was 54.
Agins, Hulda Allen, Frederick H. Aller, Sarah Jones Antes, George W. Arons, Solomon A. Bailey, Sarah A. Birkins, Henry C. Bound, Louis Fiske

In the unpredictable course of human events, the World Center for Women's Arohives, first projected only two years ago, will achieve status as a permanent institution next week with the records of one of its youngest and most enthusiastio sponsors as its initial memorabilia.

The Society of Textile Chemists and Colorists was told today that a new method had been perfected by which almost every fundamental organic reaction of chemistry could be duplicated in a fraction of the time previously required.

Following the advance in Treasury bill rates yesterday to the highest point of this year. the discount rate for short and three-month bills rose today to fifteen-sixteenths of 1 per cent, up 1/8, and a further advance in the quotation is expected, following next week's tender. Week-end money was plentiful at one-half of 1 per cent.

In the opinion of several large development builders, the home market has been considerably widened in recent years due to the willingness to accept smaller down payments and a long-term mortgage system, which has become a popular method of financing mediumpriced homes.

United States Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission; Lewis W. Douglas, principal of McGill University, and Wayne C. Taylor, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, will be speakers at a dinner of the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor on Tuesday night.

Nine clubs of the ninth district of the State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs will sponsor a forum on the coming constitutional convention, tomorrow evening in the White Plains Court House.

Sonny Sam O'Hart, owned by Douglas Hartshorne of New York City and handled by Mrs. Ned Morford of Amagansett, L. I., won first prize in the open all-age class at the first field trials of the Irish Water Spaniel Club of America at Lordship today.

The return of Nicholas Titulescu this week from the exile he imposed on himself sixteen months ago after King Carol and Premier George Tatarescu had ousted him as Foreign Minister by an adroit manoeuvre, marks the determination of Dr. Julius Maniu,

Citrus fruits took a considerable drop in pric3 this week and are now as cheap as they have' been for a year. The consumer is benefiting from the fact that a year's agreement among growers controlling shipments of fruit from Florida came to an end two weeks ago, and supplies are now arriving in heavy quantities.
Six years ago the city of Fall River was down and almost out. Today that long-time famous cotton-textile center is up and coming. Courage and confidence have replaced despair and doubt.

The Dramatic Association of the College of Mount St. Vincent will present "Berkeley Square" tomorrow at 8:15 P. M. at the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium, 261st Street and Riverdale Avenue, for the benefit of the college's Christmas fund for the poor.

The marriage of Miss Constance Mary Barwis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Barwis, to Walter Richard Bliss, son of Mrs. Harry A. Bliss of Buffalo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Bliss, took place yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of the Intercession of Trinity Parish, Broadway and 155th Street. The noons.

Early acceptance received by the committee for the first of the Yorkville Dinner Dances this season, to he held Tuesday at the Ritz-Carlton, indicate that the party will be one of the largest given under the auspices of the Yorkville Community Association in recent years.

Many large industrial expansion projects in this country either have been abandoned or indefinitely postponed in recent months because it has been found impossible to finance them through the sale of new security issues, J. C. Stewart, president of James Stewart Co., general contractors, said yesterday.

REDUCED rates will be available on railroad trains in France for travelers going to the "snow cities" of the Alps and the Pyrenees, or to the "sunshine resorts" of the Riviera, according to an announcement made by the Railways of France.
The possibility of civil service status without written examination was held out to more than 1,000 custodial employes in the public school

The United Automobile Workers of America, which has been on strike since Nov. 24 at the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here, broadened its activities today by picketing seven Ford dealers. The union declared that the Ford agencies had been supplying the plant with men and with automobiles to carry them to and from their jobs.

WASHINGTON THE largest crowd in the nine years of its history turned out for the Winter championship tournament here of the American Contract Bridge League, which was in progress all last week and will end tonight with the completion of the final round of the open pair championship.

The recent football season was a smashing success, not only on the field but at the box office. The Yale Bowl and the Harvard Stadium were filled for the first time since 1929 and there was similar cheerful news from athletic association treasurers in all parts of the country.

More than 500 savings and loan officials are expected to attend the annual midwinter conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Wedhesday and Thursday, Zebulon V. Woodward, executive vice president of the league, announced yesterday.

The annual invasion of women into shops normally entered only by men is on. They hunt frantically through wares that are strange to them. in search of gifts. If they look hard enough they will find, made particularly for this Christmas season, articles so new that a gift of one is not likely to duplicate something the recipient already possesses.

" Industrial and Public Relations" will be the theme of the twentyfirst annual meeting of the Toy Manufacturers of the U. S. A. to be held next Thursday and Friday at the Hotel New Yorker, it was announced yesterday by James L. Fri. executive director.
NOW that the custodians of the barns for the bored have formally surrendered an it to plebeian perusal, cafe society may be listed among the newer toys of the free-lance trend tracers.

University psychologists are busily engaged in repeating the experiments of Professor J. B. Rhine of Duke University -experiments which have convinced him that telepathy and clairvoyance are realities and not the delusions of wishful thinking.

A group of young women are aiding Mrs. Edward A. Clark and hard members of the executive committee in the arrangements for the tea heard dance, dinner dance and entertainment in behalf of the child welfare work of La Margherita Society to be held Saturday at Le Mirage.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Shepherd Leggb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Leggo of Rockville Centre, to Douglas Munroe, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Munroe, also of Rockville Centre, took place here this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Duncan M. Genns, rector of St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Lawrence Hart of the Ambassador gave a large dinner party last night in the Trianon Room of the hotel for Miss Nancy Van Vleck, debutante daughter of Mrs. William de Wilder Atkinson of New York and Ballyshear, Southampton, who will be formally introduced to society at a supper dance on Dec. 28 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Plans for an eight-week student seminar in Scandinavia next Summer are announced by Dr. Herbert A. Bloch, head of the Social Studies Department of St Lawrence University.

A proposed refashioning of high school education, with all subjects in the curriculum closely woven by an enlarged conception of science teaching, was presented Thursday to more than 100 students and faculty members of Teachers College.

Mrs. Josephine Vlahos, 26 years old, of 4,417 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, the first person to be served by the new City Pneumonia Typing and Control Service since stations in each borough were opened last Tuesday, was so much improved yesterday that she was able to sit up in bed and receive visitors at the Shore Road Hospital, Shore Road and Ninety-second Street, Brooklyn.

The growing tendency of Middle Western lake cities to conduct their own international trade without use of coastal ports is shown by Chicago. During the first six months of 1937, according to the Chicago Association of Commerce, customs collections made locally at the Chicago Custom House totaled $10,461,777, against $7.279,582 during the same period a year previous.
BY no means inconsiderable progress has been made of late in the way of broadening and deepening the relationship that should exist between art and the people.

Loblaw Groceterias, Ltd., reported yesterday that after depreciation, income taxes and other charges, its net profit for the twenty-four weeks ended on Nov. 13 amounted to $371,318, compared with $351,793 in the corresponding period last year.
Chinese dispatches today said Japanese airplanes had bombed the HankowCanton Railway, by which the British Charge d'Affaires, R. C. Howe, is speeding toward Hong Kong.

AIRPLANES have been flying on a strange new mission this year and last over wide stretches of the United States. They are not engaged in the ordinary tasks of airplanes. They follow routes unrelated to airports and cities.

The engagement of Miss Myrtle Elizabeth Hillman, daughter of Mrs. Myrtle L. Hillman of this munity, and Captain W. P. Hillman of Long Beach, Calif., to David Gaines Kingsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Kingsley of Boonton, was announced today at a tea given by Mrs. Hillman at her home here.

The marriage of Miss Frances Sloan Worrall, daughter of Mrs. Schoolfield Grace and the late Frank Inloes Worrall, to George E. Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. .Mortimer Ward of this place, took place today at Chart Lodge, the home of the bride's mother and Major Grace of the Overlook.

The security and commodity markets moved narrowly yesterday for the most part. Stocks fluctuated with a range from fractions to 3 points and closed steady in the smallest volume of trading since Nov. 13.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 3: COLONELS Mettler, C. G., Ordnance Dept. Hawaii to Watervliet Arsenal, N. Y.
CAROLYN WELLS hates autobiographies. When her friends, looking back themselves upon that sparkling life of hers, urged her to write its story, she steadfastly refused.
Germain Glidden, defending champion in the tenth annual Gold Racquet tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club, today moved into the third round by winning both his first and second round matched.

Albert Marinelli, the former County Clerk, yesterday began serving out his time as Tammanyi leader of the Second Assembly District West, a "lame duck" in every sense except that his successor has not yet been named.

Rolf Grote of George Washington yesterday won his 100-yard free style duel with Jack Koerner of James Monroe at the weekly series of dual meets for the ManhattanBronx-Richmond senior high swimming championship of the Public Schools Athletic League in the 25yard De Witt Clinton pool.

Trailing by four points with that many minutes to play, Dartmouth staged a rally, with Joe Batchelder and Bob White leading the attack, to score a 35-to-30 victory over the University of Vermont in the opening basketball game of the season tonight.

Contrary to expectations, buying of machinery and supplies at the recent convention of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages substantially exceeded that of last year. executives who returned last week from the New Orleans meeting reported yesterday. Expecting to have their sales volume cut in half. machinery and supply producers registered gains of about 25 per cent, it was said.

FEATURES of the week in music will include the appearance of Bruna Castagna as Dalila in the Metropolitan's "Samson et Dalila"; Isidor Achron, who will be soloist with the Philharmonic-Symphony in the first performance of his piano concerto, and Yehudi Menuhin's first concert here in two years, which will take place tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall.
DETROIT. WITH production lines now running smoothly, automobile companies are turning their attention to the problem of what happens to a new car after it is placed in the owner's hands.

Colgate football schedules for 1938 and 1939 were released today by William A. Reid, director of athletics. The Red Raiders are booked to play all games away from home next Fall, including three contests in New York.

FOR the scene of his newest novel Frank H. Spearman has gone-back to Old Cali fornia in the days of the Mexican War. While the United States was fighting Mexico for new territory both countries had to fight the Indians.

It is just a year since the voice of the former King Edward VIII announced to an amazed world that he had abdicated a sovereignty over one-quarter of the human race. The event was without parallel in the annals of the monarchy.
Negotiations between representatives of the Steel cartel and steel interests in the United States looking to a marketing and price agreement are continuing.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine admitted yesterday that the present police protection in the city, especially in the parks, was inadequate because of a shortage of men.

Reports that the larger manufacturers of cotton goods were planning to extend curtailment schedules had an unsettling influence on prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list ended with losses of 4 to 7 points, or 20 to 35 cents a bale.

Real Play, one of the most consistent of the 1937 juveniles, added the 2,000 Biloxi Handicap to her string of victories today when she carried the silks of the Southland Stable to an easy triumph over nine other. juveniles in the feature at the Fair Grounds.

WALL STREET has an attack of bear-fever and the market takes a dive. An international conference abroad is upset by a dictator. A series of unfavorable economic factors is listed in a business report.

Unrest and disturbances in Algerla, Morocco and Tunis, coinciding with the ItaloGerman demands for colonies, have resulted in the creation by the French Government of a Commission of Coordination for North Africa, under the supervision of M. Albert Sarraut.

Mexico prepared today to complete socialization of her 8,562-mile National Railway System. A government department, newly created by President Lazaro Cardenas, prepared to operate the lines until "direct exploitation" by the workers is arranged.
NO fewer than five group exhibitions designed to attract the attention of the Christmas buyer have opened, with works specially priced for the holiday season.

Following completion of rehabilitation work, the fourteen-story apartment house at 925 Park Avenue, northeast corner of Eightieth Street, is fully rented, according to Payson McL. Merrill Company, Inc., managing agent of the building since its erection thirty years ago.

In the long conversations today between Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Minister, and Col. Josef Beck, official steersman of Polish policy in foreign relations, the inclinations of both statesmen seem to have come out strongly.
A hearing on the proposal to extend the East River Drive from Grand Street to Montgomery Street, cutting through Corlears Hook Park, will be held before the Board of Estimate next Friday.

A good volume of orders was placed last week on merchandise for January and early Spring selling, due to the opinion of a number of merchants that many price lines face no further reductions, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

Tessa Bloom, young American pianist, who made her debut at the Town Hall last season, re-appeared in the same auditorium last night in a recital which was well attended and warmly received. Her schedule comprised the Bach "Chromatic Fantasie and Fugue," the Beethoven sonata in C major, Op. 2, No. 3;

Without benefit of legal counsel, the high cost of living will be arraigned as a public nuisance on Saturday as the main feature of a two-day forum under the auspices of the Consumers National Federation at the Ethical Culture Society headquarters at 2 West Sixty-fourth Street. The sponsoring group comprises some 125 organizations and 300 private individuals.

JOSEPHUS DANIELS, Ambassador to Mexico, in an address to teachers and students of Spanish in universities and colleges throughout the United States, recently opened a series of short-wave educational programs which are broadcast weekly by station XECR in Mexico City.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 3 unless specified: San Diego to San Pedro: Kingfisher, Dec. 4; Cincinnati.

A pledge to remove all soldiers and military establishments from Nanking's proposed safety zone within three days was given by a spokesman for the defense commander, General Tang Sheng-chih today in responding to protests of the international committee establishing a zone against the continued construction of fortifications and movements of troops within the proposed refugee area.

The annual memorial service of the Episcopal Actors Guild of America will be held today at 4 P. M. in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street. This will inauguiate a custom of holding the service in different churches.

A broadening by the Federal Government of its tax base so that the "unjust" burden on real estate may be relieved is advocated by Herman A. Acker, Bronx broker, who expresses the belief that lower realty taxes would do much to stimulate building of all kinds.

MR. LEON seizes upon present-day international monetary uncertainty as a promising opportunity to renew his advocacy of bimetallism as a cure for many of the world's troubles. The volume includes views he has expressed before Congressional committees and in addresses, and these Mr. Leon rounds out with other observations.

The National Industrial Council, sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers, will hold its annual Congress of American Industry today and tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The congress will be followed by the annual convention of the association on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

The term "Lord" will be substituted for "Jehovah" in the Old Testament in the revision of the American Standard Edition of the Bible that is being undertaken by a committee of scholars, it was learned last night.

Gardeners will view with interest the evidence of discoveries made in regard to accelerating plant growth and the control of plant pests at the sixteenth Exposition of Chemical Industries opening at Grand Central Palace tomorrow at 2 o'clock and continuing through Saturday, the hours being noon to 10:30 P. M. with the exception of the last day, when the doors will close at 6.
Mrs. John D. M. Hamilton Sr., mother of the Republican National Committee Chairman, John D. M. Hamilton, died today at the home of another soin, Hale Hamilton, actor. She was 80 years old.

Senator La Follette of the Civil Liberties Committee conferred today with a committee seeking to interest him in an investigation of Mayor Frank Hague's actions in Jersey City last week when the police barred organizers of the Committee for Industrial Organization from the city.

Under the heading "Vainglory in Shanghai" a Times editorial today suggests that yesterday's incident paraded Japan's most serious weakness before the world and showed the workings of the Japanese military mind in a characteristic light. It said:

Features for both parents and children have been included in the second annual Educational Toy Exhibit of the Norwalk, Conn., branch of the American Association of University Women, scheduled for Friday and Saturday at Grace Church Parish House, Norwalk.

FOR those addicted to the picaresque, the gory and the horrible. this collection of narrations of twentyfive instances of mutiny on the ocean should fill the most exacting requirement "Revolt at Sea" is not fiction, or any mingling of history and fiction. Every one of these mutinies took place, and the story of many of them has been often told. Irvin Anthony.

Thursday's dispatch from London reporting the rejuvenation of the British Army Council and sweeping changes in the general staff probably forecasts the approaching demise of that mythical and yet formidable figure, "Colonel Blimp," for too many years the real ruler of the British Army.
Labor's Non-Partisan League, which is dominated by the C. I. O., will make its first move toward forming a State Labor party at a convention tomorrow in the Newark Labor Lyceum.

CALIFORNIA in Forty-nine was more remote from the settled East than any spot on earth is nowadays. The sudden flash of that recollection throws a light of swift understanding on the "old California" scene.

For the last few years committees of students at the Groton and St. Mark's Schools have combined to give a dance each Winter to raise funds for a welfare project at the respective Summer camps of the two institutions.

The shelter for young women which is maintained by the Florence Crittenton League at 427 West Twenty-first Street is supported through voluntary contributions, and through proceeds from benefit enterprises held during the year.
Lawrenceville's championship polo team defeated the Essex Troop B team at the 112th Field Artillery armory today, 19 to 13 1/2.

Z. G. Simmons and Harry Thoens tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, each breaking 98 out of 100 targets. In the first shoot-off, the rivals deadlocked at 25 and continued without missing a target in the second string.

Confronted by the force of the Berlin-Rome axis, supplemented by the Italo-German-Japanese treaty, the two great Old World democracies are evidently making a careful review of the situation to see just where matters stand in the conflict or contest between fascism and free government. Foreign Minister Delbos of France, fresh from the Franco-British conversations in London, is now in Warsaw and is going from there to Prague and Belgrade.

Funeral services for Colonel Fred Warren Weller, retired vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, will be held at 3 P. M. today at his residence in New Rochelle. The honorary pallbearers include John D. Rockefeller Jr., Walter C. Teagle, Robert Fulton, Walter Coursen, Thomas Burton, James Moffat, Frank McReynolds and Captain Kenneth Whiting, U.S.N.

More than twenty national religious and welfare organizations will be represented at an all-day leaders' conference at the Hotel Biltmore Thursday to plan cooperative participation in a fourteenmonth national stewardship campaign under the sponsorship of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, it was announced yesterday.

The Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 109 East Thirty-eighth Street, announces that the newly formed Chinese Catholic War Relief Association has appealed to Catholie Bishops throughout the world to

DEVOTEES of outdoor sports during the cold months are looking ahead to an active Winter and making elaborate preparations for it. Undismayed by the fortunes of last year, when mild weather curtailed their programs considerably,

In an attempt to end the liquor price war in New York City, two of the larger distilling companies obtrained twelve orders from Supreme Court Justice Timothy A. Leary yesterday morning requiring six retail liquor dealers to show cause tomorrow morning why they should not be enjoined temporarily from cutting prices in violation of the Feld-Crawford Price Maintenance Law.
THE Winter brings heavy weather on the North Atlantic, and the seagoing photographer, if he is not confined to his berth, makes every effort to take full advantage of it.
The Nashville Banner and The Tennessean announced tonight the formation of a printing corporation to publish both, but with each preserving its own corporate identity.

The price-cutting on liquors in the metropolitan area last week plus the increasing belief of retailers that prices must be made attractive to spur volume in a time of business uncertainty put enforcement of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Law in a "tighter spot" than it has been since the law was enacted, comments in merchandising circles here last week indicated.

John L. Lewis, chief of the C. I. O. and leader of the industrial union labor movement, is to have a newspaper of his own to reflect his views on labor. The Committee for Industrial Organization announced today it would begin publication of a

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hopkins Livingston and Mrs. Andrew Christian Zabriskie gave a dinner dance last night in the roof garden of the Pierre to introduce to society Miss Eleanor Mulford Livingston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Livingston, and Miss Frances Powis Jones, granddaughter of Mrs. Zabriskie.

Dickinson High School's eleven captured the Jersey City football championship for the third straight season before 8,000 persons at Roosevelt Stadium today by conquering Lincoln in the final game of the Hudson County season, 13 to 0.
The model home library of 500 volumes selected by the American Booksellers Association for the tenants of the White House at
Mrs. Virginia Bennett Crocker has arrived here to make residence with the intention to divorcing Charles Crocker of San Francisco. Mr. Crocker is heir to a railroad and banking fortune.

Dr. Livingston Farrand, former president of Cornell University, was elected yesterday a member of the board of governors of the Society of the New York Hospital, 525 East Sixty-eighth Street. Henry G. Barbey president of the society, who made the announcement, disclosed that Dr. Farrand would be sworn in Tuesday evening.

LITTLE did I think, that hot July afternoon in the Summer of 1934, as I went scampering about a dusty tennis court in Muskoka, that in a few moments a casual remark from our lone spectator, Mrs. G., would be launching me on a career as a playwright.

Under graduates of the University of Pennsylvania who are interested in the serious drama lave combined forces and, after years of agitation, have won official recognition from the university administration.

Still burdened with large stocks as a result of the heavy advance buying early in the year, shoe distributors last week bought sparingly when volume manufacturers exhibited their Spring lines at the New Yorker Hotel here last week. For January and February selling of women's shoes, relatively small orders were placed for Spring numbers with which to "sweeten" current stocks.

Operations in wheat futures were restricted today, and prices fluctuated in an erratic manner within a range of about 1 1/2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade here breaking sharply early in sympathy with Liverpool only to rally rapidly later on commission-house buying and short covering and then react on profittaking to close 1/8 cent a bushel higher to 1/8 cent lower, the former on December.

Winter vacation time for dogdom all over the United States will begin tomorrow and continue for five weeks. Like the Summer vacation during the month of July, it is an unofficial holiday taken by common consent.

Many persons prominent in society who have long taken an active interest in the National Cathedral Association have subscribed to the performance of "Father Malachy's Miracle" on Thursday night at the St. James Theatre, which has been taken over by members of the New York Junior Committee of the association.

The National League of American Citizens of Foreign Descent. Inc., 331 Vadison Avenue, made public yesterday a tribute to its late president, Colonel Frederick H. Allen, who died in Newport, R. I., on Friday.
Chancellor Hitler intends to make Berlin a modern Rome-not merely a city but a symbol of political power and glory such as Rome was to the Roman world.

The Mount Holyoke College Glee Club, singing under the leadership of Associate Professor Ruth Douglass of the Music Department, will give its annual Christmas concert in Town Hall, New York, on Dec. 17.

Baltimore's famous Bachelors Cotillion, with a distinguished lineage dating back through more than 100 years of social activity, will usher in its 1937-38 season on Monday. Debutante daughters of the leading families of Maryland will be presented formally to society.
Instead of ordering wreaths for doors and windows or buying readymade decorations for mantelpiece and dining table, many amateur gardeners these days are making their own Christmas decorations.

STOCKHOLM. WHICH white man first saw America? As the discussion on this point continues, scholars are inclined to place more and more credence in the claims advanced, in ancient Icelandic and Norwegian sagas, on behalf of adventurous Norsemen who lived about the year 1000 A. D.

Ralph Lewis. noted on the stage and silent screen for his characterizations, died today of auto injuries suffered on Oct. 24. He was 65 years old. A native of Englewood, Ill., Mr. Lewis was educated at Northwestern University.
A total value of $140,131,740 in gold produced in Canada this year, an increase of 7 per cent over the total of $131,293,420 for 1936, has been indicated by the production figures for September.

In addition to revision of the capital gains and undistributed profits taxes, W. Clement Moore, tax consultant, yesterday advocated an amendment to the Revenue Act governing bad debts, which would allow the debt to be charged off in the year in which it is finally and definitely determined to be bad, whether by the taxpayer or the Internal Revenue Bureau.

Scoring twice in the first half the Manual Training H. S. soccer team defeated Cleveland, 2 to 1, y?? terday at Commercial Field to capture the championship in the Brooklyn-Queens division of the P. S. A. L. The winners will now meet Evander for the city crown some time next week.

Dr. Ray Palmer Baker, assistant director of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, said today that while "the problem of students who cut classes confronts all educators, fortunately at Rensselaer we have kept it to a minimum, characterized by others as outstanding."
THIS two-volume work consists of a new biography of Germany's foremost lyric poet and translations by Mr. Untermeyer, himself a poet of no mean attainments, of virtually all of Heine's poetry.

The ascendancy of army groups in many countries has emphasized the responsibility of the church to combat military domination by inculcating the doctrine of christianity in the armed formed of the world, the Rev. George G. Murdock, Catholic chaplain of the Military Academy at West Point, declared yesterday.
With the rapid approach of Christmas the Postoffice Department again brings attention to the closing dates for Christmas mail intended for foreign countries.

In the interests of the Kosciuszko Foundation and its fifth annual Night in Poland ball to be held on Jan. 28 at the Waldorf-Astoria, Mrs. Thaddeus S. Skladzien of New Rochelle will give a large reception, musical and supper tonight in the Green and Blue Rooms of the Hotel McAlpin.

IMPROVEMENT in retail trade was sustained in the week although reports continued to run quite spotty. It was indicated in many cases that inventories had been reduced. Main floor items have been favored so far in holiday buying.

A Industrial mobilization and war procurement plan, ready to be put into instant operation in time of emergency, was declared today a vital factor in national defense by Louis Johnson, Assistant Secretary of War, in his report for the last fiscal year to Secretary Woodring.

With Manager Burleigh Grimes re-enforced by the arrival of James Mulvey, vice president, the Dodgers today took a more stubborn stand in the various negotiations involving their fiery fi eball pitcher, Van Lingle Mungo.

Margin requirements covering the extension and maintenance of credit by brokers, dealers and members of national securities exchanges for the purchase and carrying of securities were liberalized further and made more workable in a revision of Regulation T, effective on Jan. 1, adopted by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve Bank System yesterday and made public today.
Dr. Joseph H. Bryan, 86, who founded the New York University Glee Club in 1883, will be the guest of honor at the choral organization's Annual Town Hall Concert on Saturday evening.

A mix-up in targets cost Brooklyn Technical High School's rifle team its chance of retaining the honors in the second annual C. C. N. Y. interscholastic invitation Fall tournament yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. Tech's first team made 1,004 points to take second place behind Jamaica, which totaled 1,025.

A REPRESENTATIVE of dealer interests in Germany is currently attempting, thus far without appreciable success, to dump on the American stamp market 200,000 copies of the miniature sheet which Germany released to commemorate the "Brown Ribbon" horse race meet on Aug. 1.

The hearing into the explosion of the main stop valve on the steamship Brazos here on Oct. 6 that killed Chief Engineer Alexander Kennedy and two others and injured five men was ended yesterday afternoon at the offices of the Steamboat Inspection Service, 45 Broadway.

The thirty-sixth annual New Jersey Conference of Social Work adjourned here this afternoon after re-electing Dr. David Fales Jr. of Newark as president, and hearing Professor Eduard C. Lindeman of the New York School for Social Work warn that there were no guarantees of a democratic future.

THE week began with the Habima Players' opening of a four weeks' season. Their collective acting in "The Dybbuk" is faultless in its own convention and so powerful in its emotional impact that, in their presence, inexperienced playgoers are always in danger of supposing that the Habima method of production is the only right method of producing plays.

Places of honor will be given to students who have been leaders in both academic and extracurricular life at New Jersey College for Women at the Yule Log ceremony, which will be held Dec. 17, on the eve of the Christmas recess.

The young men of Samoa are going in for brightly colored shirts and those banes of the white man's existence, collars and ties, according to a letter received by Secretary Swanson from the island Governor, Captain MacGillivray Milne. Furthermore, they have taken up bicycling.

The principal foreign exchanges strengthened yesterday in terms of the dollar, but showed substantial losses for the week as a whole. The pound sterling was up A cent yesterday to $4.99 1/4 and the franc rose ?? point to 3.39 ?? cents.

The following Foreign Service changes since Nov. 20 were announced by the State Department today: Maynard B. Barnes of Vinton, Iowa. State Department, assigned to Paris as first secretary of the American Embassy.

DOUGLAS McMURTRIE has added another title to the impressive list of more than thirty that bear his name as author. This latest, and the most pretentious single volume, has the virtues and the faults of his other work.

Administration leaders in the House went forward today with their plans to obtain passage of the pending Wages and Hours Bill, in almost complete disregard of the recommendations which the American Federation of Labor will submit early next week for substantial changes in the proposed legislation.

ARTICLES of old glass, china and pewter are perhaps the most popular of all to collect, because their costliness can be adjusted to the purse of the individual. At the top of the scale are rare early European porcelains, centuriesold ceramics of the East, Italian and English glassware and pewter plates and tankards with the marks or "touches" of recognized makers.

To crown a year that has seen Bach's name predominant on record lists, comes the second volume of organ works played by Dr. Albert Schweitzer. Drawing from the composer's last period, selection has been made from the chorale preludes: seven from the Little Organ Book, four from the Eighteen and two from the Miscellaneous collections.

More liquor taxes have been collected by the government in Illinois since prohibition was repealed on Dec. 5, 1933, than from any other State. The nation as a whole paid $1,310,000,000 in such levies in the four years.
Numerous bands of well-armed natives, taking advantage of the rainy season, which began in August, have been striking at Italy's colonial forces in Ethiopia.

If this comment had been made in a tone of horror and coupled with a fierce denunciation of the New Deal, it would have been approved by most of those who were shocked by such candor.

Superior Judge Edward R. Brand added some advice about thrift when he ordered Ben Blue, comedian, to pay Mary Blue $600 monthly alimony. "You are no exception to the rule that theatrical careers do not last long, and yours already has been a long one," the judge said.

Mayor Harry Scott of New Rochelle cut a ribbon barrier at 9:30 A. M. today to open to the public the Westchester store of Arnold Constable Co., the New York concern's first branch store, at Main Street and North Avenue here.

BEHBRENS--Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Behrens (nee Elizabeth Seltzer) announce the birth of a son, Friday. Dec. 3. DANNETT--Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Dannett (nee Sylvia Liebovitz) of 15 West 75th, announce the birth of a son on Dec. 1, Doctors Hospital. DISTISTATOR--Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Distillator (nee Frances Salmanowitz). are pleased to announce arrival of Paulette Marie. Sunday, Nov. 28, at Doctors Hospital.

This year's program of the committee in charge of the Calvin Coolidge Memorial Library of the Women's National Republican Club will be a tribute to Guide, the club's official organ launched this Autumn. A dinner at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street, Thursday evening will be sponsored by the library committee of which Miss Maria V. Leavitt is chairman.

With successful commercial skyscraper construction methods pointing the way for private enterprise to meet New York City's demands for housing, large-scale operations in this field are in prospect, according to Thomas S. Holden, chairman of the special housing committee of the Merchants Association of New York.

Mme. Irene Schmeder, French aviatrix, fainted and was carried unconscious from the court room tonight after a jury had declared her guilty, but absolved her from penalty for shooting aviator Pierre Lallement. She will be set free after paying the costs.

Paris newspapers deplore recent incidents in Shanghai, declaring the situation demands serious attention from the powers but there are no moves in official circles. Europe appears to continue to look to the United States for leadership and the Brussels conference discouraged that.

Following the recent announcement of plans for apartment houses in the Riverdale section of the West Bronx, near the new Henry Hudson Memorial Parkway, Ben Riley, owner of the Arrowhead Inn, announced yesterday plans for eight garden-type apartments on land he owns near the restaurant.
The new editorial board of The Fordham Law Review, studentedited publication, was announced yesterday by Ignatius M. Wilkinson dear of the Fordham Law School.

Dean Irving H. Berg, announced yesterday the names of 107 students at the University Heights colleges of New York University who have a been pledged to eleven fraternities this semester. They were selected from the university's College of Engineering and the College of Arts and Pure Science.

Wilbur L. Adams, Acting Postmaster at Georgetown and former Representative in Congress, died today at Lewes at the age of 53. Mr. Adams practiced law in Georgetown and later in Wilmington. He was elected to the House of Representatives in 1932 and served one term. He was a Democrat.
Frank Matrunola, president of the Colonial Realty Company of Bay Ridge in the lower Brooklyn section, reports that his firm has placed mortgages totaling $62,000 on twelve properties in that section.

An ingenious plan for exploiting Sweden's rocky cliffs for the protection of warships against an air attack was submitted to the Navy Ministry today by Chief Admiral Tham. He suggested the blasting of caves where submarines and similar craft could shelter.

Federal and State officials, representatives of leading civic and comercial organizations and troops from New York and New Jersey will participate in the dedication of the new $43,000,000 vehicular Linooln Tunnel on Dec. 21, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

The Roosevelt High School basketball team defeated Townsend Harris yesterday, 34 to 11, on the latter's court. The Rough Riders got sway to a fast start, amassed an early lead and never were overhauled. Roosevelt led at half-time, 24-6.

OF COURSE It is too easy to be cynical about it. But there are those who say-and this wary column merely passes it along-that Columbia Pictures didn't really mean it when it said it was going to produce plays on Broadway.

George W. Service is in the trading department of Fuerst Co. Pelz Co. have installed a private wire between their New York and Syracuse offices. The First National Bank of Jersey City has been appointed cotransfer agent and co-registrar for the Class B common stock of the Niagara Share Corporation.

The United States Military Academy was restored to the list of opponents eligible for competition with Western Conference universities today, when the Big Ten faculty committee rescinded the ban placed on the Cadets in 1932.

RECENTLY returned from a survey of educational broad casting in several European countries. Dr. James Rowland Angell. former president of Yale and now educational counselor for the National Broadcasting Company, reported to the Conference on Educational Broadcasting in Chicago during the past week that the problem of school broadcasting must be solved locally and not nationally.

The place of Jesus in the synagogue was discussed yesterday in a sermon by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, where he told the congregation the question was always present in the minds of Christians and Jews eager for a "finer sense of brotherhood."

A FORTNIGHT'S opera at Covent Garden, which is about to begin, is nothing to boast of in a city of some seven million souls. It is little enough in comparison with what is done in this respect on the Continent. But it does mean 'that some progress has been made and that the indefatigable propaganda of Sir Thomas Beecham is bearing, if not fruit, some clusters of blossoms.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Case of Amityville have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Case, to Sidney F. Lush, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Lush, also of this village.

General Shigeta Fujii, retired Japanese Army commander, has sent a letter to General John J. Pershing, retired commander of the United States World War Expeditionary Force, explaining Japan's position in the Chinese-Japanese conflict. General Fujii was Chief of Staff of the Japanese First Army during the Russo-Japanese War and became acquainted with General Pershing, then a military observer.
HOLLYWOOD, with its tendency to simplify names of actors and to make them short, terse and glamorous, is a haven for the copywriter who had trouble passing his spelling exam.

Joseph Medwick, St. Louis Cardinal outfielder, was sought this morning by two Middlesex County Sheriff's deputies who had a writ of capias for his arrest. Medwick's mother informed the deputies, however, the ball player had left Carteret last night for St. Louis.

LONDON.-Not the least of Britain's worries in these days of heavy armaments and the consequent heavy taxation is the problem of a future decline in population. The discovery was made recently that, if present trends continue, the next hundred years will see the population of Britain reduced by half.

Observations on the spontaneous mutations of fruit flies lead him to the revolutionary conclusion that the genes, fundamental units of heredity upon which rest the foundations of the whole structure of the modern genetics, have been all along a mere figment of scientists' imagination, according to Professor Richard Goldschmidt of the Department of Zoology, University of California, formerly director of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute in Geimany.

Sixty members of the University of Pennsylvania's Mask and Wig Club came to the city yesterday and, just four hours after their arrival, gave a nimble and tuneful performance of their Golden Jubilee production, "Fifty-Fifty."

At the turn of the century almost all the great powers of the world, the United States excepted, had holds on China and were ready to parcel up the ancient empire into numerous colonial and commercial spheres.

Leslie HoreBelisha, 44-year-old Secretary of State for War, today proclaimed the end of promotion by seniority, which has had such a paralyzing influence upon Great Britain's regular army for many years.
It is a crime to dramatize crime on the radio in Argentina, says a report from Buenos Aires made public by the Department of Commerce.

Steps to organize a credit union and to provide training for the consumer cooperative methods t be employed at the Greenbelt, Md., model home project of the government are being launched. Last night, at a meeting in the new town, plans to organize a credit union for the project were launched, with advice given by T. Doig, field representative, and Miss Dora Maxwell, Eastern representative of the Credit Union National Association.

A scientific approach to the highway safety problem was outlined in papers read by experts in various fields at the annual meeting. of the Highway Research Board of the National Research Council, which started on Tuesday and concluded last night.

A romance between King Leopold III of the Belgians and Lady Anne Cavendish-Bentinck, granddaughter of the Duke and Duchess of Portland, is expected to result from a private visit that the King is paying to Welbeck Abbey, the Duke's Nottinghamshire home, this week-end.
CHRISTMAS cards with a distinctly personal touch--a fireside scene, an inviting door way festooned with holly, a family group-are keeping many a camera fan up late these nights.

NOW that the blast has been tempered by time (twenty-four hours in cold storage), the fiery philippic hurled against the indigenous football Giants by George Preston (the Magnificent) Marshall, owner of the Washington Redskins, is herewith exposed to public view.

Members of the Junior Daughters of the American Revolution Round Table of Greater New York and Near-by Vicinity will give a Hawaiian tea on Saturday at the Beekman Tower to establish a reserve fund for headquarters in this city.

As forecast when the special session of Congress convened Nov. 15, the proposed investigation of the broadcasting industry and the Federal Communications Commission and all legislation effecting radio have been definitely sidetracked by House and Senate leaders until the regular session, beginning Jan. 3.

Featured by addresses on labor relations, the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management will begin at the Hotel New Yorker tomorrow and continue throughout the week. Declaring that problems of group dealings with workers are prompting "more management thinking than any other single subject today,"

FOR many years the American woman has been reguarded by the world as the most emancipated. In politics, in the professions, in industry, the doors have opened wider and wider for her until at present there are few places where she is denied some form of representation.
Brooklyn fans got their first glimpse of indoor polo for the 19371938 season last night as Squadron C broke even in two abbreviated exhibition matches contested in the Squadron C Armory.
Paprin's Restaurant at Sixty-first Street and Roosevelt Avenue, Woodside, Queens is being enlarged and renovated.
The annual aviation ball which took place tonight at the Miami Biltmore Country Club marked the conclusion of social events in connection with the tenth annual all-American manoeuvres.

Reports of the progress of their ten scholarship engineering students will be one of the highlights of the annual meeting of the Woman's Auxiliary to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, to be held Tuesday at 11 A. M. at the Engineering Woman's Club. Mrs. Roy V. Wright, chairman of the educational committee, will present the report with Mrs. William H. Boehm, president, in the chair.
President Roosevelt started the first leg of a 1,450-mile trip back to Washington by sea and land today, interrupting a fishing cruise to return for dental treatment of a slowhealing gum.

A five-year study to evaluate and improve radio broadcasts planned for school use has been started under the sponsorship of the Federal Radio Education Committee, of which John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, is the chairman.
Few newspapers can boast of an older or more loyal subscriber than John Marshall of this town, who, in his ninety-sixth year, has been reading THE NEW YORK TIMES "ever since he can remember."

Hugh L. O'Neill, a retired silk dealer and descendant of a Colonia: family, died at his home in Germantown today in his eighty-first year. He was the son of James and Martha O'Neill and was a member of the Sons of the American Revolution and Society of the War of 1812.

The League of Nations Financial Committee concluded its sixty-fifth session tonight by proposing that the Economic Committee, opening its session Monday, join it in establishing a mixed experts' committee to study measures for dealing with the depression, including' questions of monetary policy.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Hurlburt, daughter, of Mrs. William B. Hurlburt of Wilton, and Arthur Bennett Leonard of Danbury were married this morning at the home of the bride's mother by Mgr. Thomas J. Finn of' St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Norwalk.

The steamship Hamburg of the Hamburg-American Line arrived yesterday from Europe with a shipment of animals and birds valued at $5,000, which includes three miniature kangaroos from the Dobo Islands, New Guinea.

Dealers in municipal bonds have given serious consideration for some time to the persistent agitation in certain quarters for a constitutional amendment or legislation which would enable the levying of taxes on the income from both Federal Government and State and municipal bonds.

The University of Tennessee rolled up five touchdowns today to defeat the University of Mississippi, 32 to 0. Sophomore Halfback George Cafego sparked the Volunteer ground and aerial attack which clicked with ease through the much heavier Ole Miss line. The game was played in a mist before 7,000 spectators.

A new season of indoor polo opened at a fast pace at Squadron A Armory last night, with Boulder Brook defeating one squadron team, 14 to 5, and the Metropolitan League champion New York Athletic Club stopping another, 13 to 8.
THE Christmas holidays will once more find American ski enthusiasts heading north toward the rolling Laurentian hills to the northwest of Montreal.

The Savage basketball team routed the N. Y. U. School of Commerce, 55 to 25, yesterday on the Savage court. The winners led at half time, 27 to 8. Moskowitz and Werner were the high scorers with nine points each.
On fine mornings, especially Sundays, many smartly dressed women are seen promenading their dogs in the Bois. Some wear fur-trimmed suits, the majority being black.

The invading eleven of Manhattan College and the University of Tulsa's Missouri Valley Conference champions battled through four scoreless periods of football today in an intersectional game that ended the 1937 campaign for both teams.

Denouncing the presentment to curb strike picketing, handed up by the Kings County grand jury to Judge John J. Fitzgerald Friday, Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and American Labor party Councilman-eleot from the Bronx, announced yesterday that he would join the picket lines of the New York Newspaper Guild at the plant of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle tomorrow morning.

The annual appeal to contributors to the Christmas Stocking Fund of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor was made yesterday. Private schools, women's clubs and churches, as well as individuals, were asked to aid by William H. Matthews, director of the Department of Family Welfare.

The sixth annual Charity Ball was held at Smith College last night in the Scott Gymnasium. Seven hundred and fifty persons attended. The profit from the sale of tickets will go to the Community Chest; therefore, in order to increase this amount, expenses are kept to a minimum. The decorations this year carried out the football motif.
Mr. and, Mrs. Arthur Kinne Hilts of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Wells Hilts, to Harry Wyndham Ruggles Jr., son of M-r. and Mrs. Ruggles of Kingston, Pa.

When completed early next Spring the twelve-story apartment building under construction at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-third Street will contain several features designed to make all apartments soundproof, reports Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents.
Mr. and, Mrs. Arthur Kinne Hilts of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Wells Hilts, to Harry Wyndham Ruggles Jr., son of M-r. and Mrs. Ruggles of Kingston, Pa.

When completed early next Spring the twelve-story apartment building under construction at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-third Street will contain several features designed to make all apartments soundproof, reports Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents.

BRITAIN'S high hopes of becoming ore of the tourist centers of the world have been dampened by the recent issue of figures showing that during the first eight months of 1937 the number of foreign visitors increased by only 21,000 or so.
Sefiorita Olga Fabrega, daughter of 3Mr. and Mrs. Leopoldo Fabrega, was married to Dr. Emilio Nunez Portuondo, Cuban Minister to Panama, in a private ceremony here last night.

Alfred J. Beaulac, 32, of Waterbury and Miss Helen Newfield, 25, of New Britain were burned to death at daybreak today and Victor Kysek, 27, and Anna Anderson, 23, both of New Britain, were badly burned when all four were pinned in Beaulac's automobile after a crash.

T0 those for whom Leo Tolstoy's personality still remains one of the most fascinating riddles in the history of human spirit and flesh this book will be a treat. Coming, as it does, from the pen of Ivan A. Bunin, the Russian winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature for 1933, it is interestingly conceived and written with the artistic mastery and penetration which are typical of this leader in contemporary Russian letters.
A Pyrrhic victory was won by Wilbur G. Voliva in Zion today. The town voted against movies and bowling alleys, but there was a catch to it. Mr. Voliva's movies are going out of the window, too.
