Details of a system of economic reciprocity developed by four hill tribes of Southern India were announced today by the Department of Anthropology of Yale University, with the comment by Dr. Leslie Spier, acting chairman, that Dr. David G. Mandelbaum, who has spent a year in India, has uncovered information of importance for the general study of primitive culture.

New York University students will receive approximately $150,000 in aid from the National Youth Administration in the current academic year, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

Borough President Lyons of the Bronx has informed the members of the Bronx Board of Trade that contracts have been let for the widening and repairing of 149th Street from Third Avenue to Exterior Street.

The net result of the visit to London this week by the French Premier and Foreign Minister, following Lord Halifax's trip to Germany, may be summed up by saying that it brought no substantial change in the European situation but did constitute mroe

Tests now under way at the University of Rochester may decide whether the courts will eventually be able to determine in compenstation suits precisely the extent to which a worker has been disabled by silicosis.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two national problems are now of pressing importance. Neither is by itself easy of solution. Yet both could be rendered much less acute by a single measure-a measure such as England several years ago adopted.

With the field hockey season now a matter of the past, interest is being focused on squash racquets. For the last three weeks women of the metropolitan district have been playing interclub and intergroup team matches, but this week they will have a chance to show their individual skill in the Metropolitan Association Class A championship, which begins tomorrow and lasts until Thursday.
The Supreme Court met today to prepare for a busy session Monday at which opinions may be delivered on subjects ranging from payment of interest on government bonds to valuation of public utilities.

Calling on their splendid sprinting ability to carry them through the sizzling last hour, the hardy German team of Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel won the sixty-third sixday bicycle race which came to an end at Madison Square Garden last night.

Pre-season Winter sports activity, which has been gaining momentum for the past three weeks, will reach its high-water mark in the metropolitan area on Tuesday night when the second annual Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet has its premiere at Madison Square Garden.

THOSE familiar with the writings of Paul Radin will not be surprised to hear that his new book on aboriginal religion is a most original and important one. Not only do the great and highly developed religious systems have many fundamental traits in common, but even the aboriginal beliefs of the primitive man likewise share basic elements and structures which remain unchanged among many peoples untouched of modern civilization, still living on the earth today.

A campus-wide radio and telephone system, planned and built entirely by undergraduates, began regular broadcasts to dormitories and fraternity houses at Brown University this week-the result of a "Saturday afternoon idea" which two freshmen had a year ago.

WHEN a dealer in rare books is not busy poring over the innumerable catalogues that assail him or studying the bibliographies and books about books that issue endlessly from the press, what does he do for relaxation? The answer could be many things, Dr. A. S. W.
BUENOS AIRES. THIS capital city of Argentina is assuming the lead in one important motoring development-underground parking.

THE announcement from Shanghai that Japan has taken over control and supervision of the Chinese postal organization there is of interest to collectors because of the possibility that the invading forces either seized stocks of Chinese stamps at the postoffices and overprinted them with Japanese characters or brought Japanese stamps with them and overprinted them for use locally.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Cannon Mills Co. Celanese Corp. of America. Endicott-Johnson Corp. pf. com. Filene's (Wm.) Sons Co. Goodyear Tire Rubber Co. International Nickel Co. of Canada, Ltd. pf.
CLEOPATRA, fascinating endlessly long centuries after she fell into dust, has caught the imagination of men so various as Plutarch, Shakespeare, Bernard Shaw and now Emil Ludwig.

CALLED OFF: As far as the New York Park Department was concerned, Central Park today might have been the scene of a touch-football game between New York society girls (home team) and Princeton students (visitors).

KIMBERLEY, Union of South Africa.-Sales of diamonds from the mines of South Africa have been affected by the recent slump in Wall Street and European anxieties to such an extent that the estimated $50,000,000 trade for 1937 and the expected increase in 1938 may not materialize.

Speaking on the topic "Love in Action," the Rev. Dr. C. Jeffares McCombe, the newly installed pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, said love was that part of ourselves that belongs to others.

The havoc wrought by bombs among children and other non-combatants in the Sino-Japanese war zone is described in a report that was forwarded to the Board of Foreign Missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church by Dr. Edward Carter Perkins, medical superintendent of the Water-of-Life Hospital at Kiukiang, China.

In the opening matches of the indoor polo season at the 112th Field Artillery Armory today, the home trio defeated the Metropolitan League champion New York Athletic Club riders, 17 to 11, and Ponolo, led by Billy Reber, triumphed over the Red Bank Polo Club, 13 to 8.

Misdirected intelligence is one of the most dangerous things in the world today, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in his sermon at James Memorial Chapel at the seminary, 122d Street and Broadway.
More than twenty dinghies competed today in an invitation regatta held ' over the three-quarter-mile course off the Indian Harbor Yacht Club for Classes D, B and X boats.
Using a plane he had never before sat in, Mike Murphy of Kokomo, Ind., won the Freddy Lund Trophy for exhibition flying in the closing event of the all-American air manoeuvres here this evening.
Leander H. Warren, who as a boy helped bury the Union dead after the battle of Gettysburg, died yesterday after a five weeks' illness. He would have been 88 on Tuesday.

Predicting stormy times for the church in the near future, the Rev. L. Humphrey Walz in his first sermon as pastor-elect of the Second Presbyterian Church, Ninety-sixth Street near Central Park West, urged all Christians yesterday to remain steadfast in their devotion to God.
When a bandit seizes a cash register it is not necessarily news, but when a cash register captures a bandit it certainly is.

The Rev. Harold E. Nicely, pastor of the Central Brick Presbyterian Church here for nearly eight years, announced to his congregation today that he would accept a call to the pulpit of the Brick Presbyterian Church of Rochester, N. Y. He received the call on Nov. 20.

The Rev. Dr. Fridolin Emil Oberlander, a prominent figure for many years in the United Lutheran Synod of New York and pastor of St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church at 81 Christopher Street, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 79 Christopher Street, after an illness of six weeks. He was in his seventy-second year.

Billy Rose will come back to Broadway as lessee of the French Casino, opening that theatre-restaurant on Christmas night, it was announced yesterday by the Louis F. Blumenthal-Jules Shapiro interests, which own it.

The Japanese march in Shanghai Friday is now described by officials here, after several days of reserve, as a military movement made by the Japanese commander by agreement with the authorities concerned and as not intended to signify any change in the status of the International Settlement. The Foreign Office, it is explained, knew of the intention,
The Dollar Line is suspending the New York-California-Orient service of its five "535"-type express steamers.

The marriage of Mrs. Gwendolyn Robinson de Alzaga Unzue, daughter of the Marquess and Marchioness of La Claras of Biarritz, France, to John Rutherford Heaton, son of Mrs. John Edward Heaton and the late Mr. Heaton of this city, was announced today upon receipt of a letter from Paris, where the wedding took place Nov. 22.

The possibility that the fatal stabbing of Charles A. Klein in Central Park Thursday night was a suicide was under investigation yesterday after the police received information from two youths who said they saw a man resembling the 60-yearold public accountant there.
The second installment in the repayment of the British loan to the French railways took place yesterday, according to a note issued by the French Ministry of Finance today.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Heasley of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gretchen G. Heasley, to Douglas Franchot Hickok, son of Mrs. Neil MacDonald Wilder of Goshen, N. Y., and of Lieut. Col. William Orville Hickok 4th of New York.

The Bishop Loughlin High School team scored an easy victory in the C. H. S. A. A. swimming meet at the Columbus Council Knights of Columbus pool in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, defeating St. Augustine's, 55--16. In another meet St. Francis conquered St. John's, 48--27.

Featured by a fourteen-game basketball schedule, programs for the Winter sports season at the United States Military Academy were announced by Lieut. Col. Jacob L. Devers, director of physical education, today.

The keel of the new passenger and freight ship which the United States Lines plans to build for its transatlantic service will be laid early in the Spring and the vessel will be ready to enter service for the 1940 season, it became known yesterday.
Something new in luncheon clubs has been organized by the Rev. Karl V. Moore, pastor of St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church here.
Maria Jeritza's return to the na. tion's opera boards, scheduled for tonight with the St. Louis Opera Company, Guy Golterman, director, has been deferred to January. Mme.
Mrs. John Sherman Raymond of 380 Riverside Drive has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elisabeth Frances Raymond, to Frank H. Heiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Heiss of Meridian, Miss.

While all deliveries of corn on the Board of Trade here sold last week at the lowest prices since 1934, the market developed a much firmer undertone in the later dealings as the result of buying of futures to remove hedges against export sales of the cash staple, and the close yesterday was at net gains of 3/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel on the week.
Japanese officials revealed today that they had occupied St. John [Sancian] Island, 120 miles southwest of Hong Kong, which contains the Saint Francis Xavier shrine at the place where he died.
The new Union Pacific streamline train City of Los Angeles will be placed on exhibition at the Grand Central Terminal on Saturday, Dec. 18, for the one day, it was announced yesterday.

Despite the protests of Secretary Perkins, the American Association for Labor Legislation and the press in general, the State Legislature last year amended the workmen's compensation law to place silicosis in a class by itself.

The appointment of Professor Lindsay Rogers of Columbia University as a member of the Transit Commission to succeed Leon G. Godley, whose resignation will become effective Jan. 1, will be urged upon Governor Lehman by a group of civic and business organizations, it was disclosed yesterday.
The Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street, announced yesterday that it would open its eleventh annual Christmas show tomorrow.
The annual card party to aid the brace and shoe fund of the Hospital and Home for Crippled Children in Newark will take place on Jan. 6 in the Women's Club of Orange.

Governor George H. Earie of Pennsylvania today paid tribute to Johan Printz, first Governor of New Sweden, in an ancient candlelit church twenty miles from here. Governor Earle, on a good-will visit, said "this place marks the very beginning of the State of Pennsylvania."

Dr. Alphonse Mingana, distinguished Orientalist, died today at Birmingham at the age of 55. Among the ancient Christian manuscripts he recovered on visits to the Near East was "The Book of Faith," by Bishop Theodore, which had been lost to Western readers for 1,500 years.

Reports from London of the imminent sale of the steamship Leviathan for scrap iron were confirmed here yesterday with the revelation that two British metal concerns have submitted bids which are now in Washington for approval. Approval of the sale is expected today.

Fort Totten's football team triumphed over the Elroy A. C. of Brooklyn, 24 to 7, yesterday on the winning team's gridiron at Bayside, Queens. It was the fifth victory for Fort Totten, whose attack was led by Warren Kirsten with two touchdowns on line plunges.
Three youths who two weeks ago robbed a detective of his pocket money and service revolver were arrested Saturday night and yesterday morning by their police victim.

The need for cooperation between government and business and for increased knowledge through research in the fields of trade and industry was emphasized in the annual report of Secretary Roper, made public today, covering the fiscal year ending June 30.
THE luck of the Maras held right to the end of the season. The weather all over the Polo Grounds was beautiful yesterday. However, it was a little hot down in the field.

Only a religion that can deal with the real abysmal depths of man's character will succeed in this day, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said in his sermon yesterday.

Count Konrad von Preysing. Catholic Bishop of Berlin, had read from the pulpits of his diocese today a pastoral letter denouncing Church Minister Hanns Kerrl's assertions that the Nazi regime was not attacking Christianity and replying that on the contrary Christian Germans were being robbed of freedom of conscience and liberty of worship.

THE CRADLE WILL ROCK, an operetta in two acts. Book, music and lyrics by Marc Blitzstein. Sponsored by the Mercury Theatre as the first offering of its Worklight group. To be performed again next Sunday evening at the Mercury.

Mrs. Robert Hawthorne Wylie of 1,115 Fifth Avenue and Quogue, L. I., has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Belle M. Wylie, to John O'Hara, author and son of Mrs. Patrick H. O'Hara of Pottsville, Pa., and the late Dr. O'Hara, which took place on Friday at Elkton, Md.

French capital, which has returned home in the last two months, has not been invested in national enterprises. Capitalists are afraid of the risks attendant upon investment in French concerns whose margin of profits is at present jeopardized by the demands of labor and by heavy taxation.
Play in the Metropolitan Badminton Association competition progressed through its second stages as the Garden City Casino registered a 4-to-1 triumph over the Central second team in a Class

The Italian Renaissance art gallery which the late Thomas Fortune Ryan built to house his art treasures, and which has stood dark at 3 East Sixty-seventh Street for a number of years, has been turned over to the Municipal Art Committee, it was announced yesterday.
Unfavourable crop reports from Argentina and the development of a fairly active European demand for United States hard Winter wheat dominated the action of the wheat market last week.

An effort by a man who had just killed his secretary and shot himself through the head to pay a bill of $12.26 revealed a murder mystery to detectives of the Fort Hamilton station, Brooklyn, last night.
Preparations were made today to fly twenty women and children by moonlight back to the mainland from three ships frozen fast in this region of polar ice.
The twenty-sixth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund began yesterday with ninetynine contributions in hand, aggregating $31,920.08.

The work of foreign artists bulks large in the exhibitions of the week, with no less than a dozen shows in which paintings, sculpture and drawings by French, German and Italian artists may be seen. In the remaining exhibitions, -numbering approximately thirty, American artists are showing paintings and prints, camera work and silver in another pre-holiday flood of new gallery attractions.

An amendment to the Federal Housing Act to provide for the issuance of mortgages up to $200,000 by the Federal Housing Administration on existing multiple dwellings was recommended in a letter to Senator Robert F. Wagner and Stewart MacDonald, Federal Housing Administrator, by Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the joint legislative committee investigating guaranteed mortgages, made public yesterday.

Witnessing no particularly favorable domestic developments and feeling rather uneasy lest the confusion in Shanghai precipitate at any hour an AngloJapanese collision, business circles here this week avoided commitments, banks reported that newly taken credits were sparsely utilized and, in an exceptionally dull market, stocks sagged.

The Port of New York Authority, in a report to Governor Lehman of New York and Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, recommended the complete development of both New York municipal fields for transatlantic airplane and airship terminal facilities, it was disclosed yesterday.

Without being unduly hopeful, financial London is viewing the situation in the United States with less alarm. It detects some softening in the attitude of the strongest critics of President Roosevelt's policy, although the President himself is responsible for this.
Sir Andrew Taylor, an architect for many years on the faculty of McGill University, died today at the age of 87. He retired from his Canadian practice in 1904 and returned to London to live.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William E. Clow Jr. of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Melville Clow, to Mario Braggiotti of New York, son of the late Isidore Braggiotti of Boston and Florence, Italy.

At the completion of three weeks of its special session Congress finds itself in much more than the usual confusion. The Agricultural Committees in each house have hastily thrown together huge, complicated, and half-unintelligible bills, one eighty-six, the other ninety-seven pages long.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Warren Stevens of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Ford de Mott Stevens, to Russell Ellsworth Watson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson, also of New Brunswick.
The New York Americans and Brookhattans battled to a 3-3 tie yesterday at Starlight Park as 4,000 soccer fans looked on.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Christine Henrikson of 140 East Sixty-third Street to Jerome V. Detmer, son of Julian Francis Detmer of Edgemont, Tarrytown-on-Hudson, N. Y.
The Russian Winter has settled heavily on Moscow and tonight it is bitterly cold with even the air frozen into a gray halo broken by occasional snow flurries over the city's drifted streets.

With sharp criticism of the American Newspaper Guild and its method of picketing, The Brooklyn Daily Eagle devoted its leading editorial in yesterday's edition to the strike which started on Sept. 13. It was the first time that the newspaper affected has mentioned the strike.
The nation's leading bankers have replied to a questionnaire that inventory holdings of business are not large enough to constitute a serious handicap to recovery in the United States.

No general tendency to cut wages has yet emerged in the current recession, according to a show of hands yesterday at the opening session of the National Industrial Council in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The lack of definiteness in our current religion was deplored yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in his sermon at the morning services.

New evidence of the remoteness of peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization appeared yesterday in an announcement by Allen S. Haywood, regional director of the C. I. O., that a central labor council for industrial unions in this city would be set up within a week.

The novelty of the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall was Charles Wakefield Cadman's orchestral fantasy, "Dark Dancers of the Mardi-Gras," scored for full modern orchestra, with an important piano part played by the composer.
Shernoff Woolen Co., in 215 4th Ave.; United Motorists of America, in 250 W. 57th St.; Fred Conhagen, dress importer. in 2u W. 47th St.; Cushman Wakefield, Inc.. brokers.

Choking clouds of smoke sent eighteen pajama-clad fraternity men into the street early today from Phi Phi Delta house of Hobart College. Originating in the basement of the three-story frame building, flames went upward through partitions and along the chimney.

Current efforts by the Administration to revive construction have been highly encouraging to building material and supply lines, with the result that plans are now under way for promoting the drive with more extensive advertising campaigns next year, according to executives of various companies yesterday.
Myron L. Whitcomb, president of BA the Merrimac National Bank for the last fifteen years and long prominent in Haverhill affairs, today at his home at the age of 75.

The Board of Transportation has again refused to take part in an informal conference called by the State Labor Relations Board to discuss the pending petition of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, for certification as sole bargaining agent for the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Chicago Bears, who clinched the Western division title last week, finished their regular National Football League schedule today by romping over their home-town rivals, the Cardinals, 42 to 28, in a game called in the final minutes because of darkness.
It appears from the condition of the sterlingdollar exchange market that the effects of the recent gold scare have entirely disappeared.

Formation of the American Labor party of New Jersey was voted unanimously tonight by delegates of 164 unions throughout the State, convening in the Newark Labor Lyceum at the invitation of Labor's Non-Partisan League of New Jersey.

To be a Christian is a true mark of being different from the world about us, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, said in his sermon yesterday. "A calm, sane, balanced life will give you true distinction In our troubled age," he declared.

The place of the Bible in the lives of those who have access to it was the subject of several sermons in pulpits here yesterday. The second Sunday in Advent is known in many churches as Bible Sunday and many clergymen have for the last few years, devoted their sermons on that day to a general discussion of the Scriptures.

In anticipation of the dedication Dec. 21 of the south tube of the Lincoln Tunnel in New York, the Public Works Administration made public today some statistics showing how widely the money for constructing the $40,000,000 tube was distributed.
The Bankers Magazine's index of 365 representative securities based on December, 1921, as 100, was 121 on Nov. 19, compared with 121.6 the month before, and 133.8 correspondingly last year.

William Coombs Baker, Professor of Physics at Queen's University, died last night at the age of 66. Professor Baker was a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John F. Baker and was of Quaker descent. He was educated at Cambridge University and Queen's, obtaining his Master of Arts degree at the latter university in 1895.

Three of the four nitrogen companies that have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with violation of the Robinson-Patman act have filed answers admitting "all material allegations of the complaints to be true," indicating that a probable consent order against them will be issued soon.

Comments by banks this week are guarded on the subject of the industrial situation in the United States. Press surveys are somewhat less favorable. Only Adolf Wagner, the Reich's Price Commissar, among official authorities, intimates that the American outlook may be considered serious.

Walter Lindner of 1,854 Bryant Avenue, the Bronx, part owner of a restaurant at 407 East Fiftyfifth Street, was locked for thirty minutes in the wine safe of the 85-year-old restaurant early yesterday after a woman customer who had been drinking too much had playfully closed the door and spun the combination knob.

The doughboy" as an individual receives relatively little space in the report of the Chief of Staff of the Army made public today, although, collectively, General Craig pays tribute to the infantry. But the doughboyy"

Denunciations of the Nazi regime for abridging human rights in Germany were punctuated with beer and entertainment at the annual German Day of the German-American League for Culture held yesterday afternoon in the Royal Windsor Hall, 69 Went Sixty-sixth Street. About 1,600 attended.

Barnet M. Hoffman, owner of a drug store at 2,021 Seventh Avenue, where he has been the victim of hold-up men four times during the last two years, refused to submit to a fifth robbery early yesterday and disarmed Andrew Schools, 22-yearold Negro,

After two years' voluntary exile in England, Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh returned yesterday to their homeland. They left behind them in the country where they sought sanctuary from kidnappers and intruders on their privacy their two children, 5-year-old Jon and Land, who was born in the week of the coronation of George VI last May.

Embattled farmers of this town, founded twelve years after the Revolutionary War, who have been protesting for several weeks the establishment here of the first New England pro-Nazi camp, invoked Connecticut's historic "blue laws" today when a posse of six constables 'arrested two of thirty members of the German-American Bund engaged in clearing the heavily wooded campsite of trees.

Prince Charles, King Leopold's 34-year-old brother, arrived unexpectedly in London tonight and Mayfair gossips immediately decided that it was he rather than the widowed Belgian monarch who is to be the husband of Lady Anne Cavendish-Bentnick.

A memorial plot on the grounds of the Merrick Grammar School, named for William S. Christy, an original member of the Board of Education here, was dedicated today at ceremonies in the school auditorium and on the grounds.

The development of the automobile lawsuit as a racket through commercial scrambling for profit by persons not involved in the accidents, and of divorce cases as one of the largest classes of civil actions, is emphasized as the result of a ten-year study of the courts of Connecticut, made under the supervision of Dean Charles E. Clark and Professor Harry Shulman of the Yale School of Law.
Three naval fliers of the U. S. S. Heron were injured seriously today when their amphibian plane crashed into a mountainside shortly after taking off from Baguio.

Now that the gunning is gradually creeping to a close in the Norththat is, above that invisible line of the Messrs. Mason and Dixonwe're getting a number of inquiries on the quality of Southern fishing.

There was improvement last week in certain wholesale lines, particularly gift items, early Spring apparel, sweaters and skirts. Retailers were proceeding cautiously and orders were more numerous than large. Formal and dinner types were outstanding in the dress markets.
On behalf of the Jews in Poland, whose condition he described as "serious," Samuel Untermyer called a conference yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to form an emergency committee.

Observers here point out that President Roosevelt seems to have adopted quite a different policy from the one he has hitherto followed. The two messages to Congress this week on the national building program and on reduction in the budgetary expenditures are considered in financial quarters here to indicate that the White House has abandoned the idea that a lasting prosperity could be based on increases in the public spending, and higher salaries and prices.

De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry has been retained as head coach of Brown football, Dr. Frederick W. Marvel, director of athletics, said tonight. No announcement was made on the length or terms of the contract or the naming of assistant coaches.
The New York Civic Orchestra, conducted by Edgar Schenkman, gave a concert last night at the WPA Theatre of Music, with Harriett Eells, mezzo-soprano, as soloist.

Paul F. Haddock, a leader in textile T. T and allied lines, died today on the eve of his fifty-first birthday. He was born in England and came to America in his youth. He had been a resident of Charlotte for many years.

Passengers arriving from Europe today on the French liner Normandie include Count Robert de Dampierre, French Minister to Canada, and Countess de Dampierre; Jose Morales, Cuban Minister to France, and Mme. Morales;

A mortgage loan of $150,000 has been made by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to the 41 Kew Gardens Corporation, J. Julius Spitzer, president, on the new sixstory apartment house at 41 Kew Gardens Road, Kew Gardens, L. I.
Henry A. Smeed, a printer for seventy years and dean of printing tradesmen in the city, died today in his home of pneumonia, at the age of 87.
Members of the New York Board of Trade will be asked at the annual meeting on Wednesday at the Hotel Astor to approve a memorial to Congress which requests "definite encouragement" to business.

The engagement of Miss Lucille Natanson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander S. Natanson of 15 West Eighty-first Street, to Mortimer M. Reznick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Reznick of 333 West End Avenue, has been announced by her parents.

The seven Hewitt brothers of Paterson, believed to be.New Jersey's only prospectors, spurred on by the discovery of a vein of zinc forty feet underground, applied their brawn to the task of digging further here today, confident that their mine would yield riches.
The Jewish ship owner and operator of two transatlantic lines, Arnold Bernstein, is entering the last week of his trial on the charges of economic treason under German exchange regulations.

Eastman N. Jacobs, aeronautical engineer of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, has received from the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences the Slyvanus Albert Reed award for his work in improving the efficiency of airplane wing sections.

I SPEAK FOR THE CHINESE, by Carl Crow. (Harper, $1). The author of "400 Million Customers" looks at the Sino - Japanese crisis. COLUMBIA POETRY 1937, (Columbia University Press, $1). Verse by Columbia students.

The annual dinner and dance of the Society of the Virginians will be held Thursday in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Dr. Francis Pendleton Gaines, president of Washington and Lee University, will be the guest of honor and principal speaker.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Howes of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hilda Howes, to Joseph Miller Thomas of Durham, N. C., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Miller Thomas of Philadelphia.

A gift of $3,600 from the Commercial Investment Trust, Inc., andone of $3,000 from the Ittleson Foundation were announced last night by Clarence Francis, chairman of the commerce and industry committee of the United Hospital Campaign.

Owing to an undue depression of the market by bear operators, the Australian Woolgrowers Council decided today to reduce the selling allocation by 20 per cent. Consequently, sales in the last half of the season will be spread over a period extending in some States to the end of June.

Germain Glidden of Englewood, N. J., successfully defended the Gold Racquet at the Rockaway Hunting Club today as he conquered Neil J. Sullivan of Philadelphia, winner in 1932 and 1934, in the final of the tenth annual squash racquets fixture. The score was 18-16, 18-13, 15-7.
The annual loss of bird life through migration is tremendous, Alexander Wetmore, ornithologist of the National Museum at Washington, related here, en route home from Venezuela, where,

" Merely Murder," the mystery play, developed into something of a mystery itself over the week-end. Rowland Stebbins, A. E. Thomas, Miriam Doyle and Charles G. Stewart, respectively its producer, author, director and general manager, asserted positively yesterday that it had closed last Saturday at the Playhouse after three performances.

The Theatrical Costume Workers Union, a unit of the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday that henceforth only unionmade costumes might be used in theatres or night clubs employing members of the unions of stagehands, electricians, musicians,

Permission to call a strike or "labor holiday" in protest against the general expiration of household leases on Oct. 1 is being asked of moving-van owners by the Union of Van Drivers, Packers and Furniture Handlers, Local 814, of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

R. G. Howe, British Charge d'Affaires in China, arrived here today after a railway journey from Hankow, whither he followed the Chinese Foreign Office two weeks ago. He brought other members of the embassy staff and embassy archives with him because Britain is moving her embassy to Shanghai, nearer the scene of frictions arising from Japan's conquests.

The outlook for Germany's foreign trade is considered generally satisfactory provided the current world-wide recession tendencies are not aggravated. Rudolph Eicke, a director of the Reichsbank, writes that Germany's development measures have as good as neutralized the 40 per cent advantage which competitors gained in the international field through currency devaluations.
The chiefs of the National Socialist regime, government and party organizations collected 7,655,000 marks yesterday for the Winter relief program.

The wars in Spain and in China have demonstrated again that tanks and aviation are "valuable auxiliaries" to the infantry but that "neither of these arms can bring about a decision in land operations," General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff of the army, declared today in his annual report for the fiscal year 1937.

Mickey Mouse, whose doings in a comic strip resulted in his being banned by the Yugoslav censor last week, is going to be responsible for the expulsion of a correspondent from Yugoslavia unless the Belgrade Government intervenes.

Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker said today he would discharge the present Essex County grand jury on Dec. 13 and charge a new grand jury to continue the investigation of Newark governmental affairs, which already has brought about the indictment of at least twenty-seven persons, including Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein and his four colleagues on the former City Commission.
Beveridge Webster, American pianist, who appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night, gave a series of performances that were, at one and the same time, dazzling and disappointing.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,967,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

An appeal for "the whole Bible," which, he said, had been mutilated by "a very noisy bloc of Scottish Presbyterians" who had been able to obtain the elimination of the books of the Apocrypha, was made yesterday by the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Movies of the forward pass Kenny Washington threw to Hal Hirshon in yesterday's football game between Southern California and the University of California at Los Angeles, showed today that the ball traveled sixty-two yards in the air.

The Bourse was rather dull and irregular all this week. Although supported fairly well at the opening, quotations sagged suddenly in sympathy with government securities upon announcement of the issuance of a new loan, but on Friday the market hardened considerably and transactions were in a much larger volume.

Capturing a best-in-show award for the twenty-sixth time in his brilliant competitive career, the striking liver and white pointer, Ch. Nancolleth Marquis, yesterday provided the Giralda Farms of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N. J., with top honors in the Bronx County Kennel Club's all-breed exhibition for the second straight year.

President Getulio Vargas has taken another step toward the establishment in Brazil of "democracy in the modern manner." His latest decree-foreshadowed in the Constitution which he promulgated three weeks ago in the midst of the Presidential campaign, thus staving off his own retirementabolishes all parties, including all "organizations serving auxiliary party purposes."

It is impossible to develop good housing out of bad housing in New York by laws that will merely make tenements a little safer, because the slum buildings are undesirable in design and must be replaced, Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, declared in a radio broadcast yesterday afternoon.

The Bancamerica-Blair Corporation and the Hydro-Electric Securities Corporation are not named as defendants in the $100,000,000 lawsuit brought by stockholders of the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

" Mrs. Tenth Avenue," typical mother of Manhattan's "Hell's Kitchen" district, will share honors with Commissioner Austin H. MacCormick of the Department of Correction at the opening tomorrow of New York's latest recreation center for children, 698 Tenth Avenue, near Forty-ninth Street.
The Montreal Canadiens, spotting their opponents a two-goal lead, came from behind tonight to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 2, in a fast National Hockey League battle witnessed by 13,000.

Marcus Heiman, president of the League of New York Theatres, has asked for a meeting of committees representing the league and the Dramatists Guild, it was learned yesterday. Purpose: to discuss the Guild's disputed minimum basic agreement.

Cotton prices last week lost virtually all the gains of the preceding week. On the New York Cotton Exchange net changes were declines of 22 to 26 points, in contrast with advances of 23 to 31 points the week before.

187th St (11-3114), s s, 26 ft e of Prospect Ave. 34x70; Raymond J. Scully, referee, to Yonkers General Hospital; mtg, $13,000. 221st St, 929 (16-4692); Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Nicola Vecchiotti, 837 Neill Ave.

Ben Bernie, in Hotel Savoy-Plaza, 5th Ave and 59th St. Joseph H. Young, in 242 E 19th St; John M. Faulhaber, Mrs. Florence Weaver, Irwin M. Nathanson, in 315 E 68th St; Sylvan E. Rosenthal, in 345 E 68th St; the J. H. Taylor Management Corp, broker.
Construction of a ten-story apartment building to cost $1,500,000 will be started here within two weeks, Clifford F. MacEvoy, Newark banker and building contractor, announced today.

The general improved condition of agriculture has been reflected in an increase of borrowing for farm purchases and a decline in refinancing of farm indebtedness, according to A. S. Goss, land bank commissioner of the Farm Credit Administration, in a statement today.

Returning from Manhattan last night, where she had taken her 5-year-old granddaughter to see Santa Claus, Mrs. Grace R. Reiss of Baldwin, Grand Royal Matron of the State of New York, Order of Amaranth, was seized with a heart attack and died here at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Isabelle Albro, 83 Centre Avenue. Her age was 57.

So vigorously did more than 100 wedding guests dance the mazurka at near-by Jerzow today that the floor collapsed, pitching the whole company into the cellar. Arms and legs of many were broken; no one escaped injury.

The stock markets are steadily and quietly moving into a sounder and more promising condition. A relatively good recovery has been in progress, with minor interruptions, throughout the last fortnight.

One hundred and two children's books that were on exhibit at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair last month will be the feature of a public conference on children's literature Saturday at the Washington Square Center of New York University.

Members of the Czechoslovak Trade Treaty Commission arrived yesterday from Prague on the steamship President Harding of the United States Lines on their way to Washington to discuss new trade agreements with the United States.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84.6, which compares with 85.1 a week ago, 86.1 two weeks ago, 87.1 three weeks ago and 87.9 four weeks ago.

Hamilton Terrace, 46, 17x100; St Luke's Hospital to Trosley Realty Corp, 299 Bway ($5). 94th St, 52-54 W, 50x100.8; Frederick Hambrock Jr to 52 W 94 St Realty Corp. 5254 W 94th St: mtg, $60,000, 1/4 interest.

Liquidation In the lard market developed early last week, prices on the Board of Trade dropping to the lowest level of the season on the near-by future. Cash lard sold down to $8.25 per 100 pounds, the lowest price quoted since August, 1934.

Twelve hours after setting out from Cambridge at 10 o'clock this morning, the caravan of thirty-seven young impersonators of the pioneers of 1787 tonight wearily plodded up to the Wayside Inn, the objective of the third day of their trek to Marietta, Ohio.

During the first full year of operation under the silicosis amendment to the State Workmen's Compensation Act, silicosis compensation cases were closed with awards to only six victims in New York State, totaling $4,535, the American Labor Legislation Review, quarterly publocation of the American Association for Labor Legislation, reports in its December issue, published today.

The membership of the new American committee of the International Chamber of Commerce was announced today by Eliot Wadsworth, president of the Boston Chamber of Commerce and chairman of the American section of the Council of the International Chamber. Twentyseven of the seventy-five members are from New York City.

University Ave (11-2868), e s, 615 ft n of Tremont Ave, 50x62; Sophie Jucory to Bowery Savings Bank; $10,800. 231st St (13-3404a), n s, 105 ft w of Broadway, 158x140; Beckrose Realty Co to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave; extends mtg to Dec. 1, 1947, at 5 per cent to Dec. 1, 1942, and 4 1/2 per cent thereafter; $220.000.
Shearson, Hammill Co. have moved their uptown office to the Guaranty Trust Building, 522 Fifth Avenue. The office will be under the management of John J. Boyd, resident partner.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:
Frank Campbell, in his Class B craft Felix, made a clean sweep of the dinghy racing today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, taking six contests, all that were sailed.

A second group of youths, with some from New York State included, will receive the benefits of the National Youth Administration's work-experience project at Passamaquoddy Village, Me., as a resuit of approval by President Roosevelt of continuance of the project in 1938.

The Civilian Conservation ??ps in the fiscal year ended June 30 devoted increasing attention to the individual needs of enrollees, Robert Fechner, director, said in his annual report, made public today, detailing the expenditure of $396,547,796.

Barnes and Waldemar von Zedtwitz of New York, scoring 529 1/2 points, won tonight the open-pair title in the national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League. New York players took most of the leading positions at the end of the night's play, which started with thirty-two pairs out of an original field of ninety-five.
Warsaw, Bucharest, Belgrade and Prague, the four capitals to which Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France has gone to inform and to woo, are capitals of uncertainty.

The engagement of Miss Marjorie Ethel Helms, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Helms of Camp Hill, near Harrisburg, to Gordon Edward Bolter, son of Mrs. Carl Eggers of New York and the late Edward Bolter of Chicago, has been announced by her parents.

The illness and failing sight of Rudolph Blaschka, the last of the makers of Harvard's internationally famous glass flowers, brought tonight announcement that the collection had probably reached its final form.
The Fort Hamilton football team triumphed over the Nutley (N. J.) Club, 7 to 0, at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn yesterday.

Fred MacMurray and Bing Crosby will be co-starred in "Harmony for Three," which Wesley Ruggles will produce and direct, Paramount has announced. It will be the first film in which the two have been teamed. Claude Binyon, who had written most of Ruggies's scripts in recent seasons,

Out of a welter of rumors which pound the lobbies of the two hostelries where the nation's foremost baseball authorities have assembled for the annual major league conclaves there rose today the tall, gaunt figure of Babe Herman to capture the spotlight.

To keep union lines firm in the face of a rise in unemployment the Committee for Industrial Organization has advised its affiliates throughout the nation to establish unemployment committees and help jobless members to get unemployment insurance, WPA employment or home relief, it was learned last night.
The collapse of the coffee market as a result of Brazil's action withdrawing the restriction on its exports has made an agreement on the budget in the Costa Rican Congress impossible at this time.
The Celtics scored a 34-31 victory over the New York Yankees last night at the Hippodome, where a crowd of 4,000 persons turned out for the weekly basketball program.

The fifty-eighth annual convention of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers will open today at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. Sessions will continue through Friday.

The world need not fall into a state of anarchy because the old supernatural authorities are weakening or have disappeared, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons, pastor of All Souls Unitarian Church, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, said in his sermon yesterday.

The most successful annual national open bird show in the short three-year history of the Brooklyn Cage Bird Association ended last night in Saengerbund Hall. Officials reported with evident satisfaction that nearly 1,000 birds had been exhibited by fanciers from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Pennsylvania and Washington, D. C.

Nassau Hall's most recent bid for nation-wide attention, the Lonely Hearts Club, founded for the announced purpose of arranging correspondence between Princeton and Vassar students, was formally abandoned today, closing six weeks of spasmodic activity.

At the end of last week three events in this city drew fresh attention to the increasingly familiar problem of the picket line. Supreme Court Justice Steinbrink granted a modified injunction restraining members of the New York Newspaper Guild from causing any kind of demonstration outside the shop of a hairdressing establishment which was being picketed merely because it had published advertising in The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, against which a strike is now in progress.
With both professional operators and the public holding aloof from participation in this week's stock market, conditions tended to be exceptionally dull.
With gay spirits and pageantry more than a thousand Yugoslavs celebrated yesterday Yugoslavia's National Unity Week, the nineteenth anniversary of the Union of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.

" Antigone," by Sophocles, will be presented by the Thirty-second Street Branch of the Hunter College Classical Club as the thirteenth of a series of Greek and Roman plays today in the student room of the annex.

William Diehl, founder and president of F. Diehl Sons, fuel and building supply dealers of Wellesley, died tonight at his home in South Natick at the age of 77. He founded the fuel and building supply business in Wellesley when he was 17.

Churchgoers carried rusty muskets and police listed names of Sunday yard-rakers for possible "arrest" today as Windham County residents staged a comic-opera protest against "blue laws," some dating as far back as 1770.
Taiana Sofiano, for eight years secretary of the Moscow office of the AmericanRussian Chamber of Commerce, and known to scores of American businessmen who have visited Moscow, has been arrested.

F. A. Scola and L. F. Sanman, Class A gunners, and R. K. Fawcett, who competed in Class B, finished on even terms in the contest for the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday.
To some extent, the movements of note circulation of the Bank of England are being obscured by Continental European dehoarding.
A board to set minimum wage standards for women and children in the laundry industry in New York State was named yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

EMERSON N. ABBOTT, salesman, 593 Riverside Dr.-Liabilities $4,313 and no assets. CAPEK BROS., 212 E. 92d St.-Liabilities $5,296 and no assets. The members of the firm are Frank A. and John Capek Jr. JOHN A. CAMPBELL. insurance salesman, 24 E. 82d St.--Liabillties $123,798, partly secured claims; assets $9, exclusive of securities pledged as collateral.
With the largest crowd to see a hockey game in several years looking on, the New York Rangers returned to their winning ways at the expense of the Boston Bruins last night.

The index for wholesale prices on Nov. 27 was 590, compared with 595 on Nov. 20. Native products were 636 and 638, respectively; imported products, 506 and 517; foodstuffs, 591 and 592, and industrial materials, 590 and 598.

The Washington Redskins, as hot as the great Chicago fire, routed the New York Giants, 49 to 14, at the Polo Grounds yesterday to gain the Tastern champiship of the National Football League and the right to meet the Chicago Bears in the play-off at Wrigley Field next Sunday, Those poor Bears! They seem to be in for it.
California's All-Stars evened their international polo series with their Mexican rivals today, scoring a 12-8 victory in the fourth meeting of the teams before 7,500.

The $450,000,000 of securities which the Treasury Department will offer for subscription tomorrow will consist of about $250,000,000 of eight-year 2 1/2 per cent Treasury bonds of 1945 and approximately $200,000,000 of five-year 1 3/4 per cent Treasury notes, series C-1942, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

George M. Hallwachs, director of the boys' bureau of the Charity Organization Society and the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, announced yesterday that applications for aid from homeless boys reached a higher total last month than in any month since June. The applications were fewer, however, than in November. 1932, he reported.
Already awaiting grand jury action on an extortion charge, William P. Deisler, 42 years old, Medford justice of the peace, was jailed here today for the second time on a similar count.

The Chinese Women's Relief Association held a cocktail party yesterday at the Park Lane Hotel to raise money for China. It began with the playing of a section of a Chinese drama and a pageant of Chinese costumes, and ended, as Miss Mai-Mai Sze put it, with something "American"-an auction.

The Japanese confidently expect to enter Nanking triumphantly before the week-end. Nothing could exceed the confidence with which they announce continuing victories and prophesy further steady advances.

A. George Townsend of Jackson Heights, ranked sixth in the Long Island squash racquets championship, was the only seeded star to be eliminated yesterday at the Jackson Heights Squash Club. Pitted against M. W. Metzler of the City A. C., rated third, Townsend bowed in the third round, 1813, 16-13, 7-15, 15-11.
Morocco has been the scene of the most violent outbreaks of the native nationalist movement in North Africa which the French Government has determined to put down.

Luther Harr, Secretary of Banking for Pennsylvania, who demanded a reversal of the Federal Reserve Board's "deflationary moves" in a speech at Bradford, Pa., on Friday night, will preside here tomorrow at his last meeting as chairman of the executive committee of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

Staging a great comeback in the final period after trailing for two sessions, the New York Rovers skated to a 5-3 success over the Atlantic City Sea Gulls in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

German industrial reports this week indicated that the light industries are seasonally rather slack, but the heavy lines are active, owing to the demand for materials for out-of-door construction, which is attributable to the mild weather.

The debuts of Zinka Milanov, Yugoslavian soprano, and Nicola Moscona, Greek basso, and the revival of Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette," absent from the repertory for three years, will mark the third week of the Metropolitan Opera season next week.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 77.0 on Dec. 1, compared with 78.4 a fortnight before, 79.7 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Jack Doyle has quit the billiard business. In some quarters the reaction to this announcement is likely to be: "So what?" But to hundreds of persons interested and active in the sports and theatrical world the news will be received with keen regret.

International amity and brotherhood were described as "a vital part of Christianity's objective" in a sermon yesterday morning at Zion Protestant Episcopal Church, Northern Boulevard and Douglaston Parkway, Queens, by the Rev. Dr. Lester Leake Riley.

In most respects the decided reversal in October of this year's balance of merchandise trade against us, as shown last week. by the Commerce Department's report, represents merely return to the traditional position.
The German wholesale price index on Nov. 24 stood at 105.5, compared with 105.6 on Nov. 17. The cost-of-living index for November was 124.9, against 124.8 in October.

Joseph M. Schenck, chairman of the board of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation, has accepted the chairmanship for the southern part of California for the "fightinfantile-paralysis" campaign to be waged in connection with the celebration of President Roosevelt's birthday.

Today's 'major events: Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, at Carnegie Hall tonight, returning after a sabbatical absence; "La Boheme," opening second week of Metropolitan Opera season, and Ida Deck and Andrew Haigh, second pianist, at Town Hall in the afternoon.

Reginald Watkins, instructor at the Maryland Art Institute, who contends that Baltimore Art Museum juries select "outlandishly childish stuff," disclosed today a jury had picked for exhibition a water-color picture for a mill which his 10-yearold son did five years ago.

The Rev. David Wesley Soper, pastor of the Castle Heights Methodist Episcopal Church here, who recently announced a free taxi service to his church to increase his congregation, started another novelty this morning when he presented a living parable sermon entitled "The Church of America and the Wreckage in China."
The foreign exchange market continues quiet, with only slight fluctuations in all the foreign currency rates. All fears over the future of the franc, nevertheless, are far from being diminished.

Looking well and cheerful despite the tooth infection which compelled him to cut his Southern trip short, President Roosevelt debarked from his yacht Potomac today at Miami and headed northward for Washington.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia arrived here this evening, returning the visit Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano made to Belgrade last month and was received at the station by Premier Mussolini,

A block front in Harlem changed hands when the Graylor Holding Corporation representing Jerome H. Frank, operator, bought the fivestory hotel and six brick houses on the south side of West 123d Street, between Eighth and St. Nicholas Avenues.

A banking group headed by A. G. Becker Co., Inc., and including Shields Co. and F. S. Moseley Co. will offer today at $100 a share a new issue of 20,000 shares of Abbott Laboratories 4 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock of $100 par value.
John O'H. Anderson has been named assistant district sales manager at New York for the Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation.
The Hershey sextet had little trouble turning back the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 1, tonight in an Eastern Hockey League contest.
William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, made public today a complete outline of a Wagee and Hours Bill which would receive federation backing.
The National Rayon Weavers Association released for publication today results of a survey showing that in the week ended Nov. 27, loom activity was sharply under the year's peak.
A new pictorial magazine, Rising Tide, published by persons associated with the Oxford Group Movement, will appear on the newsstands in this country on Dec. 14.
Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, scored his first victory in the annual title tournament at the expense of S. S. Cohen yesterday. Cohen in turn won from J. Soudakoff.

A special assembly of East Islip High School pupils will be called tomorrow in an effort to identify the vandals who placed more than seventy bricks of ice cream on that number of desks in two class rooms last night.
Erich Lexer, eminent surgeon, died today at the age of 70. He conducted extensive experiments in human rejuvenation by gland transplantation which resulted negatively.

A decline in United States exports of tobacco and tobacco products, from a value of $111,879,234 in the first ten months of 1936 to $104,985,615 in the corresponding period of this year, has been announced by the tobacco division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.
A bill authorizing bullfighting in Cuba as an attraction for American tourists was approved by the Senate last night.
Miss Marjorie Ann Pinckney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Cotesworth Pinckney of this place, will be introduced to society at a tea to be given by her parents at their home here on Jan. 2.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Janet Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Rose of 7,201 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, to Arthur Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Levy of Long Beach. L. I.

In anticipation of the sale on Tuesday of a $10,000,000 issue of New York State bonds for grade-crossing elimination purposes, State Controller Morris S. Tremaine announced today the distribution of a condensed financial statement of the State's fiscal position as of Nov. 1.

Municipally operated parking garages built on the Ferris wheel principle are under close study by city traffic experts and will be proposed as a solution of the parking problem to the Mayor's Traffic Committee at its next meeting, it was learned yesterday.

Annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management with the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the Personnel Research Federation will begin today at 9:30 A. M. at Hotel New Yorker and Engineering Societies Building and continue all week.

Miss Dorothy Barnard will be married to Dr. Eben Kelly Jenkins of Boston, son of Mrs. Althia Jenkins of Cape Cod, the evening of Dec. 25 in the Congregational Church here, with the Rev. Don Ivan Patch, the pastor, officiating. Miss Barnard is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey P. Barnard of this place.

Bobby Pacho, welterweight boxer from Mexico, and Irish George Daly of Liverpool will furnish the action in the star bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight. Daly, in his last appearance at the St. Nick's, showed to good advantage, defeating Paul Junior.
An extraordinary pianistic talent was disclosed by Emile Baume, young French pianist, at his second New York recital given yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
More than 100 men and women, including representatives of the liquor industry, attended a dinner dance here tonight in celebration of the fourth anniversary of prohibition repeal.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the last three weeks:
The Montclair Athletic Club, defending champion, shut-out the Short Hills Club, 5--0, today, as Class B division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Dave (Sweeney) Schriner shot the New York Americans to within a point of the International Division leadership in the National Hockey League before 9,000 fans tonight, tallying two first-period goals for a 2-to-1 conquest of Detroit's champion Red Wings.
Golf "widows" played a tournament of their own today, but their husbands-all big-time professionals-didn't stay at home and knit.

" This Troubled World," a new book by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, has been announced by H C. Kinsey for publication on Jan. 3. In this book, Mrs. Roosevelt analyzes various peace plans, and presents her own ideas as to how peace can be brought about.
Max Schmeling and Harry Thomas, who will meet in a fifteenround bout at Madison Square Garden a week from tonight, went through their training paces vigorously at their respective camps yesterday.
Charles Ives, former Yale star, won the 100-yard free style event in the weekly A. A. U. swimming meet in the part Central pool Yesterday.

The cost of maintaining strict neutrality by the United States in time of a major war abroad will be much greater than is now realized by the general public, according to a survey by the Neutrality Committee of the National Economic and Social Planning Association, made public today.

Walter R. Hicks of 8,911 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, president of Daniel M. Hicks, Inc., 565 Fifth Avenue dealers in supplies for paper and textile mills, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn, of pneumonia following an operation. He was born in Brooklyn fifty-three years ago.

Chesapeake Bay dogs performed on land and water today, retrieving pheasants and ducks at the R. R. Spring Farm near here. In the puppy class, Barnagle Bill owned by John G. Alley of Easton, was first;

Memorial services for members of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks who died during the past year were held last night by New York Lodge 1 at its clubhouse, 799 Seventh Avenue. The services were attended by 300 members and friends, including friends and relatives of the eighty-six members who were honored. Joseph V. Burns, Exalted Ruler, presided.

Scoring in the last ninety seconds on two neatly executed passes that covered 80 yards, the'Fifty-second Coast Artillery of Fort Hancock, N. J., came from behind to defeat the Naval Receiving Station of Washington, 8 to 6, before 5,000 spectators today in a charity football game sponsored by the West Hoboken Post, 14, American Legion.

The New York World's Fair will apply zoning, successfully adopted by larger municipalities, to the exposition concessions in its as yet unnamed amusement area, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

The Rev. Samuel W. Stagg, veteran American clergyman, today bitterly assailed Commonwealth President Manuel Quezon as a dictator "drunk with power" and said the Philippines was "surely getting independence but losing its liberties."
A description of Patrolman George Gerken of the Irvington Police Department, who has been missing for five days, has been sent out over the eight-State teletype system by Police Chief Abraham Ruban.

Maintenance of the Jewish tradition is a requisite to maintenance of the prestige of the Jewish people in the modern world, Governor Lehman declared last night at the sixteenth annual Chanukkah dinner of the Jewish Education Association at the Hotel Astor.
State Department attaches refuted today many "maybe's" about Colonel Lindbergh's secret return from Europe.

In their statement endorsing the twenty-sixth annual appeal of THE TIMES for the Hundred Neediest Cases, the heads of the Federal, State and municipal relief agencies in this city explain why private aid must be invoked at a time when governmental agencies are still ministering to the wants of many people in distress.

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Stewart of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Daphne Jean Stewart, to Herbert Bell Urquhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Urquhart of Southport, England.
At least a "temporary cessation" of the upward movement in wage levels is indicated by the latest wage report of the National Industrial Conference Board, issued today.
A dispatch from the Shanghai front gives details of a race between two Japanese officers to see who will be the first to slay 100 Chinese with the Japanese sword.
Egbert Moxham Jr. and Leonard Romagna were the victors in Classes B and D in today's regatta of the Manhasset Bay dinghy fleet. Nineteen boats sailed in the two classes.

Mrs. Charles Herbert Jones will give a luncheon in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's on Dec. 23 for her daughter, Miss Mary G. Jones. Roy McWilliams, United States Vice Consul at Biarritz, France, and Mrs. McWilliams will arrive today on the Normandie, and will be at the St. Regis.

Otis Skinner, the actor, speaking yesterday afternoon at the annual memorial service of the Episcopal Actors Guild at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftyfirst Street, said that he could not "imagine a truly gifted play-actor without a religion of some sort."

Chesapeake Bay Retrlever-Relew Kennels' Ch. Airline Theresa. German Short-Haired Pointer-Clifford A. Nagle's Carl Rellerhau of Middlesex. Labrador Retriever-Eugene D. Brennan's Cleo II. English Setter-Mr. and Mrs. A. Biddle Duke's Bayldone Buccaneer of Prune's Own. Gordon Setter-Edward R. Koch's Duke Inglehurst.

Dartmouth's undefeated gridiron forces and the once-beaten team of Yale each placed three players on the all-Ivy League team which will be released simultaneously tomorrow morning in the undergraduate newspapers of the seven Ivy League colleges.

Because plans fixed for the stipulated airplanes are still beyond the builder's art, the Postoffice Department has been unable to get bids for two proposed air routes and has changed the aircraft specifications.

The Philippines' latest typhoon moved slowly but with great force across the Visayan Sea today, sweeping over Romblon and Masbate and toward the southern part of Luzon Island, about 150 miles south of Manila.

An Investigation of all the city colleges by a committee of five members of the Board of Higher Education, designed to remove "existing irritations" from the municipal college system, Was begun in the four city colleges on Friday, it was disclosed yesterday.

I do not know whether any particular President, politician, labor leader or member of a regulating authority for minding other people's business has ever studied political economy in high school or college.

More than 400 custodial employes of the public-school system voted last night at a meeting at Public School 27, Third Avenue and Fortysecond Street, to affiliate with the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate.
Fleets of Government bombing planes were reported today to have succeeded in breaking up Insurgent troop concentrations by repeated raids on the Aragon front in Northeast Spain.

New York's birth and death rates moved nearer to each other in October, the birth rate dropping to an all-time low for the month, while the death rate rose fractionally, as compared to October, 1936, the State Health Department reported today.

It is reported here that some New York importers of Seville green olives have placed important contracts with Seville exporters, thus accepting the basic prices fixed by the Insurgents' Export Council, formed to protect economy in their area.
The memory of Joyce Kilmer, soldier-poet who was killed in France nearly twenty years ago, was honored yesterday on the fiftyfourth anniversary of his birth by a series of events in Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Power Trench of 308 East Seventy-ninth Street have announced the engagement of Mrs. Trench's daughter, Miss Mona Law Fotterall Trench, to Robert Hamilton Murray, son of Joseph Norris Murray of this city and Quogue, L. I.

The Christmas sale of articles made by instructors, semi-professional members and students of the Craft Students League of the Y. W. C. A. at 745 Tenth Avenue will be opened this afternoon with a tea, and will be continued through Dec. 18. Tea will be served on Tuesdays and Thursdays for the duration of the sale.

The squad that will seek to main- Goali tain the supremacy of Dartmouth in intercollegiate skiing against Washington's Pacific Coast Conference champions at Sun Valley, Idaho, on Dec. 31 and Jan. 1 was announced yesterday by Coach Walter Prager.

A syndicate represented by Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney, bought the four-story apartment house at 8,687 Bay Parkway, southeast corner of Benson Avenue, Brooklyn, for cash over a first mortgage of $42,000 held by a savings bank. Ernest A.

The Rev. Isaac Lane, Negro educational leader, founder of Lane College and oldest Bishop in the world, who had been in the ministry for seventy-one years, died here this afternoon at the age of 103. He had been ill for ten days following a stroke.

Miss Charlotte Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel A. Richards of Maplewood, will be married the afternoon of Dec. 24 to Kenneth B. Gair, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. B. Gair of Dorchester, Mass. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. J. Spencer Voorhees of Maplewood, who officiated at the wedding of the bride-elect's parents and her sister, Mrs. H. S. Gardner Jr. of Bangor, Me.
A British gunboat and two British merchantmen were struck by bombs in a Japanese air raid on Wuhu, above Nanking, yesterday. All three vessels plainly displayed British colors.
Nation wide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 30 per cent of capacity, down only 1 point in the week, but less than threeeighths of the rate at the end of August.

Business deserves a large share of the credit for the great progress made by public education in New York City in the last forty years, since the consolidation of Greater New York, according to a report by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, published yesterday in the Reveal-New York-toNew Yorkers program conducted by the Merchants Association in connection with its fortieth anniversary.

In order to centralize under one organization the supervision and control of the activities of all insurance companies in Peru, the government has issued a decree transferring their inspection to the office of the Superintendence of Banks.

ALLER--At Mount Vernon, N. Y., on Dec. 4, 1937. Sarah Jones, wife of the late Stephen B. Aller. Funeral service at the home of her daughter, Mrs. harold E. Squire, 5 Urban St., Monday afternoon 2 o'clock.

Miss Elizabeth McCain, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Ross McCain, and Miss Judith Russell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Russell, were introduced to society last night at a dance given by their parents at the Hartford Golf Club. A dinner for the debutantes and out-of-town guests preceded the dance.

Declaring that the Republican party is in "a nearly complete state of demoralization," Governor George D. Aiken tonight called upon its national committee to "purge" itself of reactionary and unfair elements.

The Newark Tornadoes and the White Plains Bears battled to a 3-all tie at Newark Schools' Stadium today in a play-off game intended to decide the American Professional Football Association championship. A crowd of 8,000 witnessed the contest.

Mrs. Hilde Taubert, 45 years old, a teacher in the public schools, ended her life last night by jumping from the bedroom of her six-room apartment on the eleventh floor of 520 West 110th Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue.

Miss Helen F. Newton of this city was married to Siegfried Weiss of Norfolk, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Weiss of Clinton, yesterday afternoon in the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Professor and Mrs. Howard D. Newton of Storrs. The Rev. J. Garland Waggoner of Storrs performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception.

A library of books on tuberculosis, named after Dr. Luther Fiske Warren, prominent Brooklyn physician, who died last January, was dedicated yesterday in the Brooklyn Home for Consumptives, 240 Kingston Avenue, after special memorial services in the institution's chapel.

Gustave Verbeck of 125 Sherman Avenue, an artist whose cartoons were published in the old New York Herald for eleven years, died yesterday in the Home for Incurables, Third Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx, where he had been a patient for two months. He had been ill for two years.

Giles W. Mead, one of the three founders of the Union Carbide and Carbon Company, died late yesterday of coronary thrombosis, with which he was stricken earlier in the day at his Beverly Hills estate. His age was 71.

Mrs. John H. Finley and Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge head the general committee for the annual Christmas bazaar of the Near East industries which opens this afternoon at the headquarters of the Near East Foundation, 2 West Forty-sixth Street, and will continue there throughout the week.

Indications are that the decline in steel production is close to the bottom, and while there is no expectation of an immediate upward movement, general sentiment is that whatever important change comes will be favorable, according to the magazine Steel.
Song characterizations in costume were offered by Bernice Kamsler, American disease, at the Guild Theatre last night, and were well received by a sizable audience.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Jeanette Bruck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Bruck of Kew Gardens, Queens, to Leonard G. Robinson Jr., son of Mrs. William J. Shore of New York and of Leonard G. Robinson of Washington.

The National Ski Association lined up with the International Olympic Ski Games Committee in opposition to its governing body, the International Ski Federation, today, adopting a resolution asking the federation to reconsider its ruling against participation in the coming Olympics unless ski teachers are recognized as amateurs.

From sentiments privately expressed by the French delegation there is reason to believe that Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos will return home greatly reassured by what he has learned regarding the internal political situation in Poland.

Speeding homeward through a blinding snowstorm after its scoreless tie with Tulsa University, Manhattan's football team today elected as its 1938 leader Alfred John Caruso, quarterback and field general of the Jasper eleven for the last two years.

Communism and fascism both fail in their quest for equality because they emphasize only economic factors, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University, Washington, D. C., said in his sermon yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament, Seventy-first Street near BroadwaY.

Christians who assume attitudes of pity and condescension toward the poor may expect to be met with turned backs, declared the Very Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving, dean of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, L. I., in a sermon in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

A delegation representing the National Council of the American Youth Congress, which held an emergency session here today, called on Aubrey Williams, Deputy WPA Administrator, to request expenditure of the maximum Congressional allowance of $75,000,000 as a means of offsetting the effects on youth of the current recession in business.
CAMPION, JOHN J. (Oct. 27). Estate, more than $10.000. To Elizabeth Campion, widow. Roundhill Road, Greenwich, Conn., residue. Guaranty Trust Co. of New York. 140 Broadway. executor.

A promotion scheme started by Harper's Bazaar to call attention to a special Paris issue in the Spring took an unexpected turn yesterday to confound the sponsors. The new angle, inadvertently embodied in the scheme, involves a missing pigeon with a tube containing a diamond attached to its leg.
Tear gas was used briefly by police at the Ford plant here late today to disperse a demonstration by several hundred men across a street from the plant as employes finished the day's work.

Nine diamond rings, valued at $1,800, were scattered through Foley Square yesterday noon by a thief fleeing before the shots of a store manager who pursued him. When the man was caught three rings worth $1,200 were found in an overcoat pocket.

Governor Charles Martin criticized "a few high-salaried labor leaders" and charged the National Labor Relations Board with "running ou on a critical situation" tonight in announcing that he would conduct plant elections to end a C. I. O.A. F. L. jurisdictional dispute which has closed Portland sawmills for 117 days.

New marks for team and league forward passing and total scoring were established in the National Football League, according to final statistics released yesterday. Only two of the five 1936 leaders retained their laurels.

The directors of the Maryland Jockey Club today decided to schedule seven additional stake events for the meeting next Spring as well as to spend more than $300,000 in the most extensive program of improvement planned for the Pimlico track since the Civil War.

Ten police officers applied to Police Commissioner Valentine for retirement yesterday. With a single exception, the men, who include a deputy inspector, four 'captains and five lieutenants, have passed the 63year age limit recently established by the commissioner.
A campaign to raise funds to organize a radio orchestra and choral group of blind musicians was opened yesterday at a meeting of the National Bureau for Blind Artists at the Hotel Astor.

Points on the Panama-Colombia boundary on which the joint Boundary Commission was unable to agree have been settled by an exchange of notes between the Colombian Minister, Hector Jose Vargas, and Foreign Secretary Jose Lefevre, according to a statement made by the Foreign Office today.

Several renewals of leases on large quarters featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. At 245 Fifth Avenue, the J. J. Newberry Company, chain store operators, again leased two and one-half floors and made arrangements for the leasing of another half-floor. Adams and Company, Inc., was the broker.

An exhibition of prints, commemorating the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Alphonse Legros, has opened in Room 316 at the New York Public Library. It was arranged by Frank Weitenkampf, director of the library's print department, and will be current through this month and January (closed Sundays).
Annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers begins at the Waldorf-Astoria at 10 o'clock this morning and continues Wednesday and Thursday.
Terms of the Treasury's new security offering were, on the whole, in line with expectations and, if anything, proved to be more generous than many had expected.
