Paul Codos, French airman, landed at this West African port today after crossing the South Atlantic from Natal, Brazil.

Contracts on textile supplies for the army were awarded at the local Quartermaster Depot today as follows: Invitation 112, for the manufacture from government materials of 27,218 roll collar woolen overcoats, went to the National Sheeplining Clothing Company at $1.7384 each, less one-fourth 1 per cent 20 days, accepting government materials F. 0. B., Philadelphia.

Leading life insurance companies in this State are expected to follow the lead of the New York Life Insurance Company in reducing from 6 per cent to 5 per cent the interest rate for loans and new life insurance policies to be made available after Jan. 1. There were hints in financial circles yesterday that even a further cut might be announced later by some companies.

A twophase campaign to combat increasing unemployment will be announced by John L. Lewis tomorrow in the first issue of "The C. I. O. News," a new paper started by the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Federal competition in the Tennessee Basin through the Tennessee Valley Authority in the electric industry, has "dried up" funds which otherwise would be available to private utility corporations to carry on their normal operations, Francis E. Frothingham, Boston investment banker, testified in Federal court here today.
The Columbia Grammar School basketball team, led by Gene Wallach, defeated the Collegiate School five, 23 to 18, yesterday on the latter's court.
Miss Florence Griswold, "patron saint" of the artist colony here, died today in the home on Main Street in which she was born eighty-six years ago. No members of her immediate family survive.

60th St, 35 E, 19.11x100.5; Bessie M. Cooley, as exec. Paul F. Cooley, who was the exr o?? Wm Cowen, to Jewish Theological Seminary of America. B'way and 122d St. 14th St, 437 E, 25x103.4; Elvira Maggi to Rose Maggi. 2.105 Quentin Rd, Bklyn, N Y, mtg $15.500. Nathan Davis Place, 33, 26.6x100; Pauline O. Stern to Alfred Abbott, 9 W 123d St, $14.800 ($17).

The Ways and Means subcommittee on taxation tentatively agreed today on a change in the law designed to reduce countless controversies with the Treasury Department on the question of deducting losses.

The adjutant general released the following orders today: Buskirk, 1st Lt. Arthur H.. having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to the commanding officer, 106th Infantry, for assignment to Company F.
Bitterness of elderly "Brass Hats" over the recent shake-up in the army council flared up publicly for the first time in the House of Commons today.

Charles D. Axman, banker and merchant, died yesterday at his apartment in the Park Central Hotel. He was 87 years old. Until about six months ago, until ill health forced him to retire, Mr. Axman was associated with Ladenburg, Thalmann Co.,

A proposal to give athletic directors equal voting power with faculty representatives may inject much debating into the proceedings when the Southeastern Conference goes into annual session this week.

Two large Park Avenue apartments will be offered at auction today in the Vesey Street salesrooms. One is the fifteen-story multi-family dwelling at 1,185 Park Avenue, comprising the block front on the east side of the avenue between Ninety-third and Ninety-fourth Streets.
Mrs. Suzanne Silvercruys Farnham of New York, sculptress and author, was injured near here today when her automobile, which she was driving, skidded on icy pavement and struck a large rock.

Fear of arrest because her dog had bitten a child last Saturday was believed yesterday to have been responsible for the death of Miss Margaret Quigley, 45 years old, a servant living in a furnished room at 708 Halsey Street. Brooklyn.

Within three weeks a large scale police drive against parking in the congested zone of Manhattan will be launched to clear the streets of the 15,762 parked vehicles that now clog traffic every day in the area bounded by Fourteenth and Fiftysixth Streets between Second and Eighth Avenues.

The League of Nations Economic Committee began its forty-seventh session today by deciding to draft a declaration of policy on raw materials to which both producer and purchaser countries might subscribe.
The 400 winning amateur snapshots of the recently completed 1937 Newspaper National Snapshot Awards were placed on exhibition yesterday for thirteen days at 610 Fifth Avenue.

BARRY, MARY E. (June 15). Gross assets $25,750, net $24,041. To Catholic Foreign Mission Society America, Inc. and the Marquette League, $1,140 each; Servants for Relief for Incurablee Cancer, $570; four other charitable bequests: Cornelius Roach, household effects, $150 and residue; twelve specific bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and Insurance, $21,225. McDonough Moore,

An assurance that the traditional friendship between the peoples of Brazil and the United States has not been impaired by misinterpretations that have been placed on the recent coup d'etat of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil when he established a "corporate" State was given by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, in an address tonight before the Inter-American Center of George Washington University here.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, and the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance sent to Governor Lehman yesterday their approval of an amendment to the State Unemployment Law to bring within its provisions persons earning more than $3,000 annually.

President Roosevelt, returning here at 4:15 o'clock this afternoon from his shortened fishing cruise, went straight from the train to the dentist's chair, where he was assured that the infection on the left side of his jaw, which resulted from an abscessed tooth, was much improved.

The Munitions Control Board in its monthly report today on the export of arms, ammunition and implements of war disclosed that most of the licenses issued for these purposes during November were granted to countries involved or directly concerned In the Far Eastern conflict.

Miss Jean Seagrove, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Day Seagrove of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Carl Nicholas Dunn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl N. Dunn of Wilmington and Fayetteville, N. C., which will take place on Jan. 1 in the Reformed Church here. The Rev. John Henderson Powell Jr., the pastor, will perform the ceremony. A reception will be given at the Seagrove home here.
A Federal investigation into the activities of former New York County Clerk Albert Marinelli in the Charles Falci matter opened yesterday.

The pound sterling yesterday rose to the highest level in its relation to the dollar since Nov. 24 in quiet trading in the foreign exchange market. Touching a high of $5.007-16, sterling closed at $5.00%, up 1 1/3 cents on the day.

Republicans in Congress gave their approval generally today to the letter of Governor Aiken of Vermont, who demanded reorganization of the Republican party, a reduction in Southern representatives in the national conventions, and a constructive platform, including a ninepoint affirmative program for social aims.

Miss Mary Learned Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Everett Hall of Plainfield, N. J., has completed plans for her marriage to George Davol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bradford Davol of Brookline, Mass., which will take place Dec. 22 in the Church of Our Saviour in Brookline.

Congressional leaders declared today that if the membership remains as economy-minded as it seems at present, there is a strong probability that appropriation bills reduced in line with the indicated 193839 budget recommendations will go through with little trouble.

King Leopold of the Belgians, suffering from a cold, remained in the seclusion of Welbeck Abbey today while Lady Anne Cavendish-Bentinck, with whom his name was linked romantically, drove through a snowstorm to open the Christmas shopping week at Worksop.

The small business man has never before had as much protection from the law as he has today and should take full advantage of this favorable position to get a greater share of the available trade, Henry Ward Beer, president of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, declared tonight in an address before the Men's Club of Mt. Sinai.

Hundreds of blasphemous cartoons, books, newspapers, magazines, pamphlets and similar material are included in an "AntiGod" exhibit which was opened last night at the Center Association, an organization of 1,000 Catholic college graduates. at its headquarters. 120 Central Park South.
Bobby Pacho, 147 1/2, durable Mexican welterweight, easily outpointed Georgie Daley, 144 1/2, of London in the feature ten-round bout before 2,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.
Every WPA security wage worker will have an opportunity to earn as much Christmas money as possible, under an order issued by Aubrey Williams, Deputy Administrator.

The former Spahn house on Great Oak Lane, Pleasantville, Westchester County, has been sold by the Hudson Harlem Valley Title Company of White Plains to Abraham H. Stroke. Harry Jaffy was the broker in the deal.

Supreme Court Justice John MacCrate of Brooklyn granted an order yesterday directing the Board of Elections of Brooklyn to show cause today in Brooklyn Supreme Court why there should not be an examination of votes cast for Peter Cacchione, Communist party candidate for City Council in Brooklyn.
The House Labor Committee set out today to rewrite its Wages-Hours Bill to include provisions that it be administered by the Labor Department instead of a five-man board.

Directors of the Republic Steel Corporation yesterday announced a dividend of $13,50 a share on the 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock. Of this amount, $1.50 is for the current quarter and the additional $12 is against arrears, leaving a balance of $13.50 still owing on accumulations.

Crop news from Argentina dominated the action of the wheat market today and prices at the extreme showed an advance of 2 1/2 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish, with the December selling at a new high level since late in October.
Senator Capper, Kansas Republican, proposed today "uniform regulation of marriage and divorce" through a constitutional amendment that would give to Congress this power.

Decision of the majority of the country's wide cotton printcloth mills over the week-end to curtail production approximately 25 per cent for an indefinite period, amounting to at least ninety days, brought a certain degree of encouragement to the local market yesterday.

The world's airplane speed record was beaten yesterday by Engineer Furio Niclot, who attained 344.46 miles an hour. The machine used, which forms part of the standard equipment of the Italian Air Force,
Both AngloAmerican evacuation hospitals in Tarancon were destroyed in Saturday's Rebel bombing, it was learned today.
Jersey ity, where thirteen C. I. O organizers were arrested a week ago today, was the scene of two labor disturbances tonight.

Denying reports of friction and dissatisfaction among studio executives, Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, today issued a statement in which he announced that Louis B. Mayer had signed a new five-year contract as head of production.

Mrs. Florette Guggenheim. widow of Benjamin Guggenheim, who perished on the Titanic, left her residuary estate in trust for her two daughters, it was learned yesterday when her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. Mrs. Guggenheim died on Nov. 15 last. The value of her estate was not disclosed.

THE matter of deciding who said it is one to try the soul of any conscientious adult. At breakfast, for example, the 12-year-old daughter insists upon Knowing why she may not call her younger brother a fool when, as anybody ought to be able to see, he is one. Daddy,

J. B. Williams Company has issued fair-trade contracts covering the retail sale of all Williams shaving soaps, toilet soaps and toilet articles to retailers in the forty-two States having fair-trade laws, William E. Neagle, sales manager, announced yesterday.

There was a time--and in the mechanized era of tomorrow the poets will sing of it with longing tunes--when dingy little steamers shouldered their way up the Hudson against the murky tides, deep-laden beyond their Plimsoll marks with splendid cargoes of the common and the rare.

Maurice Evans, Shakespearean actor, defied superstition today and tried on a pair of gloves worn by William Shakespeare. Dating to about 1590, they are part of the Horace Howard Furneys Memorial Collection at the University of Pennsylvania Library.

Hartley W. Barclay, editor of the magazine Mill and Factory, did not appear today to answer a National Labor Relations Board subpoena ordering him to submit records at a hearing into charges that the Weirton Steel Company violated the Wagner Labor Relations Act.

The longer Congress debates the new farm bill, the clearer it becomes that nobody knows what its probable cost will be. Nobody knows, because both the House and the Senate versions promise to involve the Government in speculative operations whose outcome cannot be foreseen.
Finland today celebrated the twentieth anniversary of her proclamation of political independence. A national holiday was observed with divine services and many public meetings and military parades.

Strange as it seems, the abolishment of the center tap, which had been opposed so vigorously by Eastern basketball coaches, is now being hailed as a real improvement in this year's changes in the rules. Nat Holman, coach of C. C. N. Y. who had long advocated this change, was particularly elated at elimination of the jump.

In the first test of Congressional sentiment on compulsory crop control phases of the pending farm legislation, the House today voted preference for the present voluntary method by striking out provisions for marketing quotas and penalty taxes designed to check the accumulation of large surpluses.
The Foreign Ministers of France and Poland, Yvon Delbos and Colonel Josef Beck, issued a joint communique tonight reaffirming the Franco-Polish alliance.

The Bureau or Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 3: CAPTAINS Washburn. E. D. Jr., Evanston, Ill., to command the California. Biello, J. A., Med. Corps, Battle Force. to the staff of the Commander in Chief Fleet, as Fleet Medical Officer.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, last night denied reports that he was retiring from the commission at the end of this week. He did indicate, however, that he would leave the commission about the know first of the year.

Catcher Gilly Campbell was sold today by the Cincinnati Reds to Montreal of the International League. Campbell was the property of the Reds for four years and played part of the 1937 season with Syracuse.

Benjamin Bosworth, a collector for the Marshall Mortgage Company, 26 Court Street, Brooklyn; swas robbed of $3,000 in cash and $1,000 in checks yesterday, by three men whose automobile pulled alongside his and forced it to the curb In Bond Street, near Butler Street, Brooklyn.

Yehudi Menuhin returned last night, after a year's absence from the concert platform, to play in Carnegie Hall. He enjoyed an unequivocal triumph, with all the incidents of a success before an audience which packed the house and overflowed onto the stage.
The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today a six-State petition to dismiss further consideration of a request by railroads for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates.

Oberlin M. Carter of Chicago, 81, former army captain, lost in the Supreme Court today an effort to have set aside a court-martial verdict under which he was dismissed from the army nearly forty years ago.

Dr. Edwin Linton, research fellow in zoology at the University of Pennsylvania and a pioneer in the study of worm parasites of American marine fishes, was announced today as this year's recipient of the Leidy medal, presented every third year by the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia.
Death Announced Retired Fireman John A. Condren. formerly a member of H. L. 28. residing at 51 W. 157th St., Manhattan, died Nov. 29.

City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr., who has advocated abolition of his post since he assumed it in 1934, gave his formal resignation to Mayor La Guardia yesterday following the Mayor's declaration that Almerindo Portfolio would be the new City Treasurer after the first of the year.

It is understood on the most reliable authority that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek will soon go into retirement, while Foreign Minister Wang Ching-hui and General Chang Chun, former Foreign Minister, probably will head a reorganized government with the onerous task of negotiating the best peace terms obtainable.

Mrs. Mae Bainton, 43 years old, of 31-13 Steinway Street, Astoria, Queens, mother of three children, who resigned last week as a Deputy Sheriff in Queens County, was sworn in yesterday as a deputy United States Marshal for the Eastern District of New York at a salary of $1,620 a year.

Being a trouper, and a courageous trouper at that, Fred La Reine, lying in his bed at the French Hospital here, did not think he had done anything remarkable when doctors confirmed yesterday that he had scorned an anesthetic and had played the harmonica while they amputated his leg.

Subsoription books for the Treasury's current offering of $250,000,000 of eight year 2 1/2 per cent bonds and $200.000,000 of five year 13/4 per cent Treasury notes were closed at the close of business tonight with the bond issue oversubscribed fifteen times and the notes eleven times, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference late this afternoon.

Francis Campbell Boileau Cadell, one of the best known of Scottish modern painters, died in Edinburgh today at the age of 54. Throughout his career his name was associated with the "Fauves," a group of exhibitors led by Matisse which had a special room at the Paris Autumn salon in 1905-so-called because of the ferocity of their reaction from the aftermath of impressionism.

The work of the Palestine Society for the Hard of Hearing was outlined here yesterday by Mrs. Miriam Schaar Schloessinger, its founder, who with her husband, Dr. Max Schloessinger, will return to the Near East on the Exochorda today after a visit of a few months.

A Federal judge ordered today Herbert Fleishhacker and the Anglo California National Bank to account for alleged "secret profits" resulting from a steel deal in 1919 with Barde Brothers of Portland, Ore., and to repay the profits to a receiver for distribution to stockholders.

Mrs. Sarah Jameson Blythe Hyman, wife of Herbert R. Hyman, production manager for the Conde Nast publications, died yesterday at her home, 325 East Fifty-seventh Street, in her fifty-first year. She was born in East Liverpool, Ohio,

Mr. and Mrs. Ailing Prudden Beardsley of this city have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Blackstone Beardsley, to Buckley Crist, of Bound Brook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harris M. Crist of New York and Vineyard Haven, Mass., which will take place Dec. 22 in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.

W. Krivitzsky, a member of the Russian Communist party, long associated with the Red Army and more recently head of the War Industries Institute in Moscow, is the second Soviet leader within a week to claim French protection.

The third portion of the famous Clumber library collection of historic manuscripts brought [Pound]8,797 at Sotheby's today. Most of the library was acquired in 1833 by the Fourth Duke of Newcastle when he purchased the estate, including lands, pictures and books, for [Pound]70,000.

The Supreme Court in two five-to-four decisions headed in a direction today which revenue experts said might modify the long established rule under which a State Government has been barred from taxing an instrumentality of the Federal Government and vice versa.

Peddic School tonight honored its football team at a dinner in the social room. Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, toastmaster, introduced the speakers, presenting Walter C. Black, '86, treasurer of the board of corporators; James W. Eben, '21, and Samuel M. Parslow Jr., '27, donor of the John D. Plant Cup awarded annually to the outstanding graduate in college athletics.

Rear Admiral Cary T. Grayson, retired, chairman of the American Red Cross, was appointed today chairman of the United States delegation to the sixteenth International Red Cross Conference in London, June 20-24.

Senator George L. Berry and a TVA attorney snarled charges at each other today in the opening of condemnation hearings to determine the value of mineral rights in land now covered by the water of Norris Lake.
Carrying out a "mandate" adopted last September at its annual convention in Buffalo, the Veterans of Foreign Wars have started a campaign to

Representatives of the banking group headed by the Atlas Corporation and Lehman Brothers, who hold options to buy the remainder of Radio Corporation of America holdings in the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, have been negotiating with R. C. A. for an extension of the options, it was learned yesterday.

The contract for the sale of the United States liner Leviathan to British interests for about $800,000 was forwarded yesterday to the Maritime Commission for approval, and formal action is expected within forty-eight hours, according to officials of the lines.

A new advisory dental health service will be organized in New York City shortly, Health Commissioner John L. Rice told more than 1,000 persons last night at the first general session of the annual Greater New York Dental Meeting, in convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Grace Donohue, Inc., 640 Madison Avenue, New York, has stipulated to discontinue certain advertising representations in connection with the sale of Seba Gland Cleanser and other products, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

Flying detachments of China's former Communist armies were reported reliably tonight to be organizing a guerrilla army of 100,000 for largescale sabotage operations against the Japanese in North China.

Officials of Kansas City, have invited bankers to submit bids on Dec. 21 for a new issue of $500,000 of school-district bonds to be dated Jan. 1, 1938, and to mature serially on Jan. 1, 1949 to 1958. idders have been asked to name a rate of interest of 2 1/2, 2 3/4 or 3 per cent.
The Gloucester Master Mariners Association today voted unanimously in favor of renewal of the international fishermen's races next Summer.
The Browning King Corporation, retailers of men's clothing, obtained a judgment for $1,108 in Nassau County Supreme Court here today against the volunteer fire department of Long Beach.

Tribute to the memory of Lieutenant Norman Prince of the Lafayette Escadrille was paid today at his tomb and monument in the Washington Cathedral by General John J. Pershing and by Major Gen. Adelbert de Chambrun, representing the French Army in which the American aviator volunteered in March, 1915.

Dr. Wilberforce Eames, for more than forty years connected with the New York Public Library, died yesterday in the Kane Pavilion at the Home for the Incurables, Third Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx. He was 82 years old.

Reduction of English county cricket championship teams from seventeen to fifteen was recommended today by a commission appointed by the Marylebone Cricket Club, ruling body of the sport, to investigate problems confronting first-class counties.

The Lord's Day Alliance will mark its fiftieth anniversary next year by seeking a fund of $250,000 and embarking on Jan. 1 on a five-year program of "war on the commercialized Sunday wherever found," it was decided yesterday at the annual meeting here.

A net profit of $2,369,967 (Canadian currency) was reported yesterday by the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and all subsidiaries for the quarter ended Oct. 31, after depreciation, interest, income and profite taxes. After dividend requirements on the 5 per cen., preferred stock, the profit equaled $1.25 a share on 1,742,645 shares of capital stock.

Trading was fair to slow on most classes of locally dressed meats yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to lower, calf cuts were lower and lamb cuts steady to sharply lower. The lamb market was fully 50c-$1 lower; other classes showed little change. Kosher markets opened weak to lower, as reported by the United States Deapartment of Agriculture.

Offering will be made to the public today by Leach Brothers, Inc., by means of a prospectus, of 156,000 shares of capital stock of Ohio Sheet and Tin. Plate Corporation. The stock will be priced at $3.75 a share.
President Roosevelt returned from his Florida fishing trip and immediately received treatment for his infected jaw. He was welcomed by a delegation of officials, but held no conferences.
James Caras, former world's pocket billiard champion, defeated Ralph Greenleaf, present titleholder, in the first two blocks of their twelve-block exhibition contest at the Strand Academy yesterday.

Detectives of the Bathgate Avenue station in the Bronx were searching yesterday for a hit-andrun trolley car. During the heavy rain at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning at 175th Street a northbound Webster Avenue trolley car jolted the rear of a wagon being driven to the Bronx Terminal Market by Samuel Sandach, 8 West 181st Street.
Proceedings were started today to make the young son of Princess von Starhemberg the legal heir of the Prince, to whom she was married last Thursday.
Bishop Elias Cottrell of the Colored Methodist Episcopal Church, a leading Negro educator, died at his home here last night. He was 84 years old.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 4: MAJORS Hamlin, W. S. (Capt.). Air Corps. Ft. Sam Houston. Texas, to Chanute Field, Rantoul, III.

Arthur Fried, 32-year-old manager of one of Generoso Pope's sand and gravel companies, has been missing from his home in White Plains since Saturday night, it became known yesterday as Westchester County detectives and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation investigated reports that he had been kidnapped and was being held for $200,000 ransom.
The sun rose and set yesterday without being seen clearly at any time in the city. As a result lights were turned on in most office buildwings to counteract the semblance of an Arctic night.

The League of Nations Health Organization has recruited three sanitary teams under "epidemic commissioners" to help China fight the epidemic danger in the war, in accordance with the appropriation by the September League Assembly of 2,000,000 Swiss francs for this purpose.

The hostilities along a five-mile front created by the spearhead of the Japanese advance on Nanking, where two tattered and sleepless Cantonese divisions were attempting desperately to hold up the invaders' drive, were viewed at close range by this correspondent yesterday.

Documentary material in support of the charge that the anti-union policy of Mayor Frank Hague in Jersey City represents a violation of civil rights is being sent to Senator Robert La Follette, chairman of the Senate Civil Liberties Committee, Morris L. Ernst, an attorney for the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced yesterday.
Otto Englebrecht, 24 years old, a baker's helper with a $25 weekly job, was going hungry trying to meet $40-a-month installments on his car, on which he had already paid $800.

Lamentations over the plight of the Republican party are about as useful as putting on mourning for Hecuba. Proposals for a Republican national platform either glitter with generalities or show too close a cousinship with the New Deal to befit an opposition party.
Additional export of $5,000,000 in gold to France reduced the Treasury's inactive gold fund today to $1,237,555,020.

M. and Mine. Jacques Heim, Paris couturiers, who are making their first visit to America, will be guests of honor at a luncheon today at the Hotel Pierre. More than 100 leading merchants, store executives and fashion editors have accepted invitations to attend.
Seven students and a laboratory assistant in a Columbia University chemistry class suffered acid burns yesterday afternoon in the accidental explosion of an open bottle of cleaning fluid.

An atmosphere of uncertainty and indecision characterized slower trading yesterday in listed bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. As reflected by the various group price averages, values in the main worked irregularly lower, although there were numerous instances of marked improvement in selected railroad and industrial loans.

Election to Phi Beta Kappa, the highest undergraduate scholarship honor open to Yale students, has been won for the current year by forty-one, including twenty-seven members of the class of '38 and fourteen of the class of '39, who were initiated tonight into the Yale chapter, which celebrated the 175th anniversary of its founding.

Great Britain today protested to Japanese naval authorities against the aerial bombing of two British merchant ships and damage to a British gunboat at Wuhu. The protest was lodged formally by Vice Admiral Sir Charles Little, commander of Britain's Far Eastern naval forces.

A substantial increase in the number of police assigned to the New York County District Attorney's office is expected to be requested by Thomas E. Dewey when he takes office on the first of the year, it was learned yesterday.

Turpentine firm, 26 1/4 cents; sales, 129 barrels: recelpte, 705 barrels; shipments, 196 barrels; stock, 37,992 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 1,014; receipts, 2,299; shipments. 1.402; stock, 82,808. Quote: B. D. E. $4.75; F. $5.25; G, $5.30; H, $5.35; I, $5.40; K. $5.55; M. $5.85; N, $5.95; WG, $6.55; WW, X, $6.90.
The Maritime Commission denied today the application of the Baltimore Mail Steamship Company for a permanent operating-differential subsidy contract.

Ida Deck and Andrew Haigh appeared in a program of music for two pianos at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The concert began with three Bach chorale preludes: "Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme," "Ertoedt' uns surch dein Guete" and "In dir ist Freude."

After a ballot taken behind' closed doors gave Oscar R. Wilensky of Passaic County 31 votes to 9 for Frank C. Osmers Jr. of Bergen, the former was elected unanimously at an open Republican caucus at the State House today as majority floor leader of the 1938 Assembly.

The Japanese vanguard, four miles outside Nanking, saw the city covered with black smoke last evening. This morning defending troops were reported. hurriedly crossing the Yangtze River under pretext of consolidating defenses on the north bank. The signs suggest that the city is being abandoned, but fearing traps, the Japanese are exercising caution and no movement has been reported since last evening.

The developments of the last two years in chemical engineering skill were placed on view yesterday at the Grand Central Palace as the sixteenth Exposition of Chemical Industries opened to the prize slogan of "Chemical Research Creates Industries."

Judge Winfred H. Whiting, Superior Court justice for fifteen years, died early today at his home at the age of 57. He was appointed an associate justice of the First Worcester District Court in 1910 and was elevated to the Superior Court by Governor Cox in 1922.
Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia had long conferences today, first with Foreign Minister Count Galeazzo Ciano alone and then with Premier Benito Mussolini and Count Ciano together.
Building projects estimated to cost a total of $3,350,000 were filed in the Bronx yesterday. They consist of eight eight-story apartment buildings and one of six stories.

It is fifty-five years since the laws governing the City of New York were last codified. In consequence, the contrast between our Code of Laws and our new city charter is more or less like that between an oxcart and the latest high-powered truck.
The Committee for Industrial Organization was variously denounced in a succession of addresses at the annual meeting of the National Industrial Council in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday.

Gifts totaling $12,080.62 swelled the total of the 1937 Neediest Cases Fund to $44,000.70 yesterday as 140 contributors befriended the ill, the destitute, the orphaned children, the trembling old folk and the other worthy sufferers among the Neediest.

Business in the stock market here was small today, but most sections improved. Among the gilt-edge and transatlantic securities there was some weakness. United States Steel fell, but International Nickel strengthened.

S. N. Harrison, publisher of The Bellingham Evening News, and George Hipkoe, president of the Bellingham Newspaper Guild unit, announced a settlement ending picketing which delayed publication several hours today.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended December : Decrease of $46,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $5,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities, $8,000,000 in "other securities," $53,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $39,000,000 in time deposits; and an increase of $44,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.
Henry T. Fleitmann, 50 years old, a stock broker of 187 East Sixtyfourth Street, was found dead shortly before midnight last night in the kitchen of his home.
Panzer College overwhelmed Hofstra tonight, winning 56-26, as the teams opened their basketball seasons. Panzer led at the half, 2915. Knupple, the winners' center, accounted for nine field goals.

Max Schmellng, engaged in training for his fifteen-round bout with Harry Thomas at Madison Square Garden next Monday night, will be honored by a visit from Gene Tunney, former heavyweight champion of the world, at the German's quarters in Summit, N. J., today.
Mrs. Larned Donaldson Randolph of Estouteville, Albemarle County, died this morning at University Hospital from an infection resulting from an extracted tooth. Her age was 25.

A five-team league, sponsored by the New York Amateur Hockey Association, has been organized to operate in the renovated Brooklyn Ice Palace, it was announced yesterday by John Thomas, president of the new circuit.

A special court trying Arnold Bernstein, Jewish ship magnate, on exchange law charges attempted today to disentangle the labyrinth of transactions constituting the brief history of the Palestine Shipping Company which operated with one vessel between Haifa and New York.

The Bausch Lomb Optical Company, Rochester, N. Y., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 50,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock $100 par and 250,000 common shares of $10 par.

Dr. David Lvovitch, vice president of the ORT Union, the organization for reconstruction of the economic life of Jews in Eastern and Central Europe, arrived yesterday on the Normandie of the French Line.
On the desk of this correspondent reposes at the moment a compact little chart which constitutes the answer of the administration to charges of inconsistency about price levels.

The marriage of Miss Mary Regensburg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melville E. Regensburg of 895 Park Avenue, to Leonard S. Feist, son of Mrs. Leo Feist of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Mr. Feist, took place yesterday afternoon in the Starlight Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The Rev. Dr. Nathan Perilman of Temple EmanuEl performed the ceremony.

ASSISTANT FISHERIES STATISTICAS AND MARKETING AGENT, $1,800 A YEAR. JUNIOR FISHERIES STATISTtCAL AND MARKETING AGENT. $1,620. Bureau of Fisheries, Department of Commerce. Applications must be on file with the United States Civil Service Commission at Washington, D. C., not later than Jan. 4. if received from States other than those named beloW, Jan. 7,
Mrs. Margaret Abeel Whitney, wife of Arthur T. Whitney of 13 Arbor Close, Forest Hills, Queens, died yesterday in the New York Hospital of pneumonia at the age of 33. Mrs. Whitney,
Every social worker knows that individuals and families often get into fixes to which none of the rules of Government charity apply. "Case work" means more than the giving of money.

Charles T. Douds, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, said today that he and counsel for the board were reviewing the records of an interview with Harry T. O'Brien, editor of The St. Mary's Press of St. Mary's, Pa.

Mrs. Marjorie Wallman De Lano of 929 Park Avenue, New York, and William E. Hutton Miller, a stock broker, of 430 East Eighty-sixth Street, New York, were married in Blancahard Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church here on Nov. 4, it was learned today.
Unusually narrow fluctuations characterized trading on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday, with closing quotations 1 point lower to 3 points higher than Saturday.

Norman T. Rogers, a master in chancery, indicated after a hearing today that he would recommend that a preliminary decree of divorce be granted to Mrs. Margot Marianoff of Princeton, daughter of Professor Albert Einstein, from Dmitri Marianoff of 125 Riverside Drive, New York, on the ground of desertion.

William S. Hart spent his sixty-third birthday in a hospital today. The former two-gun man has been ill for some time with pleurisy. "I have a set of fractured ribs as an added attraction," Hart said.

A well-known architect herewith offers his contribution to the widespread discussion and conflicting suggestions as to what steps should be taken to bring about a sound expansion in residential building activity.

While rain fell over the metropolitan area yesterday Madison Square Garden's spacious arena was being submerged under six inches of snow in preparation for the North American Winter sports Show and International Ski Meet, which starts a five-day run tonight.

Andrew G. Pierce 3d, heir to a New Bedford, Mass., textile fortune, filed suit here today to divorce Mrs. Marion Hughes Pierce of New York. He charged desertion. His counsel said that if a cross-complaint were filed it would not be contested.
J. M. Manson, director of the Tate Gallery, was authorized tonight to decide which imported sculptures are "works of art" and which are merely "carving."

Samuel Taylor, 20 years old, of 40 Simonson Avenue, Port Richmond, S.I., was arrested early this morning charged with criminally assaulting Mrs. Anna Jones, 45, in her home at 183 Hart Boulevard, West New Brighton, S. I.

Dan Cox of the Salem Crescent Athletic Club won a three-round decision over John Craig, unattached, in the 150-pound class final at the New York A. C. fortnightly amateur boxing show before a crowd of 1,000 at the Winged Foot clubhouse last night.

The French liner Normandie arrived here yesterday from Havre via Southampton with 805 passengers. She was five hours late in docking through encountering Sunday one of the worst storms of her two years of service.

?? of American shares of the ?? an Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., of record of Dec. 14 will be entitled to receive on Dec. 21 two additional American shares for each share held. it was announced yesterday. Stockholders may decide by Dec. 17 whether they wish to take delivery in London of shares of the company's ordinary stock to which they are entitled.

Nevada-California Electric Corporation and Subsidiaries --Twelve months to Oct. 31: Net income $796,393 after all expenses and charges, compared with $899,483 in the twelve months to Oct. 31, 1936. For October the net was $60,592, against $13,915 in October, 1936.

The St. John's University rifle team, which has engaged in two telegraphic meets already this season, will shoot in twenty-two more matches during the next three months, Coach Joe Cascone has announced.

The Chief Justice and two judges of the new Federal Court of India, wearing black and gold gowns, today held the first session of the tribunal which, in its way, is as great a step toward complete home rule as was the creation of the new provincial governments.

176th St, 320 E (11-2892); Max Nisnewitz to East River Savings Bank; extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $226,900. Longfellow Ave, 825 (10-2762C); H and H Estates, Inc. to Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum, 24 E 52d: extends mtg to Dec. 1, 1942, at 5 per Cent; $52,500.

Mr. and Mrs. Bert C. Pond of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Elizabeth Pond, to Harry F. Padelford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Padelford of this city.

A mysterious intruder made his way undetected into the offices of Chancellor Hitler's Secretary of the Reich Chancellery last month and was examining papers on the desk when he was discovered, the Berlin correspondent of The Daily Telegraph reported tonight.

A large audience heard Handel's "Messiah," presented by the Greenwich Choral Society, under the direction of Professor Lowell Beveridge, in Christ Episcopal Church here tonight. The soloists were Mrs.

Dr. Eugene Hillhouse Pool, senior attending surgeon at the New York Hospital and Professor of Clinical Surgery in the Cornell University Medical College, was elected an alumni trustee of Columbia University yesterday.

A sharp rise in unemployment during the October-November period was shown tonight in the Ministry of Labor report. In the face of the ordinary seasonal trend usually favoring employment, the registered unemplayed workers rose by 108,954 ??tween Oct. 18 and Nov. 15.

An allotment of 17,900,000 cubic feet of helium has been granted by the Munitions Control Board to agents of the German Zeppelin Company, presumably for operation of the sister ship of the Hindenburg on a transatlantic route.

The Evander Childs High School basketball team defeated the St. Simon Stock quintet,. 31 to 26, on the victors' court yesterday. It popular ski centers will be airplane service from New York to the Laurentians. The Canadian-Colonial Airways, Inc., will use the Snowplane, a fourteen-passenger
JUNO AND THE PAYCOCK, a tragedy In three acts, by Sean O'Casey Revived by the Abbey Theatre Irish Players under the sponsorship of Lee Shubert. At the Ambassador Theatre.

A prediction that a bill calling for the Federal licensing of all manufacturers of drugs, chemicals, insecticides and disinfectants which are sold direct to the public will be pushed in Congress at its current session or at the regular session in January was made yesterday by Richard K. Hines, general counsel for the Vick Chemical Company.

On the State Department instructions the charge d'affaires at Belgrade today called at the Yugoslav Foreign Office to see Acting Foreign Minister Andritch and requested him to postpone execution of the police order expelling Hubert Harrison, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and of Reuters, pending the return of Premier Milan Stojadinovich so the latter might consider the case.

Bermuda is enlisting the aid of Perry Shaw Hepburn, Boston architects who carried out the restoration of Williamsburg, Va., under a Rockefeller grant, in preserving ancient Bermudian buildings contemporaneous with old Williamsburg.

A Christmas sale of articles made by the blind was opened yesterday at the Lighthouse Craft Shop, 115 East Fifty-ninth Street, where the sale will be continued untilDec. 24. Proceeds will be given directly to the sightless workers who made the various articles.
Cloudbursts flooded rivers and gales ripped out communication lines today in the central Philippine archipelago as the third typhoon this season brought new destruction to the islands.

Defeating Harold Sussman of Brooklyn College in the third round, Frank J. Marshall, defending his title in the annual tournament of the Marshall Chess Club, made it three straight yesterday, to retain first place in a field of thirteen.
A federal district department decree today abolished the Mexican capital's notorious segregated vice district, which has existed for nearly a century.

The Cash Office of Foreign Credits at Budapest, Hungary, announced yesterday that it will pay through its correspondent in New York, the Schroder Trust Company, at the rate of $8.75 a coupon detached from each $1,000 bond of eleven issues pursuant to its offer of July 23 last.

The number of business failures in the United States for the full week ended on Dec. 2 was 208, compared with 184 in the five-day week preceding and 162 for the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly report yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Sales of copper on the export market were negotiated yesterday from 10.25 to 10.48 cents a pound c. i. f., the European base ports. Most of the business was reported to have been done between 10.35 and 10.45 cents. On Saturday, the range was between 10.25 and 10.32 cents.

By a vote of 327 to 37, and over the protests of three New York Representatives, the House today made available for travel expenses for the special session $225,000, which had been appropriated for mileage for 1938.
Three of the seeded players in the Fall scratch squash tennis tournament were eliminated as third-round play was concluded yesterday at the Harvard Club.

Joseph C. Lewis, formerly general manager. of Horton Manufacturing Company, has been appointed manager of the home laundry equipment division of Fairbanks, Morse Co. Lewis P. Faddis has been named home laundry equipment engineer.
Joseph E. Davies, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, arrived yesterday from Moscow on the French liner Normandie to spend Christmas with Mrs. Davies, who returned several weeks ago.

E. Phyllis Snyder has given Farrar Rinehart the manuscript of her book, "The Other America: Is Uncle Sam a Bad Neighbor," which will be published late in March. Miss Snyder's book deals with relations between the United States and the South American countries.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, and American Labor Party Councilman-elect from the Bronx, paraded yesterday morning for more than thirty-five

Taking the offensive in the investigation by the National Labor Relations Board of the Berkshire Employes Association of the Berkshire Knitting Mills, an alleged company union of this city, attorneys of the association today carried the fight to the board by testimony, purporting to show that the association's fight against the C. I. O. was not in violation of the Wagner Act.
Premier Duplessis of Quebec rejected today, a proposal to sell Anticosti Island, in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, to a German syndicate. He declared that Anticosti was one of Canada's strategic outposts.

The big four of the Toronto Maple Leafs, with more than a half-hundred points between them, remain out in front in the National Hockey League scoring race. There is no serious challenge to the top man of the group, young Cordon Drillon.

Twelve Japanese consular police raided a Chinese-operated, British-registered hotel in the Shanghai International Settlement today without notifying Settlement authorities or obtaining their permission.

Emerging from a liquor price war that has engrossed their attention since last Wednesday, retail liquor store proprietors found themselves faced with a new problem last night when unionized sales clerks threatened a strike tomorrow morning unless demands for higher wages and other concessions are granted by midnight tonight.

G. S. Carrel of the home club and J. Whitbeck of the Harvard Club, seeded second and third respectively, were among those to score opening-round victories as play in the fourth annual invitation Class B singles squash racquets tournament started at the Squash Club yesterrday. W. K. Rice, top-rated player,

Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Flynn of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Elizabeth Flynn, to Martin Warren Davenport of Port Washington, L. I., son of the late Professor and Mrs. Herbert Joseph Davenport of Ithaca, N. Y.

Stockholders of the Federal Knitting Mills Company voted today to dissolve. The vote was 28,102 shares against 50. Following this meeting the directors decided to pay an initial liquidating dividend of $10 a share on Dec. 20 to stock of record of Dec. 15.

Demetrios Sicilianos, Greek Minister to the United States, came here from Washington yesterday to give to John D. Rockefeller the Great Cross of the Order of George III of Greece. The presentation of the medal was made in Mr. Rockefeller's office in Rockefeller Center.

Favorable action by Governor Lehman on Mayor La Guardia's demand that he call an extraordinary session of the Legislature in the immediate future to pass a new administrative code bill for the city was regarded probable yesterday after the Mayor had received assurances from the Republican leaders of the law-making body of support not only for the Mayor's demand but also for the bill.

With illness of employes costing industry seven times as much as accidents, the problem should be approached as vigorously as industry has dealt with injuries, executives were told yesterday at a conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

The World's Fair will show Americans that theyy don't have to wait to become millionaires before they can enjoy the arts," Robert D. Kohn, chairman of the Fair Committee on Theme, told members of the League for Political Education yesterday at a luncheon in Town Hall.

Bartering Kate, 18-5 shot, owned by Mrs. G. B. Scallon, took the Amite Purse that topped the Vair Grounds program today. Coming from behind under a well-timed ride by Jockey F. Grill, Bartering Kate took command of the six-furlong dash halfway down the stretch and opened a good lead, but she was doing her best at the finish to off Frank Abbate's Veeks.

Following the dissolution of the Integralist (Fascist) party by Presidential decree, the party's offices through Rio de Janeiro have been closed. However, before locking the doors to the premises, the police made a thorough search and reported the seizure of arins, ammunition and gas bombs.
Kirsten Flagstad, Metropolitan Opera soprano, will appear in recital at Carnegie Hall tonight in the Hurok series of concerts.

In an effort to prevent injustice to unemployed theatrical performers, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott has forbidden the use of free acts at any social affairs given by the men of his department, it was learned yesterday.
Murray Witherbee Dodge, former vice president of the Chase Securities Corporation, died yesterday in his New York apartment, 823 Park Avenue. He was 59 years old. His home was at Mount Kisco.

The operations of the United States Steel Corporation from 1928 to 1936, inclusive, are summarized in an unusual form in the December issue of United States Steel News, under the caption "How We Earn Our Living." The article describes the disposition of the $5,921,000,000 received in the nine years from the public in exchange for goods and services.

Benjamin F. Schreiber, a lawyer who has managed the campaigns of many political candidates, is scheduled for election as president of the National Democratie Club at its annual meeting tonight, it became known yesterday. Other nominations follow:
Two hundred art objects made by WPA artists were placed on exhibition today in the County Office Building here by the Federal Art Project. The show will continue through Dec. 16.

The four-story business building at 19 Main Street and 277-83 Front Street, Hempstead, L. I., on a plot 133 by 250 feet, has been sold by the Smith estate, owners of the property for more than 100 years, to an investing client of Riker Co., Inc., brokers in the transaction.
The one-woman theatre known as Cornelia Otis Skinner arrives at the Little tonight, playing all eight characters of her own dramatization of "Edna His Wife," the Margaret Ayer Barnes novel.

Trustees appointed by Supreme Court Justice Alfred H. Frankenthaler to administer the $2,665,00 Series F issue of guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company annoutnced yesterday that they would make an interest distribution of $5 on each $100 certificate on Dec. 24. The checks will go to holders of record of Dec. 11.

The volume of business of the F. W. Woolworth Company in the first eleven months of this year increased 5.2 per cent to $257,593,537 from $244,872,448 in the corresponding period of 1936. November sales amounted to $25,143,275 compared with $23,891,172 in November, last sear a gain of 5.2 per cent.

Numerous mail orders reached the local merchandise markets yesterday, but in practically all instances, as has been the cases in recent weeks, they were for fill-in purposes, manufacturers and resident buyers reported.

Representatives Curley and Beiter announced today that they had received telegrams from the Associated Industries of New York State protesting bituminous prices announced last week by the Federal Coal Commission.
The New York City Police Department reported yesterday a substantial decrease in accidents, deaths and injuries last week compared with the corresponding week last year. The survey,
Of many inquiries about the New Year's Day Cotton Bowl game between Colorado University and Rice Institute, that of Manuel Irala of Bilbao, Spain. caused the most excitement.

Conditions under which trucks may move through the south tube of the new Lincoln Tunnel, between New York and New Jersey, which will be opened for two-way traffic at 4 A. M. on Wednesday, Dec. 22, have been announced by Billings Wilson, assistant general manager in charge of operations of the Port of New York Authority.

Thirty-one members of Fordham's football team, a record number, have been awarded major letters and seven varsity cross-country men have won minor letters, it was announced yesterday by John F. Coffey, graduate manager of athletics.

A new plan for the merger of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company with its underlying companies, the third to be filed in the Federal District Court here in three years, was laid before Judge George A. Welsh today by the company's directors.

Football attendance figures, rising steadily since the depression years 1929-32, continued upward in 1937 despite twin handicaps of a business recession and bad weather in the climax stages of the season.

Mr. and Mrs. Percival S. Goddard of 118 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marjorie Goddard, to Joseph Victor Leidy, son of Mrs. Joseph Schreiber and of Russell Leidy, both of Philadelphia.

Stuyvesant St, 38-40, 50x55.2x52x70, prior mtg, $35,250: also Stuyvesant St, 48, 28.4x63.1x25x79.3: prior mtg, $17,600; also Stanton St. 90-96, 98x25; prior mtg, $43,200: also 2d Ave. 522-524. 44X57.7X35.6X 53; prior mtg, $38.500; Harry Engel et al, trustees; Martin Engel to Regina Rothinan, 149 8th Ave; collateral mtg due Jan. 11, 1938. at 4 per cent; $8,000.
A band of whooping Indians-the professional football Redskins Tribechased the politicians right out of the capital spotlight today.

The new $1,000,000 Bronx County jail at River Avenue and 151st Street, the Bronx, received its first prisoners yesterday. Two hundred and sixty-seven persons, including two accused of murder, were transferred to the modern jail, from the old, obsolete quarters, in a Sheriff's van and a patrol wagon with six detective squad cars as escorts.

In a blaze of traditional splendor that dates back more than a century, seventysix debutantes, many from New York and from States near and far, tonight made their formal bow to society at the famous first Monday german of the Bachelors' Cotillion. The dance floor of the old Lyrio Theatre was transformed into a bower of beauty.

Governor Richard Leche today announced plans for a "national high school football championship game" in Louisiana State University's Stadium as an annual event beginning next Fall. Leche said the game would be "patterned after the bowl affaiW,".but that a name had not been selected.

The United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, Railway Equipment Workers Local No. 610, a C. I. O. affiliate, was certified today by the National Labor Relations Board as the exclusive bargaining agency of the production and maintenance employes of the Westinghouse Airbrakes Company at Wilmerding, Pa., after a plant election.
Sonja Henie, queen of the ice, was decorated today by King Haakon, who made her a member of the Knightly Order of Saint Olaf. She is not the first woman to be admitted to that order.

A capital outlay budget of $60,851,627 for the nine-month period beginning April 1, 1938, was submitted yesterday by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, to Kenneth Dayton, acting director of the budget.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Dec. 5 unless specified: Shanghai to Tsingtao: Bulmer. Edsall. At Mare Island Yard: Nautilus, Dec. 6: Pompano, Dec. 4; Cuyama. At San Diego, Dec. 4: King, Narwhal, Trenton.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, beginning today an investigation of the financial affairs of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacifio Railway, charges that two of the country's best-known law firms--Cravath, de Gersdorff, Swaine Wood of New York and Winston, Strawn Shaw of Chicago-had been guilty of unethical practices in connection with the first receivership of that road.
Advance parties of hunters have been scouting the deer woods of South Jersey for several days, seeking good camp sites for the opening of the season a week from Friday.

In an effort to help retailers improve their services to customers, resident buyers and manufacturers of women's dresses yesterday established a "conference council" at a meeting at the Hotel Astor. A series of discussions on styling, sizing, departmentalization and other aspects of the production and marketing of women's dresses will be held.
Permission for the government to proceed in New York with its anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America was granted by the Supreme Court today.
Paragraph 18, Special Orders 267, 'Nov. 17, 1937, relating to Capt. Leon Earl Nixon. C.W. Res., is revoked. Capt. Leon Earl Nixon, C.W.-Res., now on active duty at Headquarters Binghamton

Nicholas (Nick) Montana, 39 years old, who had served part of a twenty-five year sentence in Sing Sing on his vice conviction when it was reversed by the Appellate Division last July, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years on a plea of guilty to a misdemeanor count in the same indictment.

LA BOHEME, Opera in Italian in four acts. Music by Giacomo Puccini; book by giuseppe Giacosa and Luigi Illica, founded on Henri Murger's "La Vie de Boheme." Conductor, Gennaro Papl; chorus master, Cleva; stage director, Desire Defrere. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter Elliot Travers will give a tea dance on Dec. 22 at Sherry's to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Ann Travers.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES editorial "In the Cards" so misstates the issues involved in the opposition to Dr. J. B. Rhine's conclusions as to call for an immediate reply.
The Twenty-third Street Association will hold its annual Christmas party and luncheon meeting at the Hotel Gramercy Park, 52 Gramercy Park North, on Dec. 22.

Although the Treasury Department had not yet formulated its recommendations to the President, there appeared to be some sentiment today within the Treasury's high command for a lowering of the price paid for domestic silver.
Auburn will play Michigan State in the Orange Bowl football game here on New Year's Day, it was announced tonight.

While sixteen managers still strove to make headway in that elusive piece of business known as "getting something for nothing," club owners of the American and National Leagues emerged from the first of their executive sessions today satisfied that nobody had touched off bombshells.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made known today that Judge Webster of the Federal Court for the Eastern District of the State of Washington had temporarily enjoined Mining Truth Publishing Company and Leon Starmont from the further sale of units of participation in the Mining Truth Blind Pool of 1937, without registration under the Securities Act of 1933.

The Greyhound Corporation of Chicago received permission today from the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue $1,368.300 par-value of 5.5 per cent preference stock as a stock dividend to reduce its estimated surtax for the year on undistributed profits from $369,000 to about $119,000.

Manhattan's football squad arrived back in New York at noon yesterday from its 3,000-mile round trip to Tulsa, Okla., where on Saturday the Jaspers closed their season with a scoreless tie against the powerful University of Tulsa eleven.

A complaint was filed yesterday in Supreme Court charging that James H. R. Cromwell, his former wife, Mrs. Delphine Dodge Cromwell Baker, and Robert J. Coverdale had wrongfully taken $50,000 from Robert F. Norton in a transaction involving the leasing of the building at 502 Park Avenue in 1927.
Tommy Rawson of Boston and Johnny- Rohrig of Clifton, N. J., lightweights, will furnish the action

The Window Glass Manufacturers Association, which included Libbey Owens, Pittsburgh Plate Glass, American Window Glass and the Fourco Sales Corporation, was dissolved at a meeting here Friday, it was learned today.

Actual deliveries of contract cotton in settlement of the October, 1937, future on the New York Cotton Exchange were 74,924 bales, the largest delivery since 1931, Dr. J. W. T. Duvel, chief of the Commodity Exchange Administration, reported today.

A representative gathering of persons prominent in society yesterday attended Albert Morris Bagby's third Musical Morning of the season at the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Maria Mueller, soprano; Richard Bonelli, baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Guiomar Novaes, South American pianist.
The Procurement Division of the Treasury Department announced today awards totaling 13,178,400 yards of textiles for the Works Progress Administration. The awards follow:

Because our Belgrade correspondent, Hubert Harrison, gave to the world a few days ago the most heartening piece of news that has come out of Central Europe in a long time, the police in the Yugoslav capital have ordered him to leave the country.

The Sacred Bundle of the Water Busters Clan of the Gros Ventre (Big Belly) Indians of North Dakota is to be returned to them by the Museum of the American Indian, Heye Foundation, at fitting ceremonies in New York City.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals. Robert R. Bruce, New York, was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had.

WHAT with the indoor season hard at hand and a report that Jack Doyle, the Sage of Broadway, was about to retire from the billiard business, this observer rushed around to get some information on the strange trend in balkline billiards before the genial Mr. Doyle took his cue and buried himself among his books, of which he has a great store.

The City Athletic Club strengthened its hold on the lead in the Class B metropolitan league team squash tennis tournament yesterday by a 4-to-1 victory over the Princeton Club, undefeated winner of the 1936-37 double round-robin.

CAPTAIN John H. Quirk, 25th Precinct, at $2,950 per annum, Appointed Oct. 1, 1896. LIEUTENANTS-Nathaniel Minion, Borough Headquarters Squad, Manhattan. at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Aug. 13, 1901. William H. Anderson, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $2,000 per annum. Appointed July 16, 1901.

Lord Tweedsmuir has presented to McGill University the longhand manuscript of his most recent publication, "Augustus." The 284-page volume, bound in white leather, bears the inscription: "Presented by the Governor General of Canada to the Library of McGill University Ottawa, Dec. 3, 1937.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. discussed housing in general terms yesterday with Mayor La Guardia in the Mayor's temporary offices in the Empire State Building.

In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today: ANNOUNCEMENTS J-24-Grace M. Ekstrom. administratrix. Findings of fact. Plaintiff entitled to recover. The entry of judgment suspended awaiting the filing of stipulation by the parties. Opinion by judge Green.

A set of seven policies through which business, labor, agriculture and the government might cooperate "in a common-sense way to resume the recovery march" was put forward by Secretary of Agriculture Wallace tonight in a coast-to-coast radio broadcast.
Americans who visited France, principally the Paris Exposition, during eleven months of this year totaled 92,800. This was roughly a 100 per cent increase over last year's figure.
What will be the case for the defense in next Saturday's trial at Southbury, Conn.?

A move to give State banks an official voice in the operation of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, thus strengthening the dual banking system, was launched to day at a special meeting of the executive committee of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

J. B. Weymess, 71-yearold engineer, who has spent fiftytwo years in the service of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad, fulfilled a lifelong ambition today. On the eve of permanent retirement, Mr. Weymess was at the throttle of a Presidential special.

Clydell Castleman, young hurler for the Giants, has returned to his home at Donelson, Tenn., to spend the Winter, apparently well on his way to recovery from a spinal operation performed here in October.

The silk hat into which the magician breaks the eggs is not the one he has just borrowed from Judge Whiffletree in the second row center. Or else they are not real eggs. We have long suspected this and now we know it. The lady is not really sawed in two.

The current inventory of incomes over $100,000 by the Bureau of Internal Revenue has no connection with any plan for taxing capital assets, and the information is not to be publicized in any way, Secretary Morgenthau stated at his press conference today.

Forty three years in baseball-fifteen as a pitcher and twenty-eight as an American League umpire-ended for William Henry (Big Bill) Dinneen today. Over the protests of President Will Harridge, who pleaded with him for another year of calling 'em, Dinneen resigned his umpiring post.

Swearing in the newly appointed laundry wage board yesterday at his office in the State Building, State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews urged the nine members to fix minimum pay schedules for the industry as soon as possible.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, honored last night by the St. Nicholas Society with presentation of its first annual award, a medal for distinguished civic service, told his hosts that future work of his department would be planned to take care of the city's shifting population.
Following the holiday, automobile production last week increased more than seasonally and the adjusted index spurted to 91.9 from 77.3. The figure for the week ended Dec. 5, 1936, was 97.1.

While plans were being made here today for the beginning on Dec. 28 of a Supreme Court inquiry into Republican charges of fraud in the recent gubernatorial election, a handwriting expert testified in a Circuit Court inquiry into the Hudson County Republican primary election on Sept. 21 that thirty-two ballots cast in the fifth district of the Second Ward were written by a single person.

F. Abbot Goodhue, chairman of the finance section of the United Hospital Campaign, announced last night a contribution of $7,500 from the Bankers Trust Company. Other corporation gifts included $2,000 from the Marine Midland Trust Company, $1,650 from the Great American Group of Fire Insurance Companies and $1,000 from the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company.

President Roosevelt's Christmas shopping has included 175 pieces of pewter from the Val-Kill shop at Hyde Park, of which his wife is the sponsor, Mrs. Roosevelt said yesterday as she attended the opening of a new department at Arnold Constable, where the products will be on sale.
The New York Central Railroad last night announced a comprehensive schedule of snow trains for the coming season.

Valentine Ave (12-3308), s e cor of 203d St, 100x72; Gable Associates, Inc. to Morris Gable, 1,536 Jesup Ave; mtge $85,250. Washington Ave, 2,159 (11-3033); Samuel S. Multer, referee, to Home Owners Load Corp, 350 5th Ave.

Three outstanding football players have accepted invitations to play with the all-East team against an all-West eleven in San Francisco, Calif., New Year's Day, Andy Kerr, co-coach of the Eastern team, announced tonight.

Count and Countess F. Vanden Heuvel, Sir Louis and Lady Beale, Dr. Vladimer Rybaey, Mr. and Mrs. A. Watson Armour, Frank McHugh, actor, and Mrs. McHugh, and Clarence Mallinson are among the passengers due to arrive from Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

Appeasement for both warring factions in the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States was seen in the list of standing national committee heads for 1938, announced yesterday by Samuel E. Hoyt of New Haven, recently elected compromise candidate for president.

Mrs. Margaret Gonzalez, 62 years old, of 2,819 Tilden Avenue, Brooklyn, was knocked down by one automobile and run over by another at Tilden Avenue and East Twenty-ninth Street just before 6 o'clock last night and died two hours later at Kings County Hosnital. Both cars left the scene.

Although plans are still in an unformed stage, proponents of price maintenance in various industries have definitely decided upon a campaign to counteract the barrage of criticism now being unloosed on fair trade contracts and the Tydings-Miller law, it was learned here Yesterday.
Danno O' Mahoney, 225, Ireland, and Jesse James, 190 Greece, wrestled to a draw in the feature match before 2,500 persons at the Hippodrome last night.
Dr. and Mrs. Matthew C. Pearce of East Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Pearce, to William H. Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Potter of Orange.

Japanese troops took possession of the entire compound surrounding Dr. Sun Yat-sen's tomb on Purple Mountain, in the suburbs of Nanking, just before sunset yesterday, and they had also advanced in large force to within a mile of the Nanking gate, the highway from which leads to the tomb.

Exporters to Mexico do not have to mark their products in terms of the metrio system under the new Mexican law effective Jan. 1 since the importer or distributor in Mexico is obliged to change the content marle ing before such products are marketed, according to a report from Mexico City made public today by the Department of Commerce.
Ten Princeion Fall teams, engagins in fifty-nine contests, compiled one of the best records in Nassau athletic history, according to figures released today by the University Athletic Association.

While still classifying the case as a homicide, the police revealed evidence yesterday that strengthened the theory that Charles A. Klein, 60-year-old public accountant who was fatally stabbed in Central Park Thursday. night, may have committed suicide.
President Getulio Vargas of Brazil and President Agustin P. Justo of Argentina will inaugurate jointly, late this month, work on a bridge across the Paraguay River, connecting their two countries.

The Varsity C Club will give its annual dinner for Columbia athletes, present and past, at the Columbia University Club tonight. Block Cs will be awarded to approximately 130 men for participation during 1936-37 in track, crew, basketball, baseball, football, tennis, swimming, fencing, wrestling and cross-country.

Fat silver tankards that foamed with beer when New York was young and later underwent conversion into water pitchers as temperance sentiment grew, are included in a panoramic exhibition of the work of New York silversmiths at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue, between 103d and 104th Streets.

Thirty-two suits against the National City Company of New York asking $350,000 were filed in the District Court today by individuals who bought National City Bank stock before the depression years. The suits maintain the stock had not been registered with the State Securities Commission and that the sale in Minnesota was illegal.

Miss. Nancy Les Byers, daughter of J. Frederic Byers of Goodwood, Sewickley, was married to John William Young Martin of Glyndon, Md., this afternoon in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Sewickley, by the rector, the Rev. Louis M. Hirshon.

While the Japanese Army continues smashing its way relentlessly into the heart of this country the Chinese people here who cannot read the foreign language press are being buoyed with false tales of victories and bright prospects.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 135-Frank Palko, applt., v. State of Connecticut Appeal from the Supreme Court of Errors of Connecticut. Judgment affirmed. Opinion by Justice Cardozo. DissentingJustice Butler.
The Public Service Commission heard today final proposals for a plan to reorganize the Rochester Division of the New York State Railways.
An explosion which blew out the front of a children's clothing shop here today and a resultant fire took the lives of five persons. The dead are: Mildred Engel, proprietor of the store.
The next to the last offering in the Treasury's current issue of bills was sold today at an average price of 99.964, a rate of approximately 0.129 cent, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.

Henry Armstrong, world featherweight champion, knocked out Tony Chavez, claimant of the Mexican featherweight title, in the first session of their scheduled ten-round non-championship bout before 12,000 spectators tonight.

Funeral services were held yesterday afternoon at her home in Hazlet, N. J., for Mrs. Thomas Roseyear, who died Friday at the age of 95. She was the widow of a partner in James McCreery Co. of this ctiy. Her house in Hazlet had belonged to her family for 175 years.

Father Charles E. Coughlin, who abandoned radio talks a few months ago subsequent to differences with his Archbishop followed by an indirect reproof from Rome, announced plans tonight to return to the air.

Philip Trovato, 24 years old, of 400 Henry Street, Brooklyn, is the first motorist to be convicted in Kings County under a recently enacted law on the charge of criminal negligence in the operation of a motor vehicle resulting in death.

The appointment of R. Kenneth Fairman, '34, basketball coach and one of Princeton's outstanding athletes in recent years, as acting graduate manager of athletics at Princeton, was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the university council on athletics.
Plans for creation of a memorial to Amelia Earhart in the form of a national foundation "to serve the cause of women," were announced here today by the board of trustees of Thiel College, Greenville,

Plans for the new ten-story Family Court Building to be constructed on the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Twenty-second Street adjoining the Children's Court Building were submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate by Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan.

While Antonio de San Groniz, chief of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's "diplomatic cabinet," insisted here today that permission to reopen the United States Consulate at Bilbao had never been made conditional on recognition of the Nationalist [Franco] government, United States Consul W. E. Chapman, now in Saint-Jean-deLuz, France, said the State Department had authorized him last week to go home for Christmas on a thirty-day leave and meanwhile the Bilbao consulate would remain closed.

The National Socialist regime seems to be having trouble here keeping alive the Hitler salute and its accompanying greeting of "Heil Hitler." Saxons, like residents of other sections of the Reich, are drifting back to "Good day" and "Until we meet again."
Seven jurors were selected yesterday at the third trial of Louis Luckman on a charge of perjuring himself before the special grand jury investigating the 'Sahuel Drukman murder case.
John McD. Murray, president of the New York Produce Exchange, announced yesterday that the Exchange was organizing a futures market for trading in shelled peanuts.
Dr. and Mrs. Walter P. Anderton gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for their daughter, Miss Audrey K. Anderton,

The application of Philadelphia for a revision of its rail rates on freight shipments in import and export trade moving through the port of Philadelphia which would give it a parity with Baltimore and Norfolk was attacked by a group of New York trade groups in a brief filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The government's policy of having refrained from applying the Neutrality Act to China and Japan and of maintaining armed forces in China was defended in a letter from Secretary of State Cordell Hull to Representative Sam D. McReynolds of Tennessee, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, made public by the committee today.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 30,000 head, ' including 10.000 directs. Market 15 to 25 cents lower than Friday's average; mostly 25 cents lower. Bulk good and choice 150-200 pounds, $8.35$8.50; top light lights, $8.60; 210-250 pounds, $8.10-$8.40; 250-300 pounds, $7.85$8.10. Most good packing sows, $7.15$7.40: lightweights to $7.50, shippers 3,000; estimated holdover, 2,000.

The Attorney General requested the courts today to issue a receiving order for the Cochran Corporation Ltd., the concern that Charles B. Cochran formed five years ago to carry on his theatrical organization, because of [Pound]750 in unpaid taxes.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against JACK LERNER AND JOSEPH LERNER, trading as Lerner Bros., fur manufacturers, 227 W. 29th St., involuntary, by Brickner Bernfeld, Inc., for $250; Brickner Bros., Inc., $260; Reliable Silk House $250. Petitions Filed-By NATHAN BUSHLER, Unemployed, 916 Fails St., Bronx.-Liabilities $2,230, assets 5200.
The first house erected in the new development on the Percy A. Rockefeller estate on North Maple Avenue has been purchased by Mrs. Henry T. Kilburn for occupancy.

Stocks closed heavy with losses of a fraction to 2 points after fluctuating irregularly; turnover, 836,760 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, other groups steady and mixed; transactions, $7,587,200.
President Anastasio Somoza has decreed that all cattle in Nicaragua must be vaccinated against anthrax and other diseases. The government offers vaccination at 15 centavos.
J. C. Berkson has retired as president of Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., and has been elected chairman. Herman Husch of St. Louis was named new president and active head of the company.

Alexandre Alexandrovtich von Aljechin (or Alekhine), native of Russia and naturalized citizen of France, was born in Moscow on Oct. 19, 1892. Therefore he is now 45 years of age, or nine years older than Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the rival he dethroned yesterday in world chess championship play at The Hague.
John M. Chapman, promoter and manager of the six-day bicycle races in Madison Square Garden for the last twenty-five years, resigned the position yesterday. Mr. Chapman said:
