John Henry Lewis, world's light heavyweight champion, bounced back into the heavyweight spotlight tonight with a technical knockout victory over Isidore Gastanaga in the ninth round of their scheduled fifteen-round fight.

For the first nine months of this years the Mission Corporation reported yesterday a net income of $2,336,088 after all charges but before provision for Federal income taxes or surtax on undistributed profits.

Breaking all precedent in the annals of world chess championship play, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris tonight retained the title which he lost to Dr. Max Euwe two years ago by defeating the Amsterdam schoolmaster in the twenty-fifth game of the series after 43 moves.

Frank Gillmore resigned yesterday as president of the Actors Equity Association, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, because of ill health. The resignation was accepted with regret by Equity's council, which will hold a special meeting on Dec. 17 to consider his successor.

King Gustaf V of Sweden will cele- ti brate tomorrow the thirtieth anniversary of his accession to the throne. At his special request and in keeping with the democratic simplicity of the life of this 79-yearold monarch there will be no official ceremony.

The London Intimate Opera Company, which is composed of only three persons, arrived yesterday on the Aquitania and will give its first American performance at Wagner College, Staten Island, next Monday evening.

Roger Duncan of Hartford, Conn., was elected secretary and treasurer of the National Trotting Association at the annual meeting of the Board of Review held yesterday at the Murray Hill Hotel. He succeeds the late William Gocher of the same city, who held the positions for forty-two years.

The first of the Yorkville Dinner Dances for this season took place last night in the main ballroom and Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. These dances were organized many years ago to provide funds for the philanthropic enterprises of the Yorkville Community Association of this city and the subscribers to the entertainments comprise a representative group of members of society.

Appeals for the support of Episcopal missions and the general church budget were made yesterday to more than 600 women who attended the Advent meeting of the Women's Missionary Auxiliary of the Episcopal Diocese of New York at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The five-story apartment house at 316 Forty-ninth Street, Union City, N. in., was sold to the Penbrook Realty Company by the Hudson Trust Company. The building contains eleven five-room apartments and has a reported annual rental of approximately $4,800.

Directors of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation authorized yesterday the issuance of 11,520 shares of second series $2.50 preferred stock, and declared a dividend payable on Dec. 24 consisting of 1/75th share of such preferred stock on each common share held of record Dec. 17.

The sound-equipment service division of Electrical Research Products, Inc., has been purchased by the Altec Service Corporation, a new company formed by private interests headed by Roswell C. Tripp, according to an announcement yesterday by Mr. Tripp.

The price war which resulted In sharp reductions in retail charges for packaged liquors for the last week was virtually over last night. Most of the larger retailers had returned prices to the levels fixed by Feld-Crawford Act agreements with distillers and others were following suit.

Accused of obtaining $3,565 from thirty persons by promising to get them jobs through his "political influence," Arthur Gladstone, 39 years old, of 155 Norwood Avenue, Long Branch, N. J., was sentenced yesterday by County Judge George W. Martin in Brooklyn to serve two to five years in Sing Sing.

The sixth annual women's metropolitan squash racquets tournament, being played on the courts of the Cosmopolitan Club, advanced to the quarter-final round yesterday without any upsets, although two seeded players had to go four games before winning.

A hint that the La Guardia Administration may seek a drastic change in the present relations between the city and State governments was contained in an informal speech delivered before the Queensborough Chamber of Commerce last night by Newbold Morris, President-elect of the City Council. The civic group held its twenty-seventh annual dinner at the WaldorfAstoria.

The New Jersey Power and Light Company, an Associated Gas and Electric subsidiary, obtained yesterday from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court a temporary stay restraining the New York Trust Company from selling 712,411

The Ford Motor Company will be represented at the World's Fair of 1939 by an exhibit on a plot of 298,718 square feet, the largest con- or tracted for thus far by an individual exhibitor, according to an announcement yesterday by the fair corporation.

The appointment of a committee to devise means for correcting the "shocking lack of coordination" between the hospitals and other agencies for the organized care of the sick, was announced yesterday by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, at a special meeting of the trustees at their offices, 370 Park Avenue.

M?? Mme. Jacques Heim, visiting ?? couturiers, were guests of honor yesterday at a luncheon attended by more than 100 leading merchants, retail and newspaper executives, manufacturers and fashion experts, held in the Hotel Pierre.

Sixty-six undergraduate students at City College were designated as pledgees of eleven College Greek Letter societies, it was announced yesterday by the Inter-Fraternity Council, after a six-week trial period.

The three-man Federal commission hearing the suit of the Tennessee Valley Authority seeking condemnation of mineral rights covered by leases owned by Senator George L. Berry, C. A. Harris and George Collins was told today by Mr. Harris that landowners in the Norris Dam basin insisted upon giving him and Mr. Berry powers of attorney to sell mineral rights to the government and retain half of all sums collected as fees.

With the collapse of the Ponce murder trial because of the illness of three jurors, United States District Attorney Cecil Snyder today announced Jan. 10 as the date for the new trial of ten Nationalists charged with an attempt to assassinate Federal District Judge Robert Cooper last June 8.

After ninety-two years in the same building, 15 Gold Street, Thomas Prosser Son, importers, engineers and steel dealers, have signed a lease for large quarters at 120 Wall Steet, it was revealed yesterday.

Extension through municipal agencies and charitable organizations of i the city's distribution of 8-cent milk to the poor was urged at a conference yesterday between William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, and representatives of thirty consumer groups, settlement houses and civic organizations.

The number of out of town buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was well above the preceding week, However, the total was less than in the corresponding week a year age, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-thecounter market:
Gene Tunney, who will be remembered as a rather fair-to-middlin' heavyweight at the time he retired undefeated as champion of the world in 1928, placed the stamp of approval on Max Schmeling today.
Jean J. Dugas, proprietor of the Chateau Dugas, widely known Western New York eating place on Keuka Lake, near here, died tonight at the chateau. He was 60 years old.

The chairman's subcommittee of the Non-Intervention Committee today "recognized as satisfactory" the replies of the Barcelona and Salamanca authorities in Spain to the proposal to begin the withdrawal of foreign "volunteers."
Audrey Phillips, Inc., stores located in Perth Amboy, Hoboken and Port Richmond, S. I., have been added to the list of accounts of Ben F. Levis, Inc.

Army tonight settled, once and for all, the most famous collegiate controversy over athletic eligibility by changing its varsity rules for athletes to conform with the threeyear standard in force at virtually every major college in the country.

Arguments now proceeding before a three-judge court at Chattanooga and the Supreme Court at Washington may bring, more quickly than the oft-deferred White House "peace conference," a solution of the dispute between the administration and the public utilities.

William E. Dodd has resigned as United States Ambassador to Germany, and Hugh R. Wilson, veteran diplomat and at present Assistant Secretary of State, has been selected as his successor, according to authoritative indications today.

Townsend Pinkney of 41 Kew Gardens Road, Kew Gardens, Queens, died suddenly late Monday night while on his way home on the Eighth Avenue subway after attending a dinner at the Hotel Plaza of the St. Nicholas Society, of which he was a member.

Federal income tax agents have begun the distribution of new tax forms to taxpayers with annual net incomes of $100,000 or more, requiring them to furnish information as to all their assets and liabilities-including, under assets, even property which is not taxable and from which no income is derived.

The Union League Club's Class B squash racquets team defeated last year's champion, the Squash Club, in a Group I Metropolitan League series match last night. John Doeg, former national tennis titleholder, led the Union League, capturing the No. 1 match from G. S. Carrel, 17-16, 10-15, 17-16 15-9.

ANDERSON--Florence M., Dec. 7, 1937, beloved wife of Harry Anderson. Funeral services at her residence, 950 Grant Ave., Pelham Manor, N. Y., on Saturday, Dec. 11, 10 A. M. AXMAN--Charles David, beloved husband of Sophie C. and beloved father of Laurence II., in his eighty-eighth year. Funeral Wednesday, Dec. 8, 10 A. M., from Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St.

A new indoor playground for the children of "Hell's Kitchen" was opened yesterday afternoon. Situated at 698 Tenth Avenue, near Forty-ninth Street, it will be run by the Boys Athletic League at a cost of $8,000 a year.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia late this afternoon had another long conference with Premier Benito Mussolini and Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, in which they continued the conversations begun yesterday.

Members of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Taxation divided their session today between discussions of the administrative features of their proposed changes in the undistributed profits tax and a study of yesterday's decision by the Supreme Court which upheld the right of a State to tax income of contractors derived from a contract for a Federal project within the State.

Stuart Putnam Meech, Associate Professor of Finance at the University of Chicago since 1927, was found shot early today in his hotel apartment here. He was reported as unconscious and in a grave condition tonight at the Illinois Central Hospital.

Trading was only fair to slow in the wholesale markets yesterday. Slaughter house business was fair to mostly slow. The lamb market was weak to lower; cow and bull steady; fresh pork steady to slightly lower; other classes steady to weak. Early trading in kosher meats indicated most classes to be weak to lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A banking group headed by Brown Harriman Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $10,000,000 of fifteen-year first-mortgage 41/2 per cent bonds of West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1937, and maturing Dec. 1, 1952, will be priced at par and accrued interest.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Mrs. Betty Buck Kirkland of Beverly Hills, Calif., former wife of John M. (Jack) Kirkland, playwright, to A. Coster Schermerhorn of this city and Locust Valley, son of Mrs. Alfred E. Schermerhorn and the late Mr. Schermerhorn.

Florence Griswold was born on Christmas Day. The next would have been her eighty-seventh. She came into the news and into the hearts of many of us last year when the artists to whom she had been so kind in their hard-up days associated themselves to buy her house, mortgaged to the ridgepole, give her a home for life and then make it a public, as it has long been a private, museum.

Lammot du Pont sounded yesterday the keynote of American industrial sentiment at a manufacturers' congress here in declaring that business was ready to assume the burden of social responsibility if only the government would "lift the fog" of what lies ahead in taxation and similar stability were assured by labor. [Page 1.]

Eighteen American aviators landed they planes at Camp Columbia airport this afternoon in the Miami-Havana air cruise. The cruise is a contest, the three winning fliers being selected on the basis of adherence to schedule.

Kings Brewery, Inc., with plants at 225-279 Pulaski Street and 254 Hart Street, Brooklyn, filed yesterday a petition for reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act with the clerk of the Brooklyn Federal Court.

Low prices and the prompt taking of inventory losses by the trade here will spur activity in the domestic fur trade, whereas any attempt to maintain high levels will impede buying and make for a cautious start of the new season, foreign buyers now in this market said yesterday.

Anton Bauer, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Zagreb and a strong Croat Nationalist, died here this afternoon. He was 82 years old. On several occasions in recent years Archbishop Bauer fearlessly denounced what he regarded as unjust treatment of fellow-members of his church.

Leo L. Fenbert, attorney, of 2 Lafayette Street was held in bail of $1.000 yesterday by Garret W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, after his arrest by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the charge that he misappropriated $25,000 in funds of the bankrupt estate of Ray Long and Richard R. Smith, Inc:,- publishers,
Dr. Morris Fishbein of the American Medical Association today pledged the cooperation of the association to Warner Brothers for the production of a picture exposing and denouncing quack doctors.

Would you go out to hunt elephants with a .22 rifle? That sounds like a fantastic question, doesn't it? But you never can tell what an angler or a hunter will try next. Colonel William Schauftier Jr., a New Jersey big-game angler, is going to do something equally ambitious-he's going to try hooking and landing a whale with rod and reel.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 6. unless specified: At Tsingtao: Bulmer, Edsall. At San Diego: Hovey. Simpson. Antares, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Philadelphia Yard. Asheville, at Swatow, Dec. 7.
Mrs. Louisa Lawrence Burlingham of 860 Park Avenue, wife of Charles C. Burlingham, lawyer and civic leader, died last night in the New York Hospital, after a long illness, at the age of 74.

Alexander F. Wojciechowicz, Fordham's fine center, was presented with the Madow Trophy, annually awarded to the outstanding player in the Fordham-New York University football game, by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J., president of Fordham University, at a formal bridge party held in Keating Hall, on the Fordham campus, last night.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in a report for the third quarter of 1937 sent to Congress today, said that under its loan provisions disbursements in that period aggregated $76,373,159 and repayments amounted to $111,773,661.

Harmonious relations between baseball's two major leagues, which for the past four seasons saw both circuits using a uniform ball, came to an abrupt end today when the American and National Leagues, concluding their separate sessions, announced that each would go its own way in the type of ball to be used in 1938.

The names of 124 persons, including seven women, who passed the October examination for licenses to practice in New Jersey as physicians and surgeons were announced today by the State Board of Medical Examiners.

Porcellus, 4-year-old Hard Tack filly who races for B. M. Smith, won by a length and a half in the Morgan City Purse, which topped the Fair Grounds program today. Coming through under a well-timed ride by R. L. Vedder, Porcellus ran over the pacemakers and drew away from Mrs. A. M. Creech's Gold Mesh, a strong second.

Using the leather cushions of office furniture to deaden the sound of the blasts, cracksmenn" leisurely ripped open three safes in the offices of the Central Dental Laboratory Company at 108 West Thirty-ninth Street, and escaped early yesterday with dental gold and platinum worth about $5,000.
Finland took steps today to preserve her record for prompt payment of her war debt to the United States, notifying the United States that she would meet her Dec. 15 installment of $232,143.

While twentyfour Government planes sped to Palma, Majorca, in a heavy and apparently successful attack on that port, fifteen Rebel bombers and pursuit planes came across the water from the Majorca base and raided Barcelona, killing more than fifty persons and wounding about 100, according to communiques.

The curb on picketing proposed by the Kings County November grand jury last Friday was denounced as "an unjustified attack on elementary rights of labor" by twenty-two local unions affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, at a conference yesterday afternoon at 3 West Sixteenth Street.

Clyde A. Armstrong, attorney for the Weirton Steel Company, charged at the National Labor Relations Board hearing today that the board attorney, Isadore Polier, had made "undue reflection on the press."
Turkey denounced her treaty of friendship and non-aggression with Syria today in a note to the French Government, which administers Syria under League of Nations mandate.

A new salary schedule increasing the pay of nearly 3,500 substitutes in the New York City school system by $536,000 was recommended yesterday by the law committee of the Board of Education. Action on the proposal will be taken at the regular meeting of the board this afternoon.
Control of Brazil's economy by corporations of employers and workers rather than directly by the government is preferred by Minister of Justice Francisco Campos, author of the new constitution.

The Floyd D. Cerf Company of Chicago was reported yesterday to be forming a selling group to offer 65,000 shares of Class A 7 per cent cumulative convertible stock of the Reed Drug Company, which represents a recent merger of the Reed Drug Company of Wisconsin, the Fay Drug Company of Illinois and the Wood Drug Company of Illinois.

Statements that some of the large decreases in the 1939 fiscal estimates were largely in recurring items and that expenses for many administrative items had been actually increased came today from members of the House Appropriations Committee, some of whom expressed surprise that government agencies would ask for more money in the face of President Roosevelt's announced intention to balance the budget.
Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich reserved decision here

Counterfeiters worked so quick-ly imitating the new nickel sucre coins that the government has ordered their immediate withdrawal only two days after they were placed in circulation according to the Telegrafo.
American exports of tin-plate scrap next F year will be restricted to 25 per cent of such production in 1937 under rules and regulations issued by the Munitions Control Board today.

Harvard's varsity hockey team showed an unexpectedly strong offense in overwhelming M. I. T., 13 to 0, at the Arena tonight. George Carnrick guarded the Tech nets but the New Jersey boy, plainly showing the effects of recent tragic circumstances, could not stem the tide as the Crimson riddled Tech's defense.

Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Kountze Douglas entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa, where Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Hitt of Glen Cove, L. I., are their guests. William Theodore Hoops was host to a group for cocktails today at Casa Eleda for his guests, Mr. and Mrs. William S. Lair.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Dec. 21 on the application of the New York Stock Exchange to strike from listing and registration the unstamped ten-year 4 1/4 per cent debentures due on Aug. 1, 1946, of the Adams Express Company on the ground that

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,387,000 barrels, compared to 3,425,S00 in the preceding week, a drop of 38,800, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
The dollar recovered moderately in foreign exchange yesterday following its weakness on Monday. The pound sterling fell 1/8 cent to $4.99 7/8 and the franc was down 1/8 point to 3.40 cents.
Jacques Singer, 27-year-old violinist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, is to be conductor for a preliminary season, Feb. 1 to May 1, of the reorganized Symphony Orchestra of Dallas, Texas.

Seven of the eight seeded players in the fourth annual Class B singles squash racquets tourney current at the Squash Club will go into the second round today. J. J. Reynolds Jr., University Club, No. 8 on the list, won yesterday from R. Watts, Short Hills, to complete the firstround contests.

Earl Fink of the Englewood Field Club won his way into the final of the veterans' squash racquets tournament at the University Club yesterday by defeating J. H. Terry, Racquet and Tennis Club, in straight games, 15-13 and 15-10.

William R. Morehouse, former president of the savings division of the American Bankers Association, died early today at his home. He was 58 years old. A vice president of the SecurityFirst National Bank, he was the author of seven books on banking, including "Banker's Guide Book."
The champion Red Wings, flashing in their old-time form, overpowered the Bruins for a 3-2 victory tonight before 13,000 at the Boston Garden.

Mayor Daniel A. Knaggs "stood on his record" and was re-lected yesterday for the third time. His record consisted in part of smashing a C. I. O. picket line in June at the Newton Steel Company plant with deputies and vigilantes.

Amundson Ave (17-4989), e s, 200 ft n of Strang Ave, 37x100; William E. Braham to Louis Hess, 4,020 Amundson Ave. Bryant Ave (11-2999) e s, 450 of Jennings St, 50x100; Anna M. App to Congregation Kehal Adath Yeshurun of the Bronx, 1,408 Bryant Ave.
Coach Andy Kerr tonight selected two more players for his All-East team, bringing to seven the number chosen for the squad that will meet an All-West eleven at San Francisco New Year's Day.

In the increasingly critical matter of bringing the national budget into balance, after seven successive deficits which have more than doubled the public debt, there is too much willingness to expect a miracle in Washington.

The best thing that the government could do to help business would be to relieve business of the "unreasonable handicaps" under which it is operating, J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, said yesterday to shareholders of the bank at their annual meeting, held at noon in the bank's main office, 40 Wall Street.

A copy of the rare first edition of James Fenimore Cooper's "The Spy" brought $1,350 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the library of Dr. William C. Braislin of Brooklyn.

The New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company, better known as the Ward Line, filed a libel yesterday in Federal court for $1,119,817 against the Continental Insurance Company of New York, alleging that the defendant sought to repudiate its obligations growing out of claims filed by victims of the Morro Castle and Mohawk disasters.

Cornelius J. Dacey, 38 years old, of 31 Ormond Place, Rye, N. Y., was found guilty last night by a General Sessions jury of participation in the theft of $6,000 in bonds nearly a year ago from Mrs. Margaret L. Toomey, a widow, of 14 Webster Place, Jersey City. The jury, including five women, recommended mercy.

The Senate-Committee on Interstate Commerce, continuing today its inquiry into the financial affairs of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, sought to show that in 1925, the first year of the receivership of the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul, the predecessor company, a reorganization was put into effect which made Kuhn, Loeb Co. of New York the complete masters of that transcontinental system.
The British Army lays its generals off at the age of 63 and Commissioner Valentine thinks policemen should be retired at the

1st Lt. Edward A. Solomon, Qm-Res., 350 5th Ave., New York, First Quartermaster Regiment, is ordered to active duty Dec. 5 at Fort Jay, N. Y., for training. He will be relieved from active duty Dec. 18.

Check exchanges in 194 clearing houses throughout the country in November amounted to $24,389,767,774, a decline of 11.6 per cent, compared with the preceding month and of 9.9 per cent compared with November, 1936.

There is no longer any doubt that the Nazi leaders are waging a comprehensive campaign to destroy German Christianity or that their activities in this field are creating a serious breach in the Reich.

Fifty-three Spanish Insurgent refugees, enjoying full freedom in the Netherlands, were arrested today and interned in a fortress near Utrecht because fifteen of their companions crossed the frontier, thus breaking their promises not to leave the country until the end of the civil war in Spain.

Charters were issued to 16,074 stock companies in New York State in the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, compared with 17,056 in the corresponding period in 1936, Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, announced today.

A suit to compel the Bethlehem o Steel Company to redeem in undevalued Dutch guilders or their dollar equivalent $598,000 of "alternative" 5 per cent bonds called on Nov. 1 was instituted yesterday in Supreme Court by "Credimus" Maatschappij Tot Deelneming in Industrieele Bedrijven, N. V.

Richard J. Beamish, Public Utilities Commissioner, announced today that a test showed that the Allentown reserve plant of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company would be "practically useless in an emergency."

My life is uneventful, and no glitter Of sequin gown or restless silver shoe Highlights my eyelids shadowed blue by bitter Remembrance of unworthiness come due. My name will never be electric-lighted As glamour-girl or actress of repute; For research or for fame I'll not be knighted,

William Wyatt Barber, for nearly half a century a teacher of Greek at St. Mark's School, died here today in his campus home, in his seventy-third year. For the last few years he had been senior master, retiring last June after forty-eight years of teaching.

The northwest corner of East Tremont and Washington Avenues in the Bronx was showered with diamonds yesterday and the police had a busy fifteen minutes holding back a crowd of several hundred would-be prospectors.
Newburyport's fiery Mayor, Andrew J. (Bossy) Gillis, was defeated today for a fourth term by James A. Carens, a former city solicitor, in one of eight Mayoralty elections in Massachusetts.

Dr. Livingston Farrand, former president of Cornell University, was sworn in as a governor of the Society of the New York Hospital at a meeting of the board yesterday at 225 East Sixty-eighth Street. Dr. Farrand became the 376th governor elected since the society received its charter from George III in 1771.

King Victor Emmanuel today conferred upon Marshal Rodolfo Graziani the hereditary title of Marquis of Neghelli in recognition of his services to the nation in the conquest, subjection and administration of the East African empire.

President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Perkins, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, and Floyd Reeves, chairman of the Advisory Committee on Education, and held his regular press conference.

As part of President Roosevelt's plan to stimulate recovery from the business recession and pursuant to Presidential instructions received here on Monday, the local Works Progress Administration will begin immediately to place orders for materials and supplies that will be required for WPA projects during the first quarter of 1938.

The resumption of inflation was declared "an overwhelming likelihood," and the breakdown of the present economic and political system within about five years was foreseen, yesterday, by Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, a research organization supported by the largest employers in the country.

Heavy losses to the government and to farmers resulted from improper classification of cotton acquired by the government under the Commodity Credit Corporation loan programs and the old Cotton Producers' Pool, the American Cotton Cooperative Association charged in a report made public today.

Alan M. Lincoln of Rye, N. Y., senior partner of Clarke Co., paper brokers, 475 Fifth Avenue, suffered a heart attack yesterday morning while walking up a ramp in Grand Central Terminal and died a few minutes later in the emergency hospital of the terminal.
The Fordham basketball team began its fourth season under Coach Vincent Cavanagh by posting a decisive 28-15 victory over the alumni on Rose Hill last night.

Though the enforcement of existing parking regulations, as mentioned in your front page article today, may be a beginning of improved traffic conditions in the midtown area, yet it will hardly accomplish permanent improvement unless drastic limitation of taxicab licenses is brought about; and also reduction of the excessive number of Fifth Avenue buses which now use Fifth Avenue.
Frank H. Wood, 46, postmaster here since March, 1932, was found dead in his home today. Sheriff Baker said Mr. Wood had been shot through the heart.
Robbed of $100,000 worth of diamonds he had carried across the continent, Louis Heyman of New York City identified today a police picture of one of two men he said held him up here yesterday.

The perfection of American-made women's shoes was extolled in the House of Commons today by a Scottish Conservative who demanded a reduction of Great Britain's heavy tariff so that more British women could afford them.
Luther M. Walter, co-trustee of the Chicago Great Western Railroad, said today that railway labor and management should beware of placing too heavy a financial burden on shippers.

Advertising is the greatest safety measure ever devised for the protection of the consumer, Lee H. Bristol, vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company, declared yesterday in an address before the twenty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Insecticide and Disinfectant Manufacturers at the Hotel Biltmore.

Brooklyn Technical High School and Alexander Hamilton High went into a deadlock for first place in Section 1 of the Brooklyn Division of the P. S. A. L. basketball championship race by scoring triumphs yesterday. The victories were the second in as many starts for both fives.

William H. Harkness, one of the founders of the William Wrigley Company, died at his home here today. He was 76 years old. For many years one of the leading salesmen of the company he helped establish, Mr. Harkness had been in failing health for several years, although not seriously ill until a few days before death.
The New York State Federation of Labor proposed tonight extension of the Workmen's Compensation Law to include all employes, including domestic workers of non-profit-making organizations.

Today's major events: "Samson ti et Dalila," Metropolitan Opera u House, 8:30 o'clock; Maria Carreras, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Rosalyn Tureck, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Madrigal Singers, WPA Theatre of Music, 8:45.

Chinese and Japanese troops opened a battle for possession of the first line of the inner defenses of Nanking proper yesterday after three columns of the advancing invaders had reached positions along a semicircular front about ten miles from the city.

Dean Arthur Davenport Black of the Northwest?rn University Dental School died tonight at the age of 67. He was a son of Dr. G. V. Black, known as the father of modern dentistry, and had been dean of the Northwestern Dental School for twenty years.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Woolworth and William M. Brady gave a dinner last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Beatrice Barclay Elphinstone, daughter of Mrs. Reginald C. Elphinstone, and Henry Van Duzer Wing, whose marriage will take place tomorrow in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. John Bullock,

Cooperation between government and business to stem the business recession by a balanced budget and broad tax revision was urged in a statement yesterday by Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company.
Frank J. Shakespeare has been appointed manager of the railroad bond department of E. W. Hughes Co. Charles C. Walter was made manager of the public utility bond department.

The fifteen-story apartment house comprising the block front on the east side of Park Avenue between Ninety-third and Ninety-fourth Streets, and known as 1,185 Park Avenue, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

John R. Nicholson, former Chancellor and former Attorney General of Delaware, died in the Delaware Hospital tonight from complications due to his advanced age and injuries suffered Oct. 30 when he was struck by an automobile. His age was 88.

Experts of the League of Nations committee on the use of radiotherapy in treating cancer of the uterine cervix concluded its regular meeting here today with a decision to publish a book illustrating the different types and stages of this disease.

Watson G. Clark, for the last several years Assistant State Director of the Coast and Geodetic Survey for New Jersey and former State Highway Engineer, died this morning of a heart attack in his home here. He was 66 years old.

Back from the major league meetings in Chicago with the clamorous voices of National League owners and managers still ringing in his ears, Jim Mulvey, vice president of the Dodgers, yesterday still stood pat in his determination that Van Lingle Mungo remain a Dodger "unless"

The mortality rate among the white population of the country has decreased since 1900 to the extent that there were 768,402 fewer deaths in 1935, statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reported yesterday.

Vice Ordinary Malcolm G. Buchanan of the Prerogative Court today ordered George L. and John A. Hartford, sons of the late George H. Hartford and trustees of his estate, to pay to New Jersey a transfer inheritance tax of $90,807, with interest at 10 per cent a year from August, 1918. The interest will approximate $180,000.

Japanese high officials in Shanghai are pleased by reports that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek will retire as head of the Chinese Government and be succeeded by Wang Chingwei, former Premier, and General Chang Chun, former Foreign Minister.
G. A. Laing's Captain Bill, returning to the flat tracks after being beaten in three hunt races this season, won the last race today and paid $145.60 for $2 in the mutuels.

Southern Blvd (11-2981): 1,486 Boulevard Corp to N. Y. Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, 105 E 22d St; extends mtg to June 1, 1942, at 41/2 per cent; $25,000. 3d Ave, 3,818-20 (11-2928): Halselm Estates, Ltd, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtg to Dec. 1, 1942, at 3 1/2 to 4 per cent; $30,450.
The Arnold College basketball team defeated the Savage School of New York City, 48 to 38, tonight. Lewis of Arnold was high scorer with 17 points.
Dr. Charles H. La Wall, dean of the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science since 1918, died of pneumonia today at Jewish Hospital after an illness of two weeks. He was 66 years old.

The dental need of the people of the United States is "beyond comprehension," Dr. Ralph F. Sommer, assistant Professor of Operative Dentistry and Radiology at the University of Michigan, asserted yesterday at the second session of the annual Greater New York Dental Meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order today permitting five amendments to a registration statement filed on Jan. 21, 1937, under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Bondholders Committee for Republic of Colombia Dollar Bonds, to become effective immediately, and dismissing stop-order proceedings which had been instituted by the SEC on Feb. 10.
Andrew W. Mellon, Secretary of the Treasury in three Administrations, was exonerated today by the Board of Tax Appeals of the charge of income tax fraud.
Rushing to the front from fourth position in the stretch, Alaskan captured the Sequoia Handicap at Tanforan today, defeating Floragina by two lengths. Polvo's Prince was third.

A proposal for reduction of parking charges in Manhattan as a step toward cooperation with the forthcoming police drive against parking will be discussed at a meeting of the Metropolitan Garage Owners Board of Trade within a week, it was learned yesterday.
Contrary to experience in other media, car card advertising in the last month has taken a definite spurt and both new business and renewals are coming in at a rate considerably ahead of a year ago.

Bert Young, in 42 W. 72d St: Mrs. Helaine Schweitzer, in 116 W. 72d St; Miss Ethel Kendall, in 255 West End Ave; Miss Marion Jones, in 40 W 73d St; Mrs. Jeanne Jordan, in 201 W 77th St; Mrs. Otto B. Shulof, in 535 W 110th St: John Pullman, in 510 W 110th St; A. Gabor, in 245 W 74th St; Low Gross, brokers.
The following ununiformed firemen shall be directed to report to the chief medical officer 'at these headquarters at 12 noon, Wednesday, Dec. 15:

The fate of the New Deal proposal to lend money to build publicly owned hydro-electric power plants was put before the Supreme Court today as government counsel and corporation attorneys debated the lawsuits of the Alabama Power Company and Duke Power Company against loans and grants from the Public Works Administration to the municipal enterprises.

The Hitler Elite Guard, in an article or rather a declaration of faith in its official organ, The Black Corps, formally recognizes today the existence in Germany of a "State religion" above and independent of the Christian churches.

Mrs. Loretta Finn O'Neil, widow of Municipal Court Justice John F. O'Neil, who was fatally stabbed last April, has lost her fight for a city pension of $6,000 a year during her lifetime and will receive a lump sum of $25,000. Justice O'Neil lived for three days after the attack and died in St. Vincent's Hospital.

The Junior Auxiliary of the American Association of Teachers of German will present Goethe's "Faust" in the Pauline Edwards Theatre of the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, on the evenings of Dec. 17 and 18.

Twelve more braces were run today in the Pointer Club of America's $1,500 open all-age stakes, and although some of the dogs found birds they failed to come up to the style of yesterday's performers. Six more braces will be run tomorrow.

Making provision for "setting the clock back thousands of-years." as Home Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare sadly put it, the House of Commons passed tonight the air-raid precautions bill for safeguarding the civilian population in time of war.

Jose R. de Capriles defeated Dr. John R. Huffman by the margin of a single touch to give the Salle Santelli a 5-to-4 victory over the New York Athletic Club in an open foils team competition last night. Sponsored by the Amateur Fencers League of America, the contest was held on the strips of the Salle Santelli in the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C.A.

Had the late George Gershwin, known around the world as a composer, lived a short time longer, he would have achieved his ambition to appear before the public as a painter, for he was planning to hold his first one-man exhibition of paintings and drawings next year.
Irwin Shaw's first full-length play will get a hearing at the Longacre this evening, when Norman Bel Geddes opens "Siege," a story set in the front lines of the Spanish revolution.

Representatives of the Montclair A. C. and the Columbia University Club are certain to meet for final honors in the Fall scratch tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association at the Harvard Club this week.

The House, reversing its stand of yesterday, when it rejected compulsory marketing control of the wheat crop, defeated today by a vote of 80 to 51 a-motion to strike from the Farm Bill provisions for similar control of the cotton crop.

French Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos left here today for Bucharest much gratified with his Polish visit as he reiterated to reporters as the train started. The Polish Foreign Minister Josef Beck and M. Delbos were all smiles as they warmly shook hands while the crowd cheered France.

Bonds made a dull market yesterday as prices drifted moderately lower in restricted trading. Except for a few sharp declines in usually inactive issues, attributed largely to tax selling and special circumstances, the market was without feature.

An attack on taxation that hampers business, and particularly on the undistributed profits tax, was made yesterday by Max Graves, president of the New York State Tax Commission, in an address befor the National Association of Manufacturers at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.
Mrs. Harold A. Rosenbaum of 550 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Peggy Lashanska Rosenbaum, to Peter G. Lehman, son of Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman.
Campaign statements by high Soviet sources tonight urged the people to regard Sunday's election of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) as a "mobilization" to show the world the nation s united.

Honorary membership in the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the highest award of the society, was given last night to Lorenzo Allievi, Rome engineer, at the fifty-eighth annual meeting in the Engineering Societies Building.

President Roosevelt has not discussed the rumored appointment of Jerome Frank, formerly solicitor of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration. to one of the two vacancies on the Securities and Exchange Commission, he said today.
The Bank of the Manhattan Company bought today an issue of $10,000,000 of State grade-crossing elimination bonds at a net interest rate of 2.4725 per cent.

THE feeling of many of the spectators who were at the Polo Grounds on Sunday is that the Chicago Bears would be wise to shuck their football suits immediately, leave the Windy City under cover of darkness, scatter in all directions across the country and refuse to give their right names if halted and questioned.

Announcement was made here last night of the death on Saturday at her home in Los Angeles of Mrs. Frances McKeon Benzecry, widow of Benjamin Benzecry and until six years ago a resident of this city. She was 59 years old.
Mr. and Mrs. A. P. Bauman of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emma Bauman, to Edward Roller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Roller, also of this city.

M. E. Kennedy Co. of 29 Broadway and Herbert Company of 80 Wall Street, both securities brokers, have been permanently restrained by the Supreme Court from dealings in securities in this State, it was announced yesterday by Attorney General Bennett.

A group of newspaper men in the Philippines have formed the Philippine Press Wirele-ss with an authorized capital stock of $100,000 to receive and transmit press dispatches by radio, says a report from Manila made public today by the Department of Commerce.

2d St, 124 E, 24.8x121.11; Henslo Realty Corp (Herman Epstein, pres) to Hulda Hirsch, 1,475 Sheridan Ave, et al.; 5 years, 6 per cent; $12,000. 89th St, 350 E, 25.8x100.8: Weldon Estates, Inc (Louis Peskin, press , to Frank Wolf, 225 W 106th St; pr mtg $11,500, 3 years, 6 per cent; $3,500.

The estimate of the Department of Agriculture as to the production of cotton in the United States this year will be made public at 11 A. M. today. Largely because of private estimates, which have averaged 18,440,000 bales, the trade is expecting that the report will show an increase over the 18,243,000 bales forecast a month ago.

Ten players advanced to the second round as the Fall Class B and C tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association got under way yesterday at the City Athletic Club. Two of the competitors, A. Knox Jr. of the Princeton Club and J. K. Fitzgerald of the New York A. C. won by defaults.

Calling up statistics to refute charges against science, Dr. Robert A. Millikan declared today in an address at the University of Cincinnati that the percentage of our population gainfully employed had risen "steadily" in the last fifty years "when science has been most rapidly applied."

Most of the 180 students of Tome Institute at Port Deposit went on strike today, refusing to attend classes, in a protest over the school trustees' request for the resignation of Dr. Charles J. Keppel, headmaster since 1935.

Wilbur S. Wright, descendant of one of the oldest families of Greenwich, head of Wright, Hirschberg, Pettengill Strong, a law firm here, died at his home in Belle Haven today of a heart attack after a lingering illness. He was 66 years old.

The establishment of an inter-American radio office with headquarters at Havana for the exchange of information and experiences in radio communication and broadcasting was agreed upon by the second committee of the radio conference last night.
Ninetythree race horses, a record number, have been nominated for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap on March 5.

Movements in the livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 2,400, including 5,000 directs. Hogs 200 pounds down and packing sows fully steady with yesterday's average. Others weak to 10 cents lower; top, $8.60; bulk good and choice 150-200 pounds, $8.35$8.55; comparable 210-240 pounds, $8.10$8.50; 250-300 pounds, $7.75-$8; most good packing sows, $7-$7.40; few lightweights to $7.50; shippers, 2,000; estimated holdover, 5,000.
Clinton Frank stood up amid the deafening acclaim of a thousand admirers last night to receive the John W. Heisman Memorial Trophy as the outstanding college player of the season.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 6: COLONELS Beckham, D. Y., Adjutant General's Dept., eight days' leave, Dec. 25. Smith, S. D., Cav., one month extension of leave on account of sickness.

Ralph Greenleaf, world champion, won both blocks in his pocket billiard match with James Caras, former titleholder, at the Strand Billiard Academy last night. In the first game Greenleaf triumphed, 125 to 83, in six innings. His best run was 42 while Caras had a string of 47.

Asphalt burners were wheeled on to Wrigley Field today to thaw the frozen gridiron for the National Football League championship game Sunday between the Chicago Bears, Western division rulers, and the Washington Redskins, Eastern titleholders.
The directors of the J. C. Penney Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock in addition to the regular payment of $1 a share.

The imminent' fall of Nanking is accepted in German quarters as marking the end of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's authority and the inevitable expansion of Japanese influence over those provinces not yet occupied.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania arrived yesterday from Europe in the charge of Captain Edgar Edkin, who is relieving Captain J. C. Townley for two voyages. The ship escaped the northeastern gale on Sunday which kept the Normandie back, but it felt the heavy swell that followed the storm.
For the first time in the history of air transport, fares on Northwest Airlines will be comparable to train fares, it was announced yesterdav by Croil Hunter, president.

A new gallery, which is to present modern Italian art, opened with a preview yesterday. It is called the Comet and the address is 10 East Fifty-second Street. The director, Anna Laetitia Pecci-Blunt, has a gallery of the same name and dedicated to the same program in Rome, only the Romans call it Cometa.

A hosiery knitting machine, which will start with the pressing of an electric button and will produce twenty-six full-fashioned stocking blanks at a time, was patented today by Alfred F. Ischinger of Mount Penn, Pa., attorney for the Textile Machine Works of Wyomissing, Pa., assignee of the patent.
Four Soviet explorers drifting from the North Pole toward the Atlantie, indicated today they were ready to be rescused as their ice floe approached possible danger.

Colonel William Kelly, former army engineer and president of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation, told a threejudge Federal court here today that the Tennessee Valley Authority's high dam project in the Tennessee basin is not justifiable, if measured alone from its benefits to navigation and flood control.

ATLAS STORE EQUIPMENT CO., 149 Bowery.-By National Plywood Co., Inc., for $245; Meyer Grimes Weiner, Inc., $245; Amos Mosson Lumber Co.. Inc., $198. The members of the firm are listed as Louis Siegel and Louis Michael. Petitions Filed-By MAXWELL DORNE, unemployed painter, 1,042 Hoe Ave.-Liabilities, $3,128; no assets.
A concert of chamber music and lieder was given last night at Town Hall before a large audience for the benefit of the Teachers Guild Associates.

Figured solely on the won and lost records, the nation's No. 1 college football team for the last fiveyear stretch is Alabama's Crimson Tide, rival of California in the coming Rose Bowl game at Pasadena.
Madison Square Garden echoed to the joyous cries of 10,000 Winter sports devotees last night as the second annual North American Winter Sports Show and international ski meet opened.

A Sing Sing sentence of two and one-half to five years was imposed by Judge Collins in General Sessions yesterday on Giuseppe Parloti, 60 years old, formerly of 532 East Eighteenth Street, who pleaded guilty of first-degree manslaughter in the shooting of a youth in the Summer of 1936.
Last week 1,471 persons died in this city, the largest number in any seven-day period in the last twenty weeks, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Anonymous gifts of $5,000 and of $1,000 to the United Hospital Campaign were announced last night by George J. Lyons, vice chairman. Donations of $1,000 from Mrs. Anderson B. Fowler, from Miss Grace Scoville and from Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker were also reported.

Tommy Rawson, 134 pounds, of Boston, defeated Johnny Rohrig, 135 1/2, of Clifton, N. J., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. A crowd of 8,000 witnessed the well-fought battle.
Dr. and Mrs. H. P. Feldman of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Feldman, to F. Gerald Tove of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Tove of Lisbon, N. Y.

The Court of Appeals, citing "unity of interest" between a retailer and the manufacturer of goods which he sells, today modified an order of the Appellate Division so as to permit, under certain conditions, peaceful picketing at a retail establishment selling products of a manufacturer with whom a union was at odds.

LIEUTENANT Albert Kolson, 100th Prea cinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Feb, 28, 1907. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANT John J. Murphy, from 15th Division to 100th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.
Four new retirement applications from police officials reaching the age of 63 were received yesterday by Commissioner Valentine.

The 1937 community service campaign of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities yielded $141,132, it was announced at a final report luncheon held yesterday at the bureau headquarters, 285 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn.
Hence, in the absence of a determined and unmistakable change in the course of public policy, what we are now witnessing may gradually assume the proportions of a world-wide economic depression.
President Maximiliano Martinez received Mrs. Ana del Pulgar de Burke, a member of the "Flying Caravan" for peace, today and assured her of El Salvador's support of the Buenos Aires peace pact.

Six motion-picture producing and distributing companies sought today to have the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals change its ruling that their "ban" on "double features" violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Arthur V. McDermott, a Brooklyn attorney who was Mayor La Guardia's original choice as a candidate for Controller In the last election, was named as First Deputy Controller yesterday by Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller-elect.

Additional contributions of $7,819 to the $200,000 budget campaign of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York City, bringing the total raised to $132,244, were reported yesterday at a luncheon of women campaign workers at the Central Branch Y. W. C. A., 610 Lexington Avenue.

The American markets for the American farmer and a limiting of imports to commodities which farmers in this country cannot produce was urged today by David H. Agans of Three Bridges, N. J., master of the New Jersey Grange for the last eighteen years.

The honors and the acclaim that have been heaped on Kirsten Flagstad as the greatest Isolde and Bruennhilde of the generation have not altered her essential simplicity. Last night, when she finished the first group of her Carnegie Hall recital, she asked an attendant of the hall how he had liked her singing.
St. John's University of Brooklyn overwhelmed St. Peter's College of Jersey City in basketball tonight, 51 to 25, for its second straight victory. The visitors led at the half, 24 to 14.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has asked the Board of Estimate to acquire title to rights of way for the long-discussed series of circumferential parkways connecting Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. With the recommendation Mr. Moses has submitted maps for a definite plan.

Twenty-two men and four youths, the Norwegian crew of the freighter Charles Racine, who started a sitdown strike on board the ship on Saturday night as she was preparing to leave for Pacific ports from Brooklyn, were cleared of disorderly conduct charges in Bay Ridge Court by Magistrate Sweeney yesterday.
His Majesty and 40,000 other spectators saw Oxford University overwhelm Cambridge by 17-4 today in their annual varsity Rugby football match. It was Oxford's first victory since 1932.
The rehabilitation of Manhattan as a residential borough to lower the heavy tax burden on real estate was advocated yesterday by Stanley M. Isaacs, President-elect of the Borough of Manhattan.

The hunt for Mrs. Sarah Flavin, wife of Martin Flavin, a Broadway playwright, and missing since yesterday noon, was concentrated tonight along the Carmel shoreline after searchers found her tripod camera a foot from the edge of a cliff dropping thirty feet to the sea.

Charges that proceedings were conducted in a manner partial to the American Federation of Hosiery Workers, C. I. 0. affiliate, were made at the hearing of the National Labor Relations Board in the Berkshire Mills case here today.
Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming proposed today to put the Wool Top Exchange of New York under Federal regulation after its operations had been criticized before a special Senate committee.
Jane Topping, 22-year-old flier of Hempstead, L. I., flew a new type of plane here today from Detroit in 2 hours 20 minutes, believed to be an unofficial record for the flight of 550 miles.

After the arrest of two more Brooklyn Daily Eagle pickets yesterday on disorderly conduct charges in connection with the strike, the New York Newspaper Guild, through its executive secretary, Milton Kaufman, sent telegrams to Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine protesting an alleged order of Police Inspector Harry L. Lobdell, directing patrolmen assigned to strike duty outside the Eagle plant, to solicit arrests.

Following is the text of the address delivered yesterday by Lammot du Pont before the National Association of Manufacturers in the Hotet Waldorf-Astoria: I cannot stand before you today to speak on the subject of the industrial future without giving the impression of a prophet-which is not intended. I am no prophet.
The most severe cold wave of the season tumbled temperatures throughout Florida to a low of 20 degrees here, a nine-year record. Forecasters said fruit and vegetable damage undoubtedly was extensive.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 4: Wright, Capt. N. H., Long Beach, Calif., to continue treatment at the Naval Hospital. San Diego, Calif., and when discharged to home. relieved from all active duty.

Despite opposition on the ground that he is not sufficiently close to certain financial interests to facilitate the collection of campaign funds, Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican Chairman, is virtually certain of election as a member of the Republican National Committee, it was learned yesterday.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave a luncheon today for the women of the Cabinet circle, and this afternoon was hostess at two teas, inaugurating the Winter season's White House hospitalities.

New York of the future was pictured yesterday by George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association, as a city abundantly dotted with gardens and parks, lined with landscaped parkways and boulevards and having modern, healthful office buildings and apartment houses.

Although the recession in steel ingot output last week was less sharp than in previous weeks, it occurred in face of a steady seasonal trend, and the adjusted index eased to 46.1 from 47.7. The figure for the week ended Dec. 5, 1936, was 118.8.

Alexander D. Noyes, financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has accepted an invitation to serve on a special committee which will cooperate with the Twentieth Century Fund in studying the effect of short selling on security markets.
Fifty actors, stagehands and ushers began a sit-down strike at the Renaissance Theatre last night when the owner served a dispossess notice of the management for non-payment of rent.

Demand for bar and grill equipment and supplies has shrunk to 60 per cent of normal as a result of the recession in business in the last six to eight weeks, I. Arthur Ganger, president of Ganger, Inc., said yesterday at the opening of the Bar, Grill and Tavern Equipment Show at the Park Central Hotel.
Contributions amounting to $8,853 came in yesterday from 315 donors for the benefit of the Neediest Cases Fund. They brought the total to date in the 1937 appeal to $52,853.70.

Although the twenty-sixth annual campaign for the Hundred Neediest Cases is still in its first week, some of the neediest have already been given assurance of the help that will give them a chance to re-establish themselves. The others still need our generosity and our sympathy.
President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that the statement that there is a business recession was an assumption.

Memories of the days when desirable land was selling at less than $5 an acre in Rockland County, and Dutch families figured in many of the realty deals, have been revived by title searches on the property in West Nyack, N. Y., where the Independence Foundation, Inc., is creating the county's second nonprofit cooperative homestead community.

Answering charges that the National Labor Relations Board was biased, favorable to labor, inconsistent, and that personal views weighed its decisions, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director, declared yesterday that the courts, including the nation's highest tribunal, had "almost uniformly sustained" the NLRB.

Secretary Albert Hurter of the German Embassy narrowly escaped death by machine-gun fire yesterday afternoon when driving back from an investigation of the condition of $5,000,000 worth of German machinery at the newly completed Kiangnan cement works at Chihseshan.
In the Supreme Court of the United States Frank A. Reid. A. J. Gustin Priest and Jess H. Rosenberg of New York were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had:
Benjamin F. Schreiber was elected president of the National Democratic Club last night, and proceded to pledge support to President Roosevelt.
The Supreme Court now has a lockup, or what is more vulgarly known as a hoosegow.

Chief Justice Hughes asked an attorney today to attack the Roosevelt power program less vigorously. But the request had nothing to do with the merits of the litigation. Waving his arms and shouting, W. S. O'B. Robinson Jr., counsel for the Duke Power Company, was arguing against government financing of publicly owned power plants.

Count Charles de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General in New York; Colonel Bentley Mott, former United States Military Attache in Paris, and Mrs. Mott; Emil Ludwig and Abbe Ernest Dimnet are booked to sail today for Europe on the French liner Normandie.
Abraham Rosenthal of Opera Dress and Blouse, Inc., was elected head of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers at the association's annual meeting last night at the Park Central Hotel.
Reports that prices on No. 2 cans, used widely for the canning of fruit and vegetables, will advance $1.30 a thousand on Jan. 1, were current in the food industry yesterday.

IT would be an exaggeration to say that Ferdinand Lundberg, biographer of Hearst and former financial writer for The Herald Tribune, is a calm social thinker and an objective historian. Nevertheless, he has written a significant book entitled "America's 60 Families,"* and its significance is likely to increase with the years. For the problem treated is one that will become more and more real as time goes on.
Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. ruled today that savings banks in New York State must pay to the State Controller all dividends and interest that have accrued on abandoned accounts.

With the cooperation of school authorities, the Department of Health gave chest X-ray examinations yesterday to 1,000 boys at Stuyvesant High School, 345 East Fifteenth Street, to determine how many are suffering from tuberculosis.
Mrs. Mary Eddy Fox, widow of Edward Campbell Fox, a member of the New York Stock Exchange died of a heart attack on Monday at her home, 157 East Seventy second Street. Her age was 84.

Edward West Browning, real estate dealer, left an estate of $8,873,520 at the time of his death on Oct. 12, 1934, and it was valued at $7,246,247 on June 30, last, according to an accounting submitted to Surrogate James A. Delehanty yesterday by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, executor of the estate.

Despite vigorous efforts on behalf of Hubert Harrison, Belgrade correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and of Reuters, British news agency, the Yugoslav Government will listen to no representations and has decided to expel him.

The New York Shipbuilding Corporation won the award today of naval construction work for its Camden plant, projecting employment of 5,000 or more men, directly or for materials, on contracts to build a seaplane tender and a destroyer tender and install in them steam-propelled machinery.

Neutral foreign travelers who arrived in Tientsin yesterday reported that all Japanese-owned properties and mills at Tsingtao in Shantung Province suffered in five days of looting by 3,000 members of the long-unpaid peace preservation corps, the police organization.

Verdi's opera, "Otello," will be seen in dress rehearsal by members ot the Metropolitan Opera Guild on Monday, Dec. 20, in the opera house at 10:45 A. M. In making the announcement, Mrs. August Belmont, guild chairman, remarked that the work had not been heard in its entirety at the Metropolitan since 1912.

Aldous Huxley, author of "Eyeless in Gaza" and "Ends and Means" (Harper), will speak at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday evening, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Wheat futures closed 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel lower today after one of the dullest sessions in some time. There was nothing in the news to induce the professional element to take a decided stand on the buying side, and several operators, impressed by the five-day advance, were of the belief that the technical position had been weakened and took profits.

John Wright Jr., 190-pound tackle from Hamburg, N. Y., was elected captain of Columbia's football team for 1938, it was announced last night at the annual Varsity C dinner held at the Columbia University Club.

Notice that the offer of Edward B. Smith 'Co. to make the 5 per cent cumulative preferred shares of the Pure Oil Company available for purchase will be withdrawn at the close of business tomorrow has been received by the committee on secucities of the New York Stock Exchange. The underwriting house has offered up to 5,000 shares at $100 a share, available after Dec. 6.

Thirteen Princes and Princesses of Turkey's former imperial family are suing the former Caliph, Abdul-Medjid II, in a local court to obtain an accounting for properties he has allegedly been holding in trust for them since 1922, when revolution ended the Osman dynasty's reign.

The undergraduate dramatic groups of Amherst and Mount Holyoke Colleges are joining forces in the production of Anton Chekhov's comedy, "The Three Sisters," under the direction of Professor Curtis Canfield of Amherst, in College Hall, Amherst, on Thursday and Friday evenings, and in Chapin Auditorium, South Hadley, on Saturday.

Allen W. Rucker, president of the Eddy-Rucker-Nickels Company, marketing counsel, and author of "Labor's Road to Plenty," will speak at the second dinner meeting of the season of the Commodity Club of New York in the Park Central Hotel on Dec. 16.

Princeton University's hockey team continued its winning ways tonight on the Hobey Baker Memorial ice and in a loosely played encounter conquered the Manhattan Arrows, 3--1, for its third consecutive triumph of the young campaign.
After Nanking's fall there will be a pause in military operations, and the Chinese reactions will be allowed to clarify before the Japanese Government makes decisions regarding its future policy.

Minimum wage laws will improve conditions for American workers only if care is taken that the lowest permitted wage does not become the maximum, nor even the prevailing wage in the industries affected, Mrs. Roosevelt said today.

A memorial service was held this afternoon in Vassar College chapel in honor of Moritz A. Geiger, Professor of Philosophy at Goettingen University from 1923 to 1933 and at Vassar from 1934 until his death last September.

Robert Owen Lord of New York, former Detroit banker, and Mrs. Carol Newberry Brooks, daughter of for mer United States Senator Truman H. Newberry from Michigan, were married here at 5 o'clock this afternoon, three hours after Mr. Lord's marriage to Mrs. Marie Leopold Lord had been terminated by divorce.

The number of commercial fallures in the United States in the week ended Dec. 2, showed increases in all groups as compared with a year ago, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Constance Worth, film actress from Australia, won a divorce today from George Brent, who failed in an attempt several weeks ago to annul their Mexican marriage.

The engagement has been announced of Lady Patricia Douglas, 19-year-old daughter of the Marquess of Queensberry and his first wife, now Lady Dunn, to Count John De Bendern, better known as John De Forest, amateur golfer.

In recognition of twenty years of service to the people of Greece and the Near Eastern refugees, Dr. William E. Doughty will be made a Grand Commander of the Greek Order of the Phoenix today as part of the opening ceremonies of the refugee handicraft bazaar of the Near East Foundation, at 2 West Forty-sixth Street.

Joseph W. Catharine of Brooklyn, president-elect of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, was honored by his fellow-members of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Bossert.
Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone granted today motions for directed verdicts of acquittal for three more individual defendants in the government's gasoline price-fixing case.

A permanent first mortgage of $25,000 on the show room and service station building, on a plot 100x100 at the 8 w cor of Queens Blvd and 66th. Ave, Forest Hills, L. I., has been placed through the Herbert Callman Company, brokers. The Forest Hills Heights Corp building.

The American Federation of Labor announced plans yesterday for the organization of a new union of seamen serving on ships operating from Atlantic and Gulf ports as competitor of the National Maritime Union, whose members favor affiliation with the C. I. O.

Dr. George Ross Starr of this city, formerly president of the New Jersey Osteopathic Society and onetime secretary of the New York Osteopathic Society, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital at the age of 58. He underwent an operation three weeks ago.

Brief memorial services were held yesterday at the Maine Monument in Columbus Circle by the Comite Pro-Cuba in honor of those who died fighting for Cuba's independence and those who lost their lives in the Maine disaster. The day was Cuban Memorial Day.

Governor Charles H. Martin moved today to end the 118-day tie-up of the Portland lumber industry by ordering a series of employe elections in the face of the nation-wide boycott by the American Federaton of Labor against C. I. O. lumber and the National Labor Relations Board's certification of the C. I. O. Sawmill Union as the mill workers' agency for collective bargaining.

After several years of industrious apprentice work, Cornella Otis Skinner has extended the onewoman theatre to include a fulllength play, "Edna His Wife," in which she acted all the speaking parts at the Little last evening.

Herbie Katz, 166, of Brownsville, Score scored a technical knockout over Eddie Maguire, 165 pounds, of Ireland, in 0:32 of the seventh of their scheduled eight-round bout before 3,000 persons at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Referee Jim Crowley intervened when a cut over Maguire's right eye bled profusely. At the time Katz was far ahead on points.
Apartment house projects for the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens were filed with the Building Department yesterday.

Despite the continued absence of Arthur Fried from his home in White Plains, members of his family expressed confidence in his early safe return and scoffed at reports that he was being held for $200,000 ransom.

Within a few moments after leaving his house to attend--a church Christmas-season play in which four of his seven children were appearing, Patrolman Edward P. Lynch, 41 years old, attached to the West Sixty-eighth Street police station, was shot and killed at 8:10 o'clock last night near his home, 3,250 Fenton Avenue, the Bronx.

Gross assets, $30,656; net, $26,833. To sister, Vilma Anderson. $1,000 and life interest in specific realty; Klovidals Comun Klovedals Sacken, $1,000; daughter. Alice B. J. Petterson, $1,000 and pictures, stamps and photographs with albums; son, Olaf J. Anderson, $1,000;

After holding within the narrowest range of the entire season for four hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased in the last at hour to end with losses of 3 to 6 points, or 15 to 30 cents a bale. Uncertainty over the outcome of farm legislation as well as today's annual government crop estimate curtailed the volume of new business.

In the final match of the Class B interclub team play of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association the Rockaway Hunting Club defeated the Junior League, 5 to 0, on the latter's courts yesterday.

Dr. Carlos Brenes Jarquin, former President of Nicaragua and former Minister to Washington, delivered today a United States Treasury check for damages incurred during the occupation by United States Marines more than fifteen years ago.

Overloaded inventories, the chief reason for the 1920 depression, have similarly brought about the present recession in business, Jack Jones, vice president of the Alexander Hamilton Institute, yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Turpentine firm, 26 1/4c; sales, 57 barrels; receipts, 219 barrels; shipments, 85 barrels; stock, 38,126 barrels. Resin firm sales, 701: receipts, 2.080; no shipments; stock, 84,888. Quote: B. D. E. $4.60; F. $5.15; G. $5.20; H. $5.25; I, $5.30; K. $5.45; $5.75; N, $5.90; WG, $6.50; WW. X, $6.85.

The third annual wassail bowl party of the British Empire Chamber of Commerce was attended by a large gathering of persons prominent in American, British and Continental society yesterday at the British Empire Exhibition Building, Rockefeller Center.

Mrs. Ernest R. Adee has left her home in Tuxedo Park and will be for the Winter at 161 East Seventieth Street, where her granddaughters, the Misses Barbara and Geraldine Bradley, will join her for the holidays.
Commander Robert Donohue has been assigned as commandant of the new Coast Guard air station at Floyd Bennett Airport, Brooklyn, effective Dec. 15, it was announced today.
Republicans elected their entire city ticket and eight of ten members of the Board of Aldermen in the biennial city election today, thus ending eight years of Demooratio rule,

Contemplated restrictions on investments by insurance companies, particularly in common stocks and mortgage loans, were criticized yesterday by officials in the insurance business at a public hearing of the joint legislative committee for revision of the insurance laws, held in the State Building.

Estate, $1,500. To Beryl C. Gale, cousin, 113 Park St., Groton, N. Y., Lucie C. Nixon, cousin. 708 Jackson St., Dallas, Texas, Cecil Childs Baldwin, Riverdale Country School, Eleanore A. Cross, 59 W. 76th St., Dorothy McJohnson, 3,716 79th St., Jackson Heights, Lilian McClintic, executrix, 3,716 79th St., Jackson Heigths, and Lillian M.
Charles W. Pry, vice president of the Chicago Board of Education and a labor leader in the city for many years, died today at the Ravenswood Hospital. He was 68 yars old.

Miss Eleanor May Kent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Kent of this place, was married to George Thomas Duram, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Duram of Scarsdale and Springfield, Ill., this morning in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church here.

Relinquishing the position of president of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., which he has held since the organization of the concern in 1914, H. Hobart Porter assumed yesterday the duties of chairman of the board of the company and in his place Earle S. Thompson, executive vice president, was elected president.

A new drug compounded from allantoin, the healing properties of which were determined about two years ago by scientists of the United States Bureau of Entomology, has been invented and, in the opinion of medical authorities, offers "great promise" in the treatment of gastric ulcers, it was learned yesterday.

Properties of varied types in many sections of the Bronx were reported yesterday by brokers as having changed hands. The six-story apartment house on an irregular plot 100 by 100 feet at 1,024 Fox Street, near 165th Street, was sold by its former trustees to a client of the Kempner Realty Corporation, broker in the deal.
The Treaty of Ghent ended the War of 1812 the day before Christmas 122 years ago, but the government still has two pensioners on the rolls of that war.

Nazi reports that Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg was seeking an accord with the Social Democrats were discredited today by the news that thirty former Socialist leaders had been arrested in simultaneous raids on various homes early on the morning of Nov. 27. The news leaked out today.
The Port of New York Authority has filed a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking dismissal of a petition by Philadelphia for a readjustment of rates on water-borne commerce.
The texts of the opinions and memoranda in the Goldfinger picketing case handed down by the Court of Appeals today were as follows:

A delegation of miners and merchants from the anthracite region warned Mayor Wilson and the'City Council today that introduction of natural gas into Philadelphia would ruin this city's $132,000,000 merchandise market in the hard-coal area.

The Hellenic Bank Trust Company of 51 Maiden Lane has not had any solicitors seeking deposits from Greek-Americans for more than five years, Evangelos Hardapoulas, president of the bank, told Ambrose V. McCall,

The Sacred Bundle of the Water Busters clan of the Gros Ventre Indians of North Dakota is to be returned to them. In exchange, the Museum of the American Indian will receive from Foolish Bear and Drags Wolf, elders of the Water Busters, a sacred Buffalo Medecine Horn.

Regulations governing the operation of the new housing program under the Wagner-Steagall act were anbounced today by Nathan Straus, head of the United States Housing Authority, after all-day discussions with housing officials not represented at a preliminary conference last month.

70th St, 261-269 W, 56x100.5; Emma Janoff to Najof Holding Corp, 1,425 Teller Ave (50c). 98th St, 37-41 W, 50x100.11; Paniute Hanast to 302 11th Ave Corp, 76 Beaver St; mtg $44,500; p m $6,000 ($12). St Nicholas Ave, 1,091-1,099, 86.3x124x irreg; New York Savings Bank to 540 W 115th St Corp. 345 7th Ave; mtg 170,00; p m $27,000 ($237).

As the police make plans to get unnecessarily parked vehicles off the streets of midtown Manhattan, Mr. Robert Moses comes forward with a proposal to open the heart of the city to the great parkways of Westchester and Long Island.

One of the oldest fireproof business buildings in the city figured in the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday. The four-story and basement bank structure on the northeast corner of Seventh Street and Third Avenue, known as 59-61 Cooper Square, which was the home of the Metropolitan Savings Bank from 1867 to 1935, has been sold to the First Ukrainian Evangelical Pentecostal Church, Inc., which will use it for religious purposes.

De Witt Clinton High's quintet, 1936-37 city P. S. A. L. ruler, registered its second straight triumph of the season by downing Haaren, 52 to 29, at Clinton yesterday. The game was one of many non-tournament tests played by New York City schoolboy fives.

A Christmas dance in honor of Miss Anne Clark, fiance of John Roosevelt, and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., the former Miss Ethel du Pont, to be attended by about 400 young people, and the usual children's party for the very young members of the White House family, are features of the holiday program announced today by Mrs. Roosevelt.

About 1,500 members and guests of the Economic Club of New York heard the present and past policies of the New Deal attacked last night as largely responsible for the current business recession by critics of the Administration, and the prospects for its future in leading the way to a balanced budget praised by its friends.

Personnel of the jury of award and details of the seventh competition for the Irwin D. Wolf awards for distinctive merit in packaging were announced yesterday by the American Management Association, sponsoring organization.

Recent unconfirmable rumors to the effect that Valery I. Mezhlauk, chairman of the State Planning Commission and well known in America where he has spent much time, was in difficulties received new impetus today.
