Three of America's foremost men of science were the principal speakers yesterday afternoon before the Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the National Association of Manufacturers.

The listings of commercial rentals announced yesterday carried a number of leases for full-floor units of space. Many involved the occupancy of new quarters, while several renewals for extensive areas also appeared.
Keeping the promise made ten days ago by its president, Charles R. Gay, in a message to William O Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the governing committee of the New York

Search along the rocky Carmel shoreline for the missing Mrs. Martin Flavin, 54, wife of the Broadway playwright, was intensified tonight after a blue half-sock Identified as hers was found near the edge of a cliff.

" Utterly disgusted" with th cowardice of some management today, because of a "flicker of the stock market," Gerald E. Stedman vice president in charge of marke planning, Cramer-Krasselt Com pany, Milwaukee, yesterday urge a luncheon meeting of the New York Business Paper Editors al the Town Hall Club, to campaign against the practices of such indus trialists.
Eight sophomores at the University of Delaware were suspended today for an indefinite period for their part in the "branding" of three freshmenl during a hazing party on Nov. 12.

The Mexican Government maintained strict silence today on the speech Monday in which Sumner Welles, United States Under-Secretary of State. indicated that the United States would allow the division of landed estates of its nationals in Latin America but would insist on equitable payment.

Trapped and surrounded by Japanese troops at the summit of a coneshaped peak along the Tangshan Road twelve miles from Nanking, 300 Chinese soldiers were annihilated almost to a man during a dramatic engagement lasting throughout yesterday.

A recommendation that the State Superintendent of Insurance have the power to fix annually the interest rate on loans against new life insurance policies between limits of 4 1/2 and 6 per cent was made yesterday by Superintendent Louis H. Pink to the joint legislative committee for revision of the insurance laws.
Industrial properties In Brooklyn figured in a majority of the realty deals in the borough reported yesterday.
The Eastern college football teams, leading contributors of individual stars to the All-America lists, also were supreme in competition against rivals from other sectors.

Final statistics for the 1937 National Football League season as announced yesterday reveal that four new individual records were established and that only two ol seven leaders retained top rankling in their specialties. Passers and aerial receivers accounted for the new marks.
The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today that the total area estimated as sown to principal field crops in 1937 was

The training of officers and unlicensed personnel for service in the merchant marine is a duty of the Federal Government and should be undertaken immediately if the American merchant marine is to continue to compete with ships of foreign nations, according to Commander Robert C. Lee.

Another fascinating and thrilling program of events on ice and snow, with skiing occupying the feature role, was staged last night in the transformed Alpine setting of Madison Square Garden as the second annual North American Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet ended its second day of a fiveday run.
Fourteen giant patrol planes roared off the waters of San Diego Bay today on the United States Navy's greatest massed non-stop flight. Their goal was Coco Solo, Canal Zone, 3,080 miles away.
The Orioles of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League took a 4-1 lead during the first period tonight but blew up in the last two periods and the Rovers won, 8-6.

Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, addressing the annual dinner of the New York County Lawyers Association last night, appealed for a new liberal spirit on the part of members of the bar toward proposals that will be made at the State constitutional convention.
THIRD MILITARY AREA So much of Paragraph 1, Special Orders 124, as pertains to the assignment of 1st Lt. Charles WV. Stoddard, Finance Reserve, to headquarters, 7Sth Division. Is revoked.

Foreign newspapers are engaged in campaigns to sell the public on buying advertised products and to sell advertisers on the advantages of running copy consistently, George Bijur, head of the advertising agency of that name, yesterday told members of the New York Newspaper Promotion Group at a luncheon at the Advertising Club.

Trade Minister Euler disclosed tonight that the Canadian Wheat Board had disposed of all of its holdings. It inherited 200,000,000 bushels in 1935. Mr. Euler said he believed the board had held lately 7,000,000
C. O. Wellington of the Harvard Club, former champion, captured a semi-final-round match in the veterans' squash racquets tournament at the University Club yesterday.
A city-wide building program calling for the construction of thirtyeight schools for $45,603,500 was voted by the Board of Education yesterday. When completed,

Dr. Charles L. Parsons, secretary of the American Chemical Society, announced yesterday that Professor James E. Kendall, head of the Department of Chemistry at Edinburgh University, Scotland, had given $1,000 to the society for the 1938 American Chemical Society Award in Pure Chemistry.

Today's major events: "Tannhaeuser," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Jeanne Gautier, violinist, Town Hall, 3; Federal Symphony Orchestra, WPA Theatre of Music, evening.

A British survey of world aircraft today noted an "enormous" increase in the size and efficiency of the United States air force to "one of the biggest and possibly the most efficiently armed" in the world.
President Stenio Vincent charged today that 8,000 Haitians had been victims of "mass murder" on territory of the Dominican republic since October.

Lawrenceville's basketball team opened its season by defeating Germantown Academy, 45-36, today. The victors were paced by Tutwiler and Marquardt, with 16 points apiece, while Captain Biedler led the scoring for the losers with 11.
Declaring that the trial was a "travesty on justice," County Judge Brancato in Brooklyn ordered a jury yesterday to acquit Detective Daniel R. Sullivan of a charge of

The Interior Department made public today the annual report of Governor Blanton Winship of Puertc Rico, who said that the island had risen to the rank of sixth place among world customers of the United States mainland.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 397-Duke Power Co., et al., peters, ov Greenwood County and E. L. Brooks, et at Argument continued for respondents, concluded for Petitioners.

The contracts recently negotiated with the operators of the largest taxicab fleets have been reopened and revised to afford 15,000 drivers an opportunity to earn from 10 to 25 per cent more, the Transport Workers Union announced yesterdav.

Petey Sarron of Birmingham, Ala., former world featherweight champion, made his first appearance as a lightweight at the Hippodrome last night and gained a decision over Carl Guggino of Tampa, Fla., in ten slashing rounds before a crowd of 2,500. Sarron weighed 133 1/2 pounds and Guggino 130 1/2.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York, at its monthly meeting yesterday in the assembly room of the Merchants' Association, approved proposed legislation to create an agency similar to the Railway Labor Board to rule on maritime labor problems and place coastwise as well as intercoastal freight rates under control of the Maritime Commission.

Having settled the great issue between them, which resulted in the recovery by Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris of the world championship at chess, the new titleholder and Dr. Max Euwe, dethroned after twenty-five games, settled down tonight to a continuance of their play in the remaining five contests in fulfillment of their contract.

Cadeau II, owned by Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark, topped the moneywinners among the French steeplechase horses that were brought to this country last January by a committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association. His earnings were $10,850 in nine starts, of which he won four.

The marriage of Miss Ida Maria Bonzi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ercole Bonzi of Pasadena, Calif., to Charles Watkins Lewis of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Baskerville Lewis of Danville, Va., took place here yesterday morning in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Philip Watson of 1,125 Fifth Avenue will give a tea on Dec. 21 at their home to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Monique Watson. The debutante who attended the Chapin School, this city,

Willie Lee Johnson, the nation's secondranking jockey, from Philpot, Ky., had another of his good days at the Fair Grounds today when he brought home three winners and finished in the money in two other events.

Contributions from Cornelius V. Whitney and Miss Edith Scoville of $2,500 each were added yesterday to the total collected in the United Hospital Campaign, according to an announcement by George J. Lyons, vice chairman. A $2,000 gift came from Robert Beaver Smith.

Steps were taken yesterday to dissolve the Power Securities Corporation, a subsidiary of the Electric Power and Light Company which controls the Idaho Power Company. This is a continuation of the program seeking the elimination of intermediate concerns in the Electric Power and Light system.

When St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia faces C. C. N. Y. at Madison Square Garden in one game of the opening double-header of the season on Dec. 18, those present will see one of the really good teams of the last few years.

The visit of Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France began this morning under highly favorable auspices, but the practical results it will have are another matter. On his arrival M. Delbos was received by officials of the Rumanian Foreign Office and his own legation.

Miss Mary K. O'Connor, 19-year-old college athlete, was ordered held in $5,000 bail for the grand jury today after a coroner's jury had completed a second inquest in the death of Nancy Glenn, 5, on Labor Day.

The New York County grand jury yesterday handed up to General Sessions Judge Freschi a first-degree murder indictment against Joseph Healy, 17 years old, of 41 Renwick Street. Healy is accused of the fatal stabbing of Mrs. Martha Hore, 65, in the robbery of her grocery at 564 Greenwich Street last Nov. 26.

A promising Princeton University basketball team pried the lid off its 1937-38 campaign tonight in the university gymnasium by turning back the Red Devils of Dickinson College, 47-32. It was also the initial game of the season for the visitors.
The University of Newark defeated the Wagner College quintet tonight, 55 to 30. Nick Halulakos of the victors led the scorers with 14 points.

If the President nominates Hugh R. Wilson to succeed Professor William E. Dodd as Ambassador to Germany it will be another welcome example of the practice-fortunately becoming less exceptional-of naming "career" men to the highest diplomatic posts.

Testfmony that the Berkshire Knitting Mills interfered with collective bargaining by discouraging employes from joining the American Federation of Hosiery Workers and promoting a company union was given by Jacob Englehart,

Although the stock market here continued quietly today, there was a steadier tendency, assisted by the rally in Wall Street. Gilt-edge issues, after being dull, improved in late trading, while among the foreign loans Far Eastern bonds hardened.

Sixty members of the United Automobile Workers of America were arrested for "obstructing traffic" this afternoon when they distributed union literature at the Miller Road gates of the Ford Motor Company in defiance of an order by Dearborn city officials.

longshoremen's strike, which has tied up the Merchants and Miners Transportation' Company terminal here since mid-November, spread today to the company's terminals in Boston, Providence and Philadelphia.
Except for a moderate amount of activity in commercial paper, the money market experienced another quiet session. Rates for all classifications of loans remained unchanged.
Mr. and Mrs. George B. St. George, who have been at Mayfair House for several weeks, sailed on the Normandie to pass the Winter in Paris.

The problem of picketing has assumed such large proportions--for municipal authorities, for the lower courts, for the police and for the public generally-that the findings of the Court of Appeals in its decision handed down on Tuesday have a special importance.

William P. Devou, capitalist, died at St. Mary's Hospital today of pneumonia. He was 83 years old. Mr. Devou, whose name was widely known in Cincinnati, lived in the poorest part of the city, despite his wealth.
Six persons were dead in New York State tonight as a result of two days of snowstorms which left traffic snarled and hazardous. More snow was forecast before morning.
Miss Agnes Franklin Keyes will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 115 East Sixty-seventh Street, for officers and directors of the Lots for Little Shop, of which she is president and founder.

Miss Beverly Lane, 18-year-old Chicagoan, made her operatic debut tonight before a capacity Chicago City Opera Company audience as Gilda in "Rigoletto," and "triumphantly demonstrated the magnitude of her natural gifts," according to Edward Barry, music critic of The Chicago Tribune.

Twelve bad. textile companies participated in contracts awarded under Invitation 101, calling for twenty items of various types of textiles, at the Quartermaster Depot here today. They were as follows:
Joe McCarthy, manager of the world-champion Yankees, and Larry Kelley of Yale fame, now football coach at Peddie School, will be the principal speakers for the third annual dinner of the Green and
With much of what Mr. Lewis Douglas had to say of the present business reaction, in his address of Tuesday at the Economic Club's dinner, there will be full agreement.
Sales of the leading mail order and chain store companies increased in November, but the effects of business uncertainty were more apparent than in preceding months.
John L. Kronenberg, of the American Lithographic Division, has been elected president of the newly organized Young Lithographers Association, it was announced yesterday. Other new officers are W.

M. L. Urann of South Hanson, a cranberry grower, said today that growers in Massachusetts, Wisconsin and New Jersey had added 60,000 barrels of cranberries to their canning pool because of a fear that this year's record crop would flood the market.

Governor Francis P. Murphy of New Hampshire, one of the few Republican candidates to escape the Roosevelt landslide, declared today that "the best thing that could happen to the Republican party would be for every member of the national committee to resign."

Mott St, 174-8, n e cor Broome St; Samuel Plumer, referes, to Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, 346 Bway; foreclosure ($1). 70th St, 251 W; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee, to Samuel Lax, 170 Bway, trustee; mtg $11,000.

The New York World's Fair board of design has selected Miss Augusta Savage, New York Negro sculptor and one of the leading artists of her race, to execute a sculptural group symbolic of the unique contribution made by the American Negro to the world's

Unofficial estimates involving the claims of Tennessee's junior United States Senator, George L. Berry, and his associates against the United States for marble deposits underlying lands now flooded by the Tennessee Valley Authority's Norris
Abraham Rosenthal of Opera Dress and Blouse, Inc., has been elected president of the National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., succeeding Lou Brecher, it was announced yesterday.

In so many of the Neediest Cases the description of the need is followed by an "if"-the outcome is put into the subjunctive mood: "If" friends will aid Case 1 now, she will not always be an "outsider."

The marriage of Captain Hans Amlie, commanded of the Lincoln-Washington Battalion on the Belchite front, and Mrs. Mildred Mitchell, known in journalistic circles from Moscow to Shanghai as "Millie Bennett," was announced today. The ceremony occurred at Albacete, Dec. 1.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today:

The name of Walter E. Treanor, judge of the Indiana Supreme Court, has been sent to the White House for consideration by President Roosevelt to fill the vacancy on the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago.

Mrs. Rosa D. Barker, 45 years old, wife of Thompson P. Barker, stock broker, died yesterday at her home, 410 East Fifty-seventh Street, following what detectives of the East Fifty-first Street police _ station described as an apparent overdose of a sedative.
Two alternative policies are slowly emerging from the clouds of speculation, rumor and argument that the impending fall of Nanking is releasing in the press.
The Genesee Publishing Company has filed articles of incorporation here preparatory to starting a new daily newspaper in this city. Capital is set at $1,100,000,

The American Aid Society at Nice revealed yesterday that it had been instrumental in repatriating Margaret Gozmanian, 14 years old, an American girl, who had been "sold" in marriage for $135 to a 40-year-old farmer near Lyon.

An exhibition of small paintings, works in black and white, and sculpture opened last evening at the National Arts Club in Gramercy Park. These have been contributed by artist members, and Henry R. Rittenberg, chairman of the art committee,
Segundo Albino Roman, Consul General of Nicaragua in New York and a former Supreme Court Justice of his country, died here today in Hahnemann Hospital. He was 71 years old.

" Everything is under control * * * leave everything to me and don't worry," Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City wrote in a special delivery letter mailed to night to twenty-six Representatives who had sent

Sectional football champions of New Jersey were selected tonight at the annual meeting of the executive committee of the New Jersey State i Interscholastic Athletic Association held in the Stacey Trent Hotel.
John A. Olsen of 46 Circle Avenue, an accountant with the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York, was listed today as a missing person in an eight-State police teletype alarm.

When the Federal Wage-Hour Bill is called up in the House the Labor Committee itself will have about sixty amendments to offer. As the nature of these amendments has been indicated only vaguely, it is impossible for any one to know precisely what the effect of the revised measure is likely to be.

Colonel Theodore W. McCullough, former editor of The Omaha Bee-News and since its suspension a member of The Omaha World-Herald staff, died early today at the age of 75. Colonel McCullough began newspaper work at 12 and served on Omaha newspapers for forty-eight years.

Norman K. Winston of New York, who with a group of associates is understood to be planning a huge apartment development on the Holmes Airport property in Queens, has arranged an appointment with Stewart McDonald tomorrow to negotiate for possible Federal Housing Administration aid.

Bradbury F. Cushing, manager of the Hotel Statler, Boston, since 1927, has been appointed manager of all the properties of the Hotels Statler Company, Inc., in New England. D. B. Stanbro has been promoted from the post of resident manager of the Hotel Statler, Boston, to that of manager.

House and Senate managers of the general farm legislation made plans today to pass their respective bills Friday after the House smothered an attempt to write into its measure provisions for mandatory "parity" loans on all farm products and the Senate, by a single vote,

The four-story business building at 145 West Sixty-third Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, has been leased by the Oquossoo Realty Corporation to the S. A. E. Motor Parts Company for offices and a service station. The HaggstromCallen-Davis Company was the broker.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Frances Marie Sarner, daughter of Mrs. Eva Joseph Sarner of this place, to Harold Zirkin of Washington.
A cotton crop 50 per cent greater than that of last year and the largest in the history of the United States was predicted today for 1937 by the Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture.

Speaking as a friendly. critic of the Administration's Social Security Act and the pending wage and hour legislation, Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, asserted at a luncheon meeting of the Bond Club yesterday that administration of the proposed Wages and Hours Bill would be "well nigh impossible and would add tremendously to our already great costs of government."

Now that the Fall flights are over in this zone, Fred Jordan, director of the National Wildlife Restoration Week, has come forward with several arguments, many of them sound, in defense of the United States Bureau of Biological Survey, that body which has come in for so much criticism from wildfowlers this year.

Dr. C. J. Keppel, headmaster of the Tome School, tonight persuaded students to call off their strike against his dismissal and go back to their classes tomorrow. Earlier in the day the students, had cheered him but refused to end f the strike.
The Columbia University Club's Class A squash tennis team retained second place in the Metropolitan League race last night by virtue of a victory over the Haryard Club.
The National Sugar Institute, to assure that Cuba will fill the 1937 quota for the United States, resolved tonight to release 104,400 long tons for immediate shipment.
Miss L. Annie Whitney, whose interest in music brought many noted concert artists here under sponsorship of Greenfield's Woman's Club, died at her High Street home today after a brief illness.

Holluschickie, Mrs. P. A. Shaw's 3-year-old bay colt, conquered five other racers in a strong field today to win the Morgan Handicap over the Charles Town course of a little more than six furlongs. The victor returned $17.60 for $2.

A statement that the action of Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson of Chicago in giving "private consideration" to proposals submitted to him by counsel representing Kuhn, Loeb Co. and the National City Company of New York in connection with the receivership of the Chicago, Milwaukee St. Paul Railroad in 1925,

Robert Frothingham, who was one of the most prominent advertising managers of the early 1900's, died in San Francisco on Tuesday, according to word received here by his son, Donald Frothingham. He had been ill for only a short time. He was in his seventy-second year. Mr. Frothingham made a name for himself as advertising manager of Life, humorous magazine, in the first five years of this century.
It was estimated today by Nat C. Murray, statistician for Clement, Curtis Co., that 57,530,000 acres of Winter wheat were seeded for the 1938 crop, the largest area on record.

A "cheap and dangerous burglar" who for months has victimized residents of the Wakefield section of the Bronx was sought last night as the slayer of Patrolman Edward P. Lynch, killed on Tuesday night, when he tried to apprehend the marauder near his home, 3,250 Fenton Avenue, the Bronx.

Dr. Bayard Dodge, president of the American University of Beirut and International College, Syria, was guest of honor last night. at a dinner given by the Near East College Association in the Music Room of the Biltmore.

A recital will be given on the afternoon of Dec. 20 at the home of Mrs. Shepard Fabbri, 7 East Ninety-fifth Street, for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York at 283 Lexington Avenue, a club and a home for the 10,000 enlisted service men stationed in the neighborhood of the city.

Stocks closed steadier at fractionally higher levels after extending Tuesday's gains 1 to 3 points; turnover, 1,520,330 shares. United States Government and speculative rail bonds steady, foreign issues higher; transactions, $10,010,700.

165th St. 650 E (10-2632); Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Frank B. Olsenbuttei 89-51 Metropolitan Ave. West Forest Hills, N Y; mtg $18,000. 160th St, 318 E (9-2419); Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Barwein Realty Corp, 48 W 125th St; mtg $10,000.
THE NEW YORK TIMES said today in a dispatch from its Washington bureau that President Roosevelt characterized as an assumption the statement that there is a business recession.

President Roosevelt's asserted intentions to balance the Federal budget were called insincere today by Republicans, who charged that he was imposing upon Congress the responsibility of making needed reductions in the expenditures for the next fiscal year.

Miss Jessie Hixon, formerly for twenty years general secretary of the Brooklyn Association for. Improving the Condition of the Poor, died yesterday at her residence, Butler Hall, 88 Morningside Drive, Manhattan, after an illness of ten months. She was 78 years old.

Federal funds totaling $30,500,000 were earmarked today for eight cities including Syracuse and Bridgeport, whose low-cost house plans as discussed by their representatives with Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, were approved.

The President has decided upon the appointment of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, as Ambassador to Great Britain. This was learned tonight from an authoritative source.

A display of samples of foreign and domestic products will be a feature of the Central American and Antilles Olympic Games to be held in Panama City in February, according to an announcement sent out by the Pro-Tourist Board of the Province of Panama.

Mysterious Betty Carstairs, former British speed-boat racer, emerged today from the seclusion in which she had hidden since she acquired a private island in the Bahamas several years ago, to aid a yacht in distress.

Dentists attending the annual Greater New York dental meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday were told by Dr. Douglas Quick. cancer authority, that it was advisable "from the clinical cancer standpoint" for them to extract the third molar, commonly known as the wisdom tooth, when it Is "open to question" as a point of infection.

Secretary Roper announced today that when the foreign trade figures for 1937 were completed they would show a favorable trade balance of close to $100,000,000 and perhaps more. Last year exports exceeded imports by $33,000,000, Mr. Roper said.

Falastin, the leading Arab newspaper in Palestine, will print tomorrow a report that a compromise has been reached in negotiations between Jewish and Arab leaders. The negotiations were said to have been started by Nuri Pasha as-Said, former Premier of Iraq,

A copy of the first edition of Washington Irving's "The Sketch Book," in the original parts, uncut, brought $1,300 yesterday afternoon at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the library of Dr. William C. Braislin of Brooklyn.

The National Bituminous Coal Commission late today announced that it would hold a hearing in Washington Dec. 14 on protests filed by nine producing companies which are dissatisfied with the minimum prices published by the commission last week.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on "American Aloofness" has called forth so many suggestive comments that I am emboldened to make one myself.
Prince Said Halim, second cousin of King Farouk of Egypt, and the Countess Blanche Louise Marika Posse of Sweden were married here at Caxton Hall today.

The list of the steamship Ausonia of the Cunard White Star Line, sailing today, includes Captain W. G. S. Anderson, G. E. Green, Miss Katherine V. Spencer, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Archbold, A. S. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. J. G. P. Wilson and Miss Phoebe Emery.
Miss Mary F. Maguire, a teacher in Public School 41, 36 Greenwich Avenue, Manhattan, for more than forty years, died Tuesday at her home, 104-77 126th Street, Richmond Hill; Queens.

Sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States and Canada and shipments overseas combined totaled 195,136 units in November, compared to 191,720 in November, 1936, thereby setting a new high record for the month.
Dodd, United States Ambassador to Germany, announced in a formal statement today that he was retiring "early in January." By that time, it is assumed, Hugh R. Wilson, Assistant Secretary of State,

ANDERSON-Florence M., Dec. 7, 1937, beloved wife of Harry Anderson. Funeral services at her residence, 950 Grant Ave., Pelham Manor, N. Y., on Saturday, Dec. 11, 10 A. M. BAKER-Elizabeth Colt Hand, widow of Dr. Arthur Latham Baker and mother of Mrs. J. Roy Allen, at her residence, 101 East 75th St., Dec. 7. Funeral prlvate.

The Bureau of Navigation released the folloWing orders today dated Dec. 6.4 CAPTAIN Church. A. '.. New York. N. Y.. to office of the Director of Shore Establishments, Navy Department. Washington, D. C.

Movements In the livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 22,000, Including 5,000 directs. Early market steady to 10 cents lower than yesterday's average,

Despondent since the death of his wife a year ago, Lawrence A. Boynton, 49 years old, New York bond broker, shot and killed himself today, according to county authorities, in a garage at the rear of his home at 224 Cleveland Street here.
Long Island University's basketball team earned its second victory in as many starts by defeating Panzer College last night on the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court, 87 to 34.

In his first public speech in Germany, Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten Germans in Czechoslovakia, today proIclaimed again the ideological and cultural unity, of all Germans throughout the world.
A special session of the Legislature to approve the New York City administrative code was ordered by Governor Lehman today, to convene Thursday, Dec. 16.
The War DeIg ment released the following orders tdda9% dated Dec. 7: LIEUTENANI' COLONELS Watts, L., Signal Corps, one month leave Dec. 8. with permission to visit foreiga countries.

The current depression will be a deep one but may run itself out by Spring, C. W. Young, president of the C. W. Young Management Corportion, said yesterday in a speech before the weekly luncheon meeting of the Executives Club at the Hotel Astor.
WORLD HISTORY OF THE DANCE, by Dr Curt Sachs. (Norton, $5.) The dance from the Stone Age to the present. FIRST PERSON PLURAL, by Angna Enters. (Stackpole, $4.) Reminiscences of the dancer.

With second-grade and speculative railroad issues leading the way, the bond market spurted ahead yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. A steady demand which marked the opening developed with renewed surges that swelled the volume of sales to the largest since Nov. 19.

Miss Alice Susan Chadwick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Chadwick of this place, was married to Dr. Raymond Abbott Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon A. Taylor, also of Lakewood, here today at All Saints Episcopal Church. The Rev. John M. Hunter officiated.

Offering will be made today by John J. Bergen Co., Ltd., of 95,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation of Bethpage, L. I. The shares will be offered by means of a prospectus at $9 a share. The net proceeds will be used by the company to pay notes held by certain stockholders and for additional working capital.
A hint that Great Britain may build a naval base on the Island of Cyprus in the Eastern Mediterranean was given by Admiral Sir Herbert Richmond last night.
A charge by Frank B. .Powers, president of the Commercial Telegraphers Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate, that "subordinate officials of the National Labor Relations Board had given preferential
An optimistic outlook forl938 in the retail building materials field is indicated in a survey sponsored by the Johns-Manville Corporation.
Taking it by and large and year in and year out, Max and Min get more attention than any other couple. Their marriage is an open scandal.

In his initial match in the fourth annual invitation squash racquets tourney being staged by the Squash Club for Class B players, Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club justified his No. 1 seeding by defeating G. V. Coe Jr. of the Union League in comparatively easy fashion yesterday.

Maximilian William Korhammer, Civil War veteran and former St. Louis business man, died yesterday in his home here after a brief illness. Mr. Korhammer had lived for the last ten years with his sonin-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander F. Stoeger. His age was 93.

SERGEANTS--Frank G. Spottke, from 24th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office, N. Y. County. for 5 days; Henry F. Huners, from 77th Precinct to 18th Division, duty In D. A. Office, Kings County, for one day.
Charles Walzer, operator, has moved his offices to 19 West Fortyfourth Street. Henry Fippinger, Inc., has taken larger quarters in 295 Madison Avenue.

Rosalyn Tureck gave the fifth of her series of six piano recitals devoted to the music of Johann Sebastian Bach at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Although her undertaking is one of the most exacting that any artist, man or woman, has attempted this season, her power, her enthusiasm and her interpretative flair were undiminished at yesterday's program.
Samuel J. Bloomingdale, chairman of the board of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., and Michael Schaap, president, have left on an inspection tour of department stores in the Central States.

Application to strike from listing the capital stock of the Mother Lode Coalition Mines Company is being made to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the New York Stock Exchange. The date for delisting has been set for Feb. 1, or such later date as may be fixed by the commission.

Miss Ethel Glass, daughter of Mrs. Jacob Glass of 215 West Ninety-fourth Street, Manhattan, and the late Dr. Glass, was married to Thomas G. Grace of Brooklyn, New York State Director of the Federal Housing Administration, yesterday afternoon in the Church of Our Lady of Angels, Brooklyn, by Mgr. Francis O'Hara, the rector.
The Grand International Prize of Courage and Devotion was presented to the American Red Cross today in behalf of President Lebrun of

A decision to abandon for the present at least all thought of taxing salaries of State and municipal employes, or levying on the interest of securities now tax exempt, was made today by by the House subcommittee on taxation after study of the Supreme Court decision Monday in the Dravo case.
In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today: Case submitted without argument: 42852-George J. Mellinger, et al. Cases argued and submitted:

Andy Kerr, head coach of the AllEast team that will meet an AllWest eleven in a New Year's Day football game at San Francisco, named two members of Pittsburgh's Ihigh-powered eleven to his squad today.

W. T. Grant Company capital stock, no par value, and Manufacturers Trust Company participation certificates in the A. I. Namm Son 6 per cent sinking fund gold loan due in 1943 have been stricken from New York Stock Exchange listing and registration.
The St. John's University track team faces one of the most extensive campaigns in its history, Coach James Rosenberger announced yesterday in releasing the schedule for the coming indoor season.

Proffers of increased wages to two groups of workers in the local liquor trade removed yesterday the threat that strikes would interrupt the pre-holiday sales. Members of the Retail Wine and Liquor Clerks Union, Local 906A,

Officials of the Cumberland County Power and Light Company said today that they would seek authorization by stockholders of a $1,000,000 stock issue for an expansion program designed to help counteract unemployment in this section.

Dr. Earnest Albert Hooton, Professor of Anthropology and curator of Peabody Museum at Harvard University, said last night that the machine age was producing a race of morons who are in danger of reverting to the status of apes and destroying civilization because man's
The annual meeting of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad's preferred stockholders was postponed sine die yesterday because of lack of a quorum.

Removal of direct control of the operations of all the steel subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation from New York City to Pittsburgh, to take effect on Jan. 1, 1938, was approved at a meeting here yesterday of presidents of the subsidiary operating companies, following authorization of the sweeping changes at a special meeting of the board of directors held on Tuesday.

John Marshall College of Law of Jersey City launched its basketball schedule tonight by defeating the Jersey City State Teachers, 30 to 14. The victors led at half time, 14 to 7. and were led by Tony Killat with 10 points.

Opposition leaders' electoral speeches directed against King Carol's system of personal government through a subservient Cabinet and attacking his refusal to allow the National Peasant party to form a government to hold elections have evoked sharp orders by the Ministry of Justice to local police authorities.

Eighteen actors sitting on a set is Norman Bel Geddes's notion of the Spanish Revolution. Irwin Shaw, author of "Bury the Dead," has written some lines for it. Chester Erskin, the wonder boy of six or seven years ago, has dropped in from Hollywood to direct it.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad's gross revenues are running about 15 per cent below last year's levels, according to Ralph Budd, president. He said that grain, lumber and miscellaneous traffic showed declines.

Trading was mostly slow yesterday. Steer cuts sold very unevenly: lamb cuts were steady to lower; other classes showed very little change in price. Early trading in kosher meats was slow; beef owened steady; veal and calf weak; lamb lower, as reported by the United States Departmnent of Agriculture.

George Philip, geographer, whose cartographical works established the world-wide reputation for the publishing house of George Philip Son, Ltd., of which he was chairman, died today after a short illness at the age of 67.

While striking employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle continued to picket the establishments of advertisers yesterday, the newspaper, in a first-page editorial interpreting the Court of Appeals decision on secondary picketing, declared it Evas illegal for the strikers to picket the advertisers.
The President did not mean that it is an assumption to say that a business recession exists. He does not question the fact of a business slump.

The 1,375 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,175,452,551 par value as of Dec. 1, had a total market value of $42,109,154,661, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that under a stipulation entered into with it. George Wagner, 2,640 Broadway, New York, trading as American Detective Training School and as American Detective System, will discontinue representing that the correspondence course he sells contains instructions in every problem a detective is called upon to solve and that it is offered to qualify a student for a position with the United States Secret Service.
Jobless workers who become ill while receiving unemployment insurance benefits in this State will not be entitled to payments until they have recovered sufficiently to accept a call for employment,

The second of the new type of Schulte retail stores featuring a widely expanded line of merchandise will be opened about Dec. 15 at Forty-second Street and Third Ave nue, it was stated yesterday by Stanley Roth, vice president.

Scotland crushed Czechoslovakia. 5 to 0, in an international soccer match before more than 40,000 at Ibrox Park. Paced by A. Black of Hearts and D. McCulloch of Brentford, Scotland became assured of victory with three goals in the first half.

No European war is in prospect for at least two years, but the United States inevitably will be involved in the next conflict, and meanwhile a large arms program here is in immediate prospect. Roger Babson, economist, predicted yesterday in an address in the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of Rasbsonn's Reports.

After two days of deliberation, a "Platform for American Industry for 1938" was adopted yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria by the National Association of Manufacturers for the guidance of its 5,000 members, the largest organized employing group in this country.

With unexpected speed Noel Coward has finished that musical play which he was reported last October to be working on leisurely. Its name is "Operette," and, with book, lyrics and score entirely by himself, will open in Manchester, England, in February.

The first mobile television station in this country, soon to be used in experimental pick-ups of outdoor events, will be formally turned over on Sunday afternoon to the National Broadcasting Company at Rockefeller Center. The ceremony will be broadcast on the 2 to 3 P. M. program over the WJZ network.

Recommendations that the New York Stock Exchange increase its commission rates to non-members by an average of 10.8 per cent, establish a minimum $3 commission on transactions involving $50 or more and authorize a $2 monthly minimum service charge on inactive accounts were submitted to that body's governing committee yesterday by its committee on quotations and commissions.

City Collector William Reid was the guest of 500 members of the New York State Credit Union League last night at a dinner at the Hotel New Yorker. Mr. Reid, is president of the State league and also of the Municipal Credit League. Speakers included Controller Frank J. Taylor,
The House of Representatives yesterday discussed the revision of the Ottawa Empire Trade Agreement and the Anglo-American trade negotiations with which it is interlocked.

John W. Creedon, president of the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade, said yesterday that his organization would submit a plan to Mayor La Guardia on Wednesday outlining its ideas on cooperating with the police to eliminate traffic congestion from midtown Manhatan.

Film programs to be shown to-. morrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
Homewood Frolic, a white and liver pointer bitch owned by H. M. Curry of Pittsburgh, was adjudged the winner of the Pointer Club of America's open all-age stakes today. First money was $600.

William Hotaling, former Onondaga County Assemblyman, former Town of Tully Supervisor, retired farmer and business man, died at the home of a son, Emmett G. Hotaling, in Nedrow last night. He was 90 years old.
Mrs. Jeanette Tuck of 159 Clove Road, New Rochelle died here yesterday on a shopping trip in front of 5 East Thirty-seventh Street, apparently of a heart attack.

Amos Pinchot, lawyer and publicist, charged in an address here yesterday that the intent of four of the major bills of the New Deal legislative program was not democratic, but the purpose was to set up an executive dictatorship similar to the Fascist governments of Europe.
While irregularity is still noticeable in Canadian industry, it is less than might have been expected from deflationary influences in the United States, according to the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

Mrs. Rebecca Hourwich Reyher of New York, one of the four delegates of the "Flying Caravan for Peace," has had a tremendously successful visit in Honduras. The wife of President Tiburcio Carias made her a guest of the government and she was received by the President and the Foreign Minister when presented by the American Minister, John Erwig.

With farm legislation and the Wages and Hours Bill holding the spotlight in Washington, housing experts are expressing concern over the possibility that Congress may fail to give adequate consideration to President Roosevelt's proposals for amendments to the National Housing Act.
Conference of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recover, Hotel Biltmore. Morning and afternoon sessions at 10 A. M. and 2 P. M. Dinner session, 7 P. M. Speakers: Dr. Ralph Sockman, Dr.
Margaret Mitchell, author of "Gone With the Wind," has appealed to the State Department to help prevent publication of her book in The Netherlands without her permission.

A sale involving eight properties in-the Spring Brook Estate development near Morristown, N. J., was reported yesterday by Eugene V. Welsh, co-broker in the deal with F. M. Crawley Sons. The purchaser was Thomas A. Desmond of New York. He bought two houses and six lots of land.

Plans for National Children's Week from Feb. 14 to 20, with Feb. 20 to be "Young America Day," are being vigorously pushed from both the trade standpoint and the obtaining of support for the suggestion from civic and child welfare organinations.
Carl K. Frey of Utica, photographer and winner of blue ribbons at national conventions of the Professional Photographers Society, died last night of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.

Supreme Court Justices in Manhattan and the Bronx have agreed to sit until 5 P. M., instead of 4 P. M., in an effort to bring the calendars of jury cases up to date, it was disclosed yesterday by Justice Louis A. Valente in a notice to attorneys.
The affairs of Arnold Bernstein's short-lived Palestine Shipping Company continued to be discussed today before the special court trying him on exchange law charges.

A woman passenger who fell or jumped into the sea some time after 1 A. M. last Sunday and was rescued after swimming for nearly six hours, was landed in Brooklyn yesterday from the freighter Lillian Luckenbach.

The accidental touching of a hidden spring in an artificial leg by a prospective purchaser led to the recovery of eighty-eight $1,000 bills which had been cached in the leg owned by the late Frank Laikin, East Side furrier and real estate dealer, who died in Vienna, Austria, in 1929.

A biography of Hugh R. Wilson, Assistant Secretary of State, who has been selected to succeed William E. Dodd, present Ambassador to Germany, will be published by Longmans, Green next Spring. The title of the book is "The Education of a Diplomat."

Led by Cecil Smith, a 25-goal United States polo team will play the Mexican Army quartet in a three-game series starting Dec. 19, the Mexican Polo Federation announced today. The second and third games will be played Dec. 22 and 26.

Maria Carreras, whose pianism has long been favorably known in this city, gave a recital in Town Hall last night. Inasmuch as Miss Carreras was trained in the Liszt tradition, it was logical that half of her program should be given over to compositions by that composer.
A monument to President Franklin D. Roosevelt for his aid towardrehabilitation of Puerto Ricans was proposed today by a committee headed by Chancellor Juan B. Soto of the University of Puerto Rico.

The Varsity Club of Brooklyn College last night held the first annual Varsity B dinner at the Midwood Grill in honor of the varsity football team, which recently closed the most successful season in the history of the college.

Provisional President Alberto Enriquez has appointed ten prominent lawyers, including former President Jose Luis Tamayo, to revise Ecuador's laws. His decree directs that all laws be harmonized on the basis of the country's actual needs and of Juridical science.

Because he had stayed up until 3 A. M. to finish his biography of President Roosevelt and had overslept, Emil Ludwig, German author, missed the French liner Normandie yesterday, and sailed an hour later on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

William Green, A. F. of L. president, declared today that the C. I. O. had "made wounds in labor which can never be healed" and warned of newand more extensive labor warfare unless a quick settlement was reached.

Paul M. Segal, an attorney specializing in radio matters, has been suspended by the Federal Communications Commission from practice before it for two months. The suspension will expire Feb. 5. Mr. Segal was charged with setting up dummy corporations for the
Harvard's basketball forces were in mid-season form tonight as they overwhelmed M. I. T. by 58 to 33. Harvard led all the way, having a margin of 30 to 13 at the half.

A conference on agricultural problems in this State in relation to banking will be held tomorrow morning in the Hotel Roosevelt under the sponsorship of the committee on agriculture of the New York State Bankers Association.

Dr. Frank McLaury, medical director of the Chase National Bank for the last fifteen years, died yesterday morning in the New York Post-Graduate Hospital of a coronary thrombosis after being stricken on Tuesday night at his home at 14 Washington Square North. He had worked at his office at the Pank, 18 Pine Street, until 5:30 P. M. on Tuesday. His age was 64.

Bondholders of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway made a proposal here today to operate the thirty-one-mile transit system for the first three months of 1938 if taxes on the railroad for the last two years are reduced 50 per cent, and to grant three-month extensions if operating deficits are not incurred.

The election by which two canoidates were chosen members of the Republican State Committee from Hudson County was declared invalid today by Judge Thomas Brown in Circuit Court here on the prouind fraud had been committed.

Pig iron production also dropped sharply last month, according to The Iron Age, the loss in the daily rate amounting to 28.3 per cent. Total output was 2,006,724 tons, compared with 2,892,629 tons in October. The daily rate in November of 66,891 tons was the lowest since March, 1936.
The seamen's union of the American Federation of Labor has been designated the bargaining agency of the unlicensed personnel employed by the South Atlantic

Syracuse University opened its basketball season tonight with a 49-to-31 victory over Toronto. The Canadians threw a scare into the Orange camp by taking a 17-to-15 lead at half time, but fast work by Billy Thompson and Bob Stewart, Syracuse forwards, headed a strong home rally in the last half.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teachers-in-training in day secondary schools other than junior high schools in the subjects indicated be issued, as of Dec. 6, 1937, to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:

The Middle Atlantic Division of the Association of Bank Women will hold its first meeting of the 1937-38 season tomorrow afternoon at the Bowery Savings Bank, 110 East Forty-second Street, it was announced yesterday by Miss Catherine S. Pepper of the National City Bank, who is regional vice president.

The Universal Order of Plenocrats, which promised, among other things, to retrieve losses sustained in the depression, was enjoined today by Judge Woodward in the Federal Court for the Northern District of

James B. Murray, retired lawyer, an uncle of the late Senator Bronson M. Cutting, died here tonight at his home, 19 Dudley Place, at the age of 87. Mr. Murray was an active member of the New York bar for twentyfive years, retiring in 1900.

Electric power production increased last week, but the daily average receded, moving counter to normal seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index eased to 96.1 from 97.4. For the week ended Dec. 5, 1937, the figure was 105.3.

President John Gehm of the Buffalo International League Baseball Club announced tonight that Steve O'Neill, former Cleveland Indians' baseball manager, had been signed as field and business manager of the Bisons.

Maryland launched today a second attempt to tax shares of stock owned by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, paving the way for a possible Supreme Court ruling involving millions of dollars in RFC holdings.
The engagement is announced of Mrs. Dorothy Garthwaite, only child of Lord and Lady Duveen, to Dr. Bryan H. Burns, a fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons.
Movements of vessels follow: At New York Yard, Dec. 8: Brooklyn, Sirius. At Puget Sound Yard: Jarvis, Lapwing, Dec. 7. At Coco Solo, Des. 8: Permit, Pollack, Dec. 7. Acushnet, atYorktown. Dec. 8.

Lawrenceville's polo team easily defeated a weaker 112th Field Artillery trio at the latter's armory today. 151/2--10. After taking the lead in the first period, the Laurentians were never seriously pressed.

Generous donors from all walks of life-the wealthy and those of slender means, professional men and women, children, college students-joined yesterday in adding $8,527.10 to the Neediest Cases Fund, bringing the total that has been received so far this year to $61,380.80.
The forecast of the Crop Reporting Board for the largest cotton crop on record, 18,746,000 bales, was accompanied by the unusual spectacle of a rise in prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday.

Endorsing the work done this year in promoting wider use of wool rugs and carpets, the board of trustees of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., yesterday approved continuation of the work through next year.
This is the loud, cool meeting-place of waves. One current rides from the west, one from the south. Here in their quarreling the sunlight laves, The glittering tide spits jewels from its mouth.

Harold W. Osterhout, assistant vice president of the National City Bank of New York, was elected president of the Bankers Club of Brooklyn at a meeting in the Hotel Bossert last night. He is associated with the Brooklyn and Queens branch division of the National City.

The dollar continued to improve in the foreign exchange market yesterday. The pound sterling was 3-18 cent cheaper at $4.99 11-16, the franc off 1/4 point at 3.39 3/4 cents, the guilder down 3 points at 55.61 cents, the belga off 1/2 point at 17 cents and the Swiss franc 1 1/4 points lower at 23.14 cents.

A new issue of $1,912,000 city of Syracuse, N. Y., 2.20 per cent bonds was awarded yesterday to the banking group headed by Lehman Brothers on a bid of 100.2899, representing an interest cost to the city of 2.1631 per cent.
Wealthy and influential men with Fascist leanings are using communism in this country as "a wooden horse within the bowels of which fascism may enter the shrine of liberty," Harold L. Ickes,
NOT only poets write poetry; we have it from salesmen, pre-adolescent girls, philosophers, clubwomen, farmers, hermits, school teachers, sophomores and a variety of other uninhibited individuals.

Dorothy Bourek, 33, of Minneapolis, Minn., was rushed to the American Hospital this morning after a concierge had discovered her with a fractured skull in the vestibule of the house in the Etoile quarter where she had lived for a month.

Bringing to a close eight days of intensive but more or less futile wind-jamming which began a week ago in Milwaukee, the American and National League club owners concluded their annual Winter conclaves today with a joint meeting that seemed to have for its sole objective a swift and peaceful exodus.

Jenkin R. Hockert, former Queens County Clerk, will be appointed as a City Magistrate to succeed Magistrate Anthony Hoekstra when the latter's term expires on Dec. 31, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.
Mrs. Mary Emma Bunn, resident of the Shinnecock Indian Reservation near this village, died there yesterday morning at the home of her son, Charles Bunn. Her age was 90.

Mrs. John S. Ferguson gave a large buffet dinner with dancing last night at 116 East Fifty-third Street. Although her apartment is at the same address, Mrs. Ferguson took over a large unoccupied suite in the same building for the party.
More than 100 building and loan associations operating in New Jersey were directed today by Carl K. Withers, State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, to strengthen their financial positions.
The rules committee of the Indoor Polo Association has announced another demonstration game for Saturday night among high-goal players at the Squadron A Armory on Madison Avenue.

Unless otherwise stated, the result of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases,

Mrs. Anna Marie Bibra Sutton, author and educator, the former Baroness von Bibra, died here last night after an extended illness. She had been Assistant Professor of Modern Languages at Colorado College here since 1928. Her age was 48.
Committees of both the Senate and the House today heard witnesses urge revision of the Merchant Marine Act so as to incorporate in it proposals recommended by the Maritime Commission.
Overcoming all opposition with ease, the Manhattan basketball team defeated Cooper Union, 43 to 19, last night in the Manhattan Gymnasium before a crowd of 800.
The amazing Redskins from Washington are coming to town tomorrow for their play-off game for the championship of the National Football League with the Bears at Wrigley Field Sunday.
Karl F. Glaesser, a partner in the private banking firm of Huth Co. of 63 Wall Street, died on Tuesday at his home, 225 Howard Avenue, Tompkinsville, S. I., after a long illness. His age was 51.

The cruel fang of time is doubtless principally responsible for the fact that the initial act of "Samson et Dalila," which had its first Metropolitan performance of the season last night, is about the dreariest stretch imaginable until the moment that Samson himself appears on the scene. The Franklin K. Lane High School basketball team defeated Thomas Jefferson High, 27 to 17, on the latter's court yesterday in Section 1 of the Brooklyn division P. S. A. L. competition. Holtzman with 15 points was high scorer for the winners, who led at half time, 15 to 8.

Collapse of the sale of the holdings in United Artists-Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks and Charles Chaplin-to Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda was announced today by Goldwyn and Korda due to "unsurmountable legal complications."

Congress, after all, determines the size of the budget. All the Executive can do is to propose a limit and outline the division of expenditures. The President can, of course, veto any appropriation bill, but Congress has the power to repass it and make it law by a two-thirds vote.

Members of the entertainment committee for the benefit matinee performance of "Tristan und Isolde" on Jan. 4 at the Metropolitan Opera House will meet today at the home of Mrs. J. Nelson Borland, 116 East Thirty-seventh Street.
Chile, according to Department of Commerce reports, is likely to be in the market for $120,000 worth of roadbuilding equipment during 1938. Most of the sum will go for truck units.

KINGS AUSTERLITZ, LOUIS (April 5, 1937). Gross assets, $22,397 net, $18,872. To mother, Sophia Austerlitz, life income from residuary estate; alster, Rose Maros, two-thirds remainder interest in life estate; brother, Mike Austeriits,

County and State officials questioned four guests at a recent cocktail party of Samuel Armstrong Walsh here tonight, thirty-six hours after he died in Doctors Hospital, New York City, a victim of hypostatic pneumonia attributed to the effects of a fracture of the jaw.
Robert L. Green Jr. of St. Davids, Pa., today was elected captain of the Harvard football team for next year. He was regular left end the last two seasons.

Thomas D'A. Brophy, first vice president of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., has been elected president of the organization, succeeding Henry Eckhardt, who becomes chairman of the board, the agency announced yesterday.

Hubert Harrison, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and of Reuters, British news agency, was expelled from Belgrade tonight amid scenes suggesting the departure of a national hero into exile rather than the expulsion of an undesirable alien.

The chamber of Deputies will be asked to vote "maximum credits" of 450,000,000 francs for next year's re-opening of the Paris Exposition. The finance committee today adopted this in principle 27 to 9 with one abstention.

Miss Barbara Williams of the Rockaway Hunting Club advanced to the semi-final round of the sixth annual women's metropolitan squash racquets tournament by defeating Miss Marjorie Le Boutillier after a strenuous five-game match, 15-10, 15-3, 11-15, 12-15, 15-5, yesterday on the courts of the Cosmopolitan Club.
Now that the Japanese campaign against Nanking is nearly completed, certain matters hitherto termed military secrets may be revealed.

The usually sensitive scrap market is beginning to reflect signs of a turn in the steel situation which may not be fully apparent until the December inventory period is past, The Iron Age says this week. and this change has been felt even without the stimulus of steel mill buying.
Benny Friedman, City College football coach, made his bow as a tournament squash tennis player in the annual Fall Class B and C event at the City A. C. with complete success yesterday.
Yale's hockey team found itself tonight after a slow start and defeated Boston University in a thrilling hockey game, 6 to 3. The visitors took a 2-to-1 lead in the initial
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a small office building in Manhattan and two large apartment houses in the Bronx.

The Rev.Cyprian Frink of Mount Carmel, Ill., a missionary in China of the Roman Catholic Passionist Order of Union City, N. J., was kidnapped by Chinese bandits on Monday at Kaotsun, in Hunan Province.
Frederick D. Corley, president of Marshall Field Co., today announced the appointment of Charles C. Bunker as general merchandise manager. Mr.

Transfer of the regular Exchange membership of Gayer G. Dominick to Ranald H. Macdonald of Dominick Dominick has been approved.. Pressed Metals of America, Inc., has postponed until next year the offering to its common stockholders

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday morning in Berlin of Adele Aus der Ohe, one of the last surviving pupils of Franz Liszt. Born in Germany about 1865, she had been an invalid for some years, and, having lost her fortune with the inflation of the mark, had been aided since April, 1928, by a pension from the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., of this city.

Laddie Cliff, comedian and producer of many London stage shows, died in the British Sanitarium here after a long illness. He was 46 years old. His wife, Phyllis Monkman, the actress, was at his bedside.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today amendment of its regulations to require inclusion in the selling prospectus accompanying a registration statement of investment trusts and investment companies, registering on Form A-2 under the Securities Act of

Italy manufactured 3,258,006 pounds of raw silk during the first nine months of 1937 and her exports of the commodity were valued at $11,450,000 during the period, according to a Commerce Department report from Rome.
Operators were active yesterday in the Washington Heights and Harlem sections, where they figured as the buyers and sellers of housing properties.

Demetrios Sicilianos, ureeK zainister to the United States, yesterday expressed the appreciation of his government for the work of the Near East Foundation, by presenting at 2 West Forty-sixth Street the decoration of Grand Commander of the Order of the Phoenix to Dr. William E. Doughty, recently retired as a staff member of the foundation.

France will not be bluffed by threats of war into surrendering to Germany any of her African mandates, General Jean Tilho said at today's meeting of the French Colonial Institute, at which Germany's colonial claims were discussed.

Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, for a group of the women who are actively interested in the children's ballet "La Boite a Joujoux," which will be given on Dec. 30 at the, Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the New York Orthopaedic Dispensary and Hospital.
The confirmation of Joseph R. Jackson of New York to be an associate justice of the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals was recommended to the Senate by the Judiciary Committee today.
Modernization of the storage facilities for filing the city's law records was completed yesterday in the offices of the Law Department, In the Manhattan Municipal Building.

Revoking an opinion given early this year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue has ruled that life-insurance agents and soliciting agents are not employes under the taxing provisions of the Federal Social Security Law, according to word received yesterday by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.

The Right Rev. Herbert Guy Bullen, 41 years old, assistant Anglican Bishop in Egypt and the Sudan, and Flying Officer F. W. Richmond of the Royal Air Force, were killed yesterday when their plane crashed about 100 miles north of Juba, Sudan.

Brown Jade, 1-10 choice, turned in a convincing seven-length victory today in the Cuyama Handicap at Tanforan, running the six furlongs in 1:103-5 to tie the track record set last Saturday by Indian Broom.
Hudson St, 112, and Franklin St. 160, twO 6-story loft buildings; City Bank Farmers Trust Co against John de Raismes Storey; due, $48,582; taxes, etc, $2,992; to plaintiff for $44,200.

Dr. Arthur B. Statton, Bishop of the Southwest -Area of the United Brethren Church, died of heart disease today. He was 67 years old. In 1925 Dr. Arthur Biggs Statton became Bishop of the Southwest Area, which embraces Iowa, Missouri, Nebraska, Colorado, Oklahoma and New Mexico.

Loans totaling $3,900,200 on five properties owned by Joseph Paterno and his affiliated corporations have been refinanced with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and extended for ten years, through Wood, Dolson Co., Inc., broker.

Three subsidiaries of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey declared yesterday year-end dividends on common stock. The Huasteca Petroleum Company voted a disbursement of $5.50 a share; the Lago Petroleum Company. $4 a share. and the Pan American Foreign Cooperation, $17.75 a share.

Overwhelmed, 17-4, on the rugby field yesterday, Cambridge came right back with a winning soccer team at Highbury today, defeating Oxford University, 3-2, in one of the best-played matches in years. On the same ground last year they drew, 1-1.

Turpentine firm, 26c; sales, 64 barrels: receipts, 395 barrels; shipments, 41 barrels; stock, 38,480 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 640: receipts,1,160; shipments. 160; stock, 85,888. New impetus was given today to the movement for business aid through tax revision with a recommendation by the Brookings Institution for outright repeal of the highly controversial levy on undistributed corporate profits.

Ralph Greenleaf and James Caras divided the fifth and sixth blocks of their 12-block pocket billiard match at the Strand Academy yesterday. Caras scored, 125 to 77, in six frames, clicking off a string of 43 against Greenleaf's 26.

Prices of most commodity futures were steady to higher in moderate activity on the local Exchanges yesterday. Rubber and hide futures showed small gains, while silk, cocoa and sugar held firm. Coffee futures, however,

Revision of the United States Military Academy's athletic eligibility code, to be effective with the start of the new year and embracing the so-called "three-year varsity rule" for the first time, climaxes a fiveyear "de-emphasis" program aimed especially at Army football.
The international radio convention that ended here today adopted a resolution asking that a sound library be created for great world events.

Complicated ownerships and the varied interests which might have a claim for a share in any piece of real estate militate against the success of the so-called Torrens law for registering title to property, George Allin, of the law firm of Allin, Tucker Allen, told the Long Island Real Estate Board at a luncheon meeting yesterday at 90-14 161st Street, Jamaica.

Patrolman Louis Gandert, 55 years old, was fatally wounded yesterday when he accidentally shot himself in the head while cleaning his service revolver in the basement of his home, 626 Courtlandt Avenue, the Bronx, according to the police. He died at 9 o'clock last night in Lincoln Hospital.

So that the business of this department for the year 1937 may be closed out in a prompt and orderly manner, no requisitions other than those necessary for fuel lubricating oils or gasoline should be made by company commanders unless an actual necessity exists.

Based on figures for the first ten months, the output of gold in the world in 1937 will establish a record. Excluding Russia's output, for which data are not available, the world production in the first ten months was 6.8 per cent larger than for the similar period last year.
Dartmouth opened its home season by defeating the veteran Amherst quintet. 53-30, before 1,500 spectators tonight.

An indictment charging violation of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1935 was voted yesterday by a Federal grand jury against eleven individuals and four corporations, who are accused in twenty-one counts of using fraudulent representations in the sale of oil royalties and of conspiracy.

California-Oregon Power Company--Year ended on Oct. 31: Net income after all expenses and charges $1.029,714. compared with net of $1,019.862 in year ended on Oct. 31, 1936; gross revenues for period $4,675,025, against $4,354,431 in preceding period.

Lieutenant Patrick Shanahan, United States Navy, retired, holder of the Medal of Honor for heroism and a veteran of the World and Spanish-American Wars, died of a heart attack on Tuesday in his home, 7,501 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn. His age was 70.
Estate, more than $10,000. To Matilda Gay, widow, Chateau du Breau, Seine et farne, Villier en Biere, France, residue. William 0. Gay, brother. 12 E. 68th St., petitioner.
Coaches of the Pacific Coast Conference today sent several recommendations for rules changes to the rules committee of the national association. Meeting yesterday, the coaches proposed to:

Mrs. Morgan Wightman Daboll entertained today with a house warming and cocktail party for forty at her new place here. Her house guests are Mrs. Gertrude B. Leeming, Mrs. Ethel Kidd and Mrs Kathleen Lawler of New York.
Many dinner and supper parties were given last night in connection with a dance contest in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.
A field goal by Bob Carey in the last second of play gave St. Francis College a 37-to-35 victory over Cathedral College of New York on the Butler Street court last night.
A miniature blizzard was manufactured today with the snow sent heavenward by ten snow loaders sent here for tryouts by New York City's Department of Sanitation.

Higher duties on coal and wheat were recommended by the Economy and Financial Technical Council on its induction today. Calling for an immediate study of foreign debt problems, the council urged revision of custom duties in order to increase revenue and incidentally to improve the trade balance.
Thirteen students, most of them football players, were suspended today from classes for a week at Upsala College here for falsifying health reports.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Nov. 30 showed the ratio of gold reserve to notes in circulation to be 128.97 per cent against 130.21 per cent on Nov. 15.

The annual Christmas sale which opened yesterday at the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Forty-seventh Street, will continue there until the holiday. Miss Carolyn Davey heads a group of women who will act as Mr. saleswomen for the duration of the sale.

Councilman-elect Joseph ClarK Baldwin 3d, Republican, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the City Club that in the organization of the new City C uncil he would take "pride and pleasure in functioning under the leadership" of B. Charney Vladeck, American Labor party member slated to be minority leader of the body.

A total of $133,250 was pledged last night at five dinner meetings of business and civic leaders toward the $6,250,000 fund being raised by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.

The necessity of increased revenue for the railroads, because of decreases in their incomes in the last few months, and particularly in November, was laid before President Roosevelt today by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The Fordham College Mimes and Mummers, student dramatic organization, will present tonight and tomorrow night as its annual varsity production "Yellow Jack," the Sidney Howard and Paul de Kruif drama of yellow fever which ran for more than four months on Broadway in 1934.

A dinner was given last night by Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. Douglas at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the tenyear development program of the institution. After dinner the guests were conducted to the laboratories of the department of experimental biology, where Dr. G. Kingsley Noble, curator of the department, explained the observations being made with live animals.

THE big fellow drawing diagrams on a card was A. Earle (Greasy) Neale, backfield coach for Eli Yale. He looked up and said: "Hello. This? Oh, I was just showing this' old play-a triple pass. Used it years ago-and then gave it to Pop Warner when he was at Pitt. Met him on a train.

A. E. Watt of the New York A. C. gained the final round in the Long Island open squash racquets championship tournament at the Jackson Heights Squash Club yesterday by beating Richard Rothchild of the Downtown A. C.
Mr. and Mrs. Frost M. Wheeler of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Wheeler, to Paul Burks Jr., son of the late Judge and Mrs. Paul Burks of Los Angeles.
Following is the test of "The Platform for American Industry for 1938" adopted unanimously by the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria:
The Insurgents today launched a sudden thrust at government lines fifteen miles due west of Madrid. It was the first engagement of any importance on the central front in several weeks.
Samuel T. Walker of 81 Crescent Place, Yonkers, has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Anna E. Walker, to James R. Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Kelly of Astoria.
Jacob Zeitlin, Professor of English at the University of Illinois since 1925 and a member of the faculty since 1907, died of a heart ailment early this morning at the age of 54.
Bernard M. Culver, Paul B. Sommers and Montgomery Clark were elected directors of the Reinsurance Corporation of New York yesterday at a meeting of the board.
The Interstate Commerce Commission, which has listened for a week and a half to laments of the railroads, heard today that the new motor truck industry also was in financial difficulties.

Police Inspector Harry L. Lobdell, after a hearing at Brooklyn Police Headquarters yesterday, reserved decision on the complaint that Patrolman Benjamin Bushe of the Stagg Street precinct had interfered illegally with a picket line outside The Brooklyn Daily Eagle and had solicited the arrest of pickets.
Dr. Richard Hutchins Whelpley of 161 West Sixteenth Street died yesterday at New York Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 27 years old. Dr. Whelpley was born in Rochester.
Both houses of Congress, under the plea of "emergency," are now rushing to passage long, complicated farm bills the implications of which few Congressmen understand.

With covers laid for 175 persons, the Touchdown Club of New York closed its "season" with its annual dinner in the Hotel McAlpin last night. Movies, songs and a few speeches brought the final touch to the weeks in which these former football players have been meeting to talk over the game.

Charles A. Levine, first an plane passenger to cross the Atlantic Ocean, was taken last night to the Federal House of Detention when a surety company withdrew a $1,500 bond it had put up as his bail on an indictment charging that he conspired to smuggle 2,000 pounds of tungsten powder into the United I States in 1936.

The indications are for fair anu continued cold weather today and tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night. Pressure continued low over the provinces of Ontario and Quebec and southward to include the Great Lakes region, and the North Atlantic States.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, Richard H. Welsh, New York City, and Frederick L. Bissinger, Forest Hills, L. I., N. Y., Were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announced today that 350,000 additional workers would receive employment on WPA projects to take care of present and developing relief needs throughout the country.
TODAY-New England: Generally cloudy, colder with freezing temperatures over entire section; probably followed by some snow over the south during late afternoon or night. New York State:
The Ohio Utilities Commission granted yesterday authorization to the Toledo Edison Company to issue and sell at par $2,000,000 of first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due 1942,

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, testifying yesterday before a New York State legislative committee on law enforcement, said he was violently opposed to having delinquent children haled into court. He said this tended to make them lose their self-respect.

From the files of Mark W. Potter of New York, former member of the law firm of Hornblower, Miller, Garrison Potter and later a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today produced evidence critical of the management of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in the period between the first and present receiverships of that road.

A special meeting of the Fascist Grand Council will be held at 10 o'clock Saturday night for the purpose, according to reports that spread like wildfire today through Rome's political and diplomatic circles, of sanctioning the government's decision to join Germany and Japan, the two other members of the Fascist anti-Communist triangle, in abandoning the League of Nations.

At this moment (i. e. midnight) some genius somewhere is at work on a play that will never be produced. He is a poet; he is a philosopher; he knows all things, understands all things and out of the agony of his spirit he is creating a masterpiece.

Benjamin F. Fairless, son of an Ohio coal miner, was designated yesterday chairman of the executive committee and elected president of the United States Steel Corporation of Delaware, and thus emerges as the principal operating executive of the organization at the age of 47.
Insistent cheers called a 65-year-old Maude Adams back to the stage here last night after another successful performance of Rostand's "Chantecler."
A group of investors has purchased from David S. Meister the six-story apartment known as the Pelham-Biltmore, which faces the grounds of the Pelham Country Club at Pelham Manor, Westchester.

Stockholders of the E. W. Bliss Company approved yesterday amendments to the plan of recapitalization introduced on Aug. 17.
