The amendments provide for the purchase of notes and new 5 per cent preferred stock by ten principal preferred stockholders with cash to be receive on account of preferred dividend arrears.

Announcement of further earmarking of funds for cities whose plans and policies in regard to low-cost housing have been approved at the conferencec with United States Housing Authority officials, called by Nathan Straus, administrator, will be made tomorrow.

A picked squad of Bronx detectives under Deputy Inspector John J. O'Connor questioned thirty victims of recent robberies yesterday in the hope of obtaining a better description of the murderer of Patrolman Edward P. Lynch.

President Lazaro Cardenas decreed today the closing of the Church of the Sacred Heart in the town of Jalapa, State of Veracruz. The step was taken under Article 27 of the Mexican Constitution covering religious control.
Leasing of business space was featured yesterday by contracts for quarters in buildings along Madison Avenue. Most of the activity was in the midtown area.
One misses the Warner trademark on the new film at the Capitol. Had the Warners been doing it, it would have read: Mr. Edward G. Robinson in "The Life of the Last Gangster,"

In an effort to resuscitate Bermudan agriculture, which has been sorely hit by the Canadian-United States trade agreement, the Assembly today voted [Pound]18,000 for a refrigerating plant to be built on the dock at Hamilton.

Miss Helen H. McGown, formerly a teacher at Public School 48 in New York, died here yesterday in her home. Miss McGown was a member of the Retired Teachers Association of New York, the Jersey City Woman's Club and a former secretary of the Travelers Club of New Jersey.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone dismissed another defendant in the government's gasoline price-fixing case today, reducing the number of individuals on trial to thirty-seven. The court granted a directed verdict of acquittal for R. O.

The repeal of the undistributed profits tax was urged by Repretentative Clarence F. Lea of California, who is chairman of the House committee on interstate commerce, in a message presented at the sixty-fifth annual dinner of the New York Railroad Club in the Hotel Commodore last night.

Beginning next week, The Annalist's weekly index of wholesale commodity prices will be computed as of Wednesday's closing prices instead of Tuesday's prices as at present. It will cover the week ended on Wednesday rather than Tuesday.

Unless one holds his head carefully in two hands to prevent it from spinning, it is hard to keep clear the dance of personalities and policies in Federal housing. It helps if we ask ourselves what the Federal Government can do for housing and then see what it has done.

Major Gen. Paulino Santos, Chief of Staff, and two other high commanding officers of the Philippine Army were found safe with their plane undamaged today, after ninety-six hours on the tiny island of Buguitay, thirty-two miles off the east coast of Luzon, by Lieutenant Alfred Maxwell, flying one of thirty United States Army planes that had been scouring a wide area.

Rather than bring in a recommendation for life imprisonment, now permitted under the law, and chance a commutation of sentence by some future Governor, a jury in General Sessions Court yesterday brought in a verdict that makes a

The first work on a $420,000 school building program in the Northport union school district will be started immediately with the awarding this week of a contract to T. B. Campbell Construction Company for excavation for the first of two new schools.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Marjorie Tepper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Tepper of this place, to Dr. Harry L. Glass, son of Mrs. Max Glass of Carteret, N. J., took place this evening in the home of the bride's parents.
Emil Ludwig sat up till 3 o'clock in the morning finishing his biography of President Roosevelt, overslept,
The speech of C. M. Chester, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers and chairman of the General Foods Corporation, follows:

The first session of the auction of art property of the late Frederic A. Juilliard of New York and Tuxedo Park brought $10,025 yesterday afternoon at the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc. A portrait of George Washington attributed to Gilbert Stuart was bought by the Milch Galleries for $400.
The Mexican Government has taken steps toward placing the entire $450,000,000 foreign petroleum industry on a new basis which would make all companies operating here partners of the government.

Miss Beatrice Barclay Elphinstone, daughter of Mrs. Reginald Cuyler Elphinstone of 124 East Ninety-first Street, was married to Henry Van Duzer Wing yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

The performance of "Tannhaeuser" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was conspicuous for some interesting singing of principal parts, though singing by no means on a sustained artistic level and a routine and sometimes ineffective ensemble.

Obvious overtures for United States friendship made in statements by General Iwane Matsui, the Japanese Army commander here, and Rear Admiral Tadao Honda, the naval attache, caused much conjecture today.
In the Supreme Court of the United States Martin Detels and Abraham J. Rosenblum of New York City were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had:

A funeral service was held yesterday in Campbell's Funeral Church, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, for Wilberforce Eames, official bibliographer of the New York Public Library. Mir. Eames, who had been connected with the library for more than forty years, died at the age of 82 on Monday in the Kane Pavilion of the Home for Incurables, Third Avenue and 183d Street, the Bronx.

Hasty selection of garments from Paris collections, which in turn forces designers to meet a "virtual deadline," is largely responsible for the difficulties existing between the Parisian couture and American apparel trades, Jacques Heim, Paris couturier, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Fashion Group at the Hotel Biltmore.

A world trade revival growing out of an international political reorganization in which the "havenot" nations, Italy, Germany and Japan, will play a leading part, was predicted by Jackson Martindell, president of the Fiduciary Counsel, Inc., in an address read for him last night at a dinner meeting of the Beta Gamma Sigma Alumni of New York at the George Washington Hotel.

Vice President Garner called on the press today to aid him in controlling the Senate. He charged that the Senate was violating union rules by working overtime. It was after 5 o'clock and the discussion of the farm bill was still going on.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 8: Beere, Lt. Col. D. M., F. A., Field Artillery Board. Fort Bragg, N. C.. to Fourth Field Artillery. Fort Bragg, N. C. Lucas, Lt. Col. J. P., F. A., Fourth Field Artillery to Field Artillery Board, Fort Bragg, N. C.

The utility corporations fighting in Federal Court here against the Tennessee Valley Authority's power program would suffer an annual loss of $26,000,000 and the damage to their capital structures would total $433,000,000 if the TVA eleven-dam program was put in operation, Professor Edward L. Moreland, Boston consulting engineer, declared in court here today.
Taking advantage of a twenty-minute penalty handed to Marty Barry in the third period, the Maroons defeated the Red Wings, 5 to 2, tonight with a three-goal outburst in the final session.

Bank clearings for the twentytwo leading cities in the United States in the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,500,637,000, an increase of $896,456,000 over the preceding week, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In the corresponding week last year, bank clearings in these cities were $6,008,196,000.

Starting slowly but pulling ahead late in both halves, Fordham University defeated Upsala in the first meeting of the two teams at the Elizabeth Armory tonight, 35 to 22. Both teams did their best playing on defense and neither could get a scoring offensive under way. It was the opening intercollegiate contest for the Rams.

Leila Morse Rummel, daughter of Samuel F. B. Morse, inventor of the telegraph, died in the American Hospital here today at the age of 87. She was the mother of Walter Rummel, pianist and composer, and Frank Morse Rummel, painter.

Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, newly crowned chess champion of the world, and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, who lost his title when defeated in the twentyfifth game of their match, continued play tonight at the Krasnapolsky Restaurant and contested the twenty-seventh game of the series.

The marriage of Miss M ry Evelyn Renton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hollings Chase Renton of Tuckahoe, to George Frederick Beckley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Beckley of Larchmont, took place here yesterday morning in the rectory of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Fifty-ninth Street and Ninth Avenue.

Outright repeal of the undistributed profits tax was advocated yesterday by the Merchants Association. The board of directors of the group approved a report of its committee on taxation and public revenue, condemning the tax for having failed to produce the expected revenue, and at the same time having imposed hardships and having acted as a brake upon business and industrial activity.

The annual Police Department ceremony of promotions, appointments and the drill of the Police Academy graduates will be held at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, Dec. 22 at 8:30 P. M., Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday.

No public-spirited citizen could have read even the abstract of the United Hospital Fund's last report on the community's medical needs without inwardly expressing gratitude for a task which was performed with rare competence, honesty, self-sacrifice of time and courage.

An immediate increase in railroad rates is imperative to avert bankruptcies, the Association of American Railroads told the Interstate Commerce Commission today. Shipping interests quickly called the plea "absurd."

Through the use of a new electrical scoring machine on civil service examinations, papers can be graded at the rate of 3,000 in a seven-hour day, compared to 140 under the old system, James E. Finegan, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, said yesterday.
St. Nicholas Ave. 641-5, 1-story brick garage, 76x126xirreg; Elliott L. Brown, trustee, against Wealfred Holding Corp, due, $62.552, taxes, etc, $759; to plaintiff for $40,000.

William E. Taylor of New York, vice president of the American Can Company, collapsed tonight after addressing a district sales banquet at the Chicago Athletic Club and was pronounced dead after arrival at St. Luke's Hospital.

Colonel J. F. Manning, authority on marble and builder of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, testified today as an expert witness for Senator George L. Berry of Tennessee and his associates before a threeman Federal condemnation commission hearing claims for marble deposits underlying land now flooded by TVA's Norris Dam.

Mrs. Henry M. Rogers, born in Waterbury, Jan. 28, 1865, daughter of the late David Abbott and Charlotte D. Sperry and a resident of Stamford for the last nine years, died today at the Ambassador Arms at the age of 72.
Negotiations leading to a merger of the S. M. A. Corporation, Cleveland baby food manufacturer, and the American Home Products Corporation, large manufacturer of medicine, are reported to have begun.
The mysterious disappearance of an American couple who were named as Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Robinson of New York was reported today to the United States Embassy.

Three Common Pleas Court judges approved a writ of mandamus today directing trustees of the Municipal Convention Hall to rent the building to the Communist party for a Lenin memorial meeting. The trustees had refused the Communists' request, on the ground that the proposed meeting would not be in the public interest.

A plea for an education aimed at training the individual as opposed to the mass as the means of solving the problems that face democracy today was made last night by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, speaking as guest of honor at the fifty-sixth annual dinner of the New York Alumni Association of Phillips Exeter Academy at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Cornell's quintet opened its season tonight with an easy 44-21 victory over Toronto. A Crowd of 1,500 was interested mainly in seeing the effect of the rule changes, but the contest was too one-sided to form an opinion of them.

American News Company capital stock, no par value, has been admitted to the New York Stock Exchange list and American News New York Corporation capital stock, no par value, has been suspended from dealings.

Declaring the John Wanamaker stores are going ahead on a basis of "confidence and faith," despite the "spirit of confusion running wild throughout the country," Charles R. Shipley formally assumed the presidency of the organization at ceremonies at the local store yesterday morning, which were attended by more than 3,000 employes.

Fourteen senior students and five members of the faculty were named for committees to conduct the Senior Promenade of City College to be held in The Essex House tomorrow evening, according to an announcement by Irving I. Anderman, vice president of the class of '38.

Judge George F. Bingham of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ordered thirty-one Greater Boston milk dealers today to pay about $20,000 for administrative expenses of the Federal Milk Administration and put about $500,000 in escrow pending a final ruling on the constitutionality of the Marketing Act.
After never being closer than second in nineteen starts, Miss Bones, 57-to-1 shot, today came through with a surprise victory in the four-and-a-half-furlong dash for 2-year-olds at Charles Town.

The Treasury's $250,000,000 offering of eight-year 21/2 per cent bonds on Monday was subscribed sixteen times and the companion offering of $2,000,000 of five-year 13/4 per cent notes was subscribed thirteen times, Secretary Morgenthau announced at his press conference today.

Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Apawamis, defending champion, will face Miss Margaret Bostwick of Ardsley, and former winner, on the courts of the Cosmopolitan Club at 3 P. M. today in the final round of the women's metropolitan squash racquets tournament.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that a nationwide movement had been started to obtain a defense fund for the fourteen members of the crew of the freighter Algic who were indicted in Baltimore on charges of mutiny growing out of their refusal to work

Enough has been published about the conspiracy trial of various oil company managers in the Federal court at Madison to demonstrate that here is an excellent illustration of one of the perplexities of American business men in present times.

Michael E. Reiburn, former State Senator, who was disbarred two years ago by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for unethical practice, pleaded not guilty yesterday to an indictment returned by a Federal grand jury accusing him and three other defendants of using the mails to swindle three widows of sums totaling $10,000.
William Edward Wyatt, elder son of the late Rev. Thomas J. Wyatt and prominent many years in Protestant Episcopal Church circles; died at his home near Baltimore today at the age of 77.

Efforts to socialize medicine and dentistry in this country were attacked yesterday by Dr. Seth A. Brumm, former president of the Philadelphia County Medical Society, as the work of "tricksters" who are seeking to lure a gullible public with "a smoke screen."

Evidence of fraud in the September primary election, which caused Circuit Court Judge Thomas Brown to set aside yesterday the election of two members of the Republican State Committee, will be presented to the Hudson County grand jury, Prosecutor Daniel T. O'Regan announced today.

W. Gerard Ryan, compensation referee in the State Labor Department from July, 1931, until last October, will be the guest of his friends in the Labor Department tomorrow night at a testimonial dinner in the Hotel New Yorker. Mr.

Featured by an intensive discussion of employer-employe relations, the twenty-first annual convention of the Toy Manufacturers of the United States, which began yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, passed a resolution approving the platform of the National Association of Manufacturers.

That unusual authority will be vested in the officials during the present season was evident as a result of the basketball clinic conducted last night under the auspices of The New York Herald Tribune at the West Side Y. M. C. A. before a crowd which jammed the gymnasium.
Hubert Harrison, Belgrade correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and of Reuters, British news agency, arrived here today after his expulsion from Yugoslavia.

Line. Virginia in Drydock Today The Panama Pacific liner Virginia will be withdrawn from the intercoastal service for a single trip to enter drydock for her quadrennial inspection as required by the insurance provisions of the British Lloyds. The ship will be taken today to Morse's drydock, in Brooklyn,

The Market Street Investment Corporation of Indianapolis, Ind., an investment trust, today filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 100,000 common shares of $10 par value which would be sold at market for approximately $2,308,000.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $107,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $7,927,000,000, according to the condition statement of the banks issued yesterday.

Conservative! members of the House of Commons I tried something new in British polities today when they attempted unsuccessfully to introduce a motion of censure against Clement R. Attlee, salaried leader of the Opposition.
Grove St. 43-5, 47x86: The 137 Macdougal St Corp (Jennie Belardi, president) to Amrnsten Corp, 29 26th St. prior mtg $37,000, 1 yr, 6 per cent: $3,500.
Word has been received by relatives here of the birth of a daughter to Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Hackett of Newcastle, Del., on Wednesday at the Delaware Hospital in Wilmington.

From below the front porch of a villa at Celle-Saint-Cloud, where it had been buried by her confessed murderer last July, the body of the 22-year-old dancer, Jean De Koven of Brooklyn, was recovered this afternoon and the mystery of her disappearance was finally solved.

Myles Dunne, successor to Patrick J. Corcoran, slain labor leader, disclosed today that three men attempted to ambush him Tuesday night just as assassins waited for Corcoran and shot him to death the night of Nov. 17.

Some custom smelters yesterday were selling copper in the domestic market at 10.25 cents a pound. The reduction was not initiated by American Smelting and Refining Company, but the concern met the out.

Three coaches have been appointed to direct Temple University athletic teams during the Winter campaigns. Al Baran, former member of the championship gymnastic team, was selected by Head Coach Max Younger to tutor the freshman gymnasts.

Twenty-four families were forced to flee from a six-story tenement house at 607 East Thirteenth Street yesterday afternoon as a fire of undetermined origin swept through an adjoining four-story abandoned building and spread to the two upper floors of the tenement.

A new contract between the Ontario Hydro-Electric Commission and the Beauharnois Power Corporation will receive approval through an order in council some time tomorrow, it was understood today at Queens Park.

It was disclosed yesterday by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences that the Lawrence Sperry Award, given annually to the young man under 30 years old who has made the greatest contribution to the advancement of aeronautics during the year for which the award is presented, would go this year to Clarence L. Johnson of Burbank, Calif. The choice of Mr.

The Rev. A. Judson Arnold, former examinating chaplain in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania, died here today at the age of 88. He was born in New London, Conn. After serving churches in New York and Little Falls, N. Y., and Pottstown, Ardmore and Media, Pa., he became secretary to the late Bishop Philip M. Rhinelander.

George H. Hoyt Jr., 27-year-old automobile salesman of Fort Salonga, near here, was held in $2,500 bail for the Suffolk County grand jury, following his arraignment here today on a charge of manslaughter for the death of Samuel A. Walsh, retired broker of Fort Salonga.

During the week ended Dec. 8 member bank reserve balances decreased $70,000,000. Reduction in member bank reserves arose from increases of $23,000,000 in money in circulation, $65,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $5,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold, offset in part by increases of $9,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency and a decrease of $12,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.

Eleven of the sixteen secondround matches in the Fall B and C squash tennis tournament at the City Athletic Club were played yesterday, with five of the eight seeded entrants who competed winning their way into the third round.
The bugaboo of governmental competition with private enterprise appears to be disturbing the architectural profession as well as more prosaic lines of business.

The proposed issuance of $2,040,300 of 4 per cent unsecured promissory notes maturing on July 1, 1943, as a dividend payment on outstanding common stock by the Southwestern Development Company, a registered holding company, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Newark Tornadoes and the White Plains Bears last night officially became co-champions of the American Football Association for the 1937 season. This decision was reached at a meeting of the board of directors held at the Hotel New Yorker, presided over by President Joseph Rosentover of Passaic.
Robert McKelvy, vice president and director of the Tidewater Oil Company, died yesterday at his home, 765 Park Avenue, after being ill since last April. He was 62 years old.

The historic building of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street opened its doors yesterday afternoon to the wives and daughters of members, and friends of their families,

Fire destroyed the Pulaski Academy early today with damage estimated by Fire Chief Frank Bonney at $200,000. The blaze, fanned by a strong wind, spread rapidly through the old Colonial three-story structure and at times threatened Pulaski's residential and business districts.
After an ownership of thirtyfour years the estate of Frederick Hambrock has sold the two fivestory apartment houses at 52 and 54 West Ninety-fourth Street to a client of Louis F. Hines, broker.

John Marshall College of Law registered its second straight victory tonight, defeating the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy quintet, 43 to 19. The victors set a fast pace and held an advantage at half time of 23-10. Jerry Kelly and Tony Killat featured with 16 and 14 points, resnectivelv.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles James Bacon Jr. of 37 Stephens Court, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanette Mariner Bacon, to Albert Percival Warwick Ayer, also of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Adelbert Warwick Ayer of Devonshire. England, and the late Lieut. Col. Sir Adelbert Warwick Ayer, R. A.

The League of Nations Economic Committee concluded its forty-seventh session today by adopting an unusually brief report, notable mainly for its declaration of principles regarding the supply of raw materials.

Ruth West, member of the copy staff of the J. Walter Thompson Company, has been appointed fashion promotion director of SaksFifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by I. A. Hirschmann, vice president of the store.

The New York Drama Critics Circle, usually satisfied to look at actors across a row of footlights, will pay its respects to a select group of them when it sits down to a Christmas party dinner on Dec. 18 at the 21 Club.
Fourteen new flying boats commanded by Lieut. Comdr. B. E. Grow successfully completed today their nonstop mass flight from San Diego, Calif., to the United States Navy Air Base at Coco Solo.
Professor Erastus Palmer, founder and head of the public speaking department at the College of the City of New York, died here this morning in his home at the age of 78.

The University of Michigan, one of football's strongholds since the turn of the century, was in the market for a new coach tonight. Harry G. Kipke, one-time AllAmerica pupil of Fielding H. Yost, was notified today by the university board of control of athletics that his contract would not be renewed when it expires on June 1, 1938.
Joe F. Carr, head of the National Football League, denied emphatically today reports that he would relinquish the presidency of the organization he founded seventeen years ago.

Greenwood Gardens, the fourstory apartment at 14-30 Greenport Road, Far Rockaway, Queens, has been sold by the Prudential Life Insurance Company to a client of Bernard Kantor, attorney, through Carl Davis, broker.

The speeches delivered tonight at the official banquet that marked the climax of Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos's visit have given the French delegation great satisfaction. Foreign Minister Victor Antonescu was most emphatic in recognizing Rumania's debt to France.

Two of the older Wall Street firms will be brought together about Jan. 1 in a merger of Edward B. Smith Co. and Charles D. Barney Co., according to an announcement made yesterday by Joseph R. Swan and John W. Hanes on behalf of their respective firms.
The Reich Press Chief, Dr. Otto Dietrich, explained to a student audience at Berlin University tonight that no such thing as individual liberty exists.
Eugene J. Buffington, who rose from a nail salesman to president of the Illinois Steel Company, died today in Presbyterian Hospital following an operation. He was 74 years old.
A new Soviet film on the Bolshevist revolution, starring actors impersonating Nikolai Lenin and Joseph Stalin, went back to the studios today for revision.
Menow is Jack Campbell's top horse among the juveniles of 1937, according to the weights announced yesterday by the Jockey Club in what is Campbell's third Experimental Handicap.

THERE were some who grieved for Gabby Street when he was sentenced officially to manage the St. Louis Browns for the coming season, but they couldn't have picked a better man for the job. As long as he can sit down and his supply of pipe tobacco holds out, the Old Sarge can stand a terrific amount of punishment with magnificent calm.
The yearly report of the Graengesberg Ore Company's subsidiary, the Luossavaara-Kiirunavaara Ore Company, discloses a large rise in ore exports, attributable largely to rearmament programs.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is trustee, paying agent and registrar for $9,000,000 of serial notes of the Phililps Petroleum Company due as follows: 3 per cent Series A, due Dec. 1, 1939; 31/2 per cent Series B, on Dec. 1, 1944, and 31/2 per cent Series C, on Dec. 1, 1945.

Vehicular traffic along Broadway, between Fifty-first and Fifty-third Streets, was detoured for about a half hour shortly after 11 o'clock last night as firemen fought a blaze of undetermined origin in the rear of Leon's shoe store on the ground floor at 1,677 Broadway.

Criticizing the New Deal as being the product of "snap judgments," Elihu Root Jr., attorney and son of the late statesman, urged the Republican party yesterday to profit by the mistakes of the Administration and eventually adopt an affirmative program based on the Fabian maxim of making haste slowly.

The resistance of commodity prices to further price declines is considered encouraging in many sections of the financial community, which believe that it may mean that the current business recession is nearing its bottom.
Nicholas Torre, 64-year-old ironworker, received a directed verdict of acquittal on a charge of felonious assault in Kings County Court yesterday.
The Cabinet was called into session today to deliberate the next phase of Japan's course in China. At the present stage an "if" decision is expected.

Administration spokesmen on both sides of the Capitol conceded today that the special session would probably end without final action on general farm legislation and that when adjournment was taken for the Christmas holidays the measure would be deadlocked in a conference committee to which controversial issues will be referred.

Guided by Willie Lee Johnson, the country's second ranking jockey, Virginia J. had no trouble winning the mile and seventy yards of the Port Allen purse at the Fair Grounds today for N. L. Naylor of Houston, Texas.

Lester Carpenter, 25 years old, was in Mount Holly Hospital today with serious internal injuries suffered in a leap from a railway trestle here last night after an unsuccessful attempt to save the life of his dog. Mr. Carpenter and his brother, Frank, both of Lakewood, had been 'coon hunting when the dog wandered onto the trestle.

The BankOhio Securities Company obtained the award yesterday of a new issue of $150,000 of bonds of the city of Youngstown, Ohio, on a bid of 100.125 for 21/2. The bonds are to be dated Oct. 1, 1937, and will mature on Oct. 1, 1942.

The Cabinet today accepted decrees providing for compensation of creditors and others not directly involved who have suffered through confiscation of the property of "enemies of the State" and of funds and property of former labor unions.

The membership of the Union League Club of New York, which turned its back last January on its history of stanch Republican partisanship to admit anti-New Deal Democrats to the roster, issued a statement last night praising Washington legislators who are conferring on opposing "unsound and dangerous legislation."

Corn was the leader in the grain markets today, showing independent strength and selling at the highest prices in nearly a month on reports that around 1,500,000 bushels had been sold for export, making nearly 5,000,000 bushels sold so far this week.

The Federal Trade Commission today charged the Carter Carburetor Corporation of St. Louis with tending to create a monopoly through the enforcement of exclusive dealer contracts and with unfair methods of competition.
As a result of the death of James O. McKinsey, chairman and chief executive of service of Marshall Field Co.. two changes in the firm's executive personnel were announced today.

The New York University varsity fencing team will engage in seven dual meets this season, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager. The Violet, last year's winner of the intercollegiate fencing championship, will defend its titular honors at the 1938 Intercollegiates on March 25 and 26.

A tenyear agreement governing the production and export of sugar from Czechoslovakia has been made by the ninety-two sugar companies of that country, according to a report to the Department of Commerce.

Retailers, whose stocks were depleted in the widespread price war of last week, began replenishing here yesterday. Orders for domestic blends and for bottled-in-bond domestic ryes and bourbons were particularly heavy, jobbers said, as those types of whisky were among the fastest moving items in the price war.

West End Ave, 865, n w cor 102d St, Sunappe Realty Corp, Armino A. Campagna, president. to Joseph A. Sutton, 438 E. 188th St: ;Tg $893,000 (S1). Same property, Joseph A. Sutton to Ebbtide Realty Corp, 745 5th Aye; mtg $893,000 ($1).

Henry A. Jacunski of New Britain, Conn., and Michael J. Kochel of Bloomfield, N. J., were elected co-captains of the 1938 Fordham varsity football team yesterday. Joseph I. Grealy of the Bronx was named assistant manager. Robert J. Gallow of the Bronx and Robert D. Russo of Bridgeport, Conn., automatically became co-managers for 1938,
War Admiral, unbeaten 3-year-old owned by Samuel Riddle of Philadelphia, today was awarded the turf's highest honor when he was judged the outstnading race horse of the year by 256 sports writers.

A capacity gathering again paid homage to King Winter and the sports of ice and snow at Madison Square Garden last night on the third evening of the North American Winter sports show and international ski meet.

Dr. Winfield A. Holcomb of Geneseo, principal of Geneseo State Normal School for twelve years until his retirement in 1934 and former chief of the Bureau of Teacher Certification in the State Department of Education, died today in a hospital here after a long illness. He was 75.
Amsterdam Ave. 1,320; to 5-story tenement and stores: Kallenko Estates, Inc, 2,140 Williamsbridge Rd. Bronx, owner; J. M. Berlinger. architect; cost, $3,000.

Edward John Fellows, editor and publisher for the last fourteen years of Master Painter and Decorator, a trade journal published in Newark, died last night at his home here after a five-month illness. His age was 61.

Contracts for approximately 4,346,150 barrels of fuel oil at a cost of $3,996,720 for naval requirements on the West Coast for the six months form Jan. 1 to June 30, 1938, were announced today by the Navy Department. The awards follow:

Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said last night that private enterprise was the best hope of renewed prosperity, in an address at the thirty-eighth annual dinner of the Technology Club of New York in the Hotel Astor.
Lutheran clergy opened a two-day session here today to hear details of the anniversary appeal which will mark in 1938 the twentieth year of the United Lutheran Church of America.
An anonymous $15,000 corporation gift to the United Hospital Campaign headed a list of business and employee contributions announced yesterday by F. Abbot Goodhue, chairman of the finance section.

On their own applications. INSPECTOR-Michael T. Ahearn. Third District Traffic, at $2,950 per annum. Appointed June 19, 1900. DEPUTY INSPECTORS-Thomas H. F. Kelly, 13th Division. at $2,950 per annum. Appointed Dec. 1, 1896. John L. Falconer. 15th Division, at $2,950cper annum. Appointed Dec. 22, 1896.
The following table shows the 11teen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Praise for the interdenominational activities of the Presbyterian Church of the Sea and Land, Market and Henry Streets, was voiced by the Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Savage, executive secretary of the Presbytery of New York, at a dinner last night celebrating the 120th anniversary of the erection of the historic church building.

Orders to buy, represented by values, exceeded orders to sell in odd-lot trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Dec. 4 by $4,863,081, and there were 187,566 more shares involved in the buying orders than in orders to sell, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
Mother Superior Rostaing, who was known as Pope Pius's "spiritual daughter," died today in Rome at the age of 80. She was head of the Sisters of Our Lady of Cenacle in Italy.

Miss Estelle Deutsch, public school teacher, welfare worker and the sister of the late Bernard S Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, died on Wednesday night at her home, 675 West End Avenue. Miss Deutsch had undergone an op eration last Spring and had since been il. Her age was 48.

Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, disclosed today during a visit to the Edison plant here that he had been unofficially approached about succeeding Governor-elect A. Harry Moore in the United States Senate, but that his mind was "practically" made up to decline the appointment.

Following is the text of a "Statement on Employment Relations" and an outline of "Employment Procedures" presented by the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers and adopted yesterday by its "Congress of American Industry" at the closing session in the Waldorf Astoria Hotel:
Miss Laura Adams Buckingham, for many years a teacher in New York public schools, died on Monday at the West Hill Sanitarium in Riverdale, N. Y., at the age of 84.

At a time when closer cooperation between business and Government has become increasingly essential, it is reassuring to find the National Association of Manufacturers taking the position that business must keep its own house in good order and that Government has many social obligations which it cannot shirk.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:
Officially authorizing the export of lower types of coffee, President Getulio Vargas has signed a decree permitting immediate exportation of coffees above type 8, heretofore prohibited.

Mayor La Guardia expressed surprise yesterday over reports that he was at odds with Nathan Straus, Federal Housing Administrator, and indicated that he might see Mr. Straus while he is in Washington for the dinner of the Gridiron Club tomorrow evening.
Arnold Weston Lederer, Brooklyn architect. has prepared a digest of the new New York City Building Code.

A year ago a TIMES reader who was out of work found that he wasn't able to spare anything for the Hundred Neediest Cases. This week he sent a contribution. "I decided," he wrote, "that next year I would give something.

Emerson H. McWhorter Sr., charter member of the Long Island Real Estate Board and developer of Brentwood, L. I., died at his home here today at the age of 82. Before entering the real estate business, Mr McWhorter was general sales manager for the Houghton-Mifflin Publishing House, and held a similar post with D. Appleton Sons.

Evidence that foreign central banks and governments are still disposing of the dollar balances that they have acquired here and are converting the funds into gold to be shipped abroad or held under earmark was provided yesterday by items reported in the weekly Federal Reserve reports.

Oxford University has canceled a series of lectures on "Aspects of Japanese Culture" by Professor K. Doi, Japan's "academic ambassador," it was revealed tonight. The disclosure was made by Professor Doi himself.
None -of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year.

Senator King, moving for Immediate action on his proposal to modify the undistributed profits and capital gains taxes, offered an amendment to that effect today to a House tax bill pending in the Senate.

The Spanish Government today delivered a strong protest to the British Foreign, Office, expressing "surprise and displeasure" at London's warning to British shipping following General Francisco Franco's announcement of his intended blockade of the Spanish coasts.

WHAT is remarkable about the novelists of our gun-haunted time is the magnitude of the work many of them have produced in it. This is a conclusion of Herbert Muller, whose "Modern Fiction"* is a briskly written, fairly comprehensive and useful point of departure for the ideas you have on the novelists of the last sixty years or so.

Mrs. Esther M. Margolis, wife of Dr. Elias Margolis, rabbi of the Emanu-El Synagogue of Mount Vernon and a worker in charitable organizations, died here tonight at her home, 16 Glenn Avenue, at the age of 54.

Mayor La Guardia's new plan for reduction of traffic congestion in midtown Manhattan will start on an experimental basis on Sunday morning, it was learned yesterday following a meeting of the Mayor's Traffic Commission at the Empire State Building, where the Mayor has temporary offices.

Representatives of twenty-five C. I. O. unions, "speaking in defense of the rights of all working people and representing 500,000 C. I. 0. unionists in New York City," set forth yesterday their intention of resisting "any attempt of any nature to limit our right to picket."
William H. Berg today was elevated to the presidency of the Standard Oil Company of California, succeeding the late Kenneth R. Kingsbury.
The British people are wasting no emotion tonight in commemorating the "final and irrevocable decision" which Edward VIII announced just a year ago tomorrow.

The marriage of Mrs. Louise Kaye Whittell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wallace Kaye of Beverly Hills, Calif., to Paige Monteagle, son of Louis Findlay Monteagle of San Francisco and the late Mrs. Monteagle, took place here yesterday afternoon at the Savoy-Plaza.
Alfred Harcourt, president of Harcourt, Brace Co., spoke last night at the New York Public Library to more than 300 publishers, authors, librarians and other bookmen on "Publishing Since 1900."

Held in the Monmouth County Shelter Home here since Nov. 21, when he shot and killed his father, Robert E. Miller, 41 years old, of Keyport, to "save my mother," Robert Clinton Miller, 16, was discharged from custody today.
Two Metropolitan Opera singers, a British author and a noted motion-picture director were among the lessees of apartments listed by brokers yesterday.
Swarthmore College was made the beneficiary of a $100,000 trust fund, the income of which is to be used to pay salaries of chemistry professors, in the will of Miss Laura Allen, probated today.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls moved into first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League race last night by defeating the Bronx Tigers, 3 to 1, at the New York Coliseum before 1,500 persons. The Gulls thus displaced the New York Rovers as the pace-setters of the circuit.

A plea for mutual trust between government and industry, and the undertaking of a real fact-finding job in relation to labor, social security, profits tax, and other problems now troubling business, was urged last night by George T. Trundle Jr., president of the Trundle Engineering Company, speaking at the annual dinner of the Society for the Advancement of Management at the Hotel New Yorker.

Decision to make its own awards regardless of the action of various guilds was made today by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. March 3 was set as the date for the annual dinner of the group.

Counsel for Allen B. duMont Laboratories, Inc., intimated yesterday that they will not file exceptions to the report of H. Victor Schwimmer, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, in stop-order proceedings against the company.
The Hannah Penn House group opened its thirteenth annual holiday market today at its headquarters.
Near-zero weather tightened the grip of a three-day storm on up-State New York tonight as the death toll reached nine and new snow squalls struck many areas.

Thousands of skiers in the East are beginning to check up on steel edges and wooden runners in preparation for a season that will enable them to make up for last year's lean diet., Already a feeling of gayety and festivity has permeated their ranks as reports from the "Northlands" indicate that it won't be long before a spreading maze of ski tracks will out up the high slopes and mountain tops.

A manifesto signed by the adherents of the Opposition's "non-aggression pact" for the duration of the elections--Dr. Julius Maniu, National Peasant party leader; Constantin Argetoianu, leader of the Agrarian Union party;
Miss Myllicent Bartholomew, aunt and guardian of Freddie Bartholomew, won complete control today over the 13-year-old film star's interests and affairs.
Bullock Mary, a pointer owned by Judge James H. Sims of Union Springs, Ala., and handled by Ed Farrior, placed first in the Pointer Club of America's open derby field trial stakes completed today.

King Winter has crossed up the men from New York who came to the Adirondack Mountains to operate the new steel snow-removal machines in a "practice session." The ten machines bought by the Greater City to handle its Winter drifts scraped along today in a new two-inch snowfall.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gave a tea this afternoon at 4 o'clock and at 5 o'clock was hostess at another "departmental tea." at which she was assisted in receiving by Mrs. Claude Swanson, Mrs. Henry A. Wallace and Mrs. Daniel Roper.

Mrs. Margaret G. Smith of Blackwell Mills, Belle Mead, authority on special library training methods and a member of the staff of the Newark Public Library, died in St. Peter's Hospital here today after a long illness. She was in her late thirties.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conducting, gave a program last night at Carnegie Hall whose chief items of anticipation were the Beethoven Sixth ("Pastoral") Symphony and the first performance of Isidor Achron's Piano Concerto in B flat minor, the composer as soloist.

A victory celebration was held tonight in honor of Captain George H. Monsell, sailing master who headed the twenty-three professionals on Harold S. Vanderbilt's successful America's Cup defender Ranger last Summer.
Benito Mussolini's second son, Bruno, and Major Attilio Biseo are preparing to lead a flight of three planes to South America for propaganda purposes.

Donald Budge, Oakland, Calif., redhead who gained the final of the Victorian tennis championships today with an 8-6, 6-3, 8-6 victory over Vivian McGrath of Australia, underwent medical treatment for a sore shoulder after the match.

Gas-light nights in New York, when Niblo's Garden was often the scene of social festivities, and memories of the hoop-skirt and bustle, were revived last night at the Fireman's Ball at the American Music Hall, 141 East Fifty-fifth Street.
The West Side Association of Commerce wants everybody to forget there ever was a "Hell's Kitchen" on the midtown West Side.

Showing splendid progress since last season, Miss Dorothy Grimmelmann, former New York University star now carrying the colors of the Salle Santelli, came through to victory on her home strips last night in the open women's foil competition held. under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

Urban (Red) Faber, last of baseball's great spitball pitchers and for twenty years a major league star, said tonight he has signed a contract to instruct young players in the school Ray L. Doan will conduct at Hot Springs, Ark.

The board of directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation declared a year-end dividend of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 24 to stockholders of record on Dec. 17, at a special meeting here yesterday.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
A large industrial property in Newark, N. J., with frontages on three streets was reported yesterday to have passed into new hands.
Mr. and Mrs. Luther A. Wait entertained with a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club. Their guests included:

Harry F. Wolf of the Montclair Athletic Club, the country's outstanding amateur squash tennis ace, advanced to the final round of the annual Fall scratch tournament of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association yesterday when he defeated Edward L. Kemble, his Montclair team-mate, in straight games.
Gross assets, $2,339; net, $1,850. To Ella B. Anderson, widow. Chief assets, real estate, $1,100. Wildebush, Howard Makinin, attorneys, 123 William St.

The Bank of Canada issued today its statement for the week ended yesterday, showing an increase of more than $2,000,000 in notes in circulation. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit labilities was 53.36 per cent, compared with 52.59 the previous week.

Great interest was aroused here today by dispatches from Berlin quoting General Chiang Po-li, Chinese special envoy, as having denied that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was likely to go into retirement soon, leaving the government to be headed by Wang Ching-wei, former Premier, and Chang Chun, former Foreign Minister, who would make peace with Japan.

The policy of imperial preference was stressed without qualification tonight by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain as the most important contributing force alike to the British Empire's growing prosperity and the "spiritual unity" of the United Kingdom and the Dominions.

Jeanne Gautier, youthful French violinist, made an agreeable impression at her local debut recital given at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Miss Gautier received her musical education at the Paris Conservatoire. She has given many concerts abroad, having made appearances in Greece, Rumania and England as well as in her native land.
Practice scores in the high 60's indicated tonight the new fourteen club limitation wasn't going to bother the contestants in the $10,000 Miami-Biltmore golf tournament starting tomorrow.
Your quick departure from the places where We used to meet was like a shadow changed From light to darkest dark. And I, deranged
Pedestrians under 16 years of age are by far the best traffic risks, according to J. R. Crossley, vice president of the Automobile Club of New York.

Despite the fact that we saw only does, the other New York deer hunters seem to have had a successful season. The Conservation Commission report indicates that this State had the largest "take" of deer this season than any since 1924.

Hudson County Republicans tried to elect two members of the State Committee in the September primaries. Some of them tried too hard. After a recount Circuit Court Justice Brown, sitting at Jersey City, has declared the election invalid on account of fraud.

Asserting that the majority of members of the Textile Export Association of the United States of America was thoroughly in sympathy with the Cuban regulations governing goods eligible for admission to Cuba at favored tariff rates, Harry Lauten, chairman of the group's Latin-American committee,

The Senate confirmed today the appointment of Joseph R. Jackson of New York as associate judge of the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals. It also confirmed Henry White Edgerton of New York and Fred M. Vinson of Kentucky as associate justices of the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

Melrich V. Rosenberg, author and publishers' representative, died last night of a heart attack at his home, 1,182 Broadway, at the age of 33. Mr. Rosenberg, who was graduated from Cornell University in 1925, was the author of "Eleanor of Aquitaine," which appeared in February of this year, and "With Sword and Song," published last month.
The advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange here continued yesterday with foreign and domestic trade interests together with commission houses bidding for a limited supply of contracts.
Estate, less than $5,000. To William Bannon, brother, address undetermined; three specific bequests; Rose T. Offerman, sister, executrix, specific insurance and mortgages.
White Plains Rd (15-3936), e s, 100 ft n of McGraw Ave. 125x100; Loring Estates, Inc. to Fern Management Corp, 152 W 42d St.

Business in the stock markets here was extremely small today and price movements generally were irregular. Gilt-edge issues improved slightly, while among the foreign loans Brazilian issues were firm on rumors of an early debt settlement.

The Rangers put on a third-period sprint to beat their New York rivals, the Americans, 8--4, tonight in an exhibition game for charity. Lester Patrick's crew rammed in four goals in the final period to break a 4-all tie.

Certificates confirming the merger of American Equities Company into the Interational Utilities Corporation were filed yesterday in Dover, Del., and Baltimore, Md. Under terms of the merger, which were approved by shareholders of both concerns,

After pleading guilty yesterday to the State's charge that he had run down a young woman deliberately and struck and robbed her, Edward Sienkiewicz, 30 years old, of 2,927 Coddington Avenue, the Bronx, was sent by Judge James Barrett
For the first time since 1915 the Socialist members of the lower house today voted for the government's national defense appropriations which were adopted by the unprecedented majority of 85 to 9.
Eugene Leigh, famous as a race horse trainer for having trained Epinard, died this morning at his residence at Maison Lafitte, training center near Paris, at the age of 77.
Gifts totaling $8,251.14 came in yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund from 310 contributors. They brought the total received so far this year to $69,631.94.
Several witnesses who said they spoke for consumers found fault today with the new government-fixed prices for soft coal, provided under the second Guffey Act.

City College will open its 1937-38 varsity swimming schedule tonight by opposing Fordham in a dual meet in the C. C. N. Y. pool. Captain Gori Bruno, 220 and 440 yard free-style star, will lead the Lavender swimmers into action.
The Montclair Junior League sponsored the world premiere of "Wine of Choice," a New York Theatre Guild production at the Montclair Theatre tonight to aid its charitable projects. The play, by S. N.

The marriage of Miss Olga V. Yurevitch, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Vsevolod A. Yurevitch of New York and this community, to Lieut. Comdr. Albert G. Hillberg of the Civil Engineering Corps Reserve, U. S. N., took place this evening at the home of the bride's uncle, General Theodore A. Lodijenski and Mrs. Lodijenski.

A delegation of Committee for Industrial Organization organizers, with their attorney, Morris L. Ernst, described today to a group of Representatives conditions facing labor agents in Jersey City, where Mayor Frank Hague is accused of unfair treatment of union organizers.

The schedule committee of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League announced completed plans for this season's play yesterday. Competition in the circuit, which for the past five years has featured the early campaign leading up to the championship, will get under way after the holidays and continue through the second Saturday of March.

Another site on the Henry Hudson Parkway in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been selected for improvement with an apartment house. The southeast corner of the parkway and West 231st Street was sold by Jamison-Moran, as broker, for Mrs. Mildred De Pace to the Max-Gor Realty Corporation.

Business observers, who regard the cotton gray goods market as an excellent barometer of general conditions, were cheered considerably yesterday, with the sales of some 20,000,000 yards of cloth, the largest turnover in many months.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today the cash income of farmers in the United States in the first ten months of 1937 was approximately $751,000,000 above their income for the same period last year.
Madame de Thebes," who achieved world fame as a clairvoyante by prophesying the World War and many other capital events, died in a local hospital today after a long illness.

The sixth annual Miami Biltmore Fashion Show and Ball will take place tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event was inaugurated in 1932 by Colonel Henry L. Doherty, president of the Florida Year-Round Clubs, and has been given under his sponsorship each year as a benefit for the Goddard Neighborhood Center,

Investment purchases accounted for a large share of the real property transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday. The two five-story apartment houses at 426-28 West Forty-eighth Street, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, were acquired by J. P. Finneran, operator, from Marie J. Bowen in the first change of ownership for these parcels in forty years.

The Grace Line announced yesterday the itinerary of a new passenger and freight service which it will start in January between New York, the Bahamas and Carribean and South American ports through the transfer of its luxury liners Santa Rosa, Santa Paula and Santa Elena from the intercoastal service.

Andrew Strug, Polish novelist, died today. He was 62 years old. Andrew Strug, who used the pen name of Galecki Taddeus, was born at Lublin, Poland, on Nov. 26, 1875, of a family of Polish landowners, and studied philosophy at the University of Cracow.

The report that Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, had been selected by President Roosevelt to succeed Robert W. Bingham as Ambassador to Great Britain drew favorable comment today from members of both branches of Congress, although leaders generally refrained from stating their approval until the announcement had been made officially.

Ordered that the following members of the uniformed force shall be allowed the time served by them in the Police Department. which shall be included and counted as service in the Fire Department: Firemen Fourth Grade Edward F. Mulcahy, Engine 86; Dominick F. Florello, Engine 215; Martin F. Carmody, Engine 215.

Following a complaint of neighbors, the Board of Selectmen today issued an order to Judge Townsend Scudder, retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court, and Mrs. Alice McCutcheon Scudder, to remove a majority of their dogs from their kennels on the estate on or before Feb. 1.
Arrangements were made by the Supreme Court today to hear arguments next week on a series of case decisions which are likely to have a marked effect upon the tax program of Congress.

From the way people were scurrying through this city, as voluntary aides to Santa Claus, it seemed yesterday as though the generous old gentleman would not forget a single child when Christmas comes. A good many of the scurriers wore uniforms, but their minds were not filled with thoughts of war or aggression, but with the spirit of Christmas.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn sold houses in that borough as follows: 432 East Fifty-first Street to George Waltram through John Baldanza; 3,705 Avenue L to Lee Myers through the Nelson B. Nelson Corporation;
The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

A reduction in world production of tin in the face of falling prices and fear of a drop in consumption in the United States, was forecast tonight as a likely result of tomorrow's meeting of the International Tin Committee.

Cooperation in plans to achieve a nation-wide program of residential construction through I ivate initiative, "as a driving force in economic improvement" was voted by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, meeting here yesterday.

Guy A. Boeche, a wood engraver for the Conde Nast Publishing Company. died suddenly of a heart attack at his home, 112 Pollard Road here today. He was 60 years old. Born and educated in Chicago, Mr. Boeche was first employed as a magazine cover engraver for The Ladies Home Journal and was later with the Color Plate Engraving Company of New York.

A protest against the present budget plans to decrease expenditures for the Civilian Conservation Corps for the next fiscal year was made to President Roosevelt today by a subcommittee of the Democratic Steering Committee of the House.

At the monthly meeting of the Cruising Club, held last night at the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, several members of the organization recounted their experiences during extensive cruises last Summer.

Noted artists came to this Connecticut valley village today to pay a final tribute to Miss Florence Ann Griswold, "patron saint" of the art colony here. They joined friends and members of her family at funeral services in the white pillared Griswold mansion,

Another chapter in the warfare between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was opened today when the C. I. O. announced it had issued a charter of affiliation to the United Furniture Workers of America, a union established recently in accordance with a decision made by a group of furniture unions in and out of both organizations.

While trading in wool markets this week continued light, sentiment was more cheerful and the trade looked forward to a decided improvement in sales after Jan. 1, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 7: CAPTAINS Carpender, A. S., the Northampton. to duty as Professor of Naval Science and Tactics, Northwestern University, Evanston, Ill.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday he had declined definitely appointment by Mayor La Guardia as chairman of the new City Planning Commission. Mr. Moses refused to discuss why he had- refused the MIayor's offer of one of the most important municipal positions created by the new city charter going into effect Jan. 1.

The government was invited to "sit down with business and with labor to cure the present depression, before it gets beyond control" in an address last night by Colby M. Chester as chairman of the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Reports from Chicago that one of the main objectives of the National Association of Retail Druggists in 1938 would be a reduction in the wholesale prices of magazines and elimination of the service charge failed to impress publishers here yesterday.

The offer of higher wages for greater output has brought the production rate of the WPA sewing project in this city "within striking distance" of the rate prevailing in private garment factories, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

A trade practice conference sponsored by the Federal Trade Commission will be held for the fur industry at the Hotel New Yorker on Dec. 29 with Commissioner Charles H. March presiding, the commission announced today.

Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont, who would "purge" the Republican party of reactionaries and rebuild it with younger. more progressive men, said here today that he would be in favor of a coalition of antiNew Deal Democrats and Republicans, although it might involve the dropping of the title "Republican" for the party.

The United States liner American Merchant will sail today for London via Plymouth, carrying among her passengers Mrs. M. G. Ferguson, N. M. Sonmez, Miss Eva Urmy, Aksel Neilsen, J. Dalbert Coutts, Mrs. Mildred N. Smith, E. W. HIarker, R. C. Pawsey and Robert N. P. Jackson.

If and when his automobile Is stolen again, Theodore L. Kamille of 1,750 Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, earnestly hopes that police will pick it up instead of putting tags on it for parking overtime. It cost him $2 yesterday.

Miss Helen Keller, who by all ordinary standards is blind, deaf and mute, paid an unexpected visit yesterday afternoon to the annual meeting of the New York Association for the Blind in Lighthouse 1 at 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

Nils Gustaf Dalen, inventor of the Aga beacon and sun valve light, winner of the Nobel prize for physics, died today at the age of 68. He had been blind for the last twenty-five years as the result of a laboratory explosion.
Twenty-six cash gifts totaling $22,541 were made to Columbia University in November, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday.

Proposals of the State Insurance Department that the requirements of capital and surplus of casualty insurance and surety companies be increased were opposed yesterday at the continued public hearing of the Joint Legislative Committee for the Revision of the Insurance Laws, in the State Building, 80 Center Street.

Coming from a part of the world where things are deliberately made to discourage use, where sheets are fastened to blankets by numberless buttons, where libraries are built to guard books against obtrusive readers, where the State is an instrument ingeniously devised for making people as miserable as possible, I looked forward with joyful expectation to this country, the abode of common sense and automatic refrigerators.
The construction of four new public buildings here at a cost of $452,416 was proposed today in a brochure distributed to taxpayers by the village board of trustees.
The general level of wholesale prices continued unchanged in the week ended on Dec. 4, thus halting a decline which had been in progress since late in August.
The United States Army has, except for machine guns, only forty-two modern mobile anti-aircraft guns available for the defense of continental United States,
W. Herbert Adams of 65 East Fifty-fifth Street has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Gay Adams, to Richard C. P. Coogan, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Gordon Coogan of Madison, N. J.

Voting today in the special labor election ordered by Governor Martin, employes of the Inman-Poulsen Lumber Company chose the Committee for Industrial Organization as their collective bargaining agency.

A standard educational program for advertising students here, suc as the Advertising Association of Great Britain sponsors, was advocated yesterday by G. Russell Chapman, secretary of the English organization, at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.
A capacity audience is expected at the Metropolitan'Opera House this afternoon for the performance of "Tristan und Isolde," the first benefit matinee at the Metropolitan this season.

The coldest weather so far this year is expected today, when, according to the official Weather Bureau forecast, the temperature will drop to 15 degrees. The cold snap will be accompanied by continued fair weather, it is predicted. Yesterday the mercury fell to 24 degrees at 8:45 A. M.

His fight with Max Schmeling only four days away, Harry Thomas, the Chicago heavyweight who hopes to crash the championship picture, went through a spirited workout today. The Middle Western fighter meets Schmeling in Madison Square Garden on Monday night, and from what he showed today is in top physical condition for the German.

Whether the organization of a labor group in Jersey City, such as the Committee for Industrial Organization, is "an attempted invasion" is decided by one man, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City said yesterday. That man, the Mayor said emphatically is himself.
At a late hour last night the Shubert office decided to postpone "Love of Women" until next Monday night at the Golden Theatre. Two new actors in the cast require further rehearsals.

Fred Haug, field agent for the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, said today that company officials had assured the union that veteran employes of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company would have steady work despite a recession in orders.

Kenneth F. Simpson, president of the New York County Republican committee, has been endorsed for the nomination for Republican national committeeman from this State, to succeed Charles D. Hilles, by the New York Young Republican Club and by the board of governors of the Young Women's Republican Club of New York.
Fourteen youths, mostly members of Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German party, today received suspended sentences after their trial on homosexual charges.

A gift of $300,000 from the Maurice and Laura Falk Foundation to the Carnegie Institute of Technology for the support of a program of education and research in social relations was announced today by President Robert E. Doherty of Carnegie.

The House Labor Committee decided tonight to stick to its guns in the matter of offering an amendment to the wages and hours bill which would put administration of the measure under the Department of Labor instead of the five-man board which the Senate bill, passed at the last session, would establish.

Charles Fahy, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, told 3,000 members of the National Association of Manufacturers at a "labor clinic," held in connection with their annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, that he opposed amendment or modification of the Labor Relations Act to protect employers against unions that break contracts in violation of the law.

New evidence based on experiments into the stratosphere last Summer concerning the mystery of the cosmic rays, the ultimate solution of which may explain the origin and the destiny of the universe. was presented here yesterday by Dr. Robert A. Millikan, Nobel Prize physicist, as he opened the Pupin lectures of Columbia University.
Mrs. Harris Fahnestock will give a luncheon on Tuesday at her home, 15 East Sixty-sixth Street, for Miss Helen Michalis, debutante daughter of Clarence G. Michalis.
The appoinment of Dr. Carl Shoup of New York and Dr. Roger Traynor of California as tax consultants to the Treasury was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau.
Daniel Crawford Sr., a building constructor and hotel man, died today in his apartment at the Hotel Philadelphia after an illness of several months. He was 60.

Harry P. Aumack, an assistant cashier of the Chase National Bank, died yesterday afternoon in the Paul Kimball Hospital, Lakewood, N. J., of a heart attack suffered a few hours before while at the First National Bank of Toms River, N. J.

A meeting of this town's 1,300 inhabitants has been called for Tuesday to discuss a zoning proposal which would indirectly block the establishment here by the German-American Bund of a week-end Summer camp for 3,000 to 7,000 followers.

JANITOR ENGINEER (CUSTODIAN ENGINEER). Salary: Compensation depends upon the size of the building to which assignment is made and is commensurate with the high grade of experience required; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies: Nineteen in the Denartment of Education.

Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, set forth yesterday a program of tax reform at the midwinter conference of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Association, which he asserted would halt business recession and spur economic activity.

League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Books and Plays," William Lyon Phelps. Pan-American luncheon and fashion show, Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, Jose Tercero, Nathan M. Ohrbach.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Nov. 27 amounted to 304,156,000 barrels, off 168,000 from the week before, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Television over wire lines, transmitted from the lobby of the Hotel Lincoln to Jack Dempsey's Restaurant, was demonstrated yesterday as the first installation of a new system designed by J. Hoyt Peck, New York inventor,

Edgar F. Luckenbach, president of the steamship line bearing his name, suggested to Congress today that subsidized vessels be barred from this country's intercoastal trade. Government aid to ships in this service, he told the House Merchant Marine Committee,

Lumber production increased last week, but the daily average declined more than seasonally. The adjusted index eased to 56.8. It was 58.7 for the previous week and 74.8 for the week ended Dec. 5, 1936.

The 1937 Associated Press "Little All-America" football team may be little in name but not in stature. The team-five players from the South and Southwest, three from the Middle West, two from the East and one from the Pacific Coastaverages better than 189 pounds.

Movements in the livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 23,000, including 6,000 directs; 10 to 15 cents lower than yesterday's average; spots off more. Bulk good and choice 150200 pounds, $8.25-$8.35: tops, $8.35: 210-240 pounds, $7.85-$8.20; 250-300 pounds, $7.50$7.85. Most good Dacking sows. $6.75-$7.10.

The estate of Mantis J. Van Sweringen is "hopelessly insolvent," Trafton M. Dye, administrator, said today in filing in probate court a schedule of claims, debts and liabilities against the estate aggregating $68,123 760.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday withstood a moderate volume of profit-taking and tax-selling. After moving forward early, quotations eased from the highest levels of the morning, although most issues ended the day on a firm undertone.
A large increase in the sale of cuff links and dress jewelry since Sept. 1 was reported today by S. Rae Hickok, president of Hickok Manufacturing Company.

Senator Burke, Democrat of Nebraska, asked a Senate investigation today of charges that the National Labor Relations Board had been guilty of "continuous and flagrant violation of the will of Congress."

The Harvard Club's strong squash racquets team, headed by Germain G. Glidden, the national champion, advanced into a tie with the University Club unit for Class A honors in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association race last night.

The Minneapolis-Moline Power Implement Company and subsidiaries in the report for the year ended on Oct. 31, released yesterday, showed a net profit of $1,524,585 after depreciation, interest, Federal income and undistributed profits taxes and other charges.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw of 60 East Sixty-sixth Street entertained with a dinner last night at her home, later taking her guests to the opera. In her party were Mr. and Mrs. Dana Converse Backus, Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Hadley, Mr. and Mrs. Luther Lee Blake, Miss Pauline Askwith and Joachim Stressemann.

Clint Frank of Yale, Samuel Chapman of California and Bryon White of Colorado, all backs, were chosen unanimously for the allAmerica eleven named by Collier's yesterday. The team was selected by Collier's board and over fifty football coaches.

A Spring business revival which will be wide in scope and steady in progress was forecast yesterday by Carl H. Henrikson, director of education of the National Association of Credit Men, at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Rotary Club of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

A cavalry sergeant bugled "A-Hunting We Will Go" tonight over fat slices of the deer which Vice President Garner shot during his recent hunt in Pennsylvania. The dinner was given by Senator Guffey for the Vice President and twenty-four other guests.

The use of "steinie" bottles for packaging beer increased to 24 per cent of the total packaged volume in July, as compared with 15.4 per cent last Spring and 9.4 per cent in July, 1936, according to a survey just completed by the Ross Federal Market Research organization for the Glass Container Association.

The New Jersey Grange went on record today in opposition to "regimentation of the farmer and any compulsory crop control" in a resolution adopted at the sixty-fifth annual convention at the Hotel Morton here.

Tokyo received reports from the Nanking war front today that Japanese forces had launched a huge offensive against Nanking. The reports said the offensive started at 12:30 P. M., Nanking time [11:30 P. M. Thursday in New York].

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated and charges, but excluding any in come or losses of Spanish subsidiaries, of $7,044,070.

The Kinsey Distilling Company announced yesterday that $4,099,000 of collateral trust notes had been issued for the period from April 1, 1936, to Nov. 30, 1937. In the period redemption of notes amounted to $2,933,000, leaving notes of $1,166,000 outstanding on Nov. 30.

Today's major events: "Tristan und Isolde," afternoon, and "Manon," evening, Metropolitan Opera House; Samuel Dushkin, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Anne Mundy, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Maria Maximovitch, soprano, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Federal Opera Chorus, Theatre of Music, evening.

D. Paul Reed, J. R. Whitbeck, J. S. Harrison and G. S. Carrel, all seeded players, filled the semifinal brackets in the fourth annual invitation Class B singles squash racquets tournament at the Squash Club yesterday.

Red Pollard, Seabiscuit's rider, was suspended today for the balance of the Tanforan meeting because of a foul he committed yesterday aboard Exhibit, Seabiscuit's workmate. Exhibit was disqualified and placed third in yesterday's feature race.

Thirty-five important administrative positions, having an aggregate salary of $215,000, are vacant in the New York City school system, it was announced yesterday. Candidates for many of these posts are being examined by the Board of Superintendents.

Prince Alexander Lopouchin Demidoff, once one of the greatest noblemen of imperial Russia, died today from a fall from a hay wagon, with which he had been eking out an existence in East Finland. He was 68 years old.

Those mighty Redskins from Washington, their noses blue from cold, arrived today on a hunt for bear. Although the frigid weather gave them the shivers, they were confident they would conquer their Western rivals, the Chicago Bears, in the battle for the 1937 professional football championship at Wrigley Field Sunday.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today a final offering of about $50,000,000 in the Treasury's current series of bills which mature around the quarterly income tax date, March 15. In all $450,000,000 of the bills will have been sold in the series.

A county jury toaay Iouna Franz Hanawald guilty of the kidnapping in September of Julius Redlich, 60-year-old operator of the Berkshire Country Club, a Manhattan wine-importing firm and a Florida resort.

Department store sales showed little change from October to November, although a slight increase is usual at this season of year, according to preliminary figures made public toda" by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The board's adjusted index dropped, therefore, from 93 for October to 91 for November.
A new "missing link" between man and the higher apes has been discovered on the island of Java, the Carnegie Institution of Washington said today.

Ernst Lissauer, German poet, died here in obscurity today on his fifty-fifth birthday. He made his name familiar throughout the Englishspeaking world during the first year of 'the World War by his "Hymn of Hate Against England."

As a preliminary step in a program designed to regain the Davis and Wightman Cups from the United States, the British Lawn Tennis Association today decided to set up a training system for promising young players.

Women's waist lines have wriggled into Senate debate on the farm bill. Senator O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, was protesting against an attempt to reduce crop production, saying more consumption of farm products was needed.
With a number of exceptions, top prices for New Year's Eve performances in the legitimate Broadway theatres will represent an increase of 50 per cent or more above the regular scale. Inquiry among

Eight leading manufacturers of aircraft in the United States received invitations yesterday from Pan American Airways to submit bids for planes capable of carrying 100 passengers, with full stateroom, dressing room and dining room accommodations, for a range of 5,000 miles, at a cruising speed of 200 miles an hour. Such aircraft, with a payload of 25,000 pounds, would have ten times the capacity,
A marked let-up developed today in the European demand for cash corn, sales being estimated at only 200,000 bushels. It is understood, however,

Out in Fairfield County, Conn., where the final waves of commuters are scattered among low but rugged hills, where Art and Literature have gone to renew their contact with one of the saltiest of our native- soils and have been followed by business and the professions, eager to be near Culture if not to manufacture it, a problem in conservation has arisen.

Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont appeared before the House Rivers and Harbors Committee today and voiced New England opposition to Chairman Mansfield's bill carrying out President Roosevelt's suggestion for seven Federal regional planning agencies modeled on the Tennessee Valley Authority.

Former City Judge William D.
