Brinnier shot and killed himself at his home here today when two police officers called at his home to serve a warrant issued on charges that he had appropriated to his own use $2,900 of an estate for which he was attorney. He asked the officers to wait while he changed his clothes.

Four well-known American artists received awards of $2,000 each last night to illustrate American literary classics for the Limited Editions Club. Those selected are Thomas Hart Benton, John Steuart Curry, Reginald Marsh and Henry Varnum Poor.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Preliminary consideration is being given to the withdrawal of the Sixth Regiment of United States Marines from Shanghai, with the subsidence of the emergency there. A decision will not be reached for several weeks.

William Peyser, former assistant pri4cipal of Public School 77, in the Bronx, who was a classmate in college and close friend of United States Senator Robert Wagner, died at his home, 260 Valentine Lane, today after an illness of several days. He retired a few weeks ago.

If those hunters and fishermen who are tempted to ignore conservation laws only knew how thoroughly the enforcement agents of the various State conservation bodies carry on their work they would soon banish temptation. Some remarkable arrests are being made all the time, before, during and after the various open seasons.

E. Dana Johnson, for twenty-four years editor of The Santa Fe New Mexican and close friend of the late Senator Cutting, died at a hospital today after a heart attack. He was 58 years old and known throughout the Southwest for his vigorous editorials and firm stand on governmental questions.

At a meeting yesterday of the board of the American I. G. Chemical Corporation directors voted to declare an additional dividend of $2 a share to holders of the common A stock. In addition, a 20-cent distribution was declared to holders of the common B stock. Both are payable on Dec. 28 to stock of record of Dec. 24.

Purchase of a quartet of Stradivarius instruments, two violins, a viola and a 'cello, valued at $250,000, for the use of the Musical Art Quertet, headed by Sacha Jacobsen, was announced yesterday by the Stradivarius Memorial Association, Inc., recently organized to assist talented musical students in obtaining fine musical instruments otherwise beyond their reach.

Alf M. Landon definitely withdrew himself today from consideration for the Republican nomination for President in 1940. Conceding that the possibility might well be "remote," he nevertheless said to reporters:
The University of Georgia presented retiring Coach Harry Mehre with a 26-0 victory over the University of Miami tonight before a stadiumdedicating crowd of 14,625 persons.
Critics here agree in stressing the ingenious plot of Alec Coppel's "I Killed the Count," produced at the Whitehall Theatre tonight. But both
Dartmouth's Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball entry won a hard fought game from Springfield, 40-38, tonight. The contest marked the opening of the local team's season.

Meeting the challenge of the Securities and Exchange Commission that the New York Stock Exchange "clean house," Charles R. Gay, president of the trading body, appointed yesterday a committee of nine financial experts to "consider all aspects of the further development of the organization and administration of the Exchange." The appointees are:

This is the story of the decline of an American town, a town returning to its grass roots. Its history was compressed today in a notice that Postmaster General James A. Farley's own postoffice must close down after a century of service. Business is bad.

The National Airline of Chile has called for bids by Dec. 23 on five airplanes and other aviation equipment, according to a report to the Department of Commerce made public today. Firms able to make early delivery will be accorded preference,

Massenet's "Manon" received its second presentation of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. As before it was heard by an audience of good size and again was enthusiastically welcomed.

Firmly closing its eyes to the possibility that the army of the future may be a cold, mechanized organization of men who have not music in their souls or their ranks, the United States Army recruiting service sent out a call yesterday for flutists,

Two contracts signed Nov. 25, 1935, in which powers of attorney granfed to Senator George L. Berry and his partner, C. A. Harris, were revoked, were introduced today before the three-man Federal commission hearing the condemnation suits brought by the Tennessee Valley Authority against mineral claims of Senator Berry and his associates submerged by Norris Dam.

A test of the penal provisions of the Home Owners Loan Corporation Act was put before the Supreme Court today in the case of Miss Gertrude Kay of Brooklyn. Arguments were concluded and the justices took the case under advisement.

Mrs. Fay Lippmann obtained a divorce from Walter Lippmann yesterday in the Circuit Court, it was disclosed today. Judge Whitehurst ordered the bill of complaint and the testimony sealed and filed in the court records.

University Ave (9-2536), e s, 225 s of Ogden Ave, 101x100; Elizabeth Richmond to Alpe Estates, Inc. 75 Fort Washington Ave. Netherland Ave (13-3424), e s, 463 n of 252d St, 50x100; Emer Holding Corp to Del-Co Construction Corp, 352 E 141st St. Riverdale Ave (13-3424), w a, 450 n of 252d St, 50x101; Emer Holding Corp to Del-Co Construction Corp, 352 E 141st St.
The Triangle Club of Princeton University this evening opened its forty-ninth annual musical comedy production, "Fol-De-Rol," in the McCarter Theatre.

One of the most important things that Congress could do at this time to restore the confidence of business would be to amend the Wagner Labor Relations Act. The disturbing fact about this measure in its present form is not that it supports the principle of collective bargaining.

Mr. and Mrs. George C. Van Dusen gave a dinner tonight at their home. Mr. and Mrs. Homer Sawyer were hosts at luncheon for Mrs. Henry Darlington and her mother, Mrs. Robert Dun Douglass, at the Bath and Tennis Club.
On the eve of the first anniversary of his accession it was announced tonight that King George would broadcast a message to his people on Christmas Day.

Drastic safety measures, especially under Winter flying conditions, have been put into effect by United Airlines, Harold Crary, vice president in charge of traffic, disclosed here yesterday. New minimum altitudes below which its pilots may not fly have been put into the regulations governing operation on all divisions.

For achievements in industrial chemistry in 1937 "which hold great promise for the future of American industry and the American public," the Monsanto Chemical Company received last night an award for chemical engineering before a distinguished gathering of chemists at a dinner at the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Will you impanel a jury of professional football critics and let me present my case for the play-forpay boys? On the strength of the evidence at hand there is only one possible verdict that can be brought in. Hence, reversing the usual

Charles G. Hellinger, an executive of the National Surety Company for the last twenty-eight years, died early yesterday morning in Kingston, N. Y., where he had been visiting since last Friday. His death was due to a heart attack. He was 49 years old.

Joseph Ogden, 39 years old, who shot and killed his roommate on Aug. 17 and tried to hide the crime by shipping the body in a trunk to Memphis, Tenn., was sentenced yesterday by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions to imprisonment of twenty Years to life. The victim,

A group of young women have formed an auxiliary committee for the presentation of "Fifty-Fifty," the golden jubilee production of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania, tomorrow night at the Montclair Theatre and the dance at the Montclair Golf Club later.

The body of John A. Olsen, 65 years old, an accountant employed by the Manufacturers Trust Company, who had been reported missing since last Tuesday, when he left the bank complaining of illness, was found yesterday afternoon in a

The railway equipment manufacturers are providing on an increasingly larger scale specialized types of rolling stock to meet the individual needs of different industries, V. R. Willoughby, general mechanical engineer of the American Car and Foundry Company, said last night before the New York Chapter of the Railway and Locomotive
The Mount Vernon Men's Glee Club of sixty-two members presented its annual Fall concert tonight at the Wood Auditorium here before an audience of about 400 persons. Theodore Van Yorx was the leader.
Stocks closed 1 to 2 points lower; turnover, 1,075,260 shares. United States Government bonds steady, other groups irregular; transactions, $9,420,000.

President Roosevelt's discussion of the needs of the railways aroused approval in railroad circles yesterday. It provided a culmination to a series of developments which indicate that recognition of the railroads' lack of revenues was widespread.
James M. Sweeney, charged with being a member of the O'Connell kidnap gang, pleaded not guilty today to three indictments charging kidnapping, conspiracy and income tax evasion.

" Complete accord" in a discussion of the tax revision program of the Ways and Means Committee was reported after a conference this afternoon among President Roosevelt, Treasury officials and Congressional leaders.
John A. Fahey, chairman of the board of the Federal Home Loan Bank, called yesterday upon private enterprise to play a larger part in stimulation of a housing program for the nation.

Repeated proposals by the Commonwealth Southern Corporation and its affiliated companies in the Tennessee basin for a truce with the Tennessee Valley Authority on the question of power distribution have ben rejected, Wendell L. Willkie, president of the corporation, asserted in Federal court this afternoon.
King Gustaf today presented this year's Nobel Prizes in physics, chemistry, physiology and medicine and literature to their winners in the flower-decked hall of the Stockholm Concert House.

The St. John's University quintet turned back the Pratt Institute team, 47 to 29, in a game that marked the resumption of basketball relations between the schools after a lapse of eleven years, last night in the De Gray Gymnasium in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Mary Grace Worthington, widow of Thomas K. Worthington, Baltimore lawyer, died yesterday in Fernhurst, England, after an illness of several weeks, according to word received here last night. She was 71 years old.

Widespread discussion of the proposals for reduction in interest rates and 90 per cent loans on small homes has obscured another prospective change in FHA regulations which many realty observers believe will prove of considerable benefit to the construction industry.

Curtailment of production and employment in all General Motors Chevrolet plants seemed imminent today, although General Motors officials declined to discuss employment prospects. They said, however, that no general lay-offs in the company's plants were expected.

Emil B. Meyrowitz, founder and president of the Opticians League in New York and head of E. B. Meyrowitz, Inc., 520 Fifth Avenue, one of the world's largest optical firms, died'Thursday at his home, 277 Park Avenue, after an illness of two months. He was 85 years old.

The largest naval manoeuvres in the country's history will be held over several million square miles of the Eastern Pacific in March and April. Almost 175 men of war, about 500 planes and about 50,000 to 60,000 men are expected to participate in "fleet problem nineteen" under

Appearance in uniform of some New York National Guardsmen at a Russian-sponsored social affair brought a demand today by Governor Lehman for an order forbidding militiamen "to further or promote a called nationalistic group."

The stock markets here were spotty and very quiet today, but they closed on a cheerful note. Gilt-edge issues improved, while among the foreign bonds German loans eased. I rnational shares moved downward, with United States Steel and International Nickel losing small amounts.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn unanimously affirmed yesterday the recent decision by Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May upholding the closed shop provision in a contract between the B. M. T. and the Transport Workers Union.

Receipt is hereby gratefully acknowledged of the latest number of Indian Education, "A Fortnightly Field Letter of the Education Division, United States Office of Indian Affairs." The title of the leading article is "Indians Are Not Afraid to Work."

New bond financing this week amounted to $24,512,000, compared with a total of $16,114,300 in new issues marketed last week. During this week a year ago $92,309,500 in new bonds were placed on the market.

Seward Park High School's powerful quintet, runner-up for the city P. S. A. L. crown last season, took first place in the Lower Manhattan division of the circuit yesterday by downing Haaren High, 36 to 12, at Seward.

Banks making loans to farmers should be as conversant with the individual farms as they are with business concerns to which they lend money, Otis A. Thompson, cashier of the National Bank and Trust Company of Norwich, N. Y., said yesterday at a conference on agricultural problems in the State with regard to banking. The conference was at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The engagement has been anounced of Miss Grace Adelaide Brown of this place, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Brown of Seattle, Wash., to George W. N. Riddle, son of Mrs. Ernest Joseph Riddle of Brighton, England, and the late Mr. Riddle.

Calling the membership of the State Transit Commission "deadwood," Mayor La Guardia, at a meeting of the Board of Estimate, said yesterday that he would not refer anything to them as long as he was Mayor.

Thirty-four four and five story tenements in New York City, most of them on the East Side of Manhattan, have been purchased in a block by Irving I. Hiram S. Lewine from a client, of A. S. W. Hutchins, attorneys, through Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., brokers.

The 189th Assembly was held tonight in the Bellevue-Stratford-ballroom and was attended by descendants of notable Philadelphia families and distinguished guests from out of town. Escorts of the patronesses were George W. Norris, Judge Charles Sinkler, Emile C. Geyelin.

Annual Fall meeting of the Middle States Association of History and Social Science Teachers, School of Education, New York University, 10 A. M. Speakers: Daniel C. Knowlton, John W. Withers, E. Schuyler Palmer, Alice V. Keliher, Lyman Bryson. Luncheon at Hotel Albert
SECOND MILITARY AREA Each of the following Medical Department Reserve Officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated: 8th Hospital Center (RAI).

An application was filed yesterday for the incorporation of the Consumer-Farmer Milk Cooperative, which, it is claimed, will be the first cooperative of its kind designed to serve low-income families on a city-wide scale.

Estate owners in Purchase, N. Y., lost their fight today in Supreme Court here to prevent the construction beside Kenilworth Road of a ninety-foot steel water tower, which they contended would dominate the landscape "like a sore thumb" and cause property values to depreciate sharply in the wealthy residential district.

A gain of forty-four votes, the largest number for any one day since the recount began, was recorded today for Senator Lester H. Clee as the recheck continued here of the ballots cast in Hudson County in the recent Governorship election won by United States Senator A.
Amor Brujo, black flyer of the turf from Uruguay, was assigned top weight of 121 pounds today for the $2,500 added one mile Half Moon Handicap to be run at the Tanforan track tomorrow.

Mrs. Theodore Frelinghuysen left the Plaza yesterday to pass the rest of the season in Palm Beach. Mrs. Erastus Corning 2d of Albany is at the Weylin. The Marques and Marquesa Georges de Cuevas, who have been at the Pierre since their arrival from Europe, will leave next month for Palm Beach.

Skiing enthusiasts looked forward tonight to the first week-end of the season favorable to their sport. Reports from the Speculator, Gore Mountain and Lake Placid areas are most favorable for the skiers, with some of the mountain sport available in the Catskills.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, told the Chicago World Trade Conference tonight that "economic strife between business and government is retarding the general prosperity of our nation." The blame for this,
Miss Mona Law Fotterall Trench and Robert Hamilton Murray, whose engagement was announced earlier this week, will be married next Saturday in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
R. S. Reynolds, president of the Reynolds Metal Company, announced today the company's executive and central offices wbuld be moved from New York to Richmond on Jan. 1.

Five thousand union workers in the Mexican oil industry defied President Lazaro Cardenas's orders and walked out at noon today at Tampico on a twenty-four-hour strike in protest against the government's failure to rule on the oil wage controversy in the seven months since the nation-wide general oil strike.
The International Tin Committee fixed the quota today for the first quarter of 1938 at 70 per cent of standard tonnage. The quota for the current quarter is 110 per cent.
Chubby Jane Withers, who is going to grow up one of these years and become a heavyweight wrestler, returned to the Roxy yesterday with another case history of a Little Miss Fixit. "45 Fathers,"

Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., using only eleven of the fourteen clubs in his golf bag, fashioned a four-under-par 67 today to take a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open tournament.

Thirty-four were killed and more than sixty injured in a Scottish train wreck tonight. In a blinding snowstorm the Edinburgh-Glasgow express crashed into the rear of a stationary passenger train near the isolated village of Castlecary, Stirlingshire.

President Roosevelt spiked the agitation for government ownership of railroads, conferred with Secretary Morgenthau and Congressional leaders over tax matters, and chatted for a time with Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, his opponent in the last Presidential race.

To eliminate any possibility of applicants for unemployment insurance benefits having to wait in long lines and to enable the unemployment insurance administrative staff to concentrate on finding employment for the jobless, all registration for payments during January will be by mail, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, disclosed yesterday.

Although major film companies have agreed not to back plays written by members of the Dramatists Guild, D. A. Doran, an executive on the staff of Columbia Pictures and recently appointed head of its play production department, will sponsor a mid-January presentation of "Sunup to Sundown."

More contracts for the leasing of business space in buildings in Madison Avenue were announced yesterday. The Stafford Chemists, Inc., druggists, took a store at 143 Madison Avenue, through Butts Molloy, Inc., and the Kane Realty Company.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation totaled 587,241 tons in November, 1937, a decrease of 205,069 tons from October and 395,402 tons-less than in November, 1936.

Dillon, Read Co., as sinkingfund agent for Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street Building (One East Fifty-fifth Street Corporation) 4 per cent first-mortgage leasehold bonds due in 1955 announced yesterday that it would receive, until Dec. 24, tenders for the purchase and retirement of these bonds-in an ,amount sufficient to exhaust the sum of $47,152 now in the sinking fund' Bonds so tendered will be

Trial Besults Lieutenant Arthur J. Jones. E. Li. 11 (now Engine 223). Charge: Neglect of duty (permitted member without proper authority to leave quarters for the purpose of using public telephone). Guilty. Sentence suspended.

A strong bill aimed at eliminating the Worst evils of the "hire purchase"-installment buying-system as developed in Britain received such endorsementin the House of Commons today as to make its eventual passage appear assured.

The National Labor Relations Board today certified the National Maritime Union, a C. L O. affiliate, as the exclusive collective bargaining agency for unlicensed personnel on three steamship lines with home ports in New York.

A new record for attendance at a schoolboy football game in New Jersey is expected to be set tomorroW at Foley Field, where the Bloomfield High School Bengals, Northern New Jersey champions, and the New Brunswick Zebras, Central New Jersey rulers, will battle for the unofficial championship of the State.

Mrs. Florence Baker Loew, daughter of the late George F. Baker, left a net estate of $4,158,538, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Her husband, William Goadby Loew, and four daughter are the principal beneficiaries.
" Well, I guess you got the best of it," President Roosevelt told former Governor Landon when they met at the White House late this afternoon.

Agitation for government ownership of railroads, which had been growing in certain quarters since they applied for a rate increase, received a distinct setback today when President Roosevelt set himself against any such plan.

Overwhelming success in the Treasury's mid-December financing was reported today in a statement by Secretary Morgenthau covering the amount in which the Treasury's issues of bonds and notes were subscribed and the extent to which holders of Treasury notes maturing on Feb. 1 availed themselves of the provision for an exchange of their securities.

J. R. Whitbeck of the Harvard Club and J. S. Harrison of the Squash Club will meet at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon in the final of the Class B invitation squash racquets tournament at the Squash Club as the result of semi-final victories yesterday.

Just as 1936 was the season of one major trend in college football, so 1937 was the season of many trends. The annual Associated Press survey, which has as its object the discovery of which way the football winds are blowing, shows they were blowing every which way.

The discovery of important new roles for vitamins A, B, C, and G, as well as the development of a revolutionary method for extracting natural vitamins in large quantities in their purest form by a newly designed vitamin still, was reported last night by several authorities at a symposium on vitamins at the Hotel Pennsylvania,

Maybe those two Omaha bulls had a premonition yesterday of what was at the end of the "last mile" for them. Maybe that is why they escaped from the truck carrying them through the Holland Tunnel to their doom. At any rate, they tied up traffic in the eastbound tube for ten minutes at 10:30A.M.
Japan has shipped another consignment of gold, amounting to $7,300,000, to this country, according to reports received by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.
Charles W. Murphy, oldest practicing attorney in Fairfield County, died today at his home in Danbury after a brief illness.
Having advanced by a clever stratagem to the very gates of Nanking, Japanese troops are shelling the wall tonight and desperate Chinese troops are engaging the attackers at many points

The Benjamin Franklin Foundation, Inc., Philadelphia, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering Benjamin Franklin Foundation certificates to be offered for estimated cash proceeds of $10,000,000, which will be used for investment.

Dr. Walter E. Spahr, secretary-treasurer of the Economists National, Committee on Monetary Policy, advocated tonight a return to the gold standard, return of relief to the States and a budget balanced "by cutting down expenses, not by increasing taxes."

Tonight's closings on Broadway are two-"Juno and the Paycock," a routine departure, and "Siege," which will have had six performances at the Longacre. Another casualty of the week is "Something for Nothing," which opened on Thursday at the Windsor but did not wait to take the traditional Saturday night exit: it closed with last
The Duchess of Windsor has been placed last of all Britain's Duchesses, the current edition of Burke's Peerage disclosed today, on the anniversary of the Duke's abdication.
Gross assets, $5,186; net, $4,623. To Mary L. Prial and Josephine T. Clark, sisters, onehalf residue each. Chief assets, jointly owned property, $4,224. Joseph Schwartzman. attorney. 551 5th Ave.

Gray and finished stocks of all kinds of hosiery at the end of October were 20.2 per cent ahead of those of a year ago, despite a drop in production in October of 17 per cent from last year, and unfilled orders at the end of the month were 15.5 per cent under 1936, data issued by the Census Bureau yesterday showed.

The St. Ann's Academy basketball team turned back Cathedral Boys High School, 20 to 10, as competition in the Manhattan-Richmond Division of the C. H. S. A. A. began yesterday. The game, played on the victors' court, marked their fourth straight triumph this season.

Now that the collapse of the Chinese armies can no longer be concealed from the rest of the world, astonishing admissions are coming from high Chinese officials in Hankow and Hong Kong, while the few remaining quietly in the foreign areas of Shanghai are beginning to talk with unusual frankness and extreme bitterness.

Paul Moss, License Commissioner, licensed yesterday three former burlesque houses for a ninety-day period. The theatres, which for several weeks have been operating without any permits, are the Republic, 209 West Forty-second Street; the Eltinge, 236 West Fortysecond Street, and the Star, 389 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

The New York University basketball team opened its season last night by defeating the University of Newark, 47-30, at the University Heights gymnasium. The victory was the Violets' forty-first in a row on the home court.

The Board of Estimate moved yesterday to construct a complete circumferential highway around Manhattan Island when it accepted plans for a new Harlem River Drive connecting the East River Drive with the Triborough Bridge.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 55-Mary Duke Biddle, petr., v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and 505-Commissioner of Internal Revenue, petr., v. George W. Elkins. Argued for both.
Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh slipped quietly into the nation's capital this morning, motoring from Englewood and driving directly to the offices and exhibition rooms of the Carnegie Institution.

The protective committee for preferred stockholders of the Sohulte Retail Stores Corporation has addressed a letter to stockholders reporting progress in the negotiations for a reorganization, with final details still to be determined, and announcing that the store at Eightysixth Street and Broadway has ben re-equipped as one of ten stores where a new merchandising policy is being tested.

The frontier between two government systems, Belgium is a good observation post on both. The Belgians have definitely -chosen their own road. They have rejected extremist movements on both sides to follow the middle way of democracy.

Respondents in the Interstate Commerce Commission's proceeding on lake coal demurrage charges today petitioned the commission for a rehearing and indefinite postponement of the date for filing exceptions to the examiner's report.

Miss Marcille Littlefield, daughter of Mrs. Mildred F. Littlefield of 155 Riverside Drive and of George Homer Littlefield, also of this city. was married last night in the West End Presbyterian Church to Richard Servis Petty, son of Mrs. Robert Davison Petty of New York and the late Professor Petty, former dean of the New York Law School.

In contrast to the fanfare that marked its establishment about a year ago, the Jury School of the United States District Court in New Jersey was abolished today with a laconic announcement from the four district judges.
Modern Age Books, Inc., the new publishing house started last September by Richard Storrs Childs and Samuel W. Craig, has now published twenty-eight books under its imprint, The Three Seals.

In a thrilling match, Mrs. Ary J. Lamme successfully defended her metropolitan women's squash racquets title by defeating Miss Margaret Bostwick, a former titleholder, 16-13, 15-3, 16-17, 15-11, yesterday at the Cosmopolitan Club.
The Harvard Club's Class C squash tennis team went into a tie for the lead in the metropolitan interclub series last night by halting the Crescent A. C., 5 to 0.

Henry Ford and the Ford Motor Company transferred about 1,200 acres near the Rouge plant to the Ford Foundation today, giving rise to reports that the foundation soon would begin an ambitious housing project.

Mr. and Mrs. Darragh A. Park of Glen Head, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith G. Park, to Alastair Bradley Martin, son of Bradley Martin of Westbury and the late Mrs. Martin.

Two goals in the last period, scored within four minutes of each other, enabled the New York Rovers to register a 4-2 triumph over the Bronx Tigers in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game last night in the New York Coliseum before 2,200 persons.

As a result of trading players between Columbia and Warners, several realignments of casts are under way at the Burbank studio. The Warners have received Melvyn Douglas in exchange for Joan Blondell and he will be seen in the annual musical, this year known as "Gold Diggers in Paris," which will feature Rudy Vallee, Rosemary Lane and Johnny (Scat) Davis.

With Jose Iturbi as conductor, the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra played at the County Center here tonight before an audience of about 2,300 persons. It was the third event in the current Mrs. Julian Olney series.

As a means of stimulating construction activity, B. G. Dahlberg, president of the Celotex Corporation, yesterday suggested Federal legislation to provide tax relief as an incentive for building and repair work.
12th St, 334 W; Evelyn C. Murnan to Beryl R. McClaskey, 139 Lexington Ave, purchase money mtg $6,500 ($8.50). 14th St, 344-6 W; E. Gluck, referee, to St. Luke's Hospital, foreclosure ($70).

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 a net income of $13,517,967 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, interest, subsidiary preferred dividends and other deductions.

The State Banking Department has approved the change of location of the Lawyers Trust Company of New York from 160 Broadway to 135 Broadway, according to an announcement in the department's weekly bulletin.

Boynton Ave, 1,241, 24xl00; Mortgage Commission of N Y against Rose Rosenbaum; due, $11,005: taxes, etc., $1,234; to plaintiff for $5,000 Ward Ave. 1,019, 25x100; Banco Di Napoli Trust Co. of N Y against Giuseppi Mileti; due, $13,107; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Residential properties formed the bulk of the trading in New Jersey properties reported yesterday. The four-story brick apartment at 92-98 Waldo Avenue, Jersey City, was sold by a client of J. I. Kislak, Inc., to the Norman Management Corporation, a group of investors.

The mortgage of $700,000 on The Clebourne, the twelve-story apartment house at 924 West End Avenue, has been renewed for five years by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, through Slawson Hobbs, broker.

Dr. Henry H. Lucas, a member of the staff of St. Joseph's Hospital here, who had practiced medicine in Paterson for forty-two years, died last night at his home here at the age of 74. He was graduated from the University of Michigan Medical School in 1895.

An audience of dentists saw the first histological proof of the presence of nerve tissue in the dentin of the tooth yesterday in a series of slides illustrating a paper delivered at the closing session of the Greater New York Dental Meeting by Dr. Harold A. Osserman, a member of the dental staff of the New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital.
The final auction sale of the real estate holdings of five closed national banks in Westchester County will be held today at the New Rochelle Women's Club, 50 Lockwood Avenue, New Rochelle.
Universal Bible Sunday will be observed tomorrow in all Protestant churches. Sermons will be preached urging the support of the work of distributing the Scriptures in all lands and in every language.

Active buying of print cloths continued yesterday, although volume was held down to some extent by advancing prices. The sales for the week were estimated at about 87 1/2 per cent ahead of limited production.

A plan for payment of the public works obligations, in default since 1933, has been agreed upon by the government's commission studying the question for the last few months, Julio Forcade, president of the Havana Stock Exchange, heading the Cuban bondholders' committee, said tonight. Mr. Forcade said details of the plan were handed to him by the Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon, following a meeting of the commission.
President Roosevelt sent today to the Senate the nominations of Jerome N. Frank and John Wesley Hanes to be members of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Sailors aboard French Navy ships today gave three cheers when the news filtered through that they will in the future be allowed to. wear pajamas instead of the old-fashioned night shirts.

Member trading in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Nov. 13 represented 22.21 per cent of total volume, compared with 21.54 per cent in the previous week.
Jack Crawford and Vivian McGrath of Australia today defeated Donald Budge and Gene Mako of the United States, 1-6, 6-3, 6-4, 7-5, in the men's doubles final of the Victorian tennis tournament.

While driving home this morning after ordering corsages for her wedding today, Miss Margaret McCarthy, 30 years old, of 17 Division Street, was killed instantly when her automobile was struck by the Albany Express on a private crossing in West Haverstraw.

The engagement of Miss Anne Rankin Brown, daughter of Mrs. Ralph M. Brown of this city and the late Mr. Brown, to Clement Olmstead Davidson, son of Mrs. Edward Crawford Davidson, also of Elizabeth. and the late Mr. Davidson, has been announced by her mother.

Joe F. Carr, president of the National Football League, announced today the players who are eligible to compete at Chicago Sunday in the game between the Washington Redskins and the Chicago Bears for the pro championship.

Warner-Quinlan Company ten-year 6 per cent gold debentures due in 1939 have been stricken from listing and registration by the New York Stock Exchange. The issue had been suspended from dealings since Oct. 21.

Herman G. Fisher of Fisher-Price Toys, Inc., East Aurora, N. Y., was elected president of the Toy Manufacturers of the United States of America at the concluding session yesterday of the organization's annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker. He succeeds Cass Hough of the Daisy Manufacturing Company, Plymouth, Mich.

Mrs. Vincent Astor gave a tea yesterday at her home, 130 East Eightieth Street, to formulate plans for a musical and dinner to be given on Jan. 2 at the WaldorfAstoria for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which she is acting president. Mrs. Astor will serve as general chairman of the benefit and Thomas J. Watson as treasurer.

We need planners and we need performers if we are to get our city fixed up the way it ought to be. Probably we do well not to get them mixed. Robert Moses is a performer--or, if that word seems to overemphasize his occasional bursts of fireworks, a doer.

The fruit and vegetable venders who tenant the forty-eight-year old "Paddy's Market" lost yesterday the first round of their legal battle to prevent the city from pushing them off Ninth Avenue and into the side streets between Forty-second and Thirty-ninth Streets to make way for an approach to the new Lincoln vehicular tunnel.

Fourteen more death sentences were reported today as Soviet Russia's "purge" of its suspected internal enemies centered on the livestock industry. Seven veterinaries indicted in the Georgian Republic on charges of spreading livestock epidemics received the supreme penalty, and

A group of members of Local 791 of the International Longshoremen's Association demanded yesterday that officers of their union file charges against Joseph P. Ryan, president of the international body, on several grounds, including one to the effect that he had withheld information om the state of the union's finances.

Cantor Isadore H. Weinstock of Central Synagogue died yesterday morning in Booth Memorial Hospital after a week's illness. Mr. Weinstock, who was 63 years old, had resided at 6741 Kessel Street, Forest Hills.

The Maritime Commission approved the sale today of the Leviathan, once the largest passenger ship afloat,at a price of $732,000. The vessel will be broken up for scrap after her final voyage to Glasgow, Scotland, probably within the next three or four weeks.

The Dollar liner President Hoover, with 650 passengers and a crew of 408 aboard, ran aground on Hoishito Island, eighteen miles from the east coast of Formosa, last night, but a message received here this afternoon by Globe Wireless indicated that all the passengers had been landed on the island.

Shipment of model gowns from Paris on a "sample manifest" under which the merchandise will be given special stowage, moved onto the dock shortly after the boat docks here and moved through customs rapidly, has been arranged by customs brokers through conferences with the Cunard White Star Line, James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern Stiner Co., announced here yesterday.

Swamp Angel, well backed despite a none too consistent record this year, came from behind under Cornelio Mojena's well-timed ride to annex the mile and seventy yards of the Kaplan Claiming Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

The Central Badminton Club Seconds turned back the New York Badminton Club, 5 to 0, in the only men's Class A match of the Metropolitan Badminton Association's team tournament played this week. The results of twenty-one other matches in various divisions also were announced yesterday.

Establishment by Pope Plus XI of two new ecclesiastical provinces in this country, one to consist of the State of New Jersey, hitherto a part of the ecclesiastical province of New York, and the other to include the States of Kentucky and Tennessee,

An application by the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for authority to abandon 106.64 miles of line in Litchfield County, Conn., and in Columbia and Dutchess Counties, N. Y., should be granted, Examiners R. R. Moister and Jerome K. Lyle recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

A farm bill designed to carry out Secretary Wallace's ever-normal granary plan and provide compulsory control of crop surpluses was passed by the House today by a vote of 267 to 130, bringing to a close a hard-fought battle.

The Haverford College quintet lost its opening game of the season to Wesleyan tonight, 30 to 15. High scorers for the contest were Richards of Wesleyan with 10 points and Beeler, who scored 9 for the losers.

Net earnings of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., for the year ended on Sept. 30 were $730,474, against $182,400 for the preceding twelve months, according to a message to shareholders yesterday by R. W. Moore, president.

Mayor Meyer Ellenstein was among ten persons who surrendered today at the office of the Essex County Prosecutor on indictments returned by the Essex County grand jury In connection with an investigation of the affairs of the city of Newark.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 8: Hepburn, Admiral A. J., Commander in Chief, U. S. Fleet, to duty as commandant of the 12th Naval District, San Francisco, Calif., and to additional duty as commandant of Naval Operating Base, San Francisco, Calif., about Jan. 29.

A special Senate committee's five members united tonight in support of legislation which they said could be enacted in the special session to bring the Wool Top Futures Exchange under Federal regulation.
Twenty-two enemy planes were shot down by the Nationalists [Insurgents] today in the war's bigbest air battle, according to an official announcement here.

Broadway, 547, 5 and 6 story brick loft and store, 24.9x200.3; Marine Midland Trust Co of New York against City Estates Co; due, $73,350; to plaintiff for $32,500. By L LINCOLN SEIDE 1st Ave, 1,334, 5-story stone tenement and stores, 27x85; American Mortgage Co against Gustav Pick; due, $35,108; taxes, etc., $968: to plaintiff for $32,000.

A smaller increase than anticipated seasonally took place in the daily average of cotton mill activity last week, and the adjusted index eased to 107.4 from 110.8. The figure for the week ended Dec. 5, 1936, was 144.8.

Most bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange drifted irregularly to slightly lower levels yesterday. Pivotal loans, in consonance with stocks, reflected a hesitant trend, which. together with the influence of reports from Washington concerning the position .of the railroads, resulted in the market,

Bundled in football togs, ear muffs and mittens, the Redskins from Washington braved Chicago's frigid weather today to practice in the open for their professional football championship game against the Chicago Bears at Wrigley Field Sunday.

Trinity College opened its basketball season tonight with a 40-to20 victory over Bard College of Annandale-on-Hudson, N. Y. Trinity jumped into an 8-to-l lead in the first five minutes, ran it to 16 to 5 at the half and to 30 to 9 in the first six minutes of the second half. Randall, Mountford and
Canon Charles T. Bridgeman of the Anglican Cathedral of St. George the Martyr, Jerusalem, will preach tomorrow at the 11 A. M. service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The canon,

Mrs. Addie Walling Forman, a pianist, organist and composer, died at her home here today at the age of 82. As Mrs. R. R. Forman, the name signed to her compositions, she gained a considerable reputation many years ago.

AVIS-Of 400 West 118th St., New York City, on Dec. 8, 1937, George Elmer Avis. Fund:al services will be held at the Lewis Maycock Funeral Home, 205 Whitney Ave., New Haven, Conn., on Tuesday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock. Friends invited to attend. Interment New Haven, Conn.

As police plans to ban parking in ten key streets in the midtown zone took more definite form yesterday, Major E. L. Leindorf, head of the Leindorf Bus and Truck Corporation, submitted' a ten-point program to Mayor La Guardia for the elimination of traffic congestion in the area.

Extension of the cold wave, bringing a rush for Winter goods, and heavier Christmas shopping lifted retail sales this week 3 to 6 per cent over the preceding week and 4 to 15 per cent over the corresponding period of 1936, according to the weekly trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

A session on legislation and fairtrade practices and joint meetings with both the American Statistical Association and the American Economic Association will feature the annual convention of the American Marketing Association to be held at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall Hotels, Atlantic City, Dec. 27 to 30. Among the topics will be marketing research activities at universities, market price and cost analysis, measurements of markets and adequacy of marketing methods and durable consumer goods.

Benjamin Rush Stoddard of Havana, Cuba, ormerr resident of New Rochelle for many years, died last night at Saranac Lake, N. Y., according to word received here today. He was former president of the West India Steamship Company, a cargo-carrying line. His age was 62.

Trading slackened yesterday in commodity futures on the local exchanges and closing prices generally were lower. In the cash markets corn, eggs; tin, cotton and printcloth were higher, while wheat, . rye, oats, cocoa,. butter, lard, silk and rubber declined.

Movements In the livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow; HOGS Receipts, 20,000 head, including 5.000 direct. Market around 10 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday's average; spots 15 cents off on weights 200 pounds and up. Top light lights, $8.30; bulk good
Three suspected as members of the Weidmann gang this Afternoon voluntarily surrendered for questioning in the murders of Jean De Koven, 22-year-old Brooklyn dancer, and four other persons.

The International Printing Pressmen and Assistants Union of North America and the American Newspaper Publishers Association today renewed for a five-year term the thirty-year international arbitration agreement between the two associations.

96th St, 219-21 E, 56x100; Rebar Const Co, Inc (Samuel E. Klein, pres), to Jennie W. Klein, 1,125 Park Ave, prior mtg $25,000, due on demand, 4 1/2%; $2,833.50. 102d St, 212-14 W. 50x120; Brurum Realty Const Corp (Carlos L. Henriquez Jr, pres) to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, p m, due on demand, interest as per bond; $34,285.

The following Marine Corps changes dated Dec. 6, were announced today: Williams, Brig. Gen: S., appointed the Quartermaster of the Marine Corps, with rank of Brigadier General. McDougal, 1st Lt. D. D., 4th MarInes, Shanghai, to the Asheville.

The Hospital for Joint Diseases filed yesterday plans for a fourstory clinic adjoining its main building, which occupies the block front on the east side of Madison Avenue, between East 123d and 124th Streets. The addition will cost $450,000 and will occupy a frontage of 99.2 feet on 123d Street and 57.8 feet on 124th Street, running through the block.

The United Automobile Workers of America called a strike today at Kansas City's Ford assembly plant, where company officials protested recently there was inadequate police protection, and 150 police promptly arrested all 49 men who attempted picketing.

The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, continuing its investigation of the financial affairs of the bankrupt Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad, produced today documentary evidence that the railroad management, after obtaining in June. 1932. a loan of $8,000,-

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted permission to the Nebraska Natural Gas Company, a subsidiary of the North American Light and Power Company, to dedare a dividend out of capital or unearned surplus after certain capital adjustments are made to avoid payment of the undistributed profits taxes.
Mrs. Laura M. Curtis, Washington and New York society and sports woman, filed suit in District Court today for a divorce from James Freeman Curtis, New York attorney.

President Roosevelt's summary of the railroad situation was considered yesterday in Wall Street as providing more than a hint that, after a lapse of years, consolidation might become an active issue. His remarks concerning the elimination of competition between parallel lines and the abandonment of uneconomic mileage were thought to point to this conclusion.

Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Minister, will continue his tour to Belgrade tomorrow highly satisfied with the results of his visit. A communique issued tonight, with Premier George Tatarescu's approval, declared that all problems concerning the international situatior and the two countries had been candidly discussed.

Mr. and Mrs. Glover Beardsley of 31 East Seventy-ninth Street gave a large dinner dance last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annette Beardsley, to Charles F. Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. Wagner of Dayton, Ohio.

A small fire yesterday in the First Baptist Church, believed of incendiary origin, today was revealed by the Rev. W. S. V. Robinson, the pastor, to have been preceded by letters to himself and members of the congregation threatening action unless a prominent member of the congregation was dismissed.

Sales of copper were made in the export market yesterday at 10.04 cents a pound. However, one, important seller said buyers showed virtually no interest in the metal above 10 cents a pound for shipment abroad and that the market actually was no better than 9.90 to 9.95 cents.

Neither official quarters nor the usual well-informed circles have given the slightest indication or hint what will be announced to the expectant Italian nation after the special meeting of the Fascist Grand Council tomorrow night, but political and diplomatic circles believe the crowds filling the Piazza Venezia at Permier Mussolini's command will be told that Italy has decided to resign from the League of Nations.

Estate, not more than $10,000. To the pastor of St. John's Baptist Church, 210 W. 31st St., $1,000 for the education of youth for the priesthood; Barbara Schilling, sisterin-law. 1,830 2d Ave., $1,000; five other bequests; Lietha Antes, widow, 445 W;. 36th St., bank accounts and insurance. George Goodstein, 1,205 College Ave., Bronx, executor.
Unusually heavy rains required the opening of ten gates. of the spillway at Gatun Dam yesterday to keep Gatun Lake at a safe operating level for ships.
The Surete National made two more arrests today in its widespreadd investigation of a purported Rightist plot against the government.

Federal runds totaling $41,100,000 were earmarked today by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, for ten cities including Buffalo and Yonkers. Today's earmarkings bring to a grand total of $71,600,000 the funds set aside from the Congressional appropriation of $500,000,000, of which $300,000,000 will be available during the next two years.

William Garret, Connecticut organization director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, today announced that a campaign would begin Monday to enroll all Yale employes, beginning with dining hall workmen and janitors, as recently attempted at Harvard.

One of the most active periods in some time in the market for new tax-exempt securities is indicated for next week, with a total of $40,385,000 in new State and municipal issues scheduled for sale. They will consist of loans of one State and sixty municipalities.

Subscribers to the annual Friday Assemblies gathered again in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton last night for the first dance of this season's series. These Assemblies are patterned after the Junior and Knickerbocker Assemblies and draw their membership from girls who in previous years have attended those dances. Established in 1926,

On police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMAN-George W. Brewster, 19th Division, Raided Premises Squad. at $2,250 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 1903. On his own application: PATROLMAN-John G. Beyer, 105th Precinct. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 25, 1910.
Franklin P. Trautman, a practicing lawyer for sixty-two years, died yesterday at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn. after a two years' illness. He was 84 years old.

Benny Friedman, C. C. N. Y. football mentor and graduate of Michigan in the class of 1927, was hailed as "our next head coach" last night when he rose to act as toastmaster at a dinner of the University of Michigan Club of New York, held at the Hotel Belmont Plaza, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street.

The threatened revolt in Congress against President Roosevelt's economy program broke partially into the open today with an announcement by Representative Cartwright of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Roads Committee, that he would not call his committee together during the special session to carry out the Presidential recommendation for withdrawal of Federal road aid authorizations for the 1939 fiscal year.
All seeded players in the Fall B and C squash tennis tournament at the City Athletic Club were in line to start third-round competition today, three having won their matches yesterday.
The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today nine Greyhound operating companies to issue an aggregate of $3,512,000 of notes to finance the purchase of 328 new buses.

While the worst December snowstorm that has struck Western New York State in years continued unabated tonight, after three days, suffering and peril spread in this city and a wide surrounding area today.

City College's varsity swimming team opened its schedule at the C. C. N. Y. pool last night by defeating Fordham, 38 to 33, in their annual meet. Fordham won three individual first places and the final relay race.

The thermometer at the Weather Bureau yesterday at 12:15 P. M. read 28 degrees above zero when Thomas Tolson, 8-year-old Negro boy, ventured out on the ice-caked Central Park lake, opposite 109th Street and Fifth Avenue.

At the direction of Cardinal Hayes, Catholic churches of New York City will join tomorrow in an appeal for donations to the United Hospital Campaign, which is seeking a fund of more than $3,000,000 for ninety-two voluntary hospitals of the city and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn.

Federal Judge George A. Welsh awarded today to underlying companies of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company a $1,000,000 allowance for distribution among their stockholders. The underliers' petition asked for $3,000,000 for "use and occupancy" of their property by the P. R. T.

And once you've raised it you may find you've taken a header into the enormous field of clamorous proposals and desperate needs that is known as the housing problem-a problem forever under discussion and forever unresolved. A "Gay Thirties" dinner dance, for which the subscribers included many younger married couples of prominence in society, took place last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Because of the refusal of Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx to approve the new city Administrative Code on the ground that he had not read it, Mayor La Guardia was unsuccessful yesterday in his effort to have the code endorsed by all the members of the Board of Estimate.

Miss Jane Gardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Gardner of this place. was married today to Hubert Walter Moseley Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert W. Moseley of Crestwood, at the Gardner home here. The Rev. Edward T. Taggart, the Rector of Christ's Episcopal Church here, performed the ceremony.

Maria Maximovitch, soprano, who appeared in recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, at once proved herself an important singer of first rate attainments. Miss Maximovitch, a mature artist at the height of her powers, made known a fine voice, thoroughly schooled and admirably controlled, which she employed expertly in interpretations remarkable for their sure grasp of style, emotional intensity, poetry and communicative eloquence.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, for the last ten years Bishop of Virginia, who at midnight on Dec. 31 will become Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, will tomorrow preach his first sermons in this city since his election to his new office.

Another rules demonstration game, with some of the top ranking players in the game in action, is the feature of tonight's indoor polo double header at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission to permit the Chesapeake Ohio Railway to acquire direct control of the New York, Chicago St. Louis and Erie railroads was described yesterday as "extremely favorable" to the plans of the syndicate headed by Robert R. Young for reformation of the Van Sweringen railway holding structure.

The Hutchinson River Parkway Extension, an express automobile highway between the Hutchinson River Parkway in New Rochelle and Eastern Boulevard, which is the main traffic connection through the East Bronx with the Triborough Bridge, will be opened to motorists

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls battled the Hershey Bears to a 2-2 tie in an Eastern Amateur Hookey League game tonight. Hal Dewey of the Sea Gulls scored the first goal of the game in the opening period on a solo dash in 8:59, but Hershey knotted the count in the next session.
Major Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, announced yesterday that James J. Braddock and his manager, Joe Gould, each had paid a fine of.$1,000 to the board:

Governor Frank Murphy of. Michigan, will speak tonight at the opening session in Yeshiva College..of a two-day national conference of- ewish organizations which will be attended by more than 600 delegates. Other speakers will be Dr. Bernard Revel, president of the college, and

Formal organization has been completed of a Negro Actors Guild which would function along the lines of the Catholic, Jewish and Episcopal Actors Guilds, it is announced by Noble Sissle, president of the new group.

Joseph P. Kennedy of Bronxville is chairman of the Maritime Commission and President Roosevelt's reported choice as Ambassador to Great Britain. Joseph P. Kennedy of Yonkers is a plumber. Joseph P. Kennedy of Bronxville is not listed in the Westchester telephone hook. Joseph P. Kennedy
" I decide. I do. Me. Right here."-Mayor Frank Hague in yesterday's TIMES. "L' tat de New Jersey, c'est moi," said Mayor

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 4 amounted to 623,337 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 64,710 cars, or 11.6 per cent, more than for the preceding week, but 121,958 cars, or 16.4 per cent, fewer thanl for the corresponding week last year and 15,181 cars, or 2.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week two years ago.
While most governments are complaining of falling birth rates, Stockholm authorities are facing an extraordinary rise in the birth rate.

The appointment of John W. Hanes and Jerome Frank to fill the vacancies in the Securities and Exchange Commission comes immediately upon the heels of the announcement that a committee will be appointed by the Stock Exchange to investigate the possibility of internal reforms in management.

Trading was uneven, fairly active to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to lower: veal and calf weak; lamb 50c-$1 higher: fresh pork cuts uneven, some weak, others stronger. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb prices to be unevenly steady to higher; veal higher: calf steady; beef weak to sharply lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Mrs. Walter Gibb gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 1,040 Fifth Avenue, to introduce to society her granddaughters, Miss Elaine Gibb Eldredge and Miss M. Althea Eldredge.
Donald L. Robinson, New York writer, and his wife were still missing tonight, and no explanation whatever could be found for Mr. Robinson's puzzling disappearance Dec. 2 and Mrs.
Today's major events: Wagnerian Festival Singers, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M., and at the Hotel Plaza, 8:30 P. M.; "Traviata," 2 P. M., "Norma," 8:15 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House;

A drop of more than $2,000,000 in the value of tax exempt properties in Westchester County was reported to the Board of Supervisors here today by its tax equalization committee. The new figure of "$327,
Alabama Polytechnic Institute of Auburn was given formal permission today to participate in the
Mrs. Jane Nagle Lear, known for her work with Catholic organizations and honored by Pope Pius and President Coolidge, died today after a short illness.

Susan Beardslee Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edwin Hall of Greenwich, Conn., was married this afternoon in St. Ethelburg Church, London, to Eric L. F. Archdeacon, formerly of London. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. S. B. Archdeacon and is the European representative of the Bankers Trust Company of New York, with offices in Berlin.

The "day of youth" was celebrated yesterday at the Charity Bazaar, of the German-American Conference, with which twelve leading German-American organizations are affiliated, at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
Turrpentlne firm, 26c; sales 38 barrels; receipts 161 barrels; shipments 384 barrels; stock 38,469 barrels. Resin firm; sales 672; receipts 909; shipments 213: stock 87,633.
The diploma granted by a school in New Hampshire more than eighty years ago to Lydia F. Wadleigh certified that she was "a scholar and a lady." She was also a teacher who had

The cost of food at retail declined during the month ended on Nov. 16, the Bureau of. Labor Statistics reported today. The bureau's foodcost index, based on the 1923-25 average as 100, was 83.6 on Nov. 16, compared with 84.9 on Oct. 12 and 82.5 on Nov. 17, 1936.
In an attempt to bolster the sextet's defense the Chicago Black Hawks today acquired William MacKenzie, 26-year-old defense player with the Montreal Canadiens, for Marty Burke, also a defense man.

The American Chamber of Commerce in Brazil today nominated Stephen P. Danforth, importer, Richard P. Momsen, lawyer, and Ralph H. Greenwood, General Electric, general manager, to serve on the joint Brazilian-American
In a game marking the dedication of its new gymnasium, Manhattan College of Staten Island bowed yesterday afternoon to Hofstra College of Hempstead, L. I, 40 to 35.

The high command of the Japanese fleet changed hands quietly on Dec. 1, it was learned here today. In a ceremony in the Imperial Palace in Tokyo, Vice Admiral Zengo Yoshida, who commanded a Japanese naval training squadron

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 959,000 bales, against 964,000 a week ago, 866,000 two weeks ago, 802,000 three weeks ago and 825,000 a year ago; of which American 538,000 bales, against 538,000 bales a week ago, 434,000 two weeks ago, 362,000 three weeks ago and 298,000 a year ago.

An eighteenth century Beauvais marine tapestry was bought by Frank Schnittjer for $1,600 yesterday afternoon at the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc., at the second session of the auction of art property of the late Frederick A. Juilliard of New York and Tuxedo Park.

Joseph Engel of 2,510 Broadway, president of A. J. Engel, furriers, died on Thursday of a heart attack in his Winter residence at Miami Beach, Fla., according to word received here yesterday. He was 65 years old.

New working conditions for actors, including the establishment of a single minimum wage of $40 weekly, were endorsed yesterday by official committees of the Actors Equity Association at the union's quarterly meeting in the Astor.

The newest popular Winter sports center, the indoor snow bowl at Madison Square Garden. reported excellent conditions last night and a record throng of 13,000 turned out for the varied program of the North American Winter sports show and international ski meet.

The Brooklyn Knights of Columbus basketball team registered its third straight victory tonight by downing St. Peter's College, 43 to 37. Jack Brown paced Columbus Council with 14 points. The Caseys led at half-time, 20-19.
The first Japanese detachment to enter Nanking broke through Kunghwa Gate shortly before 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Encountering defense forces, they spread in a fanlike formation and advanced.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 10 unless specified: Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to Yorktown. Charleston, Galapagos Island to Balboa, Dec. 9. Claxton, Casablanca to Gibraltar.

The Pan American Trust Company, New York, is paying a bonus of two weeks' salary to all its employes, it was announced yesterday by John B. Glenn, president. Mr. Glenn said the bank, formed on Jan. 2, 1937, had had a highly successful first year.
Dr. Benjamin F. Cline, pathologist, died at his home here last night after a brief Illness. He would have celebrated his sixty-seventh birthday on Dec. 39.
Lilias Armstrong (wife of professor Simon Boyanus), one of the foremost exponents of phonetic science, died today at the height of a unique career.

A letter from one of yesterday's contributors suggests that the reading of, the biographies of the "Neediest Cases" makes one's own personal and business cares seem trivial.I But it does more. In revealing the fortitude with which these unfortunate

Great Britain defaulted on the payment of her war-debt installment in a note to the State Department from her embassy here and made public today. Great Britain on Dec. 15 owes $122,670,765 in a new payment and $871,815,602 in accumulated arrears, a total of $994,486,367.

George Balanchine, duplex apartment In 11 E 77th St; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., broker. Carol Dickson, in 160 W 73d St; First Madison Corp, broker. Max Orren, in 110 W 69th St; The Apartment Locating Bureau, broker.

Miss Ellen Mudge Burrill for forty-three years secretary to the sergeant at arms at the State House in Boston and an authority on the State House itself, died yesterday at her home of a heart attack. She was 65 years old.

Thursday's buying movement did not carry over into dealings yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here. After holding within narrow limits prices ended with a gain of 2 to a loss of 3 points. Liverpool failed to

The Department of Agriculture today received a large quantity of tropical fruit trees and vegetables from Puerto Rico. Many of the plants will be grown here for the first time, while others will be used to improve local plants.

The Phelps Dodge Corporation has extended for two years from Dec. 31 an option whereby Louis S. Cates, president, has the right to buy 5,884 shares of the company's capital stock at $21.50 a share, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Former Governor Harry G. Leslie of Indiana died tonight of a heart ailment. His age was 59. Death came unexpectedly to Mr. Leslie, whose condition was reported as "good" several hours earlier at St. Francis Hospital. where he was taken from a hotel last night.

Acquisition of the New York, Chicago St. Louis, or Nickel Plate Railroad and the Erie Railroad by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company through purchase of stock was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission, subject to the condition that the C. O. abide by the commission's future decision with respect to its purchase of two short lines.

Bourjois, Inc., 35 West Thirty-fourth Street, New York, and its subsidiary, Barbara Gould Sales Corporation, have been ordered to cease and desist misrepresenting the therapeutio value and place of origin of certain cosmetics, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed on the eligible list oi holders of license for service as teacher of health education in junior high schools, as of Dec. 8, 1937, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a better tone in the wool market generally, and more business is being done. Activity is most pronounced in the pulled wool section of the market, especially in scoured medium wools on the basis of about 55 to 58 cents for good to choice white types.

Miss Mary Gill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Gill of South Orange, was married to William Sterling Roby Jr.. son of Mrs. William S. Roby of Rochester and the late Mr. Roby, this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church, Orange.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Henry, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John R. Henry of this place, to Griffith ap Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell C. Jones of Bronxville, N. Y., and Washington, Conn., will take place on the night of Dec. 21.

Dr. T. H. Hogg, chairman of the Ontario Hydroelectric Power Commission, announced tonight that a new contract for delivery of power to the commission had been signed with the Beauharnois Light, Heat and Power Company.

Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large and this country's delegate to the Nine-Power Treaty conference in Brussels, will return today on the United States liner Washington, accompanied by Dr. Stanley Hornbeck, Far Eastern adviser to the Secretary of State, and Robert T. Pell, who served as press officer of the delegation.

Columbia's basketball team de??ated an alumni squad including four former captains. 47-23, in its opening game at the Columbia gymnasium last night. The Lion varsity handled the ball deftly in a fastbreaking attack that completely disorganized the alumni defense.

The subtropics were moved North last night to feign a mild- December day along Park Ayenue, with the aid of air-conditioning, transplanted palm trees, and an artificial moon. The stately measures of the minuet were trod on the ballroom floor of the Hotel WaldorfAstoria, and 300 years of history

The Board of Estimate denied a yearly pension of $6,000 yesterday to Mrs. Loretta O'Neil, widow of the late Municipal Court Justice John O'Neil who died three days after he was stabbed last April 27 as he was on his way to court.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, cite- and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Earl Fink of the Englewood Field Club a former national squash tennis champion, captured the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association veterans' championship yesterday when he defeated C. O. Wellington of the Harvard Club in the final at the University Club.

A GROUP of sportsmen gathered at Tuxedo Park were discussing championship form and comparing the idols of the various divisions of athletics. Out of a clear sky one of them made the challenging statement that of all the American sports heroes, past and present, none was so predominantly the master of his chosen field as was the late Jay Gould in court tennis.

President Roosevelt has accused Vice President Garner of shooting a cow (a pet cow, at that) on his recent deer hunting expedition. Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania made the disclosure. He gave out a letter signed "Franklin D. Roosevelt" and said that it was read last night at a dinner at which some meat was served. Mr. Garner asserted that the meat was part of a deer he shot.

Large families as the best means of tax avoidance was suggested today to the New England Trust Conference of the Corporate Fiduciaries Association of Boston.
