Large families as the best means of tax avoidance was suggested today to the New England Trust Conference of the Corporate Fiduciaries Association of Boston.
Operators again were active yesterday in the purchase and sale of apartment houses in Manhattan. The activity was marked by resales, some of the buyers being investors.

While reading from the Bible during a funeral service at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon, the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, rector of the church, collapsed. He was taken to Roosevelt Hospital, where his

A convention called "A Pact of Reciprocal Agreements" was signed by delegations representing Nicaragua and Honduras here today, ending a threat of war over an old boundary question. The pact was achieved in the presence of President Leon Cortes and members of the mediation commission, representing the United States, Venezuela and Costa Rica.

Charles A. Levine, who has been in numerous difficulties since 1927, when he won acclaim by flying as a passenger across the Atlantic Ocean in a plane piloted by Clarence Chamberlin, went on trial yesterday before Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard and a jury on the charge that he took part in a conspiracy to smuggle 5,000 pounds of tungsten powder into the United States from Canada last year.
The army's view that the conflict in China must go on has been accepted by the Cabinet. The Prime Minister, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, will make a public statement after the fall of Nanking.
After a lapse of five years the Ringling family has regained complete control of the Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Combined Shows and allied circus interests, it was announced yesterday.

As a stimulant to business activity and the development of new products, the exemption of expenditures for authentic industrial research, facilities and activities from the income tax of corporations was urged here yesterday by Maurice Holland, director of the division of engineering and industrial research of the National Research Council.

More than 300 guests attended the first of three subscription dances tonight at the Sulgrave Club under the sponsorship of the Three Dance Club of Washington. A number of dinner parties preceded the dance, including those given by Mr. and Mrs. Fleming Newbold and Mr. and Mrs. John B. Caswell.
The Soviet press today accused Germany of having colonial designs on Iran (Persia) in reporting the visit of young Nazis to Teheran, headed by Baldur von Schirach, Reich youth leader.
Donald Budge, American champion, today won the Victoria tennis singles title by defeating Jack Bromwich of Australia in the final match, 8-6, 6-3, 9-7.
Princeton's basketball forces rang up their second consecutive victory of the young season tonight in the university gymnasium by repulsing Lafayette, 31 to 25, before some 800 spectators.
Charles P. Taft of Cincinnati, son of the late President Taft, suggested jestingly today that some funerals would do the Republican party no harm.

The question whether our educational systems are not forgetting first principles in pursuit of fase prophets was raised last night by Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, in an address before the New York Schoolmasters Club at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue.

In a contest filled with fast action, Syracuse's high-geared basketball team defeated St. Lawrence tonight, 45 to 29, before about 1,800 spectators. Marty Rockmore, burly forward, who led the visitors with 13 points, counted two baskets and a foul to give the Larries an early advantage. Syracuse soon took command, however, and ran up a 25-to-16 lead at half-time, with Billy Thompson as the standout performer.
An alleged violation of British territorial waters was reported early today by the British captain of a Chinese maritime customs cruiser when he arrived here.

Senator Bilbo of Mississippi suggested today that the government help solve the surplus-cotton problem by presenting a sixty-pound mattress made of "good, clean cotton" to every poverty-stricken family.

General Evangeline Booth of the Salvation Army in a letter to The Times of London gives her impressions of the United States on her recent visit. "After an almost continuous absence of three years," she writes, "I found a changed and still changing United States during my recent tour of two months.

Oddly enough, observes a writer in The Consumers Guide, a lemon tree begins with the planting of orange seed for rootstocks. Later these seedling rootstock trees are budded with the lemon. That is, a bud from a lemon tree is inserted in a slit made in the bark of the rootstock about two inches above the ground.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were approximately in the same volume as in the previous week. Except for a few entire issues of outstanding industrial bonds, the announcements were principally for parts of numerous issues called to satisfy sinking fund requirements.

The chaotic situation gripping Oregon's lumber industry today seemed back where it was before Governor Charles S. Martin superseded the National Labor Relations Board in attempting to settle the bitter conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

IN Secretary Roper's annual report on the Department of Comlmerce for the. fiscal year end ed June 30, 1937, just released, there are just seven pages devoted to the affairs of the Bureau of Air Commerce. Yet it is probable that more controversial speeches were made and more words written concerting the affairs of the Bureau of Air Commerce than any other bureau of, that important department.

Premier Mussolini's announcement of Italy's withdrawal from the League of Nations came here by radio tonight while Geneva was enjoying the traditional masquerade celebrating the retreat from Geneva of the House of Savoy after its failure to take the city in 1602. It did not seem to dampen the festivities. The few serious-minded listened in but for the most it was on with the dance.

To the Drama Editor: Every season we are treated with articles by producers who are leaving the theatre. They complain of many things, but most often of critics, playwrights and actors. Their cry is that the critics pan bad plays which the producers have put on to satisfy the tastes of the "money public";

Hugo Vavrecka, former minister of the Czechoslovak Republic in Vienna and director of the Bata Shoe Company, who arrived here a few days ago, will be the guest of honor and principal speaker at the annual dinner meeting of the American-Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce, Inc.
J. S. Harrison waged a successful uphill battle with J. R. Whitbeck in the final of the fourth annual Class B invitation squash racquets tournament at the Squash Club yesterday.

As investigators sought to fix the cause of the train crash in which thirty-five persons were killed last night, one of the victims was identified tonight as Mrs. Annabella MacLeod Ritchie of Schenectady, N. Y.

As Yvon Delbos, Foreign Minister of France, makes his round of eastern capitals-Warsaw and Bucharest this week, Belgrade and Prague next week-the division grows sharper than ever between the AngloFrench desire for a general European settlement with all-around guarantees and German insistence upon dealing with one issue and one power at a time in a series of partial bargains.

Rugged Americanism is not dead yet in the sport of speed boating. It develops that at least one driver has been brooding over the loss to England last Summer of the world record of 129.5 miles an hour which Sir Malcolm Campbell wrenched from Gar Wood.

FLORIDA is expecting to extend Winter hospitality to 3,000,000 visitors who are solvent and vacation-bent. Tourists of modest means began to settle in communities all over the State several weeks ago, and the increasing number of yachts and limousines offers evidence that the more affluent have begun to arrive.
President Charles Seymour of Yale University and Mrs. Seymour tonight held a reception in the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts for New Haven friends and members of the faculty of Yale University.

Offerings of combination deals by drug producers will be considerably restricted, if the recommendations last week of the National Association of Retail Druggists are followed by manufacturers, comment in local circles indicated yesterday.

A meeting of the committee of transportation of the National Council of American Importers and Traders, Inc., to protest what they term the scant attention given by the U. S. Maritime Commission to their views on the question of free storage time for merchandise on New York piers, will be held at the group's headquarters tomorrow.

To provide a training laboratory for students qualified for professional radio work,' to improve the quality of educational and public service programs, and to train listeners in program appreciation, a radio workshop is being rushed to completion oh the Syracuse University campus.

Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Winthrop arrived on the Washington from Paris and are at the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. Frederic D. Huntington of Seven Acres, Katonah, N. Y., are at the Ritz-Carlton. Dr. and Mrs. Loring T. Swaim of Chestnut Hill, Mass., are at the Commodore.

ICE skating, skiing and other Winter sports are popular items in the Scout outdoor program during the cold season. To make these activities more enjoyable and absolutely safe the Health and Safety Service of the organization offers some simple, common-sense instructions.
Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Willoughby of Maplewood, N. J., will give a tea dance on Dec. 27 at the Maplewood Country Club to introduce their daughter, Miss Lucia Helene Willoughby.
The local unit of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America bought this week the machinery of the clothing factory of Sonneborn Brothers, Inc., and will operate the plant.

Announcement of 294 new appointments to the instructional staff of New York University for the current academic year was made yesterday by Chacellor Harry Woodburn Chase. Among them were the following:

PARIS.-Under the auspices of the Ministry of Beaux Arts, France is conducting these days a complete revision of her national military and navy heroes. She is to have only fifty-four, and the problem is to get a lot of the time-honored ones on the list and still make room for some new ones.

A group of women including Mrs. K. Curtis Wagstaff and the Misses Mary Louise Johnstone, Audrey Paige, Charmian Campbell, Barbara Hope Gatins, Peggy Ballantine and Dorothea Lehmann will be manikins at a luncheon and style revue to be known as "Accent on the Evening" on Tuesday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

President Lazaro Cardenas today submitted to Congress a projected law to prevent the use of extraordinary powers by the President while Congress is recessing, not only during his own administration but thereafter.

THE excellent custom of showing sculpture and drawings and prints together has been responsible for two interesting December group exhibitions, and a third is primarily sculpture, but is supplemented by water-colors and drawings.

Stocks closed steady and mixed in slowest trading since Oct. 2; aviation issues strongest feature; turnover, 389,970 shares. United States Government issuei steady and slightly lower; other- bonds irregular in the smallest turnover since Oct. 9; transactions, $3,989,100.

The construction of four public buildings of Georgian Colonial architecture, with two facing the village green to be created between church Lane and the Post Road, was recommended by the Scarsdale Board of Trustees in a brochure being distributed today to 3,000 residents.

ALSBERG-Sol, dearly beloved husband of Rose, brother of Rebecca Altmayer, Irving, Louis, Lillie and the late Morris, at his residence, 200 West 86th St. Services at Park West Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., Monday, Dec. 13, 2 P. M. ALSBERG--Board of Trustees of Mount Neboh Congregation, members and seatholders requested to attend funeral of Sol Alsberg at Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., Monday, Dec. 13, at 2 P. M.

PROPAGANDA on the radio today "wears a wig and false whiskers," David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, reported at the recent Harvard Guardian conference on American Foreign Policy at Cambridge, Mass. Propaganda, Mr. Sarnoff pointed out, when it happens to be "the truth and nothing but the truth," Is never quite the whole truth. He sees such broadcasts withholding essential facts,

Check clearings through the Northern New Jersey Clearing House Association for the week ended on Friday amounted to $35,648,739, compared with $32,411,965 in the previous week and with $32,972,640 in the week ended on Dec. 10, 1936. .

Gales and torrential rain lashed the Pacific Coast from Mexico to Alaska today, causing the greatest damage in Northern California, where towns were flooded and a reservoir broke.

The Grace Line's Santa Rosa bade adieu to the port of San Francisco, yesterday, the first of the "luxury liner" to say farewell among the six Grace and Panama-Pacific ships scheduled for transfer from the California-New York intercoastal run.

Dr. William J. Robbins, recently appointed as the new director for the New York Botanical Garden, has had a lifelong training in horticulture as a background for his duties as head of one of the country's leading institutions in this field.

Because certain chemicals change color when ultra-short radio waves impinge upon them, it may be possible to see objects; such as ships and airplanes hidden in dense fog or darkness, according to a patent just awarded to Clarence W. Hansell of Rocky Point, N. Y.

Charlie Gehringer, the strong, silent man of the Detroit Tigers and for virtually a decade the foremost second baseman in his circuit, provided a crowning climax to a brilliant career by carrying off the 1937 individual batting championship of the American League after a keen struggle with his two renowned Yankee rivals, Lou Gehrig and Joe DiMaggio.

George Mantha's goal in the last second of play gave the Montreal Canadiens a 4-3 overtime decision over the New York Americans tonight and undisputed possession of first place in the International group of the National Hockey League.

Ginger Foran, 129 1/4, Ireland, knocked out Jimmy English, 126, West Side, in 2:17 of the second of a scheduled eight-rounder at the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, before 3,000 persons. In listed six-rounders Joe Boscarino, 135, Ridgewood,

RETAIL trade drew closer to the figures of a year ago in the week, so that some sections of the country were running even or better. But a common complaint in the reports received here was that sales were very spotty.

Acts of terrorism are not abating in Palestine but now are concentrated in the northern district. Several murderous attacks have been committed by Arabs in the past three days, costing the lives of a Jewish boy, Limeleh Gromet, and an Arab Sheikh, Mahmoud Khatib. A Jewish policeman also was seriously injured. All these happenings took place in Haifa, capital of the northern district.

The Interstate Commerce Commission evidenced today an intention to hasten action on the petition of railroads for higher freight rates .by moving forward three weeks the date set for taking closing testimony.

ROM the standpoint of national sentiment, the Italian symphonic season was launched with the concert of the Santa Cecilia Orchestra, under Bernardino Molinari, and broadcast from the Teatro Adriano of Rome, in celebration of Italy' victory of Vittorio Veneto in the World War (the Italian equivalent of Armistice Day).

THE penalty of the reviewer who spends his hours chronicling the major professional musical activities of this city-the huge and impressive performances given in the Metropolitan Opera House and Carnegie
The Committee for Industrial Organization has given notice to about 200 organizers that they would be laid off because of the business recession. Its staff of organizers had reached a peak of 652.

The North American Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet, which has been holding forth at Madison Square Garden since last Tuesday night, attracted a total of 90,000 persons for its nine performances.

Checked in their assaults on the wall of Nanking from Tachiaochang Airdrome, Japanese troops spent yesterday consolidating positions and smoothing out the front along a semi-circular line running four to eight miles from the city symetrically with the curve of the city wall.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I vividly recall a popular musical comedy star who a generation ago chanted a ditty entitled "I Don't Care." Although Eva Tanguay's song is not a current hit, the philosophy which- she vocalized is not entirely dormant.
Charles A. Jewett of Utica, Supreme Court reporter, was elected president of the New York State Shorthand Reporters Association, which closed a two-day convention at the Hotel Astor yesterday after

The popular concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra given last night at Carnegie Hall, John Barbirolli conducting, began with the Handel Concerto Grosso in B flat and the Beethoven "Pastoral" Symphony heard Thursday evening and Friday afternoon.

The Juvenile Aid Society of the Police Department began a drive yesterday against boys and men who jump on the running boards of taxicabs and open the door for theatre-goers in expectation of receiving a tip.

The New York Commandery of the Naval and Military Order of the Spanish-American War gave a dinner last night at the Hotel Commodore in commemoration of the signing of the Treaty of Paris, on Dec. 10, 1898, ending the Spanish-American War.
The underwear industry in general is now running at approximately a 44 per cent productive raEte, according to a survey released yesterday by the Underwear Institute.
Hans Christian Adamson, World War flier, radio commentator and author, will address a meeting of Les Amis next Thursday night at the Hotel White, Thirty-seventh Street and Lexington Avenue.

Returning from a transcontinental tour, the Wagnerian Festival Singers appeared yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall in their final American concert. The members of the group will now disband and return to their respective opera houses in Europe.

Thirteen civic organizations have associated themselves with the Civil Service Reform Association in recommending that many of the subordinate positions in the offices of the five District Attorneys in New York City be placed under competitive civil service, according to H. Elliott Kaplan, executive secretary of the association.

GREAT TINICUM ISLAND In the Delaware River has only recently come to be recognized as a shrine of A.merIean history. The tercentenary of the arrival of the Swedes, to be celebrated in 1938, has drawn attention as never before to the island.

One of the entertainments of the early new year, to which many debutantes of this season and former years are giving their active cooperation and support, is the Viennese Ball to be held in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton on Jan. 15 in aid of the Judson Health Center.

Two boys were drowned and three others were rescued from Lower Mill Pond, near Old Country Road, this afternoon when the ice on which they were skating suddenly gave way. There were a dozen skaters on the pond at the time enjoying the first day of skating.
Expressing the fear that Philadelphia, where Thomas Paine wrote and published "Common Sense" and "The American Crisis," would let the 200th anniversary of Paine's birth pass without recognition,

Heap big war between soda jerkers and Thunder Bird priests! Such a phrase-or any plausible paraphrase you care to make of itrepresents, in a roughly approximate sense, the current military and sociological situation on the American Indian front.

BORGENICHT--LUBELL--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Lubell. 789 Went End Ave., announce the engagement of their daughter, Grace, to Mr. Jack Borgenicht, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Borgenicht of New York City. DREYER--ANGEL--Mr. and Mrs. Louis N, Angel, 771 West End Ave.,

The Federal Power Commission held today, in denying a joint application for transfer of the facilities of the filand Power and Light Company in Oregon and Washington to the Pacific Power and Light Company,
Mis Fredericka Allen gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Miss EFmily Chadbourne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. Chadbourne, whose marriage to Allen H. Minor, son of Colonel and Mrs.
Cornell's basketball team won easily from Alfred, 53-35, tonight, Walt Foertsch and Tom Rich, forwards, teaming for 34 points.
Mrs. John Fellows of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katherine Alice Fellows, to Maitland Charles De Sormo of Tarrytown, son of Mrs. Charles J. De Sormo of Malone, N. Y.

BOYS and girls. in the early days of the world, who with their elders heard from the lips of bard and story-teller the legends of their tribe, were in one respect greatly privileged. They ran no danger, at least, of being surfeited with the mediocre; the tales to which they listened had gone through a selective process; they were great enough to endure and to be fresh with each repetition.

THE PSYCHOLOGY OF BELIEF. By Helge Lundholm. 234 pp. Durhom, N. C.: Duke University Press. $3. WITH unusual clarity and organization Dr. Lund holm analyzes the subject of belief from the standpoint of the psychologist.
TURN OF THE WORLD. By Elizabeth, Lady Decies. Illustrated. 289 pp. Philadelphia: J. B. Lippincott Company. $3.

A SERIOUS business, this swimming, and dancing, and digging in the sand; serious even to crouch with wooden gun In hand, brave and romantically stealthy, behind nurse's chair in the park; and terribly serious to kick a ball The "great unconscious gravity" of happy and untrammeled childhood is in these latest pictures of J. H. Dowd's;
AN echo of the Olympic Games held in Germany Ilast year comes to us in a beautiful volume in which Professor Walter Hege once more proves his mastery of the art of photography.

Attacking the Agricultural Bill now before the Senate as a new "gimme monstrosity that outspends and outdoes the wildest nightmares of the old legislation," but does not treat the fundamental problem of distribution, Samuel C. Lamport, head of the Lamport Manufacturing and Supply Company, and active proponent of increasing cotton exports through governmental cooperation, said in a statement yesterday that "our remaining hope now, lies in the House bill and in the conference committee."

Exeter defeated the Lawrence Academy basketball team, 40 to 16, today, Leading, 17 to 2, after the first quarter, the home forces gradually widened the margin. The visitors were never dangerous. John Magee and Harold Johnson were Exeter's stars.

Today's weekly grade and staple report issued by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics for the Cotton Belt as a whole shows that 51 per cent of the upland cotton classed to date is white middilng and better in grade, and that 34 per cent is an inch and longer in staple.

Angel Pestana, founder of the Syndicalist movement in Spain, died here today. He was 51 years old. An extremist, Mr. Pestana was an ardent supporter of social reforms and spent much of his time traveling through Spain speaking in behalf of better labor conditions.

Announcement hlas been mace by Professor Austin Morris Harmon of Yale University and Mrs. Harmon of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Newell Harmon, to Howard Newton Porter, son of Mrs. C. Talbot Porter, also of New Haven, and the late Mr. Porter.

General William Roeder, the War Minister, left today for a ten-day official visit to Italy, where he will confer with Premier Benito Mussolini and visit various military institutions and armament factories.
KINGSTON-Catskill Mountain Winter sports officials at a dozen or more resorts are biding their time and taking much encouragement from the hardy woodsmen, who assure them, "It won't be long now."

Five Hamburg merchants were held today on suspicion of violating Germany's foreign exchange laws. Among them was Alfred Toepfer, philanthropist and grain dealer. The names of the others were not disclosed.

John Allyn McAlpin Berryman of New York has received the Charles Oldham Shakespeare Scholarship of Cambridge University. As Euretta J. Kellet Fellow of Columbia College, Mr. Berryman is enrolled in the English university, where he will complete two years of graduate study in English literature next June.
Recent sennational changes in the Army Council may yet turn out to be the most encouraging event of a year which has given Britain more than her share of humiliation.

Members of the New York Young Republicans Club held their annual dance last night in the main ballroon' suite of the IAitz-Carlton. The entertainment included dancing contests, in which the guests participated, and exhibition dancing.

WHILE European nations furnished the bulk of the new stamps which reached New York during this past week, one of the more picturesque vignettes is to be found on a halfsen purple released as part of Japan's program for "modernizing" its postal paper.

Harry G. Leslie, who rose from grocery clerk to Governor of Indiana, will be buried here Tuesday following funeral services set for 1 P. M. He died last night at Miami Beach/Fla., at the age of 59. His body will lie in state Monday in the Capitol, where his gift of salty phrase and homely philosophy helped him through trying days of strikes, unemployment and drought during his four years in the Governor's chair, 1929-32.

Establishment of "a Federal authority for the control of pollution in navigable waters, and the tributaries thereto" was opposed today in a resolution adopted at the final session of the convention of the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin.

Considerable activity in the residential market on Long Island is reported by many brokers despite the recession in general business. Low-priced dwellings particularly have been in demand. One of the significant factors in connection with the large volume of new home construction and sales in Queens and adjacent sections of

Poinsettias are welcoming holiday visitors to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, where the rose poinsettia and the double poinsettia, as well as the usual red type, are on display in the conservatories. Hollies with black and yellow berries, and the native red-berried species (Ilex opaca), are to be seen in the outdoor plantations in ..the- south central part of the garden, east of the brook.
Julian W. Ciurtiss was the honor guest at the annual dinner of the Middle Patent Golf Club, held at the field club here last night. Mrs. George W. Vanderhoef Dresided.

Extending. its service in the field of radio, Massachusetts State College has under way plans for several programs over the air this year. A series of programs called "Spotlight on the World Newsfront" presents each week two or three-authorities in various fields to discuss a few significant news developments.

President Roosevelt, Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Associate Supreme Court Justices Harlan F. Stone and Benjamin N. Cardozo are among the 7,810 alumni of the Columbia University School of Law whose careers will sketched in the 1937 edition of the Columbia Law Register, now in preparation.

An employer cannot evade the payment of awards to injured workers or dodge other provisions of the State Workmen's Compensation Law by "leasing" to his employes the equipment in his shop, according to a ruling by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

When Governor Aiken of Vermont stepped dramatically into the national spotlight by openly offering a double handful of constructive criticism to the G. O. P., attention was simultaneously focused upon the fact that the Governor is a horticulturist.

The annual meeting of the recommendations committee of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association was held yesterday at the Hotel Paramount, along with the meeting of the lacrosse coaches.

Mr. and Mrs. George Paull Alexander of Coconut Grove have sent out invitations to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Faith Alexander, and William John Matheson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh M. Matheson of Coconut Grove and Northeast Harbor, Me., on Dec. 27 in the Church of the Little Flower, Coral Gables.

Four girls compose the first group of undergraduates elected to the new Omicron Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, just installed at the University of Buffalo. No undergraduate men were elected to the fraternity.

Teresa Gonzalez, whose horsemeat stews kept the Insurgent defenders of the Alcazar alive during the famous siege at Toledo, was awarded the Spanish Cross of Military Merit today by the Insurgent Government.

Opportunities for self-expression and education in current affairs are provided at Hunter College; throughh the activities of six open-Forum clubs, it was explained at the college yesterday. Each week Liberal Club, Open Forum, History Club, International Relations Club, Peace Club and Ottinger Debating Society present symposiums and Lectures on national and international questions.

AUSTRIA'S annual "Day of the Stamp," Dec. 5, brings a series of semi-postal adhe sives. This year's series, released last Monday because the 5th feel on Sunday, honors men, not all of them native Austrians, who were notably identified with medicine.

SOMETHING by Ernest Bloch seems always to be on the tapis, about to be recorded or on the verge of release. But nothing ever comes of these and Bloch remain the most promised and yet most disgracefully neglected contemporary.

President Roosevelt has endorsed Universal Bible Sunday, which will be nationally observed today. The President wrote from Washington that he wished for the observance the full measure of success which its high purpose merits.

THE motorcycle was merely a means to an end. This would have been just as good a book if the author had girdled the world in steamships and trains. He used the "futfut gharie," as it was called in India, because he considered it the most useful vehicle for taking him to the places he wished to see.

Revised plans for building two huge housing projects, one in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn and the other in the Queens Bridge area of Queens, were presented to Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, by Mayor La Guardia this morning.

THREE group exhibitions designed to offer collectors works by well-known French moderns at moderate prices opened last week and will remain current. until Christmas or later. In the first of these Mrs. Cornelius J. Sullivan has assembled at her

Of the new plays to be produced next week, three will be seen on Sunday. The Repertory Players will produce "The King's Breakfast," by Rita Weiman and Maurice Marks, with a cast headed by Jack Hawkins and Dorothy Black.

The value of United States exports of merchandise, including re-exports, to each of the principal foreign countries except five-China,France, Greece, Japan and the Union of South Africa-increased in October, compared with the same month a year ago, the Department of Commerce reported today in a survey of exports and imports by countries.

The tradition that lasting paper can be made only from rags has been shattered by the photographic division of the Eastman Kodak Company. After ten years of research it is now producing permanent photographic paper from wood pulp.

At the annual meeting of the Larchmont Yacht Club tonight Thomas L. Burton was elected commodore, succeeding Rudolph J. Schaefer, who had held the office for two years. Harvey Connover Jr. was chosen vice commodore and Clair L. Farrand, rear commodore. Robert E. Carrick was re-elected secretary, as was Vincent Cullen, treasurer.

A NUMBER of new gadgets have been devised to enhance the joys of skiing this season. They touch on manifold phases of the sport, from the personal comfort of the skier to the preservation of his skiing equipment.
NEW EAR'S EVE prices will be substantially lower in many places than those of last year, the decrease ranging from $1 to $6, judging from the announced asking prices.

Better interest in shoes, leather and hides following sharp reduction of shoe inventories resulted last week in sales of hides at higher prices, an advance in asking prices on leather and a firmer tone in the shoe market.

Compared with the first six months of this year, construction of one-family homes dropped less sharply during July and August than did that of multi-family dwellings, reports the United States Building and Loan League.

A grant of $135,000 for a threeyear study by the American Council on Education, which will mobilize the educational resources of the country in an endeavor to improve and evaluate the current output of educational movies for classroom use, was announced yesterday by Dr. George F. Zook, president of the council.
The New York University Glee Club of 100 members, comprising undergraduates, alumni and faculty, presented a concert last night at Town Hall under the direction of Professor Alfred M. Greenfield.

The annual conference of the Chiefs of Staff of the Little Entente nations will be held in Prague next week. General Jonescu of Rumania left today for Prague after conferring with the Minister of War, reportedly on the results of the visit of Yvon Delbos, the French Foreign Minister.
A program of interneships in business, which has always formed part of the training at the Prince School of Store Service Education, has been enlarged by the school, now a part of Simmons College.

Its leaders predicted today that the House would approve a wage-hour bill quickly next week. They said privately that they believed controversy over the administrative features of the measure and the exact terms of the control of wages and hours would not endanger final adoption.

The Angriff carried a picture supplement today attacking a NEW YORK TIMES editorial of Nov. 30 proposing economic pressure against aggressive dictatorial powers if the need should arise. The pictures represent hunger scenes in Germany resulting from the wartime allied blockade. French caricatures likewise are reproduced.

AFTER his "Deserts on the March" Paul B. Sears can a Ibe sure of an audience for anything he cares to write. He is, as his former book showed, one of those born simplifierswho seem to be cropping up with encouraging frequency in our scientific world.

Joseph V. Battin, once the highest salaried player in baseball, died here today. His age was 86. Mr. Battin's baseball career included fifteen years with major league clubs, beginning with the Philadelphia Athletics in 1874. Later he played with the St. Louis Browns as catcher and captain of the team.

Whatever might have been happening to other values in the United States during the last few days, the stock of those intimates who advised President Roosevelt against calling a special session of Congress has been mounting steadily.

Stormy weather continues at the base of the MacGregor Arctic expedition here. The records just completed for November show that snow fell on twenty-three days out of thirty, which, coupled with a considerable number of days with high winds, made it very disagreeable to carry on outside work.

For American industry 1937 has been a harried year. In its first half markets, prices and profits rose; but labor, as is usual in a period of recovery, sought by strikes to restore depression pay-cuts, to establish new high standards and to perfect its organization.

A $5,000 contribution from the City Bank Farmers Trust Company to the United Hospitals Campaign, which is seeking a fund of more than $3,000,000 for ninety-two voluntary hospitals of the city and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, was announced yesterday by F. Abbot Goodhue, chairman of the finance section.
After a debate marked by criticisms and fears of French inferiority in the air, the Chamber of Deputies united today in voting an aviation budget of 7,000,000,000 francs. The vote was 523 to 8.

Although cold weather and Christmas shopping crowded the nation's retail stores last week, several sections reported sales were below those of a year ago. and where gains were reported they were in minor percentages.
For the first time in five years the apartment buildings at 817 and 820 FLfth Avenue are fully occupied, according to Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., agents for the Matchette Realty Corporation, owners.
The Toronto Argonauts won the Canadian football title today, defeating Winnipeg's Blue Bombers, 4-3, on a frozen field before a crowd of 16,000.

The disoovery of a new elemental particle of matter, which may be the longsought-for negative proton, and of another new mysterious fundamental particle which has a mass less than that of the proton, was reported today to the Carnegie Institution by Dr. Robert A. Millikan,

Twenty-five States will be represented at the nineteenth annual convention of the National Association of Marketing Officials, opening Thursday at the Pennsylvania Hotel. The meeting will continue on Friday and Saturday.

Antiquities and rarities, collected by the late Sumner Healey in his globe-encircling searches for curiosities, arts and crafts will be sold at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Saturday afternoon.

A fortnight ago Mickey Mouse, appearing in a comic strip in Yugoslavia, was banished by the royal censor. In reporting the incident, Hubert Harrison, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Belgrade, noted that the comic sequence had been prohibited just as it disclosed the hatching of revolt against the ruler of a mythical kingdom.

The potential market for "practical Winter air-conditioning" is in homes costing $5,000 or more, and all-year conditioning, including Summer air cooling, is confined to residences selling at $7,500 or more, according to the findings of atwelvemonth survey announced yesterday by W. H. Stangle of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.
A calendar crowded with events marking the Christmas season has been planned by the students of Pembroke College in Brown University for next week before the beginning of the holidays.

AROUND two portraits of the eighteenth century, long cherished in her family, Gabriele Reuter weaves the slender story of her new novel. Though full of deft, imaginative touches, it is founded upon solid historical fact and is well calculated to provide the reader with a hostalgic and charming excursion into the German past.

THE giant clam, nightmare bivalve of the Australian seas, is one of the queerest mankillers in the world. The clam is a huge hinged shell, in two parts like an oyster, and museum specimens reveal that it attaine a length of anything up to eight feet.

THE character of the Rome-Berlin axis has changed unmistakably in recent weeks. It is still, as the writer was told on the highest authority, simply "an instrument of policy," a means to another end. Official enthusiasm here is perfunctory and not a little nervous as the instrument sharpens. Popular enthusiasm is non-existent. In a fortnight in Italy I have met only one non-official Italian who does not actively dislike the tightening tie with-Germany.

Warning that buildings planned by speculators in the Riverdale section of the Bronx along the new Hendrick Hudson Parkway constitute a threat to the rural charm of the area, Harry Colen, builder, urges the sponsors of such projects to limit their developments to the garden type.

The New York University Museum of Living Art, the first and reputedly the finest collection of twentieth-century paintings in America, marks today the tenth anniversary of its establishment by Albert E.

Mr. and Mrs. G. Horton Glover entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa. Mr. and Mrs. Byron D. Chandler gave a dinner at the Plantation for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Edgar P. Lawson of Southport, Conn.;

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag sustained a ruling of the Board of Standards and Appeals yesterday, refusing permission to the Socony Vacuum Oil Company and Sobol Brothers Service Stations to cut the curbs on property at 127-135 Fourth Avenue and 102104 East Thirteenth Street, where it was proposed to build a gasoline service station, repair shop and salesroom.

Through Science Service Harold F. Dorn, health statistician of the United States Public Health Service, tells us that the mean expectancy of life at birth may ultimately be raised from its present level of more than sixty years to as high as seventy. But not higher.
Lehigh University will name the first unit of its new dormitory system the Richards House in honor of Dr. Charles Russ Richards of Minneapolis, president emeritus.

Instruction and amusement by way of the candid camera will be introduced into the annual meeting this afternoon of the New York City Alumnae, Kappa Kappa Gamma, national women's fraternity, at the New York City Panhellenic, Beekman Tower. William E. C.

FROM ancient legends to the decoration of modern homes, and all around the world for tradition and custom and song and feasting, this book goes questing to celebrate the Christmastide. It is, as its title states, a book of facts and of fancies; it is also a book of foods and home-made candles and Christmas cards.

Mr. and Mrs. Morton Reck Campbell of this city have announced the engagement of their only daughter, Miss Catherine Wood Campbell, to Randolph Apperson Hearst, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Hearst of New York and San Simeon, Calif. The marriage will take place in the near future.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Robinson of 120 North Avenue have made known the engagement of Mr. Robinson's daughter, Miss Helena Beatrice Cowburn Robinson, to Clarence Bradford Carter, son of Mrs. Alice Carter of New Haven, Conn., and the late Charles H. Carter. The marriage will take place this month in the Church of St. Edward the Martyr in New York.

More than 100 teachers of history in secondary schools in the East voted yesterday to retain the "unit system" in teaching their courses. They conferred at the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the Secondary Education Board to discuss the recent report of the commission on examinations In history of the college entrance examination board.

It is frequently asserted that the cause of the recent recession in business is the reduction in governmental expenditures. It is pointed out that, on the one hand, we paid a soldiers' bonus in 1936 but not this year, and, on the other, that the Federal Government is this year collecting social security taxes which it was not collecting a year ago.
Nine Rebel planes and one Government pursuit plane were shot down in yesterday's air battle in Aragon, according to a National Defense Ministry communique issued at 2 o'clock this morning.

Prompt action by the Board of Estimate in acquiring the land needed for the easterly approach to the Triborough Bridge in the Bronx is urged by Roderick Stephens, president of the Bronx Board of Trade and a member of the Triborough Bridge Authority.

Mrs. Ellsworth H. Rollins of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Abbie Adaline Rollins, to Gardner Arthur Caverly of Laconia and Boston, son of Mrs. Arthur L. Caverly of Laconia and the late Mr. Caverly.

The manifests of liners arriving from foreign ports in the last week told in their own way the story of the approaching Christmas. Table delicacies, foods and wines of the Christmas season were listed along with decorative novelties.

The Harvard Crimson, student publication, said today university officials had declined commercial sponsorship of radio broadcasts of Harvard's seven home football games next Fall although athletic committee members had voiced a favorable attitude.

" An Ambassador," wrote Sir Henry Wotton about 300 years ago, "is an honest man sent to lie abroad for the good of his country." That definition may have been true then; it is not necessarily valid today.
Coming through with an unexpected victory, Boston defeated Philadelphia yesterday, 4 to 3, in the opening match of the tri-city squash racquets matches for the Lockett Trophy at the University Club.

There is a strong possibility that the new City Council will be organized by a majority "on the side of good government," Newbold Morris, President-elect of the Council, said yesterday at a luncheon of the Women's City Club, 20 West Fifty-first Street.

A separate map showing the approaches to the new Lincoln Tunnel, which will be formally dedicated Dec. 21, has been prepared by the Port of New York Authority, together with a new folder showing highway routes in the metropolitan area, with special reference to its interstate tunnels and bridges.

With George Buttle, Scarlet center, pacing the attack with 21 points, the Rutgers basketball team registered its second victory of the season tonight, defeating Montclair State Teachers 49 to 39 before 2,000 spectators.

THIS is the second of the twenty-four volumes to be issued under the general title of "Rivers of America." Miss Constance Lindsay Skinner, editor of this extended series, states that its purpose is to retell the folk sagas of our people as they developed along the banks of our greatest rivers, and to show the pioneer experience, its color and texture, as it unfolded and reached forward with the natural rhythm of flowing waters.

A parade of bicyclists through the cycle paths of Central Park and down Fifth Avenue, culminating in a series of races in East Sixtieth Street, will be seen next Sunday morning and afternoon in connection with the third annual Bicycle Breakfast, which again will be held for the benefit of the Children's Welfare Federation. The breakfast will take place at La Salle du Bois, 36 East Sixtieth Street.
After generations of myopic approach to some of our major welfare problems, the present may be an auspicious time to enlist public attention for better methodology in handling our delinquents.

THESE PLATATIONS. By J. Earl Clauson. Svo. Providence. R L: The Roger Williams Press. E. A. Johnson Company. Historical sketches and tales of old Rhode Island. THE GOLDEN CENTURY OF SPAIN, 1501-1621. By R. Trevor Davies. 8vo. New York: The Macmillan Company. $6. A social, economic and cultural history.

There was a smaller demand here today for francs in connection with the repatriation of French funds, and consequently less pressure on the dollar. The dollar rate improved fractionally to $4.99-A to the pound, while the British exchange authorities had to take francs to keep the rate steady at 147 5-64.

The swimming team of Textile High School defeated Theodore Roosevelt, 41 to 30, yesterday, and thereby won the Manhattan-BronxRichmond senior high school championship of the Public School Athletic League, in the 25-yard pool of De Witt Clinton High School.

The celebrated Madame Famous de Thebes, soothsayer and S??byl prophetess, is dead in Gone Paris at a ripe old age. She foretold a good many things which people remember to have happened. No doubt she foretold a great many more things which did not come to pass but which people conveniently forgot. She worked under astral influences.
Miss Elizabeth Willcox, a granddaughter of the late Major Gen. Orlando B. Willcox, U.S.A., was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church to Thomas Lambard Robinson of New York.

Faced by a shortage of four-year trained instructors for its elementary schools, Connecticut is now in the process of reorganizing its teacher-training program. Three former normal schools, those at New Haven, Willimantic and Danbury, have just started a new career as four-year, degree-granting teachers' colleges, offering a new and greatly expanded curriculum for elementary school teachers, as well as a variety of courses fitting for every school post.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Phillips of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Phillips, to Deane W. Krueger, son of Mrs. Charles H. Krueger of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Krueger.

Unless otherwise stated, the resuit of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, ard after deductions for operating expenses and normal lFederal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Misinterpretation of the basic decision of the United States Supreme Court on the taxability of a stock dividend as income, rendered in 1920 (Eisner v. Macomber), has had an extraordinary effect upon statutory law on this subject.

BOTH international broadcast stations at Schenectady, N. Y., W2XAD and W2XAF, will be on the air continuously and simultaneously for forty hours, from 9 A. M. (EST), on Dec. 31, until 1 A. M. (EST) Jan. 2, so that short-wave fans all over the world may enjoy the programs broadcast in connection with the New Year's celebration. Dance bands from coast to coast will serenade 1938 in the various time zones.

Squadron C teams rode to victory in two exhibition indoor polo matches at the Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn last night as the home forces continued preparations for the coming Metropolitan League campaign.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Latrielle of this place gave a dinner party at their home last night for their son, Frederick G. Latrielle, before the children's dancing class at the Greenwich Country Club.

Ground will be broken at an early date for the first of a series of three apartment houses .to be built on Queens Boulevard between Sixty-sixth Avenue and Sixty-seventh Drive, Forest- Hills, L. I., Manoug Exerjian, architect for the structures, announced yesterday.

The Montclair Athletic Club is the only undefeated team in the New Jersey C Division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association as a result of its victory over the Elizabeth Town and Country Club today, 3-2.
Facts about nurses and nursing will receive the widest possible circulation through a speakers' bureau organized by the New York Counties Registered Nurses' Association.
Miss Sara Clucas is chairman of the junior committee for the three folk dance recitals to be held this week in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery.

Miss Elizabeth Millett of Paris and New York, daughter of the American painter, Stephen C. Millett, was married today to Henry de Vilmorin. Duke Pozzo di Borgo, a prisoner in connection with the alleged plot to overthrow the French Republic, had obtained a magistrate's permission to be present-at the wed-ding as a witness but at the last minute word was received that his release could not be arranged.

The second unofficial fourday test cricket match between an Indian eleven and Lord Tennyson's touring team started today. The Englishmen won the first test by nine wickets. Batting first, the Indians compiled a first-innings score of 153, while the visitors chalked up 521 runs for no wickets before stumps were drawn.
THE making of pottery in the United States is developing into a highly in dividual art, no longer bounded by the techniques of ancient Chinese ceramics, long devoutly followed.

In one of the most spectacular finishes of the meeting, Mrs. R. A. Smith's gelding Trouper, 9-to-1 shot, captured the $2,000 added Jefferson Park Handicap at the Fair Grounds today by inches over Butsey Hernandez's Woodlander and Coward Coffey's Waxwing.
Senator Bridges of New Hampshire called tonight for support of his move to repeal the law giving the President the power to issue $3,000,000,000 in new currency.

By an astronomical paradox Dec. 23, one of the shortest days in the year, is also the longest. This can be proved with a pole. The shortest day each year in New York, judged from sunrise to sunset, falls about Dec. 23. But judged by the day which extends from noon to noon-or midnight to midnight-the shortest day is the longest.

Denouncing the "governmentmade depression," radicalism, the President's plan to "pack" the Supreme Court and the eventuality of American entry into foreign wars or entanglements, Hamilton Fish, Republican Representative from New York, made a plea yesterday for the unified support of "the government envisioned by our forefathers."
In the article on Professor Rhine's experiments in extra-sensory perception, which was published on this page in last Sunday's Nzw YORK TIMES, two errors appeared which need correction.

Nearly 125 persons, most of them members of the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, held a demonstration yesterday at noon outside the central offices of the Consolidated Edison Company, Irving Place and Fourteenth Street.
The annual Christmas candlelight musical sponsored by the music section of the Bronxville Women's Club will be held Sunday of next week at the clubhouse.

THE final five concerts of the Current Stradivari bicentennial festival being held at the Library of Congress, Washington, D. C., under the auspices of the Gertrude Clarke Whittall Foundation, will be given daffy this week from Tuesday to Saturday inclusive.

The auction of the first part of the art properties of the late Frederick A. Juilliard was completed yesterday afternoon at the Plaza Art Galleries, 9 East Fifty-ninth Street. The sale, which began on Thursday, realized $83,806.50, the total for the final session alone being $50,232.50.

William J. Keyes, for thirty-five years a member of the Democratic City Committee and father of former Aldermanic President Daniel Keyes of Poughkeepsie, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 77.

An ambitious five-point program for interested businesses and governmental agencies to promote travel to the United States is outlined in a pamphlet issued by the United States Tourist Bureau, set up last February under the Department of the Interior by Secretary Harold L. Ickes.

The League of Nations armaments year book, published today, showed that the world's expenditures on armaments in 1937 will total $11,857,000,000, nearly three times as much as in 1913, the year before the World War began. The world's standing armies totaled 8,500,000, as against only 6,000,000 in 1913.

PALM BEACH, Fla.--Returning members of the Palm Beach colony are finding the face of the island much altered sinoe last season. Nearly seventy new homes have- been built and many of the old Spanish dwellings have been remodeled.

After a seven weeks' course in body mechanics, the Smith College freshman class shows a marked improvement. Records of the Department of Physical Education show that of -523 students whose pictures were taken before the course only three got A; 109 got B; 371 got C, and four got D.

NEAR the Hans Christian Andersen Museum and Memorial Hall in this ancient Danish city another object of interest now beckons the sightseeing tourist. On the north coast of the island of Funen there has been uncovered what was once a

MISS SACKVILlEWEST, by marriage Mrs. Harold Nicolson, here portrays her ancestors. The coat-of-arms was crossed, not so long ago, with what heraldry records as the bar sinister. But the blot on the scutcheon, as Browning would have dramatized it, is reflected by no blush in these vivacious pages.
Joseph E. Davies will soon give up his position as Ambassador to Russia and be transferred to another diplomatic post.

Leisurely safe robbers broke into Caruso's Restaurant at 40 West Thirty-third Street early yesterday morning, stole $4,525 and a pistol, ate four or five cold, cooked chickens, drank three-quarters of a bottle of the most expensive Scotch in the place and left their safe-breaking tools and the chicken bones on the floor when they departed.

The Norwegian freighter Triton, chartered by Isbrandtsen-Moller Company, Inc., steamship agents, sailed for Manila from her pier at Sedgwick Street, Brooklyn, two hours late shortly after last midnight after the crew of thirty had

A drive to limit total expenditures under new farm legislation to $500,000,000 a year and to cut present administrative costs by nearly 50 per cent was started in the Senate today with the support of Democratic and Republican members.
Replies from 419 Vassar students to a questionnaire on Summer- activi ties prepared by the college vocational bureau, show that- 24 per cent had paid jobs and 11 per cent engaged in volunteer work.

With Dr. Herman N. Bundesen, president of the Board of Health, furnishing the blood, physicians at St. Elizabeth's Hospital today resorted to an unusual technique in administering a transfusion to an infant desperately ill of epidemic diarrhea, a mysterious disease which recently killed eleven babies at the hospital.

BXCURSIONS IN ENGLISH DRAMA. By Robert Withington, Ph. D. 260 pp. New York: D. Appleton-Century Company. $1.50. IT is always interesting and even stimulating to learn the professorial viewpoint on any given subject, let alone the theatre.
Plans for the marriage of Miss Marie Bergenfeld of New York, a student at Goucher College, to Morton Hecht Jr. of Baltimore, a student of Maryland University, were announced to- I day.

Plans for the erection of 500 dwellings, most of them in the $5,000 price class, were announced yesterday by Haring Blumenthal Realty Corporation, Westchester developers. The decision to concentrate on the low-cost market was reached, Charles F. Haring explained,

The volume of prosecutions of fraudulent securities dealers by the Attorney General's office reached a high record for October and November, according to Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Bureau of Securities here.

As a result of the successful music festival held in Silvermine, Conn., last August, the Silvermine Guild Music Festival Association, Inc., has been formed and will hold a five-day festival there next August.

A new chorus, the Folk Singers of Philadelphia, composed of eighteen professional vocalists under the direction of Isadore Freed, will specialise in polyphonic music of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries and folk literatures of various countries.

Mrs. John Moxon, who has retired after six years as executive secretary of the Associate Alumnae of New Jersey College for Women, will be the guest of honor tomorrow at a dinner in Cooper Hall to be given by the alumnae board of directors.

CHRISTMAS and New Year's Day, because they fall Saturday this year, are chal lenging many to make that long-planned cruise. Multiple tours have been planned by steamship lines to near-by islands and ports, tours from six to thirteen days, or even longer for the tourist with ample leisure. By Dec. 18 the Christmas trek is expected to be well under way.

The soccer teams of Manual Training High of Brooklyn and Evander Childs of the Bronx played to a 1-all deadlock in the final play-off for the city P. S. A. L. championship at Monroe High School field yesterday. The elevens battled through two extra periods.

I WOULD like to say a few words about the English origins of documentary, because I think they carry a very special significanoe for today, and particularly for you of the English-Speaking Union. For all practical purposes our documentary began with a film unit established by the British Government's Empire Marketing Board.

Responsive to the smaller rate of decline in industrial activity, the stock market leveled off last week. THE NEW YORK TIMES, index of fifty stocks moved within a, range of only 4.04 points, the narrowest of any week since mid-August.

IS the shadow of a "class struggle" lying, for the first time, across the American landscape? This question might have been asked before. It might have been asked, if the phrase had been current, when inland farmers in pre-Revolutionary times got out their squirrel rifles to take pot shots at what the seaboard called law and order.

THE capacity of the Elizabethan man to combine in his life or his work activities of radically opposite nature is sometimes a little puzzling, always interesting and frequently not a little amusing. Thus a Drake could be both a pirate and a patriot. And in his less obtrusive life the Puritan author,

ALMOST a legendary figure in the field of art, Dr. AlIbert C. Barnes has become, like all decided and unusual personalities, the peg of innumerable stories, difficult to classify as mythical or merely picturesque.

Mrs. Roosevelt gave her fourth annual "Gridiron Widows' Party" tonight, entertaining more than 400 women in the White House. Among the guests were women members of the Senate and House, Secretary Perkins and "widows" of Gridiron Club members.
THAT aged epigram, "Everybody talks about the weather, but nobody does anything about it," is disproved by a large body of enthusiasts who really are doing something about the weather.

Joseph Stalin closed the first Soviet election campaign tonight in a speech, part jocular and part serious, before delegates from the "Stalin district of Moscow," where he is a candidate for the Supreme Council, at a mass meeting at the Bolshoi Theatre.
A contract for a service-test lot of thirteen P-37 pursuit airplanes and spare parts was awarded by the Army Air Corps today to the Curtiss Aeroplane Division

Adrenalin, secreted by the little adrenals that straddle the kidneys, arouses anger and marshals the body's defenses in an emergency. When it is poured into the circulatory system the amount of blood sugar increases.
Candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor will predominate among the speakers at the Jackson Day dinner of the National Democratic Committee at the Hotel Commodore on Jan. 8,
The Yale University squash racquets team vanquished the Yale Club players, 5 to 2, in a special match at the Yale Club courts in this city yesterday.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls nosed out the Bronx Tigers, 2 to 1, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game tonight. The victory enabled the Gulls to break their first-place tie with the New York Rovers.
THE first tinie that hard working Texas cowboy, big brawny Clay Bannerman, rode up to the trail-end, rail-end town of Bird City he had been a thirty-dollar-a-month "hand."

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Van Houten Read' of Indian Hill, this place, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shirley Lefavour Read, to Michael Clinton Scilipoti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Scilipoti of Towaco.

Student government at Keuka College has become an entirely selfruling organization, through the Cooperative Government Association, whose power is vested in a Student-Faculty Congress. Within the congress are the House Government Unit, which has complete charge of rules concerning dates and quiet hours, and interest group units.

Dick Crean, owner of a clothing business, announced today Christmas bonuses for his thirty-five employes totaling $30,000--an average of about $857 each. The bonuses will range from $50 for employes who have been in his employ two weeks to $2,800 each

THE six years' struggle to establish parks in Great Britain-like the great public preserves in this country-made headway recently when the National Forest Park Committee recommended that a national forest park be made 6f Gwydyr Forest, about 18,000 acres forming a fringe to the wild and open mountain land ending in the Snowdon range, highest mountain in Wales.

Evidences of increased industrial activity in Newark, N. J., are indicated by two important deals just closed in that city through the brokerage firm of David Cronheim. The property at 740 Frelinghuysen Avenue was purchased by the Brass Yeast Corporation from the sheet metal firm of J. Steinberg Son. A single-story factory building occupies the rear portion of the plot,
A Foreign Office spokesman declared tonight that sentiment was growing in Japan for "resolute action" against Soviet Russia in connection with a Russo-Japanese fisheries dispute.

ART ARBITER: James Bolivar Manson, director of London's Tate Gallery, was appointed last week to decide whether sculptures imported into Britain are works of art or not. If not, a duty will be levied on them in order to protect domestic stone carvers. Mr. Manson studied painting in his youth (he is 58 years old) in England and France.

Discussion of "How Can the Accountant, the Banker and the Credit Man Better Serve the Business Community?" will - feature a joint meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants and the New York Credit Men's Association tomorrow night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A step in the right direction was taken recently at the annual meeting of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association when it decided to revise members' handicaps in accordance with those of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.
Ten leading candidates have been picked from the host of nominees for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy, annually awarded to the nation's outstanding amateur athlete.
Except for the excitement caused by the revelation of the Cagoulard plot and the arrest of some of its alleged participants, France is Just now enjoying an exceptionally calm time politically.

Subsiding seas after a period of the heaviest surf and highest tides in nine years have left a problem of serious beach erosion here. The pounding surf has been described by L. Trevette Lockwood, town manager, as the worst since the 1928 storm.

The rarest and most interesting prints,.. implements and serimshaws from the whaling collection of Henry P. Kendall, one of the most complete records of a New England industry which once occupied 70,000 men and a fleet of 700 ships, will be exhibited for the first time at a private showing. for guests of President Compton and the corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology here. Sunday.

The Jewish system of ethics is "complete," having been based from the beginning on the fundamental concepts of liberty, justice and truth, Rabbi Louis I. Newman declared yesterday at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eightythird Street, in a sermon in which he differed with last week's suggestion by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum that the teachings of Jesus be included in Jewish ritual.

MIAMI, Fla.--Sport interest here has reached a high pitch at the outset of the Winter season. Some of the nation's best golfers are moving to tomorrow's finals of the MiamiBiltmore $10,000 open tournament, which began on Friday, followed by large galleries.

TWO football classics will be on the air New Year's Day with WEAF's hook-up handling the New Orleans' Sugar Bowl engagement between Louisiana State University and Santa Clara University, beginning at about 2 P. M. Announcer Bill Stern will be at the microphone.
THE political and literary world of Paris is mourning the loss of one of its most celebrated rendezvous, for after 169 well-filled years the Restaurant Fovot is closing its doors.
" I predict that within three months--provided we can hold out, which I am sure we can -- Japan will be on the brink of bankruptcy and facing revolution!"

FORTUNATELY, this book is published in America as well as in England. It would be a sad mistake for any one to assume that it will be of interest mainly to Englanders. For the world comes to attention "when England goes to press."
(All time in P. M., Eastern standard, unless otherwise indicated; dial locations are. in megacycles.)

NASSAU, Bahamas.--American and Canadian contestants in the annual international golf tournament will arrive by chip from Miamil on Dec. 16. Ths will give them one day to practice on the course, which has been considerably changed.

BLIND individuals throughout the country may now enjoy in their homes many of the outstanding plays of the Broadway theatre. These plays, acted in their entirety by actors and actresses from the New York stage in the sound studio of the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, New York City, have been recorded there on photographic disks as talking books.

The United States liner Washington arrived yesterday, a day behind schedule as a result of a combination of circumstances. Fog and bad sailing weather delayed her for several hours and three more were lost when Captain Ralph C. Dooley, master, answered an appeal from the Shephard Line freighter Wind Rush Wednesday and took aboard a fireman injured in a fight with a fellow seaman.

ADVENTURES AMONG IMMORTALS. As-told by Percy Burton to LoweU Thomas. 350 pp. Neio York: Dodd, Mead d Co. $3. PHINEAS T. BARNUM was dead when Percy Burton--wearing eyeglasses to make himself look less callow and youthful--joined the staff of the Greatest Show on Earth.

Yale rallied in the closing minutes of the second period of tonight's game with the Manhattan Arrows, produced a tie early in the third and, with three seconds of play remaining. captured the game. 4 to 3.

THOUGH only a few railroad men foresaw the competition their lines would receive from the transcontinental airlines, it appears that all the steamship companies will eventually participate in transoceanic flying. Just last week, John E. Slater, executive vice president of the American Steamship Corporation, put his company on record again in Washington in support of the Maritime Commission's control of foreign airlines.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 10: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Wright, F. W. (MaJ.), Air Corps, Wright Field, Dayton, Ohio, to McChord Field, Tacoma, Wash., to sail from New York about Jan. 6 for San Francisco.

A compilation by the Twenty-third Street Association of the traffic figures recently reported by the Transit Commission for the fiscal year ending June 30. last, revealed the fact that, excluding motor bus fares, the total collections at the various subway and elevated stations at Twenty-third Street showed an increase during the year of 1,213,777 fares.

In a "Who'Who" of the Rutgers University campus, The Targum, undergraduate. newspaper, published in today's issue a listing of student leaders in forty-four clubs, honorary societies and student government classifications.

Plans for a mile-long Central Mall for the New York World's Fair of 1939, said to be the most elaborate artistic project in the history of such expositions, were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corportion.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Fabian Franklin, with his usual perspicacity, goes to the root of the matter in discussing your editorial "Britain Nationalizes Coal" in his recent letter. in this move, as he shows, there is no attempt to deal with the problem of adjusting the extralegal institution of absolute private ownership of natural resources along the lines proposed by Henry George to the demands of modern social conditions.

The 100-acre estate with thirteenroom Colonial-style house, known as Lookout Ledge, at Sorrento, Me., has been sold by the Huckleberry Hills Corporation of New Canaan, Conn., to Robert H. Loomis of Boston, Mass. The property also contains a guest house, gardener's cottage, gatehouse and boathouse.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Dec. 9, 1937, upon the eligible list of holders of license as laboratory assistant in physics and chemistry in day secondary schools other than junior high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

Dartmouth's hockey team opened its season tonight with a 7-to-O victory over the Columbia Lions before 1,200 undergraduates. Dave Walsh and Fud Mather started the Green scoring in the second period with three tallies.
The Metropolitan season's first ."Traviata," given yesterday afternoon, was one of sporadic excellences set off from what may be broadly termed an unobjectionably routine performance.
Assistance in the form of loans from the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee is being received by at least 50,000 Jewish artisans in Poland, according to a committee announcement yesterday.

New York City is being used as a laboratory for a first-hand study of the participation of the Federal Government in .housing projects and in the settlement of labor disputes by Barnard College students taking the course in social legislanation given by Dr. Jane Perry Clark of the government department.
Led by Captain Sonstroem, w?? scored 13 points, the Wesleya quintet captured a hard-playc contest from Swarthmore College. 52-43, on the Garnet's court tonight.

The horse show team of the Sixty-first Cavalry Division Reserve of New York captured the jumping competition of the fourteenth annual Troop F military horse show tonight before a crowd of 2,500 at Essex Troop Armory.

The common goal of Christian and Jew is the "fulfillment of the ideal of democracy in its every phasepolitical, social and economic," Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan declared last night at the opening of a two-day conference celerating the fiftieth anniversary of the Yeshiva-the Rabbi Isaac E1chanan Theological Seminary-and the tenth anniversary of Yeshiva College.

Nanking is now lost to China, and the China-Japan war enters its political phase. From now on there are two battlefronts and two strategies, the military and the political. For both China and Japan the problem is to improvise something to replace what Nanking stood for, a problem even more difficult for Japan than for China.

A vaccine for preventing pneumonia, being prepared at the Army Medical School in Washington, is now being distributed toCCC camps throughout the country. Young men at the camps will receive shots of the vaccine, which it is believed will protect them during the Winter against the disease which ranks third as a cause of death among all diseases, writes Jane Stafford of Science Service.

Dr. Beresford H. Thompson of 140 Milton Street, Brooklyn, collapsed yesterday while shopping in Astoria, Queens, and died later in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, Queens, of a heart ailment. His age was 52.

Mexican labor unions will seek a blanket contract in the mining industry, where United States and British companies predominate, Vicente Lombardo Toledano, chief of the Mexican Federation of Workers, said today.
Viscountess Massereene, one of the best-known London hostesses and an authority on ghost and phantom lore, died in her Scottish home, nock 'House, Isle of Mull, today at the age of 54.

AFTER thirty-four years aviation is still based on the work Aof the Wright brothers. Even targest airplanes, the huge substratosphere transports, the giant bombers and all the rest must possess the fundamental characteristios of the first real flying machine which Wilbur and Orville Wright flew off the storm-swept sands at Kitty Hawk, N. C., on Deo. 17, 1903.

The thirty-fifth annual report of Greenwich House, which has recently been published, announces that, in conjunction with its Children's Health Service, 3,000 visits were made during the year by nurses and clinic visitors and 500 visits to clinics were made either to see doctor or nurse..

Five American Labor party councilmen-elect informally inspected the city's markets last week in the first of a series of weekly trips. They hope to acquire a working knowledge of city departments to aid in drafting social betterment legislation.
A discovery that when a man does mental work the muscles all over his body get busy was made public today at Indiana University. The muscular accompaniments were found all the way down into the legs.

Forced to travel at top speed for three-quarters of the contest, and held practically even in an exciting first half, City College's basketball team put on the pressure midway through the second period against Seton Hall at the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium last night to win a wellplayed battle, 46-32.
ALDOUS EHUXLEYS "Ends and Means" is a volume certain to be discussed over intellectual dinner tables for many months to come. It is written with the lucidity and

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, A. S. Cornhill won the high-overall cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. In the handicap shooting the Class A trophy was taken by B. M. Higginson, who had a full card. In Class B five gunners tied, F. A. Sansome scoring in the shoot-off.

The presence of a large number of debutantes in this year's group whose families have long been dentified with Brooklyn society has inspired an entertainment to be given on Jan. 14 at the WaldorfAstoria known as "Three Generations Dinner Dance."

IF every editor in the nation were requested to make a list of the half dozen most colorful places in this country, Bunker Hill, the Stock Exchange, the California studios and the Vieux Carre of New Orleans would all receive mention.

The engagement of Miss Virginia Ruth Bludworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Franklin Bludworth of this place, to Alf 0. Gautesen, son of Mrs. Gunval A. Gautesen of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and Bluepoint, L. I., has been announced by her parents.
Aubrey Williams, deputy work progress administrator, said today that Christmas earnings of WPA and National Youth Administration workers would amount to nearly $85,000,000.

Sharp opposition is developing in Wall Street to the proposal to raise New York Stock Exchange commission rates by 11 or is per cent. Critics base their complaints on calculations that possibly a quarter of the business now done in New York will be driven to other cities.

Charged with peddling without a license, a young lawyer who was admitted to the bar three years ago was freed in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday by Magistrate Edgar Bromberger after it was ascertained that the defendant was unaware that he had been violating the law.

New York City public school children, taught by experimental progressive education methods, are showing superior ability in many significant fields and are apparently outstripping their classmates who receive schooling under the traditional system.

Lawrenceville's polo team won its second encounter of the season, 13 1/2 to 8 1/2, over the Princeton freshmen today. Many fouls slowed the game. Mather and Osmun featured the victors' attack. Bowles, a member of the Lawrenceville squad last year, led the Tiger freshmen with four goals.
WASHINGTON-The largest consumption of tobacco in twenty years is being registered for 1937 by government statisticians.

Edward Kl'ne, Long Island architect, declares that the prevailing style for suburban homes in 1938 will be a blending of modern and Colonial designs. He points out 'that as English architecture was the predominant style of the Nineteen Twenties and pure Colonial types lead today, a modernized form of Colonial architecture serving to circumvent building costs is raDidlv coming into vogue.
Dr. and Mrs. Ora M. Walker of Bloomfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alma Allis, to Arthur Ericksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Eriksen, also of Bloomfield.

President Roosevelt will receive 200 additional books for the White House Library tomorrow as a gift from the book trade. A committee of publishers, authors and librarians, headed by Lewis B. Traver, president of the American Booksellers- Association, will make the presentation at the White House.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. prepared yesterday an answer to the. letters he received from Morris L. Ernst, special assistant to the Attorney General, to investigate vote frauds under proportional representation, in which, it was expected, he would advise Mr. Ernst to hold his evidence until Jan. 1.

Colonization of vast unpopulated areas in the rich farming lands of Aysen and Magallanes Provinces by immigrants will start soon. The Immigration Control Committee issued questionnaires to landowners in the southern provinces to learn their needs.
The annual bridge party and tea under the auspices of the alumnae association of St. Joseph's College for Women, Brooklyn, will take nlstoa on Jan. 15 at Essex House.
