Miss Flora Blanc, daughter of Mrs. Edward H. Blanc of 114 East Eighty-fourth Street and the late Mr. Blanc, was married to Edward Dickinson Reeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dean Worthington Reeder of Fort Worth, Texas, yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Stanley Richter at 1.133 Fifth Avenue.
The existence in Great Britain of two societies having as their declared purpose the perpetuation of the memory of the Duke of Windsor in orie form or another is revealed by The Sunday Pictorial.

With Captain Vernon Struck and George Lowman showing the way, the Harvard basketball team annexed its third victory of tne season by vanquishing the Williams quintet, 39 to 17, before a capacity crowd in the Lasell Gymnasium tonight.
The Federal Government made National Guard trucks available tonight to help Erie County municipalities open roads and streets after one of the worst blizzards in the history of the region.

SECOND MILITARY AREA Each of the following Reserve officers is relieved from his present assignment and Is assigned to the organization indicated: 1200TH SERVICE UNIT (CASC) Capt. Edward Stone, Engr.-Res., 317 W. 99th St., New York. N. Y. 1208TH SERVICE UNIT (CASC).

WASHINGTON. - The United States Treasury Department has abandoned its retail butter business. In so doing it has brought to an end a thriving merchandising operation in which it had been engaged for twenty-three years.

HERE are two books of distinction for the country lover. True, it is of the English countryside that they are written, and of which their woodcuts have been made, but they are not books of parochial interest:
Miss Estella Maresi of 270 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Nina E. Maresi, to Christopher C. Campanari of Genoa, Italy, formerly of this city.

Miss Myrtle Helen Mueller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mueller of this place, was married here today at the home of her parents to J. William Esberg Jr., son of Mrs. Susan Pierce Esberg of Biltmore Forest, N. C., and Sacramento, Calif. The Rev. George A. Liggett, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Springfield, performed the ceremony.

The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the four months from Aug. 1 to Nov. 30 amounted to 2,817,219 tons, compared with 2,126,008 in the corresponding period last year, and cottonseed on hand at mills on Nov. 30 amounted to 1,720,295 tons, against 1,391.558 a vear before.

Al Gainer, 169 1/2, New Haven, knocked out Jerry Reilly, 175 1/2, Pennsylvania, in 47 seconds of the second of a listed eight-round feature contest at the Rockland Palace last night before 3,800 persons.

Wightwick Manor, famous Victorian country house whose design and furnishings were carried out under the influence of the pre-Raphaelite brotherhood, is to join the baronial keeps and Elizabethan mansions that will be -preserved for all time by the national trust.
The International Rotary News Letter records that the Rotary Club in Tokyo, Japan, recently sent a check for $100 to the club at Tientsin, China, to be used by the Tientsin members for relief work.

Mrs. William Massena- Benjamin gave a dinner and dance last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Sarah Morris Benjamin. The party also served as a celebration of the birthday of Miss Benjamin's sister, Miss Mary Benjamin.

Overruling a motion for a new trial, Circuit Judge A. Clay Williams formally sentenced the Rev. C. E. Newton to life imprisonment today for the murder of Mrs. Dennis Kelly, his "devout friend and loyal co-worker," at Paris, Mo.

With the figure dependent upon the inventory status at the end of the year, preliminary buying budgets of retail stores for early Spring will probably show an average reduction in dollar volume of 10 to 15 per cent under a year ago, according to estimates made here yesterday by merchandising executives. Unit purchases will reveal a somewhat smaller drop.

Major A. B. Waller was burned to death and Staff Sergeant John Johnson had a miraculous escap from death this afternoon where their pursuit plane crashed in flames during the aerial show held in connection with a charity fair being staged at Langley Field.

Many years ago the late Professor Ernst Abbe, who did the mathematical work on optics for Carl Zeiss of Jena, decided that it would be difficult, if not impossible, to build a microscope which would magnify more than 1,500 diameters.

KENNETH GANDAR DOWER never found the spotted lion, and the quest is calling to him still. Butathletic, adventurous, humorous, and 26 years old-he had a glorious time in Africa; and from that experience he has written a genuinely unusual book.

The motor yacht Polaris, which was stranded with nine aboard three days ago on a sandbar near Whale Cay, arrived here today. Miss Betty Carstairs, former British speed-boat racer, who bought and retired to the island of Whale Cay in 1934, summoned Coast Guard aid from Miami, Fla.,

Democracy is endangered by a bombardment of propagandistic short-wave radio programs from foreign lands, seeking to draw residents of this country into the orbit of nazism, fascism or communism, Professor Lyman Bryson of Teachers College, Columbia University, charged yesterday.

In a world-wide symposium sponsored by the University of Pennsylvania about half of a group of diplomats requested to define "the place of education in today's scheme of things" pointed to the universities as potentially great forces in furthering international peace.

AMONG the famous "problems" of art history there Lis none, perhaps, more fascinating than the riddle that hsagwrapped itself about the career -of the great Venetian painter, Giorgione. who often, indeed. seems in danger of becoming but the hero of a myth.

The High Cost of Living was placed on trial at the bar of public opinion yesterday afternoon before 260 delegates of 112 organizations of the Consumers National Federation Conference Committee meeting at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.
Carlos Garcia Martinez was executed by a firing squad at dawn today in the capital of Puebla. It was the first criminal execution in twenty years in Puebla and the first in many years in all Mexico.

THE recent assumption of the production reins of a major lot by an attorney-a man unversed in the mechanics ofpicture making-provoked inquiry this week into one of the less romantic aspects of the industry.

The annual Christmas party and bridge under the auspices of the alumnae and students of the Semple School will take place tomorrow afternoon at the school, 351 Riverside Drive, for the benefit of the philanthropic fund of the institution.

JOHN TAYLOR ARMS informs us that the Swedish prints recently shown in conjunction with the annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers at Rockefeller Center have been shipped to Washington, where the Swedish group will launch, with an engagement at the Library of Congress, its nation-wide tour. Says Mr. Arms:
Miss Nancy Church Logan and Miss Jeanne Logan were introduced to society yesterday at a large reception given at the Junior League of New York by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. William John Logan.

THE express that speeds in six hours from Berlin to Prague winds its way along the Elbe Valley through the hazy brown of an Autumn afternoon. On the German side of the frontier stout men and women are out for a walk; some stop at cafes to have their Sunday afternoon coffee and cake.

A re-examination of Feld-Crawford act price maintenance contracts by both liquor retailers and distillers is considered likely next week as an aftermath of the price war which swept the metropolitan market here for several days.

Committees of Parent-Teachers Associations of twenty-three schools will attend a mass meeting at the Abraham Lincoln High School Thursday at 8:30 P. M. to consider the question of overcrowding and discuss plans for getting a new vocational high school.

Not the least important of the railroad problems thrown into relief by the remarks of President Roosevelt on Friday, according to a consensus in Wall Street, is the present conflict of interest between bondholders and stockholders of the carriers that are in bankruptcy or receivership.

Robert C. Johnson, who headed the first bureaus of The Associated Press here and at Seattle, died today after several months' illness at the age of 73. Born in Dallas, Ore., on July 2, 1864, he came to Portland in 1888 as a reporter for The News.

For the first time since its inception thirty years ago, the New York Association for the Blind, familiarly known as the Pioneer Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, has introduced in its recreational activities the art of pottery making. The art, itself, has proved of deep satisfaction to the pupils.

Division of New York City into approximately 100 districts based on population figures and other statistical data will be proposed to the City Planning Commission in January by Dr. Julius B. Mailer of Teachers College, Columbia University, as a means of coordinating the services of various city departments and facilitating city planning.

Dr H. 'Harold Axworthy, chairman of the committee on student affairs at New York University Washington- Square College, expressed satisfaction yesterday with the manner in which student-controlled organizations were being run, as the names of fifty-two officers of undergraduate clubs were announced by Provost Rufus D. about Smith, acting dean of the college.

AFTER speaking contemptuously of the commercial theatre on many occasions, this column is prepared to eat its words this morning. "Of Mice and Men" is the quintessence of comaercial theatre and it is also a maserpiece.
Imported articles of merchandise offered for sale in the department stores of Shanghai are priced at from 5 to 30 per cent in advance of the prices prevailing in July of this year,

Eight hundred cheering, chattering youngsters had a good time yesterday afternoon at the annual show of the Sons of the American Legion, which went on for four and a half hours at the Manhattan Opera House.

A survey just completed based on replies from a representative group of 2,400 building owners and managers throughout the United States indicates that more than $63,000,000 will be spent during 1938 in modernization work. The survey was made by the publication, Buildings and Building Management. It includes reports from 154 cities forty-three States and the District of Columbia.

Plans for establishing what he called the second largest Internal Revenue bonded warehouse on the Eastern seaboard were disclosed yesterday by Irving T. Bush, following receipt of a basic permit issued in Washington by the Federal Alcohol Administration.
The Port Authority has begun the distribution of its new folder showing highway routes into the Greater New York area, with special reference to tunnels and bridges under its jurisdiction.

The only known copy of a Swedish three "skillings" stamp has been sold through a London stamp dealer, H. R. Hammer, for [Pound]6,000 on behalf of J. Ramberg, a Gothenburg lawyer who ten years ago bought the stamp for [Pound]1,700.

Johnny Revolta, former Professional Golfers Association champion, overtook Sam Snead at the half-way mark in the $10,000 MiamiBiltmore open tournament today with his second sub-par round, a 70, for a thirty-six hole tie at 139.

MANHATTAN LEERBURGER, HANNAH (Oct. 27). Estate, less than $10,000. To Elsie Leerburger, daughter, 1,239 Madison Ave., residue. MORRIS, ABRAM (July 15). Estate, less than $500. To sons. Samuel A. Morris, executor, 200 W. 86th St., and George Morris, 15 W. 75th St.. equal shares in residue. Jacob H. Morris, brother, 393 West End Ave., executor.

A. E. Watt Jr. of the New York A. C. became the Long Island squash racquets champion yesterday by beating W. N. Metzler Jr. of the City A. C. in the final of the tournament at the Jackson Heights Squash Club.

Typical "between-season" activity was noted in the New York wholesale market last week, according to a special report prepared for THI NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.
More confidence prevailed among retail executives and elsewhere last week that the volume of lastminute Christmas shopping would push holiday sales figures above those for 1936.
ISLEBORO, Me--A maritime museum as a memorial to the men of Isleboro who went down to the sea in ships will be ready for inspection at this Penobscot Bay Is. land resort next Summer.
Bad weather hampered ships steaming to the relief of passengers and crew of the stranded liner President Hoover today, the Cavite navy radio was informed.

More than 200 surveys of real estate and mortgage conditions in major cities of the United States have been completed during the past two years by the division of research statistics of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, according to Corwin Fergus, chief of the division.

Narrow and mixed price movements characterized extremely dull trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The turnover dwindled to $3,989,100, the smallest two-hour sales volume since Oct. 9, and compared with $4,884,500 on Saturday the week before.

ASTOR--The Hurricane: Jon Hall, Dorothy Lamour.* BELMONT--Love or a Kingdom, Polish film.* CAMEO--Der Purimspieler, Yiddish film.* CAPITOL--The Last Gangster: Edward G. Robinson ; Navy Blue and Gold: Florence Rice, James Stewart, opens Thursday. CENTRAL--Swing It, Sailor and Trigger Trio. CINEMA DE PARIS--Klart Till Drabbning, Swedish film. CRITERION--Mssing Witness: John Litel, Dick Purcell. 55TH ST. PLAYHOUSE-Life and Loves of Beethoven: Harry Baur.*
The board of the Walter Hines Page Chapter. D. A. R., gave a farewell luncheon Wednesday for Mrs. Amos Dean at the Dorchester Hotel, with Mrs. Theodore Luling serving as chairman.

National Conference of Yeshiva College, Hotel Astor, 10:30 A. M. Afternoon session, 2:30 P. M. Dinner at 7 P. M. "The Present Challenge to Democracy," Senator Alben W. Barkley. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Arts of China" (tour of collections), Mabel Harrison Duncan, 2 P. M.;

About four months have elapsed since Sigismund Levanevsky and his companions set out for the United States by air from Soviet Russia and laid their course over the North Pole. By this time most newspaper readers have given them up as lost. But not Sir Hubert Wilkins and the members of the Explorers Club of New York.
Detectives last night photographed the tire prints of an automobile that skidded at Park Avenue, between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Streets, on the northbound side.

A standard formula for counting rooms in apartment houses in the metropolitan district has been prepared by the Mortgage Conference of New York City with the object of standardizing methods used in making a room count for houses on which mortgage loan applications are under consideration.

Frank J. Marshall, captain of the champion United States chess team at Stockholm, and Isaac I. Kashdan, team member who carried off the special prize for the highest individual score, are defending their championships in the tournaments at the Marshall and Manhattan Clubs, respectively.

SMOKEMONT, N. C.-One of the broadest museum programs in the entire National Park system is now being developed, step by step, in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in Western North Carolina and East Tennessee. The tentative plan. of development includes two main museum 'buildings, a geological observation station, trailside and roadside exhibit structures, restoration of existing buildings, exhibits along proposed nature trails, and outdoor facilities for an educational program.

A parade of planes crossing the city's sky lanes and trailing peace banners is being organized by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom in observance of the thirty-fourth anniversary on Friday of the Kitty Hawk flight of the Wright brothers.

The West's squad for the New Year's Day charity East-West football game here was completed today. Percy Locey, chairman of the West's selection committee, announced the following players had accepted:

The National Labor Relations Board was defended today by its chairman, J. Warren Madden, on complaints that it violated the constitutional principle of "freedom of the press" when it subpoenaed Hartlay W. Barclay, editor of a trade magazine, in connection with the board's hearing on charges that the Weirton Steel Company had violated the Wagner Act.

Young people from many walks of life, from colleges to labor unions. joined last week in a formal statement to President Roosevelt's Advisory Committee on Education, recommending a permanent planning commission for education to bring schools, where necessary, up to certain minimum standards.

Pacific settlement of the boundary dispute between Honduras and Nicaragua was announced here today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull, after President Roosevelt had received a telegram from the mediation committee sitting at San Jose, Costa Rica, declaring that a satisfactory arrangement had been reached.

Recalling by contrast the hardships of the first women students at Cornell University because of the lack of living quarters on or near the campus in the early Seventies, two new sorority houses have arisen in the past few months, while others have been remodeled and redecorated, giving an air of permanency to the use of sorority houses as supplements to Cornell's extensive dormitory system.

Labor in the future should look to the further development of foreign trade, because the percentage of its income from that source is growing steadily, Neal Dow Becker, chairman of the foreign trade committee of the Merchants Association of New York, said here yesterday.

TEN years ago today-on Dec. 12, 1927-the Museum of Living Art first opened its doors to the public, at New York University. It still occupies the same galleries,although the exhibition space has been extended, on the ground floor of the main university building at 100 Washington Square East.

Protests from women's civic groups grew sharply articulate last week as extension of the merit system was threatened with a fresh set-back from the special session of Congress. Spurred to action by the recent favorable reporting of the McKellar bill by the Senate Committee, a concerted movement has been launched to prevent its passage.
WHEN Henry Clay Cannon of Pisgah, Carosippi, having achieved all the attainable political honors in his home territory, decided to run for Congress he had just one misgiving.
Belgrade awaits Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France with beflagged streets. Several national organizations have summoned their members to be at the station tomorwelcome.

El Salvador will select municipal officials for the entire company tomorrow for 1938-39, according to a call by the incumbent Mayors for free elections. The candidates will be announced the day of the election.

The stock market backed and filled throughout yesterday's twohour-trading period. Dullness was relieved only by activity and strength in the airplane issues. Trading on the' Stock Exchange amounted to but 389,000'shares, the smallest since Oct. 2, The closing was irregular.

PHILOSOPHIC traditions, like theories of science, have died. The difference is only that contemporary philosophers cannot agree on just which of the traditions are to be buried. There is at least one very reasonable way of determining this. We may call a philosophic work or tradition alive which, first,

TUCSON, Ariz.--The Winter migrations from the lands of snow and rain, fog and slush are getting under way. More thann 1,000,000 people from the East and North are expected to turn toward the Southwest for a "place in the sun."
MORLEY'S "A Plaine and Easie Introduction to Practicall Musicke" has been issued in facsimile in England by the Shakespeare Association and the Oxford University Press.

Captain Art Christian led the Cornell poloists to victory over the 112th Field Artillery, New Jersey National Guard, in their home debut tonight. The score was 25 1/2--12 1/2. Christian drove home twelve goals.

Tokyo began celebrating the fall of Nanking prematurely yesterday and is continuing today on a colossal scale. The announcement that the Japanese flag had been planted on the Southeastern gate was taken as the forerunner of complete occupation.

Two large estates in the Brookfield section of Fairfield County, Conn., were reported yesterday as having been sold to New Yorkers. One was the Bronson Homestead property at Brookfield, formerly owned by Mrs. Therese Brink, which was purchased for occupancy by Aaron Tuchmann of Manhattan.
BACK TO AIR: A few years ago the pastor of the Shrine of the Little Flower at Royal Oak, Mich., spoke regularly over the radio to an audience estimated at 30,000.

Despite orders of the Theatre Authority of New York, controlling group of the actors' unions, forbidding their members to participate in Chicago's "Night of Stars" Christmas benefit performance Wednesday night at the Chicago Stadium, the committee said that the show would be staged as scheduled.
As the setting sun dipped last Monday behind the Purple-Gold Mountains in the suburbs of Nanking, soldiers of Japan planted the flag of the Rising Sun in the compound of Dr.

FOR more than a third of a century. leading powers of the Western World have predicated their Far Eastern policies upon the assumption that the best guarantee of peace in the Orient lay in their mutually respecting China's territorial and administrative integrity.

An exhibition of fifty-six oil and tempera paintings, water-colors and pastel drawings of scenes in New York's parks and playgrounds since 1903 will be opened to the public today in the International Art Center, Riverside Drive at 103d Street. The pictures, which have been lent by forty-two artists as well as by six galleries, will be seen daily except Mondays through Jan. 2.

Back in the early days of the AAA, a group of cotton State Congressmen came to Secretary Wallace to ask his support of the first compulsory crop-control law. The plow-up campaign of the year before had convinced them that less cotton meant better prices.
More than 5,300,000 joined the annual roll call of the American Red Cross which ended Thanksgiving Day, Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman, said today.

In announcing the program for its Spring meeting, the English Setter Club of America is establishing a precedent for Eastern field trials for pointers and setters that similar organizations hereabout must eventually follow if they are to keep step with the development of the sport.

A plea for a new building on the West Side in which to continue the tradition of Wadleigh High School as an institution for "gentlewomen" was made yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor marking the close of a week's celebration of the school's fortieth anniversary.

Joseph P. Day announced yesterday that the five auction sales conducted during September, October and November to dispose of the realty holdings of several defunct national banks, chiefly in the metropolitan area, resulted in the disposal of 251 properties for an aggregate sum of $1,483,226.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Usher J. Schwartz of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lillian Gertrude Schwartz, to Martin D. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Cohen, also of Brooklyn.
WITH the death of Isaac Mendoza a few weeks ago the second-hand book trade lost one of its best-liked and most valued members.
It has been announced abroad that a dangerous plot had been formed against the French Republic and that, but for the timely intervention of the police, civil war might have broken out at any time.

Education for temperance, directed through channels undreamed of in the lifetime of Frances Willard, will, figuratively, be the monument which the Women's Christian Temperance Union will rear to the memory of Miss Willard on the centenary of her birth in 1939.

IN England to dine well and at leisure is, for better or for worse, part of the whole cere mony of playgoing. It is this, more than anything else, which has prevented so long a play as Eugene O'Neill's "Mourning Becomes Electra" from being produced here until this week.

A dinner dance will be-held Friday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a tribute to the memory of the late Miss Lila Agnew Stewart, who was widely esteemed in the social and artistic life of New York and many other cities.

A virtual unknown in the ranks of pugilism will attempt to batter his way to championship consideration tomorrow night when Harry Thomas of Eagle Bend, Minn., opposes Max Schmeling, former holder of the world title. The pair will meet in the Madison Square Garden ring in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds.

MUCH of the civilized world is deeply concerned with the housing problem. Here in the United States the President and the new United States Housing Authority have just launched a drive to stimulate building on a large scale.

The Manhattan College student branch of the Society for the Advancement of Management received the Trundle Trophy, given annually by George T. Trundle Jr., consulting engineer, of Cleveland, to "the most outstanding" student branch, at the third annual meeting of the college branches yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

Issues involved in a consumer boycott against Japanese goods will be discussed before an audience composed of representatives of women's groups at an all-day forum on "The Consumer and Peace" called for Saturday at 99 Park Avenue.

As if suddenly aware of the power they can wield through political equality with men resulting from recent victory in their long-fought suffrage campaign, women of the Philippines are responding enthusiastically to the idea of feminine participation in government.

Princeton University's School of Public and International Affairs will endeavor to pave the way for a compromise between two opposing academic theories, cultural generalization and practical specialization, next Wednesday evening with a symposium on education open to all undergraduates and faculty members.

In the historic building from, which the National Womans party directed its campaign for equal suffrage twenty years ago, the drive for the adoption of the Lucretia Mott Equal Rights Amendment will be launched during the biennial conference of the party in Washington this week.

The annual benefit performance for the Adirondack Sanatorium will be held on Tuesday evening at the Music Box Theatre, where contributors to the sanatorium vill witness the performance of "Of Mice and Men."

Invitations have been sent out for the first vacation dance of the Greenwich Country Club which will be held on Jan. 1 at the clubhouse for the young people of Greenwich and Rye, N. Y. On the committee for the dance are the Misses Macy Anne Reilly of Rye, Virginia Fraser, Barbara Brooks, Marie Abbett , Barbara Hogan, Mary Louise Klipstein, Deborah Wood and Leslie Lovejoy, all of Greenwich.

Preparation for the greatest of all professions, that of motherhood and child-training,is being given the students at Elmira College in the Nursery School which is Conducted as part of the Department of Euthenics.

SAN JUAN, P. R.-In undertaking to settle through diplomacydifferences between Haiti and the Dominican Republic, representatives of the United States, Cuba and Mexico have accepted the task of attempting to restore friendly relations between neighboring peoples whose clashes for more than a century have red to frequent bloodshed.

The Manhattan College debaters will renew an ancient rivalry on Dec. 20, when they meet the representatives of Fordham University to discuss the National Labor Relations Board. The contest will be broadcast over radio station WMCA at 1:30 P. M.
Restoration of the former Republican National Chinese Government in North China by the Japanese Army within a few days was forecast today by well-informed Chinese sources.

With taxable holdings of $6,055,080, Yale University has become the largest single tax payer in New Haven, it was announced today. The University displaced the United Illuminating Company which holds property assessed at $5,797,195.

Poland's internal situation leads to her desire for European peace. She has nothing to gain from war. She needs peace for internal improvements and for amelioration of the condition of her own people, most of whom are terribly poor.

A combined net operating income of $60-747,446 for October was reported to the Interstate Commerce Commission by 141 Class I railroads. This compares with $89,809,572 in October, 1936. For the first ten months of the year net was $530,770,020, against $524,292,106 in the same period last year.

Although cables from Tokyo report the Japanese Cabinet decision to refuse to negotiate with Chiang Kai-shek's regime, it is believed this is not an irrevocable attitude if the present Chinese Government wishes to make peace quickly.
A steady stream of gifts added $9,534.36 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday are brought the total amount received thus far this year to $84,916.90.

DIPLOMATS and their wives from more than fifty countries have been invited to eat cakes and drink fruit punch at the White House next Thursday night. The occasion is the annual White House reception to the diplomatic corps A month later, on Jan. 13, many are expected again for dinner.

After a slow start that caused them to trail by 7 points at one time in the first half, Brooklyn College's basketball forces rallied to tie the score, 18-18, at the half, and went on to gain a 41-35 victory over Manhattan College at the winner's gymnasium last night in a game that thrilled 1,200 spectators.

The Long Island University basketball team gained its third victory. in as many starts this season by routing the East Stroudsburg Teachers College quintet in the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy Gymnasium last night, 85 to 39.

Mrs. Asa Shiverick of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Shiverick, to John Manning Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Hall of Boston. The prospective bride, daughter of the late Mr. Shiverick, attended the Hathaway-Brown School in Cleveland, was graduated from Oldfield's School in Maryland and continued her studies at Miss Nixon's School in Florence.
Five out- of thirty-seven divisions of local department stores had gains in advertising linage during November, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records.

Figures in the Christmas festivities at New Jersey College for Women during the coming week will be Le Pere Noel and the Weihnachtsmann, traditional French and German counterparts of Santa Claus, when the foreign-language houses hold traditional celebrations of the Christmas season. Departmental language clubs will join resident students of the German,

Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals administered the oath of office yesterday to the six American Labor party members of the new City Council. The ceremony took place in the Aldermanic Chamber at City Hall in the presence of a large group of visitors, including high officials of the party.
Leopold Stokowski, completing his local term as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, returned to the stage ten times to take bows after tonight's concert at the Academy of Music.

Dorothy Mildred Bourek of Minneapolis, Minn., who was found unconscious Wednesday in her locked apartment, was sufficiently recovered today to offer an explanation for her injuries. She corroborated the story of Etienne Ekyan, an engineer, that she was hit by an automobile in a street in the Etoile district.
Stuents of Bryn Mawr College whose obby is social service work will be ostesses on Tuesday to underrivileged children at an annual Christmas party in the Common Room of the Goodhart Hall.

Wearing a veil of old family lace and a gown of cream-colored velvet embroidered in silver, Miss Louise Geer Wilcox was married yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension to William Richardson Knowlton of New York. The Rev. Dr. Donald Aldrlch, the rector, perfonrmed the nceremony.

It took an army of men to clear snow from football fields of England and Scotland today, but despite the efforts, five games in the English league and second-round cup play were either abandoned or canceled and eleven matches were postponed north of the Tweed.

Isador J. Gennett, Bronx news dealer and member of the Jewish War Veterans, came back from Europe yesterday still a bit excited by his adventure in Berlin, where he upset the official aplomb of Nazi military police by laying a nonAryan wreath on the shrine of the German war dead.
Long absent from these parts, the New York Americans will return to their home ice at Madison Square Garden tonight to tackle the surprising.Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League game.
Air traffic at Newark Airport is growing with such rapidity that by 1941 it probably will reach a stage beyond which further development would be dangerous, Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein predicted today.

President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Walter E. Treanor of Indiana to be a justice of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit Court, comprising Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin.
SCHIAPARELLI shows the shortest jacket in Paris; it is her newest invention. "The bust-length bolero," she calls it. She does it for all hours, and in many fabrics, not even excluding fur.
New health records were made in this city in November, according to the Department of Health. Fewer. deaths from all causes and fewer infant deaths were recorded than for any previous November.

Dr. Donald Thomson, research fellow of Melbourne University, who has spent fifteen months in Arnhemland living among the aborigines as a special patrol officer for the Commonwealth and will soon go to Cambridge on a Rockefeller Foundation fellowship, strongly condemns the selection of Groote Island, in the Gulf of Carpentaria, as a base for flying boats.

Fear among members of the Interstate Commerce Commission, aroused by President Roosevelt's plan for governmental reorganization which would divest them of their indepedent status and make them directly responsible to the Executive, appeared to have been increased today by the President's statement yesterday on the plight of the railroads.

The Auburn Automobile Company and its subsidiary, the Lycoming Manufacturing Company, today began reorganIzation proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act in the Federal District Court in Fort Wayne, Ind. Officials here announced the action.

RUMORS that had Louis B. Mayer on the verge of relinquishing the vice presidency of Metro-GoldwynMayer were set at rest the other day when Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's Incorporated, which controls Metro, announced that the production chief had signed a new five-year contract.

Led by Captain Willie Thomas, diminutive left forward, who tallied 10 points, a powerful Dartmouth basketball team won its fourth consecutive game before 1,500 spectators at the alumni gymnasium tonight, defeating St. Anselm's, 48-33.

Available factory space in Queens, L.I., is being disposed of rapidly, reports C. Grant Keck, Long Island City broker, who states that many industrial buildings have been leased recently and several others have been sold.

COME to France from the United States and France looks hard-working and very neat. Rich and orderly fields stretch back from Le Havre, the broad and busy Seine hurries its long canal boats down to the sea. Every detail in the landscape is occupied with its allotted task.

The commission comprising W. L. Payne, chairman of the Queensland Lands Administration, and J. W. Fletcher, Queensland grazier, which was requested by the Commonwealth government to submit a plan for the development of the Northern Territory, having traveled 10,000 miles and heard 150 witnesses, criticizes the Commonwealth's administration of the territory and holds the territory could have been better governed if divided between adjoining States.
SOME time in Februay the Metropolitan Opera Association will present in a oom pletely professional performance the latest aspirant to the illustrious ranks of Italian operatic heroines.

By capturing second and fifth positions in the 660-yard unlimitedweight relay race, the final event, the Public School 44 athletes of Brooklyn defeated their borough rivals, Public School 9, by one point to win the championship in the annual city P. S. A. L. elementary school indoor track and field games at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn yesterday.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday designated ten midtown streets between Third and Ninth Avenues where parking will be prohibited throughout the twenty-four hours of the day, except on Sundays.
Wilson College students will begin the Christmas recess next Thursday after a series of pre-vacation programs which include the production of Plautus's "Mostellaria" in the original Latin.

SOUTHER PINES, N. C.With the hotels and clubs of Southern Pines reporting good bookings for the Christmas holidays, the remainder of December will be marked by many color ful teas, dinners and dances.

The engagement of Miss Mary Virginia Whaley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James O. Whaley of Ten Hills, this city, to William Pennington Cleaver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester H. Cleaver of Asbury Park, N. J., has been announced by her parents.

Among the 815 patents granted this week the following stand out for their unusual turn: An lce bag, shaped and worn over the eyes- like a pair of goggles, to help get rid of "shiners" in a hurry. The bag comprises two doughnut-shaped "lenses"

The Municipal Art Commission has given its final approval to four of the completed murals executed under the WPA Federal Art Project, it was announced yesterday. The four in question, totaling approximately 2,500 square feet, are located at Morrisania, Riverside and Harlem Hospitals and Public School 164 in Brooklyn.
Undiscouraged by the failure of the conference of signatories to the Nine-Power treaty to bring a peaceful end to the Sino-Japanese conflict, Norman H. Davis,

Arthur N. Starin, Newark architect and vice president of the New Jersey Society of Architects, states that, following a recent study of changes in housing conditions in the United States, the principal causes of such changes are dlue to economic forces, new methods of transportation, government influences and the effect of developments in industry, mechanical invention and chemical research.

The continued success of Princeton University's all-inclusive intramural Athletic program was assured this Tall with nearly one-half of the undergraduate body of some 2,300 Participating informally in nine branches of sport, according to the ??all report of William F. Halsey 3d, 38, of Long Beach, Calif., president of the Intramural Athletic Associaion.

Congressional leaders said today that uncertainties created by the business recession would make it impossible for President Roosevelt to estimate next year's relief needs when he makes the annual budget forecasts in January.

Governor George D. Aiken of Vermont right now is surrounded by a battalion of bristling interrogation points. What sort of man is he? By what authority does he castigate the Republican National Committee? What are the motives behind his open letter to that group of party leaders?

Chicago's Austin High champions completed an undefeated and untied season today with a 13-0 intersectional football triumph over Jackson, Tenn., in a game marred by an injury to Wild Bill De Correvont, sensational Austin back.

In an attempt to clarify the provisions of Local Law No. 64 of 1936, which exempts aerations and improvements to property from local taxation, Jacob Rudd, an attorney specializing in real estate taxes and assessments, has prepared a detive tailed study of the statute. With a view to aiding property owners ing seeking exemption and officials of the Tax Department charged with

Formal dedication of City College House Plan Center at 292 Convent Avenue on Friday will mark the purchase of the center for student social activities and the culmination of three years of steady growth in membership and importance of extra-curricular activity.

For the second successive year Hale Jones of Wood River, Ill., has earned the crown as America's leading amateur trapshooter. Official averages for 1937, released today by Ray Loaring of the Amateur Trapshooting Association of America, reveal that Jones broke 1,783 out of 1,800 registered sixteen-yard targets this year. His average was .9905.
THE list of our literary prizes is steadily lengthening. latest addition consists of four gold medals, instituted by The Sunday Times in connection with the National Book Fair.

Mr. and Mrs. Joel Judson of 315 Central Park West, formerly of Woodmere, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Anne Judson, to Charles Hecht Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hecht of White Plains, N. Y., and Ridgefield, Conn.

Isamu Noguchi, one of America's greatest sculptors, was born thirtythree years ago in California, son of a Japanese father--the famous poet, Yone Noguchi--and an Irish mother His art ranges from pure abstraction to social propaganda (one of the latter works--far from his best artistically--is the metal figure of a lynched

DOUBLEDAY, DORAN CO. have received a portion of the original manuscript of "The Life of Christ," by the late Sir Hall Caine, and they plan to publish the book some time near Easter. Hall Caine's notebooks show that he contemplated writing this book as early as 1888, although his first public announcement of his intention was not made until 1892.

Pittsburgh's undefeated Panthers were ranked today as the nation's most powerful football array under the system originated by Dr. Frank G. Dickinson of the University of Illinois, with the Rose Bowl contestants, Alabama and California, rated fourth and seventh respectively.
Children of the kindergarten at the Silver Cross Day Nursery will be aided by the annual dinner dance under the auspices of the Junior Auxiliary of the nursery to be held on Jan. 21 at the Pierre.

THE revival of Gounod's "Romeo and Juliette" after an absence of three years from the repertoire, and the debuts of Zinka Milanov, Yugoslav dramatic soprano, and Nicola Moscona, Greek basso, are features of the third week of the Metropolitan Opera season.
Mrs. James Gordon Rowe Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lorena Brooks Rowe, to James A. Corroon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Corroon of Massapequa Manor, Massapequa, L. I.

Striking swiftly in the first period when they scored three goals, the New York Rangers went on to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-3, in a spotty National Hockey League game tonight before 11,500 fans. It was the Rangers' first visit of the season to Toronto.

To a divining rod is attributed an important discovery in the Netherlands. The municipality of Breda in North Brabant invited a woman water-diviner to find out if there were any underground waterways at Breda. She stated that there were several such waterways under the town and that they crossed below the Princes' Chapel in the northern part of the Great Church.

Architects of the United States Government are selecting a site for the new legation, which, according to reports, will be constructed soon. United States Minister Boaz Long occupies a frame shack very much like a garage and rain enters it on all sides.
Bloomfield High School's mighty football team demonstrated today that it is unquestionably entitled to the championship of New Jersey.
The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Bureau of Child Guidance, 46 Forsythe Street, New York City-15 children's paintings, 4 easel paintings, 8 graphic prints.
ROME.--The "Battle of Oil," which Italy began during the sanctionist period to make herself independent of foreign supplies of this indispensable raw material, is now in full swing.

HAMILXTON, Bermuda.--Once the Bermuda season was Just around Easter; later it grew to include early Spring, and even Summer; now it begins ust before Christmas, when the holiday cruise ships dock in Haxmilton.

The annual dance of the Sophomore Class of Connecticut College for Women was given tonight. There was a tea dance in the afternoon which all classes could attend. Tonight's formal event was open only to sophomores and seniors.

Analysis of the increase in industrial production costs in relation to general wage levels, payrolls and other price indices, and the index of the volume of building indicates that construction costs have not increased sufficiently to be of themselves the major factor that has delayed recovery in construction activity.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. - The Atlantic coast squash racquets championships for wo men on the Haddon Hall courts tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday top the sports attractions here during this week. Leading women players from all sections of the East will compete.

The new Federal housing program while primarily a socio-economic movement, will, if successful, prove a great boon to public education. It offers real hope for the solution of the all-important problem of school maladjustment and delin quency, which presents itself chief ly in the slum areas and arises oul of unsatisfactory home conditions unwholesome environment and lack of play space.

A New Year's Eve celebration of a new order is being arranged as a benefit for the Opportunity Shop. It is a Winter Sports Ball and it will take place in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in realistic mid-Winter settings.

Police Commissioner Valentine, his six deputy commissioners and many other high-ranking police officials were among 3,000 persons who attended the funeral yesterday morning for Patrolman Edward P. Lynch, who was shot and killed last Tuesday night by a flat burglar for whom the police are still searching.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday to losses of 3 to 51 points, but May ended the week at 8.1l cents, compared with T.94 cents on the previous Saturday.
The view that it would be to the best advantage of the fur industry to take inventory losses and start the new season off on a substantially lower price basis gained headway here last week.

From a hand-picked group of the country's leading college stars who will be eligible for professional play a year hence, the National Football League today chose 110 performers in its annual draft for the 1938 season.

Substantial, although unofficial, confirmation of repeated reports that Japan is building monster battleships larger than any now afloat is thought to be contained in an article recently published in an Italian paper, which is being studied here by government officials.

Truckloads of poinsettias have been rolling in from the greenhouses recently as florists everywhere prepare to lay up a store of the flaming red flower so widely associated with the Christmas season. Rivaled only by cacti gardens and the Christmas rose or Jerusalem cherry, the poinsettia is a botanical best seller during the holiday period.

Before leaving Paris for Rome last night, Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris, in a public lecture condemned States that "repress the essential rights of human personality," and proclaimed that the Catholic Church was in accord with liberal democracy.

The students of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel began rehearsing this week for the annual Carol Night, which will take place on Dec. 21, the last day before Christmas vacation. Beginning with a Christmas dinner in Preston Hall, the traditional ceremony celebrating the

WE suspected the recent mail truck robbery of being just a publicity build-up for "Wells-Fargo" (due soon at the Paramount) until we spoke last week with Frank Lloyd, its producer, who modestly denied the soft impeachment.

The second of a series of subscription tea dances known as the Gotham Dances will be held on Dec. 21 at Sherry's. The series was inaugurated last year to provide entertainment for girls who will be introduced to society during the next few years and young men home from preparatory schools and colleges for the holidays.

FRANCONIA, N. H.-The ski racks are in place now on the porches of Franconia's seven Winter sports hotels and already from Sugar Hill you can see the white line of snow on Richard Taft Trail curving down from Cannon Mountain. Innkeepers.

The "KellyNash machine," which next year enters a campaign to re-establish its control of Chicago, has been rudely jolted by the recent activity of Thomas J. Courtney, State's Attorney for Cook County.
Americans are likely to assume, when something is referred to as the largest and hughest, that they built it. It was somewhat of a blow, therefore, to discover Colonel Gen. Hermann

Professor Albert Einstein's theory of relativity, once denounced by National Socialist scholars as Jewish and un-German, appears to have been restored to grace in the Third Reich by virtue of a decree issued by Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, supervisor of spiritual and ideological training in the National Socialist party.

Mrs. Arthur B. Duel of Holmes, N. Y., has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Hobart Duel, to William A. S. Dollard, son of William G. Dollard of New York, and the late Mary Irene Dollard.

ASSAU, capital of the Bahamas, is a small town on a small island, and believes it can count more visitors per square mile than any town where tourists go. Right now it is getting ready for an international influx.

Standing on a Palazzo Venezia balcony under a heavy downpour and in the center of a circle of light formed by a score of searchlights, Premier Mussolini proclaimed tonight to cheering Black Shirts who filled the huge square below that Italy had decided to withdraw from the League of Nations.
Growing controversy over the course of American foreign policy has created a major upheaval in the ranks of scores of peace societies now flourishing in the United States.
IN the ten years since he produced "Schwanda" Jaromir Weinberger has never approached even remotely the success of that delectable "best-seller" which, to be sure, has failed to hold its ground.
ARCHIBALD RUTLEDGE, in An American Hunter (Stokes, $4), is not content in merely taking his readers along on his varied excursions after game.

Dr. Matilda Fischer Groth, who had practiced dentistry here with her husband, the late Dr. Charles F. Groth, for thirty-five years, died Thursday night at her residence, 3,436 North Thirteenth Street, after a long illness, at the age of 79.

A blind man gave the police a clue in a murder case today. Detective John McEnroe said Frank Reynolds, aged 69, formerly a circus performer but now blind, described how two men burst into his rooming house last night and shot a man identified through fingerprints as Samuel Goldstein.
Pilot Harold Gillam, Northland aerial Santa Claus, radioed tonight from Cape Halkett that his monoplane had crashed and asked Sir George Hubert Wilkins to come to his rescue.

IN this masterpiece of the literature that addresses public opinion literary qualities overshadow all others, great as these may be. In Borgese our country has gained possession of Italy's leading publicist and intellectual.

Mrs. Frances Nearing Read of 40-15 157th Street, Flushing, wife of Warren W. Read, chairman of the English Department of Flushing High School, died Friday afternoon of a heart attack on the platform of-the Seventy-fourth Street station of the I. R. T. in Elmhurst. Her age was 53.

KING GEORGE Vl has just completed the first year of his reign, having well begun his mission of restoring the prestige and popular esteem of the monarchy. which were impaired by the extraordinary events that brought him unexpectedly to the throne. It was an exacting task.

THE prospect of an annual "national bridge party" to benefit the control of infantile paralysis developed in a talk last week between Stephen Early, secretary to President Roosevelt, and William E. McKenney, executive secretary of the American Contract Bridge League.

Scattered liquidation by holders of December contracts unsettled the wheat market today on the Board of Trade and closing trades were at net losses of 1 to 1h cents a bushel, the near-by delivery leading the decline.

The total cost of all highway, road and street projects placed in operation by the Works Progress Administration as of last March is estimated to be $1,462,480,000, according to The Index, monthly publication of the New York Trust Company.

Wellesley students are deep in Christmas festivities. Yesterday afternoon the college Verse Speaking Choir chanted seasonal poetry in the Memorial Chapel. In the evening the Barnswallows gave a first performance of Katharine Clugston's "Finished," assisted by members of the Harvard Dramatic Association.

A recital will be given by LotteLehmann and Lauritz Melchior of the Metropolitan Opera on the night of Jan. 11 at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the educational department of the New York Women's Trade Union League.

In order to obtain facts on conditions in Harlem, on which to base its recommendations to the next Legislature, the New York State Temporary Commission on Urban Colored Population will hold public hearings next week, it was announced yesterday by Lester B. Granger, director of the ocmmission.

One Class C player remained in the running as the Fall B and C squash tennis tournament reached the quarter-final round yesterday at the City A. C. He was A. D. Weeks Jr. of the Harvard Club, last of the many players from the lower division to survive despite the 5 points a game they. get from the B players.

THIS book, of large quarto size, is the combined work of an outstanding artist and an outstanding poet. Edward Seago's paintings of the English rural scene hang in many a private gallery of note, and it is some twoscore of these paintings, excellently reproduced in color, which form the backbone of the book.

THE proprietor of a Hollywood scandal sheet is found dead in his little adobe shack not far from the film capital but in another county. He has been shot, and an effort has been made to make his death appear to be suicide, but you can't fool Deputy Sheriff Sam Brice.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothie E. Berry of this place to Ernest A. Knoblauch Jr., also of Summit, by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Berry of Sussex. N. B.
SUZANNE BLOCH, daughter of Ernst Bloch, given her first public solo recital in New York this Friday night at Steinway Hall.

Twelve performances of "The Secret Garden," by Frances Hodgson Burnett, will be presented in the near future by the Players of the New York Junior League in various hospitals and settlement houses in the city.

ERNEST GRAY, an English surgeon, has created an Ingenious and amuaing fictionalized reconstruction of two years in the life of an eighteenth-century surgeon. The material is presented in the form of a diary, which runs from September, 1751, to November. 1752.

MADISON, Wis. (Science Service).-If you would reduce fuel oil consumption in your home, give your attio a floor. Although the unfloored attic long has been condemned by domestic heating engineers as a source of great loss of heat, it was not until the United States Forest Products Laboratory here completed a fouryear study that factual information as to the magnitude of such loss became available.

The international commission that has been investigating the charges made against Leon Trotsky in the Moscow trials has completed its report, a document of 80,000 words, which it will present at a public meeting this evening at the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street.

The latest recession in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity was the smallest in two months. The figure has eased to 85.0 for the week ended Dee. 4, compared with 85.7 for the previous week and 105.1 for the corresponding week last year.
Four persons were killed and one critically injured today when a Baltimore Ohio passenger train struck an automobile at Flemington.

The Choral Club, Orchestral Society and Dramatic Club of Marymount College here will present Balfe's "Bohemian Girl" in the college auditorium next Sunday afternoon for the annual Christmas charity benefit, it was announced today.

The dollar improved slightly in a dull and irregular foreign exchange market yesterday. In the entire week the dollar showed a loss. The pound sterling yesterday fell 1/4 cent to $4.99 13/18, while the French franc was off s point to 3.39%s cents and the belga fell '4 point to 17 cents.
Mrs. Louise Blagden Lord today obtained a divorce from Franklin Butler Lord Jr. of New York on a charge of cruelty. Under an agreement she will receive $400 a month.

With the approval of Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn a school for bonafide labor union members is to be started next month at 1,150 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, with facilities provided by Brooklyn Prep School.

LET us get most of the tedious comparisons out of the way at once. Alphonse Legros, the one-hundredth anniversary of whose birth is now being celebrated with an exhibition of prints at the New York Public Library, was not a great artist in quite the sense that artists of his own period in France such as Daumier, Millet, Courbet and Ingres deserve to be considered great.

With the coming of Winter the hours of beneficial sunlight lessen, daylight is shorter and there is a corresponding marked effect on our house plants; for they no longer are able to get in a full day's growth.

" LOCUSTS loose in Nicaragua," flash the cables from Managua. "Las langostas! Las langostas!" cry the Central American planters, the peasant farmers. And first, no larger than a man's hand, appears the black cloud of the terrible visitants. Then like a hurricane they darken all the sky.

An illustration of mortgage investment stability over a long period of years is cited by Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the Nationral Association of Real Estate Boards, who calls attention to the fact that Connecticut has a State school fund which by law is required to be invested in first mortgages in Conneoticut real estate or stock in Connecticut banks.

TRAVEL, experts say that two million Americans will spend a billion dollars on Winter vacations this year, which shows how times have changed since the days when honest toil was the only approved Winter activity.

Current history, both here and abroad, touched off with burlesque and satire, moved with hilarious abandon across the stage tonight at the semi-annual dinner of the Gridiron Club at the Hotel Willard.
A new issue revolving about a justice of the peace hearing behind locked doors developed today in this town's controversy over the pro-Nazi camp in Kettletown.

Thousands of children in the elementary school grades, many of whom have "never been off the block," are now studying points of interest in all parts of the city through special trips conducted by the Board of Education.

A group of Bryn Mawr alumnae of this city is now arranging four old-fashioned skating parties on the Rockefeller Plaza rink to raise funds for the archaeological work of the college now being conducted at Tarsus.

It was disclosed today that Franz Havel, formerly of the French Foreign Legion and a wounded veteran of the International Brigade fighting for the Spanish Loyalists, had been arrested by the Czechoslovak police in Neustadl several days ago on suspicion of being involved in a plot to assassinate Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France during his Eastern European tour.
Police tonight sought the fate of a second American who, they feared, might have brought the number of victims of a mass murder syndicate to ten.

Adolphe Rothblatt, who four years ago was Republican-Fusion candidate for Assembly in the Sixth District of the Bronx, died on Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital after an illness of-five weeks. Mr. Rothblatt, who was 30 years old, was a graduate of City College and St. John's Law School.

Hamilton Jewett Smith, writer, lecturer and college professor, died early this morning at his home here from an accidental overdose of a hypnotic drug. He was forty-seven years old and had returned to his former home in Port Washington after a stay of two years in California.

A group of Bryn Mawr alumnae of this city is now arranging four old-fashioned skating parties on the Rockefeller Plaza rink to raise funds for the archaeological work of the college now being conducted at Tarsus.

Police tonight sought the fate of a second American who, they feared, might have brought the number of victims of a mass murder syndicate to ten.

Adolphe Rothblatt, who four years ago was Republican-Fusion candidate for Assembly in the Sixth District of the Bronx, died on Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital after an illness of-five weeks. Mr. Rothblatt, who was 30 years old, was a graduate of City College and St. John's Law School.

Hamilton Jewett Smith, writer, lecturer and college professor, died early this morning at his home here from an accidental overdose of a hypnotic drug. He was forty-seven years old and had returned to his former home in Port Washington after a stay of two years in California.

Modern sociologists who contend that the educational standards of children's literature should be raised and that fairy stories and the like should not be stressed too greatly in the elementary schools were disputed yesterday when a guest speaker at the Conference on Children's Literature upheld

The German Foreignn Office was officially informed by the Soviet Charge d'Affaires today that Konstantin Yureneff would not return to his post of Russian Ambassador. The formal notification volunteered no information whether Mr. Yureneff would be assigned to some other diplomatic post or continue in the government service in some other capacity.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS. To take effect 12 noon, Dec. 16: PATROLMEN - Charles E. Pechin,17th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 28, 1903. John A. Reilly, 28th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 27, 1902.

Hanns Kerrl, Minister for Church Affairs, issued a decree today delegating dictatorial authority over the Protestant church to his appointee, Dr. Friedrich Werner, a civil servant in charge of the Reich Church Chancellery.

It is learned that in some private and some not so private conversations with friends Dr. Hjalmar Schacht already has announced that he is determined to resign the Reichsbank presidency when his term-which was prolonged for one year onlyexpires next March.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Barker Bros. Corp.. pf. Carolina, Clinchfield Ohio Ry. Carriers General Corp. Paramount Pictures Corp.
Alexander Schmidt gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Cornelia Durant Robbins of Pittsfield, Mass., and Russ Van Vleck, whose engagement has been announced.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Haynes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Carlisle Haynes, to William Arnold Forstbauer of Centerport, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Forstbauer of Elmhurst, Queens, took place here today at the home of her parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Parker Holloway, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Plainfield.

Under the presidency of Finance Minister Arthur. Souza: Costa the Finance Secretaries of Brazil's coffee States met today to devise means to increase coffee exports by reducing the taxes imposed by these States on their coffees.

Christmas cheer for the blind will be augmented by the proceeds of a card party to be given on Tuesday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria by the Daughters of Ohio in New York, of which Mrs. Rudolph M. Binder is president.

The cocky Washington Redskins will battle the tough Chicago Bears for the national professional football championship at Wrigley Field tomorrow on a gridiron that probably will be frozen as hard as concrete.
Ed (Strangler) Lewis returned yesterday on the United States liner Washington after a tour around the world and announced that he would retire from the wrestling ring and live in Hollywood.

Production of minerals in Canada,- according fo reports from individual mines, maintained its high level in November, with some properties announcing new record outputs and few reporting reduced recovery.
Mr. and Mr. Robert A. Chambers gave a dinner last night in the Crystal Room at the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Dorothy Dyer Butler, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Butler.

Bellini's "Norma" received its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The presentation, a special one given for the benefit of the New York chapter of Hadassah, was attended by a capacity audience.

Henry H. Curran, recently appointed Deputy Mayor of the city, and Newbold W. Morris, newly elected President of the City Council, will be among the speakers at the Woman's Forum meeting at 11 A. M. Friday in the Hotel Roosevelt.

At this time of year, when New York City is more dependent on Florida than on any other State for fresh vegetables, last week's freezing weather in the extreme South seriously interfered with receipts.

Dr. Myre Joel Brooks, who conducted a sanitarium for tubercular patients in New Canaan for thirty. years and was Health Officer and Medical Examiner for nineteen years, died in Honolulu Friday at the age of 70. He went to Honolulu in 1935 to live, immediately after resigning his New Canaan post, but continued to operate a sanitarium at West Sand Lake, Albany.

The New York A. C. trio defeated the Optimists, 14 to 11, in a polo upset last night at Squadron A Armory. Winston Guest's team was weakened by the inability of Stewart Iglehart to play, but Major F. A. Vietor who took his place often showed flashes of brilliant polo.

Ralph Greenleaf will defend his world pocket billiard championship against Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., in a 1,500-point challenge match starting on Wednesday at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. The fifteen-times holder of the title and his youthful rival will play for a purse of $500, put up by the Sportsmen's Tournaments, Inc.
Administration leaders enlisted the aid today of the Democratic National Committee for President Roosevelt's proposals to scale down Federal highway expenditures as a budget balancing step.

DANCE INTERNATIONAL, the exposition of dancing and its related arts, which spreads fairly freely over the facilities of Rockefeller Center, begins its third week today with a gala performance at the Center Theatre, which, according to boxoffice reports on Wednesday, was virtually sold out then. The performance bears the title of "An Evening of Ballet," and will engage the services of three companies and three independent soloists

The downward trend in foreclosure sales in Manhattan continues. Steady improvement in the realty market, as represented by this branch of the industry, is indicated in the monthly report of the Real Estate Board of New York showing that "progressively lower totals in the number of forced sales have been registered in each month since the turn of the half-year."

Today A. W. A. -Illustrated lecture by Robert Edison Fulton Jr. on "One Man Caravan," 8:30 P. M. Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities (Women's Division)-Breakfast, Hotel Delmonico. Hortense M. Odlum. speaker.

For the first ten months of the present year plans were filed in Brooklyn for 2,735 buildings at an estimated cost of $32,310,600, according to Building Commissioner . Edwin H. Thatcher of that borough.
Miss Natalie Hope Negus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Pike Negus of Brookline, was married this afternoon to Justin Grant Sholes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Grant Sholes of Cleveland.
Official Albany, administering New York State's multiple affairs, has not spoken exclusively in basso profundo or resonant baritone for a nurpber of years.

A challenge to the "Frontier Thinkers" of education to develop concrete methods and techniques for fulfilling their demand that our schools "help build the new social order" was presented yesterday in the annual report of Dr. William F. Russell, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University.

From the University of California comes the news that the grant of $30,000 made personally to Professor E. O. Lawrence earlier in the month by the National Advisory Cancer Council of Washington, D. C., out of the first annual government appropriation of $750,000 for cancer research is to be used to increase the output of his new would cylcotron.

For the first ten months of the present year plans were filed in Brooklyn for 2,735 buildings at an estimated cost of $32,310,600, according to Building Commissioner . Edwin H. Thatcher of that borough.
Miss Natalie Hope Negus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Pike Negus of Brookline, was married this afternoon to Justin Grant Sholes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Grant Sholes of Cleveland.

Greater promise of prosperity and a more stable economic future than Puerto Rico has known hitherto is forecast in the annual report of Governor Blanton Winship to the Secretary of the Interior in which he reviews the fiscal year ended last June.

BERGER--Mr. and Mrs. Irving F., announce birth of a son, Dec. 4, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. CHAMY--Mr. and Mrs. George announce birth of a daughter, Dec. 3, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. CLARK--Mr. and Mrs. Wallis (nee Kats Byron) announce the birth of a son on Dec. 4 at 4,671 Encino Ave., Van Nuys, Calif.

The fifteen-story apartment building on the southwest corner Of Ninetieth Street and West End Avenue has been altered by converting the original ten-room suites, which occupied the upper fourteen floors, into apartments of four and onehalf and five rooms.

IT is evident that under Mayor La Guardia and his commissioners major attacks are to be made promptly on the ils of choked automobile traffic in the heart of New York and its approaches through the outlying boroughs.
If the clear, cold weather continues-and that is the Weather Bureau's forecast-the outdoor iceskating season on the public rinks operated by the City Department of Parks will begin today.

Sir Frederick Maze, Inspector General of Chinese Maritime Customs, has reorganized the Shanghai customs staff to include twenty additional Japanese employes. The Japanese will be transferred from other Chinese ports.
To the Radio Editor: Allow me heartily to endorse the suggestion of a Boston listener to the effect that the broadcasting companies give us something besides dance music after 11 P. M.

Almost every day we get word of the discovery of some new fishing ground where the "real big fellows" fight to get at the bait. Usually this ground is adjacent to either a Winter resort or a visiting point on a Winter cruise. The competition between fishing ports these days really something fierce.

ALONG about the time each year when thoughts turn to Christmas shopping the Stage Relief Fund quietly celebrates a birthday. If any one were to bake a cake for the occasion, five candles would be needed this year because it was on Dec. 13, 1932, that the organization came into the world.

E. Clifford Potter of 340 Park Avenue, a real estate operator in New York for many years, who led in the modern development of Park Avenue between Fiftieth and Fiftyninth Streets, died yesterday after a short illness at the ranch of -his son, Dickson Bayard Potter, in Tucson, Ariz. He was 74 years old.
OUR friendly editors, your impresarios and their agents tell us that we, who come from beyond the rivers and mountains, have something to say about New York to New York if we say it in our own way.
Many signs point to an impending collapse of the American Federation of Labor-Committee for Industrial Organization peace negotiations which began late in October.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Irvin- of this city and Rye, N. Y., gave a dinrier dance'last night in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Mrs. CZlarence A. Chandler of Pinehurst, N. C. The guests were seated at long tables decorated with roses, African daisies and white sweet nnps.

The annual entertainment, known as the New Year's Eve Fun and Frolic, arranged by Mrs. Julius S. Walsh for the benefit of the crippled children in the Bellevue, Willard Parker and Orthopedic Hospitals will take place Dec. 31 in the Silver Room of the Ambassador.

IT is a topic that usually waits for the turn of the year, but down Gramercy Park way they The Players-are already talking about it: the Spring revival that was perennial until it was omitted last season. But this time it will be something extra, for 1938 will mark the fiftieth anniversary of that distinguished club, and accordingly the next festival will need some extra pondering. A general meeting will take the preliminary steps tomorrow.

Miss Doris I. Byrne, Executive Deputy Secretary of State, was the guest of honor at a dinner-dance given last night at the Hotel Roosevelt by the Women's Bronx Bar Association. About 500 persons attended.

Striking coal trimmers returned to their jobs yesterday without the Signed agreement for which they went on strike a week ago. William Morrissey, president of the Coal Trimmers Association, an affiliate of the C. I. O. Inland Boatmen's Union, said the men had been instructed to return pending an election to determine the collective bargaining representative for the group.

The final garden operation of the year (and a very important one, too) is the safeguarding of tender plants against the Winter. A simple mulching may be insufficient with the shrubs; other measures may have to be taken to bring some of bur most valued plants through the frosts and high winds unscathed.
THE toll road, regarded in this era as a part of the romantic past along with post chaises, highwaymen on horseback and the Pickwick Club, may provide a cure for some modern traffic problems.
Members of the New York-New Jersey Chapter of the Maryland College Alumnae Association will hold their annual supper dance Dec. 28 at the Commodore.

Although credit executives are attempting to be as lenient and patient as possible in the face of a sharp slowing down in collections, business failures are increasing at a rate where they are now running about 200 a month higher than in the earlier part of the year, according to reports here yesterday.

John V. Mara, president of the New York Football Giants- crept quietly into his office last Monday behind along black beard that was supposed to disguise him effectively from elevator boys, doormen, clerks and the like who were ready to pounce on him with the question: "What happened to the Giants against the Redskins yesterday?"

Eugene McQuillin, former circuit judge and municipal law authority, died yesterday at the age of 76. Judge McQuillin, who sat on the circuit court bench from 1909 to 1915, was born in Lee County, Iowa, Dec. 14, 1860.

LONDON.-A "New Deal" for India, which, at the insistence of M. K. Gandhi, includes a campaign for the complete prohibition of alcoholic beverages, as well as the right of collective bargaining for labor and improved conditions of land tenancy for peasants, has been inaugurated by the Congress party in the six provinces it now governs.

Mrs. Callie Hunderhill Harris of this city, wife of William B. Harris, vice president of the Fairfax Advertising Agency in New York, died today at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N. J., after a threemonth illness.

At St. Romford dog racing stadium tonight, Helen, a full-grown cheetah, fierce - looking descendant of Pharoah's giant hunting cats, was set to race against two greyhounds and established the claim of her species to be the fastest animals in the world.

THOMAS NAST, greatest of American cartoonists, foe of Tammany, and creator of the symbols which identify our major parties-the Democratic donkey and the Republican elephant--died thirtyfive years ago last Tuesday.

Wide-scale evacuation of Soviet Russian districts adjoining Estonia is now progressing at accelerated speed. This week demolition of houses in Koboljosk, a village near the Estonian frontier, was begun. The material was transported to inner Russia.

DANIEL FROHMAN' wrote of his own long career as a theatre manager in "Daniel Frohman Presents." Now, like a lanky Orlando, he moves through the theatre, at home in any century but preferring the distant past.

Harvard's recent "boom" in the social sciences, over which college officials confess they are worried, is continuing apace with more than 39 per cent of the upperclassmen majoring in history, government or economics.
AHYMN about the Creation, written 3,400 years before Haydn's oratorio, is discussed in Canon Galpin's new book, "The Music of the Sumerians," published by the Cambridge University Press.

Fordham's basketball team met a surprisingly strong University of Newark five on Rose Hill last night, but Captain Dick Davis and Bobby Hassmiller led a second-half rally that gave the Maroon its third straight victory of the season, 21-11.

Police of the Bathgate Avenue station in the Bronx last night were looking for a new "meanest thief." He worked a confidence game on Charles Grandel, 12 years old, of 4,058 Third Avenue, the Bronx, who shines shoes, and robbed him of his receipts yesterday afternoon--a total of four nickels.

The Rev. Dr. Charles Albert Padrick, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church of Maspeth, Queens, died of pneumonia Friday night in Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, after a week's illness. He was 44 years old.
An autopsy performed on the body of John A. Olsen, auditor, who was found dead last Friday, disclosed yesterday that he had, died from a spontaneous cerebral hemorrhage.

Colonel Fidel Segundo, one of three high Philippine Army officers rescued yesterday from an island where their plane had been forced down in a typhoon, was injured seriously today when struck in the right eye by a polo ball. Physicians said he might lose the sight of the eye.

NEW YORK'S first mobile television van will roll into Radio City today, and will be presented to engineers of the National Broadcasting Company who plan to roam the metropolitan area for television pick-ups. By short-wave they hope to relay sports events, parades and other outdoor scenes to the main image transmitter atop the Empire State Building.

Tours into the Middle West and the. metropolitan area are scheduled for the Holy Cross debating team this season. The list includes Columbia, Feb. 19; St. Peter's College at Jersey City, Feb. 20; Manhattan College,

Applications for home relief, the most sensitive barometer of industrial conditions known to welfare officials in this city, have more than doubled in the last three months, according to statistics made public yesterday by the Emergency Relief Bureau.

When the United States Steel Corporation needs the right man for a big job, it reaches out and hires him, wherever he may be. Thus it was that when the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation was set up on Oct. 1, 1935, by combining various United States Steel

AGNES REPPTIER: did not learn to read until she was 10 years old; and the first book she read was Hayward's translation of "Faust." But this was not because modern educational ideas were regnant in Philadelphia seventy years ago.
