Urgent diplomatic representations were made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today to Alexander Troyanovsky, the Russian Ambassador, on behalf of Donald L. Robinson, New York writer, and his wife, who have been missing for several days in Moscow.

ARION, N. C.--Gatherers of galax leaves are braving the early morning fogs and wintry winds of the mountains of Southern Appalachia to garner their yearly harvest of this material for holiday decorations.

Two trustees and a water commissioner will be elected and two propositions will be decided when the annual Ossining election is held on Tuesday between noon and 8 P. M. The other twenty-three villages in Westchester County have elections in the Spring.

Dartmouth's fraternities, in an effort to prove their value to the college, will start a twenty-one-point program during the current year which contains several new features. For the first time, a Job Hunters School will be conducted informally, with experts giving advice to fraternity men on what to look for in a job, how to get what they are looking for, and what chances there are in the various vocational fields.
Announcement has been made by Mrs. Lewis Daniel Gilbert of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean Gilbert, to Roger William Moister Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Moister of Summit, N. J.

Return of Father Charles E. Coughlin to the radio about Jan. 9 has raised considerable discussion as to whether or not there has been a change in attitude of church officials to the militant radio priest.
The fluent, colorful playing put forth by Guiomar Novaes, Brazilian pianist, at her recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon, was rapturously received by the host of her admirers present.

Mayor La Guardia will appoint Kenneth F. Dayton, acting budget director, to the post of director, according to an announcement made at City Hall yesterday while the Mayor was absent in Washington. The appointment will be made Wednesday, at which time Lester B. Stone, secretary to the Mayor, will be named to succeed Mr. Dayton as assistant budget director.

The deadline for Christmas passengers and mail to foreign countries is at hand. With the departure from here of two liners on Tuesday and three on Wednesday the--annual rush of Christmas visitors and Christmas mails to other shores will come to a close.

Mrs. George Waller Blow heads the executive committee in charge of the sale of seats for the performance of "Barchester Towers," with Ina Claire in the leading role, on Tuesday night at the Martin Beck Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for Metropolitan Junior Achievement, Inc. A supper party with dancing at the Larue Restaurant will follow the performance.

THE organized trucking industry of America, as demonstrated at the sessions of the fourth annual convention of the American Trucking Association, held recently at Louisville, Ky.; has set for itself a very active

ADD to the contingent of Yale graduates who have made news in the theatre the name of Harold J. Rome, who received the accolade for his songs and lyrics in "Pins and Needles," the I. L. G. W. U.-sponsored musical revue at Labor Stage.

TIME was when every old lady had to wear lavender and the old lace and loom as a stalag mite of sweetness upon the dramatic scene. Then along came certain acidulous suggestions that some of the old parties were addieted to shapeless sweaters, knew how to smoke and drink and carry
Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, provost of Columbia - University, and Joseph. H. Appel, chairman of the board .of John Wanamaker's, New York, have been elected trustees of Franklin and Marshall College.

Dr. John C. S. Pitta, dean of the Portuguese physicians in New Bedford, died today at the age of 77. He was honored a year ago at a testimonial dinner given by the Portuguese - American Colony of Bristol County.

BLOOMFIELD-FEDERMAN-Mr. Morris Federman of 123 West 74th announces the marriage of his daughter, Kathryn, to Mr. Gerard M. Bloomfield, son of Mrs. Johanna Bloomfield of 1,162 Grant Ave., to take place on Dec. 19. Reception 3 to 5 at Waldorf-Astoria.
Mrs. Marion H. Britt has been appointed legislative representative of the National Federation of Buxiness and Professional Women's Clubs.
MR. WOOLLCOTTS bypaths in the minor realms of gold, with their After words, anecdotes and sponsorship from the theatre world, make another very good Christmas book.

Publication this season, almost simultaneously, of revised and amplified editions of two well-known books of quotations is testimony to the reading public's demand for such collections. Mr. Burton Stevenson gives us the third edition of his own "Home Book of Quotations, Classical and Modern";

Winter has set in in Alberta, a Province where Winter can mean howling blizzards. There will be a little extra menace in its blasts and a little added bleakness in its prospects for one citizen of Alberta-the Bible class teacher, radio broadcaster and exhigh school principal who heads its government, the only Social Credit government in the world.

James Robert Cray, Uniontown attorney, banker and coal man, died today in the West Penn Hospital. He was 77 years old. Mr. Cray pioneered in the development of the coal and coke industries in Fayette and Greene Counties and was interested in several large banks, including the National Bank of Fayette County, of which he was president.

FOUR ship lines make regular stops at Jamaica, and now eight additional vessels will include this island in their cruise itineraries for the 1937-38 season. All told, more than forty vessels will here disembark visitors, some for a day, some for a month or more.

An aggressive Boston University hockey team swirled into the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink today, and, after seventy minutes of grueling play, including a ten-minute overtime period, emerged with a splendidly wrought 5-4 triumph at the expense of the hitherto undefeated Princeton sextet.

With Christmas not two weeks off, shoppers are scurrying through the stores looking for holiday decorations with which to dress up their dwelling places for the festal day. The shops are lavishly supplied with decorative items.
COMMONA NEUROSES OF CHILDREN AND ADULTS. By O. 8. English and G. H. L. Pearson. 315 pp. New York: W. W. Norton Co. $3.50.

A series of teas and receptions have been given during the last month to evoke an even keener interest in and to complete the many arrangements incident to the benefit matinee performance on Jan. 14 at the Metropolitan Opera House of "Die Meistersinger."

Dr. Esther Blair, former Professor of Hygiene at the Margaret Morrison College in Pittsburgh, where she practiced medicine for many years, died here today in the Orange Memorial Hospital, after a three weeks' illness at the age of 75.

In trying to estimate the effect of the present business recession upon real estate conditions, many perplexing factors are presented, states William J. Demorest, first vice president of Wm. A. White Sons. "One interesting fact in the situatioh," declares Mr. Demorest, "s that real estate prices have not had
George V. McPherson, Brooklyn builder, has just completed a sixstory apartment building on the site of the old Hamilton Club at the southwest corner of Clinton and Remsen Streets. Brooklyn.

More than 500 persons, mostly women who wore cotton, lisle or rayon stockings, participated yesterday in an "anti-silk parade" under the auspices of the Boycott Committee of the American Friends of the Chinese People.
WORLD-CRUISE travelers the hardy perennial variety-need no longer stifle a yawn when their shipsshove off for ports both east and west of Suez, for today's travel map is being redrawn.
ZEUS with his thunderbolts hurling down from lofty Olympus and Aeolus with his winds howling furiously out of the frozen north had nothing on James Basevi, who makes the elements rage for Hollywood.
The fourth annual concert by students of the High School of Music and Art, Convent Avenue and 135th Street, will take place Friday evening in the school auditorium.

NOT many mlles distant from the recently explored Shiva Temple and the "Islands in the Sky" in Arizona is a formation as strange and as beautiful as any other in a land where natural wonders abound--a "Peninsula in the Sky."

THIS massive and weighty volume is of a kind to give even the hardiest reviewer pause. The survey which it embodies begins with the remote past of man's animal heritage, comes down to the present moment, and parts the veil of the future for a look at the next world war.

NOT many mlles distant from the recently explored Shiva Temple and the "Islands in the Sky" in Arizona is a formation as strange and as beautiful as any other in a land where natural wonders abound--a "Peninsula in the Sky."

THIS massive and weighty volume is of a kind to give even the hardiest reviewer pause. The survey which it embodies begins with the remote past of man's animal heritage, comes down to the present moment, and parts the veil of the future for a look at the next world war.

A witness who turned detective after observing a hold-up received credit from the police last night for the arrest of a young man accused of beating and robbing Jacob Herzog, 52 years old, proprietor of a candy store at 432 Seventh Avenue, between Fourteenth and Fifteenth Streets, Brooklyn.

Aldous Huxley has just completed his second inspection tour of the United States. The thing that struck him most about the country, he said in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Sulgrave, was its hopefulness.

The British year book of the air, Jane's All the World's Aircraft, affirms the fact that our leadership in military aircraft, and especially in commercial aircraft, still exists. The expansion of services and improvement of equipment in the civil field can only bring amazement to those who stop to realize the rapidity which has marked this progress.

Eight natives working in a Rand mine 4,000 feet underground were killed today by a bolt of lightning which struck a wire on the surface of the ground and detonated dynamite they were laying for a blast.

The marriage of Miss Marian Greenlee, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Stebbins Greenlee of this city and the late Mr. Greenlee, to Detmar H. Finke, son of Mrs. Detmar Heinrich Finke of New York and the late Mr. Finke of Bremen, Germany, will take place here on Dec. 31 in the Chapel of St. James's Episcopal Church.
Three armed bandits took $1,343 from the safe and $70 from employes of the Big Ben Market at 133-05 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park, early yesterday morning.

Japan's imports from the United States were 65.3 per cent greater during the first ten months of 1937 than for the same period in 1936, figures 'of the Commerce Ministry showed today. Japanese exports to America rose 20.6 per cent.

Sales by emigres are reported here to have been the main factor in the decline of stocks early this week. Unfavorable opinion was aroused by the Reichsbank's intensified campaign to compel the holders of foreigncurrency stocks and bonds to sell them to it.
The five-story apartment house at 330 to 334 East Houston Street, reconstructed recently by the Dry Dock Savings Institution, has been purchased by Loomis J. Grossman.
Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., today shot a 70, his third sub-par round, to lead the field with 209 at the fifty-fourth-hole mark in the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open golf tournament.
Anxious to finish his book on the peace treaties and unable to get the work done in London, David Lloyd George arrived today for that purpose at the Hotel Can Antibes.

An unfilled demand for more than 2,000,000 dwelling units, all of which are needed for families paying $30 or less in monthly rent, has developed in this country since 1930, according to a national survey of housing needs and residential construction made by the National Housing Committee.

Lawrence H. Clark, a 21-year-old senior at the university here, was killed this morning by smoke from a fire which apparently originated in an upholstered chair in his dormitory room at 44 Mitchell Hall.

Nothing could more clearly illustrate the irresponsibility of the present leadership in Congress than its plans for going ahead with the Federal WageHour Bill. It may be doubted whether a proposed law of greater economic importance to the country has ever been considered.

Two members of the household and a fireman were injured during a fire early yesterday morning at 7-06 122d Street, College Point, Queens. Howard Carr, 33 years old, and his son Lawrence, 16, received second-degree burns. Mrs.

In a bitter battle that abounded with penalties as well as goals, the New York Americans fought the Canadiens of Montreal to a 4-to-4 tie at Madison Square Garden last night. The rivals tore at each other from first bell to last and thrilled a crowd of 15,000 persons with their stirring performances, but they had to be content with the deadlock when the overtime session came to a close.

Not even a group of architects and engineers can agree on any one "best" view that will show New York City's beauty most typically, the Merchants Association has learned. The association, which is celebrating its fortieth anniverBary, is carrying on a program intended to "reveal New York to New Yorkers."
A bronze tablet honoring Dr. Edgar Starr Barney for his half-century of service to the Hebrew Technical Institute will be presented to the institute Tuesday at 8 P. M. by the Alumni Association.
Something further i being done toward the re-awakening of the experimental theatre with the founding of the Play Room Club which acted Jean Cocteau's "The Infernal Machine" last evening.

urged to "purge" its leadership of 'such "Old Guard" members as Herbert Hoover, Alf M. Landon and John D. M. Hamilton, in a statement made here today by Robert W. Johnson, president of Johnson ,Johnson, surgical supply manufacturers, who has been active in New Jersey politics as an independent Republican.
Miss Susan Stewart Miles, a member of an old Philadelphia family who had been living in New York since 1915, died yesterday of a heart attack at her home, 45 East Sixtysixth Street, at the age of 87.
Steel production in the United States has attracted world-wide attention by its unprecedented decline in the last four months.
The end of both the world's undeclared wars may be in sight, it is believed here, although the termination of major military operations in Spain and in China may mean merely a calm between storms.

The New English Singers, headed by Mr. Cuthbert Kelly, returned to this city yesterday afternoon and appeared in Town Hall. Again they gave manifest pleasure by the poetical feeling, and diction, and sensibility of their performance.
Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,348,099,500.

Mrs. Theodore Kiendl and her debutante daughter, Miss Helen Vaughan Kiendl, will give a luncheon in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador on Dec. 22 for Miss Virginia Bacon Penfield, daughter of Mrs. Eugene Ong.
The interAmerican radio conference last night began its final plenary session which will terminate more than six weeks of negotiations on radio communications throughout the Americas.
Prices of cotton advanced moderately last week following slight declines in the previous week. On the New York Cott?? Exchange active future deliveries made net gains of 12 to 17 points.

The story of the career of District Attorney-Elect Thomas E. Dewey, about to be shown in the films, threatens to assume the proportions of a cycle. RKO has purchased a series of articles by Forrest Davis, "Smashing the Rackets," which will be welded into a photoplay in January by Davis, and it is probable that Preston Foster will play the lead.

Captain Colon Elay Alfaro, Ecuadorian Ambassador to the United States, left here by plane today, returning to Washington after a visit to Ecuador. While at Quito Captain Alfaro conferred with the Council and the Foreign Office, according to the press of that city, and reported progress in the boundary negotiations with Peru.

Congressional leaders plan to make a determined effort to send to conference this week two of the four measures for which the special session was called, the Farm Bill voted by the House last week and the Wages and Hours measure, which has long been tied up in the House Rules Committee.
Japanese bombs sank the United States gunboat Panay in the Yangtze River twenty-five miles above Nanking yesterday.

Outdoor business lines are inactive now, because of the setting in of Winter weather, and general manufacturing also is quiet. Retail stores are unable to supply bed linen, some kinds of hardware and woolen articles of common use.

Holly-decorated signs appealing to the Christmas mood of motorists were set up throughout a seventyblock area in mid-town Manhattan yesterday to warn that parking would be banned in ten cross-town streets beginning Jan. 3.

Merck Co., Inc., chemical manufacturers, will put into effect on Jan. 1 a retirement income plan for its 1,500 employes, combining the insurance benefits of the Federal Social Security Act with a form of participation in the profits of the company.

With Rhodes scholarships becoming more attractive than ever before, nearly 600 candidates for election as this year's scholars will face their first hurdles this week when they appear before the State committees of selection.

The fact that "man is a judging creature" makes him unnatural and unethical when his birth quality of self-judgment is lacking from his principles, said the Rev. Dr. J. Valdemar Moldenhawer, the pastor, in his sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street.

Miss Leahbelle Coykendall of this city has chosen Dec. 29 as the date for her marriage to Russell Milton Grandahl of Windsor. The ceremony will take place in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr.

Peace between labor and capital to cope with a serious business recession was urged today by Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, as the keynote for the three-day National Steel Workers congress, opening Tuesday.

Contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund fell off yesterday to $3,135, the smallest total that has been received on any day since the twenty-sixth annual appeal for the Fund was launched in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 5.

Plans for revision of the army's organization on the basis of a smaller and more mobile infantry division are being made at the War Department even in advance of formal reports on the field tests of the proposed division conducted in Texas recently.

The Christian Church should present itself less as a tradition and more as a movement, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

It is too late to hope for any basic reconsideration of the principles on which the Farm Bill is based. But it is not too late to hope that at least some limit may be placed on the Government's possible losses under that bill.

NOW and again authors will inquire of a book review department why their works have not received notice and appraisal. Some authors write letters, others telephone, still others make embarrassing personal visits. In most cases this solicitude doesn't help a great deal.

That last year's snow drought has in no way diminished the enthusiasm of metropolitan skiers was clearly demonstrated last week when the second annual North American Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet attracted a record throng for its nine performances.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Zack Phelps of Wilmington, Del., formerly of this city, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Kaye Phelps, to Robert R. M. Carpenter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. M. Carpenter of Wilmington.

A machine-gun company of National Guardsmen fired tear-gas shells today to subdue six convicts who stabbed a prison guard captain to death and barricaded themselves in the captain's office in a desperate attempt to escape from the State penitentiary.

The estate of Mrs. Anna Sheldon Camp Sneath, widow of Professor E. Hershey Sneath of Yale University, is valued at $750,362, according to a report filed in the Probate Court by the Second National Bank, executor.

Miss Frances Wood Metcalf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Metcalf of Newark, was married to William Edward Barr of Rochester, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Barr, last evening in the Park Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Herman L. Brockway of Ithaca, uncle of the bride, who was assisted by the Rev. Willis Sanderson, the pastor.

A "searchlight of black light" has reached out billions of miles into the depths of space and revealed to the gaze of man millions of new stars in the center of our galactic system, as well as some new globular clusters of stars so deeply imbedded in distant cosmic haze that they left no trace on ordinary photographs.

The teachings of the Bible provide the one sure way, Secretary Hull said today, to the spiritual rebirth of which humanity is in desperate need. He spoke on the present value of the Bible in a talk broadcast over the Columbia System as

Corn was the market leader on the Board of Trade here last week. An aggressive foreign demand and a marked let-up in the movement of cash grain to terminal markets lifted prices to the highest level in almost a month.
Slight signs of improvement in the steel market apparent a week ago have been multiplied, and a distinct change in sentiment has taken place, according to the magazine Steel.

Daniel Frohman, 86-year-old dean of American theatrical producers, left his bed yesterday, making his first public appearance since he was injured in a fall a month ago, to attend the unveiling of a bas-relief of him in the Episcopal Actors Guild Hall at the "Little Church Around the Corner," 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

Although Supreme Court Justice Sydney Syme denied last week an application by wealthy residents of Harrison for an injunction to restrain the Westchester Joint Water Works from erecting a water tower not far from the estate of Mrs. Henry Wallerstein, her attorneys, Ralph Becker and Benjamin Taylor, announced today that they would carry the fight to the Court of Appeals.
J. C. (Rube) Benton, one-time major league baseball pitcher, died here from injuries he received in an automobile accident near Ozark last night.
The first skating of the season on lakes and ponds of the North Shore brought out large. crowds today and parking spaces were at a premium in some localities.

Verdi's "Otello" will be revived at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday evening, Dec. 22, after an absence of twenty-four years. In the major roles will be Giovanni Martinelli as the Moor, Lawrence Tibbett as Iago and Eide Norena as Desdemona.

Stocks declined in the first half of this week and touched the lowest levels since March. Later the market was influenced favorably by the news that the Reich's proposed property-tax assessment would be postponed one year and that impounded loan and stock dividends would be refunded to shareholders in the form of taxcredit certificates.

The Robin Line announced yesterday a schedule of increased rates on certain cargoes for South Africa, effective for the first half of 1938. The commodities listed include radios, increased from $7.50 to $14 ton, and refrigerators, ranges, stoves and washing machines, with similar increases.

The Bourse was quiet this week, and the volume of transactions was small in view of the hesitant trend. International securities were relatively firmer than French issues, under the influence of reports from Wall Street and other foreign centers.
The exhibition 'pace, quickened, no doubt, by an already apparent holiday spirit, continues to keep art gallery visitors on the jump.

The Very Rev. John G. Delaney, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral here, led about 5,000 parishioners today in recitation of the "Te Deum" in celebration of the appointment by Pope Pius XI of Bishop Thomas J. Walsh as Archbishop of the new province of New Jersey.

Labor should have a greater share of the profits of production, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University, Washington, D. C., said yesterday in outlining a plan for a system of unionism based on the papal encyclicals.

Impelled by daily pleas from China for aid to war sufferers, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America sent out-yesterday a second call to 125,000 pastors in behalf of the united Christmas appeal for offerings.

Embarkation of the stranded passengers of the Dollar liner President Hoover began at tiny Hoishoto Island today with the arrival of her sister liner, the President McKinley. The latter had been hurriedly dispatched to the rescue from Hong Kong.

Mrs. Clara M. Brown of 33 Warren Street, widow of George W. Brown, died last night in St. Elizabeth's Hospital, Elizabeth, after a short illness, at the age of 74. A son of her first marriage, Austin F. J. Newman of Roselle Park, survives.
John Dodenhoff, 20 years old, of 24. Hubert Place, this city, was killed today as a result of a headon collision of two automobiles on Division Street.

The present-day Christian should live neither in the past nor the future, but in the present, said Professor Henry P. Van Dusen, dean of students of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, in his sermon in the James Memorial Chapel of the seminary yesterday morning.

Switching of a portion of their advertising budgets from November to December is one of the reasons why- retail and department store advertising during the current period will make a better showing than it did last month, according to store executives.

The withdrawal of Italy from the League of Nations was described today as "the best possible news to all lovers of peace" by Salmon O. Levinson of Chicago, well known authority on international law and termed by the late French Premier, Aristide Briand, "the real father" of the Pact of Paris outlawing war.
John A. Lambert, vice president, treasurer and general manager of the Acme Rubber Manufacturing Company here, died today at St. Francis Hospital of pneumonia.

The establishment of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension in 1827 by members of the congregation of the French Huguenot Church, L'Eglise du St. Esprit, and the building of the church's first edifice on Canal Street, which was consecrated in 1829, were commemorated at a service at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at Tenth Street, yesterday afternoon.

A reproduction of the royal red flag of France that was flown by galleys to which Huguenots were once sent was installed yesterday in the gallery of the French Church du Saint-Esprit, 229 East Sixty-first Street, to remind the worshipers of the sufferings of their ancestors for their faith.

Police disclosed today that they had discovered the clothes of twelve different women in the St. Cloud death villa where Eugene Weidmann killed at least two of his five confessed victims. One of them was Miss Jean De Koven of Brooklyn.

The historical theme for the milelong Central Mall at the New York World's Fair of 1939, with its emphasis on freedom. of the press, freedom of religion, freedom of speech and freedom of assembly, as symbolized by four statues, won widespread acclaim yesterday.

Two of the Manhasset Bay dinghy fleet's crack skippers,' Egbert Moxham Jr. and Leonard Romagna, won in their respective classes in today's frostbite regatta. The biggest fleet that has sailed here this year, eight B and twelve D Class boats competed in a light and variable northwest breeze and chilly though pleasant weather.

Government can never take the place of private charity and government alone can carry out only a part of the necessary task of relieving human misery, Governor Lehman said last night at the annual dinner of the Bronx division of the Jewish charity campaign at the Hotel Commodore.

They're predicting a $300,000 gate at the Rose Bowl New Year's day. Ticket applications for the football game between Alabama and California indicate 200,000 persons want to crowd into the bowl, which seats only 88,000.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 84.3, which compares with 84.6 a week ago, 85.1 two weeks ago, 86.1 three weeks ago and 87.1 four weeks ago.

William J. Deardon, New Jersey Deputy Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, called for "united action" by the public to "rid New Jersey of the ticket-killing evil" at the quarterly session of the New Jersey Elks Association in the Boonton Lodge here this afternoon.

Telephone communication was cut by the Rumanian censor tonight as the Bucharest correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES was trying to phone the Vienna office of this paper details of government attempts to interfere with the electoral campaign of the National Peasant party.
Coming after three days of elaborate staging, Mussolini's fervid announcement last Saturday night of Italy's withdrawal from the League of Nations was almost an anti-climax.

For perhaps the first time since Autumn trade reaction began, last week presented indications of a halt. The signs are faint as yet and, in the basic steel trade, production as a whole was reduced again from 31 per cent to 271/2, lowest since November, 1934.
League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M., "Midst Jungle and Mountain in Borneo," Edward Shackleton.

Mrs. Edward Plaut of New York and Casa del Ensuenos, Palm Beach, gave a large buffet supper with dancing last night at her home, 1,114 Fifth Avenue, for Miss Nancy Van Vleck, debutante daughter of Mrs. William de Wilder Atkinson of this city and Ballyshear, Southampton, L. I., who will be introduced to society at a supper dance on Dec. 23 at the WaldorfAstoria. Chrysanthemums and Autumn foliage were used in the decorations.

President Roosevelt has taken occasion to declare that it is not the policy of his Administration to move toward Government ownership of railways. In fact, he regards this solution of the present difficulties of the transportation industry as no better than a course of last resort.

An international commission of inquiry headed by Dr. John Dewey declared last night that Leon Trotsky was "not guilty" of the charges against him in the Moscow trials of August, 1936, and January, 1937, and that the trials were a "frame-up."

Mrs. Hazel E. Fichter, who had been a teacher in the Wharton Grammar School since 1923, died here today at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Regenza, of a heart attack, after a week's illness. She was 38 years old.

Dance International, not content with the laurels it has won with its exhibition in the International Building and its folk dance matinees in the Rainbow Room, turned last night to a larger unit of Rockefeller Center to seek for greater triumphs with an "Evening of Ballet" in the Center Theatre.
The annual Christmas sale at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue, will be held Wednesday, Thursday and Friday for the benefit of several philanthropies in aid of which the shop is maintained.
The marriage of Prince Paul of Greece, heir-presumptive to the Greek throne, and Princess Frederika Luise of Brunswick, was set today for Jan. 9 in the Athens Cathedral.
Closing their American Football League schedule, the Los Angeles Bulldogs gained their thirteenth straight victory today by downing the Cincinnati Bengals, 14 to 3.

Delegate King of Hawaii wants it understood that the $2,000 mileage allowance to him for the special session of Congress is "no Christmas present," although he is not going to spend it to go home for the holiday.
Paced by Lieutenant Milton F. Untermeyer Jr., the 112th Field Artillery riders defeated the Ponolo trio, led by Billy Reber, 11 to 10, today at the Red Bank Armory.

For the first time since he clinched the chess championship of the world by winning the twenty-fifth game, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris succeeded tonight in defeating Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam in the twentyeighth of the series after thirtyseven moves.

A few days ago-at the coming in of December-there died at the age of 55 one of New York's most able and public-spirited citizens, Mr. Lansing P. Reed. But one finds his name in the list of the "In Memory Of" contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund.

The sort of administration recommended in the royal mandate for Jerusalem perhaps should be worked out for the whole of Palestine, Canon Charles T. Bridgeman of St. George's Anglican Cathedral, Jerusalem, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Money for lending remains plentiful and the callmoney rate has sagged to 1 3/4 per cent. Three-month accommodations also are cheaper.

The Englewood Field Club, which defeated the Racquets Club of Short Hills, 4--1, here today, shared the lead in the New Jersey Class B division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association with the Montclair Athletic Club, which scored its second sweep, taking all five matches from Elizabeth Town and Country at Montclair.

The Bloomfield Savings Institution sold to Frank Blanch the four, story apartment house at the southwest corner of Morris and Fourteenth Avenues, Newark, N. J., through Louis Schlesinger, Inc., broker.

The wholesale price index on Dec. 4 stood at 593, compared with 590 a week ago and to 595 two weeks ago. The gold price index for raw materials was 45.4, compared to 44.5 the week before and 45.2 two weeks before.

Dr. John E. Daugherty, superintendent of the Jamaica Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, died in that hospital at 1:10 o'clock this morning after collapsing of a paralytic stroke yesterday afternoon while addressing a regional conference of Lions Club officers in the Hotel Franklin, Jamaica. He was 61 years old. Dr. Daugherty was vice president of the club.
David S. Polland, chess champion of New York State, defeated the former State ruler, A. E. Santasiere, yesterday in the third round -of the tournament for the Marshall Chess Club title.
MEDICAL MAGIC, by David Dietz. (Dodd, Mead, $3.50.) An account of recent discoveries in medicine and surgery, and their application to the human body.

The problem of monetary management has become chiefly a problem of capital, says Professor John Donaldson, chairman of the Academy of World Economics, in his book, "The Dollar," published this week by the Oxford University Press.

Richard Wagner appears to hold away in the concert hall as well as in the opera house. What looked like the largest Sunday afternoon audience of the PhilharmonicSymphony season turned out to hear a program of his music at Carnegie Hall yesterday.

Mrs. Glendower Evans, militant champion of liberalism, died today at her home, 7 Wellington Terrace, Brookline, after an illness of more than a year. Pneumonia, which developed ten days ago, was the immediate cause of death. Her age was 81.
Ferdinand Himmelreich, who became widely known as an organist in spite of almost total blindness since boyhood, died at his home here last night in his fiftyeighth year.

The engagement of Miss Elisabeth Marie Bryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen J. Bryan of this place, to Stuart Richardson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Richardson of Glen Ridge, has been announced by s her parents.

J. A. Topping won the third qualifying round of the twenty-ninth annual Sno Birds' golf tournament today, carding low net of 90--22-68 at Siwanoy. A. M. Cueva, with 94-22-72, and N. Peay, with 8714-73, were second and third in a field of twenty-one, of whom twelve posted scores.

Attorney St, 10-12; Sadie Michalover to Michalover Bros, Inc. 205 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn; mtg, $37.,800 ($11.50). Broome St, 165-7; same to same; mtg, $26,400 ($10). Ridge St, 84; same to same; mtg, $29,250 ($26).
If the anglers who fish New Hampshire's inland waters don't have better sport it won't be the fault of the Fish and Game Department of that State.

Mrs. Constance Schack Gracie, widow of Colonel Archibald Gracie, a Titanic disaster survivor, died here today at Fairmont Rest, a sanitarium, where she had been a patient since August. Death was due to injuries received in a fall seven months ago.
The wholesale price index for Dec. 1 was 105.6, against 105.5 on Nov. 24.

Dr. John E. Toole, 41 years old, Yale graduate and urologist, was awakened by detectives at his home, 120 East Eighty-fifth Street, shortly after 7 o'clock yesterday morning and arrested on a technical charge of homicide.

Mrs. Emanuel Gerli of 907 Fifth Avenue and of Eastwood, Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Diana Gerli, to Daniel Nelson Adams, son of Mrs. Daniel Crouse Adams of 1,130 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Adams.

An anonymous gift of $25,000 has been made to the United Hospital Campaign in behalf of ninety-two voluntary hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Service of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by John W. Davis. The donor sent his check through the trust department of a bank.

Flood-burdened rivers of Northern California threatened new destruction to homes and agricultural lands today as the run-off from a threeday torrential rain coursed seaward. American Red Cross officials estimated the homeless at about 5,000, and thousands of acres of fertile lands were under water. Three deaths were recorded and property damage was expected to run into the millions.
The British Museum has acquired nineteen fine English mezzotints collected by the late Martin Erdmann of New York which recently were sold at Christie's, it was announced today.

Despite cold weather and high winds, the North Jersey Gun Club's weekly shoot today attracted a good field. In the first fifty-target event W. H. Frederick won the High Gun Trophy. P. Corroon and A. A. Roig also gained prizes.

TWO years ago almost to the week Joe Jacobs, hidden behind the usual stogie, went down the Bay to bid welcome to a periodic visitor to these shores. That man Schmeling was in again. Those who know their jabs and hooks wondered what the restless transatlantic voyager was doing in town this time.

The pressure of mounting- relief needs has forced the city to add $300,000 to the Emergency Relief Bureau clothing allowance for December, it was learned last night. The additional funds, all of which have been allocated in advance, were obtained through the transfer of unexpended surpluses in the ERB quarterly budget of $29,147,000.

The German Government issued an official declaration this evening -saying that Germany never will return to the League of Nations under any circumstances. It joins Italy in declaring that the League of Nations system is "not only futile, but pernicious" and rejects the League as either the representative of the world's nations or as the highest organ of international cooperation.

A downward trend in the living costs of wage earners in November is disclosed by the monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board, made public yesterday. Declines were noted in each of the major groups of expenditures except coal.

The New York A. C. basketball team opened its season by defeating the Sixty-ninth Regiment A. A., 38 to 26, on the Winged Foot court yesterday afternoon. Creighton Drury, last year's Fordham captain, made 11 points for the victors, who were in front, 18 to 11, at the half.

The Empire Trust Company, trustee, will receive proposals for the sale to it on Jan. 3 of Montana Coal and Iron Company first-mortgage 5 per cent thirty-year sinking-fund bonds in an amount sufficient to exhaust the sum of $15,010 in the sinking fund.
"Begin to show some sense in your dealings with the Administration, or expect a national economic disaster which will be worse for you than any one else."

There is no security in improvidence," E. Roland Harriman, chairman of the managing committee of the National Economy League, asserted in a foreword of a booklet denouncing the government's financing of its social security program.
Japanese troops, preceded by tanks, have been pouring into Nanking since 4 A. M., when they captured Chungshan gate. The city's capitulation is imminent, according to Japanese army headquarters.

The International Secret Service Institute of 68 Hudson Street, Hoboken, has agreed to stop representing that its course will qualify a student for a position with the United States Secret Service, or as a "G-man," the Federal Trade Commission said today.

Thomas Hertzler Towers and the former Miss Helen Jane Barber, who were secretly married on June 29, were remarried on Saturday night at the home of her parents, Dr. and Mrs. William Howard Barber, 84-48 120th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Gorman of 303 Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Gorman, to Paul W. Connelly Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Connelly, also of Brooklyn. Miss Gorman attended St.

William B. Herlands, chief assistant to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, who was recently appointed by Mayor La Guardia as Commissioner of Investigation, and Miss Gertrude C. Bendheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seigfried Bendhelm of 15 West Eighty-first Street, were married last evening at the Pierre.

Little is left of the Zuyder Zee. On its drained floor two vast tracts of land are already under cultivation. Behind a tremendous dike built to separate it from the North Sea farmers work their fields fifteen feet below sea level.

Although the basketball season is in its early stages, three leading metropolitan teams already have been beaten. Last week, St. Francis and Brooklyn College were defeated, and Manhattan joined their ranks by bowing to Brooklyn College in an interesting game on Saturday night.

A complete change in the "hopelessly reactionary" policies of the Republican party was demanded yesterday by, a group of twelve "younger" Republicans in an open letter to the executive committee of the Republican National Committee.

Associate Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Supreme Court is ill at his residence here. Dr. John Paul Earnest Jr., the attending physician, said today that the justice has an attack of grippe, which probably will keep him indoors for several weeks.
In churches and at public gatherings throughout the State, Pennsylvania commemorates today the 150th anniversary of its ratification of the Federal Constitution.
A midget flying boat, described as revolutionary in design, underwent successful tests at Baldwin Harbor this afternoon.

Dr. Ralph J. Levy, 52 years old, of 18 West Seventy-second Street, was found dead, apparently following a heart attack, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon in his office at 25 Central Park South by his brother-in-law, Herman Saul of 98 Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn.

Not even a group of architects and engineers can agree on any one "best" view that will show New York City's beauty most typically, the Merchants Association has learned. The association, which is celebrating its fortieth anniversary, is carrying on a program intended to "reveal New York to New Yorkers."
The National. Labor Relations Board ordered today that the Star Publishing Company of Seattle reinstate twenty striking employes, members of the American Newspaper Guild.

The council of the Seneca Indian nation declined today by a vote of 14 to 2 to approve a congressional bill that would give the Department of the Interior control over leasing reservation lands to whites.

A program for payment of unemployment insurance benefits to partly unemployed persons in this State is being worked out by a committee designated by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews, it was disclosed last night by Professor Herman A. Gray of New York University, chairman of the committee.
Dr. R. A. Hutchison, for thirty years general secretary of the Board of American Missions of the United Presbyterian Church, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 75.

Senator Capper of Kansas told a radio audience tonight that former Governor Landon "did the right thing" when he said last week he would not be a Presidential candidate in 1940 even if nomination were offered him.

A three-day holiday sale of useful and decorative articles will be opened tomorrow at the Bargain Box, Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. An appeal for new and used articles suitable for the sale is being made, and donations from individuals will be called for.

A big ostentatious shrug of the shoulders was the British Government's only response today to Italy's withdrawal from the League of Nations. "We are not impressed," was the comment heard in government quarters tonight.

Charles Weidman, the noted exponent of the modern concert dance, appeared as a guest teacher yesterday at the December meeting of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., in the Hotel Astor. He demonstrated a group dance in modern form.

"Not one of the New Jersey Congressmen had the courage to do what twenty-six progressive Congressmen did in criticizing Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City. We are going to do everything in our power to see that none of them, go back in 1938."

Bert Patenaude, captain of the Philadelphia Passons, led his eleven to. a 4-to-3 victory over the New York Americans, national champions, before 3,500 fans yesterdayat Starlight Park. Patenaude tallied three goals.

Reductions of one cent per yard on percales for December and January delivery are announced as effective today. James H. Dunham Co. have priced Punjab percales at 121/2 cents. Marshall Field Co., manufacturing division, quote Fieldcrest Invader percales at 121/2 cents for both printed and plain goods, with the exception of dark shades in the plain goods, which sell at 141/2 cents.

Delegates of more than 300 organizations, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Ethical Culture Society Meeting House, 2 West Sixtyfourth Street, decided to attack utility rates as the first skirmish in a battle against the high cost of living.

There being no European tour to look forward to next Summer, yesterday's meeting of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, the fifty-fifth annual session, was devoted principally to election of officers and discussion of proposed rule changes as fortyseven coaches from leading. Eastern universities, high and prep schools and club teams convened at the Hotel Paramount.

Miss Barbara Bain Colton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Harding Colton of New York, formerly of Stamford and Darien, will be married to Walter Edward Schwab, son of Mrs. Henry Schwab and the late Mr. Schwab of New York, on Jan. 22 in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector.

The enthusiasm and effectiveness of missionary work will determine whether the church will survive, the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop-elect of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States, said yesterday in his first sermon in New York at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.
Stocks irregularly lower in the slowest trading since the week ended on Sept. 4; turnover, 5,869,888 shares.

Leo Lemay, 15-year-old youth who wanted to see his mother in Hartford, Conn., early this morning kidnapped two other youths at gunpoint in Kennebunk, Me., and forced them to drive him to Boston. There he kidnapped two more youths and appropriated another car before the weird fiveour ride ended suddenly in front of the Framlngham State Police barracks.

Andy Kerr of Colgate, co-coach of the All-East football team, today completed his selection of star players with announcement that Andrew Bershak, North Carolina end, and Joe Drulis, Temple guard, had accepted invitations to play against the All-West team at San Francisco New Year's Day.

A united union in the building trades division of the electrical industry was effected yesterday under a consolidation agreement signed by the United Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. Local 3, of the A. F. of L.

The Washington Redskins, who won the national professional football title today by defeating the Chicago Bears, had almost as hard going in their dressing rooms after the game as they did on the frozen field earlier in the afternoon.

St. Mark's Evangelical Lutheran Church of 323 East Sixth Street, which lost more than 1,000 members of its congregation and their friends in the burning and sinking of the excursion boat General Slocum in 1904, marked the ninetieth anniversary of the founding of the church yesterday.

Financial activity here continued at a low ebb this week, with little prospect of a revival before the year-end. The stock markets were dull, with no definite trend. Values appear to have reached bottom but are unable to embark on a recovery.

"The King's Breakfast," by Rita Weiman and Maurice Marks, produced by the Repertory Theatre tonight, is a slick comedy relating the rise of an Irish scullery maid to become the mistress of a peer and subsequent complications with a foreign prince, his mistress and her husband.

The death of a mongrel dog resulted yesterday in the slashing of two men, one of them seriously, according to the police. Arnold Laakso, 19 years old, of 2,025 Madison Avenue, was taken to the Harlem Hospital suffering from stab wounds of the abdomen.

The First National Bank, which closed in the bank "holiday" in 1933, will pay a fourth dividend to creditors amounting to $47,097, according to an authorization received by officials of the institution.

William Gebhard Brorein, founder and president of the Peninsular Telephone Company, serving South and Central Florida, a business and civic leader of Tampa for more than a third of a century, died today in a hospital. He underwent an operation yesterday. His age was 76.

Henry H. Lee, president of the Pennroad Corporation, made public yesterday a letter to the Governor of each of the New England States declaring that the corporation could not comply with the suggestion made by the Governors that its holdings in the New York, New Haven Hartford and Boston Maine Railroads be placed in the hands of trustees during the reorganization of the New Haven.

Major Gen. Frank J. Parker announced yesterday his resignation as vice president of Goldblatt Brothers, Inc., a position which he has held since his retirement from the United States Army in September. 1936.
United States representations to the Soviet Foreign Office failed today to produce any clue to the mysterious disappearance of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Robinsonn of New York.

The Catholic drive against indecent films should be extended to include immoral plays, the Rev. Thomas L. Graham said yesterday in the presence of Cardinal-Hayes, who presided at a high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, where the congregation was called upon--as in all Catholic churches yesterday--to renew the pledge of the Legion of Decency.

After one of the keenest fights ever waged for the Lockett Trophy, Boston's team won the tricity matches that ended at the University Club yesterday. When Darwin P. Kingsley, president of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, presented the bowl to Captain Richard V. Wakeman, it marked the second time since the series was inaugurated that Boston was able to take the honors.

Professor James Grafton Rogers of Yale University, former Assistant Secretary of State, and Mrs. Rogers have issued invitations for the marriage on Dec. 30 of their daughter, Miss Lorna Rogers, to Stephen H. Hart, son of Mrs. Richard H. Hart of Denver.

Recent declines in business activity and prices- reflect "the influences of numerous maladjustments that have developed during the past year," it was stated in the December issue of the Federal Reserve Bulletin, made public today.

Out of every four Jews in Germany one is now dependent on relief, according to a report issued by the European executive officers of the American Joint Distribution Committee. This state of affairs is the result of lack of opportunities for work under the anti-Jewish laws.

The acclaim which has followed publication of the news that the President intends to appoint Joseph P. Kennedy as our Ambassador to the Court of St. James is a spontaneous testimonial to the respect and regard in which the chairman of the Maritime Commission is held by his fellow-citizens, regardless of their politics.
Eight Boy Scouts who risked their lives to save others were named yesterday by Daniel Carter Beard, National Scout Commissioner and chairman of the Scouts National Court of Honor.

The Black Hawks, with an overtime period goal by Paul Thompson, defeated the Maroons, 3 to 2, in a fast National Hockey League battle at the Stadium tonight. It was the first time the Hawks had beaten the Maroons in the last ten games between the teams.
The Paterson Caledonians gained a one-point victory in their American Soccer League match with the Hispanos at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. The score was 5-4.

The sedate audience at yesterday afternoon's concert of the New Friends of Music in Town Hall was convulsed with laughter by Mozart's "Musikalischer Spass," which most humorous of compositions terminated a program containing further the same composer's string quartet in B flat and the Schumann violin sonata in A minor.
Arnold S. Denker assumed the lead in the annual tournament for the championship of the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday when he defeated Oscar Tenner in the second round.

The California All-Stars defeated Mexico's Army polo team, 10 to 7, on the muddy Midwick. Country Club field today. Conditions were so bad that occasionally the ball was pushed out of sight into the quagmire.

Lieutenant Commander James Joseph Hughes, commander of the Panay, who was hurt in the Japanese bombing, is the son of Mrs. Eugene Hughes of New York. He was born Nov. 23, 1898 and entered the Naval Academy in 1915. He was graduated four years later.

The Brooklyn Savings Bank, which recently acquired at foreclosure the apartment and store buildings at 657 to 665a Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, has sold them to 657-665 Fifth Avenue Corporation for investment.

Mrs. May P. Haywood, clerk of the District Court, said yesterday that Mayme Fortune Ryan had signed a dismissal of her divorce action against Thomas Fortune Ryan 2d. Mrs. Hayward said she notarized the notice of dismissal and that it was mailed to Cheyenne, where the suit was on file.
An art show embellished by a concert and program of dramatics was presented by children of the Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 373 Ralph Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

More than 500 members of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Opera House, heard the milk situation in the State described as in a "critical condition" and unanimously adopted a resolution that "consumers' cooperative or State control would be welcomed only if the retailer would be established as the distribution channel."

Frank K. Houston, president of the New York State Bankers Association and president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, called attention in a statement issued yesterday to a report on banking development in this city in the last forty years, which, he said, the Merchants Association of New York had prepared as part of its fortieth anniversary program.
Mrs. William Tallman Smith, widow of a wealthy Scranton, Pa., coal mine operator, died today in her family homestead after several years of illness. Her age was 94.

The press today announces and comments on Italy's withdrawal from the League of Nations under enormous headlines liberally strewn with exclamation marks and in editorials entitled "Enough!" and "At Last!"
The New York Central Railroad i reported for October an increase of 9.6 per cent in passengers carried, excluding commuters, with a resultant increase in revenue from this class of 8.1 per cent.

Every section of the country will be represented -at the two-day biennial conference of the National Woman's party, opening here on Tuesday to organize a campaign for adoption of the Equal Rights Amendment, sponsored by the party.

Toll charges on the new Lincoln Tunnel, scheduled to open for service from midtown Manhattan to New Jersey Dec. 22, will be the same as those on the Holland Tunnel and the George Washington Bridge, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority. Combination rates,

A mobile television station, two large motor vans containing complete television pick-up and transmitting apparatus, said to be the first to be built in America, was turned over to the National Broadcasting Company by the RCA Manufacturing Company of Camden, N. J., at Rockefeller Center yesterday.
Riggie Wells, 22 years old, of Troy, Ala., a taxi dancer, was arrested at 11 East Thirty-second Street, New York, and brought here today on a bench warrant charging conspiracy to defraud.

American Commercial Alcohol Corporation has declared a "dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock and, in addition, a stock dividend of two shares of the 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock of American Distilling Company, a wholly owned subsidiary, for each five shares held of the corporation's common stock.

William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, issued yesterday his annual pre-Christmas warning against charity rackets. Pointing out that the holiday season brings a resurgence of appeals from bogus organizations, the commissioner listed one "do" and six don'tt" to guide New Yorkers in their charitable giving.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 28 per cent of capacity, down 2 points from the preceding week, and just one-third of the rate at the end of August.

Claire Harrison, beauty parior, store at 300 W 58th St, through Tankoos, Smith Co. Leonard W. Knapp, in 101 Park Ave; M. S. Marcus, in 15 E 40th St; Anna Kurtagh in 48 W 57th St; Moe M. Grubman, in 105 W 40th St; Albert . Ashforth, Inc. broker.

The fifth concert of the Beethoven series, sponsored by the Federal Music Project, was given by the Federal Symphony Orchestra, under Chalmers Clifton, at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. The program comprised the "Fidelio" overture, the Sixth symphony, and the piano concerto in C minor with Selma. Kramer as soloist.

William Picune, a 25-year-old professional stunt flier, brought his plane safely to earth here today with his woman passenger in a dead faint after his fuselage had been smashed in a midair plane collision from which John J. Diskon, 27, a lawyer of New York City, crashed to his death in a frozen swamp near by.

Mrs. A. H. Evans, 55, strangled her son, Robert, 21, to death and then took her own life by strangulation early today, Coroner Mat G. Boname reported tonight. The bodies were discovered by Mrs. Evans's daughter, Phyllis, 26.
Mrs. Florence Powers, 50, bought a .22-caliber rifle to give to her sons, Fred Jr., 15, and Charles Daniel, 16, on Christmas.

Steel production in Great Britain in November set a record at 1,178,300 tons, compared with a previous top of 1,163,000 tons in September, 1,133,600 tons in October, and with 1,001,300 tons in November, 1936.
Alfred P. Sloan Jr. announced plans yesterday for endowing the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation for economic research with securities worth about $10,000,000.

The Soviet Union elected its first Supreme Soviet under its new constitution today in a beautifully conducted vote that was carried out with all the precision, order and colorful decor of a May Day parade or a Bolshoi Theatre spectacle.

The St. Francis Prep team went into a tie for first place with Bishop Loughlin High in the Brooklyn Catholic High Schools Athletic Association swimming tournament by defeating Brooklyn Prep, 49 to 26, at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, pool yesterday.

Receipts for the first eleven days of the sale of articles made by the blind in the former Farmers Loan and Trust Company Building, Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street, total $14,077, Miss Emily Smith, sales manager for the New York State Commission for the Blind, announced yesterday.

Opinions differ here on conditions in the United States. The accumulation of inventories and the increased unemployment might, it is believed, precipitate a fresh economic crisis, but the prevailing opinion here is not so pessimistic.

Labor's Non-Partisan League announced today that a program for joint aotion politically and otherwise had been tentatively worked out between representatives of the league and representatives of the Farmers Educational and Cooperative Union at meetings held yesterday and today in St. Paul.

One thousand persons attended the fifteenth anniversary dinner of the Israel Zion Hospital last night at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. The proceeds of the dinner, about $50,000, will help defray the cost of constructing the new eight-story addition to the hospital at Fortyninth Street and Tenth Avenue, Brooklyn. Tickets for the affair sold at $100 a couple.

Liquidation by holders of lard futures was resumed last week on the Board of Trade, weakness in hogs and in cottonseed oil affecting sentiment, and prices dropped nearly to the lowest levels of the season and closed at virtually the inside figures, with net losses of 40 to 45 cents a hundredweight in futures, while the cash article was down 45 to 75 cents.

Harry Thomas gets his big chance tonight. The Eagle Bend (Minn.) heavyweight, who was little known outside of Chicago and Detroit up to this month, will be courting world-wide fame in the ring at Madison Square Garden when he opposes Max Schmeling, former champion of the world, in a battle listed for fifteen rounds.

Miss Augusta Romano, pianist, appeared in recital at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall yesterday afternoon. Her program began with three Lully dances, Beethoven's sonata Op. 81, and Franck's Prelude, Choral and Fugue. In the second half there was what was announced as a first performance of Rossini's "Profond Sommeil."
The New York Rangers defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 2, with a threegoal surge in the third period of a National Hockey League game before 9,151 spectators tonight.

Concentration of economic power in the hands of a few is greater than at any time since the beginning of curbing legislation and is a threat to democracy, Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the United States Senate, said last night at a dinner at the Hotel Astor ending the two-day celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Yeshiva and the tenth anniversary of Yeshiva College.

From Welbeck Abbey, where ne entertained Leopold, King of the Belgians, last week, the 80-year-old Duke of Portland sent a letter to The Times, published today, complaining of "the conduct of certain members of the press" who failed to respect the royal and ducal desire for privacy.

X-rays of Wild Bill De Correvont's injured shoulder disclosed today Chicago's Austin High backfield sensation suffered a fractured collarbone in the intersectional game here yesterday with Jackson (Tenn.)
The Stage Relief Fund is five years old today, Rachel Crothers and John Golden having founded it on Dec. 13, 1932.

Four thousand Catholics paid tribute to St. Francis of Assisi in a two-hour ceremony yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Candles flickered before the representation of the saint in white marble, given to the cathedral in 1926, as worshipers of all ages filed slowly past.

Liquor production rose sharply in the fiscal year ended June 30, a total of 258,956,886 gallons being registered with the Treasury's alcohol unit, compared with 253,867,925 in the preceding twelve months and 169,126,472 gallons in 1935.

Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, said today there were indications that infantile paralysis was increasing, but added: "Some day the dread polio will be eliminated."

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, took to St. Louis tonight the names of 700 or 800 Republicans who have been- suggested for membership on the party's proposed committee of 100.
Lord Tennyson's touring cricket team today took a 38-run first innings lead in the second unofficial test match against an Indian eleven.

The six-year separation of the Very Rev. Israel H. Noe, dean of St. Mary's Cathedral here, and Mrs. Noe, will end this week, the Episcopal clergyman announced in a written statement which expressed the hope "that our suffering has not been in vain."
A recent article in The Herald Tribune quotes with relish Yousuke Matsuoka's "unvarnished" explanation of why Japan

Unless otherwise stated, the result of operations of the following companies are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

The League of Nations today received a telegram from Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, "conforming with the decision of the Fascist Grand Council. I inform you that Italy withdraws from the League of Nations as of Dec. 11."

Dr. A. J. Cronin, author of "The Citadel" (Little, Brown), is scheduled to speak over the Columbia Broadcasting System at 2:15 P. M. tomorrow. Dr. Cronin returned recently from Hollywood and is on his way to his home in England.
An entertainment to be known as a Baby Party has been arranged by a group of this year's debutantes to aid the Babies' Relief Fund and will be held the evening of Dec. 27 at the Stork Club.

The passing wizardry of Slingin' Sammy Baugh shot the Washington Redskins into the championship of the National Football League on the frozen tundra of Wrigley Field today. The Indians, as accustomed as Eskimos to their arctic surroundings, toppled the Chicago Bears, 28 to 21, with a three-touchdown onslaught in the third period.
William T. Ramsey, former Mayor of Chester, who served three terms in the State Legislature and became majority leader of the House, died at his home here today after a long illness. His age was 64.

The New York Security Traders Association announced yesterday that a permanent constitution and set of by-laws have been voted and that the membership has approved the plan to incorporate under the laws of New York State.

Three men, taken into custody yesterday by a radio police patrol, were in city prison here tonight pending the outcome of ballistics tests on two loaded revolvers through which detectives seek to link them with the hold-up murder of James Tedesko, 50 years old, at Fredericktown, Pa.

The United States gunboat Panay, sunk today by bombs in the Nanking battle area, was one of six or seven such patrol boats maintained in the Yangtze River by the United States under the Sino-American treaty of 1858. Other nations also maintain patrols in the river.
Defeating the Irish-Americans, 3 to 1, the St. Mary's Celtics gained two points in the championship series of the American Soccer League at Clark's Field today.

The United States Attorney General has been asked to decide whether the island's recent laws providing for government birth-control clinics conflict with Federal statutes. Meantime fourteen clinics privately sponsored and staffed have been operating sufficiently long for Dr. Jose S. Belaval, their director, to conclude that their acceptance among the poor is excellent with only an occasional "imbecile" objecting.

Alarmed by the threat of a 100 per cent tariff surcharge on Japanese goods, representatives of Japan are making efforts to overcome the handicap of an unfavorable trade balance. Japan bought only $7,012 worth of Costa Rican products In a period in which $1,954,457 worth of Japanese goods were sold in Costa Rica.

The Civilian Conservation Corps will close 104 of its camps between now and Jan. 1, but will conduct a replacement program designed to enroll about 32,000 young men in the corps during the quarter beginning Jan. 1, Robert Fechner, CCC director, announced today.

Morgan Ave (16-4476), e s, 370 ft n of Mace Ave, 36x100; Brim Realty Corp to Mildred Porter, 1,614 Walton Ave. Vyse Ave (11-2998), e s, 153 ft a of 176th St, 116x103; Delton Realty Corp to 1,834 Vyse Realty Corp, 302 B'way; mtge $158,000.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions CIVIC FOODS, INC., cafeteria, 1,409 6th Ave.-Voluntary proceeding under section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $28.750 and assets of $43,500.

Many leading silk and rayon houses favor an established minimum wage for unskilled workers and a maximum work week, according to G. H. Conze, president of the Susquehanna Silk Mills and of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.
Announcement of eighty - three sports awards was made by the Yale Athletic Association today on the recommendation of the Board of Control. Thirty- four major Y's were included in the list.

Foreign Minister Koki Hirota expressed profoundestt apologies" today for the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay. The Foreign Minister called on the United States Ambassador; Joseph C. Grew, to convey the Japanese Government's regrets. Mr.

An appeal for contributions for the aid of Christian victims of Nazi discrimination in Germany was circulated yesterday by the American Committee for Christian German Refugees, which has offices at 287 Fourth Avenue. The appeal was signed by a long list of clergymen and educators from many parts of this country.

Miss Beverly Dorothy Fink, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Fink of this place, will be married to George J. Carmichael Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Carmichael of Brooklyn, on Jan. 14 in Christ Episcopal Church here. The Rev.
A national federation of Catholic college students was formed yesterday at a meeting attended by delegates from sixteen institutions at Manhattanville College, Convent Avenue and 133d Street.
Cornell students brought coal, food and clothing into this leather manufacturing town today as a gift to strikers at the Elkland Leather Company.

Hirsch, Lilienthal Co. have opened a branch office at 1,775 Broadway under the management of Thomas J. Callan. The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed transfer agent and the National City Bank, registrar, for the common stock of the Woodward Iron Company.

Directors of Marshall Field Co. will meet tomorrow merning to act on the selection of a successor to James O. McKinsey, chairman, who died suddenly on Nov. 30. Frederick D. Corley, president of the company, is expected to be made chief executive officer, retaining his present title.
Arthur Hutchinson, former Professor of Mineralogy at Cambridge University and until last September for nine years master of Pembroke College, Cambridge, died today at Cambridge at the age of 71.

Dr. John H. Finley, editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, has accepted the invitation of New York University's chancellor, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, to act in addition to his other activities as director of the Hall of Fame, succeeding the late Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson.
Garden City Casino defeated the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club, 4 to 1, in the only Metropolitan Badminton Association men's Class A team match played over the weekend. However,

Accessories and gift items, merchandise for January promotions and advance Spring apparel accounted for the bulk of activity in the New York wholesale market last week. In the dress market, evening apparel sold well at all prices, with dinner types coming to the fore in the upper brackets and strictly formal styles favored in the popular range.

Retail prices last month scored one of the greatest monthly declines in several years, according to the Fairchild Retail Price Index. Prices on Dec. 1 showed a decline of 1.2 per cent under those of Nov. 1, bringing the composite index down to 94.5. Current quotations are 3.1 per cent above -the Jan. 1 level, but are still 7.5 per cent above the 1936 low.

The question of what is to become of church property and the present church income in Germany is now being seriously considered in the Ministries, party organizations and among s churchmen. Various proposals have been made for the distribution of property and suppression of income in the not too distant future.

Ten Federal agencies awarded seventyfour supply contracts valued at $3,417,439 under the terms of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Dec. 9, the Department of Labor has announced. This included $157,940 for indefinite amounts based on last year's purchases.

Baron Steno Stackelberg, Baroness von Luttwitz, Lady Clipperton, Lady Hersey Boyle, Lady Sharp, Lieut. Col. George S. Cantlie, E. P. Rees, Miss Auriol Lee and Baron Hubert LeJeune are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Hearings in its cases against the Pennsylvania Whiskey Distriubting Corporation of Brooklyn; the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., of New York, and others, will be conducted by the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway, New York, tomorrow morning, the commission has announced.
R. R. Fawcett, newcomer this year at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C., did some exceptionally fine shooting in the week-end event of the Winged Foot organization yesterday.

The York, New Jersey and Connecticut last week are given in the following The Senate On the McNary amendment (to the Pope-McGill Farm Bill) proposing to limit the operation of the act by providing that no adjustment contract should be entered into covering farming operations with respect to any commodity planted for harvest in any year subsequent to 1940, defeated 51 to 25:

Declaring that there "must be no surrender" to the C. I. O. and its backers who are trying to "invade" Jersey City in spite of him, Mayor Frank Hague attacked Morris L. Ernst yesterday as an "important leader" of radicalism and an associate of "the leading Communists of this country."

Arthur M. Kaufman, in 200 W. 79th St., through the Apartment Locating Bureau. William Keel, John Dungan, in 310 E. 44th St.; Herbert Jafee, in 310 E. 74th St.; Marian McBee, B. J. McGarry, in 405 E. 54th St.; Charles Rankin, in 321 E. 54th St.; Herman Fischel, in 356 E. 57th St.; Raymond Van Sickle, in 402 E. 74th St.; Alice Ratzner, in 140 E. 28th St.; Wilbur D. Gray, broker.

Freezing weather, the first frostbite dinghy sailors have had this season, brought out a top fleet of twenty-four craft today in the racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Despite the cold, the north-northwest breeze was not too stiff, and the water of Long Island Sound was smooth.

Hundreds of snow fighters, working under a bright sun that shone for the first time in a week, attacked secondary roads and streets in North Buffalo suburbs today to complete lifting the siege of a three-day blizzard that took six lives.
The theatre shows quite a bit of life this evening, what with two Broadway openings, a couple of openings away from Broadway and various other matters of one sort or another. In order:

An important ruling granting the discount privilege to installment buying; paper which has a maturity at time of discount of not more than ninety days, was made public today by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in its December bulletin.

Continued pressure by the Transport Workers Union to gain recognition as sole bargaining agency for the 5,400 employes of the city's Independent Subway System was promised yesterday by Austin Hogan, newly elected president of the New York City local of that C. I. O. affiliate. In this campaign Mr. Hogan will have the support of City Councilman-elect Michael J. Quill, international head of the union.

Because of the concentration of Italian troops and air forces in Libya it has been rumored here that British troops and a large amount of war material were being sent to Egypt's western frontier. The writer is able to state on unimpeachable authority that the rumors are without foundation.

Charles P. Taft, chairman of the National Citizens Committee of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs, announced yesterday that a national group of business, civic and welfare leaders would meet at the Yale Club Friday to discuss the danger that the pressure for a balanced Federal budget may return to local communities a load of unemployment relief that they cannot carry.

A three-day conference here of Estonian, Latvian and Lithuanian Foreign Ministers ended yesterday. It was held in political circles to have improved relations among the three small Baltic States which have been so strained recently.

Miss Edith Louise Baker, daughter of Mrs. William Hogg Baker and the late Mr. Baker of this place, has chosen the evening of Jan. 15 for her marriage to Jameson Gilbert Campaigne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Campaigne, also of Montclair. The ceremony,
The Hershey Bears and the Baltimore Orioles battled to a scoreless tie tonight in an overtime Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.

Investment in United States savings bonds on Saturday passed the $1,000,000,000-mark, making the United States Government the largest seller of a single security in the country, Secretary Morgenthau said today.
The Spanish Insurgent armies launched today their long-awaited general offensive, Insurgent authorities announced at Irun. They struck simultaneously on the Toledo, Brunete and Teruel fronts.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, an affiliate of the C. I. O., has applied to the National Labor Relations Board for collective bargaining elections in three drydocks and certification without election in a fourth, it was announced yesterday.

A model man rather than a model environment should be the aim of tomorrow, the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Henry and Clark Streets, Brooklyn, declared in his morning sermon yesterday.
Henry Armstrong, world featherweight champion, knocked out Johnny Jones of Pittsburgh today after 1 minute 20 seconds of the second round in a scheduled tenround fight.

Today's major events: "Aida." Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 o'clock; National Orchestral Association, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Beethoven Association, Town Hall, 8:30; Robert Wallenborn, pianist, Town Hall, 3.

The franc continues steady despite the uncertainty of the domestic situation. The exchange control maintained sterling at 147.09 francs until Thursday, so that the dollar fluctuated in Paris in the same proportion as in London.
Captain Cornelius Timothy Smith, a Civil War veteran who was for seventy years a leader of the Democratic party in Caroline County, died yesterday at his home near here. He was 95 years old.
Major Gen. G. G. H. Irving, chief of the Australian General Staff in 1915, died today at the age of 76. General Irving was a son of Professor Martin H. Irving of Melbourne University.

To rebuild one's life, it is first necessary to rid one's self of the mass of debris acquired through petty dislikes, hatreds, prejudices and narrow-minded beliefs, the Rev. Dr. John L. Davis declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Washington Square Methodist Church. 133 West Fourth Street.

Champion Bozo's Bar Mate, owned and handled by Mrs. A. R. Moffit of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., was the winner of the open stake in the first field trial meeting of the Dutchess County Field Trial Club, held today in the covers of the Roweliffe game farm in this town.

The arrival here today of Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France on his official visit became immediately the occasion for enthusiastic popular demonstrations for France, coupled with a certain amount of vocal outburst against the present Yugoslav minority government, which is notoriously more inclined to dictatorship than to democracy.
