The Turkish market for electric refrigerators, which did not develop until recently, is expanding steadily, according to a report to the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce by the office of the American Commercial Attache at Istanbul.
The Colophon, a book collectors' quarterly, is putting out today an Annual of Bookmaking, containing the history of American bookmaking for the last ten years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A communication from Professor Auguste Piccard in THE TIMES of Nov. 28 suggests an apparently attractive method of exploring great depths of the ocean through the use ofa free-floating or naturally buoyant balloon-like device capable of sinking or rising at the will of the operators within.

Miss Anne Odeneal Wilbon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Thomas Wilbon, was married here yesterday to Dr. William Warren Babson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Elmer Warren Babson of Gloucester, Mass., in All Saints Episcopal Church by the Rev. Ernest Van R. Stires.
The Board of Trade's index of wholesale prices for November, based on the average for 1930 as 100, stood at 108.5, compared with 110.6 in October and 98.3 in November, 1936.

North American wheat markets, including the local Pit, showed considerable redistance to selling pressure last week and the December delivery on the Board of Trade here reached the highest price since late October.

Appointment of the Manhattan Advisory Board of the City Planning Commission was announced yesterday by Borough Presidentelect Stanley Isaacs. Mr. Isaacs's three appointees are Henry Bruere, Dr. John H. Johnson and Albert Mayer.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:
Charles Schmidt, 26 years old, of 462 East 147th Street, the Bronx, was waiting for a train at 4:30 A. M. yesterday at the Seventy-sixth Street station of the Third Avenue elevated line.

The New York Rovers moved into a first-place tie in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League yesterday, but they did it the hard way. In a bruising battle which never slowed its pace from opening faceoff to final whistle, the redoubtable Red Shirts gained a 2-to-1 triumph over their intracity rivals, the Bronx Tigers, in Madison Square Garden with 13,247 partisans cheering.

Abolition of the Transit Commission as the chief obstacle to transit unification is the leading item in the 1938 legislative program of the Citizens Union, announced yesterday by William Jay Schieffelin, its chairman.

John P. .Frey, president of the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor, demanded yesterday that the Wages and Hours Bill be recommitted to the House Labor Committee for further study. His demand was made in an interview here with a representative of The Democrat and Chronicle of Rochester. N. Y.

The Paterson Panthers today defeated the Newark Tornadoes, American Association co-champions with White Plains, 27-7. Paterson scored twice in the first quarter and added touchdowns in the second and third periods to take a convincing lead.

Abram Flaxer, executive vice president of the State, County and Municipal Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, announced yesterday that the union had won written agreements with the municipal governments of Muncie, Ind., and Jeannette, Pa., providing for union recognition, grievance machinery, a forty-hour week and other concessions.

A tall, lanky youth, whose prowess at leaping from fire-escapes earned him the nickname "the cat," was under arrest as a burglar last night, charged with jumping into the apartment of Albert Kobat at 725 West 184th Street, Saturday night, and stealing jewels and clothing valued at $475.

A campaign to encourage youth to save and build individual financial reserves was started yesterday at a luncheon in the Town Hall Club by the American Provident Society, "a nonprofit association for teaching thrift, self-reliance and economics."

James H. R. Cromwell and his former wife, Mrs. Delphine Dodge Cromwell Baker, settled yesterday a suit awaiting trial in Supreme Court in which they were charged with obtaining $50,000 from Robert F. Norton on false representations.
The Dartmouth College athletic council today released complete varsity and freshman schedules in basketball, hockey, swimming and other Winter sports.

A Spanish play by Juan de Laencina, first produced in 1498, was presented yesterday afternoon by the Spanish students of Barnard College. It was part of a preChristmas celebration which also included the singing of Spanish carols.

The Rev. Dr. Thomas T. Mutchler, retired Methodist Episcopal minister, who for thirty-four years was secretary of the Philadelphia Sabbath Association, died at his home here today after an illness of five months. He never recovered from a fall of last July in Ocean City, N. J., in which both his hips were broken. He was 87.

With practically all major producers except Ford reducing assemblies last week, total automobile output eased against a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index receded to 89.0 from 91.9. The figure for the week ended Dec. 12, 1966, was 108.8.

Enrico Venturi, holder of the European lightweight championship, will meet George Zengaras, popular Greek-American fighter from the East Side, in the star bout of ten rounds at the New York Coliseum tonight.

Before a packed house, Jack Pearl made his initial bow tonight in non-musical drama in the America premiere of "One Flight Down," dramatized by Eric Stroom from the Austrian play by Alois Freund and Armin Friedman. Mr. Pearl,

A Joint luncheon meeting of the housing, zoning and parks and playgrounds committees of the Twenty-third Street Association will be held today in the George Washington Hotel to prepare a housing program for the district, according to John J. Cavanagh, president. of the association.
Lagging behind last year, the 1937 Christmas Seal Sale Appeal for $350,000 for the tuberculosis and health associations of New York City has thus far brought in contributions of $163,193.

The Japanese Navy flier who bombed and sank the United States gunboat Panay Sunday twenty-five miles above Nanking boasted to an inquiry board yesterday that he had sunk a Chinese warship, according to Rear Admiral Tadao Honda.

The Realty Company of the Women's University Club, Mrs. William Henry Hays, president, leased to Wilbur H. Young Jr. for a residence club the building at 106-08 East Fifty-second Street, erected 1913 and used since as a clubhouse for associated women's university clubs. Isaac Gluckman, attorney,

A jury of eight women and four men was selected yesterday before Bronx County Judge James M. Barrett to try two Long Beach policemen and a woman who are alleged to have worked the "badger game" on Sol Campo, owner of a beauty parlor at 518 Willis Avenue, the Bronx.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is, wiCh his consent, continued on active duty until June 17: Capt. Terence J. Smith, Engr.-Res.; Ist Lt. Rolland G. Scott. Inf.-Res.; ist Lt. Josenh C. WPher CA -Res.
The Boston Olympics, national A. A. U. hockey champions defeated Harvard, last year's American college titleholder, 5--4, in a thrill-packed game tonight at the Boston Arena.

A Gold Star Mothers funeral service was held yesterday for Mrs. Mary Kall, 62 years old, a widow, whose death Friday in an almost bare flat at 341 South Third Street, Brooklyn, suggested the possibility of a pauper's burial.

A net income of $2,946,403 for the first ten months of this year was reported yesterday by the Western Union Telegraph Company, Inc., to the Federal Communications Commission. - This is after deductions for Federal income taxes, depreciation, interest and other charges, and is equal to $2.82 a share on 1,045,278 shares of $100-par capital stock.

A meeting and tea in the interests of the annual Russian Students' Ball were held yesterday at the home of Miss Rita Singstad, 1035 Fifth Avenue, who is co-chairman, with Miss Barbara Hill, of a junior committee now being organized.
The liner President McKinley, with all the passengers of the wrecked liner President Hoover safely transferred aboard, was proceeding to Manila tonight.

First reports say that perhaps 90,000,000 votes were cast in the election of Soviet Russia's first democratic parliament. Along with these figures Mr. Denny sends the statement that few people in Moscow expect any real change. Power will remain in the hands of Stalin and his subordinates.

Mrs. Elizabeth F. Strong obtained a divorce here today from William M. Strong on grounds of cruelty. Others who won divorces were Philip G. Wylie, author, from Mrs. Jennie Wylie of New Britain, Conn., and Mrs. Jeanne Wingfield

Gustave E. Kruse, coffee expert, I who retired last year as head of the coffee department of the Grand Union Company, with which, and its predecessors, he had been associated for half a century, died Sunday of heart disease at his residence, 151 Arlington Avenue, Brooklyn.

The English-type dwelling, formerly owned by the late Calvin B. Orcutt, at 21 DeWitt Road, Elizabeth, N. J., was purchased by Lawrence B. Gilman. The house has been unoccupied since the death of Mrs. Orcutt in April, 1936. It was sold by the executors of her estate.

The housing industry in the United States has notoriously been suffering from lack of what the economists call an effective demand. There were plenty of people who needed new houses, plenty of workmen ready to build them, plenty of business men who would have been glad to sell building materials, plenty of architects and contractors prepared to exercise their talents.
Following are the texts of statements issued by the State Department today bearing upon protests and apologies in connection with the sinking of the gunboat Panay:

An important precedent in the British Government was created today, by an inferential ruling through the failure of the House of Commons to act otherwise, that the leader of the Opposition is unaccountable for his private acts and statements, as a member of the Cabinet would be, even though he enjoys a special high salary voted for his office in the last session.
In what appeared to be a repercussion of the recent liquor price war in New York City, liquor retailers in this city slashed their prices today on several popular brands.

Radical changes in the rules governing trotting and pacing horses in 1938 will be debated here tomorrow when the United, American and National Trotting Associations, parent bodies of the sport east of the Mississippi, hold their annual joint meeting.

Police arrested Jean Morel, 35, today after they raided his apartment in connection with their investigations of secret societies and found a number of guns. Police said they found thirty rifles, three revolvers, twenty bayonets and a quantity of cartridges. Morel,
Johnny Holt, bantamweight champion of South Africa, knocked out Kid Chocolate of Jamaica tonight in the fifth round of a boxing match here.

Announcement was made in Basle today that Roger Auboin, secretary-general of the Interministerial Committee of National Economy, had been appointed director-general of the Bank for International Settlements to succeed Pierre Quesnay, who was drowned last Summer.

The annual Atlantic Coast squash racquets championships for women opened on the Haddon Hall courts today with all the favorites advancing to the second round. Only one match brought what was considered in the nature of an upset.

J. Kenneth Watson, cashier of the Rutherford National Bank for more than thirty years, died last night in his home here at the age of 75. He retired as cashier several years ago, but retained his membership in the bank's board of directors.

Four accounts in the estate of Miss Mary Morton of New York City, daughter of Levi P. Morton, one-time Vice President of the United States. distributing more than $850,000 of her estate, were adjudicated today in the Berks County Orphans Court.

Since the state of the capital market has precluded the funding of a $2,000,000 bank loan, the Robert Gair Company has deferred action on the fourth quarterly dividend on its $3 preferred stock, according to an announcement by E. Victor Donaldson, president.
Scores of underground passages in Windsor Castle, where the royal family spends more time than anywhere else except Buckingham Palace, are to be converted into bombproof and gas-proof shelters.

Plans for a $452,416 public building program here were endorsed today by a special committee of the Arthur Manor Association, a neighborhood group. The buildings are necessary and the estimated cost is reasonable, the committee said.
Heavy storms sweeping over England and Scotland today caused the loss of at least five lives and battered ships in the English Channel.

The Duchess of Westminster and Captain and Mrs. Edward Kellett, who will sail for London tomorrow on the Europa, gave a farewell supper dance last night at Hampshire House. Several dinners were given, the hosts and hostesses later taking their guests to the dance.

David H. Crowley, member of the University of Michigan Board of Regents, advised tonight in a statement appearing in The Detroit Free Press that selection of a new Wolverine football coach be made independently of -Fielding H. Yost's "nomination or suggestion."
Dr. Dan S. Renner, superintendent of the State Village for Epileptics in Skillman, died of a heart ailment in his home at that institution today at the age of 53.

Traffic accidents, 'fatalities and injuries continued to drop last week and week-end as compared with the corresponding periods of 1936, it was announced yesterday by Harold Fowler, First Deputy Police Commissioner.

Michal Michalesko will open tonight at the McKinley Theatre, the Bronx, in a series of four one-act Yiddish operettas in which he has previously appeared. The bill will consist of "The Last Dance," "Senorita," "Sweet Love" and "The Jewish General."

Patrolman Joseph P. Moran, president of the powerful Patrolmen's Benevolent Association for the last twenty-four years, will retire from the force at noon Thursday, in accordance with Commissioner Valentine's new age limit of 63.
Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals was re-elected president of Congregation Emanuel, at the annual meeting in the community house, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street. last night.
A large factory and an historical farm in Connecticut have changed hands, reports received yesterday from brokers in the Westchester and Connecticut sections revealed.
Mrs. J. Randolph Robinson of Westbury, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Celia Randolph Robinson, to Julian Peabody, also of Westbury.

If the wars in China and Spain aren't stopped, and if application of the- democratic principle isn't achieved on a world-wide basis, the fault cannot be attributed to any lack of earnestness on the part of the American Artists Congress.

As a result of the conversations between Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France and Premier, Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia 'today the Franco-Yugoslav trade agreement that has been hanging fire for months will be signed tomorrow morning at the Ministry of Commerce and come into force on Wednesday.
Condemning "obvious aggression" as dangerous to permanent peace, the trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace called upon- this country yesterday

K. M. Schaefer, who recently joined Federal Motor Truck Company, Detroit, as assistant to the general manager, has been appointed the general sales manager in charge of all domestic sales and advertising activities.

Speculation continued today over the post to which Joseph E. Davies, Ambassador to the Soviet Union, will be transferred and who will succeed him at Moscow, but no authoritative information was forthcoming from the White House or the State Depapartment.

Nation-wide studies of public opinion by seventy psychologists, aided by 536 student interviewers, are reported by the Psychological Corporation in The Journal of Applied Psychology and were made public yesterday.

Miss Adele Diamond, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Diamond, has completed plans for her marriage to Jerome Howard Adler, son of Mrs. Isaac Adler and the late Mr. Adler, which will take place Sunday night at the home of the prospective bride's parents, 16 East Eighty-third Street.

Plans to station plainclothes policemen in the second balcony of the Boston Garden to arrest persons throwing objects on the ice during hockey games were made today by President Weston Adams of the Boston Bruins and General Manager Walter Brown of the arena.

Quebec and Oitario, as the result of a conference here today between Premiers Hepburn and Duplessis, are understood to have agreed to make a joint request to the Ottawa Government for permission .to export electric power to the United States, to pursue a common policy regarding the erection of new pulp and paper mills, and to present a united front on Dominion-Provincial relations before the Royal Commission which is now investigating this subject.
MAINS: A GUIDE "DOWN EAST," by members of the Federal Writers Project. " (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50.) The fourth volume of the New England group of the American Guide Series.

Asked to comment today on the National Economy League's attack yesterday on the methods employed by the Treasury in financing the old-age provisions of the Social Security Act. Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference that "some people just don't want to understand."

The second annual midwinter review of the City College units of the Reserve Officers Training Corps will be held tonight in the armory of the 102d Engineers, at 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, Colonel Oliver Prescott Robinson, chairman of the Department of Military Science and Tactics, said yesterday.
Grover C. Vaughan, for the last twenty-eight years a detective, died Saturday night at his home, 570 West 156th Street, at the age of 58.

Barker Gummere Hamill, retired banker and a descendant of distinguished New Jersey families, died yesterday at the New York Hospital after an illness of six months. He lived at 100 Central Park South and his age was 57.

Leading at the half, 15 to 13, the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy basketbail team triumphed over New College, 40 to 23, at the Brooklyn Pharmacy gymnasium last night. Louis Weber and Morris Glasner were the mainstays of the Brooklyn attack with 10 and 9 points respectively.

A burglar believed the same, possibly, as robbed the residence of Edward J. Noble, Wall Street banker, of $8,500 in cash and jewels last May, broke into the Francis B. Vanderhoef home early this morning.
The following is a list from latest available official records (as of Oct. 31) of the officers and men of the gunboat Panay, as issued-by the Navy Department today:

Thomas swept a long left hook to the face to open the battle. After a clinch, he missed a left to the face. He hooked a light left to the body and put two light lefts to the head. Schmeling jabbed a straight left to the face and ducked Thomas's left hook for the jaw. They exchanged rights to the heart.

The report of the committee on national production is expected within the next few days. This committee, set up by the Chautemps government soon after it took office, is composed of government representatives, labor leaders and employers' representatives.

Peter Sullivan was elected president of Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, it was announced yesterday from the offices of the local following a compilation of votes cast in Sunday's election at Manhattan Lyceum, 66 East Fourth Street. Patrick Sullivan was elevated from orgahizer to business manager.

A special meeting of stockholders of the W. L. Douglas Shoe Company will be held in Brockton, Mass., on Jan. 14 to act on a plan of reorganization. The company has a capital deficit in excess of $500,000, and is borrowing $925,000 from banks. Arrears on 34,044 outstanding shares of 7 per cent preferred stock were $45.50 a share on Sept. 30.

Japanese officials here are hourly becoming more appalled over the attacks on the United States gunboat Panay and the British gunboats Ladybird, Bee, Cricket and Scarab and a dozen unarmed American and British river steamers.

This week has brought a halt in the sharp downward movement in steel operations in the United States, and activity is scheduled at 27.4 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 27.5 per cent last week, a decline of only 0.1 point, or 0.4 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Ernest Hemingway has written his first play, "The Fifth Column," according to a dispatch from Madrid. The action takes places in the Florida Hotel, Madrid, and it is there that Hemingway wrote the play.

Only a decade ago last May Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh made the Atlantic flight which may be said, because of the inspiration of its dauntless and flawless performance, to have ushered in the modern era of aviation.

An offering of bonds and pre ferred stock of the Associated Tele phone Company, Ltd., will be place on the market today by a banking syndicate consisting of Bonbrigh Co., Inc.; Paine, Webber Co. Mitchum, Tully Co. and Blyth Co., Inc. The bonds,

An increased distribution to certificate holders of two issues of the New York Title and Mortgage Company's guaranteed mortgage certificates will be paid on Dec. 31, it was announced yesterday by Abraham N. Geller trustee.

In a series of declarations defending himself from charges of hostility to Germany and Italy and undue friendship for Russia, former Foreign Minister Nicolas Titulescu has made the interesting revelation that it was King Carol who prevented the dissolution of the fascist Iron Guard.
A dead heat and a race so close the judges just did manage to pick the winner featured the Fair Grounds card today. Perfect weather and a fast track attracted a good-sized crowd.

Interstate bus lines serving New York City and New Jersey communities are planning to use the new Lincoln Tunnel between West Thirty-ninth Street and Weehawken as soon as possible after the tunnel is opened to traffic Dec. 22, it was learned yesterday.

Wages and raw material costs of the steel industry have increased substantially more since 1926 than has the volume of steel produced, while steel prices have increased only half as much, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

A legislative committee investigating alleged employment discrimination against persons over 40 years old heard a witness testify today that General Electric Company seeks younger employes when the "average age" reaches 40.

The withdrawal of six registrations as broker or dealer in the over-thecounter market was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as follows:. Miller-Murray Co., Inc., 302 Broadway, New York; Moe and Pauline H. Platt,

The Rev. Dr. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, in a letter made public last night, pleaded for the settlement before Christmas of the strike among The Brooklyn Daily Eagle employes who are members of the New York Newspaper Guild.
Alan H. Bonito, marine insurance executive, died on Sunday at the Gotham Hospital, 30 East Seventysixth Street, after a brief illness. He was 43 years old and resided at 277 Park Avenue.

A battling hockey team from the Sacred Heart Club in Concord, N. H., outskated and generally outfought a superior Dartmouth six tonight, but was defeated, 4 to 1, as Bud Foster and Dave Walsh formed a well-coordinated Green attack that scored two goals and led the way to another.

Nearly 90 per cent of the pheasants in Western New York's storm areas "are dead and buried," Andrew Wenk of Buffalo estimated today. H strapped on snowshoes yesterday and carried into the snow-covered sections several hundred pounds of grain for the birds.

A hearing has been set for Jan. 4 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on a declaration by the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc.. New York. asking approval of the issuance of $6,000,000 of 3 1/2 per cent promissory notes, payable on Dec. 31, 1939.

Showabal, 3-year-old son of Balko-Shows, had an easy time winning the Blue Ridge Purse, the feature event of today's card. He ran to the front right after the start, kept the lead all the way and finished well ahead of Prince Turley, paying $11 to win, $6.80 to place and $4.60 for third.
Stocks nervous on Far Eastern incident, and closed with leading issues off 1 to 4 prints; turnover, 1,017,284 shares. All groups of bonds heavy in quiet trading; transactions, $6,807,375.

Colgate had to come from behind in the last five minutes to beat the Hamilton College basketball team tonight, 55-51, two baskets by Johnny Debus and a basket and foul by Vic Hazard, cophomore center, giving the home team the victory.

Dr. Luis Manuel Debayle, director of the Public Health Service of Nicaragua, announced today that patent medicines arriving from the United States and other countries would in the future be subject to strict examination and analyses. This, he said,

Assurance that Italy does not intend to withdraw from the Bank for International Settlements was given today by Dr. Virfcenzo Azzolini, governor of the Bank of Italy, who is here for the monthly board session. The, bank is not connected with the League of Nations.
Sinking of the gunboat Panay and three Standard Oil Company vessels was the latest in a series of international incidents arising from the Chinese-Japanese conflict. Previous incidents include:

A cable message yesterday from the Shanghai office of the Standard Vacuum Corporation, owner of the three vessels bombed by the Japanese Sunday at the same time the U. S. S. Panay was attacked, said that of the 150 persons believed to be on the four ships, ninetq-six still were unaccounted for.
NEWS OF METROPOLITAN REAL ESTATE

A YEAR ago Mr. George Preston Marshall decided that professional football in Boston was a lot of wet wash and that it was either get out or get taken to the cleaners, literally to be interpreted in his case as carrying coal to Newcastle.
In a dimly lit lounge at New York University 1938 fashions for girl students were shown yesterday afternoon under spotlights at the school's Washington Square College.

Cynics may sneer at the announcement that the first annual convention of Santa Clauses is to be held next Sunday in Brooklyn. They may jeer at Captain William Fisher's description of Santa Clausing as "the most satisfying, the most noble profession in the world."
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 11: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Boyer, G. H., Med. Corps. four months" leave, March 8, with permission to visit foreign countries.

More than $150,000,000 will be expended on the New York World's Fair, instead of the $125,000,000 estimate made originally, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation.

Since the start of the Far Eastern conflict no Japanese attack on foreigners has had such ugly implications for Great Britain as yesterday's shelling and bombing of British and American warships in the Yangtze.

Joe Ferguson, veteran billiard official, yesterday was selected to referee the world title pocket billiard match between Ralph Greenleaf of New York and Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., which starts tomorrow night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

Nicola Moscona, 26-year-old Greek basso, made his debut at the Metropolitan Opera House last night as high priest, Ramfis, in "Aida." He is the singer whom Edward Johnson overheard in an audition while visiting a publisher in Milan last Summer.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS DEPUTY CHIEF INSPECTOR-Archibald RI. McNeill, Borough Headquarters Brooklyn and Richmond, at S.3.150 per annum. Appointed June 8, 1901. INSPECTOR-Anthony L. Howe. Fourth District Traffic, at S2,950 per annum. Appointed Jan. 11, 1896.
Alfred P. Sloan's magnificently generous gift of $10,000,000 will be devoted "to the increase and diffusion of economic knowledge." In the present state of human affairs it is difficult to think

Customs and excise revenue for the eight months of the current fiscal year totaled $223,440,478, according to figures issued by the National Revenue Department today. This was an increase of $42,159,655 over the corresponding period a year ago.

Three women and six men were chosen today as jurors to try Mark Griner, 23 years old, of Millville, on a charge of murdering Albert R. Witt, 26, on last July 27. The jury panel was exhausted and a new panel was to be drawn tomorrow. Judge Solve Tuso,

Producers themselves must take a greater interest in the mechanics of marketing, pricing and distributing their goods if distribution problems affecting farm produce are to be met satisfactorily, F. A. Wilcox of the United States Department of Agriculture told
Diana Lady Rhodes died today at her villa, Les Fleurs Delys, at the age of 76. She was the daughter of the late Daniel Murphy of San Jose, Calif.

Reported aboard when the United States gunboat Panay was bombed and sunk were seventy-six persons, including fifty-nine officers and crew, four members of the United States Embassy staff from Nanking, seven other American civilians, one British newspaper man, three Italians and two not accounted for.

The American-Hawaiian Steamship Company, which operates forty-one freighters between the Pacific and Atlantic coasts, has laid up three vessels and there is a question whether two others will continue to run. Recession of intercoastal trade.

Several buildings in mid-town Manhattan were included in realty transactions announced yesterday. The six-story private residence at 43 East Fifty-first Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, was sold by the estate of Edward C. Moore Jr. through the executors, Bankers Trust Company and Louis deB. Moore, to a syndicate represented by Henry Mandel.
A cooperative effort by poor children in New York City to give presents this Christmas to other boys and girls poorer than themselves is being made by the Boys Club of New York .

An intruder, surprised in the home of Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter, a 38year-old divorcee, at about 5 P. M. today shot and killed Mrs. Carpenter, criminally attacked Miss Mary Griffin, 22, a friend of Mrs: Carpenter, and then ransacked the house.

Members of the Manhattan team, which recently concluded the most successful gridiron campaign in the history of the college, were honored at a testimonial dinner at the New York Athletic Club last night. The affair was sponsored by Manhattan alumni, headed by James R. Dyer and William Coleman.

IT is odd, when you stop to think of it, that the average literate American should know more about Greenland, Bali or the Belgian Congo than about Australia. Yet so far as most of us are concerned, Australia could as well be a province of Mars. "Yes," says your friend, "it's a big island--a British dominion, isn't it?
The Grace Line steamship Carabobo radioed to the Coast Guard Station at Jacksonville, Fla., at 1 o'clock this morning for assistance, reporting that her boilers were out of commission.
The German Government continues in -various ways to make official distinction between foreigners of German and noni-German origin.
James C. Sheridan, Queens Democratic leader, announced yesterday that notices had been sent out for a meeting of the executive committee of the County Committee the evening of Jan. 10.

It will be Sam H. Grisman who will sponsor in its present concert version the Mercury Theatre's offering of "The Cradle Will Rock," according to reliable reports. specifically, the billing will be "Sam H. Grisman presents the Mercury Theatre's production"

A Ford mail truck was stoned and a group of men armed with brickbats was dispersed by Sheriff's deputies today as work continued at the Ford assembly plant here, where the United Automobile Workers of America called a strike on Friday.

So far as the United States is concerned, the London silver agreement of 1933 is a thing of the past, a high Federal official declared today. It was learned from Treasury sources that nothing has been done to continue the agreement, which expires on Dec, 31.

A building loan of $78,300 on twenty one-family homes now under construction at 238th St and 119th Ave, St. Albans, L. I., has been made by the KaplanHartman Corporation to the Eagle Building Corp, Benjamin Biegeleisen, president.

Observers who witnessed the Japanese aerial attack yesterday on the United States gunboat Panay declared tonight the bombing was unmistakably deliberate, precluding possibility of error. These observers were rescued by the British gunboat Bee.

The Japanese people's reactions to the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay cannot be described because the proportions of the affair as reported here differ from the incident as it appears to American readers.

At tempted Federal control of prices and production in the bituminous coal and agricultural fields were attacked from the Democratic side of the Senate today as Senator Walsh denounced recent price-fixing orders of the National Bituminous Coal Commission and Senator George condemned the pending Farm Bill as "class legislation."

The B. M. T. laid off about 2001 employes last week, it was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of the employes in the Brooklyn offices of the Transport Workers Union, 98. Flatbush Avenue. The discharged men demanded that employed members of the union share their work by giving up one of their six days'. employment.

Three American missionaries were' reported today to have disappeared from Shouyang in East Shansi Province. They have not been seen since the night of Dec. 2, when they left the mission to visit a friend.
The undefeated Regis High and St. Ann's Academy basketball teams extended their winning streaks to five games yesterday when they triumphed in contests on Manhattan courts.

George H. Holden of 81 Hornblower Avenue, former owner and publisher of The Surveyor and The Insurance Age, died today in the St. Barnabas Hospital, Newark, following a heart attack which overcame him two weeks ago while he was attending a service in the Hugh Smith Presbyterian Church here. He was 56 years old.

Mrs. Lillian Cushman Brown, formerly head of the Department of Art, School of Education of the University of Chicago, and later a staff member of the Child Study Association of America in New York, died at her home here last night of pneumonia. Her age was 71.

Mrs. James Joseph Hughes, wife of the commander of the United States gunboat Panay, bombed and sunk by Japanese planes in the Yangtze River Sunday, declared last night that she was "very happy over my husband's miraculous escape." Mrs. Hughes arrived here with her mother from Atlantic City, where they had been spending the week-end to do some Christmas shopping.

Johnny Revolta of Evanston, Ill., sent a twenty-foot putt curling into the cup on the final green today to win the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open golf tournament with 282, two under par, for the seventy-two holes.

Mrs. Meredith Hare gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History in the interest of the museum's ten-year development program. After the dinner the guests were conducted to the halls devoted to Indians of the Southwest by Dr. Clark Wissler,

Oscar Paxson, father of Joseph A. Paxson, Director of Parks and Publie Property, died today at his home, Chelsea Heights, at the age of 78. Mr. Paxson came to Atlantic City in 1900 from Lumberville, Pa., and for many years he operated a number of automobile service stations here.

Arnold A. Krantz, the young lawyer admitted to the bar three years ago but forced to peddle towels and tablecloths to support his wife, was appointed a referee yesterday by. Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. , Hofstadter in Special Term, Bronx. County.

Although realty men and builders in the metropolitan area still find it difficult to negotiate loans to finance many deals and carry, out new construction projects, a study of the official mortgage records for Manhattan indicates that the banks and insurance companies are assuming a more and more liberal attitude in advancing funds for such purposes.

Colonel Lewis H. Watkins, often called "the father" of the Tennessee Valley Authority's plan to develop the Tennessee River and its tributaries, defended his plan in Federal Court today as the only practical and effective system of obtaining flood control and navigation in the Tennessee Basin.

Acting upon a resolution adopted in November by the Republican National Committee, the national executive committee met here today to select a chairman and members of a committee of one hundred to draft a party declaration of principles.
A building program calling for the construetion of twenty-six modern homes here is in its initial stages following the breaking of ground for the first unit of ten homes.

New York University's basketball team scored its second victory in two games last night at the University Heights court, defeating Seton Hall College of South Orange, N. J., in a hard-fought overtime contest, 31 to 27 The triumph also marked the Violet's forty-second straight at the Heights gymnasium.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, 220, Ireland, threw Ed Don George, 225, Java, N. Y., in the feature bout last night at the Hippodrome before a crowd of 2,000. Using a double wrist lock and body hold, Casey won in fifty-one minutes.

A suit to collect $40,000 from three individuals alleged to be responsible for an inaccurate registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 has been instituted in the Supreme Court here, it was disclosed yesterday.
Admiral Nobumasa Suetsugu has been named Home Minister in succession to Eiichi Baba, whose health is reported to be unsatisfactory.
On the ground that settlement of a sitdown strike at the Apex Hosiery Company plant last Summer made the case a moot question,

Disagreement between Secretary Wallace and the American Farm Bureau Federation over pending agricultural legislation was brought into the open here today at its convention Mr. Wallace, who addressed the federation, also disagreed several weeks ago with its parity price program.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Epharaim Barliner and George T. Bean of New York were admitted to practice today and the following proceedlnes were had: 32--r. G. McNair, as receiver of the First National Bank of Perry, etc., petr., v. W. V. Knott, as Treasurer of Florida et al., etc. On writ of certiorari to the Fifth Clrcuit Court of APneals.

MANHATTAN CLER, JULIA LINCOLN (Dec. 7). Estate, less than $10,000. To Dorothy Mills Compton daughter, executrix, Walton St., West Annapolis, Md. FRIEND, HELEN (Nov. 25). Estate, less than $10,000. To Constance Friend, sister, executrix, 127 W. 79th St., residue.
The War Offiee announces the Italian Government has ordered thirty Italian military instructors and ten aviation experts to withdraw from China. They will leave Hankow for Kiukiang tomorrow.
Excerpts from opinions on the sinking of the Panay, as given today by several members of Congress, follow:

By contributing 5 per cent of the day's gross receipts to the $6,250,000 New York - Brooklyn Federation Campaign, 250 restaurants in the metropolitan area will celebrate Federation Restaurant Day tomorrow. Edward Levine,

A survey among the basketball officials in the metropolitan district reveals that the elimination of the center jump does not quite meet with their approval. They are all agreed that it places an extra burden on them and express the hope that it may be abolished.

Officers of the government-owned freighter Algic told a Federal Court jury today that the Algic's seamen refused for more than eight hours to work while strike-breaking, nonunion,stevedores loaded the ship at Montevideo, Uruguay, last Sept. 10.

The Rev. Dr. John Montgomery Gill, senior member of the Maryland Conference of the Methodist Protestant Church, died yesterday at his home near this city at the age of 81. For fifty years he had filled pastorates in Seattle, Wash., Baltimore and Washington, D. C.
The Civic Choral Club of Port Chester presented Handel's "Messiah" tonight in the Summerfield Methodist Episcopal Church here. A chorus bf forty-two sang under the baton of Miss Anne Merritt.

The recession now afflicting the business of the country, Governor Richard W Leche of Louisiana said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel New Yorker, is caused by a "sit-down strike" of capital and industry in every State but his own, where he declared a boom'was under way.

The first snow in five years blanketed Madrid and the whole central front this morning, bringing suffering not only to soldiers but to those In unheated houses where even electricity has been reduced to save power.

The suggestion for rehabilitation of the nation's ailing railroads, as put forward by President Roosevelt last Friday and, by which, through the Interstate Commerce Commission, consolidations, abandonment of uneconomio lines and readjustment of capital set-ups would return the roads to solvency within private hands, is favored by Carroll Miller, chairman of the commission, it was learned today.
In a free-scoring but thrilling game Lehigh University launched its basketball season tonight and defeated Pennsylvania Military College, 59 to 43.

The wheat market on the Board of Trade here fluctuated in an erratic manner today, declining around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading, largely in sympathy with securities, but rallying sharply toward the close when Buenos Aires futures turned upward.
Thomas H. Schultz, assistant treasurer of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company, died yesterday at the age of 72. He had been on the railroad staff fifty-four years.

From The Chronicle (Ind. Rep.) This time the Japanese Government seeks to forestall American protests by volunteering its apologies first for a "terrible mistake." But apologies are not enough for something which was very much worse than a "mistake." Not,

Chrystie St, 69-71, 49.6x50; Walter E. Godfrey, ref, to Citizens Savings Bank, foreclosure ($1). 15th St, 132 W, 25x103.3; Joseph Siegel to Horace Siegel, 974 46th St, Bklyn, quitclaim, 1-3 interest, mtg, $18,000. 22d St, 267 W, 25x98.9; Joseph Siegel to Horace Siegel, 974 46th St. Bklyn, quitclaim, 1-3 interest. mtg, S10,500.

Paced by Pete Smith and Heinie Young, both of whom scored a pair of goals and an assist, the Princeton junior varsity sextet overwhelmed the Nassau yearlings. 8-1, on the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink today in the opening encounter of the season for both aggregations.

Senator Geald P. Nye of North Dakota, here for a public address tonight, laid the blame for the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay by Japanese bombs at the door of President Roosevelt, in an interview this afternoon.

A boycott of Japanese goods was urged as a "just and pacific means" of protesting Japanese aggression in China by Dr. Mousheng Lin, Chinese author, yesterday at a luncheon of the Congregational and Christian Ministers Federation at the Broadway Tabernacle, Fiftysixth Street and Broadway. He said a boycott would be within the provisions of international law.

Although the subject is unconventional, the style and craftsmanship are comfortably ordinary in "Love of. Women," which was put on at the John Golden last evening. It is the work of the English playwrights Aimee and Philip Stuart, who are authors of "Lady Clara," "Nine Till Six" and "Birthday," which have been performed in this vicinity. If the authors' names

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that the Department of Justice was conducting a "careful investigation" into reports of peonage in cotton fields throughout the South, notably in Warren County, Ga. The organization said it was informed of the investigation by Brien McMahon, Assistant Attorney General.
Mrs. Mary Reynolds Sharpe, wife of the Rev. Dr. John C. Sharpe, headmaster emeritus of Blair Academy, died at her home here yesterday after a brief illness at the age of 76.

The seven-room Colonial-style residence, on a corner plot 60 by 130 feet, at 29-29 146th Street, Flushing, L. I., was sold by C. W. Copp of West Palm Beach, Fla., to a Long Island City investor. The property is assessed at $8,000 and adjoins the Old Country Club.

At the recent Phi Beta Kappa initiations Helen O'Connell, blind Hunter College student, added one more triumph to her list of scholastic achievements. A graduating senior after only three and a half years of college work, she was initiated into the honorary society.

Uncompromising refusal to consent to the return to Germany of colonies held by Britain was unanimously voted tonight by the parliamentary committee of the Empire Industries Association, a group of conservative business men who are more in sympathy with many of Chancellor Hitler's aims than any other section of British opinion.

Filipino women, enfranchised early this year, will march to the polls along with the men tomorrow to vote. The women will vote for eleven members of their own sex seeking positions on provincial boards.

The problem of government will transcend all others in the United States in 1938, according to the consensus of the members of the National Economic League. By a margin of more than three to one, the league's members voted that the question of government was more pressing than the present business depression, the nationaldebt or crime.

The charge that the I. R. T. suit to have its elevated leases disaffirmed is inspired by financial interests that have "steered Interborough toward ruin by their anti-public attitude," is made in the city's brief filed with Federal Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday by William G. Mulligan Jr., Assistant Corporation Counsel.

Amos B. Jaquith, former threeterm Mayor of this village and a Democratic leader of the town of Saratoga, died at the age of 70 last night in his home. A native of Schuylerville, Mr. Jaquith retired from politics at the completion of his third term as Mayor in 1934 after an active life of forty-five years in Democratic politics.

The existence of a new chemlat process which may lead to the identification of hitherto unknown old masters was claimed here yesterday, as a preliminary to its proposed introduction in the United States. It has already been tested in at least two European museums, it was said.
The State of South Carolina has invited sealed proposals to be opened on Jan. 5, 1938, for an issue of $1,350,000 of State certificates of indebtedness.

Dr. Dixon Ryan Fox, president of Union College, defended tonight the scheduled appearance here tomorrow of Fritz Kuhn, German-American Bund leader, as giving to students "first-hand information" on "both sides of important questions."

State administration of the system of group classification in workmen's compensation and other types of insurance was criticized last night as "arbitrary" and "inefficient" by Michael Levy, New York broker, in an address before the New York Furniture Warehousemen's Association at the Prince George Hotel.

Though prices on the New York Cotton Exchange declined yesterday in the early trading in response to lower quotations in Liverpool and weakness in the stock market, a rally later left the list 3 to 6 points higher than on Saturday. Mill price fixing before the December goes off the board at noon

United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt called at the Foreign Office today for a conversation which diplomatic sources believed was concerned with the Far Eastern situation after the sinking of the American gunboat Panay.
Before crowded galleries the House today opened debate on the second item of the President's special-session program, the Wages and Hours Bill.
The trial of two suits to prevent construction of two apartment houses in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn was started yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. in Brooklyn.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director for the National Labor Relations Board, was chosen as Juror 3 and Elmer Rice the playwright as Juror 7 for the first-degree manslaughter trial of Joseph Moses, a Negro, which is to start before Judge Donnellan in General Sessions today. Mrs. Herrick is one of four women on the jury.

Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninetyfirst Street, in his sermon there Sunday and again before the Men's Club last night, amplified his sermon of Saturday, Dec. 4, on the place of Jesus in the synagogue.

Among leading inquiries for steel are 20,000 tons for equipment for the Grand Coulee Dam, Wash., for which bids will be taken on Jan. 6, and 14,000 tons of armor plate, on which the Navy Department will receive proposals on Dec. 29.

Automobile vehicle production in Great Britain increased 10 per cent during the twelve months ended Sept. 30, according to a report from London made public today by the Department of Commerce. Passenger-car production amounted to 389,633

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in connection with its study of investment trusts and investing companies, has called a public hearing on the General Investment Corporation, International Equities, Inc.,

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson today sharply criticized the Pennsylvania anthracite industry for charging "inordinately high prices for coal-to the consumers" and paying "fabulous" sums to executives.

Lafayette's undefeated and untied football team was honored tonight by more than 1,000 students and alumni at the largest testimonial dinner in gridiron history of the college. The event was held in the Alumni Memorial gymnasium.

District Attorney Wlliam C. Crossley today declared the death of Mrs. Randolph B. Shackelford, 40, of Philadelphia, was caused by "asphyxia due to probable drowning, with nothing to indicate homicide."

Trial of a $50,000 damage suit against Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, and her chauffeur began here today before Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson and a jury. Frederick Grewen of 46 Van Guilder Avenue,

Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Pittroff of Baltimore today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Falvia Lee Pittroff, to Henry Burgess Thielbar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Thielbar of River Forest, a Chicago suburb.

Countess Marietta Palffy, whose marriage in 1934 to Clendenin J. Ryan Jr. of New York resulted in an annulment action three months later, has filed divorce proceedings against Count Palffy, her attorney disclosed today.

The whipping post, the ducking stool, or the public stocks, punishments of Massachusetts' Colonial days, would be revived and inflicted on persons convicted of driving while drunk, under the terms of a bill filed today by State Representative Charles W. Olsen, Ashland Republican.

The Marseilles, ten-story hotel structure at the southwest corner of Broadway and 103d Street, was solid at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms. The Morewood Realty Corporation, as plaintiff, bought in the structure for S635,000.

The hospital and school systems of the city were charged with discriminating against Negroes by complainants appearing yesterday before the New York State Temporary Commission on Urban Colored Population.

In the tabulation showing how members from the New York area voted in Congress last week, printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning, Representative Hancock of New York, was erroneously recorded as having voted against the adoption of the Boileau amendment to the Jones Farm Bill to prevent land taken out of intensive crops being used for feeding livestock and dairy cattle. Mr. Hancock of New York,

Harold Russel Ryder, 41 years Old, an ex-convict, who was known as the "playboy of Broadway" when he first was sentenced to Sing Sing six years ago, was sent back to that prison yesterday by General Sessions Judge Nott to serve five to ten years.

The prompt, firm and wholly admirable manner in which the President and the Secretary of State acted today in dispatching to Japan stipulations of guarantees, as welt as protests, in connection with the bombing of the gunboat Panay makes even more unbelievable the fact that nearly enough signatures have been procured in the House to force consideration of the Ludlow Anti-War Resolution.

" We must aid the farmer" is one of the chief laments which has been coming out of Washington for the last several years. But apparently the more the farmer has been aided the louder and more insistent have become the cries from his many and active spokesmen for still greater assistance from the National Treasury.

P. K. Wrigley, owner-president of the Chicago Cubs, said today that Tony Lazzeri, former New York Yankee infielder, and Catcher Gabby Hartnett would act as advisers next season to Manager Charlie Grimm.
Ship-to-shore telephone service will be opened tomorrow for passengers on the Washington of the United States Lines, it was announced yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

President Roosevelt moved swiftly today to meet the grave situation presented by the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay of the Yangtze River Patrol above Nanking by Japanese naval aviators. Full expressions of regret and full compensation were demanded of Japan as well as guarantees against a repetition of any similar attack in the future.

With Jose Iturbi, pianist, as guest artist, and Rene Pollain as conductor, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra gave its first concert of the season at Orange High School tonight to more than 1,200 persons, including many prominent in Essex County social circles.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended December 8: Increases of $108,000,000 in total loans and investments, $70,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities, $50,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations, $95,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $36,000,000 in vault cash;

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dunlevy Milbank of 1,026 Fifth Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ella Dunlevy Milbank, to William Ward Foshay, son of Mrs. William B. Foshay of Port Chester, N. Y., and the late Mr. Foshay.

The Beethoven Association afforded its guests and patrons a concert of uncommon distinctions last night in Town Hall. There were chamber music and solo instrumental performances, and two groups of songs sung by Mme. Povla Frisch.
Max Schmeling's knockout victory over Harry Thomas started an all-night celebration for German boxing fans who followed the fight via a nation-wide radio hook-up last night.

This pottery capital of America struck a defensive blow at cheap Japanese wares, causing ruinous competition to its basic ceramic industry, today in a spectacular inauguration of a local boycott against foreign importations which it is hoped will spread to nation-wide proportions.

Although the Detroit Lions finished no higher than third in the Western Division of the National Football League, the professional gridiron representatives of the Automobile City showed the way in eight phases of play during the season.

Edwin Gold, 31 years old, a collector. for the Rand Tea and Coffee Stores, Inc., 158 Franklin Street, was robbed of $2,300 at noon yesterday by two men who accosted him in front of 1,946 Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

The New York Rangers, with a string of three successive victories, will oppose the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League encounter at Madison Square Garden tonight. It will be the third meeting of the season between the sextets.

Dr. James R. Angell, president emeritus of Yale University and now educational counselor for the National Broadcasting Company, said today in his first statement since his return from Europe, where he spent several weeks studying radio systems, that the possibility of a controlled radio system to eliminate the sponsored commercial broadcasts in this country was somewhat remote.

Friction between the so-called administration Republicans and the North Jersey "clean government" bloc flared anew today when the former charged the latter with attempting to force the selection of Senator Lester H. Clee of Essex County as chairman of the Joint Appropriations Committee of the incoming Legislature.

Combination deals in the drug and toilet goods field continued to meet further barriers this week, as the National Wholesale Druggists Association protested- the newest offerings of a dental cream and a toothbrush for 49 and 59 cents.
The Rev. Leroy E. DeMarsh, pastor of Friends Church here and a former pastor in Portland, Me., died here early today.

A vote of confidence was given Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's AsAociation, last night by the membership of his local, No. 791, at a meeting at the Straubenmuller Textile .High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street.

A group headed by David Stern 3d of Philadelphia made late today a formal offer to buy the Providence Tribune Company, publisher of The Providence Star- Tribune, which went, into receivership a fortnight ago on the petition of Walter E. O'Hara, president and sole stockholder.

A record entry is expected for the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' annual college week ski tournament starting Dec. 28 and ending New Year's Day. The twelfth yearly competition for women athletes will occupy the first two days, while the men will compete for the many coveted prizes at stake the last three days.

Sagamore St (15-4256), n e cor of Unionport Rd, 100x125; Sonat Realty Corp to Gibraltar Credit Corp, 16 Court St, Brooklyn. Bryant Ave (11-2997), n w cor of 173d St, 10Ox100; Moses Fieber to Namo Realty Corp, 1,117 West Farms Rd; mtg $108,900. 179th St (11-3221), n s, 65 It e of Loring Pl, 35x114; Rose Schneider to Louise Spector, 1,940 Andrews Ave.

The stock market here was predominantly dull today due to the news from the Far East, but there were some small improvements during late trading. Gilt-edge issues were lower, while foreign bonds were idle. Transatlantic stocks, after a firm start, suffered from reaction, so the list weakened.

The first national convention of steel workers to be held under the auspices of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization will open here tomorrow and continue for three days in order to frame a national wage -policy and discuss other important problems.

An extension of the fair trade practice program of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, whereby the dress producers will be subject to definite penalties for making "secret deals" with retailers in violation of the fair trade rules,

Consumption of apparel wool during October was 23 per cent less than in the previous month and 37 per cent below October, 1936, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, continuing today its investigation of the financial affairs of the bankrupt Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, disclosed from the files of the road itself, banks and lawyers the cost of the first reorganization which covered the period 1925 to 1928, inclusive.

Plans for a school on 160th Street, between Forest and Tinton Avenues, the Bronx, costing $380,000; a group of 304 bungalows on Rockaway Point, at an estimated cost of $304,000; a brick factory building in Maspeth, costing $300,000, and a large apartment house in Kew Gardens, were among the building projects filed yesterday.

Craigweil House at Bognor Regis, Sussex, where King George V recuperated after his severe illness of 1929, will be demolished because the owner, Sir Arthur Du Cros, felt it would not be "fitting that the house in which the late King was nursed back to health" be made into a hotel.

Re pudiating his earlier testimony, Dallas I. Dement, a male nurse, admitted in Orphans Court today that he fraudulently obtained the signature of Mrs. Bertha E. Chew on a will bequeathing $50,000 to Elizabeth T. Henderson, superintendent of a nurses' directory.

The firemen of this city risked their lives yesterday to save plant instead of human tenants. Dashing into flames which were sweeping the greenhouses and potting shed of the Ford Hook farm of David Burpee, president of the W. Atlee Burpee Company, the firemen saved many rare specimens of experimental flora.

Nearly half a million more vehicles used the interstate crossings of the Port of New York Authority in the first eleven months of this year than in the entire twelve months of 1936, the authority disclosed yesterday.

Directors of Marshall Field Co. yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of $1.75 a share on the prior preferred stock and old unexchanged cumulative preferred stock and a quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock.
A dealer in marble testified today that a portion of the stone from the quarries of Senator George L. Berry and associates in the TVA's Norris Dam basin was "the finest of its kind" he ever saw.

An agreement to prolong for one year from next Feb. 28 the "standstill" agreement on Germany's short-term foreign bank debt was signed in London yesterday afternoon, according to a cable received here by Siegfried Stern, vice president of the Chase National Bank. who is secretary of the American Standstill Committee.

Jake Schaefer triumphed over Jim Lewis in the first two blocks of their 3,600-point 18.2 balkline match which started at Lawler's Manhattan Academy yesterday. In the afternoon Schaefer prevailed, 300 to 182, in eight innings, and at night Schaefer won, 300 to 21, in five stanzas. Schaefer had clusters of 151 and 105.

With Administration leaders bending every effort to soft-pedal all discussion of the Panay incident today, congressional reaction was largely dominated by the personal predilections of the various members.
Paulie Walker, 151/2, Trenton welterweight, took a ten-round decision tonight from Dem Wakerlis, 152, Boston.
Samuel Arnowitz, cigars and stationery, store at 76 W 55th St: Maxwell C. Carlin, laundry, store at 78 W 55th St; Jacob Terchun, tailor, store at 67 W 56th St; Huberth Huberth, brokers.

An elderly brother and sister, one blind and the other partly blind, who for the last twenty years had fought a losing battle against poverty, were burned to death last evening when fire swept through their three-room cold water flat on the first floor of a five-story tenement at 104 West Ninety-ninth Street.

There is always the possibility that the New York World's Fair may be just another "colossal, stupendous exposition," but if Larry Herzog has his way the fisheries exhibit will be something worth traveling a long distance to see.

An explanation of the workings of the new regulations governing the filing of income-tax returns pertaining to foreign personal holding companies was approved today by Secretary Morgenthau for publication in tomorrow's Federal Register.

Although generally accepted as accurate, reports of the collapse of the Selznick International- Metro alliance were without more than a veiled confirmation today. The David 0. Selznick organization dedined to discuss the matter, commeeting only that "as we have f: never announced or rumored any negotiations, we are in no position to say that they have failed." MGM was equally noncommittal.

Dr. John E. Toole, 41 years old, of 120 East Eighty-fifth Street, was held in $1,000 bail in Felony Court yesterday after he had pleaded not guilty as a suspect in an automobile killing. Magistrate Ford set a hearing for Friday.

Philip Guedalla, the English biographer and historian, who has written for the most part about the England and France of the last century, told yesterday of his plans for writing a history of America.

Tabulation of the party enrollment figures in Manhattan for 1937-1938 showed yesterday that 41,789 voters in that borough enrolled under the emblem of the American Labor party, according to S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections.

Miss Mona Law Fotterall Trench, daughter of Mrs. Stewart Power Trench of 208 East Seventy-ninth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Hamilton Murray, which will take place on Saturday in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

A strike of employes of the Parmelee taxicab system was threatened yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, because of notice given by the company that it intended to abrogate its closed shop agreement with the union.
John Flynn, 45 years old, a government clerk, was suffocated when the one-story bungalow at 82-19 235th Street, Bellerose, Queens, in which he was sleeping burned about 6 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Japanese Army headquarters here announced last night that Japanese troops had completed the occupation of Nanking. It was just a few hours less than four months after hostilities had begun on the outskirts of Shanghai.

The William S. Paley Foundation has given $4,000 to the United Hospital Campaign, it was announced yesterday by Arthur A. Ballantine, chairman of the professional section. Mr. Ballantine, who is a member of the law firm of Root, Clark, Buckner Ballantine, also announced a gift of $1,000 from the Air Reduction Company, Inc., and subsidiaries, and one of $500 from Hallgarten Co.

Harlow H. Curtice, president of the Buick division of General Motors, announced today that December production schedules call for the output of 20,191 cars, bringing total production of 1938 models through Dec. 31 to 85,516 cars.

KINGS BULL, SIDNEY W. (March 21, 1937). Gross assets, $16,900; net, $16.900. To wife. Nina Q. Bull. Chtef assets, real estate, $5,500; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance. $7,445; miscellaneous property, S3.955.

The number of business failures in the United States for the week ended Dec. 9 was 234, against 208 for the previous week and 154 for the corresponding period last year, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Leonard Replogie gave a dinner at Trailside tonight, having as guests Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick, Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington, Mr. and Mrs. Aksel C. P. Wichfeld and Mrs. Annie F. Breniser. Mr. And Mrs. Wichfeld,

The increased tension in the Far East over the latest attacks on neutral shipping by the Japanese had an unsettling effect on the bond market yesterday and issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange worked lower with Japanese obligations showing sharp declines, especially among the non-government bonds.
The new Manhattan telephone book, a directory with 432,000 names, addresses and telephone numbers, is now being distributed. During the next week more than 600,000 copies will be distributed.
President Roosevelt discussed the attacks upon American ships in the Yangtze with Secretary Hull, whom he instructed to formally protest the Panay incident and demand of Japan full compensation.

An apartment house with bombproof cellars and gasproof compartments is soon to be constructed by the Goteborg Savings Bank of Goteborg, Sweden, according to a foreign report made public today by the Department of Commerce.

United States ASSISTANT MARKETING SPECIALIST (MEAT GRADER), $2,600 a year. Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Department of Agriculture. ppllcations must be on file not later than Jan. 10, if received from States other than those named below.

Dr. Avery W. Skinner, retired director of examinations and inspections in the State Education Department, died of a heart attack today at the age of 67. Dr. Skinner was stricken in the office of Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Education Commissioner, where he had come for a talk with his former chief. He had retired in July, 1936, because of ill health.

Brigadier General Sir Charles Delme-Radcliffe died here' today at the age of 73. He was born in England, and twenty years later joined the Connaught Rangers to begin a military career which ended with his retirement in 1921. He had served in Europe, India and Africa.
The thirteenth expedition in the ten-year quest for Paul Redfern, American aviator, started today up the Essequibo River from Bartica, a mining town fifty miles south of Georgetown.

Charles J. Hardy, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, reported to stockholders yesterday that for the six months through October the company and its wholly owned subsidiaries earned a net income of $1,483,135 after depreciation and Federal normal tax.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals awarded damages of $10,000 yesterday to Eunice Skelley, whose husband, Joseph Harold t Skelley the actor, was killed three years ago by a New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad train in a grade-crossing accident at West Cornwall, Conn.
The total of bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding on Nov. 30 was $348,026,993, according to the monthly acceptance survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which was issued yesterday.
The international stock market indices for Dec. 11, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

One result of King Leopold's state visit to London a few weeks ago was revealed today when a group of bankers announced that they had granted to Belgium a loan of [Pound]5,000,000 at 4 per cent, payable in 1960.

Michael J. Quill, , Councilmanelect from the Bronx. and international president of the 'Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O.affiliate, will -sail on the' liner Washington tonight for Ireland to marry Miss Mollie O'Neill in Kilgarvan, County Kerry, on Dec. 26.

Lawrence Million, 18 years old, of 6,809 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, who accidentally killed a woman June 13 while firing a rifle at electric light bulbs on the marquee of a motion picture theatre near his home, was sentenced yesterday by Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato to an indefinite term in the New York Vocational Institution at West Coxsackie.

Pope Pius seized the opportunity offered this morning by a secret consistory for the creation of five Cardinals to deliver an allocution expressing the grave anxiety and deep sorrow with which he regards the Far Eastern conflict no less than the sadness with which he sees "impious and atrocious things being perpetrated in Russia and those being prepared to the danger of Christian life in Germany."

In view of the fact that the Amateur Athletic Union last Winter outlawed the Eastern Amateur Hockey League, Princeton University officials canceled the game scheduled tomorrow night between the Tigers and the New York Rovers.

A field of 111 nominations for the $50,000 added Santa Anita Derby, Feb. 22, was announced today by the Los Angeles Turf Club. The 1937 nominations for the mileand-one-eighth route topped last year's record of 103.

Certified public accountants should assume the chief responsibility for insuring that credit granters receive a true, complete statement of the condition of business concerns, it was declared last night by a banker, a credit man and a representative of business at a forum

Preparations to put on the fifth annual "Night of Stars" Christmas benefit at the Chicago Stadium Wednesday night without the aid of stage people belonging to the Actors Equity Association were completed today.

A notice was sent out yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent ofSchools, offering 2,500 licensed teachers awaiting appointment an opportunity to have their names kept on existing eligible lists.

Louis Luckman, at the end of his third trial on perjury charges linked with the Drukman murder case, was found 'guilty by a blue ribbon jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court early today, with a recommendation of mercy. The jurors,

Assistant DistrictAttorney Donald McArthur refused to prosecute Mrs. Agatha Grove Midgley, 23 years old, on her arraignment in the Felony Court yesterday on a charge of abandoning her 4-year-old daughter, the oldest of two children, last Sunday, although she offered to plead guilty.

Yakichiro Suma, second in authority at the Japanese Embassy in Washington, spoke today before the Economic Club at a luncheon in the ballroom of the Book Cadillac Hotel, taking for his subject "Where Japan Stands."

The opinion that business would have an immediate upturn if assured that President Roosevelt really means to put through a program of economy in governmental expenditures and revision of methods of Federal taxation was expressed yesterday by former Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, Republican nominee for President in 1936.

The passenger list of the steamship Washington of the United States Lines which will leave tonight for the Channel ports includes: Colonel Frank Chappell, Miss Stella Andreva, Lady G. M. Drummond-Hay, Mrs. Lawrence T. Paul, George A. Armstrong, secretary of the United States Legation, Dublin; Miss Madeline Harn,

The Knickerbocker Greys, junior military organization, will hold their first review of the season at 4 P. M. today at the 107th (Old Seventh) Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street. Former members of the unit, which was founded in 1881, will be guests of honor.

Vermont's Republican State Committee voted unanimous endorsement today of Governor George D. Aiken's open letter last week demanding that the Republican National Committee purge itself of "reactionary elements."

Despite a definite weakness for flamboyant clothing, the average American man dresses in better taste than ever before, according to Captain John A. Murdocke of London, arbiter of what is correct in men's clothing, who arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
The Treasury sold today its last issue in the current series of bills at an average interest rate of 0.124 per cent, compared with 0.129 per cent last week and 0.119 the week before.

The National Maritime Union, which was created in May by a group that quit the International Seamen's Union in protest against its leadership, has voted to affiliate with the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was announced last night.

The interpretation of its rediscounting regulations issued by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System in its current monthly bulletin, which indicates that installment and other finance paper is now eligible for rediscount, was regarded in Wall Street as an inevitable consequence of the change in wording of the board's "regulation A," which was made known some weeks ago. However,

Pitt's first "paid" football player, Joseph C. Trees, now a millionaire oil producer, asserted at a banquet for the undefeated 1937 varsity team tonight that "subsidization is eminently sound and proper" and urged colleges to end "hypocrisy."
Lincoln A. Osborn of 2,770 Kingsbridge Terrace, playwright and former actor, died yesterday of heart disease in the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 58.
Don Budge, with all the decisiveness of one of his own overhead smashes, is ranked as the nation's No. 1 athlete of 1937.

An opportunity for President Roosevelt to help the railroad at the sacrifice of his previously announced intention of liquidating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as part of his economy program was afforded today when the Erie Railroad applied for a loan of $6,006,000 from the RFC.

Wilfrid Hill, member of the administrative council of the British National Union of Manufacturers, and president of the Comite International des Exchanges, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to confer with officials in Washington.

A House tax subcommittee decided today to try to prevent real estate construction companies from falling into the tax classification of personal holding companies and paying rates of 65 and 75 per cent.

Although retail trade in most sections of the country was reported quite fair last week, with Saturday a particularly good day, mail orders coming into the local wholesale markets yesterday did not show any appreciable improvement, manufacturers and resident buyers reported.

Joseph Malone, a trainer and second, who retired as a lightweight boxer fifteen years ago, died suddenly of a heart attack early yesterday morning in front of 640 Pelham Parkway South, Bronx, while waiting for a bus to take him to his home, 2,102 Tomlinson Avenue. He was 44 years old.

76th St, 22 W, 25X102.2; 22 W 76th St Corp (Mary Nagel, pres) to Gustav Walker, 521 5th Ave, et al, execrs, Clara, E Walker, 5 yrs, 5%; $24,000. 88th St, 339 E, 25x100.8; Rose A. Kaufman, to Fifth Ave Bank of N. Y., 530 5th Ave, trustee, 5 yrs; 4 1/2%; $12,000.

The goal-getting rush of speedy. George Mantha put the Montreal Canadien wingman in second place in the National Hockey League's scoring race during the past week. Six goals and an assists--five of the goals in two week-end games against the New York Americans-sent Mantha to within 3 points of Gordon Drillon of the Toronto Maple Leafs, who continues to set the pace.

Harry F. Wolf, veteran star of the Montclair Athletic Club, blasted his way to a convincing triumph over E. G. McLaughlin of the Columbia University Club in the final at the Harvard Club yesterday to capture the National Squash Tennis Association's Fall scratch tournament.

Major events today: Philadelphia Orchestra, led by Leopold Stokowski, at Carnegie Hall tonight; Ida Krehm, pianist, at the Town Hall in the afternoon, and Daniel Ericourt, pianist, at the Town Hall in the evening.
Beginning with Christmas the butter ration will be reduced to 85 per cent of the quantity consumed in October of this year, according to a Reich Food Administration order.
Rene A. Viosca, Federal attorney, said today that criminal charges brought against five men in connection with an alleged munitions shipment to Honduras had been dropped.

A warning that the issues involved in "the blood purges being reported almost daily" from Soviet Russia and in Moscow judicial "frame-ups" are being forced upon this country by Communist propa, gandists, and that the American people must be prepared to meet them, was given in a radio address last night by Dr. John Dewey.
Aaron Blumenthal, who observed his 101st birthday on May 4, died today at the Hotel Breakers, where he had lived for many years.

Trading was only fair in the wholesale markets yesterday. Slaughter house business was fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to lower; some sales year hindsaddles lower; lamb lower; fresh pork mostly steady to lower: other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be lower;

Mrs. Margaret Pikington, 70 years old, died of the effects of rat poison in New York Hospital at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and her grandson, Joseph Folsom, 15, who lived with her at 301 East Sixtyfourth Street, is critically ill in the hospital as a result of eating poisoned oatmeal.

Christian Boussus has regained his place as France's No. 1 tennis player. Top-ranking French player in 193435, the 28-year-old Boussus was displaced last year by long, lanky Bernard Destremeau, who was just old enough to vote.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. George Clement Holton of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Holton, to Dr. E. Bryon Master, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Master, also of Great Neck.

Another in the series of musical mornings conducted by Albert Morris Bagby took place yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was the 400th concert of the series, which was inaugurated in 1891 in the Rembrandt Studios, in West Fiftyseventh Street.
