There were twelve out in front when the Junior League gave a play at the Laura Franklin Delano Foundation yesterday afternoon. There were others, of course--society women, doctors and nurses, and a few adult patients.

Plenty of action marked the course of the twenty-second game of the chess championship match between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, the new champion, and Dr. Max Euwe. The full score of the contest, which lasted sixty-two moves, has reached here from Delft in The Netherlands.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone refused today to admit to the record in the government's gasoline pricefixing case, letters which were offered by the defense seeking to show that they had governmental approval for price-stabilization activities.

Miss Susanne Chase Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Lucius Hart, of Waterbury, Conn.; will be married to Philip Hale Conklin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leander Hale Conklin of New York and Madison, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Waterbury, the afternoon of Jan. 8.

Although daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas for the first eleven months of the current year were about 7 per cent above the same period of 1936, they were 3 1/2 per cent lower in November

The League of Nations, in a statement based on its 1937 Armaments Yearbook, out today, estimates that "world military expenditure in 1937 is almost three times as much as the amount spent annually In the pre-war period.
The Neediest Cases Fund was aided yesterday by 307 contributors whose joint efforts added $7,697.82 to its total. This brought the sum that has been raised thus far this year to $95,749.72.
Secretary Woodring approved today plans of supervisors of Nassau County, N. Y., for a bridge across Mill Neck Creek, near Bayville, N.Y.

On his promise to make restitu tior. to his victim, Isidor A. Rabinow, 45 years old, a lawyer of 317 West Fifty-fifth Street, was released on a suspended sentence yesterday by General Sessions Judge Freschi. Rabinow, on Nov. 24 last,
" Wine of Choice," a Theatre Guild production, opened tonight in the Erlanger Theatre with Miriam Hopkins and Leslie Banks in the central roles.
League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "An American Doctor's Odyssey," Dr. Victor G. Heiser. . "Outstanding Writers of Today," Eleanor, Markell, Hotel Plaza, A. M.
King George VI wilt observe his fortysecond birthday tomorrow at a small family luncheon party in Buckingham Palace.
Captain A. H. A. Baldridge, U. S. N. (retired), has been appointed curator of the Naval Academy Museum and will give his whole time to the work.

In the great city one's neighbor may live around the corner, in the next block or miles away. He is the person who is in greatest need. The welfare societies know where such neighbors live and have let us know without revealing their identity how they can be reached and helped in that need.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 30,000, including 11,000 directs. Closing active, market strong to 10 cents higher than Friday's average; spots up more on butchers 210-300 pounds. Top, $8.30; bulk good and choice 150-200 pounds,

Reports of a further Soviet "purge" involving a group of prominent persons reached London tonight through ordinarily well-informed quarters. While the reports are not verified from Moscow, they are current in Riga.

Mrs. Charles H. Stout entertained at dinner last night at Sherry's. Her guests included Dr. and Mrs. Merrell L. Stout of Baltimore, Mr. and Mrs. Prescott Evarts, Miss Virginia Stout and Gordon and Malcolm MacGregor.

Fully 95 percent of the Soviet Union's voters cast ballots in the election of the supreme Soviet yesterday, it was announced today by the Central Election Commission on the basis of preliminary estimates.

A unique collection of simian embryos showing for the first time the successive stages of development from the one-cell egg to the stages where the organs have attained their main features, providing the first direct observations of the animal with the closest anatomical resemblance to man, was described here today at the annual scientific exhibit of the Carnegie Institution of Washington.

King Farouk clashed anew with his Cabinet today, giving rise to fears of another political crisis. Tension resulted from the young monarch's rejection of the government's nominee for the Senate seat vacated by elevation of Maher Pasha to head the royal Cabinet as the King's adviser.

The Essex County grand jury for the September term closed its deliberations here today by returning seventeen more indictments in connection with the jury's investigation of the affairs of the city of Newark.

Acting at the request of Melvin M. Hawley, attorney for the trustees of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, Federal Judge William H. Holly authorized today the cancellation of an insurance policy for $1,550,000 held by the company on the life of Harley L. Clarke, former president.

Thomas J. Naughton has joined the management department of Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc. B. Charley Vladeck, City Councilman-elect, will discuss "Politics and Housing" at the New School for Social Research tomorrow night.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 10: COMMANDERS Benson, F. W., the Dale, to Board of Inspection and Survey, Pacllfc Coast Section Long Beach. Calif.
Fannie Hall MacCollin, once a well-known light opera prima donna and in recent years a guest at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood, died on Sunday. She was in her seventy-seventh year.

Contending that no increase in the fine for illegal parking was justified until the city had provided ample off-street parking facilities, Magistrate Frank Oliver protested yesterday against the increase from $1 to $2 in a letter to Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr.

Dr. George H. Scott, retired army colonel, of New Rochelle, N. Y., was found dead today of carbon monoxide gas in the garage of a friend, Adam H. Sarver, whom he had been visiting for two weeks. Police said he was overcome apparently while warming up the motor of an automobile.

The Rev. Dr. Elam M. Garton, for many years a member of the Newark Methodist Conference, who retired seventeen years ago, died tonight at his home here at the age of 89. He had. been in poor health since early in October.
It was John Howard Payne who almost wrote, 'Mid pleasures and palaces though we may roam, Be it ever so humble,

The New Deal won an important victory in its dollar-devaluation program today when the Supreme Court, in a six-to-three decision, sustained the power of the Treasury to call goldclause Liberty Loan bonds for redemption in currency without paying interest to their original date of maturity.

The fact that Thanksgiving volume was well above expectations has served to dispel the panicky feelings which spread among grocery retailers and wholesalers a short time ago, the American Institute of Food Distribution reported yesterday in its weekly survey of conditions in the food business.

Workmen who since last Thursday have been making extensive alterations in the District Attorney's nine-story building at Center and White Streets for the advent of Thomas E. Dewey on Jan. 1, disclosed yesterday that his present rackets bureau was not to be dismantled, but would be carried on as a separate entity.
Brooklyn's nine new Councilmen will get a lesson on their new duties Wednesday night at Borough Hall when they attend the final hearing this year of the borough's local improvement boards.

Before the largest gathering for an indoor fight here in two years, Max Schmeling, the German who wants to be the only man ever to regain the world heavyweight crown, knocked out sturdy Harry Thomas of Eagle Bend, Minn., in the eighth round of what was to have been a fifteen-round battle in Madison Square Garden last night.
Two funeral services, one in Washington and the other here, will be held for Mrs. Constance Schack Gracie, Colonel Archibald Gracie's widow, well, known in society, who died in Washington on Sunday.
Rome G. Hopkins said today that his brother, Harry L. Hopkins, National Relief Administrator, was "completely fagged out" and would have to rest for two or three months.

Snow and "glaze" storms slowed traffic in the Midwest tonight. Rain froze on roads in Illinois, Indiana, Missouri, Nebraska and parts of Iowa and Kentucky. Motorists were warned of "extremely hazardous" conditions.

Henry Newell Beers, in 655 Park Ave. through Ida Catlin: L. M. Brannon, Isaac Files, Elizabeth Mink, in 301 W 53d St; Alfred Partride Klots, in 1 W 67th St; Charles H. Herman, in 45 5th Ave; Willlam A. White Sons, brokers.

The first of the series of Coffee Dances for this season took place last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. Named for the custom of the subscribers taking their guests to the club for coffee and dancing after dinner parties, these dances have been held for many years.

James J. Braddock, former world heavyweight champion, is back in good standing with the State Athletic Commission for the first time since he ignored Max Schmeling as the title challenger and fought Joe Louis, to whom he lost the crown.
Eugene Weidmann this afternoon called in his three lawyers to tell them he had also killed Janine Keller, pretty Alsatian,

The Japanese Government has accepted full responsibility for the unwarranted attack on three American merchant vessels on the Yangtze River and the sinking of the gunboat Panay, with the attendant loss of American lives. The circumstances being what they are, no other course was possible.

The report of the Shawmut Bank Investment Trust for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 shows a net loss of $2,038, after including $39,330 net gain from sales of securities, after all expenses, charges and taxes.
Yale defeated Brown in hockey, 5 to 1; tonight to avenge last season's Bruin conquest. Kite, Gibson, Howe, Nagel and Gillispie scored for the Blue, with three goals falling in the initial period.

Members of Congress, municipal. officials and business men from New York and New England shoe centers urged the Tariff Commission today to grant a 50 per cent increase in duties on women's cemented shoes to protect the American industry from "cheap labor" competition abroad.
Various festivities to mark the holiday season will be held under the auspices of officers and members of the board of managers of the West Sixty-third Street Community House.

Senate Investigators asserted today that Kuhn, Loeb Co. profited in 1935 by having "inside information" on the intention of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad to petition for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Law.

Board of Trade figures for November, published today, show total imports of [Pound]97,250,000; exports of British products, [Pound]45,180,000; re-exports, [Pound]5,300.000; total exports, [Pound]50,480,000, and excess of imports, [Pound]46,770,000.

A special dividend of 50 cents was declared on the common stock by the Adams-Millis Corporation. American Brake Shoe Foundry The American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company declared a dividend of $1.40 a common share.

A bonus equivalent to almost an extra month's salary will be distributed by the Continental Oil Company to its employes out of 1937 earnings, Dan Moran, president, announced yesterday, Mr. Moran said that the company's business in 1937 will be the best in its history and "we are gratified to distribute this bonus in recognition of the contribution made by each employe."

Any voice that is raised, amid today's alarms of war and threats of war, to call for respect for moral principles in the relations of States to one another and of Governments to their peoples deserves to be heard.

The number of commercial failures in the United States in the week ended Dec. 9 showed increases in four groups, and a decline in the construction division, as compared with a year ago, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Specialty and novelty retailers accounted for many of the store leases announced yesterday by brokers and agents.
Members of the Senate Commerce Committee opened fire today on labor troubles at sea, asserting that the public was becoming afraid to ride on American ships.

The War Department announced today that Colonel George H. Scott of the army medical corps died yesterday in Detroit, where he was on leave after being stationed at Fort Slocum, N. Y. He was 58 years old.
Investment purchases again featured the Manhattan real estate market yesterday. Apartment properties furnished the bulk of the activity.

A legacy of $12,935.64, provided under the will of Miss Mary Alice Hutchins, helped swell the receipts for the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday to $24,128.54, the largest sum received in a single day this year and one of the largest in recent years.

The December grand jury indicted Mary Keenan O'Connor today on charges of murder and manslaughter in connection with the death of 5-yearold Nancy Glenn on Labor Day. Date of trial for the student, now free under $5,000 bail, was not announced.

Announcement of the formation of a legislative committee of the American Labor party to guide its delegations in the Assembly and the City Council was made yesterday by Alex Rose, State executive secretary.

The InterAmerican Radio Conference, which opened Nov. 1 with sixteen nations in attendance, closed last night following the signing of all the agreements reached concerning radio communication in the Americas.

John Oliver Thompson, 27-yearold elevator operator, was booked yesterday at the East Twenty-second Street Police Station on a charge of homicide after he approached a patrolman in the street and said he had just killed his wife, Delia, 24 years old, in his apartment at 221 East Twenty-sixth Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

Benjamin Hemley, a member of :he Hemley Supply Company, an importing firm at 95 Lorimer Street, Brooklyn, died suddenly yesterday morning while he was attending a meeting at the Downtown Athletic Dlub. Mr. Hemley was 55 years old.

Administration leaders in the House received a surprise today when the 218th signature was affixed to the discharge petition which will bring to the floor on Jan. 10 the Ludlow constitutional amendment to take away from Congress the power to declare war, except after a national referendum.

Miss Helen Blumer Howe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Denckla Howe of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to Walter H. Lippincott Jr. of Sydbury House, Wynnewood, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Lippincott.

Disturbed because Westchester County is maintaining many parcels of tax-free real estate here which are not used for county purposes, the City of White Plains has decided to levy taxes against the parcels and sue, if necessary, to collect them, it was announced today by Gustav E. Olson, White Plains Commissioner of Finance.
An industrial property comprising ten acres with various factory buildings at Lyndhurst, N. J., has been sold by Joseph P. Day to S. B. Penick Co. of New York, manufacturers of drugs and chemicals.

Seven persons-four of them women--were injured early this morning when a runaway Broadway trolley car jumped the tracks at 125th Street and crashed into a pillar supporting the I. R. T. subway structure.

Mrs. Ethel Iselin Goodridge, widow of Dr. Frederic Grosvenor Goodridge of Pomfret Center, died yesterday in a hotel in San Diego, Calif., after a brief illness at the age of 64. She- is survived by a son, Frederic Goodridge of San Diego, and two daughters, Mrs. Thomas H. Barber and Miss Helen I. Goodnnridge of Pnmfret Center.

The arrangement under which Federal unemployment relief workers have been utilized to carry out most of the demolition work in recent years on outmoded tenements in New York probably will be continued, since this type of work is retained in the WPA list of approved projects despite curtailment of the Federal agency's program.

Brig. Gen. John Miller Carson, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Carson celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage at a reception given yesterday afternoon by their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Holt, at their home, 45 East. Sixty-sixth Street.

Guatemala has adopted the American plan for low-cost housing, and a system is being worked out for construction of small and medium-sized houses on land owned by a group of business men, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The Senate Banking Committee sent the new housing program to a subcommittee for study today after a stormy session in which Senator Wagner offered to resign from the committee chairmanship.

More than 2,000 relatives and guests, including many veterans of the unit, saw the Knickerbocker Greys, junior cadet military organization, hold its annual Christmas drill yesterday at the 107th (Old Seventh) Regiment Armory, Sixtysixth Street and Park Avenue.

With tomorrow set as the "deadline" for submitting written suggestions to the Committee- for Reciprocity Information regarding items which might be included in negotiations for a trade agreement with Great Britain, importers yesterday sent more than a score of suggestions to Washington.

Trading was fair to slow. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to weak; veal and calf steady to lower; lamb and fresh pork mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and lamb to be weak; calf and veal strong as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

MANHATTAN BAADE, MARGARET (Oct. 26. 1937). Gross assets, $8,198: net, $7,036. To Arthur McGowan, grandnephew, $2,093; William J. Baade, Joseph F., Peter 3., and John T. McGowan, nephews, one-fifth residue each; four grandnephews share one-fifth residue. Chief assets, mortgages. notes, cash and insurance, $8,198. Joseph Schwartzman, attorney, 551 5th Ave.

With the selection of Sammy Baugh, Cliff Battles and Glenn (Turk) Edwards on the All-League team, based on the voting of the ten coaches in the National Football League, the champion Washington Redskins gained the largest representation on the honor team of the professional circuit.

The W. Sergeant Bouvier Memorial Cup of Columbia College has been awarded to Henry S. Wheeler of Amsterdam, N. Y., a sophomore, who was a member of last season's freshman crew, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes.
The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company on Nov. 22 redeemed $500,000 of notes held by five banks in Chicago, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, made public yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Frances Holliday Melitzer of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Amelia Franklin Holliday, to S. Richard Silbert, son of Mrs. Meyer Silberstein of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Silberstein.

Distillers and distributors of liquors moved promptly yesterday to prevent a new retail price war, following a decision of Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook refusing to enjoin temporarily the Nussbaum Liquor Store, Inc., 61 Cortlandt Street, from selling Seagram, Calvert and Schenley products below the prices fixed by the distillers.

John Blair Co., national radio station representatives, will open a new office in Seattle, Wash., Jan. 1, according to an announcement made today by John Blair, president. The office will be in charge of Dick McBroom.

The Ohio Bell Telephone Company is planning a 1938 expansion program amounting to more than $17,000,000, Randolph Edie, president, announced yesterday. During the current year the company spent about $14,000,000 for the same purpose.
With four seeded players winning yesterday, the Fall B and C squash tennis tournament at the City Athletic Club will go into the semifinals tomorrow without any upsets having been recorded.

Miss Ida Krehm, who made her New York debut as a pianist at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon, had been preceded by the recognition that came from having won three prizes in one season. Her appearance here was her award from the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation.

Paul Sifton, administrator of the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the Department of Labor, issued a statement yesterday correcting an error that appeared Monday in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Washington Redskins, champions of the National Football League, are considering a series of exhibition games on the Pacific Coast.
League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "The World Abroad," James G. McDonald.

In Yugoslavia, which today signed a highly favorable trade agreement with France made under the pressure of political events in Southeastern Europe, national economy and national finance are dark mysteries impenetrable not only to foreigners but to ordinary Yugoslavs.

Staging a rally late in the fourth quarter, the Evander Childs High five topped DeWitt Clinton, defending city P. S. A. L. champion, 25-20, in an Upper Manhattan-Bronx P. S. A. L. game on the loser's court yesterday.

The conferences between President Roosevelt and public utility executives, looking toward a truce between the government and private power interests, will be resumed next week, the President disclosed this afternoon.
The twenty-eighth annual meeting of the Chase Bank Club, a social organization of employes of the Chase National Bank, was held last night in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Winthrop W. Aldrich,

In this capital, as presumably in London, an air of unreality surrounds the announcement ir Shanghai dispatches that the Japanese were hopeful of driving a wedge between the United States and Great Britain in the Far East, and therefore are particularly downcast by the bombing of the American gunboat Panay.
Constitutional differences between King Farouk and the Cabinet approached a climax today when the Cabinet gave the monarch ten days to approve bills voted recently by Parliament.
Manhattan's inexperienced basketball team lost to St. Francis Co1lege's deft band of veterans, 37 to 23, at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. At half time the visitors led, 17 to 10. .

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today that fears of a "slump" were "not only exaggerated but dangerous," but failed to rule out the possibility of a "temporary decline in trade." His statement, which is the nearest that responsible quarters have yet come to admitting that Great

Descendants of men who fought under Washington and of women who gathered at near-by Bullet Hill to cast slugs for their husbands' muskets decided in the white-walled Community House today that they would not brook a Nazi camp in their backyard.

The Laundry Wage Board was Informed by the State Department of Labor yesterday that a working woman in New York.State requires an annual income-of $1,078.95 for "adequate maintenance and protection of health," if living with her family; and $1,215.73 if she lives alone.

The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace is distributing several hundred copies of Livingston Hartley's "Is America Afraid?: A New Foreign Policy for the United States" (Prentice-Hall) to university and college students.

Representative Celler of New York today sent to the Federal Trade Commission what he said were details supporting his charge that certain trade groups had made alleged efforts to force the withdrawal of magazine articles on price fixing from newsstands.

Robert McDowell, vice president of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation, testified in Federal court today that a gasoline-buying program of major oil companies in 1935 and 1936 was not a price-fixing scheme. He is one of thirtyseven individual defendants on trial with sixteen oil companies on charges of conspiring to violate the Sherman Anti-Trust Act by raising and fixing prices.

The three children of the late James E. O'Neill, wealthy oil operator who figured as a fugitive witness during the Teapot Dome oil trials, are suing the National City Bank for an accounting of alleged losses of nearly $3,000,000 on a $5,000,000 trust fund created by their father in 1928 for their benefit after his death.

The "Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Robinson" who disappeared mysteriously in Moscow early this month have been found by State Department investigating agents to have been traveling on fraudulent passports, and the department does not know who they are or whether they are United States citizens.

Countess Haugwitz - Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, arrived yesterday afternoon on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to spend the Christmas holidays with her father, Franklin L. Hutton. As usual her name was not on the passenger list, but was Included only in the official list for customs and immigration officials.

The usual atmosphere of gayety and fun was displaced by one of sorrow yesterday afternoon at a gathering of members and guests of the Circus Saints and Sinners Club. In meetings of the past, the East Ballroom of the Hotel Commodore, where the group assembles monthly, has rung with laughter and jokes.

J. Cuthbert Wigham of Gloucester England, has announced the engagement of Gloucester, England, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Hazel K. Wigham, to William F. Brinton, son of Mr. And Mrs. David Brinton of West Chester, Pa.

Registrations of visiting buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday were well below the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings published in THE TIMES.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight gave the first state dinner of the season, entertaining in honor of the members of the Cabinet. There were 80 guests at dinner and more than 200 at a musical afterward in the East Room.
Like a slowly developing film in a dark room, the story of the horrors, privations and dangers undergone by the Panay survivors was slowly becoming discernible today.

The latest "gold-clause" decision of the Supreme Court turned on the question whether the Treasury had the power to call gold-clause Liberty Loan bonds for redemption in currency without paying interest to their original date of maturity.

Mrs. William J. Hutchinson and Mrs. Woodin Miner entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's. Their guests included Mrs. Linn M. A. Evans, Mrs. Edgar M. Williams, Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin, Mrs. Townsend Morgan,
Michael E. Reiburn, 44 years old, a former Tammany State Senator from Washington Heights and disbarred lawyer, was found guilty yesterday in General Sessions in a ten-year-old theft from a client.

Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade postponed today hearing of charges against the Cargill Grain Company of Illinois for the latter's failure to obey an order of the business conduct committee of the Exchange in the September corn squeeze. The trial, originally scheduled for Dec. 21, was postponed until Jan. 25.

The number of gifts to date in this year's United Hospital Campaign has already exceeded by nearly 7,000 the total number of gifts last year, John W. Davis, campaign chairman, announced yesterday. The day's list of contributions was headed by one of $10,000 from the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company.

The Panama American calls attention to the progress of a campaign to boycott Japanese goods. The Department of Commerce and Industries reports an average monthly decrease of more than $100,000 in imports from Japan in August, September and October.
Funeral services for E. Clifford Potter, real estate operator who died in Tucson, Ariz., on Saturday, will be held at 2 P. M. today in St. Bartholomew's Church, Fifty-first Street and Park Avenue.

Metropolitan skiers, particularly beginners, better known as "toe trappers" will be glad to hear that officials of the Department of Parks of New York City will do everything within their power to make conditions suitable for skiing once sufficient snow falls.

Officials at Johns Hopkins Hospital said today an exploratory operation on Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to Great Britain, disclosed "an inflammatory condition' of the abdomen but nothing malignant, nothing cancerous."

The essential grounds for the formal protest which our Government sent to Tokyo are clearly stated in its note: The American ships which were bombed by Japanese airplanes in the Yangtze River were in that river by "uncontested and incontestable right."
The Grace liner Carabobo, which radioed a call for assistance because of damaged boilers early yesterday morning, was reported later under tow.
The ban on political processions in the East End of London, which was originally intended as a temporary measure, is to be renewed for another three months.

Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that he would like to institute a progressive system of traffic lights to speed traffic through the crosstown streets of Manhattan, but explained that the heavy flow of north and south traffic made it impracticable from an engineering standpoint.
John T. Ross, '39, of Chicago today was elected president of the Princeton University Ski Club for the remainder of the academic year, the elections committee of the undergraduate council announced.

UNCLE SAM'S couriers today are making their appointed rounds loaded down with bulky envelopes from the offices of Edward B. Moss. The call for the annual-meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association has gone forward to the delegates, and on Jan. 15 these unfortunate gentlemen must tear themselves away from all that is dear to them to answer the summons to duty in Miami Beach.
Mrs. Jane Bell D'Korsakoff, well known in New York and Baltimore, died yesterday in her home at Sharp Point, near Annapolis, at the age of 64.

7th Ave, 371-7, 88.3x200.6x irreg: Governor Clinton Co (George Frankenthaler, president) to Connecticut Mutual Life Ins Co; ten years, 4 1/2%; $750.000. 9th Ave, 282, 22x98; Canajoharie Holding Corp (William Jacobus, president) to Hugh M. Reeves, 87-08 85th St, Queens; p mtg $15,000, 3 years, 6% $8,500.

Miss Marie McRae Smith, granddaughter of Colonel Milton A. McRae of the Scripps-McRae (later Scripps Howard) newspapers, was married to Lieut. Commander T. C. Conway Lloyd of the Royal Navy today at St. Clement Danes Church here.

The faint possibility of joint Anglo-American measures against Japan at the present time faded away almost completely tonight in view of Great Britain's unwillingness to take lone risks in the Far East and the United States' apparent refusal to be drawn into concerted action with other powers.

" Pinocchio," the puppet that wanted to be human, will provide the basis for Walt Disney's next feature-length cartoon, replacing the scheduled "Bambi." Like "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," which will be unveiled

Air-transport leadership across the Atlantic, the leading mail, passenger and express route of the world, was foreseen for the United States yesterday by William H. Coverdale, president of American Export Lines.

Mayor La Guardia made two admirable appointments yesterday when he named Alfred Rheinstein and Edward F. McGrady to membership on the New York Housing Authority. He made another when he designated Mr. Rheinstein also as head of the new Department of Housing and Building, a salaried post created under the new city charter.

Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division took under advisement yesterday an application made by- the merchants in Paddy's Market for a temporary stay of their scheduled eviction on Saturday from stands along Ninth Avenue between Forty-second and Thirty-ninth Streets.

Business in Great Britain has shown a marked upturn, G. Russell Chapman, general secretary of the Advertising Association of Great Britain, said yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by the Advertising Federation of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A boar hunter's chance discovery of a skeleton chained to trees in Feuillerote Forest near here has started an investigation that may solve the mystery of the disappearance of a German philosopher, Dr. Heinrich Hellmund, a 42-year-old Jewish refugee from Hamburg, who has not been heard of since the end of June.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 34,000, including 8,000 directs. Market uneven, steady to 10 cents lower than Monday's average;

Mrs. Harris Fahnestock gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 15 East Sixty-sixth Street, for Miss Helen Michalis, debutante daughter of Clarence G. Michalis and granddaughter of Mrs. John Hubbard, sister of Mr. Fahnestock.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York turned back Princeton, 4-1, tonight in the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink before 500 persons and thereby gained revenge for a 7-1 trouncing sustained against the collegians less than a fortnight ago.

Dr. Theodore J. Curphey, pathologist at Meadowbrook Hospital, Hempstead, will serve as county medical examiner after Dec. 31 when the new Nassau County charter becomes effective, it was announced today after a meeting of the Board of Supervisors.
The Harvard Club moved into a tie for the league lead in Group I of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B interclub matches last night by defeating the Squash Club, 3 to 2.

Lord Tennyson's touring cricket eleven today won the second unofficial cricket test match against a representative Indian team by six wickets. The first encounter went to the English players by a nine-wicket margin.

Japan was formally called upon to give full satisfaction for her attack on the United States gunboat Panay and three Standard Oil ships on the Yangtze River above Nanking, as well as adequate assurances for future avoidance of such incidents, in a stern note of protest dispatched by Secretary of State Cordell Hull late last night.

The New York Rangers had little trouble with the Detroit Red Wings last night. The Patrickmen defeated the hapless world champions by the score of 3 to 1 in Madison Square Garden, while a crowd of 11,000 persons looked on.

The Colombian Petroleum Company, controlled jointly by the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and the Texas Corporation has sold $15,000,000 of 3 per cent notes to a group of life insurance companies, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Colgate won its second straight basketball game tonight, beating St. Lawrence, 44-41. Byrnes, of the visitors, led the scoring with 13 points. Cliff Clinton, former Lynbrook (L. I.) star, gave Colgate the scoring punch necessary to come from behind and win.
Dance International will today inaugurate an "Isadora Duncan Week" at its exhibition of art objects related to the dance in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. In observance of the tenth

Willie Hoppe, world's 18.1 balkline and cushion-carom billiard champion, won two exhibition matches at the New York Athletic Club last night. Playing against two Winged Foot members, Hoppe defeated Edgar T. Appleby, holder of the world amateur 18.1 crown, 150-91, in ten innings in an 18.2 engagement and Edward Lee. world amateur threecushion titleholder, 25-24, in twenty-nine innings in a three-cushion game.

Nine bids on a contract for planting and seeding along Grand Central Parkway, between the Long Island Railroad and Horace Harding Boulevard in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens, fitting in with the planting to be done by the World's Fair Corporation, have been opened by the Department of Parks, it was announced yesterday.

The stock market here is anxiously watching developments in the Far East, so trading conditions were extremely quiet today, with prices sagging in several sections. Gilt-edge issues were lower, while foreign loans were weaker on the whole.

A theory that the man who murdered Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter, 32-yearold widow, and beat Mary Griffin, 22-year-old manager of Mrs. Carpenter's beauty parlor, was known to the household was advanced tonight by Dr. A. J. Craig of Fort Washington, first physician to examine the body of Mrs. Carpenter.

Since diphtheria has been showing a gradual weekly increase in the number of cases recently, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, appealed yesterday for "every unimmunized child" in the city to be inoculated with the department's protective toxoid without further delay.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Corcoran of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Annette B. Corcoran, to Charles T. Crowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. J. Crowley of Elizabeth. Mr. Crowley's father is city treasurer of Elizabeth.

Adoption of the city's new Administrative Code by the Assembly N at Albany tomorrow is seriously jeopardized by the threatened refusal of a group of Democratic As- T semblymen from New York City to vote for the code until they are convinced that it will not displace Tammany jobholders in the county offices, it was learned last night.

Vegetable growers were asked to give "serious thought" to the effect which chain store tax legislation will have upon their business in an address delivered by Earl R. French, national promotion director of the Atlantic Commission Company, produce buying subsidiary of A. P., before the twentyninth annual convention of the Vegetable Growers Association of America, Inc., at the Hotel New Yorker.
Chinese today reported the death of Admiral Osami Nagano from injuries received when fifteen Chinese bombers sank the battleship Nagato on Nov. 24 near Kiangyin.

Pensioned On their own applications: LIEUTENANT-Louis Mensching, Juvenile Aid Bureau, at $2.000 per annum. Ap pointed Sept 22, 1896. PATROLMEN-Augustine L. Costello, 15th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointee July 29, 1904. William J Nammack, 18th Division M. O. D. D., at S1,500 per annum. Ap pointed Feb. 27, 1896.

Dr. Jacob J. Taubenhaus, one of the most widely known and active plant pathologists in the United States, died on Monday at Bryan, Texas, after an illness of several months. Frequently a visitor here, Dr. Taubenhaus was chief of the Division of Plant Pathology and Physiology of the Texas Agricultural Experiment Station. His age 1 was 52.

The Amateur Athletic Union yesterday released a circular letter forwarded to the officers and chairmen of registration and hockey committees of all the district associations in the country clarifying the present amateur ice hockey setup.

The Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted today to report favorably the nominations of John Wesley Hanes, member of the brokerage firm of Charles D. Barney Co., and Jerome N. Frank, former general counsel of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, as members of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A buffet supper was given tonight by Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff at Cas Marcheta for members of the Romany Chorus and Orchestra, board members and sponsors of the organization and several additional friends. One hundred guests attended.
The volume of Christmas mail this year apparently will exceed that of a year ago by at least 5 per cent, according to present indications, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

The former A. J. Reach Company factory at Tulip, Palmer and Eyre Streets, Philadelphia, has been sold by A. G. Spalding Brothers, who for many years have used it for the manufacture of sporting goods. An investing client of the Cross Brown Company was the purchasers
William Johnson Harahan, president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, died here late today. He would have been 70 years old on Dec. 22.
Enrico Venturi, rugged Italian lightweight, gained the decision over George Zengaras, Harlem battler, in an exciting eight-round battle before 11,000 fans at the New York Coliseum last night.
Charles Henry Dorr, a former newspaper man and for many years owner of the Dorr News Syndicate, died on Monday of a heart attack at 'his home, 331 West Fourteenth Street.

Members of the New York Curb Exchange have been advised by the committee on securities that Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation $2.50 convertible preferred stock, second series, which will be issued as a dividend to holders of common stock on Dec. 24, is not the same

Drastic changes in the starting, classification and eligibility rules governing America's harness horse racing won the approval today of the three parent organizations ruling the trotters and pacers from coast to coast.

The one-year delayed national elections for provincial and city posts yielded a fresh victoryy for Quezon's political forces :n the basis of incomplete returns. Violence marked the polling in several provinces and at least five were killed and seven wounded in vicious political fights.

Ralph Greenleaf of New York will launch the defense of his world's pocket billiard championship in a 1,500-point challenge match against young Irving Crane of Livonia,N. Y., tonight at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy, Broadway and Fifty-second Street.
By WILLIAM KENNELLY 74th St, 9 E, 5-story dwelling, 20x102.2: Mutual Life Insurance Co of N. Y. against 9 East 74th St Corp; due, $97,740; to plaintiff for $10,000.

Quinlax Cold Tablets, new product of Vadsco Sales Corporation, will be promoted by an extensive newspaper and radio campaign. Beginning Sunday, Jan. 9, Vadsco takes over sponsorship of the radio series, "The Court of Human Relations," over nineteen stations of the Mutual network.

Max Schmeling was $30,000 richer yesterday, with nothing more unpleasant than a slight bruise around his right eye as a memento of his battle with rugged Harry Thomas in Madison Square Garden Monday night.

A benefit for Don Marquis, the author, who has been seriously ill at intervals for several years, will be given by his friends in a New York theatre next month, it was said yesterday by Harry E. Maule of Doubleday, Doran Co., Mr. Marquis's publishers.
" Rehabilitation" of Tammany Hall and other regular Democratic: organizations within this city is the objective of a new movement that got under way yesterday.

That france will approve and support whatever action is taken by the United States and Great Britain to maintain respect for international law in the Far East was made clear today in official quarters, but it is only to be expected that the French will not take the initiative in any action. It is felt here as in London

Winning six of eight events, Princeton's varsity swimming team today scored a 4224 victory in Brokaw Pool at the expense of an all-star aggregation composed of Nassau freshmen and Hun School and Trenton High School stars.

The J. G. White Engineering Corporation has obtained a contract for construction of a 20,000 kilowatt-hour power plant for Venezuelan Oil Concessions, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch-Shell group operating in Venezuela, it was announced yesterday by the engineering company.

Leopold Stokowski made his last appearance in New York this season as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra yesterday evening in Carnegie Hall. A large and a brilliant audience gathered for him and enthusiastically applauded his brilliant leadership and his magnificent band.
Alfred Rheinstein, a building contractor, and Edward F. McGrady, former Assistant Secretary of Labor, were named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as new members of the New York City Housing Authority.
The Spanish Government artillery bombarded Insurgent positions north of Madrid today, directing fire at convoys bringing fresh troops to the front.

Low prices featured the auction sale yesterday of fur coats conducted by Brill Brill, Inc., auctioneers, with much of the merchandise bringing "40 to 50 per cent or more" under previous regular prices.

ALDERDICE-Harry M.. suddenly, on Dec. 13; 1937, brother of William, of Montclair, N. J., and Arthur, of Des Moines, Iowa. Funeral services Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway and 66th St., Thursday, Dec. 16, 2 P. M.

Professor Harry Allen Overstreet, chairman of the Department of Philosophy at City College announced yesterday that Dr. Morris Raphael Cohen, former president of the American Philosophical Association, would retire from the college faculty at the end of this semester in January.

Paced by Ken Neubauer and Barney Hassett, the undefeated Manhattan Prep quintet recorded its fourth straight success by downing Loyola School, 49 to 15, in a nonleague game at the Manhattan College gymnasium yesterday.

The Kiwanis Club of Boston today voted unanimously to exclude Japanesemade toys from Christmas-gift bags to be given to underprivileged children. Raymond W. Leonard, Boston Coke Company official, who offered the motion, said:

The Chase National Bank headed the successful banking group of twenty-three members in the sale yesterday of a new issue of $10,000,000 of city of Chicago refunding bonds. The group bid 101.14 for 3s, for the bonds, which will be dated Jan. 1, 1938, and will mature serially from Jan. 1, 1941 to 1948, inclusive.
There was an attendance of sixtythree at the quarterly meeting yesterday of the delegates to the American Kennel Club. Admitted to membership were the followingnamed clubs:

Under a rule announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, public utility companies and their subsidiaries are exempted under the Public Utility Holding Company Act from the necessity of making declarations in respect to the endorsement or guarantee of installment paper received from customers in connection with the sale of appliances the purchase price of which does not exceed $1,000.
Lady Lister Kaye, in the Ambassador, Park Ave at 51st St. William Ravner, in 875 Park Ave: Mark O'Dea, in 325 E 57th St; George Kappes, in 31 Park Ave; Brett Wyckoff, Inc, brokers.

The Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239, affiliated with the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, a C. I. O. organization, began yesterday the circulation of petitions to be addressed to the State Labor Department for the setting up of an impartial board to determine minimum wage standards for women and children in the cleaning and dyeing industry.
Swamp Angel, a gelding owned by Clyde Troutt, scored his second straight victory in the Mandeville Purse, mile and seventy-yard feature at the Fair Grounds today.

Unless we are greatly mistaken, a few little villages in New Jersey will be overcrowded this week-end and a certain area on Route 39 in the southern part of the State will present something of a traffic problem Friday morning.

President Eamon de Valera stated tonight that the Irish Free State was now recognizing the annexation of Abyssinia by Italy and that the new Irish Minister to Rome would be accredited to the King of Italy as King, and Emperor of Ethiopia.

2d St, 240 E; to 6-story tenement and stores; Louis J. Shapiro, 262 E 4th St, owner; James McKillop, architect; cost, $7,000. 2d Ave, 2,290; to 5-story tenement and stores; Elena Arpaia, premises, owner; De Rose Cavalieri, architects; cost, 5,500.

The special committee on expansion, recently appointed by the committee in charge of the bureau of advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, has completed a presentation tp be used in a major campaign for new members and a greatly increased budget for the bureau, it was announced yesterday.

Miss Cornelia R. Lum of Chatham, N. J., riding instructor for two years at Stoneleigh-Prospect Hill School for Girls, died late last night at the Franklin County Hospital from injuries received in the morning when her horse slipped on the ice and she was thrown. She did not regain consciousness.

3d Ave. 3,373, 3-story tenement, 25x80.6; Guaranty Trust Co of N Y, trustee, against Julius Calden: due. 513.064; taxes, etc. $80; to plaintiff for $9.000. Broadway, w s, 150 a 240th St, 2-story garage, 75x163 Irregular; Mortgage Commission of New York against Independent Builders, Inc; due, 5121.101; taxes, , S13.431: to plaintiff for $1.000.

Because of the steadily widening gap between the rate of industrial activity and prices of stocks in the early part of this year, the recent decline in security values "is perfectly normal" and brings share prices into line with business conditions, Dr. Daniel Starch, head of

A heart attack was fatal to Colonel Levy M. Hathaway, 60, former chief surgeon of the army air corps, at his home here tonight. A native of Owensboro, Colonel Hlathaway was a World War veteran, serving in France as chief surgeon of the Ninth Army Corps.
Mr. and Mrs. Craig Colgate will give a dinner in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for their debutante daughter, Miss Henrietta Colgate, on Feb. 4 before the final Junior Assembly of this season.

Joseph D. Flick, who had been superintendent of the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled for the last twenty years, died yesterday at his residence, 327 East Forty-second Street, after an illness of six months. He was born in Belgium sixty-five years ago.

The report of the Atlas Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, made public yesterday, indicates a net asset value of $13.36 a share for the common stock at the close of the period, compared with $18.17 a share on July 31, 1937, and with $18.77 a share on Oct. 31, 1936.

A ruling in favor of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 79, A. F. of L. affiliate, was rendered yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board when it certified the brotherhood as the collective bargaining agency of production employes in the electrical, gas distribution, staff and commercial departments of the Central New York Power Corporation. with headquarters in Syracuse.
Bud Williamson, Glendale, with a 65, clipped five strokes from par today and led the way through the first round of the annual Southern California open golf championship over the Clover Field course.

Speaking before about 300 students and faculty members of Union College at the International Relations Club meeting tonight, Fritz Kuhn, German American Bund leader, gave up the platform after he had attempted to answer questions put by students, and pleaded that William Kunze, his "director of public enlightenment" answer the remaining questions of the forum part of the meeting.
Italian press reports today on the bombing of the United States Gunboat Panay, in which one Italian was killed and two reported wounded, treated the incident as an "accident."

Ignoring President Roosevelt's demand that Farm-Bill costs be held to $500,000,000 a year unless new taxes were imposed to cover any additional amount authorized, the Senate today rejected by a vote of 49 to 23 an amendment by Senator Vandenberg to limit expenditures under the measure to the half-billion.

J. B. Spencer has been elected a vice president of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company. He is president of the Ramapo Ajax Corporation, a subsidiary. James E. Scott and Frank Welsh have joined the trading department of Kennedy, Hall Co.
A celebration honoring Dr. Edgar Starr Barney for his halfcentury of service to the Hebrew Technical Institute was held last night in the auditorium of the institute. at 36 Stuyvesant Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Perry Thompson of Yonkers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret E. Thompson, to Alan Munro-Lindsay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Cameron Lindsay of Southport, England.

Joao Francisco Nascimento, who claims to be 135 years old and to have 410 descendants, will probably be candidate No. 1 to compensation for a large family under Article 124 of the new Brazilian Constitution. He says he was born in 1802.

Labor and industry were warned today by Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, that restrictive practices raising costs and diminishing production were responsible for the present decline in economic activity, and that a continuation of
The fifteen-story apartment building at 33 Fifth Avenue, corner of Tenth Street, is now 100 per cent rented. Meyer Steffens, Inc., are the agents.

The text of the United States note to Japan formally protesting the bombing of American war and commercial ships follows: The government and people ofthe United States have been deeply shocked by the facts of the bombardment and sinking of the U. S. S. Panay and the sinking or burning of the American steamers Meiping, Meian and Meisian by Japanese aircraft.
The New York A. C., Jackson Heights and Midston House were the victors last night in the Group I team contests of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association.

President Stenio Vincent of Haiti informed President Roosevelt tonight that efforts to settle the HaitianDominican -controversy through diplomatic channels did not appear to promise a speedy and practical solution.

Mme. Dusolina Giannini, operatic soprano, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa from a seven-months concert tour during which she sang in the principal cities on the Continent and in 1 London.

A denial that the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company had violated the Robinson-Patman Act in accepting brokerage fees was made before the Federal Trade Commission today by Caruthers Ewing, attorney for the respondents, who have been charged by the commission with accepting allowances, or discounts in lieu of brokerage, for which no service had been performed.

Miss Jane Allen Runyon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarkson Runyon of 730 Park Avenue and Camp Medamin, Upper St. Regis Lake, N. Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Lieutenant Thomas West Hammond, U. S. A., son of Mrs. Thomas West Hammond and the late Colonel Hammond.

Two large properties in New Jersey were reported yesterday by brokers as having changed hands. At Garfield, the two-story factory, formerly occupied by the Continental Baking Company on Maple Street near the Erie Railroad, was purchased by the J. L. B. Corporation of Newark.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Mayte Elizabeth Boylan and Peter Van Dyke Voorhees of New York were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had: 615-James L. Taulbee as admrr., etc., petr., v. Great Northern Railway Co. Motion for an extension of time within which to file brief opposing petition for writ of certiorari submitted for the respondent.

The six-story building at 10 West Fifty-sixth Street has been leased to Boue Souers, dealing in gowns and lingerie. The lessees occupied the neighboring building at 13 West Fifty-sixth Street for more than twenty-one years.

Dr. Charles R. Foster, associate superintendent of Pittsburgh schools in charge of secondary education and a nationally known educator, died today in the Cathedral of Learning a few minutes after he had collapsed of a heart attack as he was entering the Faculty Club dining room on the seventeenth floor. He was 58 years old.

The monthly rents for apartments in Harlem, especially in slum areas, are artificially higher than the costs for similar accommodations in any other part of the city, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post said yesterday before the New York State Commission on the Condition of the Urban Colored Population, sitting at 447 West 151st Street.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: President Roosevelt's retort in his press conference of Dec. 10 regarding the railroads was more adroit than responsive.

Former Assemblyman Albert J. Brackley, president of the Far Rockaway Regular Democratic Club, died on Monday night of a heart ailment in his home, 1,293 Brunswick Avenue, Far Rockaway. He was 63 years old.
Cooney Weiland rapped two goals home in the space of twelve seconds while his Boston team-mates were ending their three weeks' slump with a 3-1 victory over Toronto tonight before 15,000 fans.

Harriet Levin, Hunter college senior, has won the first prize of $40 in the Amelia Ottinger prize debate held at the college, it was announced today. Ruth F. Rosenthal and Sonia Steinman each received $30.

As a result of increasing interest shown by foreign concerns in securities of American utility and utility-holding companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission has adopted amendments to its rules under the Public Utility Holding Company
Major James O. Green Jr., who was on duty at army headquarters of the Panama Canal Department, died in Gorgas Hospital yesterday at the age of 43, the War Department was notified today.
The steamship President McKinley, bearing 453 passengers from the Dollar liner President Hoover, aground near Formosa, arrived at quarantine here this morning.

Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commanding general of the Second Corps Area, will decorate Major Benjamin T. Anuskewicz, Chemical Warfare Reserve, with the Soldier's Medal, the army's highest peacetime award for heroism, today at 10:30 A. M. at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.

The Jacob Wendell Scholarship of $500, given each year to a high scholar in the sophomore class and including an invitation to an annual Wendell family dinner in Boston, has been awarded at Harvard to Charles G. Swain of Wollaston, Mass. The scholarship is given as a prize, regardless of financial need.

Bonbright Co., Inc., in behalf of the underwriting group that offered $1,800,000 of Associated Telephone Company, Ltd., first mortgage 4 per cent bonds and 36,688 shares of cumulative preferred stock, announced yesterday that both issues have been versubscribed and the subscription books closed.
Queena Mario, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, is offering a competitive scholarship in voice, the examinations to be held Christmas week.

Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, announced last night that he had resigned as Kings County Public Administrator. The resignation, which becomes effective today, was sent to George A. Wingate, Kings County Surrogate, who has the appointive power.

Wallace Ave (15-4321), e s, 365 ft n of Lydig Ave, 200x100; also Wallace Ave, e s, 165 ft n of Lydig Ave, 200x100; Max Nisnewitz to Zobot Realty Corp, 2.160 Wallace Ave. 179th St (11-3221), n s, 135 ft e of Loring Pl, 35x116; Anna Miller to Khyber Realties, Inc, 1,355 Shakespeare Ave; mtg $12,000.

" Babes in Arms," the Richard Rodgers-Lorenz Hart musical show, will end its New York engagement on Saturday evening at the Majestic, and, instead of moving next week to the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, will go to Philadelphia, opening at the Forrest Street Theatre on Christmas night. It will have played 289 performances on Broadway.
The Federal grand jury aided Federal agents in their campaign to prevent ticket agents and agencies from escaping payment of taxes, by filing informations against several alleged offenders yesterday.
Japan is expected to place all the conquered provinces of China, including the Shanghai-Nanking area, under the new Peiping provisional government of the republic, established yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week amounted to 3,414,450 barrels, compared to 3,387,000 in the previous week, an increase of 27,45O, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 76,-

Police today found the body of Janine Keller, Strasbourg matron, in the exact spot indicated yesterday in the murder confession of Eugene Weidmann. In a cave in Fountainbleau Forest just outside Barbizon they discovered the body, barely covered by a thin layer of sand and dry Autumn leaves.

Adam M. Ganson, who was in charge of the construction of the Flatiron Building and Pennsylvania Station in New York, died in his home here today. He was a native of Scotland and lived here twentytwo years. He was 75 years old. Survivors are his widow. Mrs. Maria B. Ganson; two daughters and two sons.

Francis Joseph Batchelder of this place, said to have been the first student enrolled at Stanford University, died of a heart attack last night at Blawenburg, where he had gone on business. His age was 65. He was a certified public accountant, with offices at 11 Park Place, New York.

A testimonial dinner in honor of Mgr. John D. Roach, pastor of the Holy Spirit Roman Catholic Church in .the Bronx, will be held at the Hotel Commodore a week from tonight on the forty-ninth anniversary of his entry into the priesthood.

Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, predicted today that both industrial production and stock prices probably would average lower in 1938 than in 1936 and 1937. Wholesale prices also probably would be
Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the North Ger- f man Lloyd liner Europa was Dr. Edward Charles Schacht, brother of Hjalmar Schacht, president of the German Reichsbank in Berlin.

Several supper parties were given at Larue last night after the performance of "Barchester Towers" at the Martin Beck Theatre for the benefit of Metropolitan Junior Achievement, Inc. Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wheeler entertained for Mr. and Mrs. Albert P. Hinckley, Mr.

Officials of the borough of Fort Lee were directed in a peremptory writ of mandamus filed today in the Federal court clerk's office here to pay a Federal court judgment of $575,924.66 over a period of fifteen years. The judgment was obtained almost a year ago by holders of Fort Lee bonds in default.
Ed Walker retired as football coach at the University of Mississippi today, bringing to three the number of Southeastern Conference schools looking for new grid mentors.

Lee Warren, Imperial Airways official at Brindisi, has been obliged to leave Italy for throwing water onto the heads of a group of Fascisti who kept him and his wife awake by singing and shouting under his hotel window early in the morning.

Endorsement of the proposed equal rights amendment was voiced tonight by Senator Burke of Nebraska, Miss Vera Brittain, English author and lecturer, and Raymond Gram Swing, news writer, at the biennial conference session of the National Woman's Party.

United States Ambassador Joseph C. Grew presented to the Japanese Foreign Office last night demands for apologies, indemnification and punishment of those responsible for sinking the United States gunboat Panay and satisfactory assurances that attacks on Americans or American interests would not be repeated.

Led by Irving Torgoff, who tallied 19 points, the Long Island University basketball team won, 73 to 35, from the University of Newark on the Brooklyn Pharmacy court last night. The Blackbirds led at half time, 36 to 16.
Dr. and Mrs. John G. Humphrey of this city have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Margaret Esher of Montclair, to Franklin Everett Standish of Pittsburgh.

The demand of the Electric Bond and Share Company for a test of the constitutionality of the registration provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act reached the Supreme Court for the second time today. The government is expected to join in the request for a speedy determination of the issue in which the lower courts decided against the company.

Dissension among advocates of wages and hours legislation, which threatens to scuttle the measure now before the House, broke into the open today amid greater bitterness than ever before, as the chamber completed general debate and made ready for the consideration of amendments.

Japanese naval authorities issued this afternoon an informal suggestion directed to the United States and British naval chiefs in China waters to the effect "that since an extension of hostilities along the Yangtze corridor was possible" it might be found that the most practical method of avoiding further tragic incidents would be for all American and British vessels to be removed from the danger zone.

Two hurlers, a southpaw and a right-hander, each struggling along the comeback trail, stormed the heights of baseball fame in 1937 in one of the most remarkable exhibitions of form reversals seen in years, according to the official American League pitching records announced yesterday.
Steel ingot output eased further last week, although the seasonal factor was unchanged and the adjusted index receded to 43.0 from 46.1. It stood at 122.2 for the week ended Dec. 12, 1936.

Max Schmeling's popularity, particularly with the Brown Shirts, now knows no bounds. The German heavyweight's success with the American fight crowd at Madison Square Garden has attracted more attention than his victory over Harry Thomas, of whom little is known here.
Holding hands and prolonged handshakes are looked upon with disfavor by the local sanitary authorities, although handshaking both at meeting and on parting is a universal custom in Latin America.

Recent Federal proposals to encourage home building are having a beneficial effect on lots sales at Atlantic Beach, L. I., according to Joseph P. Day and William L. Austin Jr., agents, who reported yesterday two group purchases inevolving seventy-nine plots for improvement with residences.

Victor in the closest battle of ballots in the history of The Associated Press' year-end polls, Miss Katherine (Kitty) Rawls, young Florida aquatic ace, yesterday was adjudged the No. 1 feminine athlete of 1937.

The beauty and gayety of the Christmas season, expressed in the charm and grace of figure skating, will be brought to Madison Square Garden Dec. 20 to 24 by the "Ice Follies of 1938," the largest skating troupe touring the country.

Corn futures advanced as much as 1 3/4 cents a bushel at the extreme on the Board of Trade here today on reports indicating shipments had been made out of here all rail to the seaboard for export to Europe.

Miss Jean Powrie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Powrie of Copenhagen, Denmark, formerly of Waukesha, Wis., was married today to Dr. David Tolmie of Tuxedo Park at Rock Ledge, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Chisholm.
Rental activity in the Rogers Peet Building, 485 Fifth Avenue, reported by Leonard J. Beck, Inc., agents, yesterday has completed the leasing of that structure.

Freddie Lindstrom, one-time Giant star who subsequently wandered into various pastures and eventually ended his major league career with the Dodgers in 1936, returned yesterday to the Giant organization when it was announced he had accepted Manager Bill Terry's offer to join the Jersey City club.

Determined to make the party's policy-writing committee thoroughly representative, the Republican National Committee's executive committee decided today to increase from 100 to 200 the number to be selected for the group to draft a platform, and to include in its membership all elements.
The Italian Pugilistic Federation today suspended former world heavyweight champion Primo Carnera from further fights abroad because of his recent showings.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 13, unless specified: At San Diego: Brazos, Dec. 14; Holland, Neches. Lynnhaven Roads to sea, Dec. 14, Jacob Jones, Leary. Acushnet, at Lynnhaven Roads, Dec. 14. Antares, at Quantico, Dec. 14.

An effort will be made by the Twenty-third Street Association to obtain an amendment to the National Housing Act which would aid residential development in urban central areas, it was disclosed yesterday at a meeting of the association at the George Washington Hotel.

The emergency court here trying the Jewish shipping operator, Arnold Bernstein, under the exchange laws charged him today with the intention of leaving Germany and becoming an American citizen and perhaps changing. the registry of his lines. He denied the charge.
Oliver A. Thayer, 24, son of a retired fuel dealer, shot and killed his sister, Katherine, 32, in their home here tonight and probably fatally wounded his aunt, Miss Alice Thayer, 72.

Shipments of wheat from Fort William and Port Arthur in the season of navigation on the Great Lakes, which was closed on Dec. 9, were reported today by E. A. Ursell, statistician to the Board of Grain Commissioners, as 89,230,890 bushels, compared with 166,809,142 in the previous season, a decrease of 77,578,252.

Following dissolution of Brazil's political parties, President Getulio Vargas by a new decree has ruled that the dissolved parties may operate as cultural or sporting groups only by permission of the Ministry of Justice.

The Treasury announced today the allotment of $512,544,450 in cash subscriptions and $260,768,000 in exchanges of the 2 1/2 per cent bonds and 1 3/4 per cent notes offered in cash and in exchange for about $276,600,000 of Treasury 2 5/8 per cent notes maturing on Feb. 1. The maturing notes not exchanged will be paid off in cash out of the general fund.
Stub Allison, coach of California's Golden Bears, promised today that "we won't monkey with our system or try a lot of fancy new stuff" in the Rose Bowl football game with Alabama New Year's Day.

George A. Stafford Sr., a cotton exporter living at 18 East Eighteenth Street and one-time commodore of the Stamford Yacht Club, died at Flower Hospital yesterday at the age of 70 after an illness of two months.
The general conclusions of the committee of inquiry into French production were handed today to Premier Camille Chautemps by the committee's president, Georges CahenSalvador.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 11: Vogelsang, Comdr. W. A., Med. Corps, Newport, R. I., to the staff of the Commander of Battle Force, as Force Surgeon, about March 1. Allen, Lt. G. W., the Vega, to command the Quail.
The War Department today released the following orders, dated Dec. 13: Burnett, Brigdr. Gen. C., Chief of the Bureau of Insular Affairs, one day leave, Dec. 14.
The Eleventh Congressional District today elected State Representative Thomas F. Flaherty, 39, a New Dealer, to fill the seat vacated by John P. Higgins, Democrat.

Japanese -Army, Embassy and Navy spokesmen mysteriously profess an utter lack of information regarding conditions in Nanking, although nearly two days have elapsed since the city was completely occupied, according to their claims.

Miss Elinor Ladd, daughter of Mrs. Payson McL. Merrill of this city and Syosset, L. I., and of William F. Ladd, will be married to William Ladd Storey on Dec. 29 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr. George P.

Sweeping revision of the requirements for licenses in the New York City school system, with. greater emphasis on teaching experience and less on written examinations, was announced yesterday in a joint report issued by the Board of Education and the Board of Examiners.

Dartmouth's basketball team found little opposition in Norwich tonight, rolling up a 75-16 score over the cadets. Coach Osborne Cowles started his second team and this group, paced by George Hanna, was in front, 25-4, when the varsity took over.

Because of complaints about the price and quality of police uniforms the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association voted yesterday to ask the State Legislature for permission to establish a cooperative for the manufacture of police uniforms.

A reduction of 25 per cent in the Federal income tax in -the higher brackets was recommended yesterday by State Controller Morris S. Tremaine at a conference of the American Management Association for financial executives in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

President Roosevelt discussed the Far Eastern situation with Secretary Hull; awarded the Schiff Trophy for safety in the air to Commander Robert Fuller of the V. P. Squadron No. 7, of the Fleet air base at San Diego; held his regular press conference, and, with Mrs. Roosevelt, was host tonight at the annual Cabinet dinner at the White House.

THE CHRISTMAS FESTIVAL, by Kirsopp Lake. (Pierpont Morgan Library, $1.25.) An address delivered at the Morgan Library. LETTERS TO PHILIPPA, by Dorothea Brande. (Sheed Ward, $1.50.) Letters discussing contemporary books and motion pictures.
Columbia St. 12. 21.11x65: Catherine T. Freston, wife of, and Thomas Freston to Gussie Brown, 12 Columbia St, mtg $4,500.

Republicans elected two village Trustees and a Water Commissioner today in the annual village election here. Propositions calling for construction of a swimming pool and the payment of salaries to the village president and trustees were defeated.
Cathedral College of New York was defeated by the St. Joseph's quintet, 60-40, at Kenney Gymnasium tonight before a large crowd.

Abel Hansen, banker and founder of the Fords Porcelain Works in Perth Amboy, one of the largest manufacturers of porcelain plumbing fixtures in the world, died this morning in his home, Maplehurst, in Metuchen, after an illness of several months. He was 74 years old.

It would be a grand thing if our streets were so wide and our curb space so long that any one could park his car anywhere at any time and leave it until he needed it again. Because there is so little street space and because there are so many cars we have to compromise.
The trend toward ever greater military control of German economy was confirmed today by the announcement that the corps of "military economy Fuehrers" soon will be expanded to include all arms.

Discovering a typographical error in the resolution adopted by the Board of Aldermen on Dec. 2 approving the 1938 city budget, which made it appear that the Aldermen had voted a nine-year instead of a one-year budget, Mayor La Guardia returned the resolution yesterday with his veto.

Unable to shake off the nervousness that gripped trading on Monday, the market for bonds continued yesterday to drift irregularly lower. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was dull and featureless as total transactions amounted to $6,909,300, compared with $6,807,375 on the preceding day.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition GRAND BABY SHOP, INC., infants' wear, 329 Grant St. and 291 Jackson Ave., Jersey City--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, listing liabilities of $32,201 and assets of $40,076.

Miss Isabelle Shevelove, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob J. Shevelove of this place, was married today to Harry L. Levin, son of Mrs. Isidore Levin of Trenton. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Rabbi Julius Silberfeld.

Rentals of full-floor units for commercial purposes featured yesterday's leasing report. Three floors and part of a fourth in the eight-story building at 514 West Fifty-seventh Street were taken by Edward Nolin for use as an automobile garage, from the Schock Estate through Garage Trading Corporation.
Today's major events: "Siegfried," Metropolitan Opera House, 7:45 o'clock; Downtown Glee Club, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Composers' Forum Laboratory, Theatre of Music, 8:45.

By agreement of attorneys for both sides argument on a motion in the first suit brought by security purchasers under the Securities Act of 1933 was adjourned yesterday in Supreme Court until next Monday.
Miss Julia Rodman, sister-inlaw of the late General George W. Goethals, chief engineer of construction for the Panama Canal, died at her home here today at the age of 82.

Harry Potter Fish of 140 West Fifty-eighth Street has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Elizabeth Alden Fish, to John Alden Stanton, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Lester Stanton of 180 East Seventy-ninth Street.

The agreement for the reorganization of the Interstate Bakeries Corporation and the Schulze Baking Company and the liquidation of the Western Bakeries Corporation, Ltd., has been approved by the stockholders, R. L. Nafziger, president, announced yesterday.
The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon its memorial exhibition of work by Charles Demuth, who died in 1935.

Assemblyman-elect Robert J. Crews, twin brother of John R. Crews, Brooklyn Republican leader, joined about forty striking employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle yesterday morning on their picket line outside the newspaper plant, Washington and Johnson Streets.

Advertising men here are considering the advisability of an international advertising convention to be held in New York in the early Summer of 1939, in conjunction with the World's Fair. The subject will be discussed by the board of directors of the Advertising Federation of America at its next meeting in January.

Warning that the country cannot afford another major business and industrial depression, Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Republic Steel Company, demanded tonight that the national Administration cease lending support to labor leaders who mislead the workers; that it

MANHATTAN BERNSTEIN, JULIUS (Dec. 1). Estate, less than $1,000. To Charles Bernstein, son, executor, 901 Washington Ave., Brooklyn, residue. Gertrude Bernstein, daughter-in-law, same address, executrix. HOROWITZ, SAMUEL I. (Nov. 17). Estate, more than $10,000. To children, Eva Lober, Alexandria, Egypt; Edward Horowitz, 220 Highland Ave.; Leah Horowitz, William Horowitz, Joel Horowitz

La Salle Academy of Second Street has been substituted for La Salle Military Academy of Oakdale, L. I., in the special invitation one-mile relay race which will be one of the features of the annual De La Salle Institute interscholastic track meet at the 102d Engineers Armory Saturday night.

William Shepard, a Negro, 17 years old, of 589 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot and fatally wounded by a policeman at 9:45 o'clock last night on the Reid Avenue station of the Fulton Street elevated line after, the police reported, the Negro lunged at another policeman with a knife.

Revelation in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the presence here of Bruno Mussolini, son of the Italian Premier, formed the real reason for the sudden decision to "repatriate" him early in November, an aide of Vice Admiral Fernandez Moreno, the commander-in-chief here, declared today.

In the lower house of Parliament today during the debate on a government bill for the naturalization of 1,453 aliens, the National Socialists accused the government of allowing the country to be overrun by Jewish refugees from Germany.

Prospects for peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization received another-setback today at the opening of the convention of the Steel Workers Organization Committee, which is an affiliate of the organization dominated by John L. Lewis.

Active mill calling before trading in the December position ceases at noon tomorrow, in conjunction with commission house and foreign buying, advanced prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange 8 to 13 points.
An indication of the recession in general business was shown yesterday in the report of the Census Bureau on cotton consumption in the United States in November.

Introducing a bill renewing the law concerning the dissolution of subversive political parties approved in 1933 to enable the dissolution of the German Nazi movement, the government inserted important changes tightening the law and enabling closer control of Konrad Henlein's Nazi movement.

Retail shoe prices are now at about the same level as they were early in 1937 and should remain stable for some time to come, Jesse Adler, president of the Adler Shoe Company, declared last night at a dinner meeting of the Shoe Club at the Hotel McAlpin.

THERE are some dozen personal portraits in Louis Untermeyer's new biography of Heine, which appears together with a new volume of Mr. Untermeyer's translation of Heine's poems.* The first portrait is from an engraving by Ludwig Grimm, and shows a typical romantic youngster gazing soulfully and dreamily off into space.
The Treasury awarded today a $573,433 contract to the J. Weinstein Rubin Building Corporation of New York City for construction of the Canal Street station, New York City postoffice.

Portrait busts of Will Rogers and Wiley Post, designed as gifts to the Oklahoma Historical Society, have just been completed by Herbert Adams, sculptor. The bronzes were ordered by Frank Phillips of Tulsa, Okla., the donor.

Lady MacRobert, Dr. A. J. Cronin, novelist; Richard Tauber, operatic tenor, and Mrs. Tauber; T. Christopher Ratsey, Mr. and Mrs. F. W.
