Challis, Betty Allen, Helene Tondratieva and Joan Ingram, tennis star, are among the passengers booked to sail for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Roger N. Baldwin, director of the American Civil Liberties Union, declared in a radio address last night attacking Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City that the real issue in Jersey City "is the maintenance of an honest Americanism against the tyranny and corruption of the Hague machine."

The Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company will distribute $500,000 to about 15,000 workers this week and next in the form of deferred vacation money. Added to the regular
In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today: Order discharging rule to show cause In L-262, the Seminole Nation, and L-263, the Creek Nation.
For the second time George Ketchum, president of a Pittsburgh advertising firm, did not appear today in response to a subpoena to testify at a National Labor Board hearing.

Jansuz Zoltowski, financial counselor of the Embassy of Poland, will announce today that Poland will offer twenty-year 3 per cent dollar funding bonds in exchange for equal face amounts of coupons of the following loans:

About 500 persons are expected to attend the luncheon of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York today in the Hotel Commodore, when Frank S. O'Hara of Jackson Heights will be installed as president of the association, to succeed Herman A. Acker.

Preliminary plans for the United States chess championship tournament, to be conducted under the auspices of the National Chess Federation, were discussed at a meeting of the tournament committee at its headquarters, 120 Broadway, yesterday, with Silas W. Howland, chairman, presiding.

The Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, confronted by the abrogation of its agreement with the Parmelee System, largest operators in the taxi industry, announced yesterday it would take a poll of the employes of the major operators on a strike call. Parmelee employes voted Monday night and yesterday morning to authorize the union board-to call a strike.

An eyewitness account from the British gunboat Bee reported today that two Japanese motor launches had machine-gunned the United States gunboat Panay before she sank on Sunday after a Japanese bomb attack.

Turpentine firm, 26c; sales, 91 barrels; receipts, 271 barrels; shipments, 145 barrels; stock, 34,299 barrels. Resin firm; sales. 403: receipts, 1,160; shipments, 373; stock, 86,641. Quote: B. D, E, $4.20; F. $5; G. $5.05; H, $5.20; I, $5.25; K, $5.45; M, $5.75; N, $6; WG, $6.60; WW, X, $7.

Death Announced Retired Lieutenant Peter Farrell, formerly a member of Engine 254, residing at 61-A 7th Ave., Brooklyn, died Dec. 9. Appointment The following is appointed as an ununiformed fireman in this department, with compensation at the rate of $2,000 per annum, for a probationary period of three months. Thomas E. Mulligan. Engine 59.

The International Mercantile Marine Company rejected yesterday the demand of the National Maritime Union for inclusion of Provisions for a closed shop and exclusive employment of the company's unlicensed sea-going personnel through union-controlled hiring halls, in a contract to be signed by the company and the union.
The twenty-ninth game of the match for the chess championship of the world between Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam was started tonight and adjourned after forty moves.
A hearing will be held on Saturday in Superior Court here on an offer of a group headed by David Stern 3d of Philadelphia to buy the Providence Tribune Company, publisher of The Providence Star-.
A first mortgage of $40,000 at 4 1/2 per cent interest has been placed by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc, for the 774 E Tremont Ave Corp on the business building at 774-82 E Tremont Ave.

Dr. Joseph S. Tennen of 65 South Street, a practicing physician here for -twelve years, died Sunday afternoon in University of Michigan Hospital at Ann Arbor, Mich., after an illness of three weeks. He was 43 -years old. Born in Brooklyn,

The engagement of Miss Jo Boykin Underwood, youngest daughter of Mrs. Joseph Boykin Underwood of Fayettesville, N. C., and this city, and the late Mr. Underwood, to Raymond Charles Harwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Harwood of Richmond Hill, Queens, has been announced here by her mother, who is the former Miss Nellie Pemberton.
Legislation is needed to stop the "merciless, reckless punishment" of forward passers in college football games, Clark Shaughnessy,' head coach at the University of Chicago, declared today.

Albertson Estates, consisting of. 450 lots at Albertson Station, in Nassau County, has been purchased by La Salle Homes, Inc. The new owners plan to erect 150 small dwellings, according to Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney for the purchasers.
Miss Anne Page, national women's.titleholder, advanced to the semi-final. round of -the annual Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship with two victories on the Haddon Hall courts today.

The ground floor and basement comprising the Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue corner of the Empire State Building, have been leased as a unit to Longchamps Restaurant, Alfred E. Smith, president of Empire State, Inc., announced yesterday.

Miss Kate S. Buckingham, distinguished patron of the arts, died today at her home at 2,450 Lakeview Avenue. She was 79 years old. Miss Buckingham, last member of an eminent Chicago family, had been ill with spinal arthritis since last Summer. Death, however, was attributed to heart disease.
The Cuban Senate ratified last night five conventions of the Buenos Aires-PanAmerican peace conference, held last year.

Bishop William T. Manning of New York is called "a child of hell, a pseudo priest and a wolf in sheep's clothing" in Julius Streicher's newspaper, the Stuermer, today because of his attack upon antiSemitism in a recent address. The Stuermer declares Christ himself was anti-Semite.

Dr. Joseph S. Tennen of 65 South Street, a practicing physician here for -twelve years, died Sunday afternoon in University of Michigan Hospital at Ann Arbor, Mich., after an illness of three weeks. He was 43 -years old. Born in Brooklyn,

C., and this city, and the late Mr. Underwood, to Raymond Charles Harwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Harwood of Richmond Hill, Queens, has been announced here by her mother, who is the former Miss Nellie Pemberton.

Albertson Estates, consisting of. 450 lots at Albertson Station, in Nassau County, has been purchased by La Salle Homes, Inc. The new owners plan to erect 150 small dwellings, according to Charles M. Hiesiger, attorney for the purchasers.
Miss Anne Page, national women's.titleholder, advanced to the semi-final. round of -the annual Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship with two victories on the Haddon Hall courts today.

The Cuban Senate ratified last night five conventions of the Buenos Aires-PanAmerican peace conference, held last year.

Bishop William T. Manning of New York is called "a child of hell, a pseudo priest and a wolf in sheep's clothing" in Julius Streicher's newspaper, the Stuermer, today because of his attack upon antiSemitism in a recent address. The Stuermer declares Christ himself was anti-Semite.

The Japanese people "should build a replica of the gunboat Panay" and present it to the United States as "a symbol of Japanese - American good-will," writes a reader of the newspaper Nichi Nichi under a nom de plume.
Today's major events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 o'clock; "Romeo et Juliette," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15; Federal Symphony Orchestra, Theatre of Music, 8:45.

An Academy of Sport, to present the history of athletics and- supplement a sweeping sports program, is to be a feature of the New York World's Fair, Grover Whalen, president of the fair corporation, announced yesterday.

After an early advance to around high records of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased slightly yesterday and ended unchanged to 6 points lower than on Tuesday. Mill calling of the December delivery, which will go off the board at noon today, kept fluctuations within narrow limits.

The American Federation of Actors, a union of vaudeville performers, was ordered yesterday to desist from organizing any actors in burlesque theatres outside New York. The order was issued by the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, the parent of all American Federation of Labor actor unions, on the ground that the outof-town burlesque actors were covered by the Burlesque Artists Association.

Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel gave a luncheon yesterday at the Stork Club for Miss Nancy Van Vleck, debutante daughter of Mrs. William de Wilder Atkinson, who will be introduced formally at a supper dance on Dec. 23 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

When it was decided to eliminate the center tap from basketball, except at the start of each half, it was expected that scores would run higher than in the past. In fact, that was one of the reasons why so many advocated the change in rules.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt ave a luncheon at the White House today in honor of Mrs. Hughes, wife of the Chief Justice of the United States; Mrs. Taft, widow of the former President and Chief Justice;
The Hon. Michael Astor, son of Viscount and Viscountess Astor of London, is at the Waldorf-Astoria before returning to England.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Naomi Rubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Rubin of 285 Central Park West, to Jerome C. Strumpf, son of Mrs. Harold Strumpf, also of this city, and the late Mr. Strumpf.

James H. Connors, Boston business man, today was elected president of the Eastern Racing Association, which owns and operates the Suffolk Downs track. Connors succeeds Charles F. Adams, chain grocery magnate and sportsman, who becomes chairman of the racing association's board of directors.

The State commission on conditions among urban negroes, sitting at 447 West 151st Street, inquired yesterday into charges that New York utilities, savings banks and labor unions discriminate against the Negro's chance to attain employment, especially in positions paying better-than-average salaries.

An ugly story of insolence and insubordination among the President Hoover's seamen and engine crew while ashore on tiny Hoishoto Island, off Formosa, where the liner grounded, was brought to Manila upon the arrival of 453 passengers aboard the rescue ship President McKinley.

Borough President George U. Harvey announced yesterday that he would appoint in the next few days an Industrial Commission for Queens in an effort to attract business enterprises to the borough. He said that Dr. George J. Ryan, former president of the Board of Education, had accepted the chairmanship of the commission.

Nearly 5,000,000 acres of wild country has gained protection against inroads of "mechanized civilization" through an order issued by Secretary Ickes and John Collier, Commissioner of Indian Affairs, designating twelve tracts of Indian lands in the West as "roadless" and four tracts as "wild."

Contrary to his custom of remaining at home on anniversaries of the first airplane flight, Orville Wright plans to come to New York from Dayton, Ohio, tomorrow to attend the meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences at Columbia University at 3 P. M.

The preliminary reports from ninety-two Class I railroads, representing 82.6 per cent of total operating revenues, showed that these roads had estimated operating revenues in November amounting to $261,619,434, according to an announcement today by the Association of American Railroads.

State committees began today to narrow the field of 590 candidates for Rhodes scholarships. Four States named two candidates each for the awards, which allow study at Oxford University for two years under the terms of the will of Cecil Rhodes.

Attorney General David T. Wilentz is expected to be urged by the Democrats for appointment to the New Jersey Supreme Court when Justice Frank T. Lloyd of Merchantville retires from the bench at the expiration of his term Jan. 29, it was learned here today.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Dec. 27 on applications by Kentucky Securities Company and Lexington Utilities Company, subsidiaries of the Middle West Corporation,
The Virgin Islands, the former Danish West Indies, today celebrated the completion of twentyone years under United States rule since their purchase from Denmark.

Evidence of what may be a growing sentiment for a change in one of the leading sporting fixtures of American life, the Poughkeepsie regatta, came yesterday with the meeting of the Rowing Coaches Organization of America at the Hotel New Yorker.
A reception was given last night by the board of directors of the Associate Alumnae of Barnard College to the faculty in Brooks Hall on the college campus.
In the Supreme Court of the United States William E. Ringel of New York City was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:
Corn continued the market leader on the Board of Trade here today and prices advanced 3/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel to new high levels since early in November, of an aggressive export demand.

At a meeting of the directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday, Elihu Root Jr. of this city and David A. Crawford of Chicago were elected to fill vacancies caused by the deaths of E. E. Loomis and Thomas N. Perkins.

While some of the men stars at Hollywood are well dressed, the rotogravures disclose a lamentable tendency toward carelessness on the part of many actors in wearing slacks and open-neck shirts, Captain John A. Murdocke, English authority on men's fashions, said yesterday.

Syracuse's basketball team humbled Niagara tonight, 54 to 38, before 2,200 spectators. It was the visitors' first setback in four games. With Billy Thompson and Wilmeth Sidat-Singh, football star, showing the way, Syracuse had a 34-20 lead at half-time.

The New York Stock Exchange hockey team staged a five-goal drive in the third period to rout the Princeton freshmen, 10-3, in the season's opener for the losers in Baker Rink tonight. John Wilken, Bill Chadwick and Harry Sniffen led the victors' assault with two goals and an assist each.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Repeating her victories of the past four years, Miss Anne Page, women's- national squash racquets champion, won the annual women's Atlantic Coast title on the Haddon Hall courts today, 7-15, 15-6, 10-15, 15-7, 15-9.

Hank Greenberg, hard clouting first baseman and long-range siege gun of the Detroit Tigers, topped the hitters in the American League for runs batted in with a near-record total of 183, according to the official figures released for publication yesterday.

In defiance of the police, 100 men and women pickets paraded shortly after 6 o'clock last night to the Horn Hardart Automat Restaurant at 1,557 Broadway, in Times Square, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, and for three quarters of an hour staged the worst disturbance with which the police have had to cope wince the restaurant chain strike was called Aug. 6.

President Anastasio Somoza read his first message to Congress which opened today. He thanked President Roosevelt and the governments of Costa Rica and Venezuela for their good offices in the mediation of the boundary dispute between Nicaragua and Honduras.

Apparently under the stimulus of news from China, enough signatures to a discharge petition have been obtained to make certain that the Ludlow resolution will be brought before the House of Representatives at an early date.

Eighteen hundred workers of the Goodrich tire factory in Colombes, northwestern Paris suburb, began a stay-in strike today in protest against what union officials said was application of the Bedaux system of increased production.
A 40-year-old former sawmill hand who converted a worn-out hill farm into a paying business in seven years, was crowned tonight as the Mid-South's champion "plant-toprosper" farmer.

The first order of the Pennsylvania Labor Relations Board to be subjected to judicial review was set aside today by Judge Edwin 0. Lewis in Common Pleas Court 2. The board was taken to task in a written opinion.

The merger of the Title and Mortgage Bureau of the State Department of Insurance with the Real Estate Bureau of the same department was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance.

Bert Beers Tichenor, 43-year-old bookkeeper, of 483 Valley Road, Montclair, shot and killed John T. Condron, 41, a relative by marriage, and then ended his own life with the same pistol tonight in the Tichenor home.
The problem of America's role and destiny in world affairs, which THE TIMES dealt with in a recent editorial, comes more strongly to the fore with each development in international affairs.

Lawrenceville's champion polo team vanquished the Princeton jayvees today, 151/2 to 51/2. The victors obtained the lead in the first chukker when Shaffer scored twice, and were ahead by 51/2 to 3 at the end of the second. Then the Laurentian trio, paced by Osmun, scored five goals in the third and five more in the fourth.

Magistrate William Klapp granted six weeks' credit yesterday to a man he had found guilty of leaving the scene of an automobile accident when it developed that the defendant had just, obtained a job as an elevator operator.
The outstanding athletic team of 1937, the experts have ruled, was the New York Yankees, champions of the baseball world.
The management of the Chicago Northwestern Railway Company amended its plan of reorganization today, making sharp reductions in capitalization and fixed charges.

The highest army peacetime decoration for heroism, the Soldier's Medal, was awarded to Major Benjamin T. Anuskewicz, Chemical Warfare Reserve, by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area, at a ceremony yesterday morning in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.

Electric power production increased last week but fell under a year ago. The gain was contrary to the seasonal dip and exceeded the long-term increase. The adjusted index advanced to 98.5 and compared with 96.1 in the previous week and 106.9 for the week ended Dec. 12, 1936.
James H. Leonard, headmaster of the Cambridge High and Latin School Annex for ten years, died today in his office at the school. He was 51 years old.

Cooperative apartments having an appraised value of $10,293,000 in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx are owned and operated by over 2,200 families, according to a survey of cooperative housing just completed by the Bureau of Labor

Lin Yutang, author of "My Country and My People" and "The Importance of Living" (Reynal Hitchcock), will give a series of three lectures on eminent Chinese thinkers and poets at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Mayor La Guardia received last night checks totaling $105,000, the proceeds from the annual baseball game between the Police and Fire Department teams last Summer, at a. dinner-meeting of the Mayor's Committee on Municipal Athletic Activities at the Hotel Paramount.

New life insurance written in November was 3.9 per cent below that in the same month last year, but the total for eleven months of 1937 was 4.9 per cent above the 1936 period, according to a report made by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.

Mrs. Christiane de Milly Berna dae of Paris, daughter of Mrs. Jules de Milly and the late Mr. de Milly, was married to Stanley J. Halle of Chappaqua this afternoon at the home here of Dr. and Mrs. Horace Eddy Robinson. The Rev.
Before 2,000 undergraduates, the Dartmouth hockey team defeated the Blue Way Hockey Club of Springfield, Mass., tonight, 3 to 0.

Japanese forces will make a dramatic formal entry into Nanking tomorrow afternoon at 1:30 o'clock under the leadership of General Iwane Matsui, commander of the army in the Shanghai-Nanking area, and Vice Admiral Kiyoshi Hasegawa, commander of the Third Fleet, it was announced here today.
Christmas bonuses to employes were announced yesterday by several banks. All employes of the Bensonhurst National Bank of Brooklyn are to receive an extra payment equal to one month's salary.

Recipients of understamped air mail letters from abroad will not be asked to pay the surcharge between now and Christmas. In the true Christmas spirit the postoffice has decided to endorse understamped air mail letters as follows:

A definite prospect of a break in the deadlock over defaulted war debts and debts resulting from the war developed when Hungary not only made a partial installment payment of her obligation due today, but indicated that soon she would take up with the United States the question of an adjustment of her indebtedness.
Gifts from 442 contributors added $9,928.75 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday and brought the total that has been received so far in this twenty-sixth annual appeal to $129,801.01.

Election of J. F. Kelly Jr., export manager of the Electrio Storage Battery Company of this city, as president of the Overseas Automotive Club, Inc., was announced by the organization yesterday. Mr. Kelly succeeds R. C. Thompson of the Prest-O-Lite Battery Company, Inc.,
Estate, less than $5,000. To Priscilla Fleltman, daughter, Volta House, Windmill Hill, Hampstead, N. W. 3, London, England, residue. Blaine Ewing, brother-in-law, executor, 149 E. 73d St.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 25,000, including 9,000 directs. The market was 10 to 15 cents higher than Tuesday's average, but closed with the advance lost.

The Cornell Club turned in a masterful performance in Group II of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C team matches yesterday in scoring a sweep over the Williams Club with the loss of only a single game. All but C.

A halt in the decline of steelmaking operations has appeared for the first time in more than three months with this week's esti-, mated rate at 27 1/2 per cent of capacity unchanged since last week, according to the weekly summary of The Iron Age.
The Montclair A. C. squash tennis eam retained undisputed possesion of the Class A Metropolitan League lead last night by scoring ts seventh consecutive triumph of :he season.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the Yugoslav Government was entirely within its rights in expelling Hubert Harrison, Belgrade correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and Reuters Agency, because of his story about a political Mickey Mouse cartoon.

In swearing in two new appointees to the New York City Housing Authority yesterday Mayor La Guardia said he considered the agency one of the most important in the city because of the impetus given to housing by the terms of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act.

Two new restaurant enterprises were listed yesterday among the lessees of business quarters. In the midtown district, Grand Central Restaurant, Inc., rented the entire ground floor and the rear mezzanine of the building at 146 East Forty-sixth Street.
The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, as a result of its investigation of the financial structures of domestic railroads, will recommend to Congress "important remedial legislation"

The committee for the reorganization of the Vertientes Sugar Company and Camaguey Sugar Company is notifying holders of certificates of deposit for the first mortgage bonds that the common shares of Vertientes-Camaguey Sugar Company, the new corporation, are now ready for delivery in exchange for the certificates.

Alexander Koszegi of 911 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, a member of the viola section of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society Orchestra, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. He was 57 years old.

STAR STATIONERL CO., INC., 100 W. 72d St. anc 628 Lexington Ave.-By Harry Blum's Natural Blooms, Inc., for $425; Charles S. Greene, 366; Rabinowitz Bros., $847. Petitions FUed-By THE ART CRAFT DYEING CO., INC., 48 W. 15th St.-No schedules filed.

An anonymous contribution of $10,000 to the United Hospital Campaign, 57 William Street, and a donation of 50 cents from a 7-year-old boy were announced last night by F. Abbot Goodhue, chairman of the finance section.

Galliano Masini, well known Italian tenor, has been engaged to sing at the Metropolitan Opera during the first half of the season of 193839, General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday. Mr. Masini will be heard in leading roles of the Italian operas such as "Lucia di Lammermoor," "Tosca," "Boheme," "Rigoletto," "ioconda" and "Traviata."

Although "True Confession" had a pulpwood sound, it proved yesterday to be a highly polished, smoothly grained Yule log which deserves to crackle right merrily at the Paramount from now until well after Christmas. Being a comedy, it runs into valiant opposition, for this year has been generous with its laughfests.

Scoring its third triumph in as many starts, New York University's basketball team defeated a hardfighting Upsala quintet, 60-34, last night in the University Heights gymnasium. The victory made it forty-three in a row for the Violet on its home court.
Spring St, 158, 4-story brick loft and store, 20x79.11 x irreg; Cranford Holding Corp against Briggs Realty Constr.. Corp, due, $15,685, taxes, etc, $3,342; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Tammany Hall has recommended the names of two district leaders for consideration by the. Appellate Division for the appointment to the lifetime job of County-Clerk of New York County, it became known yesterday.

In effort to give definite form and direction to the new attitude of independence on Capitol Hill, a group of conservative Senators, most of them Democrats, have drawn up a ten-point program of nonpartisan action toward encouraging economic recovery and restoring to Congress its lost prestige.
Wesleyan defeated the Coast Guard Academy at basketball tonight, 52 to 32. The Cardinals led, 23 to 15, at the intermission and their second team was on the floor in the second half.
For the first time in the ten weeks since he ascended the bench of the Supreme Court on Oct. 4, Justice Black today asked questions during argument of a case.

Real estate activity in Manhattan was marked yesterday by sales of private dwellings. The residence of the late Colonel Grayson M.-P. Murphy at 24 East Sixty-fourth Street was sold by his estate to a client of the Raymond P. Quinn Company for occupancy.

Proofreaders who work all night at the Government Printing Office got credit today from Representative Maverick for not allowing members of Congress, in the Congressional Record, to put a coat of many colors on David and to sink the Merrimac in Manila Bay.

Great Britain's response to the Yangtze bombings turned out today to be another note of protest to Tokyo. The note was of a familiar pattern. It reminded the Japanese that attacks on British naval and merchant shipping "raise grave issues."
The four-story apartment house on the northeast corner of South First Avenue and East Third Street, Mount Vernon, has been sold to David S. Meister through Hardy Brauneis, brokers.

Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Minister, reached this evening the climax and the culmination of his tour of the capitals of France's allies and his reception here was all that the most ardent Prencbman could have desired.

Charles Hackett, singer, 9 rooms and 5 baths in 447 E 57th St; Madison Realty Co, broker. Tilly Losch, actress, in Hotel Ambassador, Park Ave and 51st St. Robert J. Maroney, in 969 Park Ave; R. Wolcott Ripley, in 530 E 88th St; William E. Detlor in 146 E 49th St;

Fordham University came from behind in the last thirty seconds at Collins Memorial Gymnasium tonight to gain a 29-to-27 victory over St. Peter's College in a thrilling basketball game before a capacity crowd of 1,000 persons.

The House Immigration Committee today adopted a resolution requesting the Departments of Labor and Jus-. tice to gather all available information as soon as possible concerning the activities in this country of Fritz Julius Kuhn, head of the German American Bund.

The Rev. Dr. Alexander Sprunt, former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Southern Presbyterian Church and pastor emeritus of the First Presbyterian Church of Charleston, S. C., died today. He was 85 years old.

Requisition papers signed by Governor Olin D. Johnston of South Carolina for extradition of Fleming Mix, 19 years old, a Negro chain-gang fugitive, were brought to Governor Hoffman's office at the State House here today by S. P. Watkins of the Kershaw County police.

The New York City school system is planning to introduce twenty-four-hour teaching schedules in order to provide courses for elevator men, janitors, house superintendents and other building service employes, who, because of their irregular working hours, cannot now go to school, Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens representative on the Board of Education, disclosed yesterday.

The Rev. John J. Blythe, -pastor of St, James Methodist Episcopal Church in Brooklyn for the last five years, died on Tuesday at his home, 2,021 Eighty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 72. He was born in England, studied at McGill University in Montreal and did post-graduate work at Yale University.

Miss Jane Honour McCreery was married to Henry Theodor Schapps, son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Schapps of Sacramento and Lankenberg, Germany, at noon today at the home here of her mother, Mrs. Robert S. McCreery.
Two Yonkers banks, the First National and the Central National, announced today they would make dividend distributions soon to stockholders.

Sister Ella Myer, who had been a member of the Shaker religious colony near here since she was 10 years old, died yesterday at the age of 76, leaving only four aging women of the group still alive. The colony is one of several founded in the early eighteenth century by Mother Ann Lee of England.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in November is estimated at 33,984 long tons, compared with 38,707 in the preceding month land 50,433 in November, 1936, the Rubber Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

H. E. Babcock of Ithaca told the New York State Grange today that the Federal Government was exerting "constant pressure" upon Cornell University in seeking to have "more and more to say about the conduct of agricultural research and education."

The seventy-first annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society will be held at the American Fine Arts Building from Jan. 26 to Feb. 11. Work must be received at 210 West Fifty-eighth Street on Jan. 18 between the hours of 9 A. M. and 5 P. M.

Japan has begun to lay severely punishing hands in high quarters as the result of the bombing of the United States gunboat Panay. It was announced here today at noon that Rear Admiral Mitsuzawa, who has been commanding the Japanese naval air force in China, has been dismissed from the post he held here and is being returned to Japan immediately.

In most of the Southern States the season on deer is just getting into swing, and the reports have been Unusually good this year. Of course, in most of these States it is legal to hunt deer with dogs, which is not only forbidden but frowned upon in the North.
The Senate Joint Maritime Committee heard charges today that ship owners had hired circus hands to replace twelve seamen who went on Strike at Tampa Nov. 10, 1936.
Scores of singing, shouting men and women, some carrying or leading children, attempted mass picketing today at the Ford assembly plant and were arrested by police as fast as they appeared.

The Chicago Board of Trade today suspended the trading privileges of sixteen members for non-payment of dues. Before the close of the market four of the delinquent members were reinstated, having paid the annual assessment of $200.

France and Germany have concluded a treaty concerning border populations in both countries. A second pact, curbing attacks on each other in the press, is under consideration. These treaties are interpreted as evidence that the two countries are meeting their problems in a friendly spirit.

The government believes that 750,000 florins is necessary for The Netherlands and East Indies and West Indies participation in the New York Fair. Asking the lower house to grant this sum, Finance Minister M. P. L. Steenberghe explained today that The Netherlands cannot fail to be represented at the fair.

The fourth Pan-American Anti-Tuberculosis Congress opened here today. Minister of Health Eduardo Cruz Coke outlined plans for general application of preventive medicine as the most modern method of checking the advance of diseases on the South American Continent in their first stages.

Any day's list of contributions to the Fund for the Hundred Neediest Cases has its touching story to tell. This week nearly $13,000 came to the Fund from the bequest of Miss Mary Alice Hutchins, for many years curator of the Litchfield Historical Society at Litchfield, Conn.

G. Herbert Windeler, former president of the United States Golf Association and a member of the Boston insurance firm of Patterson, Wylde Windeler, died today at his Winter home in Boca Grande, Fla., according to word received here tonight. His age was 77.

Imports of distilled liquors for ten months of the year were 13,639,805 gallons, an increase of 3,487,015 over the same period in 1936, the Customs Bureau reported today. Stocks in customs bonded warehouses at the end of October amounted to 4,784,651 gallons.

Following a meeting of the executive committee of the Handicap Class Yacht Racing Association, was announced yesterday that George P. Granbery had been appointed acting president, succeeding temporarily the late Walter S. Sullivan.

The College of Arms, it was disclosed today, has refused to record any precedence for the Duchess of Windsor, American-born wife of the former British King. By declining to grant her the same precedence as her husband the college broke one of the oldest customs in the history of British nobility.
The schedules of minimum prices for soft coal, promulgated by the Bituminous Coal Commission and modified slightly after a hearing yesterday, became effective at 12:01 A. M. today.
The Eastern District and Bryant High School basketball teams scored Victories in P. S. A. L. games to provide some of the features of schoolboy competition yesterday.

R. H. Macy Co. applied yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook for a release from consent injunctions restraining the company from selling Schenley, Calvert and Seagram liquors at prices below those fixed by the distillers.

Policeman Harry Jones spent a lot of time preparing for a rabbit-hunting expedition today. He oiled his gun, greased his boots and checked his ammunition supply. With another officer, he trudged through snowdrifts, up hill and down, sighting nary a bunny.

Maternal love, glorified by countless poets, can be boiled down to a mere matter of chemicals, Dr. Elmer V. McCollum of Johns Hopkins University asserted last night. "The lack of maternal instinct in a mother can be traced to a deficiency in manganese," he told a University of Buffalo audience.

After hours of time-killing tactics which kept the House in a parliamentary tangle, the drastic A. F. of L. substitute for pending wages and hours legislation was rejected early this evening by a vote of 162 to 131.

Featuring of cotton lisle hosiery for high style wear, highlighting of Chinese red and Chinese green as the outstanding colors for Spring, and introduction of cotton petticoats and slips at a fashion show staged at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel yesterday brought comment from

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Troxell of Carmel, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna M. Troxell, to John M. Crowley of White Plains, N. Y. The marriage will take place in Carmel on Dec. 28.
Distribution of State lands to tenant farmers is provided in a bill approved by the Senate early this morning as part of Colonel Fulgenclo Batista's threeyear plan.

Ralph Greenleaf, sixteen times champion, opened the defense of his world pocket billiard title at the Capital Bowling and Billiard Academy last night by defeating Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., 125 to 1, in the first block. The game went only two innings.

Prince Torch, 6-year-old son of Torchilla, owned by Fred Abbate, gained his second straight triumph over Mrs. Ed Haughton's consistent Rough Diamond in capturing the mile and seventy yards claiming handicap that topped the Fair Grounds card today.

Max Schmeling will engage in one more bout in this country before his scheduled June encounter against Champion Joe Louis if present plans materialize. The German ex-champion made this announcement last night before he sailed on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for Germany.

Contributions and pledges amounting to $82,277 have been received by the national anti-syphilis committee of the American Social Hygiene Association, it was announced yesterday by Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of the association.

Union officials announced last night that a call to strike this morning had been sent to more than 5,000 employes of the F. W. Woolworth Company in its 124 five-andten-cent stores in the metropolitan area.

Captain Fritz Wiedermann, personal adjutant to Chancellor Hitler of Germany, sailed for home last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after a three weeks' visit to gather impressions of the United States.

Martin F. Hislinger, end, and Richard H. Farrell, quarterback, were chosen co-captains of next year's Hamilton College football team, and Richard F. Geer, a sophomore, was elected captain of the soccer team, it was announced at the football dinner tonight.

Thomas Moses, who rose from a miner to head one of the nation's leading coal companies, stepped down today from the presidency of the H. C. Erick Coke Company and the united States Coal and Coke Company in favor of his son.

The United Hunts Racing Association enjoyed one of its best years during 1937, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of the directors at the Recess Club. This statement was based on the financial report of the-Roslyn and Belmont Park meetings, read by L. E. Waring, secretary-treasurer.

A General Sessions jury, of which Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, and Elmer Rice, the playwright, were members, yesterday acquitted Moses Joseph, 46 years old, a Negro, on a second-degree- manslaughter charge in the killing of a 13-year-old Negro, Russell Blacknall, last Oct. 26.

Delegates to the convention of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, emphatically opposed in a resolution today any amendment of the Wagner act.

The possibility that some chapters of Phi Beta Kappa, the national honorary scholastic society, may for the first time in the society's history lose their charters, became apparent yesterday at the annual meeting here of the senate of the United Chapters of Phi Beta Kappa.

The lease which the Federal Theatre Project of the WPA has held on the New Yorker Theatre, Fiftyfourth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, for the past year has been renewed. The building has been used as headquarters for the Federal Music Project.

Formation of a committee to act in an advisory capacity to the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, as well as to cooperate with all other existing committees of the union in New York, was announced yesterday at a luncheon at the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.
Russia believes that Italy's withdrawal from the League of Nations presages some vast new adventure by a bloc of aggressor States, namely, Germany, Japan and Italy.
The Senate met in an after-dinner session tonight in an effort to hasten the General Farm Bill to conference, after rejecting again any specific limitation on the funds to be spent under the program.

John Peter Johanson, a veteran of four wars and in the United States Navy for more than thirty years, died Tuesday night at his home, 134-16 Fifty-ninth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, at the age of 69. A service will be held tonight at the home.
Alexander Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador, declared tonight that an unofficial verdict declaring Leon Trotsky innocent of terrorism and Fascist conspiracy was only a whitewash.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an opinion made public today, gave recognition to difficulties facing many public utility companies in selling equity securities in the present market by granting permission to the Northern States

Various types of Bronx residential properties changed hands in realty deals announced yesterday. The five-story multi-family house at 1,456 Wilkins Avenue was purchased by the Manchester Construction Corporation, through Leo Freedman, attorney, from the Pensa Realty Corporation.

A chairman for the committee on program which is to write a new charter for the Republican party was agreed on today by the executive committee of the Republican National Committee at its meeting here and his election is expected to be announced tomorrow.

The possibility of a general taxicab strike involving the principal operating fleets and nearly 14,000 drivers grew stronger yesterday when the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, called for a strike vote meeting to be held tonight by the 2,300 employes of the Terminal, Bell and Town taxicab systems.

The American section of the International League for Academic Freedom, on behalf of 994 teachers associated with 110 universities, has appealed to the Polish Ministry of Education to abolish "Ghetto benches," it became known yesterday.

A Federal court jury that has heard evidence for the last five weeks will be asked today by Judge John C. Knox to determine the guilt or innocence of eight men, three labor organizations and a corporation, all accused of racketeering in the city's $75,000,000-a-year fur-dressing industry.

Funeral services for Frank H. Myer, retired, who for almost a half century was connected with Hudson River steamboats in different capacities and who died at his home in Saugerties Sunday at the age of 82, were held at his residence today.
Nineteenth annual convention-of the National Association of Marketing Officials will open at the Hotel Pennsylvania this morning at 10 o'clock and continue Friday and Saturday.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Francis of Westfield, N. J., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Francis, to the Rev. Arthur Henry Limouze of East Marion, L. I., took place here yesterday in the chapel of the Union Theological Seminary. The ceremony was -performed by the Rev. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the seminary.

A large window in the newly established German tourist bureau on Kaerntnerstrasse here was smashed tonight. Police arrested a Jewish merchant, Michael Lebenschuss, who confessed to smashing the window as a protest against Nazi Germany.

The Federal Trade Commission today made public proposed trade practice rules for the popular music publishing industry, as adopted by the industry at a meeting here last Oct. 4, and offered opportunity for those opposed to their adoption to present such objections and views not later than next Jan. 4.

With. various estimates that a maximum of 2,000,000 homes must be constructed within five years, practically every division of the home furnishings and building industry is making 1938 advertising plans to tie in with governmental effort to revive construction, agency executives said here yesterday.

The Tennessee Valley Authority development on the Tennessee River and its tributaries is designed to aid in the control of flood waters on the Mississippi River, George R. Clemens, senior hydraulic engineer for the Mississippi River Commission, testified in Federal court here today.

Departmental requests for the city's capital outlay budget for 1938, as published yesterday in The City Record, reach a total of $414,518,050. Of this sum $112,134,324 represents renewals of appropriations authorized in the capital outlay budget for 1937.

Fifteen hundred persons representing 110 civic groups in Brooklyn attended a mass meeting last night to demand increased police protection in Brooklyn. The gathering was held at Girls High School, Nostrand Avenue and Halsey Street, Brooklyn.

Despite a desperate rally in the closing minutes that cut its opponents' 12point lead in half, the Trenton State Teachers College quintet was defeated, 33 to 27, on its court at nearby Hillwood Lakes today by the Rutgers University quintet.
The text of the note sent today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden to Japanese Foreign Minister Koki Hirota follows:

AHEARN-Martin B.. beloved husband of the late Henrietta (nee Nelson) and devoted brother of Catherine and the late John F. and James J. Ahearn. Funeral from his residence, 321 East 21st St.. on Saturday at 9:30 A. M.; thence to Epiphany Church, where Solemn Requiem Mass will be offered for repose of his soul. Interment Calvary Cemetery.
Governor Hoffman held today the first of a series of conferences with claimants to the $25,000 reward in the Lindbergh kidnapping case, which was voted by the Legislature.

Information has been received by this Department to the effect that a man, not in uniform, has been soliciting business men in this city and representing himself as a member of the New York City Fire Department.

William V. Elliott, who has been in public service since 1896, was appointed yesterday morning as the Kings County Public Administrator by Surrogate George A. Wingate. He succeeds Frank V. Kelly, who announced his resignation on Tuesday.

Borough President Harvey of Queens announced yesterday his Cabinet for his new term starting Jan. 1. All members of his existing Cabinet except those whose jobs are abolished by the new charter were renamed.

To guard against sit-down strikes in district relief offices, the Emergency Relief Bureau has ordered that persons bearing food, blankets, radios or other appurtenances of a long stay be barred, it was learned last night.

The "provisional Government of all China," proclaimed on Tuesday in the capital of Peiping-now renamed Peking-appears plainly to be another Japanese puppet regime in the process of formation. As organized at present, it is likely to have only local and temporary significance.
The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: Cold weather glaze and absence of snow cover in portions of the Winter wheat belt were unfavorable during most of the week.

Held even for three-quarters of the contest, Princeton University's basketball team turned on its power in the final ten minutes and registered a 39-28 triumph over Rider College tonight before 2,000 fans.

Rector St, 15 - 17, 96.3x45.10x100.4x51.2, equal lien with mtg of $68,500; Nellie V. McCarthy, 310 W 106th St and Chase National Bank of N Y, as trustees of Patrick McCarthy, to Bank for Savings, 3 yrs, 4 1/2 per cent; $10,000.

Six bus companies will operate 250 buses a day each way through the new Lincoln Tunnel opening next week, tightening the link between midtown New York and virtually all points in New Jersey, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

Rocco S. Pauline, quarterback, and Philip E. Swiadon, tackle, were elected co-captains of the 1938 New York University football team at a meeting of the Violet lettermen yesterday at University Heights.

Harold Remington, an authority on bankruptcy law and member of the law firm of Remington Twitchell, 150 Broadway, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 36 Boulevard, Malba, Queens. He had been in court the day before. His age was 72.
James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said after a White House conference today that President Roosevelt would address a Jackson Day dinner here Jan. 8.

Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney and William E. Warner, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, will discuss the question, "Shall We Have a National Incorporation Law?" in a radio broadcast next Sunday at 7 P. M. over the Mutual network.
The longdrawn-out lawsuit between the Archduchess Blanca of Habsburg and her son, Archduke Leopold Salvator, about financial matters has been settled by agreement in a Vienna court.

Major Gen. Lord Edward Gleichen, grandson of Queen Victoria's half-sister, the Princess Feodora, died here today after a short illness at the age of 74. A member of the Grenadier Guards, he was a familiar figure to the older generation, which knew him as Count Gleichen.
Former Governor George washington Donaghey died at his home here early today of heart disease and complications. He was 81 years old.

The Arundel Corporation reported yesterday for the first eleven months of this year a profit of $1,060,162 after depreciation and other charges but before Federal income taxes. This compared with a profit of $741,781 for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, 1936.

The Christmas season was welcomed officially on Morningside Heights yesterday afternoon when Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, lit the Yule log in John Jay Hall and extended the season's greetings to a gathering of university officials, dormitory residents and their guests.

Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay yesterday accepted the honorary chairmanship of a committee being formed to sponsor a series of concerts early next year for the benefit of young musicians in a project being undertaken by the educational division of the Municipal Opera Association.

In a stirring finish that found Harvard behind Brown until the final four minutes, the Crimson pulled ahead to defeat Brown, 47 to 42, in a varsity basketball encounter tonight. Brown took a 22to-15 lead at half time.

Broadway, 2,220-26; to 2-story factory and store; estate of Archibald D. Russell, 60 Wall St, owner; A. F. Winter, architect; cost, $5,000. Brooklyn Orange St, 72-78; 41-family brick apartment house, 6-story, 71.6x85.9; Clarkson Homes; 147 Montague St, owner; Seelig Finkelstein, architect; cost, $150.000.
The second game of the intracity series between New York's two teams in the National Hockey League, the Rangers and the Americans, will be played at Madison Square Garden tonight.

President Roosevelt shattered a precedent today by receiving, in a business suit instead of cutaway and striped trousers, the new Minister from Nicaragua, Dr. Don Leon de Bayle. Dr. de Bayle, who succeeds Dr. Carlos Brenes Jarquin, was also attired in a business suit.

Displaying a powerful secondhalf offensive the Williams College basketball team defeated Middlebury, 45 to 34, tonight. Led by Captain Mike Latvis and Pete Seay with ten and eight points respectively, the Purple gained a 20-to-14 lead at half time. Coach Charlie Caldwell used his entire Williams squad in the encounter.

J. Edward Bird, for thirty years proprietor of one of Baltimore's largest dry goods establishments, died at his home here today at the age of 80. He retired from business more than twenty years ago and since then had traveled extensively.

Following the capture of most of Nanking and the arrival of units of the Japanese fleet near Wuhu, 50 miles upriver from Nanking, panic is spreading up the Yangtze valley. At Hankow, 400 miles west of Shanghai, an enormous evacuation is proceeding.

The Hershey Bears and Atlantic City Sea Gulls skated through a listless 1-to-1 overtime tie tonight. The point they gained from the draw, however, advanced the Gulls from a tie with the New York Rovers into undisputed possession of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League lead.

The acquisition of Island Beach, a ten-mile, 2,000-acre strip from Seaside Park to Barnegat Inlet, was recommended to the Governor today by the New Jersey Planning Board, which envisaged a State park development similar to Jones Beach on Long Island.

Franklin St., 162, to Hudson St., 112, Patrick J. McGrath, referee, to Hudson Franklin Streets Corp., 20 Exchange Pl., foreclosure ($44.50). Attorney St., 155-7, Arcy Realty Corp., Charles Rubinger, president, to Joseph L. Buttenwieser, 885 Park Ave.; mtg. $23,400 held by grantee, deed dated Jan. 16. 1935 (50c).

Increasing memberships in the Metropolitan Guild, both in this city and outlying territory, were reported to 500 members of the guild and their guests who attended the guild's final campaign luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Pierre.

Last night's session of the Composers Forum-Laboratory at the Theatre of Music presented compositions of Rudolph Forst, Jessie Baetz and Harrison Kerr. The first was represented by a string quarter that won the N. B. C. Guild prize in January.
Under a government bill to be submitted to Parliament next week the nation's defense forces in peacetime would be open to Polish women from 19 to 45.
Representatives of industry and labor joined today in an appeal to the tariff commission for higher duties on shoes to "protect the American standard of living."

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of $11,210,000 of New York City bonds on a bid of 100.618 for 2 1/2s. The bid afforded to the city a net interest cost of 2.4202 per cent for the funds.

To meet the Canadian National Railways' deficit this year, "a little less than $40,000,000" will be required from the Federal Treasury, C. D. Howe, Canada's Minister of Transport, said tonight at a dinner of the Boston Canadian Club, Gross earnings will exceed $200,000,000, he added, the best showing of the company in several years.
The Ocean Steamship Company of Savannah, Ga., asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to extend its operations into Canda.

A case of man biting dog came up here today when the police made a new discovery of hidden arms in the somnolent Cagoulard affair, to wit, munitions allegedly smuggled from Spain into France to help the hooded order upset the republican regime.

The report of the Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal taxes and other charges, of $10,370,175.
A proposal to liberalize President Roosevelt's housing program in the hope of stimulating construction of homes costing $6,000 to $10,000 won the approval of the House Banking Committee today.

The application of forty-one anthracite coal shippers for a reduction of 50 to 75 cents a ton in freight rates from the Pennsylvania mining regions to New York harbor was heard yesterday by Commissioner Joseph B. Eastman and F. L. Sharp, examiner, of the Interstate Commerce Commission, at the Hotel New Yorker.
Mrs. Francis F. Storm of Indian Harbor, Greenwich, Conn., entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's. Her guests included Mrs. James H. Caldwell, Mrs. Albert H.
A special master ruled invalid today two leases held by Senator George L. Berry and his associates on marble deposits in the Norris Dam reservoir.

Reports from both sides in Spain's civil war tonight state that fighting on a large scale has broken out on the southern sector of the Aragon front after the period of comparative calm that followed the conclusion of the Asturias campaign.

To Omar Bonney's broadaxe, bill and plow The forest yielded, and the quickened soil Proved fertile, apt for tillage; stalk and bough Bore witness to his talent and his toil With fruitful tribute. Omar grew by thrift

The Rev. James Lawrence Travis, who had been pastor of the Church of Christ the King here since February, died of cancer this morning at St. Francis Hospital, Hartford, where ha had been since Oct. 18.

The Ontario and Quebec Governments are prepared to challenge the validity of Dominion legislation governing power export to the United States unless permission is granted for Ontario. to export a hydro-electric power commission surplus. Premier Mitchell Hepburn announced the plan today.

A celebration last night at the Hotel Biltmore, signalizing the achievement of a permanent status for the projected World Center for Women's Archives, became a testimonial for Amelia Earhart, one of its youngest and most ardent supporters at its inception two years ago.

Disregarding the earnest request of the President and the warnings of Secretary Wallace, the Senate has voted to place no limitations whatever 6n the expenditures that may be made under the new Farm Bill.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 14:
Charles S. Howard's mighty Seabiscuit drew top weight of 130 pounds today as the .Los Angeles Turf Club announced imposts for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap next March 5.

The State Department issued today a list of approximately 41,000 corporations which have been dissolved because of failure to file an annual franchise tax report with the State Tax Commission in the last three years.

Bonds followed an uncertain course in the greater part of yesterday's session, with prices on the average easing off slightly on the day. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was stepped up somewhat, the turnover in all classifications being $7,469,200, compared with $6,909,300 on Tuesday.

Bishop William T. Manning renewed his attack yesterday on the anti-Semitism of Nazi leaders in Germany, answering an article in Julius Streicher's newspaper, Der Stuermer, in Berlin, in which he was denounced as "a child of hell, a pseudo priest and a wolf in sheep's clothing." The Streicher attack referred to a recent address by Bishop Manning.

Maurice J. (Clipper) Smith, who brought his Villanova college team through an undefeated season, denied today a report that he was seeking to succeed Chick Meehan, who resigned as football coach of Manhattan College.

Subject to approval by stockholders and the Interstate Commerce Commission, the directors of the companies involved have authorized the merger of eight subsidiary companies into the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago St. Louis Railway Company, known as the Big Four,

Mayor La Guardia has been asked to revive consideration of the proposal to construct a shore parkway from Owls Head Park to Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, the Brooklyn Real Estate Board announced yesterday.

The returns of Sunday's elections to the Supreme Soviet (Parliament), complete today except for a few small and remote precincts, showed that a total of 90,319,346 persons--96.5 per cent-voted out of the Soviet Union's 93,639,478 registered voters.
The State Legislature is meeting today in special session for a purpose which ought to be in no wise controversial. It is nearly fifty-six years since New York City's local laws were codified.
The Apostolic Delegate announced tonight that Pope Pius XI had appointed three new Bishops to preside over recently created dioceses in the United States.
Retail deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban area showed an increase of 1 per cent for the week ended Dec. 11, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.
Despite the recent recession in general business, building activity in New York as indicated by permits filed in the five boroughs continues to hold well above the level of last year.

Two newcomers, Pennsylvania Military College and the University of Delaware, are on Lehigh's ninegame football schedule for next Fall, according to an announcement made today by Nelson A. Kellogg, director of athletics.

Miss Faustina Rochester, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richmond Rochester of this city, formerly of Mountain Lakes, N. J., was married last night in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church to John Frederick McKnight, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. McKnight of Brookline, Mass.

The Grace Line has sold the passenger and freight ship Carabobo to the Northland Transportation Company, it was announced yesterday. The ship will be renovated in Seattle and operated in the Alaskan trade.

The British desire for joint Anglo-American action in the Far East, even now, was reflected today in The Yorkshire Post, a powerful Conservative newspaper that is believed to be so close to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden that it is known in diplomatic circles here as "Eden's paper."
Johnny Adams raised his score as the nation's leading jockey when enter he piloted Mrs. James F. Waters's tired Time Flight to victory today in the six-furlong feature at Tanforan.

Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut, presiding at the trial of fourteen seamen charged with mutiny on the government-owned freighter Algic, charged the jury today that legally "there is no right to strike against the laws of the United States at any time, any place or under any conditions."

Supreme Court Justice Peter P. Smith in Brooklyn granted yesterday a peremptory order of mandamus directing Controller Frank J. Taylor and the Board of Estimate to include in the city budget for 1938 and for the first half of 1939 the amounts fixed by Surrogate George Albert Wingate in Brooklyn as compensation for the Surrogate's chief clerk and certain other employes of the office.
The Cabinet this morning approved final figures of the budget for the fiscal year of 1936-37 which ended June 30.

Miss Gertrude Ross Brodhead, daughter of Elber Howe Brodhead of this place, will be married to Kirby Hewitt Tappan, son of Mrs. Ogden Hewitt Tappan of New York, on Saturday afternoon in St. Mary's Church, Ardmore.

The Mexican Catholic Episcopate is accused of using a message of sympathy sent to the Spanish clergy, favoring Generalissimo Francisco Franco, "to play a political role in Mexico" and to oppose directly the Mexican "republican" system and President Lazardo Cardenas.

On the theory that "the kids want father and mother and brother and sister" present when they empty their stockings Christmas morning, the State Alcoholic Beverage Commissioner, D. Frederick Burnett, refused today to permit West Orange taverns to remain open all night Christmas Eve.

The discovery of the life cycles of seven species of a group of parasites, which throws new light on the origin and evolution of parasites in general, as well as on some of the important processes of evolution itself, was reported last night at the annual dinner meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences and affiliated societies at the Hotel Astor.
After six hours of voting in eight ballots, the Rev. Raymond A. Heron, Archdeacon of Boston, was elected today Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts.

The official figures of the Nov. 2 voting for delegates to the 1938 Constitutional Convention, announced today by the State Board of Canvassers, shows that Assemblyman Moffat of New York City led the balloting for delegate-at-large with 1,909,658 votes.

Contempt of court proceedings against Sylvia Hendler, bookkeeper for Local 167 of the Chicken Drivers, Chauffeurs and Helpers Union, were dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora on recommendation of Sol Gelb, assistant to Special Rackets Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

The Republican State Committee will meet this afternoon at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street, to select Republican County Chairman Kenneth F. Simpson as National Committeeman from New York State, succeeding Charles D. Hilles.

Charles E. Patton, former member of Congress and former Pennsylvania Secretary of Agriculture, died of heart disease at his farm home near here today after an illness of two weeks. He was 78 years old.

LIEUTENANTS Patrick J. O'Riordan, 18th Division, 12th Detective District, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Oct. 31, 1896. Michael J. Nilon, 4th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 14, 1902. John J. Reilly, 7th Precinct, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed July 16, 1901.
Returns from yesterday's riot-marred election indicated today a sweeping victory for President Manuel L. Quezon's Nacionalista party in Provincial gubernatorial races.

While there is much confusion over what price level is best for the country, it is not the level of prices but the necessity for a balanced price structure that is important, Dr. G. F. Warren, of the department of agricultural economics of Cornell University, declared last night at the annual dinner of the Vegetable Growers Association of America, Inc., at the Hotel New Yorker.

A national conference of realty men, builders, material dealers and representatives of labor was proposed yesterday by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, as the logical means of reducing construction costs and meeting the need for homes in the low-price field.

Numerous gifts made in October or previous months, including one of 48,450 shares of common stock of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company with a market value of about $970,000 by Harvey S. Firestone, a director of the company,

Domestic stocks of refined copper at refineries, exclusive of consumers' stocks at their plants or warehouses, at the end of November amounted to 221,670 tons, compared to 182,910 on Oct. 31, an increase of 38,760, according to the Copper Institute.

The Comite Pro-Cuba presented a Cuban flag to New York State yesterday, marking thus its "Day of the United States of North America." The ceremony took place in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

THE OXFORD COMPANION TO CLASSICAL LITERATURE, edited by Sir Paul Harvey. (Oxford University Press, $3.) A reference book with explanations of various elements in classical literature, biographies and descriptions of literary works.

No one knows what will be the annual cost of the Senate or House versions of the Farm Relief Bill. No one knows whether the President will sign or veto whatever is passed, since he has said he would not approve any measure that exceeds the budgetary provisions.

The United States should take the lead in calling an international conferencee to drop the world price of gold and to stabilize it in the future, Hudson B. Hastings, Professor of Industrial Administration at Yale University, declared here last night.

The French penal colony on Devil's Island will come under the scrutiny of Paramount's cameras. Today the purchase of "Song of Hell," by Jean, was announced. The story deals with the escape of several prisoners. The screen play, which will be written by Kurt Siodmak and Thomas Monroe, will be fashioned for George' Raft, Georges Rigaud and Akim Tamiroff.

Beatrice Berle, 6 years old, and her sister, Alice, 8, heard Mayor La Guardia at a Sinking Fund meeting yesterday close a long chapter in their family history when the Mayor put on record the two demure little girls "whose great-great-great grandfather was the first City Chamberlain of New York" and whose father Adolf A. Berle Jr., will be the last.

Decatur Ave, 2,638-40, 2-story frame dwelling, 50.1x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Nellie V. Condon, due, $16,686; to plaintiff for $500. 220th St, 6.63 E, 50x114; Bankers Trust Co execrs, against Anna W. Stolfa, due, $8,735, taxes, etc, $624; to plaintiff for $7,500.

Trading was fair to mostly slow. The lamb market was lower and some steer and fresh pork cuts were lower; otherwise prices were about in line with Tuesday. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and lamb prices to be weak; veal and calf strong, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The bottom of the present recession has been reached and business will show another upturn this week such as was shown last week for the first time in three months, Glenn Griswold, vice president of McGraw-Hill Company, told an American Management Association conference yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, with Mrs. Earle and twenty-two members of his official staff, will return today from Europe on the Swedish American motorship Kungsholm.

Without resuming play, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, newly crowned chess champion of the world, resigned the twentyninth game of the title match with Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, which was adjourned after forty moves had been made last night.

In analyzing today the recent events in the Far East, the Chilean press reveals an inclination to favor the American and British point of view by pointing out the disastrous con-. sequences of the sinking of American and other neutral vessels.

Robert Francis Grant, resident manager of the Canadian International Paper Company in Three Rivers, Que., died there on Monday after a long illness, according to word received here yesterday by the International Paper Company. He was 79 years old.
Awards to 119 members of the four football squads playing regular schedules last Fall at the University of Pennsylvania were made today at a meeting of the awards committee in Weightman Hall.

The marriage of Miss Jane Baerwald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Baerwald of 9 East Eightyeighth Street, to Jack R. Aron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Aron of New York and Kings Point, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon at the Pierre. The Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise performed the ceremony.

Firsthand accounts of the Japanese attack on the United States gunboat Panay and the three Standard Oil ships on the Yangtze River above Nanking, with their reports of deliberate, premeditated action by Japanese aviators, surface vessels and troops, have presented a much more serious picture of the incident than was given in first reports.

Charles E. Wilson, vice president in charge of the appliance and merchandise department of the General Electric Company since 1930, was elected yesterday executive vice president of the company, a new position, it was announced by Gerard- Swope, president.
The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld today the right of long established railway labor groups to operate independently of largely competing organizations.

Pledges to enlist the cooperation of employes of motion-picture theatres in the $6,250,000 drive of the New York - Brooklyn Federation Campaign for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies were made by 500 members of local theatres and their assistants at a meeting yesterday morning in the Astor Theatre. County Judge Algeron I. Nova of Brooklyn and License Commissioner Paul Moss spoke at the meeting.
The much discussed public-utility situation will have the spotlight of public attention again when President Roosevelt holds his scheduled conference with utility executives next week.

Evidence that the Administration is striving for a truce with private utilities was seen today when it became known that the House Rivers and Harbors Committee plans to eliminate from the President's Regional Planning Bill all reference to hydroelectric development, except on the Columbia River where the Bonneville Dam already is in operation.
Richard A. Lewis has been appointed manager of the Philadelphia office of Burton, Cluett Dana.

A newspaper campaign for "Sofkurd," a processed milk produced by M. R. Dietetic Laboratories of Columbus, Ohio, just concluded here, will be repeated and increased in other cities in proportion to allocation of license permits and installation of the system in dairies.

Uday Shan-Kar brought his company of Hindu dancers and musicians back to New York last night to begin their fourth American season with a performance at the Town Hall as the third event in the Town Hall Endowment Series.

Word was received here today that Winfred Lambert Smith, who resided in this city until ten years ago and was well known for more than forty years in New York maritime circles, died yesterday at his home in Lakeland, Fla., at the ag of 65.
Mrs. Nathan D. Bill entertained twenty for luncheon and bridge today at her home for Mrs. George Finch-Hatton and Mrs. Walter Furman Schuyler, guests of Mrs. Frank V. Skiff.

HERE is a book almost as rare as the white blackbird--a good book about New York. It might have been a more valuable book had it not been published in dear old Philadelphia, as will appear, but it is still highly entertaining. The author is Hulbert Footner, an ex-native who nowadays lives in Maryland and writes mystery novels.
Slowly, step by step, at first with much bitterness but at length with a nearer approach to agreement, the French have been working themselves out of the worst aspects of their Forty-Hour Week Law.
The stock market here continued to be extremely quiet today but a more cheerful tone was evident in most sections. Gilt-edge issues were firm while foreign bonds did well.

Andrews Ave (11-3216) e s, 46 ft s of 179th St, 100x215; Julie Burns to 1,940 Andrews Ave Corp. 18 E 41st St; mtg, $192,000. Franklin Ave (10-2607) e s, 455 ft s of 166th St, 54x201; Keller Realty Co, Inc, to Mildrun Realty Co, 644 Prospect Ave; mtg. $53,000.

Contracts totaling $473,483 were awarded by the War Department today for the construction and completion of interior work in the Army Air Corps Engineering Shop and Repair Docks at the Sacramento (Calif.) Air Depot, as follows: Eaton Smith, San Francisco,

Reminding Democratic leaders that they have made no move to carry out President Roosevelt's recommendation for a reduction in 1939 authorizations for Federal road aid, Representative Bacon of New York, second ranking minority member of the Appropriations Committee, introduced a bill today in line with the recommendations and called upon the majority party for support if its membership "still accepts the leadership" of Mr. Roosevelt.

The United States gunboat Panay "kept her guns blazing until the last minute," Jim Marshall, Far East correspondent of Collier's magazine, narrated from a hospital cot today. Mr. Marshall was one of four survivors of Sunday's tragedy on the Yangtze, all wounded, who were flown back to Shanghai today.

Announcement of ninety-three insignia awards to Rutgers University athletes for participation in Fall sports was made today by George E. Little, director of athletics. Recommendations for the awards -were made by the undergraduate board of managers.
" Room Service," the American comedy by John Murray and Allen Boretz, which opened at the Strand Theatre tonight, seems set to repeat the success of "Three Men on a Horse."

Roderick Stephens, coordinator of the Retail Solid Fuel Industry in New York City, was re-elected president of the Bronx Board of Trade at the board's forty-third annual meeting yesterday at its offices, 349 East 149th Street. Edward O. Seiffert, president of the Standard Plumbing Supplies Company, was elected vice president. Howell T.

Federal investigators at work here on the mysterious case of "Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Robinson," who have disappeared in Soviet Russia, whither they had gone on fraudulent American passports issued in the names of children who died twenty years ago, disclosed yesterday that the applications and affidavits upon which the passports were obtained were sworn to in the office of Albert Marinelli, former County Clerk.

Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter, who was shot to death by an intruder in her home at Camp Hill last Monday, revealed a year ago that she had received threats against her life, according to her brother, Emil Dorsett of Kankakee, Ill.

Exports of aeronautical equipment in the first ten months of the current year were valued at $31,088,911, as compared with $18,271,077 for the same period of 1936, and established a new record for any one year, the Commerce Department reported today. In the full calendar year of 1936, the report said, exports were valued at $23,055,761.

Joseph Reines, 30 years old, of 30 Clinton Street, one of a ring of loan sharks who victimized WPA workers in the Municipal Building through usurious charges on loans on their small salaries, was convicted yesterday in Special Sessions on evidence submitted by Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson.

Mr. and Mrs. William McCallum Cameron of 465 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Jean McCallum Cameron, to Stephen Hotchkiss Hartshorn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Winfred Morgan Hartshorn of 830 Park Avenue.

Cheered by reports of diminishing opposition in organized labor circles to the proposed equal rights amendment and steadily increasing Congressional support for the joint resolution on which favorable subcommittee reports have been made to the Judiciary Committees, the National Woman's party adjourned this afternoon its biennial council meeting.

The fate of Tom Mooney was advanced, at a mass meeting of 12,000 workers in Madison Square Garden last night, as a political symbol around which labor might rally in its campaign for a larger voice in governmental control.

Cliff Battles, the Redskins' great running back, accomplished a feat that no other man in the history of the National Football League ever before achieved when he gained a total of 874 yards during the 1937 campaign, since it was the second time the erstwhile star from West Virginia Wesleyan had led the

Each of the following Ordnance Reserve officers, having recently been promoted, is assigned to the organization indicated: 511th Ordnance Co. (Hv. Maint.), Capt. Vernon 0. Bowles, 7 1/2 Le Roy St., New York, N. Y. 66th Ordnance Co. (Maint.) (RAI), Capt. John K. Donald, 37 Chase Ave., White Plains, N. Y.

WINDOW CLEANER, $1,320 a year. Custodial Service, Postoffice Department, New York, N. Y. (including postoffices at Brooklyn, Flushing, Jamaica, Long Island City, New York and Jersey City, N. J.) Applications must be on file with the Manager, Second U. S. Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher St.,

Schieffelin Co., wholesale druggists, have bought from Samuel Lax, trustee for mortgage certificate holders under a Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company issue, the tenstory building at 28-30 Cooper Square.

J. E. Aldred, Canadian-American chairman of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company, who put hydro-developed power in this Province into its present strong position, reviewed tonight the results of what he set out to accomplish twenty-five years ago.

Survivors of the Panay sinking, en route to Shanghai aboard the United States gunboat Oahu and the British gunboat Ladybird, were making slow progress down the Yangtze today because of the danger from mines and partly blocked channels.

The defense in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case began today to introduce evidence on retail prices in the Midwest in 1935 and 1936 after presenting its claim that the sixteen oil companies on trial were indicted because they followed the objectives of NRA after that law was invalidated.

The three-man arbitration board set up under the contract between the Consolidated Edison Company and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. of L., to review the dismissal last October of about 950 Consolidated employes reported yesterday that the lay-off was caused by lack of work.

THE football hot-stove league is going full blast. All over the country coaches are engaged in the post-season pastime of holding postmortems on the rules. Their findings and recommendations will be forwarded to Lou Little and the Columbia maestro will present the evidence for and against to the football coaches' convention in New Orleans Dec. 29.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City has recognized the Social Service Employes Union, a C. I.
