O. affiliate, as representative of the workers in its administrative offices at 71 West Forty-seventh Street, Jacob Fischer, president of the union, announced yesterday.
Japan has developed a new technique in her effort to improve unfavorable trade balances in Latin-American countries.

The Downtown Glee Club, now in its twelfth season, gave its annual Christmas concert last night at Carnegie Hall before 'a capacity house that frequently manifested its enjoyment. The club was directed, as usual, by Channing Lefebvre. The assisting soloist was Reed Kennedy, baritone. In the final selections the choir boys of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine collaborated with the choir.

A gain of forty-four more votes in three election districts increased to 297 today Senator Lester H. Clee's total net gain in the recount of the Governorship vote in Hudson County. The districts were the first, fourth and seventh of the Second Ward in Jersey City.

Holders of receipts for New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad first mortgage 4 per cent bonds due on Oct. 1 have been notified that the bonds that were deposited for extension by agreement are ready for delivery at the Guaranty Trust Company.
Clinton E. Frank, Yale's All-America halfback tonight received the Maxwell Club award as "the outstanding American college football player."

The Messrs. Bushar and Tuerk will produce at the Mansfield tonight "Tell Me Pretty Maiden," a comedy by Dorothy Day .Wendell which deals with the memories of a movie star while she is being interviewed. Doris Nolan is the star; others in the cast are Alan Bunce, Ann Thomas, Constance McKay, Harold West, Otto Hulett and Ivy Troutman. Time, 8:40.
The Chicago Railway Equipment Company declared a dividend of $1 on the $25-par common stock, the first declaration in seven years.
Amendments to the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange were approved yesterday by the governing committee and for two weeks will be before the membership for adoption or rejection.
It is not for an outsider to set himself up as a judge of Irish Free State policy, even if it is a vote in the Dail recognizing

Morton I Rosenthal, a teacher of civics and dramatics in Public School 64, Tenth Street and Second Avenue, died yesterday at his home, 215 West Ninety-first Street, after a brief illness of heart disease. He was 51 years old.

Production of knitted underwear, other than glove silk and rayon, during October totaled 1,468,520 dozen garments, compared with 1,632,635 in September and 2,054,537 in October, 1936, according to .figures just released by the Bureau of the Census.

Police Commissioner Valentine asked reporters yesterday for help in solving a little mystery that is uzzling him and other members of he department. Why, Mr. Valenine would like to know, is a man lamed Clark sending money to the police "pention fund"? So far, Mr. Clark has sent in $100.

The extraordinary session of the Legislature called by Governor Lehman at the request of Mayor La Guardia to approve the proposed new administrative code, drafted to implement the city's new Charter, will open at noon tomorrow with no certainty,
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 14, unless specified: Acushnet, N.O.B., Norfolk, to Yorktown, Dec. 15. Antares, Quantico to Parris Island, Dec. 15. Barker, Hoishoto Island to Manila.

The Federal Reserve System elected to exchange all its holdings of the 25/8 per cent Tre?ury notes maturing on next Feb. 1 for the new 21/2 per cent bonds of 1945, it appears from this week's statement.

The stock markets here were generally cheerful today, with small improvements registered in most sections. Giltedge issues were unchanged, while among the foreign loans Brazilian and German bonds were weak.

Lake Placid-Ten inches snow in village; 24 above; four inches new powder atop seven inches old at Adirondack Loj; trails need packing because of soft base; five inches new powder atop fifteen inches old at 3,200-foot elevation of Mount Marcy Trail: seven inches new powder atop twenty-one inches old powder at 4,400 (Marcy Plateau); 28 above.

The Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, receives one-fifth of the residuary estate of Anne Aspinwall Curtis of 138 East Thirty-sixth Street, and the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church, Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue, a similar amount on the termination of a trust.

Mrs. Ethel White, 37 years old, wife of Frank White, missing Wanaque Borough tax collector who has been charged with embezzlement of borough funds, ended her life by drinking disinfectant in her Laurel Street home last night.

During the week ended Dec. 15 member bank reserve balances increased $48,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from increases of $19,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency and decreases of $10,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $19,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $2,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold offset in part by an increase of $5,000,000 in money in circulation.
Elbow Beach Hotel was seriously threatened early this morning when the power house and laundry were destroyed by fire. The damage, it is believed, will be between [Pound]15,000 and [Pound]20,000.
The attempt to organize the new independent spirit of Congress into a coalition group for business recovery measures appeared today to have died aborning.

Actors Equity's council picks a new president today to succeed Frank Gillmore. The council may decide to appoint a president to fill the balance of Mr. Gillmore's term, which was to end in 1940, or make a temporary selection until next June's annual meeting.

A residential property comprising more than seven acres, on the north side of Ridge Road in Rumson, N. J., has been sold by Arthur W. Bingham to Dr. James Van Nostrand, through William H. Hintelmann, broker.

Dr. Alexander Guy Holborn Spiers, Associate Professor of French at Columbia University for twenty-one years, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion, Medical Center, at the age of 56. He had been ill since Summer.
President and Mrs. Roosevelt held their first State reception of the season tonight, in honor of the Diplomatic Corps, under conditions faintly reminiscent of the early days of the World War.

Charles Glover, 28, whose last address was 830 Bloomfield Street, Hoboken, was sentenced today to five to seven years in State's prison by Judge Robert V. Kinkead in Common Pleas Court here after pleading non vult to three charges of sending threatening letters for the purpose of extortion and one charge of larceny.

The New York State Grange, estimated by its leaders to represent "135,000 farm folk," overwhelmingly adopted today a resolution favoring continuance of the Rogers-Allen State Milk Price Bargaining Law.

Don Hutson of the Green Bay Packers and Gaynell Tinsley of the Chicago Cardinals distinguished themselves as the leading pass receivers in the National Football League during .the recently concluded professional gridiron season, according to the complete statistics for that department of play released yesterday by league officials.

The New York Chapter of the Society for the Advancement of Management, at a meeting last night at the Metals and Plastics Bureau, 45 Rockefeller Plaza, organized four discussion groups which will meet independently of the chapter's monthly meetings, beginning in January.
Miss Mary May, co-director of the May School for Girls for twenty years, died today at her home in Cambridge. She was 72 years old.

Mrs. M. Brewster La Monte will give a luncheon today in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for her niece, Miss Frances Isabel Arnold, debutante daughter of Mrs. Dan Hinckley Arnold of Scarsdale and Washington, Conn. Mrs. Frederick A. Sterling of Washington is at the Ambassador.

Employes of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation in New York and six other cities staged a "standup" demonstration in the offices of the company yesterday that interrupted service for several hours.

Reports circulated here today indicated that in some quarters not otherwise unfriendly to New York City's new administrative code, fears had arisen that part of its provisions might be construed as authorizing new taxation on public utilities.
The International Labor Organization announced the receipt today of this telegram from Italian Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano, dated yesterday:
Students of the Neighborhood Playhouse School of the Theatre, 16 West Forty-sixth Street, will appear this afternoon in a demonstration of their work in dancing, acting and speech.
Louis Amadeus von Gaertner of 3,803 Atlantio Avenue, Sea Gate, violin virtuoso of a past generation and a composer, died of a heart ailment in Doctors Hospital, on Tuesday. He was 71 years old.
Forty-eight strikes involving 2,491 workers in New York State were called during November, it was reported yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner.

Three men held up the night cashier at the Vanderbilt Hotel, Park Avenue, between Thirty-third and Thirty-fourth Streets, at 1:35 o'clock this morning and escaped with $500 after lining up half a dozen guests against a wall and firing a warning shot when the cashier resisted.

Katharine Hepburn will not attempt a Broadway appearance this season in "Jane Eyre," it was learned today when RKO assigned her to "The Mad Miss Manton," which will go before the cameras in February. Miss Hepburn has been noncommittal on her stage plans ever since her return to Hollywood from her road tour. "Manton,"
Secretary Morgenthau today announced an offering of $50,000,000 of Treasury bills. They will represent the first of a new series to he used to meet maturities of similar bill emissions.
Stanley M Isaacs, Borough President-elect of Manhattan, was sworn in yesterday afternoon by Mayor La Guardia at the Mayor's temporary office in the Empire State Building. Mr. Isaacs,

The markets for both wheat and corn showed fair strength in the early trading today on the Board of Trade here, but the buying was not aggressive and late in the session prices sagged on scattered professional and commissionhouse selling, partly in the way of profit-taking.

Three armed men within an hour and a half held up three storekeepers in the Bronx last night and escaped with $300. About 9:30 o'clock they entered the grocery store of Theodore Schwartz at 679 Fox Street, hit him on the head with a pistol butt when he resisted and took $50.

A painting called "The Juggler" by the well known contemporary American artist, Walt Kuhn, has been purchased from the Marie Harriman Gallery, 63 East Fiftyseventh Street, by the Friends of Art in Kansas City for presentation to the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery in Kansas City.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 14: COMMANDERS Ostrander, J. E., Jr.. Aircraft. Battle Force to Naval Examining Board. Washington. D. C. orders of Nov. 19 revoked.

Premature publicity, one of the most deadly of political diseases, seems to have overtaken the plan for a new conservative "coalition" in the Senate. Mr. McNary, the Republican leader, is openly opposed to it. Other Republicans are lukewarm. Some of the Democrats are skeptical. The plan,

Allen W. Rucker of Boston, business counsel and economist, told members of the Commodity Club of New York at a dinner meeting last night in the Park Central Hotel that business men must learn to soften the impact of a declining price level upon the system of productive enterprise or "expect to see that system engulfed in a wave of reaction that may sweep away both economic and political freedom before its force is spent."

Some gains in retail sales of furs have developed, but the effect has not as yet been marked in the industry. Pre-Christmas promotions and colder weather, generally, have been factors in the improved retail showing.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation is willing to make any loans within reason which the railroads of the country may need, Jesse Jones, chairman of the corporation, announced this afternoon at a press conference.
A gift of $1,000 from the United States Rubber Products, Inc., to the United Hospitals Campaign, 57 William Street, was announced last night by George J. Lyons, vice chairman of the drive.

President Getulio Dornelles Vargas is contemplating a vast highway building program and the rearming of the Brazilian Army and Navy, it was announced here today. However, serious obstacles may be presented by the condition of the nation's finances.

THE year has only a couple of weeks to run. It will soon be 1938. And then it will be time for some one to read again the last lines of "The Education of Henry Adams" and answer the rather saturnine question implied there.
P. J. Odier, secretary of the Swiss Association, of Ski Clubs, recently put a classified advertisement in The Times of London seeking a hotel to lease or manage.
The British Government sat back today to await definite assurance from Tokyo that the British note of yesterday had been understood and heeded by the military rulers of Japan.
The termination of service on the New York, Westchester Boston Railway appeared imminent here today to Mayors and Corporation Counsels of communities served by the line.

Louis Luckman, who was convicted of perjury before the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case, was man sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Rogers in Brooklyn to serve from eighteen months to three years at hard labor in Sing Sing prison.
The University of Pennsylvania Press is publishing today the biography of a banker of the Revolutionary period under the title "Thomas Willing and the First American Financial System."

In sympathy with an improvement in outside markets and a further rise in both Liverpool and Bombay quotations, futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday and ended 8 to 11 points higher than on Wednesday.

General Robert C. Davis, executive secretary of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, announced yesterday the chapter had sent Christmas gifts to all veterans in out-of-town hospitals who formerly resided in Manhattan and the Bronx.

Jerome David Kern, the composer, and Mrs. Kern of Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jane Kern, to Richard Alan Green, also of Beverly Hills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vivian Green of 7 Park Avenue and Greenhaven, Mamaroneck. N. Y.

Charles B. Meyers, architect, filed yesterday the plans for the ten-story Family Court building at 11 to 15 Lexington Avenue, corner of Twenty-second Street, adjoining the Children's Court building. The new building will cost $850,000 and wil occupy a plot 75 by 100 feet. The site will be cleared soon after Jan. 1.
The banking quarters formerly occupied by the Bank of Manhattan at 135 Broadway, northwest corner of Cedar Street, have been leased to the Lawyers Trust Company for its downtown main office.
Philip Kron, one of this city's leading real estate dealers and builders, died late yesterday in his home. Mr. Kron began work in the real estate business in his youth.

Major Umberto Rovis, veteran flier who participated in Marshal Italo Balbo's mass seaplane flight to Chicago in 1933, and two other army fliers were killed today when a bomber, lost in the clouds, crashed against Spilimbergo Mountain and burst into flames.

The engagement of Miss Katherine Ryan Clark, daughter of Mrs. Joseph V. Clark of this city and the late Mr. Clark, to William Seward Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Hall of New York, has been announced by her mother.
The fourth Pan American Anti-Tuberculosis Congress carried out all the plans on the schedule for its second day.

Samuel Goodman, founder and president of the Goodman Warehouse and the Goodman Furniture Company, 830 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, died today at his home, 36 West Thirty-second Street, at the age of 78.
The voluminous tables of the League of Nations' Year Book on Trade in "Certain Raw Materials" was released today.

In one sense, of course, the fifteenth century Venetian primitive, Francesco dei Franceschi, fulfills his function in our modern world by providing fresh fuel for the debates of the art scholars and attributionists, now that he appears conclusively to have emerged as an individual from the mists surrounding a feIlow-painter of his time, Michele Giambono.

If New York City and State are to embark on any large-scale, longrange, low-rent housing programs, four amendments to the State Constitution are necessary, Ira S. Robbins, counsel to the New York State Housing Board, declared yesterday at a meeting of the housing section of the Welfare Council at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson refused today a request to appoint independent trustees for the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company's $95,000,000 properties pending submission of a plan for reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

One of yesterday's letters tells of a contribution which the members of a family of six made to the Neediest Cases Fund-a father and mother, three children and a grandmother, each according to his or her ability, but all of like interest.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, told members of the Irish Club of New York last night that "the condition of Ireland at the present time is something that ought to make all of us very happy" and expressed the wish that "every man here will live to see all of Treland united."

A charge that members of the Police Department were "consorting" with strikebreaking "thugs" was filed with Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday by Austin Hogan, president of the New York local of the Transport Workers Union of America. C. I. 0. affiliate.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

The 1937 Thomas A. Edison Medal of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers will be awarded to Gano Dunn, president for twentyfour years of the J. G. White Engineering Corporation and the author of more than thirty inventions in the design and construction of electrical machinery, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Dunn,

James E. Stephens, 46 years old, a Negro, who had been a Democratic Assemblyman from a Harlem district for five years in 1935 when he was indicted on an alleged "job-fixing" charge, was acquitted last night by a General Sessions jury before Judge Collins.
Turpentine firm, 26c; sales 78 barrels; receipts 109 barrels; shipments 5 barrels; stock 34,674 barrels. Resin firm; sales 161; receipts 1,103; shipments 586; stock 86,354.

A Federal court jury late last night freed two alleged henchmen of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, missing racketeer defendants, but convicted five union officials, three labor organizations, and a man accused of heading a racketeering organization directed by the fugitives, on charges of violating the anti-trust law n the city's $75,000,000-a-year furdressing industry.

Open championship, Cherry Hills Country Club, Englewood, Col., June 9-11. (Sectional qualifying rounds, May 31; entries close May 17.) Public links championship, Highland Park Municipal Course, Cleveland, Aug. 22-27. (District qualifying rounds. July 22Aug. 6: entries close Aug. 10.) Curtis Cup match, Essex C. C., Manchester, Mass., Sept. 7-8.
Lockwood R. Doty, former Livingston County judge and member of a pioneer Genesee Valley family, died today in a Rochester hospital. He was 79 years old.
Evidence accumulates that dust thou art, to dust returnest, was not spoken of the Dust Bowl. In the current Saturday Evening Post is an

Two long-term convicts escaped from the Alcatraz Island Federal prison today to become the object of the most intensive manhunt in recent California history. It was the first break from the supposedly escapeproof prison for desperadoes.
King George and Queen Elizabeth only smiled today when a small car crashed into the royal limousine in Trafalgar Square. They were en route to Buckingham Palace from a charity matinee.

Magistrate Frank Oliver, who in the past has usually defended labor when it was hailed into court for small disturbances of the peace, paused a few minutes in his duties in Harlem Court yesterday to express a sense of disappointment that, in his opinion, his old friend, labor, had not lived up to its responsibilities.

Recommendations aimed at boosting French production by at least 30 per cent have been submitted to the French Cabinet in an inquiry committee's official report, the complete text of which was published today.

It is a little embarrassing to know what to do about Mayor Hague of Jersey City. Other officials in this broad country have successfully suppressed this or that civil liberty for a time. But most of them have thought it necessary to surround their action with an alibi of some sort, a pretense of legality, a touch of that hypocrisy which is the homage that vice customarily pays to virtue. Not so Mayor Hague.

Miss Helen England, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert C. England, was married at her home this evening to Justin Albert Godchaux, son of Mrs. Albert Godchaux of New Orleans. Rabbi' Saul Habas of Temple Anshe Amonim performed the ceremony in a living room bay-window'setting of Southern smilax, silver eucalyptus, white chrysanthemums and palms.

Dr. Mary Lowell Coolidge, dean of Wellesley College for six years, will resign from her administrative duties in June to devote her full time to the study of philosophy. President Mildred H. McAfee announced the resignation in a special assembly in the Memorial Chapel this morning.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
The Independent Food Distributors Council has acted favorably on several suggestions and recommendations from the Department of Agriculture.
Mrs. Ida Schultz Dohme, widow of Charles E. Dohme, for many years president of the firm of Sharp Dohme, died today at her Roland Park home in her ninety-seventh year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Let me offer a solution for the parking problem which will settle the matter promptly, without cost to the city and to the satisfaction of all; My plan is "a garage on every block" free to the motorist.
Cecil Jerome Allen, society editor of The New York Sun, died early yesterday at his home at 150 West 106th Street. He was'stricken ten days ago with a heart attack. His age was 69.

The marriage of Miss Katherine L. Ebling, daughter of Mrs. Albert Mayer of Montreux, Switzerland, and of the late Lewis M. Ebling, to Francis X. Stephens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Stephens of New York, took place here yesterday afternoon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday, issued today, showed that the ratio of net reserve to notes and liabilities was 53.46, compared with 53.36 the week before.
Presaging their early departure from Paris, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor were received this afternoon in the Elysee Palace by President and Mme. Albert Lebrun.

Frederick B. Smillie, District Attorney of Montgomery County, announced tonight that a warrant had been issued for the arrest of Wendell F. Bowers, 19 years old, of Ambler, in the police investigation into the slaying of Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter at her home near Camp Hill Monday afternoon.

Chier Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the State Supreme Court denied today the application of Senator Lester H. Clee, defeated Republican candidate for Governor, to make a preliminary examination of voters' signatures in the Hudson County recount.

Commodity prices appear to have established a temporary bottom, The Annalist says, its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices standing on Wednesday at 85.9 (1926=100), unchanged from the preceding week, but 3.5 points lower than a year ago.

Traveling bands and orchestras that employ singers or entertainers as features have been notified by the American Federation of Musicians that such singers or entertainers must be, or become, members of the A. F. of M. or one of its associated unions, according to Joseph Weber, A. F. of M. president.

All the officers of the New York Yacht Club were re-elected at the annual meeting held last night in the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. They were Commodore W. A. W. Stewart; Vice Commodore E. Townsend Irvin, Rear Commodore George E. Roosevelt, Secretary George A. Cormack and Treasurer Richard Whitney.

The price of lead was reduced yesterday 1/4 cent a pound. The American Smelting and Refining Company's new price here is 4.75 cents a pound. The St. Joseph Lead Company posted 4.60 cents at East St. Louis. The new price here is the lowest of the year. The highest price was 7.75 cents, on March 10.

The report of the United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $5,173,712.

Superb Auto Sales and Refinishing Corp. auto storage, 5,000 sq ft in 419 W 55th St; John J. Meenan, Inc, broker. It's An Elf, Inc: Sol Goldstein, Inc; Skytop Frocks, Inc, in 1,385 Broadway, Yorke Sportswear, Inc, In 260 W 35th St; Schwartz Mack, Inc. in 53-7 W 36th St; Kane Realty Co, Inc, broker.

The American Federation of Labor, disappointed at the rejection of its substitute Wages and Hours Bill by the House yesterday, sent identical telegrams today to all members urging them to vote to recommit the Labor Committee's bill for revision. The message was read to the House from the floor by Representative Hartley of New Jersey and was received with a scattering of "boos" from the Democratic side of the aisle.

Fourteen seamen of the government-owned freighter Algic were found guilty by a jury in Federal court this afternoon under a 147-year-old mutiny statute, on two counts of an indictment charging them with conspiring and endeavoring to revolt against the authority of the master of their vessel.

Don M. Nelson, vice president of Sears, Roebuck Co., has been elected president of the Institute of Distribution, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors of the institute.

The Republican State Committee, after a last-minute attempt by up-State leaders to upset the scheduled program, yesterday unanimously selected Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican chairman of New York County, to be Republican national committeeman, succeeding Charles D. Hilles, who retired from the post after seventeen years of service in it.

The Foreign Office spokesman flatly denied today that the United States gunboat Panay had been machinegunned by Japanese boats and declared that no Japanese craft of any kind had been in the vicinity.

Despite record iron and steel production exceeding all pre-war levels, a decree forbidding the domestic use of a long list of additional products hitherto manufactured from those metals was issued today.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The State's attorney who is prosecuting Arnold Bernstein, Germany's only Jewish shipping operator, on exchange charges, asked the court today for a sentence amounting to the confiscation of everything the defendant owns. Included are his holdings in two shipping lines-the Bernstein and the Red Star.
French and German diplomats at the Quai d'Orsay this evening signed an accord regulating relations on the Frahco-German border in the region of the Saar Basin.

Colgate's basketball players spotted their rivals a half-time lead for the third time in as many starts but again rallied in the second half to beat Clarkson Tech tonight, 42 to 39, ringing up their third victory of the season.

The American Labor party enrolled 205,338 of the 481,000 voters who east their ballots under the Labor emblem on election day, it was revealed yesterday when the party enrollment figures were made public by the Board of Elections.

The concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli, conductor, began last night in Carnegie Hall with a brilliant exhilarating performance of Smetana's overture to "The Bartered Bride."

In expressing approval of Nationally Advertised Brands Week, scheduled for Feb. 24 to March 5, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers, yesterday urged distributors who will participate in the event to abstain from the featuring of competitive prices.

The efforts of young Irving Crane to wrest the world pocket billiard title from Ralph Greenleaf via the challenge route at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy went into another tailspin last night when the champion won, 124 to 16, in three innings after taking the afternoon block, 133 to 106.

The F. E. Myers Bro. Company, manufacturer of pumps and water systems, reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $1,063,195, after depreciation, normal Federal income taxes, excess-profits taxes and $20,500 provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.

Mr. and Mrs. John Henry MacCracken of this city have sent out invitations for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Louise MacCracken, to Robert Groves Olmsted, which will take place the afternoon of Jan. 19 in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, will perform the ceremony.

There was much hilarity in graybearded Justice Johnston's High Court here today when the judge innocently asked if former heavyweight champion Jack Dempsey was a colored gentleman. "Not at all," answered King's Counsel Edward Phelps. "Jack is not only a white man but an Irishman to the backbone."

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 11-Original. State of Texas, complainant, v. State of New Mexico, et al. Motion of the complainant that further hearings before the special master be deferred until after April 1, presented by special master.

The champion Detroit Red Wings, whose slump this season has been the biggest mystery of the NationaL Hockey league campaign, lost their fourth straight game tonight, bowing to the Black Hawks, 3 to 1.

Declaring that "Americans must stop eating vegetables and agricultural products produced in foreign countries," Mrs. Virginia E. Jenckes, Representative from Indiana, said yesterday she has appealed to President Roosevelt and to Secretary of State Hull "to remove immediately the unfair provisions in the reciprocal trade agreement with Cuba, which is doing so much harm to the vegetable-growing industry in this country."

The four Soviet scientists on the North Polar ice floe are frightened at times as their crevasse-riddled camp drifts southward amid grinding ice fields but they do not intend to be taken off until their work is finished;
Jerry Nolan's field goal in the last ninety seconds of play enabled the New York Cathedral College basketball team to down Webb Institute, 43 to 41, on the losers' court last night.
James Preston Linn, farmer, merchant and textile executive, died today at Rowan Memorial Hospital in Salisbury, N. C., of a heart ailment at the age of 63.

Effective Jan. 1. the firm of Dwight, Voorhis Perry, Inc., will be known as Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, Inc. The change is due to the death this year of two officers of the firm, John B. Perry and Henry Voorhis.

The Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A interclub championship was won by the Apawamis Country Club of Westchester yesterday when it defeated the Rockaway Hunting Club contingent, 3-2, on the courts of the Junior League.

James M. Parsons, justice of the Supreme Court of Iowa, died here this morning at the age of 79. Justice Parsons attended Iowa State College and Cornell College, Mount Vernon, Iowa, where he completed a civil engineering course.

In accordance with a twenty-five year old custom, a Christmas bonus of $235,000 will be distributed today among more than 4,000 employes of the Horn Hardart Automat restaurants in this city, Joseph V. Horn of the restaurant company announced last night.

The Keeshin Transcontinental Freight Lines, Inc., applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue $1,600,000 of 4 1/2 per cent debentures dated Nov. 1 and maturing serially from Feb. 1, 1940, to Nov. 1, 1945, except for $400,000 of Series C debentures which would mature collectively on Nov. 1, 1947.
The Japanese Navy today announced it would take action without precedent in its recent annals to ease the tension arising from the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay by Japanese planes.

Mrs. Ada Pearl Lyon, 53 years old, a lecturer on psychology, who recently was brought back to this city from Jonesboro, Ark., and pleaded guilty to a petit larceny charge in the theft of $500 from a woman servant in an apartment at 1,111 Park Avenue last Spring, escaped yesterday with a suspended sentence in General Sessions.

Miss Marjorie A. Saxton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester E. Saxton of Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas, formerly of New York, was married to James Whitney King Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Whitney King of Birmingham, Ala., here last evening in Government House. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. J. Arthur Swinson, rector of All Saints Church.

Wadsworth Terrace, 45-49; Ben-Dor Corp, Charles Benenson, President, to Martha Beerman, 1,482 Montgomery Ave. 103d St, 112-14 W; Irving Shapiro, executor of Bernard May, to 112 West 103d Corp, 11 Park P1; mtg $36,000 and purchase money mtg $8,500 ($16). Same property, Fanny May, widow of Bernard May, to same. quitclaim.
Contracts were awarded at the Army Quartermaster Depot here today as follows: Invitation 114 for four-inhand, ready-tied black neckties, went to the Uris Sales Corporation at 45 cents, net, each.

Bonuses totaling $34,551 were approved today for employes and officers of the Wilmington Trust Company under a profit-sharing plan adopted last Summer. The distribution amounts to 9.42 per cent of annual salaries.
The Swiss Federal Assembly today elected Dr. Johannes Baumann President of the Confederation for 1938 by a vote of 153 out of 195.

The Rev. Pryor McNeill Grant, rector of Christ Church, Riverdaleon-Hudson, and known here and abroad for his work with boys and seamen through the international religious organization known as "Toe H," died yesterday afternoon of pneumonia in the Harkness Pavilion of Medical Center. He was 43 years old.

The following Marine Corps changes, dated Dec. 13, were announced today: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Sebree, J. B., Portsmouth, N. H.. to Department of the Pacific, San Francisco, Calif., via the Republic from New York on Jan. 6.
Long Island University's basketball team crushed the HampdenSydney quintet at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium last night, 94 to 59.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in france:

A deadline set by the Health Deapartment for the installation of approved, hygienic dispensing devices for loose milk in all restaurants and lunch counters was extended yesterday from Jan. 1 to March 31. Dr. John Rice, Health Commissioner, found that the machines could not all be manufactured and delivered by the end of this month.

Lynn Patrick put the New York Rangers a goal ahead of the Amer icans in the first period of the game at Madison Square Garden last night. And from that point on the spangled skaters tried with all the power at their command to retaliate, only to find the task impossible.

Following is the address of Herbert Hoover before the Economic Club of Chicago on "Economic Security and the Present Situation": I have been led to make this address by the urgent appeal of your invitation. You-said in part:

Rallying in the second half, the Alexander Hamilton High School quintet scored its third victory in as many starts in Section 1 of the Brooklyn Division of the P. S. A. L. yesterday by downing Franklin K. Lane High, 32-28, at Lane.
William C. Haskins, 65-year-old newspaper man, sailed today for Houston, Texas, whence he plans to ride a bicycle over the route of the Inter-American highway from Texas to Panama.

Mayor La Guardia's administrative code bill of 3,350 printed pages, was pronounced the most ambitious project of legislation ever undertaken by any governmental or private body in a report submitted tonight to the Senate and Assembly by the Board of Statutory Consolidation, which drafted the code. The Mayor is chairman of the board.

Gounod's "Romeo et Juliette" was revived last night at the Metropolitan Opera House where it had not been attempted since Jan. 26, 1935, when it was heard with a cast headed by Eide Norena and Francis Hackett. A large and demonstrative audience was on hand for the performance of the reinstated work, which received an earnest but none too inspiring presentation.

A rise of $54,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City in their condition statement, issued yesterday.

The possibility that the missing couple posing as Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Robinson of New York have been arrested by Soviet authorities is strongly suggested today by Izvestia in commenting on their strange disappearance.

A blue-eyed doll with a football in her lap perched unconcerned yesterday atop a great pile of gifts in the foyer of the Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Seventeenth Street. Santa Claus had arrived and left fully ten sleigh loads of good things.

Yvon Delbos's mission in Czechoslovakia is going exceptionally well. The French Foreign Minister, after having luncheon today with President Edouard Benes, ent most of the afternoon in intimate conversation with Premier Milan Hodza.
" No matter how the present situation may change we must not surrender but march onward," declares Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in a manifesto the Chinese nation broadcast from a field headquarters.

Blondell Ave, (15-4074), s w side, at n w side of Roberts Ave, 98x100: Walter F. Downey, receiver, to Meadowbrook Farms, Inc, 1,650 Adee Ave. West Kingsbridge Rd, 135-45 (12-3248); Mayo Estates, Inc. to Elizabeth Richmond. 560 W. 180 St.
Uriah Butler, Trinidad strike leader allegedly responsible for the June riots, was found guilty of sedition here today. He faces a maximum penalty of two years at hard labor.

The British note to Japan must be taken more seriously than the other "firm and stern" but ineffective communications which Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has sent to dictatorial law-breakers in recent months.

The purpose of the unaccompanied overnight visit of Countess Barbara Hutton Haugwitz-Reventlow to this country was revealed yesterday. She renounced her American citizenship and became completely a Dane.

Appointments The following are appointed as ununiformed firemen with compensation each at the rate of $2,000 per annum, for a probationary period of three months, to take effect at 9 A. M., Dec. 17, 1937, and they will be charged to the codes noted below.

With a grand jury reported to be ready to return indictments, the future of the Federal Government's investigation of automobile finance cornpanices rested tonight upon the outcome of a conference called for tomorrow morning by Federal Judge F. A. Geiger.

The House Banking and Currency Committee reported favorably today the Administration's new housing hill with several amendments. Chairman Steagall said he hoped the House would take up the measure by Saturday and pass it before the end of the special session tentatively scheduled for Wednesday.
After John L. Lewis's address to the steel workers' convention today, a delegate shouted a request to Chairman Murray of the S. W. O. C. to put the following question to the C. I. O. chief:

Machinations of "enemies of the people" in the field of astronomy were alleged both by Pravda and Izvestia today in connection with a meeting of directors of the Academy of Sciences, now in session here.

Successful in his last appearance, but much too late to save the chess championship of the world which had been his, Dr. Max Euwe of this city won the thirtieth game of his return match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in 40 moves tonight, thereby bringing to a conclusion a contest which began at The Hague on Oct. 5.

With workers in three stores of the F. W. Woolworth Company on strike here, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, appointed a fact-finding committee yesterday to sift all aspects of the dispute between the company and the Department Store Employes Union, Local 1,250, a C. I. 0. affiliate.

A banking group composed of The Firstt Boston Corporation, B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and A. C. Allyn Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $831,000 of highway and refunding bonds of The Suffolk County, L. I., on a bid of 100.14 for 2s. The bonds,

Former President Hoover tonight denounced the "planned economy" of the Roosevelt Administration as a philosophy of government abhorrent to free Americans and set forth a five-point alternative social and economic system.

The inquiry into charges of violation of the civil rights of Negroes, sponsored by the State Temporary Commission on the Condition of the Urban Colored, sitting at 447 West 151st Street, received new impetus yesterday with allegations that the Midtown Civic League of Brooklyn is a "vigilante organization to terrorize Negroes."
The government surprise offensive which started yesterday against the Teruel communication lines brought "frankly satisfactory results," according to tonight's war communique.
Stocks advanced moderately and closed steady and higher; turnover, 1,033,830 lares. United States Government bonds higher, other groups irregular; transactions, $7,550,525.

Nearly 500 members of the Maine Society of New York heard speakers from Maine tell about the situation "across the frontier" at their annual dinner and dance last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Dr.
The City Council passed to their third reading today two proposed leases of the $60,000,000 municipal gas plant so that final action might be taken tomorrow.

A serious reversal was suffered by the Administration leadership in the Senate today when a Farm Bill amendment by Senator McNary, minority leader, was adopted. It would prevent the use of land, taken out of other crops for the production of dairy products.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Silvia Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould, to Charles Dabney Thomson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Atexander Thomson of College Hill, Cincinnati, which will take place on Jan. 14 at the home of Miss Gould's parents, 160 East Seventy-second Street.
The L. L. Construction Company sold to a buyer represented by Netter Netter, attorneys, the twostory taxpayer at 2,113 and 2,115 Southern Boulevard, between 180th and 181st Streets, the Bronx.
Two army officers and the wife of one of them were injured seriously today when their automobile and a freight truck were in collision.
Thomas Ellis French, dean of South Jersey lawyers, senior member of the Camden, N. J., law firm of French, Richards Bradley, died today at his Swedesboro estate, ten miles from here. His age was 82.

There may be "banker controlled" railroads in the United States, but the Pennsylvania Railroad is not one of them, M. W. Clement, president of the company, testified today before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce.

August Belmont 4th, 28 years old, New York broker, who lives in Far Hills, slipped this morning as he tried to board a moving train at the Far Hills station of the Lackawanna Railroad and suffered a hip injury. Mr. Belmont, a descendant of the noted financier, was brought to Morristown Memorial Hospital here for X-ray examination and observation.
Dr. G. H. F. Nuttall, American-born Emeritus Professor of Biology at Cambridge University, died today in a London hotel.

A suggestion that a chain of opera houses be established in this country, subsidized by a Federal fund, which would give young American singers an opportunity to sing in opera, was made yesterday afternoon by Geraldine Farrar, former member of the Metropolitan Opera Company.
The country's sports writers put their stamp of approval yesterday on Vernon Gomez as the hero of 1937's most amazing athletic comeback.

Scoring in all three periods and repulsing a rally by the Bengals in the final stanza, the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Bronx Tigers last night, 5 to 2, at the New York Coliseum in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game before about 1,000 persons.

Despite an increase of 3.6 per cent over last year in the full-time enrollment of students in 602 approved colleges and universities, and a gain of 4 per cent in total attendance, including part-time and Summer school registration, President Raymond Walters of the University of Cincinnati foresees a downward trend and warns that by 1943 these institutions will face "a diminished human reservoir" from which to draw.
Russian gold constitutes no threat to world markets, Dr. W. S. McCann of London, a mining engineer, said last night to the Ottawa Branch of the Canadian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy.

Official reports received by Secretary of State Cordell Hull concerning the Japanese attack on the United States gunboat Panay and the three accompanying Standard Oil vessels confirm the unofficial first-hand accounts of machine-gunning of the vessels and details as to clear visibility and other circumstances that present the incident as a deliberate act by the Japanese.

The Giants, whose major business these days seems to concern the mending of their fences in their Jersey City farm venture, bolstered Manager Travis Jackson's team some more yesterday, when Secretary Eddie Brannick announced that four players recalled by the Giants since last Fall have now been assigned on option to Jersey City.

John G. Hardin, Texas philanthropist, died here today. He was 83 years old. At death his oil fortune has dwindled, as he carefully planned, to $100,000. Baptist institutions, civic enterprises and hospitals were beneficiaries of his $5,000,000 philanthropy.

Sinclair Lewis, in an address last night at the Columbia University Institute of Arts and Sciences, denounced theatre censorship by the Roman Catholic Church as one of the compulsions in America today creating the "slave-type mind" susceptible to dictatorship.

Declaring that elimination of the chain store will restrict the markets for agricultural produce and impair the income of farmers, John A. Logan, executive vice president of the National Association of Food Chains, yesterday urged the protection of chains from "discriminatory legislation" at the afternoon session of the annual convention of the National Association of Marketing Officials at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

John L. Lewis, addressing the convention of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee today, delivered an ultimatum to the American Federation of Labor by demanding that it permit industrial organization in the basic industries and take in the C. I. O.'s claimed 4,000,000 members all together.

Stephen D. Finale of 9,917 Shore Road, Brooklyn, Greek-American lawyer, was appointed yesterday by Attorney General Bennett as a special Assistant Attorney General to aid in Mr. Bennett's inquiry into the affairs of the Hellenic Bank and Trust Company of 51 Maiden Lane. Mr. Finale, who will serve as interpreter, as well as investigator, under Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall, will be sworn in tomorrow.

Man triumphs over Nature by means of the Machine. If a mountain is not decently inaccessible and unsocial, there must be a road up it for his convenience. The modern communion with Nature likes to be accompanied with the barking of hot dogs.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Interstate Cooperation on Uniform Banking Laws will hold its second annual conference at the Hotel Biltmore today, it was announced yesterday by Assemblyman Harold Ostertag, chairman of the committee. The meeting,

Almost every student of the 1,200 enrolled at Bucknell University signed a petition which was presented to Acting President Arnaud C. Martz in convocation this morning, urging him to accept a permanent presidency. The petition took him completely by surprise.
The League of Nations published today the annual report of the supervisory body dealing with the "estimated World's requirements of dangerous drugs for 1938."

The A. C. Horn Company declared yesterday on its common stock a dividend of 60 cents, of which 40 cents will be payable in 6 per cent non-cumulative, non-voting $5 par preferred stock of Horn Maintenance Division, Inc., at the rate of one share of such stock for each twelve and one-half shares of A. C. Horn Company held.
The management of the Standard Gas and Electric Company mailed Copies of a plan of reorganization for the utility to security holders yesterday and also requested acceptance of the plan.
World rearmament, causing a scramble for iron ore, has brought prosperity to at least one company and a handsome Christmas bonus to its miners.
Panzer overwhelmed Wagner, 4822, tonight for its fourth victory of the season. Panzer was ahead at the half, 24-12. Ed Martins's 13 points gave him scoring honors.

Sir Courtenay Walter Bennett, British Consul General in San Francisco during the earthquake in 1906, died at his home in Postbridge, Devon, today at the age of 82. In 1907 he was appointed Consul General in New York, which post he held until the second year of the World War.
Long shots played a prominent role in racing at the Fair Grounds today as H. H. Chopin's Persuader captured the featured mile-and-a-sixteenth event under Frankie Grill's fine ride.
In a see-saw game, Harvard's hockey team came from behind to tie a plucky Boston University six, then go on to win, 5-4, in overtime at the Boston Arena tonight.
Edward Richards, 42 years old, who said he lived at the West Side branch of the Y. M. C. A. in New York, was convicted here today by City Judge Charles A. Voss on a
If the New Jersey deer census doesn't show a decided drop tonight it won't be because the hunters weren't out, for this looks like a record season for that State, at least in the number of hunters.

Redmond Co. will distribute a Christmas bonus of one week's salary to all employes, it was announced yesterday. The Chase National Bank has been appointed transfer agent for the 6 per cent convertible preferred, 5 per cent convertible preferred and common shares of the E. W. Bliss Company.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the CCC, is continued on active duty until the date indicated. Capt. Benjamin Harris, Q.M.-Res., June 17. 1st Lt. George W. Warren, C.A.-Res., June 20.

The competitive spirit that carried Bill Bonthron to the world outdoor 1,500-meter record in his heyday as a runner again has seized the former Princeton track star. Forsaking the mile, Bonthron will essay a comeback during the 1938 outdoor season in the longer distances-two or three miles.

George H. Hoyt Jr., 27-year-old automobile salesman of Fort Salonga, was exonerated today by the Suffolk County grand jury when it refused to indict him on a charge of second-degree manslaughter in connection with the death of Samuel A, Walsh, retired broker, also of Fort Salonga.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull made plain today in commenting on the partial payment by Hungary of her war debt installment yesterday and her indication that she would soon approach the United States for an adjustment of her debt that any debt readjustments will be subject to the consent of Congress.

Mayor La Guardia warned yesterday that there is no possibility of more than a small part of the $414,518,050 capital outlay budget requests made by city departments and agencies being translated into actuality this coming year at least, since,- as he explained, he "can neither print money nor revise the multiplication table."

George Lansbury arrived here today on the last stage of his "quest for peace" tour, which has already embraced Prague and Warsaw. Soon after arriving he was received by Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt.

Dr. John Dewey, chairman of the International Commission of Inquiry which investigated the Moscow trials and pronounced them to have been "frame-ups," declared yesterday that a new frame-up may be in process of formation in Moscow. This new frame-up, he said, "will attempt to besmirch" the commission "and discredit its work."

A justice of the peace has no legal right to change a jail sentence, once it has been pronounced, Justice Francis Bergan of the State Supreme Court decided today. He sustained a writ of habeas corpus, releasing Garfield Roe from the Schoharie County jail. Roe, arrested Nov. 15,
The foreign department of the Manufacturers Trust Company has compiled an exporters' handbook for distribution to customers of the bank engaged in export trade.

Frederick A. Hodgman, former manufacturer of rubber sundries, died last night at his home here at the age of 67. He was vice president of the Hodgman Rubber Company, a concern established a century ago by his grandfather, until it closed in 1925.

J. Donald Budge of Oakland. Calif., and Miss Alice Marble of Beverly Hills, Calif., again head the national rankings of the United States Lawn Tennis Association as recommended by the national ranking committee. The ratings,

Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Fatio were hosts to twelve tonight for dinner at their home here. Mrs. Ward Ames Jr. gave a luncheon at her villa. Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer entertained with a dinner at their villa, where Milton W. Holden of New York is a guest.

Chairman Royal S. Copeland or New York said today that the Senate Maritime Committee would ask information from the United States Vice Consul at Manila about reports that passengers on the President Hoover were terrorized by drunken crew members after the ship ran aground near Taiwan (Formosa) last Friday.

Miss Mary H. Lynch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lynch of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Dr. Paul F. Jarrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Jarrett of Stamford. The ceremony will take place on Jan. 11 in St. Catherine's Church, Riverside.

President Roosevelt sent to Congress amendments to broaden the Social Security Act, presented Lincoln Ellsworth with a gold medal in recognition of Antarctic land claimed for the United States, and Was host tonight at the diplomatic reception, first of the White House Winter social series.

There is an irreconcilable conflict between religious groups and a totalitarian State, Irving Lehman, Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, declared last night at a meeting of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America and its New York society in the library of the seminary, 122d Street and Broadway, commemorating the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution of the United States.

The Hamburg - American liner Deutschland will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports, bringing Otto Lehmann, Joseph P. Goodyear, Ludwig F. Bauer, Mr. and Mrs. D. B. Monroe, Mr. and Mrs. F. Bierling, Mrs. M. C. Slane, Mrs. Hertha Kramer, Mrs. Elizabeth Fench, Mrs. Marie Barning, Mr. and Mrs. Hermann Grag, Mrs. Marie Timpe, Mr. and Mrs. Carl William Spohr and Mr. and Mrs. Siegfried Strauss.
The arrival of $7,217,000 of gold from Japan at San Francisco on Wednesday was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Dr. Glenn Frank, former president of the University of Wisconsin, was chosen chairman of the Republican party's Committee on Program, which will draft a declaration of party principles.
Stockholders of Stone Webster, Inc., have approved the plan whereby the company will relinquish controlling interest in public utility companies, it was announced today.
Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone recessed the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case today until after Dec. 28 after the death of Mrs. Stone's mother, Mrs. Louis Dessert, at Wausau, Wis.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to listing the common stock of the Community Public Service Company, which was issued, share for share, in exchange for stock trust certificates representing the common shares. Dealings in the stock trust certificates have been suspended..
Wrangling and confusion among members of the Legislature tonight blocked Mayor La Guardia's plan for adoption of the city's new administrative code in a one-day special session.

In the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria tonight a large dinner dance will be held as a commemorative tribute to the late Miss Lila Agnew Stewart, who for many years before her death last January was a leading organizer and director of charity balls and pageants.
Lumber output declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index eased to 56.5 from 56.8. The figure for the week ended Dec. 12, 1936, was 77.8.

Appraisals of the value of the collateral behind the three bond issues of the Alleghany Corporation made by the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee, as of Dec. 2, show that it is below the level of Nov. 1.

Six more of the indictments handed up in 1934 in the investigation by a New York County grand jury into alleged irregularities in the management of several title mortgage companies were quashed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Wallace.

Order of Retirement SURGEON-Patrick J. York, 16th Medical District, on an annual pension of $2,650. LIEUTENANT-Michael J. Tormey, 87th Precinct, on an annual pension of $2,000. LIEUTENANT-John J. Ward, 18th Drvi. sion. M. 0. D., Brooklyn, on an annual pension of $2,000.

Mrs. Richard Laurence Parish of 988 Fifth Avenue entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Colony Restaurant for her debutante stepdaughter, Miss Rae Emily Parish, who was introduced to society on Nov. 27 at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Parish at Rock Ridge Farm, their place in Brewster, N. Y.
In the match that decided the Class A interclub championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, the Harvard Club team defeated the University Club, 5 to Q, last night.

In addition to their toll in human suffering, the extremely heavy snows in Northern New York and the conditions of heavy crust and ice sheathing which already have marked such wide areas of the country this year, have spelled tragedy for the birds. Game birds, especially, are sufferers.

Sidney Stajer, who used to be one of Arnold Rothstein's closest friends and who was held in $100,000 bail for a time as a witness in the murder of th gambler in 1928, was in custody again yesterday charged with violation of Section. 101 of the United States Criminal Code.
Nassau County police were searching today for a man who stole several yachting cups and pieces of silverware from the home of Paul Hammond, Manhattan real estate dealer, at East Norwich last night.

The Eli White Memorial Building, a new $1,500,000 structure for the nurses of St. Luke's Hospital, was opened formally last night. With nurses as guides, several hundred guests inspected the fourteen-story building that extends from Amsterdam Avenue and West 114th Street to West 115th Street.
A group of prominent residents of Staten Island have purchased from the executors of the estate of George Cromwell a tract of about twenty-six acres of undeveloped land at Dongan Hills.
The Treasury announced today that the net deficit had fallen below the $695,245,000 estimate for the fiscal year made by President Roosevelt day on Oct. 19, last.

Thirty-three mortgage certificates on properties in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island, and six first mortgages on properties in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Long Island, were offered for sale at auction in the Vesey Street salesroom yesterday by Joseph P. Day, Inc.

William McGuire, veteran senior guard, was elected captain of the Brooklyn College basketball team yesterday after Coach Arthur Musicant had sent his Kingsmen through a workout for the weekend games with New York University and Lafayette College.

Movements of ships follow. All dates are Dec. 15 unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Acush net, Kewaydin, Dec. 16; Fairfax. Lynn Haven Roads to sea, Dec. 16: Jacob Jones. Leary. Barker, at Sangley Point, Dec. 16. Charleston, Balboa to Panama Bay Area, Dec. 16.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in light trading on the local Exchanges yesterday. Cocoa, rubber and silk futures were better, while copper, lead, zinc and wool-top futures declined. In the cash market rye, cocoa, tins, cotton, silk and rubber advanced. Wheat, corn, flour, lard, copper and lead declined.

Charles C. Fagg, vice president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, in charge of its branch at Forty-first Street and Madison Avenue, was elected president of the Association of Uptown Bankers at a dinner meeting last night at the Harvard Club. Edward Streeter,

President Roosevelt presented today a gold Congressional Medal to Lieut. Comdr. Lincoln Ellsworth in recognition of his Antarctic flight in 1935, during which he claimed 350,000 square miles of territory on behalf of the United States.

Abandonment of any attempt by Congressional leaders to put through President Roosevelt's recommendation for a reduction in Federal road aid authorizations was virtually decided on today, after it became known that new Administration moves had failed to dislodge the House Roads Committee from its almost unanimous stand against the recommendation.

Nine days of freezing weather, which had brought general expectations of an old-fashioned Christmas, ended yesterday when the temperature rose to 45 degrees at 1:30 P. M. The Weather Bureau announced that similar conditions would prevail today and that any precipitation would be likely to be rain rather than snow.

Declining for the fifth consecutive week, bank clearings of the twenty-two principal cities of the country fell 24.3 per cent below the corresponding total of last year. tripling the loss of the preceding week.

Believing that nothing is what it seems in the theatre, Dorothy Day Wendell has burrowed into the private dossier of a lustrous star in "Tell Me, Pretty Maiden," which was put on at the Mansfield last evening. Sidewalk sources,
Meeting of the Woman's Forum, Hotel Roosevelt 10:45 A. M. Speakers: Natalie F. Couch, Henry H. Curran, Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d.
In a flare-up of labor disputes here 450 passengers were left behind when a sudden strike on the Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda forced her to sail with a skeleton crew. [Page 1.]

A somewhat better tone ruled in most sections of the bond market yesterday in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. About the most outstanding group movement occurred in the market for United States Government obligations, which responded to a brisk demand with good-sized gains. Corporate loans were mixed and closed irregularly higher.
Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne, who will leave early next week to pass the holidays at Claremont, their home in Columbia, S. C., gave a tea yesterday afternoon at their suite in the Ambassador.

The report of engineering construction awards made in the week ended yesterday again reflected a decline from the corresponding week of last year. The total for the week, $35,706,000, was 11 per cent under the $39,853,000 registered in 1936, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Charles Fuller Young, from estate of Ogden Goelet. in 180 E 78th St: William A. Abbot, through Maryland Realty Co, Inc. in 349 E 58th St; Dorothy Raymond, in 48 E 49th St; William Steele, 3d and Donald Snowden, in 53 E 51st St; Frank W. Berrien, through Bilbal Corp, in 38 E 75th St; Burgoyne Hamilton Co, Inc. broker.

The directors of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company declared yesterday a Christmas bonus equal to 5 per cent of annual salary for all employes who receive less than $5,000 a year. About 1,400 employes will receive the extra payment.

After dropping severely for eleven consecutive weeks, business in the Pittsburgh district rose slightly in the week ended Dec. 11, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

Alfred University staved off a desperate last-minute attack to defeat the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute quintet, 28 to 26, tonight. Captain Pitman of Brooklyn and Bob Clynn or Alfred tied for scoring honors with 10 points each.

George Washington, John Adams, Thomas Jefterson, James Madison, James Monroe and John Quincy Adams would be startled to know that an American President had refused to dress up to receive an Ambassador.

The Taxpayers Association of the Tenth, Eleventh and Seventeenth Wards of the City of New York, Inc., will hold a meeting this evening in the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street. Nomination of officers will take place and discussion of the water tax is one of the items on the program.

The six-story garden apartment house at 83-19 116th Street, Kew Gardens, Queens, has been sold by the Stern Brothers estate to Brown Shenker, operators. Situated on a plot 83 by 250 feet, the building houses fifty-nine families in suites of two to five rooms.
Approval by the House Banking Committee of proposed liberalization of FHA mortgage insurance policies brightens the prospect of early passage of the measure by Congress. .

Officials for the Rose Bowl football game in Pasadena between Alabama and the University of California on New Year's Day were announced today by Herb Dana, Pacific Coast Conference. Commissioner of Officials.

Charles Dibble Bostwick, Cornell University's controller since 1919, died today at his home here. He was stricken a year ago, lacking a day, at a meeting of the university's finance committee in New York.

16.-Tables in Beverly Hills police station today were piled high with plunder which Arthur Kent, Communist party leader, told officers he had taken from homes here as "compulsory social taxation." At the same time Kent, his wife, Mrs. Harriet Kent, and Tom Johnson, business manager of The C. I. O.'s Industrial Unionist, faced trial on felony charges.

Robert Sweeny, Americanborn holder of the British amateur golf championship, will not be considered for a place on Great Britain's 1938 Walker Cup team. Henry Gullen, secretary of the Royal and Ancient Club, said today.

Members of District Attorney William C. Dodge's staff were informed yesterday that on Tuesday night last the nine General Sessions judges had been the guests of District Attorney-elect Thomas E. Dewey at a dinner in the University Club. All but two of the judges are Tammany men.

Moving to build up a merchant marine as a "real" auxiliary to national defense, the Maritime Commission asked bids today for twelve fast single-screw steel cargo vessels, the cost expected to be $18,000,000 to $23,000,000.

Taking an early lead, the Seton Hall basketball team defeated Lafayette at the Orange Armory tonight, 40-23. The winners led at the half, 17-6. Ed Sadowski topped the individual scorers with 9 points.

Officials for the Rose Bowl football game in Pasadena between Alabama and the University of California on New Year's Day were announced today by Herb Dana, Pacific Coast Conference. Commissioner of Officials.

Moving to build up a merchant marine as a "real" auxiliary to national defense, the Maritime Commission asked bids today for twelve fast single-screw steel cargo vessels, the cost expected to be $18,000,000 to $23,000,000.

Taking an early lead, the Seton Hall basketball team defeated Lafayette at the Orange Armory tonight, 40-23. The winners led at the half, 17-6. Ed Sadowski topped the individual scorers with 9 points.

A bill being prepared for submission to Congress would cancel approxilately $2,675,000.000 of notes of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation that are held by the Treasury for money expended for relief and advanced to other governmental agencies, Jesse Jones, chairman of the RFC. announced this afternoon.

The Taxpayers Association of the Tenth, Eleventh and Seventeenth Wards of the City of New York, Inc., will hold a meeting this evening in the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street. Nomination of officers will take place and discussion of the water tax is one of the items on the program.

The six-story garden apartment house at 83-19 116th Street, Kew Gardens, Queens, has been sold by the Stern Brothers estate to Brown Shenker, operators. Situated on a plot 83 by 250 feet, the building houses fifty-nine families in suites of two to five rooms.

Declaring he favored fair-trade laws "enthusiastically," Earl A. Means, vice president in charge of sales of the Bristol-Myers Company, yesterday told a luncheon meeting of the Pharmaceutical Advertising Directors Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania that the Tydings-Miller law "would never be killed."
France's financial situation was laid on the table and dissected today in the Chamber of Deputies when, next year's appropriations having been voted, the deputies began consideration of income.

Employe relations problems led in the voting of member stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association for the selection of the "big issues" of retailing, which are to be spotlighted at the twentyseventh annual convention of the association to be held here from Jan. 31 to Feb. 4, it was announced yesterday.
Don Noble of the Crescent A. C. and Joseph De Raismes of the Montclair A. C. gained the final round yesterday of the Fall B and C squash tennis tournament at the City A. C. courts.
French insane asylums are filled to overflowing because of the depression, war scare, unemployment and worries for tomorrow growing out of the social unrest, so A. Villey,

The Midston House players turned in their fifth victory in as many times out and strengthened their hold on first place in Group II of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association by blanking the City Athletic Club, 5-0, on the Midston courts yesterday.
Resolutions urging the Dominion to stop export of war material to Japan and calling on Canadians to refrain from buying Japanese goods were passed unanimously at a mass meeting here last night.

A French military mission, headed by General Rutzinger, commander of the French forces in Syria, arrived at Angora today to discuss with Turkish military experts the question of demilitarization of the Sanjak of Alexandretta in accordance with the Geneva agreement.

Members of the House Rivers and Harbors Committee, considering the Administration's measure for the creation of seven planning zones for flood control, land conservation and incidental power- development, failed today to obtain a flat answer approving or disapproving the proposed measure from Major Gen. J. L. Schley, chief of the Army Engineering Corps.

Trading was fair to slow in local markets yesterday. Veal cuts sold higher, fresh pork and steer cuts steady to lower, other classes mostly unchanged from Wednesday's close. Thursday, being an off-kosher day.

A pair of hard-hitting heavyweights will trade punches tonight at Madison Square Garden, where Buddy Baer, younger brother of Max, former heavyweight champion of the world, opposes Eddie Hogan of Waterbury, Conn. They will meet in the feature bout of ten rounds and are expected to attract a crowd of 10,000 fans.
Orders to buy odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange last week exceeded orders to sell by 9,312, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today in its weekly summary of odd-lot operations.

Among the 429 gifts that added $8,675.71 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, increasing the total for the twenty-sixth annual appeal to $138,483.22, was one of $1.23 in pennies accompanied by the following letters:
103d St. 112-14 W, 42.10x100.11; 112 W 103d Corp (Hyman Bernstein, pres) to Irving Shapiro, 79 Seaman Ave, et al., p m, prior mtg $36,000, due Dec. 15, 1948. at 5%: $8.500.

Complete reorganization of the evening school system to create a separate full-time personnel, give tenure rights to teachers and more than double the present services was proposed yesterday by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, chairman of the Board of Education's instructional affairs committee.
Pauline Fleming, a freshman, was selected as the student with the most perfect posture in a contest sponsored by the Athletic Association at Barnard College yesterday.

TODAY-New England: Generally cloudy, with occasional snow and sleet, with rising temperatures to near and probably above the freezing points over the north; generally cloudy, with higher and thawing temperature over central and southern portions. New York State:

Central Europe, with a rapidly increasing population which has already reached 70,000,000, offers tremendous opportunities for American trade, Hugo Vavrecka, director of Bata Shoe Company and former Minister of the Czechoslovak Republic in Vienna, declared last night at the annual dinner of the American - Czechoslovak Chamber of Commerce at the Belmont Plaza Hotel. The territory to which Mr.

Overwhelming sentiment against retaining the stymie has been expressed in this area, it was made public last night at the fortieth annual meeting of thg Metropolitan Golf Association in the Hotel Commodore.

Running through fog so thick the horses were not visible until they hit the sixteenth pole, Lame Duck won today's feature race at Tanforan track. The time for the mile was 1:39 3-5. Searover II, an Argentine importation, ran second, anid Exhibit, post-time favorite, third.

Lieut. Col. Charles A. Eastman, who served as chief of the fuel supply division of the A. E. F. in France, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, 130 Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, at the age of 74.

Today's major events: "Trovatore," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 P. M.; Mount Holyoke Glee Club, Town Hall, evening; Suzanne Bloch, lutanist, Steinway Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Federal Opera Chorus and Greenwich Orchestra, Theatre of Music, 8:45 P. M.

None of the important items in yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks reached a new high or low figure for the year. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."
Miss Arlene A. Beecher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Beecher, was married to Grant Joseph Durley, son of Dayton Durley, all of this village, last night in the First Congregational Church.

The effect of putting the Ludlow war referendum resolution in the Constitution would achieve its undeclared purpose. This is-in addition to requiring assent by a popular majority of the voters to a declaration of war, except when our territory is invaded and our citizens are attacked-to shackle the Executive in the conduct of foreign policy in critical times.

Nominees for election as Rhodes scholars were chosen today by committees in twenty States. The selection of State nominees will be completed on Saturday and the district committees, which are to name the thirty-two scholars entering Oxford University next Fall for two or three year courses, will have their meetings on Monday.
Police of suburban Dearborn arrested 208 union members today, thus breaking up another attempt of the United Automobile Workers to distribute hand bills to employes of the Ford Motor Company.
Amid cheers of "Hoch Habsburg!" the Federal Parliament unanimously enacted a law today restoring eight estates to the Habsburg family.

Continued active trading in hides this week has brought further price advances and has resulted in a liquidation of stocks of calfskins in the hands of collectors and butchers. Prices on several standard grades of hides have advanced 1/2 cent in the week.

Nominees for election as Rhodes scholars were chosen today by committees in twenty States. The selection of State nominees will be completed on Saturday and the district committees, which are to name the thirty-two scholars entering Oxford University next Fall for two or three year courses, will have their meetings on Monday.
Police of suburban Dearborn arrested 208 union members today, thus breaking up another attempt of the United Automobile Workers to distribute hand bills to employes of the Ford Motor Company.
Amid cheers of "Hoch Habsburg!" the Federal Parliament unanimously enacted a law today restoring eight estates to the Habsburg family.

Continued active trading in hides this week has brought further price advances and has resulted in a liquidation of stocks of calfskins in the hands of collectors and butchers. Prices on several standard grades of hides have advanced 1/2 cent in the week.

Even before the celebrations attendant upon the formal Japanese entry into Nanking today, the Japanese Army launched three new drives against a great semi-circle of Chinese forces estimated at thirty divisions, or more than 300,000 men, disposed on a new front with a total length of about 220 miles.
Fifty or more of the most important leaders in the American amusement field held an informal luncheon conference yesterday to consider plans for the diversion features of the New York World's Fair.

Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message to the extraordinary session of the Legislature, urging "consideration" of Mayor La Guardia's Administrative Code Bill and supplementary legislation:

Lincoln's portrait is going to be restored to its place among the nation's postage stamps after an absence of several years. Representative Sauthoff of Wisconsin received that information today from Roy M. North, acting third assistant Postmaster general, after protesting against discontinuance of 3-cent Lincoln stamps in 1932. Mr.

James N. MacLean, general chairman of the Municipal Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, announced yesterday that the committee would continue its services to distressed mortgagors and mortgagees. After operating since March,
Germany has either building or "planned" a total of 115 warships with a combined tonnage of 304,128, according to Weyer's 1938 Naval Handbook, just issued.

Patrolman Charles H. Wellman of the West New York(N. J.) police force testified yesterday in Special Sessions that when New York motorists are caught in that State violating the traffic laws they are given a break on showing "courtesy cards" and purchasing tickets for any of the charity enterprises of the Police- and Court Officers Benevolent Association of New Jersey..

W. H. Tilman, leader of last year's successful attempt to scale Nanda Devi, 25,645 feet, highest peak yet climbed, and a member of the Mount Everest reconnaissance party in 1935, has been chosen to lead a new British expedition that will make an attempt on Everest next year.

An air of festivity and gayety prevailed in the ranks of the vast Eastern skiing army yesterday as reports from the "Northlands" indicated that the first big period of running this season is in store for this week-end.

Dr. Leigh Harrison Hunt, Professor Emeritus of Art at the College of the City of New York, etcher, noted art lecturer, art critic and physician; died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.

Dance International has added two lectures to its series at its headquarters in the International Building, Rockefeller Center. This morning at 10 Dr. Hans Schuman of the Mozarteum in Salzburg will speak on "Dancing in Relation to the Other Arts."
