Mr. and Mrs. Howard R. Schroyer of Evanston, III., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Virginia Seldomridge, to John Lansing Zabriskie, son of Mrs. Nicholas Lansing Zabriskie of Aurora, N. Y., and the late Mr. Zabriskie.

Frederic Augustus Stevenson of Croton-on-Hudson, N. Y., retired assistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, who took an important part in the development of longdistance telephone service to its present world-wide scope, died yesterday in New York Hospital, after an illness of several weeks. He was 71 years old.

Strength in United States Government bonds was the feature of an otherwise dull and routine trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The Treasury loans responded to a good demand and, in heavier trading, recorded gains of 1-32 to 8-32 of a point.

Commemorative public tribute was paid to the late Miss Lila Agnew Stewart, for many years a leading organizer and director of colorful society pageants and charity balls, at a large dinner dance in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

Morris Broomer, 39 years old, a letter carrier of 1,755 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn to serve two and one-half years in a Federal penitentiary for robbing the mails.

Without opinion, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously affirmed yesterday a decision of Supreme Court Justice Shientag dismissing a government suit to recover $2,842,616 from nine member banks of the New York Ge Clearing House to complete the payment of depositors in the closed Harriman National Bank. The action was brought in the name of the Controller of the Currency.
Borrowing by States and municlpalities again featured the new-issue market this week as tax-exempt loans accounted for $27,399,000 of the total of $29,199,000 of new bonds publicly offered.

The late Edward M. Shepard, '68, in whose name the City College House Plan Center at 292 Convent Avenue was dedicated yesterday, was described as one of the moving spirits of the college in its early days by friends and alumni.

A forthcoming volume in Macmillan's series of Pioneer Histories is "The Invasion of China by the Western World." The author, E. R. Hughes, Reader in Chinese Religion and Philosophy at Oxford, lived for several years in a rural interior district of China and later resided in Shanghai and Peking.

Edwin A. Shewan of 1,075 Park Avenue has announced the marriage of his daughter, Miss Anne Barbara Shewan, to David Milne Smith, son of Mrs. Gouverneur E. Smith of Syosset, L. I., which took place on Wednesday in Elkton, Md.

60th St, 134 E; Eighty-fourth St. Second Ave. Corp., Samuel Siegel, president, to Dry Dock Savings Institution; purchase money mtg., $30,000. 2d Ave., 2,274-6, s e cor 117th St: Carlotta Cincotti to Fifth Ave. Bank, trustee of Frank Eveland; due Dec. 1. 1942; $12,000.

President Roosevelt indicated emphatic opposition today to the Ludlow resolution proposing a constitutional amendment requiring a national referendum to declare war except in case of invasion. Without hesitation, and with a sharpness not characteristic of him, he uttered the one word, "No," to the question:
Not the least puzzling feature in the story of the pseudo-Robinsons of East Seventeenth Street and Moscow is their reported

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today the value for ratemaking purposes of the properties of the Shell Pipe Line Corporation, the Texas Pipe Line Company (Texas) and the Atlantic Pipe Line Company, as of Dec. 31, 1934.

Patrick J. Higgins, retired police chief of this borough, died today at his home here following a stroke. His age was 77. Mr. Higgins served as chief seventeen years, being succeeded by his son, William P., ten years ago.

Edward Wheelock Runyan, pharmacist, chemist and a descendant of Eleazar Wheelock, founder of Dartmouth College, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 237 West Seventy-fourth Street, at the age of 86.

The story of the Travelers Aid is the same year by year, but it is ever new in that fifty thousand new individuals are each year dealt with. Those of the preceding years have gone their several ways, thanks to the patient, kind-souled, resourceful women who helped them to their destinations.

By a vote of 59 to 29, the Senate early this evening passed the omnibus farm bill, designed to carry out Secretary Wallace's ever-normal granary plan with its provisions for compulsory crop surplus control, and sent the much-amended measure to conference between the two legislative bodies.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today an order suspending effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 on July 23, 1936, by ,the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., Glendale, Calif., covering 500,640 shares of $1-par value common stock.

Reorganization proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act are for the relief of debtors, Federal Judge Hulbert said yesterday, slashing fees asked by attorneys and others in the reorganization of the Warner-Quinlan Company by almost 75 per cent.
Plans for low-cost group hospitalization for 1,000,000 persons now unable to pay for medical service are now being formed, Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, revealed yesterday.
Through wholesale atrocities and vandalism at Nanking the Japanese Army has thrown arway a rare opportunity to gain the respect and confidence of the Chinese inhabitants and of foreign opinion there.
Those scoreless wonders of three grueling football games, Pitt and Fordham, clashed last night in a game where they couldn't help making some points.

Basketball will open with a grand flourish in Madison Square Garden tonight as two singularly attractive offerings mark the start of the fourth season of the court game there under the direction of Ned Irish.

John W. Hanes, recently appointed to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has transferred his New York Stock Exchange membership to John B. Moriarty for a nominal consideration. Mr. Moriarty will become a general partner in Mitchel, Whitner Watts.

Julius Streicher, the high priest of anti-Semitism and organizer of the first anti-Jewish boycott in 1933, declared today a new boycott of Jewishs shops in his district, where placards to that effect have been posted in front of all Jewish shops and on all public billboards.
A proposal that Congress take the initiative in bringing Orville Wright's first airplane back to this country marked the thirtyfourth birthday of the airplane.

An intensified anti-trust drive is contemplated by the Department of Justice, it was disclosed today, when Attorney General Cummings asked the House Appropriations Committee for funds with which to employ twenty-five additional special assistants and to increase his permanent personnel slightly.

A Yorkville transaction involving an exchange of cablegrams with the buyer in France was announced yesterday. It included the three five-story apartment houses at 322, 324 and 326 East Eighty-second Street, Which were sold by the estate of Samuel I. Davis to the Keid Corporation representing a French syndicate.

Economists of the Department of Agriculture estimated today that farmers in the United States, despite the bumper crops that depressed prices, would receive a cash income of $8,500,000,000 this yearthe largest since the boom year of 1929.
Salvatore Cilento, president of the Alcoholicc Beverage Salesmen's Union, A. F. of L., called a strike yesterday which he said affected fifteen importers of wines, champagne and Scotch whisky.

Coronet Hat, Inc, milliner, in 417 5th Ave: Edwin L. Howard. in 101 Park Ave. Isidore Warshaw, in 130 W 42d St: Irving Phillips in 12-14 W 37th St; Harry Kleinman, in 3-5 W 36th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker. Family Shoe Corp, in 909 Broadway; Waldorf Novelty Corp, braids and shoelaces, in 693-7 Broadway: John Ginsburg, cigars, etc, in 354-60 4th Ave; M. and L. Hess, Inc, broker.

The police force recruited for the new Lincoln Tunnel, which will be dedicated next Tuesday, will give a "dress rehearsal" for officials of the Port of New York Authority this afternoon at 3 o'clock on the Weehawken Plaza of the tunnel.

Cardinal Hayes has renewed permission to his pastors to offer a midnight mass in their churches on Christmas Eve. He made the announcement through a letter sent to the clergy by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, the Vicar General. "This privilege is given assuming that the pastors will take every precaution to preserve the dignity and solemnity befitting the sacredness of the occasion," wrote Mgr. Lavelle.

Guests at the formal affair at the White House Dec. 30, at which the engagement of Anne Lindsay Clark of Boston and John Roosevelt, youngest son of the President, will be celebrated, will get around to doing the Big Apple if they stay long enough into the evening.

Following an early improvement, prices on the New York Cotton Exchange eased yesterday under a slight increase in hedging pressure and less aggressive buying than had occurred on previous days of the week.

Perhaps the most direct indication of the manner in which Mexican organized labor has been seeking to put foreign companies out of business was given today when the officially backed Mexican Federation of Workers publicly opposed a bill sent by President Lazaro Cardenas to Congress making the theft of electric current a criminal offense.
The Rev. Nelson Royden Rand died of a heart attack today a few hours before he was to have appeared in a radio program as Santa Claus. He was 50 years old.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool market has continued to improve, although top futures toward the end of the week have receded somewhat from their peak of Tuesday. There is more business in fine territory and Texas wool and some inquiry for medium bright wools.

Aviation developments during the next ten years will be as "great" as they have been in the last decade, Orville Wright said in an interview yesterday afternoon at Columbia University, where he attended a meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences in observance of the thirty-fourth anniversary of the first airplane flight. Mr. Wright made the first flight Dec. 17, 1903, at Kitty Hawk, N. C.

Don Budge and Gene Mako, the American Davis Cup doubles team, dropped a four-set decision today to Australia's Jack Bromwich and Adrian Quist in an international exhibition series. The scores were 3--6, 6--4, 6--3, 6--2.

Eight centuries ago Maimonides, physician and philosopher, laid down his eight degrees of charity. The sixth of these is "to know the objects of our bounty but remain unknown to them," the seventh "to bestow charity in such a way that the benefactors may not know the relieved persons, nor they the names of their benefactors."

Fox St (10-2726), e s, 98 ft n of 165th St, 1OOx1OO: Felix A. Muldoon. trustee, to Bessie Handler, 1.491 Macombs Rd, mtg, $115,000. Hone Ave, 1.517 (15-4067); George Rose to Dorothy Abrahams, 1,517 Hone Ave.

With an announced list of Christmas donations totaling $175,000, and many other gifts, the amounts of which were not made public, the trustees of the Charles Hayden Foundation, meeting here yesterday, pledged continuation of the purposes set forth in the will of the late Charles Hayden.

Scoring rallies by the Boston Olympics late in the first and early in the third periods tonight yielded a 7-4 victory over Yale. The Elis staged a drive late in the second chapter which produced three goals and cut the visitors' lead to 4-3.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Marshall gave a dinner with dancing last night in the penthouse of the St. Regis for Miss Barbara Field and Anthony Addison Bliss, whose marriage will take place Monday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Representatives of patriotic societies, persons prominent in education and military affairs in the New York area, were among the guests of honor at the annual formal dance of the Officers Club of City College unit of the R. O. T. C. held in the Hotel Roosevelt last night. More than fifteen hundred persons attended.

SECOND MILITARY AREA Capt. Donald W. MacArdle, Spec.-Res.. has qualified as pistol expert, score 89.50. Each of the following Engineer-Reserve officers, unassigned, is assigned to the organization indicated:

The Associated Railways Company and the seven railroads that organized the company to take over the longbankrupt Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad filed today strongly phrased exceptions to the recent report of a trial examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission recommending that the proposed plan be disapproved.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court refused yesterday to permit the Transit Commission to appeal its decision holding that former Mayor James J. Walker's original appointment as special counsel at $12,000 a year was illegal.

With her flags at half-staff honoring the day American dead below decks in crude Chinese coffins, the United gunboat Oahu swept around the bend just below Shanghai's Bund at 4:30 this afternoon and twenty minutes later tied up alongside the flagship Augusta.

The materialistic philosophy of American cities is leading to the disintegration of the American home, Dr. O. E. Baker, economist and statistician, warned last night in addressing the annual meeting of the Christian Rural Fellowship, at the Russell Sage Building, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Grosvenor gave a dance tonight at Wildacres, their home at Bethesda, Md., near here, for their debutante niece, Miss Anne Somerville Grosvenor, daughter of Mrs. Charles S. Whitman of New York and of the late Edwin Prescott Grosvenor.

Governor George C. Peery, highranking officials of the nation's railways and hundreds of other friends of W. J. Harahan attended last rites today for the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad president, who died Tuesday at Clifton Forge, Va.

Curtailed production by full-fashioned hosiery manufacturers for the two weeks following the hollday demand to insure a stable Spring market was urged yesterday in the Special Dress News Letter of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Scoring decisive victories yesterday, the Crescent Athletic Club and the Harvard Club remained deadlocked for first place in the Metropolitan League Class C squash tennis tournament. The Crescents invaded the Columbia University Club courts to register a 4-to-1 triumph, while Harvard, playing at home,
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 15: Albert, Comdr. F. L., Chaplain Corps, the Tennessee, to Naval Training Station, Great Lakes, Ill.

While their car was stopped by a traffic light in Brooklyn, two employes of the Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., were held up yesterday afternoon by two thugs who forced them to drive around the corner, then robbed them of a $7,156.86 payroll. The thugs drove off with the car, but abandoned it near by.

The report of the Outboard Marine and Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries, issued yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30, shows a net profit of $940,379 after depreciation, interest, $125,000 provision for loss on inventories, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed earnings.
Clement Buss Pentecost, engineer and vice president of the Deslauriers Steel Mould Company, Jersey City, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. His age was 48.

The Chorus Equity Association, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, announced plans yesterday to organize chorus girls in night clubs and restaurants. Speaking after a meeting of Chorus Equity in the Hotel Center, 108 West Forty-third Street, Miss Edith L. Christenson, executive secretary, said committees already had been appointed to further the campaign.

Turpentine firm, 26c; sales 65 barrels; receipts 187 barrels; no shipments; stock 34,861 barrels. Resin firm; sales 266; receipts 909; no shipments; stock 87,263. Quote: B, D, E, $1.25; F, $5.30; G, $5.40; H, $5.55: I, $5.60; K, $5.70; M, $6.00; N, $6.10; WG, $6.70; WW, X, $7.10.
New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $11,403,745, to be represented by one State and thirty-nine municipalities.

President Roosevelt summoned Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, to the White House today for a conference on the crisis with Japan over the sinking of the gunboat Panay. The conference gave an appearance of additional seriousness to the incident.

James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for Queen Anne Mills Company, Ellenboro, N. C., manufacturers of bedspreads. Samuel A. Morris, formerly of Morris Morris, has joined Buddy Manufacturing, Inc., men's pajama manufacturers, effective Jan. 1.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Two old midtown residences which long have resisted the inroads of trade expansion were doomed yesterday for demolition and will go the way of many of their neighbors to make further room for business.

Sixty Santa Clauses, including one female Kris Kringle and three Negro impersonators of the Christmas saint, all members of the Cleaners, Dyers, Pressers, Drivers and Allied Trades Union, Local 239, a C. I. O.
The government trustee now in charge of Germany's Jewish-owned shipping lines--the Arnold Bernstein and Red Star Lines--is negotiating their sale to "Aryans."

The 'lame duck' Board of Estimate with its Democratic majority held its last meeting in City Hall yesterday with Mayor La Guardia, in accordance with his promise of a week ago, absent. The new board, which takes office Jan. 1, will be Fusion and Republican, 15 to 1.

A jury today convicted John Travis and Orville Adkins of the fatal kidnapping of Dr. James I. Seder, 79-year-old dry leader. The verdict made the death penalty mandatory. The men will be sentenced Dec. 22 with Arnett A. Booth, another former convict, who was convicted on the same charge last week.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court refused unanimously yesterday to permit J. Richard (Dixie) Davis to appeal its decision disbarring him. Davis was formerly counsel to Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and is a fugitive from indictments charging he operated his former client's policy gambling business after the latter's murder.

Morris Ave (9-2449), w s, 236 ft n of McClellan St. 108x1O0; 1,024 Walton Ave Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave: extends mtgs to Oct. 1, 1947, at 5 per cent to Oct. 1, 1942, and 4 1/2 per cent thereafter: $137,500.

Louis Weber, 39 years old; described as the "policy king" of Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday in Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, on a charge of conspiracy to operate a policy bank with an alleged daily "take" of $5,000 and an estimated yearly income of $1,500,000. He pleaded not guilty and was released in $5,000 bail before Magistrate William O'Dwyer for a hearing Dec. 31.

With Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High's ace distance runner, heading a record entry of 1,376 boys, New York City's senior indoor interscholastic track and field campaign will be inaugurated tonight when the annual De La Salle Institute games will be conducted at the 102d Engineers Armory.

After a trying voyage upriver caused by the reckless shelling from shore, the United States gunboat Panay anchored at 11 A. M. Sunday, Deo. 12, in a broad stretch of the Yangtze River twenty-eight miles above Nanking. The weather was clear, sunny and still.

The first dinner dance in a series for young women who have not yet made their debuts took place last night at the Park Lane. Receiving with Miss Clementine Miller, who is directing the series, were Mrs. Edgerton Parsons, Mrs. Huntington Tappin, Mrs. A. Musgrave Hyde, Miss Susan Wood, Mrs. Erving Pruyn, Mrs. Edward Singleton and Mrs. Thomas Curtis.

Lee W. Branch, former president of the Georgia Bar Association, and his wife were shot to death in their home today. Patrolman Grady Marable said the two were killed by Livingston Snow, Mrs. Branch's brother. Marable said he was called to the home by neighbors and captured Snow in the dining room after a brief struggle.

Application blanks for 1938 automobile licenses may be obtained next Monday at all police stations and Motor Vehicle Bureau offices in the city, it was announced yesterday by Charles A. Harnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner. License plates will be issued beginning Jan. 3.
Conference on the Consumer and Peace, 99 Park Avenue, 10 A. M. to 3:30 P. M. Speakers: Raymond Leslie Buell, Maxwell S. Stewart, Joseph Curran, Kathleen McInerney.

The German Railroads Information Office, the American representative of the German railroads, has leased the two-story building at 10 East Fifty-seventh Street, near Fifth Avenue, from the Ziegler estate.
New York University's basketball team gave indications of returning to the high place held by the Violets two years ago with a 55-37 victory over Brooklyn College last night at the Heights gymnasium.

The marriage of Miss Doris Struck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Struck of Munsey Park, to C. Wilson Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grahame Cole of Little Neck, took place this evening in the Dutch Reformed Church at Manhasset. The pastor, the Rev. Oscar Maddaus, officiated.

Municipal INSPECTOR OF PIPES AND CASTINGS, GRADE 3--Salary: $2,400 to, but not including. $3,000 per annum; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies: Several appointments are expected in the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity in the near future; one appointment made from last list. Ages: Through 55, on Dec. 30. Applications: Received to 4 P. M.,

Biography, 6-year-old gelding owned by Norman (Butsy) Hernandez of New Orleans, annexed his third race of the Fair Grounds meeting today when he defeated five other players in the mile and a sixteenth of the Raceland Purse.

The marriage of Miss Marron Mackie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Story Mackie of Princeton, N. J., to Dudley Hume Johnson of Columbus, Ohio, son of Mrs. John Elmoran Porter of Boston and the late Charles C. Johnson, took place here at noon today at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. John Rainay McGinley.
David A. Smart, president of Esquire-Coronet, Inc., yesterday announced that on Monday a Christmas bonus of 10 per cent of 1937 earnings will be distributed to all employes.

" Journey's End," made by the old Tiffany Company in 1930, has been placed on Metro's schedule for Robert Taylor, who returned yesterday from his trip abroad. The film will follow "Northwest Passage" and will precede the announced "Three Comrades."

Plans to dissolve the investment firm of Pask Walbridge on Jan. 1 were made known yesterday in the announcement that Mackay Co., one of the oldest Stock Exchange firms, will admit as a general partner Marshall W. Pask. Mr. Pask was associated with Mackay Co. for eleven years before forming the firm of Pask Walbridge.

Harry Lundeberg, secretary of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, announced receipt today of a cablegram from the crew of the Dollar liner President Hoover denying reports of drunkenness disclosed by Senator Royal S. Copeland of New York, in Washington.
Though Winter has so far staged only a dress rehearsal, we know that it is near. We know because of skidding automobiles and the click of skates; because of the breezes

A decision precluding Chester Leo O'Brien from sharing in a $64,000 trust fund bequeathed by his late wife, Marilyn Miller, the actress, to her mother was affirmed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.
The opera last night at the Metropolitan was "II Trovatore." The cast introduced a new soprano, Miss Zinka Milanov, in the part of Leonora. Miss Milanov is a Croatian,
The tramp shipping subsidy will not be paid for the year 1937, the Board of Trade announced today. The action is in accordance
Diradour Dikijian, publisher and educator who was well known in New York Armenian circles, died in Miami on Wednesday after a brief illness at the age of 53.
Presentation of awards and talks by two former All-America football players marked the victory dinner tendered to the Hun School eleven tonight.
An aggressive basketball team from the University of Vermont handed Colgate its first defeat of the season tonight, shading the Maroon, 47 to 40.

Expectation is expressed in Paris that on the return of Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos Count Rene Doynel de SaintQuentin will be named French Ambassodor to Washington replacing George Bonnet, Finance Minister.

Mrs. Anne Barnes Charlesworth, wife of H. P. Charlesworth, assistant chief engineer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died at her home here yesterday after a long illness. She was 58 years old.

The first junior dinner dance of the season was given tonight in the Red Rooms of the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel. Patronesses include Mrs. A. J. Drexel Biddle, Mrs. Richard M. Cadwalader, Mrs. Robert Kelso Cassatt, Mrs. Alexander Gordon, Mrs. T. Charlton Henry, Mrs. Daniel L. Hutchinson Jr., who manages the affairs; Mrs. A. J. Drexel Paul and Mrs. W. Standley Stokes.

Pieceworkers earn as little as thirty-five cents a day in the production of cuddly dolls for the Christmas trade, involving both child labor and illegal homework, it was disclosed in a report issued yesterday of a survey of the industry in the State just completed by the Consumers League of New York. Suspected abuses in the industry, which has shown a steady extension in the last few years, led to the study.

The second American Artists Congress at its opening session last night in Carnegie Hall adopted resolutions condemning the Japanese attack on China and protested against the "fascist intervention against the Republican Spanish Government."

In an exciting finish to one of the most spectacular heavyweight battles seen in a local ring in years, Buddy Baer, giant younger brother of the irrepressible Max, last night knocked out Eddie Hogan, ambitious young Waterbury (Conn.) heavyweight, in the third round of their scheduled ten-round struggle in Madison Square Garden.

Alexander Kelso, secretary and treasurer of the New York district council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, and his wife, Mrs. Agnes Carlin Kelso, died this week within two days of each other.

A $50,000 damage suit against Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, was submitted to a jury here at 4:07 P. M. today and at 6 o'clock, when the jury was not ready to. report, Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson

Rear Admiral Keizo Mutsunami, who was recalled as the senior officer responsible under the Commander in Chief for Japanese naval air operations in China, was till yesterday unknown outside the Japanese naval service.

Refused permission to export electric power to the United States, Ontario's Premier, Mitchell Hepburn, charged-today the existence of a Canadian-United States agreement designed to force Ontario into supporting the St. Lawrence waterway development.

The German Government announced today another public "consolidation loan," amounting to 1,000,000,000 marks, the biggest floated so far. The last one in September originally was for 700,000,000 marks, but was raised to 850,000,000 marks to meet "the urgent demand for Treasury certificates."

Lacking the quorum required to adopt Newi York City's Administrative Code, leaders in both houses of the Legislature decided today to adjourn until noon next Thursday and devote the intervening time to eliminating points of conflict and confusion in the twenty-one pound document.

A jury before Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Byrne in Brooklyn awarded $4,670 yesterday to Miss Dorcae Edna Quinn, 22-year-old dancer, of 4,609 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, for injuries suffered when she caught her foot in a separation of floor boards

Since the democratic system functions best when the party in power faces an alert and consistent opposition, and since the Republican opposition at this time is neither as alett nor as consistent as it should be, it will be an excellent thing if the new "policy committee" now in process of formation helps to clarify the party's aims.

Forty delegates from women's labor groups will convene this afternoon at the Russell Sage Foundation for a conference on the proposed women's charter, with Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau of the United States Department of Labor, as a speaker.

Discontinuance of all operations of the bankrupt New York, Westchester Boston Railroad on Dec. 31 was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox after attorneys for the receivers and bondholders had informed him that the road was hopelessly insolvent and could not be operated profitably even if the tentative offer of various Westchester communities to halve taxes Were accepted.

A sudden Republican move to commit the Ways and Means Taxation Subcommittee to a recommendation of repeal of the tax on undistributed corporation profits was beaten today by the preponderance of Democratic members.

Authoritative quarters in this British Crown colony today discounted persistent reports that Japan is sending large army forces to South China for a drive against Canton. Such an offensive probably would isolate Hong Kong and raise numerous Anglo-Japanese frictions.

James A. C. Johnson, former New Jersey State Senator and a former Mayor of Englewood, died last night at Montigo Bay Hospital, Jamaica, British West Indies, at the age of 70, it was learned here today. He was spending the Winter there.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Halsted Vander Poel will give their annual Christmas-tree party the morning of Dec. 25 at their home, 830 Park Avenue. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Herman W. Schull have come from Washington to the Waldorf-Astoria.

Amendment to the 'Wagner-Steagall act to remove the hardship on cities unable to meet in cash the 10 per cent contribution requirement for 90 per cent Federal housing loans has been recommended by Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority. With the approval of President' Roosevelt a bill for that purpose will be introduced by Senator Wagner.
John Henry Lewis, light heavyweight champion, outpointed Johnny Risko in ten rounds tonight, with the Cleveland "rubber man" hanging on gamely to the end. Lewis weighed 183 and Risko 198 1/2.
Congregation Shaaray Tefila, familiarly known as the West End Synagogue, 160 West Eighty-second Street, which was damaged by fire several months ago, was rededicated last night at a special service.
The St. Francis swimming team opened its season last night by defeating C. C. N. Y. at the latter's pool. The score was 40-36. The victors took five of the nine events. The summaries:

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-William J. Maloney. from Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn and Richmond to 18th Division, assignment changed from supervisor of plain clothes patrolmen to desk duty. Assignment to desk duty continued:

The Rev. Anthony F. Goebel, O. S. B., pastor of the Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament since its organization as a parish here in 1919, died last night in the rectory following a long illness. His age was 57.
Sid-down strikes were started by persons reported by police to be mostly relief recipients in two ERB district bureaus, one in Harlem and one in Queens, late yesterday afternoon.
Contracts totaling over $448,000 were awarded by the Army Air Corps today for supplies and materials, as follows:

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Johnny Revolta, who won the $10,000 Miami Biltmore open golf tournament last week-end, was the favorite tonight at 6 to 1 in the $3,500 Nassau open starting tomorrow.

According to a survey issued by Captain Von Zeska, the War Ministry's press officer, the German Army now consists of thirteen army corps divided into thirty-sixty infantry divisions of three regiments each, to which are added one mountain brigade, one cavalry brigade, one light and presumably motorized brigade and three armored divisions.

Senator Wallace H. White Jr. of Maine was appointed today chairman of the American delegation to the International Radio Conference and International Telegraph and Telephone Conference which will be held in Cairo beginning Feb. 1.

Adding 221 points to his advantage, Ralph Greenleaf of New York, who is defending the world pocket billiard championship against Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., swept past his younger rival in two blocks yesterday at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy, widening the gap between the pair to 629-149.

Clifford Monroe Story, a cotton broker, of Hackensack, died today of a heart attack at the age of 54. Mr. Story was a member of the New York Cotton Exchange and was associated with E. J. Schwack Co., New York brokers.

Trailing by two goals at the opening of the final period, the Colgate hockey team scored three times in one minute and tallied three more goals later in the session to overcome Hamilton College, 7 to 3 in the season's opener for both teams tonight.

With Japan's highest army and navy leaders in control of the situation in Nanking, Chinese hoped today that the period of harsh military rule that had gripped China's former capital since the Japanese occupied it Monday would be ended.

Judge Saul S. Streit of General Sessions, in sentencing a fake stock broker yesterday to Sing Sing for cheating a widow of $22,576 in bonds she had entrusted to him, declared there was a need for immediate legislation to amend three sections of the penal law to protect gullible stock investors from such thieves.
Columbia's wrestling squad opened its season last night with the varsity and junior varsity matmen opposing the Brooklyn Polytech varsity and junior varsity, respectively, and winning their matches.

The defeat of the Old Sixty-ninth Badminton Club by the Central Badminton Club second team in the men's Class A division of the Metropolitan Badminton Association tournament marked play this week. Although the Central first team had been beaten by Old Sixty-ninth in a previous match, the seconds took the measure of this rival by a 3-to-2 score.
Overcoming a five-point deficit with less than four minutes of play remaining, Manhattan's quintet scored an impressive 36-to-33 victory over John Marshall in the Manhattan gym last night.

Modification of the undistributed-profits tax for the benefit of companies making outlays for expansion was urged here tonight by Secretary Wallace in an address in which at the same time he opposed repeal of tie tax.
The alarming developments in the Far East increase the uneasiness caused in Holland by agitation of the colonial question. A small state in Europe, this country is a great power in Eastern Asia.
Firemen wearing gas masks extinguished a small but smoky fire yesterday afternoon in a pile of rubbish in the subbasement of the Abraham Straus department store at Fulton and Hoyt Streets, Brooklyn.

Asserting that "the rights of the public have been trampled down" by mass picketing in the strike of the Horn Hardart Automat employes and that the conduct of the pickets was "a disgrace to New York City," Magistrate Anthony F. Burke imposed prison sentences of thirty, sixty and ninety days, without alternative of fine, on sixty Automat pickets who appeared before him in West Side Court yesterday.

Philip Guedalla, historian and biographer, will sail today on the Grace liner Santa Elena for California, where he will lecture at the California Institute of Technology. Mrs. Guedalla will accompany him.

The most important conversations in which Yvon Delbos, France's Foreign Minister, has engaged during his present tour were held in Prague today, with certain results that, while not yet officially announced, are likely to be both definite and far-reaching.
Member trading for their own account in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Nov. 20 followed the price trend, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Joe Louis's failure to do better than outpoint Tommy Farr in their heavyweight title match last August was rated the year's No. 1 sports upset by the country's sports-writing experts voting in the seventh annual Associated Press poll.

The Erasmus Hall High School quintet suffered its first setback in fourteen starts since early last season when it bowed to James Madison High, 24-23, on the victors' floor yesterday. It was a Section 2, Brooklyn P. S. A. L. battle.

A sharp attack on Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City as a "symbol of real dictatorship in the United States" was made by Morris L. Ernst, attorney for the C. I. O., as the National Lawyers Guild opened a three-day conference on labor relations today.
HOUSE BLOCKS WAGES BILL, RETURNING IT TO COMMITTEE; SOUTH DESERTS ROOSEVELT

Deliveries of the Vultee Aircraft division of the Aircraft Manufacturing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Aviation Corporation, fo rthe fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, amounted to $1,412,000, compared to $975,500 for the preceding year.

Miss Charlotte Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sibley Putnam of Larchmont, N. Y., was married here to Charles Miller Reppert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Miller Reppert of Pittsburgh, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

Another shipment of $5,800,000 gold has been dispatched to this country by Japan, following on the shipment of a similar amount reported to be en route on Thursday, according to an announcement yesterday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The Boston Maine Railroad Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission to modify its orders regarding certain security issues to allow pledging part of them with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a $2,000,000 loan for which the railroad contemplates applying.

Charles A. Levine, who won acclaim in 1927 as the first airplane passenger to cross the Atlantic Ocean, was convicted yesterday of smuggling 2,000 pounds or tungsten powder into the United States from Canada last year, and of conspiracy.
Dr. Glenn Frank agreed tonight to accept the chairmanship of the newly ap pointed Republican Committee on Program, "if I am able to arrange my personal and business affairs."

Harry Bacharach, president of the State Public Utility Commission, announced today that the Public Service Electric and Gas Company had agreed to reduce electric charges during 1938 in New Jersey to the extent of about $1,250,000.
Sixteenth and seventeenth century music of many types and lands was interestingly set forth by Suzanne Bloch at her recital last night in Steinway Hall.
The City Council today adopted a new lease of the city-owned gas works to the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, a subsidiary of the United Gas Improvement Company.
The four-story brick apartment building at 520-22 Nineteenth Street, Union City, N. J., has been sold by the Hudson Trust Company to the Sirab Realty Company for investment by J. I. Kislak, Inc.

Among the eight Manhattan parcels sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms was the forty-six-story office and store building on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-first Street.
Four delegates to the national convention of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee were ordered held today as material witnesses after the unclad body of a dead woman had been found in a hotel room.

Mrs. Helen Trainor, 37 years old, of Lakewood Road, was sentenced today to serve six months in the Ocean County Jail for causing an automobile death while under the influence of liquor, the first woman in the State to receive such a sentence.

Christmas will be observed tomorrow in almost all of the denominational churches. The Nativity will be observed Christmas Day, next Saturday, in all of the Roman Catholic, Protestant Episcopal and most of the Lutheran churches, together with some of the larger of the other Protestant churches in the heart of Manhattan.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here denied yesterday the application of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and six affiliated companies for stay of an order of the National Labor Relations Board.

Christmas shopping activity this week carried retail sales 4 to 10 per cent higher than in the preceding week, but with more cities falling under their figures of last December, the gain over the corresponding 1936 week was reduced to 3 to 12 per cent, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.
Mrs. Laura B. Crosthwaite of this place, daughter of Elbert S. Barlow of New York and the late Mrs. Barlow, was married tonight to John R. Ramsden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Ramsden of Glen Ridge.

The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production, "Night Must Fall," in which Robert Montgomery played his first serious screen role, has been nominated the best picture produced anywhere during the year ended Dec. 15 by the Committee on Exceptional Photoplays of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, which yesterday made known its list of the "ten best" Hollywood and foreign-made pictures.
American sailors wounded in the bombing of the gunboat Panay will be among the 16,814 service men whom the Red Cross will remember this Chirstmas.
McKim, Mead White, architects, filed yesterday with the Building Department plans for the new administration building for Bellevue Hospital, the cost of which they estimated at $3,000,000.

Another reminder of the golden era of 1929 passed today when the Rumsey estate, show place of the Adirondacks, built by John Rumsey, former owner of Broadway's Embassy Club, was donated to the Saranac Lake Society for the Control of Tuberculosis.
Frank P. Anderson, retired piano dealer, died on Thursday at his apartment in the Hotel Mohawk, 379 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

Cleveland E. Dodge announced yesterday plans for the New York World's Fair building of the Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New York, which will be the first Y. M. C. A. building ever to be erected for any fair or exposition. Mr. Dodge is chairman of the association's executive committee.

Daniel Pyzel, Clinton Seymour. William W. Law, Dr. Richard Lynch, Mrs. Wilson N. Felder, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, agent. Peter Tames, Sylvia G. Lawrey, in 140 E 28th St; Elda Pistonami, in 2 Horatio St; K. Hemrick Berthold, in 50 W 12th St; Bing Bing, Inc, broker.

Charlie Chan pops up at Monte Carlo (and the Roxy) this time, and two corpses hit the ground almost before you can say Earl Derr Biggers. Corpse No. 1 is that of a messenger bound for Paris with $1,000,000 in bonds.
Movements of livestock In the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Waterfront property forming the southwest corner of Union Street and Gowanus Canal, Brooklyn, fronting 100 feet on the canal, has been leased by the Locust Builders Supplies Company, Inc., Joseph DiFiore, president, from Thomas Paulson Son, Inc., through Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., broker.
Announcement by Mr. Jesse Jones that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is willing to make "any loans within reason which the railways of the country may need" was not unexpected.
With most of the top-rated men of the sport in action, another highgoal contest will feature the indoor polo twin bill at Squadron A Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, tonight.

Sharp protests received by the National Broadcasting Company from radio listeners as the result of Mae West's sketch, "Adam and Eve,"' on the air last Sunday night caused the sponsor's agent, the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, to express regrets to the NBC yesterday.

Rallying in the second half, the Pratt Institute basketball team downed Lafayette, 38 to 24, at the Pratt gymnasium in Brooklyn last night. The Pennsylvanians held an 18-10 lead at the half. Nick Zuraw led the attack for Pratt with 15 markers.

The Rev. Charles Albert William Brocklebank, 33 years old, for the last four years rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Easton, Md., has accepted a call to become rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's - in - the - Bouwerie, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue.

Always in command after taking the lead in the first ten seconds, Columbia University's basketball team began the intercollegiate portion of its current schedule with a 42-to-32 triumph over Springfield College in the Columbia gymnasium last night.
The following reports on the condition of near-by lakes were made yesterday to W.F. Crosby, secretary of the newly formed Eastern Ice Yachting Association and submitted to THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Anthony T. Miano, 36 years old, of 85-01 Eighty-eighth Street, W'oodhaven, Queens, who stole $28,000 from the Fitzgibbons Boiler Company, Inc., at 101 Park Avenue, where he was the assistant treasurer and credit manager, while he was borrowing $37,500 from fellowemployes, which he did not repay, was sentenced to the penitentiary yesterday.

The bondholders protective committee of the Mortgage Guarantee Company, Baltimore, Md., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for the issuance of certificates of deposit for mortgages, mortgage participation certificates and assignments and any guarantees thereof by the registrant, with respect to about 600 mortgages, with a face value of $16,106,836, made by various mortgagors.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 982.000 bales against 959,000 a week ago, 964,000 two Weeks ago, 866,000 three weeks ago and 834,000 a year ago.

Leading court tennis players from Philadelphia, Boston, New York, Tuxedo and Long Island will gather at the famous Greentree court of John Hay Whitney at Manhasset today for the annual Payne Whitney Memorial doubles matches.

Windows of several Jewish-owned stores on Vienna's main shopping street, the Kaernterstrasse, were smashed last night by two men--presumably Nazis--in retaliation for the smashing of a window in the German tourist office two days ago by a Jewish merchant named Lebeschuss.
Freight traffic through the Suez Canal during the first nine months of this year reached 24,633,000 tons, the largest figure in eight years and only slightly under the record of 1929.

Robert James Eidlitz. builder, who died May 17, 1935, left a net estate of $2,010,818, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Upon the death of Mrs. Sadie Boulton Eidlitz, the widow, about $713,000 of this amount goes to nine hospitals and other institutions in varying amounts.

SUCCESSFUL CHRISTIAN LIVING, by Harry Emerson Fosdick. (Harper, $1.50.) These twenty-five sermons by this forceful preacher of the Riverside Church of New York treat themes that have to do with the meaning of Christianity, both for personal living and social relationships.

Glyn Warren Philpot, Royal Academician, is dead here at the age of 53. A few years ago he broke away from the academic and rather "precious" painting with which he made his early reputation in favor of a larger, simpler style in a lighter key of color.

There was an opposition vote, after all, in the Soviet general elections last Sunday, although it was probably smaller in proportion to the total number of votes cast than in any other large national election ever held.

Curtis B. Dall, former son-in-law of President Roosevelt, was clearly libeled by the publication of a description of his imaginary suicide in the White House, the Appellate Division ruled -unanimously yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. George H. Wilder of Madison and Chatham, Mass., gave a dinner dance at their home here this evening at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwendolyn Eldredge Wilder, to Walter Dongan Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Dongan Wood of Summit, N. J.

John Barbirolli will conduct the season's first concert of the Philharmonic - Symphony Society's Young People's Concerts this morning at 11 o'clock at Carnegie Hall. Particular emphasis will be placed on the string section of the orchestra. Soloists will be Mishel Piastro, concert master; Joseph Schuster, first 'cellist, and Anselme Fortier, contrabass player.
Although publications are not looking for very large linage during January, the month may make a better showing than expected for several reasons, agency executives pointed out yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As usual, your columns carry many letters and much matter dealing with information necessary for the presentday citizen to understand the crisis which this country, as well as the world, faces.

The Hershey Bears moved to within one point of the second place New York Rovers in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League standings by defeating the Bronx Tigers, 5-1, before an estimated crowd of 2,000 at the New York Coliseum last night.
The surging waters of the River Tiber today were estimated to have done millions of dollars of damage as rains continued to swell the flood which has taken six lives.

A Foreign Office spokesman said today that Japan's reply to the United States note demanding full redress for the sinking of the gunboat Panay would be materially delayed by American charges that Japanese surface craft machine-gunned the Panay after she was bombed.

The right of Irenee du Pont to a deduction in his 1932 income tax for losses in a sale of stocks to trust funds he himself set up was argued in the Federal court today. Mr. du Pont is seeking the return of about $154,000 that he paid under protest as a deficiency tax and interest.

Miss Lucy Maxwell, daughter of Mrs. Edith Maxwell of Tenants Harbor, Me., was married to John Franklin McVane, son of Dr. and Mrs. W. L. McVane of Portland, Me., here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Harold F. Lemoine performed the ceremony.

Today's major events: "Die Walkuere," 1:45 P. M.; "Traviata," 8:30 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House; Pietro Yon, organist, Carnegie Hall, evening; Alexander Kelberine, pianist, Carnegie Hall, afternoon; Ortambert String Quartet, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Elvin Schmitt, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Julius Grossman, violinist, Hotel Barbizon, 8:30 P. M.

After a day of sharp debate, the House early tonight shelved the Wages and Hours Bill, voting 216 to 198 to recommit it to the Labor Committee. The action, professedly taken to allow the committee time for further study of the legislation will probably result in its indefinite shelving.

The strike in the three stores of the F. W. Woolworth Company, called on Thursday, was settled last night. Representatives of the company and the union of which the employes are members reached an agreement after a four-hour conference in the office of the State Mediation Board, 366 Broadway.

Thomas Poynton Gilman, ornithologist and horticulturist, died today at Fern Lodge, his home here, in his ninety-eighth year. Once well known in New York banking circles, Mr. Gilman retired at 33 to pursue his nature studies.
Dartmouth's second-half rally gained a 48-to-44 victory over Western Reserve in the feature of a tripleheader inaugurating basketball in Cleveland's $1,250,000 arena tonight.

Aggressive buying of wheat futures in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today was attributed to removal of hedges against export sales and to relative strength in Liverpool and resulted in an advance of around- 1 cent a bushel.

Mr. and Mrs. William Abbot Kinsman of Newburyport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Kinsman, to Norman H. Snow of this city, son of Mrs. Clinton M. Cruikshank of New Canaan, Conn.

If ever an engineer deserved the Thomas A. Edison Medal which is annually awarded by the American Institute of Electrical Engineers it is Mr. Gano Dunn. His fellow-engineers will rejoice that he is to be so fittingly honored next month.

District Attorney William C. Dodge won yesterday his legal fight to recover $13,515 which the city had deducted from his statutory pay of $20,000 a year in pay cuts from Jan. 1, 1934, to June 30, 1937, when the old rate was restored.
The Government today announced its troops had surrounded and laid siege to Teruel, the focal point of a daring drive in bitter weather against heavily entrenched Insurgents.
Charles H. Stowell, who was discharged six weeks ago as the Mamaroneck Village Chief of Police, brought suit in Supreme Court here today for reinstatement.

W. M. Jeffers, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, was a passenger on the company's newest streamlined train, the City of Los Angeles, when it arrived at Harmon, N. Y., yesterday prior to being exhibited in the Grand Central Terminal today. It will leave on an initial run to Sun Valley, Idaho, tomorrow.

The Federal Power Commission has an nounced its authorization of the purchase of the Northern Paper Mills' hydroelectric generating transmission system on the Menominee River in Northern Wisconsin by the Wisconsin Michigan Power Company and determined the transaction to be a merger within the meaning of Section 203(a) of the Federal Power Act.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The hot-stove league has been inaugurated with the Winter baseball meetings and the publication of the major league records. I would like to submit a baseball idea which I feel has possibilities.

Blanket authority to call a strike at its discretion was voted the executive committee of the Transport Workers Union yesterday at two meetings of members employed by leading taxicab fleet operators. About 5,000 drivers attended the meetings in the Center Hotel, 108 West Forty-third Street.
George H. Hopper, North Jersey real estate man and yachtsman, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of several months. He was 55 years old.

The engagement of Miss Edna Ellender, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Ellender, to Howard Bayer of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bayer of Deal, N. J., and Miami, Fla., has been announced by her brother, Raphael Ellender of 310 West Seventy-third Street.

Miss Edith Wynne Groff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden D. Groff of Elizabeth, N. J., was married here last night in the Church of the Transfiguration to Donald Brendel Geddes, son of Mrs. Lillian Brendel Geddes of Zanesville, Ohio, and of Donald Y. Geddes of Elizabeth, by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine.
A sharp contra-seasonal decline in cotton mill activity last week brought the adjusted index down to 93.1 from 104.4, the revised figure for the previous week.

The Stradivarius Memorial Association, which is sponsoring the concert to be given Monday night at Carnegie Hall in honor of the bicentenary of Stradivarius's death, which falls today. received the following message from President Ro??sevelt:

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions ATLAS TINWARE CO., INC., 2,472 3d Ave.--Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities of $39,368, exclusive of, capital stock, and assets of $71,612. BRIGBY REALTY CORP., 80 Willoughby Ave., Brooklyn.-Voluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law listing liabilities, consisting of mortgages, accrued interest and taxes, of $735,000, and assets of a book value of $746,296.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Commonwealth Subsidiary Corporation, reported today net income for November of $1,065,514, equivalent to 14 cents a share on the 7,733,676 shares outstanding.

A Cooperative Commonwealth Federation resolution protesting any export of war material to Japan and urging a provincewide boycott of Japanese goods was defeated 31 to 19 yesterday in the Manitoba Legislature.

The elaborate defensive explanation issued by the Dominican Republic yesterday is not likely to change the impression prevailing in the United States and throughout Latin America that Haiti has a substantial case against its larger neighbor. The facts speak for themselves:

The Equitable Trust Company of New York, 25 Broad Street, has been authorized to reduce its capital stock from $7,000,000 to $500,000, the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department announced today.

Patrolman George A. Heidt, who was dismissed from the police force after he appeared as a witness for the defense in the trial of Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania on vice charges, was ordered reinstated yesterday by the Appellate Division in a unanimous ruling.

Mr. and Mrs. Newell W. Tilton gave a luncheon today at La Quinta for Mrs. Francis Taylor, Mrs. John C. King, Mr. and Mrs. H. Halpine Smith, Miss Feranda deMohrenschildt, the Countess Edith di Zoppola, A. Atwater Kent, Prince George of Russia, D. Dulany Hunter and James R. Hyde.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 4049-Ex parte Tilghman G. Frederick. Dismissed upon motion of appellant. 3882--Ex part Riverbank Canning Co. Argued.

The Salle d'Armes Vince fencers won the national junior foils team championship at the Columbia University gymnasium last night. The Vince swordsmen-Nathaniel Lubel, Sidney Kaplan and Cornell Wildeconquered the New York Athletic Club team in a stirring final round encounter to capture the New York University Cup.
The Mount Holyoke College Glee Club gave its thirteenth annual Christmas concert last night at Town Hall.

The First Boston Corporation purchased yesterday an issue of $8,000,000 of tax anticipation notes of the city of Boston, paying par for a 1.75 per cent interest rate. The notes will be dated Dec. 20, 1937, and will become payable on Nov. 2, 1938.
Mrs. Jack Barnato Joel, wife of the sportsman and philanthropist, died today at the age of 61. She formerly was Miss Olive Sopwith, a sister of Tom Sopwith, the noted yachtsman.

ACKERMAN-On Friday, Dec. 17, 1937, Gertrude Anna, sister of the late Frederick Lueneberg. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend funeral services Sunday at 8 P. M. at her late residence, 318 New York Ave., Jersey City. Funeral Monday at 2 P. M.

The surplus assets of the Pennsylvania Railroad System, on Dec. 31, last, were $906,228,000, or greater b-more than $300,000,000 than are the surplus assets of any other corporation in the United States, according to a report of accountants and investigators of the Senate Commiltee on Interstate Commerce, which was made a matter of public record today.

Hardly a word was exchanged yesterday as the heart-warming little drama attending the gift of $1,000 to the Neediest by a woman who prefers to keep her identity secret was re-enacted for the eleventh consecutive year in the business office of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Times Square.

William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a letter made public last night, has suggested that the commission undertake an investigation "of the whole question of service charges by members of the New York Stock Exchange, particularly those of specialists, floor traders and odd-lot dealers."

The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Dec. 16: Townsend, Col. G. L., InfO; three months and twenty-eight days' leave, March 2, with permission to visit foreign countries. Hoge, Lt. Col. W. M., Eng'rs, twenty days' leave, Dec. 28.

Regis High School and Dwight School registered their sixth victories in seven starts this season in non-league basketball games yesterday. Regis downed Cathedral Boys High, 26-13, at Regis, and Dwight repulsed the Merchant Marine Academy five, 31-27, at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

The earth has again swallowed the "big sink," a 600-acre lake situated between Elizabethtown and Cave In Rock. The huge body of water disappeared overnight--so fast, residents of the vicinity said, thai they could see it sinking.

Nicaraguan coffee growers today requested the Federal Government to assist them in obtaining labor to pick the coffee crop, which is fast ripening. For the first time in history there is a shortage of labor to pick the crop, despite high wages paid by the planters.
David J. "Beano" Breen, 41, a local gambler and sporting world figure, was shot and killed today in what police laid to an outbreak of a "labor war."

Facing what usually is the worst business week of the year-those few days just before Christmas-a number of Broadway's legitimate children have decided simply to give up after this evening. Departing then, from the local scene:

Three men were shot, one was overcome by tear gas, at least a dozen were severely beaten and more than 100 persons were arrested here late today soon after employes of the labor-troubled Ford assembly plant quit work for the day.
Albert Everett, author and Civil War veteran, died at his home here last night. His age was 97. He was a native of Massachusetts and had lived here for fifteen years.

A sparkling century by Stanley McCabe featured the opening day's play in the Sheffield Shield cricket match between New South Wales and South Australia today. At the close the visiting team had compiled 292 runs for six wickets.
The Englander Spring Bed Company, Inc., Brooklyn, has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease marking fictitious prices in the sale of mattresses, the commission announced today.

Loans on 3,820,445 bales of cotton amounting to $168,240,303 were made in this crop year through Dec. 16, the Comomdity Credit Corporation announced today. The average loan, said the corporation, was about 8.39 cents a pound.

MANHATTAN ABRAHAMS, ROSIE (July 22, 1936). Gross assets, $16,171; net, $6,053. To Beth Abraham Home for Incurables, $500; Henrietta Newman, sister, life estate in residue; seventeen varying bequests. Chief assets, real estate, $7,360. Appel Tannebaum, attorneys, 342 Madison Ave.

Mrs. Louise Inslee Mount, a resident here for the last forty-seven years, died yesterday in the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, after an illness of six weeks. She was 84 years old. Mrs. Mount was the widow of James T. Mount, former cutlery manufacturer in Newark, who died in 1920.

MANHATTAN CARROLL, JOHN J. (Oct. 16). Estate, more than $10,000. To Agnes Walsh, 273 Warfield St., Brooklyn, $2,000; two specific bequests; Nellie A. Carroll, widow, executrix, 471 Grand St., residue. Harold V. Walsh 570 Cameron Rd., South Orange. N. J., executor.

An American historical, scientific and art museum will be erected on the heights of Rumeli Hissar, overlooking the European side of the Bosporus, by patrons of Robert College, from which many Turkish students have gone on to American universities.

Uday Shan-Kar and his company of Hindu dancers and musicians gave their second performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the St. James Theatre, repeating for the most part the program presented on Wednesday at the Town Hall.

A gift of S10,000 to the United Hospital Campaign, 57 William Street, from the Friedsam Foundation was announced last night. Two donations of $1,000, one from Edwin H. B. Pratt and one anonymous, also were reported.

The report late yesterday of the Department of Agriculture on the probable yields this year of the nation's principal grain crops indicated that production will approximate the average for 1928-32, the last five years of unlimited output.

Members of the cast of the Princeton Triangle Club's musical comedy "Fol-De-Rol," which was opened last. night at the Hudson Theatre, gave a supper party. in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton after the performance.
Mrs. M. Brewster La Monte gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for her niece, Miss Frances Isabel Arnold, debutante daughter of Mrs. Dan Hinckley Arnold.
The six-room dweling at 249-19 Thornhill Avenue, near Marathon Road, Little Neck, L. I., has been sold by Certified Builders, Inc., through King King, Inc., brokers, to John Cavanaugh.
Cornerstone laying exercises for the Swedish Methodist Episcopal Church at 150 East Sixty-second Street will be held tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock.
Captain Andy Beno led his New Brunswick (N. J.) Zebras to a 25-0 victory over Miami Edison's Red Raiders tonight in an intersectional high school football game before a crowd of 2,500.

The alumni gymnasium of Dickinson College was crowded tonight with guests at Christmas festivities which culminated in the "Doll Show." At this traditional event one corner of the gymnasium is allotted to dolls.

Deaths Announced Retired Pilot Thomas Freston formerely a member of Engine 78, residing at 2,500 Webb Ave., Bronx, died Dec. 16. Retired Engineer of Steamer Henry C. Young, formerly a member of Engine 254, residing at 183 Vincent Ave., Lynbrook. died Dec. 14.

The disappearance of Miss Juliet Stuart Poyntz, for seventeen years high in the councils of New York Communists, was made known yesterday as Federal authorities continued to seek an explanation of Donald L. and Ruth N. Robinson, who disappeared in Moscow after getting there with fraudulent American passports.

Patrick Toolan, Councilman from 1893 to 1897, foreman of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company coal docks here until 1920 when he retired, and uncle of State Senator John E. Toolan, died yesterday at his home. He was 88 years old.
Christmas shopping continued to build up toward a seasonal peak this week, with the sales crest expected to be reached next Monday and Tuesday.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 11 totaled 622,131 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

When at 5 o'clock this morning the Chamber of Deputies voted the final chapters of the budget, one member of the government described the situation by saying that honor at least was saved for on paper there will be an excedent of 1,239,000,000 francs.

Acceptances by persons named to the program committee by the executive committee of the Republican National Committee came in slowly today, with only sixteen added to the ninety-one made public last night after the executive committee had adjourned.

Havemeyer Ave, s w c Watson Ave. 103x 182.11x irreg; Mortgage Commission of N Y against Emma Herzog; due, $13,158; taxes, etc, $2,505; to plaintiff for $1,000. Ward Ave, 1,041, 25x100: Mortgage Commission of N Y against Isidore Wool: due, $10,967: taxes, etc, $1,640; to plaintiff for S1.000.
The American Colortype Company declared a dividend of $5 on the 5 per cent preferred stock. This is the first payment on the issue which was given in exchange for the old 7 per cent preferred stock.

Ice-yachting enthusiasts prepared yesterday-to take their boats to Lake Musconetcong, at Netcong, N. J., this morning for the first real week-end of the sport this Winter. More than twenty craft were set up and rigged on the shore of the lake.

A double-barreled protest from without and within the Grand Central Palace developed yesterday against both the German Exposition and third annual Christmas market and the display of the German swastika flag.

For a long time it has been quite impossible to pigeonhole Angna Enters. There is such a thing, of course, as having too many irons in the fire. On the other hand, it musk be rather bleak to live all your life 'in a pigeonhole-and as a matter of fact.

The stock markets here were generally firm today. Gilt-edge issuess were strong. Argentine rails made good gains. Iron and steel and textile stocks were firm, while tobaccos had a general rise featured by gains in shares of the British-American Tobacco Company.

Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute's basketball squad dropped a closely fought game to Hamilton today, 44-37, and chalked up its loss to the local players' accurate foul shooting. Hamilton tallied in sixteen out of nineteen attempts, while the visitors netted seven times in fifteen chances.

Authorities were almost certain tonight that the two desperadoes who fled from the Alcatraz Island Federal penitentiary yesterday had died in a long gamble on swimming the mile and a half of treacherous waters to the mainland.

In an almost philosophic article which appeared yesterday in the December issue of Spring 3100, organ of the New York Police Department, Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine outlines the duties of policemen under strike conditions and envisages for the city a new era of social and industrial advancement.

The public debt reached a new high record at $37,562,835,919 on Dec. 15, because of the sale of approximately $450,000,000 of securities to the public, the latest Treasury daily statement, dated Dec. 15, showed today.

The Federal Government's investigation of automobile financing methods came to an abrupt end in Federal court here today, when Judge Ferdinand A. Geiger ordered dismissal of a grand jury which had been investigating the subject for nearly three months.
In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 594--Calmar S. S. Corp., petr., v. Charles W. Taylor. Motion for leave to file brief as amicus curiae submitted.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher-in-training in day Secondary schools other than junior high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefore:
Queen Mary wept today as she listened to the cheers of 400 wounded exsoldiers who were being entertained at a Christmas party in the riding school at Buckingham Palace.

Strict observance of Sunday in every oil field in Texas will be started on Sunday and continue for at least four successive Sundays and perhaps indefinitely by order of the Railroad Commission to be issued tomorrow, according to present plans.

Three preliminary motions in the Federal court suit of Mrs. Marian G. Russell of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Patrick J. Delehanty of West New Brighton, Staten Island, N. Y., for the appointment of a receiver for the Newark Ledger Company were heard today by Judge Philip Forman.
The Irish Free State's decision to accredit a Minister to the Emperor of Ethiopia at Rome has made a bad impression in League of Nations circles.

Jacob Albert Preuss, owner of the Baltic Amber Company, 104 West Fortieth Street, and a founder and past president of Congregation Mount Sinai Anshe Emeth, died on Thursday at Polyclinic Hospital after a short illness. He was 56 years old.
The Japanese Government today protested to the Soivet Union against what it termed illegal detention of its subjects in Russia and in a separate memorandum demanded a "responsible answer."
About 1,500 permits to sell liquor all night New Year's Eve have been issued already by the State Liquor Authority, it was announced yesterday by Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the Authority.

An attempt by the attorney for R. P. Mills Co., Ltd., to have a representative of the Securities and Exchange Commission of the United States excluded from the trial of the local brokerage firm met no success today, for Judge J. C. Langlois dismissed an objection raised by Hugh O'Donnell, attorney for the defense.

John Francis Moore, former Republican leader of the Eleventh Assembly District in Brooklyn, was appointed yesterday as assistant counsel of the Board of Transportation, according to an announcement by the board.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed trustee and paying agent for an issue of $450,100 of the Falstaff Brewing Corporation ten-year 5 per cent debentures due on Dec. 15, 1947, and scrip certificates therefore.

The Government' has purchased the birthplace of Sir Wilfrid Laurier at St. Lin, Que., and created a fund for perpetual care of Sir John A. MacDonald's grave at Cataraqui, Ont., it was announced today by Prime Minister Mackenzie King.

Fouryear-old William J. Murray 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Murray Jr. of 144 Thoma Avenue here, returned to his home this morning after a twenty-four-hour absence convinced that, despite the proximity of Christmas, Santa Claus was a pretty hard person to find, especially "the Santa Claus who lives in a department store in New York City."
The stalkers, sitters and standers were out in force this morning, hoping to see, if not to shoot, one of the local deer. But most of the hunters we saw were disappointed on both counts.
Only the year, 1937, distinguishes the Christmas card chosen by President and Mrs. Roosevelt this year from last year's greeting.

Fort Washington Ave, 590, 175xl4Sxirreg: Casmore Realty Corp (Mae C. Wise, president) to William Roseman, 601 W 112th St; mtg $351.000 ($1). Henry St, 44, 25x100; Max J. Bernhelm to Mildred Rosenblatt, 276 Naples Terrace, Bronx (50 cents).

Professor Ralph Clewell Super, who was completing quarter of a century as Professor of Spanish and French at Hamilton College, died of bronchial pneumonia in a Utica hospital today. He was taken to the hospital on Dec. 13. His age was 62.

Italian trade discrimination against the United States are eliminated under a temporary commercial arrangement signed in Rome tonight by William Phillips, the American Ambassador. and Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Minister for Foreign Affairs.

THE football firing squad is up in arms again and the casualty list is mounting steadily. For a while it seemed that a closed season had been declared on coaches and that the status quo would be preserved.

Brown came from behind to win its first hockey game by defeating Boston College, 5 to 4, tonight. The Bruins scored three goals in the last period, the winning one at 17:41 on an Eccleston-to-Hicks play.

WPA workmen have a hard time. One set of persons, possibly not devoid of partisanship, have accused them of loafing on the job. Now we hear that they are working all too vigorously. Busy in remodeling the inside of the District Attorney's building, they are causing distress to Mr. Dodge's staff.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Dec. 17 unless specified: San Francisco to Mare Island Yard, Dec. 16: Chaumont, Pompano.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday the setting-up of a committee to solicit funds on a nation-wide scale from seamen and labor groups, with which to finance a defense of the fourteen seamen of the freighter Algie.

Amor Brujo, South American thoroughbred whose racing speed has provoked a controversy through comparison with the best in this country, gets his big test tomorrow in the $10,000 added San Francisco Handicap.

" The Admirable Crichton," by J. M. Barrie, was presented by the undergraduate members of Wigs and Cues, dramatic society of Barnard College, to a capacity audience last night in Brinckerhoff Theatre on the campus.

At 1:30 P. M. Sunday, Dec. 12, the U. S. S. Panay, a gunboat built at the Kiangin dockyard at Shanghai and commissioned in 1928 for the Yangtze Patrol, was riding at anchor peacefully, twenty-eight miles up the river from Nanking.
The Times of London editorial, commenting on the dispatch of Colin McDonald, says that it confirms beyond a doubt that the attack upon the Panav was deliberate.

Despite the business recession that set in in October, conditions in most industries in 1937 were eminently satisfactory, in the opinion of editors of trade publications throughout the country and of spokesmen for the industries and professions that such journals represent.

It seems tolerably clear that the present decline in business is primarily an inventory recession, although there have been other less important contributing influences, according to Fred Y. Presley, president of the National Investors Corporation,
Colder weather in many sections of the country in the last two weeks has brought a sharp increase in disItributors' requests for shipments against existing orders for heavy underwear.

Carl W. Harris, vice president and a member of the board of directors of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, died here yesterday morning in Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 56. Funeral services will take place tomorrow in Winston-Salem, N. C.

Eleven organizations will open their annual meetings here Monday, Dec. 27, under the auspices of the Allied Social Science Associations. Sessions will continue through the, following Thursday with some 3,500 persons expected to attend.

Miss Gertrude Ross Brodhead, daughter of Elber Howe Brodhead of Haverford, was married here this afternoon in St. Mary's Church to Kirby hewitt Tappan, son of Mrs. Ogden Hewitt Tappan of New York, by Archdeacon James F. Bullitt, who was assisted by the rector, the Rev. Louis W. Pitt.

The first William Barton Rogers Awards, established in memory of the founder of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to recognize outstanding qualifications, including high scholarship, character and leadership in student affairs, have been given to four members of the senior class: Dale F. Morgan of New Rochelle, N. Y.;

Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Newton of 974 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Newton, to Millard Obrig Hallenbeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Millard F. Hallenbeck Jr., also of Brooklyn.

During the first ten days of its operation, the new Social Hygiene Clinic at 303 Ninth Avenue had 248 visitors as a direct result of newspaper stories announcing the opening, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, said yesterday.

Dr. Nathaniel Gist Gee, head of the Biology Department of Lander College and a veteran educator, died at his home here early today of a heart attack. His age was 61. Dr. Gee, before coming to Lander in 1935, was in China for many years.

Miss Eleanor Wadsworth Cauchois, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Wadsworth Cauchois of this place, was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Church to Charles George Aubry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Aubry, also of Yonkers.
Elias Lieberman, attorney for the missing Juliet Stuart Poyntz, a former Communist leader in New York, yesterday formally asked Police Commissioner Valentine to institute a search for Miss Ponytz.

The flaming power that marked the Optimist teams of the past came back last night as Winston Guest led his trio to a 19-to-10 victory over a New York Athletic Club combination in the feature polo match at the Squadron A Armory.

WITH the Pan American Airways transpacific clippers flying the whole way from Alameda to Hong Kong instead of just to Manila, as formerly, the majority of the Pacific division pilots are warming up to demand better flying conditions.

Scoring the outstanding triumph of the series, G. Huntington Hartford of the Harvard Club, prominent young New York sportsman, gained the semi-final of the Ardsley Country Club's annual squash racquets invitation tournament today.

The thirty-fourth International Eucharistic Congress in Budapest, Hungary, May 25 to 30, is expected to attract 400,000 pilgrims from all parts of the world, including 40,000 from the United States. At the same time Hungary will celebrate the 900th anniversary of the death of her canonized King, Stephen, whose hand, said to have remained uncorrupted through the centuries, one of the country's most prized relics, will be carried in a procession.
No section of the country is more vitally interested in the fate of the Wage-Hour Bill now in the hands of Congress than is New England. No industry is more concerned than is cotton textiles.

Jack Trammel, Youngstown, Ohio, boxer, scored a first-round knockout over Oscar (King Kong) Matthews of Tallulah, La., in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds before 4,800 persons at the Rockland Palace last night. The winner weighed 184 pounds to 197 3/4 for his rival.
