REGARDLESS of what action may be taken by various Guilds within the industry, the Academy of Motion.Picture Arts and Sciences will hold its annual dinner and presentation of awards on the night of March 3.

Earlier predictions of bumper crops were borne out in the final estimates the Department of Agriculture, made public yesterday, but there was a heavier loss of acreage in the drought area than had been previously reported.

With the beginning of racing at Tropical Park in Florida tomorrow and at Santa Anita in California on Saturday, Winter racing will get under way in earnest. For some time the sport las been in progress at the Fair Grounds in Louisiana, which has taken a new lease on life since the death of racing in Texas.

Shooting for Christmas turkeys made up the program at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. The competition drew a field of nearly fifty gunners. Fifteen birds were provided for the scratch leaders and an equal number of prizes for the handicap contenders. In the scratch test, B.

IN this rollicking yarn, which is designated by the author as being a novel in verse, Gilbert Frankau sets forth the presentday adventures of "One of Us. his former friend Jack and the reincarnation of our ancient medieval friend Don Juan for whom Lord Byron did some ghost writing a century back. A PICARESQUE lady, queen of the melodramas (since Alfred Hitchcock discovered between romantic adventure and her tall, golden-haired person a certain mysterious affinity) Madeleine Carroll isn't too much surprised when she encounters in life some of those exotic and adventurous complications which beset her, say, in an average international spy picture. Many members of society who have been in New York, the Virginias and Maryland for the early Winter have returned to open their North Shore homes for the holidays to entertain for the juniors home from college and the younger married members who live elsewhere and come home for Christmas.

EVERY afternoon at 3 o'clock some 20,000 little New Yorkers stay after school of their own accord to study art in the WPA's classes. They stay to paint. or to work in clay. or carve; some in their own schools. some in settlement houses and neighborhood clubs. some in special community art centers.

The body of Joseph T. B. Woodruff, 44, planning engineer, was found today hanging from a tree in the yard of his home in Longmeadow. Medical Examiner C. J. Downey, who pronounced the death suicide, said he had been learned that Mr. Woodruff had been suffering from an acute nervous condition recently.
With a score of parties scheduled during the next six days for children, adults and the aged and with dealers in holiday season gear preparing for the final spurt in
State committees completed today the choosing of nominees for Rhodes scholars, narrowing the field of 590 candidates to fewer than 90. The original field was larger than that of last year.

Miss Suzanne Prentiss Becton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Wilbur Becton of this place, was married here this afternoon in Grace Church to William Lansing Chapman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Lansing Chapman of Rutherford and Saybrook, Conn.

Philip Guedalla, English historian and biographer, sailed yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Elena to give a series of lectures at the California Institute of Technology. He was accompanied by his wife.

Governor Charles Martin, who recently ordered a plant election to break a four-month tie-up of the sawmill industry here, called on public officials today "to preserve law and order in' the face of the greatest economic upheaval which the people of this country have yet faced."

Death wiped out a party of six young National Guardsmen in an automobile crash twelve miles east of here early today. The men, who had just left a Christmas party of their artillery company in Stockton, were:

BARON-SITTENFILD - Mr. and Mrs. Milton Slttenfield, 262 Central Park West, announce the engagement of their daughter, Carol, to Mr. Howard Baron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Baron of New York. At home Sunday, Dec. 26, 3 to 6 P.

Chairman Frank R. McNinch of the Federal Communications Commission today called upon Lenox R. Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company, for complete information concerning the Chase Sanborn broadcast Sunday night entitled "Adam and Eve."

Though inimitable Larry Kelley of Yale no longer was on hand to provide a "soccer kick" as the year's outstanding sports oddity, No. 1 position among unusual incidents again was awarded to football in the annual poll of sports writers conducted by The Associated Press.
Premier Mitchell Hepburn sent Prime Minister Mackenzie King a demand today that official documents relating to Ontario's electric power dispute be made public.

After a study of the question of rehabilitating old tenements or replacing them with new apartments-a problem which is facing many banks and other lending institutions-the directors of the Beekman Estate, a New York real estate operating corporation, have decided in favor of demolishing five old East Side tenements and a former private dwelling.

The annual Russian Students Ball, tenth in the series of entertainments given each year by the Russian Alumni and Student Association, will take place on Jan. 14 in the main ballroom suite of the Plaza. The net proceeds, as usual, will benefit the Russian Student Fund and the association's needy members.
An unusually fine set of Greek jewelry of the fourth century B. C., comprising two gold and crystal bracelets, an emerald ring, gold necklace,

High scoring featured play in Sheffield Shield cricket matches today. New South Wales completed its innings for 337, South Australia making. 163 runs. for six wickets in reply. Playing against Queensland at Melbourne, Victoria had compiled 302 for four wickets when play closed for the day.

As a climax to a series or Christmas activities at Georgian Court College here, prizes were presented this week to students who made original costumes for 150 dolls which were given to needy children of the community. The week's program included a dinner party, a candle-light procession to the accompaniment of Christmas carols and a nativity tableau.

An entertainment appropriate to the holiday season will take place on the afternoon of Dec. 30, when Debussy's children's ballet, "La Bolte Joujoux," will be performed by a cast of child dancers in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

Harold Brayman of The Philadelphia Evening Public Ledger was elected tonight president of the National Press Club. Other officers named were Arthur Hachten, Universal Service, vice president; Felix Cotten, Philadelphia Record and Central News, secretary;

Faced by union demands that it pay "living wages" or go out of business, the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company, which is involved in reorganization proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act, agreed yesterday before Federal Judge Coxe to increase wages by $580,000 on April 1, 1938, provided the company is not compel' d to liquidate before then.

Announcement has been made or the engagement of Miss Margaret Jane Lynn of 33 East Thirty-eighth Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William McGregor Lynn of Cheyenne, Wyo., to Francis Henderson Brinkley of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alec Rawlings Brinkley of Portsmouth Va.
Harvard announced last week that Professor Louis F. Fieser of its Converse Memorial Laboratory has synthetically produced no fewer than twenty - two complex compounds which can produce cancer.

Books circulated by the City Col lege Library among the graduate and undergraduate students have increased markedly in number and variety during the last six years, according to a report to Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president, by Professor Francis L. D. Goodrich, librarian.

An offer by David Stern 3d of Philadelphia and a group of associates to purchase the assets of the Providence Tribune Company, publisher of The Star-Tribune, was withdrawn today in Superior Court. The court later put the company up for cash sale.

The altar and reredos erected as a memorial to the Very Rev. William Mercer Grosvenor, first dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in the Chapel of St. Ives in the Nave, will be dedicated today at 4 P. M. by Bishop William T. Manning.

Getting people out of slums into decent living quarters is a slow-motion prooess. It has to be geared to long swings of the time pendulum, like Presidential terms, rather than to the relatively swift tempo of things like crop cycles.

Representative Kennedy of New York put in the Record today a memorial from the New York City Board of Trade, urging Congress to consider a six-point legislative program to end the present business recession.

Bleeding from two gunshot wounds, James Poole, young insurance adjuster, tonight staggered down five flights of stairs in a downtown office building and dropped dead on the street at the feet of a throng of Christmas shoppers.
The engagement of Miss Frances Miller, daughter of Mrs. Charles Miller of this city and the late Mr. Miller, to William Herrick Merriman Jr., also of New Orleans, has been anndunced by her mother.

Miss Jeanette Markell, daughter of Charles Markell and the late Mrs. Markell, was married to Charles G. Page, son of Colonel Henry Page, U; S. Army, this afternoon in Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church. A small reception was

ALBERT-Mr. and Mrs. J. Louis Albert announce the birth of a son, Dec. 18, at Park West Hospital. ANGELSON-Mr. and Mrs. Harry (nee Libbie Levlnsky), wish to announce the birth of a daughter. BERGER-Mr. and Mrs. Richard J.. announce the arrival of Maxine's brother at French Hospital, Friday, Dec. 17.

Evidence of the success of the Antioch College plan of giving its students periods of alternate study and work at paid apprentice jobs in industry is seen in the fact that fewer than 2 per cent of its graduates of the last fifteen years are unemployed. Of 437 replying to a questionnaire issued by the Personnel Department, only six are listed as without jobs.

Within a few moments after he had left home on an errand for his mother, Sylvestri Dell' Olio, 7 years old, of 321 Bronxwood Avenue, the Bronx, was struck and killed at about 6 o'clock last night on Burke Avenue, near Bronxwood Avenue, by an automobile that failed to stop afterward.

A short-lived "heat wave" invaded the city yesterday, as balmy southwest winds, carrying rain clouds, sent the temperature soaring to degrees at 2 P. M. and filled Central Park and other outdoor spots with strollers garbed in Spring attire.

The playing offered by Alexander Kelberine at his piano recital in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon called for unstinted approbation, because of the great strides forward it evidenced in this serious performer's art.

A smooth-working L. I. U. freshman quintet registered its ninth triumph in eleven starts last night against a weak Curtis High School varsity on the losers' court at St. George, S. I. The score was 44 to 15.

Harlem's Christmas stocking will bulge this week with an unusual gift in the form of a free Community Art Center for old and young alike. It opens formally tomorrow evening with a program arranged by the WPA Federal Art Project and the Harlem Citizens Sponsoring Committee.

Will Europe and America always refrain from acting? asked V. K. Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador to France, in an address yesterday in which he reviewed the Far Eastern conflict before members of the International Diplomatic Academy here.

One of the outstanding issues presented by the series of attacks by Japanese armed forces in China on Americans. British and other foreigners, aid now brought to a head by the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay on the Yangtze River, is whether, with Japan increasing her ascendancy over China, the other powers will be permitted to remain and carry on trade as they have done for a hundred years.

Holiday prices on Scotch whiskies quoted by large downtown and midtown retailers continued yesterday to be substantially less than those fixed under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act. While several stores had reductions on wide lists, the low prices were generally confined to

The meeting room of the board of governors of the Real Estate Board of New York, 12 East Forty-first Street, has been redecorated and refurnished and is now dominated by a large reproduction of a painting by Alfred Fredericks depicting Peter Minuit purchasing Manhattan Island from the Indians.

Reflecting the approach of the holiday season and the reluctance of many traders to participate in the market so long as the views of business leaders are so divergent on the probable extent of the business decline,
Pre-holiday dullness prevailed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, wheat holding within a range of around 1 cent and corn in about '2 cent a bushel.

Persons liquidating foreign personal holding companies who cannot for legitimate reasons complete the process by Jan. 1 to benefit from certain-income tax exemptions may receive an extension of time if they submit the facts fully, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.

A special committee of the New York City Cancer Committee is preparing a comprehensive cancer exhibit for the New York World's Fair of 1939, to cover 500 square feet in the Health Building on the fair grounds.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt urged Negro women to take an especial interest in education in an address at a dinner of the National Council of Negro Women at the Harlem Y. W. C. A., 179 West 137th Street.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Zeller of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Zeller, to John Hunter Gage of Glen Ridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Raymond Gage of Winchester, Mass.

Stocks closed steady and generally higher in quiet trading; steel shares strongest; turnover, 500,550 shares. United States Government issues higher, other bonds firm in slowest trading since Oct. 9; transactions, $3,872,800.

Stuyvesant High of New York was defeated by the Rogers High quintet tonight, 31-23, in the opening game for Rogers. The visitors trailed all the way, being behind by 17-8 at the half and scoring their last 15 points against the local

The requirement in the Federal Trade Commission's rayon rules that all advertising of products containing rayon must mention such content will eventually bring substantial benefit to the industry, a.ccording to some trade opinion.

Indications that Manhattan real estate sales activity has "lessened in marked sympathy with the general business reaction, both as to dollar volume and number of deals," are found in the monthly report of trading in this borough issued by the Real Estate Board of New York.

The Thomas Hardy collection in the Colby College library has. been enriched recently by some. rare items and is now believed to be one of the most complete in this country, numbering more than 2,000 books, manuscripts, letters, translations.

When the new Lincoln Tunnel starts pouring forth its streams of motor vehicles next Wednesday at Thirty-eighth Street in Manhattan and in Weehawken, N. J., a new factor in the development of real estate in the midtown West Side and in New Jersey communities will begin to make itself felt.
Motorists were warned today by Motor Vehicles Commissioner Harnett to take every precaution against poisoning by carbon monoxide gas.
UPWARD of 2,000 young folks thronged to Carnegie Hall yesterday morning to hear John Barbirolli conduct the season's first program of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society.

Elvin Schmitt, who has returned from a coast-to-coast tour as assisting pianist with the Ionian Singers, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. In a Bach Fantasia, an early Beethoven Sonata and the Brahms-Handel Variations.

Carl Nassokin, justice of the peace of Mullica Township, died at his home in Mullica Township on Thursday of a heart attack. He had been elected last month for an additional five years after having served for twenty years as a justice of the peaec and for twelve years as a member of the Mullica Township Board of Education.

Shareholders in Canadian gold and basemetal mines will have shared more than $100,000,000 in profits from the year's production when the final dividends are declared for 1937 in the last half of this month. Dividends paid or payable before Dee. 31 amount to $101,295,536.
THE Dance International will have as its special attraction this week the presentation at headquarters in the International Building of a film of Pavlova in eight of her dances.

Federal agents, concentrated here in a search for two convicts who escaped from Alcatraz Prison, in vestigated today a report that a thirty-foot launch and a rowboat were observed near an abandoned wharf at Richmond, a short distance from Alcatraz Island.

WASHINGTON.-Spending habits among Vermont farmers have been surveyed by the Bureau of Home Economics. Its report emphasizes what had been known of Vermont thriftiness, but adds testimony of a less-familiar virtuegenerosity.

Germany is Japan's ally-in an 'anti-Bolshevist" pact--before the world. Yet during the past few months reports both from Europe and the Far East have told of persistent attempts by Germany to mnediate between China and Japan. Why?

The Christmas Junior Assembly of the Women's Club of Orange will take place Wednesday at the clubhouse. Mrs. J. Wilbur Lewis of West Orange, chairman of arrangements, is being assisted by Mrs. Frederick H. Baxter, Mrs. Bernard DuBois, Mrs. Frederick G. Herbst, Mrs. Alfred E. Leadbeater, Mrs. Edward D. McKown and Mrs. S. Crane Williams.

Though chamber music is at length coming to its own in popular understanding, the field is not so crowded that a new ensemble is not welcome. This was the indication given by the large audience that greeted the lately arrived French organization, the Ortambert String Quartet, last night at Town Hall.

Descriptive labeling will be the subject of a conference of the National-American Wholesale Grocers Association with canners on Jan. 24 at the Congress Hotel, Chicago, W. H. Tyler, president of the grocers' group, made known yesterday.

Altrusa Club-Candlelight supper, 6:30 P. M., Hotel Great Northern. Bronxville Women's Club-Music section, annual Christmas candlelight party, 5:15 P. M. Catholio Teachers Sodality of Northern New Jersey-Lecture on "Peace" by the Rev. R. Rush Rankin, 4 P. M., Collins Memorial Gymnasium.

Growing tension in the taxicab industry, where the Transport Workers Union has been authorized by its 15,000 hackmen members to call a general strike at any time within the discretion of its executive board, resulted yesterday in one arrest and a single case of violence.

The following Foreign Service changes since Dec. 4 were announced today by the State Department: Bernard C. Connelly of Rock Island, Ill., Vice Consul and Third Secretary of Legation at Bucharest, assigned to Karachi. India. as Vice Consul.

The critical moment in Spain approaches. Some time this Winter the heaviest battle of the civil war must be fought between combatants who since the battle of Guadalajara in March have studiously avoided each other. The northern front of Vizcaya, Santander, and the Asturias, always as much an embarrassment as an aid -to the Government. has been swept away.

A plea to the people of the United States to ignore the doctrines of racial and religious cleavage now popular in totalitarian countries was made by President Roosevelt in a statement made public yesterday by the National Conference of Jews and Christians.
CHRISTMAS is the only day that brings the world's broadcasters together at the microphone with a single radio program theme. Broadcasts

RECENT ART PICTURES ON EXHIBIT, the new art monthly edited by Charles Z. Offin, reveals in its second (December) issue a general olicy gratifyingly flexible and alive. several improvements over the first issue have been effected. One of
The Stevens Tech quintet lost its first intercollegiate game of the season, 33-28, today to the strong Cathedral five at the Stevens gym.
Led by sharp-shooting Ed Anderson, who scored 15 points, the Columbia basketball team had little difficulty defeating the Williams quintet at the Lions' gymnasium last night.

Mr. and Mrs. Franklin M. Jones of this place and Londonderry, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwynneth Elizabeth Jones, to Dr. Robert Bascom Aiken, son of Professor and Mrs. Wellington E. Aikeni of Burlington, Vt.

A three-month commercial accord between The Netherlands and Germany was signed in Berlin today after several months of ardtuous negotiations. It includes clearing-regulations and its other clauses do not essentially modify the agreement expiring the end of this month. Negotiations for a treaty will be resumed early in the new year.

At the meeting of the American Physical Society last week in Stanford University, California, Professor Philip Abelson, 24-year-old teaching assistant in physics in the University of California, announced that with the cyclotron he had succeeded in transforming uranium, heaviest of all known elements, into two heavier ones.

Railroad and industrial workers today urged increased output as the major aim of the third Soviet Five-Year Plan to be started with the new year. In a challenge published in the Soviet press, the workers declared January would be the "Stalin month of Stakhanoff records,"

Miss Mary Louise Cleveland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Francis Cleveland of Utica, N. Y., was married to George Tremaine Mortimer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Mortimer of 610 Park Avenue, on Friday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church by the rector, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent.

Religion faces a "sinister and menacing" challenge to its basic ideals, the Rev. Dr. David de Sola Pool said yesterday in his sermon at the Congregation.. Shearith Israel, Seventieth Street and Central Park West. Dr. Pool spoke on "After Thirty Years" to commemorate the thirtieth anniversary of his induction.

Another nonsectarian appeal to the Polish Government and to the Polish nation, on behalf of Polish Jews, was made public here yesterday in a statement by the American Committee on Religious Rights and Minorities.

John W. Davis, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, announced last night a gift of $20,000 from an anonymous contributor who last week gave $25,000 to the fund to help provide for the free care given by the ninety-two voluntary hospitals of New York and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn.

Albany County Girl Scouts will add a novelty to a program of Christmas Eve carols-a living Christmas tree. Joined by about 600 Boy Scouts and 400 adults, nearly 1,000 girls will outline the tree on the steps of the State Capitol.

Mary Patricia Lochridage, 21 years old, of Forest Hills, L. I., has been awarded the Woman's Press Club Scholarship for study in the Columbia University School of Journalism during the present academic year, it was announced yesterday afternoon by Harriet Bishop Waters Christie, president of the club, at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT Charles E. Fields, from 13th Division to Telegraph Bureau, designated as acting captain, for fifteen days, from 8 A. M., Dec. 17. SERGEANT George J. Boullianne, from 114th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, Queens, for one day, from 4 ?. M., Dec. 15.

The sinking of the Panay brought into high relief Japanese anxiety not to lose American good-will. It was given both popular and official expression. School children brought their pennies to the American Embassy to console the Panay victims, and letters to editors proposed building a replica of the Panay by public subscription and presenting it to the United States as a gesture of friendship.

Calling attention to the fact that the New York City budget for 1938 includes an item of $32,000,000 for transit debt service, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, stated last t week that if that sum could be saved to the city, it might, very wisely, be used to condemn blighted areas and thereby make Manhattan a better place in which to live.

WHILE aircraft engineers were working their slide rules overtime last week in an effort to figure out the 100-passenger airplanes Pan American Airways announced that it wants for transocean service other airmen were weighing the significance of the company's unprecedented request.

Golf is without a rival as the most popular of sports for women chiefly because it is a game that can be enjoyed by all ages and all classesthose playing on the swankiest of golf courses can get no greater thrill from the game than is experienced by divot-diggers on public links.

THE country and my writing," says Sheila Kaye Smith, "are really two different parts of the same thing. They are so interwoven that I cannot separate them. * *,* I still write, I know, from the impressions of those early dayspictures that I see always in a clear sunshine, vivid, alight and sharp as swords in my memory."

Plans for the sponsorship of ten research physicists by the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company to explore the fields of pure science, thereby accelerating scientific progress, in the company's research laboratories in East Pittsburgh, Pa., were announced yesterday by Dr. L. W. Chubb, director of the laboratories.

Brother Justus of the Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer died yesterday at the rectory of St. Peter's Catholic Church. He was 57 years old. Born in Germany, he came to this country at the age of 17.

Squadron C's teams broke even in last night's double-header, which closed the 1937 indoor polo program at the victors' armory in Brooklyn. Because of the holidays, no more matches will be played there until Jan. 8.
When the producers of motion pictures opened their storage vaults of short subjects to the scrutiny of educators, the lowly "short" assumed real significance as an educational medium.

The first non-professional production of "Idiot's Delight," the Pulitzer prize-winning play by Robert E. Sherwood, will be offered by the Penn State Players here Jan. 21. Frank S. Neusbaum, assistant professor of dramatics at the college, has already called rehearsals.

The firm of A. C. H. M. Hall, which recently acquired a tract of approximately sixteen acres in the Riverdale section from the estate of Isaac G. Johnson, has increased its holdings in that choice residential area by buying the vacant plot,

Mrs. Dora Delano Forbes, aunt of President Roosevelt; A. Gonzalez Prada, Peruvian Minister to France, and Mine. Prada; the Very Rev. Y. U. Pin, Bishop of Nanking; Anita Loos, Count Chriatian de Dampierre and Count and Countess Riccio are due to arrive today from Europe on the French liner Champlain.

Four times as many Chinese planes crashed from poor piloting as Japanese guns shot down. That tells the story of what happened to China's air force. Most of China's American-made planes have been cracked up.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of Paragraph 8. Special Orders 263, dated Nov. 12, 1937, as continues 2d Lt. Henry E. J. MacDermott, Inf.-Res., on active duty with the CCC until June 17, 1938, is amended so as to continue him on active duty until Jan. 15, 1938.

President Roosevelt will resume on Tuesday his discussions with utility company executives on Federal power policies. He will see on that day for a discussion of rate-making and other questions Frank R. Phillips,
Clarence H. Mackay, chairman of the board of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company, was reported in a satisfactory condition last night, following an emergency operation for appendicitis.

Five students from New York City and vicinity are among the thirteen seniors to whom first honors have been awarded for outstanding work in the first quarter of the year, cording to an announcement by the Rev. John F. Cox, dean of Holy Cross College. They are: Adrian P.

Trustees of the Zachary Smith Reynolds Foundation announced tonight that the income from the $7,000,000 memorial fund formally established in 1936 would be used exclusively for a campaign in North Carolina to fight syphilis.

Captain George J. Barendse brought the flagship Statendam of the Holland America Line into port last week on his first voyage as successor to Captain Johannes J. Bijl, who went ashore to 4upervise the construction of the new liner Nieuw Amsterdam in Rotterdam.

Senator William H. Smathers, New Jersey Democrat, who is here for the week-end, declared today that the Senate was the "greatest device for time wasting and long winded speeches that I have ever had anything to do with."

A reproduction of a four-span stone bridge over the Catskill Creek at Leeds, N. Y., in which many of the original stones have been used, has been opened to traffic by the State Department of Public Works.

Sydney Sundheim, president of Theatre Advertising, Inc., died of heart disease yesterday in his fifty-fourth year. Before heading this company he was sales manager of the advertising concern of Byren Weil, Inc.

For many millions of the inhabitants of this planet this is the happiest week of the year. Certainly it is for those Neediest who have been given prospect of a happier life for the next revolution of our planet about the sun. It is hoped that the gifts of the next six days will be sufficient to add to the happiest those whose names appear for the first time today.

United States trade with China and Japan has been maintained at a higher level this year than last, despite hostilities in the Orient; but trade with both countries has fallen off ii the last few months, according to the Department of Commerce.

THE kidnapping of Lillian Gish caused not so much as a Page 1 ripple. It happened in the twinkling of an eye. There she-was, all of nine, dancing in mid-stage on the curtain's rise, while an actress, who could make a comment on - the weather seem like a fiery fragment from Cicero's harangue against Catiline, lit up the first entrance.

The late Easter in 1938 will resuit in a prolonging of the clearance sales period on men's clothing and furnishings, a development which does not appeal to either manufacturers or retailers, they said here yesterday.

INVENTIVE: Carleton Ellis of Montclair, N. J., has an inventive turn of mind. He has invented many things, ranging from dog biscuits to a substance for fireproofing airplanes against incendiary bullets. Last week he received his 700th patent from the Patent Office.

Trinity College has announced a series of scientific lectures at the Chemistry Auditorium, "which are to be known as the Francis P. Garvan Lectures, in memory of the president of the Chemical Foundation.

ARTURO TOSCANINL the little Italian maestro of the flaming spirit, incorruptible artistic integrity and almost legendary accomplishments, has come back to America to conduct for us. His audience this time will no longer be a few hundred fortunate people seated in a hall; it will number millions scattered over this country and Canada and in lands beyond the seas. It will be the radio

As the half-way mark in the challenge match for the world pocket billiard championship was passed yesterday at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy, Ralph Greenleaf of New York, the titleholder, showed no signs of slackening his pace against Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y.

The conviction in a Baltimore Federal Court Thursday of fourteen seamen of the freighter Algic for mutiny should have a salutary effect upon the reign of lawlessness afloat that has marked our recent maritime history. For the jury's decision certainly means that mutiny aboard ship is still mutiny, whether the C. I. O. chooses to call it by a gentler name or not.

Arsenal's upward thrust, expected to put the Londoners at the top of the English Football League today, received instead a bad setback by the low-placed Liverpool team. Playing on their own ground, the Lancastrians blanked the Gunners, 2-O.

The Rutgers quintet came from behind to beat Princeton, 34 to 33, before 2,500 fans tonight. George Buttle, tall center, dropped in a foul shot with less than two minutes to play to give the Scarlet its fourth victory in a row.
Two Cleveland policemen were shot and killed tonight when- they attempted to examine an automobile carrying four men near an East Side gasoline station in a busy cafe and night club district.

The demand of retailers for lisle hosiery in response to the movement to boycott Japanese products has resulted in a sharp upturn in production of the cotton product, and fifty-five manufacturers have entered the field, since six weeks ago, when only five were making lisle hosiery, it was learned yester- 1 day.
Miss Elizabeth Osbourn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Osbourn of Mount Airy, was introduced to society today at a tea dance given by her parents in the North Garden of the Bellevue Stratford.

The good which the Neediest Cases Fund does each year is limited only by the amount of money entrusted to it by generous donors; its beneficence is not limited to - the first hundred neediest cases, from which it originally took its name. As the fund has grown with the passing of the years it has come to provide for hundreds of cases of individuals in dire want through no fault of their own.

In the face of a threatened strike similar to the one on her sister ship two days ago, the Furness liner Queen of Bermuda sailed yesterday with 680 passengers, including 100 transferred from the cancelled Monarch of Bermuda Thursday.

Lemuel Crawford, father of Municipal Court Justice Harold J. Crawford and Mrs. Peter M. Daly, wife of Supreme Court Justice Daly, died yesterday at his home, 23-08 Thirtieth Avenue, Astoria, at the age of 72.
Italy Was embarked today on a program of more rigid price control to check the rising cost of living.

David Schenker, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, sought today at the resumptior of the commission's inquiry into investment trusts to trace commissions of $400,000 paid in connectior with the sale of the Buenos Ca Aires subway system by the General Investment Corporation for $7,500,000 to the Argentine Institute Movilizardo de Inversiones.

After losing the rubber to England in the rugby' tests, Australia recorded a 13-3 victory today in the last of the threegame series. The first encounter at Leeds saw the Englishmen win, 5-4, and they took the second test at Swinton, 13-3.

The Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., the new art auction galleries organized by former officers of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., has leased the first four floors of the Dobbs Building, on the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, according to announcement yesterday.

The Ridgewood Polo Club, national junior indoor champion, thrilled a crowd of 2,000 tonight by riding to a 9-to-6 victory over the First Division trio of Brooklyn at the Essex Troop Armory. Earle Hopper paced the champions with five goals.

Joint army and navy exercises in which some 500 troops of the First Division from Fort Hamilton will participate will be held in the Puerta Rican area from about the middle of January until the middle of March, it was learned yesterday.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Dorothy M. Connell, daughter of Mrs. M. J. Connell of Seattle and San Francisco, to John Francis McKiernan Jr., son of Mrs. John F. McKiernan of this city, which took place on Dec. 1 in the Cathedral Chapel, Santa Monica, Calif.

Perstare et Praestare, nonor society at the University Heights center of New York University, has inducted twelve new members this semaster, it was announced yesterday by Dean Irving H. Berg of the University College of Arts and Pure Science and Dean Thorndike Saville of the College of Engineering.

THE orchestra and chorus of the Turin Radio, home station of the E. I. A. R. (the Italian Broadcasting Corporation), have just given a concert at the Milan Conservatory under the direction of their permanent conductor, ArmandO La Rosa Parodi.

Henry Roberts, general counsel for the National Automobile Dealers Association, told a subcommittee of the House Interstate Commerce Committee today that Ford car dealers throughoutt the country were forced to contribute to a fund to buy a Cape Cod windmill for Henry Ford.

IT is certain that Mr. Nock didn't write the description of his book which is printed on the front flap of the jacket. He might like to think that his "logic is strict, his writing pungent" but he would never maintain that his "philosophy is sound."

Without government projects, art in this country "virtually has no place to go," Holger Cahill, national director, Federal Arts Project of the WPA, told the second American Artists Congress yesterday afternoon at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Holiday sales were running below a year ago in most Reserve districts last week, and a few districts reported merchants reconciled to a loss for the holiday season of 5 per cent. Sleet storms brought poor trade in Chicago and St. Louis, and rains reduced the Pacific Coast volume. Texas reported gains, but in the Southeast volume was under a year ago.

MUSIC life in Naples is often worth special attention. The high light this year will come in March with the revival at the San Carlo Opera of Ernest Bloch's "Macbeth," a strong work unjustly buried since the Paris premiere, which took place in 1910.

Satisfaction with the recent drastic action against terrorism taken by the British administration in Palestine was expressed last night by Hirsch Manischewitz in his report as president of the Federation of Palestine Jews in America opening its seventh annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

THE long-heralded "Exposition Internationale Paris 1937" souvenir sheets of the French colonies arrived. in New York last week. They resemble finely executed advertising labels, which in effect they are, rather than stamps. Although valid for postage, they were printed primarily for collectors and for this reason will receive only limited catalogue recognition.

Offering its support in developing a broad-national home building program, the Committee for Economio and. Social Progress announced yesterday that it had addressed to President Roosevelt a letter urging a plan to supplement his proposals for long-term mortgage credit for large-scale projects with adequately capitalized home building companies.

Discussions to extend the findings of the National Window Display Study, released last week, to a nation-wide basis and to map retail trading zones in a comprehensive marketing program, possibly under the sponsorship of decentralized advertising mediums, such as newspapers and outdoor, have already started, it was learned here yesterday.
The Monroe County Board of Supervisors has been asked to prohibit the erection of political advertising signs on county roads.
THE Christmas tree that is brought into the house like an honored guest, and loaded with presents, sweets and glistening ornaments, enters the city bound and flung down, a captive.

In a wild and woolly game in which points were a dime a dozen, a magnificent University of Illinois quintet last night routed St. John's of Brooklyn by 60 to 45 at Madison Square Garden while a crowd of 15,000 watched in amazement as the co-champions of the Big Ten set a collegiate scoring record for the arena.

Chauncey W. Johnson, who was 104 years old on July 20 and who had been active in business until sixteen years ago, died at Dumont Private Hospital today. He had been living with his daughter, Mrs. F. Steam Edick, of Bergenfield.

With police toleration, the newspaper Tara Noastra, organ of the Goga Fascists, daily publishes an order to adherents of Octavian Goga's and Professor A. C. Cuza's anti-Semitic groups to prevent Jews, by terrorism, from voting in the coming election.

With employee relations ranked well in the lead among the problems in which retailers are interested, increasing attention is being given to the prospect that State minimum wage law developments promise to become an important factor affecting distribution in the period directly ahead, according to a retail authority here in close touch with labor developments.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel F. Lentz of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Elizabeth Lentz, to Raymond John Rohrs, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Rohrs Jr. of Pelham, N. Y.

For the fourth successive year the American Woman's Association will hold on Wednesday evening a Christmas tree party in the holly decked ballroom of its club house at 353 West Fiftyseventh Street for 300 children of the Clinton neighborhood.

Worry over not being allowed free rein with an inheritance of $3,000.000 was held to be the cause of the suicide of Percy Grubb today at the home of his brother-inlaw, Adrian G. Wood, in Carpinterua Valley.

Residents of this country hamlet, nestled in the hills of Northern Westchester, were waiting expectantly today for the arrival of scientists who will take their temperatures, look at their tongues and perhaps obtain a few drops of blood from their arms for injection into the veins of ferrets.

There are window gardeners and country gardeners; dirt gardeners (who are satisfied with any form of gardening, so long as they get the feel of the soil) and specialty gardeners; competitive growers and recreational planterS.

Peekskill Military Academy defeated St. Michael's of Brooklyn by 43--13 today in the opening basketball game of the season for the cadets. The academy team was led by Captain Meehan, with 15 points. He was followed by Hopkins and Friedlund with 10 and 8 points, respectively.

The Federal Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decided today that the Federal Government had no right to collect the 10 per cent admission tax to football games or other athletic events at State-operated universities.
THE title and the foreword of this book lead one to antici pate further developments of psychoanalysis, perhaps more along therapeutic than theoretic lines.

Former Senator George Wharton Pepper of Pennsylvania, addressing the thirty-ninth annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night on the subject "Why a Constitution?" praised it as a living, workable document which should be changed only by the people themselves through amendment and not by judicial interpretation.

Ed Rosenthal. left forward, led the Boys High basketball team to a 43-to-27 victory over Bushwick yesterday on the Boys court in a Brooklyn P. S. A. L. Division II game. Rosenthal tallied five field gials for 10 points.
Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Catesby Jones gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 53 East Ninety-second Street, at which they introduced to society their daughter, Miss Frances Key Brooke Jones.

Mrs. Clinton Burgess Repp of Plainfield has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Cynthia Neilsen Repp, to Christie P. Hamilton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Christie P. Hamilton, also of this place.

The engagement of Miss Anne Lawson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William 0. Lawson of this place, to Gustav Eduard Schinitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans H. Schmitt of Ridgewood, was announced by her parents at a supper party given at their home tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Sommer of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsa Weber Sommer, to Robert Chanless Winters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Winters of Richmond Hill. Queens. and Allenhurst. N. J.

Several foreclosed properties in White Plains have been sold by the Home Savings Bank of White Plains, it was reported yesterday by Chauncey B. Griffen, agent for the bank in the sales. During the past three weeks five sales aggregating $60,000 were consummated.
Ever since Dr. Gilbert N. Lewis, dean of the College of Chemistry of the University of California, first isolated heavy water in 1933 the biologists have been wondering what its effects are on life.

The Far Eastern problem and the relation of the League of Nations to foreign interference in internal conflicts will be topics at the twelfth annual Model Assembly of the League of Nations, Middle Atlantic Division, to be held at Rutgers University April 7, 8 and 9.

A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. in the board headquarters, 500 Park Avenue. Election of an Associate Superintendent of Schools, postponed for seven consecutive meetings, will come up again. Action on Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof's proposal to reorganize the evening school system is also scheduled.
Coming from behind in the third period, the Atlantic City Sea Gulls nosed out the New York Rovers, 2-1 tonight nd increased their lead in the Eastern Hockey League.

In the midst of conflicting reportS, police today sought to pick up the trail of Wendell F. Bowers, 19, reformatory parolee accused of murdering Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter, a Germantown beauty shop owner, in her home near Camp Hill on Monday afternoon.

Miss Catherine Wood Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Reck Campbell of this city, will be married here to Randolph Apperson Hearst, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Randolph Hearst of New York and San Simeon, Calif., on Wednesday afternoon, Jan. 12, in the Church of the Sacred Heart.

CHILDREN'S CHRISTMAS CARNIVAL--Saturday at the Windsor Theatre. A program of Tony Sarg Marionettes (giving "Robinson Crusoe"). Toto, the clown, a group of midgets and Dorothy Gordon and "Uncle Don" of the radio.

Mrs. Shepard Fabbri gave a ball last night in her house at 7 East Ninety-fifth Street to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Edith Fabbri Clark, daughter of Mrs. James Lloyd Derby and James Cameron Clark.

Buyers coming to the New York wholesale market on their regular January trips will probably make more substantial purchases than had previously been hoped for, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, E Block Co., resident buyers.
The Savage School basketball team turned back the New College five of Columbia University, 37 to 24, at the victors' gymnasium yesterday.
ERNEST DIMNET - that French scholar who writes in the English language with such amazing mastery-has been a warm friend of the United States these many years.

The marriage of Miss Sara Webb Key, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ben Witt Key of 1,170 Fifth Avenue, to James Owen WattS Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Watts of Lynchburg, Va., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

The health program of Princeton University endeavors to reach beyond the routine treatment of undergraduate ills to an inculcation of principles and methods which will be useful in later life, Dr. Wilbur H. York, chairman of the Princeton Department of Health and Physical Education, declares in his annual report to President Harold Willis Dodds.

A special committee of the Federation of British Industries, including representatives of other bodies with interests in China, has decided to urge the Foreign Office to press again for early settlement of claims for damage to British property interests in China and to cooperate with the United States Government in bringing about a resumption of Shanghai's commercial and industrial activities and municipal services.

THE presence of one or two early pictures in the current Vlaminck show (through Jan. 8) at the Lilienfeld Galleries serves to call attention to the development of the artist away from the somewhat liquid style which followed his fauve period, into the more dramatic and vigorous manner of the present day.
