The proud possessors of a fivegame winning streak, the New York Rangers, will try to add another triumph to their list tonight when they tackle the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

Whichcee, outstanding 3-yearold gelding owned by Major Austin C. Taylor of Vancouver, B. C., won the $10,000 added San Francisco Handicap at Tanforan today in a sensational upset over the South American favorite, Amor Brujo. The time for the mile and a sixteenth was 1:441-5.

The upward trend of poultry and the downward trend of meats in price has led the City's Consumer's Food Guide to suggest that housewives "build" their Christmas dinners around meat instead of poultry. Meats, which have been almost prohibitive up to recently, have taken a down turn. Poultry, on the other hand, seems still to be climbing.

To a great extent the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay has overshadowed Japanese actions against the British, and therefore London at the moment is closely watching the development of American opinion.
Seven farmers and business men of McRae, including the Mayor, were arrested by Federal agents late today on charges of defrauding the government in connection with cotton loans.

For the first week since Aug. 14, when it reached a "high" for the year and the recovery, The New YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has advanced. It stands at 85.0 for the week ended Dec. 11, which compares with 84.8 (revised) in the previous week and 107.5 for the corresponding week last year.

The marriage of Miss Mona Law Fotterall Trench, daughter of Mrs. Stewart Power Trench of 308 East Seventy-ninth Street, and of the late William Foster Fotterall Jr. of Philadelphia, to Robert Hamilton Murray, son of Joseph Norris Murray, also of this city, and of Quogue, L. I., took place yesterday in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Pete, one of the white canaries in the two-day show of the Empire Cage Bird Association, which was opened yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, can whistle "Yankee Doodle." The trouble with him, so far as commercializing his talent is concerned, is that he sings only when he pleases.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Princeton's medley relay team was spectacular in winning the 300-yard swimming race at the New York A. C. last night, so spectacular that it undoubtedly will be heard from often in this Winter's meets.
Changes Proposed by Bill

The number of air-conditioning plants in the United States has increased 1,400 per cent since 1933. About 40 per cent of these-depend on local water supplies to cool and humidify air. Municipalities are worrying. Where is the water to come from?

If Japan had in London. been less hasty and taken elementary precautions to avoid treading on the toes of the great Western powers she probably would have of been able to conquer China at her leisure without feat of outside interference-just as Germany, if she acts adroitly, may gradually spread her sway over Eastern Europe without a major war.

Twelve committees have been chosen to serve for the Columbia College Junior Promenade on Feb. 25, it was announced yesterday by Gerhard Seidel, president of the class. General .chairman for the event is Kirby Davidson of St. Louis.

A gift of $1,000 by Mrs. Charles E. Kistler of Morganton toward the establishment of a Charles E. Kistler Memorial Library of the Medical Sciences in the Medical School of the University of North Carolina was announced today.

American medical work in Spain conducted by the Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy will be aided by net proceeds from a New Year's Eve fiesta to be given at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the women's committee of the bureau.

Mrs. Edward James Patterson of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter. Miss Margaret Patterson, to Morrill Wiggin, son of Mrs. Henry H. Wiggin of Brookline, Mass., and the late Mr.Wiggin.

The proposal to close all producing oil wells in Texas on four consecutive Sunday, beginning tomorrow, was discussed last night in all its phases by the railroad commission, and it was decided to defer action for at least a month in order that a thorough survey may be made of the market and other conditions affecting the industry.

Pupils of the music school of Bronx House, 1,637 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, gave a recital of Christmas 'and other music at the home of Mrs. Henry Morgenthau, 1,133 Fifth Avenue, last night. About 100 boys and girls took part.

Dr. Richard Hermann Jaffe, chief pathologist at the County Hospital, died last night of a heart attack in his home here. Dr. Jaffe, a native of Vienna, was 49 years old. During the last two weeks he had played a leading role in the investigation into the deaths of thirteen infants stricken with an unusual form of dysentery at St. Elizabeth's Hospital.

The collapse of the efforts of Oscar P. Trautmann, the German Ambassador, to mediate or arrange direct parleys between Japan and China, besides resulting in the founding of a new Japanese-sponsored government at Peiping, has apparently caused Generalissimo Chiang Kaishel to abandon the retirement plar he had decided upon two days before he, with Mme. Chiang and W. H. Donald, his adviser, fled from Nanking.

Home gardeners who for years have been filling their Winter windows with such standbys as ferns, begonias and geraniums now find it interesting- to add something uncommon to-the display - Suited to their purpose is the Anthurium, or flamingo flower, particularly as is quite as. easy to grow and is more floriferous than many of the customary house plants.

Announcement has been made to friends here of the engagement of Miss Mabel Olga Bloomfield. daughter of Mrs. David Bloomfield of Westmount, Montreal, and the late Mr. Bloomfield, to Jason Irwin Tarsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Robert Tarsey of Albany.

For the past two decades since the World War ended various proposals of international cooperation for the preservation of law and order among the countries have appeared on the horizon. All the way from the ambitious League of Nations covenant, past the World Court, down to recent suggestions for joint position by Great Britain and the United States in the Far East, they have come and gone. We would have none of them.

Miss Eva Mayr of 30 Daniel Low Terrace, St. George, S. I., a stenographer employed in a midtown Manhattan office, is the author of the lyrics for "Christmas Exultation," which will be played by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and sung by the People's Chorus of New York, at a concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday.

Mr. and Mrs. Mark D'Andrea of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clarice Lucille D'Andrea, to Athanasius Albert Spica, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Spica of Mount Vernon, N. Y.

Mrs. Clyde Brown will preside at a meeting and tea tomorrow afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria for all the committees actively associated with plans for the special matinee performance of "Siegfried" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Jan. 20.

With the recent production of Anton Chekhov's "The Three Sisters" by the Amherst College Masquers and the Mount Holyoke Dramatic Association, and with the Harvard and Smith Dramatic Clubs collaborating with the Northampton Players in the production of Francis R. Hart's "Straight Scotch" in Northampton on Dec. 16, college dramatics appear to have entered upon a new phase in this section.

Twentyfive additional members of the Republican party's new Committee on Program, including Orval W. Adams of Salt Lake City, president of the American Bankers Association, were announced today. The additions bring the personnel of the committee to 132, with the group not yet completed.
The Works Progress Administration, President Roosevelt's tremendous agency for the elimination of a Federal dole, stands today on the verge of a crisis in its feverish career.

THERE are several reasons why it is appropriate to talk of Daumier just now. The first reason has to do with the recent exhibition of his work in various media at the Pennsylvania Museum in Philadelphia and with the lithographs currently shown at the McDonald Gallery here in New York.
Property owners will get a measure of tax relief when the new city charter becomes effective Jan. 1 through clauses which change the system of paying assessments for civic improvements,

One way to balance the national budget is to sell the crown jewels, if there are any such things, according to a Department of Commerce report today which said the Iranian Parliament had approved a bill to get funds in this manner.

During the holiday season, which each Winter brings many young people home from schools and colleges, there will be many subscription dances for juniors In society. These parties, the majority being in series that have been conducted

Miss Jane Ogden Tanner, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Tanner of 660 Park Avenue, was guest of honor at a dinner dance given last night In the Crystal Garden of the RitzCarlton by Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Dewart.
This tiny village, deserted for fifty years, had plenty of inhabitants today, but they were all hunters. And so far as the deer were concerned, it was still deserted.

At midnight tonight a jury before Common Pleas Judge Walter D. Van Riper brought in a verdict of guilty of causing death by reckless driving against Joseph Linarducci Jr., captain of Essex County Prosecutor's detectives.

Two-thirds of the pupils who enter the New York City high schools each year do not remain to be graduated, Dr. J. Lewis Stockton of the Civics Teachers Association disclosed yesterday in making public a survey on pupil failure.
Paced by Milton Mirsky, the Montclair State Teachers quintet of New Jersey triumphed, 39-26, over the Hofstra College team at the Hempstead High School gymnasium tonight.

The Trinity College basketball team defeated Haverford College, 43-24, tonight on the losers' floor. Trinity led from the start and was never headed, largely because of the accurate shooting of Art Mountford, who garnered 14 points to take scoring honors for the evening. Beeler paced the losers with 11.

Like Henri Landru, his only equal in the annals of crime in France, Eugene Weidmann had, according to some of those who were and some who escaped being his victims, "magnetic eyes." Comparison between these two terrible murderers, however, must end there.

To the Art Editor: RECENTLY you published an article by Ruth Green Harris on "Lighting and Other Vexing Problems" in museums. This paper did not touch upon the very pertinent question of the intellectual illumination of the art museum display,

Javanese, Asiatic, Viennese and Egyptian headgear as well as floral creations and mystic veils were worn in bizarre contrast to formal evening attire by approximately 1,000 subscribers attending the "Headdress Ball" given tonight at the Bellevue-Stratford for the benefit of the Board of Women Visitors of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania.

An upswing in prices and a substantial increase in sales developed last week in several lines which ordinarily move upward or downward several months in advance of the general business trend, and trade observers said there was reasonable ground for believing that this is the forerunner of a reversal of the recession which began in the Summer.

A FORTHCOMING Parliamentary investigation of Imperial Airways, Ltd., based primarily on complaints about its handling of personnel, probably will open to public scrutiny in the distant future many details of a sweeping network of air services with which only Pan American Airways of the United States can be compared.

The financial anemia from which the American railroad system has been suffering chronically for more than a score of years has again become acute. As usual, the only remedial potion in which the patient has any confidence is a liberal dose of increased rates.

The whereabouts of 67-year-old Prince Michael Radziwill and his Jewish fiance, Mme. Jeanette Suchestow, was a question puzzling family attorneys and Warsaw courts today. They said a search of the numerous Radziwill estates and the Prince's Warsaw haunts had disclosed no trace of them.
According to a The Sunday Referee King George land his immediate advisers have been given a knotty task in settling once and for all the question of the precedence of the Duchess of Windsor.

Marx Dormoy, Minister of the Interior, was reported today to have urged that in the future all visitors to France be fingerprinted. The proposal is the direct result of the popular demand for checking the influx of undesirables which has grown recently as the result of the Weidmann case.

" The Warsaw Lady," a play by Stanislaus Wyspianski, will be presented in Polish by students in the Columbia University Department of East European Languages tomorrow at 8 P. M. in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway at 116th Street.
When the drunken driver, the highway's worst menace, is waved to one side by the uniformed officer on a motor cycle in a traffic accident, the same argument follows from the Atlantic to the Pacific.

While leaders of the Horn Hardart Automat strike. demanded the removal of Magistrate Anthony F. Burke and planned an appeal from the prison sentences imposed by him on seventy-three pickets, a spokesman for the cafeteria chain estimated yesterday that only about 35 per cent of the persons arrested in mass picketing demonstrations since the strike began last August had ever worked in the Automats.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Russell of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Russell, to Roy Carl Starr Jr., son of Mrs. Oscar H. Berger of Great Neck and of Dr. Roy Carl Starr.

FOR a number of those who attended the recent 150th anniversary festivities of "Don Giovanni" in Prague nothing about the jubilee performance of Mozart's masterpiece, not even the fact that it was given in the same theatre where the composer conducted its world premiere, had

With oratory and with military and aviation displays, interspersed with aerial bombs, sirens and a chorus of whistles of harbor craft, the Port of New York Authority will dedicate its new vehicular Lincoln Tunnel on Tuesday morning.

Robert Worth Bingham, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, died tonight in Johns Hopkins Hospital, where he had undergone a diagnostic operation Tuesday. Death came at 7:21 P. M. He was 66 years old.

Sam Snead, long-driving pro from White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., slashed four strokes from par for a 66 today to lead in the first round of the $3,500 Nassau open golf tournament. His short game at rare proficiency, Snead shot five birdies and had only one bad hole as he took a three-stroke advantage on the field.

the first Soviet general election last Sunday, in which virtually the entire electorate voted for the Stalin ticket-the only ticket available-has been the theme ever since of extravagant self-congratulation by Soviet newspapers, mass meetings, gigantic parades and every other form of propaganda that an all-powerful regime can mobilize.
The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that freight rate increases estimated to give from

Dr. Horia Hulubel, a 40-year-old Rumanian physicist living in Paris, has announced to the French Academy of Sciences that he has discovered Element 87 and reports his findings in the Comptes Rendus of the academy. Chemists probably will raise a skeptical eyebrow

We see by the papers that the Legislature of New Jersey is getting ready to adopt a revision and "simplification" of the statutes passed since the present Constitution of the State went into effect in 1844. The work of revision has been going on for twelve years. It has cost the State something more than a million dollars.

UNDER the Christmas Star this season Toyland basks in a new prosperity. Its sturdier trains run swifter. Its gleaming trucks and trailers have the strength of ten of yesteryear's. Its smartly clad doll denizens are a new race, if not of iron men. at least of almost indestructible infants. And no ordinary nursery tornado can topple its stock-proofed towers.

Twelve women lawyers recently admitted to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York will be hOnor guests at the annual Christmas tea and bundle party to be given by the New York League of Business and Professional Women at the Hotel Biltmore this afternoon.

THREE first-rate works of fiction have been published lately by well-known authors. George Bernanos and Henri Troyat give us short stories; Maxence van der Meersch provides a novel. The three works belong to the genre which grafts imaginative elements on realism. Bernanos quickens facts by an insight into the workings of the spirit.

The United States liner President Roosevelt returned from Germany yesterday after a four-week lay-up in Hamburg for repairs to one of her propellers and a propeller shaft. The liner brought back 273 passengers, with eighty-seven in cabin class and 186 in third.

Active functioning of the Consumer-Retailer Relations Council within three months was indicated yesterday by Harold Brightman, vice president of L. Bamberger Co. and sponsor of the council, regarded as a major development in the progress of the consumer movement.

Representatives of more than fifty civic and peace organizations yesterday at a joint conference adopted a resolution calling for nation-wide cooperation in a consumers' boycott of Japanese goods. An organization was named to carry on the work of the conference on a national scale.

Diversification of styles, colors and sizes, together with careful checking upon fast-selling numbers, have been the outstanding reasons for sales gains made during the Fallf season by the blouse department of Arnold, Constable Co., despite the quite general trend toward lower sales figures on this merchandise, according to Meyer Liberman, vice president of the store.

Barnard College students taking the general economics course given by Dr. Emilie J. Hutchinson have been keeping budgets of their expenditures in an attempt to determine what it costs to send a girl to college.

A collection of sixty seaweeds, to be found off the coasts of California, Florida, Bermuda, the Bahamas, the West Indies and Long Island, will be on exhibit in the museum building of the New York Botanical Garden for two weeks beginning Friday.

The distinguished career of Dr. James Renwick, Columbia scholar of a century ago, is recounted with the history of three generations of the Renwick family in memorabilia presented to Columbia University under the will of his grandson, James Armstrong Renwick, of the class of 1876, who died last Summer.

An apparent attempt to derail two passenger trains of the Long Island Railroad during the evening rush of home-bound commuters two days ago was made known today by investigators. The engineer or a ten-car train, bound from New York with about 300 persons aboard, reported on arrival at Hicksville at 7:32 P. M.

Running the effortless race that has stamped him as New York's top-ranking schoolboy distance runner, Leslie MacMitchell, George Washington High star, annexed the one-mile run for the second year in succession at the annual De La Salle Institute interscholastic indoor track

Mrs. Helen Buchan, mother of Lord Tweedsmuir, died today at the age of 80. Before her marriage to the Rev. John Buchan, the Canadian Governor General's father, Mrs. Buchan was Miss Helen Masterton, daughter of John Masterton.

National Socialist Germany is approaching the Christmas holiday this year with her soul more disturbed than ever, both sentimentally and materially. Sentimentally she is upset because the meaning of Christmas has been thrown into the National Socialist melting pot until millions of Germans no longer know whether to celebrate this "most German of all holidays" in the old-fashioned Christian or in the neo-pagan National Socialist way.

The prosecution is finding it difficult to convict Arnold Bernstein, Jewish ship owner and operator, of exchange charges brought against him. Although the trial has now proceeded for a month, defense pleas are to be interrupted and secret testimony from a high functionary of the Reich exchange control office will be taken on Monday.
The New York Conference of Economics asked a legislative committee today to include civil service commissions in its study of discrimination against employment of workers past 40.

A plan for the continuation of the New York League of Girls' Clubs is being undertaken by members and former members of the organization as a memorial to the late Miss Virginia Potter, one of its founders and for twenty-one years its president. Miss Potter was,

The high speed front lines of the champion McGill University team packed too much dynamite in their sticks for Dick Vaughan's Princeton Tigers to restrain today, the Montrealers overwhelming their rivals, 10 to 0, as the Bengals opened their International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League season at the Forum.

The revival of the town meeting by all units of local government throughout the United States is being advocated by the New York chapter of the Descendants of the Revolution, according to Miss Katherine D. Blake, a member of its advisory board.

A third-period attack gave the Boston Bruins a 3-to-1 victory over the Montreal Maroons before 5,500 fans tonight and enabled them to regain the lead in the National Hockey League's American division. The victory gave the Bruins a 1-point margin over the idle New York Rangers and left the Maroons in the cellar of the International group.

William E. Jones, retired Texas ranch owner and lumber executive, and first cousin of Jesse Jones, RFC chairman, died of a heart attack today in his home in the suburb of Hillsborough. He was 69 years old.

A half-hour's conversation yesterday with the eminent pianist, Moriz Rosenthal, who is 75 years old today, evoked as many great shades of the past as the most successful seance of master spiritualists.

Wellesley students would rather disagree with the American electorate than with their parents and are therefore overwhelmingly Republican, a survey of student political inclinations, just completed by an advanced class in social and economic statistics, reveals.

Full details of the twenty-fifth game of the championship match, contested at The Hague and which decided the question of supremacy in favor of Dr. Alekhine, have been received. Loss of the exchange on the eighteenth move gave Dr. Euwe an uphill struggle, from which he was unable to recover.

The Brooklyn College basketball team suffered its second defeat in two days, losing to the Lafayette Leopards from Easton, Pa., by 4441 in a thrilling contest at the new Brooklyn College gymnasium last night.

Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, 10:45 A. M. "Jewish Youth Service," Sol M. Stroock, Harry L. Glucksman. Convention of the Federation of Palestine Jews. Hotel Pennsylvania, 11 A. M.

North Pole, Heaven, Paradise, City Hall, Top-of-the-World, Eskimo Land-these are only a few of the addresses hopeful youngsters are using this year in sending their requests to Santa Claus. And what requests they are!

Two roughly dressed men, who according to one of their victims had a gun "so big it looked like a machine gun," held up four employes in the Haber Hair Dye Company, 211 East Broadway, at 2 P. M. yesterday and escaped with $80.

The conflict between Japan and China, now five months old, has from the first threatened to involve other countries, notably the United States and Great Britain. Both have large commerciaI stakes and many nationals in the war-stricken republic.

The bombing of the United States gunboat Panay and the similar recent "incidents' in the Chinese conflict bearing on American and other foreign interests have resulted in a re-examination of our neutrality policy. Among other things,

French Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos's tour of friendly capitals in Eastern and Southeastern Europe came to an end here at noon today and he departed for Paris to report the results of his trip. M. Delbos himself just before leaving Prague summarized these resuits in two short sentences.
The United States First Circuit Court of Appeals today ruled unconstitutional 1,012 laws passed by resolution in the Puerto Rican Legislature since 1902.

The fourth Pan American anti-tuberculosis conference ended this afternoon when Dr. Hector Orrego, president of the conference, read the conclusions reached after four days of work which included visits to many open-air establishments for the treatment of tuberculosis.
The pendulum of public feeling is swinging back from the New Deal toward Republican principles, in the view of the Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee.

The Transit Commission announced yesterday that its order requiring elimination of shuttle service on the Webster Avenue and White Plains lines of the I. R. T. in the Bronx would go into force tomorrow.

Seton Hall College of South Orange defeated the St. Peter's College quintet at Collins Memorial Gymnasium tonight, 50 to 39, for its second straight victory. The losers held an advantage of 21-18 at halftime. Ed Sadowski tallied 15 points
AYOUNG Frenchman with a very slender reputation as a minor poet went to bed one night in 1881 and got up the next morning with an assured literary standinng.

The plan put forth by the House of Representatives Banking Committee, which would make it possible for a person to purchase a $10,000 home under the FHA plan, with a 10 per cent down payment on the first $6,000 and a 20 per cent down payment on the balance, while

With a cast and staff of twenty-three members, the Yale Dramatic Association will begin next week the longest road tour in the thirty-seven years of the organization, 3,500 miles to many of the principal cities of the Middle West.
Mr. and Mrs. John Behrens of Weehawken, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, I Miss Dorothy Suzanne Behrens, to Herbert B. Davison, son of C. Herbert Davison of Princeton, N. J.

GOD is among those to whom Mr. Powell acknowledges his indebtedness in the front of this new book of observation and adventure- He thanks Him that he is a rolling stone. explaining that he would detest being covered with moss.

GLEN ROUNDS is a born story-teller. He uses no unnecessary words. but never fails to include the significant and picturesque detail which makes an incident unforgettable; going straight to the point of his tale, he conveys to the reader, as he does so, a sense of background and atmosphere.

INTO a crisis in which the nature and scope of the power of the President is disputed more bitterly than ever before, Professor Binkley has launched an historical study of it, a running commentary and analysis. which purports to be "objective" and "dispassionate."
A cold snap and sunny weather today brought relief to hundreds of flood-stricken Italian families and checked the disastrous rise of the rain-swollen Tiber.

A strong Yale Alumni hockey team tonight made four goals against the freshmen in the first period and registered two against the varsity in the second and third sessions to defeat the combined undergraduate sextet, 6 to 5, in an exhibition before 500 spectators in the Arena.

BOOKS on nutrition fall into several clearly marked categories. First and most conspicuous are the diatribes of the food-faddists. These almost invariably reduce human physiology to some weird preconceived principle. which they defend with fury and bulwark by mountains of specious evidence.
THE urge to produce big pictures-pictures honestly de serving those much abused adjectives "tremendous," "spectacular" and even "colossal"--seems to run in cycles. Of course,

Actual production of educational films on a professional "box office appeal" level to give high school and college students "insight into contemporary problems" will be started in February by the University of Minnesota, with a three-year grant of $125,000 from the General Education Board.

The tense situation over the Japanese bombing of the United States gunboat Panay continued unabated here today, although new moves were withheld pending the conclusion of the naval inquiry at Shanghai into the attack and a reply from Japan to Secretary of State Cordell Hull's note of protest.

Three leaders in New York's musical life have joined in acclaiming the city's progress and leadership in music, and in crediting the business interests of the city with a large share in making possible its cultural advancement.

THE program of playgoing has been very full and interesting. Mr. Priestley, who has two plays already running in London, has produced a third, "People at Sea," which, though not in the same rank with "I Have Been Here Before" or even with "Time and the Conways," is a better and more intelligent piece than ordinarily appears.

IT is natural, perhaps, that the results of automobile traffic safety work are less prominent ly publicized than the causes that brought them into being. They represent a negative aspect of a problem. In no sense are they as spectacular as smash-ups and screeching, swerving skids.

Miss Phyllis Floud, daughter of the British High Commissioner to Canada, Sir Francis Floud, was married today in Chelsea Old Church to Peter Du Sautoy, son of Lieut. Col and Mrs. Edward Du Sautoy of Barnet Green, Worcestershire.

New York Silver. Museum of the City of New Yor,. until Jan. 17. Extensive display of work of city craftsmen from earliest days to 1900. Old Stained Glass. Paul Van Baarn Galleries, 32 East 57th Street, until Jan. 31. Rare examples from the twelfth to early sixteenth centuries.

General authorities of the Church of Latter Day Saints, in their annual Christmas message today, saw in a troubled world the threat of an "international explosion" that would drive peace from the "midst of mankind."

Plans have just been announced for another ice-skating show with a philanthropic appeal, which will be held on Jan. 24 at Madison Square Garden. On that occasion Sonja Henie and a Hollywood ballet of skaters will appear in a diversified program, and the net proceeds from the ice revue will be donated to the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helena Apthorp Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Thompson of this place, to Louis Long Jr., son of Mrs. Louis Long of New York and the late Mr. Long.

VERDI'S "Otello," absent from the Metropolitan repertoire far twenty-four years, will have its revival Wednesday night. Giovanni Martinelli will sing the leading role, Lawrence Tibbett will sing Iago and Eide Norena will be the Desdemona.

ASCOT-Green Fields, Yiddish film. 8TH ST. PLAYHOUSE-It's Love I'm After; Tuesday and Wednesday, Lancer Spy. GRAMERCY PARK-Big City and Borneo; Wednesday and Thursday, Romeo and Juliet; starting Friday, High, Wide and Handsome. GRANADA-Dead End and Women Men Marry; Wednesday, Ah Wilderness and They Gave Him a Gun; Thursday through Christmas Day, Life Begins in College and The Perfect Specimen.

The marriage of Miss Alice Crosby Sinclair, daughter of Mrs. Donald Bunker Sinclair and the late Dr. Sinclair of Princeton, to Peter Aston Schwartz of Princeton, son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Schwartz of Wynnewood, Pa., took place this afternoon in the Princeton University Chapel.
Agreement by the United States Senate on a farm bill embracing compulsory control of corps strengthened prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.
THE defective Richad North, who does the ground and lofty sleuthing in this curious hodgepodge of murder and Oriental mysticism, reminds on at times of Philo Vance.

Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margarc' proved to be perfect hostesses at the first children's Christmas party given in Buckingham Palace since the beginning of the century. The occasion was the King's birthday. King George, Queen Elizabeth and Dowager Queen Mary were present.

Countess Edda Clano, Premier Benito Mussolini's daughter, today gave birth to her third son. His name is Marzio. The Premier received the news from the father, Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italy's Foreign Minister.

By voting to recommit the Wagesand-Hours Bill, the House of Representatives has definitely killed all chance of the enactment of this measure at the special session and made it probable, according to our Washington dispatches, that this particular plan will be shelved indefinitely.

Another of the many affairs given this week for Mrs. Walter Furman Schuyler and Mrs. George FinchHatton, who are visiting Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff, was the luncheon at which Mrs. James H. Kennedy was hostess today at Kenlewinai, followed by contract bridge.
The opening of the second annual invitation mixed doubles squash racquets tournament of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club on the club's courts today produced some exciting matches.

Obscured by the secrecy behind which the various exchange stabilization funds operate, there has been in progress for the last ten weeks a large European withdrawal of gold from this country. Precisely how large this movement has been cannot be determined.
Police Captain M. H. Pearce said today that the Southeastern Express Company had reported $5,000 mysteriously missing after an early morning hold-up of its agent.
Miss Sybil K. K. Newhall, daughter of J. George Newhall of Phoenixville, was married this afternoon to Charles L. P. Townsend of Altamont, N. Y., son of Mrs. Franklin Townsend of Albany.
Mrs. Henry M. Tompkins of Orange, N. J., formerly of Detroit, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Frances Tompkins, to William Brewster Atchison Jr. of East Orange, N. J.

Detectivee Jeremiah J. Murphy of 364 Ninety-third Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Naval Hospital Brooklyn, after a long illness at the, age of 49. Mr. Murphy, who joined the Police Department twenty-one years ago and was a detective since 1919, was born in Brooklyn. He recently was attached to the Greenwich Street squad.

The Japanese Army's high command has belatedly begun stern disciplinary measures intended speedily to end the chaos of looting, raping and killing that has made the Japanese entry into Nanking a national disgrace.

Peter R. Gatens of Garden City, L. I., counsel to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., died in the Norwegian Hospital, Brooklyn, yesterday at the age of 86. He joined the legal staff of R. G. Dun Co., the predecessor of Dun Bradstreet, in 1872 and had just rounded out sixty-five years of continuous services as counsel to the credit reporting company.

It is like pulling hippopotamus teeth for the Administration to get anything through Congress these days, and people who have been calling for opposition and examination as the guarantors of liberty should cheer up about that. Here is the extra session nearing its end with a very small legislative crop and prospect from the viewpoint of the Administration.

BOY SCOUTS throughout the country will soon be released from school by the Christmas holidays, and then will begin in earnest the fun and adventure of Winter camping. Hiking, playing, cooking and living out-of-doors in the season of snow and cold make deep demands on the Scouts' skill in campcraft.
THE residue of the library of the late Sir James M. Barrie will be offered at the beginning of the threeday sale which starts tomorrow at Sotheby's in London. What

Japanese are busy consolidating their occupation of Nanking. General Iwane Matsui, the commander of Japanese troops in the Yangtze valley, is expected to establish his headquarters in the conquered capital.

The University of Pennsylvania seems on the verge of putting into effect a program to see that "as far as possible no graduate will be handicapped in his life work by lack of a command of written and spoken English."

Many people have come to believe that in the polar region one has six months day and six months night. This is only partly correct. The closer one goes toward the Pole, the closer the long days and nights become nearly equal. However, at the Poles the days and nights are never equal.
The Yuletide spirit has moved many an inventor to contribute some bit of his ingenuity toward making each Christmas merrier. a search of the patents in Uncle Sam's Patent Office reveals.

The phenomenal development of skiing during the past few years in the United States has been attributed to many factors. The third Olympic Winter games at Lake Placid in 1932, which brought together the greatest array of amateur skiers in the world, was the beginning.

Henry Forbes McCreery, formerly with the New York firm of Hard Rand, coffee importers, 107 Wall Street. died in his home here last night at the age of 84. Mr. McCreery, uncle of Dr John A. McCreery, Greenwich, physician and surgeon, was born in New York.
Among the 753 patents granted this week by the United States Patent Office the following attracted attention for the unusual ingenuity exhibited in the inventions which they protect:
Buzz Boll led the Toronto Maple Leafs back into first place in the International group of the National Hockey League tonight by scoring two goals as the Leafs topped the New York Americans, 3-2.
Zevson, 5-year-old horse owned by Mrs. E. H. Bartlett, returned to his good form of last Winter when he won the Thibodeaux Handicap, feature of the Fair Grounds program today.
Announcement was made yesterday that nine New York Stock Exnchange firms will dissolve on Dec. 31. All save one, Ulman Brothers, are being reorganized or merged, with new alignments of partners.

The nine-story office building at 1,141-43 Broadway, northwest corner of Twenty-sixth Street, fronting 50.2 feet on Broadway by 96.11 feet on Twenty-sixth Street, will be sold under foreclosure on Wednesday by Edwin J. McDonald in the Vesev

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in the smallest volume for many weeks. The majority of calls were for small parts of numerous State, municipal, foreign and real estate issues, called to satisfy sinking fund requirements in most instances.

French Foreign Minister Delbos, who, for the past fortnight, has been visiting Central European capitals in an effort to reinvigorate the post-war system of French alliances, last week completed his tour by stops in Belgrade and Prague. Previously, in Warsaw and Bucharest, he had had apparently successful conversations with the heads of the ,Polish and Rumanian Governments. Alliances with those countries seemed almost as strong as ever.

Fears that the New York Stock Exchange, if it raises its commission rates by an average of 11 per cent, will lose business to other Exchanges in this country and Canada were only slightly allayed last week by the disclosure that William O. Douglas,

A total of 2,358,473 houses have been constructed in England and Wales from 1919 to August, 1937, according to the National Housing and Town Planning Council of London, says a report to the Department of Commerce from London.

If there is to be any Federal wage and hour legislation in the future a reasonable bill must be framed that will pass the scrutiny of the courts and it must create a semi-judicial board independent of any governmental department, said Representative Robert Ramspeck of Georgia in an address today before the National Lawyers Guild.

Mrs. Henrietta Meyer, this township's oldest resident, died yesterday at the Maplewood home of her daughter, Mrs. Albert Glasser, at the age of 93. Mrs. Meyer had left written instructions that she be buried in a gown which she made thirty years ago and that the funeral service be conducted -by a minister with -whom she had made arrangements.

The Ice Follies, with a cast of fifty expert skaters who will perform on a rink of colored ice, will open tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden and will give nightly performances on Tuesday- Wednesday, Thursday and Friday, the closing date, end matinees Wednesday and Friday.

A Christmas tea on Tuesday afternoon at the Catholic Young Women's Club, 641 Lexington Avenue, will honor Mrs. Antonio C. Gonzalez, wife of the American Minister to Ecuador, who with her husband has been decorated by the Republic of Ecuador with the Golden Insignia of Merit,

Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Rich of this place announced at a tea at their home today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Miriam Rich, to Dr. Edwin A. Seifert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Selfert, also of Glen Ridge.

" All danger is past and we are now ready to go to work for the aggrandisement of Brazil," President Getulio Vargas told the army today in an address in which he emphatically declared that there was no room for terrorists in the country.

Washington first heard the Rebel yell in July of 1861. It was a fearful, echoing cry that rang across the hills from Manassas Junction, where Union troops had been put to rout in the first Battle of Bull Run.

Presenting a program of works by noted composers as well as the premiere of a song by a chorus member and director, the People's Chorus of New York comes to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening with its tenth annual Christmas Festival. Its sponsors include
THE humor of Eric Satie came, for the space of an evening, alive for a large audience which packed the Salle d'Iena to hear the program prepared by the "Rideau de Paris."

Miss Dorothy Lindenmeyr, daughter of Mrs. Ludwig Lindenmeyr of this place, formerly of New York, and the late Mr. Lindenmeyr, was married here tonight in St. John's Episcopal Church to James Butler Brown, son of Mrs. David R. Brown of Concord. N. H., and the late Dr. Brown.
Mme. Sun Yat-sen, widow of the first President of the Chinese Republic, declared there was no truth to reports, said to have emanated from Japanese sources, that she planned to go to Moscow soon.

Mr. and Mrs. William Kent Dupre entertained yesterday afternoon with a reception at their home, 180 East Seventy-ninth Street. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Garland Allen, Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cassard, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Proctor Cooper, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Henry Darlington, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Duncan, Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould, Dr. and Mrs. J. Winston Fowlkes, Mrs. Noyes Hamilton, Mrs. Sanderson Child, Chester Doubleday and William M. Chadbourne.

It is now certain that first impressions of the character of the attack on the Panay must be revised. It is no longer possible to give credence to the Japanese contention that the United States gunboat and the three American oil tankers near by were mistaken by the attacking airmen for Chinese troop ships.

Salaries of Mexican petroleum workers were ordered increased by about onethird today, thus creating a privileged class in the ranks of Mexican labor and setting a yardstick by which the Federal Government hopes to develop further its Nationalist capitalism campaign to create a larger middle class in Mexico.

There used to be a cruel Well saying to the effect that a Dressed diplomat is a man sent Diplomats abroad to lie for his country. But obviously there are other phases. A diplomat is often a man sent abroad to keep a stiff upper lip for his country. Things may be going very badly at home, with a foreign invader, let us say, trampling over a conquered population.

Christmas vacation will be a busy season for college students this year. On at least four campuses, all the way from Vassar to the University of New Mexico, some 3,200 young conferees will gather in intercollegiate groups during the post-Christmas week to argue issues of war and peace, and government aid for youth and schools.

Members of the Society of Georgia Women of New York will hold their Christmas supper dance on Dec. 28 at the Biltmore. In charge of the arrangements is Mrs. Gerard Immediator, whose aides are Mrs. James F. Sandefur, Mrs. John A. McManus, Mrs. Clyde Heath, Mrs. Howard Fernau and Mrs. G. B. Turpin.

AVIROM--GRILL-Mr. and Mrs. Louns Grill announce the wedding of their daughter, Goldie, to Mr. Jack R. Avirom, to take place at the Hotel Astor, Sunday afternoon, Dec. 19. BORBUS--RAPP-Dr. and Mrs. Rudolf Rapp announce the marriage of their daughter, Claire Vivienne, to Harold Borrus, son of. Mrs. Sarah Borrus, taking place Sunday, Dec. 19.
William John De Correvont, at the age of 19, with the football world at his feet, is in such a dizzy whirl of attention that he doesn't know what to do about it-but his widowed mother does.

Tn three distinct fields of botany women scientists are making current history. As a botanical taxonomist one has resumed her work at the Gray Herbarium at Harvard, another has started a long trek through the Southwest in search of unusual specimens and, less dramatically, a third is starting her twelfth year of research which may be invaluable to the human race.

The gaps In people's Christmas lists just-have to be filled in the next few days, for the big day comes on Saturday, and all lastminute shoppers will have to scamper. This column is devoted' to gapfillers of all sorts and descriptions.
Ten of the city's leading high school basketball teams were the principals yesterday in a program of five games which launched the regular matinee scholastic court season at Madison Square Garden.

Colonel Theodore Roosevelt was intimately in touch with the colonial problems of the United States and may be regarded as a leading authority upon them. The former Dorothy Dunbar, one-time movie star, brought suit in District Court today to establish her right to about $270,000 in trusts which she said were due to her from the estate of one of her husbands, Thomas Bucklin Wells 2d of Minneapolis.

Fire in a six-story loft building at 191-98 Christie Street slowed traffic going to and from the Manhattan Bridge at 9 o'clock last night. Two alarms were sounded. The blaze, the Fire Department reported, started in the plant of R. Saffran Co., pajama manufacturers, who occupy quarters on the top floor of the building.

A Chinese author, an educator, a lawyer and a professor of history will conduct a group of four short lecture courses at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, beginning next month, according to an announcement yesterday.

Boon after ethylene gas was introduced to ripen green fruit in storage the plant physiologists began to make discoveries. Among other things they discovered that fruit which ripens early has a strange maturing effect on near-by fruit that ripens late.
Miss Jane Collins Rubicam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Rubicam of 770 Park Avenue, was introduced to society last night at a dance given by her parents in the roof garden of the Pierre.

The American Civil Liberties Union reported yesterday that it found no real issue of freedom of the press involved in the issuance by the National Labor Relations Board of subpoenas for Hartley W. Barclay, editor of the magazine Mill and Factory, and Harry T. O'Brien, editor of The St. Mary's Press of St. Mary's, Pa.

The Catholic Big Sisters of the Ladies of Charity of the Archdiocese of New York will be the beneficiary of a card party and tea to be held Jan. 11 at the home of Mrs. H. Lester Cuddihy, 24 East Seventythird Street.

ON Jan. 8. 1869. the Civil War had been over for nearly four years. It might reasonably be supposed that General Sheridan. assured of his place in history. was living in well-earned retirement. Actually. he was far from any of the comforts of civilization.

Striking pickets of Sachs Quality Furniture, Inc., which has three stores and a warehouse in Manhattan and the Bronx, paraded yesterday afternoon and last night in front of the store at 505 Eighth Avenue, at the northwest corner of Thirty-fifth Street. The pickets,

MRS. COLUM'S book comes at an opportune time. It sounds a salutary note in a day when crit-ical values are obscured. when books are spawned in bewildering profusion. when there is vitality in our writing, but a vitality that is for the most part undirected and aimless.
The Rev. Juan Gorozita, vicar of the Augustinian Order in Puerto Rico, was buried today. Born in Bilbao, Spain, sixty-nine years ago, Father Gorozita came to the island in 1896.

THERE may be a great deal of tinsel in the New York Christmas, as critical observers complain. The colored lights hereabout may be so profuse and dazzling that they make it hard at times to see the clear, white Christmas stars.

Miss Anne Lovice Whitall, who was introduced to society at the Bachelors Cotillion in Baltimore on Dec.-6, made her New York debut Yesterday at a tea dance given in the River Club by her mother, Mrs. Thomas Wster Whitall of Acorn Farm, Katonah, N. Y.

The Thursday Club will sponsor its annual Christmas dance on Wednesday at the Ardsley Country Club here for the benefit of St. Faith's House, Tarrytown. Members of the committee in charge include Mrs. T. Sloan Young. chairman; Mrs. Gordon L.

BETHLEHEM of Judaea will be named in song and story everywhere in Christendom at this Christmastide; the sound of the bells of the Church of the Nativity will be borne on the air all round the world, and the thoughts of millions will turn to the little town in whose fields the shepherds watched their flocks by night and heard the voices of angels.

THE recent report from Bermuda that vandals had mutilated the mysterious in scription at Spanish Rockthe colony's most ancient relic-focuses attention on the task laid out for the Historical Monuments Trust, which has been formed to preserve the ruins and buildings associated with the early history of the Bermudas.

Federal Judge Thomas W. Slick today sentenced James Dalhover, last of the Al Brady gang, to die April 8 in the electric chair at the Indiana Penitentiary for the slaying of State Policeman Paul V; Minneman on May 25 following a bank robbery.
An American viewpoint on the British industrial situation written by Mrs. Sarah Butler Lawrence will appear tomorrow In the January issue of Guide, published by the Women's National Republican Club,

The Indianapolis Star, in an early edition tonight, said Paul V. McNutt, former Indiana Governor, intends to retire in May as United States High Commissioner to the Philippines. "His friends are informed that it is his purpose to retire as High Commissioner and return to this country with his family late in May."

Wednesday STRAND--First Lady: Kay Francis, Anita Louise. Thursday CAPITOL-Navy Blue and Gold: Robert Young, James Stewart. CRITERION-Daughter of Shanghai: Anna May Wong. GLOBE-Thank You, Mr. Moto: Peter Lorre. RIALTO-Sh! The Octopus: Hugh Herbert.
Theodore S. Clark, vice president of Jay Thorpe, Inc., 24 West Fiftyseventh Street, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 53 years old.
IN a normal year-such a year as 1935, for example--8.000,000,000 tin containers are filled in this country with "scientifically processed" foods.

NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER, president of Columbia University, was revealed last week as the educator who is sponsoring the promotion of stamp collecting in America's higher institutions of learning through the establishment of "The Nicholas Murray Butler Permanent Intercollegiate Philatelic Trophy"--a silver cup which, standing twenty-eight inches high, will be placed in competition at an intercollegiate philatelic exhibition at Columbia University once each year.

Liberalization of the National Housing Act, intended to carry out the recommendations of President Roosevelt's message of Nov. 16 and spur a recovery of private construction, was voted by the House tonight, 324 to 23.

Herbert J. Bickford, engaged in law practice for many years in this city, died yesterday in Doctors Hospita, after a brief illness. His age was 70. Mr. Bickford was born in Lyndon, Vt on July 31, 1867, the son of George H. and Abby Giffin Bickford.
EX-EMPEROR WILLIAM II of Germany is tried before an international court of justice, composed of an American, an Englishman, a German, a Frenchman, and presided over by a Hollander.

Jean and Eric La Guardia, the Mayor's two children, were guests of former Governor Alfred E. Smith yesterday on a trip to the 102d floor observation tower atop the Empire State -Building. The Mayor, who also made the trip,

Newspaper circulation in the United States and Canada in 1937 surpassed all previous records, it is pointed out by the Royal Bank of Canada in its December bulletin, issued yesterday from its Montreal ofifce.

Attorneys for the National Labor Relations Board said today that they would subpoena all telegrams and other correspondence of the. Ford Motor Company relating to labor questions at its St. Louis assembly plant.

The depression and recovery through which the country has passed since 1929 had a close counter-part in the 1870s, as the above chart indicates. The two setbacks have been designated as "secondary post-war depressions."

America's three most important point-scoring trophies for outboard drivers will be renewed for 1938. The three donors last week assured the fraternity of daredevil pilots that they are ordering new replicas from the jewelers.

AOKERMAN-On Friday, Dec. 17. 1937. Gertrude Anna, sister of the late Frederick Lueneberg. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend funeral services Sunday at 8 P. M. at her late residence, 318 New York Ave.. Jersey City.. Funeral Monday at 2 P. M.

WHILE fresh amendments every day are coming before the standing committee investigating the proposed British Films Bill before it goes up for its third reading in the House of Commons, film production in this country, both by British and American companies, is slowing down to a standstill.

All of the boxes and many seats have been subscribed for the preview performance of "Between the Devil," the new musical comedy with Evelyn Laye, Jack Buchanan and Adele Dixon in the leading roles, on Tuesday night at the Imperial Theatre,

Miss Marion R. McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. McCarthy of Westfield, was married to George Witham, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Witham of Cranford, at the McCarthy home here today, the sixtieth wedding anniversary of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Vurgason of Brooklyn.
Archaeology may be on the verge of discovering the origin of the prehistoric people who built the great mounds of Ohio and Illinois.
Senator Pope of Idaho appealed today to Attorney General Cummings to give his "earliest consideration" to reports that "monopolistic practices" were skyrocketing the price of newsprint paper.

RADIO'S program statisticians, who-keep the records of time, watts and words, in totaling up their tabulations for 1937 find that President Roosevelt has been on the air twenty times during the yar--equaling his 1935 "off-political" year record.
THE heavily padded doors of the big studio at Radio City will be guarded tomorrow to observe Arturo Toscanini's strict rule that visitors are not to watch him rehearse an orchestra. He is expected

The fifteenth season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's Young People's Concerts opened yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall, John Barbirolli conducting. Ernest Schelling having been forced to forego the direction of the series, the remaining five events will be entrusted to Rudolph Ganz.

Mr. and Mrs. Tracy S. Voorhees gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 184 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, for their debutante daughter, Miss Mary Van Voorhees, who will be introduced to society tomorrow night at a dinner dance in the Neptune Room of the Pierre in Manhattan.

Debits to' individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Dec. 15, aggregated $9,679,000,000, or 16 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 18 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

A fast Dartmouth quintet subdued Canisius College, 47-28, in the second game of a double-header before 3,500 fans on the State Armory court tonight. Carnegie Tech downed Niagara, 33-29, in the opening encounter.
College of New Rochelle seniors singled out twenty of their classmates as "favorites" this week prior to the closing of the college for Christmas vacation, it was disclosed here today.

For the lover of plants who is looking for something a bit out of the ordinary either to give to a friend at Christmas or to lse as a decoration for the holidays at home, an arrangement of small living plants may be just the thing sought. And it has the double advantage of representing an expression 'of personality and of being': extremely easy on the pocketbook.

In memory of the contributions he made to civic and cultural development, a bronze plate with the name of Charles Healey Ditson, the late music publisher, has been attached to one of the orchestra chairs in the auditorium of Town Hall, home of the League for Political Education, it was announced yesterday.

Among the cases accepted for assistance by the Neediest Cases Fund this year, although it was not one of those published, was that involving Peter H., a once-prosperous merchant of 60, now so painfully crippled by arthritis that he is almost helpless.
Two Eskimo football teams, preparing for the New Year's Day Ice Bowl game, were forced to practice indoors today because their playing field had floated away.

The cost of daily food rations on a diet devised for "the adequate maintenance and protection of health" is estimated at $197.38 annually for a woman living at home in a report issued yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

Brokers in the metropolitan section of New Jersey report a well sustained demand for residential properties in many of the suburban home centers and, with the expectation of a business recovery early in the new year, builders in many localities are preparing an active home construction campaign during 1938.

A fourteen-story clubhouse and apartment building to house the Amherst Club of New York will be erected at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street, it was learned yesterday when plans were filed at the Building Department.

A new red brick collegiate gothic structure, costing $1,550,000, has just been added to the Chicago campus of the University of Illinois, to house its College of Dentistry and provide seven floors of additional medical laboratories.
CHRISTMAS chimes of the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem will be heard on short-waves throughout the world on Dec. 26.

Dr. Leo M. Davidoff of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn has leased a ten-room suite in the Lincoln Plaza Apartments recently completed at 235 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, through the Charles Partridge Company agents.

A plan designed to promote better understanding between the church and organized labor was set in motion today to have a labor representative in the social service department of the Episcopal Diocese of Rochester.

Artur Rodzinski gave his third concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Radio City, and Arturo Toscanini, who gives the first of his ten programs with the same organization next Saturday night, sat in the audience.

Real estate values, in the opinion of Roland F. Elliman, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., are not likely to be seriously affected during the present financial recession, provided business activity does not sink to lower levels.

Santa Claus was cautioned by the American Red Cross today to keep candle flames, cigarettes and other inflammables away from his whiskers. In a Christmas safety statement, the Red Cross warned householders that they "cannot light their plum pudding and have it, too, if the table is cluttered with inflammable favors and decorations."

The Rev. Dr. John R. Crosser, former pastor of American churches in Berlin and Paris, died of a heart attack at the home of friends here today. His age was 81. Born in Lisbon, Ohio, Feb. 18, 1856, Dr. Crosser was graduated from Washington and Jefferson College in 1882, from the Western Theological Seminary in 1884 and was ordained a Presbyterian clergyman in 1886.

LONG Winter evenings enable the camera enthusiast to round out his print collection (and prove his versatility into the bargain with family portraits, fireside studies, still-lifes, table-top tableaux and other pictures made indoors). Such subjects, usually neglected during warm-weather days, loom large on every ambitious amateur's list of Winter. "musts." A family group

Six young men in full evening dress, five of them in opera hats, picketed the Princeton University Triangle Club show, "Fol de Rol," at the Hudson Theatre, West Fortyfourth Street, at curtain time last night in furtherance of a campus quarrel between the dramatic club and The Tiger, Princeton's humorous magazine.
Here is the status of President Roosevelt's legislative program at the end of the fifth week of the special session: ...

A touchdown by their All-Star opponents six minutes after the game started spurred the Chicago Bears to speedy vengeance in a benefit game today, which the Western champions of the National Football League won, 28-13.

While the closing months of the present year showed a slighter recession in sales and building work in the suburban localities of Queens and other sections of Long Island, the majority of brokers report that 1937 has been one of the most satisfactory In realty activity for many seasons. The general feeling also

SELDOM is the name of any man of letters mentioned in the "Court Circular"--the daily official record of the comings and goings at Buckingham Palace. Cabinet Ministers. Ambassadors. Colonial Governors and other persons of certified distinction are continually passing through the gates.
The Junior Upton Players have completed arrangements for their itinerant theatre to visit hospitals and institutions of this city beginning Tuesday.

IF the records are right in saying that Jerome Kern, Otto Harbach and Oscar Hammerstein 2d last worked together on "Sunny" of festive memory (1925), then one of those sentimental reunions is coming up. It would be the musical over which Max Gordon's banner is even now fluttering tentatively-a song and dance show set against the background of West Point during and after the Civil War.
