SPEAKING for the Chinese, Mr. Crow emphatically warns of the yellow peril. He accepts as a serious threat Japan's desire to rule the world, emphasizing that should Japan be allowed to take over China a new Oriental power greater than any combination of Western powers will thus be created.

Quiet conditions prevailed today in the foreign exchange market here. The franc further improved slightly to 147 7-64 to the pound and improvement was shared by the one-month and threemonth forward rates.

As Christmastlde approaches interest turns to evergreens or brilliantly berried plants that may brighten home interiors for the festal days. Walks through woods or old byways reveal material that would contribute gaily to the holiday decor.

After a letdown earlier in the month, inquiries on credit ratings increased last week, the Credit Clearing House reported yesterday. The volume is now running about 8 per cent ahead of a year ago, it was said.

Emperor Hirohito was informed directly and in detail yesterday by the Premier, Prince Fumimaro Konoye, of the situation growing out of the sinking of the United States gunboat Panay in the Yangtze River last Sunday.

The old concept of the college professor as seated behind his desk in a classroom on the campus is 'becoming outmoded at New York University this Winter. By car, train and airplane, a field staff of 150 university instructors and special lecturers will travel more than 250,000 miles this year to and from classes in 86 towns and cities in the Eastern States and the District of Columbia, as part of the university's extension service.

Although there had been a suspicion along those lines for some time, confirmation finally has been given to the general belief that Joe Medwick, clouting left fielder of the St. Louis Cardinals, was by far the outstanding batsman of the National League for 1937.

An issue of 1,000,000 postage stamps commemorating the 150th anniversary of the United States Constitution was recently circulated by the Brazilian- Department of Posts and Telegraphs, says a report to the Department of Commerce from Rio de Janeiro made public today.
AT Christmas time the drama returns to the amateurs from it came. All over the country, in churches and community meeting-places, amateurs herald the holiday season with unaffected plays.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York will award cash prizes tomorrow to 208 pupils in the city's public and parochial schools for essays on "What Are My Responsibilities as a Citizen in the Occupation Which I May Choose?" About 300,000 boys and girls entered the contest, held annually in conjunction with the Board of Education and Catholic School Board.

Their lives often jeopardized by the shelling and bombing and by unruly soldiers, a small group of foreigners who stayed throughout the Japanese siege of Nanking within the walls of the city occupied unique roles of great humanitarian and political importance.

The "crash" of falling trees and the "shrill whine" of saws are still only a faint treble in the Columbia River basin. The status quo prevails in the grim labor war which has closed down logging camps and sawmills since August, with an estimated loss to the region of $9,000,000.
The Plerrettes of Newark and vicinity will hold their annual Christmas dance Wednesday in the Essex House here. Mrs. William Phillips is chairman and Miss N. Gaddis Haller, treasurer.
Capitalizing on frequent trips to the foul line, the Crescent A. C. gained a 32-to-26 verdict over the Wagner College five last night at Grymes Hill, S. I.

Members of the National Arts Club are now engrossed in the plans for their New Year's Eve party, which is described on posters recentlv sent out as "A Gala Evening of Artists and Models and Tableaur Vivant."

PROFESSOR SHOTWELL was a member of "The Inquiry," the unique body of experts, chiefly university professors, which Colonel House assembled in the Fall of 1917, under the direction of President Mezes of the College of the City of New York.

Honorary awards to students who had shown unusual athletic ability were made at New Jersey College for Women here this week, in the presence of 150 undergraduates who had taken part in the eight sports which made up the extra-curricular Fall program.

Under the Administration's policy of retrenchment, new authorizations by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, other than commitments to buy securities from the Public Works Administration for resale, fell to $6,601,471 in October, the RFC reported today to Congress.

W. R. Grace Co., has informed the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce that it cannot accede to the Chamber's request to keep the company's "luxury liners" operating between San Francisco aAd New York, pending action by Congress on the McAdoo bill..

The Douglass Junior High School of Manhattan captured the P. S. A. L. basketball crown yesterday when it defeated Junior High School 40 by the score of 40 to 28 on the P. S. 99 court in Manhattan. This marked the second title won by the school in the past three years.

Vladimir Matchek, Yugoslav Croatian leader and spokesman for 5,000,000 of the 15,000,000 population of the country, said that Yugoslavia will break up like the Austro-Hungarian Empire in 1918 if the present Premier, Milan Stoyadinoyitch, remains in power much longer.
The police of the Harbor Squad began a search of the Hudson River near 136th Street last night after an automobile had been found parked near the water with a note attached to the steering wheel.

" THE BUMBLE BEE PRINCE, " a shortened version in English of Rimsky-Korsakoff's opera "Tsar Saltan," will receive its local premiere at two children's matinees to be given Dec. 27 at the St. James Theatre.

Elimination of Jews from Germany is the inevitable result of the present policy of the Nazi regime, according to a pamphlet made public yesterday by the economic bureau of the American Jewish Congress.
NOTHING is more admirably indicative of the broadening of the Metropolitan Opera Association's repertory than the revival of Verdi's "Otello" next Wednesday evening.

A LOOFis likely to become italicized among those words That most often recur- in our thought as we go about looking at the art of Charles Demuth, assembled by way of memorial tribute at the Whitney Museum.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just read an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES by Joseph Alsop and Robert Kentner in which they quote Joseph P. Kennedy's views with regard to the present Roosevelt Administration depression.

MANHATTAN BONITO. ALAN H. (Dec. 12). Estate, less than $10,000. To Madeline R. Bonito, widow. executrix, and Alan H. Bonito Jr., son. one-half residue each. Walter J. Wells, Ridgewood. N. J., executor. DAVIDSON, ANNIE (Dec. 14). Estate, approximately $10,000. To Lorin Davidson, son. executor, Alice D. Levy, daughter, executrix. one-half residue each.

TRAINS are discharging their cargoes of girls homewardbound for their Christmas holidays. What each desires as much as a Christmas gift is a new frock that will make her shine at the parties she's been dreaming about during past months of drudgery.

PRIMITIVE is rather a suspect term in contemporary art. The modern artist who claims the ability to shed his sophistication at a drop of the hat so that he can view the world with innocence of eye and ingenuousness of mind has seldom made out a convincing case for himself.
The struggle for power between Egypt's young King Farouk and his Premier, Mustapha Nahas Pasha, today threatened to bring dismissal of the Nahas government.
Charles E. Keegan, one of five City Councilmen elected in the Bronx, was sworn in yesterday afternoon by Judge James M. Barrett in chambers of the Bronx County Building.

REFLECTING a decline in orders from the field, automobile production this week was held down to $2,500 units, against $7,600 in the previous week and 110,000 in the corresponding week a year ago. Most plants, including Chrysler, De Soto, Plymouth, Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Hudson, Nash, Studebaker, Cadillac and Chevrolet, operated on a three-day basis.

A new course, cutting sharply across departmental lines, will be given by the Department of Philosophy and Psychology at Mount Holyoke College next semester to present upper classmen with a conception of the philosophy of the physical sciences.
AGAIN it is the Sunday before Christmas, when these pages look into the side streets off Broadway (and a little bit into the files) to report what they find for the holiday trade.

Ike U..Sears, former business manager of The Daily Times of Davenport and The Wisconsin State Journal in Madison, Wis., died last night in Miami, Fla., after a long illness. His age was 67. Born in Albion, N. Y., Mr. Sears received his early newspaper experience in Chicago, where he was employed by the old Record-Herald and The Daily News in circulation work.

Hershey and the Bronx Tigers skated to an overtime 3-3 tie tonight in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League contest. Hershey led, 3 to 2, early in the last period, but a forty-foot drive by Sid Fenn that lodged in the upper left corner of the net tied the score.

" AMERRY CHRISTMAS!" The cheery greetig begins to be heard in streets and shops and happy homes throughout the city; and the good-will of the season is not content to stop with the friendly wish. To give, to share the blessings of life with others, is the essence of the Christmas spirit.

A newly formed corporation association headed by J. B. Woodside, General Motors Corporation sales representative in Washington, will buy 120,00 acres in Pearl River County, Miss., for tung oil productinn. Mr Woondside said today.
Only six women emerged last week as duly elected delegates to the State Constitutional Convention when the official count was made public by the State Board of Canvassers at Albany.
Aside from the cleavages between labor's own friends, the debate last week in the House revealed a number of sectional differences over enactment of a minimum wage-maximum hours law.
REVIEWING "a year's great progress" in television, The Observer of London reports "there are nearly 9,000 television receivers in Greater London and the rate of increase is rapidly accelerating."

THE hint, thrown out some months ago by the National Broadcasting Company, that Toscanini would like to give two public concerts in the city with the NBC Orchestra has kept the Carnegie Hall box-office busy.
The Bureau of Navigatibn released the following orders today, dated Dec. 16: CAPTAIN Duff, E. A., Chaplain Corps, the California, to continue treatment Naval Hospital, San Diego, Calif.

Price ranges narrower than those in the past so far as the gap between top and bottom price line is concerned, but which would include as many or even more individual price points than before, is being recommended to the coat and suit inndustry by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

IN this day and age when so. many things seem to move by precedent it is rather refreshing to see something come along that has never happened before: Recently, for instance, we have been hearing mutterings of a most unusual character creeping here and there into the public prints.

As the tour of friendly capitals in Eastern and Southeastern Europe by the French Foreign Minister, Yvon Delbos, draws to a close, its results might normally be expected to become apparent. Actually, little that is concrete and practical can be discerned.

THEN years and a month after the completed Holland Tunnel was hailed as an unprecedented engineering achievement Its counterpart is ready for dedication. The Lincoln Tunnel's mouth tube, connecting West Thirtyninth Street, Manhattan, with Weehawken, N. J., will be thrown open to motor traffic at 4 A. M. on Wednesday. It will be used for twoway traffic until its twin north tube is completed early in 1941.'

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday he had received three letters from civic organizations last week, praising the new non-parking traffic regulations that will go into effect Jan. 3. Parking is prohibited on certain designated east-west streets in Manhattan and within 100 feet of intersections.

Miss Eleanor Keller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. O. E. M. Keller of Toledo, will be married to Eugene MacFarlane Hinkle of New York in Maumee, Ohio, on Monday. The couple first met in Buenos Aireg, where Mr. Hinkle served as second secretary of the embassy and Miss Keller as private secretary to the military attach.

John P. Lamerdin, a New York lawyer, of 62 Rock Rose Place, Forest Hills, Queens, died here last night in the Norwalk Hospital at the age of 63. He came to Connecticut recently to look at some real estate in Westport.
Statistical reports on expenditure for building construction in this country during the month of Nomember reveal an upturn in the volume of public projects and a decline in private work.

A great performance of "Die Walkuere" was given yesterday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera Association-one that held the immense audience spellbound, and communicated full measure of the wonder of Wagner's music.

Steel labor, assembled here this week in the first convention of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, faced staggering problems arising from the economic recession and from neverending technological advancement.

John P. Lamerdin, a New York lawyer, of 62 Rock Rose Place, Forest Hills, Queens, died here last night in the Norwalk Hospital at the age of 63. He came to Connecticut recently to look at some real estate in Westport.
Statistical reports on expenditure for building construction in this country during the month of Nomember reveal an upturn in the volume of public projects and a decline in private work.

A great performance of "Die Walkuere" was given yesterday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera Association-one that held the immense audience spellbound, and communicated full measure of the wonder of Wagner's music.

Steel labor, assembled here this week in the first convention of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, faced staggering problems arising from the economic recession and from neverending technological advancement.

Any reductions in freight rates on anthracite coal shipped from Pennsylvania mining regions to the city would result in proportionate decreases to consumers here, John Meyer, treasurer of the Weber, Bunke Lange Coal Company, testified yesterday at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Merchants' Association. of New York, which was organized in 1897 and has been host on many occasions, will be "guest of honor" in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Tuesday evening at a dinner arranged by leaders to mark the association's fortieth anniversary.

A large group of patronesses has been enlisted for the Yuletide ball which takes place on Tuesday at the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, and will aid the Free Kindergarten Society. Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard Jr. is chairman of the committee in charge of arrangements.

Russian scientists disclosed today that a two-headed baby girl, also described as twins with a single body, had been under observation at the allunion institute of experimental medicine since birth six weeks ago.

The Panay bombing was the camera man's paradise. The light was excellent; the attacks continued long enough for movie men to get set-ups, and the ship even sank slowly enough for them to save their films and in some cases their cameras.

Tom Pendergast, the Kansas City Democratic leader, has received reports from political associates in Washington that Vice President Garner is coming forward as the directing force of the party's conservative faction, which will attempt to control the nomination for President in 1940.
To 19-year-old Jack Bromwich, rising Australian star, fell today the honor of handing Don Budge the first singles defeat of his tennis tour of the Antipodes.

Ernest Johnson, 46-year-old veteran of four major World War battles, died to send help to his starving wife and four children. Johnson, emaciated, hiked forty miles from his undeveloped ranch in the rugged hills around Lake Wenatchee to appeal for aid.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Austin Daly of 780 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Montgomery Daly to Irving Phillips Gould, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rutledge Gould of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y.

Instruction in social usages, ranging from the proper method of making introductions to selecting the right fork for the salad, is taking its place alongside classes in arts and sciences in American colleges and universities this Fall.

John McGovern, Labor member of Parliament, announced today that he would ask Sir Samuel Hoare, the Home Secretary, in the House of Commons Thursday concerning the circumstances under which Prince Frederick of Prussia, 26-year-old grandson of the former Kaiser, had been permitted to take up residence in England.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Dec. 17, unless specified: At Norfolk Yard, Dec. 18: Acushnet, Leary, Tsingtao to Yangtze Entrance, Bulmer, Edsall. At Mare Island Yard: Henley, Pompano.

At the State Capitol in Albany there arrived last week three volumes weighing twenty-one pounds and containing 3,350 pages. They contained New York City's new administrative code--the reclassification and codification of the city's present laws, some of which go back to colonial times.

Federal Judge W. Calvin Chesnut announced late today at the conclusion of arguments for a new trial of fourteen Algic seamen, convicted of revolt in a sit-down strike in Montevideo, that he would give his decision Monday.

The ReV. Richard F. Kelly, rector of the Catholic Church of the Epiphany and spiritual director of the Holy Name Union of Philadelphia, died of heart disease yesterday in St. Agnes Hospital after an illness of three weeks. He was 56 years old.
" Interest in foreign news has greatly increased," says Professor Harry B. Center, head of the journalism department at Boston University's College of Business Administration.

MANILA, P. I.-Lessons learned from the proximity of the SinoJapanese conflict are having their effect on Filipino thinking with regard to independence, either in 1938 or 1939, as President Quezon has proposed, or in 1946 as provided in the Independence Law enacted by Congress.

Al Davis, promising young Brownsville fighter, knocked out Johnny (Skippy) Allen, South Brooklyn veteran, in the opening round of a featured six-round bout at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 4,000 saw the 18-year-old Davis floor his opponent with a left hook to the chin in 2 minutes and 16 seconds. Davis weighed 130 3/4 and Allen 126.

The lecture committee of the Fordham University Council of Debate has arranged forty-nine lectures up to Dec. 31, and expects to eclipse its record of eighty-two lectures made during the 1936-37 season of eight months.

Despite the efforts of drug wholesalers to achieve price stability in their field, a few manufacturers are till convinced that fair trade contracts issued to wholesalers, fixing discounts, are not legal, it was reported here yesterday.
" AAMERICANS," as Mr. Carmer points out in his preface, "have been so busy doing big jobs that they have never taken time off to let their minds play with the tiny folk who have magic power.

18.-In a stake intended to determine the championship of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club, Jersey Pat, a white and liver pointer, owned and handled by S. F. Howell of Troy Hills, N. J., was declared the high dog today.

"' The Christmas Story in Art" is the title of a carefully selected special exhibition the Metropolitan Museum is opening today for the holiday period. It has been arranged and mounted in Gallely E-15.

Buoyancy in United States Government obligations again featured otherwise dull trading in bonds yesterdcay on the New York Stock Exchange. Except for the continued advance- in, the Treasury issues, which put prices in that list at highest ..levels in several months, trading took on a pre-holiday atmosphere as quotations fluctuated irregularly within narrow limits.

THE Royal Academy of Music announces that royal approval has been conferred upon the foundation of a music scholarship commemorating Coronation year. Known as the "King George VI Coronation Scholarship," it will provide free musical education in the full Academy curriculum for two or there years.
Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey urged military and naval officials today to take precautions against "suspicious attacks on the part of Japan" in the Panama Canal Zone.

Manual Training High School captured the city P. S. A. L. soccer championship by downing Evander Childs High of the Bronx, 1 to 0, in a replay of the final-round contest at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday morning.

Treasury and tax officials both here and in Washington seemed in agreement yesterday that the action of Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow in renouncing her American citizenship Wednesday would have little effect on her immediate tax problem, although it would result, theoretically at least, in large savings in estate taxes upon her death.

The stock market opened firm yesterday and picked up moderate strength as the short session progressed. Closing prices approximated the best levels of the day, with the leaders up from fractions to 2 points.

Mr. and Mrs. Crawford Hill will give a dinner dance on Christmas night at their home, 10 Gracie Square. Mrs. Clive Spencer Huffman and Mrs. James B. Duke leave today to pass the holidays with Mrs. Duke's son, Walker Inman, at his plantation near Georgetown, S. C.

L. D. Garrett, president of the National Property Appraisal Service of this city, reports that an analysis of appraisals made by his organization for owners protesting the assessed values on their properties for 1938 taxes, shows a relationship of appraised value to the assessed valuation of 68.3 per cent.

Hitlerism by inches, as it might well be called, continues to make secret but steady progress in Austria. Although the Nazi party's greeting, emblems and activity are as strictly forbidden - nominally - as ever,

Campus beauties, featured annually in The Ariel, junior class yearbook at the University of Vermont, are again being sought. Twelve candidates have been nominated and next week the number, by vote of the student body, will be reduced to seven.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 17: Thomas, Col R. S., Engrs., Hawaii, detailed as a member of the General Staff Corps at Washington, D. C. Rogers. Major N. N., Cav., Presidio of Monterery. Calif., to retirement.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Holiday visitors to this resort will be provided with a Christmas setting similar to that they would have in their own home. Most of the larger hotels will have each a visit from Santa Claus, candy and toys for the children's parties, a huge Christmas tree, stockings at the fireplace, seasonable music, a punch bowl, and turkey at dinner for each individual family or group.
Dr. and Mrs. Armistead Crump gave the first of a series of dinners planned for their debutante daughter, Miss Jean Brevard Crump, last night at their home, 213 East Forty-eighth Street.
A government communique said today that the last defenses of Teruel, strategic Insurgent city in Eastern Spain, had fallen before the government's surprise offensive.
The University of Oregon athletic board has accepted the resignation of Prince G. Callison as head football coach, ending his six years in that position, it was announced today.

To the Drama Editor: "Having Wonderful Time," which I attended belatedly last night, seems to me an extremely amusing comedy, but leaves me wondering whether its ethical suggestion is less surprising to-the general public than to this survival of a less rusty age.

A House committee heard the Administration's Regional Planning Bill denounced today on the ground that it would involve expenditure of billions of dollars for government-ieveloped power at a time when the nation is "staggering under an unprecedented public debt."

One man was instantly killed and another slightly injured yesterday afternoon when an eight-ton electrotype press being lowered down an elevator shaft by rope at 216 East Forty-fifth Street, snapped its moorings and plunged nine stories to the sub-basement.

A proposal for identical legal and civic rights for men and women, the exclusive theme of discussion last week in Washington at the annual convention of the National Woman's party, its official sponsor, has reappeared In every session of Congress during the last thirteen years, as it will again next month when the regular session convenes.

CURRENT GAI HUDSON WALKER has assembled a large number of the strikingly beautiful and rhythmic drawings of Thomas Handforth-odd neighbors for the paintings by Alfred Maurer which continue on exhibition in another room. Handforth's subjects are

The Right Rev. John Insley Blair Larned, Suffragan Bishop of Long Island, and Mrs. Larned have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emma Elizabeth Larned, to John Stowell Davidson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Robert Davidson of Dongan Hills, S. I.
A dinner dance at the Greenwich Country Club this evening attracted 250 members and guests, all of whom were in Tyrolean costumes.

Free the Philippines from United States protection today and Japan will grab them tomorrow, Dr. B. M. Gancy, director of the Filipino League for Social Justice and political foe of President Manuel Quezon, who is advocating immediate independence for the islands, warned here yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Murray of Brooklyn gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza, Manhattan, for their daughter, Miss Marie Brady Murray, who made her debut in September at the Southampton home of her parents.
A survey of business conditions in most of the leading commercial nations reveals that only in the United States has there been a severe decline in business activity in recent months.

With the election of four new clubs at the quarterly meeting of the delegates to the American Kennel Club the total membership of the governing body of the sport in the United States reached 211, the highest figure in the history of the organization.

In an exciting finish, the New York A. C. quintet defeated the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, last night in an Eastern Athletic Club Basketball League game, 41-37, at the Columbus court in Brooklyn and halted the Caseys' winning streak at five.

The defending New York team, winner of the trophy for the past five years, was eliminated from the Payne Whitney Memorial Tournament today as Philadelphia and Boston qualified for the final round of the intercity court tennis doubles matches.

Members of various women's trade union organizations approved resolutions endorsing "equal rights" for women in industry through remedial legislation, at a conference held yesterday under the auspices of two locals of the American Federation of Teachers to discuss the "Women's Charter."

Drawings for the limestone doorway and the wood paneling for the Rumanian room, one of the nineteen nationality seminars for the University of Pittsburgh's Cathedral of Learning, have been received from Bucharest.

For the first time in twenty-three years prisoners of Sing Sing today faced the prospect of a giftless Christmas. There is the largest Christmas season population in the prison's history-2,718 prisoners-and there are not enough funds in the Mutual Welfare League treasury to pay for gifts.
The thirty-six defendants in the bomb conspiracy case arising out of the Illinois mine union warfare from 1932 to 1935 were found guilty today by a jury in the Federal District Court here.

Although overshadowed by the mighty Yankees when it came to winning a pennant and a world series, the Detroit Tigers carried off the lion's share of the fielding honors, as well as the team and individual batting crowns, accord ing to the official averages announced yesterday.

Tennessee Valley Authority dams held 21,000 cubic feet per second flow out of the lower Mississippi River during its critical stage in the 1937 flood, Professor Sherman M. Woodward, chief water control planning engineer for the TVA, testified in Federal court here today.

THERE are whispers going around to the effect that Christmas, at least for the adults, is not what it once was. Nowadays, they say, there is never so much snow on the ground as there used to be and never so much crimson in the sunset and never so many berries on the holly-excepting, of course, the synthetic Christmases of the big hotels and restaurants, where everything is made to order by experts.

A delegation of Teachers Union members, headed by Dr. Bella V. Dodd, legislative representative, and Charles J. Hendley, president, presented the union's educational program for 1938 to Governor Lehman at his home, 820 Park Avenue, yesterday morning.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:
Meat appears to derive its flavor from salts, natural organic acids and from heating meat extratives in cooking, according tothe Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture.
WINTER storms proved on upsetting factor for retail trade in the week, and some substantial losses were suffered in sections afflicted by snow and sleet.

Members of the incoming Board of Estimate will see the Health Department's facilities tomorrow afternoon as guests of Health Commissioner John L. Rice and other department officials.

Miss Sarah Howard Hayward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Hayward of Chilton, Wayne, was married this afternoon to Arthur Foster Draper, son of Mrs. Lawrence Draper of San Francisco and the late Dr. Draper. Dr. Croswell Mc.

Postmaster General Farley set a twenty-five-foot Christmas tree aglow with rainbow colored bulbs yesterday morning in the lobby of the General Postoffice, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street. In a brief address to postal workers and hundreds of others attracted by the display and music, Mr. Farley remarked that postal receipts for the last fiscal year were $725,000,000 and predicted that the current year would show an increase of twenty-five to thirty-five millions.

THE new American Contract Bridge League and the Eastern championships tournament committee came to terms last week. Hereafter the committee will conduct its games under the league's rules, and winners will receive the league's master points.

PINEHURST, N. C.-Christmas is expected to be a gay period at this Midsouth resort. The festive week-end program will include a sports schedule consisting of golf, tennis, a fox hunt, an equestrian gymkhana and a turkey shoot at the Pinehurst Gun Club. Numerous social events have been planned by members of the cottage colony and hotel guests.

THE winter fashion are with us-in the shops, on the streets, in the restau rants and bars, at the theatre, in the ballroom. And they invite unusual interest, because it is evident that never before have the designers so ransacked the past for hints

WITH the present appearances of Uday Shan-Kar's Hindu Ballet promising to be the last hereabout for some time, the Victor album containing ten items from the repertoire, played by the musicians of the company, should be a welcome souvenir to many. For several

Vsevelod E. Meyerhold, head of the famous theater bearing his name and long revered by Leftist dramatic groups abroad as a prophet of the revolutionary theater, has received a terrific drubbing from Platon Kerzhentseff, chairman of the arts.committee of the Council of People's Commissars.

With Christmas trade approaching its peak period, retail employment in leading stores here rose to its highest point last week, with several leading establishments here having as many employes on their, payroll as last year and at least one hiring a larger number of salespeople.

is with a certain feeling of assurance that the filmgoer of 1938 can scan his screen calen dar of the week, safe in the knowledge that a little item billed as "Passion Is on the Air Tonight" really is an item named "Passion Is on the Air Tonight" and not some gem from stage or library dressed up for a Hollywood holiday. Seven science clubs at Hunter College have planned and executed a series of exhibits which will compose a Science Fair to be held at the college from tomorrow to Wednesday in room 1626 of the Park Avenue Building. The anthropology, biology, chemistry, geography, geology, home economics and physiology groups will each have a display.

What is left of the League of Nations and what is its future, now that the Fascists have served notice of withdrawal and the Nazis have declared they "never" will return, and both have decided to cooperate instead with the League's first secessionist and the world's last divine right monarch?

K. E. Barraclough of Durham, N. H., extension forester at the University of New Hampshire, proposed today the establishment of forest land owners' cooperatives as the solution to the "problem" of regulating the forestry practices of individual woodlot owners.

Hugh Bradford Seymour, an architect, died here last night at his home after a long illness. Born sixty-four years ago in this city, a son of the late G. De Witt Seymour, a prominent banker, and Mary Delaphine Jeffery Seymour, he was a grandson of Hezekiah B. Seymour, one of the founders of the Erie Railroad.

Three years ago President Dixon Ryan Fox added the position of a student-appointed "coordinator of student activities" to the Union College administrative staff. This week a survey was made of the benefits undergraduates have received from the office.

Contributions to date in the United Hospital Campaign exceed last year's total gifts by more than 50 per cent, it was announced last night by Gates W. McGarrah, campaign treasurer. He said more than 12,000 new contributors had given their support to the drive this year.
A man accused of taking advantage of another's crippled condition to steal $13 from him was held yesterday by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in felony court in $500 bail for the grand jury.

Meeting, Eighth Assembly District of the New York City League of Women Voters Fordham Methodist Episcopal Hall, 2,548 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, 2:15 P. M. "The Far Eastern Situation," Mrs. Margarita Anne Stewart.
Federal contracts for supplies valued at $7,048,071 were awarded under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on Dec. 16, the Department of Labor has announced.

The taxicab strike sponsored by the C. I. O.-chartered Transport Workers Union continued to spread yesterday afternoon, with drivers of four more companies joining the walk-out which has already involved some 2,000 men and tied up about 1,000 cabs.

Declaring that justice and law obligate persons who obtained government funds by fraud to return them, Provisional President Alberto Enriquez has issued a decree providing for an investigation of officials of the former dictatorial government.

A revival of Mozart's "Don Glovanni" is scheduled for New Year's afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House as a feature of the fifth week of the current season. The work has not been staged at the Metropolitan for two years.
The cost of living has advanced rapidly in recent months because of depreciation of the franc, higher taxation and wages and reduced working hours.
Representative Celler of New York said today that information connecting Nazi organizations with support of the war referendum bill had been laid before the State Department.

There has been little further movement in Japanese bonds in the last three weeks, but this does not indicate anything more than the opinion that the heavy fall which has occurred since the Sino-Japanese war began appears to have discounted the adverse effect of the campaign upon Japan's economic situation thus far.

The Foreign Office spokesman withdrew today the categorical denial made on Friday that the United States gunboat Panay had been machinegunned and boarded by Japanese soldiers before she sank in the Yangtze River above Nanking on Dec. 12.
Dr. Josef Hofmann sat quietly through another major celebration of his golden jubilee last night as guest of honor of the Bohemians, the New York Musicians Club, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Miss Nancy Mae Woodbury, debutante daughter of Mrs. Wiley Egan Woodbury, was the guest of honor at a reception yesterday given by her mother and her uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Tenney, at the Tenney home, 1,000 Park Avenue. Guests included friends of Miss Woodbury and older friends of the family.

I have had several occasions to drive over Seventeenth and Eighteenth Streets since the holly-decorated warning signs have been in place. It seems to me that this attempt on the part of our Police Department to solve part of the problem is likely to prove futile.
Representative Maury Maverick the other day made a speech in Congress in which he referred to "David's coat

A freight engine slowly hauled a modernized, 5,400-horsepower Diesel train-the streamliner City of Los Angeles-out of Grand Central Terminal at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon on its first trip. The hundred passengers were on their way to the season's opening of Sun Valley Ranch, Ketchum, Idaho, on Tuesday.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann will give their annual reception on New Year's Day at Sunken Orchard, their Oyster Bay estate.

Leon J. Garcey, director of the Wagons-Lit Company, and Thomas Cook Son, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain on one of his periodical visits and said that the travel outlook for the South of France, Italy and Egypt was better than it had been for years.

The introduction of "ghetto benches" into some of the academic institutions of Poland was condemned yesterday by leading educators throughout the United States as "absolutely destructive of gains in human progress that have been made only by great sacrifice."

The New York World's Fair 1939 will be the most truly international exposition ever held, Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation, declared yesterday in announcing that sixty, nations already had taken steps to participate. Forty-six countries and the League of Nations have officially accepted President Roosevelt's invitation and the others have reserved space and are due to sign by the end of the year.

The trend on the exchange market changed this week, when the franc underwent a fresh spell of weakness. During October and November large amounts of capital were repatriated, but beginning with December, the inflow ceased and the equalization fund no longer was forced to intervene to prevent the franc from rising.

Moderate optimism is developing in the stock market as the new year approaches. It is not unusual for hopeful sentiments to find expression at this season, but there seems some solid ground for the impression that the six months of almost uninterrupted decline has ended.

Eugene S. Wilson, a vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company since 1920, died yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Carlyle, 35 East Seventysixth Street, of a heart attack. He was 58 years old. Mr. Wilson, an athlete during his college days, enjoyed good health until four days ago.

Thomas Gordon, a retired textile manufacturer, died at his home here today at the age of 81. He was a member of a committee influential in obtaining the nomination of J. Hampton Moore for his first term as Mayor. Surviving are his widow, three sons, Dr. William D. Gordon,

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday at his home on Marion Road, Mansfield, Ohio, of Frank B. Black, chairman of the board of directors of the Ohio Brass Company, which he founded half a century ago. He was 72 years old.

R. D. Mullowney of the Harvard Club, second seeded player and run?? a year ago, won the second annual invitation Class C squash racquets tournament of the Englewood Field Club by defeating A. M. Moody of Yale Club, seeded third, in the final today, 8-15, 15-11, 1511, 15--14.

The national aspects of conservation should predominate over regional aspects, according to a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, whose report, condemning the pending Norris-Mansfield bills for creation of seven regional planning authorities, was upheld by an overwhelming vote of member organizations of the chamber, it was announced today.

The Boston Bruins kept their lead in the American Group of the National Hockey League tonight as Charlie Sands and Cooney Weiland each tallied two goals for a 4-to-2 conquest of the Detroit Red Wings before 9,885 spectators.

Whatever happens, we are to have a new farm law, and by all present indications it will be fearfully and wonderfully made. It will subsidize and regiment the farmer on a scale and scope beyond the wildest dreams of AAA.

George Hallgren has been elected vice president and director of Nathan Straus-Duparquet, Inc., of this city, according to announcement today by Samuel R. Sperans, president of the company, which is one of the largest firms in the country providing equipment, furnishings and supplies to hotels, clubs, restaurants, hospitals, etc.

If any one is planning to become an American villager and can pick his spot, it would be a good idea for him to look over some figures released today by the Bureau of Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture.

Dr. C. J. Hamilton, a practicing physician for 58 years, a former Member of Parliament and an occupant of almost every civic office here, died today after a short illness at the age of 82. During his career here he brought 6,807 babies into the world.

Mrs. A. W. Paine, president of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, and Archibald G. Thacher Jr. of the Harvard Club for the second straight year won the invitation mixed doubles squash racquets tournament at Sleepy Hollow today when they defeated Miss Margaret Bostwick, former metropolitan women's singles champion, and Brainerd H.
The Brookhattans succumbed to the hard-playing Hispanos by 4-2 in an American Soccer League game at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Grover A. Whalen gave a luncheon at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their eldest daughter, Miss Mary Whalen, to Robert Maurice Saul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Bower Saul of Rose Valley, Pa.

Bishop William T. Manning presided yesterday at the opening services of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Crucifixion, 149th Street and Convent Avenue. The church, whose congregation includes many Negroes, has been acquired from the Hamilton Grange Reformed Church.

The role of the religious spirit in a world now afflicted with fascism, communism and other violent beliefs that tend to obliterate civil and religious liberties was selected as a topic for sermons in several pulpits throughout the city yesterday.

Gold imports in November amounted to [Pound]41,160,503, lifting the total for eleven months to [Pound]283,810,028, against [Pound]278,529,904 in the same period in 1936. Exports were [Pound]9,046,341, making [Pound]207,249,644 for eleven months, against [Pound]70,781,672.

Wearing a heavy black shirt, trousers, shoes, socks and woolen underwear, freighted with a 30-yard life-line torn by the current from the hands of helpers on the shore, Patrolman John A. Erikson of the Marine Division dragged a drowning man from the dark water off the Battery at 2:30 yesterday morning.
Dr. Gerard Vissering, president of the Bank of the Netherlands from 1912 to 1932, died at his country home near Haarlem this morning at the age of 71.

A $1,600 prize essay contest for college seniors and juniors on the topic "Company, Craft and Industrial Unions and Their Legal Responsibilities" was announced yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate.

George Jacobs and Franklin Davis, the Mountain Lakes, N. J., archers who took to the woods after deer on Saturday are practically convinced that the man with the bow and arrow can't compete with the shotgun enthusiast.

The first award in King George VI's reign of the King's Gold Medal for poetry was made recently to Wystan Hugh Auden, 30-year-old poet and dramatist, who was presented to the King by the poet laureate, John Masefield.
A verdict of accidental death was returned Saturday at an inquest at the Tangmere Royal Air Force station into the crash Friday that killed Flight Lieutenant Harry

The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., through its president, Clarke G. Dailey, has sent to Senators Wagner and Copeland and New York City Representatives in the House a protest against the undistributed-profits tax and the present language of that part of the tax law referring to personal holding companies.

Except for Wednesday and Thursday, when prices advanced, the Boerse was irregular or weaker this week. Traders showed reserve while awaiting details of the Reich financing program, and selling for the accounts of emigres occasionally depressed prices.

The LokalAnzeiger prints this morning an interview with President Getulio Vargas of Brazil in which the President confirms that his is an authoritarian regime based on dominance of the executive power and subordination of all others, including that of parliament, the judiciary and private business.
Phillips T. and Douglas B. Stearns of Albany, N. Y., twins and seniors at Williams College, were elected today marshals of their class, which they will lead in the June academic processions.

Supreme Court Justice Alonzo G. Hinkley, who nine years ago imposed a mandatory life sentence on Walter Sarnowski as a fourth offender, received today his ninth Christmas card from prisoner 43274 at Auburn Penitentiary.

THE tall, gray-haired gentleman in the sweeping overcoat seemed quiet enough looking and, besides, he was very direct in his approach. "Sit down," he said. "I want to talk to you." That was fairly easy. You were sitting down already. As for his talking, well,

Private placements in November by the United States Employment Service were 25.1 per cent less than in October and 0.8 per cent below November, 1936, the latter being the first decrease in eighteen months from the corresponding month of a year earlier.
A general endowment grant of $150,000 has been made by the Carnegie Corporation to Barnard College, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday.

Dizzy Dean's combination of "Me and Paul" lost to another set of baseball brothers, Paul and Lloyd Waner of the Pittsburgh Pirates, in an 18-hole golf match over the Bobby Jones municipal course today. The Waners defeated the St. Louis Cardinals' hurlers, 4 and 3.

Miss Elizabeth Truslow, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Truslow of Brooklyn Heights, will be married on the afternoon of Jan. 8 to Thomas Melvill Pope, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Melvill Pope of Katonah, N. Y.

Frederick Davies Reed, who retired in 1918 after many years as assistant secretary of the Lawyers Title and Trust Company, New York, died at his Summer home here yesterday at the age of 68. His widow, the former Mary A. Granger of Providence, R. I., survives.

Declaration of the unity of the Christian faith, as represented by the church, was made in a valedictory sermon by the Right Rev. James De Wolf Perry, presiding bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, at the Washington Cathedral today.

Various aspects of training youth for American citizenship will be stressed at the annual Women's Conference on National Defense for an Enduring Democracy, to be held in Washington late in January, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Gladys Mooney of Detroit, chairman.

Government forces entered the eastern side of Teruel today, according to an official communique just issued. The troops apparently drove down from the cemetery on the edge of the town that was previously captured in operations described in the writer's dispatch from the front. [The dispatch referred to follows this one.]
Seventeen Italian aviators, formerly employed as instructors by the Chinese Government, arrived here today from Hankow and announced they had been recalled by their own government.

In a protest filed with Senators Copeland and Wagner and the members of the House of Representatives from 'this city, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, describes the Federal tax on undistributed profits as a "particular deterrent to any revival of construction activity."

A conference of officials of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle and the Newspaper Guild of New York at the Scarsdale home of Arthur S. Meyer, member of the State Mediation Board, resulted in progress toward settlement of the strike against the newspaper, but left "certain important issues still unsettled," Mr. Meyer said last night.

Many relatives and friends of students gathered in Marymount College auditorium here this afternoon for the students' annual Christmas charity benefit performance. The feature of the program was the presentation of Balfe's "Bohemian Girl."

Cash lard and dry salted clear bellies on the Board of Trade here were sold last week at the lowest levels since August, 1934, and closing trades yesterday were at the bottom figures, with cash lard at $8 and bellies at $11 a hundred pounds.

Announcement was made here today of the formation of the American Association for Economic Freedom, sponsored by a large group of churchmen, college leaders and representatives of the public, for the purpose of assisting in "the further democratization of our economic institutions."

Conversion of the sun deck of the Hapag Lloyd liner Columbus into a recreation center has been completed during her six-week lay-up at Pier 86, North River, it was announced yesterday. The ship will sail Wednesday on the first of a series of cruises to the West Indies.

Congress has reduced to 3,000,000 colones the 5,000,000 provided for service of the foreign debt in the budget submitted by President Leon Cortes. Since complete service on foreign loans amounts to 20,000,000 colones, this action is virtually equivalent to a moratorium.

The world trade outlook remains dark as viewed from here. Both official and private comments in Berlin are to the effect that developments in the United States in the coming months will be decisive factors in the situation.

The New York Americans continued their domination of the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, defeating the Bill Stewart team, 1 to 0, on a secondperiod goal by the veteran Hooley Smith, with help from Jack Shill.

No steps to mediate the. Horn Hardart Automat strike will be taken unless Local 302 of the Cafeteria Employes Union promises in writing to abstain from mass demonstrations during the negotiations, Arthur S. Meyer, member of the State Mediation Board, reiterated last night.

After questioning some twenty persons today, including several employes who were laid off recently because of the seasonal slack, Nassau County authorities reported they had obtained no clue to the identity of the persons involved in the apparent attempt to derail two Long Island Railroad passenger trains last Thursday evening. The investigation will continue.

To attain peace one must go back to that point in one's life at which the first moral error was made, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

A tract of more than fifty-four acres of farm land in Hicksville, L. I., has been purchased by John Froehlich Jr., who operates extensive truck farms in the vicinity, from the Ludwig Rothschild estate.

Clergymen here yesterday discussed the Christmas spirit from many angles. Some noted that wars in various parts of the world tended to drown out the Christmas spirit and others noted that in countries not now harassed by war the spirit of Christ's birthday tended to become obscure amid the trappings of modernity and commercialism.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, charged yesterday that the Senate Committee on Education and Labor was backed by liberal groups "working for the overthrow by one means or another of the American system of private enterprise."
Stocks improved irregularly on the week; turnover, 5,170,364 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds higher, corporate issues lower; transactions, $39,849,400.

John Galm, who in his working hours is in charge of the bird house in the Central Park Zoo, spends his spare time looking after birds of his own. He takes a birdman's holiday. This was learned yesterday at the second and final day of the annual show of the Empire Cage Bird Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Atterbury McGinley of Sewickley, Pa., have sent out invitations for the marriage of Mrs. McGinley's daughter, Miss Mary Elizabeth Floyd, to Walter Nathaniel Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Calvin Brown of Plainfield.
The Mexican Government indicated in a statement today that it would continue to permit the Japanese fishing fleet to operate on the Mexican west coast.

The manuscript of Rudyard Kipling's famous poem "Recessional" has just been presented to the British Museum by the author's cousin, Earl Baldwin, the former Prime Minister, to whom it was given for that purpose by Miss Elizabeth Gaskell Norton, an American.

Christmas business in Berlin's stores is brisk, but merchants complain that they are unable to supply many ordinary semi-luxury articles, and some goods, especially imported wares, are unsalable because of high prices.
A member of the House Military Committee said today that President Roosevelt wants to tighten up restrictions against the photographing of this country's fortifications.

Mrs. Carmella Favatta, 50 years old, of 200 Second Avenue, was fatally stabbed at 11:05 A. M. yesterday at the southwest corner of Thirteenth Street and First Avenue by a man who escaped in a crowd of persons patronizing pushcart markets in the block.
Victor Ghezzi, Deal, N. J., pro, skyrocketed into the lead in the $3,500 Nassau open golf tournament today with two 66s, each four under par, for a fifty-four-hole total of 204.

The State Mediation Board resumed last night its efforts to settle the strike called by the United Retail Drug Store Employes Union, Local 1,199, a C. I. O. affiliate, against the Whelan Drug Stores, Inc. The strike began on Saturday,
Spanish Republican forces are ready now, according to their commanders, to meet any attack from the Rebels thrust for thrust, and, more than that, to take them by surprise with a huge mobile army.

Congregation Shearith Is ?? 2 West Seventieth Street, last night celebrated the thirtieth anniversary of the connection of Dr. David De Sola Pool with the congregation, the oldest in the United States.
German figures have became available here indicating that when the rebuilding of the German commercial air fleet began early this year it was already by far the largest in Europe.

The similarity between the world today and the world at the time of Christ was discussed yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, in his morning sermon.

Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Dannreuther Jr. of this city have announced the engagement of their only daughter, Miss Helen Louise Dannreuther, to Edward Livingston Coster, son of Mrs. Edward Livingston Coster of White Hall, Katonah, .N. Y., and the late Mr. Coster.
Dr. Leopold Cohn, founder and former president of-the American Board of Missions to the Jews, Inc., of Brooklyn, died yesterday at the Brooklyn Hospital after a week's illness. He was 75 years old.

A vacant plot in the business section of Hackensack, N. J., has been purchased by the Red Rock Realty Company, an affiliate of the Steinmetz Construction Company of New York, which plans to erect a twostory business building on the site. The Hackensack Trust Company was the seller.

Modifiction of the five housing bills to be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow night has removed virtually all the objections made against them, Fred W. Ehrlich, chairman of the New Jersey State Housing Authority, said here today.

Representatives of 251 organizations, in session at 701 Eighth Avenue yesterday afternoon at the Cost of Living Conference of the Consumers National Federation, adopted resolutions requesting Congress to investigate living costs.

The need for improvements in the City Hall area, including the removal of the old postoffice building at Broadway and Park Row, was stressed by Archibald R. Watson, president of the City Hall Park Association, in a statement yesterday.

Despite curtailment of employment in the automobile industry which has made inroads on the income of the United Automobile Workers of America, all resources of the union are being concentrated in a "halfmillion-dollar war chest" for the organization of the Ford Motor the Company, sources close to the U. A. W. A. disclosed today.

Holland's trade shows a gradual down-trend, although the general picture still is favorable compared with the figures of last year. November's imports, for instance, were 130,000,000 guilders, compared with 149,000,000 in October, and 101,000,000 guilders in November, 1936.
Dr. Charles L. Henkin, Brooklyn physician and playwright, died of heart disease yesterday in his-home, 692 Leonard Street, at the age of 52.

Charles K. Keller, a retired compositor of 133-28 Dennis Avenue, Springfield Gardens, died Saturday night in St. Mary's Hospital, Brooklyn, after an illness of seven months. He was born in Williamsport, Pa., seventy-eight years ago. Mr. Keller served a quarter of a century with Bradstreet Co. in Manhattan.

The Real Estate Board of Newark has elected Joel L. Schlesinger president for 1938. Mr. Schlesinger, a first vice president of the board, has been in the real estate brokerage business for forty-seven years. He is secretary and treasurer of Louis Schlesinger, Inc.

The second annual American Artists Congress came to a close yesterday afternoon at the New School for Social Research with a series of resolutions condemning infringements on civil liberties and calling upon artists to ally themselves with the trade union movement.

A plea for a truce in industrial warfare during the Christmas season was made yesterday by the Rev. John Brett Langstaff, rector of St. Edmund's Protestant Episcopal Church, Morris Avenue and 177th Street, the Bronx.

Members of the socially prominent Keyser family disclosed tonight that Jane Keyser, 23, had eloped with Donald Crane, 32, a butler in the Keyser home here. A family representative said the marriage was at Rockville, Md., Friday.

Election of Dr. Charles A. Kraus, Professor of Chemistry and director of chemical research at Brown University, as president of the American Chemical Society for 1939 was announced yesterday. He was chosen in a national poll of the socity's 20,000 members.
Cecil Smith's Texas Rangers rode rings around a nineteen-goal Mexican Army polo team today and won the first contest of a three-game series, 11 to 2.

Miss Helen Leigh Fletcher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Leigh Fletcher of Brooklyn, has chosen the evening of Jan. 3 as the date for her marriage to Justin Armstrong Stanley, son of Mrs. Walter Herbert Stanley of Leesburg, Ind. The ceremony will take place at the home of Miss Fletcher's parents, 32 Remsen Street.
On the Vandenbery amendment (to the Pope-McGill Farm Bill) to limit expenditures under the measure to $500,000,000, rejected 49 to 23:

Pierre Comert of the French Foreign Office left Berlin today after nearly a week's visit reportedly with an arrangement calculated to protect French and possibly other foreign correspondents to a certain extent.

The list of the Italian motor ship Saturnia, due today from Mediterranean ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Hoffman, Mr. and Mrs. Melville Eastham, Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer P. Livingston, Mrs. Guy Currier, Mr. and Mrs. David B. Maher, Mr. and Mrs. H. G. Chatfield, Mrs. Albert H. Morse and Miss Jensal Carolyn Johnson.
Miss Esme O'Brien was introduced to society last night at a buffet dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Esmond P. O'Brien, at the Junior League Clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street.
" My Malkele," the Yiddish musical co-starring Molly Picon and Aaron Lebedeff, enters tonight on its last three weeks at the Public. Their next vehicle, "Bublichka," will open there on Jan. 15.
S. BROWN LADIES HAT MANUFACTURING CORP., 29 W. 38th St., by Louis Weinberg Associates, Inc., for upward of $250; Millinery Import Corp., upward of $100; Eurasia Import Co., Inc., upward of $250.
The psychological distance across the English Channel strikes the traveler with fresh force every time he leaves the Continent for these outlying islands.

The Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, Inc., which is a club and home at 283 Lexington Avenue for enlisted service men stationed in the neighborhood of the city, will be the beneficiary of a recital to be given this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Shepard Fabbri, 7 East Ninety-fifth Street.
Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel, German six-day bike stars, won their eighth consecutive international race tonight.

A dance will be held tomorrow night by the Bellevue Hospital Internes Association at Webster Hall to recompense internes and other hospital attaches who have suffered losses through the depredations of a "phantom burglar" who has been operating in the hospital for the last two years, it was learned yesterday.
Heavy gales and high seas tonight were reported threatening the destruction of the helpless $8,000,000 liner President Hoover, aground on rocky Hoishoto Island near Formosa.

The United States Embassy today was making arrangements to evacuate the second capital of China, Hankow, which became one of three seats of the government only a few days before Nanking fell to the Japanese advance.

As Christmas week opened, gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund fell off dishearteningly yesterday to $3,886.26, with one exception the smallest sum received on a single day since the beginning of the twenty-sixth annual appeal. Only 221 contributors were represented in the day's gifts, which brought the total for the Fund this year to $170,530.88.

The marriage of Miss Adele Diamond, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Diamond, to Jerome Howard Adler, son of Mrs. Isaac Adler and the late Mr. Adler, took place last night at the home of the bride's parents, 16 East Eighty-third Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein of Temple B'nai Jeshurun.

The Most Rev. Paul Yu Pin, Roman Catholic Bishop of Nanking, who left China on Oct. 30, arrived yesterday on the French liner Champlain on his first visit to the United States. He is 36 years old, was educated in Rome and speaks six languages.

A public mass meeting to be held in Jersey City tomorrow night to carry on the protest against Mayor Frank Hague's attitude toward the C. I. 0. was announced last night in a radio broadcast over WEVD in which the Jersey City Mayor was denounced as a "fascist dictator" who had suspended civil liberties guaranteed under the Constitution.
After decades of relative neglect under British civilian rule, the island of Cyprus, "Cinderella" of the Colonial Office, may again become-as in antiquity-a land of luxurious forests and gardens.

The possibility of the entrance of a Conservative party in the next Presidential elections is seen today in the announcement of Mariano Ospina Perez as a candidate by Silvio Villegas, publisher of the newspaper La Patria of Manizales.
The Japanese now have more than 900,000 soldiers in China and Manchukuo, informed persons said today, on the basis of unpublished dispatches from the Far East.

With sixteen players representing four colleges, all is in readiness for the opening of the annual championship tournament of the H. Y. P. D. League this morning at the Marshall Chess Club. Harvard will be pitted against Princeton and Dartmouth against Yale in the first round and play will be continued tomorrow morning and afternoon and concluded on Wednesday.

Martin F. Ehrenberg, in 139 E 94th St; Elizabeth E. Boteler, in 410 Park Ave; Brett Wyckoff, brokers. Israel Caban, Florencio Soto, in 529 W 135th St; Charles E. Wyatt, Mrs. Catherine Curran, in 640 Riverside Dr; Max Hirsch, William Rubin, in 66 Fort Washington, William Rubin, in 66 Fort Washington Ave; Canrado Robriguez,
Alex Shibicky's lightning drive in the dying minutes of the third period saved the New York Rangers from being defeated by the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night.

In contrast with the frankness concerning the most important matters discussed during Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos's Prague visit was one subject vital to Czechoslovakia which, while fully covered in the conversations, was not mentioned in the public announcements.

Combined assets of the member institutions of -the Federal Home Loan Bank System reached $4,050,000,000 in November, when two institutions joined the system, making a total of 3,929, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has announced.
Connie Mack, the lean leader of the Athletics, who will soon be starting his fifty-fifth year in baseball, leaned back in a chair at his home today and sighed.
The Clear Creek Consolidated Mining Company, Du Mont, Col., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for 400,000 shares of 10-cents-par-value capital stock.
The wholesale price index for Dec. 8 was 105.6, unchanged from a week before.

The first symphony of Sibelius returned to the active lists of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conducting, at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. Last heard in the orchestra's regular season about a year ago, the work was received by a large Sunday audience with evidence of pleasure.

Execution of eight important officials of long standing in the Soviet regime was announced tonight on the twentieth anniversary of the Russian Secret Political Police. The announcement said they had been shot for high treason.
Two United States warships reached Tsingtao today after a speedy run from Shanghai to protect and evacuate, if necessary, 300 Americans who are endangered by the spread of the Chinese-Japanese war.

A Japanese and a Chinese, one educated at Harvard, the other at Yale, thoroughly discussed the "SinoJapanese conflict" tonight before an audience of about 1,500 Washingtonians, including many government officials and socially prominent citizens.

With a program that includes six solo numbers, "The Ice Follies of 1938," featuring outstanding figure skaters, is to open tonight in Madison Square Garden. Performances are to be given each evening until Thursday inclusive, with afternoon presentations on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

The 123d automobile fatality in Westchester County this year was recorded by the police today when Mrs. Annie Aiken, 50 years old, of Boston, a widow, died in the United Hospital at Port Chester of injuries received late last night when she was struck by an automobile while walking in Boston Post Road here.
Without warning, the week-end brought forth plans whereby William Shakespeare would not only be further represented soon on Broadway but might be competing with himself again.
In the turkey shoot held today the North Jersey Gun Club made arrangements so that every competitor for honors would get a bird in the first fifty-target event.
Bishop William T. Manning appealed yesterday for funds to complete the sanctuary and choir of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in time for the World's Fair in 1939.

Charges of "arbitrary, unjust and unfair" conduct have been made against Federal Judge Ferdinand A. Geiger of Milwaukee by Attorney General Cummings in a letter to Repretentative Sumners, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee.

The dangers of knitting an innocent Japanese populace more closely to its war leaders are too great, Dr. Henry Neumann, leader of the Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society, said yesterday, to risk an organized boycott of Japanese goods.

Archibald Montgomery McCrea, chairman of the board of the Union Spring and Manufacturing Company of Pittsburgh, died at Stuart Circle Hospital here today after an illness of several weeks. His age was 61.

Ball-Kirch Post, American Legion, in observance of the official opening of North Plainfield's new borough hall this afternoon, presented an American flag to the borough at ceremonies in charge of Commander Robert J. Underhill.

Burgess Meredith, one of the featured players in "The StarWagon" at the Empire Theatre, will read Clement C. Moore's "'Twas the Night Before Christmas" on Friday afternoon at the annual Christmas Eve celebration in the London Terrace apartments at Ninth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. Freddie Bartholomew, boy film star, read the poem last year.

With the downward movements in the steel industry checked and some increase in general buying, backed by development of various large products, the situation appears better, according to the magazine Steel in its weekly summary.

F. A. Scola and A. L. Burns finished on even terms in the competition for the High-Over-All Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday, each breaking 98 out of 100 targets. As Burns decided not to wait for the shoot-off, the trophy was taken by Scola.

THE late Lord Curzon, whose opinion (in the following regard, at least) is worth some attention, once wrote to the effect that there was more of the real Persia in a novel called "Hajji Baba" than in a whole stack of earnest nonfiction. Whether one accepts this opinion or not,
Horse racing returns to Florida tomorrow to the tune of thudding hoofs at Tropical Park and the jingle of pari-mutuel betting, from which the State hopes to reap a record harvest.

After an all-day session in which it made some changes in the measure, a Senate Banking and Currency Subcommittee voted unanimously late today to report the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill to the full committee when it meets tomorrow morning.

The gold recently shipped from the United States to France was bought under the terms of the tri-partite agreement by the French control fund in October and November with dollars sold by French capitalists who had been repatriating their funds.
In the open racing today of the sailing dinghy craft at the Larchmont Yacht Club two Class X boats swept through to a point score above their Class B rivals. It was a turn-about in performance.

The idea of wholesale salvation through the State, without retail transformation in citizens, is one of the unrealistic ideas in history, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, said yesterday morning.

President Roosevelt should "have the courage to save $171,000,000 a year for the people of the United States" by refusing to issue a new silver proclamation and thus help stop "the worst of our rackets in proportion to the number of people involved," Representative John Taber, Republican of Auburn, N. Y., declared in a statement today.

Broadway, 547, to Mercer St, 118, Francis E. Rivers, referee, to Marine Midland Trust Co, foreclosure ($32.50). 38th St, 38 W, Charles J. Breck, trustee in bankruptcy of W. Tilden P. Hazard, to E. M. Wolff, 709 Read's Lane, Far Rock- Son away, L. I., all right, title and interest (50C). Same property Charles J. Breck,
Charles A. Davila, Rumanian Minister to the United States and one of the outstanding figures in the diplomatic corps here, has resigned for what are understood to be personal reasons.

The ungracious welcome that the Holy Family received at the inn of Bethlehem is widely prevalent throughout the modern world, the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Fiftyfirst Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Refusing to allow the invasion of China to divert their interest from the war in Spain, more than 9,000 members of the Labor party filled Albert Hall and overflowed into another meeting place tonight to demand "arms, food and justice for democratic Spain."
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cave of this city announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Jeanette Cave, to Herbert I. Trask, also of Hartford, at a tea given yesterday afternoon at their home.

Dawn automobile burglars struck for the third time yesterday and escaped with a mink coat of undetermined value after cutting a 12-inoh circular hole in a show window of Jaeckel, Inc., furriers, at 546 Fifth Avenue, although a watchman inside fired a shot at them through the window.

The curtailment of rayon weaving operations which began three months ago still is continuing, according to the weekly survey of the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc., released for publication today. In the week ended Dec. 11,

Joseph Fishbach, seeded second; Bernard Jacoby and Melvin Schwartman, fourth and fifth respectively, advanced as the third annual metropolitan junior indoor tennis singles championship tournament got under way on the Hamilton courts yesterday.
Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and of the C. I. 0. have given up any hope of a speedy reunion.

Profits must be earned by a manufacturing company if it is not to languish and die. Hence the assumption that an industrial laboratory is merely an adjunct of a factory, taking its orders from the business management and limiting itself to money-making discovery and invention.

Nine representatives of Harvard University will be among the ninety nominees for Rhodes scholars who will face tomorrow their final hurdles-namely, interviews before the district committees of selection.

Of the immediate future, markets in the closing weeks of an old year do not usually give clear forecast. In the four past years, Stock Exchange averages have risen during the second half of December-as they did last week,with occasional interruptions.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High and St. Francis Prep remained tied at the top in the annual Brooklyn Catholic High Schools Athletic Association swimming tournament by recording victories in the Columbus Club pool in Brooklyn yesterday.

A team of Stamford Yacht Club Class D dinghy sailors paid a visit to the Frostbite regatta here today and walked away with practically all the honors in sight, leaving the local Fristbiters with a rather reduced opinion of themselves.
California's football players, who worried Coach Leonard Allison because they worked too smoothly after a month's lay-off, were told to rest today from practice for the Rose Bowl.

The rapidly thinning ranks of unbeaten basketball teams in the metropolitan district were reduced as two more local fives were defeated for the first time last week. Fordham was the first to fall, bowing to Pittsburgh on Friday and St. John's lost to Illinois the following night.

The Federal Power Commission has denied he applications of the Carolina Aluminum Company and the State of North Carolina for a rehearing in the matter of the declaration of Carolina Aluminum to construct a hydro-electric plant on the Yadkin River near Tuckertown, N. C.

Primo Carnera, lonesome, poor and assured his fighting days are over, will be taken to Venice Tuesday. He has been in a sanatorium here with a kidney hemorrhage which physicians say will prevent his fighting again.

Officials of the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that the heaviest piece of highway wrecking equipment in the world has been constructed for the Lincoln Tunnel, which is to be dedicated tomorrow.
The Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, has received as a gift from an anonymous donor six paintings by well known modern artists.

AS the site for a six-story elevator apartment house, the property at 1,865 and 1,867 Monroe Avenue, near the Concourse and East 167th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of-Caroline Kramer and Adrian Grasselly to a client of the Faber Realty Company, broker in the deal. H.

The Orange Tigers of Princeton overwhelmed a 112th Field Artillery combination by 16--4 1/2 in the feature polo game today at the Red Bank armory. In the preliminary, the Silver Brook Farm team halted the Ponolo unit, 10 1/2--4.

A last-minute campaign for the selection of a new president of the Actors Equity Association was waged by actors last night after Burgess Meredith insisted he would not accept the post because Equity council meetings to choose a new leader had developed into a "political fracas."

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $3,636,698,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:
The Scots-Americans defeated the Philadelphia Germans by 4-3 in an American Soccer League fixture today.

Harry Bennett of 103 Graham Street, Jersey City, former Clerk of the Hoboken District Court, died last night at his home after three years of illness. A heart ailment necessitated his retirement in November, after twenty-nine years of service. His age was 61.

Slow progress in school is definitely related to health, physical characteristics and the social and economic status of parents, as well as to mental ability, it was declared in a report made public yesterday reviewing the experience of the Board of Education in dealing with problems of maladjustment.

The offiCial report on the condition of Winter cereals as Dec. 1 indicated superior grading, the same as a year ago, with rye better than wheat. On an index basis, with 2 indicating good and 3 middling, wheat stands - 2.5 and rye at 2.3.

In Class B murder mysteries it is the audience which eventually becomes the object of greatest suspicion for passively remaining in its seats. Certain elements of that insoluble mystery (of mass inertia) cling to the stereotyped happenings of "Under Suspicion," the new film at the Globe.

Checks aggregating close to $500,000 and representing a dividend payment of 18 per cent will be in the hands of 6,000 depositors of the State Bank of Binghamton, now in liquidation, by the middle of this week, William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, announced yesterday.

The situation in the commodity markets is steadier now than for some time, and fluctuations have narrowed considerably. A fair recovery from the year's low levels has taken place in some directions, and there is reason to believe that much healthier market conditions have been restored by the elimination of all weak speculative positions.

For several days there has been much talk in Parliamentary quarters of the necessity for instituting foreign exchange control. Although the present government is opposed to such a measure, the mere threat that it might become a possibility has caused the buying of foreign currencies here.

Young contestants sporting the emblem of the Women's Swimming Association of New York carried off the lion's share of the laurels in the women's A. A. U. aquatic meet held in their home pool yesterday.
Purchases of off-price and "special" merchandise for January events and selection of advance Spring stocks characterized action in the wholesale apparel market last week.
William Scott, 17 years old, of Adrian Street here, crashed through the ice while skating on Pompton Lake this afternoon and was drowned.
The marriage of Mrs. Loretta C. Baldwin of New York and Captain Paul B. Watson of the marine corps was announced here today.
