After outlining the campaign of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League for the boycott of German goods in this country, Samuel Untermyer, president of the league, urged here today that the boycott be extended to Japanese goods.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 77.2 on Dec. 15, compared with 77 a fortnight before, 78.4 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

An earnest plea that the-United States Government and people believe his sincerity in declarations that the airplane bombing of the United States gunboat Panay was entirely accidental was voiced today by Admiral Kiyoshi Hasegawa in an interview with the writer aboard the flagship Izumo.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbels, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

Mrs. Mary Maier, 36 years old, of 3,244 Third Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested at 6:20 P. M. yesterday in front of Grand Central Palace, where the German Markets Exposition is being held, on the complaint of Herbert Harris of 650 West 172d Street.

Freight cars on order by the railroads on Dec. 1 numbered 12,566, against 18,305 on Nov. 1 and 19,844 on Dec. 1, 1936, and 8,076 on Dec. 1, 1935, according to the Association of American Railroads. The figures include equipment under construction in railroad-owned plants in which reclaimed parts are used.

Having found an idea which will permit Shirley Temple to assume modern attire, Twentieth CenturyFox has announced that the next vehicle for America's No. 1 boxoffice star will be "Little Lady of Broadway." Irving Cummings,

One hundred and fifty religious, welfare, educational and labor leaders have signed a petition to President Roosevelt and Congress for enactment at the special session of "legislation which will assure the continuance of the Federal public works and relief program to the extent of the need of the surplus unemployed workers of the nation," Darwin J. Meserole, president of the National Unemployment League, announced yesterday.

Railroad traffic in the Southern Ukraine between Russia and Poland may be halted if no satisfactory reply is given to a Russian note accusing Polish railroad officials of an attempt to burn a Russian train.

Prices of cotton continued last week the upward trend of the previous week. At the close they were up 1/2 to 3/4 cent from the lowest levels reached early in October. On the New York Cotton Exchange net advances for the week ranged from 13 to 24 points.

Home from his service in a country for which he had a predilection-but it was an unconcealed liking and not a "secret passion"--Ambassador Bingham finds himself accredited by Death to the Sovereign of the only higher realm than his own land. Death found in him a shining mark.

New progress has taken place in the last few days in Anglo-French cooperation. Pierre Cot, French Minister of Air, was here last week and conferred with Viscount Swinton of Masham, British Secretary of State for Air, and his officials with the object of establishing a permanent basis for the close collaboration of the two air forces.

To meet the land shortage and widespread erosion, the experimental program of soil conservation, now under way in Puerto Rico to preserve the arable highlands and restore many thousands of acres to cultivation, offers a proving ground of the greatest value for the development of a permanent agricultural policy, according to Walter C. Lowdermilk.

The teams of the Garden City Casino scored three shut-out victories in week-end tournament competition of the Metropolitan Badminton Association. The Long Islanders' men's Class A team blanked the Central Badminton Club first team, 5 to 0, while the men's Class B combination scored 5-to-O triumphs over the Nassau Badminton Club and the Heights Casino.
Members of Lansing Local, No. 182, United Automobile Workers of America are in revolt against the regime of Lester Washburn, their president.

Frank B. Kellogg, co-author of the Kellogg-Briand peace pact and former World Court judge, was critically ill today at his home here. His physician, Dr. J. A. Lepak, said there was "virtually no hope" for his recovery, and added: "It is just a matter of hours."

Margaret and Virginia Gozmanian, American-born daughters of Osgien Gozmanian, an Armenian of Newark, N. J., returned yesterday on the French liner Champlain from France. They were met at the pier by their father.

Princeton University, in the face of adverse business conditions, has operated on a balanced budget since 1929, Gail A. Mills, bursar of the university, writes in the current issue of The Princeton Alumni Weekly.
While David S. Polland, State champion, and Sidney Bernstein both improved their standing in the Marshall Chess Club's championship tournament yesterday, Frank J. Marshall, the titleholder,

The Gourmet Society had as its honor guest at dinner yesterday afternoon Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace, who suggested to the lovers of fine food that in the "inward essence of transcendental gastronomy" might lie the solution to the farm problem of the nation.

Sixteen United States and British petroleum companies, with a total investment of $450,000,000 in Mexico, in a joint statement today alleged that the Government Labor Board's decision yesterday, increasing the wages of oil workers about one-third, violated Mexican labor laws and represented a "glaring denial of justice."
George Dutton Tillotson, former vice president of The Englewood Press, which had been founded by his father, died in Presbyterian Hospital here yesterday of pneumonia. He was 47 years old.

Offering will be made today by Freeman Co. of $780,000 of North Western Refrigerator Line 3 1/2 per cent equipment-trust certificates, Series K. The certificates, dated Dec. 15, 1937, and maturing semiannually from Oct. 15, 1938, to April 15, 1948, will be priced to yield from 2 to 4 per cent, according to maturity.

Mr. and Mrs. Skeffington S. Norton Jr. of Glen Head were hosts this evening at a buffet supper after the christening of their daughters, Janet Scott Norton, 2 years old, and Alice Ann Norton, 6 years old.

Leo M. Karakhan, who has been executed in the Soviet purge, was the government's foremost authority on Oriental affairs. He was a tall, swarthy Armenian, considered by many the handsomest man in the Soviet Administration.

One hundred and ninety-nine Princeton undergraduates during the 1937 Fall season qualified for official athletic insignia either as members of teams in four branches of sport or as student managers, according to the list of awards announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, retiring graduate manager of Nassau athletics.
Usual curtailment in highway building for the Winter months contributed partly to a 9.8 per cent decline in State construction employment in November, the Labor Department said today.
While the Japanese Army is battling Chinese forces along ever-extending fronts, a battle that is even more grim is going on within the army's highest command.

Official estimates of the United States and Argentine wheat crops were issued last week, and while they indicated a decrease of around 20,000,000 bushels from previous forecasts for the two countries, the decrease was regarded by the grain trade as inconsequential when compared with the total world's crop.

There is nothing particularly encouraging or discouraging in Britain's overseas trade in November. Imports established another post-slump record, while both imports and exports considerably exceeded those of November, 1936, the gains being 23.6 per cent and 17.5 per cent, respectively.
More than a hundred Protestant pastors and several thousand of the Catholic clergy will pass Christmas in prison.

The Mexican Senate is expected to pass the "anti-foreign" bill before it adjourns on Dec. 31. The Chamber of Deputies last week approved the project expected to affect principally 18,000 to 20,000 Jews living in Mexico.

Adoption of a non-occupational accident and sickness disability benefit plan for all employes and a new group life insurance plan were announced yesterday by Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation.
Van Horn Ely, a retired investment banker and former utilities executive, died today at his home in Haverford at the age of 71.

A statement of apology for any offense that may have been given during last Sunday's program, when the Mae West sketch, "Adam and Eve," resulted in protests, was read last night during the Chase Sanborn Company's period on a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Brien McMahon, Assistant United States Attorney General, addressing the closing session of the National Lawyears Guild, today inclined to the view that a clarifying amendment to the Byrnes act banning transporstation of strike-breakers was preferable to passing comprehensive legislation licensing detective agencies which furnish strike-breakers.

The thesis that it is more difficult to receive than to give was advanced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street in his morning sermon.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 28 per cent of capacity, marking the first absence of a weekly decline since the precipitous drop began in the early days of September. The total decline in the period was 56 points, or two-thirds.
Hartford has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Barbara Marie Brandt, to John Milton Pratt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo Todd Pratt of this city.

Phil Furr, Washington (D. C.) welterweight, will trade punches with the rugged Frankie Cavanna of the East Side in the top bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight. Cavanna recently fought a draw with Baby (Salvy) Saban, while Furr is credited with having gone fifteen rounds against Barney Ross in an over-the-weight encnunter.

Colin McDonald's dispatches to The Times of London on the sinking of the Panay were brought to the notice of the German public today in dispatches from the London correspondents of the Frankfurter Zeitung and the Hamburger Fremdenblatt.
Arthur Esdaile MacGregor, news editor of The Daily Telegraph and Morning Post, died today, a few hours after he had collapsed at his desk early in the morning. His age was 51.

Swift Co., in a report for the year ended on Oct. 30, to be made public today, shows a net profit of $8,880,496 after expenses, depreciation, depletion, interest and taxes, including surtax on undistributed earnings.

Large quantities of youthful enthusiasm were combined with generous portions of the charitable spirit of Christmas yesterday afternoon to form a spectacle that the startled residents of West 1OOth Street are not likely to forget soon.

The engagement of Miss Patricia Woolsey, daughter of Mrs. Theodore Salisbury Woolsey of this city and the late Mr. Woolsey, to Lionel Stewart Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Day Jackson, also of New Haven, has been announced by her mother.

French imports amounted to 3,931,000,000 francs in November, compared to 3,720,000,000 francs in October and 2,699,000,000 francs in November, 1936. Exports were 2,382,000,000 francs, against 2,363,000,000 francs in October and 1,710,000,000 francs a year ago.
With the popularity of siding sweeping on during the last four years, perplexing problems having to do with a healthy development of the sport have cropped up.

The Delaware State Federation of Labor today ousted William D. Hart as president. John J. McBride Jr. of Washington, special representative of the American Federation of Labor, said that the removal was authorized by the A. F. of L. executive committee for "conduct unbecoming an officer of a labor organization."
After the market fell early in the week in reflection of the incidents in the Yangtze River in China, sentiment improved and stocks recovered partly.

Rube Marquard, who pitched nineteen- consecutive victories for the Giants in 1912, returned to the mound for two innings today-and decided his once-mighty left arm was better suited to dealing parimutuel tickets.

Despite persistent press reports and rumors of the dismissal of the Cabinet of Mustafa Nahas Pasha by King Farouk and while relations between the palace and the Cabinet are tense the situation has not yet reached the point either of dismissal or the Cabhinet's resignation.
For the first time since the inaugural match in April, 1930, Philadelphia's court tennis team carried off the Payne Whitney Memorial Trophy today.
The Irish-Americans of Kearny, N. J., turned back the national champion New York Americans in an American Soccer League fixture yesterday at Starlight Park, the Bronx, before 4,000 fans, 2 to 1.

Dr. Albert Howard Wallace, former head of the dental staff of the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, died here today at his residence, 203 Bellevue Avenue, after an illness of five months. He was 61 years old.
An official radio broadcast tonight announced completion of a new 1,800mile railroad paralleling the Far Eastern section of the Trans-Siberian railway.

Campaigns now being launched for resorts, rail and steamship travel will be about equal to those of a year ago, with the main increase shown in the promotion of ski trains, according to agency executives.
Miss Ellen L. Haines, superintendent of women's work at the Madison Square Church House from 1892 until her retirement in 1933, died yesterday at her residence, 138 East Ninety-fourth Street.

The Sterling National Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee of $1,320,000 mortgage certificates on premises of ParkEighty-third Street Corporation in connection with the reorganization of an issue of the Prudence-Bonds Corporation certificates known as "983 Park Avenue Issue."

After wasting numerous opportunities to make inroads on the champion's huge lead, Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., finally recorded his initial triumph over Ralph Greenleaf of New York, annexing the eighth block of their match for the world pocket billiard crown,--133-128, last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

Announcing a design-in-merchandise program for the New York World's Fair 1939, Grover Whalen, president, reported today plans have been developed whereby manufacturers of all types of merchandise -can employ designs, insignia and terminology inspired and controlled by the fair.
The Paterson Panthers defeated the White Plains Bears, co-champions with Newark of the American Football Association, 20-0, before 4.000 fans today.
Four dance recitals on yesterday's schedule made of it quite the busiest day of the season thus far, though it put no apparent strain upon the attendance in general.

Dr. William C. Buntin, Sanitary Superintendent of the Health Department in Staten Island, and as such head of the department in that borough, died yesterday at Staten Island Hospital in New Brighton after a few days' illness. His age was 58.

Isaac I. Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, gained his second victory in the club's annual title tournament yesterday when he defeated Oscar Tenner in fortyeight moves. The opening was a Ruy Lopez adopted by Kashdan, who outmanoeuvred his opponent in the middle game.
Dense fog and ice-bound roads today sent London's traffic waltzing in a dizzy fashion and caused numerous accidents.
Confidence in a good dog was rewarded this afternoon when Ring of Rufdale wdn the silver trophy for best dog in the open stake of the second Winter meeting of the Dutchess County Field Trial Club.

Mrs. Eva Johnson, 46-year-old Negro who conducts a "Church of the Living God" in Brooklyn, interrupted a solemn high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday by rising from a rear pew to jabber an unintelligible series of sounds which she said later was a "message from God in Hebrew."
Lieut. Col. Edward Ellis Farnsworth, U.S.A. (retired), former member of the Maine State Highway Commission, died late last night in his South Portland home of a heart attack at the age of 57.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden hastened today to send Mrs. Robert W. Bingham personal messages of sympathy as well as their official condolences, which were cabled to Washington on the death of Ambassador Bingham.

A platform for the United Democracy, which under the leadership of Charles V. Halley Jr. hopes to reorganize the Democratic party locally, was put forward yesterday by Mr. Halley after a conference at the National Democratic Club.

The Merchants Association published yesterday the results of a survey of developments in the facilities for the handling of passenger and freight traffic in New York City during the last forty years which, according to William H. Chandler, traffic manager of the association, provides ample proof that the city has kept abreast of needs.

Joseph Scully of 31-24 137th Street, Flushing, Queens, driver of a mail truck for the Flushing postoffice, proved an efficient aide to Santa Claus yesterday afternoon, when by prompt action he saved a large quantity of Christmas mail in his truck from destruction by fire.

William Dyeser, 70 years old, a retired Chicago laundry owner who had been living with his daughter, Mrs. Goodell Hill, at 135 Whitehall Boulevard here, was found dead about noon today seated in an automobile in the Hill garage.

Appointment of Basil O'Connor, former law partner of President Roosevelt, as general chairman of the New York City Fight Paralysis Campaign, which will culminate Jan. 29 in the annual Birthday Balls and other fund-raising entertainments, was. announced yesterday by Keith Morgan, national chairman.

Two goals scored during the tenminute overtime period gave the Baltimore Orioles a 3-to-1 victory over the New York Rovers yesterday afternoon in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden.

International justice is unworthy of the name as long as minority peoples are allowed to be crushed and segregated, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora said last night at the annual conference dinner of the Council of Jewish Organizations for Palestine, in the Hotel Astor.

A race far more important than the Kentucky Derby or the Grand National Steeplechase is now in inconspicuous progress in this country. It is the race between the business cycle and the patience of the President.
The army, Royal Air Force and armed police today combed half of Palestine in manoeuvres that were combined with a search for terrorists.

While Postmaster General Farley was unable to prevent the abolishment of the postoffice in his native town of Grassy Point, N. Y., he did save the postoffice at Lincoln, Indiana, for a newspaper correspondent, it was revealed by letters made public today.

The broadest export demand for this country's corn since 1929 has become a market influence, and with Southern points bidding relatively high prices for the cash grain, the movement has been diverted to the Gulf of Mexico for tile time being.

The misfortunes that have followed Hunter Lott Jr. of the Philadelphia Country Club in squash racquets competition came to an abrupt end today. Lott won the annual Ardsley Country Club invitation tournament by defeating Donald Strachan,

Price reductions of 3 to 11 cents per pound on finer denier viscose process rayon yarns, with no change in the 150-denier and larger sizes, are announced today by the American Viscose Corporation. The differential of 2 cents formerly existing on "Chalkelle" yarns has been cut to 1 cent.
Charles Altman, 42 years old, formerly of Far Rockaway, Queens, was brought here today from Milwaukee to face an eleven-year-old indictment for grand larceny.

Miss Hannita E. Blackfan Janney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Allison Janney of 644 Salem Avenue, was introduced to society yesterday at a reception given by her parents and her grandmother, Mrs. Robert Field Stockton, at their home here.

Fire resulting from an accidentally dropped cigarette this morning destroyed the Theta Delta Chi fraternity house at Hobart. The seventeen members of the fraternity sleeping in the house all were saved without injury. Damage estimated at more than $35,000 is partly covered by insurance.

Japan's religion plays a part in her present foreign policy, declared the Right Rev. Shirley H. Nichols, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Kyoto, Japan, in a sermon yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

Mrs. Frank Melville gave a reception yesterday at her home, 1,060 Fifth Avenue, to introduce to society her granddaughter, Miss Margaret Melville, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Melville, who will give a dance for her on Dec. 27 at Sherry's.
The first formal luncheon dance of the season today marked the opening of the Surf Club here. Mrs. Mercer P. Moseley of New York was among those who entertained.
Chris Cagle's All-Stars went down to defeat, 13 to 0, before the Newark Tornadoes, co-champions of the American Professional, Football Association. in a charity game today.

ADAMS--Jennie Quimby, on Dec. 18, 1937, wife of the late Walker B. Adams and mother of William B., Edna M. and Robert K. Adams, in her ninetieth year. Funeral at her late residence, Bedford Hills, N. Y., Tuesday. Dec. 21, 1937, at 2:30 P. M.

General Erich Ludendorff, German World War commander, died today. He was 72 years old. The aged warrior had been operated on Nov. 29 for a bladder ailment. He had been recuperating until last night when his conedition took a sudden turn for the worse.

Mayor Allen H. Bagg, who is retiring. Jan. 3 after four years in office, said today the municipal debt had been reduced $1,129,200 during that period, and that there would be a surplus of more than $250,000 on Jan. 1.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 83.9, which compares with 84.3 a week ago, 84.6 two weeks ago, 85.1 three weeks ago and 86.1 four weeks ago.
Onehalf of the native white families in New York City had incomes of less than $1,814 in 1935-36, Isador Lubin, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, reported today.
Commissioner David C. Adie of the State Social Welfare Department said yesterday in Brooklyn that half the institutions for children in New York had passed into obsolescence.

Declaring that the press "can make or break" a war and that the American people are "idiots enough" to be "dragged into war by newspaper propaganda," Albert Payson Terhune, the author, called upon the nation's press today to "keep its head so that the populace will keep its head."

Charles Abrams, counsel to the American Federation of Housing Authorities, charged last night in a radio address that New York City was not doing its share to support the low-cost housing program in the city.

Anthony Cocorikes, restaurant, store at 1,650 Lexington Ave; Joseph Viviano, barber, store at 1,971 2d Ave; Nicholas Leydecker, baker, store at 1,975 2d Ave; Joseph Drennan, linoleum, store at 927 Columbus Ave; Edwin E. Tanzer. Inc, broker.
The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today that checks for the dividend of 112 per cent, or 75 cents a share, payable to holders of record of Nov. 20, would reach about 215,000 stockholders tomorrow.

Dr. and Mrs. Leslie Albert Spelman of this city have announced the coming marriage of their daughter, Miss Barbara Alice Spelman, to Richard Baylis Schutz, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward G. Schutz of Buffalo, N. Y. The ceremony will take place on the afternoon of Jan. 8 in Christ Church Cathedral.

There may be a monetary squeeze in the last few days of the year, but conditions in Lombard Street now are etremely easy and there is little doubt that the Bank of England will handle the year-end position with its usual success.

In the letter from that great leader in the field of human needs, Solomon Lowenstein, published today on the Neediest Fund page, he speaks of the appeal of the vivid stories which remind us how "deeply personal" and varying the suffering may be for each family.

The Papal decoration, Pro- Ecclesia et Pontifice, granted to Mrs. Sarah S. Collier by Pope Plus XI in recognition of her activities on behalf of the Catholic Church, was presented to Mrs. Collier yesterday by Cardinal Hayes in his residence at 452 Madison Avenue.
Total revenue of the electric light and power industry from ultimate r consumers for October was $186,456,100, a gain of 5.1 per cent, comnared with $177.392,700 a year ago.

A sealed verdict for $21,000 against Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, and Louis E. Depew, her chauffeur, was handed up today by a jury before Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson.

A powerful weapon for prosecution of the underworld was lost to the government today when the Supreme Court ruled, in a seven-to-two decision, that evidence obtained by tapping telephone wires cannot be used in criminal trials.

Twenty-eight members of the Police Department who have performed "meritorious service" in drowning cases during the year will receive medals and cash awards at a ceremony to be held today at 10 A. M. in the gymnasium at Police Headquarters.

The Long Island University basketball team received its first setback of the season last night, bowing to Marshall College of West Virginia at the Brooklyn Pharmacy gymnasium, 50 to 40. The Blackbirds trailed by 35-16 at half-time.

Mrs. Virginia Evans Gregory, wife of Julian A. Gregory, former Mayor of this city and one-time member of the Port of New York Authority, died Saturday at their Summer home in Wilton, Conn., after a long illness.

Miss Ida Louise Larkin made her debut last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center at a dinner dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Larkin. She received with her parents and her sister, Miss Henrietta A. Larkin, in a foyer decorated with ferns and

Two army Reserve fliers, attached to the 116th Observation Squadron here, were killed today when their plane fell near Fort Mitchell, Ala. Officers who went to the scene reported by telephone to Captain James P. Wharton, public relations officer, that the victims were Second Lieutenant James E. Darby of Chicago, Ill., and Second Lieutenant Sterling S. Tatum of Siluria, Ala.

Two gleaming aluminum street cars glided lightly over the rails of the Broadway run of the Third Avenue Railway System yesterday in the first tryout of a fleet of trolleys designed to give the road's patrons the comfort, speed and convenience of bus transportation. By early Spring fifty of the streamlined cars will be in operation.

A grand jury today called four Cleveland labor leaders "unprincipled racketeers" and charged them with "exacting tribute" by threatening to tie up construction work unless builders met demands totaling $4,800.

Johnny Townsend, a one-man basketball show, paced the University of Michigan to a 42-to-17 triumph over previously undefeated Dartmouth tonight in an intersec tional battle on the neutral court of the Westchester County Center before a capacity throng of 5,000.

In a letter sent yesterday to Harry Uviller, administrator and impartial chairman of the dress industry, Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, pointed out the large number of liquidations and contemplated liquidations in the industry and urged that the labor unions be impressed with the need for easing the obligations of collective agreements in cases where these manufacturers desire to resume business.

Mrs. Enid Dickens Hawksley was the guest of honor last night at the Hotel Astor at a dinner commemorating the 100th anniversary of the friendship of her grandfather, Charles Dickens, with Washington Irving.

Jacques Deval's "Soubrette," which Paramount purchased the other day, will serve as a starring vehicle for Franceska Gaal. It will be her fourth picture with the studio; "Buccaneer" being the first, with "Never Say Die" with Jack Benny and "Paris Honeymoon" with Bing Crosby next on her schedule.
There are certain platform and campaign pledges which for various reasons are abandoned by those elected to public office in all the American parties. Sometimes,

A slender Negro girl, her eyes hidden by almost opaque glasses, stood before several hundred school children, parents and teachers yesterday morning and read an essay on "What. Are My Responsibilities as a Citizen in the Occupation Which I May Choose?"

Four days before Christmas the Neediest Cases Funds stands at $179,768.28. Contributions from 469 donors amounting to $9,237.40 brought it yesterday to that total. Unless the tide of giving rises far higher in the few days remaining, it seems inevitable that many of the

Hearings will be held on the Marine Union Investors, Inc., as well as its predecessors and affiliates, at the offices of the Securities and Exchange Commission here on. Wednesday, and on the Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland and its subsidiaries and affiliates on Thursday, the commission announced today.

Waiters being brought here to work in the Bermudiana Hotel during the Winter season helped out in the dining room of the liner Queen of Bermuda on the ship's last run here from New York. They took the places of ninety stewards who went on strike before the ship left New York last Saturday.

The principle that workers may strike only when it does not inconvenience other workers was arbitrarily established here today when stable boys at the Joinville racing center struck for more pay and the benefits of the forty-hour week.

After an hour's debate, a motion to bar the type of rig introduced by the German entry in the world championship regatta last Summer from the waters over which it has jurisdiction was voted down last night at a meeting and dinner of the Western Long Island Sound Fleet of the International Star Class at the Williams Club.

Miss Barbara Nazro Orvis, daughter of Mrs. Hardin Orvis, was Antroduced to society yesterday at a tea dance given for her at the Colony Club by her mother and grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Waitstill Orvis.

After having charged in a report last evening that the United States gunboat Panay had "fired three cannon shots at a Japanese Army unit" before she was sunk by Japanese aerial bombs on Dec. 12, Major Gen. Kumakichi Harada, Japanese Military Attache here, made a grudging and partial retraction of the accusation today.

The annual report of the Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia, which was presented to sharehold ers at their annual meeting in Philadelphia yesterday, showed net profits of $1,873,853 for the year ended on Nov. 30.
Organization of a national conference to investigate the petroleum industry, especially from the standpoint of the consumer, was completed here today by representatives of twentythree States.

The Amateur Athletic Union will assume jurisdiction over all amateur cycling in the United States starting tomorrow, it was announced yesterday. Formerly an alliance existed between the A. A. U. and the National Cycling Association, but the .decision to terminate this arrangement was made at the recent convention of the A. A. U. in Boston.
Washington PI, 7, 4-story loft and store building, 25x100; Martha A. Moran against Bayside Holding Corp; due, $31,941; taxes, , $8,222; to plaintiff for $28,000.

Angered because a leg of lamb was not cooked to his liking, William Egan, 41 years old, superintendent of the apartment building at 102 West Ninety-ninth Street, hurled a teacup at his wife, Bridget, at dinner Sunday night.

A study of the Interstate Commerce Commission's records today showed how the various railroads in the East would benefit from an increase of a half-cent a mile in coach fares which the railroads have requested of the commission.
Robert Fechner, Civilian Conservation Corps director, said today that the country has 2,300,000 youths trained in CCC camps who are ready to act as a volunteer army in an emergency.

With the issuance of a Federal fugitive warrant this afternoon against Wendell F. Bowers, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined actively in the search for the 19-year-old reformatory parolee accused of murdering Mrs. Wilma V.

With an exhibition of perfect position play, Ralph Greenleaf of New York made an unfinished run of 122 in the tenth block of his world pocket billiard championship match against Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., last night at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy to win the game by 125 to 1 in four innings.

Revised rules governing "when issued" trading on Stock Exchanges, effective on Jan. 3, were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The changes, which were regarded here as largely inconsequential. were promulgated after conferences with representatives of the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges, according to representatives of the commission.
Harry Pincus, 30 years old, an exconvict, who formerly lived at 1,411 Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Koenig in General Sessions to thirty to sixty years in Sing Sing.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:
Charles A. Munn and Gurnee Munn of the Palm Beach colony were here today to see the opening races at Tropical Park, coming down in their private plane. William Vincent Dwyer of New York,
Phil Furr, 149 pounds, of Washington, last night won the decision from Bill Lancaster, 148, Spokane, Wash., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace before a crowd of 2,500.

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg was elected honorary chairman of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, succeeding her late husband, at the annual meeting yesterday of the committee's board of directors at its headquarters at 100 East Forty-second Street.
The Treasury's three-cornered monetary policy is working "extremely well," Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference this afternoon.

Although Japanese troops were preparing to land in South China near Canton today, the British Government maintained an almost phlegmatic attitude toward the Far Eastern situation in general and the position of Hong Kong in particular.

Forty-seven of the persons who counted the proportional representation ballots for the City Council had police records, it was learned yesterday. Of these thirtynine had been convicted of crimes ranging from burglary, grand larceny, illegal pistol carrying, bookmaking and policy slip selling to putting slugs in subway turnstiles.

Bowlers held the upper hand today in the Sheffield Shield cricket match between New South Wales and South Australia. Replying to New South Wales' scores of 337 and 104 the home team made 217 and 34 runs for three wickets.

The Senate tonight approved the long-pending amnesty bill with Senate amendments designed to liberate every political prisoner in Cuba. Considered sweeping in effect when passed by the House of Representatives last May, the law has now been broadened to include gangsters and terrorists.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Ebert K. Burlew to be First Assistant Secretary of the Interior, to succeed the late Theodore A. Walters.
New York boys gained an even break in four intercity contests with Boston boxers at the semimonthly amateur boxing show conducted at the New York. Athletic Club last night.
According to Mr. Robert Burns, an expert of considerable experience, whisky is "soul o' plays an' pranks." Doubtless the same is true of its congeners and collaterals.
Criminal prosecution of sixty-three men and women arrested in the Memorial Day steel strike riot, in which ten were killed, ended today.

An important part of the program which he has laid out for himself in his coming term as president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards will be to call together at the conference board representatives of every group concerned with home-building, Joseph Catharine, president-elect, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Manhattan chapter of the association, in the Hotel Commodore.

The need for "every responsible city officer" to have first-hand knowledge of municipal departments was pointed out yesterday on a tour of Health Department facilities by ten of the newly elected members of the Board of Estimate and the City Council.

Madison Square Garden will be the scene of a traditional scholastic hockey struggle this afternoon. The occasion will be the annual Christmas holiday visit of-the St. Paul's School sextet from Concord, N. H., the institution that is known as the "cradle of American hockey."

Twenty-five men in a motorcade of workers on the way to the labortroubled Ford assembly plant were arrested today after sheriff's deputies had searched them and reported seizure of shotguns, pistols and blackjacks.
Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, visited the sale of articles made by the blind, now being held at 475 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon and purchased many articles.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward Livingston Montgomery of Scarsdale entertained last night at Sherry's with a dinner dance at which they introduced to society their daughter, Miss Nancy Eglington Montgomery. Receiving with her mother in a bower of smilax,

SOMEWHAT over a year ago, when the Presidential campaign was at its height, Ernest Martin Hopkins wrote an article for The Atlantic Monthly. This article declared, among other things, that the United States was going to the dogs.

Miss Susanna Larter, daughter of Mrs. Henry C. Larter of this city, became the bride tonight of Clarence Dickinson Long Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Dickinson Long of Fairfield, N. J. The ceremony, which was performed at the Larter home

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Elmer H. Schwarz of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Schwarz, to Walter Theodore Rittenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rittenberg of New York.

Authors sometimes have a strange tenderness, not shared by their public, for some production of theirs. Lord Baldwin's gift to the British Museum of Kipling's "Recessional" brings out the singular case of a masterpiece rejected. Mr. Bell,

Passengers arriving today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania include Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pulitzer, Ralph Pulitzer, Lord Graves of Wallington, Sir Henry Barclay Harvey, the Hon. Wilfred Egerton, Stephen Szekely, Hungarian film director, with Mrs. Szekely;
A call for a nonpartisan coalition to help private enterprise fight the business recession and stave off collectivism was sounded in the Senate today by Senator Bailey of North Carolina.

Mr. and Mrs. Marion Eppley gave a dinner dance last night at the Colony Club for Miss Mary Q. Weeks, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Shelton Weeks. Mrs. Robert Watts, who has been living abroad for the past year and a half, will return tomorrow on the Bremen for a visit with her son-inlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Campbell Wallace, at 960 Park Avenue.

Abraham Goldfeld, chairman of the housing section of the Welfare Council, will discuss tenant activities in low-rent housing projects on the City-Wide Tenants Council program over radio Station WNEW at 4:30 P. M. tomorrow.

John A. Condon, president and secretary of an insurance company which bore his name, died at New Haven Hospital today at the age of 56. He was struck and seriously injured by an automobile a week ago.

Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Delaware and Subsidiaries--Twelve months to Oct. 31: Net income after all expenses and charges $1,486,568, against $1,813,280 in the twelve months to Oct. 31, 1936; gross revenues,

BURNETT, JENNIE H. (Oct. 30). Estate, less than $1,000. To Gilbert Burnett, 1.238 W. 62d St., Los Angeles, Calif., specific cash account; seventeen varying bequests; Helen G. H. Estelle, niece, executrix, 137 Academy St., Poughkeepsie, N. Y., specific cash account.
President Gerald P. Nugent of the Philadelphia National League Baseba Club announced today he had obtained Al Smith, former Giant pitcher, from the Cardinals via waivers.

Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and co-author of the KelloggBriand peace pact, was said by his physician late today to have rallied from the attack of pneumonia with which he was critically ill over the week-end.
Lt. Hugh McGrade, from 8th Division to 45th Precinct, assignment to desk duty continued.

Results of the Weirton Steel Com pany's independent union election held Friday and tabulated today showed, according to John Larkin, president, that 9,500 of the 9,928 workers had voted for the Employes Representative Plan Union.

Senator Reynolds of North Carolina introduced a bill today for the prompt deportation of alien spies. He called attention to printed reports that President Roosevelt was seeking legislation to protect vital defense works from photographing by aliens, and said aliens were "constantly making motion pictures and still pictures of our fortifications."
Ernest Mortimer, manufacturer, president of the M. P. Company of Derby, Conn., died today of a heart attack at his home, 300 Ogden Street.
The stock market here was generally quiet today as the approach of the holidays restricted business in most sections. Gilt-edge issues were unchanged and foreign bonds had a dull day.

Brig. Gen. Alston Hamilton, U.S.A., retired, died at Aberdeen Proving Ground, Md., on Saturday at the age of 66, the War Department announced today. He was widely known as an expert in ballistics and gunnery and for writings on those two subjects.

A fixed schedule of minimum prices for coal loaded in trucks or wagons at the mines of code members in eight districts, all of them east of the Mississippi River except Iowa, and which will become effective at 12:01 A. M. on Jan. 3, 1938, were issued today by the National Bituminous Coal Commission as follows:
Three hundred American and British women and children attempting to flee war threats in Central China today were turned back by a military boom obstructing passage down the Yangtze River.
When Minnesota arrives here for its games with Eastern rivals, the coach of the team will be returning to familiar haunts. Dave MacMillan, pilot of the Gophers is well known to metropolitan fans.

Automotive advertising rill receive a much-desired stimulant shortly after the turn of the year, if current plans reported from Detroit materialize, according to agency executives yesterday. Several companies are planning to redesign front ends of their car and

Dwight School's basketball team accounted for its seventh victory in eight starts this season by turning back the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute's freshman quintet, 30 to 24, on the Seventy-first Regiment Armory court yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth MacPherran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Withrow MacPherran of Duluth, Minn., was married to Frederick Leas Worcester of Zamboanga, P. I., son of Mrs. Dean Conant Worcester of Manila and the late Mr. Worcester,

Assertions that politicians and police are linked with racketeering in Boston p were made by Police Commissioner Joseph F. Timilty today as he pressed the inquiry into the slaying of David J. (Beano).Breen, racketeer.

Net profit of Armour Co., Illinois, and subsidiaries for the year ended on Oct. 30 amounted to $9,712,792 after depreciation, interest, amortization, contribution to employes' pension fund, Federal income taxes, minority interest, $35,000 provision for Federal surtax on
The Cabinet this afternoon fixed the price so gasoline in Havana at 291/2 cents a gallon until Congress approves regulatory legislation. ry legislation.

In order to save farm workers from death from the bites of the bushmaster, coral, fer de lance, and other poisonous snakes, Provisional President Alberto Enriquez has issued a decree compelling employers to maintain a supply of anti-venom serum.

Villanova scored its sixth straight basketball victory tonight by defeating Springfield, 47-36. The Wildcats showed a brilliant passing game in turning back the Maroons. Duzminski garnered 18 points for the visitors from a guard position and was the star of the game.

Another neighborhood mining organization was added this week to the rapidly growing group, which includes Bishop, Cima, Barstow, San Bernardino and Julian, when thirty mining men here organized the TriState Miners Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Gurney of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Esther Gurney, to William Cruikshank, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Cruikshank, also of Garden City. Miss Gurney was graduated from the Cathedral School of St. Mary

Some of the country's greatest railroad systems, most prominent lawyers, insurance companies and many of the strongest banks and investment houses were subjected to scathing criticism in the Senate today in connection with the railroad situation.
Elimination of the center jump has made basketball a faster and more exciting game to watch and "saved" the sport, Clement M. Eyler, a member of the national rules committee, said today.

Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky, in Manhattan Traffic Court yesterday, lectured a patrolman for giving a summons to the chauffeur of an 82-year-old broker who had doubleparked while his employer was shopping for flowers.

The government joined today the Electrick Bond and Share Company in seeking a quick Supreme Court decision on the constitutionality of the 1935 act regulating public utility holding companies.

The moderate recovery in the securities markets yesterday was considered to be due partly to a technical correction following several months of declining prices. Nevertheless, it was such as to cause a slightly more optimistic feeling in the financial community.

Several leases for large quarters were among those reported by brokers yesterday. Included was one for an entire floor, consisting of 10,000 square feet, in the building at 410 East Thirty-second Street, taken by Molla, Inc.,

Miss Mary van voornees was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance which her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Tracy S. Voorhees of 184 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, gave for her in the Neptune Room of the Pierre. The debutante wore a gown of white. embroidered in gold,

Joseph E. Frowde Seagram has been elected president of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Ltd., founded by his grandfather eighty years ago, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Seagram carries into the third generation the tradition that the eldest son shall succeed the father as head of the Sea?? organization.

Business buying must be encouraged if payrolls are to expand and consumer. purchasing power is to increase, William J. Kelly, president of the Machinery Institute, declared today in a statement in connection with

Automobile production continued to ease off last week, but the decline was smaller than anticipated on the basis of seasonal trend, and the adjusted index rose to 91.4 from 89.0. The figure was 104.7 for the week ended Dec. 19. 1936.

Illinois, co-champion of the Big Ten, suffered a surprising setback tonight when Temple University's basketball team rolled up a 51-38 score against the Midwesterners at the Arena in the second game of a double-header before 5,000 fans.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that a portrait of Andrew W. Mellon, former Republican Secretary, soon would displace that of Democratic Senator William G. McAdoo of California in the Secretary of the Treasury's reception room.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was among the hundreds of visitors yesterday at the Harlem Community Art Center, 290 Lenox Avenue, the first free center of fine arts in Harlem, which was formally opened last night. The center,

The marriage of Mrs. Christine Urquhart Livingston of 118 East Ninety-third Street, daughter of Mrs. Andrew Urquhart of Vancouver, B. C., and the late Mr. Urquhart, to Crawford Fairbanks Failey of Terre Haute, Ind., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Failey,
Now starring in "Barchester Towers," Ina Claire yesterday disclosed that her next Broadway appearance was virtually certain to be in Frederick Lonsdale's new play "Half a Loaf." Gilbert Miller,

A 1938 Westchester County gross budget of $11,750,382, fourteen special district budgets totaling $3,363,696 and a capital improvement budget of $907,733 were submitted to the Board of Supervisors here today by its Budget and Appropriations Committee.
Mrs. Houston Dunn, former president of the Pennsylvania Grand Opera Company, died at her home here today after a long illness. She had suffered two strokes within the last year. Her age was 57.

Upon reading your editorial "Our Silicosis Record," I find that the information contained therein is inaccurate. The War Office announces that Freetown, Sierra Leone, West Africa, is again to have a regular garrison in peace to man its coast defenses. Certain modifications and additions will be made to adapt the defenses to modern requirements.

Although snow conditions are not now conducive to good skiing in the north country with the exception of the Canadian Laurentlans, the railroads have added extra trains to their holiday schedule in anticipation of a white Christmas in the Berkshire, Poconos, Catskills and the Green and White Mountains.
With earnings for the last three months of the year estimated, the Pullman Company, sleeping and parlor car operating subsidiary of Pullman, Inc.,

Interest in city realty as reflected in the transactions reported yesterday was confined to residential properties of various types. The five-story apartment building at 302 East Eighty-third Street, adjoining the southeast corner

Some days must still elapse before the American and British notes to Japan can be answered, a Foreign Office spokesman stated tonight. The delay is principally, though not entirely, due to confusion which prevailed on the Yangtze between Nanking and Wuhu on the day of the incidents.

Domestic manufacturers had 224 locomotives on order on Dec. 1, of which 161 were steam, 26 electric and 37 oil-electric, against a total of 342 on order a year previously, according to the Department of Commerce.

The 401st in his series of Musical Mornings was given by Albert Morris Bagby yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Miss Lily Pons of the Metropolitan Opera Company; Jussi Bjoerling, -Swedish tenor, and Beveridge Webster, pianist.

Julian C. Smith, president of the Quebec Power Company, announced yesterday that a special meeting of shareholders had been called for Dec. 28 to approve a by-law which, while technically involving a reduction of capital, has for its real object a simplification of the comnany's balance sheet.
The receipt of $142,800 gold from Bolivia was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Jim Londos, 200, Greece, pinned Billy Hanson, 218, Salt Lake City, with an airplane spin and body press in 34:32 of the star wrestling attraction at the New York Hippodrome last night. A crowd of 3,000 was present.

Sensational results were not to have been expected from the tour, just completed, of the French Foreign Minister M. Delbos to the succession StatesPoland, Rumania, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia--beneficiaries of the peace treaties.
Athletic officials of Marietta College sought leading national row ing crews today as entrants in an Ohio River regatta to be held in July as part of the Northwest Territory celebration.
President Roosevelt conferred with Senate and House leaders on legislative progress and kept in touch with the Far Eastern situation.

All salaried employes of P. Ballantine Sons will receive a 15 per cent bonus today. Bishop Oil The Bishop Oil Company has paid a year-end cash bonus to all employes in California, Texas, Oklahoma and Kansas, based on the length of service.

THE ??ant life of a ball player is always a more or less fascinating piece of business. For unlike the nomadic tribes among the Arabs who roam where they please, your average ball player just roams and roams where he is told.

INSPECTOR OF RAILWAY SIGNALING AND TRAIN CONTROL, $3,800 a year, Interstate Commerce Commission. Wyoming.

A man tentatively identified through letters in his pockets as Joseph Dorfman, of 750 Morton Street, Dorchester, Mass., was killed when he fell or jumped to the roof of the mezzanine floor extension of the Hotel Times Square, Eighth Avenue and Forty-third Street,

The Rev. William Clark Wilkins, rector of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, this city, died last night at Christ Hospital. He had undergone two operations for ulcers of the stomach in the last two weeks.

Wheat prices fluctuated erratically on the Board of Trade here today within a range of around 1 1/4 cents a bushel. Holiday dullness was strongly in evidence and the market was easily influenced by small operations on either side.
Dollar Line officials said today a cablegram reported the luxury liner Hoover, aground- off Hoishoto Island, had weathered a severe blow and that the captain and a crew of twenty were standing by.

Before leaving for Cannes today the Duke and Duchess of Windsor visited some of their intimate friends, but found that United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt was not at home, as he had gone to Cherbourg to meet his daughter Anne.
Harry L. Hopkins, national Relief Administrator, was in "very good condition" at St. Mary's Hospital this afternoon, his physicians said, seven hours after he underwent a major abdominal operation.

" Substantial cash rewards" will be granted to motorists for safe driving under a new system of liability insurance for private passenger vehicles, it was announced yesterday by the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters.

Miss Alice E. Bivins, Assistant Professor of Music Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, Amsterdam Avenue and 113th Street, after a two-month illness. Miss Bivins,

Reports that Inspector Harry L. Lobdell would be promoted to the rank of Deputy Chief Inspector and put in command of the Borough of Brooklyn brought a strong protest yesterday to Mayor La Guardia from representatives of organized labor.

Under the broadest buying movement since the low records of the season to date were reached last month, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved into new high ground yesterday and ended with gains of 11 to 18 points.

The La Guardia administration chose the dinner of the Citizens Budget Commission, held last night at the Hotel Biltmore, for its first avowal that it would seek a change in the Home Rule Amendment of the State Constitution at the coming Constitutional Convention.

For a few tantalizing moments the British Broadcasting Corporation, created to protect the British public from commercialized programs, relayed tonight throughout the United Kingdom the voice. of an American announcer giving an advertising talk.
The Brazilian Government has notified Dillon, Read Co. that the country's present economic situation compelled it to suspend remittances on its debt until a new agreement could be reached.

A threatened strike of 500 employes of the H. L. Green 'Company, operators of a chain of deapartment stores, was temporarily averted yesterday when representatives of the company and the Department Store Employes Union, affiliated with the C. I. O., reached a tentative agreement at a conference in the offices of the State Mediation Board, 366 Broadway.
The Princeton Tigers wrote a brilliant page in the college athletic record by defeating the University of Montreal tonight in an International Intercollegiate Hockey League game, 3 to 2.

Albert F. Houghton, retired partner of the publishing firm of Houghton Mifflin Company, 386 Fourth Avenue, died on Sunday at the Park West Hospital, 170 West Seventysixth Street, after a ten-day illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 425 West End Avenue.

Hobart's basketball team has been practicing diligently for the court campaign, which is listed to start on Jan. 11. The quintet will play thirteen games, only six of which will be contested on the home court at Geneva, N. Y.

It would seem odd to refer to George Gershwin's show at the Marie Harriman Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, as a memorial exhibition, in view of the fact that it is also his first. The famous American composer, who died last July, had been painting,

Samuel Jackson Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., whose stretch finishes are almost as famous as his powerful tee shots, came from behind again today to win the $3,500 Nassau open golf tournament with a seven?-two-hole score of 276.

The most important development yesterday in the ready-to-wear markets was -the unusual number of rush orders for fur coats to be given as gifts, manufacturers and resident offices reported. All types and price ranges were wanted, it was said,

Louis Tannenbaum, assistant advertising manager of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., will become advertising manager on Feb. 1. He started with Macy's in 1920 as a messenger and for the last fifteen years has risen steadily through the advertising department.

Popular demonstrations of sympathy with America in the Panay affair continue and increase in Japan. Twenty representatives of Tokyo organizations that have benefited from American generosity, including the Y. M. C. A., Y. W. C. A., mission schools, universities and good-will societies, yesterday decided to draft a letter of sympathy to President Roosevelt and organize the collection of relief funds.
The United States intends to keep its present military and naval forces in China for the protection of its nationals and interests, Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated today.
More than 300 children from five New York hospitals were taken to Times Square yesterday for Christmas parties organized by Mr. and Mrs. S. S. Rosen of 145 West Fifty-fifth Street.
ARMSTRONG, JOSEPH CARLOS (June 19, 1936). Gross assets, $4,260; net, $2,945. To Antonia Armstrong, mother. Chief assets, miscellaneous property, $3,102. Arthur Watson, attorney, 55 W. 42d St.

The Mexican Federal Government is expected shortly to nationalize formally for subdivision among farm laborers 45,000 acres of the Babicora ranch of William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper publisher.
Fire of undetermined origin early this morning destroyed South Hall, Skidmore College dormitory, with a loss estimated by Miss Katherine Starbuck, college secretary, at $100,000.
Simple funeral rites were performed here today for Robert Worth Bingham, United States Ambassador to Great Britain.

A new organization to preserve the democratic form of government in the United States-the American Union for Democracy-is being formed after a year of planning, it was announced yesterday by Charles I. Stewart, secretary of the union.

Six more industrial and business organizations have contracted with the New York World's Fair as exhibitors, Grover A. Whalen, fair president, announced yesterday. He made the announcement as Bernarr MaCfadden,

Influenced by high temperatures which made stores uncomfortable, trade in department stores on Saturday averaged about 8 per cent below that of the Saturday before Christmas last year and in several stores was 10 per cent lower, a check-up by store officials

A distribution of interest totaling $40,643 is being made to holders of mortgage certificates in the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company Issue 212,246, the security for which is the Labor Temple Building at the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street.
Sports' biggest disappointment In 1937 was Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean, participants in The Associated Press' seventh annual poll decided.

New York University has bought the former residence of the late Paul M. Warburg, 17 East Eightieth Street, and will convert it into an institute of fine arts, in which will be consolidated all the university's advanced art courses, museum programs and research activities in the fine arts.
Joseph Paul Bradshaw, New York stock broker, died today in the Orange Memorial Hospital at the age of 60. He lived at 217 South Street, Morristown.

Although other producers made no price changes yesterday on rayon, following the week-end announcement by American Viscose Corporation of lower prices on finer deniers and a sixty-day guarantee on all prices, some reductions were expected in the next few days, and two other producers announced guarantees yesterday.

Miss Barbara Field, daughter of Mrs. Diego Suares of 435 East Fifty-second Street, and of Marshall Field of this city and Chicago, was married to Anthony Addison Bliss yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

The Amoskeag Company has declared out of 1937 earnings a special dividend on the common stock of $2 a share. The company also announced an increase in the regular common dividend which will be paid in 1938 out of the 1937 income to $2 a share, compared with $1.75 a share paid this year.
The passing of General Erich Ludendorff marks the end of an era while it leaves a question of how far the lessons of his war career have been digested.

Miss New York, the new municipal ferryboat built by the United Shipbuilding Corporation at an approximate cost of $1,000,000, was launched yesterday at Mariners Harbor, S. I., before 1,500 persons, including city, State and county officials.

The first of two conferences between spokesmen of American ship operators and the maritime labor unions, at which methods of ending labor troubles in the shipping industry will be considered, will be held at 2:30 P. M. today at the offices of the American Steamship Owners Association, 11 Broadway.

" General Ludendorff, the great enemy of France, would have been an unmerciful victor," says the Paris Midi. The newspaper headlines an appreciation of the late German chieftain written by General Albert Niessel, who as a staff officer in the World War helped beat off the German March offensive in 1918 and, aided by American troops, the thrust against Chateau-Thierry in July, 1918.

Contending that no driver can operate a car safely at night at a speed faster than forty' miles an hour, New Jersey authorities will soon set that mark as an absolute limit for night driving, it was announced here today by Deputy

With an entry of 130 youngsters, one of the most representative groups ever to compete in the fixture, the draw for the annual national junior and boys' indoor tennis championships was announced yesterday at the office of the United States Lawn Tennis Association,

In line with its policy to give public recognition to sportsmen who devote themselves whole-heartedly to fish and game restoration work, the New York Rod and Gun Editors Association will select for special honor clubs or other groups of sportsmen that have carried on outstanding work in this field.

J. M. Kurn, co-trustee of the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway Company, announced today that Federal Judge George H. Moore had approved, in full, a $3,464,336 emergency improvement budget for the railroad in 1938.

American Equities Company common stock has been stricken from the list of the New York Curb Exchange. Dealings in it have been suspended since Dec. 8. Each share is exchangeable for one-tenth share of $3.50 prior-preferred stock, 1931 series, and one-half share of Class B stock of the International Utilities Corporation.

Western football stars who will play in the annual East-West charity game here New Year's day, assembled today under Co-coaches Major Lawrence (Biff) Jones of Nebraska and Orin (Babe) Hollingbery of Washington State College.

John G. Haas of New Rochelle died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital a few hours after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage in the Grand Central Station while on the way to his office at 165 Broadway. He was 56 years old.

The Medical Society of the County of New York, in cooperation with the legal profession, started a movement last night to abolish racketeering growing out of fraudulent accident and life insurance claims, to place expert medical testimony on a high plane of ethics, and to devise means for improving the present workings of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

Miss Phyllis Van Buren Richard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Richard of 1,060 Fifth Avenue and Millbury Meadow, York Harbor, Me., was introduced to society last night at a supper dance given by her parents in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 18, unless specified: Yangtze Entrance to Manila: Bulmer, Edsail, Parrott, Stewart. At San Diego: Lapwing, Sandpiper, Dec. 19; Cincinnati, Fox. Kanawha, Kingfisher, Permit, Pollack, Wright. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk.

A quiet little have book room in Sotheby's was the scene today of one of the most mantic literary sales in recent years, when Gabriel Wells of New York won the manuscript of "Peter Pan and Wendy" for the United States during the sale of Sir James Barrie's library.

Despite an estimated increase in traffic volume the accident, killed and injured figures of the Police Department for last week showed continued improvement as compared with the tables of a year ago, it was announced yesterday by First Deputy Commissioner Harold Fowler.
In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today:

The Treasury sold the first issue of its new series of bills at an average interest rate of 0.102, compared with an average rate of 0.124 on the last issue of the series of bills which terminated last week, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.
Nathan Mann, rugged young New Haven heavyweight, yesterday received an offer from Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S. C. for a bout with Joe Louis in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 23.

Premier Hepburn made public today correspondence, marked confidential, between the Ontario and Dominion governments relating to the St. Lawrence waterways project and Ontario's plan to divert water into the Great Lakes system.

For her house guests Mrs. George Finch-Hatton and Mrs. Walter Furman Schuyler, Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff gave a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club. Guests included Mrs. Phil H. Sawyer, Mrs. Walter W. Foskett, Mrs. George Angue Dobyne,

The full force of the administration leadership on Capitol Hill was thrown today behind the amendments to the Federal Housing Act in an effort to deliver them to President Roosevelt's desk before the special session adjourns for the Christmas holiday.

Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc., who last year purchased the four loft buildings at 400-06 Broadway, announces that a three-story structure will replace one and possibly two of those included in the purchase, and alterations are planned to refurbish and reduce those remaining to the same height.

A somewhat better atmosphere prevailed in the listed bond market yesterday as prices of many secondry and convertible corporate loans responded to a brisk demand with fair-sized gains. The movement in those Issues, however, be traced to the marked improvement in many sections of the stock market.

The Department of Agriculture predicted today that the average price of lambs in the current marketing season, December to April, for fed animals probably would be lower than in the comparable 1936-37 season.
In response to a demand from local hockey fans, Manager Red Dutton of the New York Americans has designated next Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden as Ching Johnson Night.
Charles S. Hayden, executive secretary of the Democratic Congressional Committee since 1932, died last night at his home in Falls Church, Va., after an illness of about a year. He was 57 years old.

The trustees of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company filed today a protest with the Interstate Commerce Commission against objections to the railroad's proposed issuance of $1,800,000 of trustees' certificates of indebtedness, and submitted to the commission by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Design: French Decorative Arts," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; Far Eastern Art (general tour), noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; 'Color: Pictures in Decoration," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Egypt: Har-em-hab and the Old Order," Edward L. M. Taggart, 4 P. M.

Miss Silvia Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould, and Charles Dabney Thomson of Cincinnati, who will be married on Jan. 14, were guests of honor at a dinner given last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza by Miss Barbara Symmes,
A conference to settle the strike of the Transport Workers Union against units of the Sunshine Radio System is scheduled for tomorrow morning in City Hall.
Major events tonight: The Oratorio Society in its annual performance of Handel's "Messiah" at Carnegie Hall and Isidor Gorn, pianist, at Town Hall.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck reversed yesterday a decision he had made a week ago and ruled that Mrs. Jean Hamilton Kenny of 930 Park Avenue was not entitled to alimony from her husband, Andrew T. H. Kenny, retired banker, pending trial of her separation suit.
Two members of the champion Giants and one Dodger gained individual fielding honors during the 1937 National League season, according to official averages announced yesterday.

Mrs. Cristiana Torlonia Lord, daughter of Princess Torlonia of 375 Park Avenue, New York,. and the late Don Marino, Duke of Torlonia of Rome, received a divorce today from Daniel Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Butler Lord. Mrs. Lord charged cruelty.

Not on many occasions in world history has an audience listened to a complete string orchestra and two quartets playing only upon Stradivari instruments. But this happened last night in Carnegie Hall, and it happened with a twofold purpose.

Edward T. Marlatt, principal of Hackensack High School until June of this year, died last night at his residence, Hudson View Gardens, Pinehurst Avenue and 183d Street, of heart disease. He was 64 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Willard U. Taylor gave a supper dance tonight at their home here for their daughter, Miss Mary M. Taylor. Among the guests were the Misses Ruth Bryan, Martha Hubbell, Jane Case, Elein Smith, Lucy Dimock, Edith Gwathmey, Maude Clark,

The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned before Dec. 13 amounted to 16,811,781 running bales, including 297,891 round bales, counted as half bales, and 8,555 of American-Egyptian.
Measures tending to regularize the foreign debt and also exchange control are the next major steps on President Getulio Vargas's "New Deal" slate.

Coming from behind in a speedy stretch run, J. Emery's Guinea Doria won the featured sixth race at the Fair Grounds today in a photo finish with Mrs. J. A. Nix's Hermone. Guinea Doric, who had- not won a race since Nov. 29 and had dropped steadily down in class, got a well-timed ride from Jockey Hanauer to win by a nose.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 23.5 per cent of capacity, compared to 27.4 per cent last week, marking the seventeenth consecutive week of decline in production if the Labor Day holiday be allowed for.
Three government columns were reported today to have captured the center of besieged Teruel, driving out the Insurgent defenders of the key city on the eastern front at bayonets' points.
On the heels of the execution of Leo M. Karakhan and seven other once prominent men as traitors, the Soviet regime celebrated today as the

Important step toward the Security and Exchange Commission's goal of self-government for the over-thecounter markets was believed to have been achieved today when William O. Douglas, chairman, conferred with representatives of leading organizations of security dealers.
Heirs of Captain John Seaman, a figure of Colonial days, failed today in the Supreme Court to win a review of their fight questioning the title to certain lands in and near Jones Beach Park.
It is reported from Belgrade, Yugoslavia, that Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch, who has just returned from Italy, where great efforts were made by armament firms to obtain orders from him,

A new three-year plan for the development of Turkish mining resources, particularly coal, chrome and copper has been approved by the Council of Ministers and will be undertaken immediately, it was announced today. Under the scheme it is hoped to increase the production of various Turkish mines.

With the placing during the week-end of a mural painting by the Spanish artist Jose Maria Sert in the great hall of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, the final chapter was written in one of the city's liveliest art controversies.
The Treasury announced today that it would recognize fluctuations in the dollar value of the milreis, Brazilian currency unit, in computing customs duties on Brazilian exports to the United States.

Mimeograph machines placed at a dozen different points hurled high-explosive statements over the Jersey City labor front yesterday as Mayor Frank Hague and opposing labor and liberal forces manoeuvred for position in a new invasion of the Hague stronghold.

ITALIAN BOOK CO., a domestic corporation, 147 Mulberry St. By Ciro Troiano for $11,116; Arturo Romano, $10,809. SAUL B. YURAN, doing business as Char Lu Frocks, 23 West 42d St. By A. Alper for $300; Mannie Rader. Inc., $100; Fashion Town, Inc., $200.

The International Sugar Treaty recently concluded in London by the United States and twenty-one foreign countries was ratified by the Senate today with the understanding that if legislation setting up our own

Jan Smeterlin, Polish pianist, devoted half of his recital at the Town Hall last night to music of his country. He began with the Third Sonata, Op 36, of Karol Szymanowski, who died recently, and his third group consisted of three mazurkas, two etudes and the scherzo, Op. 31, of Chopin.

The Port Authority will dedicate its new vehicular Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River between West Thirty-ninth Street, Manhattan, and Weehawken, N. J., this morning with gala festivities, featuring a military parade, airplane manoeuvres, aerial bombs and an artillery salute.

Three Governors, presiding over more than a score of West Indies islands belonging to two nations, meet tomorrow when Governor Blanton Winship of Puerto Rico flies to Charlotte Amalia to join Governor Lawrence W. Cramer of the United States Virgin Island, and his guest, Governor Lethem of the British Virgin Islands, stationed at St. John Antigua.

The Federal grand jury, which off and on since Sept. 20 has been investigating the practices of General Motors, Ford and Chrysler Motor Companies and their associate finance corporations, was dismissed today by B. H.. Westfahl, Clerk of Court.
A dress rehearsal of Verdi's "Otello" was given yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House for a special audience comprised of about 3,000 members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

The grand ballroom of the Pierre was the setting last night for the first of the Dolphin Dances this season. The dances are arranged for girls who will be introduced to society within the next three years and for young men of college age. Another dance will take place during the Easter vacation.

Mrs. James A. Farrell gave a large luncheon yesterday in the penthouse of the St. Regis for her debutante granddaughters, the Misses Therese and Rosamond Murray, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray of 11 East Ninetieth Street and Ilex House, Southampton.
Germany learned today that General Friedrich Wilhelm Erich Ludendorff, Quartermaster General and chief strategist of the German Army during the latter half of the World War, was dead.

Charles A. Levine, who in his day has been hailed as a hero by reception committees only to be jailed and later released for want of evidence that he was a criminal, must serve two years in a Federal penitentiary as a convicted smuggler.
Muriel Rukeyser, who received the annual prize of the Yale University Press for her book of verse, "Theory of Flight," has written "U. S. 1," which Covici, Friede will publish on Jan. 25.

President Roosevelt expressed his gratification over the acceptance by the Dominican Republic of conciliation procedure for adjustment of the dispute between that republic and Haiti over the alleged slaying last Fall of thousands of Haitians on Dominican territory, in -a telegram today to President Rafael Leonidas Trujillo.

The number of business failures in the United States during the week ended on Dec. 16 was 200, compared with 234 in the preceding week and 179 in the same period last year. according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Two pickets were arrested last night outside Grand Central Palace on a complaint of Fritz Kuhn, national leader of the German-American Nazis, that they had called him a "Nazi racketeer," "Nazi spy" and other epithets.
A round of Christmas parties which will continue all week for the children, the aged, and the poor started yesterday while late holiday shoppers bustled into the stores.
Miss Anna Campbell Reiley, who was executive secretary of the associate alumnae of Barnard College from 1920 to 1924, died yesterday in New York Hospital.

Nine destroyers sailed tonight for San Pedro, Calif., under orders upon which local naval officials said they were unable to comment. Crews of the vessels were, in the large part, on holiday leave and the members were ordered back to ship late this afternoon. Shore patrol officers made announcements in theatres and other amusement places, directing personnel of the ships to return.

Retired Fireman James J. Cuff. formerly a member of Engine 277, residing at 998 Putnam Ave., Brooklyn, died Dec. 18. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M., Tuesday, Dec. 21. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

The nomination of Joseph P. Kennedy as Ambassador to Great Britain is expected to be sent to the Senate by President Roosevelt soon after the regular session convenes next month. Prompt approval of the appointment is regarded as a foregone conclusion.
Alexander, J. T., the New Mexico, to duty as Governor of Guam, and Commandant of the Naval Station, Guam.
Shutdown of the Franco-Spanish border at Perthus today followed unconfirmed reports that the Gerona garrison had mutinied as well as that serious food riots had broken out in Barcelona.

Twenty former employes of the Beardsley Wolcott Manufacturing Company returned fo the Waterville factory yesterday morning to start work for the Grand Machinery Exchange of New York, which bought the company on Saturday.
Stark Hickey, Ford automobile dealer here, denied today charges that Ford dealers throughout the country were forced to contribute to a fund tb buy a Cape Cod windmill for Henry Ford,

The 1937 Legislature adjourned sine die at 7:30 o'clock tonight after adopting a revision of New Jersey's laws and refusing to act upon bills to enable municipalities to obtain Federal funds for low-cost housing and slum clearance projects.
Numerous plans were filed yesterday with the building department for group small-dwelling projects in Queens, the largest of which calls for the construction of 124 houses in Woodside.

The City Athletic Club racquetwielders increased their leading margin in Class B of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League by topping the Harvard Club, 3 to 2, on the winners' courts yesterday. The victory was the seventh in eight starts for the City players.

More than 375 persons attended the fourth annual New York WorldTelegram dinner at the Downtown Athletic Club last night in honor of New York City high and prep school players who stood out is football during the 193T campaign.
