Thirty-two choristers comprising "The Singing Boys of America" arrived in New York from Steubenville, Ohio, yesterday and started a series of appearances at the St. Moritz Hotel last night.
A banking group headed by John Nuveen Co. obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,250,000 of highway notes of the State of Mississippi.
Countess Haugwitz-Reventlow, the former Barbara Hutton, Woolworth heiress, revealed today through her English attorneys that she would soon begin an extensive foreign tour.

A crowd of 10,000 saw the Florida racing season open at Tropical Park today with a 13-10 favorite winning the feature and a couple of long shots in the first two races making a $2 daily double ticket pay $738.60.

At a special meeting of the board of directors of the Engineers Publie Service Company yesterday, Donald C. Barnes was elected president of the utility, succeeding.Samuel B. Tuell, who resigned that position to take over the duties of vice president, controller and a director of the company.

Wearied by the parliamentary struggle over the Farm'and Wageand-Hour Bills, Representative Bruce Barton, business man turned legislator - or anti - legislator --returned from the Capitol convinced that "the South is legislating against the North and the North against the South," he told members of the Ninth Assembly District Republican Club last night.

40th St, 110 W, 75x98.9; John T. Javasile to Duval Realty Corp, 119 W 40th St; mtg $720,000. 55th St, 350 W, 100x156x101x144.7; John T. Javasile to Bosdo Corp, 119 W 40th St; mtg $371,486. Amsterdam Ave, 151, 25.1x1OO: Gertrude M. Glennon, referee, to Josephine I. O'Donohue, at Hotel Blackstone, 50 E 58th St: foreclosure.

An application by the Mountain States Power Company of Oregon, a subsidiary of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, for authority to issue $8,000,000 of 6 per cent firstmortgage bonds and $700,000 of unsecured serial notes to refund indebtedness,

An all-Democratic Assembly committee headed by Harry E. Bischoff of Weehawken recommended today that the entire record of its investigation of Wildwood's municipal affairs under the administration of Mayor Doris M. Bradway, a Republican, be referred to the proper authorities for prosecution.

The per capital cost of operation and maintenance of general departments of the city government of New York declined last year to $74.91 from $75.72 in 1935, according to a report released today by William L. Austin, Director of the Bureau of the Census. Department of Commerce.

During his lifetime Erich Ludendorff shared only a. junior partnership in glory in which he was overshadowed by the massive Paul von Hindenburg. Now he may march into history alone as the man who almost won the Great War.

Contributions to the United Hospital Campaign reported yesterday amounted to $8,900, according to an announcement by George J. Lyons, vice chairman of the campaign. The list was headed by a gift of $3,000 from Mrs. J. William Clark.

Trading was exceptionally slow in most classes of meats up to a late hour yesterday. Veal and calf were steady; steers weak; lamb and fresh pork weak to sharply lower. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady with Friday's decline; veal and calf steady to weak; lamb steady to strong, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
A hard scrimmage today ended preparations at home for Alabama's fifth Rose Bowl invasion as players reiterated confidence of victory over California at Pasadena New Year's Day.

Mayor La Guardia's recent clashes with the city and Federal Housing Authorities have lowered the prestige of the New York City Housing Authority and seriously injured the cause of public housing, Evans Clark, executive director of the Twentieth Century Fund, dedared yesterday in announcing his resignation as economic adviser to the City Housing Authority.

Approximately $4,250,000,000, or less than 25 per cent, of the $18,500,000,000 of State and municipal bonds outstanding are owned by investors having an income of $5,000 or more a year, according to a pamphlet issued yesterday by Darby Co., Inc.

The makeup of this country's 1937 delegation of thirty-two Rhodes scholars who will enter Oxford University next Fall was decided today at meetings of district committees in eight key cities. In several instances, including New. York,

Attorneys for fourteen Algic seamen, sentenced today for conspiracy and endeavor to revolt in a sit-down WRIT strike in Montevideo Sept. 10, filed an appeal late today, announcing they were prepared to carry the Certif fight, if necessary, to the Supreme 73 Court.

Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Milbank of New York were for- ally presented yesterday with the Sportsman Perpetual Field Trial Challenge Trophy for cocker spaniels, which was won for the year of 1937 by their black and white dog Cinar Spot of Earlsmoor,

In yesterday's list of contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund was one made "in memory of 'R. O.'" These are the initials of Rollo Ogden, former editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES who wrote many of the brief editorials from year to year in behalf of the Fund.

Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Brazilian Ambassador to the United States, who is to arrive here Thursday or Friday, will be officially received by the government as still the Ambassador and also as a man high in the government's esteem, a government spokesman said tonight.
A rally and tea of the Bronx chapter of the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, will be held this afternoon at the Hotel Delmonico.

Within three weeks, William H. Parsons, whose wife, Alice McDonell Parsons, disappeared on June 9, Will adopt 12-year-old Roy Parsons, son of Mrs. Anna Kupryanova Parsons, it was confirmed yesterday by Benjamin Shiverts, attorney for the former housekeeper-cOmpanion of the missing woman.

The Andrew Weston Construction Company of Woodmere was the lowest of four bidders for the contract of repairing Bayville Bridge over Mill Creek, the Nassau County Board of Supervisors revealed here today.

Youth and age are fighting it out for the National Hockey League's scoring crown. Youthas personified by Gordie Drillon of the Toronto Maple Leafs-is on top so far. But age is gaining ground. Little Johnny Gagnon, one of those veterans who never seem to grow old, is moving right up in the standing.

Dr. A. E. Morgan, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, told a three-member Federal commission today that he believed there was intent to "defraud the government" in the purchase of mineral and marble leases in the TVA's Norris Dam reservoir.

Christmas entered Wall Street in swing time yesterday. The fiftyfive-foot tree in front of the New York Stock Exchange was lighted with colored bulbs and through the public address system at the noon hour and again at the close of the day came carols and other ditties suggestive of the holiday spirit.
The Board of Higher Education named a committee last night to consider a petition from 5,000 residents of Staten Island, sent through Borough President Palma, asking for a city college in Richmond.

An interesting discussion of recent European progress and trends in housing, including small dwelling construction, is to be found in "New Homes in Old Countries," a book just published by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
Christmas trees are everywhere in the public places and public buildings to the number of twenty-seven all over the city.

New York University's unbeaten basketball team scored a 75-21 victory over Wagner College last night at the University Heights gymnasium. The triumph was the fifth straight for the Violet this season and the forty-fifth in a row on the home court.

James V. Bennett, director of the Federal Prison Bureau, said today Thomas Patrick Burke, 40, of Jersey City, N. J., died Nov. 9 at Northeastern Penitentiary, Lewisburg, Pa. Burke was serving four years and one month imprisonment

The Rev. Robert Wight Trenbath, rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church in Montclair, N. J., for the last twenty-two years, died suddenly yesterday morning of a heart attack while walking along Fiftieth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, with his wife. They had come to the city for Christmas shopping.

Stuart Davis was elected the new chairman of the American Artists Congress, it was announced yesterday, the day after the congress's second annual convention. Mr. Davis was formerly the executive secretary.

Marvin Kantrowitz, top-seeded star and winner of the title for the past two years, led the way into the third round as play in the third annual metropolitan junior indoor tennis singles championship continued on the Hamilton courts yesterday.

AKERLY-At Morristown, N. J., on Monday, Dec. 20, 1937, Lucy Du Bois Akerly of New York City, sister of the late Rev. Samuel M. and Louise Du Bois Akerly and sister of the late Mary Akerly. Funeral services will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and 10th St., New York City, on Wednesday, Dec. 22, at 11 o'clock. Interment Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, N. Y.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 15: Increases of $179,000,000 in.
Faced by another crisis in the Actors Equity Association, the Equity Council avoided it yesterday, by choosing Burgess Meredith to serve as first vice president with the duties of president.

Borrowing an honorable custom from the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, the Federal Theatre dispatched two troupes of actors throughout the town with a Nativity play last evening. One troupe is composed of white actors and will play on street corners and at church doors south of 110th Street through Christmas Eve.

The States collected $2,752,955,850 in all types of taxes for the fiscal year 1937, according to the Tax Policy League, which finds that gasoline, general sales, net income and motor vehicle taxes, in the order named, are the four most productive levies. Property,

Mrs. Nancy Wilson of 136 West Fifty-sixth Street was married to John Lobb of South Hadley, Mass., yesterday afternoon in Lampman Chapel at Union Theological Seminary by the Rev. Dr. William Adams Brown.

The Nazis continue in their effort to smash 1,000 windows in Jewish-owned shops in retaliation for the breaking of one window in a German Nazi propaganda center in Kaertnerstrasse. Last night five more were smashed. There were no arrests.
The firm of F. J. Smith Co. has been formed with offices at 20 Broad Street to specialize in trading of unlisted securities. Partners in the new firm are Frank J. Smith and Samuel Gold.
jury convicted twenty-two men today of conspiracy to commit forcible detainer in connection with the sit-down strike at the Douglas Aircraft Company factory at Santa Monica last February.

At the unveiling of a portrait of his deceased brother, Stephen, at Szolnok yesterday, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, finally made his position clear concerning the frequent use of his name by Hungarian Nazis, who have demanded that he be proclaimed "King Nicholas I" with dictatorial powers. The Regent said:

Without losing a single game and allowing only one draw on the fourth board, the chess players of Harvard, 1937 champions, made a brilliant start in the opening round of the annual tournament of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club, 23 West Tenth Street, yesterday.

White Plains Rd (15-4318), e s, 250 s of Pelham Parkway S. 100xlO0; Bon Properties, Inc, to Rumsey Realty Corp, 270 Broadway. Tibbett Ave (13-3415D), w s, 205 s of 246th St, 70x100; Augusta S Brown to Mardel Holding Corp. 441 Tibbett Ave.

Captain Mortimer Carman of St. John's Place, pilot of the Selnada, one of the best known deep sea party fishing boats on the South Shore, died today of pneumonia at the South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside. He was operated on a week ago. -His age was 38.

Frederick Hanover Cone gave a luncheon yesterday at India House for Miss Gertrude Le Boutillier, debutante daughter of Mrs. G. H. T. Le Boutillier. Guests included the Misses Ruth Auchincloss, Millicent Bowring, Elizabeth Hubbard and Polly Weeks;

Miss Ruth McGinniss triumphed over Frank Burns, 100 to 38, in 12 innings of an exhibition pocket billiard. match at the Fourteenth Street Academy last night. The winner had a high run of 15, to 8 for her rival.

The Southern Pacific Company it to contest an increase of $800,000,000 in the assessment of its property proposed by Kentucky authorities. At a rate of 50 cents on each $100, this rise would increase the company's taxes by $4,000,000 annually.

The soft whir of sharp skates across green-toned ice, colorfully inlaid with an appropriate Christmas pattern, drew the plaudits of 6,000 to 7,000 spectators at the opening of the second annual "Ice Follies" at Madison Square Garden last night.

While the State Mediation Board was continuing its efforts yesterday to bring about mediation of the strike of the Cafeteria Employes Union, Local 302, against Horn Hardart automats, the City-Wide Trade Union Conference, with thirty-five representatives of the A. F. of L. and C. I. O. unions attending, held a meeting at 701 Eighth Avenue and voted to start a movement against curtailment of picketing.

Winter will begin at 1:22 A. M. tomorrow. The season will end at 1:45 A. M. March 21. In announcing yesterday the approach of Winter, the monthly sky summary of the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History pointed
The immensity of British naval rearmament is emphasized again in the new edition of "Jane's Fighting Ships," authoritative year book of the world's navies, which will be published here tomorrow.
Four persons were killed and several Rumanian police were wounded today in outbreaks at Orhein and Muresch during elections for a new national Chamber of Deputies. About 300 were arrested.
Eiichi Baba, former Japanese Home Minister, who retired Dec. 13 because of ill health, died early today of pneumonia and complications. He was 58.

Anglo-Italian "friendship talks" will not begin until Italy calls off her antiBritish propaganda campaign in Palestine and other trouble areas in the Near and Middle East, Foreign Minister Anthony Eden told an approving House of Commons today.
Webster Ave, 2,506-08 (11-3033); Rogerson Realty Corp to Bowery Savings Bank; extends mtgs to Aug. 1, 1942, at 4 per cent; $20,198.50.
A dispatch to THE TIMES from Shanghai yesterday, based on information obtained from an unimpeachable SOrurce, threw an important new light on one Phase of the Panay incident.
The Coptic Synod today excommunicated Bishop Abuna Abraham, 75-yearold blind prelate, whom Italy had designated Patriarch of the Ethiopian Coptic Church.

After an absence of twenty-four years from the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera, "Otello" will be revived tonight, with Elisabeth Rethberg, Giovanni Martinelli and Lawrence Tibbett in the principal roles.
Every year the most numerous gifts to the Neediest Cases are made in Memory or in Loving Memory of the dead. The beloved that are gone are gratefully recalled.
A group of conservation authorities urged upon President Roosevelt today the creation of a separate government department for conservation affairs.

An extraordinary puritanical decree, issued by the Hankow branch of the Chinese Government, prescribes the death penalty for government officials who are found dancing in cabarets. A special group of gendarmes was assigned to watch for violators.

Soviet Russia tonight agreed to let Japan continue fishing in Soviet Pacific waters, thus temporarily settling an issue that has gravely troubled Russo-Japanese relations. An official announcement was made prolonging for one year the old agreement that would have expired Dec. 31.

Movements of vessels follow all dates are Dec. 20 unless specified: At San Pedro: Barry, Brooks, Childs, Fox, Gllmer, Goff, Hopkins, Reuben James, Vega, Williamson. At Honolulu: Lark, Oglala, Preble, Pruitt, Quail, Sicard, Tracy, Whippoorwill.

As part of its program for expansion of the city's educational facilities during the coming year, the Board of Education filed plans yesterday for fourteen construction projects involving a total estimated expenditure of $13,253,000 in four boroughs.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open to the public today a comprehensive exhibition of rare prints and illustrated books of the Italian Renaissance.

Clifford F. Hood, executive vice president, has been elected president of the American Steel and Wire Company, the Cyclone Fence Company and the Standard Fence Company, effective on Jan. 1. The companies are subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.

Continuance of the State Department of Social Welfare under a State-wide board, as at present, instead of its transference to the jurisdiction of a single commissioner, will be recommended to the New York State Constitutional Convention next year by the existing State Board of Social Welfare under action taken yesterday.

Sixty-three men have been nominated for ten places on the executive committee of the American Olympic Committee, it was announced yesterday by Secretary Frederick W. Rubien. The election will take place at the New York Athletic Club on Jan. 6, when the A. O. C. meets.

Last Friday afternoon Paddy Boland, the foxy, hard-working Pennsylvania Congressman who serves the Administration as Democratic whip of the House, was busily circulating through the House's fusty, pompous lobbies and corridors. The motion to rebury the New Deal's beloved wage-hour bill in committee was soon to come up, and Mr. Boland was performing his appointed task of herding the boys into line.

MANHATTAN BALDWIN, ADELAIDE BUCHANAN (July 8, 1936). Gross assets, $5,211; net, $4,816. To Charles L. Baldwin, husband; Charles L. Baldwin Jr., son, and Jean Baldwin, daughter, one-third each. Chief assets: miscellaneous property, $5,183. Davis, Symmes Schrelber, attorneys, 21 E. 40th St.

FIRST MILITARY AREA Leave of absence for eight days. effective on or about Dec. 24, is granted Major Carter R. McLennan, Cavalry. A board of officers is appointed to meet at Syracuse, N. Y., at the call of the President thereof. to examine such persons as may be properly ordered before it to determine their fitness for appointment or certificate of capacity in the Officers' Reserve Corps.

Though there have been lesser heraldings of the coming holytide, the local musical world may be said to have entered its Christmas season. Last night Albert Stoessel once again assembled the huge chorus of the Oratorio Society of New York on the Carnegie Hll stage, set before them a respectable symphony orchestra, an organ, a harpsichord-sounding piano, a competent vocal quartet, and engaged i these forces in the annual rite of Handel's "Messiah."
Barbara S., consistent 2-year-old daughter of Jock, owned by Clyde Troutt, annexed her second race of the Fair Grounds meeting today when she defeated nine other juveniles in the six-furlong feature.

Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Watson gave a reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 1,125 Fifth Avenue, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Monique H. Watson. Talisman roses and Autumn flowers were used in the decorations. Dr. and Mrs. Watson will give a dinner dance for their daughter on Jan. 7 at their home before the second Junior Assembly.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Egyptian Collection"' (general tour), 2 P. M.; "The Medieval Castle: Peasant Life," Margaret B. Freeman, 4 P. M.

Representative Snell of New York, the House Republican leader, has his own opinion of the special session of Congress which he helped bring to an end today. When asked what were the session's highlights he first said there were none, but on reconsidering, offered these three:

The in vasion of Jersey City by the Workers Defense League in behalf of free speech and civil liberties was accomplished tonight with no abridgment of the constitutional rights that served as the subject of the evening's oratory.

The marriage of Miss Susan Gutman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe C. Gutman of 31 East Sev- t enty-second Street, to Milton L. Bernstein Jr., also of this city, took place last night in the Jade Room t of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The United Hospital Campaign has obtained to date contributions of $1,951,489, the largest sum ever, raised by the United Hospital Fund, David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the fund, announced at a dinner of drive chairmen in the Union Club last night. Last year's total was $1,928,000.
A. B. Jones, chairman of the New York City Tunnel Authority, was elected yesterday to the board of the B. F. Goodrich Company, of which he was first vice president.
We have occasion today to celebrate the opening of the Lincoln Tunnel. In what we can see here, with our own eyes, in the New York Plaza there is ample cause for rejoicing.
Carmine St, 70, 21.4x59.9 irreg; 49 Leroy St Realty Corp (C. Bertram Plante, pres) to Belroy Realty Corp, 61 Broadway; mtg $8,000 (50 cents).

Miss Virginia Peugnet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ramsay Peugnet of this place, has chosen the afternoon of Jan. 14 for her marriage to Morss Lippincott, son of Mrs. J. Evans Lippincott of Cincinnati and the late Mr. Lippincott. The ceremony will take place at the home of her parents.
Harold Alvord Merriam of Elmsford, former baritone in musical comedies and actor in the silent films, died yesterday in Grasslands Hospital, Eastview. His age was 61.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Martin of Plainfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Lydia Martin, to William Henry Peterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Peterson of Colonia.
Administration officials forecast today continued low prices for wheat on the basis of a prediction of the Department of Agriculture that Winter wheat would yield 630,000,000 bushels next year.
The second annual Gotham Tea Dance for boys and girls home from preparatory schools and colleges for the holidays took place vesterdav at Sherry's.

Sales involving three Jersey City parcels were reported yesterday by the C. B. Snyder Company, Inc., broker in the deals. Included was the sale by the Columbia Building ana Loan Association of Jersey City of the three-story apartment house at 16 Broadway, Jersey City.

Governor Earle conferred for an hour today with Karl De Schweinitz, State Secretary of Public Assistance, and once more deferred his decision on whether to discharge or retain him in the face of demands by some Democratic leaders for his dismissal on charges of waste and inefficiency.

The report of the Department of Agriculture suggesting the possibility of 630,000,000 bushels of Winter wheat being harvested in 1938, issued after the market closed today, was about in line with trade expectations and is not expected to have much effect tomorrow, although it compares ith a yield of 685,0000,000 bushels this year.

Charles Falci, who District Attorney-elect Thomas E. Dewey alleged had been harbored by Albert Marinelli while a fugitive on a Federal election indictment, surrendered yesterday on a State indictment.

The release from earmarking of $1,125,300 of gold was announced yesterday by- the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which also was informed that $300,000 gold had been engaged for shipment here from Ecuador.

The Lincoln Tunnel, the Port Authority's new $85,000,000 vehicular highway under the Hudson River, was dedicated yesterday morning by Federal, State and municipal officials, who hailed it as a new link of friendship between New York and New Jersey, and another example of governmental cooperation.
A petition by Mrs. Gertrude S. Redfern asking the Probate Court to declare her aviator husband, Paul Redfern, legally dead was denied today by Judge Edward Command for lack of jurisdiction.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

New South Wales and Victoria turned in victories in Sheffield Shield cricket competition matches concluded today. The former State defeated South Australia by 33 runs here, while at Melbourne, Victoria overwhelmed Queensland by an innings and 99.

Morris Pasternack, 56 years old, president of the firm of M. Pasternack Son, butter and egg dealers at 918 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn, plunged to his death yesterday afternoon from a ledge on the twentyfirst floor of the Municipal Building. Police listed the case as a suicide.

Shipments of pneumatic casings in this third quarter amounted to 13,590,949 unit, as compared with 16, 324,381 in the second quarter and 14,557,480 in the third quarter last year, according to the Rubber 3Manufacturers Association, Inc. Shipments for the first nine months of this year were 44,582,251, against 42,032,069 in the corresponding period of 1936.

The comanagers of the Royal Dutch Shellcontrolled Mexican Eagle Oil Company, B. T. W. Van Hassalt and Ian Davison left by plane today for San Antonio, Texas, where they are expected to confer with New York officials of the company on its future course with regard to the government's decision Saturday raising oil wares one-third.
Checking a belated rally on the part of a fighting Wittenberg College team, a stubborn Rider College quintet defeated the Ohio five, 46-45, tonight.
Ernest B. Gaston, founder of the single-tax colony at Fairhope, Mobile Bay resort, died here tonight at the age of 78.

Consolidation of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Lazard Freres and its wholly owned affiliate in the underwriting field, Lazard Freres Co., Inc., and the formation of a new partnership to be known as Lazard Freres Co., was announced last night. The merger will become effective Jan. 1.

Mrs. Cass Gilbert, Miss Emily Gilbert and Charles M. Post will give a reception with dancing tomorrow afternoon at the Colony Club for Miss Julia Gilbert Post. Mrs. Cass Gilbert Jr. will give a dinner tomorrow at the clubhouse of the- New York Junior League for her daughter, Miss Jarvis Gilbert, who will be introduced next Winter.
Stacy Gunderman, former State patrolman, convicted of slaying Frank 0. Monaghan, a Uniontown (Pa.) hotel keeper, was freed today on parole by Supreme Court Justice George W. Maxey.

In one of the most one-sided challenge matches in the history of the game Ralph Greenleaf of New York last night retained his world's pocket billiard championship byturning back Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., 123-3, in the final block at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

The Federal Theatre returned to its activities in the dance field last night by presenting Tamiris and a group of dancers at the Forty-ninth Street Theatre in a revival of "How Long, Brethren?" along with two groups of Negro spirituals. Of these latter, the first group is sung by a chorus of seventeen Negrq voices under the direction of Bob Moman, and the second group is danced by Tamiris against a choral background.

As a first step in his investigation concerning the part played by the County Clerk's office in the obtaining of their fraudulent passports by the mysterious "Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Robinson," reported under arrest in Moscow, Henry Alexander, counsel for the County Clerk, issued an order yesterday discontinuing the taking of applications and affidavits for passports in that office.
A happier side of newspaper work than that shown in the formula films of Hollywood is promised by Warners, where "Unfit to Print" was placed on schedule for shooting in January.

Mrs. Babetta E. Sauler, widow of Frederick Sauler, of 87-16 Seventyfifth Street, Woodhaven, Queens, who died Dec. 12, provided gifts totaling $9,000 to five charitable endeavors, in addition to a bequest of $1,000 to THE NEW YORK TIMES Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, according to her will, which was filed yesterday in Queens Surrogate's Court. The value of the estate was not given.
Wallace Ave, 2,075 to 2.081 (15-4291); Mitchel Garden Apartments, Inc. to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave; extends mtg to March 1, 1945, at 5 per cent; $570,000.

Movement of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 22,000, including 4,000 direct. The late market was active, weights 200 pounds down being fully steady with the best time Monday.
The Duke and Duchess of Windsor arrived here this evening from Paris by train to spend the Christmas and New Year holidays with Mr. and Mrs. Herman L. Rogers at Villa Louviei.

The State Labor Relations Board continued yesterday its efforts to bring about a settlement of the strike of employes of the Whelan Drug Stores conducted by the Retail Drug Clerks Union, Local 1199, C. I. O. affiliate. The board is seeking to get both sides to agree to a compromise on the union's demands involving' wage increases, shorter hours and improvements in working conditions.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Tatnall Jr. of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaretta duPont Tatnall, to Robert Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew G. Kenndy, also of Wilmington, formerly of PhiladelDhia.

The number of commercial failures in the United States in the week ended Dec. 16 showed increases in four groups and a decline in the commercial service division, as compared with a year ago, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed comparisons follow:

It is the strange irony of the latest peace proposal which has won a following in Congress that it calls logically for the creation of the greatest military establishment the United States has ever known.

Slipping out a rear door as three gunmen held up twenty-five employes of a chain rug store in its main office at 3,060 Third Avenue, Harry Kazan, proprietor of the chain, telephoned the police, bringing four radio cars before the gunmen completed the robbery. Two of them were arrested in the office and the third was captured as he ran out the rear door.

Miss Henrietta Chapin Gray, daughter of Professor and Mrs. William Dodge Gray of this place, was married this afternoon to Burrett Eaton McBee, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hunter McBee of Montclair. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Reinhold Niebuhr, Professor of Christian Ethics at Union Theological Seminary.
Germany is preparing to give General Erich Ludendorff a grandiose funeral in spite of his expressed wish that there be neither State nor military display. His wish will be met,
Harold W. Stevens, a retired bank president of Hartford, Conn., died here tonight at his home in the Oxford Apartments. He was 82 years old.

Dr. and Mrs. Stephen Pierce Duggan of Greenwich, Conn., have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Ann Duggan, to Alfred White Weld, son of Mrs. E. Allan Wood, also of Greenwich, and Francis M. Weld of 720 Park Avenue, this city.

One of the passengers who arrived yesterday from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania was Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin, former national president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, who had spent three years in Palestine.
Thirteen persons, including seven of the city's fifteen Common Council, sfood indicted on felony charges tonight as the November Erie County grand jury closed a seven-week inquiry into city affairs.

A contract amounting to $246,500 for radio transmitting and coupling equipment to be used in modernizing communication stations at fifty points, has been awarded by the Commerce Department to the Westinghouse Electric Company.
Sacred fires blazed from hilltops throughout the Reich tonight on the occasion of the Winter solstice, the turning point of the ancient Germanic and modern pagan years.
While hundreds of thousands of Chinese are fleeing from Tsingtao, Canton and Hankow, a revival of optimism in official quarters in Hankow and Chungking indicates that Russian aid has been pledged.

The report of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $15,852,187.
The Christmas spirit and a "pained expression" on Speaker Bankhead's face moved Representative Ditter, Republican, of Pennsylvania, to cancel a speech today.
Carmine St, 70, 21.4x59.9 x irreg; ?? Realty Corp (C. Bertram Plante, pres) to C. Bertram Plante, 209 Argyle Rd, Brooklyn; pr mtg $8,000, installments, 6 per cent: $5.500.

Clark Robinson Co., Inc., have purchased for cash the entire remaining first mortgage portfolio, totaling about $250,000, of the National Exchange Bank and Trust Company of Brooklyn, which institution is in the process of voluntary liquidation.

The mechanical bank teller made its appearance in New York for the first time yesterday when two banks installed "photographic tellers, " which receive deposits of checks and record them photographically.

A [pound]120,000 bequest to unnamed American charities was annulled in Probate Court today, Justice Langton ruling that the "eccentric" donor, Alexander H. L. Bohrmann, was suffering from a "want of human instinct."
Miss Phoebe Thayer Goodhue was introduced to society last evening at a dinner dance which her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Abbot Goodhue, gave in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre.

Policemen of the West 123d Street station. have raised $163 for the widow and two young children of William' Campbell,. a truck driver who lost his life fighting. a fire in a tenement house in Harlem . on Dec. 4.
Sir Herert Marler, Canadian Minister, called today upon Wayne C. Taylor, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, o introduce the new counselor of :he legation, Dr. Walter A. Riddell.

Nearly 2,300 retired clergymen or their widows and minor orphans are receiving pensions totaling $1,304,000 annually, according to a report made yesterday by William Fellowes Morgan, president, after a meeting and election of the Church Pension Fund trustees of the Episcopal Church.
The last new show before Christmas will get going this evening at the Imperial, when Lee Shubert and Harry Kaufman set down the Howard Diets-Arthur Schwartz musical production, "Between the Devil."

In an effort to put the real estate business on a higher plane and to protect buyers as well as brokers against the evil of "kick-backs" or splitting of commissions on realty deals, the Real Estate Board of New York decided yesterday to sponsor legislation designed to check this practice in their field.

In the presence of three Archbishops, twenty-six Bishops, two abbots and members of religious orders from as far distant as Alaska and China, Cardinal Dougherty today consecrated in the Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul the Most Rev. Dr. Eugene J. McGuinness of this city as Bishop of Raleigh, N. C. Hundreds of priests, nuns and laymen thronged the cathedral.
Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, vigorously opposed yesterday the Ludlow resolution pending in Congress for a national referendum before any declaration of war.

Eight of the forty-seven persons whose fingerprints revealed police records after they had applied -for jobs counting the proportional-representation vote for City Council were restored to good standing in the Municipal Civil Service records yesterday after hearings before the Civil Service Commissioners in the Municipal Building.

George T. Barnard, harness horse trainer and driver for half a century, died last night at the Rose Hawthorne Lathrop Hospital, Fall River, according to word received here this afternoon. He was 81 years old.

The National Conference for the Study and Discussion of Petroleum Problems as They Affect the. Consumer completed today a two-day meeting by going on record as favoring studies which would evolve ways to reduce taxes on gasoline and petroleum products.
James P. Murray, a partner of his brother, George R. Murray, in the insurance brokerage firm of G. R. J. P. Murray, at 110 William Street, New York, died at his home here today-at the age of 73.
Jussi Bjoerling, young Swedish tenor, has been engaged to appear in performances at-tle Metropolitan Opera House next season, it was announced yesterday by General Manager Edward Johnson.

Action on the selection of a successor to John F. (Chick) Meehan, who recently withdrew as head coach of football at Manhattan College, will be taken shortly, it was learned yesterday. The applications of fully fifty candidates for the vacancy.have been considered- by Rev.
The fine arts committee of the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh has purchased two American paintings from the 1937 Carnegie International Exhibition for the permanent collection.
The timekeeper at the Ice Bowl game here New Year's Day will have to use a sextant--one of the instruments sea captains use to "shoot the sun"--as well as a watch, or the game may wind up on Jan. 2.

Now that the hunting season is about over in this State, except for those who still pursue foxes and cottontails, we can't help wondering what is going to be done in opening posted property for the 1938 season.

Several dinner parties were given before the pre-opening performance of "Between the Devil," the new musical comedy with Evelyn Laye, Jack Buchanan and Adele Dixon in the leading roles, last night at the Imperial Theatre, which had been taken over for the benefit of the Maternity Center Association. Mrs.
William Barhorst, 34 years old, a bus driver on the Rutherford-Newark line of the City Service Transit Company, was shot dead here tonight by a robber, who escaped in an automobile.

The National Public Housing Conference has offered its support to Mayor La Guardia in his stand on housing. The organization's position is explained in the December issue of its bulletin, Public Housing Progress, which was published yesterday.

Governor Lehman, in a proclamation tonight, urged support of the National Safety Council's campaign to reduce the Christmas traffic toll. He said: 'The National Safety Council is conducting a campaign to reduce the annual Christmas traffic toll which last December reached the alarming total of 4,420 lives.
Members of a House tax subcommittee said today they had discovered some persons who asked that their levy not be decreased and some who even wanted it raised.
Directors of the Empire Trust Company elected yesterday George B. St. George a vice president of the company. Mr. St. George is associated with the St. George Coal Company, 2 Wall Street.

Led by Johnny Sullivan and Jerry Nolan, who tallied 15 and 13 points, respectively, the Cathedral Col1ege basketball team swept to a 53-33 victory over the Brooklyn College of pharmacy in the Holy Spirit Gymnasium in the Bronx last night. The winners led at the intermission, 29-13.

First indications that Mr. Healy's death, which followed by only four days the birth of his first child, did not come from natural causes were noted by police when Dr. Wyatt Lemont, the family physician, declined to sign the death certificate.

One police sergeant and twentyseven patrolmen who rescued or assisted in the rescue of persons from drowning in 1936-37 received medals, bar pins and cash awards totaling $1,265 at police headquarters yesterday.
After yielding two goals in the first period, the Harvard freshman hockey team rallied in the following sessions to defeat a speedy St. Paul's School sextet yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

Robert G. Merrick, chairman of the board of the Maryland Title Securities Corporation of Baltimore, has notified stockholders that as of the end of this year all owners of mortgages and mortgage certificates guaranteed by the corporation will have been paid all the principal as well as accrued interest at the rate of 5 1/2 per cent.

Hope of restoring the Australian market to its former importance as an outlet for American goods was engendered among exporters yesterday by word that the Commonwealth has modified tariff restrictions on a wide range of American products.

Major Gen. William D. Connor, superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point, and Mrs. Connor will be guests of Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, at tonight's performance of the Ice Follies, skating revue in the Garden.

In New York State industries covered by the Workman's Compensation Law, 103 fatal accidents occurred during November,. the smallest number for any month this year, it was reported today by Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner.

Most of the crew of the Furness Bermuda liner Monarch of Bermuda, who went out on strike shortly before the ship sailed from New York last Thursday, will return to work when she arrives here Friday morning.

Governor Cross directed Controller Swartz today to make available tomorrow a complete list of the prices paid by the State for purchases of land for the 300-foot right of way for the thirty-two-mile Merritt Parkway from Greenwich to Stamford.

Agreement on the controversial points that blocked adoption of the city's new Administrative Code by the Legislature last Thursday was announced yesterday by State Senator William J. Murray, chairman of the Senate Committee on the Affairs of the City of New York, after a ninety-minute session of the committee at.115 Broadway.

Dizzy Dean said today the sports writers of the country "pitched a perfect game" when they tagged him the No. 1 disappointment of the 1937 sports season. The St. Louis Cardinal right-hander had received the somewhat doubtful honor in the annual sports poll of The Associated Press.

The Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that Albert A. Levin of Brooklyn owed $881,259 on his income for 1927, 1928 and 1929, including deficiencies of $587,509 and a 50 per cent penalty assessment of $293,750.

Leading throughout, the Textile High School basketball team triumphed over the City College junior varsity, 40 to 39, on Textile's court yesterday. Textile enjoyed a 24-13 advantage at the intermission.

Since the restriction on offerings went into effect, the Australian wool market has improved greatly. Compared with the lowest prices in November, fleece wools have advanced 10 to 15 per cent and skirtings from 10 to 128 per cent.

Plans for the most extensive Winter sports program in its history, with emphasis placed on skiing, have been made for the 1937-38 season by New England, it was revealed last night at a dinner tendered New York sports writers and railroad officials by the New England Council at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

William Byron Foster, advisory director of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. service department and a leader in Y. M. C. A. and Methodist Episcopal activities here, died in his home tonight of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

As their second production of the season, the Artef Players last night presented at their Sixty-third Street theatre "The Good Soldier Schweik," dramatized by the actor, Mark Schweid, from the novel by Yaroslav Hasek.

With acquisition of the Prima Vista wine interests in San Francisco and Healdsburg, Calif., and enlargement of the Santa Lucia winery at Fresno to the largest winery in the country, the Roma Wine Company, Inc., has launched an extensive expansion program, John B. Cella, president, said yesterday.
The St. Michael's High School quintet suffered its first reversal in five Brooklyn Division, C. H. S. A. A., starts yesterday when it bowed to Cathedral Prep, 20-18, at the Thonmasq McGee Club.

The conference to mediate the strike by the Transport Workers Union against the twenty-four units of the Sunshine Radio System, which will be held in City Hall at 11:30 today, may develop into a general conference to work out a new agreement for the entire taxi industry in the city.

The interdepartmental committee on banking, of which Secretary Morgenthau is chairman, met this afternoon at the Treasury Department and adjourned subject to the call of the chairman without having reached any definite conclusions except on a few minor technical proposals for changes in existing banking legislation.
The Viennese Roof of the St. Regis was the setting last night for a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Eugene Sawin to introduce their daughter, Miss Edith Moulton Sawin.

Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo denied yesterday a defense motion to dismiss a $250,000 libel suit brought by Charles O. Locke, Cincinnati newspaper man, against Benton Boles, advertising agents. Locke charged that the script for a flood broadcast that he wrote was so amended in the broadcasting by Floyd Gibbons that it made him appear inaccurate.

The Census Bureau reported today the cotton-spinning industry operated during November at 105.2 per cent of capacity, on a single-shift basis, compared with 111.1 per cent during October this year and 130.4 per cent during November last year.

After an announcement that 370 members of labor groups had been arrested in nation-wide raids, the Japanese Proletarian party and the All-Japan Council of Labor and Farmer Unions were summarily dissolved today.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a statement today, attacked the Committee for Industrial Organization and asserted that its wage-andhour bill proposal was "treacherous conduct" toward the nation's workers.

Income tax collections for the final quarter tabulated through Dec. 20 amount to $467,250,722 indicating that the amount actually collected during the month will be about $480,000,000, the Treasury reported today.

The Most Rev. James DeWolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church for eight years, celebrated holy communion yesterday in the chapel of the Church of Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue, in farewell to the staff directing a world-wide missionary task.

Great Britain's present policy in the Far East is one of watchful waiting, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden indicated today in unusually cautious speeches in the House of Commons.

Evidence obtained by tapping telephone wires crossing State lines will not be used by the Department of Justice, in view of yesterday's Supreme Court decision, Attorney General Cummings announced today.

The plight of the telegraph industry has been so sharply accentuated in the last year that it finally has reached the stage where the leading companies are petitioning the Federal Communications Commission for a 15 per cent increase in rates.

While committees of shipowners and labor union leaders were conferring yesterday afternoon on means of ending labor troubles in the shipping industry, a strike was called by the National Maritime Union on four ships of the Eastern Steamship Lines.

A two-masted auxiliary schooner has been given to the University of California by Robert P. Scripps of La Jolla for use of the Scripps Institution of Oceangraphy, under the direction of Dr. Harold U. Sverdrup, it was announced today by President Robert G. Sproul.

Broad approval of the plan announced on Monday by thirty-eight insurance companies belonging to the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters to refund 15 per cent of their premiums to owners of passenger cars who go through an accident-free year, wasexpressed in automobile circles yesterday.

The Federal grand jury, which voted indictments last May and January against corporate and individual defendants accused of plotting to ship armaments and airplanes to Bolivia in the course of the war between that country and Paraguay, voted fourteen indictments yesterday renaming some of the old defendants and adding others.
The official summary of the report of the Special Senate Committee investigating labor espionage and violations of civil liberties is as follows:

An exhibition of children's art, including paintings, murals, prints, sculpture and craft work, executed in the free classes conducted by the Art Teaching Division of the Federal Art Project, will be held at the Federal Art Gallery, 225 West Fifty-seventh Street, beginning tomorrow and will remain through Jan. 8.

World trade, which regained its 1929 level in the second quarter of the year, fell back 3 per cent in the third quarter, according to the League of Nation's Monthly Statistics Bulletin just published.

A Naples butcher's wife, the mother of ten children, was declared chief winner under the rules, which count only living, healthy. children born since April 15, 1926, when the Maternity and Infancy Organization was founded.

Christmas, now only three days away, will be a brighter, happier, more hopeful day for many of the Neediest families in New York than they have imagined it could be. A splendid flow of gifts, as the holiday spirit moved generous individuals, made that certain yesterday.
Fifteen juniors and seniors were initiated by the Lehigh University Chapter of Scabbard and Blade, horiorary military society, at the first semester initiation banquet. Lieut.

An agreement whereby five creditors for $7,860,509 of the Pittston Company, a holding company in the Van Sweringen holding structure, agreed to subordinate their claims until $500,000 owed by Pittston to a subsidiary of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway was repaid with interest, was disclosed in a statement filed yesterday by Pittston with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Eastport, home of the idle $36,000,000 Passamaquoddy Bay tide-harnessing project, asked the State Emergency Municipal Finance Board to take over the city's finances.

Mrs. John Boettiger, the former Anna Roosevelt, daughter of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, underwent a blood transfusion here today. She entered a hospital on Dec. 12 "for observation," intending to remain two or three days. It was found necessary,
Miss Margaret Ferguson Winner, an artist, best known for her portrait work, died in the Presbyterian Hospital tonight after a month's illness. She was 71 years old.

Blyth Co., Inc., headed the sueessful syndicate yesterday in the sale of a new issue of $3,700,000 of bridge bonds of Cuyahoga County, Ohio, on a bid of 101.401 for 31/2s. The bonds will be dated Jan. 1, 198, and will mature April 1 and Oct. 1, 1939 to 1963.

William Gillespie of Scarborough School, seeded third, was upset by George Kraft of Erasmus Hall as the quarter-final bracket in the annual metropolitan junior indoor tennis championship was filled at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday. The score was 7-5, 6-3.

The marriage of Miss Lucy Tew, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Tew of 157 East Eighty-first Street, to Prince Georges Dadiani of Paris, will take place here on Jan. 8 in the Greek Orthodox Cathedral.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney-elect, announced yesterday that he would retain in the District Attorney's office after Jan. 1 three members of the staff of District of Attorney William C. Dodge, one on a permanent basis and two so that they may complete a few weeks' service each in order to qualify for city pensions.

Rulings of the Bureau of Internal Revenue of July 16, 1937, and Oct. 18, 1937, which interpreted Schedule A-3, Title VIII, of the Revenue Act of 1926 to force banks to pay transfer taxes on transactions done on national security exchanges, have been revoked, according to a letter from J. P. Wenchel of the bureau to the American Bankers Association, made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Miss Margaret Henry, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John R. Henry of this place, was married to Griffith ap Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell C. Jones of Bronxville and Washington, Conn., in the Methodist Episcopal Church here.
Somewhat more than a century ago Cornelius Vanderbilt, then a stripling, borrowed $100 from his mother and became a ferryman between Staten Island and Manhattan.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick, C. Zabriskie of Hackensack, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Georgie Bicknell Zabriskie, to Walter H. Grimm of St. James, L. I.

Members of the Chicago Board of Trade voted today, 421 to 91, to make elective the office of first vice president of the exchange, changing a rule of long standing under which the second vice president automatically became first vice president.
The Maritime Commission and representatives of oil companies failed today to reach a final decision on the proposed construction of twelve high-speed tankers.
Seven Republicans elected to county and State offices in November took their oath of office here today before Supreme Court Justice George H. Furman. They are:

Servel, Inc. and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a net profit of $4,666,802 after depreciation, interterest, Federal income taxes, Federal surtax on undistributed profits and other deductions.

President Roosevelt today accused a large percentage of the press and a small minority of business men of inculcating a psychology of fear which had had much to do with prevailing economic conditions in the country.
Steel ingot output was unchanged last week, when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index moved upward to 43.6 from 43.0. The figure for the week ended Dec. 19, 1936, was 125.2.
Choice bonerss" made by applicants for teaching licenses in the New York City school system were disclosed yesterday by the Board of Examiners.

Harvard's chess players,, defending the championship of the H. Y. P. D. College League in their annual tournament with Yale, Princeton and Dartmouth at the Marshall Chess Club, and with the BeldenStephens Trophy at stake, went marching straight along to victory in the second round yesterday..

Italy is affecting surprise at the things said in the House of Commons yesterday about Italian anti-British propaganda having been carried on in Arabic by the Bari broadcasting station and other means, and especially at Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's statements, which are unanimously characterized by adjectives ranging from "astounding" to "unheard of."

Paul P. Hastings was appointed yesterday as vice president in charge of traffic of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, effective. on - March 1. He will succeed Frederick -B. Houghton, who is to retire.

Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Valentine were reported yesterday to have decided to ignore protests from labor leaders and organizations against the promotion of Inspector Harry L. Lob'dell to the rank of Deputy Chief Inspector. However,

The PierceArrow Motor Corporation filed today a petition seeking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act. Judge John Knight in Federal court approved the petition as filed by Arthur J. Chanter, president of Pierce-Arrow, and set the first hearing date as 9 A. M. Jan. 17, 1938.

The American Marine Insurance Syndicate announced today through the Maritime Commission that, 'effective about Jan. 1 or soon after, it will increase from $2,500,000 to $4,000,000 the maximum amount of insurance which it can write on a single vessel.

For the second successive year the New York women's squash racquets team won the Class A metropolitan group championship by defeating both New Jersey and Westchester with identical scores of 5 to 2 on the Plainfield Country Club courts today.
Marshall College of Huntington, W. Va., defeated the strong St. Francis College basketball team, 54-52, in an overtime game on the loser's court last night.

The two-story building and adjoining yard consisting of 10,000 square feet at 527 Hunts Point Avenue, the Bronx, was leased to the Harold Waste Material Company, Inc., which will use the property for the storage and cleaning of woolen cloths.

E. N. Brown, chairman of the board and of the executive committee of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, telegraphed to Senator Harry S. Truman yesterday a denial that he had received a gratuity of $100,000 from Speyer Co., former bankers for the company.

The Santa Claus "who lives in a department store in New York City" and who was the objective of 4-year-old William Murray's lone trip from Maywood, N. J., to this city last week was found by the youngster yesterday. Or, rather, Santa Claus found Willie.

The beginning of a militant Senate liberal group to fight any definite rightwing movement of any nonpartisan conservative coalition such as was suggested in that body this week was seen in a "secret" conference between President Roosevelt and eight Senators at the White House last night.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ended yesterday the examination of witnesses in the New York area in its investigation of the complaint filed by forty-one operators of anthracite coal mines against thirteen railroads.
Theodore Delavigne, for nearly two decades a Detroit newspaper man and public relations representative, died of pneumonia early today at the age of 47.

The Fencers Club team Of Hugh Alessandroni, Al Skrobisch and Robert Driscoll carried off the national junior epee championship last night by defeating the Columbia University outfit, 5-4, in the final round engagement on the strips of the Saltus Fencing Club at the Twenty-third Street Y. M. C. A.
Assets of the Canadian Bank of Commerce increased more than $13,000,000 in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, to $650,899,538, the annual statement issued by the board of directors showed today.

Following is the text of the letter of Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of War and later Secretary of State, opposing the Ludlow resolution for a national referendum on a declaration of war: TO THE EDITOR: THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last February there was introduced into the House of Representatives by Mr. Ludlow of Indiana a joint resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States in the following terms:

The Rev. Max Groesser, a Catholic priest who has been in the United States aiding Archbishop Joseph Francis Rummel of New Orleans in caring for Catholic, Christian and Jewish refugees, has been arrested in Hamburg by the secret political police, which has given no explanation.

The Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today that exports of domestic produce in the first eight months of the 1937-38 fiscal year were 8.2 per cent higher in value than in the corresponding previous fiscal period, being $776,682,690, compared with $717,747,405.

ARMIN KRAMER, manager, 500 Trinity Ave.-Liabilities, 1,778; no assets except Insurance. HENRY J. MATHER, director of Dept. of Agriculture and Markets. 468 Riverside Drive.-Liablities, $112,806, partly contingent on mortgages; no assets.

If New York's baby subway for carrying mail should puff up its last projectile of letters on Dec. 31, it will not be through failure to keep the defiant motto about snow, rain and sleet that the Postoffice Department borrowed from a Greek.
Wesley Ramey, Grand Rapids (Mich.) lightweight, received the decision over Pete Cara, Brooklynite, in the feature bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night.
Receipts for first eleven months of 1937 from France's indirect taxes showed a substantial increase both compared to the same period in 1936 and compared to the budget estimates.

The simple heartiness of "Bulldog Drummond Hits Out," which opened at the Savoy Theatre tonight, makes ideal fare for schoolboys, home for the Christmas holidays, although it is hoped that it will appeal to a wider audience.

The world consumption of tin in the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 amounted to 180,528 tons, compared to 159,065 in the preceding twelve months, an increase of 13.5 per cent, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

Both the general situation and the French position in the Far East were discussed today by the French Cabinet when Freign Minister Yvon Delbos gave a full account of his Eastern European journey and reviewed the situation as a whole.

The stock market here continued quiet today, but the undertone in most sections was firm. Gilt-edged issues were Steady, but dullness prevailed among the foreign loans. Transatlantic stocks, reflecting yesterday's strength in Wall Street, were well supported, but United States Steel closed slightly lower.
The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was considerably less than in the preceding week. The total, however,

Walter I. Willis, former vice president of the Three-in-One Oil Corporation who served five terms as president of the Associated Charities of Flushing, Queens, died yesterday in New York Hospital, where he had been a patient for nearly three weeks and received two blood transfusions. He was 55 years old.
Plans for a new bridge on Cross Bay Boulevard spanning Jamaica Bay in Queens were announced yesterday by Frederick J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures.
Several of the properties in Manhattan which figured in the realty deals reported yesterday were sold or leased for alteration or rehabilitation.
WE continue from yesterday the discuission of Thurman Arnold's "Folklore of -Cap italism,"* using for illustration, as before, an attitude expressed at the height of the recent Presidential campaign.

The National City Bank's annual Christmas party will be held at 6 o'clock this evening in the main banking room of the bank's head office at 55 Wall Street. The local personnel of the bank from its seventy-three branch offices and the staff of the head office, a total of about 6,000, will participate.

Transfers and Assignments SECOND GRADE DETECTIVE-Theodore H. Beckler, from 18th Division, 5th Detective District, to 110th Precinct, designation as second grade detective revoked. THIRD GRADE DETECTIVE-Edward W. Browne, from 18th Division, 5th Detective District, to 42d Precinct, designation as third grade detective revoked.
Mrs. Virginia Bennett Crocker obtained a divorce today from Charles Crocker of San Francisco and New York. An agreement creates a trust fund for their child, Ethel, '4, and the mother.
The Interstate Commerce Commission adjourned today to Jan. 10 in Chicago a hearing on the Pullman Company's application for a 10 per increase in its charges.
Confident of another Alabama victory in the Rose Bowl, this city bade good-bye today to the fifth Crimson Tide eleven to seek honors at Pasadena's New Year's Day classic.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The two letters published in THE TIMES on Sunday in support of Representative Ludlow's resolution proposing a constitutional amendment modifying, by popular referendum, the authority of Congress to declare war, only confirm my opinion that your published objections are sound and that Arthur Krock is quite correct when he says .that "No more fantastic proposal has ever had serious consideration in Congress."
Deputy Sheriff James E. Fitzpatrick of Bronx County, who resided there at 3,524 Hull Avenue, died here today in the Knoll Rest Sanatorium. He was 49 years old.

Whether New York can look forward to the possibility of producing the next world welterweight champion is expected to be decided tonight at the Hippodrome, where Leonard Del Genio of Harlem and Salvy Saban of Greenwich Village are to battle in the feature bout of ten rounds.

It was revealed tonight that Hugh Frederick Bower Sharp, wealthy Scottish jute spinner and sportsman who was killed in the train disaster at Castlecary, Scotland, Dec. 10, had privately acquired a remarkable collection of American books.
Manhattan College scored its fourth basketball victory of the season tonight by conquering St. Peter's College, 26 to 10. The game marked the sixth straight defeat for the home team.

The Bruins subdued the aggressive Black Hawks, 2-1, tonight before 12,000 at the Boston Garden. The speedy and efficient combination of Cooney Weiland and Charlie Sands gave the Bruins their fourth consecutive victory, which strengthened their hold on the top place in the league's American division.

A special meeting of the stockholders of Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., has been called for Jan. 4 at the County Court House here to approve the compromise and settlement of claims involved in an action brought by two stockholders concerning an employment contract with Samuel J. Bloomingdale and Hiram C. Bloomingdale dated Jan. 31, 1930.
Following are salient passages from the speeches of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden in the House of Commons today:
The directors of the Reo Motor Car Company have elected Roland Campbell to the new office of chairman of the board.
The Princeton and Harvard Clubs remained in a tie last night for the Group I leadership in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B interclub league series.
The Negro's contribution to American art in its widest sense is an old and authentic story, and it is only elementary justice
William H. Kouwenhoven, member of an old Brooklyn family and well known in the automobile trade in that borough, died yesterday at his home, 1,110 Ocean Avenue, in his seventy-second year.

The Bureau Navigation released the following orders day, dated Dec. 18: CAPTAINS Kilpatrick, W. K. sick leave 1 month; await orders at New York, N. Y. Duncan, G. A., Navy Dept.. to Navy Yarf Mare Island, Calif., as Public Works off cer.

Edward J. Pratt, electrical engineer, inventor and a member of the technical staff of Bell Telephone Laboratories, 463 West Street, died on Monday night in the Lutheran Hospital of Manhattan after a short illness. Mr. Pratt lived at 353 Riverside Drive. His age was 50.

The annual Christmas party of the Maritime Association for the children of destitute seamen, which was incorrectly announced as scheduled for today, will be held tomorrow afternoon on the floor of the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street.
The last Presidential campaign is but a little more than a year past, and therefore vivid in the memories of those who were engaged in or closely observed it.

the dollar value of sales on all registered securities exchanges dropped sharply in November, amounting to $1,490,044,243, or 25.8 per cent below October and 47.2 per cent below November, 1936. Sales of stocks, including rights and warrants, amounted to $1,339,666,144, a drop of 25 per cent from sales in October, and bond sales were valued at $150,360,866, a decrease of 17.2 per cent.

The University of Michigan quintet, led by Captain Johnny Townpend, played brilliant basketball tonight to defeat a fighting University of Rochester five, 50-29, and remain unbeaten in its intercollegiate campaign.
The Spanish Government tonight announced the capture of Teruel, key city of the Insurgent salient, 135 miles east of Madrid.

Declaring that New York City's traffic control system was in some respects managed "in a most arbitrary and unintelligent manner," Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan yesterday advocated that the city standardize its traffic lights and signs to conform with the suggestions set forth in a pamphlet issued by the Federal Government.
The Building Departments in the various boroughs were kept busy yesterday recording plans submitted for many private projects as well as for school buildings.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene W. Ong gave a dance last nightin the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria to introduce to society Mrs. Ong's daughter, Miss Virginia Bacon Penfield, who was among the debutantes presented at the Autumn Ball in Tuxedo Park and, more recently, at the Bachelors' Cotillion in Baltimore.

Still maintaining the unconcern which he assumed on his conviction on a first-degree murder indictment several weeks ago, Terence Roberts, 26 years old, was sentenced yesterday by General Sessions Judge Donnellan to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing in the week beginning Jan. 31. The sentence later will be stayed by a mandatory appeal.

The consumer's refusal to be satisfied has always been the mainspring of American industrial progress, and for this reason, industry is anxious for an increasing sense of partnership among its customers, employes and owners, in order to continue to improve its services, Rolland J. Hamilton, president of American Radiator Company, declared yesterday in a radio address in the series sponsored by the Department of Commerce.

No definite result in the Chamber of Deputies elections was announced today, although polling closed at 8 o'clock last night. It is believed publication of the results is being delayed in order not to influence the Senate elections tomorrow.
Employes of the Works Progress Administration project totaled 1,557,689 on Dec. 11, an increase of 20,128 over the total enrollment for the week ending Dec. 4, it was stated today.
The main body of listed bonds followed yesterday an upward course in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The upward movement under way on the Cotton Exchange in the last two weeks carried all but the two near months above 81/2 cents a pound yesterday, or more than $4 a bale above the low records of the season, and the list ended with net gains of 4 to 8 points.

Nearly 200 American educators and scholars have signed a protest against the introduction of "ghetto benches" for Jewish students in Polish universities. Among the signers are threescore college presidents, more than 100 deans and full professors, and five Nobel Prize winners in science.

A declaration that the government must destroy industrial espionage or the whole business fabric of the country will be undermined was made to the Senate today by the civil liberties subcommittee of the Education and Labor Committee, which has been investigating the subject for eighteen months.

The Honeymead Products Company, Cedar Rapids, Iowa, manufacturer of animal feeds, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for $100,000 of 41/2 per cent unsecured notes due in 1939 to be sold to underwriters at 96 for resale at 100.

The special session of Congress ended today without final action on any part of the legislative program outlined by President Roosevelt in a radio "fireside chat" when he called the second extra session of his Administration to meet on Nov. 15.

IT may be that, as observers of world affairs hold, the voice of the people is becoming faint and indistinct, drowned out by the brass of dictatorship. The rules of life may be made by the few for the many, but the rules of sport are being handled in the opposite way.

Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University; Frederick H. Stinchfield of Minneapolis, former president of the American Bar Association; Charles I. Dawson of Louisville, former Federal district judge, and J. Reuben Clark Jr. of Salt Lake City, former Ambassador to Mexico, have accepted membership on the Republican National Committee's Committee on Program, according to a list given out today.
Philip Le Boutillier, president and general manager of Best Co, in 825 5th Ave, from Henry J. S. Hall; Van Rensselaer Realty Co, broker.

Mrs. Emil Denemark's silks, which had monopolized the spotlight on Florida tracks so often the past two Winters, flashed to the fore for the first time this season when Orientalist easily led home seven other 3-year-old sprinters in the featured Dania Purse at Tropical Park today.
The life of Frank Billings Kellogg was one that was touched with romance from early boyhood, romance against a background of hard reality.

The Consolidated Edison System filed suits yesterday in Supreme Court to recover $2,350,000 paid to the city under protest as additional assessments under the emergency relief laws of 1933 and 1934. Nearly $1,500,000 of the total represents taxes, the balance penalties for delay in payment.
Both the United States and Britain, through their leading spokesmen, made clear yesterday that they did not subscribe to a policy of peace at any price.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week amounted to 3,439,850 barrels, compared to 3,314,450 in the previous week, an increase of 25,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The United States Navy has taken steps to declare as proscribed territory for airplane flights the entire California region near the Mexican border between San Diego and Mexicali, Mexico, near the Arizona border, it became known here today.

King Farouk tonight gave the Egyptian Cabinet until tomorrow morning to accept his demands in their constitutional impasse or be dismissed. A deadlock between the King and Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha resulted from Farouk's insistence on dissolution of the blue-shirted youth organizations of Nahas's Wafd [Nationalist] party,

In an atmosphere alternately made gay by laughter and sad by regret at terminating a tradition of more than two and a half centuries, the Board of Aldermen held its final meeting yesterday in City Hall before giving way to the new City Council which takes over its duties at the first of the year.

Pre-season Christmas celebrations were held in many places in New York City yesterday while other organizations planned events for the rest of the week and made arrangements for distribution of holiday cheer to all.

George Alphonse Butz, hotel executive, who was managing director of the Ritz Tower, 1934-35, died Monday at his residence, the Hotel Gotham, after a short illness of Bright's disease. He was 51 years old.
Two hundred and twenty new members were admitted to the National Republican Club last night at a meeting in its headquarters, 54 West Fortieth Street.

A jury in Brooklyn Supreme Court deliberated only ten minutes yesterday afternoon before deciding that Henry W. Dupper, former assistant secretary of the Metropolitan Racing Association, was not entitled to collect $9,998 which he said he had lost on bets on horse races placed with John Rogan between Septtember, 1929, and November, 1932.

There were forty-one new cases of diphtheria, the highest total for the last thirty-two weeks, in this city in the week ended last Saturday, it was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. The one death from this disease occurred in the Bronx.

A bootleg syndicate of the underworld as well organized as any during prohibition has defrauded the government of at least $1,800,000 in taxes during the last three years and poured 1,000,000 gallons of cheap whisky into the city annually, it was charged yesterday when a.Federal grand jury indicted fifty-four alleged members of the ring, including three policemen and an inspector of the alcohol tax unit of the Treasury Department.
The Agriculture Department estimated today the nation's orange crop available for use this Winter was about 8 per cent greater than last year and 25 per cent greater than the 1931-35 average.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order making effec tive a declaration by the South Carolina Utilities Company, a subsidiary of the States Electric and Gas Corporation, with respect to the issue and sale by the former to States Electric of an unsecured promissory note of $20,000, with interest at 6 per cent, maturing on April 27, 1936.

Widespread interest was reported yesterday in the announced plans for observance of Ching Johnson Night on Tuesday, Jan. 11, when the New York Americans play the Chicago Black Hawks in Madison Square Garden.
Enrolled Republicans still outnumber enrolled Democrats in Westchester County by a large majority, according to tabulation released today by the County Board of Elections.

Eleven murals by Louise N. Grace--daughter of the late William R. Grace, twice Mayor of New York, 'and a sister of J. P. and W. Russell Grace of the Grace Lines-were shown yesterday afternoon at a preview and reception in the galleries of Maison Frangaise, Rockefeller Center.

The United Fruit Company filed suit against the Government for $10,000,000 in the Court of Claims today for "damages" resulting from the cancellation of two mail contracts made under the Merchant Marine Act of 1928.

A lease on the store and basement in the building at 574 Fifth Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets, taken by Spencer Chemists, Inc., featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.

Instituting its second major rate inquiry within six weeks, the Federal Power Commission has called for an immediate investigation of the rates and agreements under which the Chicago District Electric Generating Corporation sells electric energy.

For the first time in fifteen years, the Kings County Medical Society rejected a regular candidate for president at the annual elections last night and chose an independent candidate, Dr. Philip I. Nash, chief surgeon of the Coney Island Hospital.

Asserting that the Tammany Tiger was far from dead, Ben Howe, chairman of the City Fusion party, declared last night that the party must continue to prevent the return of Tammany to control of the city government.

With the announcement yesterday that the Prudential Insurance Company of America has taken an assignment of and extended for ten years the temporary loan of $1,500,000 made several months ago on the thirty-six-story Hampshire House at 150 Central Park South by the Guaranty Trust Company, permanent financing of the structure is now complete.
Three new members have been added to the board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, according to announcement yesterday. They are Harry Payne Bingham, Vanderbilt Webb and Arnold Whitridge.
Frank B. Kellogg, former World Court judge and Secretary of State, died at 7:28 P. M., Guy Chase, his law partner, announced tonight.

The government is being urged to adopt relief measures for thousands of less important producers of lowgrade copper ores in the northern provinces, who contend that low prices, the sudden withdrawal of Japanese buyers from the market and the abnormal conditions affecting Japanese freight to Tokyo place them in a difficult position.
Edward H. McReynolds, board chairman and former president of the Advertising Federation of America, was found dead today in a bedroom of his apartment, a bullet wound in the right side of his head.
Hints that a fist fight in a Hollywood cafe Sunday night indirectly caused the death of Ted Healy, 41year-old screen comedian, led today to an order for an immediate autopsY on the actor's body.

Old friends of the Neediest Cases Fund and newcomers to the ranks of its benefactors joined yesterday in expressing the joy that they felt in helping to bring the spirit of Christmas home to some of the broken men and women, the orphaned children, the friendless old folk among the Neediest.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen, arriving today from Europe, will bring Thomas S. Lamont, banker; Viscount and Viscountess Astor, Mrs. Ogden L. Mills, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Fairbanks, Allison V. Armour, Otto Krause, Major A. P. Herbert, Guthrie McClintic, producer, and his wife, Katharine Cornell, the actress; Frank W. Phelan,
The Soviet polar expedition reported by wireless today that in clear weather their drifting ice floe was within sight of Greenland.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 20: BRIGADIER GENERAL Krueger, W., General Staff Corps, seven days' leave, Dec. 24. LIEUTENANT COLONELS
Georges Enesco, noted Rumanian composer and conductor, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, accompanied by his wife.

A Chrstmas service award was paid yesterday to more than 1,000 employes of the Scott Paper Company. Those who joined the company prior to Jan. 1, 1937, received $25 plus $1 a year for each year of continuous service.
A secret single-seated fighting plane, the details of which are carefully guarded, was put through a series of dive tests here today by B. Lee Gehlbach, a leading test pilot.
The Alumni Association of the Law School of Columbia University held a fiftieth anniversary luncheon in honor of the class of 1887 yesterday in the Lawyers Club. John M.
