Mile. J. Ernestine Cappelle, teacher of French in Brooklyn for more than fifty years, died on Monday in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, after a week's illness due to the breaking of a hip in a fall.

Mayor La Guardia attacked the State courts for use of the mandamus power in rescinding salary reductions for judges, court attendants and other public officials, thus wrecking his budget-balancing program, in an address last night before 1,400 persons at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria celebrating the fortieth anniversary of the Merchants Association of New York.

The leading telegraph companies throughout the United States will file a joint petition with the Federal Communications Commission at Washington today requesting a 15 per cent increase in domestic rates, covering both residential and commerical services.

Thirty-eight persons, described by their attorneys as "angels" of Father Divine's New York flock, petitioned the Board of Tax Appeals today for redetermination of 1936 income tax and penalty deficiency assessment totaling $5,516.

Trading was generally only fair to slow. Steer and lamb were sharply lower; traefa veal and calf, also fresh pork cuts, were mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be weaK to lower; other classes about steady with Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Action was taken yesterday at the monthly meeting of the games committee of the Public Schools Athletic League at the Hotel Astor to slow up the game of basketball as it is now played by New York City schoolboys.

An unheralded bonfire took place last week when ten tons of examination papers, representing five years of educational effort, went up in smoke. Seven men spent seven hours carrying these papers-200,O00 of them-from the Board of Examiners' vaults.
In the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton yesterday afternoon Miss Dorothy Riddell was introduced to society at a tea dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Fletcher Riddell Jr.

Miss Anne Mahoney, daughter of Merchant Mahoney, First Secretary of the Canadian Legation, and Mrs. Mahoney, led the line of debutantes at tonight's tenth annual Black and White Ball at the Mayflower Hotel.
The Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League competition will open here Jan. 14, with Harvard meeting Pennsylvania, Jamison Swarts, secretary-treasurer, announced today.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer ruled yesterday that the 50 per cent cut in commutation rates on the Staten Island ferries which was voted by the Sinking Fund Commission in August was void because the new rates were not recommended by the Commissioner of Plant and Structures.

The ideas of President Coolidge concerning the consolidation of the Pennsylvania, New York Central and other railroads in the Eastern territory into four systems came nearer to being realized in the period 1924-1927 than the general public ever thought possible.

Buster, 120-pound St. Bernard pup, spent six bitterly cold days precariously perched on a ledge of a 300foot cliff while men fought to rescue him. Pilot Nibs Parker landed his plane here today with the story of the grim struggle to save Rube Broderick's valuable dog.

Sound films, Introduced experimentally a year ago in eleven public schools of this city, have proved valuable as a teaching aid, although many defects must be overcome before they are generally accepted in the school system, a report made public yesterday by the Board of Superintendents disclosed.

Dr. Laura Virginia Douglas, Hunter College alumna, who wrote to The New York Sun as Virginia O'Hanlon forty years ago when she was 8 years old asking that' all-important question, "Is there a Santa Claus?" yesterday sat at her desk in Public School 31, where she is assistant principal, and said that children do not believe, in Santa Claus as much as they used to.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George M. Maverick of 330 Elmora Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Newell Maverick, to Malcolm A. Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gavin H. Cooper of Syracuse, N. Y.
Turpentine firm, 26c: sales. 79 barrels; receipts, 320 barrels; shipments, 50 barrels; stock, 35,316 barrels.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas gave a luncheon today at their villa for Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sigrist of London, here for the day from Miami. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Crozer entertained at their home, where Charles Fair of New York has joined Mrs. Fair, who is spending several weeks with her parents.

Colonel John J. Kingman, in charge of river and harbor improvements of the South Pacific Division of the Army Engineer Corps at San Francisco, was appointed by President Roosevelt today to be assistant chief of army engineers with the rank of brigadier general.

State Senator Lester H. Clee's net lead of 386 in the recount of the Hudson County ballots cast in the November Gubernatorial election, which was won by United States Senator A. Harry Moore, was reduced to 284 this afternoon by a ruling on 141 disputed ballots by Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the Supreme Court.
By B. HOLLANDER SON Boynton Ave, 1,135, 175x100; Aaron Rabinowitz, trustee, against Habendum Estates, Inc: due, $295,738: to plaintiff for $1,000.
The Providence Journal Company, publisher of The Journal and Evening Bulletin, bought The Providence Star-Tribune today and announced that publication of the paper would be continued.

Miss Jane Bedford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bedford of this city and London, was introduced to society yesterday afternoon at a reception given by her parents at their home here, 141 East Seventysecond Street.

Thanks chiefly to air-minded Sammy Baugh and the Washington Redskins, the growth in popularity of professional football was the outstanding sports development of 1937 in the opinion of a majority of the writers participating in the seventh annual Associated Press poll, the results of which were announced yesterday.
News of the death of Frank B. Kellogg. former United States Secretary of State and one-time Ambassador to the Court of St. James, was received with dep regret in England today.

Pensioned Fireman 1st Grade David Stark, Eng. 4 is retired for physical disability on an annual pension of $2,500. Fireman 1st Grade George W. Minor, H L. 170, having performed duty continuously for more than twenty years, is, or his own application, retired, on an annual pension of $1,500.
James H. Shea, for forty-two years swimming instructor and steam-bath manager of the staff of the old Boston Athletic Association, died in his eightieth year at his home in Brighton today.
Diplomats learned today that Count Rene Doynel de St. Quentin has been appointed French Ambassador to the United States, succeeding Georges Bonnet, who left here to become Finance Minister.

When Notre Dame plays Xavier at Cincinnati tonight, it will be a case of brother against brothers. The Cincinnati coach is Clem Crowe, former star at Notre Dame, while two young brothers, Mike, a senior, and Emmett, a junior, are on the South Bend squad.
By GEORGE P. SINNOTT Central Park W, 478-81, two 7-story apartments,100.11x100; Alexander R. Pincus against 478 Central Park West Corp; due, $159,364; to David Abrams, a party interest, for $240,630.

Certificate holders of Series K Issue of the State Title and Mortgage Company will receive today a distribution of 7 1/2 per cent against the principal amount of their holdings, according to Emmanuel M. Cohan, trustee.

Relying on a gain in the first half of this month of 4 per cent over a year ago, retail executives here yesterday expressed confidence that department store sales in New York and Brooklyn for the month will break even with 1936, despite their sharp loss last Saturday.

A year ago at the Gridiron Dinner, in the spirit of the old American tradition that politics cease at the water's edge, I pledged you cooperation and support in the difficult foreign situation confronting your administration.
Stebbins Ave, (10-2698), e g. 99 n of West-chester Ave, 100x80; Central Hanover Bank and Trust Co, trustee, to Giulia Vescia, 663 Crescent Ave; mtg $85,000.
A formidable-appearing squad of twenty-two Eastern football stars arrived today to prepare for the annual East-West charity game New Year's Day.

Representative Hamilton Fish of New York, ranking Republican member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, told Congress today he would ask withdrawal of United States recognition of the Dominican Republic unless the dispute with Haiti was settled promptly.

The will of Charles H. Hood. filed in Salem today, provides bequests to increase to about $1,00,000 the endowment of two charitable and. education funds he had set up for the benefit of the children of New England milk producers, children of employes of the H. P. Hook Sons Company and undernourished and underprivileged city children.

A. N. Benson, general manager of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said today that the association had no intention at a Washington hearing last week to charge "force or coercion" by the Ford Motor Company in connection with dealers' purchase of a Cape Cod windmill as a gift to Henry Ford.

William E. Wheeler, president of The New York Woman, Inc., and a trustee in bankruptcy for that magazine, announced yesterday he had written to Governor Lehman to retract charges he made to the Governor last April against Assistant Attorney General Bertha Schwartz, who had been investigating the publication's financial affairs.

A suggestion that the National Housing Act be amended further to provide for mortgage insurance for homes under $2,500, to aid in the construction of seasonal or resort dwellings and perhaps some small low-cost all-year houses, has been presented to Senator A. Harry Moore by Samuel D. Walker, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards.

Two months of effort to heal the breach between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization ended in failure today when committees from both sides "agreed to disagree" and adjourned their meetings without any plans for resumption.
Opie Read, author and master of the bon mot, will turn 85 tomorrow with a reaffirmation of his faith in books, music, philosophy, poker and a good dinner as bulwarks of an agreeable life.

Professor Hugo Burghauser, chairman of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra and close friend of Arturo Toscanin, disclaimed today any knowledge of an ultimatum the latter allegedly presented, laying down his conditions for further participation in the Salzburg Festival.
Twenty-four horses, led by Charles S. Howard's Seabiscuit, were nominated today for the $5,000 added Christmas Handicap that will feature the opening of Santa Anita's race meeting next Saturday.

Business firms in Shanghai have been using homing pigeons for the delivery of important messages and exchange- of intelligence during the emergency caused by the Japanese invasion, the Commerce Department was advised today.

Edgar F. Adams, president of the Cleveland Hardware Company until 1931, died today at the age of 66. He attracted national attention in 1929 when he advocated adoption of the five-day week in business.

MANHTAN ARONSON, ROSALIE (Dec. 18). Estate, $5,000. To Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, principal of a trust over which decedent had power of appointment; residue to the executor for Jewish charitable purposes. Jacob J. Aronson, 393 West End Ave.. executor.
Stocks lost part of early gains and closed irregularly higher on the day; turnover, 1,283,540 shares.

The Baltimore Mail Line steamship City of Hamburg collided today with the Italian steamer Confidenza in the North Sea. The City of Hamburg has two holds full of water and is returning here under her own power.

New Rochelle High School and Riverdale Country School shared honors in the second annual invitation fencing tourney for high school, prep school and college freshman bladesmen, held at the Riverdale Country School yesterday.

Three of the four members of the San Jose polo team, which unsuccessfully sought the United States open championship this year, have been reduced in a handicap shakeup of the Argentine Polo Association.
Mr. and Mrs. Angler Biddle Duke entertained tonight in their new home here for Miss Josephine Cutting and Alexander McFadden, who will be married on Jan. 1.
Thomas M. J. Regan, an attorney and former Municipal Court judge, died in Jefferson Hospital yesterday. He was 37 years old.
Neutral officials in Shanghai believe that extremist elements in the Japanese Government, as well as in the army in the Yangtze River area, have gained the upper hand.
Comparing the Japanese invasion of China to the world-shaking conquests of Genghis Khan and Tamerlane, Dr. Sven Hedin, famous Swedish explorer, said last night:

By a vote of 60 to 4, the Senate this afternoon passed its own version of the Wagner-Steagall bill to amend the National Housing Act and stimulate residential construction. The House on Saturday passed a measure, similar in its essentials.

Unsettled currencies in this and other countries may lead to an uncontrollable rise in prices, Dr. Ernest Minor Patterson, president of the American Academy of Political and Social Sciences, warned last night at a dinner meeting of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the Builders Exchange Club, 2 Park Avenue.

President Roosevelt made public a telegram from Alf M. Landon praising his handling of the Far Eastern situation and his reply. He discussed Sino-Japanese matters separately with Secretary Hull and Chinese Ambassador Wang.

Attorneys for The Seattle Star told the Regional Labor Board today that the newspaper was unable to comply with the board's order to reinstate 20 discharged employes, who are members of the American Newspaper Guild.

Director Daems of the Ostend airport faces charges of manslaughter, according to Brussels newspapers, in connection with the airliner accident in which almost the entire family of the late Grand Duke Ernst Ludwig of Hesse bei Rhein was killed near Ostend, Belgium, on Nov. 16.

A poll completed yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers revealed that 77 per cent of 150 companies replying plan at the present time to expend as much or more in advertising in 1938- as in 1937.

Alimony of $5,250 a month is demanded from E. John Brandeis, noted as a polo player, in a suit for separate maintenance started today by Mrs. Claire Brandeis, who charged infidelity and extreme cruelty.

George E. Akerson, former secretary to ex-President Herbert Hoover, died at 11:30 o'clock last night in the Rockefeller Institute Hospital, Sixty-sixth Street and York Avenue, where he had been a patient since the middle of November.
Samuel Wilkoff, who landed in the United States at 19 with 2 cents in his pocket, died today at 74, president of the Wilkoff Company, dealers in scrap, capitalized at $1,000,000.

" Business unparalleled in aviation history" has made it necessary for Eastern Air Lines to augment its New York-Miami passenger service with seven extra flight sec-tions, Captain E. V. Rickenbacher, general manager, said last night in a statement issued by the company.

Sir Oracle, representing the California sportsman Norman W. Church, who is racing in Florida for the first time, flashed one of the speediest performances of the Tropical Park meeting thus far when he won the Homestead Purse over five and a half furlongs in 1:044-5 today.

The stock market here was in a holiday mood today. Business was quiet, but prices were steady on the whole. Gilt-edge issues were firm, while among the foreign bonds Far Eastern loans were weak. Transatlantic securities were in some demand and United States Steel and International Nickel advanced.

According to The London Daily Express, the Duchess of Windsor has sent a doll to W. E. Hill, secretary of the Garw Lodge of the South Wales Miners Federation, asking that it should be presented to a child of an unemployed miner.

Gifts totaling $13,523.87 helped the Neediest Cases Fund forge ahead yesterday to $218,579.21 as 712 donors joined the ranks of those who have sought to bring fresh hope and opportunity to the beneficiaries of this twenty-sixth annual appeal.

Individuals operating the Orange and Rockland Electric Company, including its president, Roscoe W. Smith, are involved in a series of "improper activities and relationships," according to a report made public yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission.
The Hershey Bears took undisputed possession of second place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League by defeating the New York Rovers, 3 to 1, tonight.

Objecting to the progressively lower percentages of stock now being required for quorums and admitting that its own rules have been largely responsible for the tendenoy, the New York Stock Exchange altered its rules yesterday to help company managements in obtaining proxies in uncontested elections. It served warning,

Onondaga County, N. Y., will enter the market on Jan. 6, with an issue of $1,707,000 of bonds for general purposes. The issue will be dated Feb. 1, 1938, and will mature serially Feb. 1, 1939 to 1968. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 5 per cent.

Undefeated either as a team or individually, Harvard's champion chess players yesterday swept on to an unequivocal triumph in the annual tournament of the H. Y. P. D. College Chess League when they defeated Dartmouth easily by the score of 3 1/2--1/2 in the third and final round at the Marshall Chess Club.

The story of how a few differences involving a loan resulted in a loss of more than $1,300,000,000 in business to the Philadelphia banking firm of Drexel Co. and a corresponding increase in the financial operations of Kuhn, Loeb Co. was disclosed today by the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee in the course of its investigation of the Pennsylvania Railroad and its completely owned or controlled lines.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a citizen I wish to. protest against the radio broadcast by the Japanese Ambassador, reproduced in the newspapers on Monday morning last. So far as it was an apology for the. Panay incident, it had already been thoroughly circulated in its proper official form.

London critics were divided in their opinion of "You Can't Take It With You," presented at St. James's Theatre tonight. The Daily Telegraph's W. A. Darlington, welcoming the play for its "combination of large lunacy and utter truth," sees in it an exact counterpart of two English plays of much more solid architecture, Rodney Ackland's "Strange Orchestra" and "After October."

NOWADAYS we have many literary reviewers and few literary critics. Mary Colum, whose new volume "From These Roots" * inspires this observation, is surely one of the few. I say surely, although I am not quite certain wherein the two types differ; but if the obvious will do-if the reviewer is one who dashes off at more or less regular intervals reports on newly published books,

Current pre-holiday advertising campaigns of liquor companies are the largest ever undertaken and indicate that 1938 budgets will show substantial increases, according to comment by agency executives yesterday.
The State Commission of Correction recommended in an inspection report today that the system of locking devices at the Richmond County jail be examined and put in first-class condition.

An improvement in miners' earnings amounting to 7 per cent of their net wage but without an increased wage rate has been granted by the Cabinet in a law for the financial reorganization of the invalidity and pension insurance system.
The death of Ted Healy, film comedian, was due to natural causes and there will be no inquest, Coroner Frank Nance said today after an autopsy.

With Germany and Italy outside the League of Nations, Switzerland must not "dream" of withdrawing from it, but must now seek to restore Switzerland's absolute neutrality, Dr. Giuseppe Motta, speaking for the Federal Government, told the National Council this afternoon in an important statement of policy.

The official report of Lieut. Comdr. James J. Hughes, commander of the United States gunboat Panay, on the bombing of that craft by Japanese was received at the Navy Department today and immediately presented to President Roosevelt by Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations.

Marshall College of Huntington, W. Va., defeated the Prospect Park Y. M. C. A. basketball team, 64-47, last night on the losing team's court. Jack Morlock and Jules Rivlin of Marshall led the scorers, each with 18 points.
Development of a considerable amount of "under-cover trading" was reported in the hide market yesterday, with substantial sales made in excess of those disclosed by brokers.

When Minnesota arrives here this afternoon for its two games in the Garden next week, the Gophers will bring a colorful figure in the person of George (Butch) Nash, a junior on the squad. Nash, a Minneapolis boy, is a player who learned the game the hard way.
A court ruling today opened the way for a possible government decree dissolving the French Social party of Colonel Francois de la Rocque as a semi-military league.

The board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company authorized yesterday a special Christmas payment to employes. computed on the basis of $1 for each year of service with the company, with an additional bonus of $5 to each employee. The total thus distributed for the holiday season will be about $750,000, with 52,000 employes participating.
Sales of new automobiles, trucks and parts improved in November, the Internal Revenue Bureau reported today on the basis of tax returns.

Internal revenue collections for the first eleven months of the current fiscal year amounted to $2,060,748,577, an increase of $674,980,650 over the corresponding period last year, while for November receipts Were $325,736,141, an increase of $149,210,445 over November, 1936.

The New York Public Service Commission has taken steps against the Orange and Rockland Electric Company and its operators for alleged "improper management." Counsel for the State agency has been directed to initiate legal proceedings for alleged violations of law where the commission is authorized to act.
The Knox Trophy for 1937 will be awarded to Battery B, Seventysixth Field Artillery, now stationed at Fort Francis E. Warren, the War Department said today.
Isaac Cruse Blandy, philanthropist, manufacturer and former partner of the late Governor John A. Dix, died today in his home in Greenwich, N. Y.

Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander entertained with a dinner last night at the Pierre for the Duke and Duchess de Richelieu, Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor, Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart Cushman, Princess Constantin Toumanoff, Mrs. J. Sergeant Cram, Sumner Ballard, G. Creighton Webb and W. Francklyn Paris.

Ernst Wilhelm Bohle, 34-year-old chief of the National Socialist party's foreign organization and head of its foreign "Gau," or province, has been appointed State Secretary in the Foreign Ministry with authority to make independent decisions within his field in the name of the Foreign Minister.

Promotions and transfers amounting to a major Police Department shake-up and foreshadowing a sterner police policy toward strikers' demonstrations were announced last 'night by Commissioner Valentine in the presence of Mayor La Guardia and 5,000 cheering spectators at the commencement exercises of the Police Academy in the 165th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.

Governor Martin wishes President Roosevelt would "get rid of" "that miserable Secretary of Labor of his," he said here last night. "The people of Oregon resent labor gangsters using Oregon as a battleground in an unholy, senseless war in the scramble for the laboring man's fees and dues," the Governor told Clatsop County Democrats.
When the special session of the Legislature reconvenes this noon the chances of prompt passage for our new 21pound, 3,350-page City Code should be good.

President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull today led the nation in tribute to Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and coauthor of the pact to outlaw war, who died yesterday at the age of 81. Secretary Hull designated a personal representative to attend the funeral in St. Paul tomorrow in the Person of William Donovan, American Minister-designate to Uruguay.

Six members of the Department of Sanitation received medals and cash awards for saving four persons from drowning in the past year at special ceremonies held yesterday for the first time in the auditorium of the Health and Sanitation Building at 125 Worth Street.

A funeral service for George E. Akerson, former secretary to former President Hoover, will be held at 3:15 P. M. tomorrow in the Reformed Church of Bronxville. The Rev. Dr. John H. Powell, pastor of the church, will officiate.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 17,000, including 4,500 directs. The market closed 25c-35c higher than Tuesday's average. Spots were up more on butchers 210 pounds.

The marriage of Miss Emily Chadbourne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Merriam Chadbourne of 40 East Sixty-second Street, to Allen Hurlburt Minor, son of Colonel-and Mrs. John Crannell Minor, also of this city, and of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal

A field goal by William Sealy in the second extra period gave Alexander Hamilton High School a 21to-20 victory over Eastern District High on the latter's court in one of the feature P. S. A. L. basketball games yesterday.

Mrs. Frank C. Munson gave a dinner last night in the outdoor terrace of the Royal Victoria Hotel for Governor Charles Dundas of the Bahamas and Mrs. Dundas. Indirect lighting illuminated the tall coconut and palm trees which surround the terrace.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated Dec. 20: Bottom, Lt. Comdr. J. T., Jr., Mariners Harbor, S 1. N. Y., to office Naval Inspector Machinery, United Shipyards, Inc., New York, N. Y. Arnold, Jr. Lt. J. D., Pensacola, Fla., to VT-6, the Yorktown. Ethridge, Jr. Lt. W., Pensacola, Fla., to VB-6, the Yorktown. Packard, Jr. Lt. A. A., Pensacola, Fla., to VS-5, the Yorktown.
The lists of commercial rentals submitted yesterday by brokers and agents carried many leases for fullfloor space. Many of the tenants plan to use their new quarters for manufacturing purposes.

ALBERT-Ruth (nee Freedman), suddenly, on Monday, Dec. 20, 1937, dearly beloved and cherished daughter of Mrs. Hannah and the late Moritz Freedman, beloved sister of Pauline Tynberg, Lillian Nickelsburg, Beatrice Baran Bowen, Louis A. Freedman and Benjamin H. Freedman. Funeral 10 A. M. Thursday, Dec. 23, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

David H. McAlpine Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, announced last night contributions of $4,608.50 to the United Hospital Campaign from the General Electric Company and affiliated units and their employes.
Numerous complaints have reached the Civil Liberties subcommittee of the Senate Education and Labor Committee, from employers named in the committee's report as having. employed "labor spies."

With prices averaging 40 per cent lower than last year and foreign buyers bidding actively, the first auction sale of any substantial quantity of new season furs was held yesterday by the New York Auction Company. W. H. Tichenor,

General pay outs for all city employes or payless furloughs were predicted yesterday by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, as inevitable unless the city adopts an immediate policy of retrenohment to bring its expenditures within it revenues.
Commercial air service between New Zealand and the United States will be inaugurated Dec. 29 by the Samoan Clipper, Pan American Airways announced today.
Despite an injury to Cecil Smith, tengoal player, the Texas Rangers' polo team defeated a Mexican Army team today, 10 to 7.

A new health station for well babies was opened yesterday afternoon at 342 East Eighty-sixth Street by Mayor La Guardia and Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health. The gift of Mrs. Jesse Isidor Straus, it will be known as the Jesse Isidor Straus Child Health Station in memory of her husband, the late Ambassador to France.

After a close battle for three chukkers, the 112th Field Artillery indoor soloists forged ahead to defeat Essex Troop tonight, 17 1/2 to 12. Major Edward Towers's seven goals were outstanding in the triumph.

Trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today was dull and mainly of a local character, with a notable lack of the aggressive e support that was evident yesterday. Many professional traders turned to the bear aide and closing trades were at practically the bottom, with net losses of 3/4 to 1 1/2 cents a bushel.

The difference between the stage and screen versions of "First Lady" is approximately the difference between Jane Cowl and Kay Francis. That distinction, like Mercutio's wound, may not be so deep as a well, nor so wide as a church door, but it serves. It serves, indeed,

Interstate crime compacts, signed by the Governors of twenty-five States, pledging cooperation in the handling of criminals and paroled convicts, were filed today by Governor Hoffman with Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis.

Residents of Ventnor, N. J., presented to President Roosevelt a Christmas card two feet wide and four feet long. The card, signed by 200 persons, was presented personally by James J. Keating and Andrew F. McElroy, Ventnor citizens.

Mayor La Guardia expressed his thanks yesterday to his colleagues on the Sinking Fund Commission, which was holding its last meeting in City Hall before going out of existence under the terms of the new City Charter.
PARIS, Dec. 22.--To the long list of executions of political and militarv leaders in Soviet Russia, which began with the trial of Gregory Zinovieff and companions in August, 1936,

Good Omen, an inconsistent 4-yearold filly owned by Miss L. C. White, spoiled the well-laid plans of the talent today when she led the heavily played Bachelor Dinner and White Cockade home in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

HENDAYE, France (at the Spanish Frontier), Dec. 22.--Spanish Government troops, surging on through conquered Teruel, were reported tonight to be driving through disorganized Insurgent lines toward Albarracin, fifteen miles west.

" If there is any independence left, it is in New England" rather than in the rest of the land, said Wilbur L. Cross, Governor of Connecticut, last night in the Hotel Plaza at the annual dinner of the New England Society in the City of New York.

For the second time within the last six months, Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry ruled in an opinion filed here today that a strike was illegal when it had for its primary object the enforcement of a closed shop.

Members of the junior committees for the annual benefit Christmas festival concert of the People's Chorus of New York, which was held last night at Carnegie Hall, Attended a supper dance in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador after the concert.

Children excitedly looking forward to the arrival of Santa Claus nevertheless took time and thought to help bring Christmas cheer to other children for whom the day would otherwise be merely another one of suffering, according to some of the letters received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund.
Eastern and Western football stars, who will meet in the annual charity game here New Year's Day, settled down to hard practice today on widely separated fields.

Hubert B. Chappell has been elected a vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, it was announced yesterday. He will have charge of the bank's new branch in London, which is expected to be opened about March 1.
Count Rene de St. Quentin is to be the new French Ambassador in Washington. It is a name well known in America today,

Silvio Giolito of New York University turned back a strong bid by Daniel Bukantz, City College captain, last night to establish pretty conclusively that he will be a factor to be reckoned with in the forthcoming intercollegiate.

Miss Annette Hyde Vorhees, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Vorhees of this place, was married to Willard David Roberson of New York, son of Elisha M. Roberson of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Mrs. Roberson, tonight at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. Luke M. White, rector of St. Luke's Church here.

R. H. Macy Co. signed, yesterday its first agreement with a labor union when it entered into a contract with the Department Store Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate, covering 2,000 men in the delivery, warehouse and manufacturing departments of the company.

Returns from alcoholic beverage taxes were $2,165,701.55 in November, a decline of $6,717.81 as compared with the same month of 1936, Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner,. announced today, but the total for the first five months of the fiscal year, July to November inclusive, was $10,886,089.82, an increase of $326,160.27.

From the romantic South Seas came yesterday the story of a drowning kitten that fought an albatross and won. Today the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will present medals to the kitten's rescuers.
Tonight's major events: "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 o'clock; PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

Professor Nicholas A. Borodin, curator emeritus of fishes at the Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology and a former delegate to the United States from the provisional Kerensky government of Russia, died today at the Cambridge Sanatorium in his seventieth year. He had been an exile from Russia since 1918.
Claude (Tiny) Thornhill, who has guided Stanford in three Rose Bowl games, today picked California to defeat Alabama in the New Year's Day conflict.

64th St, 41 W, 25x100.5; also 82d St, 107-9 W, 83x102.2; also St. Mark's P1, 16, 26x126; also St. Nicholas Ave,- 440-6, 80.7x128x79.5x142.1; 107-9 West 82d St Corp (Irving Nichthauser, pres) to Herman Miller 1,641 York Ave, pr mtg, due as per bond; $4,150. Washington St. 365-7, 49.10x39.8; H E H Realty Co (Sam'l Eichhorn, pres) to Samuel Eichhorn, 2,690 Webb Ave, pr mtg. $40.000. 3 yrs. 5%; $10,000.

Two sailors from the United States cruiser Raleigh were married to Villefranche girls today. They were Roland Ouillet, 30, of Lawrence, Mass., who was wed to Maria Hueroupet, 32, and William Cerliki, 32, of Ware, Mass., who was married to Marie Allias, 20.

The Illinois Racing Commission today completed the schedule for 1938 by allotting 30 days to the Chicago Business Men's Racing Association, operating the Hawthorne track. The dates are from Sept. 5, Labor Day, to Oct. 8, inclusive.

Secretary Roper disclosed today that lawyers for the New York and Bermudian Air Line, Inc., of Hoboken, had discussed with the Deapartment of Commerce a proposal to establish a new airline between New York and Bermuda.

Plugging one more gap in the British social security program, Ernest Brown, Minister of Labor, announced today that 170,000 domestic servants employed in clubs, hospitals and other public institutions would be brought under the unemployment insurance scheme next April.

The resignation of Charles A. Davila, Ambassador from Rumania, creates a vacancy in the Washington diplomatic corps that will be difficult for any successor to fill. Mr. Davila's delightful personality made him a popular representative, but the important place he won for himself was the result of intellectual as well as personal qualities.

Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard urged the abolition of lunacy commissions in criminal cases, with amendment of the criminal code to refer such cases to psychiatric divisions of city hospitals, in a report yesterday to Mayor La Guardia.
A huge program of railroad, highway, canal and power-plant building under the management of the Commissariat of Internal Affairs [the secret police department] was announced today.

Mrs. Catherine Campbell-Bailey, sister of the late Frank E. Campbell, the undertaker, 'died of gas poisoning yesterday at the home of her sister, Mrs. Edward V. Peters, at 35-01 150th Place, Flushing, Queens. The police of the Bayside station said her death was accidental.

Secretary Wallace moved today to reunite the farm-labor group in Congress, which was divided during the closing days of the session by the contest which resulted in the defeat of the Wages and Hours Bill.
Adjournment of Congress without final action on the proposed amendments to the National Housing Act was no pleasing Christmas gift to builders and developers throughout the nation.

Athletic awards to ninety-five cadets at the United States Military Academy were recommended today by the Army Athletic Board for participation in Fall sports. Eighty-six members of the football, cross-country and soccer squads, as well as four cadet managers and five cheer leaders were among those honored.

Frank Calder, on the twentieth anniversary of his appointment as president of the National Hockey League, was the guest of honor at a testimonial dinner tendered to him by the board of governors of the league last night at the Hotel Commodore. About 150 persons attended the affair.

Mrs. Ethel Houston Decoursey, who had been active in amateur theatricals here and in Summer theatre projects elsewhere in the East, died last night in the Presbyterian Hospital. She became ill yesterday morning, lapsed into a coma and did not regain consciousness. She was 58.

As a National Labor Relations Board hearing of charges against the Ford Motor Company adjourned today until Dec. 29, it was learned that Trial Examiner Tilford E. Dudley was trying to end the four-week strike at the company's assembly plant here.
The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Dec. 15 shows that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation was 127.33 per cent, against 128.97 per cent on Nov. 30.

Golf professionals who work independently of their clubs do not have to pay social security taxes-but barbers who conform to shop rules and get a percentage of shop receipts are to be regarded as employes and must pay such taxes.

Electrical power output last week showed an increase smaller than anticipated on the basis of seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index declined to 97.1 from 98.5. The figure for the week ended Dec. 19, 1936, was 105.2.

Lionel S. Mapleson, for nearly fifty years librarian of the Metropolitan Opera and friend of almost every great singer during that period, died of a heart attack on Tuesday afternoon at his home, 10 Park Terrace East, the Bronx.
Sir Evan Spicer, former chairman of the London County Council and a member of the family of paper makers, died at Dulwich today at the age of 88.

The Bayonne Civil Court today granted a divorce to Grand Duke Dimitri, nephew of the late Czar Nicholas of Russia, and his American-born wife, Princess Anna Ilyinski, the former Miss Audrey Emery of New York.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Drummond of Auburn, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Loudon Drummond, to Edward Carrington Avery, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Irving Avery of Auburn.

A bomb, believed to have been tossed from an automobile as it speeded by the main entrance, tore a hole in the roof of the garage of the Garden State Bus Lines at 146 Passaic Street here about 11 o'clock tonight.
A tea dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Elliot Travers of 23 East Eighty-third Street yesterday at Sherry's to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Ann Travers.
St. John's University returned to its winning ways when the Redmen registered a 48-to-24 victory over the Illinois Wesleyan University five before a large crowd in the De Gray Gymnasium last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--President Roosevelt served notice on Congress today that it must assume full responsibility for appropriations in excess of budget estimates, and that if road building funds were not reduced other appropriations should be curtailed to make up the difference.

Deals reported yesterday in the Fieldston section of Riverdale featured realty activity in the Bronx. A. S. Brown, builder, sold to M. L. Delaney the Colonial dwelling at 4,451 Tibbett Avenue. The property was held at $30,000 and will be occupied by the buyer this week. Edgar G. Johnson was the broker in the sale.
Newly elected officers of the Inner Circle began preparations yesterday for the organization's annual stunt dinner at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria early in March.

Secretary Perkins revealed today that there was a decline of nearly 570,000 jobs in industrial employment in November as compared with October, but that the total of employed workers was only 4,000 fewer than in November, 1936.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, with unfilled orders totaling more than $6,125,000, announced today that it was increasing the floor space of its plant here by 25,000 square feet.

Despite a further recession in the production of steel ingots to 23 1/2 per cent of the country's capacity, spotty improvement in orders and inquiries is becoming more apparent and may be a forerunner of more widespread buying interest some time in January,

Clement R. Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition in the British Parliament, who recently returned to London from a trip to Spain, in a broadcast last night denounced the "tremendous amount of propaganda being put out against the Spanish Republic and its people." He spoke from London over the WABC-Columbia network.
Representatives of 52,000 up-State milk producers refused today a request by New York City distributors for a reduction in the producer price of milk shipped into the metropolitan market.

That the United States gunboat Panay was not intentionally machine-gunned by Japanese Army launches just before she sank in the Yangtze River ten days ago is the burden of an interim report issued by the Japanese Foreign Office today. The statement,
The Republican-controlled State House Commission voted today to buy a $4,500 automobile for the incoming Governr, a Democrat. The Legislature refused to make an appropriation for this purpose.

William E. Dodd, retiring United States Ambassador to Germany, said in a farewell speech today that the world must "face the sad fact that in an age when international cooperation should be the keyword, nations are farther apart than ever."
Like Tennyson's brook, "For men may come and men may go--," Connie Mack seems to go on forever in baseball. Tomorrow he will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:
Stocks sagged and closed heavy at slightly lower levels; turnover, 1,153,600 shares. United States Government issues lower; other bonds mixed; transactions, $8,733,150.
State Supreme Court Justice O. Byron Brewster of Elizabethtown will be the first president of Paul Smith's College of Arts and Sciences, which is scheduled to open next Fall.

The City Council voted tonight to license "pari-mutuel brokers" to handle bets on horse races. The unprecedented ordinance, designed to take the business into the open, drive hoodlums out, and raise $2,000,000 a year in revenue, was adopted by an overwhelming margin of 43 to 4.

By radio and by telegraph and letter, holiday greetings have been sent to soldiers and sailors wherever they are stationed, from President Roosevelt, Secretaries Woodring and Swanson, Assistant Secretary Edison, General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff of the army, and Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations.

Every one active in public life has uttered or written phrases and sentences which later arise to plague him, and the President is no exception. His famous attack, while Governor of New York, on Federal centralization is one of these; it has even entered the records of the Supreme Court.

A flutter has been caused in Denmark by the publication in Britain's lone Communist journal, The Daily Worker, of a report that Germany will found a new league of nations to lure the rich agricultural and -strategically important group of small States around the entrance of the Baltic Sea into the German-Italian network.

Nineteen pickets, all claiming to be veterans of the Spanish Loyalist army and one of them blind and lame, staged a demonstration last night outside the F. W. Woolworth Store at 1,518 Broadway, on the east side of Times Square between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, last night, caused a pedestrian tie-up on the block for fifty minutes and attracted such a large crowd that vehicular traffic was hampered.

The steamships Acadia and George Washington of the Eastern Steamship Lines sailed late yesterday afternoon for Boston and Norfolk respectively, with crews recruited from the waterfront as replacements of striking members of the National Maritime Union.
Retail deliveries showed an increase of 3 per cent for the week ended Dec. 18 over the corresponding period a year ago, according to figures issued 'yesterday by the United Parcel Service.
Continuing its undefeated pace, the Montclair A. C. squash tennis team added another victory to its string last night in the Metropolitan League Class. A interclub matches.

At least ten persons were injured tonight when the Eforia, this capital's largest revue theatre, burned down during the premiere of a new show before a packed house. . The fire broke out on the stage.
Milton Garges, who rose from telegraph operator to executive assistant to the general manager of The Associated Press, died in his home here last night at the age of 70.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernon S. Prentice will give a dinner dance tonight at the River Club for Miss Mary Josephine Cutting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting, whose marriage to Mrs. Prentice's son, Alexander McFadden, will take place on Jan. 1.

Scotland Yard detectives, trailing robbers who over the phone tricked Etienne Bellenger of Cartier's into taking [pound sterling]15,000 worth of gems on approval to a bedroom in a Hyde Park hotel on Monday and left him unconscious with a battered head, made four arrests tonight that shocked fashionable London.

With the assistance of Postmaster General James A. Farley and the United States Army, the old gentleman with the white beard who lives up on the North Pole was reported yesterday to be making magnificent progress with his Christmas deliveries.

Orie R. Kelly and his entire slate of officers have been renominated by the New-York Athletic Club for another year, it was announced yesterday. The annual election on Jan. 11 will be a mere formality since the choices of the nominating committee are unopposed.

Many loopholes in the present Ohio Securities Act are proposed to be closed under amendments drawn by Dan T. Moore, chief of the Division of Securities in the Department of Commerce and submitted in a bill to the Ohio General Assembly.
The Baltimore Orioles of the Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League staved off a last-period rush by Atlantic City tonight to win. 4-3.

Establishment in all city departments of an employe appeals system similar to that now existing in the Emergency Relief Bureau would improve the efficiency and morale of all classes of city workers, Osmond K. Fraenkel, chairman of the impartial hearings board of the ERB, told the governing board of the relief bureau in a report made public yesterday.

The proposed purchase of 141 new buses by trustees of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company was blocked today by Federal Judge George A. Welsh. The trustees also have been considering buying forty new trackless trolleys in a $2,000,000 imprbvement program.

Jake Kilrain, last of the bare-knuckle fighters, who slugged with Champion John L. Sullivan for seventyfive rounds in 1889 at Richburg, Miss., in a vain attempt to lift the heavyweight crown, died today of old age and diabetes in a private hospital. He was 78 years old.

" Between the Devil" is what Howard Dietz and Arthur Schwartz dub their new musical comedy, which opened for business at the Imperial last evening. Between the devil and the deep blue sea of a plot is what it turns out to be.
The unusually large number of sales made for cash on the New York Stock Exchange in the last few days has been attracting attention. Normally,
Two effects of the increasing tension in the Far East are plainly discernible in Europe. The first is a reduction in the scale of European controversies and conflicts.
Miss Wilmoth Cosby Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Thomas Gibson of this place, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance at the Hudson River Country Club, Yonkers.

Ada Hoffman, daughter of New Jersey's Governor, is working as a salesgirl this week in a Hearn's department store here to earn Christmas shopping money because, she said today, "I didn't like to ask my father for it."

William J. McDermott, 57 years old, a practicing lawyer for thirtyone years, who robbed seven inmates of insane asylums to speculate in the stock market, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan for two and one-half to five years on his conviction for one of the thefts.
Mrs. John Sloane of Mamaroneck, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Madelene Diane Sloane, to Smith Catlon Toulson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith C. Toulson of Montchanin, Del.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Werrenrath, daughter of Mrs. Ada Werrenrath of New York and of Reinald Werrenrath, singer, also of this city, to Carlton Brown Hutchins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton Brown Hutchins of Chicago, took place here last night,in the Church of the Transfiguration.

The board of directors of the Jersey City Chamber of Commerce in a resolution adopted today joined with Mayor Frank Hague in his pledged determination to keep the Committee for Industrial Organization out of this city and called a general meeting for next Wednesday inviting war veterans' groups and civic, fraternal and service clubs to "become interested."
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Arriving today from Europe on the French liner Normandie are Lord and Lady Rotham, Lady Gosford, Lady Atchinson, Sidney Wilkinson, Mr. and Mrs. D. H. Thornton, Mrs. Charles S. Sherrill, Mrs. Henri Morin de Linclays, Norberto Fisher, Dr. and Mrs. C. J. Davidson, Paul Elliott, Tommy Farr, Marian Anderson and Richard Rodgers.

The Soviet's reply to Finland's diplomatic protest last September against repeated violations of Finnish integrity by Russian army aviators has now arrived after the long delay--only to be considered unacceptable by the Finnish Government.
Japan will exact a 1,200,000-yen indemnity, besides a formal apology and the erection of a memorial tower, as satisfaction for the massacre at Tungchow, according to reports from Peiping.

Mrs. James Remsen Strong gavel a tea dance yesterday afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club for her granddaughter, Miss Nina Riker Van Vechten, who was introduced to society last month at a dinner dance given at Sherry's by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Van Vechten.
Charles S. Howard's Seabiscuit was declared out of the Christmas Day Handicap at Santa Anita today, leaving a field of twenty-two candidates eligible to race for the $5,000 purse.

A compromise arrangement under which Robert J. Watt of Massachusetts would continue as workers' representative on the governing body of the International Labor Office in Geneva is understood to have been worked out by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

New Jerseys agricultural income from crops, livestock and livestock products, including Government payments, was $90,893,000 for 1937, compared with $90,813,000 in 1936, it was announced today by the State Department of Agriculture.
The Labor Department will hold a hearing on charges that Harry Bridges, West Coast director for the Committee for Industrial Organization, is a communistic alien, Secretary Perkins announced today.

Jim Turner, one of the two pitching graybeards the Bees brought up from the minors last Spring, was the National League's most effective hurler for 1937, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

Only two women are known to have been arrested in the recent raids that netted 370 suspected agitators. They are Baroness Shizue Ishimoto, widely known in the United States, and Taiko Hirabayashi, a writer.

C. W. Kellogg, president of the Edison Electric Institute, tonight put on the government the blame for fear by the public, which he said had "seriously affected" the sales of utility securities to finance powerexpansion programs.

Mr. and Mrs. Mercer Beasley of New York and Bermuda have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Audrey. Beasley, to Arthur James McCulloch of the Royal Navy, eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander McCulloch of Liverpool.
President Roosevelt was revealed today as a collector not only of stamps and prints of sailing ships but also of Christmas cards.
The report of Central Aguirre Associates for the fiscal year ended on July 31, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $2,947,043 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.
President Arturo Alessandri submitted to Congress this afternoon a bill for the formation of a general fund for buying material for the army, navy and air force in the next ten years.

Miss Carolyn Blackstock Beardsley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alling Prudden Beardsley of Plainfield, was married to Buckley Crist of Bound Brook, N. J., this evening in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. John J. Moment, minister, performed the ceremony.

Mrs. C. Austin Whitehouse, member of the Authors League and the Pen and Brush Club, died early yesterday morning in Flushing Hospital. Her husband, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died two years ago.

Ordered that the following members of the Uniformed Force shall be allowed the time served by them in the Police Department, which shall be included and counted as service in the Fire Department: FIREMEN 4TH GRADE--Wiliam T. Donohue, Eng. 33; John J. Modelski, 233; John R. Peter, 261; John H. F. Fortmeyer, H. L. 110; Andrew Reder, 124.

The executive committee of the powerful Wafd (Nationalist) party, headed by Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha, today bowed to King Farouk's demand to take the Blueshirt Youth Army out of Egypt's political picture.

The Supreme Court's ruling that wiretapping is banned under the Federal Communications Act applies only in cases of interstate commerce, and government officers and the police may continue to tap wires that do not cross State lines, it was indicated yesterday in a decision by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
Mr. and Mrs. Sumner RulonMiller Jr. gave a dinner dance last night at the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Mary Jameson, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Jameson.

Louis Green, 41 years old, of 8,405 Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, and under Fred Odenwald, 45, of 106-09 Ninetyseventh Avenue, Ozone Park, Queens, who had been in custody as fugitives from justice in Pittsburgh, were ordered released yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett, in Brooklyn, before whom they appeared on a writ of habeas corpus.

Foster Strader, former district manager of the Railway Audit and Inspection Bureau office at 75 East Forty-fifth Street, appealed yesterday from a ruling last Oct. 21 by the New York Secretary of State denying him a license as a private detective.

Holly harvesters of the Delmarva peninsula counted an estimated $400,000 return today from Christmas wreaths they supplied to brighten the nation's windows. Old-timers of the holly woods of Maryland's Eastern Shore and lower Delaware regarded the fine crop they have shipped throughout the East this year as a forecast of a hard Winter, but the weather man so far has merely smiled tolerantly.
Heavyweight Max Schmeling returned from America like a hero today. His film actress wife, reporters and newsreel men boarded his boat, the Europa, in the North Sea and accompanied him to port.

Christmas bonuses and gifts from an employer to an employe are considered additional compensation, within the meaning of the Social Security Act, and are subject to taxation, James J. Hoey, Collector of.Internal Revenue for the Second New York District, announced last night.
Thomas Greenall, who began life as a pitboy in the last century and rose to be one of the founders of the Miners Federation of Great Britain, died today, aged 80.

William Bryan Nash, founder and senior member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Nash Co., 111 Broadway, died yesterday of pneumonia in the Muhlenberg Hospital here at the age of 58. His home was in Plainfield.
Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan headed a group of city officials and engineers who opened the last bank of the new elevators in the Manhattan Municipal Building for service yesterday.

Mrs. Shepard Fabbri gave a ball last night in her house at 7 East Ninety-fifth Street for her debutante grandniece, Miss Anne Louise Schieffelin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin Jr. of 1,220 Park Avenue.

Philip Wimett, 24-year-old Benson farmer, who admitted in Rutland Municipal Court today that he slew a deer out of season to provide meat for his starving wife, received a mandatory sentence of sixty days.

If the British Government partition plan of Palestine becomes a reality, the Palestine Foundation Fund, as the financial instrument of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, will become the fiscal agency for the creation of a Jewish state there, Louis Lipsky, chairman of the fund, told 400 persons at its annual meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

The commander of the HamburgAmerican liner Hansa today obtained permission to land a woman stowaway here for repatriation to New York. The woman, who gave her name as Catherine Schwartz, alias Molly Millison, was born in Chicago in 1913.

Plans were announced yesterday for afifty-family apartment house at the southwest corner of Clinton Place and North Avenue, New Rochelle, N. Y. Excavation work has been started, and Charles Mayone of Larchmont, owner and builder, expects to have the house ready for occupancy next Spring.

Roland Gundry, an exceptionally talented violinist, made his New York debut last night at Town Hall. Although but 15 years of age, he played a noble and difficult program with technical brilliance, fine sense of style and mature grasp of the musical content of the varied compositions presented.

The combined net operating income of the first six railroads to report for November showed a decline of 39.1 per cent from the total for November, 1936. This was a larger drop than was shown in October.
Christmas will be celebrated at the White House this year with all the timehonored observances dear to the Roosevelt family and with certain extra traditional festivities planned by "the children,"

Swift approval of the proposed New York City administrative code at tomorrow's special session of the Legislature, predicted after agreement on amendments, remained contingent tonight on appearance of sufficient lawmakers to provide the required vote.
A first dividend of $179,140, representing 13-per cent of the claims against the Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company of America, was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance.

George F. Rand, president of the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo, N. Y., testified today that during several years before 1936 there was a depreciation of 82 per cent in the value of bank stocks acquired by Marine Union Investors, Inc.

MANHATTAN BROWN, ANNIE L. (Dec. 9). Estate, more than $30,000. To Joseph H. and William P. Wright Jr., 1 Gray St., Cambridge, Mass., $1,000 each and contingent interests in trust; May Lester Brown, daughter. 105 W. 72d St., household effects, jewelry, $3,000 annuity and onehalf residuary income; Edith Brown Wright, 168 W. 74th St., jewelry and onehalf residuary income. Edward Beck, 300 W. 71st St.. and William P. Wright, 168 W. 74th St., executors.

Problems of State government reform were discussed last night before 300 members of the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, chairman of an advisory committee appointed by Governor Lehman to prepare data for the forthcoming constitutional convention.
Lord Monteagle of Brandon, retired naval officer, who devoted much of his interests to social credit and currency reform, died today, at the age of 85.

A number of hunters seem to be taking an increased interest in predator control these days, and this number would be even greater if sportsmen had a broader knowledge as to just how much game fell to the fox and wildcat each year.

The Federal Communications Commission disclosed today that the Western Union Telegraph Company, the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation and the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company had filed a joint petition requesting a 15 per cent increase in domestic rates.

Figures compiled overnight and submitted to Governor Cross's office today by Controller Charles C. Swartz indicated that Connecticut paid out $4,043,417 for 1,301 acres of right of way for the incomplete Merritt Parkway, from the Hutchinson River Parkway at the New York State line across Fairfield County to the Housatonic River bridge.
The Internal Revenue Bureau announced today that it had overassessed by $37,230.43 the 1922 income of Edward S. Harkness of New York City.

The American Institute of Marine Underwriters announced yesterday that, effective Feb. 1, war risk insurance would be discontinued on goods when ashore, except when they are landed temporarily in the course of transshipment.
The growth of membership in the 100 Per Cent Rented Club of the Herman A. Acker Corporation is seen as an evidence of improvement in occupancy of Bronx apartments.

PROMOTIONS Nineteen lieutenants were promoted to the rank of captain. Their names appear elsewhere in the paper Lieutenants The following promotions of sergeants to the rank of lieutenant were announced: Michael J. Flynn, 14th Precinct.

In his twenty-third year Joseph Duraccio learned recently who his father is. Both were making a .weekly visit to the State Board of Parole office when the son learned his father had been a murderer. Pasquale Duraccio stood before the youth he had abandoned as an infant and learned he had grown up to be a hold-up man.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: Welte, Capt. Eugene J., Cav., having quailtied, is placed on duty. He is to report to the commanding officer, 121st Cavalry. for assignment to Troop E.
Franz Kessler, 28-year-old Austrian ski expert, arrived on the North German Lloyd Liner Bremen yesterday and immediately left for the Eastern Slope region of New Hampshire,

More than 1,000 parishioners and other guests attended a testimonial dinner to Mgr. John D. Roach, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Spirit, 1,940 University Avenue, the Bronx, at the Hotel Commodore last night in honor of his recent elevation by Pope Pius XI to the rank of domestic prelate.

The Rev. Bernard G. Schuette, pastor emeritus of Saints Peter and Paul Catholic Church at Naperville and for fifty years a member of the priesthood, died today in St. Charles Hospital, Aurora, at the age of 74.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., operator, has purchased for cash from George T. Bowdoin the two-story private garage at 159 East Thirtyfifth Street assessed at $36,500. The sale, the first involving the property since 1907, was negotiated by William A. White Sons, brokers.

The marriage of Miss Mary Learned Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Hall of Plainfield, N. J., to George Davol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Davol of Brookline, took place this afternoon in the Church of Our Saviour in Brookline. The ceremony was followed by a reception.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Rembrandt's Etchings," Roberta M. Fansler, 11 A. M.; "American Furniture: Pioneer Types," Ethelwyn Bradish, noon; Collection of Roman Art (general tour), 2 P. M.

Announcement was made here yesterday of the death last week in Paris of Adrien de Pachmann, one of the leaders of the Paris bar specializing in cases requiring knowledge of both French and American law.
In its report on labor espionage, the civil liberties subcommittee of the Senate Education and Labor Committee, consisting of Messrs. Thomas and La Follette, has performed an essential service.

While less than the number received a year ago, entries for the stake races to be run by the Westchester Racing Association during 1939 and 1940 at Belmont Park are regarded as very satisfactory, according to an announcement made by the association yesterday.
The Cuban Senate ratified this afternoon the inter-American radio convention, the North American regional broadcasting agreement and the Madrid communications convention of 1932.
Contracts were awarded for $10,892,700 worth of residential construction work in the New York metropolitan area during November, a report issued by the F. W. Dodge Corporation revealed yesterday.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Nov. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $24,137,468.. This is equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $2.59 a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $25,025,916, or $2.76 a common share, in the twelve months to Nov. 30, 1936.
Mrs. Esther F. Roark, formerly of Boston and Pebble Beach, Calif., won a divorce today from Aidan Roark, film executive and polo star. She testified that he was rude and brusque.

A severe cold will prevent the Brazilian pianist, Guiomar Novaes, from appearing in her scheduled concerts with the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra this evening, tomorrow afternoon and Sunday afternoon. Amparo Iturbi, pianist, sister of the pianist and conductor, Jose Iturbi, will take Miss Novaes's place, playing the originally listed Beethoven G major concerto, No. 4.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson promoted his campaign for lower gas rates in Philadelphia today with the announcement that he would ask the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission to investigate "circumstances surrounding" the council's adoption of a new gas lease with the United Gas Improvement Company.

One of the supreme masterpieces of the literature of music-drama, a work that stands lonely and incomparable in conception and inspiration, and that had been long in winning public recognition of its greatness, came last night into its own in the Metropolitan Opera House. The opera was Verdi's "Otello."

In defiance of the Senate Finance Committee and a time-honored custom governing appointments, President Roosevelt reappointed F. Roy Yoke today as Collector of Internal Revenue for the West Virginia district. On Monday the Senate committee refused to confirm an original recess appointment of Mr. Yoke and it automatically became void.

Broadway, 1,141-3, 9-story brick loft and store building, 50.2x96.11xirreg; Franklin Savings Bank of N Y against Mary H. D. Dyer: due, $255,379; to plaintiff for $200,000. By SIDNEY SOLOMON 23d St, 26 E, 4-story stone office and store building, 24.8x98.9; Guaranty Trust Co of N Y against Janbyr Realty Co; due, $103,821: to plaintiff for $95,000.

A ring favorite went down last night at the Hippodrome where Baby Salvy Saban, rock-ribbed, steel-jawed Greenwich Village welterweight, hammered his way to a decision over crafty Leonard Del Genio of Harlem in a torrid tenround battle that also saw a championship march checked.

Although Glenda Farrell and Barton MacLane are no longer on the Warner contract list, the studio is negotiating with both to return periodically to continue the "Torchy Blane" series with which they are identified. They have consented to one and George Bricker is writing "Torchy' in Panama" for production in February.

Directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York have appointed John William McKeon an assistant vice president of the bank, effective Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday. Mr. McKeon, who is an assistant cashier in the foreign exchange trading department of the National City Bank, will be assigned to the foreign function of the Reserve Bank, which is under the general supervision of L. W. Knoke, vice president of the bank.
Governor Lehman gave a Christmas present of freedom today to six State prison inmates, including two serving life terms. The four others received reductions ranging from one to three years.

Litigation involving the ownership of islands in the Great South Bay and part of Jones Beach on Long Island which has been in the courts for the last ten years has been ended with the refusal of the United States Supreme Court in the Seaman-Gore case to review the findings of lower courts confirming title of the State of New York and several Long Island towns, according to the Long Island State Park Commission.

Dean Henry W. Holmes urged the Harvard Graduate School of Education today to help reduce "economic illiteracy" by attempting to determine "what should be taught in schools concerning economic and occupational life."

The senior dinner dance in the series of subscription parties conducted by Miss Adeline King Robinson for juniors in society took place last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The dances were originated about forty years ago.

Sir Tukoji Rao Puar, former Maharajah of Dewas, who followed the dancing girl Janki into exile, died today. Infatuated with the dancing girl, the ex-ruler fled his Indian State in 1933, leaving an empty treasury. He was charged with extortion and maladministration.
Harvey Gravell, a paint manufacturer in- Ambler, gave each of his seventy married workers a check today for $300 with this statement: "This is for your wife, not for you."
Mrs. Dula Rae Drake, wife of John A. Drake, financier and turf patron, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in her home, 344 West Seventy-second Street.

Findlay Ave, 1,358 (11-2782), Yetta Beckerman to Bowery Savings Bank, extends mtg. to Aug. 12, 1940, at 4 1/2 per cent; $11,000. Bronx River Ave, 1,412-14 (15-3885), lda Redbord to Board of Founders, Ginling College, 150 5th Ave, installments, 4 1/2 per cent; $15,000.

Listing application for 633,383 shares of Davison Chemical Corportion common stock was approved yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The governing committee also approved listing of Commonwealth Edison Company first mortgage gold bonds,

Even the most law-abiding of us are inclined to look on a policeman as a kind of school teacher who often makes us do things we don't want to and keeps us from doing things we do want to, and doesn't always sympathize with our innocent desire to climb lampposts or snake-dance in the middle of the street.

CONNIE MACK celebrates his seventy-fifth birthday today--doubtless in his favorite retreat in the tower of Shibe Park--and through-out the land there cannot be a man, however remotely connected with baseball, who would not extend his heartiest congratulations to this grand old character.

The Rev. Cranston Brenton of 27 Grace Court, Brooklyn, chaplain and secretary to Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Long Island Protestant Episcopal Diocese, died on Tuesday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, after he .had suffered a heart attack at Remsen and Court Streets, Brooklyn.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President-elect, confirmed a report yesterday that he had appointed S. W. Gerson, City Hall reporter for The Daily Worker and a member of the State executive committee of the Communist party, as "confidential inspector" on his staff.

An opinion that the young man of today should be "more careful" in his choice of a wife was voiced here this afternoon by Obadiah A. Hummer, who, with his wife, Mrs. Carrie Wilson Hummer, will observe the seventieth anniversary of their marriage next Sunday.
Louis Lacey, pillar of Argentine polo and one of the world's most famous players, has decided to quit championship polo. He will continue to play in club tournaments indefinitely, however.

Charles Falci, the middle-aged Tammany henchman of Albert Marinelli, East Side district leader and former County Clerk, was released from the Tombs in $1,000 bail yesterday after spending the night there on a faded indictment accusing him of fraudulent polling practices in the 1932 general elections.

Although it had seemed likely that Guthrie McClintic and Katharine Cornell would return with the American rights to "Robert's Wife," the new St. John Ervine play, they did not take an option on it. Miss Cornell, who returned here with Mr. McClintic yesterday on the Bremen, said that she had found the play "tremendously interesting," but gave the impression that it was not for her.

Awards for engineering construction made in the current short week due to the Christmas holiday, totaling $45,474,000, are 9 per cent below the same week of last year, when the figure was $49,856,000, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land of the Maritime Commission appeared today before the Senate Commerce Committee and, while no one would say what the discussion was about, it is understood that he was asked for details of negotiations with the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and other oil companies for the building of a fleet of tankers with speed enough to serve with the fleet in a national emergency.

Ignoring political recommendations, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court appointed yesterday Archibald R. Watson, editor of The New York Law Journal, as County Clerk for New York, and Michael B. McHugh, a Municipal Court Justice, as County Clerk for the Bronx. Both appointments are effective Jan. 1.

The Amateur Athletic Union, which yesterday assumed control of amateur bicycling in the United States, has appointed Otto W. Eisele, the president of the Amateur Bicycle League of America, as the chairman of its bicycling committee, A. A. U. President Samuel E. Hoyt announced.

The Maurice and Laura Falk Foundation announced today a $30,000 grant to the National Bureau of Economic Research, New York, for an eighteen-month study of changes in the amount and character of goods produced in America since 1914.

The application of the Botany Worsted Mills for listing of their preferred and Class A stock has been rejected by the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange, on the ground that certain features of the company's capitalization under its reorganization plan do not comply with Exchange requirements.

The new Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson River between midtown Manhattan and Weehawken, N. J., began to function yesterday as another of the city's important highway links to New Jersey and points west.

Two little daughters of the Japanese Ambassador spoke Yuletide greetings of peace and good-will today to a troubled world at the annual international children's party arranged by the Washington Board of Trade and the National Broadcasting Company.
Mr. Jeremiah Milbank in a letter accompanying his customary gift to the Neediest Cases Fund (and one remembers also a contribution

Heath Av., 2.912, 2-story brick dwelling, 26x100.7; Home Owners Loan Corp. against Salvador Persico, due, $18,265, taxes, etc., $212; to plaintiff for $9,000. Paulding Av., 1,821, dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp. against Margaret Esposito, due, $10,571, taxes, etc., 493; to plaintiff for $2,600.

The strike called by the Transport Workers Union against the twenty-four companies comprising the Sunshine-Radio taxicab system remained unsettled and unbroken last night despite the efforts of Nathan Frankel, labor adviser to Mayor La Guardia, to end the controversy.

The German attitude toward recent incidents in China involving foreigners fundamentally appears to be that the procedure of the Japanese does not concern Germany directly despite their diplomatic relationships.

Santa Claus, in blue uniform and brass buttons, paid a pre-Christmas. visit to poor children yesterday when the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department began the distribution of toys. The toys were collected from citizens, who gave both new and old, and the old ones were reconditioned by firemen and policemen. The distribution will continue today in the populous East Side precincts.

Mrs. Theodore, Kiendl and her debutante daughter, Miss Helen Vaughan Kiendl, entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for Miss Virginia Bacon Penfield, who made her debut on Tuesday at a supper dance given by-her mother, Mrs. Eugene W. Ong, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Frederick Lawrence, a cripple who had only one leg, lost his life when fire swept his frame dwelling on Old Kensico Road here this morning. State police said he was trapped in the basement, where the fire started, after he had shouted an alarm to other occupants. He was 47 years old and formerly was a New York Central watchman at the Marble Avenue crossing here.

Dr. John Hoch, who practiced medicine in New York from 1894 until he retired in 1929, died last night in his home here. He was 69 years old. After his graduation from City College he studied medicine in the College of Physicians and Surgeons and for the next two years he did post-graduate work in Vienna and Berlin.

Seeking to obtain inter-coastal passenger traffic resulting from the withdrawal of Grace Liners on Jan. 7, and possible abandonment by Panama-Pacific ships later, the General Steamship Corporation announced today a substitute service.

At the Bath and Tennis Club, Mrs. Elden C. De Witt gave a luncheon today. Her guests included Mrs. George A. Dobyne, Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff, Mrs. George FinchHatton, Mrs. Walter Furman Schuyler, Mrs. John Edwin Dietz, Mrs. Ernest G. Howes,
The navy said today a warning order had been issued against commercial flights over a section between San Diego, Calif., and Mexicali, Mexico, where routine airbombing exercises are to be held.
Small, wondering girl, whose hair So soft, and whose young eyes Are blue as child, of mineHow wan she seems, who lies So hungry and so cold Beneath the Winter skies!

Sale of a New York Curb Exchange membership for $17,500, down $4,000 from the previous sale and the lowest quotation since March 15, 1935, when a membership changed hands for $12,000, was reported yesterday.
Villanova annexed its seventh straight basketball victory by defeating Assumption College tonight, 30 to 21.

After fifteen years of service on the Supreme Court bench, Justice Ernest I. Edgcomb of Syracuse will retire from the Appellate Division tomorrow because of the 70-year age limit. He will participate in his last court session tomorrow.
Handy Harman, leading bullion dealers here, have adopted a policy of quoting two prices for silver in this market, it became known yesterday. One price,

Detailed instructions for filling out and mailing applications for unemployment insurance benefits were issued yesterday by State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.
