Forms for the simultaneous filing of applications for employment and notices of unemployment will be available at all postoffices from Dec. 27 to Jan. 3 inclusive, but no completed cards are to be put in the mail before Jan. 1, Mr. Andrews announced.

Miss Edith Patricia Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herrman Friedman of 1,000 Park Avenue, was married last evening in Temple Emanu-EI to Dr. Jacob Begner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Begner of Philadelphia.
An abandoned house at 711 Grote Street, the Bronx, used as a play spot by children of the neighborhood, collapsed at 5 o'clock last night while a dozen boys were inside.

Miss Louise Branch, originator and executive chairman of Dance International, has invited Miss Bess Ehrhardt, star of the Ice Follies skating revue at Madison Square Garden, to present her interpretation of the dance in the universal festival at Rockefeller Center.

Lieutenant Poyntell C. Staley, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. P. C. Staley of Providence, married Miss Mary Alger Smith, daughter of Commander Roy Campbell Smith, U. S. N., of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Smith, this afternoon at Trinity Church here.

The Celotex Corporation, manufacturer of insulating materials, announced today a plan to acquire 9,496 preferred and 109,360 common shares of the Certain-teed Products Corporation, manufacturer of asphalt and gypsum products.

Plans for two new elementary schools and one high school, to be built at a combined cost of $3,700,000, were filed yesterday with the Manhattan Buildings Department by Walter C. Martin, architect for the Board of Education.
A hitch developed yesterday over the signing of the proposed Joe Louis-Nathan Mann heavyweight championship bout, tentatively scheduled for Madison Square Garden, Feb. 23. Billy Brown,

Mrs. Osa Johnson, explorer and lecturer, who has pending a suit for $502,539 over the death of her husband, Martin E. Johnson, in an airplane accident Jan. 12, filed suit today for $204,000 for injuries to herself in the same crash.

The indications are for cloudy and colder weather today, and tomorrow will be cloudy and moderately cold, probably with rain or snow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

Minister of Finance Arthur de Souza Costa stated today that the government was seeking uniform taxes. over the entire country, but that at the same time the government wished to find a formula for helping some States handicapped by the reduction in the Federal coffee export tax.

Manhattan 78th St, 180 E; 24x30; for 1-story residence; Robert Goelet and Duke of Roxburghe. 608 5th Ave, owner; R. B. Thomas, architect; cost, $4,100. Alterations 3d Ave. 1.187-1,201; to 14-story warehouse: Lincoln Warehouse Corp. premises, owner; George S. Kingsley, architect; cost, 15,000.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 21: COLONELS Mather, J., Ordnance Dep't., Office Assistant Secretary War, Washington, D. C., effective May 31, 1938, to Watertown Arsenal, Watertown, Mass.

6th St., 426 E: Union Dime Savings Bank to Louis Akst, 15 Elliott P1; purchasemoney mtg, $11,000 ($12.50). 83d St, 310 E; Lillian Weitz to Deacon Realty Corp, 3 E 44th St; mtg $10,000 and purchase-money mtg $15,000 ($27). Broadway. 3,160, n e cor Meylan P1; Samuel Neufeld to Reglen Realty Co, 3,160 Bway. 149th St, 452-6 W; Setrose Realty Corp, David R. Rosenbaum, president, to Delset Holding Corp, 521 5th Ave.
Five evening high and trade school principals were chosen by the Board of Education yesterday at its regular meeting at 500 Park Avenue. Four of the places went to men and one to a woman.

For the first time in Rumanian history the government has been defeated in general elections. Premier George Tatarescu's Cabinet obtrained only 38.5 per cent of the total vote in Monday's balloting for the Chamber of Deputies instead of the requisite minimum of 40 per cent.

The meeting of directors of the New Haven Clock Company, scheduled for yesterday, has been postponed until Dec. 29. The American Surety -Company and its affiliate, the New York Casualty Company, held their annual Christmas party yesterday in the American Surety Building.
Great Britain's policy of watchful waiting in the Far East was endorsed by the Cabinet today on the eve of the Christmas holidays and the sixweek parliamentary recess.

Although James G. Robinson, acting executive director of the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission, has been paid during the past year at the rate of $1,000 a month and it had been assumed that the same salary would be set for Governor Hoffman if he accepts the position, which recently was offered to him, it was disclosed today that the commission last January set $15,000 annually as the remuneration.

TUTZING, Germany, Dec. 22(AP).--General Erich Ludendorff,-honored by the German nation and saluted by Chancellor Adolf Hitler at impressive rites in Munich, was buried today in the picturesque cemetery of this simple Bavarian village.

Scoring a clean sweep over the Rockaway Hunting Club last night, the Yale Club team, playing on its home courts, maintained its lead in the race for honors among the Group I Class C teams of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

High over Boston Airport a brightly costumed Santa Claus stepped from a circling plane tonight and drifted lazily down, suspended by a-wind-caught parachute, only to drop and disappear in the waters of Boston Harbor as a Christmas party of children looked on horrified.
The Sugar Bowl game here New Year's Day between Santa Clara and Louisiana State University probably will be the most expertly viewed football game in history.

Ten "outstanding non - fiction books of 1937" have been selected by the Literary Advisory Board of Current History. Members of the board are Van Wyck Brooks, Henry Seidel Canby, John Dewey, Amy Loveman, Dorothy Thompson, John W. Withers and M. E. Tracy.
Tony Manero, with a pair of 34s, was the only golfer to break the tricky par 70 of the Miami Springs municipal course today as the pros tuned up for the $2,500 Miami open, starting tomorrow.

The annual meeting of shareholders of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was adjourned yesterday until Jan. 22 because of a lack of a quorum. This marks the fourth time that the meeting has been adjourned for the same reason.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--Capitol officials estimated today the thirty-seven-day special session of Congress cost about $325,000. This total, they explained, did not include such items as salaries of Senators and Representatives, $10,000 a year, and much incidental expense which is paid on an annual basis without regard to how many times Congress meets.
Southern Blvd (11-3111), w s, 111 ft s of 181st St, 46x149; N. L. Construction Corp to Pauline M. Bell, 147 W 230th St; mtg $11,000.

A survey of open-market sales of real estate in the last year indicates that Manhattan properties are over-assessed on an average of 20 per cent, according to Jones W. Mersereau, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Mayor La Guardia flatly refused yesterday to remove Dr. S. S. Goldwater as Commissioner of Hospitals after a delegation of seventy-five Negro nurses and doctors had asked for the removal at a meeting with the Mayor in his temporary offices at the Empire State Building.

A "family quarrel" among the three directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority came into the open today when two directors accused Chairman A. E. Morgan of making statements with "false and malicious" inference.

Charles B. Rogers, long a financial and industrial leader in Central New York, died today at his home at Clinton. He was chairman of the board of the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company of Utica, treasurer and trustee of Hamilton College and had served as director of Utica corporations, some of which he helped to organize.

The stork derby will Qf.Charles Vance Millar was declared legal today by the Supreme Court of Canada. It ruled that the Toronto attorney had a right to bequeath his fortune (estimated at more than $500,000) to the mother who bore the most children in Toronto during a ten-year period dating from his death, but it also ruled that illegitimate children did not count.

The tenth annual Christmas Festival of the People's Chorus of New York was held last night at Carnegie Hall under the direction of the organization's founder, L. Camilieri. The program was given with the assistance of an orchestra composed of sixty. members of the Philharmonic-Symphony.
An estate of $59,352 was left by Dr. Ellis Paxson Oberholtzer, historian, when he died on Dec. 9, 1936, according to an inventory filed today.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe denied yesterday motions for dismissal of a mail fraud and conspiracy indictment and a directed verdict of acquittal for the State Title and Mortgage Company and four of its former officers, who have been on trial six weeks.

Nearly 2,000 children of the downtown district filed through the New York Curb Exchange yesterday afternoon for the Exchange's annual Christmas party. Entertainers sang, music was played and Santa Claus, in the person of Otto Williams of the Exchange staff, gave each child a bag containing a sweater, fruit, candy, a box of fancy crackers and an order for a pair of shoes.

Lady Astor, the former Nancy Langhorne of Virginia, first woman member of the House of Commons, arrived yesterday with Lord Astor on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, declaring that Great Britain and the United States "must stand firm to hold the peace of the world."

The Madrigal Singers, Lehman Engel conductor, gave a program last night at the Theatre of Music in double celebration of the holiday season and of the 300th anniversary of the birth of the composer, Dietrich Buxtehude.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 21, unless specified: At NOB, Norfolk, Dec. 22: Acushnet, Rewaydin; Dec. 21, New York. At Manila: Bulmer, Edsall, Parrott, Stewart. At San Diego Dec. 22: Tucker, Worden. Puget Sound Yard to sea: Northampton, Tatnuck. Dec. 22.

Death Valley Scotty invited a few friends today to come to his $2,381,000 castle in Grapevine Canyon for a Christmas feast. "I can't get up in the dry range to shoot a ram, so we'll just have a turkey feast," wrote the prospector. "That big mule, Barnum,.
Burglars invaded the home here of Bernhard K. Schaefer, New York coffee importer, carrying away jewelry valued at $15,000, last night, it was disclosed today by police.

Mr. and Mrs. Sol E. Rains of 145 Central Park West have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Julia Rains, to Julian S. Bach Jr., son of Mrs. Julian S. Bach of 911 Park Avenue and of t Julian S. Bach, also of this city.

Three Bergen County judges, who have been serving under ad interim appointments since the first of the year and whose nominations for full terms were withdrawn by Governor Hoffman at the final session of the Legislature this week, received new recess appointments from the Governor today.
Walter Alexander Wood, secretary-manager of the Engineers Club of Baltimore, well known in building and manufacturing circles, died yesterday, aged 73. Mr. Wood was a native of Pennsylvania.

Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, president of the National Public Housing Conference, disavowed yesterday responsibility for statements appearing in the December issue of Public Housing Progress, official organ of the conference, with reference to Mayor La Guardia's housing policies.

Several Long Island City industrial properties figured in yesterday's report of realty transactions in Queens. The Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company sold to the Wiljo Company, Inc., for cash the vacant plot 100 by 100 feet on the west side of Crescent Street, 100 feet north of Forty-first Avenue, Long Island City, through James C. McCormick and Harold A. Hawkins, co-brokers.

One hundred and fifty guests attended a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Alanson Trask Enos Jr. of Greenwich at the Field Club this evening in honor of their debutante daughter, Miss Susan Hulbert Enos, who is home for the holidays from Vassar College.

Judge and Mrs. Irving Lehman of 119 East Seventy-first Street gave a reception and dinner dance last night at the Waldorf-Astoria for their daughter, Miss Jane Lehman. and for Miss Anne Straus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Grant Straus.

It is scarcely a fair test of the work of the special session of Congress to say that it succeeded in pressing to final enactment no new legislation of any Importance. Congress is properly a deliberative assembly.

The bond market generally was lower yesterday with a diminished volume of business. Sizable offerings of United States Government obligations, depressing the market in these securities as such as 3/4 point, were believed to be factors in the general decline and resulted in final quotations being around the low level for the day.

The Japanese Army confidently expects to celebrate the year's close with a triumphal entry into Hangchow, south of Shanghai, before Jan. 1. With a tone tinged with scorn the army spokesman said today:

Movements of naval vessels follow, all dates are Dec. 22 unless specified: At, Puget Sound Yard: Northampton, Patterson. At San Diego: Selfridge, Vega. Ashville, Swatow to Hong Kong. Isabel, at Manila, Dec. 23. S-45, at Coco Solo.

Following the drastic shake-up in the Police Department Wednesday came indications yesterday that the wave of reorganization would soon sweep over the detective division and a hint that the Manhattan main office squad might be abolished.

The Cinderella Dance, which is held annually for young women from 15 to 18 years of age, and young men took place last night at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn Heights. The dance was founded twenty-eight years ago by Mrs. James Guthrie Shaw, and is the oldest entertainment of the kind to be held consecutively in Brooklyn.
Dr. James L. Vanderbeek, school dentist, who served as a lieutenant in the Dental Corps in the World War, died today at Overlook Hospital of pneumonia after an illness of five days.
Frankie Caris, 160, of Philadelphia won a ten-round decision from Roosevelt Rowe, 157, of Philadelphia tonight.
Officials arranging for the Senate's unemployment Investigation beginning Jan. 4 indicated today that it would develop into a broad analysis of the extent of the business recession.

Mrs. Scott Clark of The Springhouse, this place, has announced the engagement of her ward, Miss Helen Winslow Williams, to David Prescott Hall, Midshipman of the United States Naval Academy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Howe Hall of Philadelphia.

Frank Harris, a former organizer for the Inland Boatmen's Union, a subsidiary of the National Maritime Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate, charged yesterday in Supreme Court that he had been forced to join the-Communist party and contribute $5 a week of his $45 pay in order to remain an employee of the union.

A statement calling upon Senator Key Pittman of Nevada and his associates in the Congressional silver bloc to produce statistical evidence to support the assertion that 400,000 persons are employed as a consequence of the government subsidy to silver producers was issued yesterday by Walter E. Spahr, secretary-treasurer of the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy.
Mr. and Mrs. John Schaffernoth of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Henrietta S. Schaffernoth, to Henry A. Dreyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Dreyer of Cranford.

The United States Lines Company went to its sea-going personnel yesterday with a defense of its refusal to sign a wage agreement with the National Maritime Union,. by distributing several hundred copies of a statement addressed "to the men who man our ships."
Federal Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn has instructed lawyers in the reorganization proceedings afration to prepare and settle orders of confirmation of the reorganization plan.

A dinner dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Mason Brayman Starring last night at the Plaza to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Eleanor Lathrop Starring. Mrs. Starring and her daughter received before a bower of cybotium ferns trimmed with cornucopias filled with white snapdragons and red roses.

Four new trophy races will feature the annual indoor track and field meet of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, which will be held Saturday night, Jan. 15, at the 165th Infantry Armory. Captain William D. Lynch, director of the meet, plans to invite the foremost runners in training to compete in these new events.
A Japanese merchantman in Savannah harbor dipped its colors this morning to the United States Coast Guard cutter Tallapoosa as the cutter came up the river.

Agreement on payment of the public works bonds in default since 1933 was reached with formal acceptance of the proposal of the Cuban Government chan commission by representatives of the United States bondholders, made public today.
Stolid Dave Kerr recorded his sixth shutout of the National Hockey League season tonight as the New York Rangers defeated the lowly Montreat Maroons, 4 to 0.

The Annalist index of wholesale commodity prices declined in the week ended on Wednesday to 85.2, the lowest point of the year to date. This compared with 85.7 (revised) for the preceding week and 89.7 a c year ago.
The cost of reproducing the railroads of the United States new, except land and rights, would be $26,238,856,914, the Interstate Commerce Commission announced today.

Colonel Jay L. Benedict of the infantry was promoted today to the rank of brigadier general and named by Secretary Woodring to become superintendent of the Military Academy at West Point. He will succeed Major Gen. William D. Connor, who will retire from service in February.

New business booked by the structural steel fabricating industry in November totaled 136,542 gross tons, the largest in volume since July, but slightly below the average for the year. October bookings were 46,912 tons, the year's low, the high being 206,321 tons in March. In November, 1936, bookings were 121,607 tons.
Walter F. Whitmore, president of Whitmore, Rauber Vicinus, oldest firm of contractors in Rochester, died last night. He was 64 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Bernon S. Prentice gave a dinner dance last night at the River Club for Miss Mary Josephine Cutting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting, and Alexander McFadden, son of Mrs. Prentice, whose marriage will take place on Jan. 1.
SECOND MILITARY AREA Each of the following Quartermaster Reserve officers is relieved from his present assignment and is attached for training to the organization indicated:

Rayon weaving mills, relying upon the announcements of yarn prices this week to bring stability to that market, have stiffened their quotations on greige goods, and attempts to buy some fabrics at prices that prevailed last week failed yesterday.

The Illinois Bell Telephone Company was awarded today $1,503,000 remaining from the refunding of $18,897,980 ordered by the United States Supreme Court for the benefit of subscribers who paid overcharges on certain coin-box services for a period of eleven years.
Police early this morning seized several persons who in automobiles were touring the city distributing propaganda against the dictatorship of President Getulio Vargas.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Elimination of all forms of Industrial work in the home in New York State is the objective of a drive begun by the Consumers League of New York as a result of the recent survey of the manufacture of doll dresses and "stuffed body" dolls.

Trading by members for their own accounts in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Nov. 27 amounted to 3,137,024 shares bought or sold, or 22.22 per cent of total volume compared with 3,622,438, or 22.06 per cent in the previous week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
The secret political police today made the Confessional Synods a Christmas present of thirteen more arrests. Professor Ely and twelve of his students were arrested at Dortmund.
The stock markets here were generally firm today, although most sections were affected by holiday influences which kept business on a small scale. Gilt-edge issues were inactive and slightly weaker.

Mr. and Mrs. William de Wilder Atkinson gave a dance last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria' to present to society Mrs. Atkinson's daughter, Miss. Nancy Van Vleck. An unusual setting was arranged for the party.
Secretary of State Cordell Hull revealed today that the State Department had received complete reports of the Japanese attack upon the United States gunboat Panay and three Standard Oil tankers.
The casualties of a practice. session at San Antonio-Captain Leroy Monsky and Lew Bostickgot in a good limbering up workout at Tucson, Ariz., today.

Although the Copper Institute places the apparent consumption of copper in the United States in November at only 33,890 tons, or approximately one-half of that used in November, last year, the belief in the trade is that the use of copper last month in this country was about 8,000 tons higher, or roughly 42,000 tons.
Democratic leaders, including Senator Joseph F. Guffey, were represented at a conference here today as ready to support Governor Earle for the Senate next-year to succeed Senator Davis, Republican.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for an apartment house in the Bronx, a public school in Brooklyn and dwellings and large flats in Queens.
J. M. Dent has acquired the English rights to Harry Gannes's "When China Unites," and will publish the book there soon. The American edition was brought out by Alfred A. Knopf in September.

Mr. and Mrs. Sterling St. John of 452 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn and Marthas Vineyard, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Hollister St. John, to Edward Thomas Kemp, son of John Bartlett Kemp of Ridgewood, N. J.

The city's ranks of amateur and professional Santas, in costume and out, swelled rapidly yesterday as the round of pre-Christmas parties for the underprivileged, community celebrations, and distributions of toys, candy and food approached a climax.
Herbert Bayard Swope resigned yesterday from the National Public Housing Conference, of which he was a director and national advisory committee chairman.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patents Appeals the following proceedings were had today:

The Celotex Corporation and subsidiaries had a net profit of $1,266,753 for the year ended on Oct. 31, after interest, depreciation Federal income taxes and other charges, according to the annual report which was made public yesterday.
American aviation began a new conquest of the Pacific today with a precision flight over the first leg of an air line linking the United States with Australia and the South Seas.

The controversy between Mayor Frank Hague and the Committee for Industrial Organization, which he has outlawed as a Communistinspired organization, moved toward a new climax today as C. I. O. leaders, in a letter to Director of Safety Daniel Casey, applied for a permit to hold an open-air meeting here next Wednesday or Thursday.

Whatever business may be this week-and it isn't anything to write home about--the box offices are peering around the corner with a show of confidence. The following attractions, for instance, have tickets on sale at the box office and by mail for these future dates:

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Shirley T. Mawer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colin D. Mawer of 8,221 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, to Earl C. Herbst, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christian E. Herbst of Brooklyn.

In the midst of the farewells and Reminiscences which marked the final meeting this week of the Board of Aldermen, which on Jan. 1 will make way for the new City Council, little attention was paid to an announcement of one of the final Aldermanic acts which will Have a broad influence on the future of apartment construction in New York.

The funeral of George E. Akerson of Bronxville, former White House secretary to Herbert Hoover, was held this afternoon at the Dutch Reformed Church here. The Rev. Dr. John H. Powell Jr., pastor of the church, officiated, and about forty persons attended.

Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino advised two Christmas minstrels who Were brought before him yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct to choose underprivileged sections for their musical activities because Christmas spirit is more prevalent among the poor than with the rich.

A total of 7,661 motor vehicles passed through the Lincoln Tunnel during its first twenty-four hours of operation, the New York Port Authority announced yesterday. The new tube, linking Manhattan's West Side with Weehawken, N. J., was opened to the public at 4 A. M. on Wednesday.

There should be dismissed in the United States any idea that because of her diplomatic association with Japan Germany feels any responsibility or considers that she has incurred any responsibility for recent Japanese actions, including the Panay incident.

Louis Gold, who entered America as a penniless immigrant and became one of the city's wealthiest and most productive builders, died yesterday at the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn after a short illness. Mr. Gold, long a philanthropist, was 62 years old.

MANHATTAN ALSTON, NICHOLAS F. (July 9, 1937). Gross assets, $33,304; net, $30,622. To Howard, Herbert and Van D. Alston, brothers; Maria and Laura E. Alston, sisters, one-sixth of residue each; Van W. Williams, Rie W. Parker, Harry B. Williams and Fanny W. Fry, nephews and nieces, one-twenty-fourth residue each. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and Insurance, $18,700. Charles J. Katzenstein, attorney, 115 Broadway.
Mrs. Elizabeth C. Dawson died yesterday morning while on the way to -the Midtown Hospital, Manhattan, in an ambulance. She had been taken from her home at 121-20 197th Street, St. Albans.
The British Government appeared to take the attitude today that the next move in the diplomatic struggle against Japan must come from Washington.

The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company will retire another block of $10,000,000 of its preferred stock early next year, according to indications today. At the same time, it is expected, it will issue a corresponding amount of common stock, making no change in the capitalization of S75,000,000.

Colonel Tim McCoy, in Hotel SavoyPlaza, 5th Ave and 58th St. Hugh de Neufville, in 40 5th Xve; Emmett Joyce, in 208 E 51st St; Felix E. Larkin, in 142 E 49th St; Miles M. Nichols, in 53 E 65th St; Vladimir N. Kousik, through Edgar A. Levy Management Corp, in 169 E 78th St; Robert, D. Lambert, through Duff Conger, in 114 E 81st St; Potter. Hamilton Co, Inc, broker.

John E. Diefendorf, former chief examiner of miscellaneous companies for the New York State Department of Insurance, appeared yesterday in the Federal Court as a witness for the defense in the trial of the State Title and Mortgage Company and four of its former officers for mail fraud and conspiracy.
Mr. and Mrs. Ralph G. Tryon of South Glastonbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Artilla Tryon, to Ray W. Bidwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Bidwell.
BURLINGHAM, LOUISA L. (Dec. 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To Charles C. Burlingham, husband, 860 Park Ave., residue; Charles Burlingham, son, executor, 1,220 Park Ave.

The Hamburg-American liner New York, the last transatlantic liner to reach this port before Christmas, will arrive today from Hamburg and Southampton. On board are Gaspar Cassado, . Count Istvan Keglevich, Dr. Giovanni Serventi, Mr. and Mrs. Willy Hecht, Mr. and Mrs. George Weigert, Mr. and Mrs. Stefan Braun, Mrs. Lina Losert, Hugo Speier, Mrs. Mary Schou, Michael Firda and Mrs. Pauline Ingles.

The McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, Inc., sent to Senator La Follette yesterday a letter noting that it had been listed as employing "detective agencies for the purpose of labor espionage" and entering a "full and unequivocal denial."

By a vote of 337 to 260, the Chamber of Deputies tonight voted to reopen the exposition in 1938, on a "self-supporting" basis. About 450,000,000 francs will be raised by selling "rebate" coupons with a cash lottery feature to reopen the fair.
Pierpont V. Davis of Brown Bros. Harriman and J. Russell Forgan of Glore, Forgan Co. have been elected directors of the National Distillers Products Corporation to fill vacancies.

The will of Miss Kate S. Buckingham, art patron, establishes a $2,000,000 trust fund for the Chicago Art Institute and leaves $1,000,000 for an Alexander Hamilton memorial fountain here, J. P. Wilson, lawyer, disclosed tonight.

The commercial rental report yesterday contained many leases for store units in various parts of the city. Several were taken for food shops and others by retail dealers in wearing apparel and accessories.
Mise Jane Quigley, daughter of Commander W. M. Quigley of the Naval War College and Mrs. Quigley, gave a luncheon at the La Forge yesterday for naval officers' daughters home from school.

Miss Jean Moorhead, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lowry Moorhead of Brooklyn, entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for the Misses Anne Lee Bolling Duncan and Gertrude Pullman, Brooklyn debutantes.

Practicing for the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League, beginning at the Manhattan Chess Club on Monday, Columbia's varsity chess players met Yale in a match on four boards in the chess room at John Jay Hall yesterday. The Blue and White won, 2 1/2--l 1/2.
A political amnesty pardoning all crimes committed up to Dec. 19 received final approval early this morning by the House of Representatives following an all-night session.

Miss Aldean Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel H. Davis of this place, was married to David R. Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Brown,- also of Scarsdale, this evening in the Hitchcock Memorial Church. The Rev. P. J. Maveety of Battle Creek, Mich., grandfather of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony and was assisted by the Rev. Dr. George H. Smyth, the pastor.
Lady Higloss, the arduously campaigned 6-year-old mare in the stable of Miss A. Doris, made her thirty-first start of the year in the Florida City Handicap today and recorded her ninth success.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 16,000, including 4,500 directs. The market was uneven and 25-50c higher than Wednesday's average; mostly 35-50c up; packing sows around 25c higher. Top $8.70; bulk good and choice 150-200 pounds, $8.40-$8.60; 210-240 pounds, $8.25-$8.60; 250300 pounds. $7.90-$8.40. Most good packing sows, $6.85-$7.25; selected kinds up to $7.35. Shippers 4,000; estimated holdover 1,000.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John S. Braun of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Ann Braun, to Kenneth S. Hogg Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Hogg of Scarsdale.

The War De partment released the following orders today, dated Dec. 22: COLONELS Kingman, J. J., Engrs., San Francisco Calif., to office of the Chief of Engineers, Washington, D. C., to sail for New York about Jan. 14.

Slender Stanley Horne, Canadian Professional Golfers Association champion, from Ottawa, came in with the twilight shadows and a three-underpar 67 today to tie Ralph Guldahl, national open champion, for the first-round lead in the $2,500 Miami open golf tournament.

As the end of the year approaches it becomes evident that the deficit of the Federal Government for the six months' period from July to December will be less than half as large as its deficit last year.

Six quick-moving thugs stole a truck and its load of assorted holiday liquors valued at $5,000 yesterday afternoon as part of the consignment was about to be delivered to the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.
Armed Mobile Guards and police today patrolled the Paris Central Markets, where 100 army trucks brought in tons of foodstuffs left at railroad stations by striking truckmen.
Retail credit collections in November showed a decrease of 0.08 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc.

The first reorganization of a street railway to be approved by the New York State Public Service Commission was announced yesterday, when the State agency found a modified plan for the reorganization of the Rochester system of the New York State Railways Compary to be "in the public interest."

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended Dec. 20 were announced today: Fenton, Maj. F. I., on arrival at San Francisco to duty at Puget, Sound Navy Yard, Washington. Hough, Capt. J. F., Peiping, China, to Dept. of Pacific, San Francisco, Calif., via the President Coolidge, sailing from Kobe. Japan, about Jan. 13.

Bids for the delivery of fifty-seven steam locomotives of domestic manufacture are being examined by the Czechoslovak Ministry of Railways, says a report to the Department of Commerce from Prague made public today. The locomotives,

A hurricane is raging on the east coast of Nicaragua, causing great damage to banana plantations already infected with a leaf disease. At Puerto Cabezas, the headquarters of the Standard Fruit and Steamship Corporation, houses have been blown down and destroyed, but no lives have been lost.

The Senior Holiday Dance in the series conducted for juniors in society by Mrs. Huntington Tappin was held last night at the Plaza. Mrs. Tappin, who received the young subscribers, was assisted by Mrs. Charles J. Coulter, Mrs. Harry N. French, Mrs. Charles S. Sargent, Mrs. Samuel S. Walker and Mrs. Philip B. Weld.

The unbeaten Seward Park High basketball team continued to set the pace in the lower Manhattan division of the P. S. A. L. race yesterday, but it took a three-minute overtime period before the Benjamin Franklin quintet was subdued, 28-24.
Prices of cotton in Bombay lost ground yesterday for the first time in several weeks and quotations on the Cotton Exchange here declined 3 to 6 points for the second successive day.
Andrew J. Conroy, business man and civic leader, died at his home here today. He was 75 years old. Mr. Conroy was born in Ireland, reached this country in 1865 and settled in North Easton. Mass.
Christmas feasts prepared at home tomorrow will cost more than last year's dinners if the piece de resistance is turkey, duck, goose or other meats which show a substantial increase in price.
The official digest of the findings in the Ford Motor Company case, made public today by the National Labor Relations Board, is as follows:

The fact that it is built on a former lake bed, cushioning it from earthquake shocks, saved this city of nearly a million population from serious damage this morning and held the death toll to only three in the Federal District in one of the most violent quakes on record in Mexico.

A closed shop contract, calling for minimum wages for taxicab drivers and an increased percentage payment on bookings was signed at 12:30 this morning by executives of four of the largest of the city's taxicab fleets and spokesmen for the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate.

ONCE more the most famous evening the world ever has seen comes around in its regularly appointed place on the calendar. Tonight the stocking, ordinarily one of the most humble things in the wardrobe of those who have them, attains a position of tremendous importance.

Government reinforcements have been poured into the Teruel sector, where General Jose Varela has brought more heavy artillery support for the Insurgent troops under General Miguel Aranda, it is stated here.

Under the stimulus of colder weather, the movement of fur merchandise has improved and wholesale manufacturers have benefited to some extent by this improvement, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Fur Merchants Association, Inc., through its president, J. H. Bleistein.

Important memo for Santa Claus: Sigmund changed his address yesterday and would like to have the electric train sent to his new home. He is the 3-year-old Czech boy who has been staying with the State Charities Aid Association at 105 East Twenty-second Street since his father and mother died last year.

Appointment of Chase Mellen Jr., former Republican County Chairman, as his deputy, and of Marx Lewis, veteran Socialist and now an important member of the American Labor party, as a special deputy, was announced yesterday by Almerindo Portfolio, now City Chamberlain, who will become City Treasurer on Jan. 1.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Keidel of Guilford, this city, announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Gordon Keidel, to John Henry Lewin, son of Mrs. Frank Parr Lewin of Parkton, and the late Mr. Lewin.

Sharp Nassoit Management Corporation reports completion of rentals in the following buildings: 3,026 Bainbridge Avenue, 100 Greenwic Avenue, 1,352 St. Nicholas Avenue, 9-21 Sherman Avenue, 411 Warburton Avenue, 240 West Sixteenth Street, 214 West Ninety-second Street, 204 West Ninety-fourth Street, 106 West Ninety-sixth Street, 126 West Ninety-ninth Street,

The sharp improvement in the flow of new mortgage financing in the first half of this year over the same period of last year is not being maintained during the latter half of this year, according to figures compiled by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Connie Mack's "baseball family," stretching back to 1902 and - his first pennant - winner, gathered 'round the. grand old man in Shibe Park today and celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday on the spot he made famous with champions.

Miss Josephine Bond Ham, daughter of Thomas C. Ham of St. Davids, was married this afternoon to Henry Franklin Irwin Jr., son of Henry Franklin Irwin of Irvington, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard H. Gurley, the rector, in St. Martin's Church at Radnor.

By GEORGE J. IEARNS Shakespeare Ave. 1,529, 2-story brick dwelling, 25x82.19x irreg: Greater New York Taxpayers Mutual Insurance Assn against Benlamin Rubin; due, S13,278; taxes etc, f1,318; to plaintiff for $11.000.
A comprehensive sports review of 1937, including illustrated articles covering fifty-five sports and a list of more than 800 of the year's champions will appear in THE-NEW YORK TIMES on Sunday.

David Adlerblum, certified public accountant, died yesterday at the Lenox Hill Hospital, Seventy-sixth Street and Park Avenue, following an operation. He was 42 years old and lived at 35 West Ninety-second Street.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James E. Ackland of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Miriam Ackland, to William A. Johnson Jr., son of Colonel William A. Johnson, Engineer Corps, U. S. A., and Mrs. Johnson of Baltimore.

Eleven Arabs were killed and one captured in a major fight with police, troops and airplanes west of Tiberius this afternoon.- The gang of Arabs, tracked from Haifa following an attack on a bus, was about twenty strong when the police overtook it but when the fighting started the numbers swelled to more than 100.

A contract for twenty-one navy patrolpombing planes differing in many respects from any craft of the type heretofore commissioned, has been awarded to the Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore. The total amount involved for the twenty-one planes, together with spare parts, was $5,299,538.
Rollo L. Lyman, Professor of English at the University of Chicago, died at his home here late last night of a heart attack while reading in bed. His age was 59.
Stocks heavy, closed fractionally lower; turnover, 1,053,550 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues irregularly lower; transactions, $7,698,450.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France, issued today, shows the following changes, in francs:

The Neediest Cases Fund was encouraged yesterday by the receipt of an anonymous gift of $10,000. This generous contribution, made by the same donor who gave a like sum anonymously last year and also in 1935, brought the day's total to $25,499.83.

Dr. Isadore Goldstein, the ophthalmio surgeon of Mount Sinai Hospital, noted particularly for plastic surgery of the eye, died yesterday in his home at 275 Central Park West after a brief illness. He was 58 years old.

Attorney General Cummings said today that criminal prosecutions against the Democratic National Committee for selling souvenir convention books to corporations "would not be warranted." He made this decision in reply to Representative Snell's recent complaint that the committee had violated the Corrupt Practices Act when it sold such books, autographed by President Roosevelt, for as high as $250 each and obtained more than $400,000 for the party's coffers.

Bank clearings continued for the sixth consecutive week to decline in the week ended on Wednesday, the loss for twenty-two leading cities throughout the nation dropping 14.4 per cent in the year-to-year comparison after a decrease of 24.3 per cent in the preceding period.

Renewed deflation of their outstanding credit. was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, in their condition statement issued yesterday. The total of the reporting banks' loans and investments fell $112,000,000 in the week to $7,869,000,000. For the preceding week,

Details The following captain is detailed to act as deputy chief inspector, with the title while so acting of deputy chief inspector of police, is transferred and assigned as indidicated. Designation as inspector revoked: Harry L. Lobdell, from 11th Division to command Queens.

Christmas will be rung in this afternoon and tomorrow by the carillons and other bells of the churches of the city. Christmas services will be held this evening and tomorrow in all the Protestant Episcopal, Roman Catholic, most of the Lutheran churches and some of the larger of the denominational churches in midtown Manhattan.

The performance of "Tristan und Isolde" last night in the Metropolitan Opera House was the occasion of the first appearance in that thetre of Carl Hartmann in the part of the dolorous hero of Celtic legend.

Suspension of the license of the Vane Securities Company of Waterford, Wis., and its president, F. V. Cloutier, to sell securities in Wisconsin has been ordered- by the State Public Service Commission in the midst of continued State and Federal investigation into the affairs of B. E. Buckman Co. of Madison, dealers in securities, who are charged with having violated Wisconsin's blue-sky laws.
Captain Johnny Druze, Fordham's ace right end of the last three seasons, is going to see his college football career climaxed by a long train ride after all.

Commissioner Harry Armstrong of New Jersey, who spends practically all his spare time and some he can hardly spare in attempting to improve the hunting and fishing conditions in his State, was all excitement yesterday.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the Federal court denied today the petition of the Bankers Trust Company to restrain trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad from making any further rental payments under the lease of the Boston Providence Railroad, which totals $511,500 a year.
Rotogravure linage in New York newspapers registered substantial gains this year, final figures which include the last Sunday of this month, revealed yesterday.

W. R. Angell, president of Continental Motors Corporation, advises stockholders that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has extended to 1940 the payment of in staliments due in 1937 and 1938 on its loan to the company, the balance of which stood at $974,950 on Oct. 31.
Rice Institute's football offense appeared ready today for Colorado in the Cotton Bowl. Holding a hard scrimmage, the Owls gave a smooth, hustling performance in an hour's drill.

A continuance of the decline in industrial production and a sharp drop in employment and payrolls at factories were reported today by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System in a statement on business conditions based on statistics for November and the first three weeks of December.

The State of Louisiana will consider bids on Feb. 9 for a new issue of $4,000,000 of highway bonds at an interest rate not exceeding 4 per cent. The bonds will be dated Jan. 1, 1938 and will fall due serially on Jan. 1, 1942 to 1960.

Football stars who will meet New Year's Day in the annual EastWest charity game held morning and afternoon practice today. Each squad had an injured man on the sidelines. The East temporarily lost the services of Don Heap, halfback from Northwestern.

The Ford Motor Company, ordered by the National Labor Relations Board to reinstate twenty-nine employes and to stop discouraging its emplbyes from union membership, announced tonight that it would appeal the decision to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that hearings on applications to delist securities on national exchanges would be held Jan. 12 with respect -to the New York Stock Exchange application to delist first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due Oct. 1, 1937,

Coach Bernie Moore gave Louisiana State's football squad its first peek of Santa Clara plays today in a light dummy scrimmage. Third-string players simulated Santa Clara ground and pass plays as Moore directed methods L. S. U. will employ in the Sugar Bowl game at New Orleans in an effort to stop the Broncos.
There will be many first things for Christmas that will be put off till the last day. And one of these first things will no doubt be for many the Neediest Cases.
The Consolidated Cigar Corporation resumed the payment of common dividends with the declaration of 75 cents The last distribution on the stock was 75 cents on April 1 1932.

119th St 87 W, 18x100.11; Rexhold Realty Corp, James H. Cruikshank, president, to James E. Duross et ano., 88 Paulding Ave, Tarrytown, N. Y.; p m mtg, three years, 5 per cent; $4,000. Same Property; Albert M. Daniel to Rexhold'Realty Corp, 45 Nassau St; p m mtg, pr mtg, $4,000, installments, 5 per cent; $3,000.

Senator La Follette of Wiscbnsin, chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Education and Labor which investigated industrial espionage and made public a report on Tuesday, today replied to complaints of the Macmillan Company and The Newark Ledger that hiring of labor spies had been wrongly attributed to them in the subcommittee's report.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has filed an amendment to its registration statement covering an $80,000,000 securities issue in September, reducing the amount of the issue to $30,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Germany and France exchanged spies today as a Christmas gesture. Four Germans and four Frenchmen convicted and imprisoned for espionage were handed over to authorities of their respective countries at Dapach, a small frontier station.

After deliberating on the evidence three hours, a General Sessions jury. yesterday acquitted Patrolmen Edward P. Fehling and Edward J. Kelly, former detectives of the pickpocket squad, and Edward J. .O'Connor, a painter, and Andrew Fleming, a pressman, on an indictment charging first-degree robbery, first-degree larceny and second-degree assault. Judge Bohan discharged the four from custody.

Today's statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday showed a gain of more than $5,000,000 in notes in circulation, accompanied by minor drops in deposits by the government and chartered banks.

Fourteen memberships on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., have changed hands within the last few days at prices ranging from $740 to $1,025 a membership, the Exchange announced yesterday. Charles Slaughter paid $740 to $1,000 each for ten memberships; Nat N. Kaplan bought two memberships at $1,000 each, I. J. Louis one at $975, and Tudor J. Simpkins one at $1,025.

Nine of the twenty-two towns and cities in Westchester County received less advantageous rates in the proposed 1938 county tax equalization table filed here today than in the table adopted a year ago. New Rochelle, falling three points, suffered the most serious loss.
Senator Norris said today that methods of "delay and coercion" employed in opposition to-the administration might bring a "demand that President Roosevelt seek a third term."

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, returned yesterday from Europe on the French liner Normandie, having attended a London meeting of representatives of short-term German creditors.

Five armed men, four of them masked with handkerchiefs, held up the Paul E. Santangelo Association, a Democratic club at 59 Madison Street, between Catharine and Oliver Streets, shortly after 11 o'clock last night.

Mr. and Mrs. James Butler gave a dance last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Dorothy Dyer Butler. The ballroom and Oval Room were decorated with Christmas trees illuminated with red lights, and large clusters of red poinsettias and mistletoe.

John Henry -Adams, 23-year-old junior of Dartmouth College who disappeared from the college at Hanover, N. H., more than a month ago, was found here yesterday wandering on West Forty-seventh Street at about 12:30 A. M. A detective, attracted by his manner, took him to the West Forty-seventh Street police station, where after questioning, he was treated by a doctor of Metropolitan Hospital for a nervous disorder and taken to Bellevue Hospital.

Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Davis are at the Ritz Tower before returning to their home in Washington. Mr. and Mrs. Dixon Boardman of London, who arrived on the Normandie, are at the Weylin. Philip Le Boutillier is making his home at 825 Fifth Avenue.

TODAY-New England: Increasing cloudiness and colder, with temperatures near zero over the north and central portions; cloudy followed by snow and cold, with freezing temperatures over the south, excepting snow and rain over the southeast.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Dec. 21: CAPTAIN Smith, W. T., Berlin, Germany, to instruction, at the Naval War College, Newport, R. I., about May 25. COMMANDERS

Dr. William Bowie, who until his retirement a year ago had served twenty-seven years as chief of the Division of Geodesy of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, has been appointed as Officer of the Order of Orange-Nassau by the Queen of The Netherlands.

Boston Maine The Boston Maine Railroad estimated in exhibits filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission that its net income this year would be $133,495, contrasted with a net loss of $1,654,183 in 1936.

ART is long and the time to buy Christmas presents is fleeting. Here are half a dozen new books* on art that would make magnificent presents. As a matter of fact, you will probably want to buy some of them for your own pleasure. They'll all outlive the season. Some of the works they represent have been doing that now for a good many generations.
Two New York dealers in medicinal preparations have stipulated to discontinue certain unfair advertising representations, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

The intangible assets of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) have been assessed at $45,000,000, it was announced today by Jay J. Kisse, Tax Assessor of Flemington Borough. The company is the holding unit for the Standard Oil of New Jersey, a Delaware corporation.
Paul Waner, Pirates' outfielder and one of the league's leading batsmen, said today the National League's new "dead" ball should pull down batting averages, but won't eliminate "fluke" hits.
W. W. Rosser, railroad supply company official and president of the Railway Truck Corporation, died at the Edward Hines Jr. Memorial Hospital last night of pneumonia.

A new formula for the conduct of WPA projects in this city, with the city shouldering a larger share of the cost in return for the construction by WPA of schools, public buildings, roads and other civic improvements on a scale not previously undertaken by it, has been worked out by Mayor La Guardia and Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somerveil, local Works Progress Administrator, it was learned last night.

Trading was slow in local markets yesterday. Steer, beef and lamb were weak to lower; veal and calf steady to weak; fresh pork uneven. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be strong to slightly higher and other classes weak as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Thomas entertained today with cocktails on the yacht Masquerader II, the first of a series of similar events they have planned.
Today's major events: "Hansel and Gretel" and the character ballet, "The Bat," 2:30 P. M.; "Norma," 8:15 P. M., Metropolitan Opera House.
Curiouser and curiouser grows this institution called the press. Mr. Roosevelt accuses the newspapers of sowing fear in the land

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 1,054,000 bales, against 982,000 a week ago, 959,000 two weeks ago, 964,000 three weeks ago and 882,000 a year ago; of which American, 635,000 bales, against 559,000 a week ago, 538,000 two weeks ago, 538,000 three weeks ago and 334,000 a year. ago.
W. G. McCullough, president of the Collins Aikman Corporation, announced yesterday that the company would distribute a Christmas fund among its 5,000 employes.

James Reilly, former blacksmith and public official, died of a heart attack at his home here last night at the age of 72. Many persons remembered him by his flowing white mustache, which measured a foot in width.
James Adger Reynolds, president of the National Union Bank of Kinderhook and dean of Columbia County bankers, died suddenly at his home in Kinderhook early this morning. He was 86 years old.

Mrs. Eleanor du Pont Taney, daughter of the late Francis G. du Pont, wrote in her will before her death in 1934 that her daughter, Justine Constance Perot, should have none of her $5,000,000 estate if she "persisted in her friendship for Victor Frederick Emerson, which it is well known I strongly oppose."

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hill Wood of 550 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Wood, to John Triplett Harrison Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison, also of this city and of Greens Farms, Conn.

The general level of wholesale prices dedined slightly in the week ended on Dec. 18, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 weekly average as 100 receded to 81.5 from 81.9 the as 100, receded to 81.5 from 81.9 the preceding week. The level comnpared with 83.7 on Dec. 19, 1936.

The Board of Transportation will give employes of the city's Independent Subway System paid leaves of absence on Christmas and New Year's, it was disclosed yesterday. This will be the first time that such leaves have been granted.

William F. Carey, Commissioner of Sanitation, opened officially yesterday the new four-story garage unit of the Fifty-sixth Street PWA project of the Department of Sanitation, which comprises also an incinerator, power plant and office building in Twelfth Avenue from Fifty-fifth to Fifty-seventh Street.
The Public Service Commission studied today a proposed "contribution plan" to speed construction of rural electric lines by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation.

Evidence of another large-scale sale of gold by the stabilization fund in Washington to foreign stabilization funds was disclosed in the weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday. At the same time it became known that another shipment of $5,000,000 gold would be sent to France on the Normandie, sailing on Sunday.

119th St. 87 W; 87 W 119th St Corp; Reginald A. Cook, president, to Rexhold Realty Corp, 45 Nassau St (S5.50). Same property, Rexhold Realty Corp, Janet O'Connor, secretary, to Albert M. Daniel, 32 W 119th St; purchase money mtg $3,000 ($4.50).
The Mexican Government took administrative steps today to expel immediately many Jews from the country.

Independent milk dealers will sell Grade B bottled milk for 9 cents a quart to the public at ten locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, starting Monday. This is 2 cents a quart below the prevailing price for that grade of pasteurized milk sold in stores, it was announced by Mayor La Guardia.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidLaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $9,554,165.

Increased unemployment was held largely responsible for the continued decline in subway travel by Thomas W. Murray Jr., receiver of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, in his report for November filed yesterday with Federal 'Circuit Judge Julian W. Mack.

A special children's performance this afternoon will close the run of the Ice Follies skating revue at Madison Square Garden. It will be the seventh performance, a record for ice carnivals at the Garden.

Applauding President Arturo Alessandri's efforts to satisfy the more urgent requirements of Chile's armed forces even in the face of unfavorable economic conditions, the newspaper El Mercurio editorially stresses that Chile is not launching into a rearmament program, but is merely planning to modernize some obsolete equipment.
Eighty-one students chosen by lot were guests of the Faculty-Students Social Relations Committee at Hunter College at a luncheon held in the Bronx center of the college yesterday. The luncheon,

Former Assemblyman Theron McCampbell of Holmdel, N. J., who predicts the depression will not be over for several years, would like to succeed Governor-elect A. Harry Moore in the United States Senate, "just to show the country what an honest grape farmer can accomplish."
One hundred and fifty members of the younger set attended a junior subscription dance at the Round Hill Club tonight. A dinner preceded the event.
In funeral services held in the Church of St. John the Evangelist the people of Minnesota paid tribute today to Frank Billings Kellogg, former Secretary of State and author of the pact outlawing war.

Speculative interest in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here was reduced today to a minimum and prices held within a range of around 1/2 cent a bushel on wheat and corn futures with the close showing net changes of a fraction of a cent.
Mrs. George L. Ingraham, widow of a former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court for the First Division, died in her Paris home today.

The United States Chamber of Commerce reported today that trade with Latin-American countries had increased substantially during the first nine months of 1937, compared with the corresponding period of last year.

The National Community Christmas, at which National Socialist leaders and organizations vied with one another in playing Santa Claus to the nation's needy children, was celebrated throughout Germany tonight.

At a three-hour conference at the American Embassy tonight representatives of the Japanese Army and Navy recounted in minute detail the movements of the Japanese land and air forces involved in the attack on the U. S. S. Panay on Dec. 12.

The seeds of international banditry which sprouted the bombs and bullets that destroyed the gunboat Panay and spread death among those aboard the vessel were sown long before the Japanese invaded China this year in violation of treaties.

Heavy smoke pouring from a fire in the basement of the Silver Rod Drug Store, at 133 Main Street, this afternoon tied up automobile traffic in the vicinity and threw shoppers in two adjoining stores into confusion before police ordered the stores vacated. Five firemen,

Joe Medwick, who carried off the individual batting crown of the National League for 1937, was also his circuit's outstanding long-distance clouter, according to the official figures released for publication today.
The British Government today addressed a new warning to Italy to check the anti-British propaganda now pouring from the Bari radio station and from the officially controlled Italian newspapers.

Miss Helen Frances Volk, daughter of Mrs. Jacob Volk of 845 West End Avenue and the late Mr. Volk, was married yesterday morning at the home of her mother to Dr. Hilliard Dubrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dubrow of this city, by the Rev. Dr. Leo Jung.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President thinks the newspapers are fostering fear, which, of course, is not a feeling to cultivate at Christmas time. He doesn't say whether it is the news that scares us or the comments.

A bigamy indictment returned last February against Peggy Garcia, 24 years old, a night club hatcheck girl, after her unsuccessful breach of promise suit against David Rubinoff, the violinist, was dismissed yesterday by General I Sessions Judge Wallace on the motion of her lawyer.
So far as the United States Treasury is concerned, the reaction to any proposal to set up an international authority for control of foreign exchange is "definitely no,"
During the week ended Dec. 22 member bank reserve balances decreased $29,000,000.
By ROBERT FISHEL Broadway, 3,501-9, 6-story apartment and stores, 99.11x125; New York State Teachers Retirement System against Broadway Graylock Realty Corp; due, $317,840; to plaintiff for $200.000.
The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids as of Dec. 28 on the following lots of textiles for the WPA, bids to be opened on Jan. 5, with shipment by Jan. 31:

Beale M. Schmucker, Camden County engineer, died of a stomach ailment at his home here today after a long illness. His age was 49. Born in Reading, Pa., he was educated at the West Chester State Normal School and the University of Pennsylvania.
Alvin Waldman of Sol Raphael, Inc., was elected president of the Fur Garment Traveling Salesmen's Association at a meeting last night at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

John C. Whitaker was elected today vice president of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company. The directors also promoted Edward A. Darr to sales manager and created the post of advertising manager, to be held by W. T. Smither. Mr. Darr was elected a director.

Fifty-four university professors today issued a manifesto against ghetto benches for Jewish students in order to show, they said, that the measure has not the teachers' unanimous support. They consider that it harms Poland's good repute.

Considerable excitement was caused here tonight by a statement that the Electoral Commission would decide that the votes in last Monday's general election would not be counted by electoral districts according to law but would be lumped together for the whole kingdom, thus increasing the Tatarescu government's seats in the Chamber of Deputies from 150 to 180.

Programs of Christmas music will be presented in the churches of several of the denominations in New York City and vicinity at Christmas Eve services late today and at Christmas Day services tomorrow. Th programs to be given include the following:

The La Follette two-man committee accused 2,500 business firms of employing labor spies. It mentioned these companies by name. Several of them immediately protested that they have never used spies of any sort with the aim of heading off unionization, that the only purpose for which they have ever employed private detectives has been to act as guards or put a stop to petty pilfering.

Deaths Announced Captain James J. Wood of Engine 251 died Dec. 21. Funeral will take place from Murphy's Funeral Chapel, 216-08 Merrick Rd., Springfield Gardens, Queens, at 9:15 A. M., Monday, Dec. 27. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total net circulation to be at the highest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."
A $6 combination ticket on Agrarian, who ran third in the 1934 Kentucky Derby, turned up for payment at Churchill Downs yesterday.
City College's varsity basketball team had more trouble than it anticipated in registering its fifth consecutive victory at its gymnasium last night.

With the pace of last-minute shopping this week running below expectations, merchants here said yesterday the indications were that local holiday trade will show an average decrease of about 2 per cent under the dollar sales volume for last year.

The strike of employes of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle, begun nearly fourteen weeks ago, was settled yesterday by signing of an agreement between the management of the paper and the New York Newspaper Guild.
" A Lady's Gentleman," adapted by Hylton Cleaver from the Hungarian play "Jean," by Ladislaus Bus-Fekete, opened promisingly at the Vaudeville Theatre here tonight.

Argentine imports of automobiles and trucks during the first ten months of this year totaled 39,953 units, an increase of 93 per cent over the corresponding period last year, the Commerce Department has been informed.

Federal officers seized a 100-foot tuna clipper at Los Angeles harbor today and United States Attorney Benjamin Harrison said another, and possibly five more boats of suspected Japanese ownership, would be detained.

The governing boards of the Neurological Institute and the Presbyterian Hospital will be merged after Jan. 1, completing the centralization of all private hospital activities at the Medical Center, it was announced yesterday by officials of both institutions.

Sixteen games are on the basketball schedule for the Manlius School team, with the likelihood that five more will be booked before the season is long under way, according to the announcement. by Captain Mark Bradley, director of admissions, who is beginning his twentyfirst year as head coach of the court game.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. A. Hall Berry of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Berry, to J. Hunter Walton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Walton of Brooklyn.

After deliberating nine hours at the end of a two-months trial, a jury in Superior Court convicted late last night fifteen strikers of conspiracy resulting in violence and property damage in the trucking walkout which tied up highway transportation in the Connecticut Valley in September.

Bernard E. Smith, who has been a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1926, is to become a partner in Thomson, McKinnon Co. at the new year. He appeared before the Exchange's committee on quotations and commissions yesterday afternoon and his application for permission to join the firm will be posted this morning.
Colonel Woolman Hopper Gibson, prominent in business, judiciary and political circles in Eastern Maryland for half a - century, died last night at his home in Centreville at the age of 84.

Judge Frederic Palen Schoonmaker of the United States District Court of Western Pennsylvania, who resides at Bradford, Pa., and Mrs. Virginia Elliott Taylor of Pittsburgh were quietly married at a little Lutheran church here today.
Cleaveland Putnam's Black Rhapsody, an improved son of Macaw, won his second straight race at the Fair Grounds today when he came from behind to whip five rivals in the six-furlong claiming feature.
Muriel Foster, a mezzo-soprano whose name is inseparably bound up with Elgar's oratorio "The Dream of Gerontius," died here today at the age of 60.
Edward J. Donohue, a policeman attached to Traffic D, quartered in West Forty-seventh Street, Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 45-75 157th Street, Flushing, of pneumonia.

The Hippodrome, scene alternately of prize fights and operas, was filled yesterday afternoon, not with the roar of fight fans seeking action nor with the appreciative silence of music lovers; instead it rang with shrill cheers and happy laughter as the Police Department Honor Legion staged a colorful Christmas party for 5,000 sons and daughters of members of the force.
Rabbi Samuel Hurwitz, for many years in charge of a Hayas Sholom congregation and the Mishkan Sholom congregation in Baltimore, died last night at his home here.

Lieut. Gen. Count Gustav von Lambsdorff died here today at the age of 70. He cooperated with General Erich Ludendorff, who died Monday, in the capture of Liege, Belgium, at the beginning of the World War.

The Christmastide concert offered by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, last night in Carnegie Hall served to introduce Amparo Iturbi, sister of Jose Iturbi, as piano soloist with the organization in its regular surroundings.

Only United States Government obligations put up a show of relatively uniform steadiness yesterday as broad selling for incometax purposes sent the majority of listed bonds lower in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Pen and Brush Club announces that the following awards were made in the Flower and Figlure Exhibition: First prize to Charlotte Register, first honorable mention to Gertrude Nason and second honorable mention to Ethel Schiffer. The jury was composed of Anne Goldthwaite, Hilda Belcher and Henrietta King.
J. Chester Gibson, a retired banker, who lived for the last eight months at West Brother Drive, Milbrook, died today at the Greenwich Hospital. He was 66 years old.
To encourage watchful walking among the pupils of Grade 3-B, the Glassboro Public School has issued "pedestrian licenses" to the youngsters. The certificate,

Colonel Kingoro Hashimoto has not been recalled. It is learned on the best authority that he is at present actively in the field, leading his troops with batteries of mountain guns in the Japanese advance upon Hangchow, south of Shanghai.

In gay spirits and only four pounds heavier than when he stepped into the ring against Joe Louis last August, Tommy Farr, the Welsh heavyweight, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie for his second boxing expedition to this country.
Suddenly canceling all plans for Christmas at the White House Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was flying today to Seattle to spend the holiday with her daughter, Mrs. Anna Boettiger, and her two children.

Dizzy Dean should be ready to admit now that Paul and Lloyd Waner are better golfers, as a team anyway, than "me and Paul." The Pirate outfielders trounced the Cardinal pitchers today, 3 and 2, adding another victory to the one they accomplished at Sarasota last Sunday.

By unanimous vote the Chamber of Deputies today appropriated 1,500,000 francs as the government's contribution to the monument to General John J. Pershing and Franco- American comradeship erected at Versailles.

An order issued by the Governor of Santiago Province prohibiting exhibition of a film entitled "Fire in Spain," in which realistic scenes of the civil war are depicted, has caused bitter discussion both in Congress and in the press.
The Federal Power Commission today ordered its investigation of unlicensed hydroelectric power projects extended to cover the entire nation.

Representative Martin Dies of Texas, who led the assault of Southern members of the House on the administration's wage and hours bill in the Rules Committee, of which he is a member, and on the floor, Eent a letter today to President Roosevelt in which he endorsed the President's reminder to Congress that the budget could not be balanced if its responsibility for curtailing expenditures was ignored.

George Herndon Pegram, for the last forty years chief engineer of the Manhattan Elevated Railway and Interborough Rapid Transit Companies and a former president of the American Society of Civil Engineers, died yesterday in Brooklyn Hospital. He would have been 82 years old next Wednesday.
Mrs. Winifield Scott Schley of 620 Park Avenue gave a dinner dance last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Grace Virginia Schley.
The personal and policy controversy in the directorate of the Tennessee Valley Authority has now come into the open, and the general welfare can receive benefit therefrom. Chairman A.

After a day marked by sporadic revolts which taxed the peace-making ability of legislative leaders 'to the utmost, New York City's Administrative Code was adopted by the Assembly just after 7 o'clock this evening.
President Joe F. Carr of the National Football League said today the circuit's 1938 play-off game may be staged at Miami, Fla., instead of on a frozen Northern gridiron.

Strains of The Star-Spangled Banner echoed today in Westminster Abbey as Great Britain's Cabinet members and foreign diplomats and other notables attended the memorial service for United States Ambassador Robert W. Bingham.

Federal funds of $31,250,000 for slum clearance and low-cost housing in seven cities, including $18,000,000 for the Red Hook and Queens Bridge projects in New York City, were earmarked today by Nathan Straus, United States Housing Administrator.

British members of Parliament had clocks for Christmas. A fortnight ago some members had the idea that one clock in the chamber of the House of Commons was not enough. They began an agitation for another.
The Viennese Roof of the St. Regis was the setting last night for a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Elton Parks to introduce their daughter, Miss Nancy Parks.

The Bancamerica-Blair Corporation is buying Alleghany Corporation 5 per cent bonds of 1950 at the market in furtherance of a proposed recapitalization for the holding agency, it was reported yesterday in Wall Street.
Adolph Wey, son of the late Max Weyl, noted landscape artist, died today at Garfield Hospital after a short illness at the age of 66.
Nearly six months of Japanese invasion have cost China at least $750,000,000 in physical property damage. Millions have shared this loss in shattered homes, destroyed factories, ruined crops.

Clarks Pl, 30 (11-2839); Efanar Realty Corp to Louis H. Pink, State Supt. of Insurance, 345 Madison Ave, five years, 4 1/2 per cent; $110,000. Trafalgar Pl, 1,826 (11-2958); Mansuss Realty Co to Franklin Savings Bank, extends mtg to Dec 9, 1940, at 4 1/2 per cent; $27,000.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Dec. 22 were announced today: Davis, Lt. K. S., the Bibb, to engineering training duty on that vessel. Harding, Lt. J. F., Salem Air Station, to engineering training duty on the Cayuga. Calahan, Jr. Lt. E. T., the Saranac, to engineering training duty on that vessel.

Three persons, including Alan Goss, 19-year-old Chicago and Pasadena, Calif., youth, were killed in a road accident caused by fog on the ParisTroyes highway in which three cars, a truck and a passenger bus were involved.
Montgomery Sales, 45 East Seventeenth Street, has been appointed Eastern distributor for the following concerns for 1938: Louisiana Box and Lumber Company, Kenner, La.;

Dr. Theodore J. Grayson, for the last nineteen years director of the evening and extension schools of the University Of Pennsylvania, died in Bryn Mawr Hospital this afternoon a few hours after suffering a stroke. He was in his fifty-eighth year.

The annual Groton-St. Mark's supper dance, arranged by committees of students from the two schools to augment a vacation fund for under-privileged city youths, took place last night at the Pierre under the honorary patronage of President and Mrs. Roosevelt, the Rev. and Mrs. Endicott Peabody and Dr. and Mrs. Francis Parkman.
Adolph Wey, son of the late Max Weyl, noted landscape artist, died today at Garfield Hospital after a short illness at the age of 66.
Nearly six months of Japanese invasion have cost China at least $750,000,000 in physical property damage. Millions have shared this loss in shattered homes, destroyed factories, ruined crops.

Clarks Pl, 30 (11-2839); Efanar Realty Corp to Louis H. Pink, State Supt. of Insurance, 345 Madison Ave, five years, 4 1/2 per cent; $110,000. Trafalgar Pl, 1,826 (11-2958); Mansuss Realty Co to Franklin Savings Bank, extends mtg to Dec 9, 1940, at 4 1/2 per cent; $27,000.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Dec. 22 were announced today: Davis, Lt. K. S., the Bibb, to engineering training duty on that vessel. Harding, Lt. J. F., Salem Air Station, to engineering training duty on the Cayuga. Calahan, Jr. Lt. E. T., the Saranac, to engineering training duty on that vessel.

Three persons, including Alan Goss, 19-year-old Chicago and Pasadena, Calif., youth, were killed in a road accident caused by fog on the ParisTroyes highway in which three cars, a truck and a passenger bus were involved.
Montgomery Sales, 45 East Seventeenth Street, has been appointed Eastern distributor for the following concerns for 1938: Louisiana Box and Lumber Company, Kenner, La.;

Following close on the heels of the Adventures of Tom Sawyer," which will be released by Selznick International in February, Paramount will make "Tom Sawyer, Detective," in May with the stars of the Selznick epic, Tom Kelly and Jackie Moran.

With all the discussion about the return of Stanford with its famous Hank Luisetti, the other invading team which appears on the program in the double-headers at Madison Square Garden on Monday and Wednesday has been almost overlooked. Minnesota, which faces L. I. U. on Monday and N. Y. U. on Wednesday, is one of the best outfits ever to play in Big Ten competition.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday announced liberalization of the extension of death benefits of group life insurance policies whereby group cases issued on and after Jan. 1, 1938, will be written under the revised form, an innovation in such protection.

John W. Parkhurst of San Francisco, a retired banker, died yesterday at the home of his son-inlaw and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Aley, 510 East Eightyninth Street, after a brief illness, at the age of 90.

A first-degree grand larency indictment against Julius Rosenbaum, 47 years old, a Chicago life insurance agent, was quashed yesterday in General Sessions. Judge Freschi acted on the recommendation of Assistant District Attorney Eugene J. Finnegan.

New York University's basketball team redeemed a miserable firsthalf showing by rallying to beat a fighting St. Francis array, 43 to 34, last night on the University Heights gymnasium court before a capacity gathering of 1,500 persons. This marked the sixth straight triumph for the Violet and ran its winning streak on the home court to fortysix games.

Bunge Born, a New York and foreign grain firm, won today an important decision before the arbitration committee of the Board of Trade here regarding the validity of a contract entered into by the firm with a commission house here, whereby the latter is said to have sold around 1,000,000 bushels of cash rye and failed to complete its contract.

Malcolm Ferris, former expert radio aide for the United States Navy and developer of the radio direction finder used in steamship navigation, died today at the Orange Memorial Hospital, where he had been confined since an operation seven weeks ago. Mr. Ferris,

Lumber production declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index eased to 54.4, its lowest point since the week ended June 22, 1935. The figure for the previous week was 56.5, while for the week ended Dec. 19, 1936, it stood at 84.3.

Mr. and Mrs. Oliver David donaldson will be hosts at an eggnog party at Gray-Dawn, their Sutton Manor home, tomorrow evening. A feature of the evening will be the burning of a Yule log outside the house while the guests sing Christmas carols.
