Gunther Ave (16-4793). s e cor of Arnow Ave. 100x95; Home Building Loan Assn. of Mount Vernon to Rosa Spottl. 2,852 Gunther Ave. Wheeler Ave (14-3610. 3651). w s, 104 ft s of Eastern Blvd. 250x100: also Wheeler Ave. e s, 10o ft s of Eastern Blvd, 250x 100: A. F. G. Realty Corp. to Broad Hill Inc.. 3l71 E 149th St.

Soviet airplanes at Rudolf Island are ready to take the scientists off the Polar ice floe on a few hours' notice should an emergency arise, but there is no especial danger now and it is not planned to remove them before April or May, Professor Otto J. Schmidt announced in a statement today.
Unless the weather man gets into the holiday spirit and covers the "Northlands" with snow this weekend, there will be little for the vast skiing army in the East to be thankful for this Christmas.
Ernest W. Hofstatter, County Attorney of Rockland County since 1914 and an authority on county law and town government, died of a stroke here today at his home on Orchard Street. He was 70 years old.

Governor Cross today examined a preliminary report of land costs for the Merritt Parkway prepared by State Controller Charles C. Swartz, and then directed the Controller to proceed with a sweeping investigation of every detail of the incomplete parkway which is to stretch thirtytwo miles across Fairfield County from the New York State line.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Polly Abbott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Abbott of 111 East Seventy-first Street, and of St. James L. I., to William Mackey Wherry 3d, son of William Mackey Wherry of 1,088 Park Avenue, and the late Mrs. Wherry who was the former Miss Rhoda Edwards Zug of Pitto burgh.

University of Cincinnati archaeologists working at the site of ancient Troy have found a stone face which they consider the earliest piece of sculpture yet found in the eastern Aegean and western Anatolian area, and also earlier than any ever found in Greece or Crete.

After rising slightly in the week ended Dec. 11, business in the Pittsburgh district last week resumed the sharp decline which began early in Sepmember, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

A record day in the history of the New York Postoffice was marked up on Wednesday with the cancellation of stamps on 16,716,000 letters and cards, it was disclosed yesterday by Albert Goldman, Postmaster.

Savings banks disposed of houses in Harlem, on the West Side and in the Bronx in deals announced yesterday. An, investor bought from the New York Savings Bank the five-story apartment house for ten families at 71 East 120th Street.

The Board of Education has purchased the industrial arts library of the late Louis C. Tiffany, noted artist, who died on Jan. 17, 1933. The collection consists of more than 1,000 volumes, including woodcuts and drawings. Percy A. Joseph,

Mrs. Jean Aitken Paddock, who died Jan. 31, last, left a net estate of $1,055,415, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. She was the wife of Bishop Robert Lewis Paddock, retired, formerly head of the Protestant Episcopal missionary diocese of Eastern Oregon.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls battled through 60 minutes and a 10minute overtime period to a 1-1 deadlock with the Bronx Tigers last night, but the tie was sufficient to enable the seashore skaters to clinch the Hershey Cup, emblematic of supremacy in the first section of the divided Eastern Amateur Hockey League race.
A city-wide clean-up in the inferior courts was demanded yesterday by- the Joint Committee on County Clerk, which was largely instrumental in bringing about the forced retirement of Albert Marinelli.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-By HUGH A. GEIGER, electrical engineer, 1,090 St. Nicholas Ave.-Liabilities $1,362; no assets except insurance. Receiver Appointed GERRY LIND DRESS CO., INC., 1,375 Broadway.-The New York Credit Men's. Assn. was appointed under $2,000 bond by Judge Knox.

Joseph Duraccio, 23 years old, and his father, Pasquale, 50, who met for the first time since Joseph was 2, in the offices of the Parole Board at 80 Center Street last Wednesday, and later attended the police lineup together, were freed to spend Christmas out of jail yesterday.
Sir Matthew Fraser, prominent Scottish lawyer, died today. He was 80.
SECOND MILITARY AREA Capt. Eugene R. Bernardi, Engr. -Res., 6 Highland Ave., White Plains, N. Y., recently promoted, is assigned to the 1208th S.U.. C.A.S.C.. Camp Smith. N. Y.
City Judge William H. Tompkins gave "week-end" sentences to two motorists today, but the "presents" are not to be opened until after Christmas.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Edgar Meeker of Maplewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Meeker, to Dr. Frank Herbert Lushear of Newton, N. J., formerly of Maplewood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Herbert Lushear.

The official report of the commanding officer of the Panay and the findings of the naval court of inquiry, both of which are published in THE TIMES today, corroborate the essential facts in the case of the Japanese attack upon the gunboat and her convoy.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana will release an increased advertising campaign for 1938 early in January, Wesley I. Nunn, advertising manager, said today. It will be based on the theory that the best way to sell the people is to talk to them in the terms of the people, he added.

Mr. and Mrs. John E. D. Coffey of West Islip, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Coffey, to John Harrison Tompkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Tompkins of Babylon, L. I.
To those who composed the Central Committee of the Communist party in Russia and directed the revolution of October, 1917, only two are left-Stalin and Trotsky.
The Celotex Corporation has notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposal to increase its authorized common stock from 750,000 to 1,500.000 shares.
The chimney which Santa Claus slides down tonight for Mrs. Harry Brickett will be surrounded by a $12,000 house, a gift for the mother of four widowed by an automobile accident.

The so-called Torrens law for the registration of title to real property has been in effect in New York State for nearly thirty years, but never has achieved the beneficial results which the sponsors had expected.

Peace was restored to the taxicab industry yesterday afternoon when the Sunshine-Radio system, operating twenty-four fleet units, signed a closed shop agreement with the Transport Workers Union of Greater New York, an affiliate of the C. I. O., ending the two-week strike of its 4,000 drivers.
Eighty-four officers and men from the United States mid-Pacific air defense frontier are here awaiting orders to try to break the record for a massed plane flight to Hawaii.
A $15,000 reward for solution of the 1933 O'Connell kidnapping will be paid in January to the "most deserving" of seven claimants District Attorney John T. Deloney said today.

President Roosevelt's birthday will be celebrated on Jan. 29 by citizens of the United States residing in many parts of the world, Keith Morgan, chairman of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday to Fight Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday.

A dozen firemen from Engine 275 and Hook and Ladder 127, Jamaica, spent several hours yesterday afternoon shoveling coal in the basement of the United States Postoffice Building at 164th Street and Shelton Avenue, Jamaica.
Officials of Portland, Me., will receive on next Wednesday sealed proposals for $1,000,000 of temporary loan notes dated Jan-. 3, 1938, and payable on Oct. 10, 1938.

Senator Pope said today he was trying to work out a method of increasing payments to "the little fellow" under pending farm legislation. He is one of the Senate conferees on the measures passed by the Senate and House.

Mrs. Suydam Cutting, believed to be the only American woman ever to visit the forbidden city of Lhasa in Tibet, and Mr. Cutting, naturalist and explorer, who had made two previous trips to the remote Asiatic country, have returned to New York with anthropological and botanical specimens for museums here. Among the botanical items,
Leo Jurgens will "rot in jail" before he will pay $7 a week alimony to his wife who, he charges, henpecked him for thirty-eight years. He will do more than that; he will starve himself to death.

The marriage of Miss Mae Falk, daughter of Mrs. Henry Falk of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Falk, to Albert E. Wool, an attorney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Wool, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday noon in Menora Temple, Brooklyn.

WalterL Wetton, former vice prHo s Walter H. Wetton former vice president and trust officer of the National State Bank here, died this morning at his home after a long illness. He was 65 years old and was born in Philadelphia, the son of the late Charles and Annie Wetton.

Governor Merriam today denied a request of a labor committee, headed by Harry Bridges, for a Christmas pardon for Tom Mooney, stating that no action would be taken on the case while it was pending before the United States Supreme Court and stressing that Mooney had filed no official application for a pardon.

In printing the list of prize winners in the annual essay contest of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Tuesday, nine parochial high school winners were listed as attending Sacred Heart Academy.

Within an hour after she had lunched with her parents in their home, at 517 West 212th Street, Grace Gunning, a 19-year-old art student, committed suicide yesterday when, according to police, she leaped fifty feet from the 207th Street bridge into the Harlem River.

MANHATTAN BERMAN, HARRY (Nov. 3). Estate, $889. To Bella Berman, widow, executrix, 50 Northern Ave. CLARK, THEODORE S. (Dec. 18). Estate, more than $10,000. To Mamie Clark Grinell, 308 E. 79th St., and Florence Engel, 10 E. 85th St., sisters, $1,000 each: Tessie Louise Clark, sister, executrix, 40 E. 83d St., residue.

Bethune St, 20-22, 39.10x80; Florence I. White to Charles S. Utterson, 10 E 43d St, and ano, pr mtg $17,775, due and int per bond; $17.983. Irving P1, 72, 13x106.8; Eva I. Wakefield to Central Savings Bank, 5 yrs, 5%; $13,000.
Southeastern Conference coaches named Carl Columbus Hinkle Jr. today as the circuit's "most valuable" player in the 1937 football season.

Strong support of the campaign of the National Safety Council to reduce the Christmas holiday accident toll in the nation has been given by President Roosevelt. On Tuesday Governor Lehman issued a proclamation to the same end, in which he pointed out that traffic on the streets and highways last December costa total of 4,420

A brief midday demonstration was staged yesterday outside the Bowery Savings Bank Building, 110 East Forty-second Street, by 300 to 500 persons against a office of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company on the eighteenth floor of the building.

AYERS-At Summit, N. J., Dec. 23, 1937, Grace, daughter of the late David and Harriet B. Ayers, and sister of Mrs. William L. Osborn. Service private. It is earnestly requested that no flowers be sent. BARRY-On Dec. 24, 1937, James, retired New York City patrolman, Traffic C; beloved husband of the late Catherine A. (nee Walsh), father of John, Helen, Edward and Marion, brother of John and the late William.

Stanley Horne of Ottawa, young Englishborn professional who holds the Canadian Professional Golfers Asmociation title, came out of another round of Dar-blasting with a second 67 today for a half-way lead at 134 in the $2,500 Miami open golf tournament.
In a decision yesterday the New York State Labor Relations Board ordered Davega-City Radio, Ino., to cease and desist from all interference with the self-organization of its employes.

That New York University and Long Island University will be in for busy evenings when they meet Minnesota's basketball, team at Madison Square Garden next week was evident to every one who watched the Gophers work out at the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium yesterday. Fast, clever at passing and good shots, they made a fine impression.

Although State Labor Commissioner John J. Toohey Jr. reported today a decline in factory employment from Oct. 15 to Nov. 15, attended by decreasing weekly payrolls and average weekly earnings, the payrolls and earnings were higher than during the corresponding period last year and employment was off only nine-tenths of 1 per cent.
New England's "Santa Claus of the air" swung his big aerial sled northward today to drop Christmas packages to lighthouse keepers from West Quoddy Head to New York City.

Swirling snowflakes for a short while yesterday had metropolitan skiers visualizing good open slope running in the city's parks-and excellent skiing up-State, in Pennsylvania and New England, but the weather man returned to his tricks of last year by sending down rain. Good skiing conditions prevail only at a few spots.

Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver of the Interborough Rapid Transit System, announced yesterday that as a mark of respect to the memory of George H. Pegram, chief engineer of the Interborough, who died on Thursday, all train service on the subway and elevated lines will halt for two minutes at 2 P. M. Sunday, the hour when funeral services for Mr. Pegram be held at the Campbell Funeral Church, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street.

Sweeping reductions in inventories were accomplished by local department stores last month, according to the departmental analysis of sales and stocks on hand, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Wainwright Holcomb of this city and Fishers Island, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Holcomb, to Ernest Arthur Anderson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Anderson, also of Waterbury.

The United States Navy's reinforced Pacific patrol tightened its guard today following the seizure. of a sheaf of letters from a Japanese liner as it was about to clear this port yesterday and following the capture of a Japanese fishing boat by customs agents.

A builder who erected several new apartment houses in the Sutton Place and other sections has turned his attention to the Thirty-fourth Street area, where he has purchased 222, 224, 226 and 228 East Thirtyfourth Street from 224 East Thirtyfourth Street, Inc.

Jackson Ave (10-2652), n w cor of Home St, 232x101; Burton Management Corp to 1.170 Boston Road Realty Corp, 1,170 Boston Rd; mtg, $128,700. Southern Blvd (11-3108), w s, 184 ft s of 180th St, 66x149; Marmion Avenue Corp to R. M. B. Holding Corp, 11 W 44th St.

Two young women, caught in the act of holding up a women's specialty shop at 468 Ninth Avenue, near Thirty-sixth Street, at 11 P. M. last night, told police, just as bells were ushering in Christmas, that they had attempted the robbery "because we had nothing to eat all day."

The four Soviet scientists now drifting along the Greenland coast from the North Pole expect to be taken off by airplane in March or April, according to a radio message from Ivan Papanin, leader of the party, made public today.

General Evangeline Booth will celebrate tomorrow what may be her last birthday as the chief of the Salvation Army. She will be 72 and the Salvation Army requires its general to retire at 73 unless two-thirds of the commissioners on the high council decide otherwise.

The eight Americans flying southward to launch a new transpacific air service landed at Pago Pago, American Samoa, at 4:10 P. M. (7:40 P. M. E. S. T.) today after an uneventful trip of slightly more than eleven hours.
A new Minister to Afghanistan was announced today, replacing Boris Skvirsky. The announcement said K. A. Mikhail off had been appointed to the post and made no mention of Mr. Skvirsky.

Bishop William T. Manning yesterday sent a "Christmas message" to the Episcopal Diocese of New York, of which he is the head, asking every communicant to receive the holy communion today. He made his appeal in The Diocesan Bulletin, the official monthly periodical of the diocese.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the last three days:

Miss Heler Joy Lee was introduced to societ today at a tea dance, given at the Grosse Pointe Club by her mother Mrs. Helen Joy Lee. The debutante is here from her home in Winter Haven, Fla., to spend the holidays with her grandmother, Mrs. Henry B. Joy.

A committee of labor leaders who called on Mayor La Guardia in the Empire State Building yesterday to approve the transfer of Deputy Chief Inspector Harry L. Lobdell from Brooklyn to Queens were told that the Mayor did not share their interpretation of the change.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The broader. demand for wool noted a week ago has continued and the market is in a more cheerful tone than for a long time. Prices are higher slightly for fine wool both here and at country points, especially for short fine scoured wools for women's suede cloths.

New bond offerings this week were confined to two issues and constituted the smallest total since the week ended on Nov. 26. The total amounted to $3,030,000, compared with $29,199,000 in the previous week. In the corresponding period last year, new offerings amounted to $71,400,000.

Mrs. Helen M. Hill, former actress, of Hollywood, Calif., who alleged she was the widow of Benjamin L. M. Bates, New York Stock Exchange member and owner of the Murray Hill Hotel, and that she was entitled to half his estate, settled her claim for $75,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

Retail sales this week, spurred by the final surge of Christmas' buying, rose 10 to 30 per cent over the week before, but when compared with the heavy holiday volume a year ago, were held to a gain of 2 to 10 per cent, according to the weekly review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

James A. Jennings, a former Southampton town trustee and for the last fifteen years a foreman in the Town Highway Department, died at his home in Water Mill yesterday following a brief illness. His age was 73.

Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud in West Side Court yesterday sentenced to ten days in the workhouse a Horn Hardart Automat strike picket who insisted that a policeman arrest him "to see if you can pick me up for doing nothing."
Thomas Hillian and his sisters, Miss Mabel Hillian and Mrs. Bessie Dargan, Negro employes of McCosh Infirmary, Princeton University, had their faith in Santa Claus renewed today.

The close of the deferred drafting period today saw four minor league ball players advance to higher classifications. The period was held to permit clubs to draft from the rosters of those which had failed to file draft lists within the prescribed time in September.
Guy J. Bunting, vice president in charge of the accounting and treasury departments of the Illinois Central system, died today. He was 57 years old.
Harry L. Hopkins, WPA Administrator, who is convalescing from an operation in St. Mary's Hospital, played Santa Claus "in absentia" today to forty-five children patients.
Despite the adverse weather conditions, eleventh-hour Christmas shopping yesterday brought sales totals that were as good as those of Christmas Eve a year ago, store executives reported yesterday.

Pope Pius XI opened his observance of Christmas today by celebrating. midnight mass quietly in the little chapel next to his bedroom. A few members of his household, his physician, Dr. Aminta Milani, and two other medical aides were in attendance.
Mrs. Frederick T. Proctor, a leader in social and welfare work here for many years, died today of pneumonia in her home at the age of 74.
The Japanese Government handed its reply to the United States to Ambassador Joseph C. Grew last night, and officials were confident it would satisfy America and close the Panay incident.

The Westport Badminton Club remained in the running for the men's Class A championship of the Metropolitan Badminton Association by defeating the New York Badminton Club, 4 to 1, in its only match of the week. The triumph was the second in as many starts for Westport.
Oscar Philipps, 47-year-old postmaster of this tiny Christmas capital of the nation, estimated tonight his postoffice had handled since Thanksgiving more than 750,000 pieces of mail, a new record.
As the site for a six-story apartment house, the southeast corner of Morris Avenue and East 176th Street,, the Bronx, has been purIchased-by Louis Gordon, operator and builder.

Latimer P. Smith, attorney, died today following an operation for appendicities. His age was 60. Mr. Smith was born in Clinton, Iowa, in 1877. He lived in Overbrook and maintrained offices in the Philadelphia Savings Fund Society Building.

In a crooked street in Holborn Borough, associated in London with the legend of Old Scrooge and Bob Cratchit, a poultry dealer this morning was counting unsold turkeys hanging in dejected rows above his stall.

For the third time in the seven years the team has been chosen; Frank R. Kelly of West Orange, N. J., has been named captain of the All-American skeet shooting unit, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

The Eastern All-Stars worked out in the rain today, but the Western players found sunshine for their drill as the two squads continued practice for the annual charity football game New Year's Day. The Eastern boys, training at Berkeley, were prevented by rain from holding their afternoon session after they got a soaking this morning. At Stanford University,

As time moves on toward the opening kick-off of the Rose Bowl game, one continues to hear acrimonious grumblings which flared up when the identity of the contesting elevens was revealed, and that seems to be a great pity.

Buffalo's city affairs investigation, which has resulted in the indictment of seven Councilmen and nine other persons, will turn next to the Police and Fire Departments, Frank G. Raichle Jr., special investigator, said today.
Following a conference yesterday with Purchase Commissioner Russell Forbes, Mayor La Guardia announced that the city would spend about $4,000,000 soon for materials and equipment needed by the city.
Business in commercial printing plants in New York City showed a further sharp decline in November, according to a survey made by New York Employing Printers Association, Inc.

H. Percy Soule, a member of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff for the last thirty years and one of the best known newspaper men in this city, died of a heart attack at 6:57 o'clock last night in the emergency hospital of THE TIMES, less than fifteen minutes after being stricken. He was 67 years old last March 28.

Miss Yolanda Idalia Sheldon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Sheldon of Bloomfield, and Malcolm B. Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Marshall of Nutley, were married in a home ceremony tonight. The Rev. Dr. Raymond W.
Undeterred by sleet and rain, residents of this village presented early this evening their twenty-fourth annual Christmas pageant on Gramatan Hillside.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Net operating income of the first fourteen railroads to report for November showed a drop of 46.3 per cent in net operating income, compared with November,. 1936.

Mrs. Ruth Comstock Nickerson received a divorce today from Hoffman Nickerson, author, of New York City and Oyster Bay. Provision was made for the support of Mrs. Nickerson and their two children. The suit was on grounds of extreme cruelty.

Hockey makes its return to Madison Square Garden tonight when the New York Americans oppose the Boston Bruins in a National League fixture. The Bruins, with the best record of any sextet in the league, are always a good attraction in New York, and they are expected to draw a large crowd, despite the holiday.

Miss Rosella Lydia Myers of Dayton, Ohio, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Nevin Myers, was married to Samuel D. Ferster, son of Samuel D. Ferster of this city and the late Mrs. Eda Costrack Ferster, yesterday morning in the chambers of Supreme Court Justice Louis Valente, who performed the ceremony.

The Unity Campers Association of 1 Union Square last night took to task Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the Twenty-seventh Division, New York National Guard, for indirectly canceling its New Year's Eve party in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

A new note of apology came from Japan yesterday in the attack on the gunboat Panay. The note, which Tokyo hoped would satisfy the United States, cited as assurance for the future the disciplining of naval officers and reiterated that the bombing had been accidental. [Page 1.]

John Bryan Jr., 3-year-old son of a Centerville bank cashier, and his nursemaid were freed unharmed tonight several hours after the child had been kidnapped for $3,800 ransom by two men who escaped after a gun battle with the boy's father.

Drizzling skies interfered with outdoor carol singing and grounded many air travelers, but could not dampen the Yuletide spirit that pervaded New York last night. Bulging Christmas baskets entered countless needy homes, hospital wards rang with unaccustomed merriment, wires hummed with greetings, office routine gave way to the festive mood, and church bells summoned thousands to usher in the holiday in worship.
Meager Japanese Army reports tell of the capture of Hangchow, the capital of Chekiang Province, 100 miles southwest of Shanghai, yesterday.

The Navy has under consideration plans for increasing the naval seaplane forces in Alaska, according to a letter from Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, to Anthony J. Dimond, the Alaskan Delegate in Congress.
Senator Wheeler proposed today that Congress set up a permanent, independent agency as a watchdog over government appropriations.

" We will elect a Republican State ticket and a majority of both houses of the Legislature," declared William H. Murray, Republican State Chairman, who stopped here after a conference with Edwin F. Jaeckle, Erie County leader, in Buffalo.
Finance Minister Georges Bonnet announced tonight completion of th; reimbursement of a [Pound]40,000,000 loan by British banks to French railroads.

A few hours before he was to go home and play Santa Claus for his 5-yearold son, Charles F. Bark of 70 Ringwood Avenue, Wanaque Borough, was instantly killed here today. Bark, who was 37 years old, was employed as a laborer in the construction of a road crossing over the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad at McLean Boulevard.

Mrs. Betty Healy, first wife of Ted Healy, 'announced today that she would ask the District Attorney for a complete investigation of reports that the movie comedian was beaten a short time before his death on Tuesday.
In accordance with their custom of several seasons, Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry were hosts to a large group today for tea and cocktails at their new villa.

The holiday spirit kept business in the stock markets here at a minimum today, although prices generally were steady. Gilt-edge issues mostly were unchanged, while in foreign bonds Japanese loans went lower.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 18 amounted to 603,292 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced, today. This was 18,839 cars, or 3 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, and 126,756 cars, or 17.4 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, but 2,626 cars, or 0.4 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

THE Christmas season, carol-loud with music, is a good time to be reading Deems Taylor's new book. "Of Men and Music"* is a peppery. and entertaining portfolio of pieces Mr. Taylor wrote at various times for surviving magazines and a couple of newspapers that ungratefully foundered under him-or that he spoke last Winter as part of the Philharmonic's air-borne Sunday afternoons.
Justice J. A. McEvoy of the Ontario Supreme Court died today after a brief illness from pneumonia. His age was 55. His family was at his bedside when death occurred in a hospital.

A special order issued yesterday by the Police Department disclosed the promotion of two second grade detectives to the rank of first grade and seven other detectives from the rank of third grade to second grade.

Wilfred Ramella, 27 years old, described by psychiatrists as a "punch-drunk" former sparring partner of James J. Braddock and Max Baer when they were heavyweight champions, was committed to the New York City Reformatory for an indefinite term yesterday by General Sessions Judge Freschi.
Many of us have only a detached interest in "association copies." These are for fatter purses. Nor have we that sixty-pound look

Slight seismic disturbances continued to be registered in Mexico City today, but no shocks were felt since yesterday morning and the population of Mexico City is convinced it has an earthquake-proof city if yesterday's 6 degree earthquake could cause only slight damage and three deaths.
The first returns on the census of the Reich population, now compiled here, show that 92 per cent of the first 1,000,000 reports examined indicated membership in some Christian church.

Scarcely recognizable beneath an umbrella and a sou'wester capeunless he can spare himself a cellophane overcoat-Santa Claus is to make his rounds today with water instead of icicles dripping from his beard, Weather Bureau forecasts indicated last evening.

New orders in the furniture industry in November were down 15 per cent compared with October and amounted to little more than one-half of those taken in November, 1936, according to a bulletin issued yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.
A letter written by two small Canadian girls to Santa Claus at the "North Pole," but posted in an evergreen tree, was delivered today, with the tree, to the home of Joseph Mirmak.

Joan Blondell, one of Warners' stalwarts since her appearance in 1930 with James Cagney in "Sinners' Holiday," the film version of "Penny Arcade," is to leave that lot at the conclusion of her next picture and enter the free-lance ranks, she has disclosed.

Widening his investigation of apparent high land costs for the Merritt Parkway across Fairfield County, Governor Cross ordered Robert Hurley, Public Works Commissioner, and John A. MacDonald, Highway Commissioner, to supply him with complete details of every transaction since the beginning of the parkway project in 1930, when Mr. Cross was first elected Governor.

A Christmas romance that shortly was expected to bring an announcement of the engagement of Prince Louis Ferdinand, son of the former Crown Prince of Germany, and Princess Kira, daughter of Grand Duke Cyril, pretender to Russia's nonexistent throne, was reported on high authority today.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. O'Mahoney of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Cecilia O'Mahoney, to Harry Cornelius Dever, son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Dever, also of the Bronx.
There was a light in the window of the Ponikarsky house for Santa Claus tonight but it was just little Rosa Ponikarsky's way of telling Old Kris he did not have to stop.
For several months physicians have asked the Missouri Botanical (Shaw's) Garden for fresh leaves from its tropical collection of aloe vera, a succulent desert plant.

With a scrawny, black and white, five-month-old kitten in their arms, two boys appeared at the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 50 Madison Avenue, yesterday morning and demanded that Santa Claus find a home in the country where the kitten could "get big and strong."

Boris Shapiro, 52 years old, of 975 East 179th Street, the Bronx, jumped to his death from the solarium of the Bronx Hospital, 169th Street and Fulton Avenue, at 5:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The, solarium is on the ninth floor.

An eight-pound daughter was born to Mrs. Dorothy Schup, 23 years old, of 86-30 Ninety-eighth Street, Woodhaven, Queens, in Evangelical Deaconess Hospital, 627 Chauncey Street, Brooklyn, at 12:06 A. M. Christmas Day, a physician at the institution disclosed.
Mr. and Mrs. H. Otto Rothe of Devon gave a ball tonight at the Barclay to introduce their daughter, Miss Amy Rothe.

Oysters taken out of Chesapeake Bay yesterday morning graced a Bermuda dinner table last night. Neil Richardson, first officer of the Imperial Airways airliner Cavalier, wanted to give friends here a preChristmas treat, so he picked up a small barrel of oysters on the way from Baltimore yesterday morning and loaded them aboard the Cavalier. At 8 P. M. yesterday the oysters were served to guests at Mr. Richardson's cottage.

Plans for a newspaper advertising campaign to be conducted by a group of about 140 life insurance companies, in about 400 leading cities throughout the country during the week of May 9, 1938, were announced yesterday by Joseph C. Behan, vice president of Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company and chairman of the executive committee in charge of the program.
The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation is distributing $37,500 to its 400 employes as a Christmas bonus. The company has paid annual bonuses since its organization, about ten years ago.

Norman W. Church of California, whose switch to a Florida campaign this Winter has started in most auspicious fashion, today was represented by the feature winner for the second time in the five days of sport staged at Tropical Park to date.
Louisiana State's football players went through a hard, brief scrimmage today against Santa Clara plays in preparation for Sugar Bowl game on New Year's Day.

The decision of the National Labor Relations Board against the Ford Motor Company raises several issues. The most immediate are those concerning questions of fact, and the first of these relates to the attack on union sympathizers and leaders at the gates of the Ford plant at Dearborn on May 26.
The spirit of giving, as exemplified in the response to appeals for the needy made by The New York Herald Tribune and THR NEW YORK TIMES, has increased this year over preceding seasons.

Although the slugging feats of batters in the American League were not quite so outstanding last season as they were in 1936, there were a number of noteworthy performances, according to data compiled by the circuit's service bureau.

" Peter the First," the Russian biography of the Czar who founded Petersburg, or Leningrad, is-bound to have many volubly enthusiastic admirers, some of whom will be sincere. For the new film at the Cameo comes roughly under the head of "primitives." It is raw,

The Bakers Club, Inc., with clubrooms at the Hotel Commodore, is not a social club within the meaning of the Revenue Act of 1926 and therefore its members' dues are not liable to government taxation, Judge Grover M. Moscowitz ruled in an opinion filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court.

And a happy instance of the whisper of the valorous is the response to the appeal for the Neediest Cases. Those who have contributed to this Fund have incidentally given evidence of a faith in the survival of that love which endures all things and is kind.
A force of labor arbitrators headed by Premier Camille Chautemps worked late tonight, but Christmas Eve strike settlements were few and labor troubles seemed to be multiplying.

An unrestricted vacant business plot on the northwest corner of Union Turnpike and Trotting Course Lane, Forest Park, Queens, has been sold by the Deleglen Holding Corporation to Lidhayes Realty Corporation, A. W. Buschman, president, through Jamaica Brokers, Inc.

Hall P1. 1,079 (10-2691): Minnie F. Melsel to Union Dime Savings Bank, 1,065 6th Ave; extends mtg to Nov. 1, 1940, at 5%; 53,000. Castle Hill Ave. 1,361 (15-3935): 1,361 Castle Hill Avenue Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co; extends mtg to April 1, 1942,. at 5%; $160,000.
Fourteen years ago, Herbert Sanders, then owner of a general store, held a shoe sale. Soon afterward, he transferred his business interests.
Despite the smallest employment on relief and reconstruction projects in four years, Puerto Rico approached Christmas with a great buying rush. Merchants generally declared business was good.

George A. Timone, chairman of the New York State Council of the Knights of Columbus, wrote a strong protest last night to Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President-elect of Manhattan, over his appointment of Simon W. Gerson, Communist writer, as a confidential inspector on his staff.
Hervey Allen, whose new novel, "Action at Aquila," will be published by Farrar Rinehart on March 4, was recently in New York to complete publishing plans.
Captain Richard E. Cobb, from whose plane Corporal Harold Kraner, 35, of Winthrop, fell in a Santa Claus suit to his death, today found Kraner's body just off the Boston airport.

Mrs. William Walrath, who turned her 21-year-old husband over to the police when she learned he had committed a series of crimes, wept in court today when he was sent to Attica prison for a five to ten year term.

Gifts and bequests totaling $872,465 were received by Princeton University during the fiscal year 1936-37, ended last June 30, it was disclosed today in the report on benefactions annually submitted to the board of trustees by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, the day before Christmas.
Mildred, Countess of Gosford, Lady Mary Acheson, the Hon. Patrick Acheson and J. Ridgely Carter, who arrived on the Normandie, are at the St. Regis.

Tentative awards amounting to $1,778,909 were made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin for the two blocks condemned by the city as a site for the new Criminal Courts Building and jail. The awards are about 8.1 per cent above the valuations set by the city's appraisers.
A comprehensive sports review of 1937, including illustrated articles covering fifty-five sports and a list of more than 800 of the year's champions will appear in THE NEW YORK TIMES tomorrow.
In big cities and in little hamlets children and adults trained in Federal Music Project classes sang tonight Christmas carols to untold thousands.
Relchsbank's statement as of Dec. 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Edward Todd, retired manufacturer of gold pens and other gold articles and a descendant of distinguished early Americans, died yesterday of a stroke in his home, 994 Park Place, Brooklyn. His age Was 80.

Harold B. Johnson, vice president of the National Surety Corporation and one of the leading cocker spaniel fanciers in this country; died today at the South Nassau Communities Hospital at Rockville Center after an operation last Monday. He was in his forty-eighth year.

Rival unions of tugboat workers which were drawn together into one union last Summer as the means of obtaining a labor contract with the harbor operators, split during the past week, causing the tie-up of tugs owned by two companies.
Cotton-mill activity was unchanged last week when the seasonal trend was upward, and the adjusted index eased to 92.1 from 93.1. The figure was 149.3 for the week ended Dec. 19, 1936.
As a postscript to turkey, plum pudding and rum punch, the Brothers Shubert are offering tonight the musical play called "Three Waltzes."
A protest of a directness rare in papal pronouncements was uttered this morning by Pope Pius against the situation the Nazi government has created for the Catholic Church in Germany.

The Fleischmann Distilling Corporation has been appointed sole distributor in the United States for Black White Scotch whiskies. The Fleischmann Distilling Corporation is a subsidiary of Standard Brands, Inc.

The community Christmas tree has become such an established part of the annual celebration that, according to the American Forestry Association, thousands of illuminated evergreens in practically every city, town and hamlet will radiate cheer to millions of people.

Promotion of three district operating executives of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation here was announced today. Walter E. Hadley, who has been general superintendent of the corporation's Gary works since February, 1935, was made manager of operations, Chicago district, succeeding Walther Mathesius, who on Jan. 1 will become vice president in charge of operations, United States Steel Corporation of Delaware.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. follow:
Mr. and Mrs. William Stackpole have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Margaret Stackpole, to Franklin B. Lord Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin B. Lord of Syosset, L. I.
Mrs. Richard A. Carlson got her estranged husband out of jail today and gave him $10 for "Christmas spending money."
The Christmas greetings of government chieftains to their bureaus and men in the field were wrapped, figuratively speaking, in red tape.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente ruled formally yesterday that the members of the teaching staffs of the city schools were exempt from the provisions of the Lyons Residence Law, which goes into effect on Jan. 1. It requires all employes of the city to become residents of the city at that time.

It is to be hoped that the rod you've been wanting for so long and that new gun you've had your eye on for months were waiting for you under the Christmas tree this morning. The family of an angler or hunter is lucky in some respects; there are always about a thousand little items that can be bought for him.

It was not hard for the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to pick a County Clerk for New York County who would have a higher regard for the dignities and decencies of the office than Mr. Albert Marinelli, who recently resigned under fire.

A jury in Brooklyn Federal Court before Judge Grover M. Moscowitz returned a verdict yesterday awarding damages of $25,000 to Hugh Napier Jr., of 48 Reeves Place, Brooklyn, for the death of his wife, Edith, a telephone operator, on Jan. 14.

The name belongs to one religion but the spirit belongs to them all. Now, in this crisis of the modern world, when artillery drowns the sound of bells, when prayers can hardly be heard by human ears because of the groans of the dying, we need to realize this truth.

With a merriment which mocked the Spring-like weather and the changes which modern life has brought, Britain today fought through the rush of last-minute shopping and settled down to three unbroken days of Christmas celebration

Kings BAUMANN, EVA (Feb. 22, 1937). Gross assets, $16,557; net, $15,164. To sister, Agnes C. Miller, one-half life tenancy in specific realty and one-half of residuary estate; nephew, Frank Miller, one-half life tenancy in specific realty, remainder Interest in life estate, bank account and one-half of residuary estate, nieces, Agnes...
The bulk of the Business leases reported yesterday was made by apparel and textile concerns in buildings in the midtown district. Many of the contracts were for full floors.

Baroness T. von Falkenstein of Fultonham, N. Y., appeared yesterday in traffic court and paid a $1 fine on a summons she received for leaving her automobile parked at Forty-third Street and Third Avenue for four hours on last Wednesday.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Betz of Luzerne, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Veronica R. Betz, to Joseph J. Ford, son of Mrs. Marie G. Ford of Pittston, Pa.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated today that 90,000,000 bushels of this year's domestic wheat crop would move into foreign markets. Exports from the 1936 crop were 10,049,000 bushels. Exports including flour, between July 1 and Dec. 18, were reported at 31,063.000 bushels.
Mayor Edward J. Kelly signed an ordinance today authorizing "pari-mutuel brokers" to handle bets on horse races.

Vincent Stateliumas's children came to his rescue yesterday. The 60-year-old longshoreman, who went back to his native Lithuania in 1932, thirty years after first coming to this country, yesterday received a writ of habeas corpus As a result he will have a hearing on his admissibility to the country where all his children were born.
The annual trek to Santa Anita begins tomorrow as the 1937-38 race meeting gets under way with the running of the one-mile Christmas Stake for a purse of $5,000 added.

Theatrical activity will be almost suspended next week and apart from the annual Christmas pantomimes there are only two new offerings, both on Monday. "Macbeth," with Laurence Olivier and Judith Anderson, which will be transferred from the Old Vic to the New Theatre tonight, makes way for "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

The shades of John Wanamaker and Senator Bankhead, the elders, were invoked yesterday to save New York's puffing mail subway, one of the last of a pneumatic empire in five cities, as the Postoffice Department in Washington received a forlorn bid intended to keep the system breathing after the deadline next Friday.

John Sloane of W. J. Sloane leased to Dr. Samuel Friedman his former residence at 7 East Eightyninth Street, a six-story English basement house with elevator. Dr. Friedman occupies 1,140 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Ninetyfirst Street, which is being razed to make way for the new home of the Brick Church.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Bishop of Virginia for the last decade, will arrive in this city from his home in Richmond early on Jan. 2, to take up his residence in New York City. On Jan. 1, 1938, he will become Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Christmas morning finds the Neediest Cases Fund standing at $258,144.76. The contributions of 873 donors lifted it past the quartermillion dollar mark yesterday as they added $14,065.72 to the amount that had been received previously in this twenty-sixth annual appeal.

Tom mercer Girdler, chairman of the board and president of the Republic Steel Corporation, and Mrs. Girdler were among some 800 passengers who sailed late yesterday on the Rotterdam for a West Indian cruise.

Two firms have been added to the list of those that will become New York Stock Exchange houses at the new year. Lazard Freres Co. will take the place of Lazard Freres, and Deery White will come into existence.
Judge Edwin T. Dickerson's "Merry Christmas" in Circuit Court today assured Thomas H. Riley, Baltimore newspaper man, of an income of about $200 a month.

President Roosevelt bid the nation tonight to forget all enmities and in the true Christian spirit of goodwill to all men forgive every man his brother, even as Christ, With the knowledge of his own betrayal, wished well to Judas.

Miss Mary Griffin, who was beaten by the man 'who shot and killed her friend, Mrs. Wilma V. Carpenter, on Dec. 13, left the Chestnut Hill Hospital today to re-enact the scenes of the tragic happenings in Mrs. Carpenter's home in Camp Hill.

Miss Mary Rebecca Hyde, for forty years co-manager of the Lady Jane Grey School which closed in 1923, died this afternoon from heart disease. Members of the family said she was more then eighty years old.
Under the influence mostly of holiday factors, the bond market churned in a highly irregular fashion yesterday, while the volume of trading diminished to the second slowest of the month.

In observance of Christmas, leading securities and commodity markets throughout the world will be closed today. Many of the principal commodity markets throughout the United States closed early yesterday.
Two Christmas gifts of $50,000 each have been received by Tuskegee Institute, the Negro school founded by Booker T. Washington.

In a score of tiny trading posts in Canada's sub-Arctic and at many deep within the Arctic Circle white men and women will celebrate Christmas as best they can and think of their kin folk and friends living amid the comforts of civilization.

The bleakness of a cold, rainy day was dissolved yesterday in the Christmas spirit which took more than 100 Sunday school children from the Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, on a torchlight pilgrimage to the grave of Dr. Clement Clarke Moore, author of the famous "A Visit from St. Nicholas," who is buried in Trinity Cemetery, near the church.
Chancellor dolf Hitler entertained 1,300 of ?e National Socialist party old uard in the Loewenbreaukellar ere today. After dinner he spoke or an hour.
The American Federation of Labor estimated today that more than 1,000,000 jobs had been lost since September, but said that wage increases through the year had sustained buying power.

The marriage of Miss Priscilla Dreyer, daughter of Mrs. Sigismund Dreyer of New York and the late Mr. Dreyer, to Abraham W. Binder, professor of liturgical music at the Jewish Institute of Religion, took place yesterday at 40 West Sixtyeight Street in the study of the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, who performed the ceremony.
Miss Charlotte Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel A. Richards of this place, was married this afternoon to Kenneth Brooks Gair, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Gair of Dorchester, Mass.
Closing plenty of ground in the late going, Miss L. C. White's Rams Head moved up from third place in a stretch spurt today to win the Austin, mile-and-sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds.

Plans for a new and greater Shanghai under Japanese influence were reported to the Cabinet yesterday by President Masao Taki and Vice President Kazuo Aoki of the Cabinet Planning Board, which has been considering measures for Shanghai's future, Asahi reported today.
The text of the findings of the naval court of inquiry in China that investigated the bombing of the United States gunboat Panay follows:

Joseph A. C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, conferred yesterday at Berne with the Swiss Government, presumably on the "grave problems" raised in President Guiseppe Motta's Statement Wednesday that Switzerland must both remain in the League and regain absolute neutrality by obtaining exemption from the League covenant obligation to apply non-military sanctions.
Miss Helen H. Geer entertained with a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for her debutante cousin, Miss Marion F. Geer, daughter of Mrs. Firth Geer and of Garrow T. Geer.

Forty platinum fox pelts were sold to British buyers at the annual international fox pelt auctions here today for a record price of more than 2,000 crowns ($500) each. A male platinum fox was sold for 20,000 crowns ($5,000) for stud.

The heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis, the titleholder, and Nathan Mann of New Haven in Madison Square Garden Feb. 23 was closed yesterday with the signing of articles. The contest is scheduled for the regulation fifteen rounds and will be held under the direction of the Twentieth Century S. C., of which Mike Jacobs is president.

Mrs. Grace Alexander Capps, wife of Dr. Edward Capps, retired Professor of Classics at Princeton University and director of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens, died here yesterday at her home, 9 Ober Road, after an illness of two months. She was 72 years old. Mrs. Capps was born in Greenville, Ill., the daughter of Senator Jediah Alexander.

A record entry of 274 skaters will compete in the Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships to be held at Newburgh, N. Y., one week from today. According to Chairman Harry Cohen of the Newburgh Skating Association, which is conducting the event, the number of participants is fifty more than has ever been listed for the championships.

Plans for an improvement in the midtown amusement section were announced yesterday in connection with the sale by the Central Savings Bank of 239-41 and 261-3 West Fifty-second Street through to 242-64 West Fifty-third Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

America's first lady, who flew across the continent and through stormy weather for a holiday reunion with her daughter and two grandchildren, helped decorate a Christmas tree for "Sistie" and "Buzzie" Dall tonight.

Miss Elaine Lind, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben S. Lind of 300 West 108th Street, was married yesterday at noon at the Hotel 01cott to Maurice Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Levy of Mer-. rick, L. I., by the Rev. Dr. Samuel J. Levinson of Temple Beth Emeth, Brooklyn.
Stocks closed steady and mixed in featureless trading; turnover, 835,160 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues irregular in quiet trading; transactions, $5,873,200.

The Ford Motor Company spurned overtures from the United Automobile Workers of America today, and drafted a legal campaign to resist a National Labor Relations Board order that it cease anti-union activities.

Flatly refusing to sign a Board of Aldermen resolution fixing the 1938 budget at $589,980,576.64 yesterday, Mayor La Guardia took the unprecedented step of declaring that the city had no official budget for next year and for the first six months of 1939.
Word has been received here of the engagement of Miss Alice King Gade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Herman Gade of Norway and France, to Egil Holmbo, charge d'affaires for Norway at Warsaw.
If the elm is to be spared the fate of the chestnut in New York State, Dr. A. B. Buchholz, director of the Bureau of Plant Industry, said today, it will be only after a long and hard fight.

James H. Casey, 65, of Brookline, prominent in the sporting goods business for many years, rushed in his car to meet the incoming New York boat this morning to greet his son, James Jr., a theatrical man, who came home to spend the Christmas holidays.
Many pastors will preach tomorrow morning on the New Year and will offer prayers that it may see peace in China and in Spain.

Gifts to the United Hospital Campaign of $5,000 from an anonymous donor, of $2,500 from the Shell Union Oil Corporation and of $1,500 from the Cohn Hall Marx Company were announced last night by Arthur A. Ballantine, chairman of the professional section.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: I wish to enter a protest against the method now used in showing the standings of the teams in the National Hockey League-or, for that matter, in any hockey league.

That the resignation of Premier George Tatarescu is impending is denied officially. The Premier, on the contrary, it is declared, will remain in office to face the Opposition and hopes to devise some coalition that will give him a parliamentary majority.

The State Department received and made public today the Japanese note in reply to the United States demands in connection with the bombing of the gunboat Panay and three American merchant vessels on Dec. 12, but official comment was withheld pending study of the note to determine whether the Japanese had met stern demands for guarantees against such attacks.
Tomorrow is not Christmas to many residents of this fishing village on Roanoke Island. The people of Rodanthe, for the most part, celebrate instead what is known as "Old Christmas" on Jan. 5.

Playing today in the best-ball-offour-against-par Christmas tournament of the Tin Whistle Club, Eric Thomson of St. John, N. B.; J. K. Weeks of Scarsdale, N. Y.; G. W. Mansfield of Boston, and J. W. Wood of New York beat par by 10 with a net round of 62.

Alabama's undefeated football players stepped from the train into a roaring welcome today, grimly determined to uphold the Crimson Tide's untarnished record in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day. Thousands jammed the station to greet the special train and shouted a hearty welcome to the forty 'Bamans for the Tide's fifth appearance in the Tournament of Roses.

Stillman W. Weston, 32, who two years ago sued his father-in-law, James E. Kavanagh, vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, for $100,000, charging alienation of affections of Kavanagh's only daughter, Helen Weston, today was sued here for divorce,

The New York City League of Women Voters made public yeste day a letter it had sent to Senate Leader John J. Dunnigan requesting him not to reappoint Senator A. Spencer Feld of this city as chairman of the Senate Committee on Public Education.

Sad-eyed, sway-backed Sam's ugly equine face brightened up a bit yesterday afternoon even though the sleet beat down upon his head and he realized that the new year would usher in his sixteenth year of hauling a junk wagon around town.

C. E. Tuttle, president of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation, estimates net earnings this year will be $711,000 before Federal taxes and points out that the tax liability will be about $141,000 in addition to normal and excess profits taxes of $136,000, in a letter accompanying the preferred stock dividend paid to holders of common shares.
President Getulio Vargas decreed today control of exchange operations, placing all exchange transactions exclusively under the Bank of Brazil.

John Somers De Hart Jr., chairman of the Maplewood Township Committee and a leading civic figure in the Oranges and Maplewood, died early today at the Homeopathic Hospital in East Orange at the age of 68.

The Union Cooperative Building and Loan Association, 1,424 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, has received permission to change its name to Union Savings and Loan Association, according to the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department issued today.

The chance visit of a Barren Land trapper to a neighborhood cabin, 700 miles north of here, has brought to light the disappearance of a trapper and the discovery of his wife and child on the verge of starvation.

An air-mail letter sped a gift of $1,000 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday as S. E. Summerfield of Miami Beach, Fla., thus made sure that his contribution to the rescue of the men, women and children who are in the most acute distress known to ten leading charitable agencies of the city would be available by Christmas Eve.
The fourteenth annual meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers' advisory board will be held in the Hotel Warwick, Philadelphia, on Jan. 26 and 27.

Faced with the prospect of a cheerless Christmas, Albert Jalbert, .39, an unemployed leather worker, killed his wife and two children with a hammer and committed suicide by hanging in the cellar of his once happy home.

When General Sessions Judge Freschi discharged the $10,000 bail yesterday on which Vincenzo Tisbo, former private banker at 121 Mott Street. had been at liberty on four grand larceny indictments returned on the failure of his bank in 1923, Assistant District Attorney Carstarphen told the Court the cases against him had collapsed.
More than 1,000 persons attended a Christmas Eve service last night in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Arturo Toscanini will conduct his first American concert in more than a year and a half when he raises his baton at 10 o'clock tonight to conduct the newly organized radio symphony orchestra in the first of a series of ten full-length concerts to be broadcast weekly over the combined networks of WEAF and WJZ.

Reference to the name of Mae West, film actress, whose role in an "Adam and Eve" sketch over the WEAF network on Dec. 12 was critically received by many listeners, has been banned by the National Broadcasting Company on. any of its fifteen managed and operated stations throughout the country.

Trading on the local Cotton Exchange yesterday was limited to narrow fluctuations, and closing prices were unchanged to 5 points lower than on Thursday. A further reduction in outstanding January interest preparatory to circulation of the notices on Monday resulted in placing of contracts forward, and covering held the near month within limits of 4 points.

The marriage of Miss Patricia Jane Chase, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Chase of Forest Hills, Queens, to Parmely Frederick Pritchard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Britchard of New York, formerly of La Grange, Ill., took place last night in the First Presbyterian Church, Forest Hills.
District Judge Arthur W. Selover today removed P. F. Herrly as foreman of the county grand jury Investigating vice, liquor and labor conditions and named Val Ness to succeed him.

Miss Mary Josephine Cutting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fulton Cutting of 15 East Eighty-eighth Street and Wheatley Hills, L. I., has completed plans for her marriage to Alexander B. McFadden, which will take place on New Year's Day in the Church of the Advent, Westbury, L.- I.
An automobile skidded on a wet pavement tonight and crashed into a Pittsburgh-Wheeling bus, killing Frank P. Lindsay, Washington County clerk of court, and injuring six of the thirty passengers.
The text of the Japanese note replying to United States protests against the bombing of the Panay follows:

William S. Gray, New York airplane pilot, plans to fly a new seaplane from Port Washington, L. I., to San Juan, P. R., next week to establish an inter-island airplane charter service for Aerovias Nacionales Puerto Rico, Inc., a Puerto Rican operating company.
The Department of Commerce reported today that the first ten months of 1987 were the most prosperous experienced in Chile since 1929.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The organization of which I am president is the producer of the Energine newsreel program broadcast over the National Broadcasting Company network and referred to by Carr V. Van Anda in his letter discussing the recent broadcast by Ambassador Saito on this program.
Jay St, 45; William Danziger to Andrew Sorbello, 772 E 9th St, Brooklyn; mtg $20,000 (50c). Greene St. 158-60; Margaret J. Gardner to Oscar A. Ross, 121 W 90th St; mtg $5,000 ($10).
Republican leaders of the 'Westchester County Board of Supervisors announced here today their endorsement of candidates for positions in the board during 1938.
The Hudson County Board of Elections ruled-today that thirtyeight ballots, which had been held in dispute in the Clee-Moore recount, should be counted for Governor-elect A. Harry Moore.

Miss Lillia M. Newton, a practical nurse believed to be about 50 years old, was found dead yesterday in a furnished room at 35-26 156th Street, Flushing, Queens. The police listed the death as a suicide.
Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller-elect, announced yesterday six appointments to his department which will become effective on Jan. 1 when the new Controller takes office.
Henry Richard Gibson, believed to be the oldest living former member of Congress, observed his 100th birthday anniversary today in his red brick home here.

Grain markets on the Board of Trade developed a strong undertone today, with closing trades around the best prices of the day. Wheat finished with net gains of % to 1 cent a bushel, while corn was % to 1 1/8 cents higher. Oats closed 1/4 cent higher, rye was up 1/2 to 3/4 cent and soy beans, 1 to 1 1/2 cent higher.
All the world's records for production of Steel were broken in 1937, the magazine Steel reported today, exceeding the previous high, established in 1936, by 9.41 per cent.

Archie Skibrek, hoping to spread Christmas cheer among his neighbors, decorated the fir trees on his lawn, set up a Santa Claus and reindeer and rigged up a loudspeaker to broadcast carols he played inside his home.

Appointments The following persons are appointed patrolmen on probation at $2,000 per annum, effective Dec. 22. 1937. their names appearing on certifications of eligible list of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, dated Dec. 3, 4, 10 and 15, 1937, and assigned as indicated:
Strong support has developed in the Senate Judiciary Committee for a constitutional amendment offered by Senator Norris to make it easier to change the Constitution.

Henry W. Herbert, who retired as a justice of the Court of Special Sessions in August, 1935, after twenty-six years on the bench, died yesterday at his Summer home in Wading River, L. I., of a heart ailment at the age of 66.

Senator Wheeler of Montana, chairman of the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, announced today that immediately after the holiday recess he would begin conferences with government officials, railway executives and representatives of investors in railway securities preparatory to the introduction of railway legislation of major importance.

Douglas Lesueur, radio announcer, who has been missing from his Detroit home since Nov. 30, apparently is safe and well, according to word received today by his father, Percy Lesueur, noted hockey net-minder of twenty years ago.
William John Chesher Jr., 38; his wife and two small children, who faced the prospect of spending Christmas in the United States Detention Home here, believes in Santa Claus.
Several thousand names were included in the report of the LaFollette Civil Liberties Subcommittee of the Senate Education and Labor Committee as having employed labor spies or strikebreakers.

Up-State farmers and local grocers and milk officials joined hands yesterday in outspoken opposition to Mayor La Guardia's recently announced plan to permit independent dealers to sell bottled Grade B milk at 9 cents a quart at ten locations in the city.

The Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday afternoon extended its season's greetings with the annual performance of Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel," which was warmly received by a houseful of Christmas celebrants.

More reinforcements for General Miguel Aranda's relief army arrived on the Teruel front tonight. The Government, however, clung desperately to its dearly won foothold on the outskirts of the town and fought even more savagely today in a desperate effort to improve its precarious position.

Christmas Day finds warfare raging in two parts of the world. and terrorism rife in the land of the Nativity. The dispatches that follow tell how the holiday is being observed in the strife-beset countries:

Fire Commissioner John J. McE1ligott ordered the largest number of promotions in the history of his department yesterday when he established 118 men in higher ranks, effective at the first of the year.

Henry Foster Boardman, until his retirement thirty years ago the general agent in Troy, N. Y., for the Mutual Life Insurance Company, died yesterday at his home, 755 Park Avenue, after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

A forecast that the United States would export more goods to foreign countries in 1937 than it would import from other nations was made today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States on the basis of a foreign trade review just compiled.

The twelfth annual games of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, scheduled for Jan. 8, will inaugurate the 1938 indoor track and field campaign. A banner season is in prospect for metropolitan footracing followers, as many important meets are listed.

One woman was instantly killed and three others injured, two of them seriously, yesterday afternoon when a truck, with allegedly defective brakes, crashed into them as they were starting to cross West Street at Liberty Street. The driver,

The contract for the new Longchamps Restaurant which will occupy the ground floor and basement on the Thirty-fourth Street corner of the Empire State Building has been awarded to C. J. Moore, Inc., according to Brown's Letters, Inc.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Fearful that prices of silver again may be subject to the speculative fluctuations which prevailed a few years ago, Eduardo R. Suarez, Mexican Secretary of the Treasury, is continuing his official visit to Washington over the Christmas holiday in the hope of concluding negotiations which would assure Mexico a continued market for her silver at a stable price, it was learned today.

William P. Trench, for fifty-six years actively associated with the American metal trade, died yesterday at his home, 1,815 Newkirk Avenue, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, at the age of 76. He had been ill for several weeks.

Mexican financial newspapers reflect the uneasiness in general here as to whether the United States will continue to buy Mexic.n silver and, if so, at what price. Failure to continue the purchases would force a sharp curtailment of Mexican agrarian and public works programs as well as the "Mexicanization-ofindustry" campaign.

In a Christmas Eve speech transmitted to Germans who are living abroad from all German radio stations, Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the National Socialist party, declared the dominant thought in Germany tonight was "peace in security."

Seven employes of the Sure-Lite Kindler Company, 45-36 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, were deprived of their Christmas bonuses by two thugs who robbed Nathan Prussin, 46, of 143 East Thirtyninth Street, Manhattan, the general manager, of $50 at 8 A. M. yesterday.

Whisky stocks in the United States at the end of November totaled 449,911,830 tax gallons, or 88,648,106 more than in the same month last year, despite a slackening of whisky production and tax-paid withdrawals.

Sentences ranging from one month in jail to three years in the penitentiary were imposed today on fifteen members of the Truck Drivers Union, an and A. F. of L. affiliate, whose picketing tactics stopped virtually all motor transportation of freight in the Hartford area in September.

The Japanese Government has informed the American Government officially that the sinking of the Panay on Dec. 12 was accidental and unintentional. It adds that it has taken steps to punish those at fault and gives assurances that it has warned all of its forces in China to avoid a repetition of the accident.

At this time of the year, whenever the ground is covered with snow or sleet, nature's supply of food is inaccessible to birds. So long as they can get enough to eat, birds can generate enough heat to stand the cold weather; without food they often die of exposure, even if they do not starve to death.

The Panay affair occupied the Amerian and Japanese Governments last week. After a fortnight of diplomatic negotiation the Japanese promised to avoid such incidents in the future and the United States accepted those assurances.

Manufacturers of men's clothing and furnishings are banking on an average 10 per cent reduction in prices to stimulate a revival of their business during the Spring, they said here yesterday. The industry was the first to feel the effects of the current business recessions, its decline having started the first week of last March and, after a highly unprofitable year, hopes that 1938 will witness a revival.

Field-grown roses, sweet peas, fresias, gardenias, carnations and buttercups can be cut in California, shipped across the continent by air express and arrive in nearly perfect condition as a result of a new wrapping process devised by refrigeration specialists of the Bureau of Plant Industry.

At 5:13 P. M. last Tuesday, in accordance with this resolution, the House adjourned, preceded eleven minutes earlier by the Senate. Only a few members were on the House floor when adjournment came, while in the Senate, at the other end of the Capitol, only seven Senators were at their desks when the motion was put.
Mrs. Cordelia Campbell, 55 years old, daughter-in-law of the late James A. Campbell,

Sitting alone in his study at Sandringham House, King George VI today spoke over the radio to his subjects at home and overseas, whose numbers may only be guessed but not counted There was more than a note of sadness in this Christmas broadcast, because he gave a clear hint in his openingg sentences that this might be the last of the notable series of radio messages initiated by his rather.
Members of the Central Club for Nurses of the Young Women's Christian Association will give a reception the afternoon of New Year's Day at their clubhouse, 132 East Forty-fifth Street.

Joe Louis's acquisition of the world's heavyweight title and his disregard of established custom in defending the crown within two months after winning it, stood out in a year of boxing that was notable for the activity of its champions.

The twenty-third annual national junior and twenty-first annual national boys' indoor tennis championships will open tomorrow morning at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Play will continue through the week, with both competitions slated to reach the final rounds on Saturday.

Various charitable organizations in New York and Brooklyn aided iby the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop will be the beneficiaries of a sale which opens tomorrow at the headquarters of the shop, 705 Second Avenue, and will continue there throughout Thursday.
Of all the plans made in the last year to revive "The SeaGull" hereabouts, the most--impressive emerges into print this morning as follows:

' Asserting' that many millions of dollars have been wasted in former years through the use of poor materials, flimsy workmanship and lack of proper planning in the construction of medium-priced homes, Donald H. McNeal, technical director for the Federal- Home Loan Bank Board, declares that the architect must hereafter be "drafted to serve as the most practical figure in the small-home building field."

Using a new-type questionnaire which importers of goods acquired by barter with Germany must fill out in order to clear their merchandise through customs, the United States Treasury Department next year will submit all such transacI tions to a close scrutiny.

TELEVISION, often said to be the future's threat to the cinema industry, holds no terrors for British film interests if the Gaumont-British Picture Corporation is successful in its latest venture. Rather it is the other way around, for the corporation has announced that it intends to equip fifteen.theatres in the London area . for demonstrations of television, thereby threatening the British Broadcasting Corporation's monopoly of the field.

To meet increased unemployment among young men and women, the National Youth Administration will add 1,000 workers to the number employed on part-time work projects in this city. An equal number will be added to the NYA rolls in the rest of the State.

Many of the country's leading political scientists, historians and classical scholars will assemble here next week for a series of discussions on present trends in government in this country and abroad.

Citing some of the problems connected with the proper appraising of real estate properties at the present day, Pell Thompson, manager of the appraisal department of Pease Elliman,..points out that the new methods of appraising go very earnestly-into-the subjects of rentals, income, management, maintenance and the reasonable net return from the property provided it were satisfactorily improved.

Defending champions were toppled from their thrones with gay abandon in New York City schoolboy sports during 1937. Particularly was this so in senior higH school activities of the Public Schools Athletic League, in which only two titles were retained.

There is considerable Christmas spirit in Moscow today despite the red regime and despite the fact that the real Russian Christmas-that is, the one celebrated by the remaining adherents of the Orthodox Church-does not come until January 7.
Protestant Church circles reporter today the fifty-odd pastors to whom Christmas furloughs from prison were given must return to jail after the holiday season.
TURKEY'S new law forbidding its porters to carry heavy weights has started a discussion among cosmopolites on the technique of weight-carrying.

AS the year draws to a close it is possible to look into the next and perceive what sort of things women will be wearing when 1938 gets under way. It is a cheerful prospect. Clothes will be essentially attractive. The feminine will count and women will revel in it.

Interest in field hockey for women gained impetus throughout the United States in 1937. Locally, the New York and Long Island Field Hockey Associations staged inter-club matches, the results of which determined the personnel of the sectional team in the Northeast tourney, held at Smith College.

Suggestions were voiced by several business executives last week that labor should acknowledge the "reasonableness" of accepting wage reductions, in line with the recent decline in commodity prices and the cost of living.

MONTREAL.-A record number of skiers, particularly from the United States, is expected to throng the slopes of the Laurentian Mountains during the holiday season. Although many families are now celebrating the holidays in the mountains, the main influx of visitors will start tomorrow and will gradually increase with the approach of the New Year's week-end until an expected new high in Laurentian travel is reached.

LASHING, sparkling Broadway is preening itself for New Year's Eve. Already the holiday crowds throng the thoroughfare. But when the festive days have passed this brightest diadem of New York's bejeweled night, magnet for the world's wanderers, is going to the cleaners.

Joseph P. Platak, a Chicago postoffice clerk, just about stole the show at the national A. A. U. handball championships in his home city in April by winning not only the singles crown for-the third successive year but also the doubles title with Bob Weiller.

New York City acted as host to the thirty-seventh annual championship tournament of the American Bowling Congress in 1937 and found this kegling carnival a welcome guest even though, on its very first visit, it stayed for fifty-six days.

The courageous opposition of religious forces to the onslaught of totalitarianism and militarism is the one bright note on an otherwise pessimistic world, Rabbi Israel Goldstein said yesterday in his sermon at the B'nai Jeshurun, Eightyeighth Street, west of Broadway.

Little pigs come to market at New Year's-with cranberries in their eyes and lady apples in their mouths. They are garnished to be worthy of the most elaborate New Year's Day dinner table, and their flavor is fit for the most exacting of diners.
Mr. and Mrs. Lester Collins of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Wills Collins, to Garrett Birkhoff, son of Dean and Mrs. George D. Birkhoff of Cambridge, Mass.
Canada wrested the Gordon International Medal from the United States and Schenectady supplanted Utica as holder of the Gordon National Medal in the leading curling competitions of the year.

LOOKING forward to 1938 to "the flowering of several efforts," among them ?? L. R. Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company, points out that "broadcasters see radio's shortcomings more clearly than the majority of their critics."

The annual Aviators Ball under the auspices of Aviators Post, 743, American Legion, will take place on the night of Feb. 18 at the Roosevelt. Net proceeds from this event are used for the benefit of the Aviators Welfare and Relief Fund.

IN no field of literature have Americans lagged more tardily after their European colleagues than in the writing of local history. In England, and on the Continent, town and county history is no less respectable than national history,

Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Owens of Wilmington, Del., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Morton Owens, to Thomas Bradley Davidson of Washington and Richmond, Va., son of Mrs. John C. Davidson of Washington and the late Mr. Davidson.

The failure of three long-term convicts in State Prison here to show up today for their Christmas dinner aroused suspicions that led to their discovery in a tunnel they had bored to a point within ten feet of liberty.
