Members of the National Life Conservation Society are rehearsing "A New Year's Pageant" for presentation at their next meeting when the newly elected officers will be installed. The pageant, written in verse, is the work of the late Mrs. Almeda M. Costello, mother of Mrs. Charles Cyrus Marshall, founder and president of the club for the last twelve years.

Miss Ruth Hughes Aarons of New York remained an outstanding figure in table tennis during 1937, but while she continued as the women's United States champion her world singles title went by the board.

A sweeping program of "training on the job" for the 3,000 employes of the Department of Health to keep them abreast of scientific progress and public needs was announced yesterday by Commissioner John L. Rice.

Based on the universal conception of religion and the belief that what young people want is one great church which is a tremendous spiritual force, Dean William H. Powers of Hendricks Chapel, has built a religious and social program at Syracuse University in which more than 1,200 students participate regularly.

Miss Amy Estelle St. John, daughter of Mrs. George Kunath of this place, was married to Laurence Preston Fuller, only son of Mrs. Z. Preston Fuller, also of Hempstead, this afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's mother by the Rev. M: Dr. Frank M. Kerr.

Eight past presidents will be guests of honor of the Soroptimist Club at a luncheon to be held on Thursday at the Hotel Iroquois. Among them will be Mary Tuttle Towle, an assistant United States District Attorney, and Dr. Valerie Parker, a specialist in social hygiene.
An Italian mission, including representatives of the various armed forces and other branches of the government, will be sent to Japan in the near future, it was announced tonight.

Invitations have been sent out by J. Howard Magee of this city for the marriage of his daughter, Miss Virginia Warfield Magee, to George F. Lape, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lape, also of this city, on Jan. 14 in Trinity Episcopal Church. The Rev. Daniel J. Stover, rector of All Saints' Episcopal Church, will perform the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Robert Lee Bull,

DANCE International goes into its final week tomorrow, with its grand climax scheduled for next Sunday evening at the Center Theatre, when an "Evening of Modern Dance" will bring together Ruth St. Denis, Martha- Graham, Doris Humphrey, Hanya Holm,

John J. Donahue has reason to think well of his wife's police dog as a guardian of the home but not so well of him as a pet. The dog, mistaking Donahue for a burglar, lunged at him as he entered his home.

Acting Lieutenant Sam Dribben of the Sheriff Street station celebrated yesterday, not so much Christmas, as his twentieth anniversary as a voluntary filler-in at the headquarters desk for some Irish lieutenant to whom Christmas was the biggest day of the year.
AUGUSTA, Ga.-Chief interest at this resort centers this week in the fourth annual Southern Star Amateur Golf Tournament, to be played at the Forest Hills course Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Cricketers, both at home and abroad, enjoyed a busy season. England came out second best in a series of test matches with Australia down under, the Antipodeans winning three of the matches and England two.

The marriage of Miss Jane Walters Miller of Beekman Tower, New York, to Edwin Anderson Metts Jr., also of New Yorl:, will take place here on New Year's Day at Shadyhill, the home of Miss Miller's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. John C. Emison.
Mr. and Mrs. James A. Conklin of this community have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Corinne Henrietta Conklin, to Leslie D. Wielding, son of Mrs. Adna Wilding of Paterson.

Following is the text of the note sent by Secretary of State Cordell Hull to Joseph C. Grew, the United States Ambassador in Tokyo, for delivery to Koki Hirota, the Japanese Foreign Minister, in reply to the Japanese note of yesterday on the Panay incident:...

Taking advantage of the nation-wide demand that past revolutionary periods be brought to a close through the liberation of all political prisoners, Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff, has consented to the sweeping amnesty bill just approved by Congress and he has made another bid for public favor in his campaign to popularize his threeyear plan.
A thousand or more persons attended the Christmas Day communion service at 11 o'clock yesterday morning in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine celebrated by the Rev. W. D. F. Hughes.
The imposing new structures which have grown up in recent years in the vicinity of City Hall looked down yesterday on the passing of a tradition.

The widow of Ted Healy, film comedian, said today that further investigation of his death "would do no one any good." Mrs. Healy, the former Betty Hickman, is in a hospital. A son was born to her Dec. 7.

A novel edition of Aesop's familiar beast fables, designed to stimulate discussion of current events and personal problems, as well as to teach English to foreignborn adults, is being prepared by the VVPA Adult Education Project of the Board of Education.

AMONG people who write books about New York Ithere is this in common. Always the big city gets them, somehow. Either it is, nostalgically, the past, trampled under foot, uprooted. and kicked aside by the monstrous present.

ONE of the decorative principles-unity-is perhaps most easily attained in period rooms when walls are paneled, for their woodwork may then be closely harmonized both in style and coloring with the wood of the furniture.

AS correspondents frequently, often bitterly, complain, there is a depressing element in herent in the collection of records. Time enhances one's regard for a shelf of books, and new printings of old favorites can only increase the value of our early editions.

Governor Earle announced tonight that effective at midnight, Dec. 31, every Pennsylvania motorist convicted of violating the State fiftymile speed limit will have his operator's license suspended for a minimum of ninety days "in addition to any other penalty imposed by law."

Dominating today's observance of Christmas were several dinners, quiet family gatherings and special services at the churches. At many of the villas, colonists kept infor. mal open house. At Casa Marcheta, Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff entertained this noon with a dinner, as has been her custom for many seasons.

While credit executives concede that the volume of business failures in January will probably show a fairly substantial rise over the like month of this year, they expressed the opinion last week that the number will not be as large as expected a month or so ago.
Wrestling, in its professional phase, made little constructive progress during 1937. Promoters' differences arose frequently and the championship picture was considerably blurred.

Fifty miles are not so many in Texas, where it is sometimes that far from a citizen's veranda to the highway that runs in front of his place. But when you put end to end all the extra mileage that has been chalked up on South Texas speedometers in a fifty-mile detour just because of a couple of forty-foot stretches of barbed-wire fences, the result might suggest the distance between the earth and the moon.
HE last of three concerts of chamber music by Ernest Bloch, presented in London, England, this season under the auspices of the Ernest Bloch Society there, is scheduled for Jan.

A benefit entertainment, to be known as a Five o'Clock Frolic, will be held on Jan. 15at the Pierre for the benefit of the Free Kindergarten Society of Brooklyn. There will be music for dancing, and several other divertissements are being arranged.

Our correspondent at Helsingfors reported recently the death by falling from a hay wagon of Prince Alexander Demidoff. The bearer of a name for many years synonymous in Russia with that of Rockefeller had been working as a day laborer in Summer and a carter in Winter.

Recently the National Economic League announced the conclusion of its members that the problem that will transcend all others in the United States in 1938 is "government." In a preferential ballot the 5,000 members of the council agreed that the question of government was more pressing than, the business set-back, the national debt, crime, or any of a score of other questions.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. M. Deutsch of 1,050 Park Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Deutsch, to Joseph S. Herbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Herbert, also of this city.
Speed marks were shattered before record crowds at America's outstanding 1937 automobile racing classics as the sport had one of the most flourishing years in its history.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-With New Year's Eve near at hand, hotels and amusement places are rushing preparations for what is expected to be a capacity crowd, similar to the ones of recent years which taxed the facilities of the resort.

The rise of Princeton as a power in lacrosse provided one of the most significant developments in the old Indian game during 1937, showing that Northern teams are beginning to get the kind of material and coaching that has kept the State of Maryland on top through the years.

Two 7-year-old boys were found drowned in a suburban ice-covered lake today twenty-four hours after they had left their homes comparing lists of gifts they expected from Santa Claus. The victims were James Knutsen and Edward Donton Jr. Searchers who passed the lake, where the boys spent much time playing,
Stimulated by the importation of a consignment of French jumpers, which added both interest and competition, amateur racing enjoyed one of the best seasons in years during 1937.

Two rooms from early New England houses, representing the beginnings of American domestic architecture, hare been, installed in the American wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will be opened to the public on Tuesday.
Japan extracted a 400,000-yen "Christmas present" from China today. The money represented a down payment on the first indemnity assessed against China for the current war.

According to The Sunday Referee, Winston Churchill has been invited by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to join the Cabinet as Secretary of State for Air, and he will accept. Mr. Churchill, who is 63 years old, was Air Minister from 1918 to 1921. Viscount Swinton, the present Air Minister, who is 53, is to retire on New Year's Day. The Referee says.
Housing at Orange Bowl

Tobias Meyers, a Civil War veteran 94 years old, presided at a groaning Christmas table today, set for a reunion of five generations of his family. Children and grandchildren celebrated a double holiday at his home, Yuletide and the seventy-first wedding anniversary of Tobias

AFTER two and one-half years of research and painting, Miss Aline Rhonie, artist and airplane pilot, last week completed the second section of a huge fresco in which she is depicting the history of Long Island aviation on the wall of Hangar F
Intercollegiate rowing, during the season of 1937, saw records in the traditional four-mile events smashed by two of the best crews that have appeared at Poughkeepsie and New London in modern years.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Lula Sanders, daughter of Mrs. John W. Sanders of Cain-Hoy, Charleston, S. C., and the late Mr. Sanders, to John W. Fox 2d, son of Mrs. Arthur W. Lawrence of 575 Park Avenue and Mount Kisco, N. Y., and the late Rector K. Fox, which took place on Wednesday in Morehead City, N. C.
About 100 homeless newsboys and other youths had a turkey dinner in traditional Christmas style yesterday at the Brace Memorial Newsboys House of the Children's Aid Society, 244 William Street.

HOBBYISTS attracted by the smell of printers' ink to the field of amateur publishing are a busy group these days. With New Year's fast approaching, their compact presses are turning out books, pamphlets and engraved broadsides for distribution to friends in place of the customary greeting cards.

Building construction is being carried on at a rapid pace in many parts of Italy with a strong trend toward eight and ten story apartment houses in the larger cities, states Maxwell L. Scott of the realty firm of Douglas L. Elliman Co., who has recently returned from a two-months' tour in Southern Europe.
IN the thickly carpeted hall just outside the door press photographers, nursing cameras and flash bulbs, sat waiting, more or less patiently, so we knew it was Mr. Barrymore's apartment.

The article that follows is an abridgement of Mr. Benson's illustrated "Problems of Portraiture" monograph, published by the American Federation of Arts and designed to accompany the author's highly effective comparative portraiture exhibition.
Former Governor and Mrs. Charles S. Whitman of the Delmonico will give a dinner on Wednesday in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mrs. Whitman's daughter. Miss Anne S. Grosvenor.
Army and Navy circles here, from major generals to subdebutante daughters, were represented practically in full force at tonight's annual Midshipmen and Cadets Ball at the Mayflower Hotel.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. C. Harold Andrews of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Gordon Andrews, to William Edward Fackert Jr., on of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Fackert, also of Montclair.

WASHINGTON.-American agriculture is paying off its mortgage debt faster than at any time within the past seventeen years and at the' same time is acquiring new blood through a "selective" process inaugurated by the Federal Land Bank system to place in operation the farms it has been forced to acquire through foreclosure.

Building activity in the nation for November, as measured by permit filing reports from cities of more than 2,500 population, was 15 per cent below October and 7 per cent less than in the corresponding month of 1936, Secretary Perkins announced today.

While more prisoners shared today's Christmas program and feast in Sing Sing Prison than on any other Christmas in its history, the program was not as elaborate as in some recent years, especially in the generosity of the Mutual Welfare League in the distribution of gifts.

Security and commodities markets in the United States will reopen for business tomorrow. Most of the leading European markets, however, will extend the Christmas holiday until Tuesday, as will the Winnipeg Grain Exchange.

MOZART'S "Don Giovanni," absent from the Metropolitan's repertoire for two seasons, will be heard Saturday afternoon, with Ezio Pinza in the title role, and Dusolina Giannini, who will make her first appearance of the season with the company, as Donna Anna.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Roslyn Oppenheimer, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Oppenheimer of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Oppenheimer, to Joseph Worona of Poughkeepsie, N. Y. Mr. Worona was graduated from Syracuse University in 1931, and from the law school of Syracuse University in 1932.

The Chicago Lawn Bowling Club swept all national honors in lawn .bowling during 1937, its representatives taking the national four-matt team title, the doubles championship and the singles crown and also walking off with the East-West team laurels.

Information concerning the Public Service Fellowship of $1,400 for a year's study in history, economics, government or the social sciences, offered by Barnard College, was given in a report delivered by Professor Elizabeth Baker, chairman of the fund committee, yesterday.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Dorothy Niebrugge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Niebrugge of Brooklyn and Westhampton Beach, L. I., to Dr. Charles Voorhees Hults of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Eugene A. Hults and the late Dr. Hults of Perth Amboy, N. J.

Ever since the Loyalist hold along the Bay of Biscay in Northern Spain was broken last October by the Insurgents' capture of Gijon, a "final offensive" against Barcelona and Valencia on the Mediterranean has been expected. Insurgent victory in the north was said to have released 100,000 men and much equipment for a drive on the Aragon front.

Ten years after it was lost to France, the Davis Cup finally returned to the United States in 1937 and once again American tennis supremacy was restored in the most prosperous season of play in a decade.
WHAT a newspaper correspondent saw in Red China is told by Edgar Snow in "Red Star Over China," to be published on Jan. 3 by Random House.
Scenes of extraordinary gayety and lavish expenditure on the part of well-to-do Chinese in Shanghai marked the celebration of Christmas Eve and Christmas Night. Apparently entirely forgetful
Chinese Embassy employes today disclosed that Dr. Ting-fu Tsiang, Chinese Ambassador, left Moscow Thursday without expecting to return.

THERE is a considerable holiday stir at the Metropolitan Museum. Its special Christmas show, reported in the news columns last Sunday, will be on until Jan. 2. In this exhibition (Gallery E-15) is assembled appropriate material representing many nations and covering several centuries.

THE chorus girl, who these many years has been to the night club as the adjective is to the press agent, is going to carry a union card as well as a compact if the Chorus Equity Association has its way. Insisting that this time Chorus Equity intended to do more than test

No housing shortage exists so far as old-law tenements are concerned, reports James Felt, president of the realty firm bearing his name and chairman of the old-law tenement committee of the Real Estate Board of New York.

A campaign to raise a fund of $10,000 from American users of cables and radio in order to send delegates to the International Telegraph Conference meeting in Cairo, Egypt, Feb. 1, was launched last week by the National Foreign Trade Council and cooperating foreign trade organizations. The delegates are expected to oppose suggested increases ranging up to 16 2-3 per cent in cable and radio message rates.

The Five Points House will be the beneficiary of a preview performance on Thursday evening at the Ritz Theatre of J. B. Priestley's current London hit, "Time and. the Conways." The play will bring Dame Sybil Thorndike back to America.
The American Statistical Association's ninety-ninth annual meeting will begin on Monday and run through Thursday at Haddon Hall here, it was announced today by W. Randolph Burgess, president.

PALM BEACH, Fla. - Probably the largest and most brilliant social affair on New Year's Eve here will be the dinner dance which the Everglades Club has given for its members each year for more than twenty years.

The McLean New Year's Eve dance, which began thirty years ago as a children's dancing class celebration and became the capital's most elaborate annual party, will require extensive building again this year. Mrs. Evalyn Walsh McLean said today that the front terrace at Friendship, her estate,

Only one major event was held in bobsledding during the Winter of 1936-37, and that one, the world four-man championship, was run in Switzerland and won by Great Britain. Mild weather balked all attempts to conduct the usual events in this country, which left the 193536 winners still in possession of their titles.

UNCERTAINTY: Dean Henry W. Holmes of the Harvard Graduate School of Education pointed out in his annual report last week that there seemed to be no agreement on solution for economic problems. "Perhaps," he declared, "the whole world is economically illiterate."

THE conventional picture of American youth as a joyous, robust figure with eager face and laughing eyes has been grimly altered in recent years. Out of elaborate surveys by the American Youth Commission and the National Youth Administration

Throughout the period of recovery from the world-wide depression, interest in consumers' cooperatives has been rising. The consumers' cooperatives provide an entirely novel approach to the problem of maintaining price stability and limiting the power of monopolies.

In their concern for the safety of Hong Kong and their imperial interests in the Far East, the British find some consolation in the belief that Japanese blunders may contribute toward a closer Anglo-American colloboration not only in Asia but elsewhere.

THE new year begins for the democratic nations with an undeniable recession in prestige which some people fear may develop into a fullsized depression. There was an international conference at Brussels to recall Japan in China to her senses. and as a result Japan now stands astride a prostrate China. Several hundred thousand Italians before Mussolini's windows thunder approval as II Duce takes Italy out of the League of Nations.
Tommy Bland, Toronto welterweight, won a ten-round decision from Fritzie Zivic today in a boxing bout that was to start the Pittsburgher up the comeback trail.

THOSE who still believe that poetry must deal exclusively with the sublime will insist that Jonathan Swift wrote not one line of poetry but only verse. From their point of view this is true. Milton, Wordsworth. Tennyson and their followers have restricted poetry to the province of elevated thoughts nobly expressed.

The annual dance under the auspieces of the undergraduate New York committee of the Connecticut College for Women at New London will take place Tuesday night in the Palm Room of the Commodore. Proceeds of the dance will be used to augment the general fund of the New York Alumnae Association.

Don Lash, Indiana alumnus and '"iron man," the first runner in the history of the Amateur Athletic Union to win the national crosscountry championship four successive times, was the outstanding figure in the harrier sport during 1937.

The National Maritime Union in a statement distributed yesterday to its members replied to the United States Lines of the International Mercantile Marine Company, which on Thursday gave a circular to its crews defending its refusal to sign a contract with the union that included a closed shop provision.

When the new housing law goes on the statute books next month, there will stand ready to administer it a compact, businesslike organization which already, in less than three years, has done nearly two billion dollars' worth of business, business intimately related to the familiar processes of building financing and construction, yet at the same time pioneering in a field unexplored three years ago.

The gravity of the problem of achieving immediate strict control of the socalled "Young Officers' Group" of the Japanese Army is causing most serious concern in conservative army circles here and in North China as well as in the Cabinet in Tokyo.
WHEN the curtain goes up on "A Doll's House" tomorrow evening the audience will have the esthetic pleasure of sitting before a completely written play.

Spanish Vestments. Alice Baldwin Beer Gallery, 41 East 47th Street. until Jan. 8. Antique vestments and embroideries from the sixteenth to the eighteenth century. Handicraft. Decorators Club Gallery. 745 Fifth Avenue,
PARIS.-The eerie wailing of alarm sirens every Thursday at noon has reawakened Paris to danger of air attacks, against which feverish preparations were being made on a large scale two years ago.
WITH a twofold purpose in mind, scientists, business men and workmen are now engaged in a full exploration and development program at Linville Caverns.

The steamship President Monroe, which was scheduled to have sailed on Christmas eve on the regular fortnightly voyage around the world of the Dollar Line, was still at her pier at Twelfth Street, Jersey City, yesterday.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.
KINGLESS: Hungary, though without a King since the flight of the Habsburg Charles at the end of the World War, has remained a kingdom,

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Linen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Alexander Linen Jr. of this place, to Robert John Connell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Connell, also of Waverly.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace Garner Reed gave a dinner dance last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for their debutante daughter, Miss Anne Byrd Reed. The debutante, who received with her parents and her sister, Miss Elizabeth Garfield Reed, wore a long-sleeved off-the-shoulder gown of white tulle over silver, a beaded girdle and a wreath of gardenias in her hair.

THE holiday season may bring a lull in the bridge-playing activity of those who find their games at home, but at the bridge clubs there are nearly as many games as usual, even on Christmas and New Year's Day.

Holland will be the scene of an international, self-governing children's school next September with the arts of communal living and mutual understanding as underlying ideals. Enrolling pupils of various nations and all ages up to 18 years, the school will be connected with the Children's Workshop Community, established since 1926 at Bilthoven, a suburb of Utrecht.

Free ward care during 1937 in the ten medical institutions affiliated with the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities totaled 923,150 days,. an increase of more than 6 per cent over the 848,163 days provided last year, according to a report issued yesterday by Ralph E. Samuel, chairman of the executive committee of the $6,250,000 federation campaign.

Joseph Scherens of Belgium was the only world champion to retain his title in the field of bicycle racing during 1937. He shattered all precedent by capturing the sprint crown for the sixth successive year.

THE United States has much to gain and little to lose if the Senate ratifies the North American treaty agreed to by representatives from Canada, Mexico, Cuba and the United States at Havana, according to Commander T. A. M. Craven of the Federal Communications Commission, who has returned to Washington from the meeting.

This city was assured of a celebration next year of its 250th anniversary when the city council directed Mayor Harry Scott this week to appoint a committee of twelve to handle the arrangements and spend the money being raised through the sale of commemorative 50-cent pieces.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The Christmas Festival" (Tour of Collections) Margaret B. Freeman, 2 P. M.; Motion Pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Early Medival Art: The Meeting of East and West" (Tour of Collections) Margaret B. Freeman, 3:15 P. M.; "Christmas Legends," Kirsopp Lake, 6 P. M.

The Oriental Park racing meeting opened today with a large crowd of enthusiastic fans in attendance. Bothibook and mutuel betting were available to the public and the wagering was brisk throughout a well-balanced seven-race program.

Colorful episodes of pageantry in tribute to the Ninth Company of the Seventh Regiment (Company "I", 107th Infantry, N. Y. N. G.), will feature the 112th anniversary ball of the Old Guard of the City' of New York, which will take place on Jan. 28 in the grand ballroom suite of the Commodore.

A virtually new Russian Communist party is being erected on the remains of the old one, which by successive purges has been reduced to about 2,000,000 members and candidates from a total of 3,200,000 in 1933.

Uninterested in parading statistics of her 'four years and five months as regional supervisor of the Narcotics Bureau of the Ninth Federal District, Mrs. George Bass of Chicago, first and only woman to hold such a post, dismisses her record with the understatement, "The standards have not fallen."

A negligible number of requests for evading service and a continuing enthusiasm in those who volunteer characterizes the record of women jurors four months after they were made eligible, according to Acting Commissioner of Jurors James McGurrin.
Those who plan to spend some of their Christmas money on evening finery for gals New Year's Eve parties will find the shops ready to welcome them with intriguing dress-up merchandise and ideas.
AKE GEORGE.--This Winfer resort's first snow train will leave Grand Central Station at 11:50 P. M. Friday, Jan. 7, arriving at Lake George Saturday, Jan. 8, at 7 A. M.

A very reliable source confirms the belief that the report of former Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium on his economic survey will propose, among other things, the establishment of an international fund.

Newton D. Baker, who raised the largest army that the United States has ever seen in the shortest time that any such force has ever been raised in the history of the world, died of a cerebral hemorrhage at 2:10 o'clock this afternoon at his home here.

Newell James Elliott of Los Angeles, field representative of the board of pensions of the Presbyterian Church, died today of a thrombosis in an Ogden hospital at the age of 55. Mr. Elliott was stricken on a train en route from Chicago to Los Angeles.

Dr. and Mrs. Charles L. Barthen of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen L. Barthen, to Dr. John J. Eppig of Port Washington, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. John Eppig of Babylon, L. I.
With the collapse of peace negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization the relations of the two organizations enter upon a new phase.

Though the philanthropic work of the Children's Aid Society has a wide and varied field, the benefit performance of "Aida," to be given under its auspices on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the first undertaking of this kind to be attempted by the organization.

C. P. Nelson is the new commander of the South Shore Power Squadron, one of the most energetic in the entire chain of U. S. P. S. units, as the result of the annual elections this month. He succeeds Louis Streck of Freeport. J. S.

THE most important feature of this book is the directness and quiet fidelity with which it lives up to its title. William Hatfield in 1912 was a 19year-old lad reading law in England; and he wanted to go to Australia and try his luck in the Great Open Spaces; also, he wanted to write.

Pointing out some of the difficulties confronting the building industry at the present time, H. I. Feldman, New York architect, declares that the banker has the greatest opportunity for leadership in the revive' of a basic industry by lowerint' of interest rates and finance charges.

A gift of $10,000 to the United Hospital Campaign from William R. Warner Co., Inc., and subsidiaries was announced last night by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund. He reported also a gift of $1,000 from St. Theresa Roman Catholic Church.

At Washington's holiday dinner and cocktail parties this season there is a small but significant hole in the "among those present" 'lists. The absentees are some twenty-odd dignitaries and experts--not to mention their secretaries and assistants-in the State Department who, when hostesses' entreating voices

Throughout Washington County the lives of new mothers and their babies are being saved. Seventeen country doctors, aided by county, State and Federal services, are bringing modern medical practice as related to childbirth into this rural section.

Miss Elizabeth Carolyn Ros, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ross of Arlington, has chosen New Year's Day as the date for her wedding to Dr. Benjamin B. Burrill, son of B. B. Burrill of Bloomfield. The Rev. Dr. Wallace H. Carver, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Arlington, will perform the ceremony at the church.

In the theatre-even the puppet theatre-the show must go on, and Miss Dennis Dooley, marionette operator with the Tony Sarg show, adhered to this tradition after being seriously injured yesterday morning in a fall during a performance at the Windsor Theatre, Forty-eighth Street near Seventh Avenue.

Mail handled by the Post Office Department in the first twenty-two days of December set an all-time record for the period, bettering the high mark established last year by about 4 per cent on a revenue basis, Postmaster General James A. Farley announced today.
After its small rise THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has reacted and for the week ended Dec. 18 eased to 84.6 from 85.0. For the corresponding week last year the index was 108.7.

Russ Hoogerhyde of Clarenton Hills, Ill., won the men's national archery championship and Miss Jean A. Tenney of Clear Springs, Md., captured the women's title at the fifty-seventh annual target meet of the National Archery Association in Lancaster, Pa.

NOW that that unreconstructed international rebel, Mickey Mouse, has been thrown out of Yugoslavia for conspiring against the throne--he together with the newspaper correspondent who rashly reported the plotthe expulsions from foreign countries of this arch-enemy of nations have risen to two.

The Detroit Red Wings captured the Stanley Cup, emblematic of the world's professional hockey championship, last April for the second year in a row. Manager Jack Adams succeeded in keeping the trophy in the Automobile City despite a string of injuries that beset many of his star players.

AEVIEWER necessarily concerned first of all with exhibitions while the long ac tive -season is in progress (and a phenomenally active season the present one has thus far proved) finds far less time than he could wish might be- found to devote. to books.

The marriage of Miss Jean Marvin Smith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edbert A. Smith, to Robert Heath Small of East Orange, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Small of Hatboro, Pa., took place here tonight at the home of her parents.

Transcending all other triumphs in the kennel world during 1937 was the amazing victory of an American-bred dog over the best representatives of all breeds in the great exhibition of the English Kennel Club in Olympia, London, Oct. 7. All honor to Champion Shelterock Merry Sovereign and his breeder-owner, Sheldon M. Stewart of Montclair, N. J.

TWO interesting first one-man shows were among the events of last week in the local gal leries. One was the exhibition of oils, water-colors and drawings by Theodore Czebotar, at the Walker Galleries (till Jan. 8); the other was the show of oils and water-colors by Alfred Kraemer, at the Midtown (till Jan. 3).

The eight-story building known as the Lathrop Apartments at 40-56 West Eighty-third Street, fronting 100 feet between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, will be sold at auction under foreclosure proceedings tomorrow in the Vesey Street rooms by Henry Brady.

The Rev. Dr. Frank R. Slnglser, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Watertown, Mass., and Mrs. Singiser have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Rebecca Singiser, to Edgar Howard Van Santvoord, son of Howard Van Santvoord of Waterford, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Van Santvoord.

Anti-war policies and demands for academic freedom are expected to be affirmed at the national convention of the American Student Union, which opens at Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, N. Y., tomorrow and continues through Friday, New York representatives of the organization announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Francis Knight of Braintree, Mass., have announced to friends and relatives in New York the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Holden Knight, to Harvey J. O'Hare of New York and Troy, N. Y.
Mr. and Mrs. Edmund J. Karr of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Karr, to Guy Emery Shipler Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Guy Emery Shipler of the Vicarage.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Hill of East Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine J. Hill, to Victor W. Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Thompson of Hartford, Conn. Miss Hill is a graduate of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn.
AMONG eminent conductors considered special champions of contemporary music today Hermann Scherchen undoubtedly enjoys the most solid following in Italy.

As 1937 recedes into history it appears as the year in which educational roads, as never before, led to Washington and the public treasury. Organized teachers from all parts of the country, flocking there in the Spring, made their greatest drive for Federal aid for schools.

Miss Nancy Van Vleck will give a tea Thursday at her home, 1,107 Fifth Avenue, for members of her debutante committee assisting with plans for the joint recital to be given by Lotte Lehmann and Laurits Melchior of the Metropolitan Opera on the night of Jan. 11 at Carnegie Hall.

The last train will leave the Thirty-third Street terminus of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, operating the tubes to New Jersey, at 6 A. M. this morning, and the station will be closed, pending its correlation with the Sixth Avenue Subway, according to an announcement by the railroad last night.

CHRISTMAS retail business for the country on the basis of early reports was probably about 5 per cent under last year's volume. The results were very spotty as between various sections of the country. The South and Southwest pulled well ahead of a year ago, while the middle West and New England suffered declines. Best business was done on small gift items in the popular and medium price ranges.
Most startling to the reviewer of women's athletics during the past year is the discovery of the extent to which professionalism has hit the ranks of the top-notchers in several major amateur sports.

Members of the New York, Westchester and Long Island chapters of the Sweet Briar Alumnae Association, in conjunction with students of the college who are at home for the holidays, will give a tea Tuesday in the Blue Room of the Therese Worthington Grant restaurant, Park Avenue, to celebrate Sweet Briar Day.

Fairly normal commitments are expected by furniture manufacturers from buyers due to enter annual Spring markets in Chicago and Grand Rapids Jan. 3. The buyers, according to reports, will shop the new season's offerings with extreme care, but purchase liberally once they have completed their inspection of the lines.
No sportsman who has been at all active afield, whether with rod or gun, can proclaim with any degree of honesty that 1937 has been a bad year.

OF all Shakespeare's plays there is probably none which has made so little appeal to musicians as "Pericles," one of the great popular hits of the English stage in the seventeenth century, though despised by the cultivated taste of the period

At 4 A. M. last Wednesday the first toll-paying automobile sped through the south tube of the $85,000,000 Lincoln Tunnel connecting mid-Manhattan to Weehawken, N. J. Above the glass ceiling of the tube rolled the- Hudson's tides- a barrier overcome once again by the gigantic highway system which the motor age has forced upon the metropolitan area.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Horatio Minor Davis of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Eubank Davis, to Edmund Pendleton Dandridge Jr. of Baltimore, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Dandridge of Nashville, Tenn.,. and grandson of the late Rt. Rev. Arthur Selden Lloyd, Suffragan Bishop of New York.
AFTER working ten years with Florenz Ziegfeld as his press agent, I grew so accustomed to sharing his worries, triumphs and failures that I automatically identified him with myself.
The Duke of Windsor practically bought out a floral shop today to celebrate his first Christmas with his bride, the former Wallis Warfield.

Miss Frances Perkins, in her annual report as Secretary of Labor, said today that "heartening progress" had been made toward the original goal of Congress in creating the department nearly twenty-five years ago.

THE 'cellist Maurice Marbchal, in his recent appearance with the Colonne Orchestra, introduced a new 'cello concerto and an unfamiliar sonata by Francoeur. M. Fr. Bousquet, the composer of the concerto, has based his work on Spanish folk tunes.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Stevens of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Stevens, to Edward Pickering Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Foster H. Parker of Salem. The prospective bride attended Stoneleigh College at Rye Beach,

The annual Parliament of American Science will be opened here Monday by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the most comprehensive scientific body on the North American continent, for its annual review of advances in all fields of science during 1937.

The Maryknoll Concert, to be held this evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, has been planned and will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera Company. The program will include many prominent artists, including Zinlka Malinov, who made her Lbut; recently in the leading rlo of "II Trovatore."

WASHINGTON. - Government specialists say that few foods are as nutritious, per unit of weight, as eggs. They recommend, for the best results, that eggs and egg dishes should be cooked slowly at a moderate, even heat.

Of paramount interest in swimming during 1937 were the recordbreaking feats of Ralph Flanagan, 20-year-old- Florida youth, at the men's national A. A. I. outdoor championships, and the sparkling performances of the sprinters at the women's.

December business ebbed to the lowest point in many months in numerous parts of the country, the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents pointed out yesterday in its current review of business conditions.

Mrs. Daisy Wisdom of New York was married here today to Allen E. Ostrander of Larchmont, N. Y. The ceremony, performed in the village chapel, was witnessed by a few friends of the couple. The Rev. Thaddeus A. Cheatham and the Rev. J. Fred Stimson officiated.

The expected legal challenge to Chicago's new handbook licensing ordinance materialized today. Mayor Edward J. Kelly signed the ordinance late yesterday. Today the Rev. Philip Yarrow, superintendent of the Illinois Vigilance Association, said he would seek an injunction to test its legality.

With 3,000 worshippers filling St. Patrick's Cathedral, Cardinal Hayes celebrated Pontifical mass yesterday. Men in formal attire and women in expensive furs knelt side by side with those in thin cloth coats and even some in tatters as all received

THE return of Merrit Hulburd from the movies to magazine editorship is one of the few instances of the kind when the act was performed voluntarily and, consequently, it caused considerable comment around town.

The first conflict between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization in a governmental office in this city is being fought in the Department of Public Welfare and the Emergency Relief Bureau, it was learned last night.

SOME New York apartment houses are rejecting dogs as tenants; Federal housing developments have banned dogs and cats; legislation is proposed to rid the city of dogs in twelve years. Apparently New Yorkers are facing a show-down on their pets.

URNING back the pages of the year's scrapbook, the reader finds television, with its promise of a vast new industry and unlimited opportunities for artistry, leading. the list of Nineteen Thirty-seVen's contributions to the science of radio.

ONE of the most bizarre episodes in American history was the war with the Barbary States. Comparatively little space is devoted to it in textbooks, yet this struggle between the young American Navy, led by men barely more than youths. and the grasping Moors contained the elements of romance and high adventure.

Alexander Carter, 35 years old, of 169 Edgecombe Avenue, Negro operator of a truck that killed a woman and injured three others Friday afternoon as they were crossing Liberty at West Street, was arraigned yesterday on a homicide charge before Magistrate Mogilesky in Felony Court.
Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Ingalls of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adele Ingalls, to Carl M,. W. Jenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin T. C. Jenter of Pelham.

Members of the younger set home from schools and colleges are being honored at dances this week in Westchester. The Westchester assembly for juniors will be held on Wednesday at the Siwanoy Country Club here. Patronesses include Mrs. Albert B. Baker, Mrs. R. Clifford Black, Mrs. Harry W. Brown, Mrs. George W. Carrington,

DESIGNED to fit snugly into its rustic surroundings, the country residence shown above is being erected on a wooded tract of five acres on the Guinea Road overlooking the Misnus River in Stamford, Conn.

Handicapped by weather conditions, outdoor speed skating, a sport which depends entirely on low temperature, suffered considerably from lack of activity during the year, with the result that only one major meet was conducted in the East.

WHEN Angna Enters gave her first theatre performance she borrowed $25 to meet its most urgent expenses and sent advance announcements to addresses which she had taken from the telephone directory on the selective principle of nearness to the theatre.

Two round-robin tournaments for the pocket-billiard championship of the world, a challenge match for the same crown, challenge matches for the world's 18.1 and 28.2 balkline titles and a meeting for the 71.2 balkline honors of the United States, in addition to numerous minor competitions, kept the ivory game very much in the spotlight during 1937.

According to Sir Charles MorganWebb, adviser to a parliamentary committee on finance, low costs of construction, low rates of interest, and cooperation in providing credit, and capital, are the three causes of the rapid progress of housing in Great Britain during the past eight years.

During 1937 international competition was engaged in to a greater extent than ever in the long history of yachting. First in importance was the sixteenth match for the America's Cup, which was taken again by the New York Yacht Club, the defender, with the Royal Yacht Squadron of England the challenger.

Minor defects in the speech of entering college freshmen have increased in frequency during the last six years, according to a survey of defective speech among college students made by Victor M. Kleinfeld, director of the speech clinic at City College.

THE Boston Symphony, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, will present two choral works of Sibelius new to this city in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, Jan. 6. They are "The Origin of Fire," from the "Kalevala," and "The Captive Queden."

America's might as a track and field power, demonstrated so forcibly in the Olympic Games the year before, was shown in a different but equally impressive fashion last season as Olympic champions and place-winners found themselves beaten on all fronts by the upward surge of newcomers.
A giant locomotive of a Pennsylvania railroad express and mail train left the tracks and plunged 60 feet down a retaining wall into a city street today, killing the engineer and fireman.
Sixteen new death sentences were made known today for various offenses, including: Stocking stores with buttons nobody wanted.

Sixteen hundred delegates attending the national convention of the French Communist party, which opened here today, lauded Cardinal Verdier, Archbishop of Paris, for his recent anti-dictatorship remarks. The Communist Deputy Maurice Thorez said:

To the Screen Editor: "Gaumont British has another Jessie Matthews picture to make," writes Joan Littlefield from London in last Sunday's TIMES, "and then will probably cease production altogether."

With the United States about to undertake a large-scale housing program, Part 2 of the Commerce Department's World Economio Review is timely, calling attention to the fact that the United Kingdom's recovery dates from the inauguration Of a national housing program in 1932.

John W. Catharine of Brooklyn will be' Installed as president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards at a dinner meeting of the organization at the Union League Club, Chicago, Jan. 26. Paul E. Stark, retiring president, will preside at the opening of the dinner and induct Mr. Catharine into office as head of the national body for the ensuing year.

The metropolitan junior indoor singles tennis championship went to Joey Fishbach of St. John's University when he defeated the defending titleholder, Marvin Kantrowitz, in the final at the Hamilton Courts yesterday.

A Christmas truce has brought temporary peace, if not good-will, in Pennsylvania's heated battle over the administration of relief. By New Year's Day, it now appears, Karl De Schweinitz, State Secrqtary of Public Assistance, will learn from Governor Earle whether he is to retain or lose-his $12,000-a-year

The sharp competition for limited available business in rayon greige goods in the last several months has been accompanied by growing liberality in sales terms, and some selling agents were discussing the feasibility last week of calling a meeting at which the objective would be the development of a program to stabilize terms.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Dorson of 1,185 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Audre M. Dorson, to John M. Gingold, eldest son of Clarence Gingold of London and Steepleton House, Stockbridge, Hampshire, England, and the late Mrs. Gingold.

War Admiral was the big horse of 1937, sweeping through his races undefeated, despite injury, and including the triple crown of Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes in his eight victories, which left him just short of being the season's largest money-winning horse.

Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Gates McDouall of East Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Gebert McDouall, to Paul Alban Ward of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Bowles Ward of Newark.

John Hlavati, 52 years old, of 1,055 Tiffany Street, the Bronx, whose daughter Lillian, 20, told the police she stabbed him early yesterday morning, died at 3:10 P. M. in the Lincoln Hospital. He was found lying on the bedroom floor of his home by radio patrolmen who were sent
Hale C. Jones, 30-year-old resident of Wood River, Ill., was America's leading amateur trapshooter during 1937, keeping the title he won the previous year.

With another New Year's Day on Saturday, football provides at various points in the country and on a couple of islands, the various Bowl and post-season arguments which, though they come on the first day of the new year, are generally regarded as the final guns of the season.

Alabama's football team went to the horse races today to get a tip on speed from the thundering thoroughbreds. Coach Frank Thomas open. sent the squad through a morning workout at Occidental College, then escorted his 'Bamas to Santa Anita Park.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Phillipp J. R. Schmabl of 490 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Thelma Schmahl, to Thomas Humes Jay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Jay of Nutley, N. J.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Cummins Upson of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Lumpkin Upson, to Joseph Orchard Foil of Concord and Greensboro, N. C., son of Mrs. liam Archibald Foil of Concord and the late Mr. Foil.

A survey in the cafeterias at Hunter College this week has revealed that spinach, mashed potatoes and milk constitute the diet preferred by the Hunter College student. Potato salad, chow mein and coleslaw run close seconds in the favorite foods listed, according to Miss Margaret Gram, a member of the homes economics department and manager of Students' Exchange.

The Bruins of Boston came through with a lightning goal in the last three minutes of their game with the New York Americans at Madison Square Garden last night, and that counter marked the Hub sextet's margin of victory over Red Dutton's skaters, who had to accept a 1-to-O defeat.

An advance registration of nearly 700 for the second annual Christmas Conference to be held under auspices of THE NEW YORK TIMES on Tuesday at the Hotel Biltmore represents a gain of more than 800 per cent since the initial meeting last year.

Mr. and Mrs. M. Owen Dilger of this place and Windsor, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Kathryn Dilger, to Tristram Walker Metcalfe Jr., son of Dean Tristram Walker Metcalfe of Long Island University and Mrs. Metcalfe.

Mrs. Arthur Dashiell DeGroff of Orange, formerly of Maplewood, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Dashiell DeGroff, to Paul Van Ston Singler of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John A. Singler of Boston, and nephew of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Orchard of Maplewood.

The policy of secrecy concerning important international movements of gold which this country, following the European lead, attempted to adopt more than a year ago and to follow in connection with the establishment of the tripartie agreement recently has been thrown open to serious question.

Playtime for children at the Catholic day nurseries has taken on a modern aspect this Winter as the result of child guidance courses inproduced last month for the sisters in charge. Twice weekly nuns from the twenty-five centers assemble at the Divine Providence Day Nursery, 225 East Forty-fifth Street, learn new methods of child care.
Interest in Rugby continued to grow during the past year and the sport has now been accepted as a Spring fixture in several of the leading colleges in the East.

IN the Bishop's Palace in Salamanca. where Nationalist general headquarters were installed a year ago, Gen eralissimo Francisco Franco labors with the problem of conquering Spain and plans against the day when, he seems convinced, final victory will be his.

LYND WARD'S novels in woodcuts no longer belong in the classification of things that are arresting because their kind is completely new or unknown. "Vertigo" is his fourth composition in the medium of wordless.

Polo had for its feature during the last season a national open championship in which a strong Argentine quartet took part and which ended with the rise to the title of a new team which went through an impressive campaign of test matches and other competition with the loss of only one game.

The eighth annual course for the study of horticulture and of artistic flower arrangement, sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, is to be held in the Astor Gallery of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, Jan. 10-13. The opening lecture on Monday morning, Jan. 10, will be on "Japanese Flower Arrangement.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Sage Carter of Greystone- on- Hudson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Brewster Carter, to John Willard Morehouse, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Morehouse of Brewster, N. Y.

A luncheon and fashion show will be held on Jan. 4 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the benefit of the Boy Scouts of America. The show, entitled "Around the World Style Revue," will be divided into two parts, one featuring ancient and authentic costumes
A reception on Thursday afternoon in the Rainbow Grill at Rockefeller Center will honor Mme. Karin Michaelis, noted Danish writer; Lauritz Melchior, Metropolitan Opera tenor, and Mrs. Melchior.

Pupils in the first four grades in the Des Moines elementary schools no longer receive report cards. Instead, in an effort to eliminate the competitive element from the school picture, they receive "pupils' progress reports," which rate students on degrees of cooperation in forty-one phases of their school work.

THE tragedy of L'Aiglon has exercised popular imagina tion since the day Empress Marie Louise bore a son to Napoleon the Great. There could be few fates more tragic than that of the King of Rome, destined to rule the world as Napoleon II. who died as the Duke of Reichstadt at an alien court.
