Miss Rebecca C. Ligget, daughter of Mrs. Howard B. Ligget of Sycamore E House, Laverock, Chestnut Hill, has completed plans for her wedding on Feb. 16 to Stuart Wylie Buck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Wylie Buck of Hiddendale. Rvdal.

A tea will be given tomorrow afternoon in the Garden of the Ambassador by Mrs. Julius S. Walsh for members of the committee for the New Year's Eve Fun and Frolic to be held in the Silver Room of that hotel.

The engagement has been announced of Miss Beulah Hesse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hesse of West Orange, N. J., to Charles Eisler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Eisler of South Orange, N. J.

AMERICA is still discovering itself. Recently it has discovered a special ardor for Winter sports, taken to skis and found out that our immense and varied facilities for getting enjoyment out of cold weather here at home include ski fields that are a match for any in Europe. The national parks are becoming more and more the nation's playgrounds in Winter no less than in Summer. In Mount Rainier Park, in Washington;

The State Highway Commissioner would be empowered to declare an emergency during snowstorms and other weather hazards under one proposal in a five-point "highway safety" program drafted today by Assemblyman George R. Parsons, Republican, of Syracuse.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Holly Sugar Corporation (pf. and com.).

Out of recent contest conducted by a Finnish, a Norwegian and a Swedish publisher, raising the question whether or not in our age there exists any objectivity in ethics or morals, no less than nine volumes have been published with awards to three of these.

Dartmouth College will encourage its students to become public speakers by establishing an Undergraduate Speakers Bureau, affiliated with and handled by the Forensic Union and having as faculty adviser John Neale of the Department of Public Speaking.

WOODSTOCK,Vt.-With one new ski tow added to the existing seven, New England's towiest town has begun its fifth Winter sports season as a pioneer in the open-slope elevator business and is ready to show a few more thousands how to mitigate the laws of gravity.
Speaking from exile in London, Haile Selassie, deposed Emperor of Ethiopia, sent his Christmas greetings to America yesterday in a broadcast.

Miss Phyllis Brewster has been appointed chairman of a newly organized debutante committee for the benefit performance of the children's ballet, "La Boite a Joujoux," which will be given Thursday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark.-The new year will be ushered in here with elaborately planned parties at the larger hotels and night clubs. Advance reservations show that the management of the Arlington and the Eastman hotels and the Club Belvedere will have guests at their annual merrymaking from all sections of the country.

Reports that the navy, Coast Guard and Department of Justice are engaged in a sweeping counterespionage campaign on the- Pacific Coast as the result of the Japanese situation were emphatically denied in San Pedro today by a navy spokesman.

PIG-TAIL DAYS IN OLD SEATTLE. By Sophie Frye Bass. 12mo. Portland. Ore.: Metropolitan Press. $1.75. Sketches of a childhood in Seattle. SOME MEMORIES. By Thomas Frank Gallor. Svo. Kingsport, Tenn.: Southern Publishers, Inc. $2.50. Reminiscences of the third Bishop of Tennessee and Chancellor of the University of the South.

Christmas by courtesy of Federal marshal's deputies was the lot today of fourteen jurors who for weeks have beer hearing evidence in the government's gasoline price-fixing case against major oil companies.

NEW YEAR'S DAY will mark the fifth year in which El Paso has staged a "Sun Carnival." Each year it grows in size and beauty and the pageant this year, according to all arrangements now completed, promises to surpass all previous shows.

IN the eighteenth century the adventurer, says Peter Wilding, found everything ready for him: a society prosperous. self-satisfied, unmoved by religion or patriotism, yet economically insecure and individually restless and bored.

Savings, building and loan associations, by the first of the year, will have distributed semi-annual earnings estimated at $104,000,000 to 6,200,000 persons having accounts in such institutions, the United States Building and Loan League announced yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Robert Montgomery Bird of Merion have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jacqueline Bird, to George Pownall Orr Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Pownall Orr of Berwyn.

Viewing the State Department as the logical first line of defense against the onslaughts of a warmad world, Miss Josephine Schain, chairman of the National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, is assembling data to support advocacy of an increased appropriation for the maintenance of the office.

A Christmas dance, the fourth and last in the 1937 series for recently married couples, post-debutantes, debutantes and their escorts, attracted about 450 young people to the Greenwich Country Club tonight.
Five persons perished early today as flames swept a flimsy lake shore cottage, where a family of twentyfive persons had gathered for the holiday.
Although no military caste of the old style exists in the United States, hundreds of fathers and sons are in the Army and Navy, strewn from the Atlantic seaboard to Shanghai.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Wyckoff gave a reception at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Louise Wyckoff, to John Purcell Higgins, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gregory Higgins of Shrewsbury.

The State Civil Service Employes Association, in the current issue of its monthly publication, assails the activities of a Committee for Industrial Organization union which is attempting to organize State employes.

IN point of form alone, this bright little volume which Deems Taylor has developed from his radio addresses and critical articles and reviews ranks highly amid the recent American literature of music.

Edward Liotta Jr. of Cleveland cast his %S-ounce plug 323 feet, beating the old world record by twentyfour feet, but. lost the chance to annex, the 1937 national distance bait-casting crown when his average fell 5 points below that of Lee Sens of Baltimore, whose average set a new record of 304 feet.

The Sarah Lawrence College Library circulated more than 11,000 books during the first twelve weeks of classes, according to a report yesterday by Miss Ermine Stone, the librarian. The 275 students took out 7,740 books for periods from overnight to two weeks, and read 2,144 more books which were placed on reserve.
He Did raced to victory today in the $5,000 added Christmas Handicap that featured Santa Anita's inaugural racing program.

The Nueva Prensa, one of Managua's leading newspapers, published an editorial today signed by its editor, Gabry Rivas, that "Nicaragua should close its doors to the commercial activities of the Japanese Empire."

The popular Christmas poinsettia may flourish indoors for several weeks, according to Professor R. B. Farnham, ornamental horticultourist of the New Jersey Extension Service, Rutgers University. He advocates for it a high degree of humidity and a uniform temperature of about 60 degrees Fahrenheit.

SrROUDSBURG, Pa. - Heavy snow flurries in the Poconos during the past several days have bolstered up the coasting and skiing on the many mountain trails and holiday vacationists are enjoying the finest of Winter sports.
Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris regained the world championship early this month at The Hague to provide the outstanding feature of chess in 1937.

The Japanese Navy announced today that a blockade had been thrown around the industrial city of Tsingtao, where three United States war craft were standing by to evacuate 300' Americans. Japanese land forces pushing forward into North China previously had cut off communications between Tsinan, Shantung Province capital, and Tsingtao, which is on the coast 390 miles north of Shanghai.
A NEW record for transcontinental auto travel was set recently when Bob McKenzie, stunt and test driver, drove from New York to Los Angeles in 51 hours 58 minutes. McKenzie,
Mucho Gusto, a 5-year-old son of Marvin May that has thrived on considerable racing this year, made a show of five rivals in the Christmas Handicap at Tropical Park today.

N addition to the speedier access to trunk highways provided by the new Lincoln Tunnel, which saw its first regular traffic last Wednesday, many additions to the metropolitan road system have been made available of late.

Holiday quiet prevailed yesterday along the New York waterfront. Only one passenger ship arrived, the Nerissa of the Furness Lines from the West Indies, with sixtyfive passengers, which docked at 9 A. M. The immigration and customs officials were able to have their Christmas dinners with their families.

Among the numerous modifications of the Merchant Marine Act suggested to Congress by Joseph P. Kennedy, one of the most important is the recommendation for a training program for our merchant sailors.

Possessing an impressi78 streak that comprises six victories and one tie in their last seven games, the New York Rangers return to their home ice tonight to battle with the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game.

The nation's tax load in 1938 may reach the all-time record sum of $13,500,000,000, or about 20 per cent of the national income, a ratio which was declared to be a danger signal, according to a report made public today by a special committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

ASTOR-The Hurricane: Jon Hall, Dorothy Lamour.* CAMEO-Peter I,. Russian film. CAPITOL-Navy Blue and Gold: Robert Young; Rosalie: Eleanor Powell, Nelson Eddy, opens Thursday. CENTRAL--County Fair and The Singing Outlaw. CINEMA DE PARIS-Intermezzo, Swedish film.

Members of the Junior Guild of Colony House will entertain the Senior Guild at their monthly. meeting on Jan. 4 in the auditorium of Colony House, 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn. Tea and a fashion show will be features of the afternoon.
Oscar Schoenherr, a founder of the Welfare Federation of the Oranges and Maplewood in 1919 and its managing director since that time, died today at his home, 307 Heywood Avenue, at the age of 63.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter Wagner of Jamaica, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Georgia Wagner, to James A. Dearborn, son of Mrs. James A. Dearborn of Brookline, Mass., and the late Mr. Dearborn.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Davis Stone of this city of the engagement of Mrs. Stone's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Brunet, to Thomas David Abeles, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Abeles of Bronxville, N. Y.

Signs of progress in various fields and directions so definitely mark the year that is passing in club cirties that a summation of feminine achievements holds not only more substance than usual with which to glorify the past, but more promise for the year ahead.

Prosperity of the light harness turf during 1937 was indicated by the impressive results of the fortythird annual Old Glory auction sale held in the Squadron A Armory during Thanksgiving Week, when 226 head of yearlings and horses in training were sold for a total of $206,710-an average of $914.

Announcement has been made to friends here by Mrs. M. Rees Furbeck of Houghton, Mich., of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Furbeck of New York, to Maitland Lathrop Bishop Jr., son of Mrs. Howard Wainwright of 136

As a Long of Toledo won his third national checkers Championship at Martins Ferry, Ohio, when his final-round opponent, William Ryan of New York, withdrew from the tournament after they had played eight drawn games.

Dances of America and her neighbors will be featured in the fifth and final week of folk dance recitals being held for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center. Presented by Dance International, 1900-1937, the programs will take place on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday afternoons.

Underground bombproof power plants for explosives-producing and allied chemical industries are being designed in Europe, according to a report to Industrial and Engineering Chemistry, publication of the American Chemical Society. Such plants are covered by massive concreate arches or hollowed out of the rock. Space saving is of primary Importance, it is said, in order to keep cost low and reduce target surface for bombs and shells.

GUATEMALA, until but a few years ago a vague geographical expression to most Americans, has begun to take on more definite meaning. Tourists have discovered the magnificent scenery and the primitive life of the little country.

NEEDLING the operatic formula continues to be one of the most popular Hollywood pastimes, and, by and large, one of the least successful. There seems to be something about a soprano that brings out the worst in a script writer.

Cardinal Hayes will be patron of the concert to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House next Sunday evening for the benefit of the welfare fund of the New York chapter of the Knights of Columbus, it was announced yesterday.

Sit-in strikers celebrated Christmas today in the factories they have occupied in a demand for wage and hour adjustments. Twenty-five hundred workers in the Goodrich Rubber Company factory dined, danced and sang with special food and musicians on hand.

The scene when Arturo Toscanini stepped upon the stage of Studio 8-H last night in Radio City to conduct his first concert with the NBC Symphony Orchestra was unique and historic. It was historic in the occasion and its symbolism of the modern age, with its recognition of art and of genius, factors in civilization which are no longer the property of the few and no longer issues which any nation or ruler can ignore.

For throughout England disrupted the Christmas Day schedule in the English Football League. Brentford defeated Manokeste City by 2-0 to retain its one-point margin over Leeds United, 5-3 vlctor over Middlesborough.

Mrs. David T. Dana is general chairman of the annual New Year's Eve ball at the Lenox Club" which is one of the leading events of the Berkshire holidays. On the committee with Mrs. Dana are Mrs. Owen Johnson, Mrs. Frederick Goodrich Crane, Mrs. Chauncey C. Loomis, Mrs. Elmer E. Dawson, the Misses Anna Remsen Alexandre and Mary BE. Channing.

THE 185-foot yacht Mizpah, owned by Commander E. F. McDonald Jr., president of Zenith Radio Corporation, now en route to the Caribbean, has been equipped with what is described as "the most powerful new radio marine telephone installation in existence, practically twice as powerful as those found on the large ocean liners."

Japan's note concerning the attack on the United States gunboat Panay and three Standard Oil vessels was promptly accepted by the United States today as in general satisfactory, but conditional on American rights in China being observed in the future by the Tokyo government.

PRODUCTION on "Frenech Without Tears," which until the other day was scheduled for Marlene Dietrich, has been postponed indefinitely and the star has received permission from Paramount to seek work at other studios.

Despite undeclared wars and long unsolved problems of mankind, Christmas was celebrated throughout the world yesterday in a festive and grateful spirit. To millions of men, women and, in particular, children, it was a day of merriment that brought happiness and hope on a generous scale.

DR. HENRY REED STILES has a paradoxical reputation, for he is best remembered for his least important contribution to the world's knowledge: a book not even mentioned in the sketch of his life that appears in the Dictionary of American Biography.

The prestige of Eaastmern baskeitball in general and' of metropolitan basketball 'in ipartieultLr was seriously- dented ,during, the 1936-37 season. as. the pendulum of supreinacy. swung away .from New York City for the first time in recent memory.

Miss Dorothy Hay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Hay of Ivanhoe Place, here, was married to Frank J. McConnell of New York this afternoon in the Congregational Church of Bangor, Mich., by the Rev. Dr. Lawrence E. Tenhopen, pastor of the First Congregational Church of South Haven, Mich.
Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., blazed down the homestretch today with a last nine 30, five below par, to win the $2,500 Miami open with a tournament record score of 267.

Patrolman Carl Lagergen of the Wadsworth Avenue Station, patrolling the Harlem Ship Canal near 225th Street early yesterday morning, leaped into the chilly water to rescue a 20-year-old woman from a suicide attempt. He may have sacrificed his life as a result.
The University of West Virginia Mountaineers, here to meet Texas Tech in New Year's Sun Bowl football game, went through -a hard practice session in the watm sunshine today.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y.-A succession of busy days and colorful nights is in store for the 'hundreds of holiday visitors expected to throng this Winter sports center during the coming week.
The Beech-Nut Packing Company is making a holiday monetary distribution to its employes, except executives, amounting to $195,000.

THE timeliness of this book need not be urged. It may be emphasized, nevertheless, by a word of elaboration. For the book is timely not primarily because it treats of a sensational incident of less than a year ago but because it clarifies the background of events today.

Arthur B. McArdle of the Hotel Croydon, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street, died early yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital where he had been a patient for two weeks and underwent an operation for gall stones. He was born in this city 50 years ago.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr., who has won several prizes in needlework exhibitions here, will open an exhibition of her needlework panels and pictures on Wednesday at the Arden Gallery, 460 Park Avenue.

For more than thirty years an unknown Santa Claus who called himself Mickey Finn has been distributing cash just before Christmas to cheer the inmates of missions, jails and boys' and girls' homes in this area.

Viewing the results of the realty year for 1937, Charles F. Noyes, head of the firm bearing his name, states that he is looking forward to 1938 with genuine optimism. He declares that he still remains, as he has been throughout the year, an enthusiastic believer in real estate as a good investment at the existing market levels.

While sales volume for the first half of next year may be expected to compare unfavorably with the same period of 1937, a resumption of the upward trend in retail trade is probable during the late Summer and Fall of 1938, merchants throughout the country reported last week in a survey made by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Jim Thorpe, the greatest athlete the Indian race ever produced, has just learned the white man's most fascinating game-politics. Jim is back home, trying to get his people, the Sac and Fox Tribe, to rescind their vote on a new constitution, recently adopted by a 202to-120 vote.

Dr. Louise Stanley, chief of the Bureau of Home Economics, recommends in her annual report to Secretary Wallace that the agencies formulating public policies study the incomes of farm families and the way they send their earnings.

Agriculture and construction are deemed by Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, as, perhaps, the two most important factors to be considered in any effort to achieve a permanently normal level of business activity.

Members of the Danish American Women's Association will give a reception Thursday afternoon in the Rainbow Grill at Rockefeller Center for two of their well-known countrymen, Karin Michaelis, Danish writer, and Lauritz Melchior, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

There is almost universal confidence in Nationalist [Rebel] Spain that the final struggle of the civil war is about to begin. Unwise censorship has deprived Nationalist Spain of much foreign understanding which would have followed free reporting and a readiness to risk criticism. There has lately been an improvement in this respect,

Plans for the organization of a children's repertory theatre in New York and for a nation-wide nonprofit project of children's cultural entertainment, such as opera, concert, ballet and plays, at admission prices of 10 to 25 cents,
The Russian Government demanded today that Manchukuo authorities release a Soviet mail plane which apparently lost its way while flying the Khabarovsk-Vladivostok line.

Vivian Forbes, British artist, died today at the age of 46. He had come to London from Paris where he resides to attend the funeral of Glyn Philpot, a fellow artist with whom for many years he had collaborated.

Mrs. Therese Keyser Thorne of 19 East Seventy-second Street, widow of William V. S. Thorne, financier and railroad official, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital after an illness of four months, at the age of 62.

MEXICO, D. F.-President Lzaro Cardenas has recognized what he terms "the imminent danger of our republican system being converted in a personal dictatorship." He asked Congress to modify the Mexican Constitution in order to make it legally impossible for that body

New developments will be a feature of the 1938 sales program of the York Ice Machinery Corporation, according to S. E. Lauer, vice president in charge of sales, in announcing the York conference and exposition to be held in York, Pa., Jan. 11 to 13.

Mr. and Mrs. William Humboldt Vollmer of 160 Riverside Drive have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Vollmer, to Raymond J., Polhemus of San Antonio, Texas. The prospective bride was graduated last Spring from Barnard College and her fiance was graduated in 1936 from Columbia College.

Miss Marie Lesure Arnold, daughter of Mrs. Dan Hinckley Arnold of Scarsdale, N. Y., and the late Dan Hinckley Arnold of Washington, will be married Feb. 19 to Gerald Davis, son of Mrs. J. Edward Davis of Tuxedo Park and New York City.

Members of the entertainment committee for the benefit matinee performance of "Tristan und Isolde" on Jan. 4 at the Metropolitan Opera House will attend a reception Tuesday afternoon at the home of their chairman, Miss Eweretta Kernochan, 155 East Seventy-second Street.

Among those who were executed in Moscow last week along with Leo M. Karakhan and Avel S. Yenukidze were Boris Sheboldayeff and Vitally Larin, both members of the central control committee of the Communist party.

The 1937 soccer season here was enlivened by visits of teams from England and Spain, both of which went home with the satisfying knowledge that they had not been defeated. Six matches were contested by the representatives of the famous Charlton Athletic Club of London, of which they won five and tied one.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marie Elisabeth Gorman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Campbell W. Georman of St. George, S. I., to Edward B. C. Frieze, son of Mrs. Lyman B. Frieze Jr. of New Brighton and the late Mr. Frieze.

Announcement has been made by Associate Justice and Mrs. William F. Barrington of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie Barrington of Providence, R. I., to Dr. Wilbur Merrill Frohock of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. Horatio W. Frohock of Rockland, Me.

Declaring that the country is now operating under a planned economy, William Goldman, president of Cohen, Goldman Co., last week urged business men to cooperate a closely with the government, "so as to avoid the grievous losses that business has had to take this year.
It probably will be many a long year before motor boating and especially speed boat racing affairs are again as sensational and significant as they were during 1937.

ROME.-To mark the opening of the sixteenth year of Italy's fascist regime the audacious prophecy, "The Europe of tomorrow will be fascist," appeared on myriad billboards in Lombardy. Much water has flowed beneath the bridges of the Po and the Tiber since a puzzled Europe was assured that fascism was not an article for export.

DURING my recent stay in the United States a frequent subject of discussion was the art of living. Americans all declared that the art of living was practiced incomparably better in Europe than in America.

The most pretentious basketball program ever arranged for Madison Square Garden will be unfolded there tomorrow and Wednesday when Stanford, champion of the Pacifio Coast, and Minnesota, cochampion of the Big Ten, clash with metropolitan rivals.

Invitations will be sent Tuesday for the annual benefit bridge at the Plaza Hotel here on Jan. 22 of the Alumnae Association of St. Elizabeth Academy, Convent, N. J. Mrs. Frank Sheridan Moran of West Orange, president of the associlation, will entertain the bridge committee at the Plaza on Jan. 8 when she will be assisted by Mrs. Robert McDowell, Mrs. Joseph F.

A two-day review period, which students promise will really be used for reviewing rather than cramming, will begin at New Jersey College for Women before the midyear examinations, and Monday and Tuesday, Jan. 17 and 18, have been set aside for this purpose.

Mrs. M. Mona Lesser of 915 West End Avenue, formerly of Pittsburgh, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Claire Lesser, Max Statk of Quarry Heights, Canal Zone. The ceremony will take place here on Jan. 11, after which the couple "vill sail for Quarry Heights, where they will make their home,.

Germany's official annual food shortage, so to speak, started this year on Christmas morning. Henceforth butter consumers are expected to reduce their wants by 15 per cent compared with their consumption in October. The butter card system assures enforcement in cities.

Room occupancy at the Hotel Commodore by guests from twelve large cities during the first eleven months of this year was far in excess of that noted for the same period of 1936, Frank J. Crohan, president of the hotel company, announced yesterday.

Relief authorities have warned the administrators of the State unemployment insurance fund that, unless some breach is made in the wall of secrecy that has guarded all social security records from scrutiny by other governmental departments, it will be possible for jobless persons to defraud the public treasury by receiving relief and unemployment insurance payments simultaneously.
Walter Kramer of Detroit gained the honor of winning the first national badminton tournament at Chicago by defeating Hock Sim Ong of Berkeley, Calif., in the final round.
A PRIMA DONNA speaks as for these many years she had been threatening to do, in Mme. Alda's autobiography. entitled "Men. Women and Tenors."

After an unusually rainy first two months of Winter, which has caused serious floods in various parts of the country, Christmas Day dawned fine and clear throughout Italy. The north enjoyed real Christmas, weather, with plenty of snow on the ground. From Florence south there was no snow except on the mountains, but the air was cold and crisp despite the blazing sun.

The outstanding architectural opportunity for 1938 lies in largescale rental housing projects, according to William Stanley Parker of Boston, chairman of the committee on construction industry relations of the American Institute of Architects.

Ever since the economic collapse in 1929, and particularly since the invalidation of the NIRA, plans have been offered for bringing production into balance -with demand, so as to create a situation where no one should be without employment.
The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, which was due to arrive tomorrow forenoon from Europe, has been delayed and will not dock until 8:30 A. M. Tuesday.

The list of the French liner Normandie, due to sail today for Havre via Southampton, include James Moffett, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Spalding, Alexander Korda, Jeanne Renouard, Laurence Hills, Major and Mrs. Gustave Lanct6t, Mr. and Mrs. C. H. Robertson, Ernest Galesel and Mr. and Mrs. Ward Cheney.

The comprehensive review of sports in 1937, which is printed today in Section 5 of THE NEW YORK TIMES, shows that the year was an extraordinary one, marked by the success of the United States in international competition and by the appearance of a new group of super-stars.

Miss Dorothy Barnard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Pettibone Barnard of this place, was married here tonight in the First Congregational Church to Dr. Eben Kelley Jenkins, son of Mrs. Althia Jenkins of Dennisport, Cape Cod, Mass., and the late Eldon W. Jenkins. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Don Ivan Patch.

THE scare thrown into the radio people by Mae West's recent broadcast has created a comparable fright, though somewhat milder, in the picture industry, and as a result the two entertainment mediums have been drawn together for their mutual protection.
Miss Anne C. Howley of Jamaica, Queens, has announced the engagement of her sister, Miss Dorothy Honore Howley, to Eugene J. Gaffney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Gaffney of Brooklyn.

Displacing the Washington Canoe Club, which long had dominated the field, the Yonkers Canoe Club of New York captured the team title at the eighth annual national paddling championships of the American Canoe Association.
Bombs may fall in Madrid, but the business of granting patents to inventors goes on as usual in Spain's "Patent Office," the Registry for Industrial Property, it has been learned here.

Settings of Wintry aspect have been devised for the Winter Sports Ball to be held on New Year's Eve in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event has been arranged by several women of prominence who are associated with the Opportunity Shop at 46 West Forty-seventh Street,

Leaders in diplomatic, social, artistic and educational circles are cooperating in plans for the fifth annual "Night in Poland Ball," which will take place on Jan. 28 In the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
NASSAU, Bahamas.-The Development Board and other civic organizations in Nassau are offering prizes this year to encourage participation in the John Canoe (masquerade) parade on New Year's morning.

Production of bullion from Ontario's gold mines in November was valued at $7,456,983 from treatment of 713,947 tons of ore, average recovery being $10.44 to the ton, according to the gold bulletin issued by the Ontario Department of Mines. This compares with production of $7,398,887 from 728,280 tons in October, when average recovery was $10.16.

Despite a knee injury that later forced him out of competition, seventeen-year-old Robin Lee of Minneapolis, representing the Skating Club of New York, won his third men's national figure skating crown in Chicago last February.

SALVADOR and Brazil have released their promised stamps commemorating the sesquicentennial of the Constitution of the United States. The countries which either have issued or have announced they will distribute "sesqui" postal paper are Brazil, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, France, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Salvador, United States and Venezuela.
A Christmas party was given today at the Muenchinger-King by Thomas Powers of New York for the children of the Home for Friendless Children.
The Cornell University polo team, national intercollegiate champion, rode to an 11-9 victory over Essex Troop tonight in one of the games of a holiday triple-header at the Essex Troon Armory.

The resolution of Representative Louis Ludlow of Indiana providing a constitutional amendment for a national referendum on war, except in case of invasion, was defended today by five peace organizations, which charged that arguments against it represented attempts to becloud the issue. The proposal, they maintained, was "patriotic, sound, practical, and a necessary forward step in democratic government."

A dinner to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the organization of the United States Realty and Investment Company will be held on Wednesday at the Hotel Douglas, Newark. The company was formed Jan. 1, 1928, by amalgamating many realty interests under the supervision of. William E. Lehman.
Although it was Christmas, scrimmage was added today to the practice program of the East's team, preparing for the all-star charity football game with the West here New Year's Day.

Coach Charles Bachman sent his Michigan State gridiron players to the showers today in a full trot after better than an hour and a half of drill under a tropical Florida sun. It was the last practice on Gator field before the Spartans depart for Miami and the Orange Bowl game with the Auburn Tigers New Year's Day.

Emperor Hirohito, specifically mentioning a "growing friendship and cordiality" in Japan's foreign relations, today opened the seventythird Diet session. "In opening the Imperial Diet, we take the opportunity to inform the members of the House of Peers and the House of Representatives we feel greatly gratified

Full of years and honors, Clio of New. York celebrates this waning week of 1937 as a joyous occasion, ushering in the climax of her golden jubilee series of programs. Mellow with A recollection of the days of her youth, yet more enterprising than ever as she reaches the half-century mark in 1938, her future prospects inspire her members to predictions of still finer records and greater days to come.
Many large family gatherings in country homes on the North and South shores were a feature of Christmas Day.

In the Seminary, not only soldiers and Italian and German officers have taken refuge, but many priests and novices and perhaps even the Archbishop of Teruel.
This year, it seems, the interest in rifle and pistol shooting made another violent upward leap, and the national rifle and pistol matches held at Camp Perry, Ohio, drew more than 3,000 men and boys.

The 250th anniversary of the birth of Emanuel Swedenborg, which occurs Jan. 29, will be celebrated with a commemorative dinner at Delmonico's, 502 Park Avenue, on the night of Jan. 26, according to an announcement yesterday by Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip, who will preside.

The Canadian Government is preparing another enlarged defense program, with particular reference this time to the Pacific Coast to supplement that announced last year, and Quebec parliamentary representatives are girding to fight it.

A hermit who spent twenty years in a cell no larger than a telephone booth without once lying down, and who thrived on the discipline, and lamas who rose several feet in the air without jumping were described yesterday by Theos Bernard, young Tucson, Ariz., lawyer and graduate student at Columbia University, who has just returned from the so-called "forbidden city" of Lhasa. in Tibet.

The Junior Guild of New York, which is made up of students at the Chapin and Brearley Schools, will hold its annual Christmas tea dance on Wednesday on the Starlight Roof of the Waldcrf-Astoria. Proceeds of the event will go to the Speedwell Society.

The former Baroness Lillian von Manteuffel revealed today her secret marriage Oct. 27 to Max Ohm of Germany and said she intended to start immediate annulment proceedings. The ceremony was performed, she said, at Angola. Ind.

The rise of Robert Grant 3d of New York to the top of amateur racquets in this country, the continuation of OgdenPhipps's supremacy in amateur court tennis and the holding of world's championship matches for the first time in years in both sports featured the 1937 play in these exclusive indoor court games.

Once again New York University fencers held a dominant position in the intercollegiate fencing world to furnish the high spot of the past season. The Violet swordsmen won three of four team titles and one of hbree individual crowns to come, as close to a sweep as any college has done in recent history.

The year 1937 at Princeton University, 191st since the institution was founded under the provisions of a royal charter signed by King George II, has been marked by the inception of programs which have broadened the base of the university's educational philosophy.

Folders cut in the shape of a milk bottle have been sent out recently to prospective subscribers as announcements. of a "baby party" to be held tomorrow night at-the Stork Club as a benefit for. the Babies IRelief Fund.

The building endowment fund of Trinity College, Washington, D. C., will be augmented by the proceeds of a supper dance to be held Tues-i day at the Pierre under the auspices of the New York Chapter of Alumnae of the institution.

To provide an incentive for efforts in journalism, Keuka College has started its first journalism honorary society, Kappa Phi Epsilon. The new organization will consist of a limited number of seniors who have shown proficiency in journalism and creative writing.

THE alarums and excursions which have attended the arrangements for the radio performances of Mr. Toscanini and other conductors have not as yet drawn attention to one of the most salutary by-products of these engagements:

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Taylor of 32 Midwood Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Muriel Taylor, to Edwin Bailey Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Fisher, also of Brooklyn.
Mr. and Mrs. Max Baldwin Kaesche of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothea Maxine Kaesche, to John Forster Abeel, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Abeel of Hackensack.

American labor unions are urged to refuse to handle Japanese goods, and bankers, financiers and the Public are asked to boycott Japanese products in an appeal issued by the Patriot Guard of America, an organization of ex-service

There is one Indian village under the American flag which has never asked nor received outside relief. An auditor's report shows that the self-sustaining community to which the department points with pride is Metlakatla, a salmon-fishing center in Southeastern Alaska.

San Francisco has a new intercoastal passenger service. It sprang up almost overnight here late this week with the announcement from the General Steamship Corporation that, effective immediately, it will have accommodations for forty to sixty passengers every. two or three days sailing -from here to New York.

The Round Hill Club will hold a "Hollywood party" on New Year's Eve at which the guests will dress as the motion picture stars they most resemble. Mrs. Richard C. Croft heads the committee arranging the party, which will be held in a tropical setting of palm trees and orange groves.
GAY doings will enliven New York's picturesque waterfront as t e New Year gets under way, for immediately after the holidays the big cruises of 1938 are scheduled to start.

Record crowds, an unusual number of abnormally strong teams, interesting tactical developments and thrilling denouements combined in 1937 to establish football more than ever as a challenger to baseball's dominion as the national pastime.

Holiday trade suffered losses from a year ago in most Federal Reserve districts despite last-minute spurts in several cities. In a few the up swing in the final week was substantial, since shopping had been held down by poor weather earlier in the month. Some districts reported gains, notably in Texas and the Northwest.

Scribner's Magazine will be published next year by Harlan Logan Associates, Inc., which is acquiring the publishing rights from Charles Scribner's Sons, who will retain an interest in the new corporation, according to an announcement yesterday.

Dec. 28 is the seventy-ninth birthday of the late Giacomo Puccini. May I interest any one of our major orchestra conductors, who is not prejudiced, but who is willing and a true artist at heart, to give to millions of Puccini's admirers throughout the world the pleasure of listening to his solemn Requiem Mass?

Miss Elizabeth Taylor Pendleton, daughter of Mrs. Arthur T. Pendleton of this city and the late Mr. Pendleton, has chosen Jan. 22 as the date of her marriage to Archibald Gracie Ogden of Boston, son of Mrs. Archibald Gracle Ogden of this city and the late Mr. Ogden.

The metallic symphony of the shipyards will reach a new and world-wide crescendo with the new year. For the naval armaments race, started a year ago with the expiration of the treaties which limited sea power for the fifteenyear period from 1922 to 1937,

The most successful season that professional football ever has known from the artistic, the financial and every other viewpoint, marked the past campaign of the play-for-pay brigade. Crowds were larger than ever before, interest was greater and the games themselves were the most spectacular in history.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Bureau of Child Guidance, 46 Forsythe Street-15 children's paintings, 4 easel paintings. 8 graphic prints. P. S. 208, Avenue D and Forty-eighth Street,

Alfred University has one of the few New York State college libraries that emphasize a program for children. Miss Ruth P. Greene, librarian, says that often ninety youngsters gather for a story hour in the basement of the library every other Sunday afternoon.

WHAT has most impressed Ritchie Calder about "The Greenwood Hat" is its revelation of Sir James Barrie's loneliness at the height of his success. He describes it, indeed, as the autobiography of one who exchanged the loneliness of obscurity for the loneliness of eminence.

Business is actually much better than the stock market indicates, according to W. O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company. The country's greatest need, in his opinion, is more private building. "Building wages are too high by the hour and too low by the year," he declared.
Death hit the sports world with a heavy hand during the past year as notables in practically every sphere of athletic activity succumbed.

Whether an ultimatum Governor Cone issued this week against gambling will be effective is being widely discussed, with most of the argument taking place on the lower East Coast, in the Miami and Palm Beach areas,- where stakes run into millions of dollars each Winter.

The status of the picket is once more precipitating a conflict which has been waged intermittently in the United States for more than a hundred years. In the course of that dispute picketing has flowered into a full-fledged science, with textbooks and manuals of its own.

THREATTENED with investigations and probes, the industry this week is attempting to figure out whether its present plan of announcing new models in the Fall has advantages over the former system of announcing immediately after the first of the year.

Even in midwinter the gardener finds some planting to do. If he is impatient at the prospect of the long, dreary wait until April sunshine coaxes the first daring snowflakes and crocuses into bloom Itof-doors, there are a number of bulbs and roots which he can start now with the assurance that his slight labors will be rewarded while frost still grips the world outside.

An almost unchallenged continuation of Yankee dominance in a setting which bore a most extraordinary resemblance to the campaign of the preceding year provided the highlights of the 1937 baseball season, which, if not exactly a memorable or thrilling one, certainly was a remarkable one.

Squash racquets and squash tennis both proved extremely popular during the past year. There was considerable activity in squash racquets not only among "the alumni," but in the colleges as well. The women players, too, enjoyed a highly successful season.

An educational program for intellectually gifted children, geared to meet their special needs, has been developed by the New York City school system following a two-year experiment with superior pupils, it is announced by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

George M. Pashley, printer and publisher for many years, died here yesterday at the age of 70. Mr. Pashley was owner and editor of The Spencer Needle from 1891 to 1898, associated with The Ithaca Daily News, and at one time with the supply house of W. L. Packard in Geneva.

Things have picked up for Santa Claus in the last four years. Up until that time jovial Santa was the seasonal benefactor who became the most popular person in town abopt one month before Christmas and a forgotten man after his presents had been distributed on Christmas Day.

A break long anticipated by many ob servers has materialized between the Democratio Administration of Oregon and the New Deal. This week, for the first time since he was elected as a "Roosevelt Democrat" in 1934, Governor Charles H, Martin openly assailed the President.

WINTER wonderland areas in the East will be invaded by a full quota of snow trains this season if the snowfall is bountiful, and ski enthusiasts should have no difficulty in reaching their favorite spots. Plans of the various railroads follow:

Thousands of worshippers flocked to Christmas services in churches throughout Westchester County today as the weather cleared after a Christmas Eve rain and sleet storm which temporarily dampened the spirits of yule celebrants and led to the broadcast of warnings to motorists.

Christmas Day brought no relaxation of the navy patrol by sea and air which started six days ago off the coast of Southern California. Normally a day on which only a skeleton crew is found aboard the average ship, today saw the destroyers Clark and MacDonough heading to sea shortly after 8 A. M.

Activity-in the New York wholesale market last week was typical of the week before Christmas, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. Orders for holiday merchandise were practically nonexistent, due to the impossibility of delivery before the 25th.

A campaign to wipe out tuberculosis has been started by the New York City school system. The Board of Education and Department of Health are cooperating in an extensive drive to eliminate this communicable disease from the city's vast school population.

Discussions among mill selling agents and large buyers were undertaken last week with a view to extending the original period of the curtailment program which cotton print cloth mills initiated early this month. The present program calls for reduction of about 25 per cent in operations for December, January and February.

WHEN philosophers met several hundred years before the birth of Christ they usually went for their symposiums to Athens, the center of learning in ancient days. They arrived there either on foot, or by ship, donkey, mule or horse.

Mayor Hague's defiance of the C. I. O., which is now besieging Jersey City by peaceful penetration, is aided largely by the physical connections of that political oasis with the outside world. There are tube stations at Journal Square and at Exchange Place and ferryboats to Manhattan.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TMES: With so much talk about saving the country and so little concerted intelligent action, we should feel a thrill of pride to see one of our leading industrialists contribute so generously as Alfred P. Sloan has to the cause of American democracy.

Mrs. Helen Valentino, 25 years old, of 457 Locust Street, this city, died in Mount Vernon Hospital early today of injuries received last night when she was struck by one of two automobiles that collided at North Fifth and West Lincoln Avenues. The impact amputated her left leg.

Wheeler McMillen, editorial director of The Country Home and an authority on agriculture, has been elected president of the National Farm Chemurgic Council, succeeding the late Francis P. Garvan, the council announced yesterday. It was also announced that Willard H. Dow, president of the Dow Chemical Company, Midland, Mich., has been elected vice president representing industry in the council. He succeeds the late Howard E. Coffin.

Department stores and chains will feature unusually low prices on sheets and towels at their January white sales, in an effort to bring crowds that may help to liquidate inventories, which are regarded as fairly heavy, according to dry goods selling agents who were checking over needs with store buyers last week.

An explosion wrecked a 20,000-gallon gasoline tank of the Canfield Oil Company today, tossing the top across the railroad tracks 100 yards away and igniting a second tank. E. V. Helm, assistant superintendent, said the damage would not exceed $80,000 and that no one was seriously hurt.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Isabelle Schlivek, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kaufman Schlivek of 262 Central Park West, to George Kinzler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kalman Kinzler

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Burke of Elizabeth, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Estelle Burke, to John J. Kennedy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kennedy of Morristown, N. J.

The effectiveness of industrial research probably reached a high record in 1937 and there are ample indications that this progress will continue in 1938. The rapid improvement of existing products and methods and development of new ones offer encouragement for the long-range outlook.

NOW it can be told. The mystery soprano of whdm this column spoke some weeks ago has made her debut at the Metropolitan and some of the facts surrounding her engagement can be disclosed. She appeared here as Zinka Malinov and sang the role of Leonore in "Trovatore."

Dr. Christopher S. Espinosa, Assistant Professor of Foreign Languages at the University of Omaha, is the one-man staff of Panamerica, a Spanish-language newspaper which he has started this semester for students of Spanish and members of Spanish clubs in this country.

During the last two years I have been campaigning for peace. I visited the President of the United States, former Premier Leon Blum of France, former Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium, and all Scandinavian Prime Ministers and Foreign Secretaries. I have seen Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Premier Benito Mussolini and other chiefs of State in Poland, Czechoslovakia and Austria. In addition, I have had many talks with representatives of Spain, Ethiopia, China and Japan.

An appeal for contributions to churches and philanthropic institutions was sent out-yesterday by the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, which has named today "Stewardship Review Sunday." The committee's statement stressed the necessity for all "religious people to make an audit of their lives and benevolences today."

From the outbreak of the present incident one of the most impressive in Japan is that even little ones have become very much serious. It is rare nowadays to hear little ones singing merrily a folk song or a love song in the street.
Thumbing through the pages of sport's most notable contributions to 1937, one becomes struck at once by a most extraordinary difficulty. It is hard to hold in mind that much of it was not fiction.

John L. Lewis will move three blocks nearer to the White House Monday. The president of the United Mine Workers and the union's headquarters staff will move their offices from the Tower Building to the old University Club, just two blocks northeast of the White House.

FATHERS and mothers play an increasingly active role in Scouting. Parental interest in the movement may be shown in various ways. Many fathers whose sons are Scouts were Scouts themselves in the early years of the organization.

THERE is a certain class of books that have been set apart from all others for no better reason than that they were all made in the same century. The designation "incunabula," meaning "in the cradle," has come to apply to the books issued since the invention of printing. around 1455, to the end of the year 1500.

LITHUANIA has issued a new five litai silver coin in honor of Jonas Basanavicius, a Lithuanian hero. On the obverse of the coin is shown his profile, facing left, together with his name and the value of the coin.

FIFTEEN hours from coast to coast, three and a half days between New York and Rio de Janeiro, five hours between New York and Bermuda, only a week between New York and China, with preparations for still faster schedules, and also plans for regular passenger service between the United States and Europe -those were only a few of the highlights that made American air transport the most notable development during 1937.

While frozen ground may prevent any further planting of Springflowering bulbs in the open, there is still time to start them for indoor bloom. Most seed stores still have small quantities of tulips, daffodils, crocuses and hyacinths left over from the Fall season, and these can often be picked up now at bargain prices.
Thomas S. Merrill, secretary of General Motors Corporation for the last twenty-one years, Cied here today following a five-day illness. His age was 59. He was stricken with pneumonia last Monday.

Mrs. James Anderson Peasley of Waterbury has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Morrison Peasley, to William Robert Comber of New York. Miss Peasley was graduated from Saint Margaret's School, Waterbury, and Connecticut College, New London, class of 1933.

About 5,000 years ago, thirty centuries before Christ was born, a tiny sequoia tree took root in what is now General Grant National Park. Today the sequoia, one of the earth's oldest living things, served again as "the nation's Christmas tree."

Following its increased popularity after a successful Olympic campaign in 1936, gymnastics enjoyed one of its busiest years during the past twelvemonth. The competitive fields were exceedingly large not only in national and intercollegiate tournaments but among independent groups as well.

The Grand-City Container Corporation has distributed bonuses in the amount of about $6,500 to its clerical and factory employes. This was in addition to a general increase of 15 per cent in wages awarded last Spring.
The Duke and Duchess of Marlborough have a family gathering at Blenheim Palace for the holidays, including Mr. and Mrs. Winston Churchill, Randolph Churchill, and Lord Ivor Spencer-Churchill.

In a memorandum issued here this week, Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme said he would halt the "lavish waste of what is left of mortgage certificate holders' investments." He refused to grant legal fees of the size requested by James T. Heenehan of New Rochelle, attorney for three resigned trustees of 472 mortgage issues.

A three-paneled stained glass window, portraying in full vestments the three English bishops who were responsible for the translation of the New Testament of the King James version of the Holy Bible, was dedicated yesterday in the Vestry Room of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

A woman who described herself as Mrs. Anna MacDonald, 27 years old, of 443 West Forty-fourth Street, but who admitted to the police the name and address were fictitious, was arraigned yesterday morning in Felony Court on charges of robbery and violation of the Sullivan Law.

SALAMANCA.-The new Spanish Nationalist State started its career without a gold reserve and without foreign exchange, apart from such amounts as were found haphazard in the towns, villages and countryside that accepted the Nationalist movement. Great efforts were made to coordinate the resources scattered about Nationalist territory, and from them to fashion an economio backbone for the new State.

Contracts for all types of construction in Manhattan awarded during November had a total value of $7,102,700, which-brought the aggregate value of construction awards during the first eleven mnoths of the year to $117,123,000, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

Six Pennsylvania men were drowned today in the plunge of their automobile over a fifty-foot embankment into a creek four miles south of here. Rescuers worked three hours to free the bodies and Sheriff Herbert Traubert identified the men

THE difficulty of classifying Japan among the great powers of the world is illustrated by one simple fact: Japan is the only one of them which is ruled over the phrase is that of a Japanese authority, Professor Chikao Fujisawa) by a sovereign "who is believed to be an actual living deity."

Despite frequent assertions to the contrary, a majority of college youths in this country are not opposed to religion and the church, a nation-wide survey disclosed yesterday. Colleges and universities, instead of driving students away from the church, often strengthen their religious attitude, it was found.

IF a film recounts grave, frockcoated matters that happened abroad or in the East, it is a history-and such is the prestige of history on the screen that it will be solemnly admired and the director will acquire a silver cup.

Mrs. Elizabeth Masten Crocker, wife of George A. Crocker of 215 East Seventy-second Street, died yesterday in New York Hospital of pneumonia. She was a daughter of the late Arthur H. Masten, former senior member of the law firm of Masten and Nichols. In addition to her husband she left two sons, Arthur and William R. Crocker.
Mrs. Maurice Breit of 1,185 Park Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helene Sternberg, to Edward Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Myer Rosenberg of 211 Central Park West.

One of the largest residential deals made in Montclair, N. J., for some time was closed in the purchase by Dr. Edward P. Kearney of the dwelling on the northeast corner of South Fullerton Avenue and Hawthorne Place from Miss Edith C. Barry.
What help made possible by contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund means to its beneficiaries is briefly set forth by the heads of two of the ten participating charities as follows:
Coast Guardsmen abandoned hope today for two commercial fishermen who set out at noon yesterday to raise their nets in Lake Superior and did not return.

EVER since fifty unidentified scientists and engineers were quoted in the Review of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology a few weeks ago to the effect that "the small, inexpensive car outperforms the larger, more expensive model," makers of some of those larger models have been tearing their hair.

More than 750,000 conferences and treatments have been provided for students, faculty members and employes by the Columbia University Medical Office since it was established twenty-five years ago, Dr. William H. McCastline, director of the office,

Japan's immediate objectives in China, eclipsed recently by public excitement over the sinking of the Panay and the resultant disclosures, are again becoming a subject of official and semi-official speculation here.

A new stomach preparation, from seven to ten times more potent than those heretbefore used for treating pernicious anemia, is revealed in a patent just granted here to Dr. Edward A. Greenspon of Montreal, Que.

A FEW days before Congress adjourned the Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce of the House started hearings, a joint resolution, introduceseveral months ago by Representative Withrow of Wisconsin,

Two individual titles were carried off by America's strong men at the world weight-lifting championships in Paris. Tony Terlazzo of York, Pa., captured the lightweight crown and Johnny Terpak of the same city won the middleweight title.

Mrs. Russell L. Bradford of 7 Gracie Square has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Margaret Middleton Bradford, to Edouard Sandoz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Edouard Sandoz of Cambridge, Mass.

BROADWAY plays aren't produced any more, they're promoted. Of the 150-odd the atrical ventures launched along Mazda Lane last year, not a half dozen were totally financed by the man who took the bows or blame as entrepreneur.

Of all communicable diseases pneumonia is the most deadly. In 1934, 1935 and 1936 it accounted for a total annual average of 6,562 deaths in New York City; tuberculosis, next on the list, for 4,459, and syphilis, the third, for 1,034. Only heart disease and cancer are deadlier, and neither of these two is passed from person to person.
Cuba's courts today broke their traditional holiday to issue orders for the release of both political and common prisowners pardoned by the sweeping amnesty that went into effect yesterday.
Sirens from this town's two fire trucks aroused only one member of the Volunteer Fire Department one morning recently, but telephone calls and visits by the trucks to their homes succeeded.

A funeral service for H. Percy Soule, a member of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff for the last thirty years, will be held at 8 P. M. tomorrow at the funeral chapel of the New York and Brooklyn Casket Company, 187 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.

After President Roosevelt and three little girl visitors in the White House had inspected their Christmas stockings together this morning, the President went to the Church of the Covenant, where the Rev. Peter Marshall said "Peace on earth, good will toward men" was rather "ironical" in view of happenings in the world today.
The award of certificates to eighty-nine men and women who have just completed a seven-week training course in parent organization at New York University was announced yesterday.

PROBABLY few of the many New Yorkers who will hold open house or pay New Year's calls next Saturday will stop to think, as they exchange good wishes over a drink and a bite to eat, that they are carrying on a city tradition which dates back to the Dutch settlers.

The outright repeal of the Wagner act was asked as a "reassuring action by Congress" in the present "business and employment e rgency," in a letter addressed last week to Senator Henry F. Ashurst, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, by Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade.

John Rustman, 81 years old, a retired baker, of 88-13 104th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, choked to death yesterday while eating his Christmas dinner. At the dinner table with Rusman were his son, Alexander, the latter's wife, Anna, and their child, Gladys.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Mary Edith Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Carroll of 105 East Fiftythird Street, formerly of Pittsburgh,

An important clarification of the1 functions of the Board of Standards and Appeals was made by the adoption of an amendment to the new Building Code at the final meeting of the Board of Aldermen, points out Harris H. Murdock, former president of the New York Building Congress and chairman of the board.

A Christmas party for needy old folk was brightened yesterday by entertainment provided by a group of youngsters who left their own gas house district on the East Side to come up to the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue, where the tenth annual Christmas for the aged poor was being held.

Coincident with the election this week of thirty-two American Rhodes scholars who will enter Oxford University next Fall, there was completed a new survey showing the present occupations of the men who have represented this country at Oxford since the first awards of the scholarships in 1905.

A DOLL'S HOUSE-Tomorrow evening at the Morosco Theatre. Thornton Wilder's new adaptation of the Ibsen play, with Ruth Gordon, Dennis King, Paul Lukas. Sam Jaffe, Harold Johnsrud, Margaret Waller, Grace Mills and others in the cast. WESTERN WATERS-Tuesday evening at the Hudson Theatre. A play by Richard Carlson, one which concerns a Mississippi flatboat. In it are Van Heflin, Thomas Chalmers,

TURNING her back--no doubt happily--on the terrae mcognitae of the Soviet Union and the United States of America, E. M. Delafield returns herewith to the field of her most fortunate explorations and discovers the English domestic scene anew,
THE first all-paved highway linking the Great Lakes and the Gulf of Mexico will be opened on New Year's Day, in time for the greater part of this Winter's North-South travel.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Campbell Kimberly of 1,320 East Twentythird Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Campbell Kimberly, to Frederick Meyer Stuhrke, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Stuhrke of Richmond Hill, Queens.

Tear gas drove away burglars who tried to break into the main vault of the Jerseyville postoffice early today after they had rifled between 500 and 1,000 letters. As they fled the safe-crackers left an electric drill, with which they had been boring into the steel door of the vault.

The Metropolitan season's first "Lohengrin" was played last night by a cast which, with one important exception, was familiar in its respective roles to local operagoers. That exception was Irene Jessner, whose assumption of the role of Elsa was seen here for the first time,
Active savings and loan associations in New York and New Jersey made new home mortgage loans in November amounting to $4,154,000, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

Plans for organization of the Consumers Foundation, Inc., will be completed at a meeting to be held on Jan. 8 at the Hotel Astor, according to William Trufant Foster, director of the Pollock Foundation for Economio Research and former member of the NRA consumers' advisory board, who has been taking a leading part in the formation of the foundation, which is the first of its kind in the field of distribution.
Crowded into a ten-inch goldfish bowl, which occupies a place in the sun in my solarium, is almost as great a variety of plant life as is to be found in many a formal outdoor garden.

Leo J. Hickey, United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York and a prominent Brooklyn Catholic layman, died early yesterday morning of pneumonia in the Holy Family Hospital, Brooklyn. He had been ill for only a few days and had been in his office as recently as last Monday. His age was 47.
